column2: Maurice F. Holahan, Chairman of the committee having charge of the speakers who are to participate in the Congressional campaign in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congressional Districts, had a conference yesterday with a representative of the Reform Club, and it was arranged that speakers of the club and Tammany speakers should speak at each other's meetings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Secretary of War Lament heard this afternoon the arguments of both the friends and the opponents of the North River Bridge bill, which has been sent to the President and by him referred to the Secretary of War. Ail the arguments that have been heard in the Senate and the House for and against the bill were revived at this hearing.

For those who are in search of exciting experiences, the Atlantic Ocean is just now recommended. At almost any season it can be depended upon to make itself objectionable in some way to those who have a preference for a quiet life, but this mid-winter it seems bent on outdoing itself.

The tenth annual meeting of the Hebrew Technical Institute was held at 10 o'clock Sunday morning at 34 and 36 Stuyvesant Street. The meeting was attended by a large number of prominent Hebrews, most of whom were connected in some way with the institute.

William Leary, manager of Lemuel Ely Craig's Congressional campaign in the Fifteenth District, scored a neat victory over some of his old political opponents at the annual election of officers of the Republican Club last night. Mr. Leary was a candidate on the "opposition" ticket for member of the Executive Committee, and, after a battle royal, he came out victorious.

William Lester White, a mulatto, fifteen years old, of 122 East Thirty-second Street, was arrested yesterday on a charge of stealing $600 worth of carriage robes and about $300 worth of other property, mostly owned by Frederick Gebhard. He was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, but Mr. Gebhard did not appear, and he was remanded until to-day.

Not since the threatened war with Spain has the receiving ship at the Brooklyn. Navy Yard been so populous. The old line-of-battle ship Vermont, which does duty as a naval rendezvous at the yard, although a very spacious craft, is crowded to its utmost capacity.
LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The Queen has conferred the dignity of Knighthood upon William Lane Booker, Consul General of Great Britain at New-York.

Company G of the Seventh Regiment, led off last evening in the annual competition for the Kemp Trophy by putting up the fine total of 1,042 points. This competition, which has to be shot for on the armory range in the two weeks succeeding the second Saturday in January of each year, is open to teams of twenty-five men from each of the companies.
"Margaret Ferguson, disorderly conduct," was one of the records on the blotter of the Thirty-third Police Precinct on Sunday night. Concerning the case there is much mystery.

The Directors of the Real Estate Exchange yesterday announced their purpose of proceeding further with the political work determined on last week. At that time resolutions were adopted denouncing those responsible for the present condition of city affairs, and urging members of the Exchange to organize a Good Government Club. Messrs. C.W. Luyster, William Cruikshank, and Douglas Robinson, Jr., were continued as a committee on organization.

There was no brighter spot in the city last night than the Madison Square Garden, where pleasure lovers gathered in force to join the nobles of Mecca Temple of the Order of the Mystic Shrine in their annual carnival. The blaze of electric globes filled the spacious Interior and shone upon radiant faces and rich toilets, glittering jewels, and bits of tropical verdure and forestry.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- A stranger called on Mr. Tamney, who keeps a hotel at New-Paltz, on Friday and represented himself as a horse dealer. He said his name was Abraham Stein. He ordered sixteen halters of Mr. Tamney's son-in-law, a harnessmaker, and, after several hours' horse talk interested Mr. Tamney to such an extent that he and A.D. Broadhead drove with Stein to this city.
The Webster Free Library was opened yesterday afternoon by the managers of the East Side House at the foot of East Seventy-sixth Street. The library building is the grift of C.B. Webster.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Mr. Bailey of Texas introduced the following resolution in the House to-day:

An addition was made last night to the growing list of American comic operettas when a work called "The Maid of Plymouth" was produced at the Broadway Theatre by the company known as The Bostonians. This operetta has already been heard in other cities, and the accounts of it's merits were of such varying nature that there was considerable curiosity last evening to ascertain just what sort of a piece it was.

From The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, Jan. 4. George W. Young, Secretary and Treasurer of the Pioneer Printing Company, died suddenly yesterday of heart failure at the Arlington Hotel. Mr. Young was sixty-two years of age, and leaves a wife, four daughters, and one son.

From Texas Siftings. It is often sneeringly said that President Cleveland is bigger than his party. No one man can be bigger than the majority of the voters of this country, but President Cleveland is certainly a thousand times greater than those other Democratic leaders who refuge to do what the people want and are racking their lunatic brains to invent some cranky scheme to impose upon the people what they do not want.

Justice Lawrence of the Supreme Court has, upon the application of Henry Keteltas, trustee of the John Gardner estate, granted an order compelling Controller Ashbel P. Fitch to show cause why a peremptory mandamus should not be issued directing him to issue bonds for paying for the land set aside for Corlears Hook Park.

PRAGUE, Jan. 15. -- The trial of the men arrested for belonging to the Omladina, a secret political organization, the founder of which, Rudolf Mrva, otherwise known as "Rigoletto von Toscane," was recently assassinated by some of the members of the society, opened in this city to-day. Before the court proceedings began a band of fifty men wearing red ties and immense hats made a demonstration in front of the Court House.

It will be agreed that the reported decision of the Commissioners for the new Municipal Building is a most lame and impotent conclusion to the labors of that body. It is hard to see why it should be expected that the result of any future competition should be more successful than the result of this, which, according to the expert advisers of the commission, and apparently according to the commission itself, is a failure.

Every day sees an increase in the number of charitable men and women who are doing their utmost to help the poor of this city to face the terrible problem of the hardest Winter known for years, as far as business and employment for workingmen are concerned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The vacancy on the bench of the United States Supreme Court will not be filled by Mr. W.B. Hornblower of New-York. Some one not personally distasteful to David B. Hill and Edward Murphy, Jr., roust be selected by the President for this high position.
The North German Lloyd Steamship Company has been getting into trouble with the Immigration Bureau. Two lawsuits to determine which has justice on its side will soon be tested in the courts.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 15. -- Juaquin Infanta, Jr., a Spanish merchant of this city, killed himself, with a pistol this morning at his beautiful home on Esplanades Street. He was born in Cuba in 1864. He has lived in New-Orleans a number of years.

At the present session of the Legislature at Albany, that body will be asked to so amend the Consolidation act of the City of New-York as to provide that there shall be allotted "to the babies' ward of the Post-Graduate Hospital the sum of 38 cents per day for each and every infant received and cared for therein.''

The annual meeting of the Corinthian Mosquito Fleet was held last night at the Sturtevant House. The members turned out in large numbers. The following officers were elected for the coming season: Commodore -- Charles Pryer; Vice Commodore -- R. Slayd Clark; Rear Commodore -- C.M. Kennedy; Treasurer -- C.A. Harriman: Secretary -- J.B. Sparkman; Executive Committee -- Charles Pryer, R.S. Clark, J.B. Sparkman, C.A. Harriman, F.S. Grant. H.A. Gouge, Charles Chamberlain, and W.T. Stevens.
To-morrow the Austin Insurance case will go to the jury unless some unlooked-for developments arise. How soon afterward it win be decided is a problem.

Chauncey M. Depew said yesterday, in speaking of the agreements recently formulated for the maintenance of freight and passenger rates on both west and east bound traffic: "My belief is that these agreements will be stronger and more lasting than any previous ones, and my experience is that each succeeding railroad agreement lasts longer than its predecessor.

Residents and property owners in Gramerc Park, who for many years have had the exclusive right to the use of the pretty park in the centre of the square, are indignant because of the action of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, which has decided to tax the park on the ground that it is private property.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- Anthony W. Dimock, who, several years ago, was a wealthy business man of New-York City, made an application before Judge Clearwater, in this city, to-day, to be discharged from his liabilities, which, according to the schedule, are over $1,300,000, but, according to his testimony to-day, he-owes $1,000,000 not covered by the schedule.

The man over whose head eleven indictments are pending for violating the election laws in Gravesend brought his Coney Island methods into play in the City of Brooklyn yesterday at the meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors.

NEW-YORK. Monday, Jan. 15 -- P.M. Improving conditions were recognized generally to-day and speculative sentiment became much more hopeful. The trade returns give ground for encouragement and Wall Street is ready to more than discount all the improvement in sight. The bears show that they appreciate the change in sentiment, and the advance to-day was due to the covering of short contracts as much as to anything else.

Copyright. 1894, by the United Press. RIO JANEIRO, Jan. 10, via Montevideo, Jan. 15. -- An Interview was had yesterday on board the Almirante Tamandare with Admiral da Gama, who is in command of the insurgent squadron before Rio Janeiro. The Admiral said:
LISBON, Jan. 15. -- Details of the defeat of the Government force under Gen. Telles, which attacked the Ilha do Governado on Dec. 15, (have reached this city by mail.

The terrible collision on the Lackawanna Road will be called an accident, but it was not an accident in the strict sense of the word. The forward train, commonly called the Dover express, had pulled out of Newark and was making its way to the terminal station on the North River through a dense fog.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Since the beginning of the present fiscal year the Treasury Department has, up to and including today, lost $23,000,000 in gold. The exact figures are:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 15. -- The Republicans of the Legislature held a caucus to-night to nominate a candidate for the United States Senate. The nomination is equivalent to an election, since the Republicans have a good majority in joint convention. But three ballots were taken, Congressman John H. Gear receiving the majority vote on the third, and being declared the choice of the caucus. The result of the ballots follows:

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- The Sanford Carpet Mills resumed work to-day with a complete force, which will be employed on regular time. Three thousand workers were given employment. The West Shore Knitting Mill also commenced operations to-day, and the rug factory of McCleary, Wallin Crouse, at Rockton, will open Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- A cable message in cipher from Capt. Picking, at Rio Janeiro, addressed to Secretary Herbert, was translated at the Navy Department to-day, but Mr. Herbert declined to make its contents public. It is understood that it contains a summary of the situation, with a hint that the end of the insurrection is near at hand.

GLASTONBURY, Conn., Jan. 15. -- The committee of the town of Glastonbury appointed to ascertain whether an expenditure of $34,879 was lawfully chargeable as a part of the expense of caring for and maintaining the Hartford Bridge to East Hartford, submitted a unanimous report at a special town meeting in Glastonbury this morning.

No orders concerning the changes recommended to be made in the gunboats Machias and Castine have as yet been received by the Constructors at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. It will be remembered that the metacentric height of these two vessels was found to be too little to satisfy the members of the board which was detailed to inquire into the stability of the new gunboats.

Emile Augier's "Les Effrontes," acted at Abbey's last evening, is neither a great nor a pleasing play. Its charcters are, half of them, shady financiers, and the rest persons of title if anything still more umbrageous. Not one, with the exception of Clemence, a conventional "jeune fille," could pass the simplest sort of a civil service examination for any position for which ordinary respectability was a requisite.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 15. -- A man and a woman with an infant child arrived at the Morgan House a week ago last Saturday. The man registered as " Sidney Francis Bourchier," and claimed to be a person of title from Bristol, England. Bourohier went to Walter Corlies's real estate office and said he represented the Gloucestershire Stock and Breeding Company, (Limited,) and desired to purchase land for a stock farm.
The Madison Square Garden poultry show will open Thursday, Feb. 8, and close the Tuesday following. Entries will close a week from next Thursday unless the pens are taken up earlier.

John E. Milholland, the leader of the anti-machine Republicans, stood squarely by the pronunciamento issued by the Committee of Sixty Sunday night. He indicated that those who protested against the Patterson machine and opposed the turning over of the county organization to what the anti-machine men term "a new set of bosses," have further facts on which to base their statements as to corrupt deals with Tammany Hall.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- Charles Decker, an ex-convict from Jersey City, attempted to murder Policeman Albert Gleitsman of the local police to-night with an axe. The policeman, who was assigned to do special duty by Chief Foley, was on South Third Avenue, this city, when Decker, whom the officer did not know, approached him, axe in hand, and asked him if he was not Chief Foley. The policeman replied that he was not.
Permits for new buildings and alterations were issued yesterday as follows:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 15. -- The Naval Academy at Annapolis is the centre of the naval messenger pigeon service, which makes use of homing pigeons for communication between ship and land when other communication would be difficult or impossible. The loft at Annapolis is situated upon the top of the boathouse, and is admirably adapted to the purpose.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 15. -- There was a large but orderly crowd in the State House this evening. The entrance to the Senate Chamber became clogged as early as 6 o'clock. The city police took possession of the corridors and kept a passageway open for those who had business with the Legislature and the State departments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The regular meeting of the Senate Committee on Finance to-morrow will discuss the subject of a bond issue, and it is not impossible that a bill may be reported on that subject, although it cannot be done without strenuous opposition on the part of the silver men of the committee, who will urge that the seigniorage growing out of the purchase of silver bullion shall first be coined.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 15. -- The Consolidated and the New-England Road came together in a pitched battle here today. The ultimate result of this fight will decide the fate of the New-England. Upon it hinges the important question of the credit of that railroad company.

Mayor Gilroy said yesterday that, if he had time, to-day he would say something about John D. Townsend of the independent county organization and the statement which he had made about asphalt paving in this city, asphalt contracts, and the attitude of the Department of Public Works toward them.

Antonio Grenelli, a fruit vendor, who until recently lived in Stamford, Conn., early yesterday morning poisoned himself with paris green, shot himself in the head with a revolver, and then sprang out of a fifth-story window of the tenement house 143 Thompson Street, which is known as the "House of Blazes."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 16. -- The formal vote for United States Senator occurred in both houses of the General Assembly this morning. To-morrow the House and Senate will meet in joint session to record the result, and then an adjournment will be taken for a week. The vote for United States Senator in the Senate resulted: J.H. Gear, 33, and Horace Bioes, 11.

Lawyer Wheeler H. Peckham was seen yesterday in regard to the rejection of Mr. Hornblower by the Senate as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. He was rather unwilling to discuss the matter at first, but when asked if he considered Mr. Hornblower fitted for the position, he said: "I have placed my opinions concerning Mr. Hornblower on record before, and have not changed them since.

From The London Daily News. The details which the Commissioners at Indirect Taxes have at length been able to gather with respect to the yield of the French vineyards and orchards this year fully confirm the early returns, which indicated such a favorable state of things as has not been known since the insect known as the "phylloxera vastatrix" made its first appearance about eighteen years ago.

NEWPORT, R,I., Jan. 16. -- Miss Linbeck, who last Summer was employed as maid to Miss Gerry, the daughter of Commodore and Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry, has sued Commodore Gerry for damages for alleged false imprisonment. H.E. Read, Chief of Police of Newport, is implicated in her charges.

At the meeting of the Board of Police yesterday Superintendent Byrnes made formal report of the arrest and suspension from duty of Roundsman Michael Downs and Patrolmen John Kenny and Kerwin Larkin, who are accused of extorting money from Hebrew peddlers on the east side of the city.

The new Board of Governors of the New-York Athletic Club met last night at the clubhouse. The usual appropriation, $25,000, was made for athletics for the coming season. It was decided to continue the publication of the club journal. Several entertainments were arranged for the next few weeks. Feb. 3 will be ladies' day. On Feb. 24 there will be a boxing entertainment, and on March 3 there will be an entertainment of fencing.

PALERMO, Jan. 16. -- Three of the leaders of the Fasci dei Lavoratcri were arrested on board a steamer here to-day just as the vessel was about to start for Tunis. The police had been informed that the men intended to leave the island, but did not know by what means. Consequently a close watch was kept on all vessels leaving Palermo and other ports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Secretary Carlisle has reconsidered his intention of making public the report of the Fairchild Commission on the administration of the Customs Service at New-York. A synopsis of the report was prepared for the press several days ago. It has been decided to keep it back for the present.

From The Portland (Me.) Argus. A novel method of cultivating the faculty of observation in children has been introduced by a teacher in an up-town kindergarten. She tells her pupils that she is about to have a call from some one who will remain only three minutes, that no one must directly stare at him, but that the pupil Who gives the best description of him after his departure will receive a prize.

From The Boston Transcript. The Jabberwock is the name of a magazine published by the scholars of the Boston Girls' Latin School. The meaning of "Jabberwock" was as much a mystery to its founders as to the curious friends who asked questions about It.

The orator before the Senate called this an "age of progress," He was wrong. "Progress" does not half express it; it is an age of revolution. Revolutions carried on, not by armies, but by discoverers, inventors, and brainworkers. It is a marvelous age, an age when the ordinary wilt not be accepted, when the best is demanded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The Secretary of War and Mrs. Lamont gave a Cabinet dinner to-night. The decorations of the dinner table were of daffodils, the pretty effect of which was heightened by Mrs. Cleveland, Mrs. Lamont, and Miss Grace Sanders wearing gowns of yellow brocade. About the centrepiece of daffodils the candelabra were capped with white silk shades, strewn with buttercups.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Secretary Carlisle to-day transmitted to the Senate his answer to Senator Alien's resolution inquiring how he arrived at the conclusion that there had been a net gain of $56,869,482 in gold outside of the Treasury since Nov. 1, 1892.

(Copyright, 1894, by the United Press.) ROME, Jan. 16. -- There is considerable excitement to-day to Carrara and vicinity. The discovery Saturday night of an Anarchist plot to loot and burn the City of Carrara led the police and military authorities to take extraordinary precautions to prevent any attempt to carry out the plans of the conspirators.

We cannot undertake to point out all the false assertions in the Reed minority report on the Wilson bill. That would require much, more space than any journal could spare for such work. But a few samples, taken here and there, will suffice to show now untrustworthy this minority report is, and one of them relates to tin plate.

A little increase in west Side business is reported by real estate brokers. Yesterday Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. sold, for-George C. Edgar's Sons, to a Mr. Dreyfus the four-story, brownstone-extension, boxstoop residence, 22 West Sixty-ninth Street, 21 by 69 by 100.5, for about $40,000. The house is the last of eleven built by the Edgars on this block to be sold.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 16. -- The pilot boat Joseph F. Loubat of New-York went ashore in the heavy storm last night two miles east of the Amagansett Life Station. A patrolman of that station discovered the boat before daylight.

A few days of cold weather are greatly desired by the dwellers along the Hudson River. A week of such weather as was experienced in the latter part of last week would open up an industry which would at once give employment to many thousand men, cutting ice and stowing it in the houses which are scattered thickly at almost every town.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.-- Short speeches, occasionally colored by partisan expressions, and many of them of an entertaining character, were heard to-day in the House on the Tariff hill, which was again considered under the five-minute rule.

Negotiations were completed yesterday by which the Brooklyn City Railroad Company acquired possession of the Brooklyn City and Suburban Railroad Company, and, through this acquirement, practically comes into possession of the Broadway Railroad Company of Brooklyn, which comprises the Brooklyn and Jamaica and Metropolitan Avenue Railroad Companies.

No society organized for the purpose of relieving the worthy poor in a judicious manner is giving more satisfaction to its patrons and the public at large than the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, with headquarters in the United Charities Building at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

Nicholas Fish, the banker, of 120 Broadway was accosted at Eighteenth Street and Irving Place about 8 o'clock last night by a fairly well-dressed man, who asked for alms. When the banker passed on without noticing him, the beggar followed, pouring out a torrent of abusive language.

DANVILLE, Va., Jan. 16. -- The City Collector to-day posted a notice on the door of the Western Union Telegraph Company's office here advertising for sale on Jan. 26 certain desks, tables, counters, chairs, stove and pipe, 235 glass jars, switchboard and wire, and clock, taken by him to satisfy the city license tax in his hands for collection.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- Lieut. Gen. Sir George Tomkyns Chesney, M.P., delivered a speech in London this evening on the defenses of the British Empire. He expressed the opinion that the English colonies generally, with the exception of Canada, were perfectly safe. In the event of war with the United States, he said, it would be impossible for Great Britain to prevent Canada from being annexed to the United States.

The death is announced in Paris of Savinien Lapoiute, shoemaker and poet, whom Beranger, Eugene Sue and Victor Hugo praised. He was born at Sens Feb. 28, 1811. His father was a shoemaker. His favorite author was Jean-Jaeaues Kousseau. He fought at the barricades against Charles X. in 1830.

There was another long discussion before Justice Barrett in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, upon the question as to whether the court should grant an order to compel Receiver Hugh J. Grant of the St. Nicholas Bank to return moneys represented by checks which were deposited in the bank on Dec. 20 last, the day before the bank was closed by the Bank Superintendent.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- Three thousand persons crowded into Neff Opera House this evening to hear Thomas G. Sheaarnan discuss the Wilson bill. Mr. Shearman held the attention of his audience for nearly three hours. Resolutions were adopted favoring the Wilson bill with great enthusiasm.

The very interesting and conclusive investigation as to the cause of an epidemic of typhoid fever in Springfield, of which we spoke some weeks ago, was not the only inquiry of this kind recently made by Prof. Sedgwick, the biologist of the Massachusetts Board of Health.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- Ex-Senator Erwin died at Potsdam early this morning.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 16. -- The bodies of two more victims of Friday night's bridge disaster on Newtown Creels were recovered to-day. They were the bodies of John Kerwin, forty-flve years oli, of 374 Lorimer Street, and Charles B. MeGruder, forty years old, of 134 Leonard Street, Brooklyn.

NEW-YORK. Tuesday, Jan. 16 -- P.M. The stock market was dull and irregular. There was a fair amount of activity in the morning, particularly in Western Union, Chicago Gas, St. Paul, General Electric, and Reading, but in the afternoon the dullness approached stagnation. London sold its specialties and they were all fractionally lower.
John C. Austin is dead. His heirs are entitled to recover $16,752.50, the full amount, with interest, on his life insurance policy in the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Insurance Association.

VILLEFRANCHE-SUR-MER, France, Jan. 4. -- Those who think the prolonged stay of the United States men-of-war in the waters of this snug little bay is only for the benefit of those who are on pleasure bent would find themselves mistaken were they here to witness the drills and exercises that are constantly being carried on.

The charge of fraud made against Charles Leonard Fletcher, the soi-disant "professor of the dramatic art," by one Herbert Clayton, an inventor, who is anxious to become a playwright, from which charge Fletcher was released on Monday, has occasioned a great deal of gossip, principally of a reminiscent character, among actors in their up-town haunts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- Ex-Mayor Cregier was a witness at the Coughlin trial this morning. He was called by the defense to throw some light, if possible, upon the disappearance of the shorthand notes and transcript taken during the defendant's examination at the City Hall the day he was arrested.

CHARLESTOWN, R.I., Jan. 16. -- About eighty of the Narragansett Indians, the principal survivors of the once-powerful tribe of red men, met in the Old Stone Church on the reservation yesterday for a final consideration of their land claims against the State. It was decided that a committee should be appointed to present their claims at the coming session of the General Assembly, and to secure, if possible, some indemnification.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- There has been considerable gossip at the Capitol to-day concerning the rejection by the Senate of the nomination, of W.B. Horriblower of New-York to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, and several names were mentioned as likely to be considered by the President in casting about for another appointee.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 16. -- The steamship Stillwater arrived last night from Truxillo, Honduras. J. Lee of London, who came up on her, in discussing the warlike state of affairs in Central America, said that everything now pointed to the success of the rebels,' but that it was hard to tell what would be the result.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- The sessions of both houses were brief and pointless to-day, and both adjourned out of respect to the memory of ex-Senator George Zalmon Erwin. The announcement of his death was made in the Senate by his successor, Joseph Mullin of Jefferson, and in the House by the Republican leader, Danforth E. Ainsworth of Oswego.

PARIS, Jan. 16. -- Nothing has yet been learned that would throw any light on the case of Edward Webster, the young American who mysteriously disappeared in this this city on New Year's eve. Monroe Co., the bankers, have not yet received the $5,000 that was alleged to have been offered as a reward for the knowledge as to Webster's whereabouts.

BUENOS AYRES, Jan. 16. -- Dispatches received here last night from Rio de Janeiro stated that the insurgent war ship Aquidaban had taken up a position in front of the Custom House and was preparing to land troops.

The Clearing House Association yesterday afternoon met to hear the report of the committee which had been authorized to proceed with the purchase of the site for a Clearing House Building at 77, 79, and 81 Cedar Street. Upon the committee's advice it was decided to form a corporation to be known as the New-York Clearing House Building Company; capital, $375,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16.-- The annual meeting of the Lehigh Valley Railway Company was held here this afternoon, and it was marked throughout by acrimonious discussion. The chief disputants were John N. Hutchinson, a large stockholder, and William B. Lockwood, whose antagonism appeared to be of a personal character.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

The Boxing and Wrestling Championship Committee of the Amateur Athletic Union, Messrs. W.B. Curtis and James E. Sullivan, have made final arrangements with Mr. F.W. Sanger of the Madison Square Garden Company whereby the Amateur Athletic Union will hold its annual championship meeting in the amphitheatre of Madison Square Garden on Saturday, March 3.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- Gov. Flower's annual legislative reception was held to-night at the Executive Mansion. Several thousand invitations had been issued. The mansion was brilliantly lighted, and potted plants were generously distributed about the rooms of the commodious residence. From 9 until 12 o'clock the Governor was kept busy in the east drawing room receiving the constant flow of people who desired to meet him.

Postmaster Dayton has done an important municipal service by the investigation which he has instituted into the conditions of postal delivery in New-York. His account of this investigation is given in our news columns. What he happily calls the "postal census" has bad some very surprising results.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Judge Cole to-day overruled the motion to quash the indictments against Bookmaker Marvin, his three assistants, and George H. Engeman, under which they were charged with having set up and kept a gaming table or gambling device and engaging in bookmaking at the Ivy City race track last month.
The Master Plumbers' Association of Brooklyn is up in arms against the continuance of a commission created by the McLaughlin dynasty.

The information given in The New-York Times yesterday to the effect that there was an excellent chance that all of the six plans favorably reported upon by the Advisory Committee of Architects to the New Municipal Building Commission would be rejected attracted wide attention from architects, city officials, and the public in general.

Plans were approved in the Blinding Department yesterday for a six-story brick building on the northwest corner of William and Duane Streets, owned by Sherman S. Townsend of 108 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, to cost $25,000.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 16. -- The inquest on the bodies of nine men who were killed yesterday by the collision between the Orange and Dover trains west of the Hackensack River draw was begun to-day in Hoboken by Coroner Anthony J. Volk, who impaneled the following jury of business men and well-known citizens:

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- The New-York State Bar Association began its seventeenth annual meeting this afternoon in the Senate Chamber. President J. Newton Fiero presided. There were many prominent lawyers in attendance, as well as members of the Legislature. The galleries were filled.

In the campaign in the Fourteenth Congressional District, in which, by helping to elect Lemuel Ely Quigg to Congress as the successor of Col. John R. Fellows, William Leary is trying to injure the prospects of the Wilson Tariff bill, a new feature was decided on yesterday.

"I have no criticism to make. I will say, however, that the hospital was practically built up by the present staff, many of whom have, during their connection with it, devoted, to all intents and purposes, their whole professional career to advancing its welfare."

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 16. -- A national conference for good city government is to be held in this city Jan. 25 and 26. James C. Carter of New-York will preside. At the first day's session George Burnham, Jr., President of the Municipal League, will deliver an address of welcome. There will be, also, addresses sketching the condition of leading municipal governments.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 16. -- The indications are that tire two rival Senates will not come together this week. A marked change has came over the situation within the last ten hours.

For the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery a varied and enjoyable entertainment was given at the Empire Theatre yesterday afternoon. Viola Allen, W.H. Thompson, W. Faversham, and Joseph Humphreys appeared in a one-act piece, of English manufacture, called "John Thurgood, Farmer." Henry Byatt is the author.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 16. -- The cruiser Montgomery behaved well on her preliminary spin on Long Island Sound to-day. She started from New-London, at 11:30 o'clock with a portion of the trial board and their assistants. There was a light wind abeam and smooth water ahead when she got into the open water and began to increase her speed.

Work of fitting torpedo tubes in the new cruiser Marblehead, now at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was begun yesterday. Whitehead torpedoes will be carried by the vessel. A contract for the manufacture of fifty of those auto-mobile missiles has been awarded to E.W. Bliss.

The attention of J. Edward Simmons, Chairman of the Chicago and Northern Pacific Bondholders' Committee, was called yesterday to a circular issued by a Philadelphia committee of holders of bonds of the same railroad. He said:

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- If Mr. Lou Payn, Chairman Hackett, and other State Committeemen whom Mr. Platt has ordered to Albany to bulldoze independent legislators succeed in their purposes, the muchdiscussed caucus of Republican Senators and members will be held this week, perhaps on Thursday. Mr. Payn and Mr. Hackett are still on the ground, but the contract undertaken by Sisyphus was insignificant compared to that which they now have on hand.
Sidewalks on both sides of the proposed Hariem River Driveway are now thought to be practically assured.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- There will be an issue of bonds, and it will be made without the special consent of this Congress. A comparison of the statements contained in the letter of Secretary Carlisle to Mr. Voorhees, Chairman of the Senate Committee of Finance, and those which Mr. Voorhees made public this afternoon compels this conclusion.

The Hamilton Building, 40, 42, and 44 Court Street, Brooklyn, caught fire at 9:45 o'clock last evening, and but for the prompt arrival of the Fire Department would have been destroyed. The origin of the fire is not known, but flames were discovered in the elevator shaft by a man passing through the building.

-- A statement was issued by the receivers of the union Pacific Railroad yesterday showing the earnings and expenses for November of the entire system, as follows: Gross earnings. $3,300,072; operating: expenses, exclusive of taxes. $1,095,094; net earnings, $1,330.078. For the eleven months ending: Nov. 30 the gross earnings were $34,088,087, and the net earnings $11.014,040 -- a decrease in the net earnings as compared with eleven months last year of $4,300,000.

Mr. Carlisle has offered to the public $50,000,000 United States ten-year 5 per cant. bonds at not less than 117.223. The details of the proposition will be found in our Washington dispatches. The general opinion in financial circles seems to be that the loan will be promptly taken, and that by the 1st of March the bonds would command 120.
An inspiring incident at the scene of the Hackensack Bridge disaster last Monday contained evidence of the wisdom of a very ancient precept.
The funeral of Robert Livingston Cutting, which took place at Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, at 10 A.M. yesterday, was attended by representatives of many old New-York families.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17 -- Business in this vicinity has shown a decided Improvement since the opening of the new year. The New-Haven Clock Company, employing about 800 hands, has again started up, with full hours and the usual force.

A rumor was circulated about the General Sessions Building yesterday that Superintendent Byrnes was about to present more evidence to the Grand Jury in regard to members of the police force who are suspected of having received bribes from street peddlers and push-cart men. The three policemen who were indicted by the Grand Jury for bribery and extortion were rear-rested on warrants issued from the District Attorney's office.
There was an exciting time early last evening in front of Ehrich's dry goods store in Sixth Avenue, caused by a hot chase after two female shoplifters who had been detected in the store.

Otto Merath's store at 819 Tenth Avenue was robbed on New Year's night of a number of odd shoes. Tuesday night about $300 worth of clothing was taken from M. Fisher's store, at 842 Tenth Avenue, and early yesterday morning the wholesale liquor store of Christopher J. Welker, at 785 Ninth Avenue, was robbed of a large quantity of wines and liquors in bottles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The first veto of this Congress came in to the House today. The President disapproved the bill for the relief of entrymen of stone and timber lands. The ground of the Presidential objection is that the bill, by allowing entries to be perfected before judicial officers, interferes with the responsibilities properly lodged in officers of the Land Bureau.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 17 -- The outlook for a settlement of the trouble over the organization of the Senate is still not promising. The joint conference to-day resulted in nothing that would indicate that either party would yield.

The grand art function at the Fine Arts Society foretold in Monday's paper took place last night according to the programme, with due accompaniment of music. The society could hardly have made a better choice among the foreign exhibits at the World's Fair than the paintings and water colors of Holland, Sweden, and Norway.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- There was a large attendance at the second day's session of the State Bar Association to-day. The Committee on Revision of the Corporation Laws was authorized to continue work for another year. William P. Burr read an interesting paper on "The Constitutional Convention of 1846 and 1847."

Fire Commissioner John Ennis is following the example set by Police Commissioner Hayden in the matter of making promotions and appointments. Mr. Hayden, who is to retire from the Police Department Jan. 31, has been making appointments by Wholesale in order that no vacancies may be left for his successor to flll.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- Odds and ends of evidence from unimportant witnesses were brought to-day before the jury that is trying Daniel Coughlin for the murder of Dr. Cronin. The Government of the United States was represented by E.C. Vose, the weather man from the Chicago observatory in the Auditorium tower.

The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst had another bomb for the Police Department yesterday. The Police Commissioners. Superintendent Byrnes, and Mayor Gilroy have all received attention, but the official directly aimed at is Capt. Price of the Twentieth Precinct. In calling attention to Capt. Price's neglect in suppressing certain disorderly houses in his precinct, Dr. Parkhurst is sarcastic and caustic.

SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 17 -- "I am the resurrection and the life; he that believeth in me, though, he were dead, yet shall he live," said the Rev. Walter Gwynne of Cavalry Episcopal Church, as be stood this afternoon before the bier of Edward Morrell, a victim of the Hackensack meadows collision.

VERA CRUZ, Mexico, Jan. 17. -- The Ward Line steamship Seguranca is in quarantine off this port with twenty-two cases of smallpox on board. She sailed from New-York with the regulation number of passengers, and is held at Sacrificios Island, ten miles down the coast.

The work of the defaulter Francis H. Weeks was recalled to my by a sale under foreclosure which was held in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday by Auctioneer John N. Golding. In other ways, also, the sale was a notable one. The property was the handsome four-story brick dwelling 263 West Seventy-third Street, north side, 193 feet east of West End Avenue, 19 feet front, with a lot 102.2 feet deep.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 17 -- The Montgomery's trial will not take place to-morrow. The contractors were ready, but the Government was not. Capt. Cooper of the trial board, who had been out on the Sound since Sunday morning with the Government steamer Gardenia locating buoys on the course, returned this evening.

The position taken by President Cleveland in his annual message in regard to Armenians who return to Turkey as American citizens has recently had some significant commentaries. The first is an article that appeared in The Congregationalist of Boston a few weeks since. The other is a meeting held in a hall on Twenty-third Street, in this city, on the evening of the 6th.

Sheriff Clancy informed District Attorney Fellows yesterday afternoon that he did not want to hold Edward M. Field any longer in Ludlow Street Jail, and suggested that he be transferred, to the Tombs. After considering the matter further, however, the Sheriff consented to hold Field until Judge Van Brunt shall have decided the case.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Apart from the political phase of Secretary Carlisle's decision to invite proposals for the purchase of $50,000,000 in Government bonds, the general opinion, of Chicago bankers is that the course taken was expedient and will prove beneficial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The fancy-dress ball given to-night by Lieut. and Mrs. Richardson Clover recalled the delightful parties for which the hostess was famous before her marriage. The elegant new house was to-night, for the first time since its completion, opened for an evening party. The guests were all in mask until midnight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Senate has begun the discussion of the Federal Elections bill, but the indications are that it will not delve very deep into the subject mill next monday. Mr. Chandler, while seeking to convey the impression that he is anxious to debate the measure, has been unwilling to name a time when he will be prepared to begin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Nearly all the Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee held a conference at the Treasury Department to-night to consider the income-tax measure. The draft of the bill, drawn up by a sub-committee, was adopted.

William Thompson, twelve years old, of 514 West Fifty-fifth Street, told a story of abuse and suffering in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday that aroused the sympathies of the court officers. At 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning he was found asleep in the hallway of a house in Sixty-ninth Street, between Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues.

The funeral of William Livingston Hamersley was held in St. Agnes's Church, Forty-third Street and Third Avenue, yesterday morning. After a mass of requiem, the body was taken to Trinity Churchyard for burial in the family lot. There were no pall bearers. Mr. Hamersley was a relative of Louis C. Hamersley, whose widow is the Dowager Duchess of Marlborough.

There is every likelihood of the New-York baseball team being strengthened by W.H. Murphy, the Yale short stop, or Herman Long of the Bostons. Just now it looks as though Murphy would be the man if he decides to play on a league nine. The New-York magnates have for some time been considering the advisability of trying to secure Murphy, and it is understood that he has received a very flattering offer from the club.
DETROIT, Jan. 17 -- The second annual meeting of the Lake Carriers' Association was held in this city to-day. Nearly 200 vessel owners were present.

Merchants who have for years done business in the lower parts of the city, particularly in what is known as the dry goods district, extending now from Chambers Street on the south to Bleecker Street on the north, were greatly disturbed yesterday over exaggerated reports that the ordinance against sidewalk obstructions was to be arbitrarily enforced by the police.

William L. Bull, ex-President of the New-York Stock Exchange, and Charles T. Barney have sent in their resignations as Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad. The reason they assign for such action is that they are satisfied that they can be of no further service to the company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The civil service law was discussed at considerable length in the Senate to-day. Mr. Call of Florida introduced a resolution yesterday calling for an examination into the condition of the civil service of the United States, and as to the expediency of its retrenchment or its increase.

A permit was granted by the Building Department yesterday to S.V.R. Cruger, to make alterations to the three-story brick dwelling house and store on the northwest corner of Grand and Mott Streets, at a cost of $2,500.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- A dispatch from Buenos Ayres says: "The insurgent war ship Aquidaban is about to return southward, with the intention of bringing reinforcements to Rio Janeiro."

PALERMO, Jan. 17 -- The police at Catania have seized several knives, bearing on their blades the inscriptions, "Vive de Felice" and "Vive Colajanni." Both de Felice and Colajanni, who are Sicilians, are Socialist members of the Chamber of Deputies. The former is now under arrest here for the part he has taken in the Sicilian agitation.

Leonard Moody, the Brooklyn real estate dealer and President of the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage's Presbyterian Tabernacle, completed yesterday the great work of asking 3,000 people what they thought of his plan to charge 10 cents admission to Dr. Talmage's preaching.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The transportation of the mammoth shaft of red granite for the battle monument, which reached here last evening from Stony Creek, Conn., where the stone for it was quarried, caused some of the railroad officials a great deal of trouble.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- In the last two or three days several Administration Democrats of New-York State who have been appointed to more or less responsible positions have appeared in Washington to ascertain, if possible, why their nominations have not been confirmed. Valentine Fleckenstein of Rochester, named by Mr. Cleveland for the position of Collector of Internal Revenue for the Twenty-eighth District, is one of these.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Jan. 17 -- Good weather and a large attendance characterized the first day of the Hamilton Gun Club's tourney. The list of entries includes crack shots of the United States and Canada. The principal event of the day, a match for $700, 20 live birds, was unfinished on account of the large number of contestants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- By a combination of Republicans and Democrats to-day the amendment proposed, to be made to the free wool clause of the Tariff bill, postponing its operation from June 1, when the bill is to become operative, until Aug. 1, was defeated, the Republicans and Democratic free-traders acting together to approve the substitute offered by Mr. Tom L. Johnson to make wool free at once.

From The Buffalo Courier, (Dem.) In this case the Senate has adopted Senator Hill's standard of fitness for a judicial office. It is not the standard recognized by the people of this State, as a majority of more than 100,000 against Mr. Hill's candidate for a seat in the highest State court at the recent election has conclusively shown.

Mr. Isidor Straus's campaign for Congress in the Fifteenth Congressional District, was begun last night at the Harlem Democratic Club, 13 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. Honest tariff reform is to be its keynote, and there was no uncertain sound about the way in which the issue was stated.

Secretary Carlisle's action was taken too late in the day to affect the down-town markets except by anticipation. All day Wall Street had been supplied with reports from Washington which foreshadowed something of the kind. The markets broadened under this influence, and purchases, especially in securities, reflected greatly improved feeling through the unerring signs of firm, if not of advancing quotations.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The Legislature will adjourn to-morrow till Monday night in order to allow the members to go to Potsdam, to attend the funeral of ex-Senator George Z. Erwin, which will take place on Friday. The much-expected caucus will not take place. Louis Payn started, for NewYork last night thoroughly satisfied, of the impossibility of such an effort.
In spite of it being the dull season-for yachtsmen there seems to be a little life at the English yards, according to The London Field.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- One of the most important meetings ever held by the State Board of Health was held yesterday afternoon. For the first time in many years there was a full attendance, every member reporting for duty, including Attorney General Hancock, who began his term by looking after this department which his predecessors had studiously neglected.

Secretary Milbury of the Industrial Christian Ailliance, that has started so many people's five-cent restaurants in the city, is about the hardest worker in the alliance. His work for Tuesday was continued until 4 o'clock yesterday morning. Four hours later he was up again, and worked for the remainder of the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Baltimore editor who has just described the Senate as a "case of Adulism," full of Senators who are "in debt," or "distressed" or "discontented," prepared his readers for the call issued this afternoon by Secretary Carlisle for bids for $50,000,000 of 5 per cent. bonds.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 17 -- A bill was introduced in the State Senate to-day "Authorizing the purchasers of the Richmond and Danville Railroad, their successors and assigns, to become a corporation, adopt a name therefor, and possess and exercise general powers, and authorizing the consolidation therewith of other corporations."

Col. Henry A. Stoerizer last night celebrated his twenty-fifth anniversary as a riding master in New-York, and his friends gave him a testimonial benefit in Durland's Riding Academy. The big building was well filled with the friends of the popular rider, and a very interesting programme was gone through. The committee in charge of the entertainment were:

Six of the crew of the Dutch steamship Amsterdam were missing when the vessel reached port yesterday from Rotterdam. While First Officer J. Meyer, F. Requart, the boatswain: A.J. Oudyn, the carpenter; A. Bosch, the steerage steward; F.G.E. Eichorn, the quartermaster, and Seaman A. Van Vleet were on their way to save the crew of the sinking schooner Maggie E. Wells the lifeboat in which they were was swamped and they were drowned.

Miss Maud Halliday's suit against Charles Schildwachter for $50,000 for breach of promise of marriage and betrayal was continued yesterday before Judge Gildersleeve of the Superior Court, and at 5:30 o'clock in the afternoon the jury was ordered to bring in a sealed verdict.

VALLEY PARK, Mo., Jan. 17. -- John Buchner, a desperate and worthless negro, was lynched here early this morning for assaulting in one day Mrs. Albert Mungo, a middle-aged colored woman, and Miss Alice Harrison, the highly-esteemed daughter of William R. Harriaon of this place. He had only recently been released from the penitentiary, where he had served a three years' sentence for assaulting a colored school, teacher.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The National Guard Association held its annual meeting here to-day. The following were elected officers for the ensuing year: President -- Col. George C. Fox of Buffalo; Vice Presidents -- Col. John T. Camp of New-York City and Capt. Edward M. Hoffman of Elmira; Secretary -- Albert L. Judson of Albany; Treasurer -- Capt. David Wilson of the Second Battery; Chaplain -- The Rev. D. Dunnell of New-York City.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 17 -- The Duval Club to-night issued what its members termed a final and positive announcement that the Corbett-Mitchell contest will take place on Jan. 25.

There has just been forwarded to the Legislature of the State of New-York a memorial, prepared by a select committee of the Medico-Legal Society of the State of New-York, urging upon the Legislature the expediency of the abolition of the office of Coroner.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Vice President Stevenson drove in this morning from Bleak House, where he had spent last night with Senator David B. Hill. Both gentlemen repaired to the Capitol and paid their respects to Gov. Flower. Both houses of the Legislature were in session at the time, and ere long the news was conveyed to the Senate Chamber that the Vice President was in the building.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Jan. 17 -- P.M. Less than 120,000 shares of stock changed hands to-day, and considerably more than half the business was done before noon. St. Paul was the most active stock, and in only three others did the tracing exceed 10,000 shares. London prices came lower, owing to the liquidation in that market of a broker's account.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Speaker Crisp to-day announced some House committee appointments. Mr. Money (Dem., Miss.,) was appointed to the Committee on Foreign Affairs, in place of Mr. Fitch of New-York, resigned, and Mr. Dearmond (Dem., Mo.,) to the Judiciary Committee, in place of Mr. Fellows of New-York, resigned.

In the story printed in yesterday's New-York Times in relation to Charles Leonard Fletcher, the soi-disant "professor of the dramatic art," who obtained $250 from Herbert Clayton to exploit the alleged play "Temptation," it was stated by Fletcher that Clayton was a playwright and that he was the author of the play.

An evening newspaper in Brooklyn published a story yesterday stating that Mr. and Mrs. "William J. Bok. had separated, after only a year of married life. According to the report published, they had given up their residence, 259 Lafayette Avenue, and Mrs. Bok had gone to Mexico, while her husband had changed his residence to the Clarendon Hotel.

The proclamation of a state of siege in Massa and Carrara is an official acknowledgment of the most emphatic kind that the disorders of Sicily are no longer confined to the island, but have spread to the peninsula. There was, in truth, no reason for supposing that the Sicilians had any grievances that were not common to all the Italians.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The two bantams of the Senate, Cantor of New-York and Lexow of Rockland, had a passage at arms this morning which was entertaining while it lasted. Lexow is a new man with a superlative regard for the prerogative of a Senator. He is regarded as one of Mr. Platt's most faithful worshippers.

John A. Morris, lottery king, and his aspiring young son, Alfred H., were strongly in evidence yesterday before Justice Patterson of the Supreme Court as musical experts. With that chivalric modesty which at all times distinguishes him the lottery king coyly deprecated his own musical knowledge.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. ROME, Jan. 17 -- A royal decree, dated yesterday, countersigned by all the Ministers, has been issued, proclaiming a state of siege at Carrara and Massa di Carrara, the cities in which certain classes of workingmen have been acting in a riotous manner for several days.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 17 -- It was discovered this morning that a dynamite bomb had been placed against a four-story building on Grant Street, adjoining the police station. The bomb contained half a pound of dynamite incased in lead pipe, carefully closed with nitroglycerine caps and fuse. The fuse had been lighted, but for some reason had refused to burn.

Gouverneur Hospital is undoubtedly not an ideal institution. It is overtaxed, badly appointed, and in a part of the city ill adapted in most respects for such a public charity. The Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association saw fit in its annual report published yesterday to severely criticise Gouverneur, saying, among other things, "Such a hospital is a strange spectacle in this wealthy city."

The committee appointed at the dinner party at Whitelaw Reid's house to prepare a bill providing for a reorganization of the Police Board in this city proposes to send a measure to Albany to supersede the one introduced some days ago, which is supposed to have the indorsement of Thomas C. Platt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Senate has passed the House bill to improve the methods of accounting in the Post Office Department. It was taken from the calenday to-day at the-instance of Mr. Cockrell, and went through without any opposition. It had previously been approved by the Postmaster General.
Under the heading, "Day Seems to be Breaking," The Shoe and Leather Reporter thus refers to the situation:

If the Rev. George Frederick Burgoyne Howard, otherwise known as William Lord Moore, who was recently sentenced by the Federal court in Jackson, Tenn., to be imprisoned in the penitentiary for a long term of years, should be permitted by the Government to visit Jacksonville, Fla., for a few days, he could enlighten some of the residents of that city as to the merits of an undertaking in which they are deeply interested.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The Issuance by Secretary Carlisle of a circular inviting subscriptions for bonds was the chief topic of conversation on the Stock Exchange today.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Fred Simpkins is a farmer in a small way and lives in the village of Hannibal, Oswego County. He has a pretty daughter, twelve years old. A young man named Lawler, twenty-four years old, a nephew of Simpkins, has been living with the family for several months. On Tuesday Mr. Simpkins was called to Lyons on a lawsuit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The retirement of Senator Walthall of Mississippi from the Senate, even temporarily, following his resignation on account of ill health, will be greatly regretted by all who have the pleasure of his acquaintance, and is a distinct loss to the Administration, to which he was friendly in a body in which the Administration has some foes of its own party.

As indicated in The New-York Times of Wednesday, the prospect that the proposed Harlem River Driveway will be constructed with two sidewalks instead of one, and that on the inner or bluf side, are growing better every day.

The meeting of the Cleveland Democratic Club of 247 East Eighty-fourth Street was held last evening to indorse the candidacy of Isidor Strauss for election in the Fifteenth Congressional District to fill the unexpired term of Ashbel P. Fitch. James J. Daly presided. There were about 500 voters present.
RIO JANEIRO, Jan. 18 -- It is reported here that the Government and the insurgent leaders have agreed to submit their differences to arbitrators for settlement.

A distinctly better feeling has prevailed among real estate men since the beginning of the new year. There are more inquiries for various kinds of property, and the past two weeks have shown more sales than nearly the whole month of December. A. number of sales for investment have taken place which the parties, for reasons of their own, have not yet placed on record.

The Committee of Thirty from the Republican county organization, of which Cornelius N. Bliss is Chairman, met at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon and took further steps toward delivering the county organization into the hands of the Union League Club.

The railroads of the country, especially those in the West, have already begun to feel the effects of a gradual improvement in business. Movements of freight are increasing in obedience to the reawakening of mercantile trade, and the proportion or railway earnings to tie expends is steadily assuming a more favorable aspect.

American railway securities were strong in the London market. Secretary Carlisle's circular calling for bids for a new issue of bonds had a favorable influence on prices. The two stocks in which the bears lave been most active recently, St. Paul and Louisville and Nashville, made the sharpest advances.
All the Rapid-Transit Commissioners were present at yesterday's meeting for the first time in several months.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The State rested its case against Daniel Coughlin at the opening of to-day's session. The defense will begin Monday morning, the interval being allowed to arrange the order of testimony and get the witnesses into line. There will be between 75 and 100 of them.

Smallpox is increasing among the patients in the Charity Hospital on Black-well's Island. It has been found necessary to quarantine the hospital. Among those stricken by the disease is Robert Roberts, the Warden.
"As a matter of fact the times are not hard, and the country is in a prosperous condition."

Without speech or laughter, over 200 deafmutes danced Wednesday night to strains of music they could, not hear. Looking down from the balcony, it seemed a phantom dance. It was all very real and merry, however, to the dancers, who caught the rhythm of waltz and quadrille and went through all the varied intricacies of the dance with perfect ease and grace.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- "The Charlatan, a New Play of Modern Life," by Robert Buchanan, had its first night at the Hay-market Theatre this evening. It is a satire on Theosophy. Beerbohm Tree as Philip Woodville played the title role, assisted by Miss Kingston as Mme. Obnoskin. In a seance at the Earl of Wanborough's country seat Mme. Obnoskin summons the vision of the missing father of Wanborough's niece, whom Woodville loves.

PICTOU, N.S., Jan. 18 -- The Government steamer Stanley, which beeps up Winter comunication between the mainland and Prince Ed-ward Island, is still fast in the ice at Malignant Cove, fifteen, miles east of Pictou Light, having 16ft the Island side last Friday morning, and will not be able to change her position until a strong southerly wind sets in.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- In the Senate Committee on Military Affairs, of which he is Chairman, Senator Walthail of Mississippi this morning notified the members of that committee that he intended laying his resignation as a Senator before the Senate, Mr. Waithall gave as his reason his failing health and his inability to keep up with the duties that devolve upon him as the representative in the Senate of the State of Mississippi.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 18 -- A special train rolled into the station of the Delaware. Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company shortly before 1 o'clock this afternoon, with the bodies of William Ferguson and John H. Rimmer of Summit, who were killed in the Hackensack Meadows collision Monday.

Jacob Finelite, a clothing merchant at Park Row and Baxter Street, was held in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday in $2,000 ball on a charge of procuring a forgery. The complainant was Max Ball, brother of Mr. Finelite's wife and son of H. Ball of the Broadway clothing firm of A. H. King Co.

The information given in The New-York Times of Tuesday relative to the probable rejection of the six plans for the new Municipal Building, reported as being the best by the Advisory Committee of Architects, was fully corroborated at yesterday's meeting of the new Municipal Building Commission held in the Mayor's office.

Among the members of the Chamber of Commerce there is a comprehensive unanimity of opinion in favor of a single head for the Police Department. There is also a well-defined sentiment among the members that the Chamber should now depart from its traditions and make its voice heard in politics.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 18 -- A challenge from the Columbia College Track Athletic Association for a set of joint games with Princeton Just before the intercollegiate contests, has been promptly accepted by Princeton's athletic managers. A meeting of representatives of the associations will be held next month to arrange the time, place, and details.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- A certificate of authorization to do business in this State was issued by the Secretary of State today to the United States Cordage Company, which is a New-Jersey corporation. The company is the reorganized Cordage Trust and is incorporated under the laws of New-Jersey with a capital stock of $34,000,000.

The Church Choral Society, a meritorious organization, devoted to the performance of the best church music, is now in the sixth year of its activity, and its prosperity continues unabated. The first evening service of the current season was held last night in the Church of Zion and St. Timothy, which is in Fifty-seventh Street, west of Eighth Avenue.

One of the most encouraging things about the outlook for the general revival of business are the announcements that appear weekly in the trade journals of all classes of the proposed extensions of existing manufacturing establishments and propositions to build new ones. Ample capital can be had, and that the new factories are building, or in a way to be built, is proof positive that there is faith in the future.
Mayor Schieren was yesterday asked by a reporter for The New-York Times what he would do in regard to saloons with unlawful proximity of public schools and churches in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Chairman Wilson of the Committee on Ways and Means, referring to the proposed issue of bonds, said Congress should have given Secretary Carlisle authority to issue a low-rate shorttime bond; falling to receive that authority, he assumed, the Secretary had done the best he could under existing conditions.

At the conference of the Prison Association of New-York at its headquarters in East Fifteenfh Street yesterday. Warden Durston of Sing Sing had much to say about graded prisons, the dark cell, and corporal punishment. Mr. Durston was opposed to putting "life prisoners" or convicts serving out long sentences with men who had short terms of punishment.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 18 -- The Government steamer Gardenia completed the work to-day of locating buoys for the Montgomery's trial, and, weather permitting, the new cruiser will demonstrate her speed in a four hours' run to-morrow. The Gardenia, with Commander P.H. Cooper and Lieut West on board, has been since Sunday morning laying out the thirty-six-mile course on Long Island Sound.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 18 -- For the first time, Corbett and Mitchell signed articles agreeing to fight to a finish, under the direction, of the Duval Athletic Club, today. Whether the battle win be fought without interference depends on the, ability of the club to keep the place selected for the fight a secret.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The political situation in Albany is becoming more and more confused. The indecision of the Republicans in New-York and their flop from, their advocacy of a single-headed Police Commission to favor of Mr. Platt's four-headed commission has led to much uncertainty and speculation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- The truth about certain stacks and bonds claimed by Mrs. Stanford as part of the estate of Leland Stanford comes out definitely in the inventory and appraisement of the great estate. Some months ago, when an inventory was prepared for the use of the appraleers, the following paragraph formed part of the sworn declaration of Mrs. Stanford:

NEWTOWN, L. I., Jan. 18 -- Twenty Deputy Sheriffs spent to-day trying to find the men responsible for the outbreak in Winfield against the Italian laborers employed in the construction of a water-supply system, by Contractor Thomas Kavanagh of Long Island City. The deputies succeeded in arresting Frank Kolesky, Thomas Dombrasky, and Joseph M. Tymann.

Mr. Isidor Straus of R.H. Macy Co. says that, so far as he can see, the outlook for business for the Spring is good. The volume of sales in their store for this month is slightly ahead of that of a year ago, and in advance of that in 1892, and this without any special effort being made to increase the business.
"The situation is more hopeful and the prospects of a revival of business are good."

Men hunting for bargains thronged the auction room at 111 Broadway yesterday. the reports or the sale of the West Seventy-third Street dwelling, which went almost by default the day before, started many of them thither. There was, however, little attractive property offered, and the ubiquitous plaintiff was the principal purchaser.

School Commissioner Wehrum, Who represents the Board of Education before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, had a little surprise in store for the members of the board yesterday. Just before adjournment he said that the Education Board had the Legislature's authority to build a new office, at a cost of $400,000.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 18 -- John C. Sheehan of New-York, Tammany Hall district leader, Police Commissioner, and contractor, was awarded a contract in this city to-day to construct a sewer on Broadway for $359,407,80. The contract was given to him by the General Improvement Commission, which recently awarded him a contract to build a sewer on Harris Avenue for $62,764.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Secretary Carlisle received quite a number of offers today for his new bonds. One offer was for $100,000 at $1.18.

There is no ball during the season that New-Yorkers look, forward to with more pleasurable anticipation or enjoy more heartily when it occurs than the Old Guard Ball. The veterans in their handsome uniforms of blue and white, with gold lace in profusion, sweep everything before them on their festival night, and New-York's fairest daughters put on their very prettiest gowns to do the old organization honor.

Mr. Sargent's dramatic pupils, who were so successful in illustrating the mystic symbolism of Maurice Maeterlinck through the medium of his play called "L'Intruse" last Winter, presented an English translation of another of the Belgian's strange dramatic works, "Les Aveugles," called in English "The Sightless," in their little theatre at Berkeley Lyceum last evening.

HALIFAX, Jan. 18 -- The crew of the Gloucester schooner, Maggie E. Wells, which the steamer Amsterdam reported as having spoken on Sunday last, and in trying to rescue the crew of which she lost her first officer and five, men by the upsetting of a lifeboat, were brought in here this morning by the Gloucester schooner, Magnolia, which took them off their sinking craft on Monday.

Eight thousand-dollars worth, of the bonds of the Mountain Home Land and Canal Company of Idaho were purchased last Tuesday from Henry E. Simmons, President of the company, by an aged and apparently respectable individual, who paid for them with checks which had been "raised" in a clever manner from very small to large amounts.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- An Anarchist named Rodrian issued a call a few days ago for the unemployed workingmen to hold a meeting at the Friedrichshain Brewery. The meeting was to be held to-day, but the police, having in mind the origin of the serious riots in 1892, determined to arrest Rodrian, thinking that if he was locked up the meeting would not be held.

A motion for the appointment of a receiver of the property of the Thomson-Houston Electric Company of New-York was made yesterday to Justice Barrett in the Supreme Court, Chambers, at the instance of Henry R. Worthington, (incorporated,) a judgment creditor of the company, for $1,576.53.

Henry Gottlieb, who was arrested Wednesday charged with having set fire to the tenement house at 185 Avenue C, was committed yesterday until Saturday by Justice Hogan in the Essex Market Police Court for further examination at the request of Fire Marshal Mitchel.

Joseph H. Choate appeared before Judge Shipman in the United States Circuit Court yesterday on behalf of the Niagara Cataract Construction Company, which is defendant in an action brought by Prof. Rowland of the Johns Hopkins University of Baltimore to recover $30,000 for six months' services in considering and devising plans for the construction of a dynamo of 5,000 horse power to transmit electrical motive power to Buffalo.

ROME, Jan. 18 -- The correspondent of the United Press returned to-day from Carrara and Massa di Carrara, where the state of siege as been proclaimed, owing to the attempts of Anarchists to start a revolution in the district. He found both towns somewhat more animated than usual, although trade had been resumed and public confidence seemed to have been restored.

The annual dinner of the Princeton University Alumni was given last night at the Hotel Brunswick, under the auspices of the Princeton Club. About 300 members of the society were present. The decorations were simple, but artistic in design. A majestic tiger looked complacently from a central niche, and from various panels floated the colors of Yale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- There was an absurd rumor afloat this morning that Mr. Cleveland intended to reverse the action of the Senate in the Hornblower case, If possible, and have Mr. Hornblower confirmed. The Administration Senators were said to be looking for a Senator who would be willing to change his vote and move for a reconsideration of the Hornblower case in the next executive session.

MADRID, Jan. 18 -- Affairs in the Cadiz District are in an alarming condition, owing to the great number of men out of employment. These men have been rendered desperate by hunger, and the pillaging of shops and farmhouses is of frequent occurrence. The Anarchists of Cadiz were formerly well supplied with money, but now their sources of supply have been, cut off by the suppression of the Anarchist associations.

All records were broken in the Kemp Trophy match last evening by Company B of the Seventh Regiment. It not only surpassed Company F's hitherto unbroken record of 1,062 by scoring 1,073 points, but it also created new figures at 500 yards by making 565 points at that distance. Company F also held the record at this distance with a score of 556 points.

Henry Telskan, thirty years old, who was a prisoner in the Tombs awaiting transfer to the penitentiary, committed suicide yesterday by taking oxalic acid. He was convicted in the Court of Special Sessions Wednesday of assault on Annie Hurley, five years old, of 731 Second Avenue, and was sentenced to four months' imprisonment in the penitentiary.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- The strong opening was due largely to the action of the Secretary of the Treasury. The tractions were very strong, Philadelphia opening at 93 1/2 and Metropolitan at 100 1/2. Neither was very active, and the latter declined to 100 at the close. Baltimore was quite active, selling up to 17%.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- More than 100 members of the New-England Tariff Reform League gathered at the United States Hotel tonight upon the occasion of a meeting of the league for the express purpose of urging the speedy passage of the Wilson bill and to show the sentiment of business men in its favor.

On the invitation of Mayor Schieren, President Howell and Chief Engineer C.C. Martin of the Brooklyn Bridge, Gen. James Jourdan and General Manager W.T. Goundie of the Kings County Elevated Railroad, and General Manager O.F. Nichols of the Brooklyn Union Elevated Railroad met at the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon.

The Excise Reform Association has prepared an excise bill, which will be introduced in the Legislature probably early next week. The act provides for the amendment of the excise law of 1892, and seeks to accomplish the following results:

Seth L. Keeney, President of the defunct Commercial Bank, and Bank Directors Robinson Gill and Elbert Snedeker were in the Adams street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. They are charged with misdemeanor in publishing false reports as to the condition of the bank and keeping the bank open and receiving deposits when the institution was insolvent.

The historic case of Fuchs against Morris was concluded last evening before Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court. At 6:30 the weighty facts concerning the wonderful orchestrion of the Morris Park Clubhouse were given to the consideration, of the jury, and to-day a sealed verdict will be handed in.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Of all the ceremonious dinners given at the White House during the season, that to the Diplomatic Corps is always the most picturesque, and from season to season changes in the Diplomatic Corps have contributed new features of interest. The most interesting feature of the dinner to-night was the presence at the table of the wife of the Chinese Minister.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 18 -- The first person to begin suit against the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company for injuries received in the accident at the Weehawken Bridge on Monday, is Carl Lander, of 35 West Street, this city.

A number or police officials in Brooklyn are looking with longing eyes on the office of Superintendent of Police. They are secretly grieving because Patrick Campbell, the gray-haired Superintendent, does not retire.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- The steamer China arrived at 8:30 o'clock this morning from Hongkong and Yokohama. By the China it is learned that notwithstanding the recent additions to war junks cruising after the pirates along the coast, the pirates of Fukien and Taichow are still as numerous and as savage as ever.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- The Problem which confronts the Quartermaster's Department in regard to hauling the huge monolith shaft from the West Shore station to Trophy Point is becoming interesting.
