The capstone, which weighs twelve tons, rests on the iron stone boats near the library. It will remain there until sufficient snow falls to make the hauling across the Plains easy.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)
Otto Casper is in the prison ward of Bellevue Hospital and he may die of a bullet wound in the chest. He was shot by Policeman Henry Gardner of the Thirteenth Precinct.

Business men generally look first to the iron trade for indications of the revival of business. Ordinarily this is the best sort of a barometer of the business of the country. But 1894 may be an exception to e rule, and there are good reasons why it should be.

It is the custom of fur manufacturers to discharge their workmen the 1st of January, after a sufficient stock of fur garments has been made up to supply the season's trade. In ordinary times these men obtain work in other branches at reduced wages till they are again required by the manufacturers. The workmen of C.C. Shayne were unable to find work this year when they left his employ.

Mrs. Jennie Langer was a complainant in the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning against her husband, Leon Langer. She charged him with having stolen from her safe, during her absence, diamonds and money amounting to $18,000.

The bachelors' ball which, took place at the Waldorf last night will occupy a lasting and notable place in the annals of the social functions of this city. Prom the standpoint of excluslveness alone the ball deserves to rank among the smartest of the smart affairs of the season. The dance was full of vivacity.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Jan. 18 -- The through express on the Kansas City, St. Joseph and Council Bluffs Railway was stopped by train robbers this morning at 12:20 at Roy's Landing, one mile north of this city, in the same place that the Kohler gang met their Waterloo last September. Just as the train approached the landing a man appeared on the tracks and signaled the train to stop.

George S. Baxter, Treasurer; George H. Earl, Secretary, and J.A. Barker, General Auditor, of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, have resigned their respective paces because the receivers refuse to pay them salaries for doing the work of the present management. President Ives has caused an application to be made to the courts for an order directing that the salaries of the officers named shall be paid.

Comedian William H. Crane ran up to the city the other forenoon to transact some private business, and, before returning to Baltimore, where he was playing, he dropped into the Lambs' Club. In the parlor were a half dozen actors, who were telling stories about the bad business on the road, and some of them would greatly surprise the general public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Populist Senators have lost no time in producing a resolution denouncing the proposed issue of bonds. Mr. Peffer introduced a long one this morning declaring it to be illegal for Secretary Carlisle to carry out his announced intention. He was followed by Mr. Alien of Nebraska, who offered a resolution of similar import.

A dispatch from Vera Cruz, Mexico, was received this morning at the office of the Ward Line of steamers, in Wall Street, saying that none of the passengers on the Seguranca, at that port, was affected by the attack of smallpox.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- American Bell Telephone was again the most active stock on the local Hat, with the exception, perhaps, of Boston and Montana Mining. It opened at 179, sold up to 180 for a small lot, and then declined to 175 1/2, 1/2 below yesterday's lowest. Some attributed the decline to the rumor that a new telephone company, with unlimited backing.

The bond proposition of Secretary Carlisle met with universal approval yesterday in the down-town district. No one had the slightest doubt that the proposed issue would be subscribed several times over. One firm alone had prepared to subscribe for a much larger issue of bonds, and had organized a syndicate to purchase them.

R.T. Wilson Co., the well-known bankers, have submitted to the Rapid-Transit Commission a formal proposition for the construction of an underground system of rapid-transit railroads, substantially on the routes laid down by the commission two years ago, including a west-side line to Fort George and an east-side line to Harlem, with possible future extensions.

John Y. McKane's exhibition of his lightning system of voting the denizens of the Coney Island "Bowery" has been postponed until Monday. It was to have been given, this rooming in the Town Hall of Gravesend, but the members of the Senate committee that is investigating the election wish to attend the funeral of ex-State Senator Erwin, at Potsdam to-day.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 18 -- The dead-lock in the special session of the Legislature was clearly defined to-day when the Senate refused to consider the first bill submitted from the House and adjourned until to-morrow afternoon.

All signs point toward prosperity at the banks, the exchanges, and the financial houses. Even in railroad and industrial stocks, whose chronic condition has become dull, and which had been unrelieved, by distinctly favorable news, prices are well maintained. Reports of decreased railroad earnings furnish the strongest kind of bear arguments at the Stock Exchange.

The recent statement of the Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee is of a nature to reassure the country, but it is not one that a responsible legislator in a place of such importance as that of Mr. Voorhees can be forced to make without some sense of mortification.

The committee of holders of the bonds of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad has organized by the election as Chairman of Edward King, President of the Union Trust Company. C.C. Rawlins was chosen Secretary. The St. Louis and San Francisco bondholders elected Gen. Louis Fitzgerald as Chairman.

The fortunate persons who attended the ladies' reception, given by the Authors' Club at the Hotel Waldorf last evening received an exquisite impression. They asked themselves what wealth, what ephemeral possession is equivalent to the quantity of genius expended in New-York every moment.

The election of a Republican Legislature seems to give opportunity for many projects of municipal reform, of which some are highly fantastic. The people of the city must work out their own political salvation. All that the Legislature can do is to put the people of the city in more complete control of their own affairs.

Connecticut, which, with the exception of its insurance and banking interests at Hartford, the capital city, is essentially a manufacturing' State, is a specially good barometer in the East. It has woolen, cotton, and silk mills, is the great centre for the production of brass and German silver, and the largest producer of clocks, plated ware, builders' hardware, and rubber goods of any State in the Union.

Two of Tammany's most important committees organized last night for 1894. They were the Committee on Organization, which is an offspring of the General Committee, and the Executive Committee, which is nominally an offspring of the Committee on Organization, but which is really the master of the whole organization.

Fire Marshal Mitchel's belief that there is an organized body of incendiaries at work on the east side seems to be well founded. He had reason to believe yesterday that certain insurance agents or brokers were implicated in a plot to defraud companies placing risks upon furniture and household effects.

LEBANON, Mo., Jan. 19 -- Wilson Howard was hanged in the jailyard here this morning. The scaffold was erected just outside the jail building, and the execution was witnessed by only a score of people.

A City Marshal, around whom was an excited crowd, succeeded in breaking into the "Pontiac Bank," at Ninety-first Streot and Amsterdam Avenue, about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He had a replevin for the Remington typewriter machine and oak desk, which had been furnished the "bank" on credit. The articles were valued at $150.

Mrs. Anna Keller, a handsome woman whose type of beauty resembles that found in the far Blast, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday, charged with violating the customs laws in disposing of dutiable goods in bond.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19. -- The American Iron and Steel Association has received from the manufacturers complete returns of the production of pig iron in the United States in 1893, and also complete returns of the stocks of unsold pig iron in the hands of makers or their agents at the close of the year.

Grain men at the Produce Exchange were less annoyed than amused yesterday over a report from Chicago explaining recent light exports on the ground that English and Continental buyers despaired of getting wheat in good condition from New-York. Shippers from here, according to this report, had spoiled the trade by working off undesirable wheat on foreign buyers.
Ex-Assemblyman Adrian M. Suydam of Brooklyn died yesterday in Passadena, Cal.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Mrs. Ada J. Palmer, who has been connected with, the Woman's Bakery Company, was arrested, to-day on complaint of the Secretary, Miss Mary Sanderson, on the charge of embezzlement of a check for $26 sent by a dry goods house to the bakery company. Mrs. Palmer was too ill to be taken from her home, and a policeman is stationed there until she recovers.

There seems to be no doubt now that heretofore the public has not been wholly pleased with the parts in which Mme. Melba appeared. Nedda in "Pagliacci" was out of her line, and for "Lucia" the music lovers of this city have no great fondness. After having been heard in these, the prima donna was taken with the grip, and it was only after several disappointments that she finally appeared in "Semiramide."

Justice Barrett of the Supreme Court yesterday instructed Edward S. Stokes, who was appointed receiver of the Hoffman House in a suit by the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company to foreclose a $50,000 mortgage, to retain the books of the Hoffman House within this jurisdiction. This will somewhat disconcert the New-Jersey courts and litigators, for Mr. Stokes had been ordered to produce the books there.

An important traffic alliance has been arranged between the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company and the Wilkesbarre and Eastern Railroad. The last-named road extends from Wilkesbarre to Stroudsburg, where it forms a connection with the Susquehanna and Western system.

The faculty Richard Jefferies had was for expressing in vividly descriptive phrases impressions of a mind delicately sensitive to the beauties of nature. But his merits have made overenthusiastic about his work a class of English critics who apparently are perpetually sighing for new objects of exalted praise.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Philip D. Armour said to-night that there is nothing in the story of his having purchased a large tract of land on the Hackensack River.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Justice Herrick has appointed Henry S. McCall temporary receiver of the George Treadwell Company on the application of Steadman, Thompson Andrews. This corporation was formed a few years ago with a capital of $1,000,000. About $638,000 was issued, part preferred and part common stock.
The following plans for new buildings and alterations were filed with the Building Department from noon yesterday until noon to-day:

Nearly 200 graduates of Yale University who are members of the Yale Alumni Association of New-York gathered in the large dining hall at Sherry's last evening to pay their annual tribute to their Alma Mater in feast and song.

John I. Davenport, Chief Supervisor of Elections, has temporary headquarters in Room 77 on the third floor of the Federal Building, and yesterday he was swearing in Supervisors of Elections for the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congressional Districts.

-- The State Railroad Commissioners have handed down a decision refusing to grant a certificate to Mr. Depew, Mr. Rossiter, and other New-York Central people for the construction of a railroad from the Harlem station in White Plains to the new Bloomingdale Asylum, on the grounds that public necessity and convenience do not demand It.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 19 -- The conference between the hat manufacturers and the committees of the Hat Makers' and Hat Finishers' Union, which had power to settle the labor troubles here for the major portion of the trade, came to an abrupt end at midnight last night, and all hopes of a settlement are now abandoned.

VIENNA, Jan. 19 -- M. Nicolaievitch has failed to organize a working Cabinet for Servia. Although he secured the full complement of Ministers, he was unable to unite them on a programme. It is probable that the crisis in Belgrade is about to culminate. The question is whether it will affect the Ministry only or the whole system.

G.P. Putnam's Sons publish "The Religion of a Literary Man," being the profession of faith of Richard Le Gallienne, who is a literary man unmistakably, if he be nothing more. He discusses sin, pain, free will, the hereafter, essential Christianity, dogma and symbolism, and the religious senses in the mood and with the graceful intonation of a delicate man of letters.

Eecretary Milbury of the Christian Industrial Alliance has been perfecting a plan by which very poor families can obtain groceries at cost price without in any way interfering with the trade of small grocers. Such a store has been opened at 57 Avenue C. and here families can buy tea, sugar, oatmeal, coffee, and other provisions at cost price.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The House declined to-day to follow the lead of Tom L. Johnson and adopt his proposed amendment to the Tariff bill, transferring steel rails from the dutiable to the free list. In the debate preceding the vote, however, there were many utterances showing that the Democrats regard the Wilson bill as less radical than it should be.

Ex-State Senator Daniel H. McMillan of Buffalo has been staying since Wednesday at the Hoffman House. Among the gentlemen he visited while in town was Dr. Chauncey M. Depew, and rumor had it that the visit was in some way connected with Thomas C. Platt's efforts to hold in the air the bills to repeal the vicious Police bill of Buffalo which Lieut. Gov. Sheehan put through last year's Legislature.
Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. ROME, Jan. 19 -- Dispatches received from all parts of the country state that order prevails everywhere.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. HONOLULU, H.I., Jan. 12, via San Francisco, Cal., Jan. 19, per Steamer Monowai -- There is no important change in public affairs on the island since the advices carried by the Australia. Strong remonstrance s have been addressed to Minister Willis by President Dole in regard to his "menacing attitude toward the provisional Government."

A distribution of the estate of Alfred S. Barnes. the millionaire publisher, was ordered by Justice Beach of the Supreme Court yesterday in a final judgment after an accounting. There was a protracted litigation over this estate. An accounting, which has been held to be correct, shows the estate to have amounted to $2,825,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Mr. Bailey's resolution relating to the issue of bonds by the Secretary of the Treasury was discussed by the House Committee on Judiciary to-day for half an hour or more, but no conclusion was reached. The resolution reads:

Joseph Sweeney, twenty-two years old, of 515 West Thirty-second Street, was arrested last night for keeping a policy shop, and after a short stay in the West Thirtieth Street Police Station, he was balled out by "AI" Adams, who is said to be his employer.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 19 -- The eighty-eight inmates of the Queens County Insane Asylum here were removed to the State Asylum at Poughkeepsie to-day. There were forty-five women and forty-three men in the party. They were guarded by twenty male and ten female nurses. A special train on the Long Island Railroad took them to Long Island City, and they were conveyed from there to the Grand Central Station in stages.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Collector Kilbreth of New-York came to Washington this evening and registered at the Arlington. He said to a correspondent of The New-York Times that the object of his visit was to confer with Secretary Carlisle concerning the recent decision of the United States Circuit Court relating to the payment of duties on imports with certified checks.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 19. -- The string which the Duval Athletic Club has tied to the $20,000 for which Corbett and Mitchell are to fight, provided the club sees the way clear to getting its money back from admissions and the Governor of Florida can be kept in the dark, was the principal topic in sporting circles to-day.

The statistics of immigrants arriving at this port during the year 1893, as compiled by Commissioner Senner, have some interesting features. The total number was 352,885, and the nationality most largely represented was the Italian, with 69,074, and the next German, with 55,981 arrivals.

The Harlem Democratic Club about three years ago placed, for sale upon the real estate market the clubhouse and three lots it occupies at 21 and 23 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. The price asked for the property was $150,000, but no buyers responded. Recently the club has shown an anxiety to sell, and the price has been reduced to $125.000.

NEW-YORK. Friday, Jan. 19 -- P.M. There was some weakness at the openng this morning, but it did not last long, and before noon the upward tendency was dearly marked. In the afternoon there was a fair amount of activity, and the closing prices were the best of the day.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Charles E. Mincher, one of the victims of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad collision Monday, died this morning in St. Mary's Hospital. He was surrounded by his wife and other relatives when he breathed his last. Shortly before his death he listened to a communication sent him by a friend about his own affairs.

Mr. George R. Read has bought for the Constable estate from Robert and Ogden Goelet the property at 7 East Eighteenth Street, north side, between Fifth Avenue and Broadway, 25 by 92, for about $120,000. The purchasers intend to add it to their new twelve-story fire-proof building now in course of erection at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, which it adjoins.

Chairman Howard E. Raymond of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen yesterday made public the proposed changes that are to be made to the racing rules, and the much-talked-of rules, A and B. The two new rules that will be proposed by Chairman Raymond at the National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen, which meets at Louisville, Feb. 19, 20, and 21, are as follows:

John E. Wilson, at one time one of the most prominent men in Harlem, died in the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Police Station yesterday afternoon. He became suddenly ill On One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, near Lexington Avenue, and sank to the sidewalk. He was taken to the station house, where he requested that Dr. Charles A. Clinton of West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street be sent for.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A loss of $750,00 in since yesterday is shown in the Treasury gold to-day, the figures being $69,077,847. The currency balance is stated at $21,600,937, less $7,119,934 paid on account of interest and bonds.

WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Jan. 19 -- Miss Helen Gorsline, a member of the household of C.W. Hunt, a prominent manufacturer living her, had an exciting encounter with a burglar last night. Mr. Hunt's home is a large house located in a thickly populated portion of the village. Miss Gorsline, her mother, and a female servant were the only occupants of the house last night.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 19 -- It has been determined that the Brazilian war ships shall concentrate at Bahia. The cruiser Itapu, which is now in this port, has orders to proceed at once to Bahia, and it is understood that she will Join company there with the Nictheroy and Tiradentes.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 19 -- Ex-Gov. Cornell delivered the fifteenth lecture in the Butterfield practical course at the Union College chapel to-day before the students and Faculty. He was introduced by R.C. Alexander of the Board of Trustees. His subject was: "The Electro-Magnetic Telegraph," the evolution of which he traced from Franklin's earliest and rude experiments through Henry's electro-magnet to the practical establishment of the telegraph by Morse.

Joshua Page promises to make things exceedingly lively for Gen. Isaac S. Catlin of Brooklyn when his suit, mention of which was made recently, comes up for trial in the Supreme Court in New-York City.
The following dispatch was published in the newspapers on the last day of the old year:

That is a very delightful row that is reported from Washington to be raging in the Senate of the United States. It appears that certain Senators have been outraged by the design of a medal for prize winners at the recent Columbian Exposition. No doubt there is ample opportunity for a row in connection with the awards for the Columbian Exposition.

The information as to the prospect of a revival of business which we were able to lay before our readers yesterday morning seems to us, on the whole, to be encouraging. So far as our readers found it so we think, that they may have confidence in their impression, for the information was gathered with care, and was in every instance reported in a conservative spirit.

George P. Maurer, a German, thirty-five years old, was arrested Thursday night by Detectives Lang and Taylor of the Fourteenth Precinct. He is accused of extorting money by representing himself as a Parkhurst agent. The complainants in the case are Eugene and Isaac Frankel, who keep a restaurant at 112 East Eleventh Street.

From The Baltimore American, Jan. 17. Four weeks ago Mrs. Lucy Carnegie of Pittsburg lost a diamond, which was valued beyond price because of its associations. The diamond is worth between $4,000 and $5,000. It descended to Mrs. Carnegie from her mother, and was priceless in her eyes. The loss of the gem, therefore, caused Mrs. Carnegie great distress, but intelligence was received yesterday that the diamond had teen recovered in Jacksonville, Fla.

The members of the Political Science Club passed several enjoyable hours last evening at the Hotel Savoy, where, after a pleasant dinner, they discussed the question. "Is Further Annexation of Territory by the United States Desirable ?"

The great religious revival in Brooklyn interests all classes of the community. The scenes at the various churches combined in the Union for Evangelical Work, the crowds flocking into these places, and the religious enthusiasm which possesses the thousands of men and women, young and old, who are participants in the revival recall the days of the great preacher Whitefield and John Wesley, the apostle of Methodism.

At the first meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission, for the year, yesterday, Mayor Gilroy was elected Chairman and Richard A. Storrs Secretary. The question of improving the East River front from Forty-fifth to Fifty-third Street, and from Fifty-ninth to Sixty-fourth Street, will be considered in a public meeting on Feb. 6.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- The report of Superintendent Lathrop of the Department of State Prisons shows that at the end of the last fiscal year the number of convicts in the three State prisons was 3,491, being 104 less than the year previous. The average cost of maintenance was $137.04 for each convict.

From The Boston Herald. According to the figures of the city's Board of Assessors, Boston's resources, as derived from its taxes at the rate of $12.80 per $1,000 upon the assessed value for 1893, including polls, which amounted to $279,406, were $11,673,373.90. Of this, $964,336.90 went for State, $808,377 for county, and $9,900,660 for city purposes.
Mrs. Lyman Abbott, in speaking of the evil of indiscriminate almsgiving, gives evidence of the unfitness of the present Excise Commissioners of Brooklyn for the offices they fill.

Dr. H.J. Knapp, B.L. Baylis, W.B. Palmer, and seven others connected with the staff of the Eastern District Homeopathic Hospital in South Third Street, Williamsburg, resigned yesterday from that institution because of a quarrel with the Trustees of nearly two years standing.

The fourth annual dinner of the Confederate Veterans' Camp was held in Scottish Rite Hall last night, and the spacious building was filled with old soldiers and their guests. It was the anniversary of the birth of Gen. R.E. Lee.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO JANEIRO, Jan. 19 -- It is generally understood here that Rear Admiral Benham, commander of the United States fleet in the harbor, came to Rio on a mission of arbitration.

The shooting for the King trophy was con tlnued at the Seventh Regiment Armory las night. Company A going to the targets. Th shooting was good, but the total only placed th team third in the competition. Company B lead ing, with a score of 1,073, and Company G sec ond, with 1,042.

The feature of the closing testimony, in Brooklyn yesterday, before the Assembly sub-committee in the contested election case of William H. Friday against James Graham was the fact brought out during the testimony of Joseph Goodfellow, a Republican of Gravesend, that he would have worked for the election of Mr. Friday, the Republican candidate, had he not been restrained by fear of Jolin Y. McKane-- or, in Goodfellow's own words, if he "had dared."

Lawyers Goff and Ordway were in conference yesterday with Assistant District Attorney Wellman regarding the electionfraud cases. They went over the charges in detail, it was said, and, according to Mr. Wellman, Attorney Goff finally withdrew, declaring that he would have nothing to do with the prosecution.

Corean Sword Dance. An interesting figure was the sword dance, performed by four girls, dressed in crimson and yellow silk, with feathered head-dresses, to represent soldiers. Eight swords were laid on the ground in a circle. The girls began, as usual, to sway about; then, as the music quickened, they picked up their swords, one in each hand, and began waving them round their heads.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 19. -- If the officers of the Duval Club expect to pull off their fight in Georgia they will find determined opposition from Gov. Northen. The Governor does not propose to be outdone by Gov. Mitchell in upholding the moral tone of the State, and, while he will not talk, it is known that he is in active communication with the Sheriffs of all border counties.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Property owners in Harrison and Kearney are talking about a big real estate deal made Monday in Hudson County. Armour Co. of Chicago and Kansas City, it is alleged, purchased 3,000 acres of land on the Hackensack meadows from the S.N. Pike estate.

Though the efforts of Mr. Tom Johnson of Ohio to secure radical amendments to the Wilson Tariff bill cannot be considered entirely loyal to the Democratic Party, they are not without their utility. They serve to bring out very clearly the real purpose of the committee to carry out the reform of the tariff with the least injury to existing industries.

A large number of prominent residents of Madison Avenue have united in a protest against a bill which has been introduced in the State Senate intended to restrict traffic in Fifth Avenue and close it as a thoroughfare for all vehicles transporting merchandise from Twenty-fifth to Fifty-ninth Street, between the hours of 2 and 7 P.M. every day between Oct. 1 and June 1.

President James J. Martin of the Board of Police seems determined to lock horns with Superintendent Byrnes. He never lets an opportunity slip to show his hostility to the executive head of the police force. But it is seldom that he shows his teeth so publicly as he did at the regular meeting of the board yesterday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- State Controller Roberts to-day received from the State Civil Service Commission the following list of persons reported to the commission as having been appointed to positions in the State service, but who do not appear upon the civil service records as having teen appointed in accordance with the provisions of the civil service rules:

BALTIMORE, Jan. 19 -- Not since the foundation of the Maryland Confederate Society has there been such a notable gathering at its annual banquet as was present at the Carrollton Hotel last night, when the eighty-seventh anniversary of the birth of Gen. Robert E. Lee was celebrated. The occasion was one of great historic interest to all living participants in the civil war.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 19 -- The Montgomery is queen of Uncle Sam's twothousand-tonners. On her trial trip here to-day she proved herself speedier than the Detroit or Marblehead, and capable of doing nearly two knots more than her contract calls for.
The twentieth annual ball of the Nonpareil Rowing Club was held in the Central Opera House Thursday night. The ball was a big success, and the club will add a good sum to its treasury.

Early stragglers along Park Row were much interested yesterday morning in the rescue of two horses from the condult of the Third Avenue cable railroad. At Baxter Street and Park Row there is a trench 10 feet long, 3 feet wide, and 4 feet deep. It is covered with heavy iron plates. Into the trench great quantities of muddy water are drained from the condult.

Policeman Henry Smith of the steamboat squad, this city, was a prisoner in the Butler Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday. With him were arraigned Henry Clark, a stevedore, of 68 Catherine Street, and Carrie Wilson, a young woman who gave her home as Rockaway.
NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Jan. 19 -- The Assembly committee taking evidence in the Richmond County contested election case continued the hearing to-day, and will sit again Wednesday.

The Board of Directors of the Musical Mutual Protective Union acted yesterday upon the charges against Walter Damrosch of violating the laws of the union in allowing Suton Hegner to play with his orchestra on Nov. 11 and Dec. 16. Mr. Damrosch and his orchestra were present. Mr. Damrosch was found guilty of the first charge and fined $10.
Charles Lanier, Treasurer of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, 17 Nassau Street, reports the following additional contributions to the general fund of the collection:

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Dr. Brouardel, who was recently appointed to make an official report as to the condition of the health of the children of Princess Colonna, submitted his findings to the court a few days ago, and to-day the Judge, sitting in chambers, made an order authorizing the Princess Colonna to take the children to Mentone, where she will be allowed to remain with them until April 15.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- A number of important changes have been made in naval commands and on naval stations.

The Committee of One Hundred is doing active work toward the reorganization of the Democratic Party in Brooklyn. The Congressional Committee appointed at the last meeting is preparing the work to be carried out in the various wards.

The unusual Increase in the number of cases of measles reported in this city during the past few weeks has induced the health authorities to take stringent measures to prevent, if possible, a further spread of the disease. It has been greatly on the increase since the cold weather set in. During the week ending Jan. 6 there were 392 cases reported.

Politicians alone seem to be interested in the plan for displacing the present Police Commission of this city with a new bi-partisan "board," to consist of four Commissioners appointed by the Mayor, and nobody imagines that they are animated by any but political motives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Attention has already been called in these dispatches to the New-York State nominations which remain unacted upon by the Senate. Mr. Hill informed the Senate last Monday, in the course of this speech in opposition to Mr. Hornblower, that he and his colleague had, at all times, since they entered upon their Senatorial careers, been careful not to antagonize the Administration.

Assistant District Attorney O'Hare received a very indignant protest yesterday from a juror who was acting in an assault case in General Sessions, Part III., last Thursday. Tobias Cassel was on trial, charged with stabbing Sylvester Gainer at Thirty-second Street and Eighth Avenue, on the night of Dec. 3, 1893.

The Rev. Dr. A.B. Leonard, Secretary of the Board of Managers of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church, has just returned from an extended official visit to China. He was in that country when the Swedish Consul General effected a settlement with the Chinese Government for the brutal murder of two Swedish missionaries by a mob last Spring.
From the Boston Herald. There are 1,981 taxpayers in this city paying $1,000 or more apiece, and 48,545 who pay less than that amount.

An additional complaint of extortion by policemen was brought to the notice of the Police Commissioners at their meeting yesterday. It same from Mr. J. Collins Pumpelly, Secretary of the City Improvement Society, in the shape of the following communication:

John L. Stoddard is soon to resume his illustrated Lenten matinees at Daly's Theatre. He resolved after the season of 1892 to give up an entire year to travel in lands more distant than he had before seen. Crossing our continent and embarking at Vancouver, B.C., he found himself, after a stormy fortnight on the Pacific, in the Harbor of Yokohama.

Birth is taxed, marriage is taxed, death is taxed. Commodities are taxed, manufactures are taxed, trades are taxed, houses are taxed, incomes are taxed. We are taxed for our butler, if we are prosperous enough to keep one. We are taxed for our footman, groom, or gardener. The carriage we keep is taxed, the omnibus we take is taxed, the cab we hire is taxed, the railway train we travel by is taxed.

The long light shakes Across the lakes. or, more strictly speaking, the long light shakes across the lagoons of the World's Fair in the pictures of scenes at the Chicago Exposition which are contained in "Glimpses of the Fair; or, Gems of the White City," that perfect little volume of views about which so much has been said.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn has decided to reduce the dangerous speed at which trolley cars are run. Yesterday he had a conference with police Commissioner Hayden as to the best way to check the speed of the cars.

The sentimentalist idea or a nurse's occupation as consisting mainly in the gentle smoothing of pillows is now generally disabused. The work of nursing proper demands muscle, pluck, endurance, deftness, and sympathy, but does not in itself involve any serious strain to healthy and capable women.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 20. -- The Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton, recently of the West Presbyterian Church, New-York City, made his appearance this morning at the office of the United Press. During the past few weeks Dr. Paxton has been under the immediate treatment of T.M.T. McKennan, M.D., at the St. Frances Hospital, on Forty-fourth Street, near Pennsylvania Avenue.

The Harlem Wheelmen held their eighth annual ball at the Lenox Lyceum on Friday night. All the previous dances of tills flourishing wheeling organization bare taken place in Harlem, but Judging by the appearance of the ballroom daring the dancing. they have cause for congratulation in making a move further down town. More than 300 couples danced through the lone programme.

There was no one in the seaport town of Plaiceville more subject to good-natured envy than Reuben Noble. Had he been less young, handsome, and generous than he was this sentiment would still have existed against him, though without its kindliness, for he was wealthy and his own master. The riches of a score of Nobles, directly and collateratively related, had concentrated to cheer his orphanage.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20. -- Mrs. Leland Stanford is reported to be too ill to attend to business. Through her private secretary, Mr. Nash, the impression was given that she will commence suit against C.P. Huntington for the securities which it is alleged he is withholding. Mr. Nash, in reply to a question, said that suit would not be brought at present.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 20. -- "It is an axiomatic saying," said Patrick Donan today to a correspondent for The New-York Times, "that even fools learn by experience; but the fellows who masquerade as Democratic statesmen at Washington constitute a more or less notable exception to the truth of the rule.

NYACK, Jan. 20. -- Some Damocrats, as well as some Republications hereabout, are interested in the fate of certain resolutions introduced in the Senate by Senator Lexow. The resolutions called for an investigation in the various counties of conditions due as much, so many persons believe, to rascalities of legally-constituted State commissions and office holders as to the general hard times.

Saturday is generally a prosperous day for the Irving Place Theatre, perhaps because Germans keep to a European tradition of ending a week of labor with an evening of fun. Fun the audience got last night as they listened to G. von Moser's light comedy, "Der Veilchenfresser."

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- Lord Salisbury will come to town on Monday to consult with his colleagues in the last Conservative Cabinet prior to the conference of Conservative peers to be conevned next Friday. Only once since he became leader in the House of Lords has Lord Salisbury held a similar meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The World's Fair medal, designed by St. Gaudens, which represented on one side a nude male figure, and against which protests were made, on the ground of indelicacy, will be modified by draping the figure. This change Secretary Carlisle has directed to be made to observe the proprieties.

A decided improvement in railway traffic is indicated by the reports of earnings for the second week of this month. With scarcely an exception, the roads make a better showing than they did in the previous week, and both gross and net earnings for the first week in January were in excess of the earnings reported for the last week in December.

HALIFAX, N.S., Jan. 20. -- Capt. Davison of the lost schooner Maggie E. Wells of Gloucester. Mass., accuses the Captain of the steamer Amsterdam of deserting him and his crew. As the steamer drew away from them, Capt. Davison says, she dipped her flags three times in farewell, meaning: "Storm too heavy; can't stay; will report," and gradualy disappeared westward.

From The Washington Star. An army officer's outfit is expensive. The army outfit costs at the very lowest $189. Very few officers would be satisfied with a one-hundred-and-eighty-dollar outfit. It is made of cheap cloth, poorly finished. It is "regulation" and the commanding officer would have to pass it.
The New-York Tax Reform Association and the Reform Club have lately been making strenuous efforts in their respective causes.

"Poor Girls," the second melodrama presented by T. Henry French at the American Theatre, will be produced to-morrow evening with a specially selected cast. The play is attributed to the late French author, Guy de Maupassant, and in the adaptation the original has been closely followed in all particulars, except that the scene has been changed to a factory town near Boston.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Secretary Herbert to-day received from Rear Admiral Irwin, the following letters:

In his attempt to secure his election to Congress, and incidentally "smash the Wilson bill," Lemuel Ely Quigg is making his canvass in the Fourteenth District not only among the voters, but among their wives mothers, and sweethearts.

ORANGE, Mass., Jan. 20. -- Trial Justice Edward Bicknell of Orange was arrested today, charged with the embezzlement of $160. He pleaded not guilty, and a hearing was fixed for next Saturday. Bail was fixed at $1,000. An endeavor to find bondsmen was unsuccessful.

Thursday, Jan. 25. -- By Richard V. Harnett Co., foreclosure sale, Lorenzo Semple, referee, the Hotel Logerot property, 124, 126, and 128 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Eighteenth Street, 92 by 175 feet, with four-story and basement brownstone-front houses and extensions and Iron and glass banquet hall in rear. Due on judgment, $66,760; on prior mortgage, $350,000, at 4 per cent. which may remain.

The association football team of the steamship Majestic, which plays with some of the strongest teams in England, expected to have an easy victory over the Staten Island Athletic Club yesterday at West New-Brighton. The home players surprised them, however, by the game they put up, and they succeeded in quitting even by scoring 2 goals each.

Mr. Sanderson announces in his preface that he has written for general readers as well as for young students, but it is probable that his history will be used principally as a text book in schools and colleges. It is clear that a history of England covering the period from the invasion of Caesar down to 1890, and condensed into an octavo of about 1,100 pages, must be confined to outlines.

The Assembly Sub-Committee on Privileges and Elections, of which Philip Keck is Chairman, met yesterday, in the City Hall, Brooklyn, and took up the contest of George R. Pasfield. Republican, of the election of William E. Melody, member from the Ninth Assembly District.

Woolen materials are always more porous than linen fabrics, and it is mainly owing to this fact that the one is warmer than the other. Air, in common with gaseous bodies in general, is an extremely bad conductor of heat; but this property cannot be easily demonstrated owing to the extreme mobility of particles of air.

The rush to the pawnbrokers is always an infallible sign of hard times, but it is seldom that they find themselves so hampered with the amount of goods on hand as to be obliged to refuse to loan even the smallest pittance on the household goods and chattels of those who are trying to keep the wolf from the door by this last sad resort.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Official news of the defeat of the Honduras forces by Gen. Bonilla was received at the Navy Department to-day from Commander Longnecker, commanding the United States steamship Ranger, at La Union, Salvador. Commander Longnecker's dispatch is dated at La Union to-day, and reads as follows:

This Greek Madonna is not of flesh, but is rather a mystical figure. She symbolizes something quite beyond the comprehension of the least exacting of rationalists. She is an Idea, blending "the reflective depth of Grecian culture with the divine childlikeness and tender love of the Mother of Jesus."

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- There was an irregular opening to wheat to-day, and it was not altogether free from excitement, but matters soon quieted down and business dragged along in a narrow rut to the close. Opening trades were at from 64 3/8@64 3/4c for May, the market thereafter holding steady to firm and closing with a net gain of 1/8@1/4c for the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Inscribed on the register of the Arllington to-night are the names of J. Pierpont Morgan. Chauncey M. Depew, George E. Pollock, Philip Schuyler, Joseph H. Choate, F.K. Sturgis, Charles Lamier, Ronert Bacon, and B.S. Eggleston of New-York. These gentlemen reached Washington at 8 o'clock to-night on a special car.

Mayor Schieren's Excise Commissioners have held a conference with the representatives of the brewers of Brooklyn concerning the excise policy. These representatives wanted to know what the policy of the Mayor's administration was to be concerning the excise question, and also as to whether they proposed to oppose the transfer of liecuses. Mr. Welles was rather non-committal but made a general statement that disreputable saloons and concert halls would have to be closed.

In a locality where sailormen congregate can generally be found the result of an effort on the part of some philanthropist or well-meaning society to ameliorate the condition of Jack during his sojournings ashore. These usually take the shape of a free reading room, and a number of such establishments can be found in those streets which sailors frequent.

The fact is that during the twenties and thirties, the years of Hook's fame and fortune, the country was very badly off for novelists, and especially for novelists of modern and contemporary life. Nearly all Scott's best were written, and Miss Austen had ceased to write when Hook began; Dickens had but just appeared, and Bulwer not long, when Hook died.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- There were two interruptions of the tariff discussion to-day the reception of the veto message on the Hudson River Bridge bill and the latest batch of Hawaiian correspondence. But interest in these two matters did not so divert the majority that they forgot their business.

Maurice Patrick MacMahon was not sent to school young, but had private tuition at home. He was then placed at a seminary taught by priests at Autun, from which he was removed to a coaching establishment for the military school of St. Cyr, at Versailles. His two elder brothers were already officers in Hussar regiments.

When and where Miss Lillian Russell and Perugini, the tenor, are to wed is kept a secret. It had been generally supposed that the wedding would be to-day, and in New-Jersey, in case Miss Russell did not procure the consent of a Justice of the Supreme Court to have it celebrated here.

The paper read by Laird Clowes before the Naval Institute in London proves anew how purely theoretical and tentative has been the naval construction of the past generation. One of the few points upon which the constructors of battle ships seem to have been agreed has been the efficiency of the ram.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Imagine the despair that fell on me yesterday as I glanced over my clippings to find that The New-York World was publishing the statement that " Clara Barton had reported that the needs of the Southern sufferers had been met." My hands were at that moment crowded with poor, pitiful appeals for clothing, warm clothing, and bedding to help fight away pneumonia, rheumatism, and consumption.
Fire Commissioner John Ennis may have to make an explanation to the legal representatives of Brooklyn concerning his methods of civil service examinations and promotions of firemen.

Prom the London Dally News. Mr. John S. Sargent is at last an Associate of the Royal Academy. He is one of three Associates recently elected, the other two being Mr. Frank Bramley, the painter of the excellent "After Fifty Years," in last year's exhibition, and Mr. George Frampton, the sculptor of the fine Mysteriarch, exhibited at the same time.

In reference to a report from Albany that the State Controller will refuse to sign warrants for the salaries of the men employed by Health Officer Jenkins and the Quarantine Commission, Commissioner Allen said yesterday that only the employes of the commission could in any way be affected by the Controller's stand.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20. -- The steady advance in the traction stocks shows what a great lever easy money is. The earnings have not been encouraging, but then traction values depend on the future, and whenever the stocks are easy to carry there is no trouble to get a following, for the insiders promise whatever is needed to bring in buyers.

From The Washington Star. The grandest single peak on the Pacific coast and almost the most impressive mountain mass within the United States is Mount Rainier, in the State of Washington. The lands around it, a tract measuring 36 by 42 mlies. Including the entire slope and foothills of the mountain, all virgin forest and unbroken wilderness, were withdrawn from entry a year ago, and by Presidential proclamation constituted the Pacific forest reserve.
From The Philadelphia Times. The register of the Girard House yesterday recorded the arrival in the city of Thomas Godbepraised of Barrow-in-Furness, England.

The methods of our ancestors were hasty. Guido Fawkes and other Catholic gentlemen, fighting for freedom of opinion and the release from abominably oppressive laws, had the misfortune to fall into an Anarchistic order of proceedings. They were caught, and, as the ancients say, they did not die easily.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- The situation here over the attempt of both parties to organize the Senate is about as mixed as it has been at any time since the Legislature was assembled. The Democrats are to furnish on Monday night an answer to the proposition which was submitted by the Republican Senators at the joint conference held Wednesday.

President Cleveland has made a very serious mistake in vetoing the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill. It is worse than a political mistake, for a great party is buoyant and recuperative, and when its growth in one direction is stunted by the errors of its leaders, it readily develops its vital energy in others.

Two unknown men risked their lives yesterday afternoon in rescuing Mrs. Sarah Goldstein, who became a mother a few days ago, from a burning building at 46 Sheriff Street. She was lowered from a sixth-story window, lilted across an airshaft three feet wide, and taken over an iron picket fence to the roof of an adjoining building.

The art of composing the motto was subjected to severe rules. The "body" and the "soul" were required to be in such relation to each other that the "soul" should invariably explain the "body." The legend must be concise, neatly turned, and ingeniously suggestive -- like the "Desdichado" of the disinherited knight in "Ivanhoe."

ORANGE, Jan. 20. -- The most brilliant social affair of the week in the Oranges was the second of the Orange assembly dances, in Upper Music Hall, last evening. Over 100 guests were present, and the hall was artistically decorated for the occasion. The patronesses of the dance were Mrs. Graham H. Brewer, Mrs. Frank E. Gellatly, Mrs. Arthur H. Colby, Mrs. William A. Brewer, Jr., Mrs. John Pettit, and Mrs. Oliver S. Carter.

BOSTON, Jan. 20. -- The market for local stocks was exceedingly narrow, even for a Saturday. There was little gossip on the Street worth repetition. Even the talk on Bell and West End Land has subsided. Commission orders were scarce, and there seemed to be little, if any, disposition to purchase stocks.

Job E. Hedges, as assignee of H.H. Warner, the patent medicine man of Rochester, has brought an action in the Superior Court to recover from George F. Shaver a balance of $26,630, which, it is alleged, is due on a promissory note which Shaver made in November, 1891. The case came up before Judge Dugro yesterday on a demurrer.

M'KEESPORT, Penn., Jan. 20. -- The rolling mill and tube works of the National Tube Works Company will resume work in about one-half of their departments Wednesday, Jan. 24. The work will be divided among the different employes in equal proportions.

The great religious revival in Brooklyn gains fresh impetus and accessions daily. There was but one meeting, and that for children, in Association Hall, at Fulton and Bond Streets, yesterday, but it served to indicate the growing interest.

From The Baltimore American, Jan. 20. When Andrew French was a mere youth and not a staid, respectable butcher in the Belair Market, as he is to-day, he resolved to become a soldier in the Union Army. He thought that, mayhap, as he was only nineteen, the parental authority might intervene, and so, in common with thousands of others, as it has turned out, he went in under another name, that of Andrew Page.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- One of the most obvious impediments in the way of such an extensive conspiracy of revolution as that outlined a week ago as existing in Italy is the difficulty of securing the main movement against premature outbreaks. From what can be learned, the week's turbulent proceeding's round about Carrara belong to this category of the too previous.

From The Boston Transcript. Through the peculiar instructions of a lady regarding the disposal of her remains after cremation, attention has been called to the many formalities required by the law in cases of this kind. Her request was that she should be cremated, and her ashes be strewn about the grounds of the house in New-Hampshire in which she was born.

Brayton Ives, President of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, issued a circular to the stockholders yesterday explaining his reasons for seeking the removal of the receivers and asking the moral and financial co-operation of the stockholders. He suggests that each stockholder contribute oneeighth of 1 per cent., or $12.50 per 100 shares, toward a fund to be used in defraying the expenses of the legal procedings against the receivers.

The discovery, two or three weeks ago, that many cows in ex-Vice President Morton's choice herd of Guernseys had the disease which is commonly called consumption, proves once more that the best of care does not prevent the development of tuberculosis in cattle, if they have been exposed to infection.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Warden Osborne of the City Hospital to-day denied that Miss May Barrowcliff had made any statement differing from her previous story in regard to crossing the vacant lot at Sip Avenue and falling before she reached the board walk. He said she was no better, physically, than she bad been, and was unable to sit up in bed without being propped with pillows.

Eighteen men, who claim to have been sailors on the Nictheroy, the vessel which was fitted out in this port as a was ship for the Brazilian Government, arrived in this city last evening on the steamship New-York of the American Line from Southampton. They told of hardships which they said they had bean forced to endure on the Nictheroy, and against the executive officer, Lieut Hill, they made charges of a most serious nature.

A.D. Fisk, a dealer in photographers' supplies at 18 Ann Street, is anxious to find the impudent thief who, on Thursday last, walked off with, three volumes of Bauermeister's "Denkmaler des Klassichen Alterthums," a German, work of great value. They belong to Prof. Knapp of Barnard College, and contain 2,400 cuts and engravings.

From The Little Rock (Ark.) Gazette. Quanah Parker is Chief of the Comanches. Years ago a wagon train was attacked in Texas by the raiding and marauding Comanches, and all but one infant girl killed. She was raised by the chief and married his son, who, at the death of his father, was also chief. The rangers defeated the Indians in a battle and captured the woman and her infant child.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 20. -- Health Officer Allen, who has investigated the alleged cases of black fever on Stanton Street, this city, to-day denied that the two victims died of that dread disease, though their complaint, he admits, was somethings nearly akin to it. On the contrary, Dr. Sullivan, who attended the cases; asserts that the symptoms indicated black fever beyond a doubt.

"Yes, it was charming," affirmed a clever woman, alluding to the recent " ladies' night " of the Authors' Club. "Very many were there from among our most unexceptionable literary circles, it was held in the magnificent state apartments of the Waldorf, and all the arrangements were admirable, owing largely, I was told, to the efficiency of the Board of Managers of the club, of which Mr. William Carey was Chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The interest felt in Hawaiian affairs was manifested in a striking manner this afternoon when President Cleveland's message transmitting the latest diplomatic correspondence on the subject was laid before the House of Representatives.

"The Old Jew," Sydney Grundy's new play at the Garrick Theatre, seems to be a failure. The Westminster Gazette calls it one of the author's worst plays. The old Jew is Mr. Venabics, who separated from his wife years before the play begins, because of her infidelity, leaving his children in her charge. The money he leaves in trust for them is lost.
Gen. Isaac S. Catlin's remarkable letter, printed in The New-York Times yesterday, has attracted more than ordinary attention among lawyers of New-York City.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- The speech made in the Reichstag to-day by Dr. Mittnaecht, Prime Minister of Wurtemiburg, in which he pointed out that Wurtemberg had no legal reserved right to prevent the imposition of a tax on wine in that kingdom, though the kingdom, would strenuously oppose the Wine Tax bill, was more than a denunciation of the measure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Secretary Herbert has not taken any action so far on the report of the Naval Stability Board recommending that the gunboats Machias and Castine each be lengthened fourteen feet to make them stable and seaworthy.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 20. -- The cruiser Montgomery left here at 9:30 A.M. to-day for Baltimore, where the finishing touches will be put on her before she is turned over to the Government. The ship is still in charge of the contractor, but Commander C.H. Davis, Lieut. Commander Drake, and Chief Engineer J.A.B. Smith, United States Navy, who will be attached to the ship when she goes into commission, return to Baltimore on her.

A wise physician closing a laconic paper on "Medicine and Doctors." once summed up as follows: "What then, must every one who wants a dose of salts or of senna send for a doctor? No, certainly not. This would be both costly and vexatious, and nothing could be further from our meaning. We only intend to say that every one who needs a dose of salts or of senna should send for a doctor."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Westchester County officers think the jail at this place is one of the best-managed institutions of its kind in the State, and visitors comment upon its neat interior. As the population in the county has increased rapidly in recent years, and crimes are more numerous, there are now about 200 inmates.

"Oh, I'm all right," groaned Frederick McLone, "the Chevalier Cliquot," sword swallower, as he tossed uneasily on a bed in Room 66 of the Union Square Hotel last evening, when his manager, William Howell, asked him how he was getting along.

For many years there has been an annual distribution of blankets and other necessaries. Mission stations have also been established by Government and private funds in different parts of the country, where as many of the blacks as are willing to conform to the mild rules laid down for the conduct of the establishments are housed, fed, and taught.

From the beginning woman has heen held to be subordinate to man. When from primitive barbarism arose better conditions, the subjection of woman was sanctioned. Rome, imposing her legislation on the Old World, treated her with harshness, and her condition long after was one of tutelage. It was only during the Middle Ages that the unmarried woman gradually liberated herself from embarrassing restrictions which hampered even her every-day life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The first and only public reception to be held this season by Mrs. Cleveland took place this afternoon from 3:30 until 5:30 o'clock. It will be recalled as the largest afternoon reception ever held within the walls of the White House, where crushes have been the rule rather than the exception.

Flower is showing in improving the condition and effectiveness of the canals, and his recommendations on the subject, together with the recent experiments at Rochester, having for their object the utilization of the trolley system for canal boat propulsion, have awakened the people of the State to a realization of the fact that their big waterways are not doing as much as they should for the development of the State's resources.

Figures, which have been collected by The Record and Guide, show that during the last half of 1893 there were in Brooklyn 1,421 fewer buildings projected than in 1892. The total decline in building for the year was 1,602 in the numbr of buildings and $7,600,000 in amount. These data, it is urged, are entirely favorable for a resumption of building operations, and for disposing of structures hitherto built.

NASSAU, N.P., Jan. 15. -- The agitation which for several weeks has disturbed the minds of the Bahamians as to who would be appointed Chief Justice of the colony In place of Justice Yelverton has subsided, the appointment having been lately announced. The new Chief Justice is the Hon. Charles George Walpole, late Attorney General of the Leeward Islands.

Every yard of canvas the masts could carry was crowded on the ship, and toward the middle of September, 1857, the Ninety-third, 1,000 strong, was able to march, through Calcutta.

On the streets and in the stores of Windsor Terrace, Flatbush, yesterday many groups of residents, both men and women, were engaged in earnest and excited conversation. They were riscussing the school meeting of the night before in the dingy little schoolhouse, and how Police Captain Keiser and a squad of his bluecoats were present to preserve the peace.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- This was the dullest session of the week. The total sales were below 4,000 shares, and, with the exception of elevated certificates, the principal stocks closed below the opening figures.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 20. -- The Assembly Hall of the Drexel Institute contained a large gathering this afternoon, representing not only the best class of Philadelphia's citizens, but including wellknown men and women from neighboring cities as well, assembled in honor of the memory of the late Anthony J. Drexel.
G.G. Walbaum, President of the Saratoga Racing Association, returned from California yesterday for a conference with the managers of the proposed new Jockey club.

Paul Delair, whose death was announced in the columns of The New-York Times yesterday, was a great poet whom Coquelin made famous. He was born at Montereau-Fault, in the Department of Yonne, Oct. 24, 1843. He was a cashier in a business house until 1870, when he published a book of poems, "Nuits et Reveils," evidently inspired by Baudelaire's translation of Poe's poems.

From The Baltimore Sun. A bill will be shortly introduced in the House of Delegates to provide for the safety of the ancient will books of the State, now deposited in the office of the Register of Wills for Anne Arundel County. The old General Court, which was dissolved by act of Assembly in the beginning of the century, was the probate court of the whole State, and in it all the wills were recorded.

Eugene Nus. Eugene Nus, the French dramatist, whose work as the author of "Miss Multon," an adaptation of "East Lynne," is well known to Americans, died in Paris yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 20. -- Experiments have been ordered at the torpedo station with pumps for compressing air for Whitehead torpedoes. There are two forms of these pumps -- a small one, requiring a high steam pressure, for use on torpedo boats, where space has to be economized, and a larger pump for ships, which can be run under low pressure.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 20. -- While the cloudy days of this week have been far from what is known as Lakewood weather, a round of pleasures at hotels and cottages has made the week a bright one socially. Preparations are being made for a pre-Lenten ball, to be given in the ballroom of the Lakewood Hotel, where a dance followed the entertainment given by Jennie O'Neil Potter to-night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Lorin A. Thurston, representing the Hawaiian provisional Government in the United States, returned to Washington from Honolulu this evening, after an absence of about six weeks. He declined to state the nature of the communications he bears to the State Department or say when he will deliver them.

If judged by the homely standard, "handsome is that handsome does," Marshal MacMahon was in some respects a great man. He was free from discrepancies. So unswerving was his rectitude, that any one who knew him well could say what course he was sure to take under given circumstances. It would have been hard to find a man more healthy in body, mind, or moral sense.

BOSTON, Jan. 20. -- Within the past two yachting seasons there has grown up at Marblehead, that centre of Corinthian yachting in the East, a most interesting class of boats known as "knockabouts." The name seems specially appropriate, in view of the uses to which the boats are put, and in it is found the main motive for their construction.

It is a common saying in Wall Street that the bluest spot in the country has been the Stock Exchange district. During the recent financial distresses Wall Street was the most vehement in outcries, and Wall Street made the sorriest exhibit of panic devastations. There was the sensational end of the panic.

America will be well represented at the International Exposition to be held in Antwerp from May 5 to Nov. 32 if the plans of the United States commission are carried out. The exhibits, which promise to be very general in their character, will be housed in the American Building. This is to be modern Renaissance in style and 240 by 150 feet.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The defeat on Wednesday last of the amendment offered by the Ways and Means Committee which named Aug. 1 as the date for free wool under the Wilson bill was a serious disappointment to all interests connected with the woolen trade. We shall be greatly obliged if you will allow us to explain the situation.

From The Washington Star. The inter-relation of the buttons on a uniform is just as much a matter of regulation as the cut of a coat. The General wears two rows of buttons on the breast of his frock coat, twelve in each row, placed by fours. The distance between the rows is 5 1/2 inches at the top and 3 1/2 at the bottom.

Although February is the shortest month of the year, Old Sol manages to do some pretty tall climbing on his way back from the turning post at the Winter solstice. His speed in declination is greatly in excess of that of the previous month, and it will be found that he has reduced his southerly declination by more than nine degrees when the month closes.

It is not an edifying spectacle to see Italy, which owes the liberation of Lombardy and Venetia to France, combining in a league to maintain the bondage of Alsace-Lorraine. France has exasperated Italy in more ways than one -- upon the question of Papal guarantees, upon the tariff question, while the crowning offense was her annexation of Tunis. Still it is difficult to see the value of the triple alliance to Italy.

FAR ROCKAWAY. L.I., Jan. 20. -- There are two Methodist churches in Inwood, near here. One was built by the Christian Endeavor Society because the organization was expelled from the parent church for refusing to turn over to its support the profits of an entertainment held in the church.

The Young Men's Union of the Society for Ethical Culture is still hard at work at 18 Delancey Street, and the need of assistance seems to increase. Personal investigations are constantly bringing to light worthy cases of people who are too proud to ask for aid, and who will hardly receive it when offered.

There is an exhibition of such work at 929 Broadway, which contains hundreds of exquisitely-embroidered articles. The specimens of Kensington embroidery are particularly artistic and dainty.

Dole has for a year occupied the exalted position of President of the Executive Council and Minister of Foreign Affairs of the provisional Government of the Hawaiian Islands, by grace of John L. Stevens, who interposed with all the authority and might of the United States to raise him to that high eminence.

An ambulance was summoned from Harlem Hospital, but the ambulance surgeon found the woman in too serious a condition to be removed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 20. -- The condtion of the unemployed reached a point of desperation here to-day, when a big body them called on Mayor Denny, the County Commissioners, and the Commercial Club and demanded work. Many of them are in deplorable circumstances, and many of heir utterances were of an ugly nature.

The week just ended has in the main proved a fairly good one to real estate, men in this city. Business has been much brisker than in months, and when all the returns of sales are recorded the results will show a large volume of transactions at pretty good prices. Some of the sales have been given during the week, but a number of others are withheld By purchasers for special reasons.

Senator Henry C. Hansbrough of North Dakota is at the Everett House. Mrs. Hansbrough, who underwent a surgical operation in this city several weeks ago, is not yet able to leave her room, and it will probably be several months before she completely regains her health.

This is a map of New-York City -- not of New-York City as it is, but as it will be if the Bushe-Uhlmann-Lauterbach proposition, now before the Rapid-Transit Commission, shall finally be-adopted and carried out. The map shows more plainly than words can describe the precise effect of such action by the authorities.

John Y. McKane, Chief of the Gravesend Police, and the three Election Inspectors in the First District of that town, will be placed on trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, Brooklyn, to-morrow. They have been indicted jointly for misconduct as registry officers.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- The State Encampment of the Department of New-Jersey, Grand Army of the Republic, will take place on Feb. 8 and 9, at the Masonic Temple in Trenton. It will be an exceedingly interesting encampment, because of the lively contest for Department Commander. There are four candidates in the fight. Henry S. White, the United States District Attorney, is one of the members who came into the contest early.

ROSLYN, L.T. Jan. 20. -- Silas L. Albertson, Jr., thirty-two years old, son of a rich resident of this village, has been declared insane, and removed to the Amityville Insane Asylum. It is believed that domestic troubles, growing out of a separation from his wife, have unbalanced his mind.

What's in a name? Mrs. M.E. Wheeler, President of the Limerick Women's Benevolent and Social Association, thinks there's a good deal. Furthermore, she is of the opinion that, unlike the poet's rose, the organization of which she is the head has a far more savory reputation under its own name, if it is inconveniently lengthy, than under the terse and suggestive characterization of the "Lady Limericks."

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 20. -- At the last session of the General Assembly of this State a law was passed making it compulsory upon pupils in the public schools to take up the study of physiology and hygiene, with special reference, according to Section 1 of the act, to "the nature of alcoholic drinks and narcotics, and special instructions as to their effects upon the human system."

In a cross-town street and not far from Third Avenue is situated a barber's shop, which, despite (or, perhaps, because of,) its diminutive area and limited accommodations, rejoices in the imposing title of "tonsorial salon." The proprietor is a dried-up little man, whose brow is corrugated with furrows indicative of profound contemplation and whose ivory pate is a perpetual reproach to his own vaunted hair restorer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The witness before the Senate committee investigating Hawaiian relations to-day was ex-Minister Stevens, who is charged with having coerced the Hawaiians and contributed toward the establishment of the provisional Government by the use of the United States forces.

Henry Ixander, short, gray-haired, and respectable-looking, is a fish merchant of 306 Second Street, St. Louis, Mo., who made his first visit to this city a few days ago. Unlike a visitor from a large city, the fish merchant carried a carpet valise, in which he had $500 in United States currency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- There are many curious and interesting features tucked away in the generally prosy reports of Army Inspectors. For Instance, the average height of soldiers reported during the last year differs but little from that of the preceding year, but a decrease is noted in the range of extremes, which is this year from 5 feet for the shortest to 6 feet 4 1/2 inches for the tallest man in the army.

The truth is that Lord Elgin did a great service to all who care for Greek sculpture.

Through the efforts of Messrs. Tiffany and the American Numismatical and Archaeological Society the many patrons of the Columbian Exposition will be enabled to obtain a handsome souvenir of the White City and its big show. The society, recognizing the fact that no medal had been struck which was worthy of the occasion, appointed a special committee to confer with Tiffany Co. on the subject.

For more than a month numerous complaints have been made to the police in Central Park by men, women and children that a dark-complexioned man, about thirty years old, 5 feet 10 inches in height, stockily built, and wearing a brown overcoat, was prowling about the upper end of the park, stopping pedestrians and robbing them.

A colt of which great things are expected is Regal Nelson, by Nelson, 2:09, dam Marietta, sister to Directum, 2:05 1/4, and Direct, 2:05 3/4. This colt was sold by Mrs. C.R. Noyes of Boston to Lincoln Morrison, of the same city. If breeding and individuality count for anything, this yearling should come somewhere near the two-minute mark.

The weekly statement of the New York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $10,170,775. The banks now hold $102,754,450 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans of $1,500,500, an increase in specie of $5,326,400, an increase in legal tenders of $8,442,500, an increase in deposits of $14,392,500, and a decrease in circulation of $235,300.

Thomas Cosgrove, twenty-two years old, who claims Philadelphia as his home, called at Mrs. Kate Knox's boarding house, 921 Eighth Avenue, Saturday to engage board. He seemed glad when told he might share a room already occupied by two men. He went to the room and in an hour came down again.

Leaping into the sea or staying on board, to be burned to death was the outlook that confronted Capt. William Harmon and the crew of fifteen men of the little Gloucester fishing schooner Susan L. Hodge last Friday night.

NEW-ROCHELLE, Jan. 21 -- Joseph A. Pepperday, a prominent citizen and ex-Trustee of this village, was found dead at his home this morning. It is thought he committed suicide. A revolver lay beside him. Through his left temple a bullet had entered his brain. He was alone in the house with a servant, who found him dead.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 20 -- Local securities were very dull, although all conditions would seem to suggest activity. No breaks in prices, of consequence, were recorded, while many of the usually active shares are higher. The best demand at the moment is for the natural "gassers" and industrials, with Westinghouse Air Brake leading.

A Coroner's investigation of the death at Smith McNeil's Hotel, in Washington Street, on Saturday, of Richard Berrian, a painter, will probably result in a verdict of "death from want of proper food and clothing."

The baggage belonging to the members of J. K. Emmet's company, which finished its engagement at the Columbus Theatre, in Harlem, Saturday night, remained in the theatre all day yesterday. It was piled up in the centre of the stage. Deputy Sheriff John Shea kept guard over it and took care that no one removed as much as a hand bag.

VIENNA, Jan. 21.-- Ex-King Milan of Servia ultimately decided to proceed to Belgrade, and he left late last evening for the Servian capital. The Servian Cabinet Ministers were informed of his plan as soon as he started from Buda-Pesth. The Council was convened at mid night in haste, and the Radical leaders resolved to resign forth-with.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 21. -- There were two entries in a grand relay race from this city to the State line last night between an unknown and the local police. About 9 o'clock a New-London Deputy Sheriff arrived at the Union Depot with a prisoner he was taking home. While waiting for the New-London train he fell asleep and his prisoner escaped.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 21 -- The refusal of Judge William Richardson of Huntsville to enter the race for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination has somewhat simplified the situation. But two avowed candidates remain, Joseph. F. Johnston of Birmingham, ex-President of the Alabama National Bank, and Joseph C. Rich, ex-Mayor of Mobile.

The new Columbia College gymnasium has opened under most favorable auspices. One hundred and fifty lockers have already been applied for. Besides the men in regular training, many of the students from the various departments of the college take the opportunity offered them for physical development. With the exception of some apparatus reserved for the crew, all students will enjoy equal privileges.

Cardinal Gibbons of Baltimore, the highest prelate in the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, delivered the sermon yesterday morning at the celebration of the Feast of St. Agnes in the Church of St. Agnes, in East Forty-third Street, of which the Rev. Dr. Henry A. Braun is pastor.

CORNING, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Mrs. H.A. Horning, who was arrested for alleged shop-lifting in a notion store on Broadway, New-York, arrived home to-day. She denies positively the charges of theft, and ascribes the whole affair to a desire for notoriety by the female detective. She says that she did not put the article in her pocket, and believes that it was placed there by a designing person.

When the next large fire happens the firemen will be furnished with hot coffee and sandwiches at the expense of Fire Commissioner Gray. This plan has long been considered by Mr. Gray, but it is only within a few days that he was able to complete arrangements. One of the lunch wagons of the Church Temperance Society will be stationed at Broadway and Thirty-fifth Street both night and day.

Tuesday Dr. M.J. Pupin delivered a very interesting lecture before the New-York Electrical Society on "Electrical Resonance." He treated his subject exhaustively and from many points of view, concluding with a few remarks on longdistance telephony and telegraphy.

Frank Cottrell of 93 Douglass Street, Brooklyn, employed by the Committee of One Hundred, was sent to Gravesend Saturday to serve subpoenas on John E. Hinman, Captain of Police of Gravesend, and Isaac Ring, a resident of the town, to appear as witnesses before Justice Bartlett to-day in the McKane trial.
