An entertainment was given last evening by the members of Tammany Hall in the Ninth Assembly District in aid of the relief fund of the district. The proceeds amounted to over $3,000, which will be turned over to the Relief Committee, to be expended for the poor in the district.

VICTORIA, B.C., Jan. 21. -- The Militia Department at Ottawa, having heard through the press of the proposed expedition to Honolulu, organized under royalist auspices and directed on this side from Winnipeg and Vancouver, Major Gen. Herbert has caused inquiries to be made by Lieut. Col. Petera, Deputy Adjutant General for this district.

A new antidote for morphine poisoning has been discovered by Dr. William Moor of 355 Boulevard. It is permanganate of potassium, and Dr. Moor recently demonstrated its antidotal qualities by swallowing a sufficient amount of morphine to have caused death unless its effects had been neutralized by some other agent.

A Brooklyn woman called Sarturday on Superintendent Byrnes and asked him to aid her in unraveling a romantic mystery in regard to her first husband's family. She was Mrs. Rosalie Plain, wife of Francis Bartholomew Plain, a retired business man who lives at 909 Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn.

The committee of seven appointed by Samuel S. Whitehouse, Chairman of the Kings County Democratic General Committee to bring about the reorganization of the Democratic Party has issued an address to the public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- At a meeting of the majority members of the Committee on Ways and Means to-day, the form of the Internal Revenue bill was finally agreed upon and formally adjusted. It will be reported to a meeting of the full committee to-morrow morning, and afterward introduced into the House.
Clinton Street, Brooklyn, boarding-house society is agitated over a "comedy of errors."

Two bands of east-side toughs fought each other with stones yesterday forenoon at First Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, and when they had grown tired, and had gone away to nurse their battered heads and faces, they left behind damaged house fronts, broken windows, and terror-stricken people.

The stars of the Sunday evening concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last night were Mme. Melba and the orchestra. The house was crowded to its utmost capacity. Indeed its capacity was increased for the occasion by putting a flooring over the pit usually, occupied by the orchestra and covering it with chairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The importer of New-York will regret to learn that the privilege accorded to them for the last five or six years of paying customs duties by checks has been cut off by the Secretary of the Treasury. Secretary Carlisle issued the following letter of instructions covering this point late yesterday:

We have not yet got at the bottom of the transmission of electrical power or of methods by means of which electrical force can be stored or distributed. But as to a motor, that may be, as Mr. Martin says, but Secondary "to the radical improvement of the means and methods of illumination." Perhaps when we better appreciate the dynamo and the question is solved, we shall get to the economics of electrical lighting.
A team of horses attached to a street car at the foot of Grand Street, Williamsburg, broke away from the car yesterday morning and went on a rampage which created a great deal of excitement.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 21 -- The result of the election for baseball Captain has caused a complete change in football prospects. For weeks the election of a successor to Capt. Bertram G. Waters of the 'Varsity eleven has been put off, until the Athletic Committee, headed by Prof. James Barr Ames, should decide whether the election of a graduate to the Captaincy should be countenanced.

There was a collision of religious exponents in Union Square Hall yesterday morning when Mr. Nabokoff, fee of the red fez and husky voice who every Sunday morning calls the world to Islamism, found an adversary in Paul Behman, a Persian and a Christian.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 21 -- A representative of The Pittsburg Times called Upon Senator Quay at his home in Beaver today, and found that gentleman with very positive views on Secretary Carlisle's proposed issue of $50,000,000 of new bonds, and with no hesitation about expressing them.

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, Jan. 21. -- The Government has received an official report on the apparition of "Our Lady of Guadaloupe" at Lecheria, which has been attracting attention for the last ten days. A visit to the scene was paid by W.A. Garibay, Jefe Politico, or Lieutenant Governor, who has tendered a written report of his observations.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 21 -- A large number of the factories of this city have resumed operations on full or part time, and the manufacturers say that the outlook is much better than it has been. The hat trade is picking up, and most of the shops have full complements of hands at work.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21 -- Nothing in the American social system escapes the prevailing financial stringency, not even the universities, retired and remote from the busy world though they are. At Yale, which may be taken as a type of the changes enforced by the new order of things, methods of student life have been introduced which have been object lessons to every member of the university of the pervasive power of "hard times."
The largest and liveliest meeting ever held by the Young Ladies' Charitable Society took place yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the society, at the Lenox Avenue Opera House.

An important meeting of the Executive Committee of the Municipal Art Society of New-York, organized to provide adequate sculptural and pictorial decorations for the public buildings and parks in the city, was held Saturday night in the office of McKim, Mead White. The committee adopted a set of rules and conditions for a public competition for the decoration of the Court of General Sessions in the new Criminal Courts Building, in Centre Street.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 21. -- The Englishman (newspaper) says of the India Council's decision to sell bills below the former minimum of 15 1/4d.: "It was an equal surprise to the Indian Government and the public. The former should make a clean breast of its share in the matter.

It is a good many years now since Mr. Hewitt declared that he had not, in his Congressional service, met a member of Congress who represented or pretended to represent the United States of America or anything beyond the sentiment of his own party in his own district. There have since been furnished very frequent evidences that no change for the better has taken place in this respect.

JACKSON, Mich., Jan. 21 -- Gov. Stone yesterday notified both houses of the resignation of Senator Walthall, accompanying his notification with a copy of the Senator's letter. Both houses passed resolutions expressive of their regret at his retiring, highly eulogizing him as a soldier and statesman, and indorsing his career in the Senate.

Six hundred members of the Ninth Regiment, National Guard, Col. William Seward commanding, marched in uniform yesterday afternoon from the Armory in "West Twenty-sixth Street to the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, in Fifth Avenue, near Forty-fifth Street, to attend the services and listen to a sermon by the regimental chaplain, the Rev. D. Newland Maynard.

Three men who married three sisters are said to have died with the same symptoms -- weakness, followed by emaciation, dizziness, and utter collapse. Their wives got possession of their property and insurance on their lives. The brother of the man who died last suspects poisoning to secure his brother's property and part of the insurance, and has taken legal measures to make a thorough investigation of his brother's death.

The special services in the Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, at 321 East Sixty-first Street, which were commenced last Thursday night, in commemoration of the placing in the church of a statue of Blessed Brother Gerard, were ended yesterday. Services have been held nightly, and the church has been filled with thousands of worshippers.
Don Gaspar Nunez de Arce is the great poet of Spain, and neither Tennyson in England nor Hugo in France, nor Lowell in America, had his reward.

Members of the Lone Star Boat Club held their fifth annual ball and reception at the Lenox Lyceum, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, on Saturday night. The friends of the club attended in goodly numbers and made the occasion the most successful, financially and socially, in the history of the club.

John D. Townsend yesterday gave out another statement addressed "To the people of the City of New-York," in which he further discusses the asphalt paving business as it has been conducted in this city.
The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage, for twenty-five years pastor of the Brooklyn Tabernacle, astounded his congregation at the evening service last night by reading a letter of resignation.

Sir W. Richardson, in an article in Longman's Magazine on "The Athletic Life," speaks of the advantages and disadvantages of athleticism, and says, among other things: " I wish on these subjects to be very just, neither a pessimist nor alarmist on one side, nor optimist nor apologist on the other. In athleticism there are many great advantages.

The San Francisco papers are beginning to awake to the fact that the best theatrical attractions are keeping away from the City of the Golden Gate, and they are at a loss to account for the fact. During the present season, with the exception of Henry Irving, scarcely an attraction that can be called important has visited the Pacific coast.

From The Galesburg (Ill.) Spectator, Jan. 19. When The New-York Times was started by Henry J. Raymond in 1852 its highest ambition was to reach the first place among America's Independent papers. It has never taken its eye off that goal, and to-day it can be truthfully said that this great journal occupies a higher position in the confidence of the American people than any other paper published.

Plans and specifications for tinkering up the machine which Thomas C. Platt has in Albany, so that it will not go to pieces during the Winter, were considered by several political experts in Room 10, Fifth Avenue Hotel, last night.

Net deterrent result of a raid by Police Captain Moses W. Cortright on John H. McGurk's resort, 253 Bowery, just before midnight of Saturday -- only one prisoner out of 221, John H. McGurk, held by Justice Hogan for keeping a disorderly house. But for evidence that the guests of the "hotel" annex to his establishment were too transient, naught would have come of the raid.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- The beautiful new edifice of the St. James's Methodist Episcopal Church in this city was this evening formally dedicated to the service of God with impressive ceremonies by the Rev. Bishop Cyrus D. Foss.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 21 -- When at 5:30 o'clock this evening Referee and Stakeholder John Kelly returned here from Corbett's training quarters, he brought joy to the eager crowd of sporting men who anxiously awaited his return, for he announced that it had finally been agreed by the club managers, with whom he had made the trip to Corbett, that all restrictions shall be taken off that much-discussed twenty-thousand-dollar check.

The entries in the class match at the Seventh Regiment's Armory on Saturday night were very numerous, and the average of the shooting was exceptionally good. The conditions of the match were seven shots standing at the two-hundred-yard range and seven shots prone at the five-hundred-yard range; two entries; five prizes each match; all scores having the same numerical value constitute a class.

The Union for Evangelical Work, an organization in which a large number of Brooklyn's most influential Protestant churches are represented, has determined to continue the campaign for the conversion of sinners which was begun a week ago. Many conversions were made last week, and in the hope of adding largely to the number the union will continue its work for at least another week in Brooklyn.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 21 -- There was considerable excitement in South Orange today over the reported discovery of gold in the mountains above the village. A party of twenty-five prospectors have been scouring the woods all day, and over $200 worth of the precious metal was unearthed this afternoon.
The following communication regarding tracks under Third Avenue has been received by the Rapid-Transit Commissioners: To the President of the Rapid-Transit Commission:

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- The presence of Senator David B. Hill in this city for several days last week failed to make the stir here that would have been made had the Legislature been Democratic. Albany has never been a Hill town. The organization always has been anti-Hill.

A woman of middle age, with her face strongly marked by lines of sorrow, walked hesitatingly along Bleecker Street yesterday afternoon, looking up at the numbers on the doors. A faded shawl was drawn tightly around her shoulders, held together in front by a gloved hand, the fingers of which were sadly frayed and ragged.

ROME, Jan. 21. -- The Pope has fixed the Consistory in March, when the following prelates will be created Cardinals: Tancredi Fausti. Papal Auditor; Ciasca, Secretary of the Congregation of the Propaganda; Ferraud, Archbishop of Bologna; Jacobini Archbishop of Ferrara. The Papal Nuncio in Madrid, Creponi, will not be elevated to the Cardinalate, despite the wishes of several Cardinals, who are anxious that he should enter the college.

Henry Marvin Wharton was born at Western View, Culpeper County, Va., Sept. 11, 1848. He is the son of Malcon H. and Susan R. Wharton. Both his parents were noted for their intelligence, piety, and influence in the community. Henry was the youngest of eight children.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, Jan. 21. -- With the Conservatives, one wins of the National Liberals, both groups of Radicals, the Social Democrats, and many of the Clericals opposing the Government in the tax debates, the position of the Ministry seems almost hopeless. Nevertheless, the tone of official comment in the Reichstag lobby last evening after the Wine Tax bill was sent to the committee was far from despondent.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 21. -- The hat manufacturers will hold a meeting to-morrow forenoon, at which, they will decide upon the day that they will sound the whistles of their factories. This will be the signal for their old help to return and resume their old places. The test will probably be made Tuesday or Wednesday.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 21 -- Gen. A.D. McCook left for the South to-day. To a personal friend he stated that his trip was for the purpose of gaining information as to alleged raids of lawless bandits in Mexico across the border into the United States. The General will be absent three weeks.

The January meeting of the Executive Committee of the Brooklyn Christian Endeavor Union was held Saturday evening in the Throop Avenue Presbyterian Church, Throop and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn. It was an enthusiastic meeting. There were 400 Endeavorers present, and 63 societies were represented.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Attorney General Olney's attention was called by a reporter of the United Press to the published statement that the Knights of Labor would endeavor to prevent Secretary Carlisle from selling bonds in accordance with his public declaration, by means of an injunction from the courts.
The Cyclorama Building, Fourth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, is to be torn down. The painting of Niagara Falls and the rest of the contents of the building will be sold at auction.

So far there has not been any dissent from the general verdict regarding "Glimpses of the World's Fair," which The Weekly Times is giving away free with one year's subscription to the paper. The subscription price is $1, and the paper is itself alone well worth the price, not to mention the compact and beautiful little book which accompanies it.

NEW-LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The Montgomery to-day holds the first place in point of speed among the two-thousand-ton cruisers built for the Government. She is the third of that class of vessels that has been constructed.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The rates of discount last week were 1 1/2 for three months and 1 for thirty days. There was a small demand for gold for Germany. The consensus of opinion is that neither the conversion of the French 4 1/2 per cent. rentes nor the bond issue of the United States will affect London.

At a meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Catholic Summer School of America, held at the Catholic Club last Thursday, it was resolved to begin the session of 1894 on July 14 at Plattsburg, the home of the school.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 21 -- Another foreign Count, with good lineage, depleted pocketbook, and an unpronounceable name, has fallen from his high estate, and is now fleeing from justice. Count Zidzislow Kermerowski of Poland is his name.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21 -- The first week's practice of the Yale crew for the season of '94 ended yesterday. Capt. Fred Johnson thinks it has been very satisfactory on the whole. The routine work has been hard, through few of the vetern oarsmen have yet been taken into the number of candidates.

ALBABY, Jan. 21 -- The five trust companies, abstracts of whose reports for 1893, filed with the State Banking Department, are here given, show double the amount of profits in the aggregate that the reports of 1892 showed. The profits last year were $4,678,590; those of 1892 were $2,047,851. The resources on Dec. 31 last were $103,944,352, while those of the previous year were $103,409,378.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 21 -- The Andover House of Boston, one of the best known college settlements in the country, is now doing active work in aiding the poor, through the efforts of its resident members. Two of these are Harvard graduates, W.A. Clark, '93, and H.G. Pearson, '93. An appeal for clothing was lately made to the students of the college, and the result was very gratifying.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 21 -- The long and bitter fight between Mayor Fell and the Orange Common Council was brought to a close last night by the Mayor signing the contract for paving High Street, one of the principal thoroughfares in the city. The contract has been in dispute for nearly a year.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21 -- Plans have been made for a new building for the Sheffield Scientific School, to be used for chemical laboratories, to meet the growing requirements of the department. The architect is Cady of NewYork City, who also designed White, Winchester, and Dwight Halls, besides other university buildings.

Mr. Sherman of Ohio has confessed to a correspondent in the State of Washington that he views the tariff-reform bill with particular alarm. This is not so impressive as it would be if peculiar alarm on the subject of any and all Democratic measures were not known to be a professional function with Mr. Sherman.

Under the caption "A Call to Battle" The Irish Republic, issued Saturday evening, has a column and a half appeal to Irishmen, signed by William Lyman, Treasurer of the Irish National League of America. He says in part:

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- A better feeling prevailed during the week, and in some instances higher prices were made in the local security market. More than the usual number of stocks and bonds were actively traded in, and with few exceptions all the sales were made at the asked price.

NEW-YORK. Monday, Jan. 22 -- A.M. While speculation has not been active, dstinct evidence of improving conditions has induced many bears to cover their outstanding contracts, and this movement has resulted in generally higher prices. The most important event of the week was the publication of Secretary Carlisle's circular inviting subscriptions to a Government issue of $50,000,000 ten-year 5 per cent. bonds on a basis of 3 per cent.

Dr. Greer came to the metropolis five years ago from the staid old Rhode Island city of Providence, and is rector of a large and flourishing parish. He is in the very prime of life, has an excellent voice and attractive manners, and is always thoroughly in earnest. He is never without something to say which is worth saying, and he knows how to say it.

Frank Emerson, twenty-eight years old, who gave his address as 138 West Thirty-third Street, was arraigned in the Yorkville Court yesterday morning as the "twenty-second capture since the holidays" of Louise Alexandra, a woman employed as a detective in a Broadway notion store.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 7/8 @ 1 1/2 per cent., the average being about 1 per cent.

It was a tempestuous voyage that the North German Lloyd steamship Saale finished when she reached the comparatively smooth waters of New-York Harbor early yesterday morning. From the moment the vessel poked her nose outside the port of Soushampton she was buffeted toy terrific gales.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- At all the working men's meetings to-day resolutions were adopted declaring that the Government ought to immediately undertake the construction of public works in order to bene-fit the unemployed. The resolutions also declared that eight hours should be a maximum day's work for all Government workmen. The conduct of the police in attacking the unemployed workingmen last week at Friedrichshain was denounced.

Mayor Charles A. Schieren demonstrated to the citizens of Brooklyn yesterday that he is possessed of considerable strength of purpose and that he means to carry out his promise in having every department in the City Government conducted on business principles.

Col. James, counsel for Police Captain W.S. Devery, formerly of the Eldridge Street Police Station, and who was indicted for misdemeanor in alleged neglect of duty in not suppressing disorderly houses in the precinct, as charged by the agents of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, appeared before Judge Cowing, in Part II., General Sessions, yesterday, to argue in favor of a demurrer.

Supervisor Kenny of The City Record, to Whom was referred for investigation Commissioner Andrews's request for two books to cost $400, reported to the Board of City Record yesterday that Mr. Andrews wanted one of the books for the purpose of keeping a record of the movements of scows.

LYNN, Mass., Jan. 22 -- After six days walking, footsore, hungry, ragged, and nearly exhausted, a Lynn man has returned from a lumber camp in New-Hampshire and tells a tale of hardship and ill usage. He went in the latter part of December, with fourteen other men, to Lincoln, N.H., to work at the logging camp of J.E. Henry Sons, dealers in lumber and charcoal.

It is a pity that the gifted Frenchman Georges Bizet, could not have lived to see the world-wide popularity of his masterpiece, "Carmen." Perhaps such success would have inspired him to write another work of similar excellence. "Carmen" is loved and admired all the world over. Even the Germans, who cannot perform it with the requisite abandon, take delight in it, despite the fact that it is one of the glories of the French stage.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The nomination of Wheeler H. Peckham for the Supreme Court bench, of the United States was greeted with the greatest enthusiasm in this city, where he was born, particularly among the lawyers who have kept track of his career since he left here many years ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The steamer Andes, Captain Williams, went ashore at 1:30 o'clock this morning off Little Beach. She will probably be a total loss, as she lies in but about fifteen feet of water with the sea pounding her heavily. The chances for her getting off are decidedly poor.

The Superintendent, Inspectors, and Captains of Police were the hosts at Delmonico's last night, on the occasion of the thirteenth annual dinner given to their friends, and they had for their guests a large gathering of men prominent in municipal, business, and social circles.

TROY, Jan. 22 -- Thomas G. Shearman addressed a large audience in this city this evening, speaking: on the tariff question. He talked exclusively of shirts, collars, and cuffs, and endeavored to persuade his listeners, many of whom were engaged as employes in factories making these articles, that they would be better off under the tariff scheme proposed by the Democratic Party than they were under the McKinley law.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Those portions of the Bell Telephone patents which will become public property on the 30th of this month are officially described as follows:

A mass meeting will be held this evening in Harlem Temple, 135 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, to indorse the nomination of Isidor Straus for member of Congress for the Fifteenth Congressional District. Among the speakers who are expected to address the meeting are Charles S. Fairchild.

HALIFAX, Jan. 22 -- The steamer Chickahominy of the Chesapeake and Ohio Steamship Line, from Newport News, bound to London, came up the harbor to-day with a port list. She left Newport News Jan. 16, and ever since Wednesday experienced a continuance of northeast gales and heavy seas.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 -- The following is a list of the most important valuable collaterals belonging to the Stanford estate not in actual possession of Mrs. Stanford, with their values at the present market rate:

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- The funeral of Miss Helen Almira Shafer, President of Wellesley College, was conducted at the college chapel to-day as near as possible in accordance with her expressed wishes. All who had gathered in the chapel were closely identified with her in her college work, either as officers, instructors, or students.

The petition of the "Hawaiian Patriotic League." which the President has received from Minister Willis and which he submitted to Congress with other papers yesterday, rehearses again the familiar tale "of outrage and of wrong," and appeals once more to the "honor, integrity, and love of fair play" of the American Nation.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 22 -- Referee Keily has carried the day in regard to the conversion of chat twenty-thousand-dollar check into a twenty-thousand-dollar purse of actual money. He returned from a conference with Mitchell at 6:30 this evening, and immediately went to the Duval Club rooms by appointment.

Under the reference made by Judge Butler of the United States Circuit Court of Pennsylvania, a hearing was had before Special Master Crawford in Philadelphia yesterday on the petition of Isaac L. Rice, for the removal of the receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company.
"No quorum" again prevented the Park Commissioners from taking any action upon or opening the bids for the first section of the proposed Harlem River Driveway yesterday.

Preliminary argument was made yesterday before Judge Truax, in the Supreme Court, Special Term, in the suit of Amherst, and four other colleges, and many charitable institutions, to recover their proportionate shares of the residue of the estate of Daniel B. Fayerweather. James L. Bishop, for Amherst College, made the opening address.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The President to-day sent another message to Congress transmitting Hawaiian correspondence which was laid before the House at 1:15 P.M., and, on motion of Mr. Dingley, (Rep., Me.,) was read at once, with the inclosures. The President's message was as follows:

The exhibition of chain-lightning voting for which John Y. McKane's men have been quietly drilling for several weeks was given yesterday at the Gravesend Town Hall, in the presence of the Senatorial and Assembly Sub-Committees on the contested Kings County legislative election cases and of a small crowd of newspaper men.

Edwin H. Abbot, one of the defendants with Henry Villard in the case brought by John Swope of Philadelphia to determine the rights of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company to the railway station of the "Wisconsin Central Railroad Company in Chicago, filed his answer in the United States Circuit Court in this city yesterday.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The inquest into the fatal collision on the Hackensack Meadows, in Kearney Township, west of the drawbridge, on the morning of Jan. 15 was begun last night by Coroner A.J. Volk in the concert room of the Quartet Clubhouse. The room was crowded.

The British steamship State or Georgia, which sailed for Havre Jan. 17, yesterday put back to port, having met with a series of mishaps during her interrupted voyage. Bad weather was the cause of most of them, but it had nothing to do with the first casualty, which occurred soon after the vessel swung out from the Atlantic Docks.

Nearly every immigrant who reaches this country from Russia can tell a tale of wrong. There are now a number of these immigrants quartered on Ellis Island, and fifteen of them seem to have been wedded to misfortune.
ROME, Jan. 22 -- Dispatches from Palermo state that the disarming of the workingmen and peasants of Sicily is proceeding in an orderly manner.

There is a hitch in the proposition to form the Jockey Club, an organization which it is proposed to create to have supervision over the racing of thoroughbred horses on the race tracks of this State.

The family of Keeper Stewart of the Home of Industry and that of his sister-in-law. Mrs. Sarah Malcolm, who lives at 207 West Sixty-third Street, opposite the institution, are not on friendly terms. It is said that Stewart's sons, Charles and William, recently began a series of petty persecutions against their aunt.

That unusual interest is manifested in the great Brooklyn revival is demonstrated by the fact that meetings were held in nineteen churches and halls yesterday, and that there were interested crowds of men, women, and children at every meeting. During the day the following meetings were held: ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- United States Treasurer and Mrs. Daniel Nash Morgan gave a tea at the Elsemere this afternoon witth Mrs. John A. Morris for the purpose of formally introducing Miss Morris and Miss Morgan. The response to the invitations was general, and the large parlors were crowded with the friends of the two hostesses.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 22 -- A dispatch to The Independance Beige from the Congo Free State says that the German authorities in East Africa are partly responsible for the recent attack on Kassongo by the Arabs. In which Capt. Ponthler was killed. Rumalizu, the Arab leader, the dispatch adds, recruited his forces at Ujiji, under the eyes of the Germans, who did nothing to prevent him from obtaining as many men as he could.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The usual flood of resolutions appeared in the House to-night. Mr. Sulzer (Dem., New-York,) introduced a set calling upon the New-York State representatives in Congress to use their best efforts to advance the bill to repeal the election inspectors law. Having given rise to debate the resolution went over under the rules.

William T. Zell, Treasurer and Secretary of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company and Treasurer of the New-York Athletic Club, left his office in the Central, 143 Liberty Street, on Friday after President J.R. Maxwell had asked him to explain his private life, and he has not since been seen by his employers, family, or friends.
George A Pughe of 363 West Eighteenth Street found a diamond pendant valued at $1,000 at Fifth Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street on Jan. 5. It was broken into three pieces.

Wheeler H. Peckham is, one of the best-known lawyers in this city. He has won distinction in both civil and criminal practice. He is now a member of the firm of Miller, Peckham Dixon, which has offices in the Drexel Building, 29 Wall Street. In recent years his practice has almost entirely been confined to civil actions.
The seventh and last piece of cable for running the Third Avenue cars arrived at the Bayard Street power house yesterday afternoon. It is 22.084 feet long, and weighs 121.840 pounds, over 60 tons.

"Forget Me Not," the three-act drama by Messrs. Merrivale and Grove, which Miss Coghlan revived at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night, was very successful a dozen years ago at Wallack's, when Miss Coghlan played Stephanie for the first time, and its performances here later by Genevieva Ward also excited much Interest.

Although there was still pending, at adjournment, an amendment providing for the imposition of a duty on raw sugar, the report of yesterday's proceedings shows that the conclusions of the House with respect to the sugar schedule of the Wilson bill have been recorded and that the action which may hereafter be taken upon amendments still before the Committee of the Whole will simply confirm those conclusions.

Mr. Willard's Hamlet, seen for the first time in New-York by a small company of spectators at the Garden Theatre last night, will never inspire a painter, fascinate a sentimental young lady of title, drive a poet to hyperbole, occupy a chapter in theatrical history, or a niche in the dramatic pantheon.

"It was a clear case of hydrophobia," said Dr. Thomas Kelly of 357 West Fifty-seventh Street yesterday when asked by a reporter for The New-York Times whether the death of Michael Fitzpatrick, 600 West Forty-eighth Street, on Sunday night was due to hydrophobia or "nervous indigestion," as Dr. Alexander Buchanan, 358 West Thirtieth Street, diagnosed Fitzpatrick's symptoms when he called on him Saturday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- At the close of the afternoon session of the House there were probably not a half dozen members who could tell just what the Democrats had done with the sugar schedule, but almost everybody was convinced that what had been done by them would have to be done over again.

Work is the watchword. To give employment to the thousands whose Hands are now idle is acknowledged as one of the greatest boons that can be bestowed upon those who are in need. The east side of New-York has already an effective corps of citizens aiding the University Settlement society in providing a means whereby deserving persons may earn a return for a given amount of labor.

Joel O. Stevens, for many years connected with the Sheriff's office, and a well-known member and former officer of the Society of Tammany, died suddenly yesterday noon in his office in the County Court House.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- State Controller Roberts to-night transmitted to the Legislature the annual report of ex-State Controller Campbell for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1893.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The resolution offered last Thursday by Mr. Peffer (Pop., Kan.) on the subject of the notice for the Kan.,) on the subject of the notice for the issue of bonds, declaring that the Secretary of the Treasury had no lawful authority for issuing or selling such bonds, was laid before the Senate to-day, and Mr. Peffer spoke on it.
Few spirits attended Mrs. Ada Foye's public seance Sunday evening in Conservatory Hall, Fulton Street and Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. Some of the spirits that did go found no friends to welcome them.

In John D. Townsend's latest letter on asphalt, written in behalf of the independent county organization, he makes reference to Park Commissioner Clausen and his connection with the Sicilian Asphalt Paving Company. In reply Mr. Clausen has written the following letter:
Frederick A. Lovecraft laid the foundation, for one of the most interesting lawsuits on record when he made a will leaving his entire fortune to Col. Henry S. Kearney, his friend.

The stagre at Koster Bial's is rigged like a ship when Mile. Alcide Capitaine makes her bow. There is use for all the ropes and stays, for this agile young woman has a most wonderful propensity for hauttng herself overhead, steadying her body by twisting an arm or leg about a rope, and suddenly letting go with a flying leap.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- Local stocks sympathized with the general list and were strong in tone. West End Street opened at 48 1/2, 1 1/2 above Saturday's close, and declined to 48, recovering later to 48 1/4. It is said that President Little of the road reports that the gross earnings of the company have increased from $700 to $900 per day, as compared with the same period last year.

John Y. McKane, chief of the Coney Island Police, over whose head hang eleven indictments growing out of the election at Gravesend Nov. 7, was called up for trial in the Court of Oyer and Tenniner, Brooklyn, yesterday. He is first to be tried under the indictment charging him with misconduct as an election officer.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22 -- A young man who has been stopping at the New-Haven House since last Friday under the name of J.E. Lawrence of Utica, N.Y., committed suicide last night. He stuffed his handkerchief in the ventilator and plugged up the keyhole, and then, pulling the tips out of the gas burners, turned on the gas full force.

Six of the seven Good Government Clubs in this city met last night in Vienna Hall, the house of Club A, at 722 Lexington Avenue. The object of the meeting was the presentation to each club of a silk banner by an executive committee, consisting of Mrs. Joseph H. Choate, Mrs. R. Fulton Cutting, Mrs. Richard Watson Gilder.

At about the hour when lieutenants of Thomas C. Platt were giving their ideas to Speaker Malby in Room 10, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Sunday night, the committee appointed at Whitelaw Reld's dinner to prepare a new Police bill was having a conference of its own.

The announcement that Talmage has resigned the pastorate of the so-called Tabernacle of Brooklyn, by reason of the financial troubles of the meeting house in question, is in itself neither unexpected nor unwelcome. That a Talmage, after a certain lapse of time, would "play out"; that is a conclusion that every lover of civilization was bound to entertain.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- It was a good, strong market almost all day, and even at the declines at no time could it be called weak. St. Paul rallied in sympathy with NewYork, and many of the traders were scared into covering. The traction stocks sympathized with the strong tone of the market, Philadelphia advancing 3 points, to 96, at which price a very large block of stock changed hands.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The new and amended bi-partlsan police bill, approved and indorsed by all the Republican leaders in New-York City, is expected to reach here Wednesday Speaker Malby did not bring it up with him, nor does he know when it will appear.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 22 -- John Kull of Ridgewood attacked his wife with an axe to-night and then drowned himself in a cesspool back of his house. The couple lived over a saloon on Grove Street kept by a married son.
Money on call was abundant throughout the day at 1 per cent., and some borrowers obtained it at one-half that rate of Interest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The fallowing is the full text of the important sections of the Internal Revenue bill as laid before the full committee this morning and as subsequently amended by that committee in its session to-day:

As a rule the sales of (elected harness horses do not begin until well into the Spring, just before the regular road-driving season begins. The disposal of about eighty head yesterday at the American Home Exchange by W.D. Grand was, therefore, somewhat in the nature of an experiment.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- The advance copy of the annual report of the Railroad Commissioners of tale State to June 80, 1893, shows that there are 51 railroad corporations whose roads are situated wholly or in part within the State: there are 2,119 miles of main line and branch road; the aggregate capital stock is $186,440,422, an increase of $11,926,870; total amount of cash dividends on capital stock declared, $10,832,400; increase, $1,302,825.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- There was little life in the local stock market to-day, despite the more encouraging reports regarding the situation in the East. The market opened firm at about Saturday's closing quotations. A large share of the transactions was in small lots. West Chicago opened at 138 1/2, advanced to 139, but at once eased off to 138 3/4, with a few sales at 138 5/8, closing at the latter figure.

John Farrell, better known as "Red Rocks," has passed nearly half of thirty-seven years of life in prison, and he is now in danger of being imprisoned for five years more. Two months ago he was discharged from Sing Sing Prison, after serving a term of two years for drugging and robbing a man.

The news of Mr. Peekham's nomination attracted great attention when it reached the city. Mayor Gilroy, Richard Croker, Corporation Counsel William H. Clark, and Chief Clerk John F. Carroll of the Court of General Sessions were all in a group in the Mayor's office when, the news reached them.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Jan. 22 -- P.M. The system which the bears have been operating with fair success for some months failed to work to-day. According to the rules that have lately obtained in the market, a reaction from the signs of strength which the market has lately displayed was due.

Wheat advanced 3/8c on reports of cold weather West, better cables decreased stocks, and foreign buying, but declined 5/8c on increased Visible and weaker West, and closed weak art 1/4c under Saturday, with trading more active.

There was a large audience, appareled in garments more or less gleaming -- and often er more than less -- at the American Theatre last night, and for their diversion was presented a play whose title, the programme said, was "Poor Girls." As the same authority declared Guy de Maupassant to be the author of the piece, Us real name is in all probability something else.

MUNCIE, Ind., Jan. 22 -- Col. A.L. Conger, the millionaire manufacturer of Ohio, who is here looking after his manufacturing interests, in an interview to-day as to the prospects for manufacturers, especially in the iron industry, said: "Businesses fast improving throughout the country since the flrst of the year, and confidence is being restored.

The reception of Lillian Russell and Signor Perugini when they reached the Casino last night was an enthusiastic one. The company crowded around the newly-married couple and tendered congratulations and good wishes for the future of the pair. Their reception by the audience which crowded the Casino was even more demonstrative when they appeared in "Princess Nicotine."

From The London Telegraph. A haunted house at Arceuil Cachan, our Paris correspondent says, is now interesting the French police. Its tenant, Vicomte de Larnage. says that he has been for a whole month tormented with noises for which he can assign no material or other cause. A week after they began he made a complaint to the Commissioner of Police of the district.

There was an impromptu meeting on the sidewalk in front of Shipping Agent Quail's office, on South Street, yesterday morning, the participants toeing thirteen of the sailors from the Brazilian war ship Nictheroy, who were brought to this city from Southampton on Saturday by the American liner New-York.

The latest talk among the politicians who are seeking to make the Police Department of this city "non-partisan" by making the commission bi-partisan seems to be in favor of taking away the Bureau of Elections altogether, and otherwise reducing the functions of the Police Board by extending the powers of the Superintendent.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 22 -- There was genuine excitement this afternoon, when Wheeler H. Pecknam of New-York was named to the Senate for the vacancy on the Supreme Court bench, which Mr. Cleveland originally intended to be filled by W.B. Hornblower. It had been taken for granted that Mr. Cleveland would not lose any time in making a new nomination, but the gossips had not included Mr. Peekham in their calculations, and the surprise was general.
The Trustees of the Presbyterian Tabernacle of Brooklyn have abandoned President Leonard Moody's plan to charge 10 cents admission to hear the Rev. Dr. T. Do Witt Talmage preach on Sundays.
To the Editor of The New York Times: From the second column on the second page of The New-York Times of Jan. 15, I894, we quote the following:

It took a bright, warm, sunshiny day like yesterday to afford an observer an opportunity of judging how many people are out of employment in New-York City. The Springlike air had much the effect upon the crowded tenements that a May day has upon the Winter homes of insect and animal life.

For some time complaints have been pouring into the Mayor's office against the inspectors of Plumbing from builders and others. It has been claimed that these new officials have unnecessarily delayed work upon buildings by withholding permits for the plumbing work for various trivial reasons.

The householders in that exclusive part of East Sixty-fifth Street lying between Fifth and Madison Avenues are somewhat disturbed, not to say wrathy, over some real estate operations of Mr. John Jacob Astor.

William R. Grace presided at a rousing meeting in Madison Hall, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, test evening, to indorse the nomination of Isidor Straus for Congress. No better evidence of the interest felt by the citizens of New-York in the affairs of the country at large could be afforded than was manifested in this gathering.

NEW-YORK. Tuesday, Jan. 23 -- P.M. Improving conditions could not have been ter illustrated than in the course of today's market. The sympathetic relation that stocks bear to each other ought, if tration is to be observed, to carry the Several list along with a specialty of exciting interest.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 23 -- At the residence of Mr. Ed-ward Weeks, In Sandford Street, East Orange, Miss Elizabeth Harris, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Harris of Hoosick Falls, N.Y., was married this evening to Mr. John Young of the same place. The bridesmaid was Miss Bessie Mars of New-York, and the best man was Mr. John Hayes of Liewellyn Park.

The Manufacturers' Publishing Company of 150 Fifth Avenue has become insolvent, and yesterday John R. Huff was appointed temporary receiver, on the application of the Directors, to wind up the concern. The liabilities are $40,027, and the assets are given in the petition as only $1,888, and consist of stereotype plates, books, office furniture,

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The raid made on Lake Street "L" yesterday afternoon was continued to-day. The stock opened at 23, sold down to 22 5/8, and closed at 22 3/4. Alley "L" acted in sympathy, opening at 31 1/2, declining on big sales to 29 1/2, and closing there. The rest of the stock list was steady at about the closing prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The chief topic in the Senate wing of the Capitol to-day was the nomination of Wheeler H. Peckham to be an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court. A great many Senators expressed curiosity as to the attitude of their colleagues toward the nomination, and the subject was thoroughly discussed in both the Democratic and Republican cloakrooms.

A big kettle full of "fat" has been fried out for use in the campaign on behalf of Lemuel Ely Quigg in the Fourteenth Congressional District in this city. It Is used lavishly all over the district. From some sources cash has been contributed in such quantities that Mr. Quigg is enabled to make a campaign in which money is no object.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Secretary Carlisle's bond circular was issued at the Treasury Department to-day. It is as follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Senator Bradley made an argument this afternoon before the Senate Cities Committee in favor of his bill for the election of Aldermen in Brooklyn by wards. Instead of by Aldermanic districts. He said that before the district system was inaugurated the Aldermen used to be respectable, and jobs were never heard of.

The steamship Normannia, of the Hamburg-American Line, which sailed from this port Thursday, was struck by a great tidal wave at daybreak Sunday morning when she was 760 miles at sea. Yesterday she reached her dock in Hoboken, her bows all battered in, her deckhouse almost completely demolished, her furniture smashed to kindling wood, her cabins wrecked, and her decks strewn with the twisted and battered remnants.

Thomas C. Platt and Marsden J. Perry were appointed permanent receivers of the New-York and New-England Railroad by Judge Wallace of the United States Circuit Court yesterday. They were authorized to take immediate possession of the railroad and its property wherever situated or found. They are also empowered "to ascertain, with all convenient speed, the state, condition, and circumstances of the property and of the debts and liabilities charged thereon."

From The Paris Matin. "What a rascally set these Yankees! Individually they may be more or less honest but taken in a mass, or even in lots, they are a collection of fellows without scruples who go straightway, as fast as they can, caring little for those whom they disturb or even for those whom they crush on their road.

The examination of witnesses before the Master in Philadelphia in the proceedings brought by Isaac L. Rice for the removal of the Reading receivers, came to a somewhat abrupt ending yesterday, for the time being at least, owing to the inability of the officers of the company to furnish trustworthy figures upon which to proceed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- One of the members of the Louisiana delegation, speaking of the effects of the action of the House in striking off all duty upon sugar and abolishing the bounty, said that it would be disastrous.
Police Commissioner MacLean proposes to call Capt. Edward Slevln of the Fourth Precinct to account on a charge of permitting the existence of disorderly resorts in his precinct.

Tremendous impetus was given the campaign of Mr. Isidor Straus for Congress in the Fifteenth Congressional District last night. Incidentally, the canvass of Col. William L. Brown, the candidate for Congress in the Fourteenth Congressional District, received a boom.

Mrs. Burnham Warner of 37 West Twenty-fourth Street read in a morning paper yesterday an account of her action against the Imperial Chemical Manufacturing Company of 292 Fifth Avenue, to recover damages for injuries alleged to have been received through improper treatment of her hair with hair dye.

In the Trinity Building Salesroom yesterday Messrs. Smyth Ryan sold, by order of executors, the five-story brick, stone, and iron factory building 151 Crosby Street, east side, 64.10 feet north of East Houston Street, 25 by 104.6 by 25 by 101.11. The property rents for $4,000 under an old lease. Its easterly end will probably front on the widened Elm Street.

At noon yesterday Miss E. Henrietta Graves, daughter of the late Robert Graves of Brooklyn, was married to James J. Faye in Trinity Chapel, West Twenty-fifth Street. The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix performed the ceremony.

That there is necessity for the speedy issue of the $50,000,000 of 5 per cent, bonds, as proposed by Secretary Carlisle, is emphasized by the great decrease in gold payments at the Custom House since the plan of cash payment of duties was substituted for the former method of certified checks. Yesterday was the second day of cash payments, and the following table of receipts is in many ways interesting:

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Mrs. Connell, by moving to-day from 19 Fillmore Street to a house on the opposite side of the road, has given great joy to Mrs. Povey and Mrs. Lytell, who live at 19 1/2 and 23 on the same street. Flags are flying at the windows of 19 1/2 in celebration of the removal, and at 23 there has been, dancing, beating of tin pans, and other demonstrations of rejoicing.

The scehdules of N.J. Schloss Co., clothing manufacturers at 653 and 655 Broadway, were filed yesterday by Simson Wolf, the assignee. They show direct liabilities of $1,178,423, contingent liabilities of $132,851, gross nominal assets of $933,992, net nominal assets of $777,751, gross actual assets of $682,543, and net actual assets of $541,077.

Archbishop Corrigan is in the midst of another fight against a portion of his flock. This time the insurrectionists are a large body of Polish Roman Catholics, who, at a recent meeting, declared that they would "teach the Archbishop his place, and fight him clear up to the Court of Appeals for justice."

Renwick Hall, formerly known as Parepa Hall, at Third Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, was crowded last evening with enthusiastic German-American citizens, who had assembled in mass meeting to indorse the nominations of Isidor Straus and William L. Brown for Congress from the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congressional Districts, respectively.

It is not surprising that the nomination of Mr. Wheeler H. Peckham for the Supreme Court is "personally objectionable" to Senator Hill. It would be very surprising if decent citizens in the Senate or elsewhere found in that fact any evidence of Mr. Peckham's disqualification for the court.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- The old Van Rensselaer mansion, fronting the Hudson on the banks of East Greenbush, was transformed into a floral treasure house today. There was witnessed, a union of two of the oldest Dutch families in the country. The bride was Katherine Westerlo Van Rensselaer, daugthter of Mr. Visscher Van Rensselaer.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- Baron Marschall von Bieberstein, Minister of Foreign Affairs, in conversation in the lobby of the Reichstag to-day, said that Emperor William recently sent Prince Bismarck a case of wine through Count von Moltke, his Majesty's aide de camp. The Emperor also sent an inquiry as to the health of the Prince.

The second day of the trial of John Y. McKane, indicted for misconduct as an election officer, resulted in four more jurors toeing secured. When court adjourned, at 6:45 o'clock last evening, nine were in the box. They are:

The Police Commissioners received a communication from the City Improvement Society yesterday, informing them that the officers of the society would willingly present to any representative of the department the evidence in their possession that carriage drivers are compelled to pay policemen a fee of 50 cents for the privilege of breaking into line at the big balls.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 23 -- The situation here is rabidly developing comic opera characteristics, with a sub-element of tragedy. As to that remarkable purse and the check which represents it, they are, beyond all else in the situation, mysterious. The rumors regarding them come with as unvarying regularity and with about as great frequency as the waves of the ocean.

The following letter, relating to the great religious revival now progressing in Brooklyn -- a revival in which the pastors and congregations of many churches are actively engaged -- will doubtless be read with interest not only by churchgoers but by people generally who are in sympathy with any movement intended to benefit humanity:

Members of the Goethe Society spent a few very pleasant hours last night listening to an address by Prof. W.T. Hewett of Cornell University. His subject was "The Niebelungen Lied and Its Representation in Modern Art."

A. J. Levy, clothiers, on Broadway, near Eighth Street, failed in November 1892, with liabilities of $180,000. Yesterday Jacob Levy was held in $2,000 bail in the Essex Market Police Court for examination on Feb. 1 on a charge of having made false entries in the books of the firm so as to defraud the creditors and to cover misappropriation of money and property.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The new non-partisan Police Board bill is expected here to-morrow or Thursday. Up to date Mr. Platt's friends and his opponents preserve a marvelous silence concerning it. Speaker Malby and President Pro Tern. Saxton of the Senate have each heard that such a bill is under way, but when questioned feign an ignorance worthy of Mr. Platt and his worthy lieutenant, Louis F. Payn.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times. Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The Senate to-day passed the two buncombe resolutions which were adopted by the House last night condemnatory of the Wilson bill and the Hawail business. Some of the Senators had a lively tussle over pronouncing the word Hawali. Senator Collins called it "How-are-ye," Senator Owens "How-way-i," Senator Congreeshall " Hah-wah-e," and Senator Cantor hit it close with "How-why-e".

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The prosecution in the Cronin murder case has within the last three days obtained some startling evidence. It Is that Coughlin was seen in the immediate Vicinity of the Carlson cottage at the time of the preparations in that house for the murder of Dr. Cronin.

The letter of President Seth Low upon the proposition for a "non-partisan" Police Commission of four members is especially interesting and valuable as coming from a man who has not only given especially careful study to the theory of our municipal institutions, but has had experience in their practical working.

Samuel A. Beardsley, Michael Rickard, and Alfred C. Chapin, composing the State Board of Railroad Commissioners, heard arguments in the Chamber of Commerce room in this city yesterday for and against the amalgamation of the New-York and Northern Road with the New-York Central system.

The Ihpetonga Ball, which is to Brooklyn what the Patriarchs dance is to New-York, took place last night in the Assembly Rooms of the Academy of Music, Montague Street, Brooklyn. The Ihpetonga organization consists of sixty men, each of whom moves in the most exclusive social set of the City of Churches.

ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 23 -- The police of this city have been conducting a quiet crusade against the gambling dens and policy shops, and have already closed several places. The citizens of Orange had no adequate conception of the amount of gambling here, especially among the hatters, until about two years ago The New-York Times published a statement about the matter.
Wheat lost 1/4@1/2c for the day through local liquidation, foreign selling, lower cables, and weak West, with trading more active.

When Richard W.G. Welling became the assignee of Francis H. Weeks, who is now serving a ten-year term in Sing Sing Prison for having embezzled over $1,000,000 of trust estates, he found included in the assets which came into his possession, a bond and mortgage for $9,000 made by John G. Folsom.

An advertisement in yesterday's papers offered the reward of $60 and "no questions asked" for the return of a false tooth, in which was set a valuable diamond, which was lost by the owner in the lobby of one of the city's variety theatres on Sunday evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- The drive at Sugar at the opening of to-day's market encouraged traders to hammer Lehigh Valley and Pennsylvania. The latter stood the test much better than the former, which, on comparatively light sales, declined to 39. There seems to be a growing feeling of distrust against the present management of Lehigh Valley.
" It has been pretty clearly established that Mr. Zell is a defaulter, possibly to the extent of $10,000."

Railroad men generally concur in the popular opinion that every possible safeguard -- mechanical and otherwise -- should be adopted by all the railroads to prevent collisions. While many railway managers may agree with President Samuel Sloan of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western that a man is better than a machine, they also believe in the machine as a coworker with the man.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Two things were decided clearly in the House to-day. One was that its action yesterday, when it adopted the Warner proposition for free sugar, should stand, and the other was that coal should remain on the free list.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The Inter Ocean (Rep.) has the following editorial comment on the selection of Wheeler H. Peckham for the vacancy in the Supreme Court of the United States: "This appointment is generally interpreted, alike by the President's friends and his opponents, as a direct slap at Senator Hill, and very likely that was the motive, but it is none the less true that the selection was a good one.
MONTREAL, Jan. 23 -- A peculiar event has taken place at Three Rivers, viz., the blessing of a newspaper office. The Triflurlan, the journal interested, thus refers to the event:

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Wheat made another lowwater-mark record to-day. May selling at 63 1/2c, the lowest point in the history of the trade. There was no great effort used in depressing the price, and no extraordinary selling was noted. As a matter of fact, at the opening trades were made as low as 63 5/3c, from which may be seen that it was the sentiment that made the record.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Not the least entertaining feature of the meeting of the Senate to-day was the impassioned plea made by Mr. Chandler in behalf of pure elections.
The following plans for new buildings have been filed with the Building Department:

The recent order of Secretary Carlisle prohibiting the use of certified checks in payment of Custom House duties is creating much excitement among all the importers in New-York. They all declare that the old method was a perfect one, and that the new scheme has already put them to no end of trouble and actual anxiety.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- It is reported that Gov. Werts has asked Attorney General Stockton to file an information before Chief Justice Beasley as a basis for quo warranto proceedings in the Superior Court to settle the Senatorial dispute, and that the Chief Justice has been requested to call an extraordinary session of the court to settle the question.

Company F of the Seventh Regiment had their innings at the armory range last night in the annual company team competition for the Kemp Trophy. They were the seventh team to face the butts, and to stand any show to win the coveted trophy the boys of Company F had to roll up a score of better than 1,073, the record that Company B's team made last Thursday night.

The latest of the appointments of Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn is among the best. He has named Mr. William Harkness of the Twentieth Ward as President of the Department of Assessments. Mr. Harkness has taken no active part in politics, though we believe that he has usually acted with the Republican Party.

After all, the farcical show of rapidfire voting at the Gravesend Town Hall on Monday served a purpose. The legislative committees that allowed it to be got up and gravely attended the exhibition under the pretense that it was evidence in a contested-election case made themselves ridiculous, but still they got some idea of the Gravesend way of holding elections under the direction of John Y. McKane.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Representative Thomas Settle, the young Congressman, from North Carolina, has bean placed in an embarrassing position by a personating double of his who has been masquerading under his name in New-York City. This individual, Mr. Settle is informed, registered on Jan. 11 at the Gilsey House in New-York as the Hon. Thomas Settle of North Carolina, and up to the time he left New-York used Congressman Settle's name.

New-York lawmakers will be called upon at the present session of the Legislature to consider a bill authorizing the formation and maintenance of free public employment bureaus. The act proposes that the Commissioner of Statistics of Labor establish in all cities having a population of 75,000 or more a free public employment office, where applicants for work as well as would-be employers may obtain information and aid.

It is stated that Miss Anna. Gould. youngest daughter of the late Jay Gould, has become engaged to William M. Harriman, son of the late Rev. Edward Harriman and brother of Edward Harriman of E. H. Harriman Co. He is also a nephew of Oliver Harriman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Representative McCreary, Chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, has prepared, and to-day introduced into the House, a resolution defining the attitude of Congress toward Hawaii. The resolution was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and will recive consideration at Thursday's meeting.

The special meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission was held yesterday further to consider the proposition made by R. T. Wilson Co., representing a syndicate that ready to build the underground railroad a practically the plans of the commission made public some time ago, and for the construction of which no capitalists had apeared with a substantial backing, up to the appearance of the Wilson syndicate, a week ago.

A bold attempt to liberate a prisoner in Jefferson Market Police Court was made yesterday, and it would, have been successful but for the alertness of Court Officer Gardner, who was in charge of both the male and the female prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Secretary of the Navy and Miss Herbert gave a Cabinet dinner to-night. The President and Mrs. Cleveland were unable to be present, owing to the death of a nephew of the former, whose funeral took place to-day at Hartford.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- Local stocks were dull and without special feature. American Bell Telephone opened at 179 3/4, and declined on small sales to 178. Investors are apparently beginning to realize that the price has been too high, in view of the difficulties which must soon occur from threatened competition.

-- The Authorship of "Poor Girls." -- The original German play, from which "Poor Girls." now running: at the American, was adapted, was written by Messrs. A. Philip and Neumann. It is said that they got the idea from, a sketch by Guy de Maupassant, but there is nothing in the play even remotely suggestive of that brilliant French writer.

Helena Modjeska, who is acting this week at the Park Theatre, in Brooklyn, will begin a fortnight's engagement at the Fifth Avenue Theatre next Monday. Her supporting company includes Otis Skinner and some other competent actors. The principal new piece in her repertory is "Magda," a translation by Charles Bozenta of Sudermann's much-discussed play, "Heimath."

The three-story brick building at First Avenue and Nlnety-fourth Street, occupied by Hencken Co., dealers to kindling wood, was badly wrecked by a fire which started in the drying kiln at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. The fire spread so rapidly that two alarms were sent out. The rest of the block is occupied by coal and wood yards, and these were several times in danger.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 23 -- The twentyfourth annual meeting of the National Board of Trade opened at the Shoreham this afternoon. There were present representative of twenty-five of the constituent bodies of the board. The venerable Frederick Fraley of Philadelphia, who has been the President of the board since 1868, was again unanimously re-elected.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 19, (via Montevideo, Jan. 23.) -- On the night of Jan. 15 the insurgents recaptured Mocangrue Island, with three small cannon and 130 prisoners. The killed and wounded numbered fifty. The insurgents lost fourteen killed. The insurgent war ship Aquidaban brought to Rio Bay 600 men, who now occupy Conzeicao and Mocangue Islands.

Victor Edmond Regnier. Victor Edmond Vital Regnier died in London yesterday. He was a celebrated equivocal personage of the Franco-Prussian war. He was born in Paris in 1822. At twenty he was a student of law and medicine, at twenty-two a physician at the military hospital of Lille.

The story that the new play written by Sardou for Charles Frohman is based on situations furnished the French playwright by Augustin Daly for a drama ordered for his company, is indignantly denied by Mr. Frohman. Speaking on the subject to a New-York Times reporter yesterday. Mr. Frohman said:

Henry Carque, the confectioner of 282 Bleecker Street, whose place was on fire Jan. 16 and who was remanded when he was arrested for arson, was held for the Grand Jury's action yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court. He will have to furnish $5,000 bail to secure his liberty pending the action of the Grand Jury.

Ex-Congressman Henry G. Burleigh of Whitehall walked through the corridor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night, wearing a new suit of clothes. It was a black cut-away and vest, and light gray trousers with a stripe. The suit fitted Mr. Burleigh to a nicety. The trousers were creased to an edge.

A cable received yesterday by Mrs. Philip A.H. Brown of 120 West Seventy-second Street, announced the death yesterday in Venice, Italy, of Constance Fenimore Woolson, the authoress. No information as to the cause of death could be obtained. Miss Woolson had been abroad for several years.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Sixteen of the eighteen Republican Senators were in caucus for nearly three hours to-night in the Senate library. The absentees were the two Republican Senators from Kings, Owens, the accident, and Reynolds, and Senator Bradley, the independent Senator from that county, who was invited to take part in the proceedings, but declined.

Brooklyn Republicans have long threatened revolt against the State leadership of Thomas C. Platt. Opposition to his management Is now more aggressive than ever before. Hostility to his plans and intentions has assumed various forms. The principal centres of resistance are in the King's County party organization and the legislative delegation.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 24. -- The situation to-night is this: State Circuit Judge Call has grafted the Duval Club an injunction restraining the Sheriff of this county, from interfering with an entertainment in the nature of boxing contest which the club proposes to hold on the fair grounds to-morrow Corbett and Mitchell have arrived from the training quarters and are resting quietly in their hotels.

Rossini's study in vocalization, entitled "Semiramide," was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the second time this season. An audience of respectable size sat through the performance, and applauded each of the principal numbers with great enthusiasm. It is not likely that any one takes "Semiramide" very seriously in these days.

There is a point in connection with the nomination of Mr. Peckham that Senators who have not immediate knowledge of the facts may be apt to overlook. It will be admitted that the successorship to Judge Blatchford "belongs" to New-York, and that his successor ought to be a New-York lawyer of high standing who is also a Democrat.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 24. -- There was a war of arguments in the United States District Court here this afternoon when the thrice-postponed hearing on a permanent receiver of the New-York and New-England Railroad for Connecticut opened before Judge W.K. Townsend.

The officers of the Fidelity and Casualty Company are confident that in a few days they will have William T. Zell, the defaulting Treasurer and Secretary of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company, safe behind prison bars. When it was found on Saturday that Zell had disappeared, and that his accounts were short at least $10,000, the company whose money he had squandered looked to the Fidelity and Casualty Company to make good the shortage.

Members of the Rapid-Transit Commission had a secret session yesterday afternoon of two hours and a half, at which the subject under discussion, was the proposition of the Wilson syndicate to build an underground railroad on the lines of the plan which the commission has already made public.

The Park Board opened thirteen bids for the first section of the Harlem River Driveway yesterday, and demonstrated that, while two sidewalks will probably be built, the Commissioners are still much wrought up over the question.

Italians of both sexes began last week to pass a very bad, greasy counterfeit of the silver quarter of the new die of 1892. and Tuesday night Stefano Chieto and Fanny and Annie Carravelli made what is known as a "rush" in Hudson Street.

There is a bill now pending at Albany which offers what seems to be an acceptable compromise between the advocates of a speedway pure and simple and the advocates of a speedway that shall also be an addition to the park system and one of our municipal ornaments. The bill has the sanction of the Mayor and has been accepted by all persons interested in the subject merely as enlightened citizens.

A pistol, as well as threats of excommunication, seems to have figured in the troubles between Archbishop Corrigan and the priest of the Polish Church of St. Stanislaus on the one side and the members of the church who belong to the Allgememe Verein on the other. An account of the trouble was published exclusively in The New-York Times yesterday, and members of the church corroborate the story.

It was a very curious meeting that was held on Tuesday in the Mayor's office, Brooklyn, at which the question of the speed of the trolley-cars and their running was discussed. There were present the representatives of all the chief car lines, a couple of representatives of the employes' union, and two experts, members of the Subway Commission, of whom Prof. Plympton was one.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The Cabinet calls were more generally made this afternoon than at any previous time during the present season, although the weather was not the best for those intent upon making the rounds Mrs. Stevenson, at the Normandle, received in a gowm of black velvet (brimmed with jet passementerie, and about the throat was a fall of point lace.

New-York's streets, with the various forces at work in sweeping them, should, not so unclean. The regular city department now has the aid of societies on both sides of town, and in certain sections the thoroughfares are as free from cert as a ballroom floor.

The thirteenth annual report of the business of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association, just published by President Edward B. Harper, shows that the gross assets of the company increased during the year 1893 from $4,785,286.06 to $5,138,516.36. The reserve, or surplus emergency fund, it is stated, was increased within the past twelve months from $3,371,303 to $3,589,326.18.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 24. -- Dr. J.B. Hinkle of Americus, who is Speaker Crisp's family physician, and his son, A.B. Hinkle, who is also a physician and his father's professional partner, are on trial before the Superior Court of Sumter County for murder. It is charged that they killed Dr. A. W. Worsham, who was one of the best-known p hysicians of the State.

BOSTON, Jan. 24. -- Some activity was shown in local stocks to-day. Dominion Coal showed considerable strength, opening at 20, 1/2 point above the last quotation, advancing to 21, and receding to 20 1/3 at the close. There was some bullish talk on it. Bell Telephone opened at 178, declined to 177, and closed at 178.

Miss Carola Livingston, daughter of Johnston Livingston, was wedded at noon yesterday to Count de Laugier-Villar of Paris. They were married in St. Patrick's Cathedral, which was filled with their guests.

Litigation over the Chasebrough millions, which have been fought over in the courts for about twenty years, has been revived. An important question was before Surrogate Fitzgerald yesterday in proceedings to compel Charles A. Chesebrough, Sr., who lives in Northport, L.I., to render an accounting to Mrs. Mary Brandes, a young woman who alleges she is his granddaughter.

The long promised French version of "The Timing of the Shrew," made by Paul Delair, was presented carefully and capably at Abbey's Theatre last evening. It is a short play, in four act of one scene each, and much of it is written in fluent, graceful Alexandrines. It is no mere translation, either in language or spirit, and is as little as possible Shakespearean.

The Legislature of this State is in the middle of the fourth week of the session, and it has done practically nothing thus far and shows little disposition to do anything that is required by the public interests of the State. Its lack of progress shows the disadvantage of running a Legislature from the outside.

Collector Kilbreth started for Washington yesterday for another consultation with the Treasury officials in regard to the form of the payment of duties at the Custom House, not knowing that Assistant Secretary Curtis was coming to New-York to consult with him on the same subject. Possibly he was advised of Mr. Curtis's departure from Washington while on the train; in that case he naturally would have given up his journey.

The Trustees of the Brooklyn Tabernacle will meet to-morrow night. It is expected that they will order an investigation of the financial administration of ex-Treasurer John Wood, who is accused by James W. Birkett, the present Treasurer, of being short in his accounts to the amount of $21,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- There is a strong probability that some arrangement will be reached whereby the benefit of the check system in the payment of customs duties will be secured by importers with resulting safety to the Collector of Customs at the Port of New-York.

Wheat declined 1/8c early, on easier cables, foreign selling, and light clearances, advanced 1/4@3/8c on reports of cold weather West, light receipts, firmer West, and higher cables, closing firm at 1/8@1/4c over yesterday, with trading more active.

Miss Gertrude Travis and Mr. Francis Draper Bowne were married yesterday afternoon in St. George's Episcopal Church, in Flushing, L.I. The bride is a daughter of Edward Montague Travis, and the bridegroom belongs to one of the oldest Long Island families, and is a grandson of Walter Bowne, who was Mayor of New-York City in 1830-33.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- At the meeting this morning of the Ways and Means Committee the Internal Revenue bill was ordered reported to the House. The vote by which the report was directed to be made was interesting, as indicating the existence of Democratic opposition to the individual income tax which is proposed to be levied to make up for deficiencies of customs revenues.

Uncommon interest attaches to the sale to-day of the Hotel de Logerot property, at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street. The parcel is a large one and is the biggest offered under foreclosure on the avenue in many years. Mme. de Logerot paid $460,000 for the property in June, 1891.

Corporation Counsel Clark has received information from Albany that the Court of Appeals has rendered a decision in the case of the Thurber-Whyland Company in favor of the city which will have an important bearing on the taxation of foreign corporations doing business in New-York. The amount of capital invested in these corporations is over $14,000,000.
The revival meetings of the Union for Evangelistic Work which have been held in many churches in Brooklyn are to be continued all next week, and perhaps for a longer period.

As we have already remarked, the confident offer of the Wilson syndicate to construct an underground rapid-transit railroad substantially on the routes laid ant by the commission two years ago and more, provided two-thirds of the cost shall be advanced on the credit of the city, is especially significant as evidence of the belief on the part of practical and experienced capitalists that the plan is a feasible one and would prove profitable.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- An important decision has just been given by the Court of Appeals, affirming the decision of Justice Williams of the Supreme Court. Fourth Department, which was upheld by the General Term, in declaring unconstitutional the law allowing women to vote for School Commissioners.
