ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Hereafter the Senate of the State of New-York will operate under closure. The conclusion was reached after a half hour's conference between Republican and Democratic leaders in Lieut. Gov. Sheehan's room and a two hours' debate on the floor. The conference was interesting.

The movement now going on in Brooklyn for the reorganization of the Democratic Party is one of the most important in the history of politics in the highest States, not only because the motives of those engaged in it are of the highest, but because it is a sincere and energetie effort to apply to party organization a principle of the widest scope and of the greatest promise.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24. -- In the absence of support, Philadelphia Traction reacted 4 per cent. and Metropolitan 1 per cent. The demand for "Western New-York and Pennsylvania Junior securities is a feature just now. The buying comes from the inside, and is evidently based on the expectation of a market to follow the reorganisation.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 24. -- The funeral of Police Commissioner Henry E. Hastings, at which his uncle, President Cleveland, was present, was held at Mr. Hastings's residence, 71 Elm Street, at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The services were conducted by the Rev. Dir. George Leon Walker, pastor emeritus of the Ceniter Church, assisted by the Rev. Charles H. Williams.

Mrs. Laura Schirmer Mapleson, wife of Col. Henry Mapleson, died yesterday at the Everett House of pneumonia, which followed an attack of influenza caught on the stage of the Pittsburg Opera House Jan. 13. She was unconscious several hours before her death. Her husband and Dr. Valentine Mott were with her when she died.

It is the intention of those interested in the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company, which has for its object the construction of a bridge over the North River at Seventieth Street, to immediately draft a new bill, authorizing the construction of the bridge in such a maner as to meet the objections raised by President Cleveland in his veto of the original measure.

Not tall -- long -- long as 1 cent's worth of thread, with eyes that incessantly winked and a monumental beard that made his countrymen think of Barbarossa and of Unser Fritz, M. le Vicomte Paul d'Abzac, French Consul General of France at New-York, has returned to Paris. Perhaps he is not to come back.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The resolution reported yesterday from, the Committee on Foreign Relations against the consideration at present of any project of annexation of the Hawaiian Islands to the United States was laid before the Senate to-day, and Mr. West (Dem., Mo.,) offered the following substitute for it:

BOONE, Iowa, Jan. 24. -- The building on the Boone County poor farm used as an insane asylum was burned down last night and eight of the nine inmates lost their lives. The fire broke out about 10 o'clock, and when discovered was under such headway that nothing could be done to save the unfortunate inmates in the building.

Harper's Magazine has an excellent collection of fiction in the number for February. It contains five-short stories-one of Mr. Matthews's Manhattan vignettes; an American story on Italian soil by Miss Woolson, entitled "A Transplanted Boy"; one of Richard Harding Davis's Van Bibber tales, entitled "An Anonymous Letter"; a story of the French Revolution by William McLennan entitled, "An Adjustment of Accounts," and "The Flower of Death," a sketch by Flavel Scott Mines.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 24. -- Miss Caroline Louise Holzer, a well-known teacher in the public schools here, and popular in society, was, at 6 o'clock this afternoon, married to Williaan Hamilton Donogh of New-York, foreman of The New-York Times composing room. The wedding took place at St. Paul's Church.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- The cold wave fell flat on the wheat market to-day. There was a little hope left in the hearts of the bulls, that the long talked of fall in the temperature and freezing weather would work sufficient injury to the growing plant to cause apprehension as to the quality and quantity of the yield, with a resultant advance in prices.
Mrs. Mary A. Millen, a motherly-looking woman, with, old-fashioned gray curls falling over her forehead, went into the Tombs Police Court yesterday and said to Justice Martin:

Lemuel Ely Quigg, the Republican candidate for Congress in the Fourteenth District, has buckled, on his armor in the expectation of violence at the polls on election day. All that threats of violence can do to kelp on his cause while the ballots are being cast wlil be done.

In the recent run of the Montgomery, the last and fastest of the three 2,000-tonners, over the Long Island course, next to her splendid feat of beating her contract requirement of 17 knots by two full knots, her good fortune in just exceeding the mark required for earning a bonus of $200,000 is worthy of mention.
"It is surprising what mistakes even some of the best people in the world make." The speaker was one of the greatest doctors the world has ever known.
Honest Brooklyn Democrats cordially commended yesterday the address of the provisional Committee of One Hundred touching Democratic reorganization in Kings County.

After three days of constant fishing with every kind of bait known to the law, a Jury was yesterday hooked to the Court of Oyer and Terminer, in Brooklyn, for the trial of John Y. McKane for aiding the election officers of Gravesend in folding the registration lists from William J. Gaynor's copyists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- It is evident right away, in the matter of the nomination of Mr. Peckham, that Senator Hill is confident that he will be able to defeat his confirmation, because he will have the assistance of the same Senators who voted with him in rejecting Mr. Hornblower's name.

The anti-machine Republicans last night gave out an analysis of the plan adopted by the Bliss Committee of Thirty, in which they point out their objections to the proposed scheme of organizing the party in this city. Over their signatures Mr. Milholland's provisional committee members explain in detail why they are "anti machine" Republicans.

BELGRADE, Jan. 24. -- The following Cabinet was announced to-day: Prime Minister, Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Ad Interim Minister of Finance -- M. Simitch; Minister of Public Works -- Gen. Zdravkovics; Minister of the Interior -- M. Nicolaisvics; Minister of War -- Col. Pavlcowics; Minister of Commerce and Agriculture -- Prof. Lotanics; Minister of Justice and Ad Interim Minister of Education -- M. Ojorgievics.

Copyright 1894, by the United Press. PARIS, Jan. 24. -- Many Deputies, most of them supporters of the Government, are fretting under the Parliamentary obstruction caused by the innumerable interpellations and the repeated demands for urgency. They have decided, therefore, to propose a reform of the Parliamentary procedure.

Albert J. Weber, manager of the Weber Piano Manufacturing Company, was examined yesterday before Referee James Ninon in supplementary proceedings to collect a note of $300 which he had given to Leo Von Raven about four years ago. The examination took quite a lively turn when Lawyer Lehman, who appeared for the plaintiff, began to put questions to Mr. Weber which the latter apparently considered as irrelevant to the case in hand.

From The Westminster Gazette. Miss Shaw justified her position as the first woman lecturer on Australia by calling attention to an aspect of the colonizing outlook which specially affects women. In visiting the homesteads of Australia, she was often struck, it seems, by finding "young men engaged in washing dishes, scrubbing kitchen tables, feeding the fowls, and attending to the flower garden."

From The Westminster Gazette. "Were we tired of the show? Well, yes, we were very glad when the time came to take away our exhibits, and our special train -- the first English one on American lines -- was ready to start. They told us our engine would never be ready to start. But we got up steam, and she came up twenty minutes too soon.

The bill introduced in the Assembly pensioning employes of the Health Department who have contracted contagious diseases while in the discharge of their duties provides for a fund, differing from that of the Police, Fire, and Park Department Pension Funds in that the beneficiaries are to be not only those that may be unfitted for duty by long service, but those incapacitated by dangers encountered in protecting the residents of the city from contagious diseases.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24. -- Reports received this week from various parts of the State show that there is certainly a better feeling among manufacturers, in spite of the unsettled condition of affairs as to the tariff.

From The Detroit Tribune. Not many wedded lives extend to the length of three score years, and few married couples live to celebrate the sixtieth anniversary of their wedding, as Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Morin of Hull, Ontario, did on Thursday, Jan. 18. The celebration began with high mass at the cathedral, after which the aged couple renewed their nuptial vows before Father Lauzon.

A big meeting was held at Lenox Hall, Seventy-second Street and Third Avenue, last night, under the auspices of the Reform Club and the New-York State Democracy of the Twenty-second and Twenty-fourth Assembly Districts. The hall was crowded. Not half those who wanted to get in succeeded in doing so.

BROCKTON, Mass., Jan. 24. -- Fire broke out in the City Rink, on Main Street, just after the polo teams left it to-night. A strong wind was blowing, and the flames spread-rapidly. This building was directly in the heart of the city, and it was early seen that all the blocks between Centre Street and Green Street to the north of the rink were in great danger.
NIAGARA FALLS, Jan. 25. -- The first practical test of the hydraulic tunnel, which has been under construction in this city for the past three years, was made at 11 o'clock this morning.

PERRY, Oklahoma, Jan. 25. -- The Democratic Statehood Convention, which met here yesterday, contained representatives from every county in the Territory, the delegates being leading men of the party and prominent business and professional men of their localities. Though there were differences of opinion on minor details, upon the main question there was great unanimity.
BARCELONA, Jan. 25. -- Ramon Marrull, an Anarchist workingman, tried this afternoon to assassinate R. Larroca, Civil Governor of Barcelona.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The second card reception by the President and Mrs. Cleveland, given to-night in honor or the Congress and the Judiciary, was well attended. The rooms on the main floor were decorated elaborately, as they were for the diplomatic reception, and a large company of those who arrived early saw the President and Mrs. Cleveland come down the inner stairway to pass to the Blue Room.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Secretary Carlisle addressed the House Judiciary Committee to-day upon the subject of his proposed bond issue.
Money on call loaned throughout the day at 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The Hawaiian resolutions having been laid before the Senate, they were laid aside in order that Mr. Allen (Pop., Neb.,) might address the Senate on the resolution offered by him last Thursday declaring that the Secretary of the Treasury was not clothed, under existing law, with any legal authority to issue and sell bonds, and that any such bonds, when issued, would be null and void.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The firm stand taken by the President in the appointment of Wheeler H. Peckham to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, has stimulated the opposition, under the leadership of Mr. Hill, to increased and desperate efforts to defeat Mr. Peckham.

Undoubtedly the German newspapers are right which insist that there is no directly political significance in the conciliatory invitation of the Emperor to Prince Bismarck to visit Berlin as his guest at the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Emperor's entry into the German Army.

More than ordinary interest attached to the realty transactions yesterday, both at public and private sales. At auction, in the Trinity Building Salesroom, the crowd groaped around the stand of Messrs. Richard V. Harnett Co. when the Hotel de Logerot property was offered showed how much attention the result of that sale attracted.

There is a bit of rivalry between the two national organizations in the Republican Party over the question of which is entitled to be the head and front of the party for the next year. The organizations are the National Committee, of which Thomas H. Carter of Montana, is Chairman, and the National Congressional Committee, of which John A. Caldwell of Ohio is the Chairman.

BOSTON, Jan. 25. -- Another drop in Bell Telephone was the feature of to-day's market. The stock opened at 177 and declined to 174, and, although not a large quantity of the stock was sold, it appeared to be too much for buyers. From the source of the selling it would seem as if long stock were coming out, and from insiders at that.

No one who has kept track of the proceedings relative to the affairs of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company will need assurance that the story which was started by The Philadelphia Press yesterday that Mr. Isaac L. Rice had determined to abandon the proceedings against the present management is absolutely false and without the slightest foundation in fact.

If it is ever justifiable to reverse the result of an election on account of frauds in registration and voting, it is so in the contested election cases against Senator McCarty and Assemblyman Graham, whose respective districts include the town of Gravesend. But how little the judicial spirit prevails in dealing with such cases is indicated in the reports about the attitude of Senators Reynolds and Owens of Kings County toward the McCarty contest.
"Great inroads" were made last night into the Republican organization by the anti-machine Republicans. John E. Milholland gave his word for this.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Representative Dunphy (Dem., Ky.,) and Representative Geary (Dem., Cal.,) have prepared a bill which was to-day submitted to the House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce. This committee has under consideration the President's message vetoing the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill, and it is expected that the committee will favorably consider the measure offered by Messrs.

The Senate Committee on Foreign Relatic's, which is still thrashing over the old straw of the Hawaiian "resolution" of last Winter, had an interesting witness before it yesterday in the person of Dr. Stalker of Des Moines, who passed last Winter in a visit to the Hawaiian Islands and was in Honolulu during the "stirring events" which resulted in the provisional Government and the consequent complications.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Unless objections by those most concerned shall be encountered in New-York to-morrow, the plan for facilitating the payment of customs duties by importers submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury to-day by Collector Kilbreth of New-York, will be put into operation.
ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners received the following letter to-day from President Cleminshaw of the Troy City Railroad:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Miss Cornelia Bradford, a sister of the Rev. Amory H. Bradford, the Congregational clergyman, announced that she will shortly start in the pawnbroking business in Jersey City.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 25. -- The police and hospital authorities have got into a row over Miss May Barrowcliff's case. As a result, Capt. Lange, in whose precinct Miss Barrowcliff was injured, has been denied admission to the hospital.

The troubles of Fire Commissioner John Ennis, who was suspended from duty by Mayor Schieren for promoting firemen, wasting the funds of the Fire Department, and not maintaining discipline in the department, are not ended. His conduct as Fire Commissioner for the last eight years is to be investigated.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- The majority members -- Senators Pound and Mullin -- of the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections have agreed upon a report in the contest of Henry Wolfert against Senator John McCarty, (Democrat,) of the Sixth (Brooklyn) District, which includes the County of Richmond, a portion of Brooklyn, and the towns of Gravesend, Flatbush, Flatlands, and New-Utrecht.

A large meeting of Presidents and Managers of the important trunk lines, East and West, was held in this city yesterday, and the new agreement recently formulated by the General Passenger Agents was approved. This agreement provides for a fair distribution of competitive business among the different lines on a system of varying rates, and it applies to passenger traffic both east and west bound.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The House Committee on Foreign Affairs to-day, by a strict party vote, authorized Mr. McCreary (Dem., Ky.,) to report favorably his resolution defining the attitude of Congress toward Hawail. The resoultion reads as follows, and will probably be reported to the House to-morrow:

The opposition in the Democratic Party to the transfer of bituminous coal and iron ore to the free list has attracted much attention because the paragraphs relating to these products lay at the foundation, so to speak, of the Wilson bill's revision of the iron and steel schedule, and also for the reason that the noise made by the objectors was out of all proportion to the number of them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The cast-steel shell made by the Johnsons of Spuyten Duyvil, New-York, has met with so much success in recent tests at the Naval Proving Ground that it is likely that it will be distributed to ships of war as ammunition for big guns in place of the vastly more expensive forged-steel shot.

The preparations reported to be going on in England for the reinforcement of the garrison of Egypt cannot be said to be either premature or extravagant. Nobody can be prepared seriously to maintain that it would be better either for the Egyptians or for mankind at large to have the British garrison withdrawn and the country remitted to the control of its native rulers, either under the suzerainty of Turkey or without that supervision.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The National Board of Trade at its morning session today adopted, by a vote of 31 to 11, a resolution favoring such modification of the immigration laws as will admit, under agreement, professional men and women and technically expert artisans as instructors. It also adopted a resolution in favor of the appointment of an expert monetary commission.

Fiery black eyes, a tremendous forehead crowned by a brush of coarse black hair standing up straight and fierce as if it were wire, a broad face. immense shoulders and hands, a voice calculated to strike terror to the most obdurate sinner -- and there is Father Strezleski, the Polish priest.
The Greater New-York Commission met it 11 o'clock yesterday morning in the office of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company, 214 Broadway.
ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Gov. Flower to-day sent the following message to the Legislature:

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 25. -- The Attorney General has announced that he is not ready to file his bill of information in the quo warranto proceedings Gov. Werts has ordered him to bring against the eleven Republican Senators, to find out by what right they claim to constitute the Senate of New-Jersey.

Legal complications and quibbles over law points multiply as the case brought by a number of colleges to recover a portion of the residuary estate of Daniel B. Fayerweather proceeds before Judge Truax, in Special Term of the Supreme Court. A score or more prominent lawyers were in attendance at the sessions yesterday, each on the alert to score a point or shut off any possible advantage to be gained by an opponent.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 25. -- Edward M. Clark, who was internally injured in the recent wreck on the Delaware. Lackawanna and Western Railroad on the Hackensack Meadows, died in St. Mary's Hospital here early this morning. His death makes the thirteenth resulting from the accident.
"Well, I'm inclined to enter into a stipulation to recognize the correctness of these figures."

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Lake Street Elevated was the active stock to-day, as it has been for several days, but the range was disappointingly narrow, being only 3/4 of a point. Opening sales were at 22 1/2. From this figure the market dropped 1/4, rose 3/4, and finally closed at 22 3/4. Alley L, ranked second in point of activity, opening 1/4 lower, at 28 1/2, and subsequently ranging irregularly downward to 27 7/8.

John Eichler, the first lawyer convicted of blackmail in this city, was surrendered by his counsel yesterday afternoon and taken to the penitentiary by Deputy Sheriff Burke to serve a term of eighteen months' imprisonment.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Attorney General Hancock gave a hearing to-day in the matter of the application of John H. Ellsworth of Prince's Bay, (Republican and independent Democrat,) that he bring an action in the nature of a quo warranto to test the title of office of County Clerk of Richmond County, now held by John J. Kenny, regular organization Democrat.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Two hundred men and women who are prominent in the movement of municipal reform assembled at the Art Club this morning, when a twodays' session of the National Conference for Good City Government began. The hall was prettily decorated with evergreen and flags and bunting.

Excise Commissioner John Schliemann's method of conducting business in the department over which he has ruled with an iron will for the last six years is at last being exposed. Now, when he has only a few more days to serve the people of Brooklyn in his peculiar way, Mayor Schieren is making it unpleasant for Schliemann.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 25. -- A largely attended indignation meeting to discuss the recent disaster on the Morris and Essex division of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad was held at the Montclair Club last night, and a committee was appointed to confer with the Directors of the Lackawanna Road, urging them to adopt a block signal system on the Morris and Essex division at once.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 25. -- The day of prayer for schools and colleges throughout the United States was observed in Princeton to-day by appropriate exercises. The devotional services of the day consisted in an address by Dr. Gregg of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn. He also preached a sermon in the chapel at 7:30 P.M.

Two big meetings to advocate the election of Isidor Straws to Congress at the special election next Tuesday, were held in the Twenty-sixth Assembly District, which is in the Fifteenth Congressional District, last night. One was at Fischer's Dancing Academy, Third Avenue and One Hundred and Seventh Street, under the auspices of Tammany Hall.

Special elections will be held next Tuesday in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congessionial Districts in this city, to elect successors to Col. John R. Fellows and Ashbel P. Fitch, who were elected respectvely District Attorney and Controller of this city at the last general election, and who resigned their seats in Congress on that account.

Another important move was made yesterday in reference to the proposed Harlem River driveway. The bids, based upon the specifications calling for one sidewalk only, and that on the inner side of the driveway, were opened at a special meeting of the Park Commissioners, and James D. Leary was found to be the lowest bidder, at $620,916.10.

The body of the late Commodore Caldwell H. Colt arrived at Jersey City at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, in charge of Lieut. William Henn, Royal Navy, and Mr. A.F. Camacho, who were with Mr. Colt when he died at Punto Gordo, Fla. The body was received by Mr. John Hall, Vice President of the Colt Arms Company of Hartford; James Moore, George A. Cormack, and Randolph Hurry.

The first detailed account of the recent abortive efforts of some malcontents to over-throw the rule of President Heureaux of San Domingo was had yesterday, when the Clyde Line steamship Saginaw arrived in port. The vessel is from San Domingo and Turk's Island. On board were two passengers from the latter point and an American engineer, who embarked at Maeovis.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 25. -- James J. Corbett defeated Charles Mitchell of England to-day, winning the title of champion of the world and receiving $30,000, the purse and stakes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Peckham has the highest qualifications for being a Justice of the Supreme Court; yet his nomination has a far greater significance than this fact gives it. It presents an issue involving the constitutional independence of the President, the growing usurpations of the Senate, and the counter-poise and stability of the national Government itself.

F. Henry Greer of "the International Press Department of the London and Hartford Publishing Company of Jersey City," known sometimes as the London, New-York and Hartford Publishing Company, is "at it" again, although, for reasons that may be surmised, his address is secret, and, like him, the headquarters of his company cannot be found, in any directory.

The work of the police in taking a census of the unemployed is handicapped by the not unnatural reticence of many of them who shrink from telling their woes. They are laborers and artisans who formerly made good wages, lived comfortably, and felt the independence that such conditions engender.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Representative Sibley (Dem., Penn.,) has sent his resignation to the Governor of Pennsylvania as a member of Congress, to take effect Feb. 17.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- "Mr. Croker is in the Speaker's room and would like to see you."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Several Senators received through the mails yesterday a small green pamphlet, of the National League for the Protection, of American Institutions. The objects of the association, are "to secure constitutional and legislative safeguards for the protection of the common-school system and other American institutions and to promote public instruction in harmony with such institutions, and to prevent all sectarian and denominational appropriations of public funds."

BOSTON, Jan. 25. -- Messrs. Platt and Perry, the newly-appointed permanent receivers for the New-York and New-England Railroad, who are in this city, talked freely with a newspaper reporter last evening in regard to the proposed management of the company's office. Mr. Platt said: "I do not see the reason for the popular impression that, because the New-England has been unfortunate, it must pass into the control of the New-Haven Road.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 25. -- State Treasurer Gray will present his annual report next Monday night. According to his figures, it cost $1,857,982.83 to run the State Government in 1893. The disbursements of other years were: In 1892, $1,698,405.70; in 1891, $812,696.45; in 1890, $1,639,142.97; in 1889, $1,440,005.

A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce to consider what action, should be taken to secure good municipal government is in itself an event of no small importance. It shows an appreciation on the part of the commercial community of the intimate relation of the business interests of the city to the proper management of its public affairs.

One of th largest audiences that ever assembled in the Forthy-second Street Central Baptist Church collected there last night to follow Prof. Albert S. Bickmore in his "Flight Into Egypt." It was the third in the series of illustrated studies on the life of Christ which the professor is giving, and it proved as interesting as the two that have preceded it.

William Whiting Newell. A cable dispatch from Paris, France, announces the death there, on Jan. 23, of the Rev. William Whiting Newell. Among his early pastorates were the Forty-second Street Presbyterian Church in this city, and the First Presbyterian Church of Newburyport. Mass.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- Bismarck is to arrive in Berlin to-morrow to pay his visit to Emperor William. It has been arranged that the special train conveying the Prince shall leave Friedrichsruhe at such time as will allow it to arrive here to-morrow afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The Treasury Department will begin business Friday, Jan. 26, with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- In the fourth week of the session of the Legislature now drawing to a close nothing of importance has been done in either house, unless it may be considered important that the dissensions in the Republican Party, which came in power with an easy working majority in both houses, have been greatly intensified.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 25. -- The third annual meeting of the Building and Loan Association League of New-Jersey was held in the Assembly Chamber at the State House to-day. There were seventy-five delegates present. President De Witt Van Buskirk presided.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- The tone of the local market was rather weak at declining prices. Although St. Paul was very strong for a few minutes after the opening, the local securities did not sympathize much with it. Since Philadelphia and Metropolitan Traction have been so dull they have been inclined to sag off.

T.W. Higginson in Harper's Bazar. I recall with pleasure my very last interview with Miss Elizabeth Peabody, it was so thoroughly characteristic of her. In a furious snowstorm, about six years ago, I found myself at the windiest corner in Boston -- that corner at which the late Judge Russell thought that a, shorn lamb should be kept always tethered.

A young woman known as Mrs. Hopkins, who has lived for several years with an Italian named James Greco, in a rear house at 64 Franklin Avenue. Brooklyn, was found dead in her bed at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The circumstances attending her death led to the belief that she was poisoned.
John Y. McKane sent a telephone message to William J. Caynor Oct. 30:

Among the signs of returning commercial prosperity there is none more significant than the reassuring condition of the dry goods trade throughout the country. The Dry Goods Economist has made a thorough canvass among all large dealers in dry goods, and from every section the most gratifying reports have been received.

Two questions of very great importance present themselves to the Democrats of the House: Shall the income tax be put into the Tariff bill? Shall the Tariff bill, with the income tax in it, be passed? Beyond all doubt it would be a very grave political mistake to join the tax to the bill. The tax is very unpopular in States without which the Democrats cannot hold a majority in the House.

Mrs. Isabella Wheeler, wife of Albert H. Wheeler, a well-known broker at 80 Broadway, was taken ill last evening in a Madison Avenue street car. She was at once removed to the house of friends near by and physicians were summoned, but she died in less than an hour. The cause of death was heart disease.
LONDON, Jan. 26. -- The newspapers here, in their comments on the priza fight in Florida yesterday, express no sympathy with Mitchell in his defeat.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- For the first time in many sessions the trading in industrials was the feature of the market. The movement in general was not cheerful for the holders of these stocks, although Diamond Match was active and in very fair demand at 5/8 higher than the price of yesterday. American Strawboard and Street's Stable Car held most of the attention.

The "National Conference for Good City Government," which closed its two days' session in Philadelphia last evening, was, on the whole, most promising and successful. The papers that were read were clear, intelligent, and full of careful and accurate information. The crank who is liable at any moment to break in upon deliberations on any subject of reform was conspicuous by his absence.

The new freight agreement, recently devised by the general freight officers of the railroads in trunk line and Central Traffic Associatlon territory, was approved yesterday by the managing officers of the roads interested, in practically the same manner that the new passenger agreement was aparoved on the day previous.

The attention of the Maritime Exchange has been called to the fact that vessels arriving at Cuban ports, particularly from South and Central America, are heavily fined for failure to have their manifests and bills of health vised by the Spanish Consul at the port of departure. A fine of $300 is imposed for such omission, and there seems to be no way of avoiding its payment.

Not everything, it seems, of the peculiar transactions of Thomas C. Brewer, or John C. De Austin, the enterprising young man who "organized" the Pontiac Bank, has yet been told. In the Harlem Police Court yesterday Lawyer A.J. Westmayr of 99 Nassau Street accused him of circulating forged certified checks.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 26. -- The Traction Company ran out only ten cars to-day, and each made one trip, all being in the stables before dark, as it was feared that the new men would be roughly handled in the suburbs.

The most important -- in fact, perhaps the only -- feature among chess players the past week was the acceptance of Lasker's terms by Steinitz as regards the amount of stakes in the forthcoming championship chess match. When Steinitz declared his willingness to play for $2,250 a side he stipulated certain conditions as regards the stakeholder and referee, which Lasker accepted, and nothing will prevent a great struggle over the checkered board.

The taking of testimony in the contest which Seth Wilks, the defeated Republican candidate for the Assembly in the Fifteenth District of this city, is making against Adolph Schillinger, the Democratic candidate who was declared elected by a majority of 371, was continued yesterday before Assemblymen Terry, McNamee, and Vacheron.

The efforts of Lemuel Ely Quigg to "smash the Wilson, bill" go merrily on. He will continue to say, in pamphlet and circular, "Stop! This bill of wreck and ruin must go no further," and will continue to kiss and pet the children of voters until the 30th of January, when the "smashing" and the kissing will cease simultaneously.

W.S. Keiley, for many years. Docket Clerk in the Court of Common Pleas, was removed by Judge Pryor yesterday as assignee of the firm of Charles C. Reed Co., the Williamsburg varnish and paint manufacturers, who made a general assignment about two years ago. Lawyers Frederick and Edwin Ward made the applicacation in behalf of Frederick W. Blossom, one of the preferred creditors.

Senators Reynolds and Owens were roundly denounced among Republicans in Brooklyn yesterday, and especially in the Seventh and Twenty-third Wards, for their refusal to enter the caucus in Albany called to consider the unseating of Senator John McCarty.

A new bill has been prepared authorizing the construction of a bridge across the Hudson River by the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company under the charters which have been granted by the States of New-York and New-Jersey. This is in the hands of the House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce, to which the President's message vetoing the former bill was referred.
Money on call loaned throughout the day at 1 per cent.

There was considerable speculation yesterday as to a visit by Assistant District Attorney Lindsay to Police Headquarters. It was said Mr. Lindsay had called on Superintendent Byrnes regarding a case of alleged blackmail, in which Mrs. Lucy McCarthy, the keeper of a disorderly house, was the complainant, charging a prominent politician with extorting money from her for "police protection."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Ever since the Federal Elections bill was reported in the Senate Mr. Chandler has been devising ways and means to postpone action upon it. He proposed a few days ago to Mr. Gray, who had the bill in charge, that the final vote upon it Should not be taken until next December.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 26. -- The Grand Jury this afternoon began an investigation into the alleged attempt to bribe the Coroner's jury that is investigating the recent accident on the Delaware, Lackawanna, and Western Railroad, by which thirteen persons were killed. The witnesses examined were F.W. Bender, foreman of the Coroner's jury; Adolph Laukering, one of the jurors, and Augustus Seide, who first publicly made the charge that bribery had been attempted.

Dun's Review will say to-morrow: Secretary Carlisle's decision to issue bonds and the early reports of large bids for them helped to accelerate recovery of industries and trade, as was hoped last week. Sale of the amount offered will check anxiety about maintenance of note redemption, remove the only pretext for further issues of paper, and thus give a solid basis for greater confidence regarding the financial future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Richard Croker is still in Washington, and the gossip concerning his presence continues to cover a wide range. Mr. Croker did not go to the Capitol to-day, and the income-tax Democrats who were so much exercised yesterday over his occupancy of the Speaker's room were not given any fresh spasms.

CAIRO, Jan. 26. -- The Khedive has acceded to the demand made on him by Lord Cromer, British Diplomatic Agent here, that he publish a formal retraction of the strictures he recently passed on the army and issue an order praising its condition and the efficiency of the British and Egyptian officers.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- In the Senate to-day the question on the adoption of the order offered yesterday by Mr. Monk, that "the Board of Railroad Commissioners be requested to inform the Senate what proceeding's have been taken to lease, purChase, or control the Old Colony Steamboat Company, ," occasioned some debate.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 26. -- Corbett was unable to leave to-day as early as he had expected. All the men who were arrested yesterday for being connected with the prize fight were notified that there were errors in the bail bonds furnished yesterday and that they would have to appear in court at 10 o'clock and new bonds would have to be furnished.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- On reassembling this morning the National Board of Trade passed a resolution favoring the adoption of an American system of Naval Reserves. A resolution was also adopted declaring that the completion of the Nicaragua Canal had become an imperative commercial necessity, and favoring the passage of the bill on that subject introduced in the Senate by Senator Morgan.

Justice Barrett of the Supreme Court yesterday denied the application of Cardinal Gibbons and the other Trustees of the Catholic University of America, situated at Washington, for leave to mortgage its property in this city to J.B. Kissam for $40,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- The local stocks did not fully respond to the strength in New-York, but opening prices for the railroad stocks were decidedly firm. There was a continued disposition to hammer Philadelphia Traction, and the people who usually support that stock showed a disposition to stand aside and let the quotations take care of themselves.

The police of the Charles Street Station have a case on hand about which they decline to furnish any information. Their investigation of it so far has led to the arrest of a cab driver, whose name is recorded in the blotter as John Woods of 228 Chrystie Street. He was arrested Thursday night of the Desbrosses Street Ferry, The arrest was made by Detectives Brennan and Quinlan.

It cannot be denied that the depth and force of the "so-called religions revival" in Brooklyn -- "so-called" only by the flippant -- is attracting a great deal of serious attention, even from those who are not openly attached to religion. It is like the unsuspected flow of some great subterraneous river, the existence of which was hardly suspected, and which was disclosed to view only by a sudden and uncontemplated accident.

What the attorneys who appear for the colleges claiming a portion, of the residuary estate of Daniel B. Fayerweather consider an important factor in sustaining their views was brought out in the further examination of Thomas G. Ritch, one of the re -- siduary legatees, before Judge Truax, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, yesterday.

"Corbett wins" was the news brought by the wires from Jacksonville Thursday afternoon. To our thinking this is a matter of no importance since, to paraphrase the remark of the Shah of Persia, it was already well known that one brute could pound harder and himself stand more pounding than another brute.

Mrs. Mary Arians, a Syrian missionary, was caught between the guard rails of the Grand Street elevated station and a northbound train on the Sixth Avenue line, at 6:10 o'clock last evening, and was crushed so badly that death is likely to ensue.

An evening newspaper published yesterday a sensational account of an illness of Actor Charles Coghlan. An attack of hiccoughs lasting forty-two hours following a dinner at Delmonico's, a hasty summons of a doctor, and a message to Rose Coghlan informing her that her brother might die during the night were some of the features dramatically set forth.

Simson Wolf, assignee of N.J. Schloss Co., obtained from Justice Pryor of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday an injunction restraining Joseph Henry Louis, the former clerk of the firm, from disposing of any property purchased with money embezzled from the firm. It is alleged that Louis was for many years in charge of the office.

The deplorable dispute in the House yesterday about the proposed duty on precious stones calls attention to the duty itself. Probably nobody will dispute that precious stones are entirely proper objects of taxation, and that they ought to be subjected to whatever duty will produce the greatest amount of revenue.

FLUSHING, L.I., Jan. 26. -- The Schuschart homestead, which is said to have been built in 1663, was destroyed by fire during last night. The house was situated on rising ground overlooking Flushing Bay, and was one of the landmarks of this section.

From The Washington Post. Gen. Joe Shelby, who has been here for ten days, called on Gen. Schofleld at Army Headquarters Monday. Shelby commanded a cavalry brigade in Price's army during the raid in Missouri, and often came in unpleasant contact with the troops commanded by Gen. Schofleld.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The Postmaster General to-day appointed commissions to make a thorough investigation and report on the needs of the New-York and Chicago post offices. The commissions will enter at once upon their work, so that the changes and improvements recommended by them may be put into effect with the beginning of the next fiscal year.

Alois Feldman, thirty years old, and August Neiderman, thirty-two years old, two of the most expert counterfeiters who ever strove for wealth by counterfeiting the coins of the United States Government, were arrested at 157 Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, by James Scanlan, Chief of the United States Detective Service for the District of New-York, who was assisted by Brooklyn policemen.

One of the largest meetings held in Isidor Straus's canvass as Democratic candidate for Congress in the Fifteenth Congressional District, was held last night at the Tammany headquarters in the Twenty-fifth Assembly District under the auspices of the Tammany organization of the district, of which Deputy Street-Cleaning Commissioner John J. Ryan is the leader.

"The distress among the unemployed poor seems to be growing worse," a reporter for The New-York Times was told yesterday at the offices of the charitable organizations. Secretary Milbury of the Industrial Christian Alliance said yesterday he had been told by the Rev. John B. Devins of Hope Chapel that from all appearances the poor on the east side would need assistance for the nest ten weeks at least.

NEW-YORK. Friday. Jan. 26 -- P.M. The trading to-day was again confined to the professional element. There was slight activity and higher prices at the opening on London buying, but business became very flat at the end of the first hour, and prices receded.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- The second day's session of the National Conference for Good City Government this morning was well attended. James C. Carter of NewYork, the Chairman of the conference, called the gathering to order and introduced the Rev. Washington Gladden of Columbus, Ohio, who read an address on "The Influence Upon Officials in Office."

Ellsworth C. Williams, alias Dr. Williams, alias Gen. Swords, who is about eighty years old, and has flowing hair, gray beard, and military cloak, was sentenced to two years in the penitentiary by Recorder Smyth in the General Sessions yesterday. He had pleaded guilty to an indictment charging him with issuing bogus drafts on a bogus deposit supposed to be in the Bank of the Republic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Postmaster General and Mrs. Bissell gave a dinner to-night in honor of the President and Mrs. Cleveland and the Cabinet. The decorations were in violet and white. The centrepiece of lilies of the valley, imbedded in moss and surrounded with asparagus vines, was flanked at either end of the table by squares of double Parma violets, tied about with ribbon the same shade as the flowers.

Judge Freedman of the Superior Court yesterday passed upon the liability of the Trustees of a corporation for the debts of the corporation in dismissing the complaint in the action brought by James B. Witherow to recover from John D. Slayback, Charles M. Raymond, and Frank B. Robinson $11,000 upon a claim admitted to be due by the Port Henry Steel and Iron Company of Port Henry, N.Y.

Michael Curtin was taken to the insane pavilion at Bellevue yesterday afternoon from his rooms over Emanuel Dumler's crockery store, 203 Alien Street. Before he went he finished up several months of eccentricity by the general demolition of all available articles in his room.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- In the presence of a distinguished company of ladies and gentlemen, which included Vice President Stevenson, and Gen. Schofield, Dr. Zeballos, the Argentine Minister to the United States, on behalf of his Government this afternoon presented to the Memorial Association of the District of Columbia a beautiful water-color painting commemorating the action of the Argentine Republic on the occasion of the death of Abraham Lincoln.
From The Buffalo Courier, Jan. 22. When Governor of New-York Mr. Hill discussed the abuse of the confirming power. Among other things he said:

The Seventh Regiment company competition for the Kemp Trophy was finished last night at the armory range, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. The twenty-five men of Company H. were the last to face the targets, and though the boys of Company F were not expecting to have their lead for the trophy wrested from them, the score last night at 200 yards of 521 helped to keep the interest alive to the end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Income-tax Democrats and opponents of the income tax on the Democratic side were serious to-day. Reflection over the caucus proceedings of yesterday produced the feeling of concern that was manifested, and which was a sort of confirmation of Mr. Wilson's declaration to the caucus that the addition of the income-tax provision to the bill put the measure in peril.

Frank Raymond has joined hands with the Platt-Milholland anti-machine Republicans. At a meeting of many Republican residents of the Twenty-seventh Assembly District last evening Raymond resigned the Chairmanship, and Donald McLean was elected in his place. Henry Grasse and James B. Keyser were elected delegates from the organization of the provisional County Committee to be held in the Cooper Union Feb. 9.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The alterations in the gunboats Machias and Castine will be made at the Norfolk Navy Yard because Secretary Herbert has decided that the weather at that place is more favorable for ship repairs at this time of year than at either New-York or Boston, where there was some talk of doing the work.

Friendly criticism of the Erie Railway reorganization plan, supplemented by some suggestions, has been embodied in a circular letter to the Directors of the company. The signatures to the circular are Kuhn, Loeb Co., August Belmont Co., Hallgarten Co., E. H. Harriman Co., Vermilye Co., and Charles J. Peabody, a representative of the Astors.

The Executive Committee of the Coney Island Jockey Club was to have met yesterday to formulate an answer to the letter recently received from Mr. John Hunter of the Horse Owners' Association. In this letter Mr. Hunter asked the Coney Island Jockey Club to state on what terms it was willing to become a member of the new organization.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 26. -- The backbone of the hatters' lock-out is probably broken, and there is little doubt that al the eighteen factories that have been closed for nine weeks against the unions will be running independently next week on full time and with almost as many of their old employes as they care to take back.

Among those who read in The New-York Times yesterday the account of how F. Henry Greer of the "International Press Department of the London and Hartford Publishing Company of Jersey City " tried to collect numerous bills which were promptly repudiated was Henry Romeike. It was not the first time that the name of Mr. Greer had figured prominently and unfavorably in print.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The War Department has finally relaxed its secrecy about the militia reports, and they will be made public at an early day. When the reports were handed in by the regular army officers who visited the militia encampments last Summer, they were referred as usual to the Inspector General of the army and the made arrangements to have them incorporated in his annual report.
BERLIN, Jan. 26. -- In the history of Germany this will stand as a red-letter day, because to-day occurred the final act in the reconciliation between Emperor William II. and Prince Bismarck.
A well-known firm of real estate brokers has made an offer of $500,000 for the Academy of Design property at the northwest corner of Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street.
The Prohibitionists and temperance people of Brooklyn are considerably excited over the report that saloon keepers are to be allowed, under the new administration, to open their side doors on Sunday.

At the Metropolitan Opera House last evening the audience had an opportunity to compare a contemporaneous Italian opera with one of a fashion now fading away. Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci" and a part of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammennoor" were performed in the same order as named. Owing to the fact that the great lyric soprano, Mme.

Corporation Counsel Clark has received from Albany the full text of the decision of the Court of Appeals in the case of Company in regard to the taxing of pany, in regard in regard to the taxing of foreign corporations. The decision sustains the city on every point, and is far more sweeping than was at first supposed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- The execution in the County Jail this morning of George H. Painter, formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y., for the murder of his mistress, Alice Martin, was attended by a horrible scene. When the trap was sprung, the rope snapped in two, and the unfortunate man, who weighed over 200 pounds, dropped eight feet to the stone floor of the corridor.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- Judge Colt of the United States District Court here to-day appointed Thomas C. Platt of New-York and Morsden J. Perry of Providence permanent receivers of the New-York and New-England Railroad, for the district of Massachusetts, and ordered, them to furnish $100, 000 bonds.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Westfield was 100 years old yesterday, and the public-spirited citizens of the town loyally celebrated the important event last evening at a large banquet at the Westfield Clubhouse. Despite the inclemency of the weather the spacious hall was well filled. Persons prominent in the State and Nation were present.

This is emphatically a season of accessories. The main ingredients of women's toilets -- the skirt, coat or cape, and bonnet -- show little variation. The first must be plain and full, the second show abnormal sleeves and billowy skirts, or, if a cape, the same amplitude must be maintained, and the third toe very tiny, or, if a hat, very large.

Tyndall and I had long been zealous students of Carlyle's works. "Sartor Resartus" and the "Miscellanies" were among the few books devoured partly by myself and partly by the mighty hordes of cockroaches in my cabin during the cruise of the Rattlesnake, and my sense of obligation to their author was then, as it remains, extremely strong.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Strawboard was the conspicuous feature of the market. Opening at 29 1/2, it dropped to 29 on heavy selling, caused by the dissatisfaction among the Directors and with the management of the company.

Mrs. Harriet Henderson, who for a long time eluded and defied the process servers in their endeavors to serve a summons on her to appear in supplementary proceedings, made her appearence before Referee Julius Lehman at his office yesterday. She was fashionably attired and wore expensive jewelry.

BARCELONA, Jan. 3 -- One hears a great deal about Spanish slowness and laziness, in there can be but very little traveling and about the country without having those two characteristics brought very prominently into view. To this general reputation Barcelona forms a very prominent exception, and one can readily realize the applicability of the term, the Yankeedom of Spain which has been applied to this city.
The present system of making cycling records one day and lowering them the next is attacked by a writer in Boston Sport, who wants the pacemaker done away with. He says:

About a year ago the representatives of the farmers in the Minnesota Legislature were induced by that pestilent demagogue Ignatius Donnelly to support and enact a bill requiring the State to erect at Duluth a wheat elevator having a capacity of 1,500,000 bushels, to construct railroad tracks that should serve this elevator, and in other ways to undertake the business of storing and handling and shipping wheat, in competition with private enterprises of the kind.

The situation in Brooklyn is very striking. Before the court of highest jurisdiction in the county there is on trial under numerous indictments the most conspicuous and arrogant of the "Bosses" who two months ago believed that they held the voters of the city and county by a grasp as firm and cruel as that of any despot of the world over his subjects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The majority of the members of the Republican Senatorial political committee met to-day in the rooms of Senator Hale for the purpose of discussing the bills providing for the admission of the various Territories to the Union. The discussion was protracted, and when the meeting adjourned the committee, it is said, had agreed upon its line of action only so far as the Territory of Utah is concerned.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The recent death of Gustav Robert, an eccentric and noted odd wine merchant, whose cellar, at 116 Washington Street, this city, contained $30,000 worth of the rarest and costliest liquors, has caused earns peculiar legal complications.

Roughly speaking, burglars practice either as housebreakers or warehouse burglars. In the case of the last, the iron safe is the object of attack, and as the watchman is either absent, decoyed away, or an accomplice, the implements used are of the largest kind, and their use not unaccompanied by noise.

The closing prices yesterday, as compared with the week before, showed fractional changes for the majority of stocks; while a few only, were higher or lower to the extent of one point or more. It may be said, therefore, that the market, which is very narrow and consequently professional, has about maintained the advance made in the preceding week.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- The Hon. Theodore Runyon, the American Ambassador, has been busy all the week attending ceremonial functions. On Monday and Tuesday the ladies and gentlemen of the Imperial Court, under orders from the Emperor, issued in accordance with custom, waited upon Mr. Runyon at the Embassy in Thiergarten Strasse.

Lieut. John J. Conway, Gunners George Lewis and Robert Bennett, and ten sailors from the crew of the dynamite cruiser Nictheroy, which was recently fitted out in this port for service under the Brazilian flag, arrived here yesterday on the Ems, from Southampton. The men left the Nictheroy at Pernambuco, and, being unable to obtain direct passage to the United States, returned by way of Southampton.

After all, the play of the week was next "Hamlet," but "Poor Girls," that is, assuming that in a week which has more than one play one of them must be remembered afterward with an unusual degree of pleasure, which is not always the case. Under the ministration of Mr. Willard, "Hamlet," which never before seemed to be without charm, became, like life to the Danish Prince, dull, stale, flat, and unprofitable.

BAHIA, Brazil, Jan. 3 -- The United States revenue steamer Grant reached this port today after a run of little more than fifteen days from the Barbados, West Indies, New Year's Day, while the steamer was bowling along under all sail and with engines moving at full speed, the machinery suddenly refused to do its duty.

It will be a great surprise and a source of sincere regret to the parishioners and attendants at St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, at Broadway and Vesey Street, to learn that the Rev. Dr. James Mulchahey intends to resign his charge after completing twenty years of service there as minister.

The past week has witnessed a gratifying increase in the business of buying and seMng real estate, as the announcements made from day to day in the columns of The New-York Times showed. These proved, furthermore, that the activity is not confined to any one section of the city, but is general in its character.

Constant Coquelin was fifty-three years of age last Tuesday. If New-York had the exuberance of a Latin town its compliments to him might be more ornate, but they would not be more heartfelt. He has been celebrated for thirty years as a great player. He is the excellent comedian of the present time.

The task Mr. Adams has chosen is to follow, step by step, those processes which culminated in the conditions we have to-day. He begins with the time "when the barbarian warrior supplanted the Greek philosopher and the Roman statesman." Where or when the first seeds of civilization were sown will never be discovered.
Cesar Daly. The death is announced in Paris of Cesar Daly, architect and author.

There may be good reasons for the issue of 3 per cent, ten-year Government bonds in denominations as low as $20, as provided for in Representative Cummings's bill, but such an issue would not constitute a popular loan for the reason that the masses of the people-the wage earners and people of small means generally -- would not buy the bonds.
The first week of the trial of John Y. McKane for conspiring to hide the registration lists of Gravesend was concluded yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, Brooklyn.

PINE BUSH, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Millard I. Bloomer and George Croker of New-York City, while following a pack of hounds cross country to-day, were thrown from their horses by a barbed-wire fence. They were picked up unconscious. Their horses were severely cut. Both men are being cared for at Howell's farm.

ORANGE, Jan. 27 -- The four-cornered fight between the Consolidated and Suburban Traction Companies, the Orange Common Council, and the citizens of Orange over the granting of valuable electric railroad franchises is still going on, and is apparently no nearer settlement than it was many months ago.

From Household News. Celery with Cream Dressing. -- Wash and cut the celery as for salad and stand away until it is wanted. Grate one cocoanut, pour over it a pint of boiling water; allow it to stand until the water is cool; then with your hand squeeze the cocoanut in the water. Take it by handfuls, press it tightly and throw away.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 27 -- Col. Charles Marshall, who as military secretary to Gen. Lee was more intimately associated with the Confederate leader than any other man now living, has received many letters of congratulation upon the account of Lee's surrender at Appomattox, which he gave before a great audience in this city, and which was reported substantially in the dispatches to The New-York Times.

Unabated interest in the religious revival meetings in Brooklyn was shown yester- day by the great gathering at noon in Association Hall, where a children's meeting was held. The body of the hall was crowded, and in the gallery few who came at the opening hour were able to find seats.

Neely's "History of the Parliament of Religions and Religious Congresses at the Columbian Exposition" is a report of the remarkable religious gathering held in Chicago under the auspices of the World's Fair last Summer. This convention gathered under one roof the great religious creeds of the world, and the expounders of these creeds stated in addresses and papers the history and theory of the religious beliefs of which they were the high representatives.

The most valuable contribution lately made to the discussion of reform in the Police Department is to be found in the paper which was read at the recent meeting of the Chamber of Commerce by Joel B. Erhardt. Mr. Erhardt is well known as a zealous Republican in politics who does not find his political faith inconsistent with a belief in honesty and efficiency in the public service.

Mrs. Lena Kaufman has brought suit in the Superior Court for a separation from her husband, Jacob Kaufman, on the grounds of cruelty. Kaufman, who is a member of the firm of Kaufman Schrader, at 171 and 173 Wooster Street, denies his wife's charges. He claims she pursued him when he come to New-York from Philadelphia in 1885, and went to board with her.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The first commemorative meeting of the New-Jersey Society of the Colonial Dames of America was held at the residence of Mrs. Col. S. Meredith Dickinson, President of the Society, Thursday afternoon. About seventy-five ladies were present, including representatives from six States besides New-Jersey.

Fisk-Taylor. Miss May Isabel Taylor, daughter of Mrs. Belle Gray Taylor, the authoress, was married to Clinton Bowmen Fisk, son of the late Gen. Clinton B. Fisk, at the parsonage of Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, yesterday, at noon. The wedding was private, only members of the two families being present.

Ex-Gov. James E. Campbell of Ohio was examined yesterday before Judge Barrett of the Supreme Court in supplementary proceedings. Since his term expired, in January, 1892, he has been a resident of this city. In July last the First National Bank of Chicago obtained a judgment against him for $5,000 on a promissory note, which was indorsed by F.J. O'Connell of Coldgrove, Ohio, who had it discounted by the bank.

There are contradictory elements in the character of the cat. No animal is more independent, and, If we may "speak freely concerning cats," like Montaigne, no animal is more capricious in its choice of a home than a cat. Yet none is more remarkable for its power of finding its way back from great distances then a cat if if it pleases so to do.

In most particulars there is no city in the United States so conservative as the City of Brooklyn. Its manners and customs proceed forever in the same immemorial ruts, and the things that used to be done and the traditions that used to prevail twenty-five years ago are generally done and generally prevalent to-day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The report of the Judiciary Committee of the House upon Mr. Bailey's resolution relative to bond issues by the Secretary of the Treasury, returned yesterday with a favorable recommendation, was presented to the House to-day by Mr. Bailey. The resolution, says the report, states two propositions:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- In a wild valley at the foot of a rocky and precipitous mountain, near the little hamlet of Long Eddy, in Sullivan County, is the home of John C. Geer, whose business is the charming of rattlesnakes. This eccentric individual who lives in this isolated spot is known throughout that part of the country as "the rattlesnake man."

Never has a religious movement gained so much ground in Brooklyn as the present revival. It eclipses even the wonderful demonstration in the memorable Moody and Sankey campaign some years ago. In every section of the city the earnest evangelists engaged in the good work have met with a ready response to their appeals.

PERNAMBUCO, on Board the Steamship Nictheroy, Dec. 20 -- The agent of the Brazilian Government who inspected the Nictheroy, having expressed unqualified satisfaction with her, the cruiser has been accepted by the Government. President Peixoto has appointed Capt. Baker commander, and authorized him to take with him such officers and men as he may select.

Mayor Schieren has decided not to suspend Excise Commissioner Schliemann for granting the license for the saloon at Tompkins Avenue and Halsey Street, in spite of a protest signed by 400 residents, while only 10 were in favor of the application. He will leave the question of this license to his new Excise Commissioners, who will take office next Thursday.

Mrs. Annie Morris, a widow, fifty-nine years old, was shot and dangerously wounded by her son, Robert, in a quarrel late Friday night at their home, in Johnson Avenue, Spuyten Duyvil. Robert and his two brothers, John and Frank, are employed as molders at Johnson's foundry, at Spuyten Duyvil Creek.

At a meeting of the Board of Trustees and Associate Trustees of Barnard College, held Friday, the annual report of the Treasurer formed the most important subject. It declared that the affairs of the college demanded an impressive and clear statement of the conditions now existing.

NEWARK, N. J., Jam. 27.-Tine New-Jersey Historical Society, although not as old as some of its sister organizations, has collected many interesting relics and valuable curios in its forty-seven years of existence, and he -who visits the dusty little rooms on the third floor of the Newark banking institution where the collections are stored is amply repaid for his trouble.

Charles H. Hoyt, the playwright and sentor member of the theatrical firm of Hoyt McKee, is to be married early in March to Miss Caroline Seales, known to the stage as Caroline Miskell, the beautiful Ruth of "A Temperance Town."

Richard Croker arrived from Washington yesterday afternoon, and went at once to Tammany Hall to make arrangements relative to the Congressional election in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congressional Districts next Tuesday. When seen by a reporter for The New-York Times soon after his arrival at Tammany Hall he said:
