Yea: a medaj of steel, even as his muscles, like his body, like his spirit, engraved by his enthusiasm and with a margin which shall show like the unblottable motto of his glory. A glory registered, emblazoned, and sealed in every region where HONOR shall be the letter A, the first letter of the alphabet which HUMANITY commits to memory.

A report has been circulated throughout the West that, under the new classification of freight by the Trunk Line Association, it was necessary that the words "non-negotiable" should be printed in large type across the face of bills of lading. Such a rule, it was claimed, would revolutionize the grain shipping business.

The auction sales of real estate in Brooklyn during the past week amounted to $53,857, as against $282,085 for the corresponding week last year. The mortgages recorded were 252 for $830,926, of which 103, for $359,081, were at 5 per cent or less. For the same week last year, 217 mortgages, for $1,037,861, were placed on record, and of these, 118, for $437,800, were at 5 per cent, or less.
The funeral services of Capt. Edmund Blunt, who died Wednesday from a complication of diseases superinduced by grip, were held yesterday afternoon at his home, 100 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn.

"Dyed a soft brown or auburn?" was the main question Justice W.F. Moore considered yesterday wihen the case of Mrs. Burnham Warner, a Boston dressmaker, against the Imperial Chemical Manufacturing Company of 292 Fifth Avenue was tried at the Jefferson Market Police Court.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 27 -- The cornerstone of the main building of the new plant of the Tulane University was laid to-day. The buildings of the historic institution are at present in the centre of the business portion of the city. Last year a strip of land two blocks wide and a quarter of a mile in depth, fronting on St. Charles Avenue, opposite Audubon Park, was purchased by the administrators of the university.

As has been expected for some time, General Manager Nichols of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company will retire from that position to-morrow, but will remain with the company as chief engineer. Anthony Barrett, who is one of "Boss" McLaughlin's able henchmen, and who owns considerable stock in the company, will become its chief executive officer.

Richard Croker said yesterday that everything that could be done by the Tammany Hall organization in the Fifteenth and Fourteenth Congressional Districts to get the vote out for Mr. Isidor Straus and Col. William L. Brown was being done. He was quietly confident that everything would go well in both of the Congressional districts on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- John T. Hord of New-York, representing the Cherokee Indian Nation, was at the Treasury Department to-day for the purpose of conferring with Secretary Carlisle on the issue of $6,500,000 of Cherokee bonds authorized by Congress, but was unable to see the Secretary.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 27 -- Capt. Eugene Russell of the tugboat Vigilant, owned by the Newtown Creek Towing Company of this city, was arrested to-day on a bench warrant issued by County Judge Garretson. His arrest was due to two indictments found against him by the Grand Jury.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Many other people try with varied success to entertain this wearied fin de siecle European audience; but really there is no other showman fit to be mentioned on a level with young William of Germany. He is the Henry Irving of the Old World's political stage. He possesses a most spacious proscenium and has the best stock company and largest corps of superbly drilled supers and the finest stock of properties.

Heinrich Mehrman, one of the trainers of the wonderful Hagenbeck animals now exhibting at Tattersalls, Fifty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue, is daily putting through their paces a group of beasts about as antagonistic as could be brought together. It consists of four tigers, two lions, two leopards, and two goats.

It was announced yesterday that Judge Gray of the United States Supreme Court had selected Henry C. Platt, United States District Attorney Edward Mitchell's first assistant, as United States District Attorney, to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration on Friday of Mr. Mitchell's predecessor.

Fire Commissioner John Ennis of Brooklyn, who was suspended from office by Mayor Schieren Monday, was on the stand in the Supreme Court yesterday afternoon. He made some surprising statements regarding the promotions of assistant foremen and foremen, and acknowledged, under oath, that he was thoroughly incapable of properly performing the functions of Fire Commissioner.

Tourists in Egypt are required to buy tickets to gain access to the chief monuments, and the sums thus accumulated are used for repairs and arrangements of the grounds. The search for monuments is conducted with moneys from the annual budget; when, however, the results are good and the discoveries warrant selling tickets to the passing stranger to inspect the same, then the excavations are charged to the tourist fund.

Many tales of danger upon the ocean were brought by the fleet of vessels that came into port yesterday. A ship-wrecked crew which had been rescued from a sinksel hulk had sore trials to relate. One vessel reported an encounter with icebergs, and another had the most tempestuous voyage of her career.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- As usual, just at this time of the season, the gayeties are crowding fast and furious upon each other. With the beginning of Lent stagnation will settle upon society. There has been a notable lack of evening parties this year. There has been no end of dinners in the Cabinet, official and otherwise, but this season, for the first time in many years, there has been not one evening card reception.

James Zeffert, who, although but fourteen years old, has already gained the sobriquet of "Jimmie the Swiper" by his success in pilfering small articles, was a prisoner yesterday at the Yorkville Police Court. Friday morning a teacher at the East Sixty-eighth Street primary school sent one of her pupils out to get change for a five-dollar bill.

A possible obstacle to the construction of an underground road, for rapid transit as proposed by R.T. Wilson Co. appeared yesterday, when J.W. Reno, the engineer and inventor of the tunnel scheme that bears his name, said that he believed he held patent rights for the proposed form, of construction.

The Lexington Athetic Club, which is composed of east side toughs, started last night to hold a series of fights in a loft over the tin shop at 8 Second Street, near the Bowery. The police of the Fifth Street Station heard of the affair, and policemen were sent to the place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Secretary Herbert to-day made public the findings of the Court of Inquiry and his views thereon in the case of Lieut. Richard G. Davenport, United States Navy, who asked for a "Court of Honor" to pass upon his conduct while acting as Navigating Officer of the United States steamer Nipsic when that vessel was wrecked during the great Samoam hurricane, in March, 1889.

The snowfall of Friday night, although it brought still greater discomfort to the poor unemployed, was not without its compensation. The temperature was not lower than on the night previous, and when daylight dawned many hundreds of poor men saw an opportunity to earn a little money by shoveling away the snow from the stoops and sidewalks.

There seems to be no sound principle or high motive behind the attitude of the two Republican Senators from Kings County, Owens and Reynolds, in regard to the McCarty contest. They are unquestionably right in resenting and resisting the efforts of Platt and other outside politicians to dictate or control their action as Senators, and, if they stand alone in that position among Republican Senators, that fact is shameful to their party associates.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- There will be only one change in the bills at the down-town theatres next week. Frank Daniels will give place to De Wolf Hopper at the Grand. "Sinbad," which is drawing the best houses of any show in town, notwithstanding the large number of times it has been given here, will remain at the Chicago Opera House.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 27 -- There has been much concern about the payment of the members of the Legislature because of the Senatorial muddle. The State Controller, however, has been kept busy for some days paying the members and officers of the House on account. Only the hold-over Senators have been paid.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 27 -- New-York has given many of her brilliant sons to the great West. Not a few of them have been given to Wisconsin, among whom none has achieved higher places in the esteem of the people of this Commonwealth than William Penn Lyon, the retiring Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court; Harlow S. Orton, the new Chief Justice, and Alfred William Newman, the newly-elected member of the court.

A race so ancient and hitherto so self-centred as the Japanese has necessarily preserved a system of manners and customs old enough to be novel in the civilized eyes of younger nations. To the historian, therefore, comes the temptation to make much of this novelty, in place of seeking its source in such laws as may be discoverable in the growth of a people.

"As You Like It" is to be given again by the Professional Woman's League, this time for six evening performances and Thursday and Saturday matinees, this week, at the Garden Theatre. The first performance will be given Monday night.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The Rev. Henry C. Dodd of Corona, L.I., to-day applied to the police for assistance in locating a young woman named Emma Doering, who had come to this country from Berlin to work for Mrs. Emma L. Platter of Wooster, Ohio, her passage having been paid on the Dania of the Hamburg Line, which arrived at Hoboken last Saturday.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In The New-York Times of Jan. 14 was printed an article with the heading. "Wife Selling in Yorkshire," quoted from The Sheffield Telegraph, which recalled to me a very similar instance.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 -- T.B. Barr attempted yesterday to stop the funeral of the ten-months-old child of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Chadwick, at 120 St. Clair Avenue, East St. Louis, because Chadwick owed him three days' rent. When the last month's rent was due Chadwick paid it and intended to move, but the child became sick and died.

So much in the nature of attack and adverse criticism has been said and written about the Carlin hunting party, which left its guide. George Colgate, to die in the Bitter Root Mountains in Idaho, that A.L. A. Himmelwright, a civil engineer, 41 Park Row, has issued a statement justifying the action of himself and his friends.

There is recognition of some undefined force in words when Houston is spoken of, not as Samuel, but as Sam. The abbreviation induces a kind of familiarity which gives the privileges of intimacy. Houston was known from the Maine borders to the Texas line, but, as the author says, estimates of him "vary from extravagant and often fulsome eulogy to the harshest depreciation and the most envenomed attack."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The coil boiler men have won their fight with the steamship Inspectors, who made a ruling obnoxious to the boilermakers recently. The latter have presented arguments which show that these boilers can stand a much greater pressure than 175 pounds, the limit imposed by the Inspectors.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- Drs. Da Cos- ta, Leidy, and Morris, the attending physicians of George W. Childs, issued the following bulletin at midnight, after holding a conference:

SING SING, Jan. 27 -- An old-time discolored and well-worn leaf from the past, in the shape of a copy of The Westchester Herald, dated Mount Pleasant, Westchester County, Oct. 28, 1834, was found among old papers and manuscripts here a few days ago. A glance at the old relic may not prove uninteresting to the present generation, which has probably heard of most of the persons and things spoken of in the paper.

It has been proved that the electric light used by blockading vessels is not sufficient to discover vessels bent on escape, particularly if their hulls are painted black or gray. Its effect is uncertain, and in war it would draw the fire of the enemy upon the ship by which it is displayed. It has been further shown that, for the use of torpedoes, the blockaded squadron has considerable advantages over the blockaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A bill introduced to-day by Representative Maguire of California "to provide increased revenue by a direct tax on the value of land in the United States," is in the line of putting into execution the theories of Henry George, one of whose ardent disciples Mr. Maguire is.

It is nearly thirty years since Appomattox. Thirty years is a goodly slice to take out of a man's life, but there are many who were men of action from 1861 to 1865 who are yet good for a score of years in their country's service. As one goes into the galleries of the Senate he instinctively glances at the Democratic side.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 27 -- A.L. Williams, general attorney for the Union Pacific Railroad, returned to-day from a trip to Honolulu. Mr. Williams was at Honolulu about a week, and visited many points in Oahu Island. Speaking of his trip, he said:

The modern mother has had to give up a good many illusions and delusions about her children, some of them difficult to part with and only relinquished when the powerful and penetrating light of science brings out their fallacy and falsity.

Lemuel Ely Quigg, Republican candidate for Congress in the Fourteenth District, closed his campaign of sentiment and calamity last night.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 27 -- The International Law and Order League is not at all inclined to let the Corbett-Mitchell matter drop. The Rev. Clarence Greeley, General Agent of the League, says that he is informed by his attorney in Jacksonville that Manager Bowden is afraid to let the Supreme Court pass on Section L. Chapter 66, of McClellan's digest of the Florida decisions.

The will of George W. Frothingham, who died, at his home on Remsen Street, Brooklyn, Jan. 13, was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday. The estate is valued at $440,000. He leaves $3,000 each to the Brooklyn Aid Society, Brooklyn Hospital, Polytechnic Institute, Eye and Ear Hospital, Broklyn Orphan Asylum, and Brooklyn Industrial School Association, and $2,000 each to the First Unitarian Society and the Union for Christian Work.
III. "Neither, I hope," replied Carroll soberly. "My uncle's will imposes upon me certain requirements. I need not accept them."

From information obtained yesterday, it seems probable that when Feldman and Nelderland were arrested in South Brooklyn on Friday by Chief Scanlon of the United States Secret Service Department on the charge of counterfeiting, the principal counterfeiter, John Neiderland, escaped, and that his brother was taken into custody in his stead.

If the plan and the intent of Mr. Uzanne's work were simply recited, the work would appear to be extravagantly useful, but it is better than this. Sebastian Mercier's preface to the "Tableau de Paris," published in 1780, inspired it. Mercier said that his epoch was infinitely more interesting to him than the uncertain history of the Phenecians and the Egyptians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- To every conservative Democrat who regulates his zeal by wisdom and expediency the situation in which the Wilson bill is placed at the close of the general debate on the measure causes profound concern. The ill-regulated or unrestrained advocates of an income tax as a contrivance for securing revenue have paid slight regard to any desires except their own, and they fling aside as worthless the remonstrances of their party associates.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Catamounts, the fiercest of all the wild animals that prowl about the Catskill and Shawangunk Mountains, have been seen in unusual numbers this Winter, and in the town of Rochester, Ulster County, along the rocky and thickly-wooded lands at the base of the Shawangunks, several have been killed recently.

MASSILON, Ohio, Jan. 27 -- When J.S. Coxey announced the other day that he would organize an army and march from Ohio to Washington to demand the issue of $500,000,000 of Treasury notes, the declared purpose was looked upon as the whimsical idea of a rich man. It is a fact, however, that Mr. Coxey is spending a great deal of money in preparing this programme for practical execution.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 27 -- The friends of Bishop Williams of the Connecticut Diocese have decided on a definite memorial in connection with his life work as the founder and head of the Berkeley Divinity School at Middletown. It will be forty years in May since the institution was chartered by the Legislature, Bishop Williams, who had then been consecrated three years, being mainly instrumental in securing the charter.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Among the many lies sent out by the Associated Press concerning the United Press is one printed in Associated Press papers to-day saying that The Kansas City Star has abandoned the United Press in favor of the Associated Press. The Star was never a customer of the United Press, and never paid it a dollar.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Crawshay Alliston Hall, the Protestant Episcopal Bishop-elect of Vermont, arrived in this city yesterday from Liverpool on the White Star steamship Germanic. Dr. Hall was elected Bishop to succeed Bishop Bissel, who died last Summer.

Many of the local military organizations have been holding their annual reviews during the past week, among them the Twelfth, Twenty-second, and Forty-seventh Regiments. The presentation of marksmen's, sharpshooters', and expert sharpshooters' medals was made made at the same time. Mayor Gilroy reviewed the Twelfth Regiment last Thursday night, and a large crowd was in attendance.

The opening of the California Midwinter Fair is the consummation of a scheme which was termed visionary, absurd, and reckless at its inception. If the achievements of Chicago were not fresh in the minds of the people great would be the wonder expressed at this triumph of the Pacific coast, for what has been done is really marvelous.
James J. Corbett, the champion pugilist, as he is now styled, arrived in the city yesterday from Jacksonville and had a reception at Madison Square Garden.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The interest in outdoor sports, which have ever been a part of Lake-wood life, is heightened by the prospect of skating during the present cold wave. Tennis playing on the Laurel House court is a favorite pastime. The court lies in a sheltered part of the grounds, and scarcely a day passes without sharply-contested sets of singles and doubles.

Among Brooklyn Republicans, dissatisfaction with the course of Senators Reynolds and Owens, touching the Wolfert-McCarty contest, is increasing. Their reported intention to vote in favor of retaining McCarty in his seat hast drawn down upon the backsliders a torrent of remonstrance and criticism.

The directors of the seventeenth National Saengerfest made public yesterday the programme for the festival which will begin in Madison Square Garden on June 23. There will be three evening concerts and two matinees.

William Kenny, a livery-stable keeper at 999 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested last night toy Patrolman Hayes of the Fifth Avenue Police Station on the charge of grabbing a pocketbook containing a check for $204 from Mrs. Sarah Irving of 26 Coles Street.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 27 -- At last every athletic organization of Yale has commenced its Spring training. The track men were the last to fall into line, reporting to Capt. Dean Lyman last Tuesday and receiving the usual list of instructions from him relative to preliminary drill. Exactly sixty-nine applicants for places on the team, appeared and had their Spring's routine work explained to them.

A young linesman staggered into the courtyard, bareheaded, ghastly pale, his tunic half stripped off. His neck was cut deeply open at the bottom of the right side for a length of nearly six inches, and the severed flesh hung down on to the shoulder in a thick scarlet fold; he dripped with blood, and literally spattered it about him as he reeled in.

Mr. Randolph Guggenhelmer, the well-known lawyer. School Commissioner, and real estate operator, has established quite a reputation as a giver of unique and enjoyable dinners. These are held usually weekly, at his residence, 8 East Eighty-first Street, and the number of guests is limited.

ORANGE, Jan. 27 -- The big charity ball to be given by the Orange Athletic Club Friday evening next for the benefit of the Orange Memorial Hospital promises to be one of the most brilliant society events ever held in the Oranges. The entire clubhouse will be utilized, and the tennis building will be used for a ball room.

"Women should not attempt," says an eminent woman physician of London, "to carry on a profession after marriage. I mean the women of the upper and middle classes who go into the professions. It is not necessary that they should be the breadwinners, that duty should devolve upon the husband; and I am confident that the rising generation would be healthier and stronger in every way if the mothers would exert themselves less.

An effort is to be made to recover from the Directors and officers of the defunct Madison Square Bank of this city, by civil action, the enormous sums of money which were lost and wasted in the mismanagement of that institution.
MANSFIELD, Penn., Jan. 27.--Three rioters were wounded, one of them fatally, in the battle with the owners of the Beadling Brothers' mines.

From time to time public attention is centred upon cases of attachments between women, which are sufficiently absorbing in character as to induce the two thus mutually attracted to withdraw from their separate homes and establish one together, where they may live in the intimacy of daily companionship.

The Associate Alumni of the College of the City of New-York gave its fifteenth annual dinner last evening. The event led to the gathering at Delmonico's of a representative and distinguished lot of New-Yorkers.

Already in 1874 a law was passed for the protection of children and girls who had not attained their majority, in factories. This law remained almost entirely a dead letter. The law of the 2d of November, 1892, limited the labor of children of thirteen to sixteen years of age to ten hours per day, but did this necessitate the limitation of their work during the gathering of roses and jasmine in the Midi?

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- The strength of the local market was due largely to the early London quotations, but Pihiladelphia and Metropolitan Traction did not sympathize. They acted as if the clique had been filled up at higher prices. This encouraged the room traders to hammer both stocks. Philadelphia declined very rapidly to 90 1/2, at which figure covering advanced it to 92 bid.

For many centuries the Chinese nation has closely cultivated the poetic art, and still turns out annually more poetry than all the rest of the world put together. Versa making is an important factor in the national life of China. At the competitive examinations, through which admission is obtained to an official career, poetry divides the honors with prose.

Rivers flowing over the land are continually taking up mineral matter in solution, and these substances are all added to the mass of materials dissolved in the oceanic waters.

BRIDGEVILLE, Penn., Jan. 27 -- The riotus Hungarians, Slavs, Poles, and other foreigners who thronged this town to-day, spreadlng ruin and destruction in their path, have all disappeared, but many fear hey will return. The citizens are still in a state of terror, armed men stand guard at street corners and challenge all comers.

It would be hard to conceive of a volume more doubly elegant than the annual report for 1893 of the New-York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. On the one hand, it shocks with its almost incredible stories of inhuman barbarity, and points with deplorable accuracy to the plight of some of the little ones born into the lower depths of the maelstrom of New-York.

When Egbert Flamming was a sophomore at Pierson his uncle put up his name in the Metropolitan Club of the metropolis. Egbert did not demur to this; membership of a club would be part of his future life, just as comfortable bachelor quarters would be, and a leisurely attendance at the Law School. Beyond this, he didn't care to look.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 27 -- The snowstorm prevented the traction company from running any cars till nearly 10 o'clock this morning. Previous to that, however, a snow scraper was run over the line. It was greeted at various points with derisive shouts, but as policemen guarded the men no attacks were made.

A New-Yorker who went to Florida to see the prize fight, and visited Corbett at his training quarters, at Mayport, tells an amusing story. A well-known young woman of this city who is spending the Winter in Florida went, accompanied by a cousin from Jacksonville, to inspect the surroundings of the champion.

Ex-Judge George M. Van Hoesen, in the Supreme Court, before Justice Barrett, yesterday made an application for the appointment of a receiver for the Thomson-Houston Electric Company of this city, in a suit which has just been brought by the Holland Trust Company as the trustee of the bondholders for $600,000.

It has not been an unusual thing for people to mix up all Polynesia. Micronesia, and Melanesia, but the recent events which have attracted so much attention to this group must have cleared the atmosphere somewhat of these errors, and probably most readers of newspapers have located the islands in their proper place, near the centre of the great Pacific Ocean.

The Assistant Professor of Geology at Cornell presents a textbook in which special attention is given to the mineral products or the United States, but with reference to other countries when some light can be thrown on the origin of materials. Throughout the chapters the object held in view is to point out the geological aspect of the subject and the economic importance and relations of the several products.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- Quite a week of unwritten space in my journal. These were sad days for every one but the little folks. As the boy in the Figaro said to his parent recently, "Pere, I should like a year of four New Year's Days." "My son, when you are as old as papa is, one New Year's Day will suffice -- every four years."

BOSTON, Jan. 27 -- Local stocks were dull, in sympathy with the general market. West End Street was the only security which showed activity. It declined to 47, from a close of 48 yesterday. There seemed to be no special reason for the decline.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- The Chamber of Deputies was densely crowded to-day with members and visitors who desired to hear the interpellation of M. Clovis-Hugues as to the house-to-house searches and the arrests made under the new law relating to Anarchists.

The last five parts of the Millet publication, "Famous Composers and Their Works," have made their appearance. The publishers have been prompt in fulfilling their promises as to the issue of the work, and it has been completed well within the time originally set for it. The high standard of excellence which marked the first parts has been maintained throughout.

PARIS, Monday, Jan. 8 -- In the opera-bouffe imbroglio at Rio de Janeiro there is a good dead of philosophy to be found, after all. It is hard to believe that any one of the imperial family would care to return there. I happen to know a good many Brazilians, and I have yet to discover a genuine imperialist.

John G. Cole, a highwayman, was held in the Lee Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday on a charge of stealing a two-hundred-dollar diamond pin from Herman Goldberg of Eastern Parkway. Goldberg attended a performance at the Amphion Theatre, on Bedford Avenue, Saturday evening, and, while passing, with the crowd, through the lobby at the conclusion of the play, saw Cole grab the pin from, his scarf.
Word was received in this city yesterday by the Commercial Cable Company as follows:

Policeman Murphy of the East Twenty-second Street Station was accosted at Third Avenue and Twenty-third Street at 3:10 A.M. yesterday by a tall, handsome, stylishly-dressed young woman who indicated one of three young men who seemed to be in her company, and said:

The second competition of the series of four regimental team matches for the Cowell Trophy took place at the armory range of the Seventh Regiment, Sixty-seventh Street and Park Avenue, on Saturday night. This competition is open to teams of three, from each company, excluding those who have armory records of 65 or better, or who have shot on a regimental team at Creedmoor, and no member can shoot in more than one such contest.

Joseph Manus, short and stubby, smooth face, who said he had been employed as a cook at 238 East Eighty-second Street, was remanded for examination in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of having stolen a suit of clothes and a quantity of jewelry from Frank Norblock and Henry Oeyen of 656 East One Hundred and Fifty-first Street.

There seems to be quite a lively State Canvassing Board scandal out in Michigan, Last year a constitutional amendment was submitted to a vote which increased certain official salaries, including those of the Governor, Secretary, of State, and Treasurer, who are members of the State Canvassing Board.

Last year's pilgrimage to the holy cities of Mecca and Medina was marked by an appalling epidemic of cholera in those cities and the two seaports, Jeddah and Yembo, (or Jambo,) at which pilgrims journeying to them are landed. Such an outbreak was not unexpected, for the pilgrimage always brings this plague from India to the Arabian coast and commonly scatters the seeds of the dire malady all over Southeastern Europe.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 28. -- There are strong indications here that Judge Turner, who has represented the Eleventh Georgia District in Congress for twenty years, and is one of the strongest members from the South, will figure in the next Gubernatorial race. Judge Turner is not a candidate, but he has hosts of friends throughout the State, and there are influences which will, it is belived, make him a strong figure in that race.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The politicians are looking forward to an Interesting week in Albany, not only from a legislative, but from a political standpoint. It is worthy, of note that the only political measure introduced up to date in which the City of New-York is interested is the Nen-Partisan Police Commission bill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- A preliminary report of the income and expenditures of allways in the United States for the year ending June 30, 1893, has just been pubished by the Inter-State Commerce Commission.
Funeral services were held yesterday afternoon over the body of Capt. Theodore Feldstein at the headquarters of Koltes Post, No. 32, in Germania Assembly Rooms, 291 Bowery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- At the meeting to-morrow of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary it is expected that the nomination of Mr. Peckham will be considered, but there is not much confidence that it will be acted upon. From the best information procurable it is assumed that action will be deferred, to allow several Senators to become better acquainted with the qualifications of the man named by the President.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- Albert L. Sweet, President of the Chicago, Wilmington, and Vermillion Coal Company, said yesterday that he doubted if a meeting of the Ohio, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia, miners would be held in February to adjust the scale trouble. If it should take place, he said at probably would be of small benefit to the miners or mine owners.

DURANGO, Mexico, Jan. 28. -- The authorities here were notified to-day of a desperate murder and robbery, committed about eighty-five miles west of here, the perpetrators being a band of brigands, led by the notorious outlaw Francisco Reiseda.

An old theatrical license law which has been practically a dead letter for years has just been resurrected in Pennsylvania, and the order has gone forth that its provisions must be enforced. It provides that every theatrical company must take out a license for every county in the State in which it appears, and any company playing without such a license shall be subject to a fine of from $200 to $1,000.

We have in this work, which, in the main, is a grouping of war articles which have appeared in The Century Magazine, an important contribution to the literature of the war of the rebellion. All but one of the stories are narratives by actual participants in audacious enterprises incident to the war, some undertaken in offensive movements against the enemy, some in the hope of escaping from prisons and getting back to home and friends.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Jan. 28. -- Gov. G. Allardo of the Federal District of Mexico yesterday made, through El Municipio Libre, his official organ, a definite proposition for the establishmemt of a bull ring in the City of Mexico.

An unusually large congregation attended the services in the Polish Roman Catholic Church of St. Stanislaus, Stanton and Forsyth Streets, yesterday. Many of those present attended in expectation of hearing the priest, Father Strezleski, say something thrilling in regard to the struggle for possession and control of the church between himself, the Archbishop, and the Vicar General, on one side, and the Allgemeine Verein on the other.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- There were fewer sales of local securities this week than during the preceding one. There were plenty of new bids at current figures, but holders refused to make any concession to would-be buyers, hence changes in quotations are few and unimportant. The application for making permanent the receivership for the Treadwell Fur Company will be argued before Judge Herrick at the Special Term next Tuesday.

Thirsty individuals had but little difficulty yesterday in securing whatever stimulants they desired. The side doors were open as usual, although the civilian-clothed policemen who are detailed to arrest excise violators only succeeded in finding 123 bartenders or saloon proprietors at work behind the bar.

From The Washington Star. The biggest literary work ever undertaken in America is the military history now being produced by Uncle Sam under the title of "War of the Rebellion; a Compilation of the Official Records of the Union and Confederate Armies." It is not only the largest history ever published in the world, but it has for its subject, as its name indicates, the greatest conflict of ancient or modern times.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Jan. 28. -- The Cleveland Columbian Minstrels of New-York were deserted, here by the manager last nighnt. One member of the company was rouglhly handled by an angry crowd of spectators and musicians who wanted their money.

ELIZABETH, Jan. 28. -- Detective Conrad V. Sherring of this city nearly choked to death last night while eating supper at the Grand Union Hotel here. In fact, he had ceased to breathe and his heart had stopped beating, and only the vigorous use of artificial respiration restored him to life.

Navigaitors whose vessels ply through the Narrows will find in the tidal indicator which has been established on the wharf at Fort Hamilton an apparatus likely to prove of much value. It was placed there under the supervision of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey Service. So far as known, it is the only one of its kind in use.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 28. -- The Interest of the students is at present divided between the midyear examinations and the Bolles Memorial Fund. The midyears began on Wednesday and will continue till Saturday, Feb. 10. As for the Bollea Memorial, the agitation in favor of some sort of tribute to the late Secretary is the result of a timely suggestion by a well-known graduate.

The attendance at the services yesterday morning in St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Vesey Street, was unusually large, owing to the fact that the Rev. Dr. James Mulchahey, who has had pastoral charge for the last twenty years, was to retire from the mission, as announced in The New-York Times of yesterday.
"The Evolution of Morality" was the subject Prof. Feliz Adler chose for his lecture, delivered before the Society of Ethical Culture in the Music Hall yesterday. A large audience was present.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Jan. 29 -- A.M. The stock market last week was dull, as a whole, the activity being confined to Sugar, St. Paul, and Western Union. The trading included 20,000 shares in only five other stocks. Sugar overshadowed everything else, and broke nearly 5 points on Tuesday on the action of the House in voting to place the refined product on the free list.

The Trustees and Elders of the Brooklyn Tabernacle are working hard to induce the Rev. T. De Wict Talinage to reconsider his resignation. After the services last evening the Trustees held a meeting in the board room, at which Dr. Talmage was present.

Renier Herriger, a contractor living at 222 West Thirty-first Street, and his wife, Annie, were arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, on complaint of Duncan Campbell, night clerk in the Park Avenue Hotel, who charged the husband with disorderly conduct and Mrs. Herriger with intoxication.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- The response to the call by the Captain of the Track Athletic Team for candidates for the various positions on the Princeton team is very gratifying. There is much more interest manifested in this branch of athletics than usual, and the number of men who have signified their intention of competing for positions on the team is much larger than last year.

John Ussey of 31 Catharine Street became intoxicated last night, and in descending a fligt of steps fell and cut his nose. A kindly neighbor escorted him to the Chambers Street Hospital. The routine of business there did not suit Ussey, who expressed his dissatisfaction in an obstreperous manner.

MANSFIELD, Penn, Jan. 28. -- There was great excitement in Mansfield to-day, growing out of the miners' riots, and early in the evening it was believed that there would the serious trouble before midnight At midnight, however, there is quiet here, and word comes from Tom's Run that in the district about there there need be no apprehension of violence for the present.

ROME, Jan. 23. -- The Pope delivered in St. Peter's to-day an address suggested by the recent disturbances in Italy. He expressed himself with great tact and frank- ness when he referred, to the current affairs, and his words impressed deeply the minds of all present.

Secretary of the Treasury Carlisle yesterday authorized a statement calculated to relieve all doubt in the minds of those who may wish to purchase any of the proposed issue of $50,000,000 of bonds as to the validity of the issue.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 28. -- As A.J. Evans was returning home from the city late this afternoon in his wagon three drunken negroes overtook him and forced him to drive his horse at break-neck speed for about a mile. Becoming weary of this they made him stop and then began hacking at him with pocketknives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- There is a proposition before the Navy Department to include the whalebacked vessels of the lakes as an auxiliary force for the navy. Yesterday Capt. Alexander McDougal of West Superior, Wis., the inventor and builder of this class of ships, called at the department and pointed out to the officials the value of these vessels for the purpose suggested.

If the gentlemen who are trying to get the House to pass a resolution declaring that the Secretary of the Treasury cannot use the proceeds of the new loan for any purpose not specified in the Resumption act of 1875 were entirely candid, they would, we fear, preface their resolution by a preamble something like this:

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Citizens of New-Jersey are discussing the possibility that the legislative dead-lock may continue so long that there shall be a period in which the State shall be without an official authorized to grant divorces. The possibility is remote, perhaps, but it is not so remote as it would seem to be at first glance.

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 27. -- In the local stock market the noticeable feature for the week is a slightly better demand and but few offerings of stocks, and these offerings of only small amounts. The January dividends are evidently seeking reinvestment in local securities. A number of transfers of the stock of the Narragansett Electric Lighting Company have been recorded during the week, and the demand for this security is good.
The behavior of Messrs. Owens and Reynolds, the Brooklyn legislators at Albany, is receiving considerable attention from Thomas C. Platt and his lieutenants in this city.

The fourth lecture in the course, "The Church and the World," in the Church of the Divine Paternity, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, was given last evening by Miss Alice L. Woodbridge of the Working Woman's Society. Her topic was "The Needs of the Working Woman and Our Duties to Her."
The revival services conducted under the auspices of the Central Committee of the Evangelistic Campaign Association of Brooklyn clergymen are to be continued in the City of Churches.

The Rev. J.O. Wilson, pastor of the Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, preached last evening before the Junior Order of United American Mechanics on the subject, "Americans for America." Dr. Wilson's remarks were mainly devoted to an attack on the Catholic Church in the United States.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- C.H.G. Marchmedt of New-York, the theosophical head of the Marchmedt Farm, an abode of theosophists in the town of Corinth, Saratoga County, was arrested this afternoon and brought here and locked up at Police Headquarters. He is charged with grand larceny, but the facts are not known by Chief Blodgett.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Another chapter has been added to the comedy of errors associated with the St. Gaudens World's Fair medal. Senator Vilas, Chairman of the Senate Quadro-Centennial Special Committee, this morning received from Secretary Carlisle a letter, which practicaily calls for what in legal phraseology might be termed "A bill of discovery" as to the alleged improprieties of the accepted medal.

BATH, Me., Jan. 28. -- A fire to-day destroyed a large number of the best buildings in the business portion of the city. The Sagadahock House, two national banks, a savings bank, and about a dozen stores are now in ruins. The following stores were burned: D.T. Percy Sons, dry goods; Halett Co., druggists; Franks, Parks Norton, wholesale cigar dealers; John O. Shaw, stationery, confectionery, shoes, and insurance.

Another suicide resulting from an attack of grip was reported yesterday by the police of the Charles Street Station. Henry Schlobohm, thirty-five years old, of 218 West Fourth Street, was found dead early in the morning in the office of Korner Schwabeland, wholesale grocers set 25 Tenth Avenue.

It is no spiritless or perfunctory ejection that is to take place in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congressional Districts to-morrow. An issue of great moment to the Democratic Party is to be determined. The voters of these two strong Democratic districts are appealed to to sustain the party and its policies at a moment when the votes and the influence of such Democrats as Mr. Straus and Col. Brown are sorely needed at Washington.
A couple or daring attempts at highway robbery were made Saturday night, near the centre of the bridge which crosses the Harlem River at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Thirtieth Street.

For the French there is nothing but Paris, but for the stranger in the land in the provincial town there is much more of the picturesque, much more of what is distinctly national, than in the great capital. The streets in these towns are narrow, with narrower sidewalks, off of which you are pushed without ceremony, sometimes with a "pardonnez," but sometimes without.

(Copyright, 1894, by the United Press.) BERLIN, Jan. 28. -- As more details of Prince Bismarck's short sojourn in Berlin are ascertained, it becomes plainer that the reconciliation was divested carefully of political import. Certain newspapers persist in enlarging on the probable political results of his reported conferences with Emperor William and Chancellor von Caprivi, but such a course is not warranted by the facts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Notwithstanding the threatening proportions of the opposition to the income-tax proposition which the Democratic majority Intends to add to the Wilson bill, and confident as are the opponents of the tax of defeating its incorporation into the customs revenue measure, there is already manifested an inclination to relax the opposition to it if it becomes a question of income tax or no bill.

From Braustreet's. Jan. 27. In proportion as its provisions become known the opposition to the enactment of the measure will grow. The protest of representatives of their own party faith against the measure might well give the majority of the Ways and Means Committee pause.

Mary McFadden, forty-five years old, of 520 East Thirteenth Street, was severely burned about the head, face, and body yesterday at her home. She was removed to Bellevue Hospital, where it is said that she would probably die.

The new Church of St. Michael, West Thirty-second Street and Ninth Avenue, was solemnly blessed and dedicated yesterday by Archbishop Corrigan. The Archbishop celebrated the ordinary 8 o'clock, mass, and when the ceremony was over the consecration of the altars was performed The blessing and dedication of the church came next.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 28. -- Considerable excitement exists among insurance men in this city over the sensational arrest in Cleveland yesterday of a number of prominent men engaged in the business, as well as over the fact that several local companies are known to be under the espionage of the Post Office authorities.

Champion Steinitz and Lasker had another consultation at the Manhattan Chess Club on Saturday afternoon, and at the Manhattan Cafe in the evening. They have now agreed upon all the principal and minor rules of their chess match.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 28. -- The Rev. S. Edwards Young, pastor of the Westminster Presbyterian Church, in a prelude to his sermon to-night denounced prize fighting and prize fighters in this manner: "The gladiatorial combats of ancient Rome attracted an audience of 200,000, but by electric wires, clubrooms, and newspapers Corbett and Mitchell had nearly that many millions.

The case of Mr. F. Henry Greer, which has been reported in these columns, will make desirable for Mr. Greer hereafter either an alias or an alibi. Either of these time-honored devices would be useful to him in his business, and it is the nature of the business that makes it worth while to bestow some casual and passing consideration upon Greer.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 28. -- There are indications that better days for business are coming in this city. For the first time in several months a number of hands in the Atha Illingsworth Steel Works, in Harrison, were put on full time last week. Three fires under the huge furnaces are now going.
The money market continued easy. Call loams were made at 3/4@1 1/2 per cent., the average being about 1 per cent.
There was read in all of the Roman Catholic churches in this city yesterday the regulations for the observance of Lent in this archdiocese, prescribed by Archbishop Corrigan. The regulations are:

The first annual report of the State Charities Aid Association of New-York to the State Commission in Lunacy will be presented to the Legislature to-day. It was made in compliance with an amendment to Chapter 635, Laws of 1893, (Section 3,) and is signed for the Board of Managers by Miss Louise Lee Schuyler, Chairman of the Sub-Hospital Committee on the Insane, with whom is associated Dean Charles F. Chandler of Columbia College.

Unless an accident prevent, a statue of Peter Cooper, New-York's great philanthropist, will be placed in position this Spring. The site has not been selected, but the design of the statue has been completed by Augustus St. Gaudens, and it is now being cast in bronze.

RIO JANEIRO, Jan. 28. -- Dispatches from New-York refer to the alleged success of Rear Admiral Benham's mediation and to the consequent readiness of both sides to submit their differences to arbitration.

No one could doubt the ability of New-Yorkers to make a creditable showing on the snow path at a few hours' notice, after watching the endless procession of sleighs, of every make, shape, and design, and in every shade of color, that yesterday, from early in the forenoon until long after nightfall, glided, bumped, and scraped over the driveways of Central Park.

Ernst Nathan, the former Republican "boss" of Kings County, is soon to reenter active politics. Anticipations of his early return to official connection with the party have already provoked a stir among his former Republican associates.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $6,283,550. The banks now hold $109,043,000 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show a decrease in loans of $914,860, an increase in specie of $3,265,700, an increase in legal tenders of $4,369,900, an increase in deposits of $5,338,200, and a decrease in circulation of $65,000.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 28. -- The coming promenade is the topic of discussion on the campus. For this one short season, opening with next Monday, society will run riot with the quiet and sedate customs of the university. Athetics will seek a rear pew, the football Jeans will give way to the dress suit, and your football hero will pay suit in the court, where the promenade girt reigns supreme.

PARIS, Jan. 28. -- It is stated this evening that the Pardons Committee, after examining the appeal of Auguste Vaillant, the Anarchist who was sentenced to death for throwing the bomb in the Chamber, has decided to let justice take its course. President Carnot has intimated that he will not interfere.

From The Chicago Record. In Room 20 of the old service building at Jackson Park is the lost-and-found property bureau. As a result of its work during the fair season more than 3,000 articles of various descriptions are stored away one upon another. Everything from a silk hat to a dog collar is numbered among the articles, umbrellas, canes, and ladies' wraps predominating.

The funeral of Roundsman Cornelius Harrigan, formerly of the East One Hundred and fourth Street Station, was held from the residence of his brother Dennis, at 354 East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The services were conducted by the Rev. Father Duffy of St. Cecelia's Church.

The quantity of wheat and flour (in terms of wheat) exported last week was 2,947,950 bushels. There has recently been a perceptible increase of exports, the weekly average for the last four weeks having been nearly 3,000,000 bushels. The price at present in this country is the lowest on record, wheat selling for May delivery at Chicago for 63 1-2 cents, while sales for immediate delivery are made at 59 cents.

The store at 347 Grand Street, conducted under the supervision of Park Commissioner Nathan Straus to furnish coal and groceries to the poor at absolutely cost price, continues to do a large business. From the time it is opened until it is closed it is crowded with poor people, to whom it is a necessity to make their few pennies go as far as possible in sustaining life.

That is a strange story of woman's fidelity which comes from Salem. One can scarcely believe that in these days such a romance could occur, but there seems to be no doubt of it, and the woman in the case was well known. She was Elizabeth Bullock, one of three aged sisters, all of whom have died during the last three weeks of la grippe.

Thomas Lynch, the distiller, left two wills, the first distributing $400,000 worth of personal property among his sons, his sister, and his grandchildren; the second giving a special legacy to Mrs. Belle B. Hill of the interest during her lifetime upon $60,000 in Chicago water funds, to be put in the hands of Lyman J. Gage and Edward F. Lawrence as executors and trustees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- A dozen graduates of medical colleges can find places in the Army or Navy Medical Corps this year. The examination for admission to the Naval Corps will begin next week in New-York. There are five vacancies in the corps. The examination for Assistant Surgeons for the navy will begin in this city early in April, the board meeting here March 12 for preliminary work.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 29. -- A leak has been discovered in the Queens County Grand Jury. The proceedings of the January Term of that body have become common property. Who is responsible for giving out the findings of the Grand Jury is not known, but District Attorney Noble proposes to ferret out the guilty persons and punish them to the full extent of the law.

"Tannhaeuser," as prepared for the edification of the Parisians in 1861, was attempted at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It was a very heavy undertaking, especially for a theatre whose company is organized on a plan antagonistic to the best artistic achievements in the Wagnerian music-drama.

NEW-HAVEN, CONN., Jan. 29. -- More than two hundred society young ladies lent their presence to make the second day of "Prom" week at Yale a success. Mrs. Frances Wilcox entertained the sophomores and their guests, the University Club gave the seniors and their friends a reception this afternoon, and to-night 3,000 people crowded the Hyperion Theatre to hear the annual midwinter concert of the Glee and Banjo Clubs.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 29. -- The United States revenue cutter Grant has had another mishap. In consequence of it, her going around the Horn has been interrupted for a few days. She is now in this port, dry-docked.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 29. -- The contest over the will of Daniel Hand of Guilford, the millionaire philanthropist, who died in 1891, leaving about $500,000 to the American Missionary Association, came to an abrupt end in the Probate Court to-day, the attorneys for the contestants withdrawing their suits.

Have John Y. McKane or his agents been tampering with some of the witnesses for the people in the criminal suit in progress against him in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, in Brooklyn, for conspiring to hide the registration lists of Gravesend?

In addition to the new racing rules that are to be discussed at the coming assembly of the League of American Wheelmen and which have been formulated by the Racing Board as Classes A and B several amendments are to be made to other rules. They are as follows:

Mrs. William E. Sinn, or Miss Cora Tanner, as she is known on the stage, went to Dakota some time ago to bring suit for divorce against her husband, Col. William E. Sinn, the theatrical manager of Brooklyn. Since that time, stories have appeared in the newspapers throughout the country.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Where prices were not the same as the closing figures of Saturday, they were lower, making an active market for a time and a weak one for the most part.

A notable and significant change has taken place in rapid-transit matters within the last few days. The Rapid-Transit Commission seems to have seized upon a practical method for the solution of the vexed problem and the settlement of all the questions at issue concerning it.

We print elsewhere a communication from an architect who took part in the competition for the new Municipal Building. Most of his points appear to us to be very well taken. One of them is of the more consequence because it has been published, in a form which seemed to be authoritative, that the Commissioners were not limited in their choice to the six plans selected for them by their Advisory Commission.
Controller Fitch sent the following letter to Judge Daly yesterday:

Permission to lease the New-York and Putnam Railroad, formerly the New-York and Northern, was granted to the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company by the State Railroad Commissioners yesterday afternoon. The State Board made its decision known in Albany, and imposed the condition that the lessee company should give at least as good service and accommodations to the traveling public and shippers as has heretofore been rendered by the New-York and Northern.
The mystery of the Lucy McCarthy blackmailing case, which has been before the Grand Jury for nearly a week, was dispelled, yesterday by Superintendent of Police Byrnes.

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- In the Reichstag today, Count Posadowsky, Imperial Secretary of the Treasury, introduced the Financial Reform bill. He said that certain members of the House hoped to damage the bill by securing a postponement of its discussion until after the single bills connected with the financial reforms had been fully dealt with.

FREDONIA, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- The Frisbee block, occupied by J.C. Frisbee, job printing, the Buffalo Store, and the Home Medicine Co., was damaged by fire this morning to the extent of $2,000. The loss to the tenants is about $7,000, most of which falls on the Buffalo Store.

George Schiverea and his brother Ferdinand are known as "the evangelists of the masses." George was born in the City of Brooklyn thirty-two years ago, his mother being an American of old Puritan lineage and his father a Spaniard. Thirteen years ago, while the great evangelist Dwight L. Moody was preaching in the Brooklyn Rink, George, through the prayers of his widowed mother and the intercession of his brother Ferdinand, was converted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- It was to be expected that Mr. Chandler would develop something unique in his argument for the retention of the Federal elections laws, but nobody seems to have entertained the idea that he would yoke Grover Cleveland and David B. Hill together in connection with the election frauds by which the Legislature of New-York State became Democratic in 1892.

BATH, Me., Jan. 29. -- The fire in Bath yesterday was the worst the city has ever known. The heart of the business section lies in ruins. The loss closely approaches $500,000. A defective chimney in the stable office of the Sagadahoc House started the fire, and before the blaze was discovered the wooden stable building was in flames.

Edward L. Ford, thirty-two years old, of 2,054 Seventh Avenue was found drowned at 4 o'clock yesterday morning in a pond in Central Park, about 100 feet west of Fifth Avenue. The drowning is believed to have been accidental, as there does not appear to have been any motive for suicide.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- The Rev. Charles H. Parkhurst has scored a triumph, and Mr. Thomas C. Platt has been forced to change front in the presence of the enemy. The Police Department of New-York is to be investigated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Senate Committee on the Judiciary will not begin active consideration of the case of Wheeler H. Packham, nominated to be an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, until next Monday. This decision was reached at a meeting of the committee this morning.

The fickleness of Wilbur Sanford has involved the Society of Royal Good Fellows in a peck of trouble. Mr. Sanford was himself a Royal Good Fellow in his lifetime, and it is this fact that now makes him a mote in the eye of the other Good Fellows, bringing upon them a lawsuit and a swarm of lawyers.

The third production of "As You Like It," under the auspices of the Professional Women's League, was given last night at the Garden Theatre, under the management of Mr. A.M. Palmer. Among those taking part were literary and newspaper women, musicians and actors, who make up the general professional character of the league, and several non-members.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Jan. 29. -- There died here to-day a man who played an important part in a famous tragedy. Thomas Fair, in 1874, killed Oliver Ellison, and fled when an indictment for murder had been found against him. Ever since the disappearance Ellison's relatives have been looking for Fair, and have scoured the country for him, and yet for thirteen years he has been right in the heart of Milledgeville.

A new submarine cable, said to be the largest ever laid in this country, was stretched under the East River yesterday afternoon from the foot of Thirty-eighth Street to Hunter's Point, Long Island City, near the foot of Eighth Street. The cable was manufactured by the Safety Insulated Wire and Cable Company for the Metropolitan Telephone and Telegraph Company.
BOSTON, Jan. 29. -- Near the box office in Music Hall the following placard was posted this morning:

HAMILTON, Ohio, Jan. 29. -- Ex-Gov. James E. Campbell, reported to be in financial trouble in New-York, is regarded here as a poor man. It has been an open secret for two or three years that Mr. Campbell's finances were in a crippled condition. He has now little or no property here, and what he does own is incumbered.

The public will probably soon have a chance to express its opinion as to the question of sidewalks in the new speedway. Controller Fitch is looking closely into the matter, and will have something of interest to announce in a few days. Yesterday he said:

The second of the Bell Telephone Company's fundamental patents expires today. The first expired on March 7, 1893, but the suit in which the Government asks the courts to annul that patent has not yet emerged from its first stage, for the taking of testimony is not completed, although the proceedings were begun eight years ago, when seven years of the patent's term remained.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The failure to reach a prompt decision in the matter of the competitive designs for the new City Hall has caused widely-diverging comments in the daily press and in professional journals, Some of these comments were well taken, as, for instance, all those which appeared in your valuable paper.

The Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge are seriously perturbed. Complaints of their extravagant and incompetent management of the structure have multiplied to an extent that threatens their tenure of office.

The methods adopted by the Supervisors of Kings County is causing the business of the county to accumulate to the detriment of the various departments to the County Government. There was a gathering of the Republican Supervisors again yesterday, but, as there was no quorum, they adjourned to meet to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29. -- Nineteen men who sailed from New-York a few months ago on the Brazilian cruiser America were landed here to-day from Pernambuco by the British steamer De Bay. Acording to the story told by the men, the voyage of the America to Pernambuco was anything but a pleasant and easy one for the officers of the improvised war ship.
Money on call loaned, at 3/4@1 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29. -- The physicians attending George W. Childs issued the following bulletin at 1 o'clock this afternoon: "The pulse and temperature of Mr. Childs show some improvement, but otherwise his condition remains the same as at midnight last night."

Our readers will find in our news columns what the participants in the conference between Secretary Carlisle and the bankers and financiers of New-York have to report about it. We have no doubt that these reports are substantially accurate, or that the outcome of the conference will be for the public advantage.

Edward Mills, twenty-one years old, a guard on the United States Express Company's express train between Washington and Jersey City, was arrested yesterday morning by Detectives McCarthy and Cuff of the Central Office, charged in a dispatch from W.J. Moore, Chief of Police of Washington, with having shot a man in the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad station in Washington on Sunday night.

Under the above title The London Statist argues that the increase in the world's output of gold must be followed by an improvement in trade and a general rise in prices. It ascribes the fall of the past twenty years to three causes. First, the decrease in the gold output; second, the increase in the gold consumption, and third, the demonetization of silver.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Senate committee investigating the Hawaiian affair had before it this morning as its principal "witness Dr. William Shaw Bowen, the correspondent of The New-York World, who went to Honolulu shortly after the revolution. Mr. Bowen was present for the purpose of denying some statements made by Mr. Blount.
The French cooks of New-York, otherwise the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique, gave their twenty-eighth annual reception and ball last night at the Madison Square Garden.

Mrs. Dorothea Strich, who lived with her husband, Thedore, a cigar dealer, at 402 Third Avenue, was killed in the yard of her home last night by a clothes-line pole falling upon her. She was fifty years old. old.
PARIS, Jan. 29. -- The Princess Colonna, who has an action pending in the courts here for a judicial separation from her husband, has with her children and her mother, Mrs. Mackay, disappeared.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Hawaiian resolutions were taken up in the Senate today, and Mr. Teller (Rep., Col.,) made a speech. He criticised the phraseology of the resolution reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations, but intimated that he would vote for it. He did not like the phrase "de facto Government," and said that there was really no difference between a de facto-Government and a de jure Government.

The proceedings of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday were enlivened, toward the close of the session, by an animated debate on the tariff Question. There was a warm exchange of compliments between Aldermen Gullfoyle and Hess, which threatened at one time to lead to blows.

Rosina Vokes. News comes from London of the death on Saturday last of Rosina Yokes, who gave up her tour of this country because of illness a few weeks ago, and returned to England. Her malady was hasty consumption. She had been suffering with an affection of the heart for five or six years.

In the library of the University of Chicago has recently been placed probably the most complete set of the annals, debates, and records of Congress in existence. The addition to the library comprises 4,200 volumes, and includes many tomes that are not to be found in the collections of the Senate or the House of Representatives.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Wheat developed an indisputably strong tone toward the close to-day, notwithstanding the fact that the general run of news was of a nature which was calculated rather to deress than elevate values. There were, however, some encouraging ones. The opening was firm, influenced by higher Liverpool cables and quite a large decrease in the amount on passage, (1,448,000 bushels.)

BOSTON, Jan. 29. -- The market for local stocks and bonds showed rather more activity to-day in the variety of securities traded in, if not in number of shares. Atlantic and Pacific income bonds sold at 2 3/8, and Boston and Maine at 134. West End Street remained at 47. It is thought that the company will issue and sell bonds when a satisfactory price can be obtained.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 29. -- Republican Senators Voorhees and Smith were detained at their homes by illness to-day, and did not appear at the State House to-night. The Republican Senate adjourned until to-morrow without transacting any business. The Democratic Senate, in pursuance of its programme to adjourn from day to day, met, had the roll called, and immediately closed business for the night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- No information has reached the State Department, according to the officials there, of the reported action of Mr. Smythe, the United States Minister to Haiti, in sending the Haitian President an official document telling him how he should conduct his republic. Mr. Smythe's recall, it is intimated, will be a matter of quick accomplishment if the report shall prove true.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 29. -- Gen. Francois Manigat, who has been plotting to start a revolution in Haiti, was arrested to-day.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 29. -- A dispatch dated on Jan. 25, at Rio de Janeiro, says that Admiral Mello was then at Curitiba. He was expected to start north shortly. Gen. Saraiva, commander of the largest insurgent land force, was then at Sao Paulo.

Both sections of the Republican Party in this city, namely, the representatives of the Committee of Thirty and the anti-machins men, took aggressive positions yesterday, and signs of a contest large enough to be called "war" were evident on both sides.

School Commissioner Edward Bell has hit upon a very practical form of charity at this time of the year, when fickle weather conditions give us streets one day hard and frosted and another ankle deep in chilling slush -- the undertaker's best friend.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29. -- The strictly local stocks did not sympathize with the higher prices from London. Both New-England and St. Paul were active, and traders were rather disposed to hammer them. Traction stocks were all inactive. Only twenty-two shares of Philadelphia changed hands at 82 1/2, and forty shares of Metropolitan at 101 1/4.

ROME, Jan. 29. -- Burglars last night forced an entrance into the American Legation, 13 Via Nazionale, by breaking the locks. The thieves broke open the safe and the desks of the Minister and Consul General and then set fire to all the papers in the offices. A number of the archives were completely destroyed and others partially burned.

The elections that are to occur in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congressional Districts of this city to-day are really of great, and may become of national, importance. Normally, there would be no doubt at all of Democratic success in either, and the only danger now is that of overconfidence.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- In the Assembly tonight the air was thick with rumors that several resolutions detrimental to the interests of the Democrats would be introduced. Mr. Hobbie of Washington, it was reported, has a bag full of them. The Democrats thereupon agreed upon a course of obstruction calculated to prevent their passage.

To-day in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congressional Districts of this city a special election will be held, by proclamation of Gov. Flower, to fill the vacancies caused in the New-York State delegation in the National House of Representatives by the resignations of Ashbel P. Fitch, elected Controller of this city at the last election, and Col. John R. Fellows, who was elected District Attorney at the same time.

In the face of a driving gale that lashed in their faces the cutting sleet, and through streets where lay the slush almost ankle-deep, hundreds of people gathered from all parts of Brooklyn yesterday noon in the large hall of the Young Men's Christian Association, where an evangelistic meeting was held.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- The independent Senator from Kings County, Senator Bradley, has made his two simian colleagues come down from their tree, as it was exclusively predicted in these columns on Thursday last that he would do. Senator John McCarty, who up to to-night represented the Gravesend district in the Senate, was not in his seat this evening, nor will he be seen there hereafter.

In all the talk about passing a bill at Albany reorganizing the Police Board of this city and providing for four Commissioners, two of whom shall belong to each political party, there does not seem to be even a pretense that its purpose is to improve the administration of the department or that it would have any such effect.

The Coney Island Jockey Club is going to introduce hurdle racing and steeplechasing at the Sheepshead Bay courseagain. The last jumping race at this favorite track was in 1885, but then owners and riders of jumpers were in such bad repute that the Coney Island Club decided to have no more of them.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

ZURICH, Jan. 29. -- A body of Anarchists, some of whom caried red and black flags, made a demonstration to-day in front of the Italian Consulate in this city. The object of the Anarchists was to show their sympathy with the Sicillans in their revolutionary movement against the communal and other Italian authorities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish you could have your paper circulate more generally through this State. It is worth, to any man who loves his country and possesses a sense of public duty, many times the cost price thereof. Besides being a most excellent newspaper, its policy upon all public questions is broad, sound, and statesmanlike.

Miss Merrifield accepted the offer of Mr. Brooks's escort from Mrs. Symonds's reception. Miss Merrifield adored Mr. Brooks, and more than half suspected that Mr. Brooks adored her. In fact, she hoped for a declaration that very night.

The Forum, at its reduced price, maintains its high quality. In the current number are thirteen papers, the contributors including Josephine S. Lowell, Dr. Lyman Abbott, James Sehouler, Frederic Harrison, Edgar Atkinson, and Woodrow Wilson. The topics are timely, and range from charity and aid to unemployed, to the Wilson bill incomes in England, Hawaii, the Nicaragua Canal, and English literature of the present time.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- At a meeting of the State Civil Service Commission to-day the following was unanimously adopted:

The House has screwed the income tax to the Tariff bill, but it has not riveted it on, and we do not believe that that can be done. The situation is awkward, not creditable to Democratic statesmanship or Republican good sense. It is, indeed, a little ridiculous, considering the opportunity, the duty, and the interest of the party in power.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 29. -- The Dolphin Silk Mill resumed operations to-day with 500 weavers, which has greatly encouraged the Citizens' Relief Committee, which has been providing food for fifty families, the heads of which had been employed at this factory.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 26, via Montevideo, Jan. 29. -- The Minister of Justice, representing Peixoto, engaged to meet Admiral Benham officially at noon yesterday at the American Consulate. The Admiral, attired in full uniform, was at the Consulate at the appointed time, but the Minister of Justice did not appear.

MANSFIELD, Penn., Jan. 29. -- The rioting miners directed their attention to-day toward the Cherry Mines at Hayes Station, on the main line of the Pan Handle Railroad. At that place, which is about four miles from Mansfield, are situated the mines and tipple of Morris McCue.

Two policemen carrying lanterns invaded the six-story building at 537 Broadway early yesterday morning, and spent nearly an hour searching from the cellar to the roof in an unsuccessful endeavor to discover Mrs. Bertha Kovalsky, who was supposed to have been locked in the place when it was closed on Saturday night.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 29. -- In the absence of a definite expression on the part of the Yale University relative to the rules submitted last June, and in view of the necessity of deciding upon the eligibility of candidates for the crew, the nine and the track athletic team, the University Athletic Committee has recommended to the Captains and managers of those organizations the following rules:

NEW-YORK, Monday, Jan. 29 -- P.M. Irregularity was the feature of to-day's market. The trading was not large, but there was more business done than on recent days. London appeared as a good buyer at the opening of Louisville and Nashville, St. Paul, and Atchison, particularly of the first named.

It was rumored among real estate men that the Bank for Savings, which is putting up a handsome building for its own use at the southwest corner of Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, had purchased the remainder of the avenue front on that block. President Trimble of the bank said yesterday afternoon that this was news to him.

The principal theatrical incident in this city last night -- the worst "first night" of the Winter in the matter of weather -- was the beginning of the engagement of Helena Modjeska at the Fifth Avenue Theatre. This engagement by the way, is for a fortnight only; times are too hard and competition in theatrical wares too brisk for even such an artist to profitably remain in New-York longer than that this Winter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The silver Senators of both parties would like to bring about the passage of the resolution declaring the proposed bond issue to be unlawful. That is plain to every one who is watching the situation. They are endeavoring to constrain the Administration to the end that an order may be issued for the coinage of the seigniorage to restore the Government balance.

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- While Prince Bismarck was returning from Berlin to Friedrichsruh on Friday last, a group of spectators at the Wittenberge station inquired as to the Prince's health. Bismarck replied that he 'had stood the journey remarkably well.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- After considerable debate the Senate this morning passed unanimously the resolutions introduced by Senator Lenow last evening providing for an investigation of the Police Department of New-York City. It was a foregone conclusion from the first that the New-York City members, as stated in this morning's New-York Times, would not only support the resolutions, but encourage the work of the committee, which Senator Saxton will announce to-morrow.

The meeting of the Rapid-Transit Commission yesterday afternoon lasted but ten minutes, five of which were given up by Messrs. Bushe, Inman, Starin, and Porter, the Commissioners present, to listening, with a stolidity learned of long practice, to the protests of property holders on certain thoroughfares as to the route of the structure as proposed in the Bushe plan.

To the Editor of The New- York Times: So much uncertainty still exists as to the final settlement of the municipal buildings competition that competitors begin to feel that they are not receiving proper consideration.

The dissentions which have arisen in the Tomchai Talmud Thora Oheil Itzock, an institution of learning at 36 Orchard Street, were discussed before Justice Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, upon a petition presented by H. Sarasohn, who asked the court to determine who should act as officers of the corporation.

From The Leeds Mercury. The Abbe Gamier delivered a lecture the other afternoon in the Theatre d' Application, in the Rue St. Lazare, Paris, on his system for providing pensions for old age for the working classes, by means of his newly-founded Journal, Le Peuple Francais. The Abbe began by saying that there were unworked fields in which the journalist could do much good in connection with various departments of practical life.

"Wall Street's patriotism can be counted on when the Nation is in a strait. The fifty-million-dollar loan can be counted on as placed, as subscriptions aggregating $27,150,000 had been made when I left New-York."

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The Republican Senators failed to carry out the programme that was arranged last night to force through the report of the Committee on Privileges and Elections which recommends the unseating of John McCarty, the Democratic member from the Sixth District.
