Senator Cantor, the Democratic leader, in a few caustic remarks, made the suggestion that the proper course to pursue was to carry the matter over to Thursday.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- The Investigation into the management of the reformatory was resumed at the institution before Stale Charities Commissioner Edward H. Litchfield at 10 o'clock this morning. The death of Oscar Craig, Chairman of the investigating committee, and the absence of Dr. Smith, who is in Paris as United States Commissioner to the International Sanitary Congress, left Mr. Litchfield as the only member of the committee.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- The Chamber of Deputies was crowded to-day with, persons anxious to hear the interpellation of the Government by M. Lockroy in regard to the condition of the navy. The galleries were filled and the benches in the body of the house were all occupied by members. Among those present were Count Hoyos-Sprtnzenstein, the Austrian Ambassador to France.

Like every large individual property owner, the Corporation of the City of New-York has a counsel of its own, and once a year that dignitary, who is properly known, as the Corporation Counsel, submits his report, and puts in evidence a resume of what he has been doing for his money.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The hearing which is to take place on Thursday next in the Senate Chamber on the O'Connor bill promises to be unique in the annals of legislation. The O'Connor bill practically emasculates the wholesome provisions of the bill which was passed last year placing the expenditures of the eight State hospitals of the State under the supervision and control of officers representing the whole State.

The set of the current was against the Democrats in the special Congressional elections yesterday. Col. Brown in the Fourteenth District was quite swept oft his feet, his Republican opponent, Quigg, carrying the district by 984 plurality. Isidor Straus, an exceptionally strong candidate, carried the Fifteenth District for the Democrats by 4,687 plurality over Sigrist.

EASTPORT, Me., Jan. 30. -- The easterly storm which began, here last night at 8 o'clock, with possibly one exception is the most severe that has visited this section since the famous gale of 1869. The possible exception was the blizzard of March 13, 1888, which played such havoc on the Atlantic coast.

Mr. McLeod, accompanied by his counsel, Mr. J.G. Johnson, appeared before Special Master Crawford in Philadelphia yesterday on the resumption of the hearing on the complaint of Mr. Isaac L. Rice in the suit for the removal of the receivers of the Reading Railroad, and watched the progress of events with considerable interest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Intense interest has been manifested to-day at the Navy and State Departments in the public reports from Rio direct and by way of London. As a matter of course the officers of the two departments were appealed to for verification of the news, but could give nothing but denials of the report that da Gama had surrendered.

Gustav H. Schwab, manager of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company, gave out a statement yesterday in regard to the pooling of the passenger and freight business of his company with the Hamburg-American Packet Company.

Our esteemed contemporary the Courrier des Etats-Unis has received from Chicago the letter of which we subjoin a translation, reproducing, as not properly translatable, the metrical imitation of a classical and renowned French curse of Corneille into which the emotions of the writer are rapt when they, take him beyond the power of prose:

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 30. -- Bishop Wigger of the Diocese of Newark furnishes the following translation of the reply of Cardinal Ledochowski, Prefect of the Propaganda at Rome, to the appeal made by the Rev. P. Cotrrigan against the decision of Bishop Wigger and his council on the Hoboken school question:

Two fires in as many days have done $75,000 damage to the store of Hegeman Co., druggists, 196 Broadway. The first blaze was on Monday morning, and caused a loss of $45,000. The second had ruined $30,000 worth of stock and natures last evening before the firemen got it under control.

Mrs. Bertha Ehlenburg appeared before Justice Lawrence in the Supreme Court yesterday to tell what she had done with her twelve-year-old granddaughter Carrie. The child's mother. Rose Ehlenburg, obtained a writ of habeas corpus on Monday, directing her mother-in-law to produce the child in court.
Mayor Schieren's suspension of Fire Commissioner John Ennis of Brooklyn was set aside by Justice Landon in the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday. Mr. Ennis was reinstated as Fire Commissioner.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The Committee on Banks grave a Joint hearing this afternoon in the Senate Chamber on the Mullin bill, extending the field of investment of savings banks to bonds of cities in the New-England States, New-Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois, Wisconsin, Michigan, and Missouri of more than 50,000 inhabitants.

-- Martin Rouse, one of the oldest members of the Produce Exchange, and its official Provision Inspector, died yesterday at his home in Jersey City, of blood poisoning. At the time of his death he was sixty-eight years old, having passed fifty-five years of that time in active business. Mr. Rouse was a member of the firm of Goulard, Rouse Co., and had been a partner there for thirty-four years.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- In the Assembly to-day, Mr. Kerr (Dem., Greene,) introduced a bill providing for a non-partisan Board of State Assessors, to consist of five members, to be appointed by the Governor and confirmed by the Senate. The terms of the present three Assessors and of two new ones to be appointed shall be determined by the Governor, but the term of one shall expire each year.

Isaac D. Barton was yesterday appointed General Superintendent of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad, to succeed F.O. Nichols, who has held that position several years. The change is a result of the recent election of new Directors and executive officers. Mr. Barton is an old aide of Austin Corbin. He has served him as Superintendent of the Manhattan Beach Railroad and also of the Long Island Railroad.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 30. -- The General Assembly met this morning at the time to which Gov. Brown prorogued it last June. The Senate was called to order by the Governor, and the oath of office was administered to Senator Coggeshall of Bristol, a new member. Dr. Vose was the Chaplain. The House was notified that the Senate was ready for business and the Governor's mesage was read.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 30 -- This afternoon objections to the certificate of nomination and nomination papers of James Denton Hancock, the Democratic candidate for Congressman at Large, were presented to the Dauphin County Court by John M. Ormsby of Philadelphia, who claims that the certificate is defective because the convention which nominated Hancock was illegal, inasmuch as it was not convened under the rules of the party.

Edward Mills, the guard on the Baltimore and Ohio express train who shot and seriously wounded Thomas Devery in Washington while the latter was trying to board the train, Sunday night, will return to Washington without awaiting a requisition.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Jan. 30 -- P.M. To-day's market upset the calculations of the bears that fear of the failure of Secretary Carlisle's bond-issue plan would reflect upon the credit of the Government, raise interest rates, and smash prices of stocks.

FOSTORIA, Ohio, Jan. 30. -- Emerson Steele of Findlay drilled in a well on the Lambright farm this forenoon which discharges at the rate of 1,000 or more barrels of oil a day and gives every indication of lasting. The well is directly west of the Maloney well, which has been producing 300 barrels daily for some time.
Special elections for Congressmen to succeed Col. John R. Fellows in the Fourteenth and Ashbel P. Fitch in the Fifteenth Districts were held yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The State Civil Service Commission has adopted the following:

The Board of Governors of the Coney Island Jockey Club met last night to consider what answer should be sent to the Board of Horse Owners. Mr. John Hunter wrote to the club asking the Governors to state under what conditions they would Join with the ney Jockey club.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 30. -- There was a pathetic scene in the Orphans' Court to-day when Counselor Moses J. De Witt applied for an order to set the amount of money to be divided by the guardian of the eight children of John. E. Platt, who died at Avondale on Oct. 29. There was $3,000 from a Royal Arcanum lodge to be divided among the eight children.

WEST POINT, Jan. 30. -- The huge derrick erected for the purpose of hoisting the Battle Monument shaft was blown down at 2 o'clock this afternoon. A gust of wind from the west snapped the guy ropes, and 8,000 feet of lumber, which formed the pyramidal structure, swung around and toppled over.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Secretary Carlisle is to-night confident that the bond issue will be promptly taken at advantageous prices, and that the offers will exceed the $50,000,000 proposed to be sold. The last doubt about the success of the undertaking appeared to be removed to-day, as soon as the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia threw out of court the application for a restraining order upon the Secretary.

Darwin R. James, who has served as Treasurer of the Central Evangelical Committee, is one of the best-known citizens of Brooklyn. He has lived in that city since 1847, having moved there In that year from Williamsburg, Mass., his native place. His early education was at the Mount Pleasant Boarding School at Mount Pleasant, Mass.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 30 -- Andres Amaya and Santiago de Viacente, ex-office holders in San Salvador, reached this city last night from Honduras, on board the steamship Breakwater.

The suit by which the New-York Associated Press purposes to collect $50,280 from the Western Associated Press, and, incidentally, to reap the neat little additional sum of $223,000, the share of profits of the Michigan concern, was, technically, advanced yesterday before Commissioner John A. Shields, as "one of the standing examiners of the United States Circuit Court of the Southern District of New-York."

W. Steinitz, the champion chess player of the world, gave an exhibition of simultaneous play at the Newark Chess Club on Monday evening. Steinitz conducted four games, the blacks being played by two Newark men in consultation on each board. There was a large gathering of spectators, who followed the games with great interest.
In closing our article yesterday morningon "The Secretary and the Bankers," we said:
Dr. Doty of the Health Board stated yesterday that it was by no means certain that Dr. John F. Cremin of 445 "West Fifty-seventh Street had contracted smallpox as reported.

Mrs. M.E. Willson, whose singing has contributed notably to the success of the revival movement, was born in 1842 in Clearfield County, Penn. She made a public profesison of faith in Christ at the age of eight years. In company with her brother, P.P. Bliss, she acquired a high reputation as an effective religious vocalist.

BOSTON, Jan. 30. -- The steamer Santuit, which arrived at Pernambuco, Brazil, recently, from New-York, with the Brazilian torpedo boat Pirating in tow, is still at that port. She is awaiting the decision of the Brazilian Government with regard to the purchase of the steamer, which their contract with Messrs. L.G. Burnham Co., the owners of the steamer, gives them the privilege of doing, at a fixed price.

From The Utica Observer. Jan. 27. The New-York Times prints to-day a very good picture of the young New-York City Republican representative in the Assembly the Hon. James R. Sheffield. Although born in Dubuque, Mr. Sheffield is "a Utica boy," for he was reared in this town. It is not a dozen years since he sat in the Utica Free Academy, enjoying the friendship of all the boys.

Frederick W. Wurster will become Fire Commissioner of Brooklyn to-morrow. One of Ills first duties will be to institute a thorough investigation into the past administration of the department. Alike by training and inclination Mr. Wurster is well qualified for the task before him. As the owner and manager of a large manufacturing establishment he has had ample experience in the duties of practical executive work.

Justice Gaynor, in Brooklyn, heard argument yesterday in the case of William Denithorne, a member of the De Kalb Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, against the Excise Commissioners to enjoin the latter from licensing Ernest Ochs's saloon, at De Kalb and Franklin Avenues.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 30. -- Adolph Schmidt, President of the Oregon Mining Company, was sent to jail this morning by Judge Toney, after a sensational trial, for contempt of court. A warrant was also issued for George H. Dietz, Secretary of the company, but he could not be found.

W.H.T. Hughes of the Ward Line of steamships was sent for by Collector Kilbreth yesterday and asked to explain the charge that goods manufactured in Germany had, before being forwarded to Havana, been sworn to on the manifests of the company's ships as American goods.

There are signs that some friends of tariff reform, and among them representatives from the great commercial and manufacturing State of New-York, do not fully realize the imperative necessity of passing the Tariff bill in spite of the obnoxious income-tax amendment. We assure these gentlemen that any aid, direct or indirect, in defeating, delaying, or embrassing the passage of the bill would be, without regard to the income tax, an inexcusable blunder.

The Chicago Inter Ocean, a prominent and industrious defender of McKinleyism, is shocked by the vote in the House that put all kinds of sugar on the free list and cut off the bounty. It appears to believe that if this action should be confirmed the Government would lose a large sum in revenue which it now receives.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30 -- There is a fair prospect that the trouble over the organization of the Senate may be settled within a reasonable time. The Governor has under consideration several schemes by which quo warranto proceedings against the eleven Republican Senators might be begun, but it is not probable that any of them will be made use of.

Superintendent Bymes, regardless of the mysterious action of the Grand Jury in refusing to bring indictments, has not dropped his investigation into Mrs. Lucy McCarthy's charge that 32,500 was taken from, her by three "high officials," who promised her police protection -- Henry W. Beardsley, until a week, ago a Civil Service Examiner; John C. Munzinger, a lawyer practicing in the Yorkville Police Court, and Conrad M. Smyth, Clerk of the Yorkville Police Court.
Civil Justice Murphy, in the Lee Avenue Court, Williamsburg, yesterday prevented a sewing machine agent taking a machine from a family who were too poor to pay an installment upon it.

The motives of the investigation of the Police Department of this city which has been ordered by a resolution of the Senate, to be conducted by a special committee of seven appointed by President Pro Tem. Saxton, are open to suspicion. The fact that the resolution was offered by Senator Lexow is taken as evidence that the investigation was virtually "ordered" by Mr. Platt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations this morning continued the Hawalian investigation. P.W. Reader, who resides in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and was a tourist in the islands at the time of the revolution, having gone there about four months prior to the outbreak, was the witness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The news of the New-York Congressional elections was eagerly inquired for to-night. When it was learned that Col. Brown had been defeated, his many friends in Washington, knowing his desire to come here in an official capacity, were greatly disappointed, but they were not much surprised.
Capt. John T. Hinman furnished the sensation of yesterday in the trial of John Y. McKane in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer.

Mr. Philip Jeselson has sold for Max Marx, to Mr. Samuel Coles, the three-story and basement dwelling, 412 West One Hundred and Forty-sixth Street, 20 by 55 by 100, for $21,000. This is one of a row of nine sold through Mr. Jeselson for William H. Hall last week.

Thomas F. Farrell, Clerk to the Kings County Board of Supervisors, is literally running the County Legislature. Since the organization in January he has fought the Supervisor at Large, paying no attention to that official's requests, and acting in a disagreeable manner generally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The sudden return of Senator McPherson from the South, whither he went several weeks ago for the benefit of his health, following closely upon the appoitment of Mr. Mills as a member of the Senate Committee on Finance to serve during the New-Jersey Senator's absence, has caused a good deal of comment.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 30. -- A conflict between the American and insurgent fleets is possible on account of the action of Admiral Benham in protecting American commerce by the guns of the Detroit. Admiral da Gama is angry because the younger insurgent officers are eager to fight.

From Harper's Weekly. From whatever point of view the appointment of Mr. Wheeler H. Peckham to the vacant Judgeship of the Supreme Court is regarded, it is excellent. Mr. Peckham himself is one of the leaders of the bar of New-York. His father sat for many years on the Court of Appeals bench, and his brother is now a Judge of that court.

Mayor Schieren presided at a hearing in the Mayor's office, Brooklyn, yesterday, at which Excise Commissioner John Schliemann romised to produce evidence that Philo W. Scofield was not a proper man for the Mayor to associate with.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The term of importance of George A. Owens, who was in good faith elected by the citizens of the Fourth Senatorial District of Kings as a Republican, has lasted exactly four weeks. To-day Owens is a legislative outcast. He has been repudiated by his Republican colleagues, whom he has habitually snubbed.
Friends of the late Mrs. Emily E. Ford of Brooklyn met yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights, to honor her memory.

William H. Crane, the comedian, is now wearing the most expensive coat button that was ever produced in this or any other country, free trade or protectionist. It cost the actor precisely $1,815, and his chances of ever receiving a rebate are exceedingly small. This is how it happened:

Mrs. Catharine Fitzgerald, who is charged with, having killed Mrs. Carrie Pearsall, was declared sane yesterday by the commission appointed Dec. 20, 1893, to examine her. The decision was filed in Part I., General Sessions. The commission was composed of Charles F. Jackson, George B. Fowler, and John V. Wheeler.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Senate will vote on the Federal Elections bill next Tuesday afternoon. An agreement to that effect was reached to-day. Mr. Gorman, who has been chafing over the delay in the progress of the measure, undertook this morning to bring about a change for the better.

Davis's Oil Works, on the Gowanus Canal, at the foot of Eighth Street, South Brooklyn, were burned yesterday and three workmen were seriously injured. The fire was caused by an explosion, which occurred about noon in a large tank in the refinery room.

The anti-machine Republicans wish it to be understood that they are fighters not alone against the machinations of the County Committee, but in behalf of the personal safety of their members. They will add to the qualities heretofore possessed by members of the party a degree of pugnacity which they believe will be effective against those who interfere with peaceable citizens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The President and Mrs. Cleveland dined to-night at the residence of the Secretary of the Interior and Mrs. Hoke Smith. The dining room was transformed into a bower of bloom. From the centre of the ceiling countless strands of asparagus vines, gemmed with white camellia blossoms sent from Georgia for the occasion, radiated to all parts of the room.

All the trotters, imported hackneys, and crossbred hackney trotting stock, property of the late T.C. Eastman, whose farm was at Tarrytown, N.Y., were sold by auction yesterday in the American Institute Building, Third Avenue and Sixty-third Street. There were very few representative trotting horse men present, and only a few hackney breeders, as Joseph Wiedener, Philadelphia, Penn.; H.G. and R. Cheney, Manchester, Conn., and F.G. Bourne, this city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- To-morrow's debate on the Tariff bill is expected to be very interesting, and the desire to hear Speaker Crisp and Mr. Reed, who are to be heard on Thursday morning, just before the vote is taken, will undoubtedly fill the galleries to their utmost capacity.

Dr. Robert J. Haywood of 18 West Ninety-third Street charged Dr. Leopold Hibbe of 235 Sixth Street and his nephew, C.G. Marchmeedt, in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, with swindling him OUT of $12,000. Marchmeedt, who is said to be an active Thecsophist, was arrested on a farm near Saratoga, and Hibbe was arrested at his home yesterday morning.

Fully 15,000 persons assembled in Madison Square Garden last evening in response to a call issued by a conference of leaders of various representatives of workingmen in this city to all the unemployed who demand work.

The Hamburg-American steamship Fuerst Bismarck will sail this afternoon on a Winter excursion to the Mediterranean and Orient. The itinerary of the cruise embraces fourteen ports, among them such places of interest to the traveler as Alexandria, Athens, Constantinople, Naples, and Genoa. The company limited the number of saloon passengers to 270.

The condition and necessities of the Union Pacific Railroad were discussed by the Subcommittee on Reorganization at 80 Broadway yesterday. There were present Senator Brice, J. Pierpont Morgan, A.A.H. Boissevain, and Gen. Louis Fitzgerald. Mr. Morgan presided. A plan, outlined toy Mr. Boissevain, was considered, and other plans will be taken up and discussed within the next few days.

Andrew J. Weightman, a well-known real estate dealer, whose office is in Temple Court, was arraigned before Justice Martin In the Tombs Police Court yesterday. Weightman is a gray-mustached, handsome man, apparently about fifty years old. He has been prominent in real estate circles, where he earned the reputation of being one of the most active workers in the business.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., Jan. 31 -- Mrs. Leland Staford arrived at Vina Saturday evening in her private car on a tour of inspection of properties. Yesterday, having concluded her business, she ordered her car taken to a side track near the station, so she could leave by the south-bound Oregon express, passing Vina at midnight.

Harry Darrin, the champion professional short-distance runner of the world, who trained. "Charley" Mitchell, the pugilist, for his contest with Corbett, sailed for England yesterday on the Germanic. A large number of sporting men assembled on the pier and wished the popular runner a pleasant voyage.

J.M. Hill must really be out of his mind if tie thinks the adoption of a silly rural gift enterprise scheme will increase the profits of a New-York City theatre in the year 1894. It is not possible that Mr. Hill believes that New-Yorkers are generally fools, even the wayfarers of Broadway who "happen" in at such "shows" as his at Herrmann's!
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

The jury which is trying John Y. McKane in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer for conspiring to hide the Gravesend registration lists listened yesterday to the graphic story of the treatment of the watchers sent to the village by William J. Gaynor on election day.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- Edward Blake, M.P., delivered an address at Music Hall this evening, by invitation of a committee of Boston citizens, on the status of the home rule movement. The meeting was preceded by a complimentary dinner, which Mayor Matthews, Collector Beard, and other prominent Bostonians attended.

JAMAICA, L.I., Jan. 31 -- Miss Annie Muller, daughter of Martin Muller, a prosperous farmer of Springfield, was to have been married yesterday to Mr. Olvins Fletcher of Newark, N.J. The bride was ready and the guests were assembled in St. Boniface's Roman Catholic Church, at Foster's Meadow, where the ceremony was to be performed by the Rev. Joseph Hauser.

Miss Alice K. Ives, a successful writer, who has also succeeded in the difficult task of writing plays, told the members of the Professional Woman's League yesterday afternoon how the work of the playwright is done.

ITHACA, Jan. 31 -- The Museum of Classical Archaeology of Cornell University, the gift of Henry W. Sage. was dedicated this afternoon. The exercises, which took place in Barnes Hail, consisted of an address of presentation bu the donor, an address of acceptance, in behalf of the university, by President Schumnan, and an address by Prof A.C. Merriam of Columbia College on "The American School of Classical Studies at Athens."

Mr. Harry Quilter, at one time art critic for London journals -- Whistler's 'Arry, whom the American painter accused of ignoring the difference between oils and water color until he had a chance to smell of the surface -- has had the fatuousness to open an exhibition of his own pictures and appeal to the press as to his standing as an artist.
To urge the passage of a bill now before the Legislature looking to the abolition of the "vampire" system, a mass meeting was held last evening by waiters and cooks at 50 Cast Tenth Street.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Mayor Farr has devised a plan for the relief of the poor and unemployed of Bayonne, which should yield about $2,000 immediately. He proposes assessments upon all salaried city officials, and the Councilmen and School Trustees who serve without pay. He asks Councilmen and Trusteed to contribute $15 each, policemen $25, highest salaried officials $40, others various sums down to $15.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The Factory Inspectors to-day transmitted their eighth annual report to the Legislature. It will make a volume of over 700 pages. In the course of the year 1893 the Inspectors visited 11,088 factories, workshops, and sweatshops. In these places there were found 412,237 persons employed, 138,708 of whom were women and girls.
At the close of business in Wall Street yesterday the total subscriptions to the fifty-million-dollar 5 per cent, loan were $45,850,000. of which $3,000,000 came from three Boston firms.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 31 -- The greatest excitment prevails here among all classes, und among naval men especially, over the nervy action of Admiral Benham in protecting United States merchantmen from the fire of the insurgent guns.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A further loss of $400,000 in gold is reported at the Treasury to-day, leaving the gold balance at $65,500,000 and showing a loss in the month of January of $10,000,000.

Considerable interest is being manifested in the Canadian skating cmampionships to be held in Montreal on Saturday next. A dispatch from that city yesterday said that Joseph F. Donoghue and James A. Donoghue of Newburg, N.Y., John S. Johnson of Minneapolis, Harley Davidson of St. Paul, and a number of other skaters have arrived there to attend the Canadian amateur championships Saturday.

Mayor Gilroy looked weary yesterday when asked what progress had been made toward deciding on a plan for the new City Hall. He tacitly admitted that while it was improbable that the Municipal Building Commission would meet for several weeks, it was improbable that at that session anything decisive would be done.

The story of the behavior of the Brazilian insurgents in the face of the United States squadron at Rio reads much like the libretto of a new operabouffe. It is to be borne in mind that the insurgents have not, and have not had, any belligerant footing whatsoever. That is to say, they have never had undisputed possession of any Brazilian territory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- There is no longer any doubt that the Tariff bill will be passed to-morrow, and that it will go through the House with the income-tax amendment.
The members of Mayor Schieren's Cabinet take office to-day. The new chiefs of departments are:

Since the Legislature has determined to investigate the Police Department in this city, the committee appointed at Whitelaw Reid's dinner party has suspended the work of preparing a Police Commission bill. The one which the committee had substantially agreed upon, providing for the four-headed commission, is laid upon the shelf, and the committee has given up holding regular meetings.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Some twelve or fifteen years ago a clique of teachers in the public schools of this city organised a nursery into which was born a "bill " providing for the pensioning of teachers. Since then the little "bill" has been dandled before successive Legislatures, until now it has become quite a muscular and aggressive raider upon the defenses of the public treasury.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- The Eastern Baseball League Circuit Committee met this afternoon at the Hotel Kenmore. Applications were received from Syracuse, represented by George M. Kuentsch, and Toronto, represented by W.W. Burnham, formerly the manager of the Providence Grays. No action was taken on the applications.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 31 -- A shocking fatality occurred at 4:45 o'clock this afternoon on the Brownell Street grade crossing of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad. A sleighing party, made up of twenty-eight members of the sophomore class of the B.M.C. Thurfee High School, was returning from a ride.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- There was little in the Brazilian situation to-day in Washington to gratify those with a taste for the sensational. Nothing was received at the Navy Department, although the officers there expected Admiral Benham to send some message. Commodore Ramsay, the Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, visited the department at 11 o'clock last night, but no telegram had been received.

Miss Olive L. Willson, who has accompanied her mother during the revival, inherits much of Mrs. Willson's ability. Her voice is sweet and powerful, and her ability as a pianist and organist has been widely commended.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Senator McPherson of New-Jersey has decided to resume his connection with the Senate Committee on Finance, and Mr. Mills, who was appointed, last week to act in his place during his absence, will not have an opportunity to bring his knowledge of the tariff question to bear in the committee room while the Wilson bill is under discussion there.

The joint committee of horse owners and the Board of Control had a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Board of Control rooms, in the Cumberland, Twenty-second Street and Fifth Avenue. Those present were John Hunter, James R. Keene, Perry Belmont, Dr. Knapp, J.J. Galway, and Col. W.P. Thompson.

Humphrey B. Chamberlin, President of the Chamberlin Investment Company of Denver, Col., was a prisoner in this city yesterday in custody of Sheriff Clancy. He was arrested on the complaint of Joseph E. Paisley, a wealthy shoe dealer of 397 Sixth Avenue, who charges that Mr. Chamberlin swindled him out of $5.173.
The great religious revival in Brooklyn is moving onward. Four large meetings were held dpring the daytime yesterday, and at night fully a score of churches held earnest and attentive audiences.

The report of the Rapid-Transit Commission upon the Wilson plan was received by Mayor Gilroy yesterday. The Commissioners favor the adoption of the plan, which essentially provides for the construction of an underground railroad at an estimated cost of $45,000,000, of which two-thirds is to be paid by the city and the remainder by private capital.

Reports of railway earnings continue to wear an encouraging aspect. Since the 1st of January they have indicated a gradual, but steady and widespreading, increase in the business of railroad transportation. The rate of increase in the earnings for the third week over those of the second week is considerably greater than was the rate of increase of the second over the first week's earnings.

Prudery seems to flourish in the chaste atmosphere of the United Stales Senate. The medal for prize winners at the World's Fair has made a very different impression on a select body of sculptors and connoisseurs who inspected the design on Tuesday night to discover what all the fuss might be about.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 31 -- It is reported that Gov. Wefts has gone to his house in Jersey City to think out a plan by which the Senate trouble may be settled. The Republican Senators had an hour's conference at noon, at which they considered the proposition made by Gov. Werts to President Rogers of the Republican Senate yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Secretary Herbert must soon make a decrease in the temporary roll of the Navy Department. It is on this roll that 500 clerks are carried by appointment without the trouble of passing a civil service examination. The force is employed ostensibly on clerical work connected with the increase of the navy, and the employes are paid out of the general fund known as the appropriation for the increase of the navy.
There is every indication that Superintendent Byrnes's determination to push the McCarthy blackmailing cases, despite their dismissal by the January Grand Jury, will bear fruit.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The Republican Senatorial caucus which took place to-day after the adjournment of the session had several very uncertain issues presented to it. There probably would have been no caucus if it had not been for these issues.
RIO JANEIRO, Jan. 31 -- American vessels that desire to come to the piers of the city can now do so without being interfered with by the insurgents.

The Park Commissioners did not hold a formal meeting yesterday, but Messrs. Tappen, Clausen, and Straus met and talked over the matter of the Harlem River driveway. While they were discussing as to what the probable action of the Controller would be. Dr. Stanton Coit, who has been urging the city authorities to make work for the unemployed, appeared before them.

In the three-sided contest respecting the disposition of the residuary estate of Daniel B. Fayerweather, the plaintiff colleges and the defendant executors have put in the greater part of their evidence before Judge Truax in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, and yesterday Col. James, representing the executors of Mrs. Fayerweather and the next of kin, made some progress toward finishing his side of the case.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- In the Coughlin trial to-day the first alibi witness was Michael Whalen, a first cousin of the late P. O'Sullivan, who went on the Chicago police force an 1878. As a detective he was attached to the same police station as Coughlin the day of the murder, and two days afterward was assigned to travel with the defendant.
To the Editor to The New York Times: It certainly would be an interesting sight to see The Times attempt to recouncile these two statements:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your Issue of Jan. 14 you printed a letter from Troy signed " C." in which the statement was made that the linen-front collar commonly retailed at 15 cents apiece was regularly made in Troy at a cost of less than 50 cents a dozen, and that this computation showed that a profit of 289 per cent, was made on that grade of collar.

United States Commissioner Richard Morle was a very much surprised man when he started to interrogate Alois Feldman, who was a witness yesterday afternoon in the trial of August Neiderland for counterfeiting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The President, it is understood, will not send to Congress the latest batch of Hawaiian correspondence, which includes President's Dole's reply to Minister Willls, till Friday. The probability is that the Senate will not be in session on that day, and so it will happen again, as in the case of the last two installments of Hawaiian information, that the message will go to the House alone.

It has always been our opinion that the Rapid-Transit Commission made a serious mistake, to give it no harsher name, when over a year agro it turned its back upon the plan for an underground railroad because the first offer of the franchise was unsuccessful. It should have held to the ground that here was the real solution of the rapid-transit problem, and that in one way or another the plan should be executed.

William Brunner, manufacturer of embroideries at 144 and 146 South Fifth Avenue, either committed suicide by jumping from the centre of Washington Bridge at 6:30 o'clock last evening, or was thrown from the bridge.

Nine Indictments against Brooklyn officials and policemen, whose names are withheld until arrests have been made, were handed in to Justice Bartlett by the Court of Oyer and Terrainer Orand Jury yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- There has been but very little discussion of the Peckham case in the Senate wing of the Capitol thus far this week. Mr. Hill has not relinquished his efforts to secure votes against confirmation, and those who question him upon the subject are told that he believes Mr. Peckham will not be confirmed.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The Pall Mall Gazette to-day, under a spread head and in leaded lines, has the following:

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Jan. 31. -- The residence of Capt. Henry Smith in East Patchogue was broken into last night and all the furniture was either smashed, or stolen. Capt. Smith, who is a veteran, is visiting in New-York.

R.M. Stivers, 144 to 152 East Thirty-first Street, is offering cabriolet and Victoria sleighs. Dexter speed cutters, forty-two pounds and upward; sleighs and rumbles, and family sleighs at low prices. Stivers makes a specialty of the celebrated Stivers's runabout, and always has on hand a splendid collection of these most serviceable vehicles.

Charities Commissioner Gott of Brooklyn, who was President of the old board, is not having a pleasant time with his new associates. Commissioners Simis and Henry. They do not approve the methods of doing business which prevailed last year, and their criticisms occasionally make Mr. Gott exceedingly uncomfortable.

Frederick H. Hatch and those he represents in opposing the plan of the Nicaragua Canal Construction Company's reorganization committee cannot examine the books of the company Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, to whom application was made for permission to examine the books, handed down a decision yesterday denying the motion.

NEW-YORK Wednesday, Jan. 31 -- P.M. A dull, steady market, ranging within narrow limits for nearly all stocks usually st active, reflected to-day the feeling charechteristic of traders at this juncture. No wished to sell stocks, the movement is that direction having already been carried perilously far.

Palestine Commandery, No. 18, Knights Templars, held its sixteenth annual reception at Madison Square Garden last evening. When the Sir Knights entered for reception of grand officers and a review of the drill corps the Garden was crowded.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- The debate on the Financial Reform bill was continued in the Reichstag to-day. Dr. von Fregre said that us a non-Prussian, he supported the bill, which was a most important political measure, being based on the unanimous resolution of the federated governments. His party lately had not been able to support the Government, but now in a joyful manner it stood by the Government's side.

ROME, Jan. 31 -- Meriine, the most notorious of Italian Anarchists and the colleague of Cloriani and Malatesta was arrested at the rested at thepublic gardens in Naples to day. He was disguised as a priest. When he saw that he had been recognized he tried to run away, but he stumbled over the tram rails, fell, and was seize by a policeman before he could rise.

Henry C. Koerner attempted suicide yesterday morning in the rooms of the Young Men's Club of St. George's Church at 207 East Sixteenth Street. Kerner shot himself in the left breast. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where the bullet was extracted. The wound is not serious.

When Lewis E. Blair, the Astor House barber, died on Aug. 29. he left a will, giving most of his property, which is valued a $250,000, to Police Sergeant William Blair, with whom he had lived a long time at 122 West Nineteenth Street. William E. Blair and other nephews of the dead man have begun a contest over the will, on the ground that their uncle was unduly influenced by Sergt. Blair.

Mrs. Charles S. Holmes, a. sister-in-law of Wayland Trask. the Wall Street broker, applied yesterday to Police Superintendent Campbell for assistance in searching for her husband and two-year-old daughter Helen, whom Mr. Holmes has taken from her.

The promised, conference between representatives of the Independent Democrats and the Conference Committee of Seven appointed by the Democratic General Committee of Kings County was held last night at the Hotel St. George. Robert Stewart, Chairman of the Independents, explained to the committee from Jefferson Hall the plan of reorganization, based upon the election district system, which they had adopted, and ex-Police Commissioner James D. Bell replied for the old organization.

ELMIRA, Jan. 31 -- More testimony was heard to-day by the investigating commission, designed to show that the stories told of cruelties practiced upon prisoners in the Reformatory by Superintendent Brockway were false. Such of the witnesses as had seen Brockway and his assistants at work with the paddle "disciplining" "refractory" inmates expressed the belief that nobody had been unduly punished.

There was an atmosphere of decided jollity in the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The change from an extremely serious to a delightfully merry opera was a pleasant one, and the large audience seemed to have come in the most amiable of moods. Fortunately there was very little to disturb the good feeling which prevailed at the outset.

ROME, Jan. 31 -- The funeral look place to-day of Miss Constance Fenimore Woolson, the well-known American novelist, who died in Venice on Jan. 23. The remains were interred in the Protestant Cemetery here. Her grave is near that of Shelley. Among those who attended the funeral were Mr. Potter, the American Minister, and Mrs. Potter. Many flowers were sent by friends.

Lemuel Ely Quigg, Congressman-elect in the Fourteenth District owing to circumstances over which he had no control, arose when the first flush of morning reddened the east yesterday and began to answer numerous letters and telegrams in. which the senders said they were glad he was elected.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music presented a scene of unusual brilliancy and attrctiveness last evening on the occasion of the fifty-sixth annual ball of the Emerald Association, in aid of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylums of Brooklyn. The ballroom was tastefully decorated with tapestry, flags, and bunting, and literally bloomed like a bower of roses.

Owing to the financial depression, the New-York branch of the International Evangelistic Association has concluded to suspend its work temporarily. This action was taken at the annual meeting held yesterday at US Fulton Street.

The adjourned meeting of the creditors of N. J. Schloss Co., manufacturers of clothing at 653 Broadway, was held yesterday at the Metropolitan Hotel, about 200 of the creditors being present. The committee appointed, in December to investigate the affairs of the firm made a report and presented a detailed statement by R. W. Birrworth, expert accountant.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- Count von Moltke, the Emperor's aide de camp, who was the bearer to Freidrichsruh of his Majesty's letter inviting Prince Bismarck to visit him in Berlin, says that when he delivered the Emperor's message Prince Bismarck said:
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Mr. Glenn (Rep.) of Seneca offered this resolution:

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- The Evening Post this afternoon says editorially of the attempt of the Associated Press yesterday to manufacture news after having been beaten several hours by the United Press on an important dispatch from Rio Janeiro:

There was excitement in Brooklyn political circles yesterday when it became known that William D. Lohman. cashier of the Excise Bureau was missing. To add to the excitement, the possibility that he had committed suicide was suggested.

The petition of President Brayton Ives and the Board of Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad for an order compelling the receivers to deliver the stock books and other records of the company to the Directors was denied yesterday by Judge Jenkins of the United States District Court in Milwaukee.

Mrs. Iantha Wescott Sturges was born in Ellenville, Ulster County. N.Y. In her early childhood her father enlisted in the Union Army, leaving at home his wife and four children under ten years of age. He served during the four years of the war and returned from the front with a shattered constitution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The naval experts are greatly interested in the attack on the French Navy in the Chamber of Deputies, and have wondered at the criticism from Paris of that organization by Deputy Lockroy published in yesterday morning's New-York Times. There is much surprise that there should be occasion for fault finding with a navy which has been regarded as very efficient.

In consequence of the denial by Judge Jenkins of the United States court of the petition of the Northern Pacific Railroads Directors for an order to compel the receivers to turn over the stock transfer book and other books belonging to the company to the officers of the said company, the Messrs. Sullivan Cromwell of counsel for the receivers sent a letter to the Stock Exchange yesterday.

The wiles and wails of Gilberte, that always interesting young woman of the rustling robes, succeeded at Abbey's Theatre last evening the more comprehensible, if not more sincere, joys and woes of Adrienne Leecouvreur.

With the news from Washington yesterday that the bond issue had been oversubscribed, came a telegram to John A. Stewart, President of the United States Trust Company, from William E. Curtis, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, as follows:

Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day. Time money continued plentiful. Rates were 2 per cent. for thirty to sixty days, 2 1/2 per cent. for ninety days to four months, and 3 per cent, for six months.

LISBON, Feb. 1. -- The British steamer Trent, from Buenos Ayres via Rio Janeiro, whence she sailed Jan. 11, arrived here today. Among her passengers was Capt. William L. Lang, who is proceeding to England on leave of absence. Capt. Lang was the senior British naval officer at Rio Janeiro.

Thomas H. Mackie, a carpenter and builder whose office is at 201 West Forty-fifth Street, and whose home is at Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., appeared in the Tombs Police Court yesterday as complainant against his sons, Thomas J., twenty-two years old, and Peter, thirty years old. He charged them with assaulting him on Wednesday afternoon at the foot of the Warren Street Station of the Ninth Avenue Elevated Road.

It is pretty well understood that the power of the Bell Telephone Company to preserve its monopoly of the exchange telephone business depends chiefly upon the final decision of the courts in the suit in which the Government asks that the Berliner patent shall be annulled. We have already referred to the condition of the Edison transmitter patents and the questions that have arisen concerning the validity of them.

The Committee of Thirty, representing the Regular Republican County Organization, issued an address to the Republican voters of New-York Wednesday, outlining the proposed method of making the new enrollment. The address is signed by all the members. They ask each member of the party who is willing to serve as an enrolling officer to send his name and address to George W. Lyon, the Secretary of the committee.

A little dinner was given at Delmonico's a few nights ago which is likely to have an important sequel. At the table were representatives of two of the foremost banking houses of this city. They were the hosts. The guests were members of three foreign banking institutions, two of London and one of Paris.

To the Editor of the New York Times: I Note in your issue of to-day that you remark that "it is admitted by opponents of income tax. yourself among the number that a tax upon income is about the most equitable and just that could be devised. in practice it is inquiry and iniquity person d and then go on to mark some very just remarks about the possibility of evading .

Pilotboat Actaea, No. 15, which was towed into harbor yesterday morning, reports having been in collision with the White Star steamship Tauric off Fire Island, Jan. 30, at 7 A.M. The Actaea had her starboard quarter and bulwarks stove in, and copper badly torn. She will so on drydock for repairs.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 1 -- Asbury Park is making a strong and determined effort to secure the annual meet of the League of American Wheelmen for 1894. Last night a large and enthusiastic meeting of bicyclists and citizens was held at the Commercial Hotel, and substantial pledges were made that should Asbury Park secure the meet the citizens would co-operate to make the affair a success.

Since Jan. 23 Howard S. Neilson, nephew of William Tod Helmuth of 299 Madison Avenue, and Oscar N. Meyer, who are students at the New-York Homeopathic Medical College and Hospital, have experimented there with permanganate of potassium as an antidate in morphine poisoning. Their subjects have been street curs.

When Police Justice Ryan came to the Court of Special Sessions yesterday about noon, to attend the meeting of the Police Justices called for the purpose of taking action in the case of Conrad M. Smyth, Chief Clerk of the Yorkville Police Court, he was informed that Mr. Smyth had returned to his desk after an absence of over three weeks.
Richard Croker, leader of Tammany Hall; Mrs. Croker, and their sons Herbert and Frank left this city yesterday morning over the Pennsylvania Railroad on a long journey for rest and recreation.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 1. -- Gov. Werts will not call a special session of the Supreme Court to act in the establishment of a legal Senate. Last night the Governor received several suggestions from Attorney General Stockton as to how to bring the Senate muddle into the courts. He directed the Attorney General to file the suggestions as an opinion. The opinion was received to-day.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Feb. 1 -- P.M. There was very little interest displayed in Speculation today.The stocks which were fairly ve. were Sugar, Whisky, and Western Union. In only three others did the trading exceed 5,000 shares, and they were Chicago Gas, Union Pacific and St. Pard.
The new chiefs of departments took charge in Brooklyn yesterday morning. Immediately thereafter brief notes of dismissal began to circulate among the old employes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- While rejoicing over the success of the plan to recoup the Treasury by an issue of bonds, the people should not lose sight of the fact that Secretary Carlisle has been obliged to proceed without the aid or encouragement of the Congress.

William Schaefer, twenty-three years old, of 153 East Eighty-fifth Street, and Henry Secathe, thirty-eight years old, of 508 East Eighty-fifth Street, clerks, in whom their employer, William C. Flanagan, had implicit confidence for five or six years, were quietly arrested on Wednesday afternoon by Detectives Heidelberg and Doran of the Central Office, charged with having stolen about $20,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- After a desperate struggle, extending over two hours, the three bills repealing the Buffalo charter amendments of last year were passed by the Assembly. The overture to the fight was a row over the Lansingburg Repeal bills which Senator Owens (Rep., Kings,) tried to defeat in order to save his wife's uncle, who is the Chief of Police of this borough.

Mrs. Anna Beach Appleton, who is charged by McGibbon Co., furniture dealers, with obtaining goods by representing herself as the wife of Judge Miles Beach, was brought up for trial yesterday in General Sessions before Recorder Smyth. She had already pleaded not guilty.

No tidings of William D. Lohmann, the missing cashier of the Brooklyn Excise Department, were received yesterday, either by his official superiors or his family. The fear is generally entertained that he has committed suicide.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 1. -- The novel and much-talked-about luxury of a professional billiard tournament in Cincinnati was begun to-night at the Pike Opera House. It has been eighteen years since the great exponents of the gentleman's game have crossed cues here, and the present event has excited unusual interest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The dispatch from Frankfort announcing that one branch of the Kentucky legislature had adopted a resolution calling upon Senators Blackburn and Lindsay to refrain from voting for the confirmation of any nominee for the United States Supreme Court whose Democracy was not of the rock-ribbed, copper-fastened variety was taken by the opponents of Wheeler H. Peckham in the Senate as a hopeful sign.

There cannot be much question about either the indecency or the silliness of the announcement made by a London news-paper that Mr. Gladstone "had decided to resign almost immediately." The explanation that was authorized by Mr. Gladstone goes no further than to say that he is, as we say on this side, " in the hands of his friends."

The big steamship Manitoba came into port yesterday after an experience in which her stanchness alone saved her from destruction. She left London on Jan. 20, and she struggled almost daily with gales and high seas. At one time she drifted helplessly for eighteen hours at the mercy of a terrific storm that tossed her about like a toy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The Army Reister for 1891 appeared to-day at the War Department. It contains no new failures. The only material in the resist, in the register of interest to civilians is the the of student who made a record in the military department at last commencement at universities having military instructors detailed army.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Fire at 9 o'clock this morning destroyed the wooden and willow ware storehouse and factory of Felix Marston, on Canal Street, causing a loss of $50,000 on the building and $80,000 on the contents; fully covered by Insurance. The flames spread so rapidly that the elevators were abandoned, and the twenty-two employes on the upper floors were left without means of descent except by the stairways.

From a telegram from the Assistant Secretary of the Navy which was yesterday received by Rear Admiral Gherardi, commandant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the Navy Department has evidently reconsidered its determination to have the work of lengthening the gunboats Machias and Castine done at the Norfolk Navy Yard.
In the hearing in the Kneeland-Hughes Seventh Assembly District contest. In the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday, important testimony was introduced against Mr. Hughes.

The matinee for the benefit of the Kindergarten and Potted Plant Association at Palmer's Theatre yesterday afternoon was a great success in every way. Every seat in the house was taken, and there was hardly standing room on the first floor. For boxes that were already sold $125 and $150 were offered.

After eight days of stubborn legal battling the triangular contest respecting the residuary estate of Daniel B. Fayerweather, in so far as taking testimony is concerned, was finished yesterday before Judge Truax, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court. The arguments in the case will be heard by the same Judge March 6.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- The Republican Senators lassoed the wild bull from Buffalo in the Senate Chamber this afternoon, and for half an hour the liveliest proceedings were seen since that eventful January day in 1891 when Senators Saxton, O'Connor, and Erwin were brought to the bar of the Senate upon the autocratic order of the young Lieutenant Governor.

The revival meetings in Brooklyn, were well attended yesterday, notwithstanding the threatening weather. The outdoor meeting at 11:30 A.M. was not held on account of the storm, but Association Hall was well filled at the noon meeting.
The prosecution has rested in the trial of John Y. McKane, in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer, for conspiring to hide the registration lists of Gravesend.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 1. -- On Sunday next the Union Pacific will give up trains via the Gulf route between Julesburg and La Salle, and will run its Omaha-Denver trains via Cheyenne and the old line. This is one of the most important seeps taken by the Union Pacific, and further increases the responsibilities and embarrassments of Frank Trumbull, the receiver of the Gulf.

The Extraordinary Grand Jury of Kings County has returned thirty-four indictments against persons for violating the election laws at the last election. Among those indicted are ten residents of Brooklyn and twenty-four Gravesenders.

Behind a simple motion decided yesterday by Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court the story of a most pathetic family drama was hidden. The papers handed up to the Judge were framed in the usual formal legal style, and there was nothing on their face to indicate that they were the epitaph of a household hounded to despair by a conscienceless gang of swindlers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Light was thrown on the new phase of the Brazilian situation to-day by the action of Secretary Herbert in making public a dispatch received from Rear Admiral Benham and a detailed report form Minister Thompson of the occurrences in Rio Harbor on Monday. The dispatch from Admiral Benham is a report of his action in breaking the blockade and the subsequent engagement between the cruiser Detroit and an insurgent vessel.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 1. -- The services connected with the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the consecration of the Right Rev. William Croswell Doane, D.D., LL. D., Bishop of Albany, will take place to-morrow, the Feast of the Purification.

-- Controller Fitch has written letters to Senators and Assemblymen, expressing his disapproval of some of the bills introduced in the Legislature. One of them is Senate Bin 162, which proposes to release the transfer tax on the $250,000 left by Gen. George W. Cullom for a memorial at West Point. The tax amounts to $12,500.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore delivered the fourth of the series of six illustrated lecturer on "The Life of Christ," at the Central Baptist Church. Forty-second Street, near Seventh Avenue, last evening, before a large and enthusiastic audience.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- Queen Victoria, Emperor William, and the Prince of Wales will attend the wedding of Princess Victoria Melita of Coburg to the Grand Duke of Hesse, both of whom are grandchildren of Queen Victoria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The peculations of James Anderson of Indiana, a well-connected lad, eighteen years of age, employed as a messenger in the Treasury vaults, who was arrested last night for stealing silver from the vaults, prove more serious than was supposed. They amount to $794 as far as has been ascertained, and the inquiry is still in progress.

If the two colored boys from St. Lucia, who recently stowed away on the steamship Waverly, did so with the purpose of seeing something of the world, they could not have chosen a better vessel. When the ship having them on board arrived at this port the boys were turned over to the immigration authorities on Ellis Island, who ordered them to be returned to St. Lucia by the vessel that brought them.

"The future of the unemployed poor looks darker than ever," remarked Secretary Milbury of the Industrial Christian Alliance yesterday, as he hurried to attend a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Business Men's General Committee. "We now feed nearly 2,000 a day at 170 Bleecker Street."

From The Iron Age, Feb. 1. During the past week the improvement in certain branches of the iron trade has gained further headway, and a far more cheerful tone prevails. Buyers have taken hold, and it looks as though some of them have already missed their best opportunity.
Gov. Flower has taken a hand in the controversy over the Supervisor of the Eighth Ward, Brooklyn. Yesterday the Governor ordered a special election, to be held Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Tariff reform has triumphed in the House of Representatives, and in a fashion so inspiring that the record made to-day by the Democratic Party promises to become one of the proudest in its annals.

The annual meeting of the New-York Yacht Club was held last night in the club-house, 67 Madison Avenue. The members attended in large numbers. Commodore E. D. Morgan was absent, and in his place Vice Commodore W. Butler Duncan presided. Reports were received from the America's Cup Committee and from the Regatta Committee.

Robert P. Porter, for some time editor of The New-York Press, has severed his relations with that journal. He has been elected Controller of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association, and will soon enter on the duties of that office.

Suabla has been for centuries the Boeotia of Germany, and Suabians have been the accepted types for numskulls. So it happens that a Schwabenstreieh is the same thins as a piece of folly. Every man must go through with a certain number of foolish acts in his life, remarks Conrad von Schwyburg to his friend and elderly neighbor.

The selection by the Chamber of Commerce, as counsel to the Senate committee of investigation into the police, of Mr. Choate and Col. Erhardt undoubtedly "means business." It is the most hopeful sign of a good result from the investigation that has thus far been discernible. Mr. Erhardt knows as much about the police as anybody can possibly know who has not been smirched and discredited in acquiring his knowledge.

The Tariff Reform bill passed the House of Representatives yesterday by a vote of 204 to 140. This is the triumphant close of the first decisive advance movement toward the accomplishment of the work committed to the Democratic Party in the elections of 1892. It is not surprising that it was greeted by the Democrats of the House with the utmost enthusiasm.

The Alumni Association of the Adelphi Academy of Brooklyn yesterday closed negotiations for the purchase of ground for a playing field. The site is near the Eastern Parkway, about ten minutes' walk from the academy, and can be reached by the Franklin and Vanderbilt Avenue Line of cars.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- The animal meeting of the stockholders of the American Strawboard Company was held in the Iranqueting room of the Auditorium to-day, with President Barber in the Chair. The annual reports submitted by Vice President J.H. Swinarton showed that the assets, including real estate, aggregated $7,737,000 and that the liabilities, including capital stock and $376,000 of undivided profits, reached, the same figure.

The appearance of Poster L. Backus of Brooklyn as one of the chief counsel for John Y. McKane has provoked a great deal of discussion, principally because of his former attitude as an opponent of election frauds.

-- George W. Davids, for thirty years the city editor of The Poughkeepsie Eagle, died at his residence in Poughkeepsie yesterday. He was for many years the Hudson River correspondent of most of the New-York City dallies. He was one of the best-known newspaper men in the State. He was stricken with paralysis in NewYork City on Jan. 18 and never rallied from the attack.

The disturbance which Admiral Benham's conduct at Rio has caused in the British bosom finds natural expression through its organ, The London Times. Our British contemporary, it seems, has been greatly puzzled by our relations, naval and diplomatic, to the monarchical insurrection against Peixoto's Government.

The fifth annual poultry and pigeon show will be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 8, 9, 10, 12, and 13. All indications point to success for the show. There are 8,000 entries, 700 more than last year. There are to be many new features and new exhibits of interest.

The action taken by the Chamber of Commerce yesterday in support of the Torrey Bankruptcy in was wise and timely. It is expected that the minority report of the house Judiciary Committee sustaining the Torrey bill and pointing out some of ill many weaknesses of Mr. Bailey's measure will next week again briny before the House the bill it so inconsiderately disposed of two months ago by striking out the enacting clause.

If there were no official reports concerning exports and imports it would be difficult to show how misleading and false are many of the assertions of the opponents of the "Wilson bill. But there are such reports in existence, and we have shown how completely, in many instances, they refute the statements of the defenders of MeKinleyism.

The janitor of the flats at 236 West Thirty-fifth Street, about 6 o'clock last night, knocked at the apartments of John Smith to get a match. He received no answer and entered the apartment. The janitor heard a feeble moan from a bedroom. He entered the room and saw a ghastly sight.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- In the Assembly today Mr. Suizer called attention to the fact that there was present one of the most foremost educationalists of the United States -- Dr. J.G. Schurman of Cornell University. A committee, consisting of Messrs. Sulzer and Ainsworth, was appointed to escort Dr. Schurman to the Speaker's chair.

Chicago is a persistent town. It takes something more than a hint to force it to give up an adopted idea. Of all the cities of the country. Chicago probably felt the acute phases of the recent panic least severely. None the less, it has been Chicago which has most pertinaciously clung to the notion that the end of the panic has not yet been reached.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- A merry battle of ballots marked the second day's proceedings of the annual meeting of the stockholders of the American Straw board Company at the Auditorium Hotel. A million and a half of stock was represented by a committee, from Utica, consisting of Messrs. J.F. Maynard, W. Krous, and C.G. Fink.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The proposition to repeal the law imposing a tax of 10 per cent, on State bank issues was defeated in the House Committee on Banking and Currency this morning. The pending bill, introduced by Mr. Cox (Dem., Tenn.,) on Jan. 4, is as follows:

The number of The North American Review for February contains a long and diversified collection of timely articles written by persons who naturally command attention. The President of the Swiss Republic, who was the Swiss Minister to this country during the civil war, contributes some reminis of his life here.

The bonds offered by the Secretary of the Treasury are found to have been subscribed for to considerably more than the amount advertised. Still, the bids were not such rates they would have been had the condition of things been different in Washington. The shameful of silverites.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- A scheme to waylay a bank messenger and rob him of from $10,000 to $15,000 was frustrated this morning, and the conspirator, Victor H. Echorn, was arrested.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 2 -- The second fame of the great billiard tournament in which Schaefer Ives, and Slosson, the champion billiardists, are contesting for supremcy in skill, was marked by an attendance largely composed of leading society people of this city. That greater interest is evinced as the tournament progresses was manifest from the increased attendance to-night, ives and Slosson were the contestants.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- Dr. Arthur D. Markley, nominee for Congressman at Large of the anti-machine Democrats of Pennsylvania, who are organized under the name of "The Pennsylvania Democracy," has forwarded to the Executive Committee of the organization his letter of acceptance. This letter explains the nature of the revolt in the Democratic Party of this State against the State administration.

"Keeping a child without a license" was the peculiar charge made against Mrs. Violet Hamilton of 501 East Seventy-second Street in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, Mrs. Hamilton is a concert singer and is said to be the widow of Surgeon Gen. Hamilton of the German Army. She has bean in the habit of taking little children to board.

For several weeks it has been rumored that the case of the Rev. Dr. Richard Lalor Burtsell, formerly pastor of the Church of the Epiphany in this city, who went to Rome to explain certain theories which had been denounced by Archbishop Corrigan and his council, had been there decided against him.

Frank Hennessy of the Twelfth Ward, representing the First Aldermanlc District of Brooklyn, is the Alderman who was indicted by the King's County Extraordinary Grand Jury for violating the election laws by assisting persons to vote at the last election.

The Rev. Archibald B. MacLaurin has officiated acceptably since last October as pastor of the Union Avenue Baptist Church, in Greenpoint. He was born in the township at St. Vincent's, Canada, in 1865. His father and brother are engaged in the Baptist ministry, and his sister is an earnest worker in the cause of foreign missions.

Dissensions have arisen among the members of St. Jerome's Lyseum a prominent Catholic club in the annexed district, which threaten to disrupt the association. Already the President, the Treasurer, the athletic directors, and more than a dozen other members have resigned, and a rival organization is talked of.

George Washington Moore, better known as "Pony," poet, author, composer, wandering minstrel, and father-in-law of Prize Fighter Mitchell, is on a pleasure trip to this country. His sojourn here has not been of a very pleasant character, and the chances are that "Pony" will soon leave the city to seek rest and recreation in the vicinity of St. John's Wood.
The fact that Gov. Flower has ordered an election for Supervisor in the Eighth Ward, Brooklyn, to be held Feb. 28, has caused dissatisfaction among Republicans, but the Democrats are jubilant.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 2 -- A pathetic tragedy, involving the useless sacrifice of one life in an effort to save another, occurred at the Pavonia Ferry this morning. The actors in the drama were brothers, W. Alfred Morey, twenty-five years old, and John, four years younger, sons of Mr. and Mrs. Judson H. Morey of Ridgewood, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Tariff bill is now in the possession of the Senate Finance Committee. It was reported from the House late this afternoon and sent to the committee, with instructions that 2,000 copies be printed for the use of the Senate.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- Mr. George W. Childs died at, an early hour this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The President today sent to Congress a communication from Secretary Gresham, inclosing a letter received from Minister Willis in reference to the reply of President Dole to Mr. Willis's request for specific answers to what Mr. Cleveland termed Mr. Dole's "most extraordinary" document.

It is probable that the prosecution of offenders against he election laws in the Court of Oyer and Terminer next Monday will prove more or less of a farce, owing to the disappearance of many of the indicted persons. Several bondsmen who had been notified to produce defendants visited Assistant District Attorney Wellman's office yesterday, and said they were unable to find the men for whom they had given bonds.

The letter written by Park Commissioner Paul Dana before he sailed for Europe Thursday, in reference to the Harlem River Speedway, was made public by the Park Board yesterday. At the same time was made public a letter written by President Tappen and Park Commissioners Straus and Clausen, in reply to the statements made by Mr. Dana.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A committee representing District Assembly, No. 49, Knights of Labor, New-York, introduced to Secretary Carlisle this morning by Congressman Amos J. Cummings of New-York, presented to the Secretary a petition signed by the officers of the assembly against the removal of the postage-stamp printing to the Bureau of Engraving and Printing at Washington.

Robert L. Cutting has qualified as executor and trustee, under the will of his grandfather, the original Robert L. Cutting, which was admitted to probate in this city in 1887. Mr. Cutting left an estate worth several millions, and his two sons, Robert L. and Walter Cutting, were made executors and trustees.

Hassan H. Wheeler. Hassan H. Wheeler, President of the American District Telegraph Company of Brooklyn, died yesterday morning at his home, 211 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn. His death was the termination of a protracted illness.

The twenty-seventh annual exhibition of the American Water-Color Society at the National Academy of Design maintains very fairly the good record of the past, although some of the painters in water color who represent the highest level in the art are absent. Their absence brings into greater relief some men who can hardly be placed in a lower rank, except as younger, and therefore with less proofs of ability to their credit in the past.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 2 -- The answer or the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad to the petition of Brayton Ives asking for their removal will shortly be filed in the United States Circuit Court here. It makes no sensational charges against Mr. Ives.

For the twenty-fifth time in its history the Packard Club dined last evening, and for the first time this season gave a "ladies' night." In honor of the occasion, and to have in "all respects a pleasant and profitable evening," the feast of reason that followed the dinner was devoted entirely to woman and her work.

The Trustees of the State hospitals for the insane, or some of them, have secured the introduction of two different bills in the Legislature, the purpose of which seems to be to relieve them from the supervision of the Commissioners in Lunacy, at least in the matter of the expenditures of the institutions under their charge.

At a meeting at the University Athletic Club to-night, the first step to modify football rules so as to make the sport a safe as well as an interesting one will be taken. Walter Camp of Yale, J.H. Sears of Harvard, Alexander Moffatt of Princeton, and, other experts will be present.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Three bills were introduced in the Assembly to-day that will cause considerable quaking among the Police Justices and court officers of New-York City. Two of these measures came from Mr. Sheffield (Rep., New-York.) and the third from Mr. Lawson, (Rep., New-York.)

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Justice Herrick of the Supreme Court is much put out over the published report that he has been interfering with legislation in Albany by persuading the Albany County members to vote against certain bills. The Judge said to the correspondent of The New-York Times to-day that the stories were false; that he had not been near the Capitol this year, nor had he discussed pending legislation with Albany County members.

Congressman Manner, counsel for Assemblyman William Hughes, whose right to the seat in the Legislature is contested by Stillman F. Kneeland, took up the case for the defense in the Aldermanic Chamber in Brooklyn yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- The bicycle show in the First Regiment Armory has been well attended. The number of exhibits is large and the amount of business being done encouraging. As the wheel is in many cases a luxury, the hard-times feeling naturally effects the trade, but the exhibitors here are very cheerful, and think that the Spring trade will not disappoint them.

The present state of the dry goods trade, both wholesale and retail, in this city is a good indication that confidence has been restored in business circles and among the masses. That part of the commercial world is quick to respond to prosperity or business depression, and, accordingly, it reflects the general feeling of the community.

We have done Matthew Stanley Quay an injustice which we hasten to repair as promptly as possible. We expressed the opinion the other day that there was no one else in public life in the United States who would have the recklessness to declare the bonds of the United States recently offered, by the Secretary of the Treasury to be illegal or to advocate their repudiation.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- The Zukunft says that Prince Bismarck months ago declared that he was desirous of residing in Berlin part of the Winter. It adds that after his recent visit to the Emperor it is to be hoped that his desire will soon be accomplished.

Mrs. William D. Lohmann, wife of the missing cashier of the Brooklyn Excise Department, received a letter yesterday from Louis Schnieder of 311 St. Paul Street, Baltimore. He informed her that when Mr. Lohmann left him in Philadelphia, he said he was going to Richmond, Va., to attend to financial matters.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 30, via Montevideo, Feb. 2 -- The negotiations for arbitration of the differences between the Government and the insurgents have been continued during the past week. Admiral da Gama's written proposition has been submitted to Rear Admiral Benham, commander of the United States fleet.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the consecration of the Right Rev. William Croswell Doane, first Episcopalian Bishop of the Diocese of Albany, was celebrated to-day. All Saints' Cathedral was thronged with a distinguished gathering of clergy and laymen at the services this morning.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- A dispatch sent from Buenos Ayres last night has been received in this city, saying that advices have been received from Rio Janeiro that the insurgents have obtained a renewal of their supplies. A brisk cannonade has occurred between the insurgent squadron and the Government forts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Unless the enemies of the bond issue in the Senate make haste, the bonds will be distributed before the resolutions denouncing them are acted upon.

For more than a week past rumors have teen prevalent among real estate men of a large purchase on Broadway involving all the way from $2,000,000 to $3,000,000. Testerday they became more definite, and it was openly asserted that the square bounded by Sroadway and Liberty, Cedar, and Temple Streets, had been sold to a Chicago syndicate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senator Quay (Rep., Penn.,) this morning gave notice to the Senate of an amendment he intended to offer to the Tariff bill, which opens up anew the silver discussion. He proposes to add a number of sections to the bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A lively discussion was precipitated to-day in the House over a report from the Committee on Rules setting aside the nest three legislative days for the consideration of Mr. McCreary's (Dem., Ky.,) resolution censuring Minister Stevens and the Republican Administration for their share in the Hawalian imbroglio.
