While the boxing and wrestling championships of the Amateur Athletic Union have always attracted the most scientific and expert men in both branches of this sport among Eastern clubs, they have never attracted competitors from the West; but this year, fortunately, unusual interest has been manifested, not only in this city, Boston, and Philadelphia, but also in Chicago, Pittsburg, Wilmington, and Washington.
There is no abatement in the interest in the great revival meetings being held in Brooklyn. Thousands attend the meetings daily, and many conversions are reported. The great work is to be continued.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 2 -- The Rev. Dr. Arthur C.A. Hall was to-day consecrated Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Vermont. The ceremony took place in St. Paul's Church at 11 o'clock this morning, and was witnessed by distinguished men of the Church from all parts of the United States and Canada.
John Y. McKane yesterday told his side of the troubles of the Gaynor copyists and watchers at Gravesend to the jury which is trying him for conspiracy in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer.

The Senatorial committee appointed to investigate the New-York Police Department, consisting of Senator Clarence Lexow of Rockland County, Edmund O' Connor of Broome, George W. Robertson of Westchester, Charles T. Saxton of Wayne, Cuthbert W. Pound of Niagara, Daniel Bradley of Kings, and Jacob Cantor of New-York, held its preliminary session last evening in Parlor D of the Hotel Metropole, Forty-second Street and Broadway.

Gold to pay for the Government's new bonds flowed into the Bub-Treasury yesterday from the time it opened until it closed. The amount deposited at the end of the day, including Thursday's deposits of $3,000,000, was $10,000,000 in gold coin, $1,000,000 in gold certificates, and $1,500,000 in legal tenders and Treasury notes for redemption.

With the main text of this volume we have less to do than with its preface and the introductory chapter. Here and there many peculiar crochets, born of Messrs. Morris and Bax's brains, are discoverable. If nothing stirring is found in the volume where the historical method is followed, an attempt is made to treat it so that the Socialistic upheaval appears certain to occur to-morrow; if not, the day after.

The report of Capt. James K. Price of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station in reply to the charges against him by the Rev. Charles H. Parkhurst of the Society for the Preveation of crute taken up for consideration by the Police Commissioners at their meeting yesterday. The report of Capt. Price, together with the result of the investigation made by Inspector McAvov, was forwarded to the board by the Superintendent without comment.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Feb. 2 -- F.M. There was some excitement in the early trading in sugar. The first price was anywhere between 77 and 76, but the buying orders predominated, and an upward movement was soon under way. After selling at 78 1/4, the price tell to 77 1/4, but recovered sharply, and in the last hour touched 79.
H. Winthrop Gray is no longer a Fire Commissioner. The formal acceptance of his resignation was acknowledged yesterday by Mayor Gilroy.

It is to the interest of every decent citizen of New-York that the proposed investigation of the police of this city, if it is to be undertaken, should not be a farce. Whether it is possible to get out of the present Legislature of this State an investigation that shall not be a farce is a nice and difficult question.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Secretary Herbert, after the Cabinet meeting to-day, declined to make public the latest cable message received from Admiral Benham, but repeated his assurance that it had no general public interest. It is accordingly understood that the dispatch involved a question of international policy, which is the one reservation which Mr. Herbert made in his promise to give out all future dispatches.

LISBON, Feb. 2 -- A dispatch received here last night from Buenos Ayres reiterates the statement in yesterday's dispatches that Nictheroy, the town across the bay from Rio Janeiro, has surrendered to the insurgents. It adds that the insurgents now occupy a position from which they command Santa Cruz, the important fort at the entrance to the Bay of Rio Janeiro.

Robert Ayrton, the father of little Oswald Ayrton, who, with Willie Stewart, ran away from home on Sunday last, came to this city from Worcester, Mass., yesterday morning, in response to a telegram from the police authorities informing him that Willie Stewart had been killed by a train near the Bedford Park station, and that his boy was in the custody of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

The members of the Twelfth Night Club grave a reception in honor of Mme. Modjeska yesterday afternoon in their club rooms, at 126 East Twenty-third Street. There was a large attendance. The rooms were prettily decorated with roses and ferns, and the table where the refreshments were served was artistically arranged.

The Finance Committee of the Emergency Fund to Give Relief by Work reports through its Treasurer, Charles Stewart Smith, that $36,288,96 was received up to Feb. 1. Of this amount $5,000 was contributed by city officials and employes, through Mayor Gllroy. The contributions previously acknowledged amounted to $28,883,96. The latest contributions were:

From The Chicago Times. The first Monday in March the Illinois Democratic State Central Committee will meet in Chicago and fix the time and place for holding the Democratic State Convention to nominate candidates for State Treasurer, Superintendent of Public Instruction, and United States Senator.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- For the first time on any stage, "Chatterton," a miniature tragedy in one act, by Ernst Lacy, was given at McVicker's this week, Miss Julia Marlowe taking the part of the unfortunate young poet. She made a trim boy. though she was a little low in stature compared with Miss Woodward, who played the corresponding part.

Two of the election clerks indicted for violations of the election laws who could not be found were John Kiley, charged with making a false return in the Twenty-eighth Election District of the Fourth Assembly District, and Dennis J. Buckley, against whom the same charge is made in the Eighteenth Election District of the Second Assembly District.

From The Baltimore Sun, (Dem.,) Feb. 2. The Democratic Party in Congress may divide itself into cliques and coteries, and play a complicated game of cross-purposes with its own Administration, if it has no better sense; but the country will not stop to apportion the relative responsibility of those Democratic leaders who thus trifled with its vital interests and embarrassed the operations of the General Government.
The bills introduced in the Legislature Friday proposing to reduce the salaries of Police Justices in this city caused a scurrying about of some of those dignitaries yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Capt. Edmond L. Zalinski, Fifth Artillery, was placed on the retired list of the army to-day on account of disability, and the vacancy created will allow the promotion of First Lieut. Luigi Lomia. Fifth Artillery, who has served as First Lieutenant for nearly twenty-five years. Capt. Zalinski is the inventor of the pneumatic dynamite gun.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Paul Weckmueller, a saloon keeper of 22 Sussex Avenue, was before Judge Conlon this morning on a charge of assault and battery. Pete De Matt of 63 Newark Street made the complaint. He alleged that Weckmueller was beating an old man on the street; that the complainant interfered, and Weckmueller said something in German to his dog, which bit De Matt twice on the arm and on the leg.

The appearance in New-York of a committee appointed by the Senate of New-York to investigate the police means that Mr. Platt thinks the police ought to be investigated. The performances of the committee thus far, as well as the attendant probabilities of the case, show that Mr. Platt thinks the police ought not to be investigated too much.

The big dry goods store of the Liebmann Brothers Company, Fulton, Hoyt, and Livingston Streets, Brooklyn, was closed by Sheriff Buttling shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Chief Clerk Sedgwick of the Sheriff's office was placed in charge of the building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Judging by the degree of interest felt by the House in the Hawaiian question, it is no longer an engrossing subject in the minds of either Republicans or Democrats. The attendance during the debates of yesterday and to-day has been meagre, and there were only occasional moments of controversial excitement, liiruted to the disputants on the respective sides of the House.

The passage of the Tariff bill by the House failed to have any perceptible effect on the stock market. It was sluggish before the bill passed and It remained so after it. No one would have known on Friday morning that anything of importance had taken place at Washington the previous afternoon, so tame was the opening and so few the transactions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Navy Department is having trouble getting chinaware for several of the new ships. A month or more ago requisitions were made after the usual form for tableware for the Amphitrite, the Indiana, the Massachusetts, the Maine, the Minneapolis, the Columbia, the Texas, the Oregon, the Olympia, the Cincinnati, the Casfine, the Brooklyn, the Raleigh, the Monadnock, the Terror, the Montgomery, the Marblehead, and the Puritan.

From Harper's Bazar. Nobody likes being managed. The secret of management is not known to all, but those who have learned it from the good fairies who preside over domestic tranquillity have attained brevet rank among the fortunate of this world. There is everything in taking people at the right moment, and in suggesting an arrangement instead of ordering an arbitrary change of base.

At a meeting of the members of the New-York Press Club yesterday afternoon it was resolved, as a tribute of respect to the memory of George W. Childs, who was an honorary member of the club, that the members of the club attend the funeral in a body. A committee, consisting: of President Keller and Messrs. Pratt. Townsend, and Hanway, was appointed to draft suitable resolutions on the death of Mr. Childs.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 3 -- The Executive Committee of the Board of Managers of the Westchester Temporary Home for Indigent Children met here to-day to consider a complaint which charges Superintendent James Pierce with cruelly and inhumanly beating an inmate of the home.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 3. -- Sheriff Silman received a telegraphic dispatch yesterday to come with deputies immediately to Acme, as the Montgomery miners were marching on Stevens's mines to make Stevens's men quit work.
Yesterday was ladies' day at the NewYork Athletic Clubhouse, 104 West Fifty-fifth Street. It was the thirty-second ladies' day of the club, and was said to be the most successful one ever given.

At the Japanese store of Vantine Co., 877 Broadway, there are on exhibition two Peruvian mummies, which have been kindly loaned to the firm by K.H. Clarke of this city. These mummies have lately arrived from Lima, Peru, and are 500 or more years old. They belonged to the tribe called Incas, who flourished from the eleventh to the sixteenth centuries.

The publication of a rumor to the effect that the Lead Trust, or combination of the manufacturers of white lead, had taken into the fold one of the few outside concerns, has drawn from the company which was mentioned the following very interesting letter, which we commend to the attention of tariff reformers and of the tariff committees in the House and Senate:

In the Autumn of 1797, Coleridge, Wordsworth, and Poole went on a walking expedition from Alfoxden to Porlock, Linton, and Lynmouth. On the road Coleridge related a remarkable dream which had been dreamed by John Cruikshank, a resident of Nether Stowey, and which he had been thinking of making the subject of a poem.
There was a genuine surprise at Police Headquarters, Brooklyn, last night when it was stated that Wiliiam D. Lohman, the ex-cashier of the Brooklyn Department of Police and Excise, was a defaulter.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore yesterday morning resumed his course of illustrated lectures to teachers of this city and State, under the direction of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction, at the American Museum of Natural History.

From The Philadelphia Record, Feb. 2. The fact most interesting in the fortieth annual report from the Controller's office, forwarded by City Controller Thompson to the Councils yesterday, is its statement of a surplus in the city's funds. Although, on July 31 last, it was estimated that there would be a deficit of $510,800.16 in the municipal revenues at the end of 1893, there was really, on Dec. 31. a surplus of $1,248,746.17.

The Khyber Pass is no longer a hindrance to movement. Thanks to the British engineers, whose road is excellent, having no grade steeper than 1 in 50, a lady's brougham can drive from Peshawar to Landi Khana. In a military sense the pass is difficult. The gorge at Ali Masjid and the defile beyond could be held for a long time by a small force against an army.
M. Ovide Dupre has made an appeal to the courts of France against the French Consul General at New-York.

Willis Holly, Mayor Gilroy's secretary, was married yesterday afternoon to Margaret Montgomery, daughter of James P. Young of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George C. Nixon of the First Presbyterian Church of Tremont, an old friend of Mr. Holly, at the New Netherland Hotel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 3. -- From a source close to Gov. McKinley comes a statement to-day to the effect that John C. Gowdy, Chairman of the Indiana Republican Committee, on his visit here last week, was the bearer of an important message from ex-President Harrison to McKinley. It was that Harrison would not again be a candidate for the Presidency, and that his support would go to McKinley in preference to Reed.

There is an unusual amount of Interest regarding the coming blennial congress of the National Trotting Association, which meets in this city on the 14th inst. The question of a legislative union between the National and its offshoot, the American Association, is to come up again, having been referred to the regular congress by the special one which, was held in this city last June.

A young woman, who gave her name as Maggie Clinton, but who refused to tell where she lived, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning and held in default of $300 ball for trial. She was arrested Friday afternoon in R.H. Macy Co.'s store.

SING SING, Feb. 3 -- It is not an uncommon experience, particularly with suburban residents, to arrive at the railroad station, to take a train to the metropolis just in time to be too late for the train they started for.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Naval Constructor at the Union Iron Works, San Francisco, thinks he has caught the ordnance officers of the navy in a blunder. He has reported an error in the shaping of the plates for the sponsons of the battle ship Oregon, being built at that shipyard. The sponson is the bay-windowlike structure on the side of a ship out of which a gun is fired.
All the correspondence in relation to the resignation of H. Winthrop Gray from the Fire Commission was made public by Mayor Gilroy yesterday.

MOUNT VERNON, Feb. 3 -- Henry M. Downing, a plumber of this city, has signed the papers in an action which he has begun in the Supreme Court for $10,000 damages against George S, Miller, Robert M. Kelley, and Franklin Miller, who are engaged in the wholesale plumbing supplies business at 218 Pearl Street, New-York, under the name of Miller Coates.
The second week of the McKane trial in Brooklyn came yesterday to a sensational close.

Mr. Wilson, who is the President of the National Association of Democratic Clubs as well as Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, has called a meeting of the Executive Committee of the association in Washington this week. The intention is said to be to arrange for a general expression of public opinion on the question of tariff reform during the time that the House bill is pending in the Senate.

Jones and Tompkins jointly shared a disinterested friendship which even Jones's marriage had not partitioned. Indeed, in the well-fed enthusiasm succeeding their little dinners Tompkins was willing to admit Jones's pretty wife, Flora, into an humble and silent part in their fellowship, such as women held in the primitive church.

BAHIA, Brazil, Jan. 9. -- There is every indication that the first naval engagement of the Brazilian civil war will shortly take place off Bahia. The greatest precautions are being taken by the Government to keep Banians ignorant of the prospective fight. The censors at the telegraph and mail offices have redoubled their efforts, and in anticipation of public demonstrations details of cavalry are trotting constantly through the streets.

OFF PERNAMBUCO, Brazil, on Board the Steamship Nictheroy, Jan. 1 -- The Nictheroy still lies here, about two miles off shore, which nobody on board has been allowed to visit, lest the Mello fleet should suddenly appear and find a man missing from his post. The Brazilian cadets and their officers, however, go and come apparently without let or hindrance.

The movement for relieving Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, of the steam surface road of the Long Island Railroad Company is renewed this year with what its authors believe to be much better prospects of success. Mr. Blackford, President of the Sprague National Bank, which is situated on Atlantic Avenue, near the terminus of the Long Island Railroad, and who has particular means of knowledge, expresses great confidence in the result.

Different centuries produce different types of humanity, though born of the same race. The best of men will commit deeds in one era at which the worst would hesitate in another. The standard obviously, therefore, is all-important in determining morality, and not less so than is the supply of air and food and water in regulating the public health.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 23 -- Wednesday evening, the 17th, a large ball was given at Government House by their Excellencies the Governor and Lady Shea. It was by far the most elaborate entertainment of the kind in Nassau for a long time. A few American visitors were present, among them being Mrs. Delos McCurdy of New-York.

The Sub-Treasury held $20,000,000 at the close of business yesterday, deposited on account of the bond subscriptions. The deposits consisted of $14,000,000 in gold coin. $1,000,000 in gold certificates, and $5,000,000 in legal tenders and Treasury notes passed in for redemption. Deposits for redemption will be turned into gold at the Sub-Treasury.

There is, perhaps, no other group of insects which in form and color are so generally imitative, and which naturalists have found more difficult to detect in their haunts. Their bodies often resemble the roughened bark of the trees among which they live; or they seem to have growing to them little flecks of lichen or moss, which add to the deception.

John H. Inman's new house, at 874 Fifth Avenue, between Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth Streets, recently completed, adds another to the many palatial houses in that part of the city. The property on which the house stands has a frontage on Fifth Avenue of 45 feet and a depth of 200 feet. Mr. Inman purchased it four years ago with the intention of erecting on it a home.

FLUSHING, L.I., Feb. 3. -- Gen. Lewis Richmond died this morning at the house of his daughter, Mrs. John W. Weed, 30 Jamaica Avenue. He was ill only an hour. Mrs. Weed is the only surviving member of the family. Mrs. Richmond died suddenly two years ago. A. few months later their oldest son, David Richmond, died. Another son, George Richmond, died in 1888.

A meeting of the Retail Coal Dealers' Exchange was held Friday night at Fifty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue for the purpose of taking action regarding a change in the price of coal, and also to consider the weight plans which were adopted last June. After considerable discussion the following preamble and resolution were offered:

He Will Not Aoprove Nominal Elevated Railroad Damages. George H. Brush, representing the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company, appeared in the Kings County Supreme Court, before Justice Gaynor, yesterday, and moved to confirm the report of John T. Barnard, Charles Small, and Otto Huber, the commission appointed to assess damages to certain property on Myrtle Avenue by the construction of the road. The commission assessed damages in each case at 6 cents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Senate resolution calling on Secretary Carlisle for information in regard to the bond issue, names of bidders, , was received at the Treasury Department to-day. Secretary Carlisle took the resolution to the White House with him this afternoon. It is possible that he may not consider it advisable to give all the detailed information requested.

The State of Florida seems to have been startled by the revelation that the Honduras National Lottery has established its entire business, except the single operation of drawing numbers from a wheel, within its limits. The work appears to have been carried on for six months at Port Tampa City under false pretenses and brought to completion without any discovery of its design.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- There were apparently no new developments in the Brazilian situation to-day. Secretary Herbert received a telegram from Rear Admiral Benham stating that there was no change in the condition of affairs at Rio. Minister Thompson and Admiral Benham will keep their respective departments fully informed of the course of events daily.

The negro conferences held at Tuskegee, Ala., the last two years, under the auspices of the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, have proved so helpful and instructive in showing the masses of colored people how to lift themselves up in their industrial, moral, and religious life, and have created so much general interest throughout the country, that it has been decided to hold another session of this conference on Wednesday, Feb. 21.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 3 -- It is several years since the sleighing has been so good as it was hereabout on Thursday and Friday, and Orange society has made the most of it.

From The Boston Transcript. An earnest effort was made by the friends of education and letters in the House of Representatives during the tariff debate to put all books on the free list. Chief among the men who labored to this end was Representative Everett of Masachusetts. All efforts were unavailing.

Every year it is tritely announced that the custom of sending valentines is dying out, but every year they crop up in all grades of shops, and everybody knows that business men do not continue to offer merchandise for which demand has ceased or even fallen off. One sort of valentine is dying out, happily -- the comic kind.

Relief for the relief workers is the cry now beginning to be heard from all parts of the city. The large sums appropriated for general charity are almost exhausted by the undlminished demands, and donations of money, clothes, and shoes are greatly needed In almost all branches of the work for the relief of the unemployed.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The second battle of Trenton, now being waged on the banks of the Delaware River, is not without its comic side. The first battle of Trenton, which resulted in a very readable chapter of Revolutionary history and a battle monument that cost $60,000, was devoid of those pleasant incidents that give to army narratives a tinge of romance and humor.

One of the prettiest and most charming of young New-York society woman, and a member of the Drawing Room Club, has a knowledge of legal lore that would astonish any one not acquainted with the marvelous versatility of the nineteenth-century woman. "I believe you would be a splendid hand to search briefs for me," her husband, a lawyer, had remarked at one time.

Mr. Twining traveled in America when the memories of Lord Cornwallis, the surrender of Yorktown and Bunker Hill, were still fresh. He visited Philadelphia, Baltimore, and other places, traveling over newly-made roads, where the driver cleverly guided his steeds through the stumps of trees left standing, and ran imminent risk of upsetting the coach.

All the theatrical managers of this city have decided to give a performance for the benefit of the unemployed poor. The performance will take place on Feb. 9 at the Broadway Theatre, from 1 to 6 o'clock in the afternoon, and the proceeds will be handed to Mayor Gilroy to distribute among whatever charitable organizations he may judge best.

In the present case, besides these things, we have a title that is not likely to propitiate certain classes of readers.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Louis Vanderstreet, who was arrested last Monday for failing to pay back taxes, died suddenly at the county jail Thursday morning, before medical aid could be summoned.

Sitting upon a bench in front of the statue of the poet. Thomas Moore, at Fifty-ninth Street and the Eastern Driveway of Central Park, at 6:45 last evening, an Italian, who is supposed to be G. Deleo Cassa, fired a bullet from a revolver into his right temple. He died almost immediately.

Recruiting is also called brisk in the Seventh and Twenth-third Regiments, also, if placing the names of applicants for admission on the waiting list of the companies may be called by that name. The companies in these regiments are always full and the waiting lists are sometimes large enough to make another respectable company.

The value of peanuts as food is not of recent discovery. To eat a few has been recommended for indigestion, but this view of their efficacy is not exactly borne out by experience. The trouble is to eat the "few" -- peanuts having a seductive quality, like popcorn, which invites continued munching.
From The San Francisco Examiner. Patrick Baker, a resident of Oakland, discovered in one of his fellow-laborers a few days ago a brother who had been given up for dead many years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- There is $25,000 available for supplying the naval militia with arms and equipment. This appropriation was made by the latest Naval Appropriation act, and the Secretary of the Navy was instructed to prepare regulations governing its distribution. There is one corporation which has been grawing up in the community practically unheralded and unadvertised, yet which, because of the object it seeks to accomplish and the prominence of the men connected with it, already exercises an important influence on society, as well as occupies an important place in financial circles.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- Never in the history of Philadelphia has the death of one of its citizens caused more widespread regret than has that of George W. Childs, the eminent publisher and philanthropist. The city is bowed in mourning, and telegrams of condolence from prominent persons in this and other countries are being received by the score.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- A pelting rain, steady and pitiless, was falling to-night when the first carriage load of gold-laced members of the Diplomatic Corps was set down at the White House, to take part in the reception by the President and Mrs. Cleveland in honor of the army and navy, and there was no mitigation of the storm as the hour of 9 o'clock approached.

Changes of form are very slow -- though rapid enougih to explain the motion of glaciers -- but pressure increases their speed. Tresca of the French Academy has proved by his beautiful and varied experiments that under a certain pressure all solids "flow" like liquids, and that their molecules obey in such cases the laws of the motion of liquids.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 3 -- The Norwalk Mills Company, manufacturers of fine cassimeres and worsteds, have closed down several times this season, owing to the prevailing business depression. Two weeks ago another shut-down was ordered, and this week the finishing department was cleaning up the last of the work.

From The Boston Transcript. The Rev. Dr. A.C.A. Hall's career in this country, not unlike his life on the other side of the Atlantic, has been replete with interesting and remarkable events. In connection with the Rev. Edward Osborne, he for years made our city the scene of his self-denying labors for the Church and for the amelioration of the lot of the poorer classes in Boston.

Harald Hagen, the professional Norwegian skater, is still anxious to meet "Joe" Donoghue in a race for the championship of the world. Hagen at present is in Holland, and if the match is made he insists on Donoghue defraying his expenses to this country.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 3 -- The annual encampment of the Connecticut Grand Army will be held here Feb. 14 and 15, the session lasting two days. Extensive preparations are in progress for the event. A reception will be given Wednesday evening, Feb. 15 at the Foot Guard Armory, in honor of National Commander Adams of Lynn, Mass., and State Commander Rogers of Meridan. The sum of $1,000 has been raised for the festivities.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Feb. 3. -- A posse of fifty-six special deputies, under Deputy Sheriffs Walters and McDougall. went to Ridgewood to-night to prevent a boxing exhibition, advertised by the Metropolitan Athletic Club to be held in John Kreuscher's Ridgewood Hall.

A country town of a Sunday afternoon in Canada is the quietest of existing things. Everything in it seems lifeless. Not a sound is heard from any side. One's own cough startles one in the very streets. Two cows slowly wend their way homeward; an overripe apple falls heavily in an unkempt front garden -- even these signs of semi-life are a relief.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 3. -- A special committee of the Dutchess County Medical Society has concluded a long session in which charges of conduct unbecoming a physician made against Dr. John P. Wilson of this city were considered. The charges were preferred by Dr. J.W. Poucher, who was recently a defendant in a malpractice suit in which the jury brought in a verdict of no cause of action.

Brooklyn people are still in doubt as to whether the excise laws are to be enforced to-day under the new municipal administration. There were many inquiries yesterday at Police Headquarters concerning the intentions of the department in regard to Sunday selling.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 3 -- The fight which the Santa Fe and the Burlington have begun against paying their taxes for 1893 is creating increasing interest here. When the assessment for 1892 was made against the railroad properties in Kansas the Populists had one member of the board, the Attorney General.

The Senatorial committee which is to investigate the New-York Police Department met again yesterday at the Hotel Metropole without accomplishing anything. After half an hour's talk about the engagement of counsel, the committee adjourned to meet again at some indefinite date to toe fixed on Wednesday at Albany.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Feb. 3 -- Another successful test of armor plate by the Bethlehem Iron Company was made to-day. The test involved the acceptance of nearly 400 tons of armor. Its outcome was entirely satisfactory. The plate is for the cruiser Puritan, now being constructed in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. It is not Harveyized.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The prelenten ball at the Lakewood Hotel to-night was a fitting close to a season of gayety at that house. The decorations of the ballroom were unsurpassed by any former dance. Hangings of blue and white bunting, window decorations of potted plants, and a screen of vines concealing the stage where the Austrian Band played made an effective background for many handsome gowns.

President Martin said yesterday that the communication from the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, refusing to produce witnesses or furnish testimony to the Commissioners in regard to the complaint made by his society against Capt. Slevin of the Fourth Precinct, was received too late on Friday for consideration by the board.

People who descend the Hudson by boat or steam cars generally catch sight of sharp lines of earthwork, crowned by buildings with regrular outlines of roof, when they first enter the romantic section of the Highlands. These are enough to indicate to those on the lookout that West Point is in sight.

The New-York Board of Trade and Transportation held its annual dinner last night at the Hotel Waldorf. Darwin R. James, President of the board, was in the chair.

In a recent communication of the Minister of Finance, Alexandro Vial, to the Chilean Minister in France, Augusto Matte, the former outlines the present financial situation in Chile and replies to certain criticisms made by the English press, which the Minister alleges were made with the purpose of damaging the credit of his country abroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The alleged attempt to re-establish the Louisiana Lottery, under a nominal Honduras charter, at Port Tampa City, Fla., was not unknown to Senator Pasco, who has been interesting himself in the subject for the past few days, and looking into the law with the end in view of doing all he can to remove the evil from the State.

Six separate answers to the petition of the Northern Pacific Directors for the removal of the receivers have been filed in the United States Circuit Court in Milwaukee. The answers which are in refutation of the accusations of mismanagement and fraud cover more than 500 printed pages.

From The Westminster Gazette. Yesterday, at the Brompton County Court, Capt. Head claimed L15 odd from the Earl of Clancarty for breach of agreement in the hiring of a furnished house, 40 Lowndes Square. The defendant signed an agreement to take the house in question from Sept. 23 last to Nov. 18 at the rent of u100 16s.

It is easy for the utilitarian advantages derivable from a knowledge of the movements of the celestial bodies to be overlooked to-day.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 3. -- There are two millionaires in Maryland who believe that it is better to use their wealth in great enterprises for the public good while they are living than to trust then plans to trustees and courts after they are dead. Acting upon that belief they have given to the State two institutions that are models of their kind.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 -- Walter Johnson of Gloucester, Mass., this noon, shot Miss Carrie Low Andrews in the Warren Building on Park Street. He then shot himself in the head, after which he slashed his wrist with a razor, dying in a few minutes. Miss Andrews lived twenty minutes.

There was food for speculation in the week of opera which has just passed. It be gan with what has been called the noblest tragedy Wagner ever penned, and ended with Bizet's admirable setting of Prosper Merimee's tale of a wayward gypsy. Between these two intensely-modern works were a beautiful survival of the classic age of opera and the unique masterpiece of a French idealist, who gave the world only two memorable works.

"The Black Crook," with its glittering Costumes magnificent scenery, and gorgeous ballets, will remain for another week at the Colombia Theatre, where it is attracting large audiences. Next week the Lillian Russell Opera Company will appear at the house, presenting toe Casino production of "Princess Nicotine."

There is quite a large fleet of steamships now overdue at this port. Judging from the experience of the few stragglers which arrived yesterday, there is little cause to wonder that such should be the case. All of the in-comers report that their voyages were protracted by turbulent seas and heavy, adverse gales.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The House Committee on Appropriations to-day completed the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, and directed Chairman Sayers to report it to the House.

BAHIA, Brazil, Jan. 7 -- If one has any doubt of the power being wielded by the Peixoto Government of Brazil one has only to come to Bahia and observe how completely in ignorance the 200,000 people of this city are kept of the condition of affairs at Rio de Janeiro and throughout the republic.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Mr. William Waldorf Astor may derive personal satisfaction from his possession of a big London afternoon paper, and some score of bright young men who draw much better salaries from it than they could get elsewhere are undoubtedly gratified. But I should think the fact affords pleasure to nobody else in England.

LISBON, Feb. 3. -- The King yesterday received a deputation, who visited his Majesty for the purpose of protesting against the new and vexatious taxation imposed by the Government. It was these taxes that caused the recent rioting in Oporto and great dissatisfaction in Lisbon and other cities and towns.

Leaders of both parties in the State Senate were in this city yesterday, and while here they took counsel as to how they should act. in view of the recent trouble in the Senate.

A young woman, Miss Fay Fuller of Tacoma, a daughter of an editor of that city, has recently accomplished the perilous feat of climbing Mount Tacoma, America's most difficult peak. It is a grim old hill, towering 14,444 feet high, with glaciers extending far up its base.
From The North Adams (Mass.) Democrat. Parson Emerson of Conway kept a diary. I will give your readers a little of it.

The Extraordinary Grand Jury for the month of January was discharged by Justice Bartlett in Brooklyn yesterday, after presenting two additional indictments. Who the indicted persons are could not be ascertained, as the warrants had not been tested for their arrest. It was general rumor that one was for a Police Justice of Brooklyn, but this could not be verified.

Louis Liebes, a tobacco importer slid general dealer of 172 Water Street, was before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday morning charged with being a "conspirator in an attempt to defraud the Government."

ROME, Feb. 3 -- The military tribunal in Palermo to-day tried Private Lombardini, who, while on a furlough, took part in the Gibellina riot, which resulted in the death of a pawnbroker and the injury of many others. He was accused also of having tried to disarm a soldier in uniform who had been called out with his company to quell the riot.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- While the Finance Committee of the Senate has met and decided upon the programme to be followed in disposing of the Tariff bill, there will be a great deal of reckless speculation about the length of time that is to be given to hearings before the committee, and to debate after the committee has reported the bill to the Senate.

The Lenox Library has lately made a purchase that places it in an enviable position as a library of reference for students of the colonial period. This is a collection of 311 bound volumes of journals and weekly gazettes, some of which run back to the year 1733.

John Drew returns to New-York to-morrow night at Palmer's Theatre, where he will present for the first time in this city "The Butterflies," the new play written for him by Henry Guy Carleton. This will be his second season in this city as a star under the management of Charles Frohman.

Much excitement was caused in Third Avenue and the Bowery last night by a chase after a negro thief, who stole a pocketbook from Miss Jennie Lenard of 108 Woolsey Street, Astoria, L. I. She was walking in Third Avenue near Ninth Street in company with Charles K. Miller, also of Astoria, about 7:30 o'clock, when the negro suddenly sprang in front of her, snatched the pocketbook from her hand, and ran away.

They were still standing by the box laughing, when Chief of Battalion Lally arrived in his wagon, and finding there was no fire, he had them arrested.

The Home for Union Printers, in Colorado, is one of the many institutions for the bent-lit of his fellow-men that Mr. Childs made possible.

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- Financial and industrial circles whose interests are menaced by the new schemes of taxation have just begun to discover that a reference of all of Finance Minister Miquel's financial projects to a single commission means a long period of uncertainty. It must be Summer before there can be a definite settlement of the questions that affect important spheres of business.

MONTREAL, Feb. 3 -- The attendance at the annual championship races of the Canadian Amateur Skating Association here today was something enormous. The ice was in splendid condition. The weather was mild, but not enough to spoil the ice. A light snow fell during the early morning, but this was cleared off the track.

John K. Milholland the leader of the antimachine Republicans, said last night that, while Whitelaw Reid and Thomas C. Platt had not yet contributed any cash to help along his branch of the party in this ciiy, he did not doubt that they would do so if asked.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- A wampum belt which played a prominent part in the history of the State over two centuries ago is exhibited in the County Clerk's office in this city. It is 30 inches long, 3 inches wide, and is made of seven cords of tow, between which are rows of innumerable beads made from shells.

HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Bartholomew P. Madden was arrested at noon to-day in a boarding house near the Capitol, at Albany, on the charge of murdering Maurice Murphy of New-York. Madden lived at Tuckahoe, Westchester County, and both he and Murphy were stonecutters. The two men started from New-York Jan. 1 to walk to Albany.

The Board of Directors of the Coney Island Jockey Club met yesterday morning to consider the latest letter received from the Board of Control and Horse Owners' Association asking for a conference. The meeting was held in the Cumberland, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-second Street. Those present were J.G.K. Lawrence, J.H. Radford, Cornelius Fellowes, Gen. Daniel Butterfield, Col. Lawrence Kip, John G. Hecksher, Herbert C. Pell, ex-Gov. George Peabody Wetmore, and F. Gray Griswold.

February, 1894, may be considered a trifle late to begin to take vacations due in July, 1893, but that is the programme which some of the best-known men in this country are preparing to carry out just now -- all on account of the panic.

Perhaps the most interesting theme of discussion among real estate men during the week was the reported sale of the square fronting on Broadway and Liberty, Cedar, and Temple Streets. The plot contains Something over 19,000 square feet, and, at the price demanded, $2,700,000, the rate would be over $140 per square foot.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 4. -- Fox hunting has become a necessity, as well as sport, in some sections of Long Island this Winter. Sly Reynard has multiplied so rapidly that a war of extermination has been started in several localities.

None of the four naughty boys who made their escape from the Catholic Protectory at Van Nest Friday have been recaptured. Brother Leontine, the Superintendent of the protectory, however, expects they will soon be brought back.

The first important sale of trotting horses for 1894 in this city begins to-morrow at the American Institute Building, Third Avenue and Sixty-third Street. Kellogg Co., during the three days that the sale continues, will dispose of about 120 head, a very large proportion of which are seasoned campaigners, with very fast race records.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4. -- Capt. Trefry of the British ship Celeste Burrill, which arrived here to-day from Luzon Island, with a cargo of hemp and sugar, thinks that his vessel had a narrow escape from being boarded by pirates in the Sunday Straits, a stretch of water formerly as famous for its Malay freebooters as was ever the Spanish Main for its buccaneers.

Boston for more than a month has been interested in the fate of A.H. Howland, a civil engineer and contractor, and on Saturday a reporter-detective, who came here with facts that warranted doubt of Howland's having committed suicide from the Pall River steamer Pilgrim on Dec. 29 last, fortified them to the extent of going far to prove that the supposed suicide is alive.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- A dispatch, dated at Rio Janeiro yesterday, says that the Government has seized the tug Cardiff, owned by an English coal company. It was believed that the tug was smuggling dynamite aboard the insurgent war ship Trajano.

In his little book entitled "Recollections," issued in 1892, Mr. Childs published a letter from Capt. da Gama, the man who now, as Admiral, is in command of the insurgent fleet in Rio Harbor. Da Gama came to this country as a delegate to a maritime conference, and brought with him a letter of introduction to Mr. Childs, written by Emperor Dom Pedro.

The Municipal Art Society of New-York, which was organized last Spring for the purpose of providing sculptural and pictorial decorations for the public buildings and parks of the city, will make the first attempt in America at municipal art by decorating the room of the Court of Oyer and Terminer in the new Criminal Courts Building in Centre Street.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 3. -- There are few changes to note in the local or money situation. Prices of securities were varied so as to make losses about balance small grains, but it happens that the movement of securities was heavier than in weeks past. In the industrials, Air Brake shows the greatest lost, having sold down around 130, while Union Switch scored the best gain, in sales close to 16.

When it became generally known in Brooklyn yesterday that the accounts of William D. Lohman, late cashier of the Department of Excise, were short $19,000, there was considerable surprise manifested. This was especially the case among the Germans, among whom Mr. Lohman was one of the shining lights.

The first and final account of Emma L. Borden, administratrix of the murdered Andrew J. Borden of Fall River, was rendered, but contains no information as to the amount of Mr. Borden's property. The paper reads as follows:

It was one of the notable and depressing features of the recent panic that not only securities dealt in on the Stock Exchange were affected and knocked down in market value, but other securities, such as are not subject to the speculative processes of Wall Street, were also put under a cloud. This was especially true of municipal bonds.

For some reason, Deputy Coroner O'Hare failed to respond to a call to the apartments of Mrs. Milllgan, at 303 East Seventy-third Street, or the call did not reach him. As a result, the body of Mrs. Milligan's daughter, Sarah Grace Milllgan, lay in one of the rooms five days. Only yesterday were the formalities of the law complied with, so that the body could be buried.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- The past week was gay with society events. Visitors from cities In and out of the State dally swarmed over the campus, and each arriving train brought a new delegation.

Mrs. Rebecca Blumenthal was convicted in the United States District Court yesterday of passing counterfeit one-cent coins, and was sent to jail pending the hearing of a motion for a new trial made by her counsel, Alfred Hushes. She had her little daughter, about three years old, by her side in court, and she took the child with her to jail.

A slight difference of opinion as to the fitness of smoking a cigar in the supper room during "ladies' night" between two members of the Progress Club, a wealthy Hebrew organization, whose sumptuous home is at Sixty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, led to a sensational newspaper story hinting at many resignations and a probable disruption in the club.

Arthur Meyer, twenty-three years old, of 433 East Eighteenth Street, was charged in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday with forging a check for $84. The complainant was William K. Young, manager of the Boys' Club Dairy of 402 East Twelfth Street, who had employed Meyer two and a half years.

The scant courtesy shown Mayor Schieren's administration by the present Legislature has provoked much adverse comment in Brooklyn. Friends of the Mayor say he should exert his influence to defeat bills contrary to the reform policies he is trying to promote.
The East Side Relief Work Committee issues the following appeal:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4. -- In many of the churches of the various denominations today the death of George W. Childs was feelingly referred to by the officiating clergymen, and his passing away was pronounced a public loss and bereavement.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 4. -- At 8 o'clock last evening William Phipps was shot in the back of the neck and dangerously wounded by Mrs. Margaret Lovett. Miss Francis Mahoney, living with her sister, Mrs. Lovett, Oct. 19 last was assaulted in a vacant building opposite her home. The crime was charged to Phipps.

Republicans in Kings County are already preparing to assert their influence in the coming State campaign. Their first demonstration in that direction is a movement looking to the nomination of ex-Senator Charles H. Russell for Lieutenant Governor, Mr. Russell's friends have communicated with Republicans ha other parts of the State, and they believe his prospects of securing the nomination, providing he can get the united delegation from Kings County, are promising.
Frederick M. Somers died of pneumonia in Southampton, England, Friday night. He arrived there Thursday, a passenger on the steamship New-York. Mr. Somers was born in Boston in 1850.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- There are some Democrats at tine Capitol, at both, ends of that building, who will not learn how to belong to the party in power, and who insist upon being "against the Government." They made a demonstration in force when the attempt was made to repeal the silverpurchase clause of the Sherman act, and they were beaten.

The large number of people who crowded into the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon gave evidence that interest in the evangelistic revival meetings is as strong as it was three week ago. The audience listened attentively to every word spoken by the speakers.

The Catholic Directory for the present year shows a large increase in the number of priests, churches, members, schools and religious communities during the past year. The number of Catholics in the United States is given as 8,902,033. There are 72 dioceses, 17 Archbishops, 71 Bishops, and one Cardinal.

-- Ex-Senator George P. Edmunds argued a case before the United States Court in NewOrleans one day last week, and a local paper thus described him: "His tall form at times seemed to swell with the force of his intense utterances, and, again, with sarcastic politeness, he bent low before the counsel of the defendants.

The feast of St. Brigid was celebrated yesterday morning in St. Brigid's Church, Tompkins Square. A solemn high mass was chanted at 11 o'clock by the Rev. Patrick F. Sweeny, the rector, assisted by the Rev. Charles V. Reid as deacon, and the Rev. Patrick H. Drain as sub-deacon. On the altar burned hundreds of candles and wax tapers.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- The last reports of trust companies made to the State Superintendent of Banking for the year 1893, were made by the Ithaca and Newburg companies. From them these abstracts are made:

-- In the second volume of M. D, Conway's edition of Thomas Paine's works, which will be ready from the Messrs. Putnam in the Spring, will be given the most of Paine's writings, produced while he was in England, from September, 1787, until he went to France, five years later.
The Rev. Madison C. Peters, pastor of Bloomingdale Church, Boulevard and West Sixty-eighth Street, preached last evening on the topic, "Jesuits Seeking our Destruction." He said:
BEAVER, Penn., Feb. 4. -- Senator Quay arrived at his home in Beaver last evening. His health is again precarious. He will, however, return to Washington tomorrow.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 4. -- A reporter for The New-York Times called at the Westchester Temporary Home for Indigent Children to-day and saw Superintendent James W. Pierce, who is accused by Theresa See, a sixteen-year-old inmate of the home, with having whipped her severely with a, cat-o'nine-tails.

The grand officers of the Order of Germania of this city will meet Feb. 14 and decide whether to continue the society or go into bankruptcy. The order is impoverished and unable to pay its death claims. Unless financial assistance is rendered It will have to suspend.

-- Marie Burroughs as a Star. --E.S. Willard, the capable English actor, who has, by conscientious work, established himself as an artist in this country, has decided to rest all of next season. His tour, however, has already been booked, and out-of-town managers naturally insist on their rights, that if he cancel his own dates he shall fill the time that is being held for him by some equally powerful attraction.
Principal Joseph S. Burns of Brooklyn Public School No. 26 has replied to the criticisms of his methods by Superintendent Maxwell in a statement containing thirteen separate denials.

English gentlemen flew hawks at partridges ages ago, and now knock them over with "the deadly tube," as a euphuist of the Elizabethan age called a gun. Mr. Macpherson writes feelingly of the little bird that "wanders over the downs of the south coast, climbs the slopes of the northern oatfields, or threads its way through the rich pastures of the Thames Valley."

We give in another column a detailed abstract of the report of the minority of the House Judiciary Committee on the Bailey Bankruptcy bill. It opposes the passage of that bill and recommends that the Torrey bill be substituted for it. The recommendation is a sound, one which the House ought to adopt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Commander McGowan has been detached from the schoolship St. Mary's, at New-York, and will have a leave of absence while awaiting orders. Commander McGowan has served a threeyear term on the schoolship, to which he was ordered on Jan. 3, 1891. His last tour before that was completed in April, 1890.

There is an interesting story connected with the production at the Comedy Theatre, London, Saturday night, of Buchanan's comedy, "Dick Sheridan." It is not often, if indeed it has ever happened before, that a play rejected by an American manager, has been presented to a London audience; but this is the case with "Dick Sheridan."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Judge Simon P. Wolverton of Pennsylvania will submit tomorrow a report on behalf of the minority of the Committee on the Judiciary of the House, opposing the passage of the Bailey bill and offering the Torrey Bankruptcy bill as a substitute for it.

Henry H. Jackson of 63 East Ninety-second Street had a story to tell yesterday of an encounter he had late Saturday night in his kitchen with a man whom he thinks is a burglar. The supposed burglar is now locked up, pending examination. He says he is a sweetheart of a servant girl employed in the house, and went to sleep in the kitchen.

The bicycle members of the New-York Athletic Club have increased greatly in numbers during the last year. If anything, the increase in enthusiasm has more than kept pace with the growth in numbers. One of the most potent causes of this encouraging state of affairs is the awarding of medals to those bicyclists who cover a certain number of miles during the year.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 4. -- There promises to be a lively contest over the will of Francis D. Fox, who died from pneumonia at East Orange on Dec. 1. He made a will in 1889, and, after signing it in the presence of witnesses, gave it into the keeping of Clinton B. Thurber, at the time a prosperous1/2 merchant of Bay Shore, L.I.
The Trustees of Barnard College at their last meeting adopted resolutions on the death of Miss Ella Weed, the late head of the college. The following tribute is paid to her work:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The action of the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad, which in conjunction operate a line between Washington and Richmond, in discontinuing Train No. 27 on Sunday has caused great annoyance to the publishers of New-York newspapers and newsdealers and newspaper readers in towns formerly served by this train.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- The training for the freshman crew has continued far enough to warrant the coach in making some selections of the Most promising men to go into more thorough and systematic practice. Mr. Courtney has accordingly selected twenty men from the sixty-odd freshmen who presented themselves to him at the beginning of this term to train in earnest from now until the final selection is made.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, Feb. 4. -- Chancellor von Caprivi's parliamentary dinner to-morrow evening will be a proud function, attended not only by all the Cabinet Ministers, but also by an unusual number of Imperial Deputies. Members of the Opposition say that the dinner will mark the climax of the Chancellor's career, as within a month Gen. Freiherr von Loe, a strong Bismarckian with an Agrarian policy, will replace him.

The shooting on Saturday night at the armory range of the Seventh Regiment was for non-sharpshooters. The conditions were seven shots, standing, at 200 yards, and seven shots, prone, at 500 yards. Scores:

The observance of Quinquagesima Sunday in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday consisted of a solemn high mass, celebrated at 11 A.M. by the Rev. James N. Connolly, assisted by the Rev. William Daly as deacon and the Rev. P. Daly as sub-deacon. The preacher was Bishop McQuaid of Rochester, N.Y.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 4. -- Since the publication of the manifesto by Ben De Lemos, Chairman of the Republican State Campaign Committee, calling on Republicans to divorce from the Kolbites and Populites and run a separate State ticket, Republicans have held meetings all over the State and taken steps as the manifesto requested.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- The Standard's Rome correspondent says that the following prelates will be created Cardinals at the next consistory: Mgr. Tancredi Fausti, Papal Auditor; Mgr. Clasca, Secretary of the Congregation of the Propaganda; Mgr. Ferraud, Archbishop of Bologna; Mgr. Jacobini, Archbishop of Ferrara; Archbishop Satolli, Apostolic Delegate to the Church in the United States; Eugenio Clari, Bishop of Viterbo, and Father Steinhuber, the Austrian Jesuit.
The Kings County Medical Society is fighting the New-York and New-Jersey Telephone Company.

The Committee of One Hundred, as selected by ex-Secretary Charles S. Fairchild, to effect a permanent organization of the State Democracy in New-York County was announced yesterday. This committee was named by Mr. Fairchlld in accordance with the action taken at the mass meeting in Cooper Union Dec. 21.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- At daybreak this morning Auguste Vaillant, who threw the bomb in the Chamber of Deputies on Dec. 9, paid the penalty of his crime by death on the guillotine in the Place de la Roquette. The fact that he was to be executed at that hour had been spread through Paris during the night, and a large crowd had assembled to witness the scene.

OMAHA, Feb. 4. -- The loss by the fire of Saturday night, which started in the Boston Store, and eventually destroyed half a block in the business centre of the town, amounts to $350,000. Almost two-thirds of the loss was caused by the burning of the building in which it started, and the contents of that building.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- C. Potter, the alleged secret emissary of the provisional Government of Hawaii, was locked up in a cell at the Desplaines Street Police Station last night. The charge against him is obtaining money under false pretenses. The complainants are Shetler Challman, druggists, and the Moffatt Livery Company.

If, instead of aiming the flatiron at John Mahoney and hitting her husband, Mrs. Golden, a boarding-house keeper at 146 Lincoln Avenue, had aimed at her husband, the accepted mark for such a domestic weapon, and hit Mr. Mahoney, it is possible that a good deal of trouble would have been saved and that Mr. Mahoney would not have been forced to appear in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday morning.
Pretty Alma Potter, three years old, was missing from her home, 27 Carmine Street, for nearly two days, and her parents were almost crazed with grief in consequence.

NEWARK. N.J., Feb. 4. -- Trade revivals are reported from many quarters of this large manufacturing city. In the leather business the outlook is good for this Spring. S. Halsey Son are steadily increasing the force of men in their leather factory, and report increasing sales. T.P. Howell Co., another big leather firm, are working a full force of men nine hours a day.

-- The five-mile race of the Canadian Skating championships, at Montreal. Saturday, was a most exciting one, Johnson, Norseng, McCulloch, "Joe" Donoghue, and James Donoghue started. On the first lap Johnson took the lead, but fell behind in the second. Norseng then took the lead, and the order until the last lap was Norseng, Johnson, McCulloch, "Joe" Donoghue, and "Jim" Donoghue.

People who live in West Thirty-seventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, have been looking up municipal law recently. Some have even gone so far as to consult old English laws, especially those pertaining to London.

In a small room on the second floor of 88 Court Street, Brooklyn, rests the body of a young woman in an advanced state of decomposition, awaiting burial. An undertaker on Fifth Avenue, who has charge of it, refused to bury it, because the woman's husband has not the means to pay him.

Burglars and highwaymen have been busy in New-York in the last few days. Several persons have been attacked in the streeta and money and jewelry taken from them, and numerous attempts have been made to rifle business places and private dwellings. But the success of the thieves has been limited.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 3. -- The offerings in the local market during the past week have been very light, while the bid prices have been well sustained. Some strength is shown in the stocks of the Equitable and Merchants Insurance Companies. The declaration of a dividend has added somewhat to the feeling of confidence in them.
Dr. Talmage yesterday morning described to his congregation, in the Brooklyn Tabernacle, a vision of heaven which he saw In a dream.

A contention that it is useless to read the plays of the elder English dramatic poets other than Shakespeare would have in its favor the fact that it is plain sense. Those plays were the natural expressions of an age absolutely different from ours, when poetry filled England as the rustle of leaves fills a forest.

We have searched everywhere for an excuse for Sheehan's conduct, and have failed to find that his warmest friend has yet been able to devise one. Apparently it is not denied that Wolfert is legally entitled to the seat. Such being the case, the injunction will be speedily dissolved, and the Senate will go on with its business. But still the mystery haunts one: What's the matter with Sheehan?

If the Legislature of this State gets free from political wrangles and partisan squabbles, which so try the patience of the people, and settles down to business, it will find that some very important questions are waiting for consideration. For one thing, the advocates of the policy of enlarging and improving the canals are prepared to make a strong push for legislative action at this session.

Republicans in this city discussed yesterday the "punishment" to be inflicted on Judge Clute of Albany and Lieut. Gov. Sheehan for the parts they have taken in attempting to block the work of the Senate, as if it had been settled that the one would be declared in contempt and the other impeached.
An early morning fire in Brooklyn yesterday nearly destroyed three buildings and endangered the lives of several tenants.

The Council Finance Committee finished its consideration of the annual apporpriation bill yesterday. The members of the committee are a unit in support of the recommendations made. Though the members of the committee refuse to talk about the recommendations contained in the bill, it is known that they have made sweeping reductions in salaries.

HOUSTON, Texas, Feb. 4. -- An electric car last night, at the point where the track crosses the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad, ran into a tie on the track. The motorman and conductor got off the car to remove the obstruction, when they were fired upon by persons in ambush. Prank Rice, the conductor, was shot in the head and arm.

The action of the Banking Committee of the House of Representatives on Friday ought to dispose of the movement for the repeal of the State bank tax, so far as that branch of Congress is concerned, for this session at least. The committee declined to report any bill for the repeal of the tax and clinched its action by the customary parliamentary proceeding in laying on the table a motion to reconsider.

Three steamships, whose voyages bad been long extended by the buffetings of gales which blew from every direction except the right one, crept into harbor yesterday. Each of them had encountered a hurricane, and neither of the trio had emerged from it entirely unscathed.
"Freedom of the Conscience" was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's lecture before the Society of Ethical Culture in the Music Hall yesterday. A large and appreciative audience listened to him.

VISALIA. Cal., Feb. 4. -- "Chris" Evans, whose escape from the penitentiary recently attracted a great deal of attention, stopped Friday night at Stone Corral, about fourteen miles east of Visalia. Morrell, another noted outlaw, was with him. A reliable man named March, who was driving along the road in the evening, met a cart with Evans and Morrell aboard, both carrying rifles.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- There was an excellent investment demand for local bonds and a very fair inquiry for local stocks during the past week. The bond market shows an improving tendency, and there were large purchases of Albany Railway consolidated 5s, Union Railway of New-York 5s, and Westchester Electric guaranteed 5 per cent. bonds.

John Shaw, the young man who was arrested Saturday on the charge of forging the name of President George B. McClellan of the Board of Aldermen to an application for a place as conductor on the Third Avenue Railway, and George Drake, who was locked up at the same time for working with Shaw in obtaining money under false pretenses, were arraigned yesterday in the Yorkville Police Court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Postmaster General Bissell has received no information of the proposed or actual resurrection of the Louisiana Lottery and the establishment of its headquarters at Port Tampa. City, Fla. A report to that effect reached the department about two weeks ago, and the Postmaster General at once referred the matter to the inspection division, with instructions to have it immediately investigated.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 5. -- The New-Orleans Carnival was successfully opened this evening with a street show, which equals, if it does not surpass, the best Mardi-Gras exhibition of its kind ever given in the city.

Mayor Gilroy has ordered the Commissioners of Accounts to investigate the affairs and accounts of the Fire Department immediately. This action is due to the discussion that has resulted from the resignation of H. Winthrop Gray from the Fire Board. Commissioners of Accounts Owen and Wahie have already begun to make the examination.

The contest over the will of Mrs. Crescentia Mueller, who died last April, leaving her entire estate, valued at $25,000, to Mrs. Georgina Upton, was resumed yesterday morning before Surrogate Fitzgerald.
A large congregation attended the evangelistic meeting in Association Hall, Brooklyn, yesterday noon. The meeting was devoted entirely to prayer and thanksgiving.

Several gentlemen interested in bicycling in Boston have decided to build a track at Nantasket Beach that will compare favorably with the Herne Hill in England, the Springfield, or any other record-breaking course in the world. Already those interested are making an effort to secure the League of American Wheelman national meet this year.

It is reported that a committee of seven members of the American Institute of Architects is in Washington to urge the Secretary of the Treasury to use the authority conferred upon him by the law passed last year to invite competition for the design of public buildings. When the law was introduced, high and reasonable hopes were entertained that the enactment of it would work an improvement in the quality of our public architecture.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- There are two classes of opponents of the Administration about to be visited with severe disappointment.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Feb. 5. -- A number of funeral coaches returning from Calvary Cemetery this afternoon were racing down Borden Avenue to the entrance to the Thirty-fourth Street Ferry in this city. In crossing an iron drawbridge over Jack's Creek one of the coaches was crowded to one side and came in collision with the framework of the bridge and was overturned.
Mary Valentine McKenzie, seventeen years old, the daughter of Mrs. Julia A. McKenzie of 200 East Eighty-second Street, has been missing from her home for nearly a month.

On the application of Col. Albert E. Lamb, who appeared for Louis and Herman Liebmann, Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday appointed Herman Liebmann receiver for the firm of Liebmann Brothers Company, and approved the appointment made by the Court of Chancery of New-Jersey of John S. McMaster.

The Legislative Committee of the Real Estate Exchange had rather an animated session yesterday afternoon on a report from a sub-committee, on taxation and assessment. This sub-committee, whose Chairman is Mr. Andrew Powell, recommended, among other things, the defeat of a bill before the Legislature, which exempts the property of the Lebanon Hospital from taxation and assessment.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- At the opening, in the face of strong Eastern quotations, the local bears had not the hardihood to make the usual drive at securities, and for a time the market was well sustained. Subsequently, however, extreme dullness prevailed, and the bears sent prices off materially for a while.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- There is general Democratic satisfaction in the expectation that to-morrow afternoon the Senate is to dispose of the Federal Elections bill. At 4 o'clock, if nothing happens to prevent, the contentions of the Republicans for a law they no longer need will come to an end, and the bill will receive the sanction of the upper house.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The man who stands guard at the door leading to the rooms of the Senate Committee on Finance has already begun to think that his days of tribulation have come. He has to be constantly on the alert. He gazed formerly upon each applicant for admission with a lenient eye.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- There is small chance of the high schools of the big cities securing army officers as instructors in military tactics and science. It was proposed to supplement the college details by assignments to high schools of a number of military professors. The project was favorably received in some quarters, and in the War Department it found earnest advocates.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- A dispatch from Sierra Leone says that a detachment of British military police encamped in the Sofa country were recently fired upon by a French force. The British returned the fire and killed six of the French force. Several of the attacking party were captured.
Wheat lost 5/3@ 7/8c on increase on passage, small India, shipments, weak West, and local realizing, closing weak and moderately active.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- C.L. Riker, the man who jumped into notoriety by offering to take all of the new bond issue, and whose bid was not considered, arrived here to-day.

-- Henry C. Newman, founder and Superintendent of the Newman Rescue Home and Mission. Jersey City, died in that city last Sunday. He was a convert of the old Jerry McAuley Water Street Mission. The Rescue Circle of that mission will attend the funeral to be held in Jersey City to-morrow. The mission Mr. Newman founded was for the rescue of fallen men and women, and in that work he labored unceasingly.

The common notion of things English will not be disturbed by "A Woman's Revenge," which had its introduction at the American Theatre last night, bearing the stamp upon it of the Adelphi Theatre, London, where its run is still unexhausted. In pictures the play is pleasing. English lanes, hedge rows, and rose-clinging porticos, rustic bridges, and soft sunsets call upon the scenic painter for careful work.

H.R. Murray, one of the Executive Committee of the New-York Driving Club, has a favorite business horse named Charley Allen, a golden sorrel stallion, foaled July 28, 1874, by old Ethan Allen, out of Maid of Wales, by Sprague's New-York; bred by Akers Sprague. As a yearling, Charley Allen was sold at auction in Chicago for $800.
A copy of the following resolutions, adopted by the People's Party of this city, has been sent to each of the Populist Senators in Washington:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- It is stated at the Treasury Department this morning that it is probable that the bonds of the new issue will not be ready for delivery before Feb. 20. The reason assigned is that the bidders want small denominations of bonds, which, of course, will take longer to print and require much more time to sign.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Contrary to expectation, the Senate Committee on the Judiciary did not take a vote on the Peckham case to-day.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 5. -- Referring to the story telegraphed, from Cleveland, that his recent visit to Columbus, Ohio, was to bear assurance from Harrison to McKinley that he would not stand in the way of his candidacy for the Presidency, Chairman Gowdy of the Republican State Committee said:
Three incendiary fires were started in the Bedford district, Brooklyn, yesterday after-noon. One of the fires was successful.

When the war veterans gathered early yesterday morningabout the Pension Agency in Canal Street to collect their quarterly pensions they found the mercury almost at zero. A cutting wind was blowing up from the North River, and made those not well protected against the wintry blasts shiver as it found the weak spots in their covering.

-- The Torture Exhibition. -- The drunkards cloak, now on exhibition at the galleries in West Twenty-third Street, among the other instruments of torture, is one of the many worn by the soldiers in Cromwell's army when they went to London and celebrated the Lord Protector's success on the night after the last public appearance of Charles I.

The original manuscripts of "Liber Scriptorum: the Book of the Authors Club," have just come from the bindery, and are on exhibition this week at Tiffany's, Union Square. Every one of the 109 manuscripts has been inlaid, and the set bound up in three superb volumes, each 15 1/2 inches high and 3 inches thick. The covering is crushed levant morocco, old red, with gilt edges.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Mr. Hale, by request, has introduced a bill in the Senate to reorganize and increase the efficiency of the personnel of the navy. It limits the active list of the line to 20 Rear Admirals, 65 Captains, 80 Commanders, 135 Lieutenant Commanders, 260 Lieutenants, and not more than 215 Junior Lieutenants and Ensigns.

The Memorial Hospital for Women and Children, at 808 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, was destroyed by fire last evening. Twentyeight patients had to be carried out of the building, several of them on mattresses, in order to save them from the flames.

Superintendent Byrnes forwarded to Mayor Gilroy yesterday $2.022.51, the sum contributed yesterday morning by the uniformed force of the Police Department toward helping the poor and unemployed of the city. The Commissioners and clerks at the Central Office contributed $244.

At the monthly meeting of the Board of Trustees of Columbia College yesterday afternoon, Prof. Franklin H. Giddings was appointed to the Chair of Professor of Sociology. The professorship is a newly-established one, and will be in the department of political science.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 5. -- The principal address at the Chamber of Commerce banquet this evening was delivered by Benjamin Butterworth. His subject was "Our National Industries." In the course of his address he said:

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- Assemblyman Butts, (Dem., New-York,) introduced to-night two bills, one of which will be of great concern to the bench and bar of New-York, and the other to the people in the Annexed District.

For the second time, John Y. McKane yesterday confessed himself to be a perjurer. This occurred in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer, on his trial for conspiracy to hide the registration lists of Gravesend last Fall.

BOSTON, Feb. 5. -- Local stocks were dull and the few quotations were somewhat lower than last week's closing prices. Commission orders are few and far between. Gossip of any kind is entirely lacking, and the Street waits, Micawber like, for something to turn up. One hundred shares of Lamson Store Service sold at 16, an advance of 1 over the last sale.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 5. -- William J. Thompson, the Duke of Gloucester City, has under consideration a scheme to catch the temperance people of the State. His friends declare that he will build a large temperance hotel at Fancy Hill, in Gloucester County, and invite churches and societies to visit the place for pleasure.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- With the cry of "Death to the Bourgeoisie!" "Long live Anarchy!" Vailiant, the Anarchist whose name has been on the lips of Parisians ever since the 9th of December, when he threw the bomb in the Chamber of Deputies, paid this morning the penalty of his crime.

The last vacant plot around the plaza at the Fifth Avenue entrance to Central Park is about to be built on, according to plans filed a few days ago in the Building Department by Alfred Zucker, the architect. This Plot is at the northeast corner of Fifty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue, and it measures 75 by 125 feet.
The Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association yesterday decided to pay to Joseph E. Austin $16,732.50, the insurance, with interest, on the life of his brother, John C. Austin.
The twenty-first season and the sixty-third meeting of the Patriarchs were brought to a close last night with their ball at Delmonico's, which was the most successful one of the series.

English yachtsmen seem to fear anything that comes from Bristol, R.I., in the shape of a sailboat. The Herreshoffs are building a tenrater to race in England. The London Field, speaking of this, says: "It is gratifying to learn that the Earl of Dudley has given Messrs. Camper Nicholson an order for a twenty-rater, and this class will be exceptionally strong during the coming season.

"There are 120,000 wage earners in this city, men and women, who are out of employment, destitute, and on the brink of starvation," said Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, in conversation yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- In expectation of a turbulent time this evening between Lieut. Gov. Sheehan and the Republican Senators over the question who was to run the uppper branch of the Legislature, the Senate Chamber was packed to overflowing with a crowd that in numbers surpassed anything in the history of this or the old capitol.
