The galleries were stuffed with the roughest element in Albany, who congregated in spite of the zero weather.

Here is a vapid youth. He is having what he considers a hilarious time. He is wicked to an awful degree, according to his own fond imaginings, and his soul is filled with wild delight. Now, with a terribly bold, bad look, he ventures out beyond the danger line on to the dancing floor.

Certain journals occasionally announce that some newspaper has been detached from the old service circuits of the United Press and its predecessor, the New-York Associated Press, and it has come to our knowledge that the Western gentlemen who are engaged in a "news warfare" against these old agencies are assiduously circulating the story that we are not likely to continue the "contest."

The big British freighter Hankow, eighty days from Yokohama, got up to Pier 29 East River yesterday afternoon. All over the ship were traces of the great storm through which she passed from Jan. 27 to Jan. 31.
At the executive meeting of the United Press, held in this city yesterday, the following was unanimously adopted:

"Business Women" was the subject of discussion at the meeting of Sorosis yesterday, and to treat so large a subject from all points of view the society called upon its doctors, ministers, writers, women in private life, maids, and matrons to give their views.

The man at the top of the Equitable Building who says things about the weather said that yesterday was the coldest day of the season. Those who ventured out into the crisp air did not need to be told that the mercury was at low ebb.

ZANZIBAR, Feb. 5. -- Advices have been received here from the interior of Africa that William Astor Chanler, who was in command of an exploring expedition, and who was deserted by most, if not all, of his porters, is on his way to the coast. He is expected to reach Mombassa on Saturday.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 5. -- The Savannah Grocery Company and M. Ferst's Sons Co., wholesale grocers, and the Wilcox Gibbs Guano Company, manufacturers of fertilizers, occupying nearly an entire block of five-story buildings on Bay Street, in the heart of the wholesale section of the city, were burned out to-day, and other property suffered heavy damages.

NEW-YORK Monday, Feb. 6 -- P.M. Very nearly two-thirds of to-day's business was in four industrial stocks -- Sugar, Whisky, Chicago Gas, and Lead. Sugar was particularly active in the morning, and advanced from 80 2/3, Saturday's closing to 82 1/8.

-- Reuben Buchstein of 82 Ludlow Street, Max Kreiger of 28 Suffolk Street, and Lewis Kreiger of 87 1/2 Delancey Street are in the Prince Street Station awaiting trial on the charge of having swindled Lewis Berliner, dry goods dealer at 321 Spring Street, out of $28. The men charged Berliner with receiving stolen goods, and claimed to be detectives.

-- The chiefs of the Northern Pacific Federated Trades in St. Paul have wired the local union men in Tacoma, Washington, to prepare for a strike on the Northern Pacific system. If there is no change satisfactory to the employes in the situation within a day or two, it is expected the men will be called out.
Mayor Gilroy turned the first frozen sod yesterday morning on "Dead-Head" Hill, over Manhattan Field, to begin the actual work of constructing the speedway.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Lemuel Ely Quigg, who has been for one week a Congressman-elect from the Fourteenth District, will move on to Washington to-day. While Mr. Quigg has become very modest within the last few days, some of his Republican friends expect him to go to the capital with some spectacular effects.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 5. -- The Legislature met at 8 P.M. No steps had been taken to settle the Senatorial muddle. Gov. Werts and Attorney General Stockton have not been together since last Tuesday, and what the Governor may do to have the matter thrown into court is still problematical.

The Republicans in either branch of Congress are not allowed to escape the Consequences of their recent curious defense of a white man's Government in Hawaii. Senator Palmer of Illinois yesterday, in the debate on the repeal of the Federal elections law, brought Mr. Chandler to book for his professional zeal for equal rights in South Carolina and his avowed zeal for the suppression of them in Honolulu.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5. -- At no time today has the local marKet been anything but firm. Following such dull days as those of last week, the great activity of Reading furnished a good deal of excitement to the room traders. It was rumored that the Speyer loan had been taken care of that the reorganization plan was being prepared, and that Reading's earnings are most satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- According to the official Army Register, just published, the cavalry Colonels remain as they were a year ago, and but one Major was promoted to be a Lieutenant Colonel. Five Captains became Majors, seven First Lieutenants were promoted to be Captains, and ten Second Lieutenants were advanced to the next grade.

For two days it has been said by some of the anti-machine Republicans that developments would soon be reported which would startle alike the Committee of Thirty and those members of the party who profess to hold in light regard the anti-machine move-ment

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Feb. 5. -- William S. Ingelston, aged fifty years, an employe of J.R. Pond Son of Crown Point Centre, met with a horrible death this morning. While working at a circular saw the belt suddenly slipped off the driving pulley, and in attempting to replace it Ingelston's coat caught in a coupling.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5. -- An afternoon paper says: The revised plan for the reorganization of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad will shortly be issued, probably in a day or so. It is being withheld pending the satisfactory completion of negotiations for disposing of the floating debt.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 6. -- A well-dressed man of fine appearance, apparently about fifty-five years of age, was taken in a carriage last Friday to a boarding house, 119 Central Avenue. He was accompanied by a lady, who paid his board for one week and said she would call again. No names were given.
Simon Dessau, importer of carbon and borts at 4 and 6 John Street, and known as the "Carbon King," made an assignment yesterday to Leon Lewin.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- A dispatch received from Rio Janeiro late this evening says:

The new agreement recently concluded between the four northern transcontinental railroads is to be put in operation without delay. James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railway, said yesterday:

Pierre Brady, riding master at the Aldine Riding Academy, Philadelphia, committed suicide yesterday morning in his room at the St. James Hotel, in this city, by taking laudanum. He was a Frenchman, about thirty years old.

There has been no more enjoyable "first night" in New-York this season than John Drew's at Palmer's. Everybody was there, and the theatre was crowded to the doors. The brilliant audience manifested at the very beginning a disposition to be pleased, and as the performance went on it was seen that there was no need for any one to strain a point in order to be pleased.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 5. -- The Page Belting Company, whose copy of the St. Gaudens medal does not meet with the approval of that artist, has forwarded the folllowing communication to Mr. St. Gaudens, addressing him in care of Evarts, Choate Beaman of New-York City:

The Chamber of Commerce, through its President, Charles Stewart Smith, came out strongly yesterday before the sub-committee of the State Senate, which is to investigate the New-York Police Department, in favor of a single-headed commission. Mr. Smitlh voiced the sentiments of the great body which he represents in the most unequivocal manner.

BOSTON, Feb. 5. -- The Harvard Athletic Committee has refused to ratify the reelection of B.G. Waters, 94, as Captain of the eleven for next year. This was just what everybody expected, for only a few days ago the committee officially announced that it did not propose to confirm the election of any graduate to be Captain of a Harvard Varsity team.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 5. -- Thomas P. Curley, receiver of the Order of Iron Hall in this State, has just submitted his first report to the Court of Chancery, and will begin proceedingrs at once against those branches which have failed to comply with the order of the court to turn over their assets to him as receiver.

After all the blasts of trumpets with which the Society of Independents was announced last Autumn the actuality of its first exhibition is, to say the least, bewildering. No jury, no limit to contributions, no rejected, no prizes -- these negations ought to have proved alluring enough to artists to fill several very large galleries with varied work.

That chaste and tender idyl, "1492," was moved last night, with all its glories, royal and plebeian, musical and athletic, and masculine and feminine and indefinite, from Palmer's over to the Garden Theatre, and there had its third eminently successful "first night."

The ice at Manhattan Field was in fairly good condition yesterday, and during the afternoon and evening hundreds of skaters took advantage of the opportunity to glide over the slippery surface. As yet the ice is not very thick, but Receiver Freedman believes that if the cold weather continues today and to-night there will be grand skating while the present cold snap lasts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The second section of train No. 42, to which was attached the private car of General Manager Prevost, tendered by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for the accommodation of those who desired to attend the obsequies over the remains at George W. Childs, left here this morning at 8:35 o'clock.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 6. -- The hulks of old men-of-war condemned by the United States Government have for years been broken up in Cow Bay, by Matthew Gregory. He set them on fire, and after the hulls were consumed gathered up the iron and copper and sold them. The owners of oyster beds in the bay and residents along the shore have been trying to force Gregory to discontinue his operations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Senate Committee on Pacific Railroads held a meeting this morning behind closed doors, at which C.P. Huntington delivered a speech defining his views as to what should be done in the matter of reorganizing the Central Pacific Railroad. His argument was based upon a bill he had with him, and which was subsequently ordered to be printed for the use of the committee.
NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Feb. 6. -- The democratic conventions were held in four of the towns of Richmond County this evening. They were well attended. The nominations were generally made unanimous.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 6. -- Unless the Senate shall decide otherwise, the Finance Committee of that body, which is now in possession of the Tariff bill, will not give any hearings in connection with that measure. The committee held a meeting this morning, and the majority decided that, in the interests of prompt action, it would be inexpedient to give any hearings.
Pierre Brady, the young Frenchman who committed suicide at the St. James Hotel Monday morning, was twenty-nine years old. He had a very interesting history.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

There were some interesting developments yesterday in the trial of Peter Neville, the Democratic Election Inspector, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. Neville, who served in the Twenty-eighth Election District of the Fourth Assembly District at the November election, is charged with having conspired with the other Election Inspectors in his polling place to return a false count.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 6. -- Two plans were proposed to-day by the Democrats for settling the Senatorial muddle. One was that Senator Adrain, President of the Democratic majority, should begin quo warranto proceedings against President Rogers of the Republican majority and ask by what right he had usurped and was exercising the duties of the President of the Senate of New-Jersey.

The Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, in Brooklyn, is capacious, but it was not large enough to contain the people who flocked there yesterday to welcome again Evangelist Dwight L. Moody to the City of Churches.

Health Commissioner Emery of Brooklyn has appointed Dr. Frederick Jewett, formerly Sanitary Inspector, to be Superintendent of Contagious Diseases. The other Sanitary Inspectors are displeased. Dr. Jewett, under the old administration, was the only Republican on the Health Board staff. His former associates say he is altogether too strict in enforcing the rules of the department as they apply to them.

BOSTON, Feb. 6. -- Another dull day has passed to the record of the market, although more shares were traded in to-day than yesterday. Local stocks were inactive, Bell Telephone being the only one which was quoted more than once or twice, and only from 75 to 100 shares of this were sold in small lots, from 175 to 176, and back to 175 1/2.

The yacht races for the cups given by Mr. Ogden Goelet and Mr. James Gordon Bennett will be sailed off Cannes on Tuesday, March 13. One cup, worth 5,000f., is for yachts of more than twenty tonnage, and the Prince of Wales's cutter Britannia is being prepared for the race. Several of the crack French yachts will also start in this race.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 6. -- The body of a man who died suddenly in Mrs. Shay's boarding house, 119 Central Avenue, early yesterday morning, was positively identified to-day as that of John H. Blake, a former New-Yorker.

MADRID, Feb. 6. -- An official account of the reception of Gen. Martinez de Campos by Muley Hassan, Sultan of Morocco, has been received here. Gen. de Campos is the envoy of Spain to present to the Sultan the demands of the Spanish Government for the attacks made upon the Spaniards at Melilla by the Riffians.

The appearance of the great evangelistic singer, Ira D. Sankey, whose name is inseparably linked with that of his co-laborer, Dwight L. Moody, was greeted warmly and affectionately in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon. Without Mr. Sankey, memories of the services at the Rink and the old Brooklyn Tabernacle many years ago would have been incomplete.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 6. -- Two burglars were shot and seriously wounded this morning by Mrs. Christian Duehrer, who keeps a fancy notion store at 2,104 Clark Avenue. The burglars entered the store from the rear at 6:30 o'clock, and went up stairs, where Mrs. Duehrer was asleep with a Miss Maggie Sanford, who lives with her.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Mrs. Lamont gave a violet breakfast to-day in honor of Mrs. Cleveland's mother, Mrs. Henry Perrine, and of her own guest, Mrs. Gilman Collamore of New-York. Breakfast was served at 12 o'clock, and at 1 o'close the ladies of the Cabinet were asked to join the party and enjoy the violin playing of Miss Leonore Jackson, formerly of Boston, who will soon go abroad to finish her musical studies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- There has been another postponement by the Senate Judiciary Committee of action upon the nomination of Wheeler H. Peckham. It is expected by Mr. Hill and his fellow-opponents of Mr. Peckham that the committee would reach a decision to-day. Instead of that the committee voted to defer further consideration of the case until next Monday.

The last of the Tuesday evening assemblies for 1894 was held at Sherry's last night. This series of dances is considered the most exclusive of any in New-York. For this reason it is spoken of as "the Howling Swells." A great many applications for invitations have been daily refused by its patronesses during the past week.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

William Bell, the colored valet of Comedian William H. Crane, was held for the Grand Jury by Police Justice Taintor in the Tombs Police Court yesterday on the charge of stealing a package containing $1,815 in money from the actor's waistcoat pocket on Monday, Jan. 29. Bail was fixed at $2,000. Bell confessed the crime, but insists that he did not keep a dollar of the money.

City Works Commissioner White of Brooklyn yesterday dismissed forty-eight employes of the department who have enjoyed snug sinecures at the public expense during the past few years of the ring administration. All the victims of the official axe were connected with the Water Purveyor's Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Owing to the anxiety of Senators to deliver eleventh-hour speeches for or against the Federal Elections bill, the final vote on that measure will not be taken until late to-morrow afternoon. In anticipation of the close of the debate to-day, the galleries were crowded, and this fact may be responsible for the increased interest manifested in the subject by Senators.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 6. -- Maude Goff, the seventeen-year-old daughter of E. N. Goff, the evangelist and revival preacher, has eloped with John Philip Quinn, a reformed gambler and her father's assistant. Mr. Goff travels in a palace car called the Roanoke, in which he, Mrs. Goff, their daughter and younger son, and Mr. Quinn made their home.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 6. -- A new meth- od of working a tariff scare has been devised by Beerbower Co., who run the pottery works here, which employ 150 persons. The plant was closed for nearly four weeks, although there were plenty of orders on hand, and the potters were told they might look for work elsewhere, as the shut-down would be prolonged indefinitely.

The scheme on the part of some Chicago speculators to acquire the ownership of the block bounded by Broadway, Liberty, Cedar, and Temple Streets has come to naught, as was predicted in The New-York Times. Part of the plan involved the tearing down of the buildings now on the site and the erection of an eighteen or twenty story office building.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 6. -- Mardi Gras was celebrated to-day with fitting ceremonies. Day parades were by Knights of Revelry, who illustrated "Beauty and the Beast," and by Comic Cowboys, who had a take-off on the Columbian World's Fair. The two ancient mystic societies made their parades at night. The "infant mystics" appeared with twelve floats, giving pictures entitled "Dreams of Life."

Justice Ingraham in the Supreme Court yesterday gave a decision upon the motion made before him some time ago in behalf of the city to restrain the Manhattan Railway Company from proceeding with the erection of a third track on Ninth Avenue between Seventeenth and Twenty-sixth Streets, which it was insisted was being erected in violation of law.

Mrs. Minnie Lange, a comely German woman, thirty-six years of age, tall, stout, of dark complexion, with large, dark eyes, and a pleasant, open countenance, calculated to convey the impression that she was the personification of guileless honesty, was convicted yesterday before Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions, on the charge of conspiring to defraud the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association of $3,000.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 6. -- The second and last day of the New-Orleans carnival has furnished a continuous round of pleasure to citizens and visitors -- a gayer day was never known here. The crowds who have come from the North and West to witness the sights of the carnival have been more than paid for their trouble. They are almost extravagant in their expressions of delight.

-- Cadet William Kelly of Texas, a third class man, while going through the hurdle exercise in the riding hall at West Point yesterday fell from his horse and was severely injured. He was taken to the post hospital.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 6. -- The trial of Bishop Bonacum, charged by one of his priests, Father Corbett, with criminal libel, began to-day, and the expectations of those who predicted an exciting trial are being fully verified. A large number of the priests of the diocese are present.

The determination of the Finance Committee of the Senate to give no "hearings" on the Tariff bill is a perfectly sensible one, even if we consider only the chances of correct decision as to the details of the bill. Such hearings are utterly inadequate to a fair and complete investigation of so complex a subject, and are, in fact, worse than no investigation at all.

Mrs. Albertine Eichhorn, a very properlooking Swiss widow, fifty-eight years old, was arrested last evening at her home, 74 West Thirty-eighth Street, on a charge of violating the pool law by making a book at her home on the New-Orleans and Madison races.

A conference was held yesterday afternoon in Col. Joel B. Erhardt's office, in the Mutual Insurance Building, which was attended by Charles Stewart Smith, President of the Chamber of Commerce; Dr. Parkhurst, Gustav Schwab, and Col. Erhardt, relative to the work in connection with the Senate sub-committee for investigating the Police Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The tendency on the part of the Democrats of the House to lean on the other fellows to do the hard work of the body resulted to-day in the failure of the McCreary resolutions on the Hawaiian question. The absence of about 100 of the Democrats enabled Mr. Reed to filibuster and to prevent the passage of the majority resolution.

At a meeting of the University Athletic Club Committee on Football yesterday the names of the men selected to revise the rules were made public. There were present C.F. Mathewson, George Adee, E.J. Wendell, H.S. Brooks, T.H. Harris. L. E. Sexton, Richard Trimball, Percy Bolton, Guy. Richards, and L. McKim Garretson.

Athletes of the Washington Heights branch of the Young Men's Christian Association are now preparing for their second annual gymnasium championships, which will take place in the association's rooms Friday evening, Feb. 23. Four medals will be awarded to the winning athletes, and only the pick of the men will be allowed to compete.

BOSTON, Feb. 6. -- President Eliot of Harvard University spoke on Radcliffe College before the Old South Club last night. His address was an important discussion of the relations of the Harvard Annex to Harvard University. Dr. Eliot, at the outset, quoted George William Curtis, who once wrote: "It is now settled that Juliet may study, but shall she study with Romeo?" This was his text.

Ex-Pension Commissioner Tanner had two and a half inches of flesh amputated from the stump of each leg yesterday, at the Seney Hospital, in Brooklyn. The operation was made necessary by the growth of a number of tumors on the end of the stumps, which caused him intense agony.

Ex-Senator T.W. Palmer of Michigan, President of the World's Fair Commission; Prof. O.V. Tousley, one of the members of the commission from Minnesota, and John Boyd Thacher of New-York will meet in the Fifth Avenue Hotel to-day and discuss the work to be done in preparing and publishing a history of the Fair.

Andrews Doty, commission merchants in precious stones and diamond brokers at 207 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to George W. Glaze. The partners in the firm are John R. Andrews of Englewood, N.J., and Joseph G. Doty of Newark.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 6. -- A Kansas City attorney named Smith has written to Gov. Lewelling, charging the Governor with hav- ing received bribes from the policy shop men of Kansas City, Kan., for permitting them to continue their disreputable business. The Governor is accused of receiving $5,000 a month for giving his official sanction to policy shops and gambling houses.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 6. -- Margaret Grace, an old woman who says her conscience troubles her, called upon Detective John Gregory last Sunday and related a strange, but not impossible story regarding the Rahway murder mystery. The horribly-mutilated body of a young woman, believed to be Mary Dorman of Glasgow, Scotland, was one morning in March, 1886, found lying beside a fence on Central Avenue.

ROME, Feb. 6. -- The carnival season at Civita Lavigna, eighteen miles southeast of this city, has been brought to an abrupt close by the cowardly assassination of one of the prominent residents of that place.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- The joint Judiciary Committees gave a second hearing this afternoon on the ballot-reform law amendments in the Senate Chamber. Among those present were Mr. Ivins, Mr. Delafield, and Mr. Andrews, representing the New-York City organizations; Arthur L. Andrews, representing the Albany Committee of Fifty, and ex-Senator Norton Chase of Albany.

Copyright, 1894, by the United press. HONOLULU, Jan. 19, per barkentine W. H. Dimond, via San Francisco, Cal., Feb. 6. -- The observances of Abrogation Day passed off with perfect good order. The American League raised an American flag 60 by 39 feet. The military paraded, and a salute was fired at noon. A public reception was held in the Council Room.

Thomas C. Platt threw all disguises aside yesterday and came out openly in favor of the anti-machine Republicans -- the John K. Milholland faction. In doing so he places himself in opposition to the Committee of Thirty, which was appointed by the Republican County Committee at its November meeting and afterward authorized to reorganize the party.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- Dr. Jenkins, the Health Officer of the Port of New-York, is sure of his position, at least until late in the year, even if he be not reappointed. In fact, but one thing stood between him and confirmation when the Governor sent in his name to the Senate this morning. The Republicans, encouraged by the sweets of recent victories, hope to carry the State next Fall in the Gubernatorial election.

George Ripley, a real estate broker of 583 Broadway, who lives at 241 West Fortieth Street, lost his temper yesterday, and swore loudly in the street, and also in Yorkville Police Court, where he was taken.

The New-York Woman's Press Club opened its rooms, 125 East Twenty-third Street, Monday night for its annual reception. The parlors on the second floor were prettily decorated with palms. Rugs, bunting, and palms were on all sides in the room below, where refreshments were served.

SOMERSET,Penn., Feb. 6. -- The Park Hotel, the largest and most popular resort in this part of the State, was destroyed by fire early this morning. The guests all escaped in their night clothes. They ran barefooted through the snow and the raw Winter air to houses outside of the park, where they were sheltered.
The situation of John Y. McKane is growing desperate. He has twice confessed perury on his trial in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer for conspiring to conceal the Gravesend registration lists.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- The activity of yesterday having come to an end, prices were inclined to sag off to-day. Reading was the most active on the entire list, but the recorded transactions were less than 9,000 half shares. The floor commission brokers seemed to be almost entirely without orders, and such changes as occurred in quotations were made almost entirely by room traders.
Dr. Theorore Billroth, a distinguished German surgeon, died last night at Abbazia, a well-known Austrian Winter resort. Death was caused by heart disease.
The following plans of new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

DENVER, Col., Feb. 6. -- Mrs. Allie Block Carr was arrested this afternoon upon a charge of complicity in the murder of her husband, Harry Carr, a well-known attorney of this city. Bessie Sherwood, a close friend of Mrs. Carr; "Teddy" Dolson, "Jim" Tracey, and a man called "Dutch" were also held for examination.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Feb. 6 -- P.M. A drive at Chicago Gas at the opening of the market, based upon news of Aldermanic favors to a rival gas interest in that city, gave the bears a good start in the market to-day. The first sale cut 1 3/4 per cent. under Monday's price, selling at 63, against 84 3/4.

There is some force in the remarks of the member of the Senate Committee for the Investigation of the Police made at Monday's session of the committee. It is really not to be expected that a number of rural legislators should be prepared to pursue, upon their own motion, promising lines of investigation into the workings of a municipal department.

Reports of a "deal" on Chief Engineer at the Brooklyn Fire Department were revived yesterday in that city. Officials and politicians have not recovered from the surprise caused by Commissioner Ennis's failure to fill the place before his retirement a week ago.

-- In a letter from San Francisco, Capt. Nash of the Bostons says: "Poor Bennett! It broke me all up when I read of his misfortune, and I know we will miss him the coming season. * * * I see there is considerable talk about the bunt. It does not make any difference how they legislate on this matter. We can stand it as well as any club.

Brighter days are in store for the unemployed. Yesterday statisticians furnished valuable data from the police census, which tell how many men and women are out of work, and President Seth Low of Columbia College tersely sketched the situation and pointed out the gravity of the problem.

-- At the annual meeting of the St. Lawrence Yacht Club, the election of officers resulted: Honorable Commodore -- Sir Donald Smith; Commodore -- W.A. Morris; Vice Commodore -- R. Campbell Nellis; Rear Commodore -- William Davidson; Secretary -- Treasurer -- A.G. Ross; Committee -- E. Green, C.B. Morris. G.J. Gilpin. J.N. Fulton, F.W. Barlow, W.S. Clouston, C.H. Duggan, and J.C.C. Almon.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- Gov. Flower and Mrs. Flower held the annual reception at the Executive Mansion to-night. The mansion was brilliantly illuminated inside and out. Within were potted plants and palms distributed about the spacious halls and parlors. Several thousand invitations had been issued, and few regrets were received.

When George Erlinger, who says he is forty-four years old and lives at 111 East One Hundred and Fifth Street, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning a clever and successful swindler was started on the road to punishment.
The New-York Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street, opened a nurses bureau yesterday. It has been established for the purpose of providing competent nurses for physicians and patients.

FARMINGTON, Me., Feb. 6. -- Notice of the arrest of H.A. Hackett in Winnipeg, Manitoba, which was received here to-day, was read with interest. He is charged with abstracting $21,000 in bonds from the Portland Safety Deposit Vaults, belonging to the estate of the late Israel R. Bray of Freeman.

After devoting all his leisure for twenty-five years to an attempt to solve the problem of perpetual motion, Charles Heine, an expert German mechanic, became disgusted at his failure and yesterday hanged himself to the model of his unsuccessful machine. Heine was fifty-two years old, married, and lived with his wife on the second floor of 693 East One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street.

It is a very musty practice to try to make out that a particularly detestable murderer is something else than a murderer by calling him a "psychological problem." The modern Anarchist, nevertheless, does present a psychological problem, not only in his crime, but still more in the manner in which he takes his punishment.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed the judgment of the lower court to the case of the people, respondents, against Lucius, alias "Dink," Wilson, appellant. Wilson is now in Auburn awaiting death for the murder of Detective Harvey some time ago in Syracuse, while attempting to escape.

The races between "Joe" Donoghue and Adolph Norseng are off for the present. They were to have skated at Manhattan Field this week, but for some reason they have decided to remain in Montreal, where they are announced to take part in a race on Saturday next with Johnson, McCullough, Douglass, and others.

The Pennsylvania Railroad trains leaving this city at 9 and 9:30 o'clock yesterday forenoon were largely occupied by friends of the late George W. Childs and the representatives of various organizations here going to Philadelphia to attend the funeral services. Attached to the 9 o'clock train was a special car for the Press Club delegation and other newspaper men, numbering between thirty and forty.

The steamer Leibnitz, which arrived from Brazil yesterday, had on board as passengers Chief Engineer H.W. Fitch of the cruiser San Francisco, Machinist W. Howell from the Charleston, and C.F. Harrison, a seaman from that vessel. All three are invalids, and were sent home for treatment. Engineer Fitch was in Rio three days only, the San Francisco having arrived on Jan.

The committee representing the Chamber of Commerce sent a letter yesterday afternoon to the Senate committee for investigating the Police Department of New-York, announcing that it had found it impossible to retain proper legal counsel for the investigation.

Peter Neville, Democratic Inspector at the last general election in the Twenty-eighth Election District of the Fourth Assembly District, was found guilty in the Court of Oyer and Terminer last night of neglect of duty. It was alleged that in this district twenty-one more votes were returned than were actually cast. Neville was charged with having conspired with the other Inspectors to return a false count.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- George O. Jones, Chairman of the National Committee of the National Greenback Party, to-day issued the following address, calling for the preparation and signing of petitions by those who favor a largely-increased volume of money:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- John I. Davenport may as well pack up his traps. The Federal Election law, which has stood between him and an indignant country for twenty-four years, got its death blow by the Senate. In a day or two the President will affix his signature to the repeal measure, so that practically Mr. Davenport is out of a job.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- The Diamond Match Company held its annual meeting to-day. Secretary Kranz presented the annual statement, showing that the company paid quarterly dividends amounting to $862,5OO and a special dividend of $75O,OOO, making the total dividends for the year $1,612,0OO. The quick assets were stated to be equal to 42 6-7 per cent, of the capital stock -- $9,OOO,OOO.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- The members of the Reichstag who attended the Parliamentary banquet given Monday night by Chancellor von Caprivi are gradually divulging in the lobby of the Reichstag the details of the speeches made on that occasion. It is said that Emperor William fulsomely praised the Czar, saying: "He is a Prince of peace, like myself."

To write praises of Coquelin whenever the bill is changed at Abbey's Theatre, and that, too, always in superlatives, is not, of course, an unpleasant task, but none the less it has about it an element of monotony, particularly as the English language is not overrich in adjectives to which the termination "est" is congenial.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The navy, a week from to-day, will be augmented by another big steel ship, and between that time and the 1st of May three other brand-new vessels will be placed in commission. The 2,000-ton cruiser Marblehead will be commissioned Feb. 14, and the detail of her officers has been nearly completed at the Navy Department.
The Ladies' Health Protective Association held its regular monthly meeting Tuesday morning at the house of Mrs. Esther Hermann, 59 West Fifty-sixth Street.
WHITESTONE LANDING, L.I., Feb. 7. -- The freighter City of Norwalk, Capt. Peck, en route for Norwalk, Conn., from New-York, sprung a leak near Execution Light about 8 o'clock to-night.

-- A.H. Downer, who was at one time a well-known business man and wealthy oil merchant of this city, and who had resided at College Point for the last thirty-seven years, died there yesterday. He was born at Fairport, Ky., and was sixty-two years old. He was, at the time of his death, in only moderate circumstances. He leaves a wife, two daughters, and a son.

Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Curtis was in this city yesterday, in consultation with Conrad N. Jordan, Assistant United States Treasurer, and as a result of their meeting some matters relating to the new issue of bonds which had been unsatisfactory to New-York bankers who have subscribed to the bonds were adjusted.

The old building of the University of the City of New-York on Washington Square will be demolished early in the coming Spring, and on its site will be erected a modern ten-story building. The Executive Committee of the university met Tuesday and decided to begin the work of taking down the present structure in May, when the leases of the occupants of portions of the building will expire.

In view of the great strain to which all the hospitals of the city are now subjected, the Executive Committee of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association has issued a special appeal, in the hope that the figures may be brought up to last year's collection. To this appeal generous responses are now being made. Charles Lanier, the Treasurer, 17 Nassau Street, reports the following in addition to contributions previously published:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- As was indicated by the vote of the House yesterday, the Democrats of that body are with the Administration on the Hawaiian question. The fact was made plain enough to anybody when the House to-day passed the McCreary resolutions and voted down the bumptious propositions of Boutelle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The leaders of the majority of the House have had under consideration for some time the framing of a rule by which filibustering would be still further discouraged. They have not yet decided upon the phraseology of the rule, but their idea is to fine Representatives who shall indulge in this practice. There was exhibited on the floor of the House to-day the draft of a rule to the following effect:

Application was made yesterday before Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, by Ithamar Howe, through his counsel, to have the suit for $50,000 brought against Isaac Woodruff, the druggist of 88 Maiden Lane, placed in the calendar for immediate trial.

"Pony" Moore, father-in-law of "Charley" Mitchell, the prize fighter, was discharged yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions on the charge of assault preferred against him by Jacob Cohen, a Broadway cable gripman.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- The Joint Finance Committee gave a hearing this afternoon on Senator O'Connor's bill abolishing the power of the State Commissioners in Lunacy to supervise the accounts of State hospital managers.

J.G. Weaver, senior member of the firm of J.G. Weaver Co., proprietors of the Everett House, died there early yesterday of pneumonia. Mr. Weaver was fifty-four years old, and was well known. His permanent home was at Newport, R.I., but he usually lived at the Everett House during the Winter.

Arthur H. Howland, the Boston civil engineer who disappeared from the Fall River boat Pilgrim on the night of Dec. 30 in such a manner that ft was believed that he had committed suicide, returned to Boston yesterday, his place of hiding in Connecticut having been discovered, and made the statement that business embarrassments induced him to disappear so mysteriously.

In the discussion of local and State taxation we have had no hesitation in declaring more than once our belief that a single tax on the rental value of land was the "ideal taxation," but we have always maintained that in present conditions it was not practicable to apply it even for local purposes.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Every true citizen of this country, every true hearted man on this earth who has watched and known the rascality of David B. Hill, his ungodly works, his association with everything to defeat the will of the people, or, in other words, to defeat good government, will praise and bless you for your true and brave words in this day's editorial.

John Matthews, one of the principals in the alleged conspiracy to defraud the Government which has brought the firm of Pitt Scott, express forwarders at 93 Broadway, to public notice, was held in $5,000 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Shields for examination.

There was again a good attendance at the American Institute Building yesterday, when Kellogg Co. continued the big sale of trotting stock. After the few head unsold belonging to J.W. Daly of Mount Kisco had been disposed of, there was a general movement toward the auctioneer, to see the half dozen fast ones from the San Mateo Farm dispersed.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 7. -- Evangelist E.T. Goff, whose seventeen-year-old daughter Maud eloped with John Philip Quinn, the gray-haired preacher and ex-gambler, was not in an enviable frame of mind as he sat in his luxurious private car Roanoke, in the Pennsylvania Railroad yards, this afternoon.

ROME, Feb. 7. -- A court trial of the highest interest to the political and business world will begin here to-morrow. The most conspicuous of the prisoners are Pinto, a grain merchant; Gallina, an Inspector General of the National Treasury, and Chauvet, manager of the Popolo Romano newspaper. Pinto is charged with defrauding the Government of 225,000 hire by means of false documents.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- There has been a good deal of discussion of the Peckham case to-day, and much quiet work has been done in relation to it. Mr. Hill was one of the first Senators to enter the Capitol this morning, and he resumed his campaign against the confirmation of Mr. Peckham as soon as his colleagues began to appear.

Secretary Heckscher of the National Horse Show has issued entry blanks for the hackney produce prize for the show of November, 1895. The estimated value of the prize is $3,300, as follows: From subscriptions of 200 mares at $5 each, $1,000; produce left in, paying subscription Jan. 1, 1895, 100 at $10 each, $1,000; yearlings exhibited paying entrance fees, 20 at $15 each, $300; money added by the association, $1,000.

NEW-YORK. Wednesday, Feb. 7 -- P.M. Traders had the market to-day. As they are accustomed to living on others rather than on ourselves, business was dull, the total transactions reaching only 139,592 shares. No significant news appeared to tempt outside buying, and the community that pays commissions has learned better than to sell stocks at the present level of prices.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The price of bar silver to-day reached the lowest point ever known. It was quoted this afternoon in the market here at 29 13-16d. per ounce. The market was flat. The price to-day was 1/3d. lower than that of yesterday.

Several members of the New-York Stock Exchange have arranged for a course of lectures, to be given at the Exchange by Dr. Alexander H. Ely of 19 West Fortysixth Street, under the auspices of the Society for Instruction in First Aid to the Injured. There will be five lectures on successive Friday afternoons, and, after examination, the diploma of the society will be awarded to the proficient.

The saloon keepers of Brooklyn are heartily in favor of Senator Owens's excise bill, providing that the saloons be allowed to transact business on the Sabbath, by means of the side door, and they will do all in their power to have the bill become a law.

Sarah Besam appeared as complainant in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday against Solomon and Lena Bernstein of 54 Ridge Street, who had been arrested on three charges-keeping a disorderly house, telling fortuner, and larceny.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Cable dispatches having arrived here to-day from America stating that rumors were in circulation to the effect that the Queen was dead, the representative in this city of the United Press sent a telegram of inquiry to Gen. Sir Frederick Ponsonby, her Majesty's private secretary, who is with the Queen at Osborne House. A reply was received from Sir Frederick this afternoon stating that the Queen, is enjoying fine health.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 7. -- There was a new record made in wheat prices, with a liberal margin to spare, to-day. May sold at 50c. as against 59 5/8c, the previous low point. May opened at 59 1/8c, which was 1/4 below the previous low point, and it fell quickly to 59c. It closed at 59 1/8c. July opened at 61c. and closed 60 5/8c.

Frank H. Johnson of 93 Clinton Place has been hired by the patronesses of different dancing classes to call the numbers of the guests' cabs at Sherry's Assembly Rooms, in Fifth Avenue, for twenty-five or thirty years.

Justice Pryor, in Chambers of the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday severely criticised sharp practices frequently indulged in by members of the bar. Application was made for retaxation of costs in the suit of Arrowitz Wolff against Edward C. Horn. Judge Pryor, in a memorandum, says: "In an action to foreclose a mechanic's lien for $138.23, the bill of costs is $434.20.

-- Favel and Constantine Grunwaldt of 96 Fifth Avenue have begun suit in the City Court to recover possession of a fox skin, valued at $1,000, which they allege was stolen from among their exhibits at the World's Fair. It made its appearance in this city when B. Rothkowsky of 27 East Broadway offered it for sale to Joseph Ullman.

ELIZABETH, Feb. 7. -- The Rev. Dr. John F. Pingry, one of the leading Presbyterian clergymen in New-Jersey, who for fiftyseven years has conducted a noted private school in this city, now known as the Pingry Academy, is very low, and to-night his physicians say he is sinking and may not live until morning.

NEWARK. N.J., Feb. 7. -- The reports of the Executive Committee of the Newark Press Club, submitted at the annual meeting, show the institution to be in a flourishing condition. A special meeting will be held Feb. 21 to consider a proposition to incorporate the club. The following officers were elected to serve for one year:

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

"If you take your hat off your head and try to draw It you will see in a very short time how little you know about that hat," said Miss Alice Campbell at the meeting of the Professional Woman's League yesterday afternoon.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 7. -- The annual meeting of the National Farmers' Alliance began its secret sessions in this city this morning. The general reception and address of welcome by Gov. Lewelling, and responses by "Fanner" I.E. Dean of New-York and D. P. Duncan of South Carolina were all given in open meeting in Representative Hall last night.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 7. -- The Bonacum trial was resumed this morning. The question of jurisdiction was debated with vigor by contending counsel. Attorneys for the Bishop insisted that in an ecclesiastical case the Church was a court within itself, that the Bishop had a perfect right to discipline his clergy or members of the Church, and that in this the civil court did not enter.

Although the reports of railway earnings for the month of January do not quite fulfill the hopes of some of the more sanguine of traffic managers, they are equal to the expectations of railroad men generally. While indicating that there is throughout the country a gradual reawakening of business, they give evidences of encouraging spurts in various localities, particularly in the West and South.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- The nomination of Dr. Jenkins as Health Officer of the Port of New-York is awaiting the action of the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation. At the meeting of the committee this afternoon Senator Sullivan (Dem., NewYork,) moved a favorable report on the nomination, but at Chairman Donaldson's request action was postponed until next week.

The evangelistic movement in Brooklyn gained fresh impetus yesterday because of the visit of Messrs. Moody and Sankey on Tuesday. At the noonday meeting in Association Hall the building was crowded. Several hundred persons attended an outdoor meeting just before 12 o'clock.

The first of the numerous suits for damages growing out of the burning of the Hotel Royal, at Sixth Avenue and Fortieth Street, was to have been begun yesterday before Judge Bookstaver, in the Court of Common Pleas. By consent of counsel, however, the trial was adjourned until to-morrow morning.

Scarcely had the bacchanalian mists and vapors of the French ball dissipated from Madison Square Garden when the scene of that recent pandemonium began to receive other gay and festive visitors. The plumage of the gay people who fluttered in the Garden on Monday night and Tuesday morning could not compare with the gorgeouslyvariegated attire of the present clarionvoiced visitors.

The Fidelity and Casualty Company has bought of Mr. Jefferson M. Levy the property on the north side of Cedar Street extending from Temple Street to Church Street. The plot, which is covered with old buildings, measures 100 feet on Cedar Street. 62 feet on Temple Street, and 40 feet on Church Street, and contains about 5,000 square feet.

So far in the regular session, the Republican leaders have confined their action to doing everything in their power to embarrass the Democratic leaders, to get them, as the political slang is, in a series of "holes." They tried their best to do that in the Hawaiian matter, with indifferent success, their own situation having more of the characteristics of a "hole" than that of the Administration or of the leaders in Congress.

BOSTON, Feb. 7. -- Sales of stocks Improved in volume to-day, and local stocks shared somewhat in the activity, but the market was without special features. A few shares of Bell Telephone sold at 175. A bill is to be presented to the State Legislature for the creation of a Telephone Commission, with duties similar to those of the Railroad Commission.

RONDOUT, Feb. 7. -- A letter written by Dr. Burtsell just before his departure from Rome for the Holy Land, was received in this city last night by the Rev. J.J. Gallagher, who is at St. Mary's in Dr. Burtsell's place. Dr. Burtsell wrote that he would be back in his parish here soon after April 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- There is a prospect of a prolonged and persistent contest in the House over the Bland bill to authorize the coinage of the "seigniorage" in the Treasury and the issue of silver notes based on the seigniorage pending the coinage of the silver.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- In local stocks there was a somewhat Improved feeling at the opening. It came mainly from the fact that there was very little stock for sale. Notwithstanding the better feeling, the early range was narrow. Alley opened 1/4 lower, at 22 7/8, but only 50 shares sold at this, the bulk selling at 23, from which there was an improvement to 23 3/8, followed by a break to 22 7/8.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Fire was discovered in the roof of the southwest corner of the Agricultural Building at the World's Fair grounds at 4:40 this afternoon. The fire was soon under control, and the damage to the building was found to be insignificant. Twenty cases of exhibits were somewhat damaged by water.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 7. -- The regular meeting of the Newark Presbytery, which opened in this city to-day, was an extremely lively one, the discussion of resolutions on the question of doctrine being one of the points upon which the assembly nearly came to grief. These were offered by the Rev. Dr. Lewis Lampmann of the High Street Presbyterian Church:

The result of the official census of unemployed persons in New-York will seem to most people encouraging and reassuring. The figures seem to show that 67,280 persons, ordinarily at least self-supporting, if not supporting others than themselves, are at present out of employment, and that of this number 48,681, or about four-fifths, are the bread-winners of families.

Mr. E.P. Wilbur, who was one of the managers of the Reading Company under the regime of President McLeod, and a receiver up to the time of the abrogation of the Lehigh Valley lease, gave evidence yesterday, in Philadelphia, in the proceeding before the Master in the petition of Mr. Isaac L. Rice in the matter of the Reading Railroad.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Gen. W.W. Averell, the veteran cavalry officer, came to Albany this morning at the head of a distinguished delegation of citizens of Steuben County, who persuaded Gen. Martin T. McMahon to introduce a bill appropriating $25,000 for a statue to be erected at Bath, Steuben County, for the great drillmaster of the Continental Army.

The spectacle of Thomas C. Platt backing an "anti-machine" reorganization of the Republican Party in this city would be rather a joyous one if it did not suggest an eager inquiry as to what he is really driving at, because Platt always has a serious purpose even when he seems to be making a spectacle.

-- The Brooks-McVicker Company. -- Since the announcement was made in The New-York Times that Joseph Brooks, manager for William H. Crane, was to organize a stock company to play in McVicker's Theatre, Chicago, next Summer. Mr. Brooks's mall has increased to an alarming extent. All the letters come from actors who are looking for an engagement, and are a striking commentary on the trials to which players have been subjected this season.

-- In the United States Circuit Court in Milwaukee yesterday. Attorney Herbert Turner of New-York read the affidavit of President Rolston of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, denying the charges made against him in the petition of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company for the removal of the receivers. William F. Cromwell of New-York, attorney for the receivers, addressed the court on the law governing the questions at issue.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 7. -- Birmingham, on the eve of the State Convention of the Kolbites or Jeffersonian Democrats and Populists is full of politicians. There are present representatives of about every sort of politicians ever heard of, but there are no out-and-out Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- It is almost impossible to create interest in any subject outside of the tariff in the Senate wing of the Capitol. Now that the Wilson bill is in the hands of the Sub-Committee of the Senate Finance Committee, there is much wire pulling by persons interested in effecting changes in the various schedules of the bill.

Fire Marshal Mitchel expects to prove that last Monday night the cigar manufactory of Cohen Valenstein, on the third floor of 85 and 87 Reade Street, was set on fire to secure insurance amounting to $5,200.

The fourth semi-annual convention of the New-York State Custom Foremen Tailors' Association was begun in the Hotel Metropole yesterday afternoon, and will continue till to-morrow night. W.B. Webster of Binghamton, President of the association, presided. The other officers are: First Vice President -- A.E. Hulquist of Jamestown; Second Vice President -- Joseph Wilkinson of New-York City; Secretary -- E.R. Dempsey of Cortland; Treasurer -- E.O. Rothmund of Rome.

Dennis Sullivan, fifty-five years old, who lived alone in a room at 511 Second Avenue, committed suicide yesterday because he felt so keenly the loss of his position, which he had held for fifteen years.

The prices of bar silver in the New-York market yesterday kept neck and neck with those on the London Exchanges. The record was broken here. The drop was gradual, however, and for that reason caused less excitement than did the fall in prices last June, when the mints of India were closed to the white metal. Bar silver was quoted at 78 cents an ounce in June last before the Indian Council took its action.

Mrs. Dora Scheffmeyer, whose eighty-six years have told upon her to a great extent, was in the Supreme Court yesterday, before Judge Lawrence, together with other members of her family, as litigant in a suit which gave the lawyers on both sides and the court officers considerable trouble.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Official figures at the Treasury Department show that within the past thirty-four days, since a bond Issue was practically assured, gold has been withdrawn from the Treasury for the purpose of paying for the bonds. On Jan. 3 the gold balance was, in round figures, $80,000,000.

A semi-official announcement was made yesterday that the Georgia Central reorganization scheme is so nearly perfected that a proposition to the security holders may soon be made. Gen. Samuel Thomas and Thomas F. Ryan have devoted much time to the matter within the past three or four months, and a large share of their efforts had been devoted to the consolidation of the floating debt.

The extraordinary bibuious feat of John P. McNamara, a clerk in William J. Gaynor's law office yesterday transfixed the attention of the Jury which is trying John Y. McKane for conspiracy in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer.

James C. Carter, President of the City Club, was the principal speaker at a meeting of Good Government "E" in the assembly room of the Tee-to-Tum Club, 338 East Twentythird Street, last evening, and he made some stirring remarks as to the duty of those interested in purifying municipal government. They could succeed, he declared, only by active and untiring work at the polls. Richard Watson Gilder also spoke.
LEXIXGTON, Ky., Feb. 7. -- This was the third day of the auction sale of trotters here, and few good prices were realized. Seventy-nine head brought $15,24O.

The annual meeting of the New-York Yacht Racing Association was held at O'Neill's, Twenty-second Street and Sixth Avenue, last night. Nearly all the clubs were represented, and action was taken on the troublesome amendment to the constitution which, if passed, will require all clubs in the association to sail their open regattas under the rules of the association. This question was freely discussed, and then the amendment was adopted.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7. -- The twentyseventh annual encampment of the Department of New-Jersey, Grand Army of the Republic, began to-night by the meeting of the Council of Administration and the consideration of department reports. The encampment proper meets to-morrow, and will continue in session until Friday night.

The young "furnished-room" thief who calls himself William A. Crane, not being known as a professional, may be taken from the Tombs, where he awaits trial for carrying implements used by thieves, to answer several charges of robbery.

BOSTON, Feb. 7. -- The last of the series of the triangular billiard tournament begun some time ago was started in Bumstead Hall to-night, when "Jake" Schaefer and George Slosson strung for position. There were over 700 spectators present, among them being many of the leading men of Boston and its vicinity.

It was rumored yesterday in Brooklyn that William D. Lohman, the defaulting excashier of the Excise Department, had been located in New-Orieans, but the police, as well as the Excise Commissioners, denied it. They said no trace of him had been found.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7. -- The fifth week of the legislative session was brought to a close this afternoon when the House of Assembly adjourned until Monday night. The Democratic Senate met and adjourned in the morning, and the Republicans concluded the week's work yesterday. The week closed without any signs of a settlement of the controversy now going on between the Republican and Democratic Senators.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 7. -- Ex-Senator and ex-Judge William H. Kirk was burled today. The funeral services were held at the late residence of the deceased, 106 Clinton Avenue, and were conducted by the Rev. John R. Allen, pastor of the New-York Avenue Reformed Church, assisted by the Rev. Cornelius Brett, the Rev. D.H. Martin, and the Rev. Dr. David Waters.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7. -- Although London prices came frationally higher than our closing, the market opened dull and without any snap. As long as there was no pressure to sell prices did not recede, but with increased activity In the afternoon quotations slipped away easily, without any attempt at resistance.

When the Park Commissioners met yesterday ex-District Attorney DeLancey Nicoll appeared on behalf of Thomas Dwyer, who has the contract for tiling and cementing the tanks at the Castle Garden Aquarium, to answer a complaint made by the architect in charge that the tiling was not properly done.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In the course of ex-Speaker Reed's speech in Congress on Thursday last, much was made of the fact that, according to the statistical reports of Massachusetts, the average dividends of the manufacturing corporations of that State had been during the year covered by the last report somewhat less than 4 per cent.

We have before us a letter from a prominent firm of dealers in oils offering to supply kerosene oil of the best quality at 6 cents a gallon. As Mr. Gray, has shown, this city has teen made to pay 10 cents a gallon for the kerosene oil used by the Fire Department. The firm whose letter lies before us offers to supply oil fully equal in quality at a price 40 per cent less.

-- Bids were opened for the building of the armory for Troop A, at Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, by Secretary Barker, at a meeting of the Armory Board yesterday. Ten contractors bid for the work, as follows: P.K. Lantry, $138,000; Edward Frank, $138,860; Colin McLean, $147,800; James O'Toole, $136,500; John F. Johnson, $131,679; Charles A. Cowen, $135,876; Telfer Rennie, $149.679; James D. Murphy, $131,700; Horatio Watson, $133,150; P. Gallagher, $132,850.

Thomas C. Platt's effort to purloin the Republican organization in this city and subvert it to his own use, by way of the Milholland movement, has served, for one thing, to show Mr. Platt in his true light to the Republicans of this city. The best men in the party have now had enough of him. In some cases the awakening has been long deferred, but it is none the less complete.

Isaac Rathovski, the young Russian peddler who is charged with attempting to poison the entire Meyer family at 9 First Street on Monday night, was arrested yesterday morning. The chemical analysis made by the Health Department of the meat which the Meyer family ate at their supper shows that arsenic was mixed up in the stew, and there is strong evidence that Rathovski dropped the poison in the cooking pot.

A full meeting of the Executive Committee of the Business Men's General Committee, which is assisting the Industrial Christian Alliance in the work of relieving the unemployed poor, was held yesterday afternoon at the office of Vermilye Co., 18 Nassau Street. A contribution of $250 was received from H. McK. Twombly, and $50 more from Ogden Mills to carry on the good work.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 8. -- The resolution adopted by the State Senate on the Wilson bill means much more than appears upon the surface. As originally offered it called upon the Maryland Senators to vote for the bill "as it came from the House of Representatives." The purpose of that wording was plain.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 8. -- P.H. Tracey of Canaan, Conn., accidentally killed himself at Roselle to-night by drinking half a glass of aconite in mistake for whisky. Fred Wood, proprietor of the Aldine Hotel, and Nathan B. Oakley, a veterinary surgeon and liveryman, both of whom also drank the stuff, are in a critical condition, but the physicians think they will save Oakley's life.

If the disaster to the Kearsarge shall result in the total loss of that vessel, it will have removed from the list of navy ships a craft that will rank in history with such vessels as the Constitution and Hartford. Like those two historic ships, she had reached the sere and yellow leaf of her existence.

Receipts at the Sub-Treasury in New-York yesterday, in payment for subscriptions to the new $50,000,000 issue of bonds, were $1,933,318.33. Before payments were begun yesterday there had been received $44,896,840.28, making the total payments at the close of business last night $46,830,158.61, and leaving but $3,169,841.39 of the original amount yet to be paid for.

President Wallace C. Andrews and Secretary George C. St. John of the New-York Steam-Heating Company were arrested yesterday on warrants issued by Police Justice Taintor, in the Tombs Police Court. They are charged with violating the Sanitary Code by burning soft coal in the company's Dey Street place from Nov. 23 to Dec. 19 and on Feb. 7.

The annual meeting of the New-York Baseball Club was held at the office of the corporation in the Fuller Building, Jersey City, yesterday afternoon. The session was one of the most harmonious ever held by the club, and the delegates were in excellent humor throughout. The old management was indorsed in everything it had done, the financial condition of the club was particularly satisfactory, and nearly all the old Directors and officers were re-elected.
ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The Legislature to-day performed two acts, one of which is deserving of commendation, the second of condemnation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8. -- The baseball season at Princeton opened to-day. The midyear examinations closed yesterday, and to-day, in response to the call of Capt. MacKenzie, about thirty candidates reported at the cage. Among these were MacKenzie, Payne, Otto, Gunster, Forsythe, Lindsay, and Blair of last year's team.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 8. -- Ex-State Senator Charles P. McClelland and Dr. H.E. Schmid, Commissioners appointed by Justice Dykman, to-day took testimony before a Sheriff's jury as to the sanity of Miss Martha Jane Hall of Tarrytown. Miss Hall has been in Dr. Choate's sanitarium, at Pleasantville, Westchester County, since last July, suffering with paresis.

Much interest is taken by Brooklyn real estate men in the bill which Assemblyman Taylor has introduced at Albany fixing the place of judicial sales in the Real Estate Exchange room in Montague Street. Hltherto, as has been shown in The New-York Times, such sales have been scattered, and the prices obtained have not been encouraging.

The Godey Publishing Company of 21 Park Row and 10 and 12 Vandewater Street made an assignment yesterday to Benjamin S. Harmon of 45 William Street. The deed was signed by Henry J. Davison, Jr., as President and Henry Wakefield Bates as Secretary.

Mr. Ithamar Howe wants Mr. Isaac O. Woodruff to pay him $50,000 damages for the alienation of Mrs. Howe's affections. Mr. Woodruff declines, with thanks, and charges that Mr. and Mrs. Howe have entered into a conspiracy to blackmail him.

A delightful recital of Brownings "Blot on the 'Scutcheon" was given at the Berkeley Lyceum yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Sara Tawney Robson of Boston. The house was crowded with society people, and Mrs. Robson's work was received with enthusiasm.

The name of Albert E. Smith of Rahway, N.J., no longer appears on the door of Room 19 at 154 Nassau Street as Eastern business manager of the Haverhill Paper Company of Massachusetts and the Glen Manufacturing Company of New-Hampshire, which make newspaper paper and have an office in Boston.

-- "Charley's Aunt" in Boston. -- "Charley's Aunt" will remain at the Columbia Theatre in Boston for the present. After the court had refused the injunction asked for by the "Friends" company, the matter was amicably settled by Charles Frohman paying to the management of that organization $2,000 in cash, and securing it a later date at the Hollis Street Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The argument in the case of the International Contracting Company against Daniel S. Lamont, as Secretary of War, was begun to-day in the Court of Appeals. The case comes on appeal from the decision of Justice Cox, sitting at the time of the decision in Circuit Court No. 2, and involves several thousand dollars over the award of a contract for removing 900,000 cubic feet of earth in Gowanus Bay.

Another little collection of pictures lent by artists, collectors, and dealers in the fine arts hangs in the galleries of the Union League Club against the monthly meeting. The head of the main gallery is occupied by a largish painting by Jules Breton, called "Return from the Fields," lent by Mr. Latham A. Fish.

The combination sale of trotting stock which Peter C. Kellogg has been conducting at the American Institute Building this week was concluded yesterday. The many breeders who have attended the sale think that the worst of the depression in the horse market is over.

The General Passenger Agents of the Eastern trunk lines, and their Western connections, have not yet "worked out" the details of the new rate agreement recently adopted by the Presidents and General Managers. Although the agreement was unanimously approved, its practical operation was dependent on the formulation of certain rules and by-laws.

Will McNeill, the Scottish evangelist who has aided so materially in the meetings of the great Brooklyn revival, is a brother of John McNeill, the famous Scottish divine of Glasgow, Scotland, who is known as the "Scottish Spurgeon." Mr. McNeill was born in Inverkip, a small fishing village on the banks of the Firth of Clyde, about twenty miles from Glasgow, in one of the most beautiful parts of Scotland.
COLON, Feb. 8. -- The United States steamer Kearsarge foundered on the night of Feb. 2 off Roncador Reef.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry of New-York City argued before the Assembly Cities Committee this afternoon in favor of Assemblyman Sheffield's bill, giving the New-York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children $30,000 annually out of the New-York City Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The memorial of the National Wool Growers' Association, asking that no reduction of duties be made in wool or woolen goods, was laid before the Senate this morning by Mr. Sherman, and was ordered to be printed as a document.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The market for bar silver appears to be completely demoralized. The tone to-day was flat, and prices again showed a considerable decline. The quotation yesterday was 29 13-16d. per ounce. The price had fallen off 7-16 at 2:30 this afternoon, the quotation being 29 3/8d.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- The twentyfifth annual convention of the Young Men's Christian Association of New-Jersey opened this evening with a largely-attended meeting in the First Congregational Church, Montclair. President A.H. Siegfried welcomed the delegates in behalf of the local association, and was followed by the Rev. Dr. A.H. Bradford, who made an address in behalf of the local churches.

ROME, Feb. 8. -- The Pope's jubilee encyclical will appear on the 18th inst. His Holiness at the last moment struck out that part of the encyclical bearing on political affairs, owing to the changes that had supervened in the political situation, since it was written. In the document the Pope thanks Christendom for the manifestations made on the occasion of his jubilee.

Copyright, 1894, by the united Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 8. -- Thomas L. Thompson. United States Minister, and Rear Admiral Benham, commander of the United States fleet, and his staff called upon President Peixoto at the palace this after-noon. They were escorted, both going and coming, by a handsome company of Brazilian lancers.
The Greater New-York bill, introduced in the Legislature by Assemblyman Burtis of Brooklyn, is as follows:

Charles Albert, twenty-eight years old, of 114 West Sixty-third Street, was shot and slightly wounded at his home early yesterday morning by his father-in-law, George Fliedner, a produce dealer in Gansevoort Market.

The Irish National Federation Association of this city will give a reception at the Hoffman House to-night to Edward Blake, anti-Parnellite member of the British Parliament for the Southern District of County Longford, Ireland. Mr. Blake arrived in the city yesterday from Montreal, where he has been visiting for a few weeks.

The little scrimmage in the House over the Bland bill directing the coinage of the seigniorage need not, we think, be regarded with much apprehension by the business community. It is among the lingering penalties of our financial and political sins that Bland still has the power to engross the time of the House and to threaten disturbance, but we are convinced that his power for real mischief has substantially vanished.

-- Leopold Wallach of New-York, counsel for the Savannah and Western bondholders' committee and the bondholders of the Chattanooga, Rome and Columbus Railroad, after installing E.E. Jones as receiver in possession of the latter road, appeared in the United States court in Savannah yesterday, to protest against the issue of $701,000 of receivers certttlcates on the property of the Savannah and Western Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- All the bids for bonds accepted at 117.223 are scaled down 5.331 per cent. The names of the bidders, with residence, amounts, and allotments, follow in the order named:

Although Detective Kehoe and Assistant Fire Marshal Freel were abroad until after daylight yesterday, they did not succeed in arresting the man who, Fire Marshal Mitchel claims, was the accomplice of Louis Valenstein, who was arrested on Tuesday for firing the cigar manufactory of Cohen Valenstein, on the third floor of 85 and 87 Reade Street, Monday night.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Richard Supple and John Hayes stood talking on the corner of Grove and Fifth Streets at 9 o'clock to-night, when John Vaughn, a friend of both men, approached, and accused Supple of talking about him. Vaughn became wild with rage, drew a revolver, and fired four shots at Supple.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 8. -- Funeral services for Alvan P. Hyde, father of Mayor Hyde and of United States Consul Hyde at Lyons, France, were conducted at the South Church at 2 o'clock this afternoon by the Rev. Edwin Pond Parker, D.D. The honorary bearers included ex-Judges Dwight Loomis and Elisha Carpenter, Senator Edward S. Cleveland, ex-Lieut.
The Committee of One Hundred, which is working energetically for the reorganization of the Brooklyn Democracy, has placed in nomination a candidate for Supervisor in the Eighth Ward.
The Municipal Art Society of New-York invites a competition for the decoration of the courtroom of Oyer and Terminer in the new Criminal Courts Building, in Centre Street.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Feb. 8. -- George Tower, a son of the late Stephen A. Tower, at one time one of Montclair's most prominent residents, and proprietor of the Tower Manufacturing Company of Broadway and Duane Streets, New-York, is missing. It is stated that Mrs. Tower is about to bring suit for divorce against her husband, and it is rumored that Tower has eloped with the eighteen-year-old daughter of a traveling salesman in Bloomfleld.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- A deputation, consisting of ship owners, merchants, and others interested in the shipping trade, visited the Foreign Office to-day for the purpose of protesting against the Government's neglect of British interests at Rio Janeiro. The deputation complained that British ships at Rio Janeiro had been detained for months and their cargoes were not yet discharged.

Dr. Frank M. Kemp, one of the youngest physicians attached to the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, has distinguished himself, both as a doctor and a hero. A woman patient who was on the verge of death owes her life to his bravery.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Ex-Controller Edward V. Loew has sold to Mrs. Cornelia L. Marshall, widow of Jesse A. Marshall, the five-story brick apartment building, with stores, at the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, the lot being 66.11 by 100 feet. A Post Office station occupies the store floor. The property, unimproved, was bought by Mr. Loew and his brother, the late Charles E. Loew, from Jane E. Dorland on Oct. 18, 1882.

RONDOUT, N.Y,. Feb. 8. -- Mrs. George P. Dean of this city, who, according to her own story, has had a hard struggle with poverty this Winter, has been notified by a lawyer from Peekskill that she has fallen heir to a large sum of money. This money, the woman says, comes from a great-uncle, Irving Van Woert, who died recently, leaving a fortune of several million dollars.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- The will of George W. Childs was admitted to probate this morning. The document is very short, and was executed on Aug. 1, 1893, one month after the death of Anthony J. Drexel. Mr. Childs bequeaths his entire estate to his widow absolutely.

William Henry Knox, a lawyer and a well-known member of the Tammany Hall organization, said yesterday in reference to the probable action of the Senate respecting the nomination of "Wheeler H. Peckham for Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court:

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- Local stocks were dull and inclined to be heavy. Boston United Gas seconds were the exception to this, sellat 64 3/4, 2 1/4 higher than yesterday's opening. No reason is assigned for the rise, the fluctuations of gas securities being as mysterious as Herrmann's latest wonder. $1,000 Mexican Central 4s sold at 50, 1 3/4 off from the last sale.

Lovers of boxing saw more fighting in one minute in Grand Central Palace last night than was witnessed in the international encounter in Jacksonville last month. There was no fear of the Sheriff stopping the encounter. The spectators did not have to travel thousands of miles to see the battles, and, unlike the demands of the hungry Florida managers, only popular prices were charged.

Dr. William H. Guilfoyle of the Bureau of Vital Statistics made a test of permanganate of potash as an antidote for morphine in a lecture before a class in the evening high school last Monday. A small vagrant dog was the subject. Dr. Guilfoyle injected four grains of morphine hypodermically into the animal and waited fifteen minutes for the poison to take effect.

The evangelistic meeting in Association Hall, Brooklyn, yesterday noon, crowded the lower portion of the hall, as usual, and was one of the largest that has been held. The Rev. George C. Needham, who presided, announced at the opening that the meeting was to be devoted to the giving of testimony. He said:
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Interest in the Peckham case was intensified to-day by the arrival of Secretaries Gresham and Carlisle at the Capitol about 1 o'clock. Secretary Gresham went to the Marble Room and Secretary Carlisle took a seat in the private room of Secretary of the Senate Cox.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Coroner Volk this evening concluded the inquest in the Delaware, Liackawanna and Western Railroad accident on the Hackensack meadows Jan. 15. The depositions of several of the injured, who are still in St. Mary's and Christ Hospitals, were read. These threw no light on the cause of the accident, but freely criticised the management of the road. The verdict was as follows:

In spite of the protestations of Senator Saxton, who is believed to be an able and honest man, it is evident that little confidence is felt in the investigation of the Police Department of this city by the special committee of the Senate which was appointed by him and of which he is a member.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Feb. 8-P.M. The market was still undergoing the process of reaction to-day, but within narrow limits. Wherever pressure to sell appeared buyers were ready to meet it.
