In the absence, however, of energy on either side, dullness ensued, and business closed with only fractional changes in the general list.
Twenty stories and 300 feet high! That is to be the size of the latest of the sky-scraping buildings which New-York has been affecting in rapidly-increasing number within the last year or two.
It was reported at Police Headquarters yesterday that J. Kahn, a pawnbroker, had been robbed of $10,000 worth of diamonds. The stones were taken from his flat on Wednesday.
TACOMA, Washington, Feb. 8. -- Gov. McGraw has removed John McReavy from the State Capitol Commission, alleging misconduct.

Roncador Bank, usually called Roncador Reef, where the Kearsarge was wrecked, has been the scene of many similar disasters. The Pacific mail steamship Golden Rule was stranded there in 1865. There were 900 persons on board. Boats were dispatched to Colon for assistance, but it was a month before the castaways were rescued. Many of them died from the effects of the exposure.

The recent action of Gen. Flagler in ordering 5,000 pounds of Leonard and 5,000 of Peyton powder for the new .30calibre army rifle will permit thorough competitive tests between these promising American inventions. Our Ordnance Department has, indeed, made many trials of domestic and foreign smokeless powders, both as to ballistic and keeping qualities -- adequate velocity, uniform results with equal charges, low pressures, and stability under climatic changes being the leading excellences desired.

The Roanoke Associates last evening celebrated the thirty-second anniversary of the battle of Roanoke Island by a reunion and dinner at the Hotel Brunswick. Gen. Henry C. Dwight of the Twenty-seventh Massachusetts Volunteers, the President, was in the chair.

The Roanoke Associates last evening celebrated the thirty-second anniversary of the battle of Roanoke Island by a reunion and dinner at the Hotel Brunswick. Gen. Henry C. Dwight of the Twenty-seventh Massachusetts Volunteers, the President, was in the chair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- There is excellent reason to believe that the State Department has for some time past been in official possession, of the intelligence now cabled from Rio of the intention of President Peixoto to declare martial law at an end before the election for his successor to the Presidency on March 1 next.

A court of inquiry to determine the responsibility for the loss of the Kearsarge surely will be held. The three officers who are likely to be asked for explanations are the commanding officer, the navigator, and the officer who was in charge of the deck at the time the vessel stranded. Lieut. Charles H. Lyman was navigator of the vessel, but it is not known whether he was acting in that capacity at the time.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The Kings County Senators had a merry war of it this morning. It arose over the bill of Senator Bradley which provides for the election of Brooklyn Aldermen by wards. The first brand was fired by Senator Owens, who offered an amendment fixing the salary of Aldermen at $1,500 a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The resolution offered by Mr. Stewart (Rep., Nev.,) declaring it to be the sense of the Senate that the Secretary of the Treasury has no authority to issue bonds except under the Resumption act, and that the money derived from the sale of bonds issued under the act cannot be applied to any other purpose than as specified in the Resumption act, was laid before the Senate to-day.

COLUMBIA, Miss., Feb. 8. -- William Purvis, a young negro, was sentenced to be hanged here yesterday for the assassination last July of William Buckley of Marion County. Purvis was convicted on circumstantial evidence. He acknowledged being one of the party, but declared he did not fire the shot which killed Buckley.

PORT HUDSON, La., Feb. 8. -- A cyclone passed through this locality at 7 o'clock this morning, and left death and destruction in its wake. The first place it struck was on Mrs. S.A. Delambre's plantation, formerly owned by Gen. Houston, about two miles northwest of here.

Representatives of the Erie Railway bond-holders who object to the reorganization plan devised by the Board of Directors will meet to-day to consider the answer to their suggestions that the plan be modified. The answer, which is signed by President John King and J.G. McCullough as Chairman of the Readjustment Committee, practically declares that no changes will be made in the plan.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- A somewhat bearish feeling seemed to prevail on the board before and during the first hour, and when a drive was made at Western Union the traders were disposed to hammer the general list, but, except in fractional amounts, they failed to make any impression.

While it would undoubtedly be futile to attempt to play "Die Gotterdammerung" on a penny whistle. It would be quite as unnecessary to engage the orchestra of the Paris Conservatoire for a performance of "H.M.S. Pinafore." This remark is evoked by the fourth concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which was given at the Music Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Col. and Mrs. Henry entertained at break-fast, at Fort Myer, to-day Mrs. Lamont, who was accompanied by her guests, Mrs. Gilman Collamore and Miss Grace Sanders of New-York. The other guests were Miss Scott, Miss Cornell of Buffalo, Miss Breckinridge, Miss Blackburn, Miss Ruggies, Miss Slocum of New-York, Miss Lockwood, Capt. Pitcher, Capt. Stephenson, Lieut. Landis, Lieut. Perry, Lieut. Sewell, Lieut. Haines, and Lieut. Mendet.

Madison Square Garden was never filled with stranger sounds than echoed yesterday through the big amphitheatre. Four thousand feathered visitors to the metropolis from various parts of the world proclaimed in incessant chorus that they had come to down.
Thomas C. Platt, who votes in Tioga, has a new Republican machine in New-York County which is all his own.

The refusal of the Directors of the Erie Railway to modify their plan of reorganization was discussed at a well-attended meeting of representatives of the holders of the second mortgage bonds and other bonds of the Erie Company, in this city yesterday afternoon.

Mr. John Lowber Welsh, the Philadelphia banker, became a manager of the Reading Company in April, 1893, and one of the receivers of the some property in the month of August following. He was a witness yesterday in the investigation of the Reading property which is in progress in Philadelphia, before Special Master Crawford, on the proceeding brought by Mr. Isaac L. Rice.

BOSTON, Feb. 9. -- Billiards were seen in Bumstead Hall to-night that called for applause loud enough to fairly shake the historic old building in which the tournament is being held. Schaefer and Ives were pitted against each other, and there were a great many of those present who expected to see the phenomenal young player down the "Wizard." In this they were disappointed.

The amateur skaters of this vicinity have been done an injustice by the postponement of the championships this year from last Wednesday to next Tuesday. All arrangements were made for the contests by the North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club of Red Bank, and the ice was in fair condition, but at the last moment Gus Walton telegraphed Secretary Weaver ordering a postponement.

By the consent of the Attorney General the time to answer the complaint in the suit brought for the dissolution of the St. Nicholas BanK has been extended to March, and several days ago President Arthur B. Graves and the Directors of the bank joined in the following letter to Receiver Grant:

Some practical joker, with as little wit as the average of his species, and inspired, perhaps, by the prospect of selling a "sensation" to some credulous newspaper, stuck to the side of Chauncey M. Depew's house, 43 West Fifty-fourth Street, the other night a piece of paper, on which was written what purported to be a rambling threat against Mr. Depew as a rich man.

The first opinion of the Court of Appeals, written by Justice Bartlett, which has reached the Corporation Counsel's office, was received from Albany yesterday. It was in the case of the Tax Commissioners against the Second Avenue Railroad Company, and it was a decision against the city for about $18.000.

John C. Munzinger, the police court lawyer who was indicted by the Grand Jury on Thursday for grand larceny in obtaining from Lucy McCarthy, the keeper of a disorderly resort on the west side, $2,500, on the promise of securing police "protection" for her establishment, was arrested yesterday and was subsequently released on bail to await trial.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- George W. Houk, Representative in Congress from the Third District of Ohio, dropped dead at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon while visiting at 1,627 Connecticut Avenue, Northwest.

BATH, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- Major Cleary of Rochester, Department Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, and a committee of three ladies of the State Aid Charities Auxiliary Association, appeared before the Board of Trustees of the Soldiers' Home here last evening to confer regarding the bill introduced in the Legislature for the admission of soldiers' wives, widows, and children to the home.

Alderman John G. Prague of 510 Columnbus Avenue, the well-known architect and builder, made an assignment yesterday to Charles Stranss of 237 Broadway, without preference. His liabilites are between $400,000 and $430,00 and his assets are estimated at from $550,000 to $600,000.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 9. -- A strike on the Northern Pacific Railroad will probably be averted as a result of the conference held here yesterday between the officers of the company and the leaders of the several railway employes' organizations. "There is no probability of any friction between the men and the company," said Henry C. Payne, one of the receivers.

Mr. C.F. Mathewson of the University Athletic Club said yesterday that he hoped to near from the University of Pennsylvania to-day in regard to the representative chosen to act on the special Committee on Football Rules. He thinks that by Tuesday or Wednesday of next week the committee will be able to set in session and begin its labors.

An important arrest of counterfeiters was made yesterday at 922 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. It is expected this arrest will put a stop to the circulation of spurious coins among the small traders of the city, who have been preyed upon for several months. Two bushels of counterfeit quarters and dimes, amounting to several thousand dollars, were also seized on the premises.
"I ask you, gentlemen of the jury, was that a fair divulging of the facts to his client, when, at that very moment, he had the judgment for the full amount, with costs and allowances, in his pocket?"

Commissioner of Accounts Owen was busy yesterday carefully examining all the correspondence that was sent to Mayor Gilroy by President Scannell and Commissioner Eickchoff of the Fire Department and the letters of ex-Commissioner H. Winthrop Gray, who resigned after having made several charges against the manner in which business was conducted by the Fire Department.

COLON, Feb. 9. -- The steamer City of Para sailed at noon to-day for Roncador Reef to take aboard the officers and crew of the United States war ship Kearsarge, which went on the rocks last Friday. She was chartered for the voyage by the United States Government.

Robert Michael Ballantyne. Robert Michael Ballantyne, whose death was announced by The New-York Times yesterday, was born in 1825, at Edinburgh. He was in the service of the Hudson Bay Company, in British America, from 1841 to 1847. He traveled extensively. He was a very prolific author, his books being chiefly stories of travel and adventure written for young people.

Wheat made a new record yesterday, selling lower than it has ever before sold in this market. Consequently, it was an exciting day in the wheat market, and the bears had it all their own way until the close.

Jacob Worth's chum, William J. Buttling, the Republican Sheriff of Kings County, came to the defense of John Y. McKane yesterday in his trial for conspiracy in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer.

Collector Kilbreth yesterday restored the Custom House cartage contract to Thomas A. Briggs. The Treasury regulations call for the advertising of bids for the contract, which is estimated to toe worth $100,000 a year. Collector Magone, when he was in charge of the Custom House, awarded the contract to Briggs, who was the lowest bidder.

On the top floor of a dingy and dilapidated house at 130 Willett Street a reporter for The New-York Times found two young children yesterday sitting on a cot, while a neighbor was looking after them in the absence of the mother. The furniture in the room consisted of three chairs, a box, a table, and a stove.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 9. -- William R. Vaughn of Smithville, Tenn., and William M. Lewis of Fieldchester, in the same State, were arraigned before Police Superintendent Smith to-day. There was no charge against the men. They had merely been taken in for safe keeping.

JAMAICA, L.I., Feb. 9. -- Miss Sadie Bennett, a young woman living here, has instituted a suit for damages in the Queens County Supreme Court against Jacob R. Shipperd and Arthur Sanders, lawyers, living at Richmond Hill. In her complaint Miss Bennett alleges that the defendants conspired to restrain her of her liberty.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9. -- Col. Robert J. Haire of New-York, who represents Mrs. Pixley and other relatives of Annie Pixley, the dead actress, in the controversy with Robert Fulford, the actress's husband, regarding her will and estate, has been in Philadelphia examining records in the office of the Recorder of Deeds.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 9. -- The Woodard Shanklin sale of trotting stock was concluded here to-day. During the five days 377 head of horses passed under the hammer, for a total of $95,145, a general average of $229 per head. To-morrow the Sherman Stock Farm trotters will be sold by the Sheriff, and Monday the Tattersalls sale will begin here.

Horace Chase is six feet in height and forty years old, with a long, thin face and a grave demeanor. He is not a university man, and he uses the English language fairly well, to be sure, but entirely by ear. Chase is many times a millionaire, but he spells " L'Hommedieu" as it is pronounced in Asheville, N.C., "Lommy Dew."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 9. -- Just before the Kolbite-Populist Convention adjourned last night, William Stevens, Chairman of the Black Wing Republican State Executive Committee, entered the Wigwam with other colored leaders. He secured recognition, and said that he came to indorse for his people the platform of the convention.
The performance at Abbey's Theatre last evening was Coquelin's "benefit," and to honor the French comedian there was gathered an audience in many ways remarkable.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 9. -- Belle Ward, the only daughter of Barclay Ward, a rich resident of Huntington, has been missing from her home two weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9. -- The United States cruiser Columbia will so into commission on March 1. Thus far but few of her officers have been assigned for duty. The Columbia now lies at the Cramps' shipyard. Not much remains to be done upon her. She must be cleaned, have her final coat of paint, her decks planed, and her batteries mounted, and the cruiser should be ready to depart for good on April 1.

An interesting case involving money lost at roulette was tried yesterday before Justice Ingraham of the Supreme Court. The plaintiff was J.H. Vanderburg, who used to run the Saratoga Clubhouse, at Saratoga and who officiated at the wheel in that establishment.

From Printers Ink. To the average person, probably, the safe and prompt delivery of letters and postals is of far more importance than that of papers and other second or third class matter. But to the large advertising concerns, advertising agencies, and publishers and circulation superintendents of newspapers, faulty handling and slow and incorrect delivery are indeed like a thorn in the flesh.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The Albany Burgesses Corps, with its band, reached Washington this afternoon on its return trip from New-Orleans, and is now taking in the sights of the city. Late this afternoon the organization marched to the White House and serenaded the President, and afterward was received by him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce to-day ordered Mr. Bartlett of New-York to report favorably the bill introduced by Mr. Campbell of New-York amending the act approved March, 1887, authorizing the construction of a bridge across the East River, between New-York City and Long Island.

Announcement is made in Chicago that the book which W.T. Stead has been writing about that city will soon be published. In anticipation of its publication Mr. Stead has submitted to an interview in which he is reported to have said that he has found that Chicago is not very bad except in some features.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Feb. 9. -- A small black sloop appeared off this village Wednesday night. She was manned by a crew of rough-looking men. That night the Post Office at Fort Salonga, a small hamlet near here, was broken into and robbed. As the sloop was not to be seen the following morning the authorities believe her crew were the burglars.

The conference yesterday of the Senate committee with the representatives of various public bodies was not altogether satisfactory. The truth evidently is that the committee finds itself, before it has even pretended to begin its work, on its own defense. There is a general belief, which it has done nothing to dispel and which it would be very difficult for it to dispel, that it is organized to investigate a little and not too much.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Chairman Cummings of the House Naval Committee has completed the report of the committee upon the Holman resolution, declaring that the premiums paid for speed of naval vessels are excessive, and seeking; to restrain further payments on that score.
Commenting on the condition of business for the week, R.G. Dun Co.'s review tomorrow will say:

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- Details have arrived of the massacre of French troops near Timbuctoo by the Tuaregs. They contain the starring information that Col. Bonnier of the Marine Artillery, nine other European officers, two European Sergeants, six native Sergeants, and sixty-one native sharp-shooters have been killed.

For years it has cost upward of $70,000 a year to light the Post Office in this city. Since Mr. Dayton took charge he has been striving to reduce this expenditure. The first step was in securing the co-operation of his men, and the next the constructing of the new skylight. Since the skylight was put in place the bills have been cut down fully $2,500 a month, or an average of $30,000 a year.

The trial of John Dunphy, who was an Election Inspector in the Twenty-sixth Election District of the Eighth Assembly District, for neglect of duty, was concluded yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Justice Barrett. In twenty-five minutes after it retired the jury returned with a verdict of guilty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- There is reason to believe that when the Tariff bill is laid before the Finance Committee by the subcommittee which is now at work upon it its form will not be materially changed.
TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 9. -- The Ontario Prohibition plebiscite has brought out a declaration from Premier Mowat, which is said to be a Cabinet decision. The Premier says:

Despite the storm yesterday, the large hall of the Young Men's Christian Association in Brooklyn was filled with worshipers at the noonday evangelistic meeting. The platform was occupied by the ministers composing the Central Committee for Evangelistic Work. They and the congregation bad come together to hold a jubilee after five weeks of evangelical work.

The receipts at the Sub-Treasury in this city yesterday in payment for subscriptions to the new $50,000,000 issue of bonds, including subscriptions from out of town, amounted to $1,869,132.81, making a total to date of $48,699,308.73. There is yet but $2,150,000 of the New-York subscriptions to come in.

Roundsmen John J. McNally of West Thirtieth Street, Richard Walsh of Morrisania, and Joseph Burns of Church Street, were promoted Sergeants by Commissioner McClave at yesterday's meeting of the Police Board. McNally and Walsh were sent to East One Hundred and Fourth Street and Burns to East Eighty-eighth Street.

The reports sent us from Washington as to the probable course of the Finance Committee on the Tariff bill indicate some disposition to recast that measure. It is not unnatural that the members of the committee should feel some temptation in this direction. It is the first time in this generation that there has been any opportunity for tariff reformers in the Senate to take any substantial part in the framing of a tariff bill.

The trial of the suit brought by Ithamar Howe, hotel man, of Boston and formerly steward of the Megantic Club at Spider Lake, Quebec, against Isaac O. Woodruff, a dealer in physicians' supplies at 88 Maiden Lane, for $50,000 damages for alienating his wife's affections, was resumed yesterday morning before Justice Ingraham and a jury in the Supreme Court.

Henry B. Pruden, President of the Globe Brewing Company, 626 West Thirty-second Street, was charged yesterday, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, by Stephen H. Griffin, the company's bookkeeper, with misappropriating $38 collected from Dennis J. Morrissey, 122 East One Hundred and Second Street.

The outlook for a thorogh and satisfactory investigation is now very bright. The gentlemen composing the Senate investigating committeee and the representatives of the Chamber of Commerce, the Board of Trade and Transportation, the City Club, and the Society for the Prevention of Crime are now in perfect accord.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The active ballot reformers throughout the State are beginning to express the fear that his onerous committee work is seriously interfering with Senator Saxton's work as a legislator. The Legislature, which started out with every indication of improving the ballot laws of the State, has accomplished nothing up to date.

There is likely to be a row in amateur athletic circles over granting the Columbia Athletic Club permission to hold a boxing tournament in Grand Palace Rink. The Columbia Club has gone out of existence, and the present tournament, it is claimed, is being run in the interest of two old members of the defunct Columbias and a very prominent member of the Athletic Committee of the New-York Athletic Club.

Mr. Frank L. Fisher has sold, for John Casey, the builder, ten of a row of sixteen new four-story brownstone and brick dwellings on the north side of West Eighty-eighth Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. The houses are each 20 by 60 by 102.2, and are numbered from 47 to 65.

The rumors which the mongers of that Washington staple were recently peddling about Mr. Carlisle's approval of Mr. Bland's latest silver bill fail to receive any credence from Mr. Bland himself. On the contrary, that gentleman, once so confident and even threatening, has become distinctly melancholy in his manner, and confesses that the attitude of Secretary Carlisle is discouraging to him.

KEENE, N.H., Feb. 9. -- A. Willard Humphreys, at one time President of the Sterling Iron Works of New-York City, commuted suicide by shooting himself in his room in the hotel in Winchester about 7:30 this morning.

LONDON, ENG., Feb. 2. -- The following statement made by the late Dr. J. Milner Fothergill, the eminent scientist, who was physician for the London Hospital for diseases of the chest, has made quite a sensation. After denouncing oils and similar substances when used as food, he said "Fatty, oily foods cannot be taken by those whose stomachs are weak or whose digestive organs are out of order.

SCHENECTADY, Feb. 9. -- The sixteenth lecture to students of Union College in the Butterfield Course was delivered to-day by ex-Surgeon General Hammond. His subject was "Brain and Muscle," and the application lay in a discussion of college athletics.

NEW-YORK. Friday, Feb. 9 -- P.M. To-day's transactions at the Stock Exchange fell below 150,000 shares. The net result of all sales was to shares the active list only fractionally changed since yesterday. Speculation found activity and excitement enough to satisfy it, however, in wheat, in which the sales of an ordinary week were crowded into a day, and the lowest price on record was reached.

JAMAICA, L.I., Feb. 9. -- An incident showing the romantic devotion of a young woman to her sweetheart occurred here yesterday. Miss Hattie Smith of Rockville Centre dogged the footsteps of a man to whom she was engaged, from her home to Jamaica, to save him from the evil effects of bad company and liquor.

There was a cheerful mingling of fashionable folk and farmer folk yesterday in Madison Square Garden. The second day of the poultry and pigeon show attracted an increased attendance despite the storm. Raindrops drummed a brisk accompaniment on the arched roof to the shrill trumpetings of truculent fowls and the lesser pipings of smaller birds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Chief Constructor Hichborn has recommended that the batteries of the big battle ships be changed. He believes that the weights at present carried by the Massachusetts, the Indiana, and the Oregon are too great for the stability of those ships. Each vessel was intended to carry in its main battery four thirteen-inch guns, eight eight-inch guns, and four six-inch guns.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- Emperor William today celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of his entrance into the army, in which, in accordance with the custom of his family, he was made a Lieutenant on reaching his tenth year. The First Regiment of the Foot Guards, in which he held his first commission, marched to-day, under command of the Emperor, to the Lustgarten, at Potsdam.

At a meeting of the Reorganization Committee of the Nicaragua Canal Construction Company, held yesterday afternoon in the company's office, 46 Wall Street, it developed that the stockholders of the company are almost unanimous in their approval of the Bartlett plan of reorganization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Mr. Bland has found it necessary to offer a number of explanations to the House of his seigniorage bill, and the more he explains the more it becomes apparent that the bill ought to be killed.

Secretary Carlisle has recently given to the country a practical lesson in the scope and purpose of the civil service law and rules which is of great value, and which we should be glad to see heeded throughout the Federal service. The newly-appointed Collector of Customs at San Francisco found two men appointed on probation, under the civil service rules, by his predecessor.

The legislation to be attempted at Washington for the citizen soldiers during the present session is perhaps mainly what may be found embodied in Mr. Curtis's bill. One feature of that bill, however, which is unlikely to become a law is the item appropriating $600,000 for arming and equipping the militia.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9. -- Although quotations at the opening were at about yesterday's closing, the market was tame, owing to almost entire absence of commission orders. London arbitrage brokers showed some inclination to sell Pennsylvania, and the shorts hammered at Lehigh Valley, but did not succeed in getting it down below 39.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- The wheat pit on the Board of Trade to-day thought it saw undoubted evidence of liquidation by that Wall Street crowd which has been the important long interest in the market for months. All the private-wire houses were active on the selling side, those most talked of in connection with the Wall Street bull interest being the most active.

BOSTON, Feb. 9. -- Several local specialties were traded in to-day, and certain stocks showed activity, but the tendency was toward lower prices. American Bell Telephone sold in small lots down to 170, recovering later to 172. A few shares of Erie Telephone sold at 44, and 200 shares NewEngland Telephone at 50.

Georgie Robbins, a pretty fifteen-year-old girl, who disappeared from her home, 140 William Street, Brooklyn, Jan. 4, was found yesterday by Detectives Price and McCabe. Miss Robbins imagined she was ill used at home, and her fancied wrongs, combined with aspirations to be on the stage, resulted in her running away.

The fourth concert or the Kneisel Quartet of Boston was given last night in the Chamber Music Room at Music Hall. The programme was concise and interesting. It contained three numbers -- a new string quartet by the famous pianist, Eugen d'Albert; the Bach chaconne for violin, and Beethoven's quartet in C major, Opus 29.

From The Westminster Gazette. In the interview with Mr. Villiers, reported the other day in The Dally Chronicle, there are amusing reminders of the social exclusiveness of the old Whig school of politicians. "We all know," he said, "who composed the House before it was elected on the present democratic basis. Now its members are largely the men you will see at meetings of railway and other great companies.

A host of pretty girls gather nightly at the gymnasium of the Young Women's Christian Association, Brooklyn. There are 300 of them, with fresh complexions and well-rounded figures, healthy and strong.

In 1377 a "tax unheard of before," was imposed by Parliament, which took the form of a poll tax graduated chiefly according to rank, though partly according to property. Dukes had to pay u6 13s. 4d.; Earls, u4; Barons, u2; Knights, u1; Squires, 6s. 8d., or, if they had no land, 3s. 4d. Beggars were exempt.

LAKE WOOD, N.J., Feb. 10. -- With Ash Wednesday the arrival of Lenten visitors began. For many years this resort has been a favorite one for spending the forty days of quiet which precede Easter. The bookings at the large hotels indicate no change for this season, and to-night there is a large number of old guests, as well as new ones, registered here.

Henry Jessiman, thirty-six years old, was committed in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for examination as to his mental condition. Jessiman was formerly a coachman, and he has a mania for horses and stables. A week or two ago he hired a man to paint his name on a stable at 5 East Twenty-eighth Street, and employed another man as watchman.

Dr. Robson Roose, the well-known writer on subjects of health, has an article in a recent issue of The Fortnightly Review, in the course of which he says: "If good cooking be the most important of arts, the second place may be fairly assigned to proper forms and methods of dress." Clothing and food are, of course, closely connected.

Mr. Alma-Tadema is a great advocate of work. "Nothing can be done well without taking trouble," he says; "you must work hard if you mean to succeed." By these and similar encouragements. I have many times heard him urge on faint-hearted followers. He will never allow himself to be beaten by the difficulties of any subject.

There is a graveyard for ships in Manhasset Bay, off Long Island Sound. There, in the surging tide, rock the bleeching hulks of many old-time men-o'-war and merchantmen, that years ago sailed the stormy main, visiting almost every clime and port in the world, carrying a nation's arms, or laden with the riches of generations.

Edward Connolly, a tall, athletic, well-dressed man about fifty years old, was a broken-hearted father yesterday morning, when he appeared before Justice Voorhis, in the Yorkville Police Court, to prefer charges against a gang of Austrian laborers employed on the grain elevators of the New-York Central Railroad, at Sixty-first Street, North River, for the abduction of his fifteen-year-old daughter.

LYNN, Mass., Feb. 10. -- Estelle Gowen, the eighteen-year-old daughter of Frederick Gowen of 27 Spring Street, Lynn, became insane yesterday, and was last evening placed in the women's department of the police station for safe keeping.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- The Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs, M. Casimir-Perier, read in the Chamber of Deputies today dispatches received from the Governor of Senegal in regard to the attack on the French flying column near Timbuctoo, by Touaregs. The dispatches stated that when the news of the disaster reached St. Louis reinforcements were immediately dispatched to Timbuctoo.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The Treasury Department will begin business Monday, Feb. 12, with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

From The Lewiston (Me.) Journal. A man of about sixty years of age went into a store on Main Street Wednesday afternoon and stood by the stove warming himself and listening to the conversation of the men present. Happening to glance at a barrel of apples by the counter, he took up one and bit it. He stopped, looked at the apple, and then stopped reflectively.

The announcement that two officers of the National Guard have started classes of boys for instruction in military tactics, the simpler ones, which produce a soldiery bearing rather than a knowledge of intricate manoeuvres, is full of suggestion.

Luke M. Emerson's jackasses were the subject of a long discussion in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, when a motion was made before Justice Andrews on behalf of the Sheriff to tax the costs of an attachment issued against the jackasses. Mr. Emerson is the owner of an immense stock farm at Bowling Green, Ky., and is the largest importer of jackasses in this country.

Consolidation sentiment is steadily gaining ground in Brooklyn. Observant citizens interpret Thursday's vote in the Legislature as a long step toward municipal union. The absence of serious opposition in the Assembly goes to show that members are beginning to defer a little to the demands of their constituents.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The account of the large sums now flowing from private coffers for the relief of the poor moves us to appeal through your columns In the interests of an institution whose work fully supported would aid many to self-maintenance and respectability who otherwise must drift into the pauper or criminal class.

Mayor Schieren's supposed excise policy In relation to the sale of liquor on Sundays was a topic of lively discussion at a meeting of clergymen and laymen in the rooms of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association yesterday afternoon. The meeting was discordant throughout, and no definite conclusions were reached.

I had got the statue into line with a chimney in the Rue Castiglione, so as to be able to detect the slightest oscillation, but there was none at all -- the column, all wounded as it was, stood immovable. Five minutes passed, five minutes of excited hope to me, for, from the braveness of the resistance, it almost seemed as if the destroying brutes would not be able to succeed.

Wheat advanced 3/3@1/2c with the West and on shorts covering, but again declined and closed unsettled at 1/4@1/2c under yesterday, May making a new low record, or to 65 1-16c, with speculation active.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 10. -- Lieut. Gov. Gill took charge of the Executive office and its affairs at noon to-day in the absence of Gov. Altgeld, who left Wednesday on a short health-seeking tour to Hot Springs, Ark. The young Lieutenant Governor was not invited by the Chief Executive to relieve him.

SING SING, Feb. 10. -- The present open Winter, as far as the Hudson River is concerned, has led to comparisons with former years in this particular. It also recalls scenes and occurrences upon the icy bosom of the Rhine of the New World.

William D'Hertburn Washington, lately of West Virginia, now of New-York City, has in his veins more historic blood than any other American. Mr. Washington, who is still under thirty, has the unique distinction of being twice related on his father's side to the Father of His Country, once on his mother's side to the General, and once on his mother's side to Mrs. George Washington.

The credit of the Senate of the United States is so much more at stake than any other interest in the disposition of the nomination of Mr. Peckham that the delay in confirming the appointment has been almost as damaging as would have been a summary rejection. Nobody can really pretend to doubt the fitness of the candidate.

The election of a Congressman at Large in Pennsylvania has given an occasion to Mr. Reed, the leader of the Republicans in the House, to present the case of his party in a somewhat less formal and restrained manner than that he adopted in his recent speech on the Tariff Reform bill.

The Stability Board having reported that several of our new vessels, as at present constructed and armed, are topheavy and unsafe, it has been decided to change the armament of some and the plans of other vessels. Most of these changes will be made at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. A valuable but expensive lesson is to be learned by our navy from this experience.

There are a great many cook books published, but none that has a reputation better than that of the Martha Washington Cook Book, an old, standard, and reliable book of receipts which have been largely added to recently and are now several hundred in number. The objection made to most receipt books is that they contain receipts which are difficult to follow or involve considerable expense.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 10. -- The yachtsmen of Boston and vicinity are already looking ahead for next season's racing. The need of an agreement on racing dates by the local clubs was necessary, and now the Massachusetts Yacht Club has started a movement for a conference of the Regatta Committees of the clubs with that end in view.

From The St. Louis Globe Democrat. "President Abraham Lincoln and Gen. Joe Shields, who married sisters, once arranged to fight a duel at Alton," said L.F. Taylor of that place, at the Laclede. "It is remembered yet by the old settlers. Shields had offended a young lady at Springfield, and she got even by sending an article about it to a Springfield paper, signing a nom de plume.

"Dr. Hoftmann of Frankfort, the author of 'Shock-Headed Peter,' one of the most famous of child's books in the world, is now eighty-three. The Pall Mall Gazette says the doctor had no idea of publishing the book when he prepared it. He had been searching high and low for a suitable picture book for his little boy of nearly three years of age.

Corporal James Tanner is rapidly recovering, at the Methodist Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn, from the recent operation on has legless stumps. Dr. George R. Fowler, chief of the surgical staff, and other physicians who assisted at the operation are surprised at the extraordinary vitality of the patient.

It Is quite likely that the bill introduced by Assemblyman Wieman of Kings County permitting the sale of liquors and the opening of side doors of saloons on Sunday and the duplicate bill introduced by Senator Owens in the Senate will meet with considerable opposition.

There are no works more realistic than those which Lewis Carroll writes, with the care, the love, and the fidelity of an artist to whom men, women, and scenes of nature are not merely pretexts for symphonies in color.

HALIFAX, N.S., Feb. 10. -- A telegram from London says that the shareholders of the Windsor and Annapolis Railway yesterday sanctioned and confirmed the purchase of the Yarmouth and Annapolis Railway. This railway, eighty-seven miles long, was formerly known as the Western Counties.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10. -- A swindling scheme which has been worked in various parts of New-England was exposed here to-day. Two Italians giving the names of Carilla Brothers, bought a large quantity of goods for their alleged Haverhill (Mass.) store from Murray Brothers of this city. The articles were shipped, but inquiry revealed the fact that no such firm existed, but that the goods had been shipped from Haverhill back to New-Haven.

Policeman Weidersheim or the West Forty-seventh Street Station found a small boy in knickerbockers at Fifty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue early yesterday and took him to Police Headquarters. He was there recognized as Philip Lynch, seven years old, who was found homeless at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue last Sunday morning.

Maxime du Camp. Maxime du Camp died in Paris Friday. He was the son of a famous surgeon, and, unlike Gautler, Flaubert, and others of his friends among the Romanticists, he made his entrance into his literary career by the brightest of golden gates.

Two hundred bright women, alumnae of Vassar College, sat down to luncheon in the salon of the Hotel Brunswick yesterday afternoon. The members of the general association were the guests of the New-York Branch.

"Boss"McLaughlin and his lieutenants of Brooklyn are trying to make political capital out of the fact that Mayor Schieren's Commissioner of City Works, Alfred T. White, is discharging idle and useless supernumeraries in his department.

The collection of revenue from land is a matter of prime importance to the Government of India. As five-sixths of the entire population of the country belongs to the agricultural class. It is clear that a study of the system by which this tax is brought into the public treasury must lead to some acquaintance with the customs and social life of the people.

In the little village of By, a quarter of an hour's drive through the woods from the railway station at Moret, Rosa Bonheur has buried herself for years, forgetful of and fleeing from the world, devoting herself entirely to her work.

William J. McCall, George C. Germain, and George Ford have brought an action in the Supreme Court, through their attorney, John B. Clark, against Peter M. Arthur, as President of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers' Mutual Life Insurance Association, for an injunction to restrain the company from carrying on business in this State.

If it be true that want is the parent of work, the converse is also true, that comfort begets idleness. Adam Smith notes the complaint, common in his day, as in our own, that workmen are discontented, are everywhere stirring to improve their condition, and to attain to a higher standard of food, clothing, and housing.

Wheat continued Its erratic course yesterday, and touched a new record. The openng price. Influenced by the covering of short contracts, was 65% cents per bushel, an advance of 1/4 cent above Friday's closing. This Impulse carried the price to 66 cents, but no higher. Selling orders seemed to be met there, and without much resistance quotations dropped to 65 1-1C cents, the lowest on record.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10. -- The Republican Councilman and Aldermen are under a cloud. Last Tuesday night the two boards met in joint convention and elected Peter Carberry, the Democratic nominee, Sealer of Weights and Measures. As there were thirty Republicans and twenty-eight Democrats and the Democratic nominee had a majority of two, it was evident that two Republican traitors were in the camp.

The New-York Exchange for Women's Work, which has been doing good work for several years by enabling women of genteel families in reduced circumstances to earn a living, will have a sale of fancy and useful articles at reduced prices, beginning on Monday, at the Exchange rooms, 329 Fifth Avenue.

The trial of John Y. McKane for conspiring with the Election Inspectors of Gravesend to hide the registration lists rounded out its third week in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, with the main testimony not all in.

The Putnam editions of the writings of the men who are commonly referred to as the Fathers of the Republic are to be succeeded now by a series of volumes devoted to a writer who, if not commonly included among the Fathers, in many ways was quite worthy to bear company with Jefferson, Hamilton, Franklin, and Washington.
BOSTON, Feb. 10. -- The employes of the Atlantic Works, at East Boston, have received the following notice, signed by the General Manager:

A compromise dinner dress planned by an ingenious woman whose weak lungs prevented her from wearing a decolletee gown was of black satin. A fur hem bordered the plain full skirt, and a line of shallow scallops outlined In silver sequins was set on a little above. The yoke and full sleeves were of white chiffon spangled with, silver and the satin waist was outlined around the corsage and over the shoulders with sequins.

The grain movement in the West and the cotton movement in the South form two of the most interesting of the many peculiar phases of the railroad situation in this country. According to figures collected and published by The Financial Chronicle, the cotton movement has operated to enlarge the revenues of certain roads in the South.
The Association of the Medical Officers of the National Guard and Naval Militia of the State of New-York was formed Wednesday, in the armory of the Tenth Battalion, Albany.

Joseph E. Paisley of this city, who caused the arrest a few days ago of Humphrey B. Chamberlin, a promoter from Colorado, is now sorry that he was so hasty. He charged Mr. Chamberlin with fraud and swindling, and obtained an order for his arrest from Justice Lawrence of the Supreme Court.

It is seldom that a concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra fails to offer something that is suggestive. The entertainment of last Thursday night, to be sure, compelled some reflections not wholly complimentary to the conductor. It may be that he has what seem to him to be sufficient reasons for infusing an element of popularity into his programmes, and no doubt he is prepared for the inevitable comment.

There are a number of people, mostly mariners, who accept the tide tables prepared by the Naval Hydrographic Office as something to swear by. To the sailorman these tables are what the almanac is to the farmer or the funny paragraphers.

A journey to the oldest settlement in Virginia is not usual in February, and yet it is doubtful if it is possible to appreciate the difficulties with which the early colonists contended if one visits the scene when it is clothed in the garb of a Southern Summer.

One gloomy, sultry day in early Fall I entered an elevated train to go from one end of the metropolis to the other. A long distance, else I should not have spent so large a part of my scanty means; but I was feeble from sickness, and, besides, men will always venture what they have, be it great or small, in the hope of getting more.

The most startling happening in the military field during the last week has been the resignation, of Col. John N. Partridge of the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn. Col. Partridge's action has been expected for months. He said one one year ago that this would be his last year In the National Guard.

Primitive observers never suspected anything so commonplace as the presence of eggs in the middle of the ball the beetle had made; that sort of explanation belongs only to the age of science. The Egyptians saw the beetle bury the pellet, and they saw a new beetle emerge from it in due time, and they leaped straight to the not unnatural conclusion that here was a case of spontaneous generation.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Feb. 10 -- P.M. Rarely, even in midsummer, is business on the Stock Exchange so light as it was today. The total transactions were only 56,144 shares, and in only one stock, Sugar, did the trading exceed 10,000 shares. The fluctuations in Sugar were within a point, and were made by professional traders.

John Garner, in the Lee Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday said he had been arrested in front of a saloon at 79 Harrison Avenue for sucking a lemon in the presence of a German street band. Daniel Schneider, leader of the band, related a tale, however, which put the sourvisaged lemon in the background.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. LONDON, Feb. 10. -- There are many signs that the country is on the eve of a great constitutional crisis. The question of abolishing the House of Lords has become acute, and it now depends upon the action of the Cabinet meeting to be held on Tuesday whether or not the continuance of the upper house shall be discussed in the first plank of the National Liberal Federation's platform.

In an editorial discussion of the wool schedules of the Wilson Tariff bill The Tribune falls into the error of linking together the Democrats and Populists. The election of November, 1890, is referred to as the remarkable victory of these two parties in such a way as to imply that their associations are close and their aims practically identical.

A Democrat or a statistical turn of mind, who has been examining the figures of the recent election for Congressman in the Fifteenth District of this city, has found out that the Democrats actually gained ground in that election, instead of losing it.

ARKANSAS CITY, Kan., Feb. 7. -- Congressman Wheeler says that the Indian Territory must be omitted from any Oklahoma Statehood scheme. He thinks that the treaties made with the Five Civilized Tribes just at the close of the war will stop the pending negotiations looking to the allotment of lands. If this is true, it would necessitate new and modified treaties with the Cherokees, Choctaws, Chickasaws, Creeks, and Seminoles.

From The St. Louis Globe-Democrat. The Rev. T.J. Shelton, a clergyman of Little Rock, has introduced a new feature in preaching. It is the art of making the organist do the praying and the principal part of the preaching. A large congregation turned out last night to hear him preach on "The Law of Vibrations." Miss Nona Wiedeman, an accomplished musician, presided at the organ.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 10. -- Congressman Wilson of West Virginia did not speak here to-night, nor did he partake of a banquet provided at the Midland Hotel by local Democrats. A tremendous audience was disappointed in consequence. At 7 o'clock tonight Dr. Porter, a local physician, positively forbade Mr. Wilson to leave his room.

Obituary Notes. -- George G. Herman, who for six years was County Clerk of King's County and for twelve years was Secretary of the Democratic General Committee, died at his home, 177 Pork Place, Brooklyn, yesterday, alter an illness of several months. At one time Mr. Herman was in the newspaper business in Brooklyn. He also served as a Civil Service Commisisoner during Mayor Whitney's administration.-

Eight hundred and sixty-eight deaths, 1,006 births, and 464 marriages were reported at the Bureau of Vital Statistics of the Health Department during the week ending at noon yesterday. The death rate in an estimated population of 1,931,914 was 23,44. Of the deaths, 550 occurred in tenement houses and 207 in public institutions; 350 were of children under five years and 109 of persons sixty-five and over.

Coquelin sat at the table in his apartment, which is vast as the hall of a Louvre. He was writing a letter for the morning's mail to Jean, his son, and one could read its varied phases in his eyes. Some of these were serious, others gay, many were solemnly sententious.

In accordance with the desires of a lot of New-York business men, Messrs. J.E. Keelyn and Bisland of the Western Telephone Construction Company came to New-York early last week for the purpose of demonstrating the operation of the new Strombey magnetotelephone on the lines between Chicago and New-York.
The Twenty-third Regiment, the crack military organization of Brooklyn, was commanded for the last time, last evening, by Col. John N. Partridge, who retires from the regiment to-morrow.

Walter Edward Norris, a clerk in the General Post Office, was arrested yesterday as he was about to leave the office charged with the theft of many letters from the mails, some of them containing money.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- Outside of Reading, Baltimore Traction, and St. Paul, there was practically no business done. Not a share of Northern Pacific, common or preferred, Philadelphia Traction, or New-York and New-England was traded in, and only two shares of Lehigh Valley were sold. It looks now as though what had been called bear lies on Baltimore Traction were only too true.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $7,337,778, of which amount $1,992,848 was in dry goods, and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $111,778, and the exports of specie were $1,589,574.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Ever since Secretary Carlisle appeared before the House Judiciary Committee in explanation of the reasons for the issue of new bonds, there has been more or less discussion among the lawyers of the House as to the legal strength of the Secretary's position.

The Bostonians will present at the Broadway Theatre to-morrow night their new comic opera, "The Ogallallas." It is based on the familiar story of the relations between the American scout and the warlike Indians of the far West before the reservation system came into existence. The Mexican, the-old-time-cruel ally of the red man, also figures in the opera and gives color to the story.

MONTREAL, Feb. 10. -- The skating races between Johnson, Norseng, and several other cracks, which took place here this afternoon in connection with the Montreal Snowshoe Club races, proved disappointing, owing to the soft weather. A heavy thaw set in last night, and the ice was in very bad condition, and fast time was practically impossible.

BOSTON, Feb. 10. -- It may have passed out of the public view, but it is, nevertheless, a fact, that, notwithstanding the expiration of the Bell Telephone patents, the United States Government 13 still taking testimony, as it has been for four years past, to annul the Bell patent, on the claim that Drawbaugh and not Alexander Graham Bell was the original inventor of the telephone.

TACOMA, Washington, Feb. 10. -- Samuel Collyer, ex-cashier of the suspended Merchants' National Bank, was arrested today on an indictment found against him by the county Grand Jury, which charges that he received $309.70 the day before the bank closed and issued a draft therefor on the Chase National Bank, New-York, knowing at the time that the draft was worthless. He gave $1,000 bonds for his appearance.

The counsel for John Y. McKane, the Sunday school Superintendent of the Methodist church in Sheepshead Bay, has been striving to obtain evidence to demonstrate that Mr. Gaynor's copyists who went to Coney Island and Gravesend the Saturday night preceding the election were drunk, and their testimony, consequently, is not reliable.

The public records during the past week show up well for Brooklyn, realty. There were during the period 317 conveyances recorded, for $878,012 of property, besides 146 in which the consideration was nominal. For the corresponding week, last year 310 conveyances, for $1,006,522 were recorded and 122 for nominal consideration.

Mrs. Josephine Holmes of 244 Adelphi Street, Brooklyn, reported to Police Superintendent Campbell two weeks ago that her husband, Charles S. Holmes, had abducted her daughter Helen. Yesterday she notified Mr. Campbell that she had regained possession of her child. Mr. Holmes is at the Hotel Regent, on Clinton Avenue.

A desultory and enormous reader of plays and novels, with an impish humor and a facility and felicity of quotation which never deserted him under the most terrific circumstances. Tone's style is throughout literary, and in that sense artificial; but he had a passion for facts and a healthy determination to see things as they really were. He is perfectly free from every kind of illusion, delusion, and humbug.

Listen to the tale of a cloak. It begins in one of the big Sixth Avenue shops, the cloak and the tale alike. Here enters a woman who buys the cloak and pays for it $15. She takes it home, and, after the manner of her kind, becomes dissatisfied with it. It was unbecoming, and, as the day after its purchase was very cold, it was also too light in weight.

Abstinence from hurtful things in eating and in drinking is the first of these attributes, and it cannot easily be overvalued. The trainer knows this fact in all cases where he is preparing his pupils for actual contests. In some points trainers differ, but there is a point on which those whose opinion is worth any value do not differ.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As The New-York Times has always been foremost among American newspapers in the exposition of the iniquities of the Russian Government toward its oppressed subjects, especially in its persecutions of the Jews, I send you the translation of a document sent to me, which throws a striking light upon another branch of that Government's pernicious activity, the "Russification" of the Baltic provinces.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The ceaseless conflict between medieval and modern which mates all Europe its battlefield produces transformations as sudden as they are strange. For the past month the most gloomy apprehensions have been entertained in every quarter as to the likelihood of the new year bringing war in its train.

A contract for a seventy-nine-foot steam yacht, to be built by the Hereshoffs for a New-York yachtsman, who spends a great deal of his time in Montreal, has been signed. Mr, J.B. Herreshoff went to Quebec a few days ago and secured the contract. The new boat is to be a very handsome one, and to be built to go through the canals between New-York and Montreal via Lake Champlain.

Mayor Gilroy has chosen with tact and judgment the committee which he has invited to meet him at the City Hall tomorrow in order to confer as to the best means by which the well-to-do people of New-York can assist their less fortunate fellow-citizens in a season of very unusual, if not of unprecedented, destitution.

Feathers are peculiar to birds, and in their typical form have a shaft or stiff central rod fixed at one end into the skin and free at the other. From the two opposite sides of this shaft grow thin, flat plates, constituting the web or vane of the feather. This web, however, is not a simple, solid structure like a piece of paper, or even the leaf of a plant.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 10. -- One of the most extensive systems of wholesale robbery perpetrated in years has come to light among the clerks in the dry goods establishment of Shepard Co. Nearly two dozen clerks are implicated. Through the machinations of the ring, the firm has been relieved of thousands of dollars worth of goods and money.

Mlle. Anna Sophie Francoise Delphine de la Planche is Parisienne to the tips of her little boots. Why she went to Brittany can only be surmised. Probably she was tired of Paris for the nonce, and of M. Saintaine. who wanted to marry her. Her home was not a pleasant one, from the fact that her father was a mauvais sujet, and scarcely concealed his follies.

From The St. Louis Globe-Democrat. "I have had considerable experience in the somewhat unsatisfactory task of trying to educate Indians," said Bernard Denton of St. Paul. "There is a great deal of the humorous, as well as the discouraging in the work, but the most singular point I remember is the absolute gauge of an Indian's stage of civilization which the condition of the hair of his head provides.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 10. -- This city has been swept by a severe windstorm. Buildings shook, and everything loose was driven before the gale with threatening velocity. Reports from the surrounding country show that ruin is strewn in the path of the wind.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The dispatch from Constantinople published in The Temps of Paris and cabled to this country, stating that Mr. Terrell, the United States Minister to Turkey, has threatened to send an iron-clad to secure the enforcement of his demand for the release of two American citizens, of Armenian birth, imprisoned in Northern Syria, is not credited at the State Department.

Capt. Final of the steamship Hilary, which arrived from Pernambuco yesterday, reports everything quiet there on Jan. 24, the date of his departure. The cruiser Nictheroy, he said, was in port until Jan. 22, when she weighed anchor and stood out to sea, having in tow the old guardship Paranhyba, and three new torpedo boats which had just arrived from Hamburg.

From London Truth. An unusually perfect series of tableaux vivants was given last Tuesday and Wednesday at Bramshill, Sir Anthony Cope's house in Hampshire. The Duke and Duchess of Wellington, Lady Mary Mills, and Col. the Hon. F. Wellesley were among those who took part in the tableaus, and most effective representations were given of scenes from "Cymbeline," "Elaine," and "The Legend of the Mistletoe Bough."

The story of a woman with great powers of attraction who lives to make men unhappy is the author's theme in this volume. Anne Dalrymple, who has all the social advantages, should have married Hugh Forbes. Matters had gone so far that all the preliminaries had been arranged, when suddenly Anne threw Hugh Forbes over and went to Norway.

It may be of interest to society people to look over some copies of the invitations to New-York assemblies and other large functions as they were written fifty or sixty years ago. Mandeville Mower of 673 Lexington Avenue has in his possession some invitations sent to his father in the "thirties."

Most fashionable physicians have a specialty remedy, or bugaboo, which they advocate or Inveigle against perpetually. Sir Andrew, Clark led a crusade against tea; a New-York physician is as fierce against coffee, attributing to It the aggravation of every ill, from croup to gout. A well-known London doctor always ordered hot water with claret, another was fond of prescribing the hot water without the claret, and so on.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 10. -- A storm at Redondo this morning badly damaged shipping in the harbor. The schooner W. F. Jewett broke away from her anchorage and was wrecked. Her crew of ten narrowly escaped with their lives. Two fishermen lost their lives at Santa Monica. They went out in a small sloop, which was driven on the rocks and dashed to pieces.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- A nervous and apprehensive feeling was the marked feature of trade in wheat to-day. May sold down to 60c. It was expected that this price would bring out numerous and large stop orders, but, on the contrary, it seemed to develop new buying. Over 300,000 bushels were sold at 60c, yet that figure was bid all the time.

This romance, published without the name of the author, excites curiosity for its boldness and for occasional crossing of the line which divides the good from the bad. It may be taken as an outcry against those conservative methods which separate man and woman. For heroine it has Jessamine Halliday, the London reigning beauty.

The death is announced in Paris of Pierre Jules Cavelier, one of the most eminent French sculptors of the century. He was born Aug. 30, 1814. His father was a designer of bronzes, silverware and furniture. His teachers were David d'Angers and Paul Delaroche. At twenty-two he obtained the second grand Rome premium, at twenty-eight the first prize for a figure of Diomede capturing the Palladium.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 10. -- On the last day of 1893 the Louisiana Lottery, as a chartered corporation of this State, died. Nominally this blotch on the State has been removed from the United States to carry on its disreputable work and exert its baleful influences in one of the Central American States.

A very common error made in natural histories where this fish is mentioned is that it does not fly. "Its supposed flight is nothing more than a prolonged leap; it cannot deviate from a straight line, and cannot rise a second time without entering the water." This, briefly, is the sort of thing one meets with in textbooks where reference is made to this fish.
Moorish fretwork, or Moorish grille, is one of the very best things that the East has given us, and we are indebted to it for many, many comforts and almost innumerable decorative hints.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- Considerable light was thrown on the peculiar business of a "transportation agent" in a case which was dismissed in the Superior Court to-day. It was the action of Hallis J. Parks against the Jacob Dold Packing Company to collect a year's salary and $2,000 damages for wrongful dismissal from the employ of the defendant.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, Feb. 10. -- The commercial treaty with Russia was finally signed to-day. The North German Gazette, in announcing the fact, proceeds to comment on a line implying that the treaty is an offensive and defensive alliance. In the Ministerial circle the treaty is taken for what it is worth -- that it assists to prevent, but does not deter, war.

"Of course you remember," said Ponce de Leon, the well-known trainer of lions and Users for business or sporting purposes, with a deprecating smile, "that near the close of the nineteenth century the markets of the world were glutted with wheat. It was cheaper then than for many years."

In these beautiful volumes are gathered those numbers of Harper's Magazine which have been published during the year that closed with last November. They show us, as the succeeding numbers could not do, what are the varied resources of this magazine, what the extraordinary variety of topics treated, what the wealth of illustrations that a single year's subscription brings to its readers.

"Delighted to see you again. Sir," exclaimed the learned barber of the east side when the reporter for The New-York Times, attracted by the soft notes of a violin, crossed the threshold of the "tonsorial salon" last Friday afternoon.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 10. -- The second informal dance of the season was held at the Park Club Monday night. The patronesses were Mrs. Henry A. McGee, Mrs. George W. Rogers, Mrs. Samuel St. J. Mccutchen, and Mrs. Walter McGee.

Boxing bouts, good, bad, and indifferent, were witnessed in the Grand Central Palace last night. The majority were of the latter order, but here and there an occasional scientific and hard-hitting contest was witnessed. It was the second night of the Columbia Athletic Club's tournament, and the building was comfortably filled with lovers of the manly art.

PERNAMBUCO, Brazil, Jan. 13. -- After leaving New-York the work of organization on board the Brazilian cruiser America, was taken up by the executive, and every man and officer was given his station at "all hands" and "general quarters." Few drills were attempted on the way down until the ship anchored at St. Thomas. Here the America joined the Nictheroy.

Lieut. Gov. Sheehan was at the Hoffman House yesterday. Several members of the Senate, including Messrs. Coggeshall, Robertson, and Donaldson, were at the Hotel Metropole. It appears that the Lieutenant Governor took advantage of a fact which some of the Republican Senators did not think of when, on Friday, with apparent graciousness, he consented to allow the Buffalo repeal bills to come up in the Senate on Tuesday.

William Virtue, twenty-two years old, who is also known as H.C. Boyd, is a prisoner at Police Headquarters, having been arrested at his home, 49 Charles Street, by Central Office detectives, charged with complicity in the theft of a trunk containing diamonds and jewelry from the baggage room of the Boston and Maine Railroad at Springfield.
When Park Row was crowded with pedestrians at noon yesterday considerable excitement was caused by an arrest made at the corner of that thoroughfare and Beekman Street.
The ball of the Cercle Francais de l'Harmonie is called French -- and wicked -- but it is neither a ball, nor French, nor wicked.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- The great inter-city whist match between 100 players from Brooklyn and 100 of Philadelphia was commenced here last evening at 8:20 o'clock at the Continental Hotel. Mr. Robert Weems, President of the Brooklyn Inter-club Whist League, presided. The players were:

The power of spontaneous regulation of the temperature resides in a mechanism whereby more or less blood is sent to the skin as a result of relaxation or of contraction of its blood vessels. When the skin is hearted its vessels relax and contain a surplus of blood, which, if exposed to ordinary external influences, rapidly becomes cooler.

The question or graduated taxation is merely one of further regulating the capitalist by limiting his results as well as his processes. How much is it possible and how much is it prudent to take back from the capitalist's acquisitions? These are the only questions worth spending time upon. The possibility is very much a tax collector's question.
The following letter has been received from Dr. William G. Le Boutillier, who has just resigned from, the Medical Board of Visitors to the charitable institutions of the city:

Should curiosity be directed toward Mr. St. George Mivart because of his peculiar theories as to the advantages of hell, for which his work has beeen listed on the Index Expurgatorius by the Roman Catholic Church, such curiosity would find nothing to awaken it in the volume under notice. As its title indicates, it is a work, thorough of its kind, intended to be used as an introduction to the elements of science.

Seven hundred and fifty Brooklyn members of the Order of Germania, the German benefit association of that city, met in Teutonia Hall. Harrison and Tompkins Avenue, Friday evening, and resolved to secede from the parent order. Lodges 5, 6, 7, 9, 13, 15, 16, 22, 25, 28, 34, 40, 51, and 59 resolved unanimously to reorganize as an independent benefit association.

ROME, Feb. 10. -- The trial of Pinto, the grain merchant; Chauvet, manager of the Popolo Romano, and Gallina, a Treasury Inspector, for defrauding the Government of 225,000 lire has been continued daily since it began on Wednesday. To-day Chauvet caused a sensation by telling how Italia del Popolo, a Radical journal in Milan, had blackmailed him.

While John B. Milholland was putting Thomas C. Platt's new Republican machine upon exhibition at the Cooper Institute Friday night, Mr. Platt himself was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel giving an interview to his organ, attacking ex-Judge Horace Russell.

BOSTON, Feb. 10. -- The last game of the Boston series of balk-line billiards was played to-night in Bumstead Hall. The contestants were George Slosson, who defeated Schaefer in Wednesday night's game, and Frank Ives, who was so ingloriously downed last night by the Wizard. The hall was well filled, but it was noticed that the attendance was not made up of so many club and professional men as assembled to see the Schaefer-Ives match.

The Rev. Henry L. Ziegenfuss, Archdeacon of Dutchess and rector of Christ Church, Poughkeepsie, N.Y., who died at Vassar Hospital in that city last Thursday night, was a close personal friend of Bishop Potter of New-York, and was the author of "What Constitutes a Lawful Ministry," a book which has circulation among ecclesiastics of all churches.

Alexander Fullerton lectured upon "The Spirit of the Age" before the H.P.B. Theosophical Society, 142 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, last evening. The speaker portrayed medieval life, then the revival of literature, and the spirit of reason which brought relief from superstition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Secretary Carlisle's trip down the Potomac River, while taken for a well-earned rest, will not be entirely devoted to that purpose. With Assistant Secretary Hamlin, who accompanied him, he will go over the sections in the administrative part of the Tariff bill as it was adopted by the House, with the view to making such improvements as actual and practical enforcement of the tariff laws suggest.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- The new catalogue of the Summer School will be out some time during the present week. By a comparison of the attendance for the last few Summers it would seem that this feature of the university curriculum is growing more and more popular each year, and that it will ultimately develop into a fourth term of the collegiate year.

When Hannah Knuth of 1,804 Third Avenue, who is a comely young woman, was arraigned yesterday in the Harlem Police Court, at the instance of Malwiene Italiener of 2,026 1/2 First Avenue, she was fortified with a story that put the complainant at a disadvantage.

During the latter part of Mayor Boody's administration the credit of the City of Brooklyn was so poor that Controller Corwin found it almost impossible to sell the city's bonds above par. In many cases there was no bid for the bonds placed on sale.

There is a bill before the House of Representatives to repeal the law authorizing the President to appoint army officers as Indian agents. We know of no good reason for its passage, and experience confirms the inference that those familiar with the work drew beforehand that army officers could do the very best service in the agencies.

The foreign exchange market was dull, generally firm, and almost destitute of feature. Posted rates for sterling on Saturday were $4.85 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done on Saturday at $4.84 1/2@$4.84 3/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 3/4@$4.87 for demand, $4.87@ $4.87 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.83 3/4@$4.84 for commercial.

The Rev. Patrick V. McDonald, assistant pastor of St. Paul's Church, at Court and Congress Streets, Brooklyn, brought the services at the 10 o'clock mass yesterday morning to an abrupt and startling close by twice knocking down his superior, the Rev. William J. Hill, on the altar steps, and kicking him as he lay prostrate on the floor.
A dispatch from Baltimore, received Saturday, says, in regard to Dr. J.D. Kremien, who was arrested there several days ago on a charge of forgery, that he will probably be tried for murder.

LINCOLN, Ill. Feb. 11. -- Ida Spells and Georgia Williams, who were arrested here, confessed yesterday that they were parties to a conspiracy to blow up the county jail with dynamite. The arrangements were made, the girls say, to pass the dynamite into the jail by the aid of a string to be let down from the inside by Arthur D. Good-pasture, a prisoner.

The fourth concert of the Philharmonic Society, which took place Saturday night at Music Hall, was an entertainment of serious artistic interest. This seems to be a repetition of a very old saying:, for the Philharmonic concerts are always worthy of thoughtful consideration. For the second time this season, however, the conscript fathers of music gave the public an important novelty.

None of the literature of the Brazilian insurrection has been more diverting than that portion of it contributed by Ruy Barbosa. The personal courage of Barbosa has been questioned, but his prowess with the pen makes up for his want of it with the sword. Night or day, this warrior stands ready to imbrue his hands in ink for the furtherance of the insurgent cause.

Many names are suggested to fill the vacancy made by Dr. Drisler as Dean of the School of Arts. Among them are those of Prof. J.H. Van Amringe, H.T. Peck, and N.M. Butler. Dr. Drisler's resignation has not yet been accepted, nor will it be until a meeting of the Trustees, in the near future, it having been referred to a special committee.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Feb. 12 -- A.M. The stock market was by no means active last week, and the fluctuations were narrow. Events which will undoubtedly have important influences on the future have taken place, but the market did not reflect them.

If it had not been for the presence or mind of Mrs. William Freer and her husband and the bravery of Policeman Oscar Gates of the One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street Police Station, the occupants of a tenement house in One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, would undoubtedly have perished in a fire that occurred early yesterday morning.
Mrs. Annie Pope, wife of William P. Pope, who disappeared from her home, 1,104 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, Friday evening, is still missing. Mr. Pope is a manufacturer in Centre Street, New-York.

BOSTON, Feb. 11. -- Some brilliant work was done at the fifth annual indoor handicap games of the Boston Athletic Association which were held in Mechanics' Hall last evening. There were nearly 400 entries, and the list was remarkable for the large number of good men it included. New-York and New-Jersey had men in line, and Worcester, Yale, Williams, Harvard, Phillips, Andover, and other colleges were well represented.

The Princess Evelyne Galatro Colonna, stepdaughter of J.W. Mackay, the California millionaire, arrived yesterday from Southampton on board the American Line steamship New-York. She was accompanied by her three children and J.W. Mackay, Jr. The voyagers were met on the pier by Mr. Mackay and his business partner, Mr. Ward.

Dr. Stanton Colt, head or the University Settlement in this city, lectured yesterday before the Society of Ethical Culture on "The Moral Apathy of the People and How to Overcome It." He took the place of Prof. Felix Adler, and was listened to by a large and appreciative audience.

The candidates for the Columbia College track athletic team began training last Tuesday at the gymnasium. L.M. Lawson, Jr., '95, is Captain of the team. Very little can be said about the quality of the men just at present. More vim and spirit are needed, but these can only be obtained by hearty support and encouragement from the students of the university.
In his amazing and amusing speech at Philadelphia the other day, Mr. Reed, referring to the scattering State elections which were lost by the Democrats last Fall, said:

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- A workingman upset a lamp at 10 o'clock this morning in Vilmorin Andrieux's seed store in the Rue de Reuilly. The store caught fire, but firemen put out the flames before they reached any of the large receptacles of oil kept in the building. The firemen afterward went through the building to ascertain whether any sparks had been left.

Robert Fulford, husband of the late Annie Pixley, and who is just now prominent on account of a series of allegations which have been made against him by a New-York newspaper, was a passenger by the steamship New-York, which yesterday arrived from Southampton.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 11. -- The Republican County Committee held a stormy session at the Federal Clubhouse. Willow Avenue, last night. The trouble dates from the last primary election, when Alonzo Sturgis, a Police Sergeant of the sanitary squad, charged that the election of William Calhoun and John T. Evans was procured by the aid of Democratic voters who had no right to take part in the election.

An old feud between John Welsh, a bricklayer of 331 East Thirty-ninth Street, and Vincent Day, a laborer of 332 Bast Thirty-sixth Street, became eruptive Saturday night, when, each having caroused, they met in a saloon at Twenty-seventh Street and First Avenue.

The Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage has said that he intended to resign as pastor of the Brooklyn Tabernacle at the completion of his twenty-fifth year in the service of that church. Henry Eyre Browne, the Tabernacle organist, has followed his example and advertised in the newspapers that he is open for a church engagement.

Ex-Attorney General Charles J.M. Gwinn died at Baltimore yesterday of grip after a ten days illness. Mr. Gwinn has for a great many years been the political adviser of Senator German, and stood closer to him probably than any other man.

More than the usual number of sales of real estate at auction are set down for today. All are in legal proceedings, and the sales are consequently to be held at 111 Broadway. Business property, dwellings, and flats figure in the list which is given herewith:
