The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed a decrease in reserve of $25,989,300. The banks now hold $85,633,700 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans of $13,054,500, a decrease in specie of $21,759,200, a decrease in legal tenders of $8,638,100, a decrease in deposits of $17,632,000, and a decrease in circulation of $180,300.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- The "Black Horse Cavalry" began, mustering in force last week, and on Friday the word was quietly passed that a raid was in contemplation for some day the coming week. It has been three years since this famous and historical band of legislative freebooters has been allowed to do business in Albany.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 11. -- Capt. Crittenden of the schooner Mabel Leighton, which arrived from the Western Banks today, brings tidings of the loss of the schooner Robert J. Edwards. He says that Jan. 21, at 4 P.M., when he was in latitude 42 degrees 30 minutes, longitude 65 degrees 5 minutes, a carrier pigeon flew on board with a flat ring on its right leg, marked "H, 119."

With the co-operation of eleven of the students of the Union Theological Seminary, the Riverside Association visited Saturday 288 of the 937 families reported in need of assistance by the police census in the Twenty-fourth Precinct, which includes the territory between Fifty-ninth and Eighty-sixth Streets, west of Central Park.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 11. -- Charles Hughes has purchased from R. Tucker the bay colt Winfleld, three years old, by Blazo S., dam Loraine Nelson. Price, $12,000.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 11. -- The main building of the Colt Firearms Works was destroyed by fire this afternoon. This building was 350 feet long, and connected what was known as the east and west armories. The east armory was on fire several times, but the Fire Department managed by hard work to save it.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 11. -- The bitter war between influential citizens of the Oranges and the Consolidated Traction Company is being pushed on all sides. The big mass meeting to protest against the granting of further franchises to the company without proper compensation therefor held last week seems to have had but little effect upon the Aldermen, who, with six exceptions, will vote to pass the ordnance granting the Central Avenue franchise tomorrow night.

Frank B. Baldwin, one of the oldest trotting horsemen in the country, is in the city. He came on from Buffalo a week ago in charge of the consignment of trotting stock from the breeding farm of the late Gerhard Lang, which was sold at the American Institute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Representative Seth W. Cobb of St. Louis, after a visit to the White House, represents the President as still complaining earnestly of the demands made upon his time by the office seekers.

It is probable that within a short time all the public business in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards will be transacted under one roof. Since the new school building at One Hundred and Sixty-first Street was opened, the old Melrose schoolhouse has been vacant. It is proposed by the Property Owners' Association of the Twenty-third Ward to centralize the public business in the old school building.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- The local security market showed considerably more animation this week, and, with one or two exceptions, an improvement in prices is noted. Securities which, had been firmly held for some months past in anticipation of higher prices were easily disposed of. The greatest improvement was made in the bond market. Sales of Albany County Bank and Manufacturers' Bank of Troy were made at ruling quotations.

The attempt of Thomas C. Platt to break in two the Republican Party in this city by his open and bitter revolt against the regular organization has caused Republicans from many parts of the State to line themselves up in a way that promises to lengthen the breach from one end of the State to the other.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Feb. 12. -- Poundmaster James Moloney, while walking down West Eighth Street, at 10:15 o'clock last night, heard cries of "Help!" He discovered the front of a small dwelling on the rear of the lot at 59 in flames. The house was only 20 feet square, and had a door and one window in the front.

A dispatch was published yesterday stating that Samuel Collyer, ex-cashier of the suspended Merchants' National Bank of Tacoma, Washington, was arrested Saturday on an indictment found against him by the County Grand Jury, which charged that he had received $309.70 the day before the bank closed, and issued a draft therefor on the Chase National Bank of this city, knowing at the time that the draft was worthless.

Copyright. 1894. by the United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 9, via Montevideo, Feb. 12. -- The insurgent fleet attacked Armacao at 8 o'clock last evening, and continued the fight until daybreak. The insurgents landed troops and destroyed the beach and hilltop forts of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Forty years ago the United States played a very important part in the foreign commerce of the Argentine Republic. At present it has no importance so far as the commercial relations of the latter country are concerned, for Scarely 8 per cent, of its foreign trade is with the Republic.
Rabbi Silverman, in Temple Emanu-El, yesterday morning, preached on "The Mistakes of Ingersoll About Moses." It was the first of a series of se which will be delivered fortnightly.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11. -- Dr. Jay W. Seaver, associate director of the Yale gymnasium, has just introduced into his list of muscular-measurement apparatus a machine which he thinks will entirely revolutionize the method and results of measurements.

Andrew H. Green has written a letter to the Commissioners appointed to choose a site for a Municipal Building. Mr. Green urges the Commissioners not to remove the present City Hall, with which so many historic memories are associated.

What is said to be the first sermon in Gaelic ever heard in New-York was delivered yesterday afternoon in the Fourth Presbyterian Church, in Thirty-fourth Street, near Broadway. The preacher was the Rev. A.C. MacDonald of the Queen Street Free Church, Inverness, Scotland. A great many persons assembled to hear the sermon.

From The Augusta Chronicle, Feb. 8. Mr. Richard H. Edmonds, editor and general manager of the Baltimore Manufacturers' Record, and one of the best, if not the best, authority in the country on Southern statistics and development, has written a letter to the Hon. Patrick Walsh, general manager of the Southern Associated Press, in which he says:

The McKane case will start upon its fourth week to-day. It may not be finished this week, as was anticipated. The defense expects to finish its direct examination today, but it may take up part of Tuesday. Then the prosecution will require at least a day and a half to put in evidence in rebuttal. Thursday, the defense will put in evidence in surrebuttal.
It was neither a "dry" Sunday nor a "wet" Sunday in Brooklyn yesterday. As one saloon keeper remarked, it was "a medium one." Some of the saloons were closed up tightly and others were open.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11. -- The Faculty of Arts and Sciences has just adopted new regulations covering the requirements for honors in modern languages. Honors in this department are given in two branches, either for study of the Germanic languages and literature, or of the Romance languages and literature, the former including English, German, and kindred tongues, and the latter French, Italian, and Spanish.

At 11:15 o'clock last night it was just nine hours and forty-five minutes since William Holland, a sixteen-year-old newsboy, had drawn a natural breath. But in all that time his heart had not ceased to beat.

PANAMA, Feb. 3. -- Many rumors have been current here relative to the progress of the negotiations to reorganize the Panama Canal, but none has been officially confirmed, although there is a strong belief that work will be resumed before the end of the concession, in October.

The Larchmont Yacht Club will hold its annual meeting on Thursday, Feb. 22, when the officers for the year will be elected. Had Commodore Caldwell H. Colt lived he would have been renominated for the position of senior flag officer of the club. Mr. Seymour L. Husted, Jr., has been nominated for that position, and his flagship will be the old schooner Crusader.

The Rev. Thomas McElween, pastor of the Congregational Church of North New-York, One Hundred and Forty-third Street and Willis Avenue, preached yesterday morning on the evils of saloons, theatres, and card playing. The most effective way of getting rid of evil, he said, was to crowd it out with good.

Copyright. 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- The banquet at the Russian Embassy last evening is bound to provide food for reflection in all the capitals of the Continent, Count Schouvaloff, Russian Ambassador to Germany, took advantage of the occasion to speak warmly of the commercial entente just accomplished, and to add a few words pointing to a further understanding between Russia and Germany in the interest of the peace of Europe.

"Not even standing room" might have been the triumphant announcement at Niblo's Theatre last night, so large was the audience that came from the First Assembly District in response to an appeal from the managers of the Tammany Hall Relief Fund for means to relieve the poor of the First, Second, Third, and Fifth Wards, and so much of the Eighth Ward as lies south of Canal Street.

Now that John I. Davenport has lost the lucrative post of Chief Supervisor of Elections and been deprived of the delightful pastime of locking up scores of Democrats on election days until the closing of the polls, great interest is manifested in the question, What will become of the Iron Cage?

At the rate of one baptism every thirty-one and a half seconds forty colored converts were baptized yesterday in the Mount Olivet Baptist Church, at 161 West Fifty-third Street, by the pastor, the Rev. Daniel W. Wisher. It took the Rev. Mr. Wisher just twenty-one minutes to immerse the two score converts.

Mr. W.B. Hess, late United States Consul at Constantinople, Turkey, who has just returned from that city, was seen at the Metropolitan Hotel yesterday. He said that since last September all Armenians who had returned from this country to Turkey had not been allowed to land or had been turned out of the empire as soon after landing as possible.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11. -- It has been definitely decided that there will be no debate between Yale and Princeton this year. Committees from the two colleges met in New-York about Thanksgiving time, but no definite plan could be settled upon. Since that time the one question in all the negotiations has been the disagreement as to second speeches.

The annual reunion and dinner of the graduates of the old Fifth Street School, known as the "Old Boys," was held Saturday night at Clark's, 22 West Twenty-third Street. To Counselor A.W. Moynihan fell the task of securing a full representation of the graduates, and he was repaid by seeing nearly all the "Old Boys" gathered around the punch bowl, telling of their trials and tribulations when they were young boys.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- The Tenth Separate Company yesterday received and entertained the Albany Burgesses Corps, which was returning home from New-Orleans and Atlanta. Mayor Lawson extended the freedom of the city. Major Woodward responded. Gen. Joseph B. Carr and Chaplain Duff also spoke.

For the last two or three seasons, W.D. Grand has held periodical sales of selected harness and saddle horses at the American Horse Exchange, corner of Broadway and Fiftieth Street. Mr. Grand's connection with Western and Canadian stock raisers has enabled him from time to time to offer at public auction just the type of horse most suitable for the park, the riding school, or the road.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- "If the Democrats had forty-five votes in the Senate we should have a tariff bill much better than that the Finance Committee will report." That was the declaration to-day of a strong low-tariff member of the Senate, who does not expect to see a radical bill reported, or a bill without free wool, or any bill that will differ in substance from the Wilson bill as it passed the House.

The assignment of Capt. H.C. Taylor, an officer of marked ability and high standing, to the Presidency of the Naval War College at Newport, and the instructions given him to prepare a course for the next season, are sufficient indications of the interest which Secretary Herbert takes in this valuable institution.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11. -- On Monday the baseball season will actually begin. The fielders are to be called out, and preliminary practice for the positions will be started. In order that Capt. Wiggin may have a chance to know the probable material for the nine and to remedy defects.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Feb. 11. -- A fire which originated in the grocery store and saloon of John Hinsch, 142 Middleburgh Avenue, shortly after midnight last night, destroyed ten buildings. The fire was discovered by Thomas Riley, who gave the alarm. The occupants of the house hurried out in their night clothing.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 11. -- The Bonacum trial, which has been holding the boards since last Tuesday, was concluded yesterday with the charges aginst Bishop Bonacum dismissed. It has been a trial probably without a precedent, and has been as bitterly fought as any in the court records of this county.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 11. -- The eighth annual convention of the New-England Intercollegiate Athletic Association was held at the Quincy House yesterday. There were seventeen delegates present, representing nine New-England colleges, as follows: Amherst, Bowdoin, Brown, Dartmouth, Trinity, Wesleyan, Williams, Worcester Polytechnic Institute, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

It is remarked that the Prince of Wales has been singularly moderate in the use of his princely prerogative of setting the fashion to the males of the English-speaking world. His granduncle, both as Prince Regent and as monarch, was, as Thackeray has recalled, of an inventive and innovating turn of mind.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- Comparing the returns of trust companies in New-York and Brooklyn for 1893 with the returns for the year before, the figures of last year show a most gratifying improvement. Two more companies reported for 1893 than there were in operation in 1892, but the returns of these cut but a small figure in the large total of profits.

Assistant District Attorney Vernon M. Davis appeared before Justice Barrett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning, and asked permission to submit to another Grand Jury the facts in the case against the Directors of the Madison Square Bank on the charge of participating in fraudulent insolvency.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- In the following tables showing the dividends and profits of the big New-York and Brooklyn trust companies it should be understood that the figures for 1892 are only for six months of that year, and for purposes of comparison with the figures for 1893 should be doubled in each case on the supposition that the returns for the second six months of 1892 eaualed those for the first six months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The naval civil engineers, hitherto little heard, from, are after a chiefship of a bureau in the Navy Department. The position is now occupied by Commodore N.H. Farquhar, and the bureau is that of Yards and Docks, an important branch of the department, now that the Government is building large docks and equipping the navy yards with electric plants.

Upon the proclamation of Mayor Gilroy issued last week urgently calling for additional aid for the unemployed of this city and appointing a committee of nineteen prominent citizens to receive and distribute the fund, the members of that committee met in the Mayor's office at noon yesterday and signalized the beginning of their work by raising among themselves the sum of $60,000.

There was a rumor yesterday that Augustus St. Gaudens, the sculptor, would take active steps to bring the criminal law to bear against the officers of the Page Belting Company of Concord, N.H., who bad copied, without authority, his accepted design for the Columbian medals. The United States law relating to the unlawful making of Columbian medals reads as follows:

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- A meeting of the Cabinet was held at the official residence of Mr. Gladstone in Downing Street to-day, prior to the reassembling of the House of Commons. It is stated that Mr. Gladstone proposes to drop the Parish Councils bill and the Employers' Liability bill, and to make an appeal to the country within a month.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- The worst blizzard which has come to Chicago in twenty-three years has been raging here to-day. Street traffic has been greatly impeded, and walking has been accompanied with great danger to life and limb. Many persons have been injured by being blown to the ground and against walks and street posts.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- To-day, Lincoln's birthday, was observed as a holiday, and the Exchanges were closed.

Benjamin and Harry Stein, fourteen and ten years old respectively, whose home is at 257 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street, were arraigned before Justice Simms in the Harlem Police Court yesterday, charged with being incorrigible and about to run away from home. When they were taken into custody the older boy had a pistol, two tickets for a Bowery theatre, and paper and pencils in his pockets.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- A. peculiar feature of the storm that has been raging for two days in England is the destruction wrought among the churches. At Teighnmouth, in Devonshire, a church in course of erection was entirely destroyed. The spire of St. Mary's Church at Shrewsbury, County of Salop, was blown down.

The annual meeting of the Pequod Club, the Tammany organization of the Thirteenth Assembly District, was held last night in the clubhouse, 267 West Twenty-fifth Street, and the following officers were elected:

William A. Miles, the President of the Croton Brewing Company, at 55 to 59 Chrystie Street, was killed by a fall shortly before noon yesterday. He fell from the cooling room of the brewery to the ground floor, a distance of almost fifty feet.

Old John O'Brien, who was for many years a clerk in the City Court, and who was perhaps the best-known of all the old-time city employes, has made his last bet. He had several wagers that he would outlive certain well-known men, and he won all of the bets but the last one. He retired many years ago, but his mind was still bright and his memory clear when death overtook him.
The following strange story of the commitment to an insane asylum of a distinguished Syrian traveler for the purpose of getting possession of his valuables is told by N.J. Arbeely of 45 Pearl Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- If the friends of John L. Stevens, late Minister of the United States to Hawaii, believed that his connection with the Hawaiian annexation scheme was to receive no more serious condemnation in the Senate than had been bestowed upon it, they were sadly disappointed to-day when Mr. Gray took the exMinister in hand.

The Rev. James W. Putnam, formerly assistant pastor of the Tabernacle Baptist Church, 162 Second Avenue, gained a decided victory yesterday at the meeting of the Council of the Baptist Churches of the Southern Baptist Association of New-York over the Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter, the pastor of the church, the acrimonious antagonisms between whom and Mr. Putnam attracted much attention several months ago.

That able-bodied storm which the Weather Bureau had been predicting for the past two or three days made its unwelcome appearance here yesterday. According to the same prophets, it is likely to remain for some little time. It is too big, too comprehensive, to pass quickly.

The second of Mr. Platt's series of interviews on the organization of the Republicans of this city, together with the echo sounded by Mr. Hackett, Chairman of the party's State Executive Committee, opens up a view of the "boss's " calculations of the future. It is evident that he does not propose to have the fight that has been started here confined to the city, but is preparing to carry it through the State.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 12. -- Business is picking up in the cotton and woolen mills of Worcester County. Last September 462 sets of woolen machinery were idle in the county. These, when running, gave employment to 10,000 operatives, whose monthly wages aggregated $400,000. Now every cotton, mill in the county is running, and only 154 sets of woolen machinery are idle and only about 3,000 hands are now out of work.

Mr. Frank Gilsey has traded the apartment house known as the Scarboro Mansions, 221 "West Fifty-seventh Street, north side, 150 feet east of Broad-way, for Hogan Slattery, with John W. Condit, for the two four-story high-stoop brownstone dwellings 31 and 33 West Twenty-fourth Street, north side, between Broadway and Sixth Avenue.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- The suspicion that William O. Brodhead's death, which occurred in January, was not due to natural causes, and the demand of Mrs. Mary J. Redden of Greenbush that the body be exhumed and an autopsy performed, has created no little excitement at East Durham, where the death occurred.
MONTEVIDEO, Feb. 12. -- A dispatch dated at Rio Janeiro on Feb. 9 says:

Wheat was moderately active, and lost 1 1/2@1 8/4c, with May reaching the lowest price yet, or 63 9-16c, and local longs free sellers, with considerable hammering by bears, amount in passage increased, and Chicago closed for the day.

MAPIMI, Mexico, Feb. 12. -- Malvern W. Cresworth, an English mining man, well known throughout Southwest Mexico, arrived here yesterday from a long overland journey through the Sierra Madre Mountains, his starting point being Culican, near the Pacific coast, in the State of Sinaloa.

The assault on the Rev. William J. Hill by the Rev. Patrick V. McDonald in front of the altar in St. Paul's Church. Court and Congress Streets, Brooklyn, Sunday morning, may lead to a police investigation.

John B. Lamont. John B. Lamont, father of the Secretary of War, for many years an honored and respected citizen of Cortland County, N.Y., died at his home, in McGrawville, Sunday night, at the age of sixty-eight years eight months and one day. Mr. Lamont was of Scotch descent.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad, which is part of the Pennsylvania system was held to-day. Secretary Vanzandt read the annual report of the Directors, which showed that the cost of operating the road in 1893 was 69.5 per cent., against 71.2 per cent. in the preceding year.

Congressman Cummings's report on the Holman resolution and on the resulting investigation completely refutes and wrecks the theory of collusion between naval officials and ship constructors to secure an undue bonus for the latter in the trial speeds of the new vessels. That very heavy premiums have been paid is true.

John Carlin, a bookbinder at 48 Broad Street, remained at his place of business last night to finish some work. Because he did so, his stock was set afire, and three alarms were sounded. Mr. Carlin occupies a part of the fourth floor, with P.G. Wilmarth, shirt manufacturer, and William Ward, a priner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Postmaster Charles W. Dayton of New-York reached the city to-night and went to the Shoreham, where he met Postmaster Carr of Philadelphia. The two are here in accordance with an arrangement whereby they will appear to-morrow before the House Committee on Post Office and Post Roads to argue in behalf of direct appropriations to the large Post Offices of the country.

When Charles Bathgate Beck, the millionaire and philanthropist, died last October, it was found that by a will drawn on Nov. 6, 1891, he had left the greater portion of his five-million-dollar estate to Dr. Parkhurst's society, Columbia College, the Board of Home Missions, and the New-York and Presbyterian Hospitals.

The Commandant, officers, and privates of the Rochambeau Grenadiers are now combined into one man, whose name is not Legion, like that of the demon mentioned in the Gospels, but it is almost as awe-inspiring. His name is Napoleon.

More than 400 ladies and gentlemen came to Cuickering Hall last night to attend a meeting of the American Geographical Society and hear William Libbey, Jr., Professor of Physical Geography at Princeton College, lecture on "The Hawaiian Islands."

A valuable and exhaustive treatise upon the question, "What shall we do with those turbulent lunatics called cranks? " was presented last evening to the Society of Medcal Jurisprudence, 17 West Forty-third Street, by Dr. London Carter Gray, Professor of Nervous and Mental Diseases of the New-York Polyclinic.
LISBON, Feb. 12. -- The British, steamer Iberia, from South American ports, arrived here to-day. She sailed from Rio de Janeiro Jan. 28, and brings advices to that date.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- There is a prevailing impression in Washington to-night that Mr. Hill is not so sanguine of his ability to prevent the confirmation of Wheeler H. Peckham as he was a few days ago. This is due largely to the action of the Senate Judiciary Committee to-day in deciding to report Mr. Peckham's nomination to the Senate without recommendation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Minister Mendonca vehemently characterizes as sheer nonsense the latest dispatches from Buenos Ayres and Montevideo, indicating considerable insurgent gains in the southern States of Brazil, and declares, with great emphasis, that the Government is everywhere stronger than ever.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- Transactions in Reading constituted most of the business of the day. Next was St. Paul, with less than 5,000 shares, and no other listed stock reached 1,000 shares. As St. Paul was scarce, some of the shorts started in to cover, but afterward seemed to put out their line again.

John Foord was appointed by Mayor Gilroy yesterday an examiner in the Civil Service Board In place of Henry W. Beardsley, who was forced to resign on account of his connection with the Lucy McCarthy blackmail case.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 12. -- The Legislature is still struggling with the question of a new assessment. There has not been a general assessment of the property of the State for twenty years, and the need of it has been the demand of the voters in many campaigns. Twice bills have been passed and vetoed, and each time the Democratic Party has suffered and the managers are afraid to risk a third disappointment.

The proceedings in the Broadway Theatre last evening must have given rise in the minds of the judicious to surprise and regret. The company known as the Bostonians has earned for Itself a wide and valuable reputation as an operetta organization of singular excellence. It is necessary, however, that a company, in order to preserve its popularity, should, keep itself provided with the best of material in the way of libretti and music.

In that very farcical tragedy, or tragical farce, the trial of McKane, a great deal of testimony has been elicited that is highly comic, or profoundly melancholy, according to the reader's point of view. Nothing has gone further in this way, in either of these ways, than the testimony that was given yesterday, ostensibly in favor of McKane, by Mr. Herman B. Scharmann.

The Manufacturers' Record of Baltimore speaks of a railroad "deal" by which grain shipments from the Chicago and Northwestern system, which have heretofore come to New-York, are to be diverted over the "Big Four" and Chesapeake and Ohio lines for export from Newport News.
A general meeting of horse owners with whom originated the scheme for the creation of the Turf Club is called for 4:30 o'clock at the Hoffman House this afternoon.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Reports of the following roads for the quarter ended Dec. 31 have been filed with the State Railroad Commission:
Over 360 Republicans assembled last night at Deimonico's at the eighth annual dinner given by the Republican Club of the City of New-York in honor of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Worry and anxiety over tHe shipwrecked men of the Kearsarge ended this morning at 10:45 o'clock. All day yesterday Secretary Herbert waited for the dispatch that would tell the fate of Admiral Stanton and his officers and crew, but no message came. When the Secretary went to bed at an early hour this morning the expected telegram had not appeared, and he hurried to the any information had beeen received there.
Mr. Louis Windmueller wrote as follows to Senator D.W. Voorhees on Saturday on the administration of the Custom House and the merits of the ad valorem system:

From The London Economist, Feb. 3. We have obtained from a legal correspondent in New-York the following opinion as to the way in which American railway bondholders may best protect their rights when a default occurs in payment of interest. And with the advice he tenders we entirely concur:

The Princess Evelyne di Galatro Colonna, who arrived on Sunday from Southampton on the American Line steamship New-York, having recently left Paris with her three children to escape from her husband, has effectually concealed her whereabouts in this city. Her stepfather, J.W. Mackay, who met her upon her arrival here and escorted her to the Waldorf, where she breakfasted with him and her children on Sunday morning, declined yesterday to state where she is staying.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Feb. 12 -- P.M. The tendency of prices to-day was downward, although trading was very light. The holiday in Chicago may have had something to do with the restricted volume of business, but that centre has been doing very little recently in this market. The industrials were exceptionally quiet, Sugar being the only one at all active.

BOSTON, Feb. 12. -- Local stocks were very dull. The tone was rather mixed, though the general tendency was downward. There was a small sale of Boston United Gas 5s at 83. Mexican Central 4s were up 1 point, to 50. American Bell Telephone sold, in odd lots, at 170 1/2, and New-England Telephone at 50, both the same as Saturday's close.

A new four-act drama, by William C. Hudson, entitled "A Man Among Men," was successfully produced last night at the Bijou Theatre, in Brooklyn. The play turns on the rivalry of several investors for possession of a valuable iron mine in the Adirondack region. Prof. Olyphant, mineralogist of the Round Top Mining and Smelting Company, has discovered the value of the ore deposit, and secretly invested his fortune in the mine.
Before the case of Howe vs. Woodruff is ended there may be a sensational airing of the affairs of the Megantic Fish and Game Club, of which many wealthy citizens of New-York and Boston are members.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- Mrs. Harriet Morrison of Jackson, Mich., a wealthy widow of seventy-four years, accompanied by Charles Helling, the husband of her adopted daughter, and Dr. Blanchard, the family physician, presented themselves at the United States Mint this morning with two heavy bars of metal, which they supposed to be gold and worth $30,000.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L. I., Feb. 12. -- Insurance agents representing 30 per cent, of the risks placed in this city appeared at a special meeting of the Fire and Water Boards this afternoon. They stated that they had been instructed by the insurance companies represented by them to cancel all policies in force in this city unless positive assurance was received from the authorities that the fire service and water supply would be increased.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Feb. 12. -- The bill to provide for the establishment of a national currency and for the circulation and redemption thereof on the plan devised by H. Osterberg of New-York, was introduced into the House to-day by Gen. Tracey. The bill was referred to the Committee on Banking and Currency.

-- Eden Musee. -- Mlle. Tortajadada introduced a new Spanish performance at Eden Music Last evening. Her Andalusian costumes were, gorgeous, and the singing of her troupe of troubadours surpassed that heard in any preceding performance. The Spanish woman has been re-engaged for a term of several weeks by the management. Lolo Yberri gave her two most admired dances, the fan dance, and new dance of the ruses.

Pallid Pierrot, with his broad lace collar and innocent white jacket, which experience, alas! so soon turns black, succeeded, on the stage at Abbey's Theatre last night, the masterful personality of the great Coquelin. Mr. deary's company of pantomimists have returned from their travels with ranks unbroken and are for two weeks to present again Carre's exquisite fable "L. Enfant Prodlgue."

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Dennis O'Hearn, the sailor from the piratical " black sloop" Sarah, is still locked up in the county jail at White Plains. The sloop is fast aground on the rocks off Milton Point, two miles from here, and is rapidly going to pieces. Nothing has been heard from the Captain of the sloop, who came ashore with O'Hearn Saturday night, and is supposed to have gone to New-York.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 12. -- Richard Croker in an interview says that, in the language of Gen. Hancock, the tariff is simply a local issue, and he thinks it is unfortunate that Democratic Congressmen are not allowed to vote for protection when necessary to the interests of their districts. He fears that the removal of the sugar tax will lose Louisiana to the Democratic Party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- A big storm was predicted for to-night on the Atlantic seaboard. Acting on information received by the Weather Bureau, and on a forecast made there, the Secretary of Agriculture sent out dispatches to-day, warning ship Captains through Maritime Exchanges and other maritime bodies, that it would be dangerous for vessels to leave port to-day, owing to the expected storm.
The Professional Woman's League held a secret session yesterday, and for four long-hours battled with the problem of its first annual election.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 12. -- The Lincoln Association gave its twenty-ninth annual banquet this evening at the Hotel Washington. The storm delayed many of the guests, but it did not keep them away. The President of the association, Asa W. Dickinson, presided. United States Senator George F. Hoar of Massachusetts sat at his right, and Gen. Henry L. Burnett of New-York at his left.

In the trial of John Y. McKane, in the Brooklyn Court of Over and Terminer, for conspiring to hide the registration lists, the defense closed its evidence yesterday and the prosecution put in most of its rebuttal. To-day the remaining evidence on both sides will be put before the jury.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- The Ledger, in its editorial columns to-day,

Thomas C. Platt's vindictiveness is having full play, now that he is out in the open at last. As shown in his interview published yesterday, he is taking great pleasure in criticising those prominent Republicans who refuse to wear his collar, and he is stirring up all the animosity he possibly can.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- Edeon Breton, twenty-three years old, threw a bomb in the cafe of the Hotel Terminus, at the St. Lozare railway station, this evening. The bomb exploded in the middle of the room and wounded twenty persons.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 12. -- The Dr. Kremien case grows in interest, and The New-York Times of this morning has abided greatly to the interest by us interview with Assistant District Attorney McIntyre of New-York City. The suspicion of Mr. McIntyre that Kremien is Bradt is not indorsed by the police officials here.

After careful consideration, the Richmond Terminal Reorganization Committee has determined to make some important modifications in its plan of financial readjustment. Certain changes have been found to be feasible because of the action of some of the floating debt creditors in consenting to accept part of their pay in securities, instead of demanding the whole amounts in cash.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 12. -- The roughest snowstorm since the blizzard of 1888 prevails to-night along the Great South Beach, east of Fire Island. It is accompanied by hall. The wind is east of north and the waves are running high. The roaring of the sea is plainly heard in Patchogue, seven, miles distant from the shore.

A mysterious escape took place yesterday morning in Madison Square Garden. The prisoner who gained his liberty was a fine frill-back pigeon, one of the star birds of the Poultry Show. How he got out of his cage in the north gallery the vigilant keepers on his particular tier were unable to explain.

Mr. Croaker in "The Good-Natured Man" explains that one of the advantages of a foreboding disposition is that when real trouble comes one is prepared to take it philosophically. Similarly, when we are duly warned of impending visitations, we often find them, when they arrive, easier to bear than the agony of doubt which preceded them.

The reporting to the Senate of the nomination of Mr. Peckham is a triumph for public decency against Senatorial intrigue. The triumph would be signal and decisive if every Senator were compelled to take the responsibility of his vote, and the "advice and consent" of the Senate were exercised in public.

Prof. Charles Stirk, the man who was alleged to have swindled Mrs. Marie Latapie of 999 Sixth Avenue some weeks ago, was again remanded in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for further examination. The charge against him is of passing a worthless check drawn on the Fifth National Bank, purporting to bear the signature of D.F. Alexander, a Trustee of Princeton College, in which institution Stirk said he was a professor.

The annual meeting of the Atlantic Yacht Club was held last night at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn. The majority of the Atlantic yachtsmen are not fair-weather yachtsmen, and consequently there was a large attendance, in spite of the big storm. Vice Commodore Philip G. Sanford occupied the chair, in the absence of Commodore Banks.

PARIS, Feb. 13. -- The Government is determined to stop the pilgrimages that are being made to Vaillant's grave in Ivry Cemetery. An order has been issued forbidding any one to visit the grave, and policemen have been stationed at the cemetery to see that the order is carried out.

Another exhibition to show the progress made by the pupils of Nelson Wheatcroft's Empire Theatre Dramatic School was given in that playhouse yesterday afternoon. If was an "invitation" performance, and the audience, naturally, was very friendly to the students. Among those who closely watched their work were Daniel Frohman, manager of the Lyceum Theatre; William H. Crane, George Backus of the Crane company.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- When the non-partisan Election Inspectors' bill came up in Committee of the Whole in the Senate today. Senator O'Connor offered his amendments, which were agreed to. Senator Stapleton, (Rep., Madison,) for the purpose of placing himself on record, moved to strike out those sections of the bill which make it applicable to towns, so as to have it applicable to cities only.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- As a result of the report received at the Post Office Department to-day from Inspector Dice, who was instructed, to investigate the legality of the Honduras Lottery Company in its relations with the Postal Service, the Postmaster General this afternoon issued what are known as "fraud" orders against Paul Conrad, President of the National Honduras Lottery Company, the Graham Printery, and L. Graham Sons.
Four thousand members of the feathered tribe bade a boisterous farewell to Madison Square Garden last night, when the New-York Poultry and Pigeon Association wound up its fifth annual exhibition.

Strong influences have been invoked to undertake a reorganization of the New-York and New-England Railroad on a practical business basis. Holders of a large amount of the company's securities have requested John I. Waterbury, President of the Manhattan Trust Company; H.W. Cannon, President of the Chase National Bank, and T. Jefferson Coolidge, Jr., President of the Old Colony Trust Company in Boston, to take the work in hand.

On account of the absence of Mr. Starin in the country, and the fact that the pad weather confined Mr. Steinway to his house, the Rapid-Transit Commission adjourned yesterday without doing any business.

New-Yorkers arose yesterday morning to find their city mantled under 14 inches of snow. All night the flakes came skurrying down, alternating at times with fierce squalls of sleet, which stung the face like a volley of needles. Belated pedestrians struggled homeward, shivering in the wintry blasts, and exasperated car drivers steered their stumbling teams through the piling drifts and said things.

Ex-Civil Service Examiner Henry W. Beardsley, who is under indictment for obtaining money under false pretenses from Mrs. Lucy McCarthy, the proprietress of a disorderly house at 104 West Forty-ninth Street, surrendered himself yesterday afternoon to the District Attorney.

During the month of January Just past the ravages from pneumonia have been appalling. In the City of New-York alone the deaths from the dread disease number more than 600, and Judging from recent telegraphic reports, we doubt not that the mortality has been correspondingly large in other parts of the country.

The action of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment at its meeting yesterday will contribute relief to some of the unemployed poor. Plans for work were considered which will give work to more than 4,000 men.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., Feb. 13. -- William and John Kennedy, attaches of the Beach View Hotel, had a terrible struggle for life while on their way to that place about midnight last night. The hotel is situated on a point about a mile below the village. The road crosses a marsh, and was exposed to the full force of the gale.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Mr. Bland manifested to-day some anxiety to come to a vote on the Seigniorage bill, and also a willingness to have his bill amended to remove any doubt about its effect upon the redemption of the Sherman act notes of 1890.

There was submitted to Justice Lawrence, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, yesterday the question, as to whether the assessment for 1891 of $1,000,000 upon the personal property which David Dows left by his will to his executors and trustees should be set aside. David Dows died in March, 1890, leaving an estate estimated to be worth $10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- There has been an earnest effort to-day on the part of many interested people to ascertain what progress the sub-committee of the Finance Committee of the Senate was making on the Tariff bill. All inquiries have proved fruitless, however, to discover anything definite.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 13. -- Reports received here to-day from Oklahoma and the Indian Territory, make it almost certain that at least thirty lives were lost in the great storm of Sunday. Many isolated homesteads, where the families were poorly prepared for the Winter, cannot be heard from for days, and possibly weeks, and there is reason to believe that many fatalities will be reported.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Feb. 13 -- P.M. A market dependent almost wholly upon local orders, emanating from the Stock Exchange or its vicinity, and without news to give it special impulse, is naturally confined within narrow limits as to prices as well as to the volume of sales.
The following plans for new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

Capt. James K. Price of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station and his precinct detectives. Alien Hay and Patrick Curry, have been called to account by Superintendent Byrnes for their extraordinary action in the case of the "Alhambra," an Eighth Avenue concert saloon which was raided by Inspector McAvoy, under orders from the Superintendent, on the night of Jan. 24, as a disorderly house.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 13. -- The Republican Senators were not in good humor today after their celebration of the anniversary of Lincoln's birthday. The Senate was no sooner in session than Senator Ketcham of Essex read from a type-written document a long statement on the conspiracy to steal the Senate of the State of New-Jersey.

The Woman's Art Club, numbering more than half a hundred members, has opened its annual exhibition this year at 7 West Twenty-eighth Street, Klackner's new gallery. The light is excellent, and, while the exhibit is not materially better than last year's, it makes a very creditable showing.

One of the gratifying signs of the day is the increasing cheerfulness with which the average Western railroad man discusses the business situation. A few weeks ago a thick cloud of gloom obscured the visions of nearly all the Presidents and managers of the Western roads.

GRAND HAVEN, Mich., Feb. 13. -- The Detroit, Grand Haven and Milwaukee steamer Roanoke arrived at her dock here about 11 o'clok last night after a battle of twenty-four hours with a sixty-mile hurricane on Lake Michigan. The Roanoke left Milwaukee Sunday night, and was out in all of the storm of Monday.

The skating races scheduled to take place at Red Bank yesterday were postponed, and will probably be held up the Hudson on Washington's Birthday. The change to Newburg will be a disapoplntment to many lovers of the sport in this city.

The immediate results of the conference of rich men called by the Mayor to devise ways and means for alleviating the prevailing distress were very gratifying. A very respectable nucleus was obtained at once for a fund that ought to be adequate even to the unprecedented situation.
CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 13. -- The case of Henry George against John T. Woodhull, in the Camden civil courts, was settled to-day.

SAUGERTIES, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- The Cantine Card Factory in this place, during the long depression in business, has been running on more than full time, and at present the night and day forces are unable to fill all the orders received by the company. The force of employes has recently been increased, and the business outlook is most promising.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 13. -- The annual encampment of the Department of Connecticut, G.A.R., will begin here to-morrow morning. The session will last two days. The statistics for the year just closed show a membership of 6,704 in the State. There are 72 posts, with relief funds amounting to $54,794.

Following the example of Col. George Bliss, Mr. Cornelius N. Bliss has perhaps injudiciously joined in the assault on Platt. In the course of his comments upon Mr. Platt's recent pronunciamento, Mr. Bliss says:

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- A report was circulated in Berlin to-day to the effect that the Hamburg-American Line steamer Augusta Victoria, Capt. Barends, from Hamburg for New-York, had foundered. Emperor William learned of the rumor, and sent a dispatch to Count von Hatzfeldt, the German Ambassador in London, asking if it was true.

Thomas C. Platt made no further move in Person yesterday in the war he is waging to prevent the Committee of Thirty from controlling the Republican machine in this city. Although Col. George Bliss has explained that the reason why the Union League Club made small campaign contributions was because it could not trust the expenditure of its money to Mr. Platt, that statement was allowed by Mr. Platt to go unanswered for the present.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- In answer to a resolution of Congress, Worthington C. Ford, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, Treasury Department, has sent to that body an elaborate report on "Wool and the Manufactures of Wool."

It seems to be a bad season for ballotbox stuffers in New-York City. Yesterday Dennis J. Buckley, the third of the batch of ward heelers recently indicted for election frauds committed last November, was found guilty in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge Barrett of permitting a repeater to vote.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

Breton, who has suddenly emerged from the friendly obscurity that enshrouds a bad waiter to the keen sunlight of publicity, is not quite worthy to be called an Anarchist. The distinction is of some importance. Vaillant was a real Anarchist, that is to say, a person who hates people in general with the intensity which ordinary criminals reserve for their private enemies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The Senate Committee on Pacific Railroads held a meeting this morning, at which the counsel of the Union Pacific were present and a representative of the Dutch holders of securities. The committee in New-York, which is considering the proposed reorganization of the Union Pacific system, desired that their counsel should come here to-day and go before the Senate committee and make a statement regarding the road and the proposed reorganization.
WASHINGTON Feb. 13. -- M. Patenotre, the French Ambassador, has issued invitations for a dinner party on Thursday evening.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- To-day's market was jumping from one important security to another and breaking prices.

What is known in Brooklyn as the Park Slope has been recently the scene of much activity in the way of real estate sales. Mr. John. Pullman reports the following sales in this locality during the past week:

PARIS, Feb. 13. -- The excitement occasioned by the bomb explosion at the cafe of the Hotel Terminus at the St. Lazare railway station last night, has not abated, and the outrage is the subject of discussion in all the public places. It has been ascertained definitely that at least twenty-four persons were hurt.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 13. -- Bishop Bonacum has received the following letter from Archbishop Satolli relative to the recent trial of the Bishop on a charge of criminal libel preferred by Father Corbett of Palmyra:
Capt. Patty Watkins was the subject of conversation in a little group of officers gathered in the headquarters of the Salvation Army, in Reade Street, yesterday morning.

BOSTON, Feb. 13. -- Boston's largest storm since Feb. 22 of last year is practically over. About seven inches of snow has fallen in the city, but seventy-five snow plows have kept the electric street car tracks fairly free, and the cars are running with only now and then an interruption.

At the reopening of the Reading investigation in Philadelphia yesterday, Mr. J. Lowber Welsh asked to be allowed to explain his answer that he did not request Mr. McLeod to retire from the Presidency of the Reading and also from the receivership. Mr. Welsh said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- A board appointed by the Secretary of the Navy, consisting of Commander Sperry of the Ordnance Bureau, Assistant Constructor Hibbs, and Assistant Engineer White, has about completed its examination of the models, plans, and specifications of Capt. Alexander McDougall of West Superior, Wis., which were submitted with a view of providing for an auxiliary naval force on the great lakes.

An interview reported to have been had with Mr. Richard Croker in Florida has been given to the public. It reads like a rather imperfect report of a not very thorough interview, in which Mr. Croker's opinions as to tariff legislation are pictured in a vague and somewhat contradictory fashion.

BOSTON, Feb. 13. -- The Treasurer of the Lamson Stores Service Company is reported as saying that the company's debt has been reduced to about $350,000, that expenses have been lessened, and that business is satisfactory; also that the company's general financial condition is better than for a long time. Undoubtedly there was room for improvement, and it will take more of the same to induce the general public to invest in the stock.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Secretary Morton expresses much gratification at the improved Weather Bureau Service, and among a number of other recent instances, cites the following:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13. -- Philadelphia has taken a much greater interest in the wheat market lately than for some time, and the traders came down town to-day with a very nervous feeling in regard to that staple. Such panics as they have had in it ended xesterday, and its strength today encouraged traders to take hold of the general market, which started out with good feeling.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Feb. 13. -- The town elections in Richmond County to-day resulted in a victory for the independent Democrats and Republicans in four of the five towns. The Muller "machine" ticket was successful only in the town of Middletown.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 13. -- Fire started this evening at 7 o'clock in the large brick building at 80 River Street, occupied by the Preston Oil Company, manufacturers of linseed oil, and in an incredibly short space of time the entire building was a mass of flames. The building had a frontage or 80 feet on River Street and ran back to the river.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- A formal order directing Commodore Kirkland to proceed to Honolulu by the steamer Australia, leaving San Francisco Feb. 17, was issued by the Navy Department to-day. Orders were also issued detailing Lieut. John A. H. Nichkels as Flag Lieutenant to Commodore Kirkland and Lieut. York E. Noel as his Secretary.

BUENOS AYRES, Feb. 13. -- Advices received here from Rio Janeiro are to the effect that the recent attack made by the insurgents in their attempt to capture Nictheroy, a report of which was contained in the United Press dispatches of last night, lasted for six hours. The insurgents' loss is placed at 200.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn, Bridge Trustee Keeney, Secretary Harry Beam, and Mayor Schieren's son were coming to New-York on a special car, on a trip of inspection of new lights in the cars on the Brooklyn Bridge, shortly before 8 o'clock last night.

The death is announced in Paris of Joseph Wetz, Vicomte de Rainneville, formerly Senator and Administrator of the Paris-Lyon-Mediterannee Railway. He was born at Allonge April 7, 1833. He was a Pontifical Zouave and served as aid de camp to Gen. Pimodan at the battle of Castelfidardo. In the defense of Paris during the war with Germany he commanded a battalion of volunteers of the Somme Department.

The story of a suit brought by Miss Sadie Bennett of Jamaica, L.I., against Jacob R. Shipherd and Arthur Sanders, two well-known lawyers who practice in this city, as published in a Jamaica paper, has called out a statement from Miss Bennett's uncle, Hewlett J. Norris of Richmond Hill. Mr. Norris, in a published card, says regarding his niece:
This cautionary signal has been displayed by the Charity Organization Society:

An interesting discussion on the school question took place last evening before the Nineteenth Century Club at Sherry's between, the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott of Plymouth Church and the Rev. Thomas McMillan of the Paulist Fathers in this city. A large and appreciative audience, including many of the prominent clergymen of New-York and Brooklyn, was present.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 13. -- A.R. Angers, Minister of Agriculture, has forwarded to the imperial authorities a long and interesting report on the Canadian export cattle trade. It will not be made public until it has reached the Colonial Office. It is learned, however, that the report goes to establish that there is no pleuro-pneumonia now, nor has there been any at any time since the controversy commenced in Canada.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Mr. Gray concluded to-day the speech he began yesterday on the Hawaiian situation. The galleries were crowded, and many Senators remained in their seats while be held the floor in order to listen to his argument. No more searching denunciation of the acts of ex-Minister Stevens in connection with the Hawaiian revolution has been heard.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Assemblyman Simon Seibert, the member of the Erie delegation who was offered by some unknown philanthropists "inducements" to secure the passage of the Buffalo Police bill in its amended form, said to the correspondent of The New-York Times to-night:

Among the miscellaneous assortment of prisoners ararigned in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday was a strikingly handsome woman. She wore a black silk skirt, a waist of "blue silk, and a plush mantle. She was a decided brunette, about twentyseven years old. A detective arrested her on Monday at the alleged "fence" shop, 42 Division Street.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb.,13. -- This was the second day of the Tattersalls sale, and another large crowd was present, but trotters went low, the forty-six head sold bringing less than $6,000. Best prices follow:

The notable increase in the receipts from internal revenue during the first ten days of this month is, so far as it goes, an encouraging symptom. It amounted to $546,407, and if this ratio could be kept up it would bring the total receipts within about $5,000,000 of those of the last fiscal year, whereas the falling off in the first half of the year was $12,000,000.

Rumor was busy yesterday around the District Attorney's office and the Court of General Sessions as to the object of the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst in appearing before the Grand Jury. Accompanied by Frank Moss, Stephen A. Deague, and half a dozen witnesses, Dr. Parkhurst arrived in the reception room at, 11 o'clock and remained until the Grand Jury adjourned at 1.

A special meeting of the Ladies' Health Protective Association was held yesterday morning at the home of Mrs. Esther Hermann, 59 West Fifty-sixth Street, to arrange about funds to pay the expenses of the members of the association who are working at Albany for the passage of the bill to have all stable refuse in New-York City pressed or baled.

ONEIDA, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- Madison County elects Republican Supervisors for all fourteen towns. In Oneida ex-Sheriff Charles E. Remick, the Hill leader in Madison, who was a candidate for Supervisor, was defeated, being badly knifed by the Dandelion Democrats.

The action of the Kolbite and Populist Conventions at Birmingham, Ala., last week wiped out all distinction between the organizations heretofore known in that State as the Jeffersonian Democracy and the People's Party, and the failure of the Republicans, who held a conference at the same time and place, to join them in a common opposition to the regular Democracy left the Kolb ticket as simply the ticket of the "third party."
The defense of John Y. McKane began with a confession of perjury by McKane.

For some time past lovers of grand opera in German have been talking about the performance of "Die Walkure" which was given at Music Hall last night. All kinds of pleasant expectations were raised. Those who have not heard the music drama at all since it was last performed in the Metropolitan Opera House were naturally eager to revel once more in the play of tremendous emotions voiced in Wagner's music.

WATERTOWN, Feb. 13. -- The severest blizzard known to this section in several years raged from 6 o'clock last night until noon to-day, bringing about two feet of light snow, which has drifted in some of the country roads so that they are temporarily impassable. Some of the branches of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad are blockaded.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The Treasury Department will begin business Wednesday, Feb. 14, with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:
PLYMOUTH, Penn., Feb. 13. -- An extensive cave-in occurred at the Gaylord Mine of the Kingston Coal Company, at this place, this morning.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 14. -- It has been decided to remove Miss May Barrowcliff from Warden Osborne's home in the City Hospital to the residence of Aqullla W. Wanmaker, 308 Magnolia Avenue, in a few days.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- The Buffalo Police Commission bill has finally passed the Senate. After six weeks of buffeting and drifting, it went through by a vote of 20 to 11, but the vote by no means tells the story of how nearly the machinations of the tricky Lieutenant Governor succeeded in having the bills sent back to the Assembly.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14. -- The will of Annie Pixley Fulford, the actress, who died in London, England, Nov. 9, was admitted to probate this morning, and letters testamentary were granted to Charles E. Morgan, Jr., and Morris P. Bockius, the executors. The document was executed June 17, 1890, and the executors are Philadelphia lawyers.

The people of this city, from the wealth-lest citizen to the humblest wage earner, are by no means daunted by the great problem of furnishing relief to all the poor deserving assistance. On the contrary, as the demands for charity become greater the responses are proportionately generous. Interest in the work is greater and more widespread than at any time since the necessity for relief became apparent.

The first course of lectures on Colonial history, under the auspices of the Colonial Dames of the State of New-York, was opened at Hardman Hall yesterday afternoon by Prof. John Fiske, whose subject was "Virginia in the Seventeenth Century."

There were 150 vacant chairs at 160 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. Yesterday afternoon, so far as the public was concerned, those chairs might still have been vacant. They were not, however, for 150 fair forms occupied them and 150 sweet voices made music in the room.
Not two, but three, factions of the Republican Party are now in the field in this city.

Sunday next The New-York Times will publish pictures of the medals and trophies presented by the paper at the different amateur contests last year, together with the winners. The prizes, all athletes say, surpassed by long odds those presented by clubs and associations, not alone as regards value, but in elegance of design.

The Tiffany Glass Company showed at the World's Fatr. In the Liberal Arts Building, a chapel fitted up with marble-inlaid altar, jeweled cross, and candlesticks covered with precious stones and brilliant glass gems. Behind the altar was a deep recess with concentric arches of inlaid stone and clustered columns treated with darkish mosaic.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 14. -- Within a few days a most peculiar political campaign will be begun in this State. The annual election for Governor, general officers, and members of the Legislature occurs on the first Wednesday in April, and there enters into the contest factors hitherto unknown in political contests here, and which have created a feeling of doubt and uncertainty among the old politicians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- There were plenty of fresh rumors afloat at the Capitol to-day concerning the intentions of the sub-committee of the Finance Committee at the Senate with regard to the Tariff bill.
LONG ISLAND CITY, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- Countess Theophila Kreamer's residence -- known as the Villa Escho, was burned to the ground with its contents at a late hour to-night.

At a special meeting of the Board of Education yesterday Commissioner Beneville, Chairman of the committee which was appointed to consider and report on a pension bill, presented the draft of an act which will be known as the Public School Teachers' Retirement Fund. The bill provides that the Board of Education shall control the fund, but that the Controller shall be the custodian of its money.
Congressman Daniel E. Sickles called at the Mayor's office yesterday to see Mayor Gilroy, who, however, was not in.

Emma L. King, astrologer, 142 East Fifty-third Street, was arraigned at the Yorkville Police Court yesterday by Detectives O'Donohue and Lang of the Twenty-third Precinct, and charged with fortune telling. Lang on Tuesday visited the woman, who was detected through her advertisement, and was first told the "little fortune."

The work of the Armenian revolutionists, to which we referred a few weeks since, is already bearing fruit. We may indeed question the absolute accuracy of news from Asia Minor that conies to us via Vienna and London. The story of 125 killed and 340 wounded at Yuzgat may be very heavily discounted, as may also most of the statements that come in that roundabout way.

There was joy in the Markowitz family last evening when a reporter for The New-York Times entered their rooms at 130 Willett Street and gave them $30 which kind-hearted readers of the paper had subscribed for them. Markowitz, who is a tailor, has not had work for over six months, and on Friday morning he was arrested for trying to steal a chicken from 875 Grand Street to feed his hungry family.

The annual meeting of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club was held last night at the offices of the Southern Express Company, on West Twenty-third Street. The Secretary reported that there were 167 members in the club and 95 yachts in the squadron. The Treasurer's report showed that the club was sound financially.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Leonardo Martho and Francisco Tucci, Italian laborers of 319 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, fought with razors early yesterday morning, and both were in very bad shape when a policeman stopped their duel. Martho was so weak from loss of blood that he was taken to the Harlem Hospital, but Tucci, although badly slashed, was able to be arraigned at the Harlem Police Court.

George A. Freeland and Frederick H. Davis, two young Bostonians who are believed to have committed two burglaries in that city, were arrested yesterday morning in Brooklyn and are held in the Adams Street Police Station until the arrival of Boston officers.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- The National Liberal Federation, which opened at Portsmouth yesterday, continued its session to-day. Resolutions were adopted declaring in favor of the one-man one-vote system, a reform, of the registration laws, the payment of members of the House of Commons, the holding of all Parliamentary elections on the same day, and direct popular control of liquor licenses.

At 3:30 o'clock yetserday afternoon the Jury in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer, where John Y. McKane had been on trial for conspiring to hide the Gravesend registry lists, retired to the jury room.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The Seigniorage bill was the sole topic of conversation today in the House, for there was a tilt between Messrs. Reed (Rep., Me.,) and Bland, (Dem., Mo.) During the delivery of a speech by Mr. Walker, (Rep., Mass.,) he was subjected to almost continual interruption, but was assured by his questioners that his time would be extended, which was done, after considerable discussion.

There has been nothing more wholesome and promising in the recent history of this city than the conviction and sentence of the violators of the election laws. The fact that Neville and Dunphy betrayed a particular trust, as Inspectors of Election, in addition to violating the duties of good citizenship and the statutes of the State, made them peculiarly appropriate subjects of punishment.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee this afternoon beagn the examination of the circumstances under which the injunction restraining Clerk Kenyon from calling the name of Henry Wolfert in the McCarty contested election case was granted, with the view of ascertaining whether the privileges of the Senate had been encroached upon.

BOSTON, Feb. 14. -- There was some trading in local securities to-day, but the fluctuations were not wide, and interest in the market was slight. Bell Telephone declined somewhat, selling once at 169 1/2, but later recovering to 170. The agitation of telephone matters in the State Legislature may partly be responsible for the weakness of stock.

When the Executive Committee of One Hundred of the New-York State Democracy convened for the first time last night, in the hall of the Reform Club, 1 East Twenty-seventh Street, about eighty of its members answered the roll call. The meeting was called to order by William F. Hull, Secretary of the organization.

Lieut. Gov. Sheehan does not cut a very graceful figure when he assumes a virtue which, his whole political career shows that he does not possess, and he becomes absolutely ridiculous when be makes a public exhibition of his sore skin and displays a whining sensitiveness to what he calls "sensational and baseless charges."

The large holders in the American Sugar Refining Company held to the programme yesterday which Wall Street has suspected would be followed by taking no interest in the annual meeting of the company in Jersey City, which had been adjourned to yesterday. About one month ago was the regular time for the meeting, but Mr. Havemeyer and his associates presented proxies instead of personal holdings, the amount falling short of a majority of the stock.

Coroner Kene of Brooklyn yesterday morning obtained an ante-mortem statement from Salvatore Labrano, the Italian who was shot on Tuesday night while standing In front of his residence, 86 Union Street, and who is in the Long Island College Hospital. Labrano says his assailant was Francisco Catherine, a Union Street grocer.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- There was a large attendance of labor organization men before the Assembly Committee on Codes this afternoon when the Scanlon bill legalizing boycotting came up for a hearing. Mr. Charles J. Bissell of Rochester, representing the Street Railway Association of the State, was the first speaker.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- Capt. John F. Luther, a jeweler in business at 143 Fulton Street, New-York, and his young son were seriously injured in a runaway accident to-night.

The Knickerbocker Bowling Club met yesterday afternoon at 212 West Forty-flrst Street and commenced the competition for the Knickerbocker Silver Cup and the Challenge Cup. The bowling lasted from 3 till 6 o'clock, and some good scores were made.

M'GRAWVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- The funeral of John B. Lament, father of Secretary of War Lament, took place to-day. Services were held at his late residence this afternoon, which were attended by persons from all over the county. The services were conducted by the Rev. Leslie R. Groves of Albany, formerly pastor of the Presbyterian Church of McGrawville.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The Speaker laid before the House to-day a communication from the Secretary of the Treasury relative to using the statue of Liberty Enlightening the World. In New-York Harbor, as a beacon, in which the cost of installing the statue, and its subsequent maintenance as a beacon for the seven years ending June 30, 1893, was shown to be $64,757 -- an average of $9,251 per year.

Isaac S. Fishel of the defunct firm of Fishel Brothers, cloak manufacturers in Greene Street, this city, came to New-York from his home in Boston yesterday morning to plead to a charge of grand larceny before Recorder Smyth, in Part II, of the General Sessions. At the request of District Attorney Fellows the case was adjourned for two weeks.

LITTLE FALLS, N. Y., Feb. 14. -- A posse of twelve citizens, led by Daniel Hooley and Constable J. B. Sadler, captured four burglars this morning, after chasing them four miles. The prisoners gave their names as Michael Wood, John Baker, Michael O'Donnell, and Robert McLean. McLean is known as "Slim Bob," and, with O'Donnell, divides his time between Albany and Troy.

Another one of Saint Valentine's days has passed into history. Nearly everyone knows that the 14th of February is dedicated to St. Valentine and to those persons who celebrate it by inflicting witless doggerel upon their fellow man. But very few seemed to be aware that yesterday was Saint Valentine's day, and many will remember it this morning with a pang of regret for wasted opportunities.

Last night the galleries of the Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, had another attraction for the artists and their friends who make Wednesday a special evening for attendance. An orchestra occupied the stairway in the Vanderbilt Gallery and pleased the ear while a review was taken of the pictures from the World's Fair, contributed by a triple alliance of Holland, Sweden, and Norway.

The officials of the North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club have determined to hold the championship races at Red Bank, N.J., if the ice is strong enough, on Feb. 22. They are naturally indignant at the report sent out by the person who wants the races at Newburg, to the effect that the ice yacht men failed to get a sufficient amount to guarantee the prizes.
Senator Henry Cabot Lodge contributes to the current issue of Harrier's Weekly on article on "The Republican Opportunity," upon which The Weekly makes in part the following editorial comment:
The West Side Relief Association, resurrected on Feb. 3 by "Henry King, Treasurer," its incorporator, was interred again yesterday by that individual.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- Controller Roberts has appointed James S. McPherson of Kingston, from the civil service eligible list, as clerk in the Corporation Tax Department, at $1,500 a year, to fill a vacancy, and has named Chauncey S. Titus of Albany as general clerk. Mr. McPherson is a lawyer. The Controller has also appointed John J. Merrill of Alfred Centre, Allegany County, as assistant clerk, at $1,500 per year.

The annual report of the Chamber of Commerce, now in preparation, abounds in statistics of trade and finance for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1893. They show that the total of foreign imports was $910,768,555, of which this port received $560,864,234 and all other ports in the United States $349,904,321.

There is an old maxim as to certain conditions under which honest men come to their dues that is more or less directly suggested by the remarks of the leaders of each of the Republican factions in this city regarding the other. The statement on the one hand that contributions to campaign funds have not been expended for the purposes for which they are given is, of course, a mere commonplace of politics.

This is a red-letter week at the Manhattan Chess Club. Eugene Delmar and Adolf Albin, the Vienna star, are playing a match of five games up, and a series of games is being contested by J.W. Showalter and A. B. Hodges. Besides, the Manhattan handicap is in progress.
An officer from the steamship George W. Clyde, which reached here from San Domingo yesterday, is said to have told a thrilling story of affairs in the island republic.

PARIS, Feb. 14. -- The Government version of the second fight between the French and English forces in Western Africa, near the Sierra Leone frontier, says that the trouble was due to the English invading French territory and attacking a village close to the French post of Benty. The French defended the village and repulsed the attacking party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Wheeler H. Peckham will be confirmed as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court before tomorrow night if the Democrats of the Senate do not choose to accept the dictation of Mr. Hill rather than the request of the President.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 14. -- Young women who had no use whatever for burned cork gave an excellent minstrel show tonight. The complexions of the performers were all of an ebon hue, because the minstrels were colored girls. The entertainment was given in aid of charity, and a crowded house listened to some old and some new jokes and songs that were very well rendered.
At a very spirited meeting of the Mohawk Democratic Club, 165 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, last night the club decided to secede from Tammany Hall. The following resolution was adopted:

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 14. -- The Ontario Legislature assembled this afternoon. Lieut. Gov. Kirkpatrick, in an address from the throne, said that, while the raising of grain crops and the growing of live stock were not so remunerative as formerly, yet, by reason of Improved quality, these products commanded higher prices than at any time in recent years.
Joseph F. Blaut, late President of the Madison Square Bank, was placed on trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Justice Barrett yesterday to answer a charge of perjury.

Reports have been in circulation within the past few days that the Vanderbilt interests in the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad have been increased by several thousand shares. Information comes from an apparently trustworthy source that Cornelius Vanderbilt recently bought a large block of the stock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- Wheat showed a firmer front to-day than it did yesterday. There was almost a total disappearance of the panicky feeling and nervous tone. The news, as a general thing, was of a more encouraging nature, and there was more of a disposition to take the long side, with an eyually strong desire on the part of shorts to take their profits.

An odd case at the Yorkville Police Court yesterday was that of Perrin Jeffrey, a conductor on the Brooklyn City Railroad, who was remanded by Justice Voorhis to permit of a complaint being made against him by Mrs. Mary C.C. Harden of 521 Madison Street, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Finding it impossible to defeat the regular Democratic organization in this county by fair means, the HillMurphy faction has made a deal with State Committeeman Barnes, who heads the feeble Republican contingent. The result of this combine was the rushing through the Assembly this morning of a non-partisan Election Inspectors bill.

The sale in the library or the Charity Organization Society of a collection of antique and mediaeval gems worth $17,000 has been more brisk since the prices in the catalogue were reduced from 30 to 50 per cent. Nearly all the conspicuously choice lots have been disposed of, but there remain many bargains. These are chiefly in the unset gems, scarabs, scaraboid, and lockets.

Over 1,200 men were employed yesterday by the Street-Cleaning Department in cleaning the streets of snow. Of this number more than two-thirds were drivers engaged in carting the snow to the dumping docks along the North, and East Rivers. The other workmen were employed in shoveling the snow and sweeping it up in heaps on the sides of the streets, so as to have the roadway clear for vehicles.

The proposed reorganization of the New-York and New-England Railroad was much discussed yesterday among railroad men and financiers. The committee which has undertaken the task -- Messrs. John I. Waterbury, Henry W. Cannon, and T. Jefferson Coolidge, Jr. -- was generally regarded as a strong one.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- Consternation prevailed for a few minutes this afternoon in the Illinois Trust and Savings Bank.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14. -- The traders took hold of the market this morning with much more confidence than for some days past. London quotations were reported somewhat higher than the local closing. They bought and bid up Reading. Although active for a little while, the total transactions for the day were comparatively insignificant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The House Commerce Committee gave a hearing to-day on the New-YorK and Hudson River Bridge bill. The New-York Chamber of Commerce was represented by Gustav H. Schwab and S.D. Coykendahl, and the Maritime Ex. change by L.T. Romaine. Ex-Representative Phil B. Thompson, Charles H. Swan, and James P. Sparkman appeared for the bill.
Peter Neville, John A. Dunphy, and James P. Rue were sentenced yesterday by Justice Barrett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, for illegal practices at the election last Fall.
