PLYMOUTH, Penn., Feb. 14. -- The thirteen men who were entombed yesterday in the Gaylord mine by the caving in of the roof have not been reached by rescuers, and it cannot be said that much progress has been made in the effort to reach them. Whether any of them are alive is more than is known.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Assistant Secretary McAdoo of the Navy Department questions whether the department has the right, under existing law, to grant the requests received from State authorities for the use of old and abandoned vessels of the navy for naval militia purposes. The department is ready to meet all requests of this character, and discovers in this encouragement of the volunteer naval force a profitable use for the old monitors.

The Kneeland-Hughes contest for a seat in the Assembly was resumed yesterday before the Assembly sub-committee in the Brooklyn City Hall. Mr. Hughes, in the absence of Congressman Magner, conducted his own case, while George F. Elliott cared for Mr. Kneeland's interests.

Mrs. Ithamar Howe, heroine of the Megantic Club, feels that she is being severely dealt with between the upper and nether millstones that are grinding out the flour in the remarkable fifty-thousand-dollar damage suit on trial before Justice Ingraham and a jury in the Supreme Court in this city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Marter Dalzell, daughter of Representative and Mrs. Dalzell, to Mr. George Dunn took place at the Church of the Covenant at noon to-day, in the presence of a large invited company. The church was elaborately decorated, with palms, lilies, azaleas, and white bloomhig plants of various kinds.
FOSTORIA, Ohio, Feb. 14. -- The report of the financial standing of Charley Foster and Foster Co. has just been made to the committee of creditors.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Feb. 14 -- P.M. Stock speculation was dull and professional. In the morning prices were fairly strong, but in the afternoon there was some weakness. The net result of the day's trading was fractionally higher prices for most stocks on the active list.

The contest of the will of Charles Bathgate Beck, which was admitted to probate on Tuesday, has not been abandoned. On the contrary, the contestant, Mrs. Matilda Carter, who says she Is a daughter of Alexander Bathgate, an uncle of the decedent, has placed her Interests In the hands of Messrs.

The Murray Hill Hotel yesterday was the Mecca and Medina of light-harness horsemen. In spite of snow drifts, blocked railroads, stalled trains, and hard times, scores of men interested in the typical American horse gathered at the call of President Johnson to lend their aid by voice or vote to the deliberations of the sixteenth biennial congress of the National Trotting Association.

PARIS, Feb. 14. -- The Anarchists here were astounded to-day by the arrest of Paul Bernard, one of the Anarchist chiefs who exercised supreme influence among the various groups. Bernard has been several times condemned for provoking to murder, arson, and pillage. His latest conviction was had in November, 1890, when he fled to Barcelona.

Passengers on the Brooklyn Bridge view with mingled impatience and derision alleged efforts to improve the lighting of the bridge cars. In nothing has the railway service been more deficient than in the inadequate means of illumination supplied on the road.

It was expected that there would be a turbulent time at the election last night of a Captain for Company C of the Sixty-ninth Battalion, but the election passed off quietly, although there were some queer incidents. The candidates were First Lieut. John O'Connell of Company C and First Lieut. Michael J. Spellman of Company I.

Mrs. Harriet Henderson's examination in supplementary proceedings on a judgment recovered by E.B. Halsey for $598 for bonnets was continued in a private room at the City Court yesterday afternoon. On her former examination no property was disclosed. It was shown that Mrs. Henderson lived on an income from the estate of George H. Osgood, who was a friend of her father's.

"Josie Miller," Thomas Hayes, James Smith, Jeremiah Morlarty, Robert Connelly, and John R. Brown, or John Bradley, or "John Doe," who, Capt. Cortright claims, are either receivers of stolen goods or the allies of such persons, had a hearing yesterday at the Essex Market Police Court.

Real estate in the "Swamp" rarely comes up for sale at auction, and consequently there were many persons attracted by curiosity to the stand of Mr. George R. Read in the Trinity Building Salesroom, yesterday when he offered two pieces of such property. The sale was in partition proceedings affecting the Blackburne estate.

Since Monday morning, when he should have appeared at the Tombs Police Court to enter a charge against Louis Cohen, a saloon keeper at 210 Canal Street, for violation of the excise law. Detective John F. Mitchell of the Elizabeth Street Station has been missing. Mitchell's disappearance happened under mysterious circumstances, and his friends fear that he may have wandered oft while temporarily insane.

The debate in the French Chamber on Monday was very suggestive. A Deputy very properly called the attention of the Ministry to the demonstrations that had been permitted at the tomb of Vaillant, and the Minister of the Interior explained that outrageous demonstrations had occurred but once, and that he had taken order that they should not occur again.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The Brazilian Minister said to-day that he had received cablegrams to-day from President Peixoto which indicated no important changes in the situation at Rio. He wished, however, to correct what he called "another false rumor," and attributable to insurgent sources, conveyed in a dispatch from Lisbon stating that a bill for the provisional removal of the Government from Rio Janeiro to Petropolis had passed the third reading in the Brazilian Congress.

It would be interesting to see what would be the effect of public sessions of the Senate for the discussion and decision of nominations. We should like exceedingly to watch a Senator from the State of New-York gravely arguing in public that he was aggrieved by invitations from the wife of the President being sent to the wives of Senators who would otherwise vote with the New-York man on a judicial nomination.

Athletes, bicyclists, and all lovers of sports will be specially interested in Sunday's New-York Times. It will contain pictures of The Times' s medals given at various amateur meetings, together with pictures of the winners. These medals were given, to encourage strictly amateur contestants in manly, health-giving sport, and became very popular.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The Legislature correspondents scored an emphatic victory over Lieut. Gov. Sheehan before the Senate Judiciary Committee this afternoon. Simon Seibert. Republican member of Assembly from the Second District of Erie, on Monday night informed several newspaper correspondents that pending the passage of the Buffalo Police Charter bill in the House he had been improperly approached by "one of the Sheehan gang."

PASSAIC, N.J., Feb. 15. -- A peculiar case has been brought to light through the granting of an order by Chancellor McGill, restraining Muzzy Brothers, a well-known Paterson firm, from disposing of property conveyed to them by David Van Buskirk and William Lee. The story told by Van Buskirk is calculated to create a scandal, and it is claimed that Muzzy Brothers have been guilty of compounding a crime.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 15. -- The failure of Phil Stimmel Co., seed dealers, has brought nearly every farmer in Western Douglass County to the verge of bankruptcy. They mortgaged their farms and live stock and implements to raise seed for Stimmel, and now they are penniless.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- In the House of Commons to-day, Henry Fowler, President of the Local Government Board, moved that the House disagree with the amendment made by the House of Lords to the Parish Councils bill providing that only parishes having 500 inhabitants or upward should be entitled to have Councils.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- There was a hearing this afternoon before the Assembly Excise Committee on Assemblyman Lawson's High License bill, which was prepared by a number of aid societies in New-York City.

The probability that McKane's principal henchmen, Justices R.V.B. Newton and Kenneth F. Sutherland, will soon follow their convicted chief to prison has excited public interest in their careers and characteristics.

Rabbi Joseph Lack was sent to Raymond Street Jail, yesterday, by Justice Connelly, in the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, for passing a Confederate fifty-dollar bill. Lack is a Russian. He has been in this country only a year. He lives at 510 Osborn Street. The rabbi recently bought the Confederate bill from an acquaintance for $40.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- For the first time in many sessions there was a decided consolation in to-day's market for the bulls. Diamond Match opened strong at 116, steadily moved upward to 117, then, without intervening sales, to 118, and at the end of the noon call it brought 120, or 10 points higher than the lowest quotation of yesterday.

The Committee of Twenty which Mayor Gilroy appointed by proclamation to raise and distribute funds for the relief of the unemployed poor of this city has been called to meet in the Mayor's office at noon to-morrow. Notices to this effect were sent to each member of the committee yesterday, and there will probably be a full attendance.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- It is believed now that the outrage committed by Emile Henry at the cafe of the Hotel Terminus, on Monday night, when twenty-four persons were injured by the explosion of a bomb thrown by him, was part of a vast Anarchist conspiracy.

John Farley's two wives appeared in the Superior Court, before Judge Freedman, yesterday to testify against him in a divorce proceeding. As if this was not enough, his own brother took the stand in support of the wives. The only member of the family who didn't put in an appearance was John Parley himself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Since the last day of January the Treasury balance has increased in round figures $53,000,000, the assets to-day standing at $791,000,000. This increase practically represents the money derived from the bond issue, all of which, with the exception of about $2,500,000, is now in hand.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- There is a feeling of distrust among some of the Eastern members of the Associated Press on account of an incident at the meeting which took place here yesterday, and regarding which some reassuring accounts were telegraphed all over the country last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The rumors concerning the alleged action of the Senate Sub-Committee on Finance on the sugar schedule of the Tariff bill caused some commotion about the Capitol to-day. The rumor was that sugar was to be left on the free list.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- After a prolonged debate, in the course of which many of the arguments were repeated that had been heard in previous Legislatures, the Senate passed to-day the bill of Senator McMullin completion of the Museum of Natural History in New-York, was passed without objection.

STAPLETON, S.I., Feb. 15. -- Judge Stephens, in the County Court to-day granted the application for the appointment of a special District Attorney. The application was made by W. Travers Jerome on behalf of Lester A. Scofield and David J. Jones. The petitioners are the complainants against District Attorney Fitzgerald, George Van Name, and Edward S. Lawson, who are charged with violating the election laws at a primary meeting last February.
PARIS, Feb. 15. -- Judgment was handed down to-day in the case of Princess Colonna, who instituted proceedings here to obtain a judicial separation from her husband.
Friends and counsel of McKane, when they heard the verdict, were astounded. They had been bracing the "boss" of Gravesend up with assurances that he would be acquitted.

The close of the long trial of John Y. McKane with a verdict of "guilty" is a distinct triumph for representative institutions. The specific legal offense of which he has been convicted is procuring, aiding, and abetting certain Election Inspectors in Gravesend to refuse to obey the law requiring the lists of registered voters to be kept accessible to the public for examination or for copying.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- The Federal Grand Jury ran against a snag to-day in its investigation of the charges of illegal rate-cutting brought by the Inter-State Commerce Commission against the Lake Shore Railroad and the other lines in the Central Traffic Association.
LONDON, Feb. 15. -- A small bottle has been picked up on the beach of Gigha, one of the Hebrides Islands, containing a piece of paper, on which, written with a pencil, is the following:

The "jolly" Arions will be in their glory at their annual ball at the Madison Square Garden to-night, and, as usual, all former spectacular attractions and devices for promoting jollity will be eclipsed, while in the item of surprises novelties may be counted on.

Matthew Green, formerly foreman of a street-cleaning gang in this city, was yesterday put on trial for his life before Judge Martine, in General Sessions. He is charged with the murder of James Halstead, a dyer, on First Avenue, near Thirty-fourth Street, on the afternoon of July 25, 1893.

A careworn, middle-aged man, garbed as a clergyman, who said he was the Rev. Thomas R. Watkins of 54 Wales Street. Scranton, Penn., pastor of a Congregational church there, told to Sergt. Kelleher in the Information Bureau at Police Headquarters last night the story of a long and weary search for a runaway son.

Four persons suspected of being contract laborers were yesterday arrested and taken to Kills Island, where they were examined by the Inspectors. They described themselves as William Timmins, aged forty-two, a lace weaver; Bridget Gallagher, aged twenty-three, lace spinner; Owen Curran, aged twenty-six, wood carver, and Hugh Ferry, aged twenty-three, weaver.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- The State Normal and Training School at Oneonta was burned this morning. The fire was discovered by the janitor at about 5:15 o'clock in a waste-paper room in the basement. The building was constructed in the form of a double L, and the fire originated in one of the inside angles, under a point where the staircases converged.

Storm signals are flying from teacups. There is mutiny in the ranks of the Professional Woman's League, and the members are happy in consequence. They have a new subject to discuss. It was afforded at Wednesday's meeting by a little chorus girl, who raised a row out of all proportion to her size.

A reporter for The New-York Times called yesterday on the Rev. Mr. Churchill, Pastor of the church at Sheepshead Bay where John T. McKane was a shining light and Sunday School Superintendent. Mr. Churchill has been confined to the house with a cold.

Another Election Inspector was sentenced to prison yesterday. Dennis. J. Buckley, who served in the Eighteenth Election District of the Second Assembly District, was condemned, to serve one year in the penitentiary and to pay a fine of $500.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- In the Assembly today Mr. Terry, from the Committee on Privileges and Elections, handed up the report of the committee on the contested seat case of A.W. Baillie against Samuel J. Foley. It recommended the adoption of the following resolution:

If there had been a statue of John Adams and a gilded dome in this city last night the New-Yorkers might have had a fairly accurate picture of the Massachusetts Legislature. The legislators were here -- not all of them, but a large delegation -- fresh from Boston Common, and bringing the dignified atmosphere that surrounds those who are permitted to make laws for the Commonwealth.

Mr. Isaac O. Woodruff told Judge Ingraham and the jury in the Supreme Court yesterday why he should not be called on to pay Mr. Ithamar Howe $50,000 damages for the alleged alienation of Mrs. Howe's affec- tions. Mr. Woodruff made a very good witness, and gave his testimony in an easy, straightforward manner.

When it was rumored a week ago that Senator Hoar would vote to confirm the nomination of Mr. Peckham, it appeared that the confirmation would be accomplished with substantial unanimity, for no Democrat could afford to be outdone in decency by George Frisbie Hoar. In deciding to oppose confirmation, Mr. Hoar has merely exhibited himself frankly as God made him.

If there are any redeeming features about the present state of weather, they have not been made apparent to the men who are charged with keeping the streets clean. The snowfall of Wednesday night and the sleet of yesterday were a discouraging combination. The main thoroughfares had been only partially cleared of their first incumbrance of snow when the succeeding storms buried them again.

John Y. McKane has for more than twenty years occupied a unique position in the politics and affairs of Kings County. With the single exception of Hugh McLaughlin, the repudiated "boss" of Willoughby Street, he has attracted closer attention and provoked wider discussion than any other man in the county.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A small installment of the new bond issue will be sent to New-York to-morrow. The first batch of the new issue was received at the Treasury Department this afternoon from the Bureau of Engraving and Printing. It consisted of 1,500 sheets of coupon bonds of the denomination of $1,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- The annual encampment of the New-Jersey Division, Sons of Veterans, ended to-nigth. There were 150 representatives from all parts of the State, and the business session was presided over by Col. A.L. Sparks of Camden. The report of Adjt. Gen. Frederick O. Thatcher of Camden snows a membership of 944 in the State, a decrease of 147.

As sweeper No. 5 of the Third Avenue cable road was passing last night First Street, on the Bowery, with ten horses attached, a well-dressed young woman, supposed to be Maggie Balger, fell or jumped in front of the leaders.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- Two colored highwaymen made an attempt to rob the passengers in one of the day coaches of the 11:30 P.M. train on the Fort Wayne Railroad soon after it left the Union Station last night. Just before the train was about to cross the bridge at Sixteenth Street, where the engineer is required to run slow, two colored men boarded the train and entered a day coach.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Several weeks ago the Democratic State Central Committee of Connecticut Issued a circular addressed to the Federal and State officers of that Commonwealth. The circular requested funds for campaign purposes, and carried a graduated assessment of from 2 1/2 to 10 per cent., according to the salaries received.

A cheerful projector named Pynchon has been entertaining the Western Society of Engineers with a description of his system of aerial navigation. We use the word projector advisedly, since it seems that it is not only a project that he has in view, but a projectile. He proposes to find his motive power in the discharge of dynamite cartridges at the rear of his aerial vessel.
"Thousands of men and women in New-York and throughout the land are starve ing although they have plenty of money to buy the best of food!"

Again the Amateur Athletic Union is waging war on the "shady" boxers, whose methods are distasteful to the officials of that organization. Two years ago "Father Bill" Curtis threw a bombshell into the camp of the money-making amateur fighters by suspending a large number of men, and they were known as "Father Bill Curtis's 400."

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO JANEIRO, Feb. 15. -- A launch belonging to the American cruiser Newark on Tuesday night took ashore from that vessel several sailors who had been attacked by yellow fever. The men were taken to the yellow fever hospital, and the launch returned to the Newark.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Feb. 13 -- P.M. The stock market gave little attention today to anything except Sugar, which came to the front when business began, and kept itself in prominent view all day. As soon as it became apparent that the stock was to undertake one of its star performances, everything else was put aside.
If you are a poor sleeper, not only do not forget to put on your nightcap, but on retiring also take a nightcap of Horgford'a Acid Phosphate to make assurance doubly sure.

The conviction of John Y. McKane on a charge of felony has a more far-reaching effect than most persons have taken into consideration. It not only affects him personally, but it also affects the political complexion of the Kings County Board of Supervisors.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- The wheat market to-day was dominated by the foreign advices and foreign orders. The failure of Liverpool to respond to our advance of yesterday, and later the fact that Continental markets showed no advance, worked to the disadvantage of prices. New-York was prominently active in the dissemination of bearish news. An early telegram to Lamson Brothers Co. said: "European crop damage doesn't seem to materialize this morning.

Out of 200 talesmen called in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Justice Barrett only ten have been secured as jurymen to sit in the trial of Joseph F. Blaut, ex-President of the Madison Square Bank, who is charged with false swearing in signing a report of the condition of the institution on June 1, 1893.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The House bill as to railroad stations at town sites in the Territories was taken up to-day very soon after the Senate met, and was opposed by Mr. Platt (Rep., Conn.,) as a piece of special legislation, and therefore mischievous. He criticised severely the Secretary of the Interior for his activity in urging the passage of the bill.

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- American Bell Telephone sold down to 169 to-day, and Lamson Store Service was quoted at 18 1/2. Five shares of Boston and Lowell sold at 185. West End Street Railway was dull, selling off to 44. Another $10,000 is said to have been added to "snow expenses" by today's storm, making, if the report be true, this Winter's snow expenses exceed last Winter's by $30,000.

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- Special agents of the Treasury Department for the District of New-England believe they have unearthed a gigantic scheme which has been worked with success to defraud the United States Government.

The downfall of "Boss" John Y. McKane of Gravesend is especially encouraging to the citizens of the neighboring town of New-Utrecht, where "Boss" Cornelius Furgueson has been running things as if that particular section of Long Island was Specially created for his personal benefit.

The New-York Times was the first newspaper to direct attention to McKane's conspiracy against honest elections in Gravesend. The exposure began in its columns on the morning of Tuesday, Oct. 24, 1893.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- Bar sliver again declined to-day. The market was dull, and the price fell off 3/8d. per ounce. Yesterday's closing price was 29 1/2d. To-day the quotation is 29 1/8d., which is 1/8d. lower than was ever before recorded.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- It was confidently expected that by to-night, at the latest, the country would know whether the United States Senate proposed to yield to the dictation of David B. Hill and defeat the nomination of Wheeler H. Peckham to the Supreme Court bench. Another day must pass, however, before this interesting question can be answered.

The silk-ribbon weavers of New-York City will go on strike to-day at 10 o'clock unless their employers grant them an increase of wages. The weavers held a meeting last night at 568 Ninth Avenue and resolved unanimously to go out to-day. Delegrates attended from all the factories in the city.

The special committee of the Chamber of Commerce which was appointed to inquire into the rapid-transit question made a report yesterday at a special meeting of the Chamber. Action upon it was deferred for two weeks, when it will be taken up at the next regular meeting. This was wise in view of the recommendation of the committee and of its failure to give adequate consideration to an alternative for its proposed plan of action.

Mr. George H. Earle, Jr., opened the case of the defense yesterday in the proceeding brought by Mr. Isaac L. Rice against the Reading receivers in Philadelphia. Mr. Earle is still a young man, but he has had considerable experience. He began life as a lawyer, but early turned his attention to financial matters and became President of the Finance Company of Pennsylvania, which office he now holds.

Of all the social multitudes seen beneath one roof this Winter that which gathered in the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the benefit of various charities, and to hear superb gleanings from great operas, was by far the largest and most fashionable. At the box office it was officially announced that over $20,000 was cleared.

It is not very agreeable for sensible men to watch the debate over the Bland Silver Coinage bill dragging its slow length. The bill is bad in motive and would be most disastrous and discreditable in its operation. But every one knows that even it it should pass both houses it would get no further.

"Things are as calm and quiet in the Republican Party as they were in the far-famed Donnybrook Fair," was the comprehensive manner in which a well-known Republican commented last night on the harmony in his party.

At a meeting of the Directors of the Northern Central Railroad in Baltimore yesterday, the thirty-ninth annual report was approved. The figures for the year ended Dec. 31 show: Gross earnings, $6,881,806; decrease. $309,484; operating expenses, $4,763,156; decrease, $349,203; net earnings, $2,118,650; increase. $39,719.

The political career of John Y. McKane is finished. It came to an end yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer, where the Gravesend "boss" had been on trial for nearly a month for conspiracy to hide the registration lists of Gravesend.

Estelle Pettit, the young woman who says she was married to Isidor W. Fried while under the influence of a drug, was yesterday a witness in the suit brought by her father to cancel the marriage. The case is being tried before Justice Bischoff, in the Court of Common Pleas. The plaintiff is a handsome girl eighteen years of age.

The installation services or the Rev. W.T. Dorward as pastor of the Baptist Church of the Redeemer, in Thirty-first Street, near Seventh Avenue, were held in the church last evening. The church was handsomely decorated with exotic plants and cut flowers. The Rev. Dr. MacArthur, who had been invited to take part in the services, sent a letter of regret.

The bill providing for the submission to a popular vote of the plain proposition whether New-York, Brooklyn, Long Island City, and certain contiguous territory should be united in one municipality passed the Assembly last week by a nearly unanimous vote. That is the proposition which was discussed before the election, and no terms or conditions were attached to it.

An exchange of part of the Josiah Jex property has been determined upon. The Plot, 100 by 125, at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-ninth Street will be sold to Theron Berdell for about $425,000. A theatre and concert hall, it is said, will be put on the site. The Barrington apartment house, 40 and 42 East Twenty-fifth Street, 50 by 98.9, is out down as part of the consideration.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 15. -- The steamer Alameda arrived at 8 o'clock this morning with Honolulu advices up to Feb. 8. On the evening of Feb. 3 an important meeting was held in that city by the Annexation Club, which was largely attended by influential citizens.

A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon to receive the report of the committee of five appointed by President Charles S. Smith "to examine the subject of rapid transit and report what action, if any, on the part of the Chamber of Commerce it is advisable to take, for the purpose of aiding in the solution of this important problem."

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15. -- A plot to rob produce dealers and commission merchants in New-York was discovered through the arrest this morning of Patrick Coyne, a peddler, who was held under $300 ball for trial on the charge of larceny. Other arrests are to be made. Thomas W. Dawson, the President of the Stephens Condit Transportation Company, is the complainant.

In a little room opening off the Sheriff's private office, while awaiting removal to Raymond Street Jail, McKane held a reception at which many of his Gravesend admirers, some of them under indictment, were present. Among them were Justice R. U.B. Newton and S.S. Wiliamson. There were also present Cornellus Furgueton, Cornelius Furgueson, Jr., and James Church of New-Utrecht, Michael Dady; J. McGarry, Police Justice Tighe, and Civil Justice Murphy.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- A loud explosion was heard just after nightfall by the keepers of Greenwich Park, about six miles from London Bridge. A hasty search led to the discovery of a man mutilated and groaning with pain on the hilltop near the observatory. His legs were shattered. One arm had been blown from his body, and he had been almost completely disemboweled.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- Another fairly good-sized order to buy Lehigh Valley ran it up to 40 1/4 to-day, the highest price for some time, but as soon as that order was filled the price sagged off, and later in the afternoon 100 shares sold at 39 7/8. Reading and St. Paul were active spasmodically. Traders here continue to be bullish on Reading, and bought and bid it up to 11.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 16. -- The two rescuing parties at work in the Gaylord Mine trying to find the thirteen entombed timber men are making slow progress. Rock and coal continue to fall, and on more than one occasion the rescuers were obliged to flee from work in order to save themselves.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- In the House to-day Mr. Bland made an effort to secure a quorum to support his motion to close debate on his bill to coin the seigniorage of the silver bullion in the Treasury. In this he was not successful, the largest vote being 165.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- The Pennsylvania mangaement gave the stockholders of one of their lines a surprise when the Philadelphia, and Erie to-day declared, a 2 per cent. dividend. There was a big fight at the stockholders' annual meeting a few days since, and, although it was clearly shown that the dividend had been earned, the unhappy minority hardly hoped for any cash as a result.

The woman who had such a miraculous escape from death Thursday night, when she either fell or jumped in front of a six-horse sweeper of the Third Avenue Railroad in the Bowery, came to her senses yesterday morning at Bellevue Hospital. She did not appear to be much the worse for her thrilling experience.
Money on cali loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

President Knox of the Board of Education and School Commissioners Coleman, Harris, and Livingston had a conference yesterday with the Mayor and the Controller in regard to the issuing of more bonds for school purposes. They wanted the city authorities to consent to the bill which has been introduced in the Legislature instructing the Board of Estimate to appropriate $2,500,000 in bonds in addition to what has already been given.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- Superintendent James F. Pierce of the State Insurance Department, in his report for 1893 on fire and marine Insurance companies transacting business in this State, says most of the States have already set their faces against individual underwriting.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Because ex-Speaker Sulzer was not in the Chamber to object, and because the Republican members took advantage of that fact to rush through a concurrent resolution the first thing this morning, the proceedings in the Assembly to-day were lively and interesting. When the incident was ended the ex-Speaker had charged that the records had been falsified, and some hot words had been exchanged.

Yesterday's sales of real estate at; auction were neither numerous nor especially notable. At the Trinity Building Salesroom Mr. James S. McQuillen of D. Phoenix Ingraham Co. conducted four sales in foreclosure, and the purchasers were interested parties. The first of the sales was of the two five-story brick flats 113 and 115 East One Hundred and Second Street, north side, 152 feet east of Fourth Avenue, each 25 by 100.11.

The report of the State Superintendent of Insurance, giving the result of the examination of the condition of the United States Mutual Accident Association, is expected to be made public in a few days. Deputy Superintendent Shannon has the report nearly completed.

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- There was somewhat more activity in local securities than for several days, and the tone was stronger. Wisconsin Central 5s were dealt in to quite an extent, and sold up to 67, 2 points higher than the close of two days ago. It is said that a New-York estate is selling out its holding of some hundreds of thousands of these bonds, and that they are nearly sold out.

Those natty young men who compose the military organization known, as Troop A took part In their annual athletic games, sports, and manoeuvres in Dickers Riding Academy last night. The building was crowded to its utmost capacity, and, judging from the applause bestowed upon the participants in the games, the onlookers apparently enjoyed the sport

Although the bill of particulars which "President" Dole submitted to Minister Willis in support of his complaint about the letter's "attitude" toward the provisional Government of Hawaii is dated Jan. 11, less than five weeks ago, it has a flavor of ancient history about it. So far as the interest of the people of this country is concerned, it relates to a dead controversy.

American railway securities were irregular in the London market. Prices were not much changed, however, in either direction, and the business was on a very limited scale. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Lake Shore, 1/2, to 129; Erie, 1/8, to 16 3/4; Reading, 1/8, to 11 1/4, and Louisville and Nashville, 1/8, to 47 1/4.
A pathetic Incident, showing to what extremes the unemployed poor may be driven, was brought to light in the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning.

Francois victte. Francois Viette, an eminent member of the French Chamber of Deputies, died in Paris yesterday. He was born at Blamont. Department of Doubs, March 6, 1843. He began his experience in politics as a political writer for Le Doubs. Le Republican de l'Est, and as one of the founders of La Democratic Franc-Comtoise.

Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court handed down a decision yesterday awarding to Rutherford Stuyvesant damages, which amount to about $45,000, against the elevated railroad companies for injuries to his property on Third Avenue. This suit included fifty-four separate pieces of property on the avenue, stretched along at intervals from Tenth to Twentieth Street.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 12, via Montevideo, Feb. 16. -- The insurgent charge at Nictheroy on Friday, Feb. 9, was notable for acts of bravery. Admiral da Gama himself led the storming party. He shot Col. Tasso Fragoso of the Government garrison, mounted that officer's horse, and rode ahead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Secretary Carlisle has received an interesting proposition from Wlliam O. McDowell of Liberty Bell fame, in reference to the recommendation of the Lighthouse Board that the lighting of the Liberty Statue in New-York Harbor be discontinued. Mr. McDowell writes from Newark, N.J., saying:

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 16. -- The celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the State University was brought to a successful close to-night. The early exercises of the day comprised an elaborate students' recital in the Opera House, followed by the alumni reunion in Grant Memorial Hall.

NEW-YORK. Friday, Feb. 16 -- P.M. Plans went agley for the bears to-day when the Burlington Directors voted to pay the usual quarterly dividend of 1 1/4 per cent. Recent persistent selling of the Granger stocks proceeded upon the assumption that dividends of these companies would certainly be scaled.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 16. -- Patrick Eugene Prendergast, the murderer of Mayor Harrison, enlivened the proceedings before Judge Brentano to-day in the argument for a new trial by a little combat with the bailiffs. Prendergast wanted to speak to Prosecuting Attorney Trude, and when the latter entered the room the prisoner jumped from his seat and called to Mr. Trude.

A meeting of the delegates of the various Irish societies of this city which are to participate in the celebration of St. Patrick's Day on March 17 next was held last evening at Central Hall, 219 East Forty-seventh Street. Lawrence T. Langan presided. The attendance was not so large as had been expected, and another meeting will have to be held before the entire programme can be decided upon.

The General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday reversed the judgment in the case of Mrs. Julia. E. Barringer, who was convicted of grand larceny in the Court of General Sessions. She was accused of appropriating $2.000, the property of Zacharias V. Spinosa. Mrs. Barringer used to run a co-operative loan establisment at 10 East Foiurteenth Street.

There seems to be no prospect of an immediate end in the fifty-thousand-dollar damagae suit brought by Ithmar Howe, ex-steward of the Megantic Fish and Game Club, against Isaac O. Woodruff, the wealthy Maiden Lane chemist, for the alienation of Mrs. Howe's affections. Yesterday Mr. Woodruff was on the stand again, under cross and redirect examination, and his testimony took up the entire session.

Capt. John S. Shepherd, the famous sharpshooter and commander of Company D, Twenty-third Regiment, died yesterday of pneumonia, at the house of his cousin, Cyrus Staples, 113 Remsen Street, Brooklyn. Capt. Shepherd was never married. He lived for a number of years with his cousin. Arrangements have been made to hold funeral services at his late home to-morrow afternoon.

SARANAC LAKE, Feb. 16. -- Trains on all the roads north, south, east, and west are stalled in snowbanks. On the Keysville Road no connections have been made, Delaware and Hudson trains are very much overdue, Chateaugay trains are late, and there are no trains for traffic running on the Northern Adirondack Railroad.

In the proceedings yesterday before Surrogate Arnold, brought by Robert L. Cutting, who recently qualified as one of the executors of the will of his grandfather, the first Robert L. Cutting, to compel an accounting from his uncle, Walter Cutting, his co-executor, it was publicly announced that young Cutting had been disinherited because of his marriage to Minnie Seligman, the actress.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- A dispatch received here to-day from Rio de Janeiro states that yellow fever continues to spread in that city. On an average, forty cases of that distase are reported daily, and twenty cases of other fevers.
WASHINGTON Feb. 16. -- In an interview with the representative of the United Press, Senator Lodge said:

Some interesting facts developed yesterday during the examination of John Matthews, before United States Commissioner Shields on the charge of defrauding the Government of customs duties. Matthews was the manager for Pitt Scott, European forwarders and Custom House brokers, at 39 Broadway.

May Brookyn's death by suicide in San Francisco on Thursday is regarded, by those who knew her her? as a sequel to the sad ending of Frederick A. Lovecraft, to whom she was said to have been engaged when ha committed suicide several months ago. It is supposed that brooding over his death induced melancholia and caused her to end her own life.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 16. -- Miss Laura Hoffman of this place narrowly escaped losing her life yesterday while skating in the Great South Bay. She ventured too near the edge of the frozen mass and skated upon a piece of ice which became detached.

Sergeant Elias B. Dunn, who, since the Department of Agriculture has taken charge of the Weather Bureau, has been popularly known as Farmer Dunn, is one of the very best known men in this city. His popularity, except with his legion of personal friends, is, however, of a varying quality.

The Land Title and Trust Company of Philadelphia has begun proceedings in the United States Circuit Court in this city to secure an examination, under direction of the court, of all the books and securities of the Equitable Mortgage Company, so that all the bondholders may know its actual financial condition before any plan of resumption is adopted.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 16. -- Train robbers wrecked Passenger Train No. 20 on the Southern Pacific Railroad at Roscoe Station, twelve miles north of here, at 1 o'clock this morning. They blew open the express car with dynamite and fired several shots at the trainmen, who attempted to escape. Those shot by the robbers or injured in the wreck are:

Conviction of John T. McKane has prostrated the ring politicians in Brooklyn. A dynamite bomb exploding in Willoughby Street could not have provoked greater consternation than was produced by the verdict of Thursday among the adherents of the old machine. "Boss" McLaughlin is said to be deeply affected by the conviction of the Coney Island "boss."

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- John J. Braham will soon go to London for Mr. Stetson to rehearse the music and take charge of the orchestra of Gilbert Sullivan's new opera. "Utopia, Limited," which will be produced in this country in a few months, under the joint management of John Stetson and H. D'Oyly Carte.

Wheeler H. Peckfham was Chairman of the mass meeting in Cooper Union on Thursday evening, Oct. 26, 1893, called by the New-York Bar Association to protest against the nomination of Isaac Horton Maynard for Judge of the Court of Appeals, and to Mr. Peckham's prominence in the anti-Maynard movement was due the hostility to him of Senator Hill.

TITUSVILLE, Fla., Feb. 16. -- An alarming state of affairs exists in the Indian River country. H.M. Flagler, owner of the Royal Ponciana Hotel on Lake Worth, is building a railroad to the hotel. The road cuts through many of the prettiest places on Indian River, and thirty of the property owners, it is said, have combined and placed dynamite bombs along the proposed route of the railway through their lands.

PARIS, Feb. 16. -- Emile Henry, the Anarchist who threw the bomb in the cafe of the Hotel Terminus, was questioned at length to-day by Judge Meyer, the examining Magistrate in the case. Henry admitted that he made the bomb which was found several years ago in the Banque de la Societe Generals.

The conviction of McKane reinforces the effect of the convictions of Dunphy and Neville, and in this fact is to be found its greatest impressiveness as a moral lesson. The lesson is that "the organization" in behalf of which a politician commits crimes cannot save him from the statutory consequences of those crimes.

The Keppel Gallery is lined with some six score drawings in pen and ink, or sepia washes, by Albert E. Sterner, together with a few paintings and water colors. Although Mr. Sterner is best known for his work as an illustrator of books and magazines, he is by no means unskillful with colored pigments.

The Executive Committee of the PlattMilholland movement met last night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, in Parlor D R, and it did business looking to the interest of Mr. Platt's new local machine in this city. Acting upon suggestions furnished by Mr. Platt, a Committee of Seven was appointed to look into legislation at Albany.

The boys of the Barnard School, 119 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, had their fourth annual games last night in the armory of the Eighth Battalion, at Ninety-fifth Street and Park Avenue. Most of the events were closely contested. In the open events the Berkeley boys managed, to carry off the prizes.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Feb. 16. -- two-story frame house, 708 Pomeroy Street, occupied by William H. Burns, was destroyed by fire to-night. The fire was caused by a pipe chimney exploding. Only a portion of the contents were saved. The loss is $3,600, covered by insurance. Frame houses adjoining on each side were badly damaged.

FLUSHING, L.I., Feb. 16. -- The trouble in the First Baptist Church here, resulting from the attempt of a faction of the congregation to get rid of the pastor, the Rev. D.P. Chockley, reached an unexpected climax last evening. A short time ago five of the Trustees held a meeting, and adopted a resolution requesting the pastor to resign.

At Manhattan Field and the different small lakes up in the annexed district skating was excellent yesterday. The present cold snap has made the ice hard and clear, and the lover of the sport had a rare opportunity to glide over the slippery surface.

Since Joseph H. Choate declined to act as legal adviser for the Senatorial investigating committee, a number of other prominent lawyers have been spoken of in that connection. Simon Sterne has been mentioned as a lawyer who is thoroughly equipped for conducting a thorough and searching investigation of the Police Department.

About 500 silk-ribbon weavers struck yesterday in the various silk factories in this city for an advance of wages. They want the same rates they were paid two years ago. Committees from the different shops submitted to their employers last Tuesday copies of a new list that had been drawn up by the unions, calling for a considerable advance.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Feb. 16. -- The Newfoundland Legislature opened to-day. Gov. O'Brien, in his speech, congratulated the houses upon the general prosperity of the country and that the general depression had not affected Newfoundland, there having been no business failures. The seal fishery was a comparative failure, the catch being not half that of the previous year.

QUEENSTOWN, Feb. 16. -- The American Line steamship Paris is at anchor off Roche's Point, with her rudder disabled. She was towed into port by tugs which went to her relief in response to signals of distress which she showed off Daunt's Rock.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 16. -- In an interview concerning Judge Caldwell's recent decision in the matter of the Union Pacific Railroad's wage schedule, Judge Dundy of the United States court said: " The impression that Judge Caldwell has overruled the orders of this court is wrong, as you may see by a perusal of the dispatches.

Two hundred and twenty-four men were called in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before twelve were selected to act as jurymen in the trial of Joseph F. Blaut, ex-President of the Madison Square Bank, who is charged with perjury in swearing to an alleged false statement respecting the condition of the institution on June 1, 1893.

Edward B. Goss, the keeper of Chiko and Johanna, the Central Park chimpanzees, occupies a cot in the Presbyterian Hospital. He is likely to be kept in the hospital for a long time. He was severely bitten and clawed Thursday night in the chimpanzees' cage in the Arsenal.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- A great shooting contest at live pigeons took place this afternoon on the grounds of the Riverton Gun Club, at Riverton, N.J., between teams representing the crack shots from Philadelphia and New-York. The match proved very exciting and will be long remembered on account of the New-York team winning the five-hundred-dollar stake by killing 138 birds to 106 birds dropped by the Philadelphians.

The suit of Estelle Pettit, through her father, Thomas W. Pettit of Far Rockaway, to have her marriage with Isidor Fried annulled on the ground that he drugged her and induced her, while under the influence of the drug, to marry him, was continued before Judge Bischoff in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.

KIEL, Feb. 16. -- A terrible boiler explosion occurred, to-day upon the cruiser Brandenburg, at this port. Forty-one were instantly killed and nine were fatally wounded. With the usual secrecy that pervades naval affairs, the officers of the ship refused to give details regarding the accident, but it is known that as many of the crew were killed and hurt as has been stated, and that considerable damage was done to the vessel.

The Harlem Regatta Association met last night In the Grand Union Hotel. Delegates representing the following clubs were present Union, Nassau, Wyanoake, Lone Star, Atalanta, New-York Athletic, Nonpareil, Friendship, First Bohemian, Dauntless, and Columbia College. Henry J. Behrens, Jr., presided.

The Senate yesterday by a vote of 32 ayes to 41 noes, of which latter only 13 were Democrats and 24 were Republicans, refused its advice and consent to the appointment of Mr. Peckham to the Supreme Court bench. A like refusal by a similar coalition had already been given to the appointment of Mr. Hornblower.
Democrats -- Berry, Call, Cockrell, Coke, Daniel, Gibson, Gorman, Hill, Irby, Jones, (Ark.,) McLaurin, Murphy, Pugh Vest White. (Cal.) -- 15.

The preliminary bouts of the West Side Athletic Club tournament were decided last night in Maennerchor Hall, 205 East Fifty-sixth Street. The hall was well filled with patrons of the fistic art. Inspector Williams and Capt. Reilly and a number of policemen were on hand to see that the boxers did not go beyond the limits.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Only four days for work, including Sunday, remain to the Senate Finance Committee if it meets the prediction of Chairman Voorhees, and reports the Tariff bill next Tuesday. It appears, if all reports be true, that so early a completion of the task will be impossible, but no time is being lost.
BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- A correspondent of The Transcript, writing from Honolulu, under date of Feb. 8, says:
John Y. McKane received his friends yet terday at the Raymond Street Jail in Brooklyn. A good many called. McKane receive them in the Warden's handsomely-furnished private office.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The police at 9 o'clock to-night raided the Autonomie Club. They encountered no opposition. They took possession of the house and detained all the inmates. The raid was managed so quietly that neither the pedestrians in the street nor the nearest neighbors knew what was happening, and the members arriving late walked unsuspectingly into the arms of the policemen waiting to arrest them.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 16. -- The funeral services over the body of the Rev. Thomas J. Toomey, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, were held this morning and were attended by an immense concourse of people. An all-night watch was kept in the church by delegates from the Father Mathew Total Abstinence Benevolent Society.

Two members of the vaccinating corps of the Health Department, accompanied by a policeman, invaded the headquarters of the Salvation Army, at 111 Reade Street, last night, armed with several hundred vaccine points. They expected to vaccinate the members of the army corps who were supposed to be in garrison at the headquarters.

Many war veterans were present at the reception given last night in Masonic Temple to J.G.B. Adams, Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, by Lafayette Post. Commander in Chief Adams spoke of his war time days, Gen. Howard told of the time he was sent home wounded, and sturdy old Gen. Swayne shouldered his crutch and showed how fields were won.
For several weeks past Brooklyn has been the scene of a great revival of religious enthusiasm. On Monday the band of evangelists who have been laboring in Brooklyn will begin work in this city.

Gen. Edward Ferrero's suit against Oscar Hammerstein, to recover the rent for Lenox Lyceum during the production of "Cavalleria Rusticana" in September, 1891, was tried before Judge Freedman, in the Superior Court, yesterday. Mr. Hammerstein said that Gen. Ferrero told him he would be able to get a theatrical license because of his acquaintance with John D. Crimmins and Hugh J. Grant, then Mayor.
The law presumes that a man is innocent until he is proved guilty. Is this presumption binding likewise upon the Church?

Whenever Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" la as well given as it was last night at the Metropolitan Opera House it will delight all hearers, from child to octogenarian. The spirit of the performance was admirable. It was correct and full of life, and if one or two of the members of the cast had displayed a trifle more animation the performance would have been beyond criticism.

A woman who said her name was Mary Stanynought told Justice Simms, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday that her husband, John, a former agent of Dr. Parkhurst's society, deserted her last November, and that she and her three children, who have been supported since then by her sister, living at 828 Tinton Avenue, are now destitute.

Mr. A.A. McLeod told his version of the incidents which led up to Reading's troubles in Philadelphia yesterday before the Special Master in the proceeding brought by Mr. Isaac L. Rice against the Reading management. In giving his testimony he adopted a conversational tone, and related incident after incident as only one who had thoroughly considered the testimony he was about to give could do.

The New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, with headquarters in the United Charities Building, 105 East Twenty-second Street, is making successful efforts to meet the pressing demands upon its resources for work and physical relief to the worthy and unemployed poor, and earnestly requests its friends and the philanthropic public to strengthen its hands.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 16. -- A battalion of the Salvation Army, under Capt. Cowan and Lieut. Brown, held a meeting last evening in the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church in Brooklyn, a village near here.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- The regular meeting of the Board of Directors of the Philadelphia, and Erie Railroad Company was held to-day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The Senate Subcommittee on Foreign Relations, which has been investigating Hawaiian matters, met this morning to consider the report Mr. Morgan has prepared, but adjourned until Wednesday.

Frank Byrne, formerly Secretary of the Irish Home Rule Confederation and afterward Secretary of the Irish Land League and confidential agent of Mr. Parnell, died in a hospital in Providence, R.I., on Friday.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 17. -- It is probable that there will be a Summer encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic. The citizens of Cape May guarantee to raise enough money to supply all that will be necessary to make the veterans comfortable. During the recent encampment, where the matter was freely discussed, the general feeling prevailed that an encampment under such favorable conditions would be a success.

Charles J. Edwards, who has been a prominent and efficient participant in the reform movement in Brooklyn, has been compelled, for domestic reasons, to resign his post as Secretary of the Committee of One Hundred, the independent Democratic body engaged in the reorganization of the party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The sub-committee of the Senate having the Tariff bill in charge adjourned at 4 o'clock this afternoon, but will probably hold a meeting tomorrow. The impression is that nothing will be known about the sugar schedules until Monday morning.
The reappearance on a New-York stage last week of Mlle. Theo was a "dramatic event" of no appreciable importance from a serious point of view, but it was none the less of considerable interest.

It seems to us that the General Term of the Supreme Court takes a pretty robust view of the law of libel in the decision it rendered on Friday. The defendant had demurred, declaring that there was no cause of action, since no libel had been uttered, unless in the form of innuendoes, which it was not admissible to consider.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 17. -- Miss Jennie L. Patterson of the Uniondale school, has won in her fight against School Trustee George N. Paff, who tried to force her to sift ashes, build fires, and clean out the schoolroom, besides turning out graduates.

It was sad to think that the last of the old comedians had gone from us. The gay, venerable Charles had made his last bow and left us -- the black curtain being run down. As he looked so smilingly on the audience on the last night that he performed, what if it had been whispered to him, "You will never be here again. Here is the last, of this fairy world!"

The facts brought out judicially in the trial of John Y. McKane show conclusively the danger of leaving a town like Gravesend, so near to a large city, to the crude and inefficient methods of rural management. In many important respects Gravesend is subject to the conditions of a city ward, particularly as to matters requiring police control.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- There is a strong probability that the Chilean Claims Commission will be enabled to continue its sessions long enough to satisfactorily adjust all the claims that have been brought before it, notwithstanding the recent action of the Chilean Government in notifying the United States authorities that the term within which the original treaty provided for the sessions of the commission could not be extended.

BOSTON, Feb. 17. -- Writing from Glasgow about the prospect of sport next season, a yachting correspondent says: "The twenty-rater Mr. G.L. Watson has designed for Lord Dudley is to be built by Messrs. Camper Nicholson of Gosport, an old and well-known firm of yacht builders, but whose reputation was made by the building of family schooners.

This is not so much a story of discovery and research as a narrative of adventures. Count Teleki, who was at the head of the expedition, the operations of which Lieut. von Hohnel describes, went into African, we judge, without great expectation, or of alteringthe map of the Dark Continent, or of contributing much of value to the fund of information already extant.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The year 1893 was not quite so profitable as the preceding one for New-York State joint-stock fire insurance companies, though the difference was not so great as in some previous years. The premiums received last year were $1,478,065 greater than the aggregate in 1892, while the losses last year were larger by $2,142,963 than during the previous year.

A mission for women has been going on during the past week in the Church of the Epiphany at Second Avenue and Twentysecond Street, conducted by Father Cunnion. At 6 o'clock yesterday morning the church was crowded with women, and the service was about to commence, when a wild-eyed man.

An athlete must make himself deaf to all entreaties, all suggestions, and must act for himself, abiding by his own judgment. I had an opportunity of questioning a most noted tight-rope expert on this subject. He explained to me that on a large rope half a foot from the ground the most timorous person might be taught to walk any reasonable distance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The House today voted to non-concur in the Senate amendment to the bill to require railroads to stop their trains at such town sites in Oklahoma as were fixed by the Interior Department.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 17. -- Richard Miller, seventeen years old, a special delivery messenger, was suspended in midair for two hours to-day on the precipitous cliff near the Duquesne inclined plane, with nothing between him and instant death except a hold on a projecting rock. Had Miller's grasp slipped he would have been precipitated over the bluff and fallen upon the rocks, 200 feet below.

The Yale College team has refused to play a game this year with the New-York Baseball Club. Just Why this step is taken is a matter of conjecture, but it is believed that the collegians feel hurt on account of the engagement of Murphy, the best player on the team, by the Giants.
Citizens of Brooklyn are deeply interested in the pending contest for Supervisor of the Eighth Ward. The contest will be decided at a special election March 6.

The total number or entries for the coming bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which opens next Tuesday in Madison Square Garden, is 1,470. Last year there were 1,492 entries. It was expected that there would be a falling off this year, but, in spite of business troubles, the dog men seem to be able to keep their dogs and to exhibit them.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- C.L. Riker of Esopus, Ulster County, whose attempt to compel Secretary Carlisle to turn over, in compliance with his bid for them, the $50,000,000 of gold bonds recently issued, has given him such widespread notoriety, is a person whose life has been one continual transition from one wild scheme to another.

The throwing of an old shoe after a newly-married couple on their departure is general all over the country; in Kent the custom is accompanied by a little more detail than is usually observed in other parts of the country. The principal bridesmaid throws the shoe, the other bridesmaids run after it, the belief being that the one who gets it will be the first to be married.

In the last paragraph of the long and ingenious preface to this little volume of sketches, which has been selected for translation from the original collection of short stories published in Paris. Mr. Brander Matthews turns his attention to justifying the title which some one not the author has invented for It. He says:

St. Valentine would undoubtedly have smiled with satisfaction if he had dropped in at the fair named after him and given at Sherry's yesterday by a number of society women for the benefit of the Samaritan Home for the Aged. On leaving the fair he might have worn a longer face than on entering, for his pockets would certainly have been well-nigh empty.

More than 10,000 letter carriers throughout the country, especially the carriers of New-York and Brooklyn, as well as the business community, which is so deeply interested in maintaining the efficiency at the Postal Service, heartily approve the action of The New-York Times in advocating the bill now before Congress whose object is to prevent arbitrary removals by partisan Postmasters on political grounds.

Joseph Burns of Albany Avenue, King's Bridge, was arraigned in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday morning, charged with having threatened his wife and children while he was intoxicated Friday night. Mrs. Burns said that her husband came home intoxicated, and, not finding supper waiting for him, became very ugly.

From The Housekeeper. In buying tablecloths and napkins it is always best to get good quality. Not only will it wear much longer, but it gives the table a richer appearance than an inferior quality of linen. Have plenty of changes and never use a tablecloth or napkin until badly soiled, thereby necessitating morerubbing to get it clean, and consequently more wear on the material.

The question of providing annuities for daughters, after the English and French manner, is being discussed in Philadelphia, which city has a large contingent or attractive unmarried young women. It is asserted that these annuities can now be had in this country, as abroad, and it is pointed out that one bought and kept up for a term of years, and perhaps increased, secures comfort and independence to the daughter who dots not marry.

Brooklyn people are at last convinced that the word reform means something. McKane's conviction has made a deeper impression on the public mind than any similar event, in municipal history. Nothing like the interest which attached to his trial was ever aroused by arraignments of earlier offenders against the election laws.

Another week the same as before -- a narrow market, Sugar distancing all other stocks in activity; some trading in the Grangers, some in Distilling and Chicago Gas; wheat making new records daily in lowest prices, silver the same; dullness the prevailing feature of the general list. Fluctuations in prices comparatively small.
Richard P. Dana, a retired merchant of scholarly tastes and of remarkable personality, died suddenly at his home, 146 West Fourteenth Street, early yesterday morning.

Ex-Mayor Chapin sent a check for $204.31 to Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn yesterday. The check represents the remainder of the fund raised for the benefit of the Jacksonville fever sufferers. Mr. Chapin was trustee of the fund. The following letter accompanied the check:

The Boxing and Wrestling Championship Committee of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, at a meeting held yesterday afternoon, made complete arrangements for the final bouts of the championships meeting to be held March 5 at Maennerchor Hall. Owing to the wholesale suspensions recently of the so-called amateur boxers.

Occupied as they were with a profound earnestness in purely spiritual things, the evangelists of the recent Brooklyn revival struck a note which at once echoed and still continues to echo in circles where religious thought can hardly be considered to be paramount. It is a far cry to the fashionable dancing class from the crowded hall of the revival prayer meeting, but none the less in a single day was the transit made.

The fourth annual service of the New-York Sons of the Revolution will be held in the Collegiate Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, at 4 o'clock this afternoon, in commemoration of the one hundred and sixty-second anniversary of the death of George Washington.

A lady in this city recently received a letter from Mrs. Rachel C. Mather, head of an industrial school at Beaufort, S.C., in which she tells of the needs of the Sea Island sufferers. In the course of this letter Mrs. Mather says:
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

Mr. Ruskin is an instance of precocity as remarkable as Thirlwall, though he did not begin to publish so early. He began to write "books" at six years of age. His first dated poem was written a month before he reached the age of seven. A poem he wrote when seven years old reminds Mr. Collingwood (see "Life," 1893. Vol. I., page 26) of "Blake's best touches."

"Were many lives lost around here?" an old man was asked. He stood with his hands folded in front of him and his eyes seeking the ground. If he had held his faded and flabby hat in his hands his attitude would have been that of the peasant in Millet's picture of the Angelus. He stood stock still, his bare feet placed close together.

An appreciative audience listened last night to the concert of the Columbia College Musical Society, made up of the Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs, in Madison Square Garden Concert Hall. It was the seventeenth annual entertainment of the clubs, and it fully sustained their previously established reputation as purveyors of well-selected and artistically-rendered music.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 17. -- Among the dicisons handed down by the Court of Appeals recently is an important one to insurance companies, as it is the first case of its kind which has been determined by that court since the adoption by the Legislature of the standard policy of insurance. This is the case of Philip J. Moore et al., executors, vs. The Hanover Insurance Company of New-York City.

Patrick J. Finn, arrested Friday night, charged with having abstracted package from the mails, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday. He admitted his guilt, and was remanded to await the action of the Grand Jury, in default of $1,500 ball.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The hold that the love of public life has upon man is well illustrated in the case of Galusha A. Grow, who is now asking to be elected Congressman at Large from Pennsylvania, to succeed Wiliam Lilly, who died recently. The election takes place next Tuesday, and, if Mr. Grow be successful, he will return to the House after an absence of thirty-one years.

Cornelius Furgueson, the Democratic "boss" of New-Utrecht, has long received support from the ring Republicans of the town. The straightout Republicans are angry with, the ring men, and have started a movement to break up the alliance.
Diamonds valued at $1,000, belonging to Mrs. Helen Butterworth of 38 East Thirtyfifth Street have been missing since Jan. 23, and the police have been unable to find them.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- "Speedy action on the part of the Senate is vitally necessary," said Representative Isidor Straus of New-York this morning, in speaking of the Wilson Tariff bill.

Prof. Donovan, the popular boxing instructor of the New-York Athletic Club, was given a rousing testimonial in the Lenox Lyceum last night. Every seat in the house was occupied, and gentlemen in evening dress filled the boxes. The sport consisted of boxing and a display of strength by Prof. Attilla.

Dr. William G. Wright, thirty-eight years old of 360 Quincy Street, Brooklyn, is a prisoner in Raymond Street Jail for stabbing James H. Rogers, an engineer, forty years old, of 312 Kosciusko Street. Dr. Wright and Rogers have been friends for some time. They live within a few blocks of each other.

The bill providing for the use of the blanket ballot at elections in this State is likely to be reported in both branches of the Legislature this week. There is hardly any subject of greater importance to be considered at the present session, and it is to be hoped that final action will not be defeated by any disagreement over minor details.

LAKE GROVE, L.I., Feb. 17. -- A most exciting fox chase was enjoyed by the sportsmen of this and neighboring villages this afternoon. A large red fox had been captured alive a few days ago, and neighboring hunters were invited to bring their hounds and enter into a joint race when the fox should be turned loose, the first dog at the burrow or to catch the fox to have a silver cup.

Brehm informs us that the flesh of the young peacock is very delicate, and has "a wild odor" which is very agreeable. He thinks an old bird fit only for stewing. The Greeks must have found it marvelous costly feeding, if it be true, as Aelian says, that a single bird was worth a thousand drachmas -- nearly u60.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The gossips here have already begun to speculate regarding the next selection to be made by the President for the vacancy on the Supreme Court bench. Having had full knowledge of the coalition between Senators Chandler and Hill, the public was not unprepared for the news of Mr. Peckham's rejection.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In Sunday's issue of The New-York Times of Jan. 28 your usually accurate and critical book reviewer cites the so-called Ulster massacre of 1641 as an instance of the many Christian persecutions which serve to offset and palliate the cruelty of Ieyasu toward Christian missionaries and their converts in Japan.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 7 -- The amateur dramatic company styled "The Dabblers" gave their first public entertainment at their hall, in Masonic Temple, on Wednesday night, Jan, 24, to a large and enthusiastic audience. Government House was represented by Lady Shea and the Governor's private secretary.

This is a story of one Reason at Peterh of, a sanatorium in the Alps, poetically called by the author "The city of the Suffering." It is a book that holds the attention, and one that is not easily put aside before it is finished, and yet the reader is inclined to wonder afterward where the strong interest lies.

Jennie Yeamans, in her artistic impersonation of "Jane," will be the attraction at the Columbia Theatre this week. Miss Yeamans's work in this farce is far superior to that of Johnstone Bennett, who created the part in this country, and no better way of passing an entertaining evening can be found than in observing her treatment of the character.

Canoeists in England are actively preparing for the coming season. New rules are being advocated, and are being freely discussed. One of these is the restricted class, restricted as to cost. On this The London Field says:

The strike of the silk ribbon weavers promises to be a long and bitter one. A comimttee of the strikers had a conference yesterday at Steinhardt's Mills, to West Fiftieth Street, with the manufacturers, and demanded an increase of 75 per cent, in the wages of the weavers. This was refused, and Mr. Steinhardt said no concessions would be made.

As we emerged from under the scorched, disjointed archway a block of marble cornice fell from somewhere, almost on to Oliphant. He jumped aside, exclaiming: "That was close!" We found our way barred at once, and in every direction, by steep, tall slopes of riven, pitchy stones; the smoke half stifled us; the heat was intense; our eyes were stung by the scorching, dancing glimmer in the air.

If dry woolen clothing be put on immediately after exercise, the vapor from the surface of the body is condensed in and upon the wool, and the heat which has become latent in the process of evaporation is again given off. Flannel clothes, therefore, put on during perspiration, always feel warm, whereas cotton and linen articles allow the perspiration to pass through them, so that the evaporation and cooling processes are unchecked.

BOSTON, Feb. 17. -- Some or the dates of the local yacht clubs for next season are now fixed, and seem to show that the regatta committees intend doing all in their power to make the season a lively one. The Corinthian Club of Marblehead starts the season, June 18, with handicap races for the cruising and knockabout classes.

Attached to the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, is the Wharton School of Finance and Economy, the students of which devote themselves to the study of politics and economics. In addition to the general knowledge which they acquire from text books and lectures, the students learn much from examinations of public questions and analyses of Governmental institutions.

In a treatise upon "What Shall Be Done with Turbulent Lunatics Called Cranks," read before the Society of Medical Jurisprudence, Dr. Landon Carter Gray advised that all paranoiaca should be kept in confinement, whether regarded as harmless or not. Dr. Gray divided the insane who threaten or commit crimes into two classes, one of which, with all other insane persons, should be confined in lunatic asylums.

Mrs. John Sherwood in The American Woman. There have been but few women poets. When we have mentioned a creature, perhaps a myth, named Sappho, a reality named Elizabeth Barrett Browning, and a greater wonder, George Eliot, we have nearly exhausted the subject. There is no female Shakespeare, or Milton, or Byron, no woman Dryden, or Pope, or Goldsmith.

When the cholera was at our doors, within them, indeed, eighteen months ago, the efficiency of fear as a hygienic teacher was seen. Children protected themselves against infection, and those ladies of rank and power -- the kitchenmaids -- appreciated and carried out the sanitary requirements of their employers.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Now that the "income tax" is creating so much interest throughout the States, I send you the following interesting article on the subject, which appeared some years ago in a London magazine. The scheme was one for automatically adjusting all incomes and reducing them to something like equilibrium -- that is, the operation of the process set in motion would tend in that direction.

Nothing could be more exemplary or encouraging than the fate of Bourdin, who carried a dynamite bomb to Greenwich Observatory and made himself jump by a premature explosion of the same. If it be always rare sport to the enemy to see the engineer hoist with his own petard, it is especially rare sport when the enemy is the whole of the human race against which the engineer has declared and is waging war.

The funeral of the Rev. Joseph J. Grein was held at the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, 165 Third Street, yesterday. Father Grein died on Thursday at St. Clement's College, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where he held a professorship. He was born in the parish of the Most Holy Redeemer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- How to destroy the Russian thistle and afford relief to the suffering farmers of the Dakotas is the problem that the House Agricultural Committee considered this morning. The committee had before it a bill bearing upon this subject, introduced by Mr. Boen of Minnesota.

After some weeks of rest, chess players have taken to work again, and while the Manhattan, Brooklyn, and City chess men are engaged in the handicap and championship tournaments, Albin, Delmar, Hodges, and Showalter began their respective series of match encounters. Albin and Delmar fight in a five-games-up combat, while Hodges and Showalter are engaged in a seven-games-up tug-of-war.

Ex-Mayor David A. Boody was not present at the dinner which the Montauk Club of Brooklyn, gave last night to Mayor Charles A. Schleren and his Cabinet, at the clubhouse on Eighth Avenue. Mr. Boody's absence was commented on. He is said to still feel sensitive over the result of the last election.
Letter Carrier James W. Cummings of the Van Brunt Station, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, has been arrested by the Post Office authorities for robbing the mails.

The reader with a student's mind will trace in Prof. Blumner's work with the enthusiasm of a lover of pedigrees the kinship between our life of the nineteenth century and that of the free period of Greece before the Roman rule. It is interesting to remember that Greece, although at that time it included Thessaly and out lying.

The General Alumnae Association of Vassar College covered itself with glory at its recent annual meeting in electing Mrs. J. Welles Champney to the office of President. Mrs. Champney is the personification of gracious womanliness, and she added much to the charm of the dinner, which followed the election by her graceful tact. Mrs. Champ-
Mrs. Mekla Arndstein, who disappeared from her home, 342 East Eighty-seventh Street, on the 10th inst., has been found. Her return is shrouded in as much mystery as her disappearance was.

Cyclists, and, in fact, lovers of out-door sport in all sections of the country are looking forward with interest to the meeting of the League of American Wheelmen, which is to be held in Louisville to-morrow. Questions of the utmost importance are to come up for discussion, and the future of this popular sport will depend on the judgment displayed by the delegates.

From The London Globe. An interesting account of "spirit photographs" has been given by M. Fourtier in a French scientific journal. The discoverer, it seems, was an American engraver named Mumler, employed by Mr. Bigelow, a jeweler of Boston. His hobby was photography, and one day in 1861, while developing a plate, he was surprised to see a faint head beside that of the model.

Science is supreme in American production, and the Americans have outrun us all in its application. They were the first to utilize electricity, not merely in the developponent of telegraphy and the kindred arts, but as a powerful ally in manufacture. In the welding of metals, for instance, it now plays an important part.

From The Chicago Tribune, Feb. 7. Stanislaus Jeschke, seven years old. was given a verdict for $15,000 yesterday against the City of Chicago and the People's Gaslight and Coke Company, in Judge Blanke's court, as damages for personal Injuries. In June, 1889, Jeschke was walking on Dixon Street, near Blackhawk, when an explosion occurred in a manhole belonging to the defendants.
