The Maid of Orleans has nothing to gain in honors from being canonized, says The Saturday Review. She is canonized already in the hearts of all who love courage, truth, gentleness, and beauty. The ecclesiastical delay to admit her among the ranks which include such a mere pious marvel-monger as St. Joseph of Cupertino is not easily understood by the lay mind.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- The session of the Coughlin case was given up to-day to the address of Attorney Scanlan to the jury. He did not finish, and will probably close Monday. Referring to the efforts of the Conklins to discover the fate of Dr. Cronin, the attorney said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see that your esteemed contemporaries, The World and The Herald, with their usual charming modesty, are claiming the credit for landing that arch ruffian, John Y. McKane, behind the bars.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Having read with interest in a recent issue of The Times a letter from a Philadelphia architect, Mr. Munoz, in relation to the competition for the new Municipal Building, I take the liberty of writing you, commending the ideas expressed therein.

Tuesday next is the day on which all declarations for the Brooklyn Handicap must be made. When these are announced -- which should be by a week from to-day -- then the prospective racing season of 1894 will begin to make itself felt among the lovers of racing and the owners and trainers of racehorses.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: To make business generally prosperous, it is necessary to find a safe and honest plan by which both gold and silver, permanently and at their relative market values, may be made available as the metallic basis of currency.

The past week has been rather a monotonous one for real estate men. Many things were promising. They are still in the same condition. Actual sales continue to be scarce, and few of any special significance are reported. The present week, if present indications prove true, will make a better showing.

Congressman Tyler of Virginia has introduced a bill into the House of Representatives, authorizing the appropriation of $10,000 by Congress for the purchase of the old Nelson house? at Yorktown, Va. This is the house which frequently, although mistakenly, has been called the headquarters of Cornwallis during the siege of Yorktown.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Mme. Sarah Bernhardt produced last night in her theatre. The Renaissance, a drama in verse, "Izeyl," by MM. Armand Silvestre and Eugene Morand, both well-known authors and the writers of "Griselidis," a play of the same peculiar kind and one of the most legitimate triumphs of the Comedie Francaise.

There were recorded during the past week in Brooklyn 248 conveyances, for the expressed consideration of $4654,830, and 140 where the consideration was nominal. For the corresponding week last year there were 308 conveyances, for $884,478, and 125 for nominal consideration. last week 182 mortgages, for $510,815, were placed on record.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- The argument of the motion for a new trial for Patrick Eugene Prendergast, convicted of the murder of Mayor Harrison, was resumed before Judge Brentano to-day. While Mr. Trude was arguing for the State, he said:
Mrs. Henry O. Havemeyer, wife of the millionaire sugar refiner, had a narrow escape from death while sleighriding on Friday afternoon.

This is a book written with the avowed purpose of showing "how a young man, without inherited resources or influential supporters, and even without proper preliminary culture, may, solely through his own industry, rise and do something useful in the world."
A missionary mass meeting of Sunday schools and mission bands was held yesterday afternoon in the old First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

Yachtsmen are showing signs of getting ready for the season. Few new boats will be out this year, but the old ones should furnish lots of sport, especially in the eighty-five-foot class. In the schooner classes, too, there will be good racing. These classes last year were put in the shade through the interest taken in the cup defenders and cup races, but this year the performances of these boats will be carefully watched.

BUFFALO, Feb. 17. -- Leroy Harris, alias William H. Clark, undergoing examination in United States Commissioner Fairchild's office in the Federal Building, escaped today. He pointed a revolver at the Commissioner, United States District Attorney Mackey, Special Post Office Inspector Latimer, and Deputy United States Marshal Watts, and then made good his escape.

Eighty horses, composing the Huntington Stud of Clay and Arab stock owned by the Arab, Anglo-Arab, and Clay Stock Farm of Oyster Bay. L.I., have gone into the hands of a receiver, and will be sold by order of court at the American Institute Building, New-York, Feb. 22 and 23, by Peter C. Kellogg Co., auctioneers.

There is considerable difference between the Bunch of Grapes Tavern in Boston of the Eighteenth century and Delmonico's of to-day, but the difference was bridged over by the Ohio Company and its offspring, the Ohio Society of New-York, which dined at the modern hostelry last night. The Ohio Company was organized at the Bunch of Grapes Tavern Jan. 25, 1786.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Fred May does not find it easy to keep out of brawls. In spite of the very serious lesson he recently had in the courts, he has again disturbed the peace, but without glory.

Rather peculiar family relations were partially developed yesterday when Mrs. C. S. Parker, a middle-aged though well-pre-served woman, was brought up at the Yorkville Police Court on a charge of horsewhipping her nephew, Charles E. King, who is said to be a newspaper man, and who lives at Asbury Park, N.J.

There is mourning in Gravesend. From Coney Island Point to the Flatlands border the town is plunged in gloom. With their chief on the threshold of State prison and twenty-four of his followers under indictment, the tribe of McKane is completely demoralized. They are so bewildered that they do not know which way to turn for consolation or relief.

The reports from the various charity organizations still are that distress among the unemployed poor is on the increase, and that many families who up to the present have endured semi-starvation have been compelled to go to the people's restaurants for five-cent meals.
LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 17. -- The following special dispatch from Washington was printed here to-day:

At the Casa Camadra are two old log houses, and in them live some squalid, yellow-hided humans who are to farm a little stretch of bottom land this year. They require work steers to do their plowing, and Mr. Bell has brought up half a dozen vicious old "stags," which are both truculent and swift of foot.

My elder by some five years, Tyndall's very marked and vigorous personality must have long taken its final set when we foregathered in 1851. The dyer's hand is subdued to that it works in; and, it may be, that much occupation with types of structure, elsewhere, is responsible for a habit of classifying men to which I was, and am, given.

If forgotten plays like poor Troughton's "Nina Sforza" could be profitably revived, with a few changes of dialogue, and a comma added here and there to the text, to secure modern effect, the lot of the speculator who ventures boldly into the theatrical business (with no knowledge whatever of its requirements) would be much pleasanter.

Now that woman's suffrage is so generally "in the air," says an English print, it is consoling to learn that at the recent general election in New-Zealand everything went off well. For the first time in the history of the British Empire a Parliamentary election has been held, in which the votes of women have been taken as equivalent to those of men.

If it had not been for Plunket Greene, Wagner, and Walter Damrosch in the role of accompanist, nothing would have prevented the fifth concert of the Symphony Society from earning the dread reproach of dullness, than which there is nothing harder to forgive in this world. The principal instrumental number was Saint-Saens's third symphony, which is written for orchestra, piano, and organ.

A committee of the Coney Island Jockey Club conferred with a committee of the new jockey club yesterday afternoon to try and arrange matters so that the Coney Island club could join with the new power that is to govern the turf. The meeting was held in the Coney Island Jockey Clubrooms, in the Cumberland, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-second Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- It was a dull market to-day, without activity in any particular stock, although transactions were made in almost everything on the list. Compared with the closing prices of yesterday, today's figures on final sales show the market to have been a weak and a lower one. West Chicago opened at 135, and at once declined to 134 1/4, recovering later to 134 1/2.

Representative teams of New-Yorkers and Philadelphians are to have another test of strength and skill in the football field, and the struggle will be carried on under the rules of the English Football Association, which have come strangely into prominence since the recent discussion on the improvement of the American game.

The chief source of ivory is that obtained from the elephants of Africa and Asia. Ivory so obtained may be distinguished, owing to the African, when first cut, exhibiting hardly any grain, being first of a transparent tint, afterward becoming liglrter in color. Asiatic, when first cut, is like African which has been cut for some time, but becomes yellow by exposure to light.

The history of mathematics is the history of a science to which the world is immeasurably indebted. Take out what has come to us through this science and the residuum would be pitiful. It has been, in all ages, part of men's daily lives. They have depended on it in the economy of the household, in the operations of business, in the development of great enterprises, and other sciences have been built upon it.

If it had not been for Plunket Greene, Wagner, and Walter Damrosch in the role of accompanist, nothing would have prevented the fifth concert of the Symphony Society from earning the dread reproach of dullness, than which there is nothing harder to forgive in this world. The principal instrumental number was Saint-Saens's third symphony, which is written for orchestra, piano, and organ.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 17. -- The snowstorm of the early part of the week afforded the best sleighing of this season. At this resort the snow remains well packed and smooth in the drives long after the roads about the village are little more than mud. Among the many sleighing parties was that of Mrs. George J. Gould Tuesday afternoon, which included Mrs. Charles B. Alexander of New-York.

Amateur oarsmen on this side of the Atlantic are going to make another effort to win the Diamond Sculls, the great single-shell prize in England. With that purpose in view, the Toronto Rowing Club has decided to send J.J. Ryan and Joseph Wright to compete at the Henley Regatta. They will also enter in the double-scull race at the same regatta for the Silver Goblet prize.

Eighty thousand dollars is the amount already raised by the Committee of Twenty appointed by Mayor Gilroy to raise and distribute a fund for the relief of the unemployed of this city. This amount has been contributed by the members of the committee itself. Other contributions made to the committee are not included in the $80,000.

At the meeting of the City Vigilance Leagrue last night at 222 Bowery the Rev. Dr. C.H. Parkhurst was the principal speaker. He spoke of ex-Senator T.C. Platt in a manner far from flattering. He said:

Airy gowns of sheerest muslin and filmiest lace, made for garden parties in Augrust; crisp, cool-looking ginghams, dimities, batistes, and wash crepons -- these set against a background of a Dakota blizzard are sufficiently incongruous. In these forehanded days, however, when Thanksgiving numbers of the periodicals are made up in May, and Christmas carols are composed in July, they are not unusual.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 17. -- The American Citizen, a weekly publication in the interests of the Catholics, and directly antagonistic to the American Protective Association, to-day prints the following letter on American citizenship from Theodore Roosevelt:

While riding on the freight elevator in the seven-story factory building 167 Elm Street, yesterday afternoon, Maurice Berman, eighteen years old, of 82 Avenue C. was caught between the floor of the elevator and the wall of the shaft, and had both legs cut off. He was taken to the Chambers Street Hospital in a dying condition.

Profs. Woodrow Wilson of Princeton and Burt G. Wilder of Cornell discussed the question, "Ought Football to be Encouraged?" recently before the Art Club of Philadelphia. The former took the affirmative. The meeting was called by the Contemporary Club, and Dr. Harrison Allen, who presided, introduced the speakers.

Last season The New-York Times, in order to encourage purely amateur sport of all kinds, offered several gold, silver, and bronze medals for various contests. The prizes were offered to organizations and clubs that were deserving of support, and were given solely to promote interest in the contests for which they were offered and in the interest of amateur contests.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17. -- Minority stockholders of the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad, who own upward of 10,000 shares of stock, have retained Counselor James W. M. Newlin for the purpose of filing a bill in equity against the Board of Directors of the road if the latter refuses to furnish the information which David S. Thompson called upon the Secretary to give at the annual meeting of the stockholders last Monday.

This year the gymnastic championships of the Amateur Athletic Union promise to be of more than ordinary interest. They will be held under the auspices of the Orange Athletic Club in the club's large tennis building on the evening of Feb. 22.

With no Winter racing within a thousand miles of New-York, the dally Winter conferences of horsemen which have been a feature for the past few years have been missed at the St. James Hotel, the Hoffman House, and Delmonico's. Horsemen get together occasionally, but many familiar faces are missed.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 17. -- It is rumored in political circles here, to-night that Associate Justices B.B. Battle and W.W. Mansfield of the State Supreme Bench intend handing their resignations to the Governor early next week, assigning as a reason therefor ill health, overwork, and inadequacy of salary.
William Browne of Tavistock wrote in the time of James I., in the Elizabethan manner, but without the freshness of the early pastoral poets, heartfelt praises of the scenery of Devonshire.

Bickerings between stepmother, stepchildren, and the woman's own son have furnished Fire Marshal Mitchel with a peculiar and somewhat interesting case, as he will have to determine whether Esther Cohen maliciously destroyed property by fire at 213 East Sixty-eighth Street on Thursday and Friday, on testimony to be given by Mrs. Cohen's husband, Bernard, and his children by his first wife.

BERLIN, Feb. 17. -- The Reichstag debated to-day the condition of Germany's African colonies, notably the Cameroons. On a table near the President's seat several whips of hippopotamus hide and other instruments of castigation were displayed. They were said to be specimens of German authority in Africa and were discussed as such by speakers who attacked the Government's colonial policy.
"He's the most insufferable prig," said Winthrop Rutgers to Chalmers Channing one night a little later at the club, "that it has ever thus far been my sombre fate to encounter."

In the good old, prosperous days of Aberdeen, a pier was built 100 yards or so out into the river, affording a harbor along the city's front. On its stony area great buildings were constructed, warehouses and granaries, the precursors of modern elevators. For a time that haven was crowded to overbrimming with all the various craft of traffic.

Frederic R. Coudert gave a delightful lecture last evening at the Catholic Club, 120 West Fifty-ninth Street, on "Manners and Morals." He was presented by President Fornes. For an hour and a half he talked in an unconventional way, with an entertaining mixture of satire, cynicism, humor, and seriousness.

Rufus M. Stivers's carriage factory, 144 to 152 West Thirty-first Street, was seriously damaged by fire yesterday afternoon. Shortly after 1 o'clock persons living opposite the factory saw smoke issuing from the lower floor of the eastern end of the building.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18. -- The advance sheets of President Eliot's annual report, which were read on Wednesday by Prof. Briggs to the classes in English A. have caused great discussion in the college, on account of the radical changes in athletics which are suggested. The President pleads for reform in college athletics, and suggests that no contests between athletic teams from colleges should be held on other than college grounds.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18. -- At Yale the topic of the day is the approaching annual election to the editorships of The Yale Literary Magazine, one of the oldest college magazines published, and one of the best literary productions edited by university students. Alumni of Yale everywhere nave accorded the magazine cordial support for years, and it has won for itself a wide circle of readers outside the college world.

In this new volume of the beautiful Appleton edition of the writings of Prof. Huxley, the author in his preface throws down the gauntlet at once, and perhaps in a manner that will irritate those who hold certain traditions as sacred. He may at least be taxed with not having alone a fixed amount of intolerance, but with being occasionally contemptuous.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- It is expected that this year's baseball team at the Military Academy will be the strongest ever seen on the diamond here. The majority of the members have had several years' experience at the game.

The foreign exchange market was dull, generally firm, and almost destitute of feature. Posted rates for sterling on Saturday were $4.86 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.88 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done on Saturday at $4.85 1/2@$4.85 3/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.87 1/2@$4.87 3/4 for demand, $4.87 3/4@ $4.88 for cable transfers, and $4.84 3/4@$4.85 for commercial.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18. -- The work of the religious societies of the college is being stimulated by the presence of two eminent teachers. Bishop John H. Vincent, one of the university preachers, is now holding the morning services at the chapel, and is doing beneficial outside work through his course of lectures at the Divinity School on "The Pastor," and his addresses before the Oxford Club and the Epworth League.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 18. -- One killed and several slightly injured is the result of a most thrilling accident in this city this afternoon. The drawing cable of an aerial car snapped in two, leaving the car and passengers 200 feet in midair, while the broken end of the cable smashed through the frail box.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- The Executive Committee of the State Board of Health has made a report of an investigation it conducted into some branches of its own office, which shows a condition of things little, if any, short of a scandal. When the situation was learned radical changes were recommended, to take effect on March 1.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 18. -- The attempted religious conquest of the large Italian colony in Orange by the mission workers of the First Presbyterian Church is being hotly contested by the clergy and members of St. John's Roman Catholic Church, and the war between the forces of the two religious beliefs has begun to assume a very bitter aspetc.

The announcement that the Cambridge Hotel, at Water and Catharine Streets, is closed, and that its owner, Heinrich Stiehler, butcher, at 16 Catharine Street, would be glad to secure a tenant, should, to be complete, recite that it was once the Fourth Ward Hotel, and, in April, 1891, the East River Hotel.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 18. -- During the morning services at the East Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church to-day, the pastor, the Rev. C.M. Pegg, roundly scored Manager William Kling and his conduct of the Gem Theatre. Kling recently opened a variety theatre in the hose company's hall, near the East Avenue Church.

Mr. Bland of Missouri will renew his fight for his "Seigniorage" bill this week. It has already been a weary one on his side, and the opposition to it has been very determined. The noteworthy thing about it is that it has attracted almost no attention, and that even the "Washington wires" running to Wall Street have hardly taken cognizance of it.

Several of the most active promoters of the new Suburban Driving Club met yesterday at the West End Club, on Riverside Drive and One Hundred and Fiftieth Street. Although all these men own fast trotters, the roads were in such a bad state that not one of them drove out, but found their way by horse car.

Several complaints have been made recently to the police of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station that women alighting from the Madison Avenue cars at the tunnel stairways between Thirty-third and Forty-second Streets have been insulted by well-dressed men who loitered around the tunnel stairways.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Postmaster General Bissell has determined to see whether or not the Government can save considerable money in the stamped-envelope contract during the next few years, and to that end has had the specifications prepared unusually early, with the intention of advertising the contract on or about March 1, and throwing open the competition to everyone who can give satisfactory assurances of ability to execute its terms.

The traditional thief that walked off with a red-hot stove was not of a more original turn in peculation than John Leerle and Walter Bailey, who were arrested at One Hundred and Sixty-third Street and Sheridan Avenue by Policeman Sheehan Saturday night, and arraigned in the Morrisanla Police Court yesterday.

It has long been the boast of New-Yorkers that, since the advent of the electric light and the improvement in the municipal police force, any one -- man, woman, or child -- could walk the streets of this city at all hours of the day or night in almost perfect security from insult, attack, or robbery.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- A sequel to the story of Robert G.H. Huntingdon, the defaulting Secretary of the House Building and Loan Association, who died in Costa Rica, promises to involve a number of men heretofore unsuspected and untarnished, who, it is claimed, acted as confederates of Huntington and assisted in his work of plunder.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, Feb. 18. -- The Agrarians rallied their thousands in Berlin yesterday to make their final protest against the Russo-German commercial treaty. The demonstration was successful from the party point of view, as the assemblages were enormous and enthusiastic.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Therer was a fair activity in the market for local securities the last week, although little result is shown in changes of quotations. Hudson River Telephone was the feature of the dealings, and a block of the stock which had been offered for some time was absorbed between 30 and ALBANY, Feb. 18 32.

PROVIDENCE, Feb. 17. -- Little can be said of our local stock market this week, as the sales of local securities have been very limited. A number of transactions for small lots of Providence and Worcester Railroad took place at about 249. Perhaps the most noticeable feature is the extremely light offerings of the better class of securities.

Alexander H. Strouse, who was formerly a manufacturer of trimmings in this city, was attacked with apoplexy at Minke Causse's restaurant, Seventy-second Street and Third Avenue, Friday evening, and died soon after. He had been accustomed to pass his evenings there, and Friday evening took his usual seat near a window.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Feb. 18. -- A report that the Richmond County Grand Jury has found indictments in the election cases has created great excitement. Rumor says that the indictments found are in the cases of certain Southfleld Inspectors of Election. As the evidence of fraud in four Castleton districts is much stronger than the evidence to the district where the indictments are said to have been found, many additional indictments seem certain.

Moored to a wharf at the Pierpont Stores, Brooklyn, lies one of the biggest sailing ships afloat. This vessel, which has been planned on such a heroic scale, is the Roanoke, of Bath. She is comparatively new, and, despite her great size and enormous spread of canvass, has not earned yet earned particular distinction as a fast sailer.

The constant practice at the armory range which the men of the Seventh Regiment get and the emulation created by the frequently-recurring prize competitions have had the effect of placing the marksmen of this regiment far in advance of those of any other organization. Week after week they roll up scores which show a very high state of efficiency.

A mode of advertising that has been growing very popular with theatrical managers during the past few seasons is the placing of large frames containing photographs of the scenes and people in the plays under their management in the shop windows along the principal thoroughfares in the cities they visit.

ORANGE, Feb. 18. -- The annual championship gymnastic competitions of the Amateur Athletic Union which will be held in the Orangre Athletic Club tennis building next Thursday promise to be spirited and quite a field of notable performers will be presented from which to pick the winners. The full list of entries, which has now closed, is as follows:

The Executive Committee of the United States Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of the Free Sons of Israel, met yesterday at its headquarters, 791 Lexington Avenue. There were present Julius Harburger. Grand Master; S. Hofftheimer, Deputy Grand Master; M.S. Meyerhoff of Philadelphia, Adolph Pike, J.H. Goldsmith, David Keller, William A. Gans, Judge Philip Stein of Chicago, Samuel Stein, Maler Berliner, Herman Stiefel, Benjamin Blumenthal, L. Frankenthaler, and I.J. Sehwarzkopf.

The men who were appointed at Thomas C. Platt's show held in Cooper Union on Feb. 9 to prepare a plan of organization and a constitution and by-laws for the opposition to the Committee of Thirty issued yesterday a manifesto.

The new Fourth Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Fortyseventh Street, Brooklyn, was dedicated with imposing services yesterday. The church edifice has been in process of construction since last May. It is a handsome brick structure. The new church has been built to shelter a congregation which will be fourteen years old on May 24 next.
The campaign for the Supervisorship of the Eighth Ward, Brooklyn, promises to be lively. It will open to-night.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Feb. 19 -- A.M. The commonplaces that abounded in last week's markets were relieved by several distinctive features. Granger stocks had been the special aversion of the bears. The continued inability of this class of properties to make net earnings compare favorably with those of the corresponding period of last year had for a long time been effective in depressing prices.

Adolf Albin and Eugene Delmar contested their fourth same of the match at the Manhattan Chess Club on Saturday. The local player adopted the two knights' defense, and after a complicated game of nearly seventy moves. Albin proved the victor. The latter played a remarkably clever and patient game.

Steinitz, the champion of the world, visited the Brooklyn Chess Club on Saturday evening, when twenty-four members played twelve games against the champion, the latter conducting the games simultaneously, two always consulting at each board. Play commenced at 8 P.M., and concluded at 1:30 A.M. yesterday, when Steinitz had won nine, lost two, and drawn one.

It has become the fashion in Wall Street to find fault and indulge in wailing. Hopelessness has developed into a fad. This fact is the most conspicuous thing discernible anywhere in the Stock Exchange district. A casual observer must be forced to the conclusion that the average broker and investor have given up all expectation of ever again seeing good times.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 18. -- The public reconciliation of the Polish Catholic congregation of the Sacred Heart of Mary and its pastor, the Rev. Mr. Kolasinski, who had been at odds with the church authorities for the last five years, took place to-day.

The attempt of Senator Owens of Brooklyn to legalize the opening of saloon side doors on Sunday has aroused a tempest of opposition among the respectable residents of that city. Yesterday an indignation meeting was held by the Brooklyn Temperance League at Bedford Avenue and South Third Street, at which Senator Owens was denounced for his action.
In his remarks preceding his sermon last night, the Rev. Madison C. Peters of the Bloomingdale Church, Boulevard and West Sixty-eighth Street, said:

Gov. McKinley and Mrs. McKinley are visitors at the house of Col. William Strong, 12 West Fifty -- seventh Street. Yesterday morning they started out to go to the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church to hear Bishop Walden preach, but a shower of rain caused a change of plan and they attended services at St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, in Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- The Ballot-Reform bills are to come from the committees this week, and effort will be made to secure early consideration of them. Senator Saxton, the leader of the Republicans in the Senate, has prepared several amendments to the proposed ballot-reform laws now under consideration.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18. -- The candidates for the baseball team have been practicing in the cage regularly under the supervision of Capt. McKenzie. During the past week none of the men have been dropped, though it is likely that the "weeding" process will begin in a few days. There has been noted improvement during the last week, and some or the new material begins to look promising.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- An examination will be held here on March 12 to fill six vacancies in the Medical Corps of the army. About thirty applicants will compete for the prizes, which are considered among the best in the staff corps. The examinations are very rigid, physically and professionally, and difficulty has been found in securing young doctors who can make the averages required by the Medical Board.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- For three or four reasons there is great interest in this city in the Supreme Court vacancy. So long as it was uncertain whether Mr. Peckham's nomination would be confirmed, there was, of course, a local interest in the fight, because ex-Judge Maynard, whose "wrongs" were being avenged by Senator Hill and his peanut followers, was here all the While.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed a decrease in reserve of $11,096,875. The banks now hold $74,536,826 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans of $6,743,300, a decrease in specie of $9,212,700, a decrease to legal tenders of $2,930,200, a decrease in deposits of $4,184,100, and a decrease in circulation of $447,300.

At the Roman Catholic Church of the Visitation, Verona and Richards Streets, Brooklyn, the Rev. John F. Loughran and three policemen prevented twenty-five members of the choir from entering the choir loft just before the 11 o'clock mass yesterday. One young roan who insisted on taking part in the service was unceremoniously pushed down stairs and ejected from the church.

The New-York Genealogical and Biographical Society is to have a grand celebration Tuesday evening, Feb. 27. On that day the society will be twenty-five years old, and the members think the occasion should be duly honored. So they have invited Bishop Potter to talk to them in the evening about colonial times and the well-known families who helped to lay the foundation of America's present prosperity and greatness.

PLYMOUTH, Penn., Feb. 18. -- There has been no cessation of the efforts of the rescuers who are digging for the men who were entombed early last week by the caving in of the roof of a mine, but the general opinion is that the thirteen victims will never be rescued alive. All day the rescuers have worked ceaselessly, gang succeeding gang at regular intervals.

The Small Boy engaged the attention of the Municipal Police Department yesterday in a manner utterly disproportionate to his size. Home seemed to have no charms for him, and so he employed his leisure time by running away and getting lost. One wanderer was Purcell Lewis of Oneida, N.Y. Purcell, though but twelve years old, is an incorrigible runaway.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 17. -- Returns for the week show very few changes in the stock or financial situation. Money is in plentiful supply, and the demand is lighter, if anything, than usual. Stocks and bonds are moving about even with last week's volume and the only price changes, covering small fractions, are to be noted in National Gas stocks and the street railways.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 18. -- The campaign which is to result next Fall in the election of a Governor and a United States Senator for Georgia has already opened. The Gubernatorial fight was formally inaugurated a few days since with the first of a series of mass meetings to be held in different parts of the State, and the contest for the Senatorship has been in progress in a quiet way for many months.

BOSTON, Feb. 18. -- A.H. Linder, the Harvard student who was rendered unconscious by a single blow while boxing with Arthur Foster Tuesday night, died to-day. He had not regained consciousness since the accident.

Good Government A. Club held a successful and largely attended "smoker" at the clubhouse. 722 Lexington Avenue, Saturday evening. The members and their friends were entertained by professional talent, and also by volunteers from the members. Among the latter were Dr. Julius Wolff, cello soloist; George H. Englehard, violin: Fired McKone, whistling, and Mr. Richardson, tenor.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 18. -- An old, grizzled, toil-worn man, apparently about seventy years of age, entered one of the banks here a few days ago and inquired whether they would purchase gold dust or not. His unkempt appearance, his dirty face and hands, and his generally dilapidated appearance caused the cashier to cut him short with curt words.

Cincinnati, Ohio, is excited because the great bridge between New-York and Brooklyn is reported not to be safe. A newspaper out there alleges that the famous structure is out of plumb. This startling discovery, the newspaper says, was made by an Eastern mechanical expert, who alleges that one of the main cables has slipped through the nut at its anchorage, allowing the bridge bed to sag two inches.

The joint sub-committee charged with investigating the navy personnel will no doubt soon be hard at work on Secretary Herbert's scheme of reorganization and the other plans that, may be submitted to it. Meanwhile excitement and protest have been stirred up by the bill introduced into the Senate at request by Mr. Hale.

The Sheepshead Bay Methodist Episcopal Sunday School, over which John Y. McKane formerly presided as Superintendent, met yesterday afternoon at the usual time in the neat little schoolroom in the real of the Sheepshead Bay Methodist Episcopal Church.

ROME, Feb. 18. -- More than 100,000 persons gathered at St. Peter's between 9:40 and 11 o'clock this morning to see the Pope celebrate the last mass of his jubilee year. During the mass the Pope wore the mitre given him by the German Emperor, and afterward the tiara presented to him by Emperor Franz Joseph of Austria-Hungary.

The lectures on art by Mr. John La Farge, which The Times reported fully at the time they were delivered, have attracted so much attention among artists and art lovers that a number of gentlemen and ladies have bestirred themselves to ask the lecturer for a repetition of the course. Many people who knew of these lectures were prevented from attending them by engagements; others will be glad to hear them again.

The Rev. Dr. J.D. Fulton, in the Free Baptist Church at Twenty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue, delivered a sermon yesterday on "Fighting Priests and Frightend Romanists," the topic being suggested by the incident in a Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. when Father McDonald knocked down and kicked Father Hill.

Justices Newton, Sutherland, and Gladding of Coney Island received a shock yesterday when they read the announcement made in the columns of this paper that one of the Gravesend Inspectors of Election and another follower of John Y. McKane, have offered to give evidence for the State in its prosecution of the indicted election officials.

It has been reported since the Wilson bill was sent to the Senate that the Subcommittee of the Committee on Finance was contemplating the removal of bituminous coal and iron ore from the bill's free list. It has also been said that there was no truth in this report, but in spite of the published denials the story has been repeated.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted at 64@64 1/2c on Saturday, with sales at 64 1/4c.

The United States Treasury will begin business this morning with assets of $789,364,442 and liabilities of $651,766,112, and a total cash balance of $137,598,330, of which $105,530,332 will be in gold. It is an interesting question how long this money will last, as against current liabilities and expenditures.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 18. -- Benjamin Delemos, Secretary of the State Republican Campaign Committee, has caused a sensation by publishing in several State papers a card in which he brings certain charges against the Kolbite and Populist leaders.

In every Congress for the last ten years there have been legislators who professed to be interested deeply in certain proposed reforms affecting the existing system of patent laws and the rules of procedure in the Patent Office. These gentlemen have introduced a great many bills for the amendment of the statutes, but none of them of any importance has come to anything.

-- Imperial Music Hall. -- At the Imperial Music Hall there are two companies. Gus Hill's stars come first, and include Farnum brothers, acrobats and gymnasts; C.W. Littlefield, the mimic, and Bryant and Saville, instrumentalists and burlesque players. Harris and Walters, Manning and Griffin, McRoble and Evans, and other performers are with this company.

In passing sentence on McKane, Judge Bartlett evidently gave some heed to the recommendation of the jury. He fixed the penalty midway between the minimum and maximum terms of imprisonment which the law provides for such offenses. There will doubtless be all the delay in the execution of the sentence that can be interposed by the use of money in employing skillful counsel and resorting to every device that our judicial procedure admits of.

DANVILLE, Va., Feb. 19 -- In the Summer of 1893 a colored woman named Bettie Thompson came to this city from Raleigh, N.C. She recommended herself as a missionary, and was taken to the hearts, homes, and churches of the colored people. After making a number of talks in the churches, and ingratiating herself into the confidence of the people, she begun to talk of holiness, entire sanctification,

Bizet's "Carmen" was performed for the twelfth time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before a small audience. That was because "Carmen" was what some persons call an unexpected pleasure. Massenet's "Werther" was to have been produced for the first time in America, but Mme. Emma Eames was incapacitated yesterday morning by a very severe case of laryngitis, and so the opera had to be postponed.

The eighteenth annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club will open to-day at the Madison Square Garden. About 1,500 entries have been made in the different classes, and Superintendent James Mortimer has been sorely puzzled to know how to place the dogs so that they can all be seen.

PLYMOUTH, Penn., Feb. 19 -- Entering Plymouth to-day, one would never dream that underneath the town search was being prosecuted for thirteen entombed miners. Popular interest in the search has subsided, as there is little hope of rescuing the men alive.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- Reading declined slightly to-day on comparatively light transactions, and St. Paul showed a disposition to advance. Lehigh Valley was sold down to 39 1/4, and closed at the bottom. The officials of that company do not seem to have made much headway in the matter of listing their coal company's bonds.

It is two years since the committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art appointed to enlarge the collection of casts made its last report. Yesterday the Trustees received a pamphlet containing the report of Mr. Robert W. de Forest, Vice Chairman, which gives the condition of the collection at the beginning of the month.

The British steamer Miranda, Capt. Leisman, arrived at this port yesterday with news from Central American ports. The steamer stopped at Cape Gracias a Dios on Feb. 1, at Greytown on Feb. 7, and also Bluefields, the destination of the Kearsarge on her ill-fated voyage. James Rankin, the New-York agent of the Central American Steamship Company, and his wife were passengers on the Miranda.

Sidney Faber, the Second Avenue pharmacist, who is Secretary of the New-York German Apothecaries' Association, met a number of the members yesterday afternoon at the exhibition of instruments of torture in West Twenty-third Street, to talk as an expert about the exhibits, and to deliver a lecture on "European Executioners of the Olden Times, and Their Swords."
With the passing of sentence on McKane, the public offices he held became vacant. The County Clerk of Kings County yesterday sent the following notification to Gov. Flower:

Mlle. Arman d'Ary, a bright little chanteuse Parisienne, from Les Folies Bergeres, Paris, made her American debut at Koster Bial's music hall last night, and from the moment she stepped out from the wings, with a demure bow, until she made her exit, after a pretty little spech in French, she held the undivided attention of her audience.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 19 -- The application made recently by Peter Bentley. Mrs. Elinor B. Dixon, and Emily Bentley, for the removal of Mrs. Emma Bentley, their mother, as administratrix of their father's estate, came before Chancellor McGill this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Henry S. Holden, a wealthy dealer in gas fixtures at 67 and 69 South Canal Street, who was held under bonds of $4,000 to answer to Justice Gibbons Friday morning on a charge of bigamy, was instantly killed in the La Salle Street tunnel at noon to-day. He was riding on the grip car of a south-bound cable train.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Dr. Granger of Chester, the physician and oculist who has been in attendance upon Mr. Gladstone, was interviewed to-day in regard to the condition of Mr. Gladstone's eyes, it having been said in some quarters that the Prime Minister was threatened with blindness, resulting from cataracts.
Joseph Keppler, the noted caricaturist and one of the founders and owners of Puck, died at his home, 27 East Seventy-ninth Street, at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Another day was spent by the House in a fruitless endeavor to secure a quorum that would vote in favor of taking up Mr. Bland's bill to coin the seigniorage of the Treasury bullion.

Citizens of Kings County have another "boss" to deal with besides "Boss" McKane. Justice, having taken care of the despot of Gravesend, is now after Cornelius Furgueson of New-Utrecht. Last Summer The New-York Times turned a searchlight on his record, and now that McKane is caged, it again calls public attention to the New-Utrecht "boss."

It was announced yesterday that Maurice Barrymore, the actor, had married Miss Mamie Floyd, and that the wedding, which had thus far been kept a secret, occurred over two months ago. Mr. Barrymore has been seen frequently in the street and in dry goods stores recently in company with Miss Floyd, but his most intimate friends had no suspicion that the pair were man and wife.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Opening prices on the Exchange were slightly easier than Saturday's close, but the tone of the market was considerably improved, and under this influence there was a recovery in many instances. Lake Street, in which there was good trading, opened at 21 1/8, and before the termination of the call it had been worked up to 21 1/2.

At last night's meeting of the Republican Club, 450 Fifth Avenue, Henry L. Einstein, Chairman of the Campaign Committee, submitted a report showing what the club had done in the special Congressional elections in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congressional Districts, and predicting that the Republicans might elect four or five Congressmen at the next general election.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Mr. Daniel (Dem., Va.,) addressed the Senate to-day in defense of President's Cleveland's action in regard to Hawaii, stigmatizing Minister Stevens's conduct as "the presumptuous, vicious freak of an eccentric Minister."

The evangelistic campaign in this city, inaugurated by the Rev. A.C. Dixon of the Hanson Place Baptist Church of Brooklyn and other ministers and evangelists who labored in the recent great revival in Brooklyn, was begun yesterday under the most favorable circumstances. The first meeting was held at noon in the large hall of the Ycung Men's Christian Association at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue.

Ernesto Camillo Sivori. Ernesto Camillo Sivori, the famous violinist, pupil of Paganini, died in Genoa yesterday. He was born at Genoa June 6, 1817. His mother, who loved music ardently, had for the first time heard Paganini at the San Agostino playhouse the previous evening.

The last testimony in the suit of Ithamar Howe to recover $50,000 damages from Isaac O. Woodruff, the Maiden Lane druggist, for alienating the affections of Mrs. Howe, the impulsive girl wife, was taken yesterday before Justice Ingraham in the Supreme Court. The case will go to the jury to-day.

Michael Liddy, thirty-three years old, of 100 Third Street, South Brooklyn, was found at 10 o'clock last night, at Joralemon and Furman Streets, that city. Policeman Lynch supposed Liddy was drunk and took him to the Fifteenth Precinct Station. Liddy explained that he had been struck on the head with an iron bar by an unknown man and knocked off the dock at the foot of Joralemon Street.

The defense in the suit of Mrs. Isador Fried -- or Miss Estelle Pettit, as she prefers to be called -- against Isador Fried for an annulment of their marriage on the ground that she was under the influence of drugs when the ceremony was performed began yesterday in the Court of Common Pleas, before Judge Bischoff.

A melodrama that amuses and thrills a theatre full of people, swinging them from the first to the second form of mental activity, in quick and frequent alternation, must in very necessity be called a good melodrama.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Blatz's tannery here, after an idleness of several months, started up this morning with a full force of men, who will work full time every day, as the outlook, it is said, for the Spring trade of the firm is bright.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Acting under orders from the Ministry of the Interior, the police throughout France are engaged to-day in making extensive raids upon the haunts of Anarchists. A large number of arrests of men known to be Anarchists or suspected of sympathizing with them have been made. Among those taken into custody is Sebastian Faure.

A report recently published by the Connecticut Bureau of Labor Statistics contains some interesting information as to the labor cost of products in many of the protected industries of that State. The statistics relate to the year 1891, and were prepared by a Republican and protectionist Commissioner, who compiled them from returns made to him by the proprietors of 624 factories for three consecutive years.

In announcing his intention to hand over to the organized charities of the city the funds intrusted to him for relief of the poor the Mayor has relieved himself from a task which he has neither any time nor any special appliances for performing well. He has also put the money where there is every reason to expect that it will do the most good.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Soon after the Senate began its session to-day, the rumor reached the floor that a Senator was to be named, and the grossips immediately connected the name of Mr. Faulkner with the report. The West Virginia Senator was for some an object of considerable interest. Several Senators who are not satisfied with their present seats in the Chamber went so far as to apply for his desk, which is favorably situated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- In the House to-day Mr. De Armond offered the following resolution:

The re-sale of the old Journal of Commerce Building and lot, at Beaver, Hanover, and Pearl Streets, 22 by 99.8 by 20 by 90, was announced yesterday. The new purchasers are G. Amsinck Co., and the price paid is $141,000. This property was put up at auction early in the month and was bid in at $148,000.

When the full Board of Police Commissioners met in the Central Office courtroom yesterday to try Capt. James K. Price and Detectives Hay and Curry of the Twentieth Police Precinct, the defendants were there with their counsel, Charles W. Brooke. With the witnesses were Superintendent Byrnes and Inspector McAvoy.

The determination to keep secret the proceedings that have begun in Vienna for the trial of the Anarchists is undoubtedly judicious. Secret trials, and especially secret State trials, are so contrary to the traditions of the English-speaking countries that it would probably be impossible to secure the passage of a law giving Judges or other officials the right to order judicial proceedings to be held in secret.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Feb. 19 -- Mamie Scherter, who left her home at Valley Stream, L.I., to search for a recreant lover, is a prisoner in the county jail here. She is charged by the man she loved with conspiring to ruin his reputation.

Hanna Korany, the young Syrian who represented her countrywomen at the World's Fair with dignity and grace, was presented to Sorosis, and Sorosis to her, at Sherry's yesterday afternoon. Mrs. William Tod Helmuth made the introductions.

The peace and solemnity which usually characterize the weekly meetings of the Baptist Ministers' Association did not prevail at the conference held yesterday morning in the Twenty-third Street Baptist Church. For a time there was a lively and exciting debate on the question of compulsory attendance at the meetings.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 12 -- The steam yacht Natalie, which cleared from Savannah early last month, with a supply of arms and ammunition for Gen. Manigat, the Haitian revolutionary leader, has not been heard of here since she sailed.

Joseph F. Blaut, late President of the Madison Square Bank, who is on trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, charged with swearing falsely to a quarterly report of the condition of the institution on June 1, 1993, and the lawyers who are defending him were in a cheerful mood last evening when Justice Barrett adjourned court until to-day.

The Lyceum Theatre has had no other "first night" so thoroughly enjoyable this season. Mr. Pinero's new play, "The Amazons," is one of his whimsical pieces in the lighter vein, more in the manner of "The Cabinet Minister" than in that of "The Magistrate," but not so essentially and uncompromisingly British as that satirical piece, which could not be acclimatized hare.
The order which acts as a temporary stay for McKane was signed by Supreme Court Justice Edgar M. Cullen a few minutes before 10 o'clock last night at his residence, 144 Willow Street, Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- Emperor William to-day returned the visit recently made to his Majesty at Berlin by Prince Bismarck. The Emperor, accompanied by a suite of five officers, proceeded to the Lehrte railway station, where the imperial train was in waiting to convey them to Friedrichsruh. On the way to the station, the people, who knew the Emperor's destination, cheered him heartily.

Senator White proved his unquestionable right to the title of a good constitutional lawyer Jan. 30, 1893, in the debate in the Senate on "options," and "futures." Mr. White's opponent in the debate was Senator George of Mississippi.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 19 -- The General Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen began its session at the Gault House at 11 A.M. Ninety-five delegates were present in person and eighty-three proxies were accredited. Messrs. J.T. Holmes and H.W. Stebbens of the Michigan Division asked to be admitted.

The first of an interesting and instructive course of illustrated Monday afternoon lectures on "Art Studies in Comparative Religion" was given yesterday afternoon in Hardman Hall, Fifth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, by Prof. J. Leonard Corning, formerly Director of the department of history and literature of art in the Chautauqua University.

The fifth game of the chess match between J.W. Showalter of Kentucky and A.B. Hodges of Staten Island was played at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, when Hodges scored after twenty-nine moves. The winner selected the Sicilian Defense, and won the game in consequence of a blunder which Showalter committed in the opening -- viz., on his eleventh move with Q -- Q2.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- No startling novelty has been introduced by Mr. Herbert Hall Winslow into his new comedy, "A Fashionable Girl," which Daniel Frohman's Lyceum Comedy Company presented to-night at the Boston Museum, but the play is nevertheless an addition to the repertory of the American stage, of which both author and manager may be proud, and in which a company of clever actors finds admirable exercise for ability.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- There have been many conflicting rumors to-day concerning the sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Finance, which has charge of the Tariff bill.

HARRISBURG, Feb. 19 -- William F. Shunk of this city, who had main charge of the survey of the proposed intercontinental railway to connect the three Americas, has practically completed his report of his operations, which will soon be submitted to the commission which employed him, with financial aid from each of the associated republics in proportion to their population.

BOSTON, Feb. 19. -- There were few transactions in local securities to-day outside of the copper stocks and Wisconsin Central. The bonds and stocks of the latter were strong, particularly the first mortgage 5s, which rose 1 1/4, to 70, receding later to 69. The incomes rose to 14, and the stock advanced 1/8 to 6 3/4.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The bill to amend the Inter-State Commerce act so as to authorize railroad companies to issue 5,000-mile interchangeable railroad tickets, with excess baggage privileges to commercial travelers, will probably receive favorable action at the meeting of the Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce on Wednesday next.

NEW-YORK. Monday, Feb. 19 -- P.M. Sugar held its lead to-day in the stock market, furnishing 58,200 shares out of total sales of 153,316 shares. Reports from Washington were in circulation all day, and the market followed them, regardless of their source or motive.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 19 -- The case of the Adams Express Company against ex-Vice President Clapp Spooner of this city has been amicably settled out of court. The terms of the settlement will not be made public, but several transfers of valuable property belonging to Mr. Spooner are recorded in the Town Clerk's office in this sity.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- To celebrate the completion of Treasurer William Durant's sixty years of service to the publishers of The Evening Transcript, the employes of The Transcript Company to the number of about 150 tendered Mr. Durant a complimentary dinner this evening. Besides Mr. Durant there were present as guests of the employes all the members of The Transcript corporation.

Mr. H. Maitland Kersey, who has represented Lord Dunraven in this country, is of the opinion that there will be very little racing this year in the eighty-five-foot class, and although Lord Dunraven left the Valkyrie over here for some racing, there will only be the Navahoe and Volunteer in commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The attempt of the Louisiana Lottery Company to re-establish itself on United States soil at an obscure point in the State of Florida has called attention anew to the Federal Statutes, and, with the purpose in view of making them even more binding than they are, Senator Hoar has introduced a bill supplementary to all existing legislation.

A man with a broken jaw, a mysterious companion, a dentist, his wife, a doctor, a woman assistant, a servant, and a knife, were all more or less concerned in a desperate struggle yesterday afternoon at 1,338 Lexington Avenue, the home of Dr. Adolph Maisner, dentist.

John L. Stoddard took his audience at Daly's yesterday morning on an exploring tour of China, and, by means of a large collection of remarkably fine pictures, familiarized them with the scenes and people of that exclusive empire, which still maintains a dally newspaper the first number of which was printed sixty-seven years after the birth of Christ, and which has been running continuously ever since.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A cable message received at the Navy Department from Rear Admiral Benham confirms the United Press report of the arrival of the Government dynamite cruiser Nictheroy outside Rio Harbor. Admiral Benham says in his dispatch that the rest of the loyal fleet will arrive at Rio from Bahia on Feb. 22.

STAPLETON, S.I., Feb. 19 -- An unusually interesting will contest was begun in the Richmond County Surrogate's Court to-day. The proponent is Mrs. Minnie D. Lyman, widow of the late William H. Lyman of 559 West One Hundred and Forty-first Street, New-York. She was the fourth wife of Mr. Lyman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Cleveland to-day stopped all chance of a successful Chandler and Hill fight against him in the Senate over the vacancy in the Supreme Court by sending to the Senate the name of Edward Douglass White, United States Senator from the State of Louisiana, as the successor of the late Justice Blatchford.

If all the liquor that James Dugan, ex-saloon keeper, has absorbed in the last ten years, according to the evidence of his family before a Sheriff's jury in the Supreme Court yesterday could be recovered. It would stock several good-sized saloons. Dugan was on view as a kind of walking liquor exhibit, but he did not testify.

There was a well-defined rumor current in the village of Sheepshead Bay yesterday to the effect that John Y. McKane, who was believed to have been confined in Raymond Street Jail in the custody of Sheriff Buttling of Kings County, had really spent Saturday and Sunday with his family in his handsome residence in Voorhees Avenue, Sheepshead Bay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The recommendation made by the Postmaster General in his annual report that the Post Offices at New-York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Boston, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Brooklyn, San Francisco, Baltimore, and Pittsburg be classed by themselves, and that appropriations for them be direct, was the subject of a hearing by the House Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads to-day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Kickham Scanlan stopped talking to the Coughlin trial jury this afternoon. His address had lasted three days. Daniel Donahoe, junior counsel for the defense, will begin his address to-morrow, and says he will speak two days. These long speeches will take the end of the trial into next week.

DANVILLE, Ky., Feb. 19 -- The testimony taken here to-day in the Pollard-Breckinridge damage suit developed a sensation of great magnitude. There was only one witness to be examined. He had been summoned at the instance of the counsel for the defense, and that side had given it out that this witness would not say a great deal and that his testimony would be short.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- After an hour's wrangle in the Assembly to-night, in which great disorder prevailed, the leaders of the two parties do not agree as to whether the seventeen commissions and bureaus of the State shall be investigated or not. It all depends on how many votes on the resolution adopted last Friday were changed while the Journal was being corrected tonight.
After McKane's sentence, Sheriff Buttling treated him with the same tender consideration that he did during the trial. The Sheriff was quite dazed by the responsibility imposed upon him.

The temporary stay will at least serve to keep McKane out of State prison until next Friday, when the order addressed to the prosecution to show cause why a certificate of reasonable doubt should not be granted is made returnable for argument.

The Distribution Committee appointed on Saturday by the Citizens Relief Committee met at the office of J. Pierpont Morgan yesterday and decided to distribute $55,000 of the money already received to the Society of St. Vincent de Paul, the United Hebrew Charities, the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, and the Committee of Relief by Work.

LARCHMONT, Feb. 19 -- Many actors and actresses make their homes here the year round. Among them are Miss Kate Claxton, Miss Proctor, and Frederick Bronson. These three recently figured in a "cat-and-dog case" before Justice Boyd.

The competition invited by the Municipal Art Society of New-York for the decoration of the courtroom of Oyer and Terminer, in the new Criminal Courts Building, for which purpose the society will devote the sum of $5,000, has excited lively interest among artists in all the large cities of this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The President sent to Congress to-day a very voluminous batch of Hawaiian correspondence, accompanied by a message of transmittal, in which he simply said: "I herewith transmit copies of certain dispatches recently received from our Minister at Honolulu."

At the weekly meeting of the Methodist Ministers' Association yesterday, the news that Superintendent John Y. McKane of the Sheepshead Bay Methodist Episcopal Sunday school had been sentenced to six years imprisonment met with general approval.

The advocates of the bill introduced in the Assembly by Mr. Sheffield to make provision for a new site and building for the College of the City of New-York will have a hearing to-day before the Committee on Cities. Among those who have been taking an active part in favor of this bill is Lawyer Charles Lydecker, who is Chairman of the Alumni Committee of the college.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 19 -- There is great sympathy here for a family named Meisenberg, who live at 53 Eleventh Avenue, this city. They came to America two years ago, and Ernest, the head of the family, worked at the cutlery works, earning fair wages. All Summer he was out of work, and his wife and children were ill in bed.

BUFFALO, Feb. 19 -- The courtroom of United States Commissioner Fairchild never before has been so crowded as it was this morning on the occasion of the preliminary examination of Leroy Harris, the postal criminal, who on Saturday effected a temporary escape from the Commissioner's office by drawing a pistol and compelling every one in the room to hold up his hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Assistant Secretary Hamlin to-day made public the portion of the Fairchild commission report that pertains to undervaluation of Japanese silks imported by J.R. Simon Co. in 1891 through the New-York Custom House.

Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Jefferson Chandler to Thomas C. Brown the four-story brick and brownstone front dwelling 331 West Eighty-sixth Street, 20 by 66 by 100.8 1/2, with extension 10 by 14, for about $42,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Earnest protests on behalf of the people of New-Utrecht against the burden of "Boss" Furgueson were heard at the Capitol to-day. The dominating power of the "boss" and the monopoly which he and his family hold were set forth before the Assembly Committee on Commerce and Navigation, which gave a hearing on Mr. Wray's bill to abolish the position of Shore Inspector for New-York Harbor.

The Tribune is the leading Republican daily of Cincinnati. It is a morning newspaper. It commenced last week to take the two-wire service of the United Press. Editorially it makes the following statement:

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Feb. 20 -- P.M. Nearly all of the active stocks advanced in to-days market. Business was dull falling below the recent averagre, but the maintenance of prices, the alacrity with which advances are secured on small buying orders, and the complete reversal of the tradition that without activity prices must fall, indicate beyond all doubt the feeling of confidence that sustains the market.
BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- About 2,000 people gathered on the Common this afternoon to listen to addresses by Morrison L. Swift, Herbert N. Casson, and other "Socialist-Anarchists," as they call themselves.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: I have read with surprise the editorial approval by The Evening Post of the letter of "Democrat" which it reprints from Harper's Weekly.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

It is Kenneth F. Sutherland's turn next to tread the path which has led his master. John Y. McKane, to a prison cell. Sutherland will be arraigned for trial in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer next Monday under the indictment against him for oppression.

The Seventh Regiment, National Guard, was reviewed at its armory, in Park Avenue, last night by Adjt. Gen. Josiah Porter and staff. The regiment was out in full strength. The review was in line of masses, after which the entire command of ten companies passed in review, company front, before Gen. Porter and staff.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Senate this afternoon considered the nomination of Gen. "Joe" Shelby to be Marshal for the Western District of Missouri. The nomination did not appear to be antagonized, although there were some Republicans whose attention had been called to the record of Gen. Shelby during the war and the charge that he had been guilty of cruelty, and they asked that this be explained.

The Improved Dress Congress for Women was begun yesterday noon at the National Christian League Fair, in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall, and New-York women received their first installment of words of wisdom upon sensible gowns. It was Miss Lindley's day, and, wearing a brand new bonnet and dress, all heliotrope and gold, and not apparently a reform at all, she talked about the American woman and her environment.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- The large tin-can and japanned-ware factory of Norton Brothers, occupying half of the triangular block facing on Dock and Water Streets, and abutting the river, was destroyed by fire last night. It started at 11:30 o'clock, but it was three hours before the names were under control.

Whether a hatred for mankind in general be a more or less detestable motive for massacre than a hatred for a particular person is for murder may be a question for psychologists and casuists. Fortunately, it is not a question for legislators or Judges. The Anarchist is a more dangerous and pestilent person than the private assassin, because nobody is safe from him.
The dogs are having their day at the Madison Square Garden, and the eighteenth annual Bench Show of the Westminster Kennel Club is an assured and gratifying success.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Assemblyman Robertson of the Twenty-seventh New-York District this morning introduced a bill to abolish the Park Commission of New-York City and create a Board of Parks. This measure came up from New-York City, and is said to have been an outgrowth of the present Inactivity of the commission in the work of the speedway.

At a meeting of the Eastern Baseball League held in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday the Albany Club withdrew in favor of Syracuse. The officials of the latter club paid the sum of $1,500 for the franchise. Some weeks ago L.T. Fassett, the chief stockholder in the Albany Club, notified President Powers of his desire to withdraw on account of pressure of other business.

CORONA, L.I., Feb. 20 -- At daybreak this morning the Long Island Railroad gateman at the Grand Street crossing here rubbed his eyes and looked skyward. The sight that met his gaze caused a cold shiver to run up and down his spinal column. Suspended in midair, within fifty feet of the railroad tracks, was what appeared to be the body of a man.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 20 -- The Dartmouth sophomores, as usual, have interfered with the programme made up for the freshmen's class supper. The class of '97 arranged for its banquet on the 21st, at Manchester, and the sophomores supposed they had selected H.A. Terrell of Brooklyn, N.Y., as toastmaster.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 20 -- Mr. Charles H. Luscomb, the new President, occupied the chair when the League of American Wheelmen Convention was resumed this morning. Mr. W.W. Watts took the floor to propose an amendment to the constitution drawing the color line by inserting the word "white." In a lengthy speech Mr. Watts assigned his reasons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Edward D. White of Louisiana spent some time in the Senate Chamber to-day, and was made the recipient of many congratulations upon his appointment to the United States Supreme bench. He is undoubtedly very happy over his selection by the President.

What may be termed, in a general sense, the Vanderbilt influence, was considerably increased in the Board of Managers of the Delaware, Laekawanna and Western Railroad at the annual election yesterday. H. McK. Twombly, Frank Work, and H.C. Fahnestock, the new Managers, who succeed A.H. McClintock, W.H. Appleton, and R.F. Ballantine, enter the board in consequence of certain important changes in the holdings of Lackawanna stock which occurred last Fall.

In a little room off a big, bare, and cheerless-looking apartment at 642 East Fifth Street there lies in a tiny coffin a two-year-old girl, fair haired and blue eyed, her pretty baby face fixed in a peaceful, happy smile, as if she had known that death, in coming so suddenly to her, had come kindly and as her best friend, perhaps.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Court of Claims to-day handed down a decision in the famous ship Tom case, making awards in forty-two claims and dismissing three others. These claims were among the oldest and most important of the French spoliation claims.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The bill to prevent the building of a new City Hall on the site of the present one in New-York City and the consequent destruction of the historic plot of ground will have a hearing before the Senate Cities Committee soon.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Feb. 20 -- A bitter cold wave reached this section last night, and the mercury has ranged from 10 below zero to 10 above. Reports from Buffalo and other points in the northern part of the State tell of thermometers registering 25 below zero. In the sections of the State where the ground is covered with snow cattle are suffering a great deal.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- Manager Arthur Irwin, who is coaching the University of Pennsylvania baseball candidates, is in the city on a brief visit. Speaking of the University of Pennsylvania 'Varsity team, he said: "I think that we will have as good an organization as we had last season, if not better.

The bill amending the election laws or this State so as to provide for the use of the blanket ballot was reported in the Senate yesterday, having been previously reported in the Assembly, and it will soon be under consideration in both houses. It is a modification of the draft made by the conference committee of several organizations in this city interested in the reform, and is known as the Saxton-Sheffield bill.

Anticipation that the testimony of Mr. Isaac L. Rice in the Reading proceedings in Philadelphia yesterday would prove more than ordinarily interesting was not realized, owing to the opposition which the counsel for the receivers made to its submission. From the moment Mr. Rice was called to the stand, it became evident that all the power of the defense would be used to prevent his testifying.

Typewriter Leopold Michel was about the most interesting witness heard yesterday in the case of Joseph F. Blaut, on trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer on the charge if perjury. Assistant District Attorney Davis had called Mr. Michel to testify as to a note transaction which the prosecution has charged was part of a plan to cover up questionable methods resorted to by officers of the Madison Square Bank.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The opposition of both the Secretary of the Navy and the Secretary of the Treasury to the proposition to transfer the Revenue Cutter Service to the navy, has led the friends of the Revenue Cutter Service to resort to another plan to accomplish one of the objects contemplated by the transfer bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- As soon as the Bland Seigniorage bill is disposed of by the House, Representative Money (Dem.. Miss.,) will call up the Benham resolution. Mr. Money says that a very erroneous opinion exists regarding this resolution. It simply expresses the satisfaction of Congress at the prompt and energetic means employed by Admiral Benham to protect American interests at Rio.

A wee bit of a dog created an amount of excitement and dismay in Union Square yesterday entirely in disproportion to his size. He was really a well-bred little fellow, as was attested by his well-groomed body and the distingue air of his mistress, who led him down Broadway.

Mayor Gilroy, accompanied by District Attorney Fellows, Inspector Williams, and other officers of the City Government, inspected the New-Hampshire, at the foot of East Twenty-Eighth street, last evening, and witnessed the drill of the First Naval Battalion on board. By invitation of Commander J.W. Miller a number of prominent citizens, including J. Sergeant Cram, Capt. McGowan, United States Navy; Lieut. George Church, Aaron Vanderbilt, James Reilley, and Louis Wendel, were also present.

Cornelius Murphy, a burglar and sneak thief, was killed yesterday by falling from a roof while committing a burglary. Murphy, who was twenty-two years old and lived at 12 Forsyth Street, was a member of a gang of burglars and thieves known as the "lubegows," or "Chinese messengers," who run on errands for Chinamen about Pell and Mott Streets, and rob the Celestials and white men whenever opportunity offers.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- Local stocks were not very active to-day, but the market showed considerable strength in spots. In Boston and Albany, 70 shares sold at 205, an advance of 1 1/2 over the last sale. Wisconsin Central securities were again active and strong, the first mortgage is selling up to 70 3/4, the incomes at 14 1/2, and the stock at 7.

Next to the prisoner the man who excited the most attention in the proceedings against John Y. McKane was William J. Buttling, Sheriff of Kings County. Because of his manifestations of grief over McKane's conviction and sentence Buttling has come to be known as "the weeping Sheriff."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Edward P. Youngs, a well-dressed man about forty years old, was a prisoner in Judge Miller's court to-day on a charge of carrying concealed weapons. It was nearly 11 o'clock last night when Policeman John J. Smith found him walking in Lincoln Avenue in the direction of Glenwood Cemetery.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- At the charter election held in this city to-day Jacob Amos was re-elected Mayor for a second term of two years. His opponents were Duncan W. Peck, (Dem.,) and Jay B. Kline, regular Republican. Mayor Amos was supported by the Republican independents, who named him after they had revolted against the action of the Republican City Committee, which was charged with planning unfair caucuses.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Yesterday's caucus of Democrats did not have the effect on the Democrats in the House to-day that might have been expected.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Election day in Pennsylvania and the close of the Exchange at noon contributed to the general dullness. Some attempt was made to hammer Pennsylvania and Lehigh Valley on account of the drive made in New-York Central, but the only really weak stock on the list was Reading, and when that struck 21 it developed pretty fair buying.

The Rev. Dr. A.B. Leonard, in a speech delivered at the annual dinner of the Methodist Social Union, in the St. Denis Hotel, last evening, said that if Christianity is to triumph the day has come when, once for all, the idea that a man can have two sides to his character -- a Christian and a worldly side -- must be abandoned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- For several months there have been in the desks of the Chairman of the Senate Committee on Judiciary and of Commerce many nominations of Democrats to important offices in New-York State. Senator Hill is a member of the Judiciary Committee and Senator Murphy of the Committee on Commerce.

The eminent lawyers who have been asked to direct the investigation of the Police Department by the special committee of the Senate have presented a crucial test of the good faith of the proceedings in making it a condition of their service that money shall be appropriated by the Legislature for the expense of conducting a thorough inquiry.

The second monthly drawing of the Honduras Lottery took place at Puerto Cortez on Feb. 13. The same night the steamer Breakwater, which is chartered by the lottery company from the Macheca Brothers of New-Orleans, left for Port Tampa with the two "Commissioners," the managers, and several representatives and employes of the Graham Printery.

Judgment was entered in the City Court yesterday for $901 in favor of Grace Sherwood, an actress, who sued William H. Crane for breach of contract. Miss Sherwood stated in her complaint that on Jan. 16, 1893, Joseph Brooks, manager for Mr. Crane, made a contract with her, under which she was co create the part of Martha in "Brother John," which was to be produced at the Star Theatre.

We have already called attention to the lesson taught by McKane and McKaneism in Gravesend as to the utter inadequacy of ordinary town methods for the decent administration of a community that has outgrown the old-time conditions of town life. The essentials of those conditions were a pretty even level of character among the people, a general familiarity of the people with each other, and a fairly equal distribution of interests.

The Police Commissioners yesterday by unanimous vote dismissed the charges of unbecoming conduct preferred by Superintendent Byrnes against Capt. John K. Price of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station and his two precinct detectives, Allan Hay and Patrick Curry, on which they were tried on Monday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- About thirty freshmen of Cornell University were strangled to-night by sophomores releasing a large quantity of chlorine gas in the dining hall where the freshman banquet was in progress.
