The Law Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday gave a public hearing on the proposal of Alderman Morgan to amend a city ordinance so as to allow merchants to use the sidewalk up to within five feet of the curb line. Several fruit and dry goods merchants appeared in favor of the amendment.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Lieut. Gov. Sheehan was interviewed to-day under oath. He was put in the witness chair in the course of an investigation which he had himself requested. This grew out of the lieutenant Governor's sensitiveness because of newspaper articles with reference to the Buffalo Repeal bill.

"There are certain political influences outside of the Senate Investigating Committee which are hard at work endeavoring to get at the work of investigation which the committee is carrying on and trying to turn to their own political advantage the work that is on hand. I know this, and I can prove it."

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Local stock values were generally higher at the opening today, and few soft spots developed during the early trading. West Chicago opened at 134 1/2, against a close of 133 5/8, and, soon after the termination of the call, sold at 136. This advance was due largely to short covering.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Soon after the formal opening of the House of Commons today Mr. Gladstone arose and moved the discharge of the order of the day, which was the consideration of the amendments that had been made by the House of Lords to the Employers' Liability bill. Mr. Gladstone's motion was greeted with loud cheers by the supporters of the Government.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The Cities Committee this afternoon listened to a number of representatives of labor organizations in New-York City on the Rapid-Transit bill. The delegation was chaperoned by Charles B. Storer, Secretary of the Trades Union Rapid-Transit Conference. It was composed of Daniel Harris, President of the State branch of the Federation of Labor; Matthew Barr, Thomas Gunning, Thomas Clegg, and Edward King.

Walter Gilroy, nineteen years old, of 427 East Seventy-first Street; John Cashin, twenty-one years old, of 329 East Seventy-fifth Street, and John Ashley, twenty-one years old, of 332 East Seventy-sixth Street were arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday charged with burglary.
The American Hunt and Pony Racing Association Executive Committee held a meeting yesterday to elect officers and listen to a report on rules of racing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Senator Daniel of Virginia concluded to-day the speech on the subject of Hawaii which he began on Monday. He did not applaud every step taken by the Cleveland Administration, but he honored it for its brave and rugged honesty and for its having cherished, over all things, the honor of the country, and kept it from being tarnished.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- At the meeting of the National American Woman's Suffrage Association a series of resolutions was adopted which will serve as a platform for the current year.

Isaac O. Woodruff, the Maiden Lane druggist, was declared innocent yesterday of alienating the affections of the wife of Steward Ithamar Howe of the Megantic Fish and Game Club, who sued to recover $50,000 damages.
Charles D. Kellogg, General Secretary of the Charity Organization Society, has just made a report to the Central Council of the work done during the month of January.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 20 -- The Justices of the Supreme Court have a hard problem. It is to decide whether Mary Philbrooke is to be allowed to practice in the courts of New-Jersey.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- A bomb exploded at about, 2 o clock this morning in a small hotel, 69 Rue St. Jacques. The hotel is situated in the rear of the College of France. The preprietres of the peace a woman named Calabress and two lodgers were injured.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 20 -- The Continental Congress met in Baltimore on the 20th of December, 1776, and a week afterward conferred upon Gen. Washington extraordinary powers for the conduct of the Revolutionary War. The meeting place was an old tavern that then stood at the western limits of the town, on Baltimore Street, between Sharp and Liberty Streets.

The friends of Edward M. Field, the defaulter, and son of the late Cyrus W. Field, made an attempt yesterday to have that young man released from Ludlow Street Jail, where he is confined on three civil actions. This was the work of months of endeavor on the part of Field's friends, who have been working hard to secure his release since he was incarcerated.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Quite a sharp and unlooked-for jump was made in the price of wheat in the last half hour of the session to-day. Shorts were cleverly trapped, and, amid considerable excitement, bid the price from 58 5/8 c. and 58 3/4 c. to 60 1/4c. for May.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Gen. Fred Knefler of Indianapolis has been permitted by a Cincinnati paper to make the assertion that Gen. W.Q. Gresham "was never in a batlle," and that "he is a humbug as a soldier," and he has ventured to attempt to prove his assertions by reference to the official records.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- A suit may be necessary to decide who shall have possession of the body of Henry S. Holden, who was killed in the La Salle Street tunnel yesterday. Mrs. Catharine Holden, the New-York wife of the dead man, to-day gave Undertaker Sigmund an order to bury the body at the conclusion of the inquest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Col. Stump, Superintendent of Immigration, to-day ordered Commissioner Senner of New-York to release the four lace weavers detained at that port on the charge of being alien contract laborers. These are the laborers who, when first detained, were alleged to have been imported into this country by Mr. Wanamaker for work in his Philadelphia establishment.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 20 -- Gov. Werts has given out that he has decided to begin quo warranto proceedings at once before the Supreme Court, in order, if possible, to settle the Senatorial muddle. His decision was reached after he had conferred for four hours with Attorney General Lindabury and ex-Judge Frederic W. Stevens.

The substitution of cable power for horse power on the Third Avenue surface road is now practically completed. Hopes have been entertained that this substitution would operate as a partial substitute for rapid transit by relieving the overburdened elevated road in the same avenue. The hopes seemed reasonable.

PHILADELHIA, Feb. 20 -- Galusha A. Grow, Republican, was elected to-day Congressman at Large from Pennsylvania, to serve the unexpired term of Gen. William Lilly, Republican, who died Dec. 1, 1893. The special election was fixed for to-day for the reason that this is the day for the regular Spring elections in the various cities and towns for municipal and borough officers.

The speech of Senator Hill in executive session on Monday, from which the seal of secrecy was so promptly torn, is in the nature of a message to the country, to which his victory over the President furnished at least an occasion, if not an excuse. It is impudent, or it would not be Mr. Hill's.
Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO JANEIRO, Feb. 20 -- The United States cruiser Detroit, which has been cruising south, has returned to Rio Janeiro.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. T. A. Kerrigan sold to Nathan Kaplan, for $8,900, the four-story brick and stone flat 1,444 Fulton Street, south side, 220 feet east of Brooklyn Avenue, 20 by 100. He also sold to Wilson M. Powell, for $13,200, the two four-story brick dwellings, with stores, 73 and 77 Furman Street, the former being the southeast corner of Middagh Street, and each being 25 by 50 feet.

The athletic members of the East Eighty-sixth Street Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association are making great preparations for the fifth annual gymnastic exhibition, which will be held in the gymnasium next Tuesday evening. Athletic Director Reeve B. Howland has arranged a very interesting programme.

David Smith, an expert from the Water Purveyor's Bureau of the Brooklyn Department of City Works, made an astonishing discovery yesterday at the plant of the Citizens' Electric Illuminating Company, De Kalb Avenue and Rockwell Place.

NORVVALK, Conn., Feb. 21 -- Several manufacturing concerns here, which closed down last Fall because of the hard times, have reopened their doors, many of them with the encouraging statement that orders are numerous, and that sufficient business has accumulated in the last three months to keep the works in operation until the end of Spring.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The full Committee on Foreign Affairs to-day, for the first time, heard the report of the sub-committee which has been investigating Hawaiian affairs, as drawn by Mr. Morgan. It did not agree on the report, although Mr. Morgan's document will be made the committee report to be accompanied, however, by non-concurring statements in the shape of supplemental reports, all of which will be laid before the Senate on Monday next.

Charles G.F. Wahle and Edward Owen, Commissioners of Accounts, submitted to Mayor Gilroy yesterday their report relative to the Investigation into the methods of the Fire Department, begun Feb. 1, at the request of the Mayor.

At a meeting of Good Government Club E, held last night at its clubrooms, 338 East Twenty-third Street, resolutions were adopted expressing doubt as to the efficiency of any proposed legislation for the improvement of the Police Department until a Mayor can be elected who shall be more devoted to the interests of the people than to the success of his political organization, Resolutions were adopted similar to those declared by the Union League Club.
Theodor Westmark is to give a lecture on "Fifteen Months With the Cannibals on the Upper Congo" at Steinway Hall at 8:15 P.M. next Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- Complete returns from three-fourths of the 67 counties of the State, and close estimates of the remaining counties, show a plurality of 169,545 for Grow, Republican, for Congressman at Large. This is the largest plurality ever given by the State for any candidate, and may be increased to 175,000.

George W. Corson, a traveling salesman for a jewelry firm, was taken to the Flatbush Hospital yesterday by officers Connected with the Kings County Bureau of Charities, and will probably be soon transferred to the County Insane Asylum.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Adjt. Gen. Ruggles of the army has designated the army posts at which the young men who have been nominated for cadetships at West Point will report on March 1. This year, as last, the appointees of Congressmen will not be obliged to go to West Point for the entrance examination.

As Red Bank will not be able to pull off the skating championships, it has been decided to hold them at Manhattan Field tomorrow afternoon, beginning at 1 o'clock, should the weather prove favorable. From present indications the ice will be in perfect condition. Should the weather prove unfavorable, the races will take place the first cold day thereafter.
Mayor Schieren's administration has an Imperative duty before it in connection with the electric lighting scandals in Brooklyn.

The revival meetings being held in the large hall of the Young Men's Christian Association, at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, are daily increasing in interest. With the opening of another week, it is hoped that the ball will be too small to hold those who come to hear the evangelists. There were fully 1,000 persons present yesterday, every seat in the body of the hall being occupied.

Conspiracy and larceny were the charges made yesterday by Nathan Hulkoff, a dealer in plate glass at Ill. Wooster Street, against Joseph Neal, Michael Copper, Patrick Cohan, Andrew M. Corlich, Charles Mc-Ginn, Richard Buttgar, and Patrick Love, who had been employed by him. Hulkoff also made a charge of receiving stolen goods against Marcus Wernberg of 1,533 Second Avenue and Maurice Levine of 800 Third Avenue.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 21 -- The many mysterious robberies of grocery stores in the lower part of the city were the work of an organized gang of young boys. George Boone, twelve years old, confessed yesterday, when a basket of groceries and a bottle of whisky were found in the cellar of his home, 92 Newark Avenue.

At the opening of the hearing of the Rice case against the receivers of the Reading Railroad yesterday in Philadelphia, Mr. Daniel Jones, the Controller of the company, in reply to Mr. Dickson, counsel for the receivers, announced that the preparation of the information previously asked for by Mr. Bijur, counsel for Mr. Rice, would involve so much labor and time that he was unable to produce it.

Stacey Wilson, general manager of the Home Benefit Society, was a complainant yesterday in the Tombs Police Court against J.C. Kempton, a merchant of 60 Leonard Street, whom he charged with attempting to blackmail him and his company. Kempton, he said, claimed to be in possession of facts which, if published, would injure the company, and had demanded money.

Judging from the reports of railway earnings for the first and second weeks of the current month, this is a waiting period for most of the railroads. The reports thus far received show, with a few conspicuous exceptions in the West, that the roads are just about holding their own.

"Phil" King of Princeton, who is considered the best all-round football player in the country, has given the question of changing the rules deep study. He has heard what Camp, Deland, and others have had to say on the question, and, with Capt. Trenchard, believes that a radical change would do much toward injuring the sport.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Last night the Cornell freshmen held their banquet, which they had a perfect right to do, and the sophomores had their "fun," as they call it, with the result, as stated in to-day's New-York Times, that Mrs. Jackson, colored, now lies in Cummings's morgue, and several students are not expected to live.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Feb. 21 -- P.M. To-day's market emphasized again the strength of both stocks and bonds at the present level of prices. Total sales reached less than 100,000 shares. That volume does not much, exceed the Saturday average, when trading lasts only two hours.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Wallace, a five-hundred-pound lion on exhibition at Kohl Middleton's Clark Street Museum, escaped from his cage this afternoon, just as his trainer entered to give the usual performance, and jumped into the large crowd in the theatre part of the museum.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 21 -- The merchant vessels at this port are suffering extremely for want of water because of the refusal of the insurgents to allow a boat to go about the bay and supply such craft with fresh water.

The Union League Club, at a special meeting last evening, placed itself on record as opposed at this time to all mandatory legisation requiring the Police Commissioners to be of different political faith, but did not recommend a single head to the department.
The first intimation of the troubles which have resulted in landing Mr. Wiman in prison on a criminal charge was given exclusively in The New-York Times last February.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. T. A. Kerrigan sold to Charles M. Marsh, plaintiff, for $45,500, the nineteen two-story and basement brick dwellings 375 to 407 Bainbridge Street, north side, 212 feet east of Ralph Avenue, together 338 by 100. He sold to William O. Moore, plaintiff, at $2,020, the two-story frame dwelling 2,084 Dean Street, south side, near Rockaway Avenue, 25 by 100.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 21 -- It was at an early hour this morning that the League of American Wheelmen meeting ended. One of the last acts was to reinstate Charley Murphy, the popular Brooklyn rider, and several other men who have been on the black list. This news will be hailed with delight by the friends of Mr. Murphy, who worked night and day to get the little Brooklyn rider back into the fold.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- A representative of the United Press sought an interview with Lord Dunraven to-day in reference to the statement cabled from New-York that his Lordship's representative, Mr. H. Maitland Kersey, had said that Lords Dunraven and Wolverton would make a formal challenge for a race for the America's Cup in 1895.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners met yesterday at 22 William Street and heard arguments by Lawyer William Mitchell of 45 Wall Street in opposition to Mr. Bushe's proposed plan for an independent elevated railroad system. All the Commissioners were present. Mr. Mitchell said:

Within a few days two firms doing business in this city have published some interesting facts concerning their recent purchases of foreign window glass. One of them, writing to The Times on the 14th inst., said:

Postmaster Dayton is making energetic efforts to secure the much-needed improvements in the Postal Service. Referring to his attendance before the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads in the House of Representatives last Monday, he said:

Henry Seelig, forty years old, of 18 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday charged with the larceny of $1,396 on Feb. 8. Mr. Seelig, who was formerly a tobacconist in Maiden Lane, was arrested on a warant sworn out by Paul L. Perrier, manager for William D. Barnes, banker, at 29 Broadway.

Detective John F. Mitchell of the Elizabeth Street Police Station, who disappeared Feb. 12, has returned home. His wife called on Capt. Warts at the station house yesterday, and informed him that her husband came home about 1 o'clock yesterday morning. He was unable to give a rational account of his wanderings during his absence.

Five hundred members and guests of the Harvard Club sat down to the twentyeighth annual dinner of the club at Delmonico's last evening. After the dinner they talked about the club's now Harvard House, in Forty-fourth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, about educated men in politics, and football.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- Wisconsin Central again engaged most of the attention of the market, almost to the entire neglect of other local stocks, with, perhaps, the exception of the coppers. The desire to purchase Wisconsin Central securities is apparently contagious, and the epidemic has assumed quite sizable proportions.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The path of the Ballot Reform bill, which does not legalize the blanket paster, is not wholly smooth. Mr. Sulzer, the Democratic leader, who introduced a bill some time ago which provides for a paster of this sort, insists on making a fight for it on the floor of the Assembly. His bill was reported from the Assembly Judiciary Committee this morning.

Admiral Gherardi was a guest of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club yesterday afternoon and watched the contest for the handsome silver cup that is to become the property of the member making the highest average during the season. The bowling was at 212 West Forty-first Street. According to the rules of the club, any lady scoring over 100, or any gentleman making over 125 receives a prize.

Some half a hundred oils, water colors, and drawings by Mr. John Humphreys Johnston are at the new Klackner Galleries, 5 West Twenty-eighth Street, where they will be open to the public for a couple of weeks. There are landscapes, marines, bits of picturesque Spain and Russia, groups of Brittany peasants, studies in color as if for stained glass, heads and figures in colored chalk on brown paper, and symbolical figures.
In February, 1893, R.G. Dun Co. was owing upward of $10,000 to E.W. Bulllnger, Esq., of this city for materials purchased on the 6th of February, 1893.

Twelve men were locked up in the jury room of the County Court House last night, not having decided upon the guilt or innocence of Joseph P. Blaut, ex-President of the Madison Square Bank, who has been on trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer for a week on the charge of perjury, it being alleged that he swore falsely to a quarterly report affecting the condition of the institution, on June 1, 1893.

The election of Mr. Grow as Congressman at Large in Pennsylvania by a plurality of some 160,000 is neither to be dismissed as insignificant, as the partisan habit is with unpleasant election results, nor to be accepted as proof that the whole country has changed its views on tariff reform, as the extreme protectionists profess to believe.

Trotting horse men are very much interested in the Huntington collection of purebred Clay and Arab-bred or Americo-Arab horses that are to be sold at auction to-day and to-morrow at the American Institute Building by Peter C. Kellogg Co. The sale is by order of the receiver, R.F. Downing.

What promises to be a very interesting three-cornered contest for $53,000 of trust funds belonging to the Life Union, which was placed in control of David McClure, as receiver, a year ago, has been commenced in the Supreme Court, a feature of which presented itself in Chambers yesterday, before Judge Patterson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Tariff bill is practically ready for submission by the "sub-committee" -- which objects to being called a sub-committee to the Democratic members of the Committee on finance. Every utterance, private and public, made to-day by Democratic members of the Senate supports this understanding.
The following plans of new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- After all of the bluster which has proceeded from California regarding the President's course in the Hawalian matter, it was reassuring to-day to see a native-born, judicial-minded, and eloquent Californian stand up in the Senate and vigorously denounce the policy of the annexationists and support the effort of the Administration to undo the great wrong brought about by John L. Stevens and the revolutionists of Honolulu.

The steamship City of Para, having on board the officers and crew of the United States corvette Kearsarge, which was wrecked on Roncador Reef, in the Caribbean Sea, Feb. 2, arrived at her pier at the foot of Canal Street at noon yesterday. Hundreds were waiting to greet their friends as they were transferred from the steamship to the tugs on which they were conveyed to the navy yard.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- The feeling at Cambridge in regard to President Eliot's report on athletics is one of surprise rather than consternation. In the first place, the impression that football has been abolished or that Harvard is henceforth to be governed by the recommendations as set forth in the annual report is entirely incorrect.

Simple funeral services were held last evening over the body of Joseph Keppler, the caricaturist and part owner of Puck, at 27 East Seventy-ninth Street. The parlor of the house contained a few palms and lilies. Delegations were present from the Arion and Liederkranz Societies, and the Deutscher Verein.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- There was an absence of the vim and clash which characterized the last half hour of trading in wheat, yesterday in that market to-day. Nevertheless, there was plenty of strength, with continued anxiety in the ranks of the bears. European markets did not fully respond to the bulge, and that placed a stumbling block in the path of the bulls.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- James Graham, who has been an Assemblyman for six weeks as a beneficiary of the John Y. McKane frauds at Gravesend, is such no longer. He was bowled out of the Chamber by a vote of 72 to 51 at 3:45 this afternoon. The seat which he has been occupying will be filled, for the rest of the session by James H. Friday, the Republican who brought the contest.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- Reading and St. Paul again contributed most of the day's business, and they were both strong and active. St. Paul sold off slightly toward the close in sympathy with New-York. Pennsylvania was dull and stubbornly firm all day. Lehigh Valley held strong around 39 1/2, with very little business doing, possibly due to the probable early listing of coal company's bonds both in New-York and Philadelphia.

Policeman Simon Shattenkirk of the West Twentieth Street Station was on trial yes- terday before Commissioner Sheehan on charges preferred by Mrs. John Hagi, the wife of a bartender living at 333 West Sixteenth Street. The complainant alleged that on Feb. 10 she visited friends at Richmond Hill, L.I., and did not return to the city until past midnight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The President to-day withdrew the nomination of Arthur M. Randall to be Postmaster at St. Johnsbury, Vt. Mr. Randall is a Democrat suggested for the office by Bradley B. Smalley, and, so far as anybody can find out, there is nothing the matter with him except that he is persona non grata to Representative Grout.

Charges quite as serious as those in regard to the alleged stealing of city water are made touching other operations of the Citizens' Electric Illuminating Company. They are from responsible men who, as investigation proceeds, are expected to produce the evidence to sustain them.

Of course, nothing was further from the intentions of the sophomores of Cornell than to commit manslaughter when it occurred to them as a judicious scheme to release a quantity of malodorous and noxious gas into the room where the freshmen were at supper. They not only did not mean to take life, but they did not mean to do serious bodily harm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Secretary Gresham to-day received a cable message from Minister Thompson, dated at Rio Janeiro, stating briefly that the insurgent war ships Aquidaban and Republica had passed out of the harbor this morning under fire of the Government forts.

Major David H. Liewellyn. Major David H. Liewellyn died at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon at his residence, 45 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street. The Major's illness was the result of an injury he received several weeks ago, while alighting from a train at Lexington, Ky.

That Superintendent Byrnes is able to discover and break up evil resorts, the existence of which is either unknown or ignored by the Captains of the precincts in which they flourish, was again, demonstrated when on Tuesday night a raid was made by a batch of Central Office detectives upon a fashionable resort, which has existed for some time in an otherwise respectable neighborhood on the east side of the town.

Some interesting and new points in insurance law will be decided in the case of Spitz against the Mutual Benefit Life Association of America, which is on the calendar of the Court of Common Pleas for trial next week. The action is brought by the executors of Spitz, who died some time ago while holding a life insurance policy for $3,000 in the defendant company.

The committee of the East Side Improvement Association which called on Mayor Gilroy Tuesday to urge the building of a roadway in Central Park from One Hundred and Second Street to One Hundred and Tenth Street, a short distance west of Fifth Avenue, appeared before the Park Commissioners yesterday.
Erastus Wiman was arrested yesterday on a charge of forgery. In default of $25,000 bail he was committed to the Tombs, where he spent the night.
Shoplifters and pocketbook snatchers have been actively plying their trade in the shopping district between Eighth Street and Union Square. Two of them came to grief yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Postmaster General this afternoon settled the long controversy over the awarding of the contract for printing postage stamps for the next four years by rejecting all bids and ordering that the work be done by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing.
Mr. John N. Golding has sold for Charles C. Allen, to Edward Sturges, the four-story high-stoop brownstone dwelling 12 East Sixty-fourth Street, 20 by 100.5, for about $50,000.

Although this is the last week of the opera, "Les Huguenots" was sung at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the second time this season. The audience was one of moderate size. It would be idle to speculate as to the causes of this. In fact, most attempts to account for the vagaries of public taste are vain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The House Commerce Committee to-day, by a vote of 9 to 4, agreed to report favorably the NewYork and Hudson River Bridge bill. Messrs, Geary, Mallory, Wise, Brickner, Durborow, Caruth, Randall, Fletcher, and Mahon voted in the affirmative, and Messrs, Storer, patterson, Hepburn, and Bartiett voted in the negative.

The Colonial Dames of the State of New-York had the pleasure, yesterday afternoon, at Hardman Hall, of hearing Prof. John Fiske tells of the homes of their ancestors, the settlers of New-Netherland and Penn's Woods. There was, as usual, a large audience present.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Gov. Flower to-day took his pen and signed his name to a piece of parchment, and by that act Lieut. Gov. Sheehan's domination in Buffalo was brought to a close. It was about noon when the Governor took his pen, and the piece of parchment was the chief one of the Buffalo Repeal bills.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 21 -- Everything was very quiet at the Gaylord Mine to-day, and this evening there is nothing new to report. The hope of finding the men alive is abandoned, and there are eleven widows and forty orphans left to suffer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- When Democratic members of the House begin to talk seriously about adopting a rule authorizing the Speaker or the Chairman of the Committee of the Whole to count members present but not voting in order to make a quorum to do business, the day of Mr. Reed's triumph is not far distant.
CORONA, L.I., Feb. 21 -- The effigy of Louis Speyerer, which was suspended Tuesday night from a wire stretched across the street near the railroad station, did not swing alone this morning.

The result of the municipal election in the City of Syracuse is of special significance as a symptom of the uprising against "bossism" in this State. It is not only a triumph of independent Republicans over the local Belden machine, but it indicates a vigorous revolt against the Platt State machine.

Celebration of Washington's Birthday yesterday begun at sunrise. At the moment designated on the heavenly time tables for old Sol to make his appearance the Stars and Stripes were unfurled at the Battery and in Central Park.

The Sons of the Revolution celebrated Washington's Birthday by a banquet at Delmonico's last night, to which 225 of the association sat down. President Frederick A. Tallmadge presided. The sorbet was served in miniature stumps of cherry trees, to which were attached small hatchets on which were printed the initials "G.W."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 22 -- The Bentley scandal, which agitated society circles Monday, when a receiver was appointed to take charge of the estate, thus practically removing Mrs. Bentley from her position of administration, was continued at the Bentley home Monday night, although the facts did not become public property until to-day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- When Gov. William McKinley came on the stage of the Auditorium this afternoon, and stood before the footlights awaiting a cessation of the tumult of enthusiasm that greeted his appearance as the Washington's Birthday orator of the Union League Club, he faced one of the largest, as well as one of the most distinguished audiences that have ever assembled in Chicago.

The young woman who registered at the Grand Union Hotel Wednesday night as "Mrs. Jennie Miner, Shelton, Conn.," and was taken to Bellevue Hospital later suffering from the effects of a quantity of laudanum, died at the hospital at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. No letters or writing of any kind were found to explain her conduct.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Representative McCreary, the Chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, introduced a bill to-day which is designed to carry into effect the award rendered by the Tribunal of Arbitration at Paris under the treaty between the United States and Great Britain which was concluded at Washington on Feb. 28 of last year.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- A possible clue to the perpetrators of the outrage at the banquet of the Cornell freshmen Tuesday night, by which a colored woman was killed, was disclosed at the Coroner's inquest to-day.

The identity of "Annie Davis," the young colored sneak thief who was arrested on Wednesday as she was leaving the residence of Mrs. Gotts, 24 West Thirty-second Street, with a dress which she had stolen, and the hiding place where she concealed her booty, were both strangely revealed yesterday by the death of her four-year-old infant at her home, 182 Bond Street, Brooklyn.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- The Young Men's Christian Association State Convention spent most of the afternoon in organizing. The following permanent officers were chosen: President -- J.T. Allen, Rochester; First Vice President -- S.F. Bogg, Rochester; Second Vice President -- L. Packard, West Albany; Third Vice President -- A.E. Day, Buffalo; Secretary, A.V. Wood, Brooklyn; Assistant Secretary -- J.L. Fischner, Cornell University.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- A delegation of Company D, Fifth Regiment, New-Jersey National Guard, arrived in town this morning and were the guests of Company D, Second Regiment, at a ball this evening. Shortly before noon the visitors gave a street parade. They were met by a crowd of Yale freshmen.

The new building for the Training School for Nurses, which is attached to the German Hospital and Dispensary, Seventy-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue, was formally opened yesterday afternoon, and a reception was given by the Board of Trustees to celebrate the occasion. J.K. Krieg, Chairman of the Building Committee, turned over the building to the Board of Trustees, and President Theodore Killan and Dr. Gustav Langmann made addresses to the 300 visitors.

The persistent and promiscuous extraction of morals from current events is a practice that cannot be pursued without danger to the mentals. The danger is well known to all judicious and careful readers of newspapers, especially of newspapers of which the writers are not, on their side, equally judicious and careful.

President Daniel F. Lewis of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company announced yesterday that that company, the Long Island Traction Company, and the Brooklyn City Railroad Company had completed the consolidation of their trolley interests, and in future would conduct their business with one set of officers and probably one head.

Although the followers of John Y. McKane, who were buoyed up yesterday by the report that Justice Fursman would step in to save the convicted "boss" from Sing Sing Prison for the time being, if Justice Cullen failed to grant a certificate of reasonable doubt, will be downcast when they hear that the report is false, McKane himself is not worrying about the situation and is in the best of health.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Gymnasts prominent in amateur circles from all parts of the Union attended the annual gymnastic competition of the Amateur Athletic Union held in the Tennis Building of the Orange Athletic Club to-night. There was also a liberal scattering of ladies among the spectators.
"The Eighth Battalion of the National Guard is to be restored to the standing of a regiment."

The fourteenth annual reception of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society was held at the Orphan Asylum, at One Hundred and Fifty-first Street and Boulevard, yesterday afternoon. The entire building was thrown open to visitors, and several hundred persons assembled. The only exercises were drills and music by the life and drum corps.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The Times discusses American finances, taking as its text the letter from J.W. Cross, which it published yesterday.

Erastus Wiman could not have walked more steadily nor have had more the appearance of unruffled serenity had he promenaded around his Staten Island mansion yesterday, with all his embarrassments settled, instead of being under the eye of Keeper Frank Smith, in the South Corridor, or "Murderers' Row," in the Tombs Prison.

The Workingman's School, at 109 West Fifty-fourth Street, was in operation yesterday, and was thrown open to the public for inspection. The regular class exercises were gone through with, while crowds of school teachers from the public and private schools of the city walked about with notebooks in hand and observed the process of teaching pupils according to the latest maxims of pedagogy.

The fate of the Greater New-York bill in the Legislature is still a subject of active speculation in Brooklyn. There is a growing impression that a concerted effort is being made by certain interests opposed to the measure to defeat it in the Senate. To that end a seeming conflict has been provoked between the members of the Consolidation Commission and the Consolidation League.

Mrs. Eliza Vandenburg, the widow of Origen Vandenberg, the promoter of the underground railroad scheme in 1875, was arrested at her home, 129 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, by two detectives, on a warrant issued by Police Justice Ryan, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, at the instance of Mrs. Eliza H. Hobart of 20 West Ninth Street, charging her with the larceny of a chattel mortgage instrument.

Charles Moehling, a well-educated and highly-cultured German about fifty years old. Who was for a number of years head bookkeeper for the banking house of Ladenburg. Thalmann Co. of 46 Wall Street, committed suicide early yesterday morning in Central Park by shooting himself with a thirty-two-calibre pistol in the left ear.

The evangelistic meeting held in Association Hall, at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, yesterday, was the largest one of the week. The large hall, with the exception of a portion of the gallery where the seats are not very desirable, was filled with listeners.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- The petition of the Reading receivers for permission to issue $5,000,000 of certificates of the Reading Coal and Iron Company, to be secured by a minimum of $6,250,000 of coal and coal accounts in the hands of the Finance Company of Pennsylvania, was before Special Master Crawford to-day.

The booming of a hundred guns on Fort Greene, Brooklyn, saluted the sun yesterday morning as it rose upon the one hundred and sixty-second anniversary of the birth of George Washington. The guns were fired at intervals of a minute, and were accompanied by the cheering of a great crowd that had gathered in the park to witness the ceremony.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Assemblyman Dinkelspiel's Anti-Bucket Shop bill, which passed the Assembly to-day, proposes to do away with bucket shops.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Supreme Court Justice Edgar L. Fursman of Troy declared emphatically to-night that the report circulated in New-York and Brooklyn to-day that he would grant a "certificate of reasonable doubt" for John Y. McKane, the convicted "boss" of Coney Island, should one be refused by Justice Cullen of Brooklyn on Friday, was without foundation.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22 -- The particular event in the observance of Washington's Birthday was the unveiling of a bronze tablet which marks the site whereon stood the building in which the Continental Congress met in 1776. While here, the Congress, which had been forced to leave Philadelphia because of the approach of the British forces on Dec. 27 of that year, bestowed upon Gen. Washington extraordinary powers to reorganize the Continental Army.

The public should understand by what influences the Committee on Finance has been prevented from reporting the Wilson bill in some form to the Senate. It is now well known that the members of the committee who have the bill in hand have desired from, the beginning to report it substantially in the form in which it came to them from the House, so far as the tariff part of it is concerned.

HONOLULU, Feb. 15, via San Francisco, Feb. 22 -- Since the last outgoing mail, on the 8th, affairs have remained quiet. Minister Wills has made no communication of this Government since his friendly letter of the 3d. That letter has not yet been published here, nor has Mr. Dole yet sent a reply to it.
Kind-hearted citizens of means are still called upon by charitable organizations to send in donations for the relief of the unemployed poor, whose distress continues to be sharp and bitter.

The Rev. Dr. McGlynn lectured last evening in the Church of the Sea and Land, at Henry and Market Streets, on "How to Abolish Poverty." His audience was a large one, and consisted almost entirely of working people, who listened attentively and seemed pleased with the talk.

The Oxford and Cambridge crews are now hard at work preparing for their annual race, which is to be rowed on March 17 on the Thames. Just now the Cambridge crew is doing the best work. The London Sporting Life says the trim of the light-blue craft appears almost an ideal one. Six of the crew are old Etonians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- There will be a caucus of Democratic Senators next Monday morning, with the Tariff bill as the topic to be discussed. There was a meeting to-day of Senators who are not unreservedly friendly to the Tariff bill in its present shape. Messrs. Butler, Brice, Caffrey, Gorman, Gibson, and Hill composed the party which met in Mr. Butler's committee room and discussed the outlook for the Wilson bill.
DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 22 -- The ninth anniversary banquet of the Michigan Club took place in the Detroit Auditorium to-night. Nearly every Republican of note in Michigan and Detroit was present.

John T. Brush of the Cincinnati Club and "Chris" Von der Ahe of the St. Louis nine have been working on the rules and have prepared a report to be presented at the meeting to be held in this city on Monday next. The most important changes are as follows:
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Feb. 22 -- A.C. Fulton of this city sent to President Dole of Hawaii, Dec. 11, 1893, a box, with the following letter:

RIO JANEIRO, Jan. 20 -- There has been little change in the situation since Jan. 7, the date of the last letter sent from here by the United Press's correspondent. As noted by cable, the Aquidaban came back to port, and soon after the crest of Conceicao Island, previously unoccupied, was fortified, and Mocangue Island was recaptured from the Government forces.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Senatorial committee, with Mr. Smelzer as Chairman, to-day began an investigation of the unsavory condition of the affairs of the State Board of Health, which was set forth in The New-York Times last Monday. This committee was appointed before it was decided by the board to make public Dr. Donohue's report.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Secretary of the Navy received a cablegram to-day from Admiral Benham at Rio, dated yesterday, confirming United Press dispatches that the Aquidaban had gone out of the harbor, where she joined the Republica, and that both vessels stood away to the south.

A new and interesting phase of the wrangle between the teachers of Brooklyn Public School No. 39 and members of the Board of Education, an account of which was published yesterday in The New-York Times, has developed.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- The eleven Republican Senators and members of the Republican State Committee were very hastily summoned to Trenton to-night to discuss the quo warranto proceedings which have been begun by the Attorney General for the Governor. The conference was held in the room occupied by the Senators in the State House.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Feb. 22 -- An iron bridge built over the Shinnecock Canal by the State, at an expense of $10,000, was badly damaged by the recent heavy storm. The town officials are in a quandary as to who will repair the structure. The State paid for the bridge, with the understanding that the local authorities were to keep it in order.

A fire that caused slight damage, but resulted in the death of a little child, occurred early last evening in the frail frame tenement, occupied chiefly by Italians, at 239 North Second Street, Williamsburg. For some hours previous to the breaking out of the flames the odor of burning rags was noticeable throughout the building.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Feb. 22 -- The downfall of Erastus Wiman has been a crushing blow to his wife and family, and it has come at a time when the shadow of death threatens to fall upon them. The eldest son, William Dwight Wiman, who has been the active manager of the electric-lighting plant at St. George, is suffering from an attack of pneumonia, and his death has been looked for almost hourly since Wednesday.
"Is there any remedy for extreme emaciation? Is there any way by which a thin, weak person can be made fleshy and strong?"

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Naval officers regard as significant the cablegram yesterday from Capt. Terry of the Newark, at Montevideo, stating that another case of yellow fever had developed on board, that the patient had been transferred to Flores Island hospital, and that the Uruguayan authorities would disinfect the ship.

Joseph F. Blaut, ex-President of the Madison Square Bank, will be obliged to undergo a second trial for perjury. The jury which had been listening to his case for a week was unable to agree on a verdict and was discharged yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Gov. Flower has signed: Chapter 36 -- Assemblyman Wilcox's Auburn water supply amendment bill.

Water Purveyor Milne of Brooklyn did not inspect the plant of the Citizens' Electric Illuminating Company yesterday. He was confined to his house by illness. It was a holiday, anyway, a fact the Purveyor probably overlooked when he sent his notice to Superintendent Peck Wednesday.

Commissioners of Accounts, like Sheriff's juries, are expected to bring in a ending without much regard to the evidence. Commissioners Wahle and Owen present the usual report in the case of the charges made by ex-Fire Commissioner Henry Winthrop Gray in regard to the purchase of supplies for the department.
What with two business meetings and the splendid banquet at the Hotel Imperial last night, the members of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association had a very busy Washington's Birthday.

William T. Townes, the United States Consul General at Rio, was a passenger by the steamship Capua, which arrived from Brazil yesterday. Mr. Townes comes home for his family, and expects to return to his post within a week or so. Soon after the vessel reached her Brooklyn pier he was accosted by a reporter for The New-York Times.

Suggestions from so prominent a body of citizens as the Union League Club on the subject of reform in any branch of the municipal service are entitled to respectful consideration, but that organization has such a strong political leaning and is so apt to be animated by partisan motives that its utterances are not very helpful.

The athletic members of the Central (Twenty-third Street) Young Men's Christian Association have been doing a lot of good work this season. Dr. McCurdy, the physical director, says that the classes in the gymnasium are larger than in any past season, and he feels highly encouraged at the amount of work thus far accomplished.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The subject of the Honduras Lottery came before the Senate to-day, and the editorial in The New-York Times of yesterday denunciatory of the attempt of the lottery people to plant their gambling scheme in Florida was read by the Clerk at the suggestion of Mr. Hoar, who had evidently been much impressed by the article.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- There was a scene of extraordinary confusion and of unusual disorder in the House to-day. Since the Bland bill was taken up, the tendency of the House has been toward the discreditable conditions of to-day, the friends and opponents of the bill becoming more determined and more hostile as time passed, and the prospect of action has not improved.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Feb. 22 -- The Pettit-Fried annulment suit interests everybody here, where the plaintiff's family lives. A reporter found Miss Pettit at the home of her parents to-night. She was playing a piano and singing, and did not appear distressed or fatigued after her long and trying cross-examination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- All the executive departments closed to-day in honor of Washington's Birthday, though Congress remained in session. The District National Guard paraded through the snow and slush. Patriotic services were held by the Oldest Inhabitants' Association and the Veteran Volunteer Fire Companies.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- The police here say they have proof that the five Anarchists arrested in a batch yesterday morning are responsible for the explosion at the police station in the Rue des Bons-Enfants in November, 1892.

The meeting of the Grolier Club on Wednesday night was the most important to members of any since its foundation ten years ago. The exhibits on the walls and in wall cases were somewhat in the nature of a review of the good work done for bibliography and the science of bookbinding by one of the most charming little organizations in the country.

Chess players of the Empire State congregated at the Assembly Hall, 105 East Twenty-second Street, in this city, in order to participate in the championship or general tournament. There were sixteen competitors in the principal event and twelve in the general tournament. Only those players who succeeded in keeping a clean score were permitted finally to contest for championship honors, while those who lost two games could not go on playing for minor prizes.
The steamship Scotia, which arrived from the Mediterranean yesterday, reports a stormy passage and the loss of her port lifeboat during a heavy southwest gale.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Assembly this afternoon substituted Senator O'Connor's bill for the one before it relating to Inspectors of Election, and passed, it. It provides for non-partisan, or bi-partisan, Inspectors and poll clerks in all cities and towns of the State, except Brooklyn -- four in each election district, two from each party.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Mr. Sheffield said to-day that he would attempt to secure an early hearing on his New-York Police bill. He said the action of the Union League Club in New-York, by which a single-headed commission was favored, showed to him that a large body of representative men favored this idea.
WESTCHESTER, Feb. 22 -- Washington's Birthday was celebrated at the New-York Catholic Protectory here to-day in the presence of several hundred guests.

The portrait of the Father of his Country, hanging high up on the draperies between two American flags, smiled genially upon the women who gathered, at the dress-reform congress connected with the National Christian League fair in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon to talk about their gowns.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Prof. Edward J. Phelps of Yale, ex-Minister to England, is a trifle more comfortable to-night. He has lain in a critical condition all day, suffering a severe malarial chill this morning, and remaining very weak till this afternoon, when a slight improvement in his condition was noticed.
Senator David B. Hill's ears should have burned last night if there is anything in the old adage. He was spoken of and with a vengeance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Messrs. Warner, Hall of Missouri, and Henderson of Illinois, a sub-committee of the House Committee on Banking and Currency, have agreed to report favorably to the full committee the bill introduced by Representative Cooper of Indiana "to subject to State taxation national bank notes and United States Treasury notes."

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 22 -- In the cathedral to-day the Rev. Michael Tierney, D.D., of New-Britain, was consecrated Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Hartford in the presence of nearly 5,000 people. The solemn and impressive ceremony was rendered brilliant by the presence of nearly 400 clergymen, embracing Bishops, professors of universities, Vicars General, rectors, curates, and priests from all over the country.

A Society of Independents in art has appeared in New-York to the amazement of the world of artists and amateurs. If the society could put some life into the stagnant waters of art by acting as the champion of artistic worth oppressed by artistic Kings, cliques, oligarchies, or corporations it would do everybody a service.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The large decrease in immigration is likely to result in the contraction of the force of Immigrant Inspectors. This decrease in immigration is largely accounted for by the number of unemployed in this country, accounts of which have been sent abroad. The Bureau of Immigration is dependent for its support upon the head tax of 50 cents a head imposed upon each immigrant coming into this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The mail which arrived at the State Department from Haiti yesterday brings a still more positive refutation of the report published a few weeks ago that Minister Smythe had addressed a letter of advice to President Hippolyte concerning the management of public affairs in the Hatian Republic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The members of the Democratic State Central Committee of Connecticut say they did not mean to violate the civil service law in sending out a circular to Federal office holders asking for subscriptions to the campaign fund a few weeks ago. Mr. J.F. Brown, Secretary of the Finance Committee, has written a letter to Civil Service Commissioner Roosevelt to that effect.
The following plans of new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:
Mrs. Elizabeth Vanderburgh has had a deal of trouble for a day or two, and it all came about through certain charges preferred against her by Mrs. Eliza Hobart of 20 West Ninth Street.

When eight hundred and odd naval men are collected in one place the chances are that there are some among them whose experiences are worth relating. There is now about that number on board the receiving ship Vermont, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and among them is one whose service in the navy antedates that of many of those now wearing the blue toga of Uncle Sam's web foot.

The wheat market yesterday was moderately active and prices made a gain for the day of five-eighths of a cent a bushel, owing to higher Western markets. Cable reports were firmer, with limited orders, and shorts were covering. The market closed steady.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- George V. Hankins placed a bet of $500 against $20,000, in O'Neil's and Eckert's books, last night, on Danton to win the American Derby. Mr. Hankins first bet O'Neil $200 against $10,000. and then offered to wager $300 more at the same odds. This O'Nell refused to take but afterward compromised at odds of 40 to 1.

With the election of officers for 1894 and the passing of a resolution condemning House Bill No. 4,732 now before Congress, which provides for a censorship for the press, inasmuch as it would give a commission the right to determine what advertisements of a certain character should be rejected by newspapers and what should not, the annual meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association came to a close yesterday.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Jacob A. Moore, eighty-five years old, and Mrs. Jane Raymond, his housekeeper, ninety years old, were murdered in their home in Bushville, five miles north of here. The crime was the most ghastly in the history of Sullivan County, in which less than six mouths ago occurred another double murder.

We remark with more regret than surprise that Mr. Hewitt's remarks at the dinner of the Southern Society are restilted by many Southerners in Congress, while they are not resented by the Southerners in New-York who had the advantage of actually hearing them.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Prices for local securities to-day were, on the whole, steady and the feeling firm, although trading was desultory and the amount of business transacted limited. Diamond Match was the leader in activity, being in fair demand by investors, who bought about 1,000 shares that will go into their lockers.

Play in the tournament of the New-York State Chess Association was resumed at the City Chess Club yesterday, when W.H.K. Pollock of Albany and J. Halpern of the City Club contested their tie of the fourth round. Halpern adopted the French defense, in which Pollock, after P -- K4 with Q Kt -- K2, continued.

Rumors were circulated yesterday in Wall Street that the Governors of the Stock Exchange proposed to take action at an early day on the question submitted some months ago to a special committee as to the desirability of cutting off all the telephones connecting the floor of the Exchange with the private brogerage offices.

There will be a meeting of the Intercollegiate Athletic Association in the Fifth Avenue Hotel to-day. Some important changes will be suggested and arrangements made for the annual field day. Some of the delegates were on hand last night, and they held a caucus in Parlor F.

William Waldorf Astor has come forward to aid the unemployed poor of his native city. Yesterday morning he cabled from London to John A. Stewart of the United States Trust Company, asking him to add his name for $10,000 to the Citizens' Relief Committee's list of subscriptions for the unemployed poor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Mr. Blond has been accorded full credit for honesty and manliness in his mistaken fight for free silver and a larger supply of currency, but he will scarcely be surprised if the papers that have been candid in admitting his honesty are now outspoken in condemning his intemperate tirade in the House to-day

The Nu Epsilon Chapter of the Phi Gamma Delta Society of the University of the City of New-York held its third annual dinner at the Marlborough last night. Covers were laid for seventy. At the banquet the announcement was made that J. Emil Walscheid, a member of the sophomore class, had been elected President of the University Athletic Association.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 23 -- The Supreme Court to-day delivered an opinion in the fight between Rector Joseph B. Jennings and Bishop Scarborough for possession of Grace Episcopal Church at Westfield. The rector wins the suit.

Henry A. Gumbleton is again an office holder under the City Government. The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessment yesterday appointed him a member of the Board of Assessors to succeed Col. Edward Gilon, who was recently appointed Cleric of Arrears in the Finance Department.

The latest annual report of the Connecticut Bureau of Labor Statistics, to which we referred a few days ago, shows the percentage of wages cost or labor cost of products in nineteen prominent industries for the year 1892. This part of the report was compiled by the Republican predecessor of the present Commissioner from returns voluntarily submitted to him by the owners of 624 factories.
BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- The Transcript's correspondent sends the following from Honolulu, Feb. 12. via. Son Francisco. Feb. 23:

Seth L. Keeney, President of the defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, was before Judge Moore in the Kings County Court of Sessions yesterday on a question raised by his counsel as to the validity of the indictment for perjury found against him by the December Grand Jury.

For several months Mr. George R. Read has been gradually purchasing property at and about the northwest corner of West Broadway and Beach Street, the last parcel being acquired this week. The plot secured is from 144 to 150 West Broadway, 1 to 9 Beach Street, and 1 to 5 St. John's Lane, measuring 75, 100, and 150 feet, respectively, on these thoroughfares.

It was emphatically an Annie Jenness Miller day at the Improved Dress Congress of the Christian League Fair yesterday afternoon, and had the men who firmly believed that all women hate each other been present they would have seen the enthusiasm of women in love, for the women certainly were in love with both Mrs. Miller and her pretty gowns.

The annals of Spain are obscure back of that fatal day in July, 711, when Roderick lost his life at the battle of Guadalete, and then for hundreds of years Spanish history is uncertain. About the eleventh century there is something like historic ground to stand on, but it can be reached only by wading through unknown waters.

The Democratic Club of the City of New-York will hold its second monthly dinner of the year this evening at its handsome clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue. The tables will be laid in the banquet hall and drawing room on the first floor, and arrangements have been made to seat 125 members and guests of the club.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- "A man may be opposed to Platt and still win his little rights in the Assembly this year," was one of the comments heard over an incident in the Assembly this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Abram S. Hewitt's speech at the Southern Society banquet in New-York last night. In which he lamented that the South was represented in Congress by men much Interior to her representatives of former times, is being talked about among politicians with a great deal of interest.

The second game in the tennis championships was played at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday afternoon. George R. Fearing, Jr., of Boston, who was defeated on Thursday by B.S. De Garmendia of New-York, played against Philip S. Sears of Boston. It was expected that this would be a close game, and Sears was a slight favorite, Fearing's bad showing on Thursday causing many to think Sears would win.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The attention of high officials at the Department of Justice was to-day called to the statement sent but from Toledo, Ohio, that the United States Government intended to take action against the American Protective Association for arming themselves.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 23 -- To Bishop Tierney, who was yesterday consecrated Roman Catholic Bishop of Hartford, has been presented a beautifully-decorated gold crozier. The gift is from his alumni friends of St. Joseph's Seminary, Troy, N.Y.
Erastus Wiman will leave the Tombs on bail to-day unless something develops to complicate the charges made against him by R.G. Dun Co.

It is a curious spectacle that is presented by the House of Representatives these days. That body is supposed to be discussing Mr. Bland's bill for the issue of certificates on the seigniorage. In reality it has got pretty well through anything that can be called discussion of that measure, and has been for a couple of weeks engaged in answering or refusing to answer roll calls.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 23 -- The testimony in the Pollard-Breckinridge case, taken for the defense here to-day, before Examiner Bullock, proved of much value to the defendant, inasmuch, as the depositions of R.R. Rossell and John Brand were corroborated by men of high standing end unimpeachable integrity.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 23 -- Ex-Minister to England Edward J. Phelps has passed a comfortable day, with the exception of a short time this afternoon, when he appeared slightly weaker. The attendant physicians feel that the next two or three days will decide his case, and they have remained constantly at his bedside.

James Blewitt, a dealer in machinery at 425 Seventh Avenue and formerly a member of the Stock Exchange, has brought suit. In the Court of Common Pleas, to eject his wife, whom he calls Julia Williams, alias Mrs. Julia Blewitt, from his residence, at 378 West Thirty-second Street. He is fifty-six years old, and is believed to be worth $100,000.

"There goes a life's work for a song," said Randolph Huntington yesterday, at the American Institute, as the last of his favorite Arab-Clay trotters was knocked down for less than three figures. Mr. Huntingdon has spent almost a lifetime and some $200,000 In an effort to demonstrate that he was right and every other breeder of trotting horses wrong in the lines upon which he and they based their studs.

Counsel for John Y. McKane made an exhaustive argument in Brooklyn yesterday before Justice Cullen of the Supreme Court on the application for a certificate of reasonable doubt as to the justness of the conviction and sentence of the dethroned Czar of Gravesend.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- The market for local stocks exhibited no special features and was dull throughout the list. American Bell Telephone was heavy and declined on small offerings to 167, 2 1/4 below Wednesday's close. It is reported that the Bell Telephone Company of Canada, earned about 30 per cent. for its stockholders in spite of the fact that its basic patents there expired some years ago.

Michael J. Coffey is the only ring Democrat in the State Senate from Kings County. His majority in the Second District at the last election, as returned by the Board of County Canvassers, was a little over 1,200 votes.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Michael Fredericks, an Italian, who claims to be a practicing physician, was committed to the county Jail to-day on the charge of practicing without a diploma. Fredericks came here from New-York three months ago and represented himself as a doctor. He was employed by a number of his countrymen, and soon three of his patients died.

Peter Pindroch, sixty-five years old, is in Bellevue Hospital with a fractured skull, and his wife, Annie, is a patient in one of the female wards. She also has a fractured skull, and is suffering from shock. The injuries of the old couple were inflicted by Michael Gelar of 82 1/4 Cannon Street, who attacked them with a "slungshot" in the yard of their house, 282 Second Street.
Ten-year-old Isaac Gerstein, who was taken to Governor Hospital Jan. 10 with a broken neck, will be back home in a few days, ready to go to school.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 23 -- Miss Jennie L. Patterson. assistant teacher in the Uniondale school, who was suspended because she refused to clean out the schoolroom, build fires, and carry out ashes, and who was reinstated by State Superintendent of Public Instruction Crooker, personally served the clerk of the School Board with a certified copy of Superintendent Crooker's decision.

Mayor Gilroy and the other members of the Board of Estimate expressed, in emphatic terms, yesterday their disapproval of the manner in which the Park Department is spending the $1,000,000 appropriated by the Legislature for giving work to the unemployed. President Tappen of the Park Board and Engineer Kellogg appeared at the meeting of the board to ask for more money to carry on the projected improvements in the parks.

Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt's speech at the dinner of the Southern Society Thursday evening will be remembered as one or the striking events of the Winter, judging by the comments made upon it yesterday. It furnished in all quarters a topic less of discussion than of approval.

Dr. Albert N. Ely lectured yesterday afternoon before a class of thirty members of the Stock Exchange, who are desirous of acquiring a knowledge of surgery in connection with the subject of first aid to tae injured. This was the first lecture of a course of five to be delivered in the Exchange committee rooms.

Eli Perkins was reading his last essay on the proper method of training macaroni vines when Henry G. Sherman met him again and asked him how that account of their Utica a interview came to be printed in such shape. Eli said that it was got up by another man, who had a constitutional inability to tell the truth, and whom nobody cver believed, any way.

Nellie Nugent, daughter of James Nugent of 10 Verandah Place, Brooklyn, told a pitiful story of brutality to Justice Tighe in the Butler Street Police Court yesterday. Nellie's mother was buried Thursday. Her father, who attended the funeral, returned from his wife's grave drunk. Nellie's tears for her dead mother aroused the father's anger.
LONDON, Fob. 23 -- A dispatch from Buenos Ayres concerning Brazilian affairs says:

Just what will be the result of the raids that Superintendent Byrnes's detectives are making about the city, as regards the various police Captains in whose precincts the raids occur, is a matter of considerable speculation at present.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 23 -- The Fidelity Title and Deposit Company, as trustee of the estate of the late Elizabeth Petty, who was murdered at her home, 79 Commerce Street, last December, to-day filed an appraisement of the value of her property. The statement shows that the estate is not worth nearly as much as supposed, the real and personal property amounting to less than $12,000.

Representatives of the Buffalo elevator monopoly have succeded in inducing the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly to "lay over" the bill providing for the construction of State elevators for the benefit of the canal traffic. This laying the matter over in committee is the process by which similar bills have heretofore been pushed "the way to dusty death" in the pigeon holes.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 23 -- The Republican Senators continued in session all Thursday night and until noon to-day. They were forced to do this because of the absence of Senator John Ward of Salem. After the conference last night it was found that Ward was not in town, although it had been reported by telephone from his hotel that he was on his way to the State House.

American railway securities were irregular in the London market. Prices were not greatly changed, however, as the trading was on a rather limited scale. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Illinois Central, 1/2, to 93 1/2; Canadian Pacific, 1/4, to 70 3/4; Erie, 1/8, to 16 3/4, and Union Pacific, 1/8, to 18 3/4.

Late last night a small army of men and boys and a few women filed out of the Fourth Avenue entrance of the Madison Square Garden, each leading a dog. Some had big dogs, such as St. Bernards, mastiffs, great Danes; others had little dogs. All were well wrapped up, and in spite of the cold air, seemed to enjoy being out of doors.

NEW-YORK. Friday, Feb. 23 -- P.M. Rumors from Washington in regard to the progress of the Tariff bill and opinions and acesses over the outcome in respect to sugar furnish traders with the kind of data out of which an active market can easily be made, in the absence of genuine news of interest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- An attempt will be made to save the old war ship Kearsarge, and the first steps were taken to-day when Secretary Herbert addressed letters to the Senate and House asking for authority and an appropriation to contract with some wrecking company for saving the wreck of the historic vessel, now lying on Roncador Reef.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Vice President and Mrs. Stevenson gave a reception this afternoon from 4 to 0 o'clock in honor of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution in the parlors of the Normandie.

The leading McKinley journal of Ohio recently protested philanthropically against the enactment of the Wilson bill upon the ground that it would reduce the wages of workmen in Europe. This was an unexpected argument, but there is something still more surprising in the estimate of The New-York Tribune of Tuesday last that the enactment of the bill will cause a decrease of about 30 per cent, in the value of goods imported.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 - Pennsylvania was steady to-day at 49 3/8 @ 49 1/2. Sellers offered Philadelphia Traction at 93. Metropolitan sold at 101 1/2. People's Traction and the 4 per cent, trust certificates scored a further advance, the latter selling at 85 1/2. A feeble attempt was made to sell Baltimore, but it was steady at 15 1/4.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The House of Lords to-day resumed consideration of the Parish Councils bill. The Duke of Devonshire, leader of the Liberal-Unions, urged that before attempting to go into the details of the measure with a view of amending it, the Lords should consider the general position.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., Feb. 23 -- Intimate friends of Bishop X. Zardetti, while hoping that he has been appointed Archbishop of Roumania, are inclined to doubt it. He is not in Rome as reported, but is at St. Joseph's Convent, Milwaukee, where he is under medical treatment for insomnia.

Water Purveyor Milne of Brooklyn yesterday put an end to all question as to theft of city water by the Citizens' Electric Illuminating Company. He went to the plant of this favored political monopoly and there established the fact, beyond all question, that the company had been secretly using thousands of dollars' worth of water annually from the De Kalb Avenue main without paying a penny therefor.
The Amherst College alumni of this city and vicinity held their second meeting of the season at the St. Denis Hotel last evening, under the auspices of the Young Alumni Association.

Great excitement was created yesterday morning at the store of Ludwig Brothers, 38 West Fourteenth Street, by an attempt of a crank to do bodily harm to J.B. Ludwig. Alexander Mohr, twenty-four years old, an ex-employe of Ludwig Brothers, was responsible for the disturbance.

Tickets were placed on sale yesterday for the Corbett-Mitchell charity entertainment at Madison Square Garden to-night, and the advance demand was Indicative of a very large attendance. The box office was not opened until 1 o'clock, and for four hours there was a steady stream of purchasers. It was a strictly bona-fide sale, the ticket speculators holding off until almost the very last minute, when they began to buy.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- John Jacob Arnold, under sentence of eleven years and four months in Auburn Prison, having pleaded guilty to three indictments charging grand larceny, committed when cashier of the Merchants' Bank, and false entries made when County Treasurer, has made a full confession.

Last night the Football Committee appointed by the University Athletic Club met in the clubhouse, and, after being entertained at dinner, took the first step toward modifying the rules of the popular college sport. There were present Dr. W. A. Brooks of Harvard, Walter Camp of Yale, John C. Bell of Pennsylvania, and Alexander Moffatt of Princeton.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Henry D. Pool, a real estate and insurance agent here, and local agent for the Mercantile Co-operative Bank of New-York, was arrested today on seventeen complaints for fraud lodged against him on the part of the State of New-Jersey by the State Commissioner of Banks and Insurance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Mr. Gorman, Chairman of the Senate Caucus Committee, late this afternoon issued a call for a caucus of the Democratic Senators to be held Monday morning at 10 o'clock. About the time he signed this call the sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Finance also decided to submit the Tariff bill to the majority members of the Finance Committee Monday morning at the same hour.

On few days during the past season has there, been so much gossip and discussion among New-York clubmen as there was yesterday. A story in The Sun was the cause of it all. It stated positively that the Rev. Dr. William S. Rainsford, rector of St. George's Church, had been blackballel by the Governors of the new Metropolitan Club.

Before Special Master Crawford took up the Rice case yesterday in Philadelphia, he devoted considerable time to the taking of testimony on the petition of the Reading receivers for authority to purchase a steam collier and ten coal barges. The collier is to cost $175,000, and the barges $31,000 each, so that the expenditure involved will amount to $485,000.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- The sensation of the day in the Cornell poisoning case was caused by the announcement that one of the perpetrators of the outrage was ready to confess, he having concluded that this was the most manly stand to take. He was stopped, however, by others who were implicated in the matter.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The burial of Martial Bourdin, the Anarchist who was killed by the premature explosion of one of his own bombs near Greenwich Observatory on the night of Feb. 15, took place this afternoon. The hearse started from the place where the body had been lying in St. Paneras at 1:35 P.M.

The evangelistic meetings being held in Association Hall, Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, received a great impetus yesterday. It came in the form of a wonderful enthusiasm. On account of the high wind and cold a large attendance was not expected. Contrary to expectations, the body of the hall was filled before the meeting opened.

Bradstreet's issue to-morrow will say: "The most encouraging feature of the week is a report from Chicago that while store business has fallen off, order business has increased very largely, so that the total volume of transactions in staple lines is fully equal to that of one year ago. There are 235 business failures reported throughout the United States, against 288 last week, 202 in the week a year ago, and 227 two years ago.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

The Executive Committee of the Platt-Milholland faction of the Republican Party in this city met last night in Parlor D R of the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The most interesting feature of the discussion had to do with the part the faction should play in the investigation of the Police Department of this city by the Senate committee.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 23 -- The Bentley family troubles were again before Justice Martinez to-day. George P. Whedon, who was charged with threatening to shoot Peter Bentley, gave bail in $100 to appear for examination March 2. Warren Dixon, Mrs. Bentley's son-in-law, alleged, that Mr. Whedon threatened to shoot him and he told Mr. Whedon he was prepared for him.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 23 -- Henry Guy Fernald, alias Wentworth, who has been masquerading as tie son of a wealthy Boston banker since he came to the coast a few months ago, was arrested in this city last night on the charge of having committed the twelve-thousand-dollar burglary at the home of Pawnbroker Simon Jacobson, in San Francisco, last Saturday morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The Secretary of War to-day received from Second Controller Mansur a decision in the case of Gen. Sickles, which, while setting forth strong constitutional argument against the qualifications of a retired army officer to enter Congress, finds that Gen. Sickles cannot be divested of his retired pay, amounting to $5.625 annually, and that he continues to held his military office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Persistent efforts have been made to-day to learn the nature of the changes said to have been made in the Tariff bill by the sub-committee which has had it in charge for the last three weeks. Each member of the sub-committee who has shown himself in the corridors of the Capitol has been approached on the subject, but only evasive replies have been returned to the numerous questions.

As a result of the controversy between the Enterprise Association of Steam Fitters and the Progress Helpers' Association regarding the amalgamation of the unions representing those trades, 400 laborers employed on the Postal Telegraph and Home Life Insurance Buildings, now in course of erection on Broadway, went out on a strike early yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24. -- The stock market was dull in every department, but was firm in general. Alley offered at 24 1/2, hung there awhile, and then steadily advanced to 25. Diamond Match opened at 122 and improved to 122 1/4. Lake Street opened at 21 and closed at 21 1/8, after selling at 21 3/8. The first sale in West Chicago was at 135 1/2, the last at 135 3/4.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The Treasury Department will begin business Monday with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

As was exclusively announced in The New-York Times of Sunday last would be the case, Domino, the champion two-year old of last season, has been declared out of the Brooklyn Handicap, the first great race of the present year, as the Kentucky Derby has now lost all pretensions to greatness and is won year after year by horses of but moderate class.
