There is a great deal more in the contest for Supervisor of the Eighth Ward, Brooklyn, than appears in the surface discussions. Control of the Board of Supervisors is not the only thing involved.

From The Boston Transcript. When our grandsires and their dames were young, good old "Hallowell" used to be the most popular tune in the singing books. It was contemporary with "Portland," "Turner," and "Buckfield," and it was sung by choir and class, its inspiring air sinking deep into the hearts of the many.

The final game of the ships was played yesterday the Racquet and Tennis S. De Garmendia of New-York S. Sears of Boston. won easily, as was expected rather surprised the game he put up, particularly in the set.
The garden island of the Hawaiian group is undoubtedly the most northerly one, which is known as Kauai. To reach it, however, one almost has to "cross Jordan."

In the catalogue of sale, a volume of narrow folio of 200 pages, the quality of each "lot" is marked with scrupulous care, with notes, where needed, stating that the skins are damaged by shot, unusually lagre or small, dark or pale, wooly or rough, or "cubs," in the case of bears, dyed or stained, choice, poor, middling, or specimen skins.

Tall maidens are a phenomenon of modern times in America and England. At the sea beach, at balls, and at church, wherever the young people belonging to families in easy circumstances congregate, the young women seem to have taken inches to themselves by comparison with their mothers and grandmothers when tne latter were young.

The call sent out by the Manhattan Club for a members' meeting was responded to last night by a large gathering at the clubhouse. The meeting was held for the purpose of considering means for covering the deficiency of $13,000 in last year's accounts.

The taxeaters of Brooklyn are solidly united against consolidation with the City of New-York. They know very well that consolidation would deprive a large part of them of their places at the public trough. For this reason they are antiannexationists to a man, and it is significant that their opposition takes the form of a demand for a uniform rate of taxation over the whole extent of the Greater New-York.

The Intercollegiate Athletic Association held its annual meeting in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon. Some changes were made in the rules governing contests, records were approved, arrangements were made for the next field meeting, and officers were elected for the coming year.

The opppnents of Cornelius Furgueson, the ring "boss" of New-Utrecht, have adopted practical measures looking to his defeat at the approaching Spring election. Engaged in the movement are the Republican Association, the Reform Democratic Association, and the Taxpayers' Association, together with many independent citizens.

From The Westminster Gazette. Is "deviling" devilish? Yes, "devilish and internal " says Mr. Germaine, who writes on " The Bar as a Profession " in the new legal monthly called The Brief. But devilish or not, there the system is, and he who would succeed at the bar must make the best of it: " The chance, and the only chance, for a beginner to win clients is by showing competency in court:

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 24. -- All hope for the schooner Flash has been abandoned by the owners of the vessel, Messrs. G. Tarr Brother. Vessels that started long after the Flash sailed have arrived home, but not a vessel has reported having seen or spoken her, She left port on the morning of Jan. 12, and that night a terrible gale raged.

To-morrow, at the American Horse Exchange, Broadway and Fiftieth Street, beginning at 2 o'clock, W.D. Grand will sell an especially good lot of matched and cross-matched carriage pairs and singleharness horses. This fine collection of highclass carriage and coach horses was purchased last November for export to Europe, but, negotiations having fallen through, it was decided to place the entire lot on the New-York market for unreserved sale at auction.

There will be no legislation for a vote on municipal consolidation this year, if the Brooklyn politicians can prevent it. The snarl into which they have thrown the question at Albany is not the result of accident. It is the outcome of a carefully-arranged scheme to defeat any practicable proposition to submit the issue to the people.

FORT LEE, N.J., Feb. 24. -- Justice Henry Mabie issued a warrant for the arrest of William Barlow this morning upon complaint of his daughter. Miss Barlow said her father was acting strangely and threatening the lives of several people. When the warrant was served, Barlow, after reading it, handed it to his daughter, who was standing beside him, and retired to his room.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 24. -- A large number of prominent people were attracted to the Chancery Court room in the State House to-day to hear the taking of depositions ordered by the Supreme Court to support the rule to show cause why an information in the quo warranto proceeding's should not be filed against Senator Maurice A. Rogers and Senator Robert Adrain, contending as presiding officers of the two Senates.

John Y. McKane was not as cheerful yesterday as he has been since his incarceration in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn. He thought Justice Cullen should have granted him the certificate of reasonable doubt Friday, instead of reserving his decision until to-morrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24. -- The steamship Oceanic, from Hongkong and Yokohama, brought advices concerning the burial of Otani Kosho, ex-Chief Abbot of the Hon Wan Temple, on Monday, Jan. 20, at Kioto. Elaborate preparations had been made for the ceremony, at great expense, and the funeral cortege was reviewed by 150,000 people.

"I was once sorely tempted to allow a sati," said the Resident, spreading a dust cloth over our knees. "Long ago, as I was making my tour of inspection, I camped near the castle of a little chieftain. In the morning I heard that he was dead. When his father had died, some ten years before, his eighteen wives had been burned.

This has been a busy week for the chess fraternity. On Washington's Birthday scores of players were engaged in their struggles over the chessboard. It is, however, very doubtful, indeed, whether the institution of bath championship games, as they are played both in the Empire State and New-Jersey, should not be aboilshed, because there is too much chance as regards the final issue.

The High School girls at the Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, are doing some very good gymnastic work under the direction of Miss Jessie Lines. The training comes in the regular routine of their school work. They don't have as much time for it as they would like, but in the three years' course they attain a very good degree of proficiency.
A yachting exhibition has just been held in the Royal Aquarium of London, which, according to reports, was very interesting. Speaking of the exhibition The London Field says:
Norman L. Munro, the millionaire publisher and owner of famous steam yachts, died at the Hoffman House at 6:30 o'clock last evening. His death resulted from an operation for appendicitis.

Joseph H. Choate's denunciation of the Irish population of this city at the last annual dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick created such indignation against the society that a large number of the members had resolved upon disbanding the organization.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24. -- The Corn and Flour Exchange and the Board of Trade of this city, the two organizations which most thoroughly represent the commerce of the port, are working energetically for free iron ore. The movement which they inaugurated several weeks ago has been approved by kindred organizations in Boston, Philadelphia, and Chicago, and it is expected that New-York will cordially co-operate in it.

In the eighteenth annual report of the German Legal Aid Society Robert Goeller, the attorney for the society, says: "Frank R. Stockton, in 'The Hundredth Man,' puts into the mind of that social chameleon, J. Weatherby Stull, the notion 'to found a law hospital, where those persons who were unable to pay for legal protection should receive it as freely as the ailing poor receive medicine and treatment in hospitals of the other kind.'

"If an order is worth presenting to the court at all, it is worth the attendance of a lawyer, and not an office boy," remarked Justice Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday morning, after he had examined a document which had been presented to him for signature.

Bonds to the value of $105,000 were stolen eleven years ago from the banking office of Baring Brothers Co., in London, and nearly all of them were subsequently recovered. A year ago Jacob Cobb of 141 First Avenue, while in Amsterdam, Holland, purchased three of the missing bonds from Frederick Dieniers.

At the American Museum of Natural History yesterday morning, Prof. Albert S. Bickmore delivered the second lecture of his course of illustrated lectures in the World's Fair to teachers of the city and State.

From the first Colonial days the Bannings had continued the richest, most eminent family in Dunder County through the primogeniture of chance. Son had succeeded father in the possession of their broad estate, the Laplands, without the necessity of considering that discordant and disrupting element, a younger child.

The season of grand opera in French and Italian, under the management of Abbey Grau, at the Metropolitan Opera House, came to a close last night, with the fourteenth performance in this city of "Carmen." For some reason the house was far from being full but the audience evinced a determination to alone for its comparative smallness by an abundance of applause.

As a continent it is the home of a vigorous race of mankind, which, while resisting assimilation with European civilization, defies permanent conquest. It views with equanimity, or at least is powerless to resent, the occupation of its coasts and the more healthy contiguous regions; but the heart of the continent remains, and must ever remain, the home of the African.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 24. -- As a result of the investigation of the books of Adjt. Gen. H. H. Artz, which has been in progress for several days, that official tendered his resignation to the Governor this afternoon. The report of the expert accountant showed several irregularities in Artz's accounts.

To the Editor of the New York Times: Was the leader in Saturday's Tribune headed "A Change For Farmers" meant to impress those utterly ignorant of the present status of the "grain trade." who only know from day to day that "wheat has again broken the record" and made a new price for that cereal?

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- The new commercial treaty with Russia will come up for its first reading in the Reichstag on Monday, and Deputies of all shades of politics are making preparations for a grand parliamentary tournament. The contest preliminary to the admission of the treaty to its first reading is certain to be protracted, all sides agreeing that it will extend over four or five days.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 24. -- Judge Colt's order restraining the Consolidated Road from discriminating agrainst the NewYork and New-England is the subject of much discussion in the railroad circles of this city. President Clark is out of town, but the officials say they have been notified of the proceedings.

Members of the Board of Aldermen are not satisfied with the amount of patronage they have received from the Park Board since work was begun under the milliondollar appropriation. At least half a dozen Aldermen have called at the Park Board offices every day since the men were put at work, but they got little or no encouragement.

Mr. Thomas B. Reed, sometime Speaker of the House of Representatives, which he exulted in having redeemed from the reproach of being "a deliberative body," has just published, under the above title, a work of which the sub-title is "A Manual of General Parliamentary Law." Everybody will suspect him of a humorous intention.

Hugh Cochran, forty-eight years old, of 145 North Eighth Street, Brooklyn, while, at work in the Nassau Smelting and Refining Works, 540 and 544 West Sixteenth Street, yesterday was severely burned about the face and neck by molten lead. He was melting lead in a huge iron kettle, when a fellowworkman plunged a wet shovel into the kettle, causing the metal to spatter on Cochran's face.

Water Purveyor Peter Milne of Brooklyn, after considerable work, has demonstrated without the slightest doubt that the Citizens' Electric Illuminating Company has been secretly using thousands of dollars' worth of the city's water yearly, and has not paid a cent to the city for it.
WEST POINT, N.Y. promontory overlooking the mile north of the spot contains an acres, more than been added to gaint above monuments.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The work of the East Side Relief-Work Committee is only limited by the lack of funds to extend it, and while the need continues and increases the committee cannot believe that men and women who ask for the opportunity to work to support themselves and their children will be denied it by the people of New-York.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 24. -- Fox hunting has not by any means become an extinct pastime in Connecticut. While the only surviving charter member of the old Hartford Fox Club, Dr. David Crary of this city, who was master of ceremonies at the club's reception fifty years ago, has been housed for the Winter, his disciples have been having exciting sport since December on Talcott Mountain and in the Farmington Valley.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 24. -- The Arkansas Press, a new morning paper with strong backing, will be issued to-morrow. The paper will be published every day, and will receive the full reports of The United Press on a leased wire direct from Chicago and simultaneously with Cincinnati, St. Louis, and Memphis.

Two men, who refuse to give their names, saying they were from Bridgeport, Conn., visited the Morgue yesterday morning, and, after viewing the body of "Mrs. Miner," the young woman who committed suicide by taking a dose of poison at the Grand Union Hotel, said she was Maggie Lawlor, twenty-six-years old, who had been employed in a shirt factory at 165 Fairfield Avenue, Bridgeport.

Patriotism is warm in the hearts of the Colonial Dames of the State of New-York, and not even the unusually cold breezes of yesterday could chill their enthusiasm or lessen their interest in colonial history.

Mr. Brander Matthews keeps bravely on, turning to profitable ends his knowledge of theatrical history and his liking for the stage. These studies make such a pretty little book that one who has a taste for bookmaklng could hardly resist buying if it met his eye, yet there is nothing in it that will measurably benefit the cause of dramatic art in America, if, indeed, there is such a cause.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- With the crocuses blooming in sheltered nooks and the Forsythia pushing its yellow blooms through the light snow that fell on Wednesday night, the capital has been having what Washingtonians are pleased to call an "oldfashioned" Winter. There has been nothing of Winter here, as a matter of fact, and it is now too late to mend.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24. -- One of the results of the election in this State is the utter annihilation of the nondescript political coterie known as the "Pennsylvania Democracy." This has existed for several years under different names, and in different disguises, and its greatest hostility has been toward Mr. Cleveland and the regular Democratic organization as represented toy the present State administration.

From The Brunswick (Me.) Telegraph. We commenced editorial work March 10, 1836, and it was on the 10th of April, 1857, that we issued our first number of The Telegraph, so that we have been nearly thirtyseven years connected with it, for neariy thirty-three years its sole editor and proprietor -- for little more than three years having a partner.

This volume becomes all the better reading because of a personal element in it, but the autobiographical feature is never put too much to the front. What Sir William Dawaon has tried to do is not to make the reader familiar with all the salfent points of geological science, or even with all those that he has reached, but to lead him to some of the viewing places "which he thinks have been particularly instructive."

"Our Business Men's Executive Committee has received a large number of letters making urgent appeals for help," said Arthur W. Milbury, Secretary of the Industrial Christian Alliance, yesterday. "Just look over some of these," he added, handing to the reporter for The New-York Times a batch of letters.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24. -- A prominent steel merchant of Philadelphia, who does not desire to be quoted, but who speaks authoritatively, stated to-night that a pool has been formed which embraces all of the manufacturers of steel castings in this country, with but one exception. The exception is the Midvale Steel Company of this city, which will not be antagonized.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The Senate Committee on Printing, consisting of Senators German, Ransom, and Manderson, resumed its investigation of the Patent Office Gazette lithographic contract this morning. Josiah Quincy and Commissioner Seymour were present, as was also William E. Curtis, who preferred the charges, and several clerks from the Patent Office.

William Loeder, who was twenty-four years old, and employed by Michael Wundt, butcher, at 1,952 Amsterdam Avenue, perished yesterday morning in a fire which ravaged three frame dwellings on the southwest corner of One Hundred and Fiftyseventh Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The fire did about $15,000 damage and a score of imperiled persons had narrow escapes.

Washington Letter to The Philadelphia Times. Chairman Wilson is a slender man, not over five feet, if that, with a pale face, bright blue eyes, and a fine head of rapidly-whitening hair. He and Mrs. Wilson live in a very quiet and unpretentious way, occupying rooms in a neighborhood far from fashionable, and taking their meals at a near-by boarding house.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 24. -- Washington's Birthday of this year will be long remembered as a red-letter day in the Lakewood calendar. The people came in fullyexpected numbers, a special train Wednesday night bringing a large complement of guests to the hotels. The feature of the day was the dinner of the Society of the Cincinnati at the Lakewood Hotel, which brought together an unusual number of men prominent in New-Jersey political life.

The Colonial Dames of the State of NewYork, although only organized last April, have already over seventy members. No one is admitted to membership who cannot show a geneological tree with some ancestor living in this country as early as 1750, and who served his country in some noteworthy office -- if in the army or navy, holding no lower position than that of Lieutenant.

YONKERS, Feb. 24. -- This city is soon to enjoy the benefits of a new hospital building, to take the place of the old and timehonored one on Woodworth Avenue, which for over twenty years has afforded relief to the sufferers of Sing Sing and vicinity. The old St. John's Riverside Hospital has taken care of hundreds of patients.

NASSUA, N.P., Feb. 20. -- The steam yacht Natalie, which arrived here on Feb. 4, was suspected by the authorities of being engaged in violation of British neutrality laws, and was searched, but, nothing being discovered to justify seizure, she was not held.

Club chat just now has one interesting theme -- the realization of the plans of the Metropolitan Club in the opening of its home at 1 East Sixtieth Street. This will occur very soon, and the housewarming will be of a character adequate to the importance of the social event.

The sequel of the hazing outrage at Cornell is much more discreditable to the students concerned than the outrage itself. The Faculty has in formal resolutions taken the ground that it is not its business, but that of the civil authorities, "to preserve the peace and maintain the law."
Col. John Middleton Huger, a distinguished member of an old Southern family, died at his late residence, 537 Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning.

Police Captain McKelvey of the Classon Avenue Precinct, Brooklyn, is investigating a peculiar and fruitless burglary which is causing considerable anxiety to the family of George Zollinhoffer of 24 Clinton Place.

From Harper's Bazar. Fashion has given its sanction to the use of the single bed, and large numbers of socalled "twin bedsteads" are now in the market, many of them made of costly woods, rich with carving. They are so designed that when placed side by side the effect is that of one wide bedstead, whereas, a separate spring mattress and bed clothing are provided for each one.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24. -- There were no transactions in any of the fraction stocks to-day, except in Baltimore, which sold at 15 1/4 @ 15 3/8, and odd lots of Electric at 48, but the list held strong. Philadelphia was quoted at 92 @ 93, and Metropolitan at 101 1/2. Although traction earnings are suffering in sympathy with railroads, the stocks have apparently drifted into such strong hands that none seems to come out.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 24. -- The report emanating from Washington that the receivers of the Northern Pacific Road were instigating the proposed investigation of Judge Jenkins's actions in issuing the order affecting employes of the system having been circulated here, Attorney Harper of counsel for the receivers said to a United Press reporter last night that there was not a word of truth in it.

The Republican Governor of Michigan has suspended from office the Republican Secretary of State, Treasurer, and Land Commissioner, who as members of the State Canvassing Board are charged with falsifying the election returns of last year on the proposition to amend the Constitution so as to increase certain official salaries, including their own.

Among the notable riflemen in the National Guard there is none better known than Francis J. Stuart of the Sixty-ninth Battalion. He has had a career as a rifleman never equaled by any other member of the old Sixty-ninth Regiment.

The great blue granite edifice which has stood for more than a half a century at the northeast corner of Broome and Elizabeth Streets, within view of the down tracks of the Madison Avenue horse cars as they turn out of the Bowery, is about to be vacated by its present occupants, the oldest Lutheran congregation in the city.

It is said that the Republican National Committee is likely to adopt the plan of basing representation in the next National Convention in part on the party vote instead of entirely on population. Instead of two delegates from each Congressional district it is proposed to have one from each Congressional district and an additional one for every 7,000 Republican votes cast at the last Presidential election.

Is the time ripe for new standards of appraisal in city real estate values? This is a question that has suggested itself to many careful observers who have noticed the erratic streaks in prices disclosed by the sales of the past twelve months. Valuations are too often mere matters of abstract opinion, whose connection with prices obtained at real sales is very remote.

Although the author of this review of the poets who wrote during the reign of James I. in England gives a good reason for their literary demarkation, there is an air of artificiality about his theory which his expert workmanship never entirely dispels. Mr. Gosse says:

WABASH, Ind., Feb. 24. -- Zella Lytle Nicolaus, somewhat faded since she left Wabash to enter upon a career which has brought her into national prominence, but still very beautiful, arrived in Wabash at 4 o'clock this morning. She came from Chicago, and telegraphed from Logansport for a cab to convey her to the home of her parents.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Feb. 24. -- Representatives of the railroads centring in this city have made a proposition to President Hyde of the Bath Iron Works to induce that big shipbuilding concern to locate in this city. President E.C. Smith of the Central Vermont, President Colt of the New-London Northern, Augustus Brandegue, counsel for the corporations; President Clark of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford, and other officials of these roads have presented the case for New-London.

The wife of Thomas H. Robins of 629 Park Avenue was arrested Friday night, her husband charging her with assault. Mr. Robins is an upholsterer and lives over his store. He ran out of his apartments Friday night with blood streaming from a cut over his right eye. He told a policeman his wife had made the wound.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24. -- The graceful dome of the Agricultural Building, World's Fair grounds, was completely destroyed by fire this morning. Shortly before 7 o'clock, a guard passing by the building saw smoke and flame coming from the outside pillars, near the point at which previous fires had started.

The season of grand opera which has just come to an end at the Metropolitan Opera House was remarkable in more ways than one. If in no other, it was notable for its vocal excellence. It is a long time since this public has heard so much good singing. Now it so happens that singing is an essential factor in opera, and consequently it is silly for extreme Wagnerites to decry pure vocal achievements.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 24. -- It is a fact of considerable interest to Grand Army men, that not one of the present officers of the Connecticut Department served outside of the ranks in the war. The new Commander, Selah G. Blakeman of Shelton, enlisted as a private in the Seventeenth Connecticut from the town of Stratford, and, after three years' service, was mustered out as a Sergeant in his company.

From London Truth. The sensational reports regarding the health of the Princess of Wales have been happily much exaggerated. It is nevertheless, certain that the Princess has decided to withdraw from society, and, according to her present resolve, she will seldom again accompany the Prince either upon his visits to country houses or to London balls and parties.

The Political Equality League of Kings County resumed its conference in the hall of the Long Island Historical Society, Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, yesterday. Mrs. Cornelia K. Hood presided and read a report from Dr. Alice D. Campbell on the progress in the Eastern District.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- I suppose that it would be just possible to be a good general and a clever musician; but such is not the fate of the ambitious M. Cesar Cui, The Russian General has done nothing to favor the musical alliance. The premiere of the "Flibustier" was given every chance by very boisterous puffing.

Though now associated with Scotland, the bagpipe is an instrument of great antiquity, and was known long ago to some Indian races, also to the Italians and Bretons. It appears to have reached its most popular development from the musical and utilitarian view in the case of the Highland bagpipe.

The English were first to see the possibilities of brown bread used as a flavoring for ice cream, and the vogue which the dish enjoyed after reaching America proved that its right to be was well established.

The Valkyrie will sail for home about May 1. This is on the authority of Mr. H. Maltland Kersey. The crew to take the English yacht across the Atlantic will come out here on the Majestic, which will sail from Liverpool on April 4. The Valkyrie will go direct to the Clyde and fit out at once for the English racing season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Under the act of May 10, I892, known as the Cockran bill, the Paris and the New-York, Britishbuilt ships, were admitted to American registry, on condition that the owner, the International Navigation Company, should build their equivalents in American shipyards.

We do not understand that the International Sanitary Conference at Paris has undertaken to use its influence to prevent the transmission of cholera from India to Mecca and the cities at the head of the Persian Gulf or to insure the enforcement of sanitary regulations at Mecca.

Last week an up-town woman bought an umbrella. It was a beautiful umbrella; it was slender, shapely, and strong; it was light, durable, and stylish; it had silk, stick, and ball handle, all of a deep, lapis-lazull blue -- and was, in fact, just what the soul of the woman had long desired in the way of an umbrella.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Some days ago the Judge Advocate General of the Army decided that the releases which are granted deserters from the army were discharges; not honorable discharges, but discharges without honor. This gives the deserter an opportunity to secure a pension, since he has been relieved from the odium of desertion.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24. -- The edge was off the bull campaign in wheat at the opening to-day, and the enthusiasm which has marked the trade for the last few days was entirely abated. Several big scalping lines of long wheat were thrown overboard at the start and further depressed prices -- they had opened off 1/2 @ 5/8 C from last night's close.

Hotel proprietors have taken active steps to oppose the bill now before the Legislature, which proposes to increase the price of licenses for hotel bars. The measure has been considered by the Hotel Men's Association, and its attorney has been directed to ask the Excise Committee of the Assembly for a hearing before action is taken on the bill.

Of all the plants used for food, there is none which has been so long known, or has had, so to say, so distinguished a lineage as asparagus. Its record, in fact, reaches back to almost the commencement of authentic history, as it is mentioned by the comic poet Cratinus, who died about 425 B.C., and was a contemporary of, though slightly older than, Aristophanes.

One of the most difficult things in animal training is the teaching them to be driven. This is especially difficult in the case of lions. The king of the forest, in the first place, objects strenuously to having anything put about his neck, and, secondly, to be made to draw a vehicle of any kind is a thing to him degrading.

On the cabin passenger list of the Cunarder Etruria, which sailed for Liverpool yesterday, appears the names of Ireland and Griffin. The men who took passage under those names are really Fathers M.C. Martin and G. Hallon, two Roman Catholic priests. They are en route for Rome, where they hope to get a hearing from the Pope, having failed to obtain an audience with Mgr. Satolli, the Apostolic Delegate here.

The chances are that early this week the Tariff bill will come out of committee into the open Senate. So long as discussion continued behind closed doors over those schedules which affected stocks in the market, there was great opportunity to work the stocks on rumors. The effect has been that almost the only active stock in the market the past week and the week before was Sugrar, with Distillers' a good second.

It is gradually leaking out that William D. Lohman, the defaulting ex-cashier of the Brooklyn Excise Department, conducted the affairs of that department in a most amazing manner. His methods appear to have been known to the Excise Commissioners whom Mayor Schieren displaced.

Martin and G. Hallon, two Roman Catholic priests. They are en route for Rome, where they hope to get a hearing from the Pope, having failed to obtain an audience with Mgr. It is gradually leaking out that William D. Lohman, the defaulting ex-cashier of the Brooklyn Excise Department, conducted the affairs of that department in a most amazing manner. His methods appear to have been known to the Excise Commissioners whom Mayor Schieren displaced.

HAVERHILL, Mass., Feb. 24 -- The Tufts College Glee Club gave a concert in City Hall Wednesday evening. They were afterward entertained by the Pentucket Club, and then the members of the club indulged in a prank which has caused the expulsion of three young women from Bradford Academy.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- The sensational developments anticipated yesterday in the student banquet incident have not materialized; consequently there is very little progress to report. Coroner Brown is devoting a great deal of time and energy in an endeavor to clear up the mystery surrounding the affair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The statement recently made that the Postmaster General was contemplating bringing suit against the Pacific Mail Steamship Company for nonfulfillment of its contract for carrying the mails, is denied at the Post Office Department. The contract which the steamship company has with the Government calls for one trip a week from San Francisco to Hongkong, and one trip a month from New-York to Colon.

There is a branch of architecture which is very much in need of woman's discernment and experience. It is the planning of the interior arrangements of apartments and flats. Most of them are designed without apparent reference to the needs of the labor question and by men who have judgment about placing water and gas pipes to save a few feet of tubing, but who have evidently never done a day's kitchen work.

A Cuban girl's life is very restricted, and she is never alowed to go out alone nor receive callers of the other sex except in the presence of her chaperon or some member of her family. If during her childhood she attends a day school, a maid or some family servant takes her there every day, and she cannot go as short a distance as across the street unaccompanied.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Feb. 24. -- The William J. Mathieson Company's sumac and dye works, in Vernon Avenue, were burned this evening. A gale was blowing from the northeast and no water was available. The factory was a four-story brick building, filled with combustible materials and explosive chemicals.

DANVILLE, Ky., Feb. 24. -- William Swope of Fayette County is here consulting with his brother, James Swope, relative to the testimony given by Dr. T.M. Lewis, in which the name of their deceased brother, the Hon. A.M. Swope, was dragged into the Pollard-Breckinridge scandal. The Swopes and Dr. Lewis have both retained lawyers, and there are probabilities of coming trouble.

WILLIAMSTOWN. Mass., Feb. 24. -- This year it is thought that Williams will have a strong baseball team in the field, and, as a result, there is joy among the students here. There are only three vacancies from last year's team, but, in spite of that fact, a large number of candidates go to the gymnasium for practice every day.

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- Emperor William went to Brandenburg City to-day to attend the annual banquet of the Diet of Brandenburg Province. At 7 o'clock he arrived with his suite at the door of the Englisches Haus, where he was met by Dr. von Aschenbach, President of the Province. The party entered the dining room at once.

Dr. Wolfred Nelson of this city, whose election as a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society, London, is announced, is a Canadian and a subject of her Britannia Majesty. He was born in Montreal April 9, 1846. He comes of a medical family, ten members having been graduated in surgery, and medicine.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24. -- An effort is making to protect and increase the game of Maryland. For years the shooting has proceeded with little thought of the future of the sport, and the consequence is that the supply is running low. In the Green Spring Valley, one of the most beautiful sections of the State, a game protective association has been formed, and thousands of quail will be turned loose upon large estates.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Feb. 24 -- P.M. Out of total sales of 121,829 shares of stocks to-day, 92.200 were in Sugar and Whisky. They furnished quite an interesting spectacle, for they worked in opposite directions. Sugar moved upward, touching its highest price for some time.

The auction sales of real estate in Brooklyn during the past week footed up $121,895, as against $92.229 for the corresponding week last year. For the present week the principal sale at auction of Brooklyn real estate will be had by Messrs. Richard V. Harnett Co., in the Real Estate Exchange Salesroom, in Liberty Street, in this city.

A Western turf Journal, true to the "wild and woolly" slang of that section, thus epitomizes the condition of the trottinghorse industry, so far as regards the publicsale feature of the business: "The bottom has dropped out and a few of the stronger men among the breeders are now clinging to the sides."

From The Baltimore Sun. The Baltimore market is now well supplied with terrapin and game of excellent quality. In one store an exhibition of terrapins is to be seen. They are in a dozen or more bins and there are hundreds of them. They are graded according to size and quality.

The provisional Government which was set up at Honolulu something over a year ago, with the aid of the United States Minister and the marines, is as fine an example of an oligarchy as has been seen in modern times. Those directly engaged in setting it up hardly exceeded a score of men, and they took possession of all the important public functions.

In pours the black portion of the congregation. It is composed, for the most part, of women. They are gorgeously arrayed in silks and cottons of the most bewildering brilliancy, with golden beehive-shaped ornaments in their ears and twists of gold about their necks, and all are beaming and smiling with the utmost complacency and self-satisfaction.

Park Commissioner Frank Squiers of Brooklyn has decided to make important changes in that department, which he belives will be in the interest of the public. In speaking to the newspaper reporters yesterday regarding the changes, he said:

Political crimes are not the only offenses charged against John Y. McKane. He will soon be called upon to show whether his fortune was accumulated wholly out of his connection with politics and public office, or whether a large share of it was not made in unlawful private transactions.

The death of Louis Etienne Dussieux, historian and geographer, formerly professor in the Military School in St. Cyr, is announced in Paris. He was born in Lyons, April 5, 1815. He obtained in 1839 and 1840 the annual premiums of the Academic des Inscriptions et Belles Lettres. He became Professor of History in St. Cyr in 1850.
The New-York Free Circulating Library Society presents, in the simple facts of its fourteenth annual report, an impressive review of the services which it renders to New-York.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 24. -- Since the announcement was made in a press dispatch three weeks ago that the brillant meteor of Jan. 20 was being investigated by Prof. Newton of Yale, the well-known authority on such matters, he has received scores of letters from all parts of the East describing the phenomenon as seen at the point of observation of the witness, and asking: "Did I see the meteor?

BUENOS AYRES, Feb. 24. -- According to advices from Rio Janeiro, the insurgent transport Mercurio has been sunk by the guns of the Government battery at Porto Madama. The shots penetrated the boiler of the transport, which exploded and killed several of the men on board.

BOSTON, Feb. 24. -- American Bell Telephone sold down to-day to 165, but recovered at the close to 166. Each wave of selling leaves this stock on a lower level, and the buying demand seems to decrease with the price. Erie Telephone sold at 42 1/2, and remains steady around that figure. West End Street Railway sold off 1/2, to 46 1/2.

During last Summer Holguin and Glbara, Cuba, were prominently before the world as foci of revolutionary movements. Glbara is a charming seaport town nearly midway between Havana and Santiago de Cuba. On the trip from the Paris of the West Indies, Havana, the steamer makes a turn to the right and enters one of the several score of fine harbors for which Cuba, or the Queen of the Antilles, is noted.

By the largest meeting in the interests of Irish home rule held in this city in a long time, Major John Byrne was enthusiastically applauded yesterday when he spoke of wealthy Irish-Americans of New-York, who, "behind batteries of champagne on St. Patrick's Day," boasted of the prowess of the Irish race, while they were unwilling to render the slightest assistance to their countrymen at home.

Mr. Leland would be final authority, if asked whether that active and passive verb, "to schnorr" was admissible to the sacred vocabulary of a canting dictionary. The derivation of the word is vaguely traceable to a Hebrew root. Actually, it is Yiddish pure. Schnorr runs through all the parts of speech.

MIDDLE-TOWN, Conn., Feb. 25. -- An autopsy was held this afternoon on the body of Charles Payne Reed, the Wesleyan student who died yesterday suddenly after he had been pitching for a short time in the baseball cage. It showed that death was due to the rupture of a blood vessel in the brain.

The second concert of the series which is being given under the direction of the Provisional Committee for the aid of the hungry, of which Oliver Sumaer Teall is Chairman, was held at the Grand Central Palace last evening. The music was by the Seventh Regiment Band, assisted by Nina Bertini Humphrys, soprano; Emil Sanger, basso, and W.B. Rogers, cornet soloist.

The history of Spain readily yields to treatment by the writer who desires to interest children. It abounds in romantic, chivairous, and adventurous episodes, in which wonderful chieftains and picturesque people are the performers, and it is almost theatrical in its transformations and shiftings of scenes.

Alexander Isaac Cotheal, on old resident of New-York, died at his residence, 62 West Thirty-sixth Street, yesterday morning. Mr. Cotheal was born in this city Nov. 5. 1804. He was educated here, and resided in the city all his life.

Copyright, 1994, by the United Press. BERLIN, Feb. 25. -- The slow progress of the Reichstag committee in examining the budget proposals makes it evident that nothing except the Boerse tax will be settled before the Easier holidays. The Government newspaper organs, foreseeing the reduction on the proposed tobacco tariff, declare that any deficit in the estimates from this source will be met with a duty on alcohol.

The conference of Democratic Senators announced for this morning will, of course, amount to nothing unless the Finance Committee shall have received the Tariff bill from the sub-committee and be prepared to lay before the conference the changes, whatever they may be, that have been suggested in the bill as it came from the House.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24. -- A strong attempt is being made in the college to stimulate the interest of the students in the Question of civil service reform. To this end the university threw open Sanders Theatre on Tuesday night to two speakers who had made a study of the evils of the present civil service system, and who were oratorically fitted to present those evils to the students in the clearest possible light.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 25. -- Three of the prisoners who escaped from jail at Thomasville Thursday afternoon, after dangerously wounding the Sheriff, have been recaptured. One of the men is Spencer, the murderer. He drew a pistol, and had to be shot before he would surrender. His wounds are not dangerous.

Impressive services in memory of George William Chiles will be held at 2 P.M. on Sunday, March 11, under the auspices of Typographical Union No. 6, in the Fifth Avenue Theatre, the use of which for the occasion has been generously given by Henry C. Miner, the manager.

It is difficult for a writer having a distinct individuality to impress the greater number of readers exactly as he desires. His style has not the form in which ideas present themselves to the greater number. To be immediately popular, absolute faithfulness to a carefully-collected dictionary of commonplace phrases is necessary.

Lord Forester, writes a correspondent, who is about to resign the Canonry Residentiary of York Minster, as announced in The Westminster Gazette, shares with one other nobleman -- Lord Kinsale, who is Premier Baron in the Peerage of Ireland -- the singular privilege of wearing his hat in the royal presence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- President Cleveland sailed away from Washington this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock, in the lighthouse tender Violet, for a duck-shooting trip along the North Carolina coast. He was accompanied by Secretary Gresham and Capt. Robley D. Evans, the Naval Secretary of the Lighthouse Board.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- The demand for local securities this week was confined to about the same securities that were in demand and active last week. Transactions were not so numerous, due no doubt to the fact that the week's trading was interrupted by a legal holiday. Hudson River Telephone stock was again the feature, and the asked price is 3 per cent. higher.

TROY, Feb. 25. -- Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., has been at home for a few days devoting his personal attention to his political machine. This has been thought necessary by the Senator, because there is an election to be held here on March 6, and some Democrats who are weary of the domination of the Senator are making it warm for the man he has proposed to put into the Mayor's chair.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 25. -- The Knights of Labor of the United States are about to embark upon a campaign having for its object the removal of the negroes from the United States and their colonization in the Congo Basin, Liberia, or some other part of Africa.

We grant the reasonableness of Brooklyn's demand for equal taxation. Her sins of misgovernment and corruption are visited upon her head in the form of taxes much heavier than New-Yorkers have to pay, and she suffers further from the fact that her burden of taxation falls mostly upon the homes of her people.

RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 25. -- Late last night a well-dressed stranger alighted from a west-bound train and inquired from Officer Dunham the whereabouts of a good hotel. Dunham directed him to the Rahway House, near the station, where he registered, in a bold hand, as "Albert Sacks, Dubuque, Iowa."

KINGSTON, Feb. 25. -- If the cold shall continue for a few days longer, the ice harvesting along the Hudson will be completed. No time is being lost by the Superintendents in charge of the work. Several gangs were kept busy at various points today. There is now little fear that the ice crop will be scant, though the quality, to a large extent, will be inferior to that gathered in previous years.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25. -- During the last week the number of candidates for the baseball nine has been reduced by Capt. MacKenzie to thirty men. Their names and the positions for which they are competing are as follows: For Catcher -- Lindsay, '94; Trenchard, '95; W.D. Ward, '95; Williams, '96; Smith, '97; Brokaw, '97; Vorhis, '97.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 24. -- There seems to be a disposition by investors to buy stocks, and fewer shares were offered than for several weeks, but the number of sales is limited. American National Bank is in better demand, at slightly higher prices, with little stock offered. Commercial National Bank is also sought after, with only small lots for sale.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- It is not at all improbable that before the investigation into the lithographic contract with which, the name of Mr. Josiah Quincy has been freely used, apparently to do him injury, some of the persons who have industriously published reflections upon him may conclude that they were doing something more serious than simply printing a political paragraph.

NAPLES, Feb. 25. -- An interesting trial of Socialists and Anarchists will begin soon in this city. There will be forty-two defendants, one of them a Deputy. All are implicated With the Sicilian Socialist Deputy de Felice and the exiled Anarchist Cipriani in plotting to start a revolution in Italy.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 25. -- The Rev. S. Edward Young, pastor of the Westminster Presbyterian Church and Secretary of the Monmouth County Law and Order League, in the prelude to his sermon this evening, epitomized the New-Jersey Senate wrangle in a parable.

An old man, who was identified as Benjamin Low, a wealthy resident of Gloucester, Mass., died late Saturday night in the office of Paige's Hotel, 301 West Street, into which he was taken from the street, where he had been found unconscious.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25. -- More Changes in the Yale crew have been made, and now only two men in the 'Varsity boat are rowing in the places they started in at the beginning of the season -- Treadway at No. 7 and Holcomb at No. 2. These men may be regarded as fixtures.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- Washington's Birthday was celebrated by a holiday and the usual Colonial Ball. George Washington, and Lafayette received the guests.
This is the story of a horse that spent all night in the East River, and then celebrated his rescue by getting drunk.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- If any doubts have heretofore been entertained as to the President's attitude on the silver seigniorage question, those doubts seem to be entirely removed by conversations had with the President just before his departure for North Carolina.

Two subjects of considerable importance in their relation to immigration -- the shipment of lunatics, imbeciles, and other paupers to this State from Europe and the rapid increase of the number of insane persons in the State asylums -- are considered in the report of the State Board of Charities transmitted to the Legislature a few days ago.

The Brooklyn firebug who created consternation in South Brooklyn a month ago has renewed his activity in another section of the city, and yesterday morning succeeded in destroying the Manhattan Opera House and a whole block of other buildings in East New-York.

Old St. John's Cemetery, at Hudson, Leroy, and Clarkson Streets, for which the city has agreed to pay $520,000 to the Trinity Corporation, and which will be transformed into a public park, was established sixty years ago. More than 10,000 bodies, mostly of the middle and poorer classes, are burled in it.

The Trustees of Columbia College, in appointing Prof. Franklin A. Giddings to the Chair of Sociology, have given to Columbia the distinction of being the first college in the United States to establish a full professorship in the comparatively recent subject. Prof. Giddings comes to Columbia from Bryn Mawr.

The Princess Galatro Colonna, who has been living quietly at the Belgravia apartment house, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, with her three children, since she came from France two weeks ago, left New-York Saturday afternoon for California. The Princess was accompanied by her three children and John W. Mackay, Jr.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Feb. 26 -- A.M. Last week's market for stocks was interesting to those who regard the situation apart from its vagaries, chiefly because of the sturdy strength it displayed in the face of news that could not be called favorable. Railroad earnings failed to show the improvement expected of them.

John E. Milholland, lieutenant of Thomas C. Platt to run the new Republican machine, is busying himself with getting evidence against the old machine, Tammany Hall, Superintendent Byrnes, and every one else who he thinks is opposed to him and the new organization.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed an increase in reserve of $230,675. The banks now hold $74,707,500 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans of $1.889,300, a decrease in specie of $671,400, an increase in legal tenders of $1,589,600, an increase in deposits of $2,750,100, and a decrease in circulation of $311.700.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 25. -- The first thing that a visitor from the North is told when he reaches this land of oranges, flowers, and "wonderful climate" is that there is a fortune awaiting him if he will only buy some land and set it out in orange trees.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- The Illinois Steel Company started up one of its blast furnaces at South Chicago yesterday. Employment was given thereby to about 100 men who had been out of steady employment since the mills shut down last Fall. It is expected that a second will be started toward the latter part of the present week.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Feb. 25. -- Policeman Patrick O'Hare of this city entered Schwalenberg's Hotel, Vernon and Borden Avenues, this morning, in full uniform and drunk. Pulling off his belt, coat, and helmet, O'Hare shouted that he could "knock out" any man under 158 pounds in the place.

The Philippine Islands are to the fore with a new and extensive railway project. In 1889 the United States Consul at Manila, the capital of the islands, reported that the first railway -- narrow gauge -- had been opened to the public. The sucess of the line and the favorable reports to the mother country, Spain, have led to new surveys for the line referred to.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst preached yesterday morning in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church on "Liberty: the Law of Liberty and the Liberty of the Law."

On Saturday evening the three games left over in the final round of the New-York State Chess Association were played at the Manhattan Chess Club. The games resulted as follows: Hodges beat J.W. Baird, Sicilian Defense, twenty-six moves; Showalter beat D.G. Baird, Ruy Lopez, twenty-one moves; Simonson beat Sonweine, Giuoco Piano, thirty-three moves.
Charles M. Clancy, Sheriff of New-York County, died at 5:10 o'clock last evening at his home, at 65 Prince Street, from pneumonia.

Light-harness horsemen have been anxiously anticipating the response to the stakes which the Driving Clab of New-York has opened for the Summer trotting meeting. There was an uneasy feeling abroad that the trotting season of 1894 would suffer from the prevailing business depression, but the list of entries which Secretary Mason has received is larger than last year.
Silver bullion certificates were not quoted on Saturday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 21, via Montevideo, Feb. 25. -- The Insurgent cruiser Republica, with Admiral Mello aboard, was off the bar on Tuesday, Feb. 20. She exchanged shots with the Government forts and signals with Admiral da Gama's flagship. The insurs-ent war ship Aquidaban sailed away at 3 o'clock this morning.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Feb. 25. -- A large new frame dwelling, 829 Vernon Avenue, was gutted by fire this morning. The fire was due to an overheated stove, put in a recently-plastered room to dry it. Several firemen were at work on the second floor of the building when the roof fell in.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Feb. 25. -- Erasius Wiman spent Sunday with his family, out the day was one of sorrow for them all. The death of his oldest son. William Dwight Wiman, seemed only a Question of a few hours. The physicians gave no encouragement.

STAPLETON, S.I., Feb. 25. -- James Connolly thirty-six years old, of Grant City, was struck by a locomotive on the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad last night and fatally injured. Thomas Fitzpatrick, engineer of the last train from Tottenville to St. George, saw an object on the track between New-York and Grant City.

Winter has no intention in his old age of losing any of his reputation so ably added to in the last few days for furnishing first-class zero weather and fierce storms. When the mercury began to climb upward yesterday, reaching 15 above zero at noon, there were hopes that a fair start was to be made toward allowing March to come in like a lamb.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25. -- The report that all the manufacturers of steel castings in the country, with one exception, had formed a pool, or combination, is somewhat premature, as the plan is still under consideration.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 25. -- The pottery manufacturers are much concerned over the announcement that the pottery operatives will send their petitions, recently signed, against a reduction of the crockery schedule to Congress with an entirely new heading over the names. They will ask the Representatives to reduce the tariff on crockery to a revenue basis.
MEXICO, Feb. 25. -- Congressman William L. Wilson, ill of typhoid fever in Guadalajara, is somewhat more comfortable to-day.

ELIZABETH, Feb. 25. -- No ball has yet been obtained by Henry D. Poole, the insurance agent here who was arrested on numerous charges made against him of alleged swindling, and it is very doubtful if he gets out of jail before next Wednesday, when he will be taken before the Supreme Court at Trenton to answer the complaint of violating the banking and insurance laws of New-Jersey.

The Rev. Father Kenelm Vaughan of London, England, who is a guest of Archbishop Corrigan's household, belongs to one of the most distinguished Catholic families in the United Kingdom. In a family of eight-six brothers and two sisters-five of the brothers are in the Church, and the sisters are members of religious communities.

Mrs. Katie Gran, thirty years old, of 1,134 Second Avenue, was arraigned in the YorkVilla Police Court yesterday, charged with throwing carbolic acid over William Dowald, fifty years old, a gasfitter, of 320 East Fifty-ninth Street.

Andrew Kearns, twenty-five years old, of 495 Warren Street, Brooklyn, was stabbed in the back and seriously wounded last night by Chiattetto Biogio in the latter's saloon, 57 Front Street. Kearns is in the City Hospital. His condition is critical.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 25. -- An effect of the Senatorial dead-lock will be seen when the term of Supreme Court Justice Magie shall expire, on Wednesday. His successor may not be named for the present. The Constitution requires that the appointment shall be made by the Governor and confirmed by the Senate.

WEST POINT, Feb. 25. -- Grant Hall was packed with an appreciative audience last nlght. The "hundredth, night entertainment," so long waited for, was given, and it was a decided success. The boys left nothing undone to throw all former efforts in the shade, and that they succeeded was attested by the words of praise heard on every side.
The fate of John Y. McKane, the convicted "boss" of Gravesend, will be decided to-day by Justice Cullen, in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The last of many changes made among the civil force at the Brooklyn Navy Yard has been authorized by Secretary Herbert. John J. Smith of 33 Cheever Place, Brooklyn, has been appointed to a clerkship in the Department of Supplies and Accounts, vice J. Mooney, also of Brooklyn.

The pretended establishment of the old Louisiana Lottery in Honduras under a charter from the Government of that country is a gigantic fraud. The gambling operations of the company are carried on in the United States, in defiance or evasion of law, just as effectually and almost as completely as before the expiration of its Louisiana charter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Representative Geary of California has prepared the report of the majority members of the House Commerce Committee on the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill. It will be laid before the House to-morrow. The report says that the pending bill, which was introduced by Mr. Dunphy, is intended to meet the objections urged by the President in his veto of the former bill.

From The Westminster Gazette. The valentine has had its day. The trade in valentines has been on the wane for over ten years, each succeeding year being worse than the previous one, until now the vanishing point is approaching. Some of the large wholesale houses which once did a big business in valentines have given up the trade altogether.

Danforth E. Ainsworth of Oswego, the Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly and the Republican leader on the floor, is at the Park Avenue Hotel. He came to this city from Albany Saturday, accompanied by his family, Who will start to-day for a visit to the South. Mr. Ainsworth will remain In the city until to-morrow morning.

One would have to travel a long distance and search thoroughly to find a more bright, attractive and pleasing little lady than Mrs. Cross, who resides at No. 326 West 23d Street, New-York. She is the wife of Mr. Clarence Cross, who is an expert telegrapher. Sealed in her parlor a few evenings since, in a pleasant conversation I was told a story which in interest and importance I have never heard excelled.

How much use is there for silver certificates? That is a question that might properly be studied by a House of Representatives that has been wasting a fortnight over a proposition to issue some $60,000,000 of this peculiar kind of "currency," based on the pretended profit of the coinage of bullion now in the vaults of the Treasury.

JERSEY CITY, N.J, Feb. 25. -- Miss May Barrowcliff left the City Hospital this morning, and went to the home of Aquilla W. Wanmaker, 308 Magnolia Avenue. The transfer was quietly affected. Mr. Wanmaker, his sister, and Miss Gertrude Dexter drove to the hospital in a closed coach.

In an article in the March number of The Forum, Mr. Simon Sterne makes the fact that since Jan. 1, 1893, one-sixth of the railroad, mileage of this country, representing a capitalization of about $1,750,000,000, has passed into the hands of receivers the text for a discussion of the causes of these failures.

SING SING, Feb. 20. -- Matthew Johnson, the colored West Indian, was executed today in the electric chair in Sing Sing Prison. After having rested well during the night, he arose early this morning and ate a substantial breakfast. While he was eating, Chaplain John C.S. Weills of the prison came in, and they had a long talk.

The report of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations as to "whether any, and if so what, irregularities have occurred in the diplomatic or other intercourse between the United States and Hawaii in relation to the recent political revolution in Hawaii" is a rather picturesque bit of patchwork, but it is not of the least consequence.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Feb. 26 -- P.M. Speculation to-day was not active and was confined to a few specialties. The total transactions were 151,000 shares, and of this number 51,300 were in Sugar, 30,300 in Distilling and Cattle Feeding, 15,400 in St. Paul, and 12,800 in Chicago Gas.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- A division was taken in the House of Commons to-day on the Lords' amendment to the Parish Councils bill enabling parishes of from 200 to 500 inhabitants to dispense with Parish Councils, and it was rejected, 212 to 161. This is the amendment offered by Lord Salisbury last Friday in the House of Lords.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Lawyer Joachenson, in behalf of Col. E.C. James, special counsel for John Y. McKane, made application at 5 o'clock this afternoon to Justice Dykman for an order to show cause why a certificate of reasonable doubt should not be issued, pending an appeal in the McKane case to the Court of Appeals.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26. -- Early this morning a collision took place at the mouth of the harbor between the outward-bound boat John H. Starin of the New-York line, and the heavily-loaded coal barge H.F. Hallock. The Hallock lay alongside the barge Martin, and the lights on both were burning brilliantly.

TRENTON, Feb. 26. -- Six of the Republican Senators were in the courtroom this morning before the Master appointed by the Supreme Court to take depositions in the suit begun by the Governor and Attorney General against Senator Maurice A. Rogers and Senator Robert Adrain, to determine which of the alleged Senates of New-Jersey is the lawful body.

BOSTON, Feb. 26. -- An overladen freight elevator in the building of the Boston Dry Goods Company, 77 Bedford Street, containing between 3,000 and 4,000 pounds of freight and three men, fell from the sixth story to the basement, a distance of sixty feet, about 6 o'clock to-night. All three men on the large car were badly injured, and one, it is feared, will die.
ROME, Feb. 26. -- An exciting incident occurred in the Chamber of Deputies to-day, which, at one stage, promised to lead to a personal encounter.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Judge Grosscup, in the United States Court, rendered to-day a decision, of national importance, especially to railroad companies, officials, and agents and shippers who complain of unlawful discrimination in freight rates. The decision practically paralyzes the administration of the inter-State commerce law, for the reason that it will be impossible in future to convict persons who violate any of its provisions.

SCRANTON, Penn., Feb. 26. -- The Scranton Glass Company resumed work at No. 2 tank furnace this morning. This furnace is one of the largest in the United States. It has been idle more than two months. Tank No. 1 is also preparing for operations, while Tank No. 3 was obliged to suspend Friday because of an accident.

In the Jefferson Market Police Court Justice Ryan yesterday expressed his regret that the whipping post or some such kindred institution was not in general use. Charles Kramer, a baker, and a wife beater by choice, who was before the bar, thanked his stars that it was not.

The election trials interrupted week before last by the trial of Joseph F. Blaut, ex-President of the Madison Square Bank, were resumed yesterday before Judge Barrett in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. All the cases now on the calendar will be finished. Assistant District Attorney Wellman representing the prosecution.

Carrie Turner is the latest actress to get married in secret, and keep the fact as long as possible from the knowledge of the public. It is now announced that Miss Turner was married last Thursday, by a priest in the Cathedral Parish House, in Albany, to John Mack, a well-known sporting man of that city.
The new Metropolitan Club, which has had no headquarters up to the present, has at last received its home and pleasure house fresh from the hands of the architects and decorators.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- In the Senate this afternoon there was presented. In compliance with a resolution adopted last week, a copy of the correspondence between the Treasury Department and the Department of Justice as to whether silver certificates issued under the Bland-Allison act of Feb. 28, 1878, are "lawful money" under certain statutes.

Pessimistic old gentlemen who have been entertaining grave fears for the "old-fashioned Winters we used to have" should have been very much cheered up yesterday. There was Winter enough to suit anybody.

John Y. McKane is a step nearer Sing Sing. Justice Edgar M. Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday refused to grant a certificate of reasonable doubt, by which the counsel of the convicted coney Island "boss" hoped to keep him out of State prison pending the appeal of his case to the court of Appeals.

"The Greater New-York" was the subject of an interesting address delivered last evening before the Brooklyn Young Republican Club by S.L. Woodhouse. The rooms of the club in the Johnson Building were well filled by members, notwithstanding the storm. Mr. Woodhouse was cordially received by his associates. His remarks, which evoked frequent applause, were as follows:

Judge Truax of the Supreme Court yesterday directed orders to be entered in certiorari, instituted on behalf of various corporations, whereby the proceedings of the Municipal Tax Commissioners with respect to assessments for purposes of taxation for 1891 and 1892 were substantially modified or set aside.

BERLIN, Feb. 26. -- To-day's sitting of the Reichstag opened with a full attendance of members, and the galleries were crowded to suffocation with visitors. All of the Cabinet Ministers were present. Contrary to expectations built upon previous announcements, neither Chancellor von Caprivi nor Freiherr Marschall von Bieberstein opened the debate on the Russian treaty.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO JANEIRO, Feb, 23. via Montevideo, Feb, 26. -- The insurgent steamer Venus was off Engenno Island early this morning bombarding the Government fort at Madama Point. Her ammunition was stored ln a magazine constructed of bags of sugar piled high from the floor, and about 7 feet thick on every side.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- The fourstory shirt and collar factory owned by A.S. Rugge was totally destroyed by fire yesterday. A two-story frame dwelling, an office building, a large number of wagon sheds owned by H. A Starbuck, R. Sims's sewing machine office, and Charles Price's livery office were also burned. The loss on Rugge's factory is estimated at $50,000, with an insurance of $20,000.

During the storm of sleet and rain Sunday night the guests of three hotels, the New Netherland, at the northeast corner of Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue; the Savoy, on the opposite side of the street, and the Madison Avenue Hotel, in Fiftyeighth Street and Madison Avenue, were suddenly aroused from their slumbers about 2 A.M. by the cry of fire and the rattling of fire engines through the streets.

The motive that prompts men and women to attend an entertainment in which Mark Twain figures as a star attraction is not to be misconstrued. They want to be amused. Their minds are made up for an evening of laughter. Having set themselves in that purpose, nothing can turn them from it -- not even Mark Twain.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The resources of savings banks of the State of New-York on Jan. 1, 1894, were $18,919,544 smaller in the aggregate than on Jan. 1, 1893. The surplus, according to the tabulation prepared by the State Banking Department, was $1,610,992 less. The falling off in resources occurs in 22 of the 31 counties in which savings banks are maintained.

Four cable cars beyond control caused wild excitement, bordering on panic, in upper Broadway last night. The trouble began at Seventeenth Street and Broadway about 6:30 o'clock, when cable car No. 117. Charles Reilly, gripman, and William A. Depew, conductor, Was signaled to stop for a passenger.
ITHACA, Feb. 26. -- The following resolutions were passed by the Executive Committee of the Cornell University at its meeting late this afternoon:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. --There are still many obstacles to overcome before the Tariff bill can be reported to the Senate. But for the obstruction of a minority of the Democratic Senators, the bill would undoubtedly be in the open Senate to-day, with a good prospect of speedy action upon it.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Diamond Match, which closed firm Saturday at 122 1/4, opened up this morning at an advance of 3/4, which it not only held without a break, but increased to 123 1/2 at the close. This was, however, the only really active stock on the list, although everything was strong, with a decidedly higher tendency.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 26. -- Six additional complaints were made to-day against Henry D. Poole. the insurance agent who is in jail here for obtaining money under false pretenses. The prisoner will now have to procure $11,500 bail in order to be released from custody. There are now twenty-three complaints against him.

Charles D. Shepard, who kept the White Elephant saloon, on Broadway, near Thirty-first Street, for fourteen years, and who, a few years ago, was considered wealthy, has been unable to settle a large number of claims which creditors have filed with the Sheriff, and the sale of the furniture and fixtures of the old place was advertised to take place yesterday at 209 and 211 West Forty-second Street, where the articles are stored.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20. -- The new battle ship Indiana, which was to have left tie Cramps' shipyard this morning for her builders' trial trip, will not sail until tomorrow week. Everything was in readiness for the start to-day, but owing to the severe storm and the fact that the big ship's anchor chains did not arrive, it was decided to postpone the trial.

The efforts of those misguided persons in Connecticut who have sought to smother the Hartford Bridge scandal have thus far served only to make that scandal more notorious and offensive. Some time ago, immediately after the deplorable action of the Hartford town meeting, we narrated the history of this remarkable scandal up to that date.

Republicans who think the Committee of Thirty which has been duly authorized by the Republican County Committee to reorganize the party in this city should be permitted to do the work which has been assigned to it, and that Thomas C. Platt should not be permitted to interfere, will find no end of encouragement in the proceedings at the meeting of the Republican County Committee last night in the Grand Opera House Hall.
After McKane -- what? That is the question which has already stirred Brooklyn residents in regard to Gravesend.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. Feb. 26. -- Olivier Longtin, the French Canadian who left Pawtucket a week ago last Monday for Canada to establish his claim to half of 512,000,000 worth of property in New-York, known as the Desire estate, arrived home Saturday afternoon. He says he has obtained his grandfather's will and the necessary papers to fully establish the right of himself and brother to his grandfather's estate.

The Adjutant's Trophy, presented by Adjt. F.G. Landon, was competed for Saturday evening at the range of the Seventh Regiment. The conditions of this match are: Five shots with the revolver, at 10 yards, "deliberate." Only commissioned officers are eligible to enter in this contest. There are three prizes. Following is the score:

On a southern reef is moldering the wreck of the historic old Kearsarge, and in the Brooklyn Navy Yard there was yesterday assembled a body of officers who are charged with determining where the blame for her being there should rest.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Senator Lexow, the Chairman of the New-York City Police Investigation Committee, has received a letter from Attorney Goff, which is supposed to have an important bearing on the future movements of the committee. Mr. Lexow said to-night that he did not think it wise to make this letter public until he had submitted it to the committee.

A meeting of railroad Presidents and General Managers has been called for to-morrow in the office of the Trunk Line Association to consider the east-bound freight and passenger situation, which has again assumed a serious aspect.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 26. -- A severe wind and rain storm prevails along the coast. All trains are delayed, and many telephone and telegraph wires have been broken. The wind is blowing a gale. Near Perth Amboy ten sections of poles, containing over fifty long-distance telephone wires, were blown down on railroad tracks, blocking travel.

Baseball men of all calibres thronged the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday when the annual meeting of the National League and American Association of Professional Baseball Clubs was held. In the crowd were the familiar faces of dyed-in-the-wool cranks, umpires, managers, stockholders, players, good and bad, and the sole topic of conversation was on the outlook for the national sport.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 26. -- The proposed seventy-two-hour bicycle race that was to have begun in Philadelphia next Monday has been declared off. George H. Van Emberg of Arlington was among the entries, but he received word that the National Association, under whose auspices the meet was to have been held, was unable to post the necessary guarantee money for the competitors.

The King's Daughters of the Protestant Episcopal Church of Zion and St. Timothy, in West Fifty-seventh Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, are in urgent need of contributions of money, clothing, fruits, and delicacies for the sick, books, periodicals, &c. This growing and watchful organization has for the last few years been doing a noble work in the relief of distress in its particular field of operations.

A conference was held at the Chamber of Commerce at noon yesterday, concerning the proposed police Investigation. The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst, Charles S. Smith, Gustav II. Schwab, and John W. Goff were present. Mr. Goff read to the committee a letter addressed to Chairman Lexow of the Senate Investigating Committee, stating the conditions upon which he would consent to act as one of the counsel of the committee.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- Senator Lemnel C. Miller of Cape May caused much excitement in the Democratic camp to-night by asserting himself as against the dead-lock, and stating that he would no longer act with the ten Democratic Senators. Senator Adrain had just called the minority branch of the Senate to order, when the Senator from Cape May arose, and in a clear voice said he would no longer sit with his Democratic colleagues.

Kenneth F. Sutherland, Justice of the Peace in the town of Gravesend, who is indicted for oppression in unlawfully arresting the copyists sent to Gravesend by William J. Gaynor to copy the registry lists the Saturday night preceding election, was placed on trial before Justice Cullen, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, Brooklyn, yesterday.

"It is easy to see that the clerk of the weather is a man," said Mrs. Marguerite Moore at the Woman Suffrage Mass Convention in Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. "This is not the kind of weather we should have turned on at all."

A generation ago there were already clubs in New-York, but they were not very numerous and they were much like each other. They had at least this in common, that they were places hated and feared by wives and mothers of families. Most of them have that feature in common yet, but they have scarcely any other.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Feb. 26. -- Daniel Doncaster's machine shop and Bronson Colligan's saw and planing mill at West Avenue and Third Street were burned shortly before midnight to-night. Sheridan's auction and livery stable, adjoining the planing mill, on Third Street, was also destroyed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Steele Mackaye's body will reach this city to-morrow morning. At 2 P.M. a funeral service will be held in the Scenatorium, on Michigan Avenue. Prof. David Swing will conduct the services. Roland Reed will deliver a eulogy on the dead actor and playwright on the part of the profession, and Elwyn A. Barron on the part of the press.

Jacob Kessler, a truckman of 630 West Forty-eighth Street, sat up Sunday night to attend his sick wife. About 3 o'clock yesterday morning he discovered that a frame building at 632 West Forty-eighth Street, occupied as a blacksmith shop, was on fire. Kessler gave an alarm. In the rear of the blacksmith shop is another frame building.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- A strong contingent of marines will leave Portsmouth on Wednesday to reinforce the British command at Bathurst, Gambia. A vigorous campaign is to be conducted against Chief Fodisilah and his slave-stealing followers, and it is announced that further reinforcements will be forwarded to Bathurst almost immediately.

The fourth lecture in the series descriptive of John L. Stoddard's tour around the world was given at Dalys yesterday morning, and in spite of the driving snowstorm the house was filled, as it invariably is at these Lenten matinees. The subject of the talk was "From Ceylon to the Himalayas," and the lecture was the first of the two devoted to India.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Feb. 26. -- Mrs. Frederika Mandelbaum, known in New-York City as a notorious "fence," and who did a profitable business there in that line for a number of years, died here this morning. She came here about ten years ago when the New-York authorities began proceedings against her and her conviction seemed probable.
