The above picture is an exact reproduction of a valuable oil painting which we were permitted to copy from a collection in a gentleman's private gallery. It tells a weird and powerful story. The vessel is going upon the rocks! The wind and waves are so deafening that the sound of the bell on the buoy cannot be heard!
St. Patrick received a rebuff yesterday at the hands of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. T. A. Kerrigan sold to Archibald C. Shenstone, plaintiff, for $2,100, the two-story frame dwelling 253 Marion Street, north side, 56.3 feet east of Howard Avenue, 18.9 by 100. To Frank Bailey, at $10,000, he sold the four-story brick and stone dwelling 90 and 92 Pierrepont Street, southwest side, 31.6 feet southeast of Henry Street, 31.6 by 100.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- There were a combination of reasons for the decline in wheat to-day, and, notwithstanding the punishment when short sellers received a few days ago, they again plucked up courage and put out their lines. Pardridge, who is in California attending the Midwinter Fair, sold a big line through his own house which initated the break that afterward carried prices a cent and a quarter below the final figures of Saturday.

Erastus Wiman, through his counsel, Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy, in the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Martine, yesterday pleaded not guilty to two indictments found against him last week for forgery in the second degree.

Justice Cullen having certified judicially what every sensible man who has followed the case at all carefully already believed, that there is no ground for reasonable doubt that McKane was fairly and legally tried, convicted, and sentenced, it is interesting to ask what is the essential offense for which he will justly pass the next six years in prison.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- The investigating committee of the Senate which is inquiring into election methods in vogue in various cities of the State last Fall held its second session in this city this morning. Chairman Mullin and Senators Persons, Stapleton, and Kilburn, the Republican members of the committee, were present, but Messrs.

The public meeting of the Methodist Historical Society of the City of New-York, which was held yesterday at the Methodist Building, in Fifth Avenue, called together a large number of clergymen and laymen.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 26. -- The production of "Twelfth Night" at Vassar College on Saturday evening was the most elaborate play attempted by Vassar students since the public production of "Antigone" at the Collingwood Opera House. The stage settings and costumes were unusually fine.

NEW-BRITAIN, Conn., Feb. 26. -- A trolley car of the Central Electric Company collided with a switcher of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railway while running toward Berlin early this morning. The trolley car was in charge of Conductor Hancock and Motorman Birmingham, and was on its way down a hill.
Ladies' day at the Lotos Club attracted many women to the clubhouse, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, yesterday.

Two hundred members of the Presbyterian Social Union of New-York assembled last evening in the banquet hall of the Hotel Brunswick and enjoyed a literary discussion and musical entertainment. The Rev. Dr. John Hall and the Rev. Dr. Chambers were among those who were on the platform.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A volume of nearly 800 printed pages (exclusive of maps) was laid before the Senate to-day representing the testimony taken by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations and its findings of facts thereon, under a resolution directing it to inquire whether any and, if so, what irregularities had occurred in the diplomatic intercourse between the United States and Hawaii in relation to the recent revolution.
Mayor Gilroy announced yesterday the following additional subscriptions to the Citizens' Relief Fund, received through Treasurer J. Pierpont Morgan:

The Republican members of the Kings County Board of Supervisors met yesterday afternoon and transacted business for the first time since the election of Supervisor James Boyd President pro tem. and the seating of Supervisor Linde of the Eighth Ward.

Mayor Gilroy will take a vacation for two or three weeks, beginning next Monday, and will make a flying visit to California. He will go to Coronado Beach, near San Diego, to join his wife and daughters, who have been there for a few days. His youngest son may accompany him. After a few days' visit in California, Mayor Gilroy and his family will return to this city.

There were hundreds of attentive listeners at the noon revival meeting yesterday in Association Hall, Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, hundreds who had braved the storm, and who made up with their fervor for the other hundreds whom the blizzard had kept indoors.
BOSTON, Feb. 27. -- About 5,000 of Boston's unemployed gathered on Boston Common early this afternoon. A large force of police was present, but there was no disorder.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Several other names were sent to the Senate to-day, among them Winslow Warren to be Collector of Customs for the District of Boston and Charlestown.

Rather than stand a criminal or civil prosecution for stealing water from the city, the officers of the Citizens' Electric Light Company of Brooklyn have agreed to pay a fair price for the water they have surreptitiously obtained.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27. -- The proposed purchase of the Ivy Hill site for a reservoir in South Orange by the Board of Works of Newark for $81,000, or about $40,000 more than its actual value, was made the subject of a presentment by the Grand Jury of Essex County late this afternoon.

Mr. Cleveland has sent to the Senate the following nominations: For Collector of Internal Revenue, A. Augustus Healy, in place of Ernst Nathan; for United States District Attorney, Eastern District, James L. Bennett, in place of Jesse Johnson, resigned; for United States Marshal, Eastern District, Henry L. Hayden, in place of Alexander Walker.

"Practically all the consolidation sentiment" of Brooklyn did not seem to exert a very powerful influence in the State Senate yesterday. Senator Reynolds was faithful to it, and announced himself as representing the "consolidation league" of that city, but only McMahon voted with him against the commission's bill, and he was not concerned for the league's pet notion of equal taxation.

Returning home last Monday evening in the height of the storm, Mrs. Mary Welsh of 122 Mott Street saw a scantily-clad young woman hurrying along Mott Street with a baby girl in her arms. It was but fifteen days old, the mother said. She herself looked eighteen years old. She was covered with snow, but she had managed to keep the child dry.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- State Treasurer-elect Swain's bond was refused in the office of Secretary of State Kelsey to-day. It was presented by Speaker Holt, Assemblyman Olcott, and Major Carl F. Lentz of Newark.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27. -- Sensational charges were made by the Connecticut Law and Order League to-night against police abuses in a petition brought by the Rev. Newman Smythe, President of the league, before the Board of Police Commissioners. A summary of the petition follows:

No urn of purple immortelles was required yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer to give to Police Justice Sutherland's trial for oppression of the Gaynor copyists the singularly lugubrious air of a memorial service.

The naval court of inquiry which has been assembled by the Secretary of the Navy to fix the responsibility for the loss of the Kearsarge on Roncador Bank resumed its labors at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday.

Not above half the trap shooters expected took part in the Washington Sweepstakes of twenty-five birds at $25 entry, which was decided yesterday at Heritage's Marion grounds. There was some reason for this, for the weather conditions were anything but favorable to good shooting. During most of the day the glare of the sunshine on the snow was very baffling to many of the men.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 27. -- From a good source at Washington comes the report that the recent visit to that city of Reuben F. Kolb, the "Populite-Kolbite" candidate for Governor of Alabama, resulted in a well-defined scheme agreed upon by Kolb and Republican and Populist leaders to wrench Alabama from the Democratic Party.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Michael J. Dady of Brooklyn, the warm, personal friend of "Boss" McKane, was in this city to-day mapping out a route for himself and five companions, who are trying to save the "boss" from prison. Dady's companions were not known by those with whom he talked, and he did not make any introductions.
Richard V. Harnett Co. sold the following securities to-day at auction at the Real Estate Exchange:

Like the barons of old, who opened their castle gates and dropped their drawbridges for the entrance of knightly cavalcades, the hospitable members of the Metropolitan Club threw open the immense iron gates in front of their spacious courtyard yesterday for the admission of the New-York social world. True, there was no drawbridge, but in every other respect the great clubhouse far outshone the castles of the ancient barons.
DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 27. -- Some of the twenty-two hat factories that have resumed are already running on full time. They report that the business situation improves every day.

More of the election-fraud cases came before Justice Barrett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday. Out of the seventy-four indictments originally found, twothirds of the trials yet remain to be heard.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The Greater NewYork bill, without any of the amendments which threatened to defeat the entire measure, passed the Senate to-day. The proposed new city includes New-York, Kings County, Long Island City, Richmond County, Westchester, Flushing, Newton, Jamaica, and that portion of the towns of East Chester and Pelham.

The objections raised by a few Senators against certain important parts of the Wilson bill's free list have a very flimsy foundation or no foundation whatever. There is not the slightest warrant, for example, for an argument against the removal of the duty on bituminous coal, in behalf of producers of such coal in the interior of the country and west of the Alleghanies.

MONTICELLO, Feb. 27. -- Ex-Sheriff B. W. Winner of Liberty was arraigned before the court to-day charged with securing large sums of money under false pretenses. Mr. Winner has been prominent in Sullivan County politics for forty years, and for a long time has been the recognized "boss" of the county.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The historic corvette Kearsarge, which now lies rocking her hull on Roncador Reef, off the coast of Yucatan, will be raised if the Secretary of the Navy and the House Committee on Naval Affairs shall be able to bring it about.

The issuance of the new postal card by the Post Office Department recalls the short but lively career of the "bargain sizes" in postal cards issued by John Wanamaker when that remarkable person was at the head of the national postal system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- A. Augustus Healy, the nominee for Collector of Internal Revenue, is well known in Brooklyn as a useful and public-spirited citizen. He was born in that city in 1850, and has lived there all his life. He was educated at the Brooklyn High School and at the Polytechnic Institute.

MONTREAL, Feb. 27. -- An unfortunate incident occurred after the performance given by Mme. Patti at the Academy of Music last evening. When the curtain fell at the conclusion the orchestra did not play, as usual, "God Save the Queen."
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

The topic of most interest to real estate men Yesterday was the application by the plumber Timothy Sullivan to set aside the sale of the Hotel de Logerot property for alleged inadequacy of price. Persons in Sullivan's interest visited a number of real estate brokers and obtained from the latter statements that, in their opinion, the property is worth $500,000.

After several weeks of dickering, the New-York Baseball Club finally secured the services of Meekin and Farrell, the pitcher and catcher of the Washington club, and the Giants now are as strong as Boston or any other team in the League. Capt. Ward, Treasurer Talcott, and the other stockholders of the local nine were in a jubilant mood last night.

The coming boxing and wrestling championships of the Amateur Athletic Union, to be held at Madison Square Garden March 19 and 22, are causing quite a stir, not only among the local boxers and wrestlers, but throughout the larger cities where amateur athletic clubs are found. Two rings will be built in the centre of the amphitheatre, one for wrestling and one for boxing.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- A dispatch from Buenos Ayres confirms the report of the explosion of the magazine of the insurgent steamer Venus at Rio de Janeiro. The commander, two other officers, and thirty sailors were killed and fifty were wounded.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 27. -- The lighthouse tender Violet, with President Cleveland and Secretary Gresham on board, passed this city this morning. She went through the canal on her way to North Carolina.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27. -- The market might have been more active had the telegraph service not been interrupted. The two or three brokers' wires running from the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to New-York this morning failed about noon, and for a time there was but one private wire working to New-York.

MORGANTON, N.C., Feb. 27. -- This thriving village, situated at the base of the Blue Ridge on the Western North Carolina Railroad, has a considerable number of negroes as a part of its population. During the war a large number of negroes crossed the mountains, entered the Union lines, and joined the army.

Michael Hayes of 378 Grand Street, Williamsburg, was arrested yesterday by Detectives Holland and Dolan on a charge of homicide. He was committed without ball by Justice Goetting in the Lee Avenue Police Court for further examination.

There was animated bidding at the rooms of the Philatelic Society last evening, when a stock of stamps belonging to R.F. Albrecht Co. was offered. Many stamp dealers and collectors were present, and good prices prevailed.

From The Medical Record, Feb. 24. The cablegrams published by the press of this city announcing the appearance of yellow fever on the men-of-war in the Harbor of Rio de Janeiro to the medical mind indicates a condition far too serious to be passed over in silence.

CITY OF MEXICO, Feb. 27. --Congressman William L. Wilson, who is lying ill with typhoid fever in Guadalajara, is making favorable progress. To-day his temperature was nearly normal, pulse strong, and appetite good. The climate of Guadalajara agrees with him.
The New-York Press Club held its annual dinner in the Hotel Marlborough last night. The affair was thoroughly enjoyable, save for the absence of several speakers whose attendance illness prevented.

The Cunard liner Aurania, which arrived yesterday morning from Liverpool and Queenstown, brought seventeen of the passengers who were on the American liner Paris, which left Southampton for this port Feb. 10 and was compelled to turn back on her third day out on account of an accident to her rudder.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The attempt of the Republicans to make a wholesale investigation of the State departments has resulted in a row of good proportions. The Democratic members of both houses protest that the investigation has not been ordered, and after some sharp words at a committee meeting to-day they withdrew in a body. The Republicans then resolved to go ahead on their own hook and overhaul the seventeen commissions.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Funeral services over the body of Steele Mackaye took place this afternoon in the Scenatorium. The body arrived over the Santa Fe Road at noon and was received at the station by a delegation, including Roland Reed. Prof. Herrmann, Joseph Holland, and James Barton Key.

The Life Insurance Association celebrated its eighth anniversary by a banquet at Delmonico's last evening. Over 120 members were present, including the Presidents and Vice Presidents of most of the prominent life insurance companies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- While the Senate is fixing up the Tariff bill to make it satisfactory to some of the Senators who declare they will not vote for it if they do not get enough protection in it, the House, that made the bill what it was when the Senate began work on it, is watching the performance at the other end of the building with interest.

The delegates from the different schools, who are trying to organize an Interscholastic Athletic Association, met yesterday afternoon at the Berkeley School, in West Forty-fourth Street, and undid all that had been done at the former meetings. Fourteen schools were represented. They were the Harvard, Barnard, Columbia Institute, Drissler, Wilson and Kellogg, Trinity, Collegiate, Condon, Cutler, Columbia Grammar, Halsey, Berkeley, Dwight, and Woodbridge schools.

TRENTON, Feb. 27. -- There was no change in the Senate muddle to-day. Although a large crowd came to the State House to hear Senator Perkins make his speech announcing that he should cease to act with the Democratic Senate, he did not make such a speech. Instead, he announced that he was misunderstood last night, and was not ready to desert his Democratic associates.

BOSTON, Feb. 27. -- The market for local securities was dull, and the tone was mixed. Wisconsin Central 5s sold at 74, 1/4 lower than the opening. The Incomes were 16 3/8. Bell Telephone said down to 163, and advanced to 165 1/2, 1/2 above yesterday's close. West End Street Railway opened at 44 and sold off to 43 3/4.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 27. -- The Santa Fe train bearing ex-President Harrison and party pulled into the station promptly at 12:30 P.M. Awaiting to greet the distinguished visitor was a crowd of more than 1,000 people, composed of well-known Republicans and a generous sprinkling of Democrats.

Interest is increasing daily in the evangelistic revival meetings held at noon in the large hall of the Young Men's Christian Association Building at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue. Conversions are being made every day, and great interest is being manifested by those who attend the meetings.

E. M. Taylor, who is employed in the office of Edward Hill's Son Co., at 25 and 27 Cedar Street, writes a letter to The NewYork Times saying that a swindler, who calls himself James R. Taylor and gives his business address as 25 and 27 Cedar Street, has been operating in this city for three months.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- There was more trading in Diamond Match to-day than any other stock, but without creating violent fluctuations. It opened at 123 1/2, sold down to 123, and closed firm at 123 3/8. For a rather dull market, considerable stock changed hands. The other industrials were steady and comparatively inactive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Unless the Democratic Senators come to an early conclusion of their labors on the Tariff bill they will be unable to prevent the country forming its opinions -- upon imperfect information, perhaps -- and concluding that the proceedings in the Senate marble room are unpleasantly like an auction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce had a hearing this morning on Mr. German's bill to amend the Inter-State Commerce act by prohibiting pooling except under certain prescribed conditions. Mr. Charles Counselman, a large grain shipper of Chicago, made the chief argument against the passage of the bill, and endeavored to show the committee that pooling resulted in lower rates and better terms in all particulars to shippers.
DURANT, Miss., Feb. 27. -- The westbound passenger train on the Yazoo and Mississippi Valley Branch of the Illinois Central Railroad met with a disastrous accident this morning three miles from here.

Fears are felt for the Safety of the steamship Briscoe, which sailed from Queenstown for New-York Jan. 30, and has not since been heard from. The Briscoe, Capt. Soares, left Hamburg Dec. 6 for New-York, and encountered a storm, which necessitated her putting back to Queenstown, where she arrived Jan. 23.

ALBANY, N,Y., Feb. 27. -- The case of Eugene Kelly, appellant, vs. Jay Gould, George J. Gould, Russell Sage, J. Henry Work, Grenville M. Dodge, the Mexican Oriental, Interoceanic and International Railroad Company, the International Railway Improvement Company, the Oriental Construction Company, and the Mexican Southern Railway Company, was decided unanimously by the Court of Appeals today in favor of the defendants.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The Queen's drawing room to-day was marked by perfect sunshine and a large attendance of privileged persons. Her Majesty was in excellent health, and extremely gracious in demeanor. About the usual number of presentations were made.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Mexican Minister and Mme. Romero gave a dinner party to-night to a company of fourteen guests. The guests were Assistant Secretary of State and Mrs. Uhl, Representative and Mrs. Tom L. Johnson, Representative and Mrs. McCreary, Marshal and Mrs. A. A. Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Thurber, Mrs. N.C. Blanchard, Senator and Mrs. Call, and the Costa Rican Minister.

The Excise Board of the City of Brooklyn was a stronghold of the McLaughlin ring. From it much of the revenue and more of the influence was obtained by which the ring secured and kept its power in public affairs. Every saloon keeper was made to contribute to the purse or the plans of the ring as the price of its favors, even its legitimate favors.

"Anything to keep John Y. McKane out of Sing Sing Prison," is now the cry of his counsel and friends. The Gravesend "boss" is making the most desperate fight of his life to stave off the day when he must put on a convict's striped suit.

James J. Elder of Whatcom, Washington, deeded $300,000 worth of land in the State of Washington to the Government. His relatives plotted to get it back, worked ingeniously on the old man's cupidity, got him involved in a plot to steal the deeds from the Land Office, had the deeds stolen, and were almost ready to substitute lithographic forgeries when their plan miscarried and their agent was arrested in this city.

Yesterday was a red-letter day in the history of the New-York Genealogical and Biographical Society, and delegates from historical societies in all parts of the country gathered in the society's rooms, in West Forty-fourth Street, to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of its foundation.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- The Court of Error and Appeals, by a vote of 7 to 5, has upheld the conviction of Lucy Gardner of East Orange for larceny of small articles from Stern Brothers of New-York.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The Edinburgh Evening News says unqualifiedly this evening that Mr. Gladstone has resigned, and that his resignation will so into effect at Easter. The paper says that the Premiership was offered to Lord Rosebery, but he declined it. The position was then offered to Earl Spencer, and he accepted it.

The appointments of Messrs. Healy, Haydn, and Bennett of Brooklyn to Federal offices were freely discussed in Brooklyn last night. They were received with expressions of commendation by nearly every one except the "hide-bound politicians of the Willoughby Street machine." The selection of Mr. Healy was especially acceptable to the independent Democrats of Kings County.

John H. Townsend, paymaster of the Passaic Rolling Mills of Paterson, N.J., came to this city Saturday to pay off the workmen employed on the bridges being constructed over the Harlem River at One Hundred and Thirtieth Street and at the Bronx River. He brought with him $1,125, which he carried in a small satchel.

Almost from the time the Inter-State Commerce Commission began to decide questions brought before it under the law of 1887, by which it was created, and to issue orders to be complied with by railroad companies in accordance with the provisions of that law, the courts of the United States have been whittling away the powers which it was intended to exercise and making the law ineffective for the purposes for which it was enacted.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The name of Superintendent Pierce of the State Insurance Department was sent to the Senate this morning by Gov. Flower, and the renomination was immediately confirmed, which action gives Mr. Pierce a second term.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- A secret meeting of representatives of a dozen commercial Exchanges in the principal cities of the country was held to-day in the Directors' room of the Chicago Board of Trade. The object was formally and emphatically to protest against the passage of any anti-option measure introduced in Congress.
ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The Governor sent to the Senate to-day the following nominations, which were referred:
The Woman Suffrage Convention had its own again yesterday, and opened Its closing sessions in Chickering Hall, where the twostarred banners and four-starred flags waved bravely.

Owing to the vacancy on the Board of Governors of the Amateur Athletic Union, caused by the retirement of F.K. Stearns, Central Association, it will be necessary to appoint a Governor in his stead, and Secretary Sullivan has requested the Central Association to forward the names of its three delegates, so that the vacancy can be filled.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 23. -- The United States revenue steamer Grant arrived at the port of Montevideo, Uruguay, Jan. 18. The Grant came direct from Bahia, Brazil, making the run from Bahia in seven days. The cutter at present is riding out an eight days' quarantine off Ratones Island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- There were two melancholy speeches in the House to-day in the course of the discussion of the Bland bill. The first was an apology from Populist Pence of Colorado for some of the rowdy utterances in which he indulged yesterday. For one thing, Pence said he had been misunderstood in his reference to Mr. Hainer.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 27. -- J. M. Weaver, a notorious criminal, who was for a number of years looked upon as a Republican leader in North Arkansas, put on a suit of striped clothing at the State penitentiary this morning and went to work within the prison walls splitting wood. Not being accustomed to manual labor, his hands were tender, but no favor was shown him.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- Thomas J. Dowling. Commissioner of the Bureau of Statistics of Labor, in his annual report submitted to the Legislature, makes special reference to the effects of the recent and present hard times on manufacturers and their working force.

Another practical step has been taken in the move to protect the news service of the United Press and to continue the distribution of the news to all clients and customers. Four of the original members of the old Associated Press have signed an agreement to this effect among themselves, and the last legal paper for its enforcement was executed yesterday.

TRENTON, Feb. 27. -- The election methods used in the famous Third District of Camden County, where William J. Thompson has his race track, are to be inquired into by the Committee on Elections of the House Assembly of New-Jersey. A resolution to that effect was introduced this afternoon.
It was as foul under foot as it was fair overhead yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- There was a good general trade in wheat to-day, but no individual operations that could be called sensation or important could be noted. The Hatch Anti-Option bill had, to all appearances, faded from view, and those who sold yesterday on that factor were glad to get their wheat back to-day at an advance over the selling price.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 27. -- The recent appointment of the Rev. A. Dynio as priest of St. Joseph's Polish Catholic Church, this city, has caused trouble that will require the efforts of Bishop O'Farrell to settle.
John B. Sexton will be Sheriff of the County of New-York until Jan. 1 of next year.

The police of the Fifth Street Station raided two alleged cafes, the cafes at 260 and 276 East Houston Street, yesterday afternoon on warrants charging the proprietors with keeping gambling dens. The former place is known as the "Cafe Lloyd," and is conducted by Adolph Heller Co. Julius Hirsch is the proprietor of the other house, which is called the "Cafe Metropole." Both places are patronized extensively and almost exclusively by Hungarians.
ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- "If this bill does not pass, I will insist upon an investigation of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge that will put more people in Sing Sing than John Y. McKane."

The woman who says she is Mrs. Caroline Miller, and who, according to Lawyer Frank Moss, has been known at various times as Mrs. Brink and Mrs. Rodman, was before Referee A.D. Andrews, at 111 Broadway, yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Miller lives at 6 West Eighty-second Street. Mr. Moss represents the holder of a second mortgage on that house.

TRENTON, Feb. 28. -- The taking of depositions to support the motion for a rule to show cause in the action begun by the Attorney General against Senators Rogers and Adrain was continued this morning in the Senate Chamber. There was a large number of interested spectators in attendance.

The five torpedo boats ordered from Germany at about the same time that the Brazilian Government was constructing its impromptu fleet in this country to send against the insurgents under Admirals da Gama and Mello are now at Bahia, Brazil, ready to assist President Peixoto in bringing the insurrectionists to terms.

Bicyclists are looking forward to a very successful season, and already they are making active preparations. The recent action taken at the national assembly of the league, it is thought, is going to boom things wonderfully.

James Wilson McDill of the Inter-State Commerce Commission died in Creston, Iowa, yesterday morning. He was born in Monroe, Butler County, Ohio, March 4, 1834. He was a law student in the Miami University at the time ex-President Harrison attended that Institution. He served in the Forty-third and Forty-fourth Congrresses. He declined a re-election, and was appointed a State Railroad Commissioner by Gov. Gear.

No steps were taken to relieve the disturbed east-bound rate situation at yesterday's meeting of the Presidents and General Managers of the railroads in Trunk Line territory. Questions pertaining to the maintenance of both passenger and freight rates from Western points to the Atlantic seaboard were discussed, and a general desire was expressed that rates should be restored to a normal basis and kept there.

Thus far in the election-fraud cases in this city four Inspectors of Election have been convicted of criminal violations of the law they were sworn to execute faithfully, four other persons have been convicted of fraudulent registration or voting, and five have pleaded guilty to the charges against them.

VALPARAISO, Chile, Feb. 28. -- The United States revenue cutter Grant. Capt. Tozier, arrived here this morning from Montevideo, having steamed through the Straits of Magellan and Smyth's Channel, reaching the Pacific by way of the Gulf of Penas. The cutter stopped long enough at Sandy Point, Straits of Magellan, to take on coal and a fresh supply of water.

TRENTON, Feb. 28. -- The proposed investigation of W.J. Thompson, the "Duke of Gloucester," is the all-absorbing topic around the State House. The "Duke" himself discusses the subject. He has the appearance of a man much worried, although he declares that the investigation will be a boomerang.
Mayor Gilroy declared himself as heartily in favor of the Greater New-York bill as it passed the State Senate, and expressed satisfaction that it had become a law.

The trial of Police Justice Kenneth F. Sutherland for oppression of the Gaynor copyists was concluded yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer, and the jury had not agreed on a verdict when Justice Cullen ordered it locked up for the night.

That Levi P. Morton, ex-Vice President of the United States, is willing to become the candidate of the Republican Party for Governor of this State is no longer a matter of doubt among certain politicians.

An earnest and well-organized opposition to the Erie reorganization plan is developing. Formal notice was served a day or two ago upon the Directors of the Erie Railway Company that a large proportion of the holders of the second consolidated mortgage bonds proposed to take immediate steps to protect their interests against what they regard as extremely unjust provisions in the reorganization plan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Mr. Bland came near to-day to closing the fight on the Seigniorage bill and winning it, but the House adjourned before he could complete a temporary victory. Several Democrats, including Clancy and Magner of New-York, abandoned their resistance to the bill and voted to make a quorum and so help it along.

The firm of O.M. Clapp Co. of 377 Broadway, one of the oldest dry goods jobbing houses in the city, is reported to be in financial difficulties. Yesterday the firm submitted a proposition to its creditors for a compromise. The terms are said to be 60 cents on the dollar, payable in the firm's notes, unsecured, in two, three, and four months.

The most successful and the most enjoyable gymnasium exhibit ever held in the Eighty-sixth Street Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association took place Tuesday night. It was the fifth entertainment of the kind held this year, and the last that will be given. None but the verybest athletes took part, and all the work was of an advanced order.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28. -- Although still a very narrow market, there was more general activity and a decided improvement in tone to-day. The traders bid up Reading and St. Paul and kept the prices on a parity with New-York all day. There seemed to be very few stocks for sale. The Reading general mortgage 5s were quite active.

The fascinating history of witchcraft, the unquestioning belief in its reality which generally prevailed until the end of the seventeenth century, and the atrocities committed to punish the so-called crime engrossed the attention of the Colonial Dames of the State of New-York yesterday afternoon at Hardman Hall, Fifth Avenue and Nineteenth Street.

E.M. Taylor, who is employed by the firm of Edward Hill's Son Co., importers of chemicals and varnish gums at 25 and 27 Cedar Street, this city, has been, as told in The New-York Times of yesterday, much annoyed for the past four months by the operations of a swindler, who masquerades under the name of James R. Taylor.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Feb. 28 -- P.M. Conditions which have prevailed for some time again governed to-day's market. There was the usual grist of alleged information from Washington as to the treatment sugar is to receive under the new tariff, but it was of the same contradictory nature as all that has come from that centre for weeks past.

The Knickerbocker Bowling Club met yesterday afternoon at 212 West Forty-first Street, and so many of the club members and their friends were present that seventeen alleys were kept in use. The contest for the Knickerbocker Cup was resumed, and some big scores were rolled up. Mr. Theodore P. Cooper made 233.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 28. -- Attorney Flanders, Gov. Peck's counsel in the "roster" suit, this morning continued his presentation of the Governor's case to the jury. He said that, so far as Gov. Peck was concerned, he would contend that the law under which the "roster" contract was let was void.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 28. -- Major Wetmore of New-York and Denver has returned to civilization from the wilds of Northern Canada, between Hudson's Bay and Labrador. He went in search of adventure, and, believing that the country was terra Incognita and belonged to no one, attempted territorial conquest.

It is not necessary to take too seriously the report of the two German professors who have "denounced" the manner in which the inspection of meats is conducted in this country; not even though the report was based on "personal studies made in Chicago." It is to be remarked that the report was submitted to a meeting of the Farmers' League, and that is quite sufficient to explain its conclusions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Senator Frye, (Rep., Me.,) in the Senate to-day, began another speech on the Hawaiian question, and will conclude to-morrow. He opened his speech with this sentence:

Henry B. Bachrach, who is suing his wife for a separation, made an application to Justice Freedman in the Superior Court yesterday for the custody of his twelvemonths-old son, Henry B. Mr. Bachrach says that he has called repeatedly at his father-in-law's house, 636 Columbus Avenue, with the intention of seeing his child, but on each occasion the mother has refused him admission to the house.

At the meeting of the Executive Committee of the Business Men's Relief Committee of the Industrial Christian Alliance yesterday afternoon in the office of Vermilye Co., 18 Nassau Street, it was stated that the condition of the unemployed poor is becoming more distressing.
Entries for the steeplechase and hurdle races for the June meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club will close to-day. The events are as follows:

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- To-day's debate in the Reichstag on the German-Russian treaty was very exciting. Dr. von Bennigsen, the leader of the National Liberals, having made a speech yesterday in which he decried the Richter Radicals, Herr Eugen Richter rose to reply to him to-day. He began with a violent assault on Dr. von Bennigsen, and his remarks to the end bristled with personalities.

From The Wall Street Journal. The London Financial Times of Jan. 2 contained a two-column interview with Receiver Paxson of Reading, an abstract of which was published by us. In the course of cross-examination in the Rice suit at Philadelphia, Receiver Paxson contradicted a number of statements therein, and said that the interview was inaccurate, and that he was not responsible for very much of it.

Funeral services over the body of Sheriff Charles M. Clancy were held yesterday morning in old St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Mott Street. The old church was filled with people, and a crowd stood in the, spacious yard outside and on the sidewalk.

Mrs. Josephine Laumar, a comely German woman, has had a peculiarly sad lot of late. About a month ago she lost her husband, and yesterday, when about to sail for her home in Berlin, her infant child died, in her arms at the ship's pier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- That conferences do not always result satisfactorily to those who bring them about is a fact which certain protection Democrats realize fully to-night. The caucus which was called last week by Senator Gorman was the outcome of the efforts of the "conservatives" on the Democratic side of the Senate chamber to force the sub-committee of the Finance Committee to make concessions which had been denied them on their individual applications.

ST. JOHN'S. N.F., Feb. 28. -- Dispatches from the Imperial Government relating to the Newfoundland French shore question have been presented to the Legislature. Lord Ripon, Secretary of the Colonies, insists that the Legislature should be bound by the promise of the Newfoundland delegates to pass a permanent act for the enforcement of the treaties.

The series of conferences which the Democratic Senators are holding in regard to the Wilson Tariff bill must be regarded as a rational way of dealing with a difficult subject. They are not caucuses in the strict sense of that term. That is to say that members of the party attending them are not bound to accept all propositions that may receive a majority vote.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Feb. 28. -- Oliver Longtin, the French carpenter who, it is alleged, is heir to half the Desue estate of many millions of New-York City property, said to-day that he knew little about the matter beyond the fact that his brother had been working on the case for thirty years. He did not even know in what part of NewYork City the property was situated.

ROME, Feb. 28. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, Signor Crispi, the Prime Minister, explained the Government's reasons for proclaiming a state of siege in Sicily. Documents which came into possession of the authorities at Massa di Carrara, proved the existence of Socialist and Anarchist plans to reorganize and repeat their uprising on a scale approaching the proportions of a revolution.

The election trials were resumed yesterday before Justice Barrett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. The first case was that of Michael S. Fay, a Republican Inspector in the Nineteenth Election District of the Second Assembly District.

ASHLAND, Penn., Feb. 28. -- While seven miners were at work this afternoon in the west gangway of the Boston Run Mine an avalanche of coal swept down on them and imprisoned them in the dark passageway where they were laboring.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The Russian bark Primus, Capt. Laine, from Darien Jan. 17, which arrived at Greenock Feb. 27, reports that on Feb. 16, in latitude 46 north, longitude 30 west, she boarded the Norwegian bark Nordkap, Capt. Gabrielsen, which sailed from Savannah Jan. 18 for Riga. There was no one on board the Nordkap, which appeared to have been recently abandoned.
SHEFFIELD, Feb. 28. -- Mme. Patey, while singing at a concert here last evening, fainted and was carried from the stage. She did not regain consciousness, and died this morning.

The proud spirit of John Y. McKane has at last been broken. For the first time in his life he recognizes the fact that the law is superior to the man. To-day, unless something unforseen happens, he will become one of the convicts in Sing Sing Prison.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The report of the Civil Service Commission, which will be laid before the Senate to-morrow, in response to a resolution calling for a return on all investigations made since March 4, 1889, regarding removals from office, will be an interesting document. The most prominent offense spoken of is that concerning the dismissal from the Treasury Department of Eugene E. Gaddis.
LANCASTER, Penn., Feb. 28. -- This city was startled shortly before midnight by the explosion of a dynamite bomb in the heart of the city, wrecking a prominent residence and imperilling many lives.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 28. -- John C. Austin, fifty years old, a publisher, of 1313 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, and George Allen, forty-nine years old, an agent, of 332 Ninth Street, Jersey City, were arrested last night and locked up. They were walking the streets in a dazed condition and unable to give an account of themselves.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The Central News bulletins the statement that Mr. Gladstone drove from Downing Street to Buckingham Palace at 3 o'clock and had an audience of an hour's duration with the Queen. He did not tender his resignation.

The evangelistic revival meeting in Association Hall yesterday was one of the most largely attended of any of the series. The lower portion of the hall was crowded with an appreciative and sympathetic audience, many persons having come long distances to attend the services. As the meetings progress they grow in interest and new faces are seen in the audience each day.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- The hands of Thomas C. Platt, of William F. Sheehan, and of other "bosses" have been discovered in an amendment which has been tacked on to Senator O'Connor's (Rep., Broome,) Bi-Partisan Election Inspectors bill. The bill came into the Senate this morning, and because of the protests from the anti-Sheehan men in Buffalo it was simply laid on the table until Senator O'Connor returns.

Patrick Barnes, known to his associates of the Battle Row Gang and to the police as "Blinkey," is under guard in the accident ward at the Presbyterian Hospital with a bullet wound in his shoulder. He received the wound while fleeing from pursuing policemen after he had, with two associates, committed a burglary at a cigar factory in Avenue A, near Seventy-fifth Street.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28. -- For several weeks the officers and Directors of the St. Louis National Bank have been aware that there was a discrepancy in the balances of their cashier, Mr. William E. Burr, Jr. Being absolutely secure from loss they quietly proceeded to investigate, and found that the shortage was, in round numbers, $57,000.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Feb. 28. -- News is received here to-night that three striking miners were killed and seven wounded at the Eagle Mines, near Montgomery, as the result of an attempt of the strikers to compel the miners at the Eagle to stop work.

Senator Bradley's bill for the abolition of the present Board of Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge and his speech before the Senate Committee on Cities in support of it, in the course of which he characterized the Trustees as incompetent men who had neglected their duty and had permitted criminal extravagance, created great interest in Brooklyn yesterday.

To the landsman there was a disheartening array of technicalities in the evidence brought forth in the Kearsarge court of inquiry yesterday. There were long stretches of sumner lines, mazes of azimuths, and of positions determined by stars, tales of hack chronometers and standard compasses, of patent logs, and of charts, and no end of latitudes and longitudes.

The New-York Vegetarian Society had its second annual dinner last night at the St. Denis Hotel. The society was organized two years ago and numbers about 100 members. There were present last night, including guests, 150 persons, about one-half of whom were strist vegetarians who never eat meat.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 28. -- The creditors of ex-President Thomas J. Swift of the Natonal Switch and Signal Company of Easton, Penn., who left his home in Poughkeepsie several months ago, leaving claims amounting to $100,000, have failed to get any money out of Mr. Swift's interest in his father's estate.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 28. -- All preparations for the Presidential election to-morrow are complete. To American eyes the campaign has appeared peculiarly quiet and devoid of popular interest. The nominations have been made known mainly by advertisements in the newspapers.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- Gov. Flower has signed the bill relating to the duties of the Attorney General in managing and conducting criminal actions and proceedings, and filed the following memorandum therewith:

There was an animated scene in the salon of the Hotel Brunswick yesterday afternoon. The odor of flowers, the soft, continuous murmur of voices, and the billowy rustle of gowns proclaimed that it was a meeting of women only.

GREENPORT, L.I., Feb. 28. -- The lighthouse on Gardiner's Island was destroyed during the storm Monday and Frank Miller, son of Keeper Jonathan Miller, was crushed to death. There is no telegraphic communication with the island, and news of the accident was brought here by a passing vessel this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I wish to express my thanks for the excellent reports your paper has given of the "Congress of Women for Improved Dress" which I conducted last week at the Madison Square Garden in the interest of the National League Fair.

A fortnight ago, in his initiation speech at the Academic Francaise as successor to the chair formerly occupied by John Lemoinne, Ferdinand Brunetiere praised his predecessor, who was an editor, for qualities which are not now essentially journalistic, and adversely criticised contemporary journalism.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- The police investigation in New-York City and the difficulties between the Milholland men and the Committee of Thirty have been pretty thoroughly discussed here to-night. It has been informally determined that John W. Goff will act as counsel for the police committee, and that he will be allowed to carry the investigation as far as he thinks best.

The most important of yesterday's sales of Brooklyn realty is given above amongthe transactions in the Real Estate Exchange in this city. In the Brooklyn Exchange room, Mr. Jacob Cole sold to Edward F. Patchen, plaintiff, for $11,490, the three-story brick dwelling 199 Clinton Street, northeast corner of Pacific Street, 22.6 by 85.

BOSTON, Feb. 28. -- The hearing on the petition of the Society for Collegiate Instruction for Women (Harvard Annex) for a change of name to Radcliffe College attracted a large number to the State House this forenoon. It is not intended to make Radcliffe College an institution entirely separate from Harvard College, but to adopt a plan under which the degrees of the annex will be countersigned by the university officials.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 28. -- The past three months form one of the most disastrous periods in the history of the Gloucester fisheries. The number of vessels reported lost is eighteen, with a total tonnage of 1,410, valued at more than $100,000, and on which there was insurance of $96,134.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 28. -- Pitcher McNabb of the Baltimore club killed himself here this evening, after having shot Louise Kellogg, formerly a member of the Alvin Joslyn theatrical company, inflicting wounds from which she probably will die.

BOSTON, Feb. 28. -- There was a little activity shown in some local specialties today, but the market was heavy except for one or two of the investment favorites. Wisconsin Central first 5s sold down to 72 3/4 and the incomes to 16. Bell Telephone sold down to 164, and closed at 165. Gossip on the stock is still bearish. West End Street Railway sold down to 43 3/4, and closed at 44.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -- The Figaro newspaper recently alleged that Capt. Comte de Beauchamp, military attache of the French Legation in Copenhagen, treated with the Czar during his visit last Fall in the Danish capital. The negotiations were said to have been conducted through the Princess Waldemar, and to have concerned the Russo-French alliance.

The Grant Monument Association held its annual meeting yesterday at the Mills Building, and elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President -- Gen. Horace Porter; Vice Presidents -- Elihu Root and Grenville M. Dodge; Treasurer -- Frederick D. Tappen; Secretary -- James C. Reed.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- John Y. McKane's lawyers, George Roderick and Milton C. Gray, came here last night for the purpose of asking Justice Hardin of the Supreme Court to grant a preliminary stay to McKane. They were accompanied by Michael Dady and D.B. Rellly, two of the most intimate friends of McKane.

Mrs. Mary E. Lease of Kansas made her first attempt last evening to captivate a New-York audience. She succeeded. The audience was not too critical, and it was very ready to be captivated. It was assembled in the large hall of the Cooper Union. Admission was 25 and 50 cents, and the proceeds were for the benefit of the unemployed. The hall was three-quarters filled.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 1. -- The Governor General this afternoon, on the recommendation of his Ministers, approved the order of the Minister of Justice releasing McGreevy and Connolly, who were imprisoned for defrauding the Government on public contracts. They have been in prison thirteen weeks.

Two officers of the wrecked corvette Kearsarge were flatly contradicted by a third in the inquiry at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday into the stranding of the vessel on Roncador Reef. Up to that point the hearing had been distinguished by the total absence of conflicting testimony.

ALBANY, March 1 -- After a bitter fight of an hour's length, Speaker Malby to-day followed the example of ex-Speaker Thomas B. Reed and transacted business with a "visible" quorum. He directed the Clerk to record as present and not voting enough Democrats who had remained silent during roll call to make the constitutional quorum.

John Y. McKane, once the mighty chieftain of Gravesend, but now shorn of his power, as well as of his hair and luxuriant mustache and goatee, and attired in the striped garb of a convict, is in Sing Sing Prison.

ALBANY, March 1. -- William Brookfield, the Chairman of the Republican State Committee and one of the Committee of Thirty in New-York City, has been busy here today attempting to line up the Republicans from all over the State against the PlattMilholland forces below Harlem Bridge.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1. -- Wooten, the charming country seat of the late George W. Childs, near Bryn Mawr, has passed into the ownership of George W. Childs Drexel, the namesake of Mr. Childs, and present publisher of The Public Ledger. The estate has been, purchased from Mrs. Childs, the price paid for it not being announced.

The first all-day meeting of the evangelistic revival services in Association Hall was held yesterday and was a great success. It began at 10 A. M. and lasted until 4 P. M., during which time fully 2,000 people were in the hall. Many business men came in at noon and remained an hour. The audience was constantly changing throughout the day, yet no sooner was a seat vacated than it was filled.

In continuing the election trials before Justice Barrett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, Assistant District Attorney Wellman first called Edward O'Donnell, who is charged with making a false canvass of the ballots in the Nineteenth Election District of the Second AssemblyDistrict. O'Donnell did not answer to his name, and Mr. Wellman smiled very significantly.

TARRYTOWN, March 1 -- The through express train from Chicago for New-York on the New-York Central Railroad was wrecked north of here at 5:30 o'clock this morning. The train, which consisted entirely of express cars, was drawn by two engines.

Ex-Coroner Michael J.B. Messemer, who had been for several years a prominent figure in the politics of this city, died Feb. 22, at a hamlet near Mentone, Italy. The news of his death did not reach his brother, Dr. Edward J. Messemer, in this city, until yesterday, owing to the fact that there is no telegraphic communication with the hamlet where the ex-Coroner died.

A modified plan of reorganization of the Richmond and West Point Terminal Railway and Warehouse Company and its subordinate companies was issued yesterday, in pamphlet form, by C. H. Coster, George Sherman, and Anthony J. Thomas, the Reorganization Committee. Several important departures from the original plan have been made.
Mr. Nathan Kaplan has sold to Dr. George C. Jeffrey the three-story frame flat 80 Truxton Street, Brooklyn, 17 by 45 by 100.

William Ewart Gladstone was born in Liverpool, the fourth son of the late Sir John Gladstone, Bart., a well-known Liverpool merchant. He was educated at Eton and Christ Church, Oxford. He was graduated from Oxford with honors in 1831. After an extended Continental tour, he returned to England, and almost immediately entered Parliament in the Conservative interest for Newark.

LONDON, March 1. -- The Pall Mall Gazette, in its "extra, special" edition, says: "Mr. Gladstone will have an audience with the Queen on Saturday, and will then place his resignation in her hands. The public announcement will be made early Monday. Lord Rosebery, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, will succeed to the Premiership.

Chauncey M. Depew expressed the belief yesterday that the meeting of the railroad Presidents and managers in this city on Wednesday would have a good effect on the railroad situation. The coming together at the representatives of so many different roads would naturally produce a better feeling, and Mr. Depew believed that the zealous freight officers of the Western roads would be restrained from cutting rates further.

Weeping Sheriff Buttling's dilatory tactics went for naught yesterday, as the forlorn hope led by Charles W. Brooke and his son, Charles Lex Brooke, was repulsed by Justice George C. Barrett of the Supreme Court.

John Burke, whose specialty is "flimflamming," was arraigned yesterday before Justice Taintor in the Tombs Police Court at the instance of John D. Purcell, cashier of Orcutt's restaurant, 200 Broadway, on a charge of larceny.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- All sorts of disquieting rumors, proceeding from one of the usual fountains of sensational stories, concerning the condition of Congressman William L. Wilson, circulated to-day, were set at rest this afternoon through a telegram received at the State Department at 3:10 o'clock from Mr. Crittenden, the United States Consul General in the City of Mexico, as follows:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 1 -- The West Point Mining and Manufacturing Company, near Florence, has doubled its force and will run night and day to fill orders for cotton textiles. This is one of the largest cotton factories in this section.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 1 -- The inquiry into the attempt to fix the jury in the trial of ex-State Inspector W.Z. McDonald, made by the court to-day, seems to involve members of the local lodge of Elks.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., March 1 -- Frank G. Tower holds the appointment of Postmaster of Bloomfield -- has held the appointment since January -- and yet he is not Postmaster, and perhaps never will be Postmaster. He decdares his intention of taking possession of the office. Edward T. Hayes, who has been the Postmaster four years, says that Tower will not get possession.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Having been defeated in the courts in the several actions taken against him by Judge Long of Michigan in the now celebrated re-rating case, the Commissioner of Pensions, under authority conferred by a recent act of Congress, this afternoon addressed the following letter to Judge Long:

Before dawn yesterday a heavy blanket of fog settled over New-York, and for a number of hours it made traveling about town extremely uncomfortable and somewhat dangerous. At 4 in the morning the fog was so thick that objects fifty feet away were not discernible. An hour later the atmosphere had taken on an inky blackness.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 1. -- The polls for the national election opened at 9 o'clock this morning and closed at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The voting was very light.

Mayor Gilroy is of the opinion that contributions to the Citizens' Relief Fund are not being received as rapidly or In as large a volume as the situation calls for. When a reporter for The New-York Times called upon him at his office yesterday and asked him how the work of relieving the unemployed poor of the city was progressing, he said:

Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews and the sun made merry work yesterday of the snow. It was nip and tuck between them for a while, but the orb of day got the better of the Commissioner In the end. Few restrictions were encountered in its labors, while Mr. Andrews had several things to bother him.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, March 1 -- P.M. The movement toward better prices than have lately prevailed became infectious today and extended to the entire list of active stocks. Rarely does a table of dealings show such uniformity of plus signs as the one to-day's market provided for the perusal of investors.

There is great trepidation among the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge. They are apprehensive that Senator Bradley's bill to legislate them out of office will become a law. The measure has been favorably reported in the Senate, and Senator Bradley is confident it will pass.

NEWARK, N.J., March 1. -- John Carberry died at 3 o'clock this afternoon, at his home, 22 Webster Street, after hiccoughing for thirteen weeks and one day. The unfortunate man's father, mother, and sisters were at his bedside when the end came.

It is, of course, desirable that the million dollars made available for immediate expenditure by the Park Department should be spent as soon as possible, if it can be spent in useful ways. But it is not desirable that it should be spent uselessly, and it is eminently undesirable that it should be spent so as to injure the parks.

Reading affairs occupied the attention of Special Master Crawford in Philadelphia all day yesterday. At 10 o'clock there was a further hearing on the petition of the receivers for leave to nave constructed certain floating equipment. This came about through a certain builder on the Jersey coast complaining that he had not been asked to bid for the work.

Mr. Irving had not acted Charles Stuart in the late W.G. Wills's beautiful tragic play during his present visit, and in his previous engagements in New-York "Charles I." was infrequently performed. Irving's portrayal of the idealized martyr is as little known here, indeed, as his fine Hamlet.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 1 -- This afternoon the jury in the case against James J. Corbett, charged with violating the laws of Florida by engaging in a prize fight, returned a verdict of not guilty.

The steamer Caribbee arrived yesterday from the Leeward and Windward Islands. Among her passengers were Mr. Oliver Smith and wife. Mr. Smith is the British Attorney General of the Leeward Islands, and comes from Antigua. He says that on the night of Feb. 17 the island was shaken by violent earthquakes, accompanied by unusually loud rumblings.

LONDON, March 1 -- The following statement of the committee of the Irish party in Parliament was given out late last night. The purpose of the statement is to define the attitude of the party on the main Irish Question -- home rule -- in the event of Mr. Gladstone's withdrawal from office:

MONTPELIER, Vt., March 1 -- The State Supreme Court met at the State House to-day and rendered a decision in the case of the State vs. John O'Neil of Rutiand. The court denied O'Neil's petition for an arrest of judgment, and sentenced him to a fine of $6,160 and two months in the House of Correction.

Mrs. Caroline M. Miller, who is charged by Lawyer Frank Moss with being the tool of H.B. Sire in an attempt to thwart the foreclosure of a second mortgage on the house 16 West Eighty-second Street, was in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday morning, when counsel made argument to have her punished for contempt of court for refusing to answer questions put to her by the referee in the foreclosure proceedings.

Harvard is to have a Latin play this year. No particulars about the projected performance have yet been published. The subjoined statement is taken from advance sheets of The Harvard Graduates' Magazine:

The famous Cross will case, which involved the question of title to about $1,000,000 worth of bonds, and which was carried to the Court of Appeals, was recalled in a motion made yesterday before Justice Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers. The question at issue is the payment of the fee of Nicholas Quackenbos, a lawyer, who represented Grace Minton, now Mrs. George Morand, one of the contestants of the will.
BERLIN, March 1 -- The debate in the Reichstag on the German-Russian treaty was closed to-day, and the treaty was referred to a committee.

More than 200 members of the St. David's Society and their friends had their annual dinner last evening at the St. Denis Hotel. The St. David's Society is the Welsh benevolent organization in this city. A flag, with the Welsh red griffin, was displayed on the wall of the dining hall.

CALCUTTA, March 1 -- James Westland announced in the Vice Regal Council to-day that the Government proposed to meet the deficit by imposing a new 5 per cent. tax on imports, besides doubling the tax on petroleum. Cottons will be excepted from the operation of the new tax.

The fourth of a series of conferences of those interested in good municipal government was held last evening in the Amity Building, 312 West Fifty-fourth Street. Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt presided. About 250 persons were present. The subject for discussion was "New-York's Dependents -- the Children, the Sick, and the Aged."

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The official comparative statement of the receipts and expenditures of the Government for the first eight months of the present fiscal year was Issued from the Treasury Department this afternoon. It shows the total receipts have been $198,274,587; expenditures, $247.411,852, or an excess of expenditures over receipts of $49,137,268.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Mr. Bland has had his way, and if the Senate should approve what was to-day done in the House there will be added to the stock of silver dollars with which the Government vaults are cumbered, "as soon as possible," the enormous sum in silver of $287,071,580, and the issue of an equal amount, eventually, of what the Attorney General has declared is not "lawful money."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Some of the enthusiastic advocates of the destruction of the Wilson bill, who were last night laboring under the Impression that the bill had been killed by Gorman, Hill, and Company, have had abundant opportunity to-day to correct their impression. The events of the day, and the course of the Finance Committee, following the caucus,

The will of Norman L. Munro was filed yesterday In the office of the Surrogate. It was executed Feb. 24, the day that Mr. Munro died, and was witnessed by Drs. Theodore Dunham of the Reform Club, 233 Fifth Avenue; Daniel P. Pease of the Hoffman House, and Wayman C, Cushman of 11 West Fiftieth Street, all of whom were in attendance upon Mr. Munro.

There is a large stock of Washington rumors regarding the tariff in the market -- not in the stock market only, but in the political market. We are told exactly what has been determined on as to coal, as to iron ore, as to sugar. As a matter of fact, nothing has been determined on. The conferences of Democratic Senators have come to an end without reaching any decision.

LONDON. March 1. -- It became finally known this afternoon that Mr. Gladstone had made up his mind to give up the Premiership and intended to resign Saturday. Up to that time the Radicals had been believing that the private representations they had made would deter Mr. Gladstone from taking any definite step.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 1 -- The Coroner's jury investigating the Cornell banquet tragedy summoned to-day F.L. Taylor, roommate of C.L. Dingens, whos suspicious disappearance after the event has not been satisfactorily explained. When he was asked if Dingens was his roommate, every one was astonished to hear him reply:

The trial of Police Justice Kenneth F. Sutherland of Gravesend, in the Brooklyn Court of Over and Terminer, for oppression of the Gaynor copyists on the Saturday night before election resulted yesterday in a disagreement of the jury.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Had It not been for the firm stand taken by Chairman Denniston of the Assembly Excise Committee, the so-called "side-door" bill would have been favorably acted upon by the committee this afternoon.

The marriage of Charles H. Hoyt, playwright and manager, to Miss Caroline Scales, known to the stage as Caroline Miskel, was celebrated at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, at the residence of Mrs. Scales, the bride's mother, 69 West Eighty-eighth Street. A few intimate friends of the parties were present.

When the special committee of the Chamber of Commerce, which was appointed to inquire into the rapid-transit question, made its report at a special meeting two weeks ago, it declared that for reasons which "need not be stated" it could not "advocate the building of any system of rapid transit by the City of New-York."

BOSTON, March 1 -- A decision was received to-day from the Supreme Court giving negative answers to three questions propounded to the court by the Legislature relative to submitting to the people the question of granting municipal suffrage to women. The questions were:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 1. -- Mrs. Lulu Baker, wife of Moore Baker, a prosperous young farmer in Franklin Park, was, with their baby girl, brutally murdered about 1 o'clock this morning by Willard Thompson, a negro, who, with Henry Baker, also a negro, had entered the house to rob it.

Mrs. Hannah Linden believes that the will of her half brother. Kaufman Hirsch, which was filed for probate last week, in which she is cut off without a penny, was made under the undue influence exerted on Mr. Hirsch, by his sister-in-law, Mrs. Fanny Hirsch, with whom he lived for some years before his death.

The monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, which was held yesterday afternoon at 32 Nassau Street, was well attended, owing to the fact that the report of the Special Committee on Rapid Transit, laid over two weeks ago, and reports from the Special Committees on the Income Tax bill and Mr. Bland's Seigniorage bill, were to come up for discussion.

An effort is being made to revive the Manhattan Athletic Club, and it begins to look as though it would be successful. Some of the old members of the club have talked the matter over, and are now working hard to get 1,000 men to subscribe $100 each. They have not been successful yet. but have enough to make them feel very much encouraged.

Nine collisions in the fog occurred yesterday morning on the Broadway branch of the Brooklyn Union Elevated Railroad. Though a number of cars were telescoped, and several engines were badly damaged, only one man was injured.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Superintendent Charles M. Preston of the State Banking Department has transmitted to the Legislature his annual report for the year 1893, relative to foreign mortgage, loan, and investment companies.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- William Frederick Poole, LL. D., died at 3 o'clock this morning in his home in Evanston. His serious illness had caused alarm among his friends for several days, and his death was not unexpected.

When the Sheffield Blanket Ballot bill came up as the special order in the Assembly on Wednesday, consideration of it was unexpectedly postponed for one week, and the reason given for the delay was that some change is to be made in the paster provisions. There was also found to be some conflict between its provisions relating to Election Inspectors and those of a pending measure which relates to that subject alone.

The so-called "Seigniorage" bill of Mr. Bland passed the House of Representatives yesterday by a majority of 39. There were 19 Republican votes in its favor and 49 Democrats against it. Certainly the bill is mischievous in principle and would be in effect. Yet the long struggle over it in the House has hardly attracted attention, much less created any excitement in the business community.

There was nothing at all in Mr. Gladstone's speech yesterday to indicate that he was about to lay down the cares of office because he found them too heavy for him. On the contrary, his remarks indicate that he enjoys them very much. His speech seemed to be inconsistent with that he made some weeks ago on the same subject.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Mr. Frye resumed his speech on the Hawaiian question in the Senate to-day. He had heretofore, he said, expressed his belief that there was not one plain, unprejudiced, unvarnished particle of truth in the Blount report, and he did not now desire to revise that opinion.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Mr. Bryan (Dem., Neb.,) to-day Introduced In the House a bill to construe that provision of the Sherman law which gives the Secretary of the Treasury the right to redeem coin obligations in gold or sliver at his discretion so as to make it clear that the Secretary has the right to redeem in either metal. The bill provides:

STROUDSBURG, Penn., March 2. -- A mob of 500 persons congregated at the Monroe County Jail at 1 o'clock this morning for the purpose of lynching Richard Puryear, the negro murderer of Christian E. Ehlers. The mob was led by neighbors of the murdered man, James W. Wilson, a storekeeper at Mount Pocono, and Luther M. Michaels, Superintendent of a farm at Shawnee.

During the last seven years the World's Woman's Christian Temperance Union has been preparing for presentation to all the Governments of the world a monster polyglot petition against the traffic in alcohol and opium, and against legalized vice.

Ever since the great storm devastated the low islands along the South Carolina coast, carrying away hundreds of homes and sweeping away hundreds of persons, the distress in the region has been heartrending and appalling.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.
Michael S. Fay, Republican Election Inspector, was yesterday sentenced to five years in Sing Sing Prison for violation of the election laws.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Representative Dunphy of New-York has forwarded to Nicholas T. Brown of Tammany Hall his resignation from the Tammany Hall General Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- After proceeding several hours in a humdrum sort of way, discussing the Fortifications and Pension Appropriation bills, an adjournment was reached by the House to-day at the close of the most sensational incident of the session.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce continued its hearing to-day on the pooling amendment proposed by Senator Gorman.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 2 -- Ex-Gov. George Peabody Wetmore formally entered into the contest for United States Senator this afternoon. The Republican State Central Committee at a recent meeting invited him to become a candidate, and a letter was received from him to-day in which he said that he should take the field.
walked down the aisle and took her seat at the desk which stands in the very centre of the circle of Senatorial desks.

Those who really think that the removal of the duties on wool will destroy or greatly depress the domestic wool-growing industry may find something to enlighten them in the effect upon the hide and leather industries of the removal of the duty on hides.

TRENTON, N. J., March 2 -- Joseph Wallwltz, known as John Malwitz, a burglar serving a twenty years' sentence in the State prison, attempted to escape early this morning, and in the effort to secure his |freedom he shot and killed Deputy Keeper James B. Lippincott, one of the most trusted officials of the prison.

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 2 -- Gen. Jubal A. Early died at 10:35 o'clock to-night. His death was immediately announced by United States Senator John W. Daniel, who has been a constant watcher for several days at the bedside of his old commander.
The dramatic gestures and sermons of the Rev. Dr. De Witt Talmage are likely to be seen and heard In the Brooklyn Tabernacle for some time to come.

Viola J. Carey, granddaughter of eccentric Benjamin Richardson, made an application, through ex-Surrogate Ransom, yesterday, to Surrogate Arnold to open the decree probating the will and to allow her to contest it. She charges that her consent to the probate was secured by fraud, and that It was Invalid because she was only nineteen years old at the time, and no guardian had been appointed for her.

From The Hartford Post. A young man wearing glasses attracted considerable attention among the people seated In the parquet circle during a performance the other evening. He insisted on going out after each act and compelling the lady who occupied the end seat of the row to rise and let him pass, which she did each time.

The evangelistic meeting in the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association yesterday was intended especially for the unemployed. Dr. Henry Marvin Wharton presided. There was a large attendance. After the opening announcement of the purpose of the gathering, the Rev. A. C. Dixon offered prayer.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 2 -- The doctors and the police are having a controversy over the mystery connected with the case of L. Dow Mayes, a lawyer, who says he was hit with a sandbag in Church Street about 7 o'clock Tuesday evening. The doctors say Mayes Is suffering from concussion of the brain produced by a blow.

WEST POINT, March 2 -- Some years ago a few benevolent women collected a fund, the interest of which was to be used in providing a Teacher's Bible for each member of the graduating class in the Military Academy at West Point. The presentation of Bibles to the class who are to be graduated took place Thursday afternoon in the old historic chapel.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The InterState Commission to-day, in opinions by Morrison, Commissioner, announced its decision in favor of complainants in the cases of C.O. Morrell against the Union Pacific Railway Company, Oregon Short Line, and Oregon Railway and Navigation Company, and A.S. Newland, and others, against the same defendants and the Northern Pacific Railroad Company.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 2 -- Mrs. Robert T. Kimlin committed suicide to-night at her home, near the Hudson River Driving Park. Mrs. Kimlin left her husband several months ago after a quarrel, and started a small store on Fourth Avenue, New-York, but became reconciled to him again and sold out and returned.

From The Aususta (Ga.) Chronicle. The recent general order by the general manager of the Southern Associated Press to all its agents to pay less attention to petty crimes of local interest, and to give more to instances of material development, is meeting with general approval and frequent indorsement.

The weight of evidence as to the condition of the foresail of the Kearsarge at the time the vessel struck on Roncador Reef as now against Lieut. Brainard and Cadet Ball, who testified Thursday that the sail was set.

TRENTON, N.J., March 2 -- The pottery manufacturers have issued "a statement of facts" in reference to the dispute between them and the operatives over a cut in prices. The 5,000 operatives have refused to accept the cut and the holding back of 20 per cent of the wages pending the settlement of the tariff legislation.

CHARLESTON, West Va., March 2 -- Peace has reigned at the Eagle Mines to-day. The strikers held a secret meeting at Montgomery last night, which gave rise to the belief that they were planning another attack on the Eagle Mines, and moved the Sheriff, the operators, and officers in command of the military to advise the Governor not to \vithdraw the troops.

Foreman Hermann Oelrichs of the Grand Jury yesterday read two presentments before Judge Marline in Part I. in the General Sessions building before the Grand Jury was discharged for the February term. One related to the condition of the workhouse and the almshouse on Blackwell's Island, the other to the practice of protective societies in making complaints directly to the Grand Jury instead of going before a police magistrate.

There was a meeting of the Interscholastic Athletic Association In the Berkeley School yesterday afternoon. A reorganization was effected, and all the threatened difficulties of the association were amicably adjusted. Representatives were present from the Cutler, Berkeley, Collegiate. Halsey, Dwight, Condon, Barnard, Columbia Grammar, Columbia Institute, Harvard, Wilson Kellogg, and Drisler Schools.

It was Policeman McPartland's day off yesterday, but the Sergeant at the Thirtieth Street Station did not think to pay any particular attention to him when, at 5 o'clock last evening, he reported for duty. Nor did McPartland receive any notice when he marched out at 6 o'clock to go on post.
The railway mortgage market continued fairly active and firm. The principal changes were:

LONDON, March 2 -- Mr. Gladstone this evening had an audience with the Queen at Windsor, and informed her of his intention to resign from the Premiership. It is probable that the formal act of resignation will be delayed till after the meeting of the Council, which the Queen will hold tomorrow.
