ALBANY, March 2 -- Gov. Flower has signed: Chapter 72 -- Mr. Prescott's bill relative to changing the number of Trustees of corporations formed to secure camp grounds and other property for the Methodist Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, March, 2 -- Lieut. Col. A. C. Wildrick's case has been disposed of at the War Department. This Is the artillery officer stationed at Fort Wadsworth, NewYork, who has been charged with drunkenness. He Is one of the best known and most popular officers of the army, and has a splendid war record.

WASHINGTON. March 2. -- If the people who have been talking so loudly in the last two days about the alleged humiliation of the majority members of the Finance Committee by the Democratic Senatorial caucus were to Interview some of the men who were responsible for that caucus they might view the situation with different eyes.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 2 -- The house of Moore Baker, in Franklin, N.J., is closed. Everything remains Just as it was yesterday after the bodies of Mrs. Baiter and her child and the two negro burglars were removed. The place is am object of much interest to large crowds of curious visitors from all parts of the county.
R. G. Dun Co.'s review of trade for the week \vlll say to-morrow:

The ill feeling between Battalion Chief Edward F. Croker of the Fire Department and Edward A. Scannell, a former member of the department, culminated Thursday night in a dastardly and entirely unprovoked assault upon Chief Croker by Scannell, who struck him on the head with a beer bottle, injuring him severely.

The men who are engaged in reorganizing the Republican Party in this city, including the Chairman of the State Committee of the party, seem at length to realize that the ultimate success of their movement, since it is antagonized by Mr. Platt, depends largely upon the control of the next State Convention.

WASHINGTON. March 2. -- The Senate Committee on Naval Affairs has made public the text of the bill Secretary Herbert has prepared as a remedy for existing conditions in regard to line officers of the navy. It makes the active list of the navy consist of 20 Rear Admirals, 60 Captains, 100 Commanders, 74 Lieutenant Commanders, 230 Lieutenants, and 73 Lieutenants of junior grade.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Chapin Home for the Aged and Infirm was celebrated yesterday at 151 East Sixty-sixth Street, and from 3 o'clock In the afternoon until 10 In the evening the house was filled with guests.

In extending the Broadway cable system through Columbus Avenue the contractors have met with considerable hard rock. To blast this out they have used dynamite in some places. At Eighty-first Street, directly under the elevated railroad station, in sinking the trench the rock was found to be particularly solid and unyielding.

A dinner and meeting of Good Government Club D took place in the Golden Eagle Restaurant, in West Thirty-third Street, last evening. This is the club which nominated and helped elect Mr. Sheffield from the Eleventh Assembly District.

That portion of the city east of Second Avenue. between Seventieth and Ninetieth Streets, is populated by large numbers of working people about whose poverty not much has been said heretofore, because they have struggled bravely against misfortune, and have made their wants known only when starvation and eviction stared them in the face.
ROME, March 2 -- The 1'ope was greeted and congratulated by the Cardinals to-day on the occasion of the celebration of his eighty-fourth birthday and the sixteenth anniversary of his coronation.
LONDON, March 2 -- T.P. O'Connor, M. P., in an interview with a United Press correspondent this morning, said:

LONDON, March 2 -- MR. Labouchere has written a letter to Edward Marjor, banks, the Liberal whip, protesting against the appointment of a peer as Premier and reiterating his arguments in favor of a commoner as the leader of a Liberal Government. In his letter Mr. Labouchere says.

ROME, March 2 --The Chamber of Deputies to-day referred to a parliamentary commission a demand for the prosecution of Deputy Casilli, who is accused of complicity with the Sicilian Socialist Deputy de Felice and the exiled Anarchist Cypriani in plotting to start a revolution in Italy.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The Troy Bi-partisan licans Inspectors bill, which the Republicans forced through the Legislature yesterday, reached Gov. Flower this morning. A careful examination of it showed that it was so faulty in construction as to be absolutely useless.

Charles D. Shepard, for many years proprietor of the "White Elephant" billiard hall at Broadway and Thirty-first Street, died last evening in the apartments of friends at Broad-way and Twenty-sixth Street. He had been ill since November, and for four weeks had been confined to his bed.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- There was less eagerness to buy West Chicago to-day, but the market was still a strong one, and the trade in it was fully as large as yesterday. It opened at 140 1/2, advanced to 141, reacted to 140, and closed at 139 3/8. Not many more people were disposed to sell than yesterday, about all the stock which came out being long holdings, in which there was a satisfactory profit.

NEW-YORK, Friday, March 2. -- P. M. A decline in prices was to be expected on the heels of yesterday's sharp advance in stocks. Profit taking on the long side of the market has been a diversion not commonly offered of late. When the chance fur it. came to-day, the temptation was not to be withstood.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 2 -- As the Hackensack local of the New-Jersey and New-York Railroad was running out of the Erie yards, at 7:30 to-night, it crashed into an Erie Pullman that was being sidetracked. The side of the Pullman was smashed in, and the pilot of the Hackensack engine was carried away.

There came to this city yesterday over the wires of the Associated Press, an institution that claims to furnish news, a strange and weird tale from the Pacific slope. Before it Baron Munchausen of old would have taken off his hat and yielded the palm, and Eli Perkins would faint at the very sight of it.

An idea of the attitude of the Tories towrard Lord Rosebery may be obtained from the leading editorial article in Edmund Yates's paper, The Worid, for Feb. 14. The World asserts that Rosebery hardly belongs in the full sense to Mr. Gladstone's administration, and in support of this proposition says:

The Right Hon. Archibald Philip Primrose, Earl of Rosebery, is the son of the late Archibald Lord Dalmeny. He was born in London in 1847. He was educated at Eton and Christ Church, Oxford. He succeeded to his title on the death of his grandfather, the Fourth Earl of Rosebery, in 1868.

Another reduction of wages in the factories of the American Axe and Tool Company is announced, and, of course, the employes are told that the Wilson bill is the cause. A reduction was ordered on Dec. 30, and it was then said in press dispatches that during the year then closing the workmen's wages had " been reduced several times."

William B. Burnett, an attorney of Cincinnati, was arrested yesterday forenoon at 102 Broadway by Deputy United States Marshals and taken before United States Commissioner Shields. He was arrested on attachment proceedings issued out of the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of Ohio, for contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Congressman Lemuel Ely Quigg of the Fourteenth District of New-York has reported to Judge Caldwell. Chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, that at least four of the ten Congressional districts in New-York City may be carried next Fall for the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Secretary of the Navy to-night made public some interesting facts Heretofore carefully kept secret in regard to the armor plate contracts of the Carnegie Company for the new navy vessels. The publication was called out by statements in Washington dispatches to The New-York Tribune.

The object that Mr. Hittell has in view in these volumes is an ambitious one. Herbert Spencer takes special subjects for study, but Mr. Hittell desires that all phases of early human life may at least be indicated in one work. It can at once be understood how vast is this topic. A history of culture is all-embracing, since everything contributing toward advance must be presented.

BABYLON, L. I., March 2 -- The Westminster Kennel Club team of pigeon shots defeated a team from the Riverton Gun Club of Philadelphia here to-day by three birds. It was a closely-contested match, and the Interest was at fever heat from the time the first gun was fired until the last bird fell.

The report of the business of the Jersey Central Railroad for the year ending Dec. 31, 1893, has just been issued in pamphlet form. It shows that the net surplus revenues of the company over all operating expenses, taxes, and fixed charges amounted to $2,138,789, as against $2,330,384 for the preceding year.

The bill which passed the House of Representatives on Thursday is, as we have already indicated, nothing to be alarmed about, and no one shows any signs of alarm concerning it save one or two of the Republican organs. Their anxiety is purely perfunctory and professional.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Penn., March 2. -- Since noon yesterday there have been no further developments in the attempt to rescue the four entombed quarrymen In the tunnel of the Williams Sons' quarry. After the rock that buried Josiah Remaly had been quarried through, a solid wall of stone about twenty-five feet high, and extending the entire width of the tunnel, barred further progress.

The Board of Street Opening met in the Mayor's office yesterday and passed a resolution to open St. Nicholas Terrace, from One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street to One Hundred and Thirtieth Street, and to close Academy Place, from One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street to One Hundred and Thirtieth Street.

"Thomas Hammond, Chicago," was the name registered at the Gedney House, Broadway and Fortieth Street, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, by a man who at 6 o'clock last evening was found dead in the room to which he had been assigned.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- John Gillies of Brooklyn, contractor for the construction of the large timber dry dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was at the Navy Department to-day and had a long interview with Secretary Herbert. He came in response to a request from the Secretary, who proposes that he shall show cause why the contract for the construction of this dock shall not be taken from him.

The principal sale of real estate reported Yesterday was that of the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant, with the adjoining parsonage at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, occupying a plot 98.9 by 155 feet. Although the consideration is not stated, it is believed to be about $300,000, this being the price at which it wits held a short time ago.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Treasury officials view with considerable interest the beginning of the Spring export movement of gold to Europe. For the past two weeks because of the rate of exchange, gold exports have been looked for, and the only reason they have not started sooner is stated to be that the banks of the principal European countries, like our own, have a plethora of money on deposit.

The Kearsarge court of inquiry opened yesterday with a statement from Judge Advocate Kelley that the evidence in the case of the lost corvette was nearly all in. This he supplemented by saying that the evidence of two witnesses, Capt. Lockwood of the steamship City of Para and First Officer Sorenson of that vessel, could not be introduced, as the City of Para had sailed.

Popular interest in the election cases is abating. Mckane's imprisonment fixes the high-water mark of public excitement over the prosecutions. With the big fish safely caught in the Sing Sing net the fate of the small fry has become a matter of secondary consideration. Something is now heard on the strets, in the cars, and at the clubs besides allusions to the late "Pooh-Bah," and "Gravesend."

The Ladies'Health Protective Association has taken up again the case against the stable, which is really the case of two millions of people against about forty-two hundred stable keepers. It is a contest of some moment, since, aside from the benefits accruing directly from a victory for the Protective Asociation, their success would be a fresh demonstration that this is a civilized community, against a great volume of disheartening evidence to the contrary.

WHITE PLAINS, March 3 -- The committee appointed by the Board of Managers of the Westchester Temporary Home for Indigent Children to investigate the charges of cruelty against Superintendent James Pierce held its final session for taking testimony this afternoon.

The Indian money lender almost everywhere is a thorough Shylock. Rajah Brooke tells me that in Sarawak, where land may not be sold for debt, unless as a penalty for swindling, and where a limit is put on the interest that his courts will enforce, the Indian money lender has been found as hard and merciless as the Chinaman and Malay are fair and reasonable.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Democratic Congressional Committee met in the room of the House Committee on Labor this morning, and discussed the question of raising funds, the printing and circulation of documents, and the location of headquarters. It was decided to have the documents printed in a uniform size and style and distribute them through the several State organizations.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The preparation of the tariff bills now in progress recalls to my mind a proposition which I made in 1883 for an enlargement of the opportunities given to our merchants in the bonded warehouse system. At the present time it is only possible for importers to take original, unbroken packages out of bond.

One at the most remarkable facts in the history of the gall fly is, that different species acting on the same tree produce totally different results. Thus, one of them puncturing the wild rose gives rise to one of those pretty moss-like tufts which so frequently adorn it. Another on the same plant produces round growths resembling currants in size and form. A much greater variety of form is produced on the oak tree.

ROME, Feb. 20 -- In the tragedy of "Horace," founded on the eventful battle of the Horatii and the Curatil in the early days of Roman history, the survivor of the victors and victims is confronted by his sister, Camilla, who was the bethrothed of one of the men he had slain, and this is the curse on her brother and on Rome that Corneille supposes to come from her lips:

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 3 -- Charles Patterson, formerly a resident of Allegheny, but who had been dead to his wife and family for twenty-nine years, unexpectedly returned several months ago. He found that his father and mother were dead and that his wife, who had supposed herself a widow, had married his brother, and that they were living on Poplar Street, Allegheny.

Paris is so deeply interested in her own World's Fair of 1900 that her papers have no room for mention concerning this year's International Exposition about to be opened by her ancient rival, Lyons. At least the chief journals are keeping a severe silence in regard to an event of the greatest importance to the old town near the junction of the Saone and the Rhone.

EL PASO, Texas, March 3 -- Hugh Bryce, who arrived from Mexico, tells a story of wrong and suffering that almost parallels that of Edmond Dantes, in Dumas's "Count of Monte Cristo." Bryce is a mechanic who passed through this city nearly four years ago from Pueblo, Col., where he had been a foreman in the railroad shops of Stearns Rogers.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., March 3 -- At the hotels many of the people who came for Washington's Birthday still remain. The dance at the Laurel-in-the-Pines last Saturday night was particularly enjoyed by a large contingent of Brooklyn people staying at that house. In the music room Sunday night there was a large gathering of cottagers, who enjoyed the music which followed the usual singing, when Mme. Amalle Hubert sang several soprano solos.

The love of bloodshed seems inherent, for even boys will draw the facon upon the slightest provocation; and, as the throat and abdomen, are the parts which are generally aimed at, the wounds are usually mortal. Murders and homicides cause little or no emotion. The man who respectfully salutes the stranger is more likely than not a hero who has cut many throats.

The Assembly Committee on Cities has under consideration a bill introduced by the Ladles' Health Protective Association of New-York, having for its object the abatement of the stable-manure nuisance. A hearing will be given on the bill next Tuesday.

NICE, France, Feb. 20. -- The United States squadron in these waters, small at any time, now appears particularly dwarfed, surrounded as it is by the huge battle ships and armored cruisers which compose the French squadron of evolution which recently arrived at the anchorage in Villefranche Bay.

In December, 1891, I was in Canton. One afternoon I visited the principal law court. Two prisoners in chains were introduced-- one an old man, too infirm to walk, the other a youth, tolerably vigorous, but abject and forlorn in demeanor. The presiding mandarin appeared, sat down and sipped his tea, while an official pattered out a long oration, presumably an indictment, for the prisoners proceeded, as I understood, to plead "not guilty."

HUDSON, N.Y., March 3 -- The DeaneOsborne Senatorial case came up to-day at Special Term, in Chambers, before Justice Edwards. The case bears title of the People ex rel. John I. Platt and others, but is better known as the Deane-Osborne case. For over three years it has been before the courts, and, strange to say, both parties to the suit have since died.

A.B. Hodges is champion of the Empire State again. His defeat of J.W. Baird in the final was told in Monday's New-York Times, thereby securing the first prize of the championship tournament, which began on Washington's Birthday. Hodges is well known in the chess world, and everybody knows the splendid record of this expert.

VIII. Philippa grew gradually better. Her illness had almost defied the physicians at first; it had been a complete nervous collapse, in which vitality had flickered low, like the flame of a lamp whose defective wick no fresh funds of oil could properly feed.

The police of the West Thirtieth Street Station were notified at 6 o'clock last evening that there was a crazy man in the synagogue Shearith Israel, 5 West Nineteenth Street, over which Rabbi P. Mendez presides. Policemen Fay and Schultz, who were sent there, were informed that the man was up stairs, at the prayer meeting.

It is interesting to note that in Holland sport has so far developed that a new paper, De Athleet, a well-printed sheet, has made its appearance in Amsterdam. Due attention is paid to cross-country athletics, and under the heading Voetbal, prominence is given to the doings of English clubs in this country, while the matches of the Felixstowe Club, which recently visited the Dutch, are very fully reported.

Miss Mary G. Potter, one of the teachers at the Berkeley Athletic Club, may be seen daily just now in the reception room of the clubhouse, swinging clubs before the mirror. She is very expert in that line of work, but is perfecting herself in some specialties, and two hours' mirror practice daily is a necessity.

HOWES CAVE, N.Y., March 3 -- Burr Merchant, a telegraph operator employed in the station, in this town, was on his way home about midnight last night, when he saw a light glimmering in the store of Parker Slingerlands. Merchant crept to the window, and saw two men, one of them holding a burning match.

The Musical Art Society of New-York, which has been organized for the purpose of bringing before the musical public a high grade of choral compositions, gave its first concert last night, in Carnegie Music Hall.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 -- Ex-President Harrison arrived at San Joss at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon and took quarters at the Hotel Vendome, where he will remain probably until Monday or Tuesday, when he will go to Stanford University. The party left Indianapolis last Monday, and includes besides the General, Mrs. McKee, the Rev. Dr. Haines, the General's private secretary, Mr. Tibbetts, and his two grandchildren.

TRENTON, N. J., March 3 -- The Senatorial dead-lock is beginning to produce some serious muddles. The Supreme Court and Court of Errors is short-handed, for the term of Justice Magie has expired, and the courts of Morris, Sussex, and Somerset Counties are now without a presiding Judge.
Alpheus Sherwin Cody talked for an hour on "The Art of Fiction and Playwriting as Based on a Scientific Study of Human Nature" in the lecture hall of the Berkeley Lyceum yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Blue Room of the Executive Mansion was this morning filled with Mrs. Cleveland's friends, invited to be present at the reception to the band of Alaskan Esquimaus. The reception took place at 11:30 o'clock, and for nearly an hour the company was entertained with the oddly-dressed guests of honor, who appeared greatly to enjoy the event.

To the Editor of The New-YorK Times: It is now twenty-two years since Congress awakened one day to the discovery that our ocean carrying trade was leaving us, although it had commenced its downward career sixteen years before. Since 1872 committee after committee has been appointed to investigate the cause and to devise a remedy, and no success has attended their efforts at discovery or cure.

For the first time in months the really big men of the financial world are out-spoken in their belief that better times are at hand for the investment interests which centre round about Wall Street. The letters now sent by the chief brokers of the Stock Exchange to out-of town clients are almost uniformly of cheerful tone.

Although mi-careme, with its interval of respite from prayers and fastening, has not yet dawned, Easter plans are not untalked of and Easter flowers are already budding. The pretty custom of remembering the fate days of the year by the exchange of simple gifts holds with especial force at Easter, commemorative as it is of new life and a fresh round of pleasures or duties, as one's tastes and environments dictate.

Alexis C. Smith, who has just been promoted from Lieutenant Colonel to the posltion of Colonel, to fill the vacancy left by the resignation of Col. John N. Partridge of the Twenty-third Regiment, is one of the most popular officers In the National Guard. Col. Smith is a native of Brooklyn, and was born In the old Smith homestead on Hicks Street, Feb. 5, 1852.

The leaf and stem of a nettle are literally clothed with erect hollow hairs. If one of these hairs is viewed under a microscope it will be seen that its free end, after tapering to a very fine degree of slimness, finishes as a little knob, while in the other direction, after gradually becoming more robust, it suddenly expands into a large bulb corresponding with the poison gland of the adder.
BERLIN, March 3 -- At the first session of the Commission to which was referred the German-Russian commercial treaty, held to-day, Articles 1 to 17 were adopted. The vote throughout was 12 to 9.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 3 -- Argument on the motion of the Northern Pacific employes to have Judge Jenkins's order modified was continued in the United States Circuit Court this morning, Attorney McNaught for the receivers speaking against the change.

Just before Mayor Gilroy left yesterday on his vacation trip, he received the following report from Commissioner William S. Andrews of the Department of Street Cleaning, upon the work done in removing the snow from the city's streets:

With this list of exceptions, the iron bark Broomhall, Capt. Taylor, was in as good condition when she came into this port yesterday as she was in when, just 108 days before, she sailed from Cuxhaven.

UTICA, N. Y., March 3 -- The acquittal Thursday of Election Inspector George B. Rowe, who was indicted with others for making incorrect returns at the last election, practically takes from Mayor Wheeler the only ground on which he expected to make a contest, and it is now generally conceded by attorneys here that Mayorelect Gibson will take office on March 13.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 3 -- This city is to have a new club, formed, on unique lines, and filling a gap which stands open in every university town. It will be distinctively a college man's club, and any person who holds a degree from any university or college of recognized standing will be eligible to membership, its name has been selected as the "Graduate Club," and it will be formally organized here the coming week.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I write to thank you for the editorial in last Thursday's issue regarding the proposed new site for the College of the City of New-York. The influence of the college, in a number of directions, upon the whole public-school system, to which influence you refer as important, deserves special comment from those who are in a position to understand that influence best.

From The Outlook. It is rightly said that this is the age of woman. She certainly has been a discovery to some, and they have employed heralds to announce the fact. There is not the slightest danger at present that woman will be allowed to hide her light under a bushel. She will not even confine it to the housetop, but will bear it in procession along the thoroughfare.

The services to be held in memory of George W. Childs under the auspices of Typographical Union No. 6, in the Fifth Avenue Theatre on next Sunday afternoon, promise to be very impressive. The Fifth Avenue Theatre orchestra, under the direction of Thomas W. Hindley, will furnish several high-class selections.

The three primary color sensations are considered to be red, green, and violet. Certain mixtures of violet and green produce a blue; red and green also give a yellow. But it is important to observe that these are primary color sensations, and not primary colors, though the expression "lights of primary colors" is admissible.
Speaking in a paper on the subject of the various diet cures for fatness, the eminent authority, Dr. Andrew Wilson, says:
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 3 -- Cheering reports of resuming mills and furnaces after long shut-downs come from all parts of the South.

The secret marriage of Andrew B. Graves to Miss Genevieve G. Herne of Cambridge, Mass., has provoked lively gossip in Brook- | lyn social circles. Mr. Graves is a member of an old and prominent family in that city, and the announcement of his alliance surprised his relatives there almost as much as it did his other friends.
The sales of realty at auction in Brooklyn during the past week amounted to $286,600. For the corresponding week last year they were $183,960.

According to my observation, the elephant is intelligent in a diabolical way at times, but rarely ever up to the mark when its intelligence would be useful. So with its docility. That quality is prominent, no doubt, when the exhibition of it is convenient to the elephant, but one often looks for it in vain when it is needed for the convenience of any other living creature.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- It is expected that Mr. White of Louisiana will take the step next week which will make him a member of the United States Supreme Court. The court reconvenes on Monday, after the February recess, and it is desirable that there shall be a full bench. The vacancy caused by the death, of Justice Blatchford has been a source of much inconvenience to all the Justices.

Mr. Hewit's vigorous remarks about the ignorance of Southern members of Congress have not unnaturally been received with pain and resentment by the persons at whom they are aimed. These statesmen insist that they are as virtuous and well informed as their predecessors of the period before the war, and that, if Mr. Hewitt does not find them so, it is because there is something wrong with his intellect or his digestion.

The Greater New-York project was indorsed last evening by the Brooklyn Consolidation League. The league has opposed legislation providing for a vote on consolidation unless a provision for equal taxation could be incorporated in the bill. Now that the Commission bill has become a law, the league has fallen into line with the movement.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 3 -- Richard Croker arrived here this morning and will remain until Monday, when he will visit the ranch of John A. Morris, forty miles north of here. A reception was given to him to-night by the San Antonio Club.

William Sibley, who was a basketmaker in the early part of this century, accumulated by his penuriousness a comfortable fortune, which he invested in real estate. He carried on his business at 238 Greenwich Street, of which he subsequently became the owner. He died in November, 1827, leaving a moderate fortune.

To me, profoundly averse to autocracy, Carlyle's political doctrines had ever been repugnant. Much as I did, and still do, admire his marvelous style and the vigor, if not the truth, of his thought -- so much so that I always enjoy any writing of his, however much I disagree with it -- intercourse with him soon proved impracticable. Twice or thrice, in 1851-2, I was taken to see him by Mr. G.H. Lewes;

The sun shines gloriously overhead, the sky is a pale, cloudless blue, and the foliage around us shows every shade and tint from brown to scarlet, from the palest to the deepest green. We saunter along the grass under the trees beside the avenue, and find a quiet spot with a pool of clear water haunted by swans before us.

George L. Fox, rector of the Hopkins Grammar School, New-Haven, Conn., gave an Illustrated lecture on Eton College last evening at Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre, Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. The lecture was the second In A course of four by Mr. Fox on the "Great Schools of England."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 24 -- The ruins of a building of stone have been discovered here within sixty feet of the present line of Elizabeth Avenue, between Broad Street and Jefferson Avenue, and only a few feet from the Elizabeth River. There is little doubt that they once formed a part of the mansion of Gov. Carteret, the first Chief Executive of New-Jersey, in which the first Legislative Assembly met, May 26, 1668.

Nothing so much illustrates the interest taken in kindergartens and kindergarten methods as a class that meets weekly at the Teachers' College, New-York. It is a mothers' class, and among its members are women of wealth and position, wives of teachers and professors, all of whom are studying the pretty educational arts, graceful mother-plays, and nursery songs of Froebel for the benefit of their children.

TRENTON, N.J., March 3 -- Coroner Bowers held an inquest this afternoon on the body of Deputy Keeper Lippincott, and it resulted in a verdict that his death was caused by pistol shots fired by Joseph Wallwitz. The jury recommended that more than one deputy be placed on guard in each ward at night.

ROME, March 3 -- Premier Crispi addressed the Deputies to-day in defense of his policy during the Sicilian uprising. "The Government would have betrayed the country," he declared, "had It allowed the insurgents to enter Palermo, where the leaders proposed to proclaim formally the Sicilian revolution. We are resolved to combat to the fullest extent all revolutionists, whether they be Anarchists or Socialists."

Among the "curiosities of literature," none, perhaps, is more interesting than the aegis of the author behind which he wages his war of words -- the nom de guerre, with its caprices, its varieties, and frequently he reasons for its choice. For in most of cases an author exercises himself as much to find a suitable name under which to write as a suitable title for that which he has written.

LONDON, March 3 -- The United Press correspondent learned from an official source at 11:30 o'clock this evening that the Queen had accepted Mr. Gladstone's resignation and had offered the Premiership to Lord Rosebery, who had consented to take the office.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The official report of Commodore Schley as to the dangerous condition of the Gardiner Island Lighthouse recalls the efforts of the Lighthouse Bureau to secure an appropriation to build a wall around the lighthouse.

All who have journeyed through the great forest must heve frequently noticed large black or dark-brown balls attached to the higher branches of trees, which are called "votry." They ore generally a little larger than a football, but occasionally attain the dimensions of a beehive. These are ants' nests. If you take one down and examine it, (a rather ticklish business,) you will find that it consists of a tough substance exactly resembling dry cowdung.

An occasional admission that it is fallible and peccant would tend, we think, to strengthen the Tammany organization with the people. In giving his reasons for withdrawing from the organization, Congressman Dunphy twits on facts in a most horribly blunt and unpleasant manner.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 3 -- A joint meeting of the Executive and Graduate Advisory Committees was held this afternoon at the Princeton Inn. There were present P.W. Miller, Max Farrand, C.C. Cuyler, J. McN. Thompson, and Capt. Trenchard. The appointment by the Executive Committee of Thomas J. Perkins, '94, of Germantown, Penn., to the office of General Athletic Treasurer, was ratified by the Graduate Advisory Committee.

RICHLAND, Kan., March 3 -- The Rev. Mr. Roberts, pastor of the Methodist Church, is the first minister in Kansas to abandon his congregation on account of the hard times. He surprised his congregation by announcing that he had preached his last sermon.

A large audience of men and women assembled at the house of Good Government Club B, 70 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, last evening, to hear an address by James C. Carter on city government, but he did not appear. The club waited half an hour for him, and then President Henry R. Elliott told the audience that no news had been received from Mr. Carter since he left town unexpectedly forty-eight hours before.
TORRENS, Mexico, March 3. -- The Patron Hacienda, situated northwest of this city, was the scene yesterday of a bloody conflict between several hundred laborers employed on the place.
Controller Ashbel P. Fitch has received the following letter:

Mrs. Margaret Maier, wife of Henry Maier, a butcher of Vesta Avenue, Brooklyn, who has for three weeks expected to be arrested, and who told the East NewYork police she had heard she was wanted in Racine, Wis., for murder, was arrested yesterday by Detective Cortwright upon a writ of extradition signed by the Governor of Wisconsin.

Edward A. Scannell, brother of Fire Commissioner John J. Scannell, was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for trial on a charge of assaulting Fire Battalion Chief Edward F. Croker with a bottle on Thursday night. Croker told Justice McMahon how Scannell knocked him down with the bottle, and his testimony was corroborated by William T. Larkin of 205 West Twentieth Street, in front of whose home the assault was made.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 20 -- A serious encounter has taken place at one of the military stations here, called Up-Park Camp, between men belonging to the Second West India Regiment of colored soldiers and men of the Leicester Regiment, all of whom are whites.

New-York is to have a Midway Plaisance of its own. To-day there are at work in the big Madison Square Garden, where the new Midway will be, a hundred carpenters and half as many scene-shifters, all busy making the transformation.

Down in New-Jersey the weather of the past week has been of the sort that the trainers of race horses have been longing for. These trainers, who are very much in the public eye during the Summer months, when racing is in progress, and very much out of sight during the enforced idleness of the Winter, are a nervous and restless set of men.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- Delightful evening at the Odeon. Nota programme, perhaps, calculated to suit the crowd, but one thoroughly enjoyable for the scholar and quite as much so for the tired, satiated theatregoer, weary Of realism and peppery mixtures.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Mr. Josiah Quincy was the first witness to appear this morning to give testimony before the Senate Committee on Printing in its investigation of the circumstances connected with granting the contract for lithographic work for The Patent Office Gazette to the National Lithograph Company, with which Mr. Quincy is alleged to be connected.

The Seventh Regiment, pride of NewYork and known all over the country as a body of citizen soldiery without an equal, is soon to add another triumph to the many that are recorded on the pages of its eventful history.

Mayor Gilroy started for a flying trip to the Pacific slope at 1 P. M. yesterday, over the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad. He was accompanied by his son Arthur. His wife and daughters are at Coronado Beach, near San Diego, and he is going there to accompany them home.

One hears a great deal of talk about moist bread, and a large number of housekeepers shut their bread in airtight boxes to keep it moist. Such barbarous treatment of bread may be efficacious in keeping it moist, but bread from which fresh air is excluded always has a disagreeable, clayey flavor, and is unpalatable to people of cultured tastes, who appreciate the nutty sweetness that is a prominent characteristic of all good bread.

CHARLESTON, West Va., March 3 -- The striking miners succeeded this morning, about 2 o'clock, in burning the Three-Mile Bridge on the Chesapeake and Ohio's short line running up Cabin Creek to the Acme Mines, and in this they have scored a point, as it will result in closing the Acme Mines until the bridge can be rebuilt, all the product of the Acme Mines being shipped out by this line.

"Byron and Shelley were as far asunder as can be imagined in their estimate of women. Byron considered them as men's inferiors: he held an absolutely Oriental view of women. He was fond of saying that he did not think they had any right at the table with men, and ought to be shut up in seraglios, as they are in the East.

The information which this book contains does not bear out the theory entertained by many persons that the participants in the recent war in Matabeleland were on the one hand a nation of liberty-loving Africans, fighting for autonomy, and on the other a commercial company seeking enlargement of territory and privileges, to which it had no just title.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 20 -- According to an article published very recently in a Boston paper, the principal pineapple-producing district in the world is the few small islands or keys adjacent to the southern coast of Florida, from which there have been shipped to New-York as many as 4,500,000 pineapples in a single year. Quite an important district, no doubt, but the Bahamas can beat that district out of sight.

The independent Democrats and Republicans held their final rally of the Eighth Ward campaign for Supervisor in Prospect Hall, Prospect Avenue, near Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, last night. The large hall was crowded. On the walls were printed signs, calling the attention of the voters to the plain facts.

William Lawrence of 9 James Slip is suffering in Bellevue Hospital from a severe scalp wound received in jumping from a second-story window at 25 Hamilton Street. About midnight yesterday Lawrence, while intoxicated, broke open the basement door of the Hamilton Street house, which is occupied by Mr. and Mrs. Morris Doyle.

March is the month usually relied on as showing not only the demand for but the actual sale and rental of dwellings. Real estate brokers and agents are, consequently, just now putting in their best work in this direction and are somewhat anxiously awaiting the outcome. All the signs up to date point to a fair volume of business at remunerative prices.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 27, via Montevideo, March 3 -- Mr. Burt, agent for Charles R. Flint Co. of New-York, left Bahia on Feb. 22 and arrived here yesterday. He says the Government fleet at Bahia consists of eight vessels.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Enough progress was made by the Finance Committee to-day to lead the Democratic members of it to believe that they can report the Tariff bill on Monday or Tuesday. That has been the expectation all this week, and the arguments heard have not changed the prospect of an early report or of a report that will give a tariff reform measure to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Secretary Herbert has written a letter to the commandant of the Washington Navy Yard, making certain discharges of persons employed therein in violation of the regulations governing such matters. In his annual report he stated that generally the regulations governing the employment of labor at navy yards had been fairly compiled with, but that some developments had shown that there was a violation of the rules at the Washington Navy Yard.

BOSTON, March 3 -- Gebhard Lewis Mayer, about thirty-three years old, recently a divinity student in the Baptist Theological Seminary, in Newton, Mass., has disappeared as a result of a discovery that he had married two women within a few years and has carried on two separate households.

The Colonial Dames of the State of NewYork listened yesterday afternoon, in Hardman Hall, to the last lecture in Prof. John Fiske's course on colonial history. His subject was, "Francis Parkman, the Historian of Primitive Society."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Speaker laid before the House to-day a communication from the Secretary of the Interior submitting a letter from the Commissioner of Pensions in reply to a resolution of the House requesting a report as to why the provisions of the act of Congress approved Dec. 31 last had not been complied with respecting certain cases referred to;

Irrigation of arid land lying in Asia and Northern Africa has been practised for ages. Long before the era of recorded history the system was perfected in those lands. Among the first Governments established by man were those founded on and by the ditch. Population was first cemented to the soil by water that flowed through ditches.

The death of Lieut. Gen. Jubal A. Early removes one of the most picturesque and striking of the fast-dwindling group of prominent Confederate commanders. Thirty years ago, in the Summer of 1864, his name was for a time hardly less talked of at the North than that of Lee himself.

The awakening of the public mind on the subject of purity of elections is one of the most encouraging signs of the present time. The question is above all party issues, for upon it depends the determination of all such issues in accordance with the convictions of the people.
Water Purveyor Milne of Brooklyn will to-morrow continue his investigation into the methods adopted by the Long Island Water Supply Company in obtaining city water without paying for the privilege.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, March 3 -- P.M. The market recovered its normal tone today, overcoming entirely the losses attending yesterday's reaction, and landing prices again at the level to which Thursday's strong rally carried them. All of the active stocks participated in the improvement, which was announced at the opening of the market by advances upon the last prices of yesterday, and which became almost buoyant as business proceeded.

SING SING, March 3 -- The probability of this village losing its only public square, one that is historically associated in many ways with the memory of times long past, has aroused a deep feeling of regret in the breasts of all. Pleasant Square is likely to have a four-story building built upon it, for business purposes.

Congressman Dunphy's resignation as a member of Tammany Hall created much talk among the Tammany Hall politicians yesterday, but not many of them would admit that they were at all surprised at it. Mayor Gilroy's comment was that the action taken by Mr. Dunphy was largely due to dissatisfaction in reference to personal matters in the district.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 3 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt will visit Newport this week to inspect the work upon the new Breakers, now being erected on Ochre Point. It will be his first view of the place since last Fall, and, in the meantime, material progress has been made. The walls of the great house have been carried up to a level with the second story, and the heavy columns for the next story are being raised.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House devoted three hours to-day, in Committee of the Whole, to a further discussion of the administration of the Pension Bureau, under cover of the Pension Appropriation bill. Mr. Outhwaite of Ohio was in the Chair. Representatives Pickler of South Dakota and Waugh of Indiana, Republicans, criticised it vigorously.

The independent Democrats of Brooklyn have finally rejected the overtures of the "machine" Democrats for a sham reorganization of the party. They have notified tea representatives of the "regular" General Committee that they will reorganize on no other ground than the plan of the Provisional Committee of One Hundred.

The subject of the third lecture in Prof. Bickmore's Spring course to the teachers of the city and State, under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction, at the Museum of Natural History, yesterday morning, was "The Educational Ex- hibits of the Columbian Exposition, Displayed in the Woman's, Government, and Art Buildings." Prof. Bickmore prefaced his lecture with this remark:

A physician commenting the other day upon the prevalence of deafness, said that the affliction in a greater or less degree was almost universal among his women patients. He had been seeking in a desultory way for a cause, and had about decided that the use of strong salts in the smelling bottle of the fashionable woman had something to do with it.

The old Kearsarge, which sank the Alabama, has herself come to a violent end. She was wrecked a few days ago in the Caribbean Sea, happily without loss of life. It is all but thirty years since she fought her great fight off Cherbourg, so she has kept the seas a long time.

Mr. Henry Wood's "Natural Law in the Business World" was a clearly-written and sound book which attracted more than ordinary attention. His new volume, though following the same general argument, covers more extended ground. It is a commonsense method of showing that political economy has nothing artificial, theoretical, or repellant about it, but is based on natural laws, and, therefore, practically understandable.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 3 -- The experiments at the Torpedo Station during the week with the new army and navy rifle barrels and with smokeless powder as amunition have been merely preliminary, but considerable progress has been made. The board in charge of the tests consists of Commander George A. Converse, United States Navy, President; Capt. George C. Reid, United States Military College; Prof. Philip R. Alger, United States Navy, and Lieut.

The Mercantile Library has lost two of its employes lately. One was the bookkeeper and cashier, McStravick, who drew his half month's pay and left in the middle of January. The other was its cataloguer, Charles Brun, who, on Wednesday, was paid for the last two weeks of February. Neither disappearance can be classed as mysterious.

LONDON, March 3 -- Of this astonishing week it may first of all be said that history will depict its events in quite another light from that in which the public to-day sees them. In this generation there has not been any other political convulsion at all like it.

The following tables show the number and tonnage of vessels of 100 tons or over recorded in Lloyd's. Lloyd's records seagoing vessels, and the tables thus do not take into consideration American inland tonnage. The statistics for steam vessels are based on gross tonnage, as the deductlons to secure net tonnage In steam vessels vary considerably among nations.

Services will be held to-day for the first time in the new Calvary Presbyterian Church, at West New-Brighton, S. I. The formal dedication will take place to-morrow evening, when the Rev. Dr. John Hall of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, NewYork, will deliver an address.
The "Thomas Hammond, Chicago," who killed himself with a pistol at the Gedney House Thursday night was Thaddeus S. Hamilton, or Thomas S. Hamilton, a native of Butte City, Mon.

SING SING, March 3 -- John Y. McKane's second day In Sing Sing Prison was a repetition of his first day. He slept better and arose at the usual hour, marched to the messroom with his company, and made his breakfast on hash and bread and coffee. He is becoming more familiar with the look-step, and does not seem so awkward as at first.

Taine has made impressive opposition against the modern regime in France. In this work, as in others, he is admirable as one of the most profound thinkers of our time. The proportion of apparent exactitude and of power of conviction that may be attributed to the art with which he arranges his arguments and his proofs is very significant.

From The Portland Oregonian. Mrs. Mary Cleveland of Portland, whom the spirits told that her husband, Dr. Dan H. Thatcher of Santa Monica, Cal., was dead, when in fact he was alive, has been awarded half of his Tacoma estate, valued at $60,000. Thatcher is now a helpless invalid at Pasadena. They were married at Santa Monica.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A counterfeit one-thousand dollar, seven-thirty United States coupon bond (or note as It is sometimes called) of the series of July 15, 1865, was presented to the Treasury to-day for redemption. It was sent by the State National Bank of Cleveland, Ohio, by its cashier H.R. Somborn.

BERLIN, March 3 -- Felix Lipschuetz, vice manager of the Dresdener Residenz Theatre, shot himself dead last night in the lavatory of the express from Munich for Berlin. He had been engaged to succeed Barnay in the management of a Berlin theatre next September.

William H. McDonough was selected yesterday by Sheriff John B. Sexton, to be Under Sheriff. Mr. McDonough's appointment was very popular with all those who have had business relations with him either in his capacity as confidential clerk to Mayor Gilroy or secretary to Sheriff Flack and Sheriff Sickles.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 3. -- Detectives McCauliffe and O'Brien of New-York came to this city this afternoon and identified the three burglars caught Thursday morning in the house of John M. Wheeler, the wealthy coal merchant. They were detected robbing the house by Policeman Larkin, who shot one of the robbers.

Lawyer Gilbert applied to Justice Bartlett in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for a writ of mandamus to compel City Clerk Benjamin to permit John Dunne to perform his duties as clerk in that office.

With the voice of Mrs. Lease ringing in our ears, with thousands of women in many States beginning to agitate newly the old question of suffrage for their sex, and with the "Woman Question" brought to the front, with sensational effect, in may publications that aim to be, above all other things, foresighted in "issues of the hour,: the time seems to have come for man to be alert and on his guard.

There is much dissatisfaction among the members of the Ninth Regiment over the selection by the Armory Board of the Cable-Sargent plan for the new Ninth Regiment Armory, which is to be erected in Fourteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue.
The Nutley Amateur Circus is to be given on March 27. The proceeds will be for the purpose of founding a branch of the Red Cross League for the benefit of the citizens of Franklin Township.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 3 -- The Congressional campaign in the Third Ohio District to choose a successor to the late George W. Houk, promises to be extremely exciting. If present indications count for anything, it is likely to rival the famous campaign of 1890, which resulted in the election of McKinley.

It is generally conceded that the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall is somewhat small for orchestral playing. Perhaps that is the reason why Mr. Anton Seidl, when he has a concert to give there, always selects music in which the trombones and the trumpets vie with the tuba and the tympani in producing wild, unearthly noise.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 3 -- The barrel mill of the Moosic Powder Company, five miles from this city, was blown up this morning, about 9 o'clock, with a force that was felt several miles in every direction. One man was killed, and two so badly injured that their recovery is doubtful. The victims are:

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 3 -- Gen. Jubal A. Early's funeral will take place Monday from St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church, of which his nieces are members. Gen. Early himself was not a member of the Church. He will be buried with civic and military honors, the details having been arranged to-night at a meeting of the Confederate Veterans.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- "If Christ came to Chicago," Editor W.T. Stead's new book, the first edition of which is soon to appear unless it is bought up or suppressed by parties interested, promises to betray some secrets of this city and supply information of the most sensational kind.

A breathing spell is always a joy, whether it be in the middle of a hard-fought YaleFrincecton football game or in the middle of an eqully hard-fought musical season. But the cessation of anti-Wagnerite hostilities at the Metropolitan Opera House left the musical season in a trance of dullness. The week which has just ended was the least interrsting of the series which began on Nov 1.

Canoeists are anticipating one of the most successful meets ever held this Summer. The camp of the American Canoa Association will be at Croton Point on the Hudson. It will last from July 13 to July 28.

In the sixteenth century the system of slavery was fast disappearing from Western Europe as being inconsistent with their duty for Christians to hold Christians as slaves. But this charity did not extend to heathens and infidels! In the latter part of the seventeenth century the African slave trade was considered the most profitable part of British commerce.

LINDENHURST, L. I., March 3 -- The residents of this usually quiet settlement are excited over charges against School Principal George Zoeliner. He is accused of being a Socialist, an Anarchist, and an atheist, as well as of carousing and drinking too freely.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 4 -- It is now announced that work on the construction of the new Law School Building will soon be begun and that the structure may be ready for occupancy before the close of another school year. Plans for the building have just been submitted to the Faculty of the school by Cady Brothers of New-York.
SING SING, March 4 -- John T. McKane marched in awkward lockstep at the rear end of the white-and-black striped legion of Sing Sing Prison to-day en route to the chapel.

ALBANY, March 4. -- The subject of ballot reform is likely to be prominent in the discussions of the Legislature this week. Mr. Sheffield's bill, which was laid aside last week, will be the special order for Wednesday in the Assembly. A vigorous debate is expected.

The last lecture in the course of the Science Sermons Society was given last evening in the lecture room of the Rev. Robert Collyer's Church, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. "Protective Covering: Its Evolution, History, and Meaning," was treated in a very interesting manner by Mrs. Lizzie Cheney-Ward.

HAY SPRINGS, Neb., March 4 -- At 2:10 o'clock this morning Gould A. Still, night telegraph operator of the Fremont, Elkhorn and Missouri Valley Railroad, was at his desk, when an unknown man shot him through the window, which was in front of the desk, killing the operator almost instantly.

Active work in the cricket world of New-York will commence from to-night, when the annual general meeting of the Metropolitan District Cricket League will take place. Thenceforward until the opening of the season, the clubs will be kept busy arranging the schedules and canvassing for new members.

PROVIDENCE, March 3 -- A little better demand is quite noticeable in the local stock market, and offerings continue very light. The bank stock list shows this more especially, and while the bid prices remain about the same, the number of shares bid for indicates a much better feeling on the part of investors.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 4 -- The championship relay foot race, under the direction of the Worcester Athletic Club, last night, was the biggest indoor athletic event of the season. Seven crack teams of New-England were on hand to try for the New-England championship, which went to the home team.

The effect of the resignation of Mr. Gladstone on the cause of home rule for Ireland was discussed at a meeting of the Municipal Council of the Irish National Federation in the Cooper Union yesterday afternoon.

The report of the Assistant Secretary of the Civil Service Association on the results of his investigation of the workings of the civil service systems in the National and State Governments has several interesting features.

PITTSBURG, March 3. -- Business has moved in conservative channels this week. Money is plentiful enough, but while watching for the verification of rumors concerning commercial enterprise the financial institutions are not encouraging new business by reducing rates. Price changes, aside from a few of the street railways and natural gas stocks, were small.

KOSCIUSKO, Miss., March 4 -- The funeral of S.A. Jackson, the Democratic politician who was killed in a street duel by the Rev. W.P. Ratliffe, occurred here today. Two thousand people from the neighboring towns and surrounding country attended the services, which were held at the Kosciusko Methodist Church.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed an increase in reserve of $1,011,400. The banks now hold $75,778,900 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show a decrease in loans of $1,914,200, a decrease in specie of $389,300, an increase in legal tenders of $1,150,400, a decrease in deposits of $1,001,200, and a decrease in circulation of $23,600.

A committee from the Ladies' Health Protective Association will appear before the Assembly Committee of Cities at Albany to-morrow to defend the bill of the association, which aims at the abatement of the stable-manure nuisance. The bill was printed in The New-York Times yesterday.
The various Police Justices had to listen to a comprehensive variety of experiences by policemen when the bluecoats mustered their respective prisoners into court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Senhor Mendonca, the Brazilian Minister to the United States, to-day received a cablegram from the Minister of Foreign Affairs reading as follows:

The peaceful election of Prudente de Moraes to the Presidency of the Brazilian Republic at once changes the political and moral status of the insurgents. They have professed to be patriots taking up arms against the unlawful and oppressive acts of Peixoto. They have disclaimed any other purpose than the maintenance of the laws and the Constitution of the republic.

Dr. Henry C. Cooper, clerk of the medical department of the University of the City of New-York, died suddenly yesterday afternoon, at his rooms in the medical college, 410 East Twenty-sixth Street, of heart failure.

WINFIELD, L.I., March 4 -- A number of young people connected with the Roman Catholic Parish of St. Mary here gave the passion play in pantomime in St. Mary's Hall to-night. The several scenes represented the passion, crucifixion, death, burial, and resurrection of Christ.

During a fight between Edward Corr, nineteen, of 400 East Fourteenth Street, and August Shaffer, Charles Shaffer, same address, and Edward Hogan, at the corner of Fourteenth Street and First Avenue, last night, Hogan was stabbed in the neck, but just who stabbed him could not be ascertained.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- One more of the frequent attempts to destroy World's Fair buildings was made this afternoon, but the attempt failed and resulted in the arrest of a man who gave his name as Michael Murphy. The police believe they have in custody one of the gang of men which has succeeded in doing so much damage to the exposition buildings by the use of the torch.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 4 -- Another week's steady practice in the cage has enabled Capt. McKenzie to reduce to twenty-three the number of candidates who will continue to try for the university baseball team. The men and their positions are as follows: First base -- Otto, '95; Geer, '97, and Lindsay, '94. Second base -- King.

Kate and Christina Kelly, thirteen and fifteen years old respectively, and both remarkably pretty, left their home, 203 East Seventy-seventh Street, about 7:30 o'clock Saturday evening, and did not return during the night. Their father, James Kelly, who is a fireman attached to Engine House No. 44, in East Seventy-fifth Street, reported the girls' absence to the police of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, and a general alarm was sent out.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 4 -- Is there an anathema more dire and potent than that of priest or pontiff, an interwoven prophecy and curse awe-inspiring as that of Baalam or Cassandra? In the following narrative is presented an instance in which persons not prone to superstition must recognize at least an astounding fatality of coincidence, the sins of the father having been visited apparently on the children of the first generation:
To an effigy of the "rag-baby" order which hung yesterday from a telegraph pole at 40 Cherry Street was attached a placard which announced:

The market for State and municipal bonds last week was active, with a good demand for the better issues. Short-time bonds, especially, have been eagerly absorbed at high prices on account of the difficulty experienced by institutions in loaning money at any rate. In the last month more than $12,000,000 of new city and county bonds have been issued and all taken at good prices.

Farmer Warren Cowen of Hillsborough, Ohio, while fox hunting recently discovered several ancient graves. They were situated upon a high point of land in Highland County, Ohio, about a mile from the famous Serpent Mound, where Prof. Putnam of Harvard made interesting discoveries. As soon as the weather permitted, Cowen excavated several of these graves.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- The engagement is announced of Miss Eleanor Louise Elverson of 2024 Walnut Street, to Monsieur Jules Patenotre, French Ambassador to the United States.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The local security market has been extremely dull this week. There have been few transactions. The investment demand appears to be satisfied for the time being. Quotations, however, hold steady, and with one or two exceptions remain unchanged.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 4. -- The Carteret Club, a social club of this city, was to-night visited by Cresswell McLaughlin, a local newspaper man. Several members said he had maligned them in print, and he was ordered out. The colored steward was called to eject him, when he drew a revolver and threatened to shoot any white or black man who touched him.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Supreme Court of the United States will reassemble to-morrow after the February recess. Its session is looked forward to with more than usual interest and curiosity, for it is expected that the newly-appointed Associate Justice, Senator Edward D. White of Louisiana, will be present and take his seat.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 4 -- Richard Croker, the Tammany chief, was angry when a reporter to-day showed him published dispatches stating that Congressman Dunphy, in his letter of resignation, arraigned him as the instigator, promoter, rewarder, and upholder of fraudulent votes and election crimes in New-York.

The report from South Bend, Inc., that the University of Notre Dame is to present to Augustin Daly this year the Laetare Medal, which is annually bestowed on a prominent Catholic layman living in this country, will be the first intimation to many that the widely-known theatrical manager of New-York and London is a zealous member of the Catholic Church, who devotes almost as much time to his religious as to his managerial duties.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The pistols and sabres which men of the artillery arm have carried as a protection during charges and in close fighting will be taken away, and they must hereafter depend entirely upon a knife, shaped something like a dagger. This weapon will serve the double purpose of general utility about camp and as a slight means of self-protection in hand-to-hand encounters.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 4 -- Special Examiners Lee Chalmers and Lee Cowart have made a sensation in Federal court circles by their report to Attorney General Olney, just made. They charge North Alabama Commissioners and Deputy Marshals with employing professional witnesses and forging bogus witnesses' names to prosecutions, thus coining thousands of unearned dollars by fraud.

Our dispatches of yesterday showed that the Senate committee has made many important changes in the Wilson bill. The free list has been shortened and the duties on many manufactured goods have been reduced. The action taken by the committee with respect to coal and iron ore is to be deplored.

Leading lion tamers and menagerie proprietors have been making merry like ordinary people at the marriage of Mlle. Baptistine Pezon with her cousin. The wedding breakfast took place in the Salon des Familles near Vincennes, and M. Habert, a Deputy for the Seine-et-Olse, made a speech complimenting the bride and bridegroom and their famous family.

The prospects for a good 'Varsity baseball team at Columbia College this Spring are very bright. As the time draws near for the team to play its opening game the candidates train more and more faithfully, and the good effects of the training they have received during the last month and a half are beginning to show in superior work in all positions.

Articles between N. Steinitz, the champion chess player of the world, and Emanuel Lasker of Berlin were signed on Saturday. The match will be for the championship of the world and $2,000 a side. It will be a ten-games-up contest, draws not counting, and it will begin on March 15 in this city, to be continued at Philadelphia, and concluded in Montreal.

LONDON, March 4 -- The Queen will come to London to-morrow to give Lord Rosebery an audience in Buckingham Palace. Sir William Harcourt, Chancellor of the Exchequer; Earl Spencer. First Lord of the Admiralty, and Herbert Asquith, Home Secretary, called upon Lord Rosebery to-day.
Senator Lexow, Chairman of the committee appointed by the Senate to investigate the New-York Police Department, said yesterday that the committee would begin its work in earnest next Thursday.

Those who remember the "Oedipus" at Harvard in 1881 are looking forward with pleasurable anticipations to the performance of a Latin play there next month. There is a genuine artistic stimulus in a representation of a classic play, such as this promises to be, quite apart from its educational value, which is, of course, the main thing in the college.

Mr. Winsor's volume on Columbus, published a year ago, has an agreeable companion in this new work from the same hands. It takes up the great subject of American exploration at the point where Columbus ceased to labor, but as resumed by the French alone, the work performed by Spaniards and Englishmen having no place in Mr. Winsor's present narrative.

Some surprise and much regret were caused among the congregation of the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, when it became generally known yesterday that the Rev. Gouverneur Morris Wilkins, the assistant rector, had tendered his resignation. It was Mr. Wilkins's original intention to relinquish his present position on Feb. 1, but, at the request of the Vestry of Ascension Church, he consented to remain until Easter.
"The Penalties of Sin" was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's lecture yesterday in Music Hall, at Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue. A large and appreciative audience was present.

Some of our Republican contemporaries are reviewing the first year of President Cleveland's Administration, and they rise from the task weeping for their unfortunate country. One achievement alone of Mr. Cleveland's first year of office justifies the people's faith in his and entitles him to the gratitude of his country.

The auction offerings of realty to-day are rather more numerous and varied in character than is customary. A detailed list of these sales, all of which are to take place in the Trinity Building Salesroom at noon to-day, is subjoined:

An organized gang of young apartment-house thieves was arrested Saturday night by detectives, who had been detailed to watch for the depredators. The arrest of a youth a few days ago charged with petty larceny furnished the detectives with a clue which led to the capture of four of the gang. They are all boys.

The Columbia Library has been largely increased during the last eight months. The number of books added during the first six months of the college year ending with Dec. 31 is a little more than 7,000 volumes. Of these 1,600 volumes, including many large and valuable works, were added to the Avery Architectural Library, which now comprises the finest collection of works relating to architecture in the world.

WOODSIDE, L.I., March 4. -- The roadhouse of Edward Blanche, corner of Jackson Avenue and Fifth Street, this village, was the scene of a prize fight at 2 o'clock this morning. It was between William McGuire and John Thornton, two well-known lightweights. The men were just starting the fourth round when Deputy Sheriff William Alien and a posse of constables broke into the hall.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 4 -- The Lehigh Coal and Iron Company, which went into a receiver's hands in April, 1893, has been declared restored to solvency. Judge Jenkins of the United States Circuit Court yesterday entered an order discharging the receiver and directing that the estate be returned to the corporation.

MONDAY. March 5 -- A.M. Last week was the best of the year in respect to improvement in prices. Comparisons with the week preceding show advances both substantial and general. Every active stock had part in them. It may be early to say that a bull market is at hand, but the course of prices is not inconsistent with such a condition.

The eighth banquet of the veterans of the Irish Revolutionary Brotherhood was given last night in the Central Opera House, in East Sixty-seventh Street, in celebration of the twenty-seventh anniversary of the rising of the 5th of March, 1867. The dinner did not begin until 11 o'clock.

While the once mighty John T. McKane is languishing in the State's prison, the people whom he oppressed are in a happy frame of mind. They are working earnestly to undo the great wrongs that McKane heaped upon their tax-laden shoulders.

The Independent County Organization, of which John D. Townsend is Chairman, wants the Legislature to give New-York City a thorough overhauling and investigation of all of the departments of the Municipal Government. The organization claims the credit in large part of taking the initiative in the movement which has resulted in the appointment by the State Senate of a committee to investigate the New-York Police Department.

Three years ago, as the result of a long agitation and strenuous efforts, a commission was created to give this city the means of rapid transit, which were already sorely needed. So far as practical results are concerned, the city stands now where it stood then, but with the need still more sorely felt.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 4 -- The accidental discovery of a half-finished tunnel in the State prison to-day prevented the escape of a half-dozen noted convicts which would have occurred in a few days. The projector and chief spirit in the conspiracy to escape is George Dawley, received last March to serve a six-year sentence for forgery in Marion County.

The $5,000 which the Driving Club of New-York earned last Fall with their Grand Circuit meeting and the Directum matches will be used in a few weeks for the alterations and repairs which will be commenced forthwith. The fire last November destroyed forty stalls. These have to be rebuilt, partly at the expense of the club, and there are twenty-five or thirty new ones needed to bring the number to about 300.

The Grand Jury will probably investigate this week the charge that an attempt was made to tamper with witnesses as well as the actions of a juryman during the trial of James Donnelly for murder before Recorder Smyth in the Court of General Sessions. Donnelly was indicted for shooting Charles Madden in a saloon at Twenty-eighth Street and Eighth Avenue last May.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 4 -- On the committee for Founder's Day, which occurs April 27, have been appointed from the Faculty Prof. Leach. Dr. Moulton, Prof. Vandugen, and Prof. O'Grady, and from the students Misses Abby A. Vaillant and A.R. Macauley of '94, Susan Evans, '95; Jessie Hart, '96; Florence Hotchkiss, '97, and Edith Lapham, special.

Saturday evening at the Seventh Regiment Armory range was "handicap" night. Fifty-six of the competitors reached or passed the sixty-point mark, and of these no less than nine made the highest possible score at the 500-yard distance. Private J. W. Halstead made 69, only one short of the highest possible at both distances.

BERLIN. March 4. -- Gen. Bronsart von Schellendorff. Prussian War Minister, made a noteworthy speech on Friday against the Social Democrats. The cause was given by August Bebel, leader of the Social Democratic Party. Bebel, after denying that Socialists were always bad soldiers, said that in the next war many men without commissions would necessarily be called to fill the places of officers.

LEWISTON, Me., March 5 -- In the city election to-day, the Republicans elected Mayor, and carried five of seven wards in the city. In Auburn, Smith, (Rep.,) is elected Mayor, and the Aldermen are all Republicans.
In the billiard room of the Cogburn Club last evening one of the members remarked that he had not had a full night's rest the night before, and complained of feeling "all broken up."

WINFIELD, L.I., March 5 -- From the expressions of surprise and indignation heard in this village to-day, it is safe to say that no attempt will be made to repeat the crude but startling pantomime "passion play" produced in St. Mary's Hall last night.

Detective Joseph Bush of the East Fifth Street Station had a fierce fight yesterday afternoon with a gang of thirty east side thugs in Lewis Lesser's saloon, 526 East Fourteenth Street, only a block and a half from the spot where Edward Hogan received his death wound Sunday night at the hands of Charles Schaefer.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Mr. McCreary, Chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, presented the Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill to the House this morning.

At a lively meeting of the Executive Committee of the Kings County Prohibition Party, held last evening at 517 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, charges made against the Rev. Dr. I.K. Funk, editor of The Voice, for sending Schieren and Gaynor pasters to Prohibitionists during the last political campaign were considered.

Edward Hogan, an east side youth, paid the penalty of evil associations late on Sunday night, when he received his death wound at the hands of Charles Schaefer at Fourteenth Street and First Avenue. As reported in The New-York Times yesterday, Hogan died in Bellevue Hospital shortly, after 1 A.M.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- An experimental test of armor is to be made at the naval proving grounds this week. It is to be an attack under severe conditions of the first heavy Harveyized armor made in this country. The material comes from the Carnegie Works, and was prepared especially for the trial.
Mr. Thomas R. Farley has bought from George E. Lovett & Co., for $20,000, the property at 335 and 337 Bridge Street. A factory will be erected on the site.

NEW-YORK, Monday, March 5 -- P.M. The stock market took another forward stride to-day, making a brilliant record alike in the advances scored and in the volume of sales, and plus signs that mean something, that add to the substantial value of properties, and that reflect unmistakably genuine confidence in improving business conditions, make the day a notable one.

Our readers were informed by our San Antonio dispatches yesterday morning that Mr. Richard Croker was in a state of irritation and resentment over the account a reporter had given him of Mr. Dunphy's letter of resignation from Tammany Hall. The account was not strictly correct.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 5 -- Interest in the Italian settlers in this State is perceptibly increasing. In the principal cities these settlers are acquiring property and business more rapidly than has been supposed. They are co-operating in the establishment of churches of their own, and at the end of the Lenten season native priests will be settled at different points in the State for the purpose of organizing the religious enterprises in hand.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 5 -- The "Athens of America," as this city was called while the colonial government flourished, celebrated to-day its bi-centennial as the seat of State Government. The capital of the State was removed from St. Mary's to Annapolis 200 years ago. There was a parade at 1 o'clock this afternoon, and at 4 o'clock exercises were held under direction of St. John's College, in the Masonic Opera House.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- In the House to-day, on motion of Mr. Mallory, (Dem., Fla.,) a bill was passed amending the act authorizing the construction of a bridge across the East River, from New-York to Long Island, so that the lowest part of the bridge shall be not less than 127 feet above mean high water at Spring tide, instead of 142 feet.

CHARLESTON, West Va., March 5 -- The striking miners seem bent on destruction of property among the mines of the Kanawha Valley. They set fire to-day before sunrise to twenty-three coal cars standing on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway track at Paint Creek, and the cars were totally consumed.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 5 -- A.D. Gwynn and R.D. Morgan, Trustees, and W.J. Chase, receiver of The Memphis Appeal-Avalanche, filed a sensational bill in the Chancery Court and United States Court to-day against the Western Associated Press and The Memphis Evening Scimitar protesting against the action of the officers of the Associated Press in taking away from The Appeal-Avalanche the day franchise and giving it to The Scimitar.

The statements by the Assistant Secretary of the New-York Civil Service Reform Association, which we published yesterday, regarding the State service are not pleasant reading. It will be remembered that by the efforts of the association, and especially its Committee on Examinations, it was shown that a very large number of places in the State service were held illegally.

The jumping races to be decided at the Spring meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, closed on March 1, received liberal support from horsemen. The following number of entries were received for each stake: Grand national steeplechase, 48; bay hurdle race, 48; hurdle selling, 51; steeplechase selling, 55.
