WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Capt. N.H. Farguhar, Chief of the Naval Bureau of Yards and Docks, will leave this city to-morrow for his new post at the League Island Navy Yard. There is considerable speculation regarding his successor.

John L. Stoddard began the final week of his series of Lenten matinees at Daly's yesterday morning, when he unfolded the "Glories of the Heart of India," to an audience which packed the theatre to its full capacity. This final lecture proved, in some respects, the most interesting of the course of five, as it introduced the audience to the very heart of that great empire of 280,000,000 souls, over which England rules supreme.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The House spent an eventless day in Committee of the Whole, considering the Pension Appropriation bill. Toward the end of the session the monotony was broken somewhat by a tilt between Mr. Cannon and Mr. Black of Illinois, caused by the former making an attempt to have Gen. Black tell whether he was or was not in favor of Mr. Cleveland's pension policy while he was Commissioner of Pensions.

There is an architectural anomaly on West Fourteenth Street which, curiously enough, is closely related to another and absolutely dissimilar architectural anomaly on Broadway, just opposite Union Square.

Where lately the inebriate woes or Old Lavender were celebrated and the mystery of the Leather Patch was solved, in Harrigan's Theatre, Pauline Hall and her company last night began an engagement. They appeared in what was once an opera bouffe, with music by Jacques Offenbach. The music is still there, but it is like Bottom, much translated.

If the various charitable institutions of this city which on previous occasions have received money from the Citizens' Relief Committee expected to be voted more funds at the meeting of the Distributing Committee of the Citizens' Relief Committee yesterday in the office of Treasurer J. Pierpont Morgan, they must have been sadly disappointed when the meeting was over.

ALBANY, March 5 -- There is more trouble over the police investigation. The Senators who were in New-York City Sunday and talked with Thomas C. Platt about the investigation and the Police bill were in their places at to-night's session. Those of them who are members of the Investigation Committee are not inclined to discuss the trouble for publication, but some of it has been made public.

ALBANY, March 5 -- There will be no bipartisan Boards of Inspectors at the election which will be held in Troy to-morrow. Gov. Flower refused to sign the bill, which was rushed through the Legislature last week, and no new bill was mentioned in either branch to-night. The ground on which Gov. Flower withheld his signature was that the bill was imperfectly drawn.

RONDOUT, March 5 -- When Paymaster James A. King of the wrecked corvette Kearsarge left New-York several days ago for Coxsackie, where his wife lives with her mother, Mrs. Loomis, he took with him a young bootblack, whom he had "picked up" in New-York.

LONDON, March 5 -- The Queen, accompanied by ex-Empress Frederick and Princess Beatrice, arrived at Buckingham Palace this morning. The royal speech proroguing Parliament is unusually brief. It expresses formally regret at the shortness of the recess, releasing members from their labors, and thanks Parliament for its various enactments, among them the Parish Councils bill and the bill limiting the working hours of railway employes.

The Brooklyn Young Republican Club held a symposium last evening at the Johnston Building, Flatbush Avenue and Nevins Street. The subject of the discussion was "The Proposed Greater New-York; Is It Desirable for Brooklyn?"

It is refreshing, now and then, to find evidence to sustain the theory that melodrama is a perfectly legitimate, if not particularly high, form of dramatic construction, and that it does not necessarily presuppose the abandonment by the author of common sense and possibilities in favor of gush and miracles.

Joseph Brewster Coe, who for nearly a quarter of a century had served as a clerk in the Court of Common Pleas, was found dead yesterday morning in a vacant lot twenty feet below the street level, at One Hundred and Fifthteenth Street and Fifth Avenue, not more than twenty steps from his home.

TRENTON, N.J., March 5 -- The argument in the quo warranto proceeding to determine which of the two bodies calling themselves Senates is the legal Senate of New-Jersey, which was to begin before the Supreme Court this forenoon, was adjourned until next Thursday on suggestion of the counsel, who intimated that, owing to lack of conferences between themselves, they were not ready to proceed.

SING SING, March 6 -- Warden Durston of Sing Sing Prison said this evening that John Y. McKane was getting along very well. No change has been made in his work. He seems to be learning his duties in the clothing industry.

BUFFALO, March 5 -- Gebhard Lewis Mayer, the divinity student expelled from the Baptist Theological Seminary at Newton, Mass., because he had two wives, came to this city last Friday and crossed the river to Victoria, Ontario, where Wife No. 2 was staying with her sister, Mrs. Louise Wenz. There he was found yesterday and reluctantly consented to talk about his case.

New-York can boast of a Midway Plaisance of its own, and a good one. The Metropolitan Midway is a reproduction of the Chicago attraction, the only difference being that the one opened in the Madison Square Garden last night is built of stage scenery. All the features of the Chicago exhibition are in the Garden, so that to one who had visited the World's Fair it would seem that the Chicago Midway had been transplanted.

BUFFALO, March 5 -- After more than two years of the wandering life of a "wanted" criminal, Harry C. Wiltshaw, alias Harry C. Watkins, of New-York, occupies a felon's cell in the Erie County Jail. He was arrested Saturday evening as he was stepping from a train from the East at the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western station.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Some of Tammany's foes were busy last night passing resolutions. The anti-Tammany Democracy, made up of ex-Sheriff James O'Brien, ex-Senator Langbein, exSenator Bixby, and others, met and resolved to issue an address to the voters of the City and County of New-York.

The special election for Supervisor of the Eighth Ward, Brooklyn, occurs to-day. The campaign has been the liveliest ever conducted for a ward office in that city. Both parties attach great importance to the result.

CAPE TOWN, March 5 -- A trader from the Shangani River district, who has arrived at Buluwayo, states that he found within a radius of fifty feet, at a point where the party under command of Capt. Wilson are suppesed to have made their last stand before being massacred by the Matabeles, the bones of thirty-three men.

The Rev. Dr. A.C. Dixon began preaching at a series of evangelistic revival meetings in the Thirty-fourth Street Reformed Dutch Church, of which the Rev. Peter Stryker is pastor, last night. The church was filled with the congregations of twelve other churches, which have united in holding the meetings with Dr. Stryker's church.

The services at the funeral of William H. Osborn, ex-President of the Illinois Central Railroad, which took place at the family residence, 32 Park Avenue, yesterday, were marked with, extreme simplicity.

Sorosis has a new President. Mrs. Fanny I. Helmuth, wife of William Tod Helmuth, the surgeon, was elected to the office yesterday, after an exciting contest, by only ten majority. Over a score of officers were elected, all told, but the entire interest of the occasion centred in the office of President.

Out of the original seventy-five cases against election officials for violation of the election laws, only ten remained to be tried when Justice Barrett opened the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning. The greater number of these were for trivial violations of the law, in comparison with the cases that have been decided.

Year after year, for ten years at least, the newspapers of New-York and Brooklyn have been calling attention to the Brooklyn Watershed. Its condition is scarcely less inimical to public health than was the Croton Watershed before Commissioner Daly of New-York City made his raids through that region a year ago.
There was an interesting controversy yesterday between President George B. McClellan of the Board of Aldermen and President Tappen of the Park Department.

Of course, the retirement of Mr. Gladstone is a very great blow to the Liberal Party in Great Britain. It is especially disastrous to the prospects of the immediate or the near triumph of home rule. Probably no reflective Englishman any longer doubts that the ultimate triumph of home rule is inevitable.

Yielding to the appeals of demagogues and the influences exerted by the pension claim agents, Congress has passed a law that will compel the Commissioner of Pensions to pay about $500,000 to persons who are not entitled to the money, persons whose names have been put on the pension rolls by fraud.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 -- Mr. Bijur, counsel for Mr. Isaac L. Rice in the proceeding for the removal of the Reading receivers, spent two hours this morning before Special Master Crawford in presenting the features of the case which bear particularly on matters pertaining to the Lehigh Valley lease and the action of the receivers in connection with the same.

TRENTON, N.J., March 5 -- The investigation by the Elections Committee of the House of the methods by which William J. Thompson was returned as a member from the Third Camden District will begin tomorrow, presumably with the counting of the ballots. The committee sat this afternoon to receive the ballot boxes and the registry lists.

Prof. J. Leonard Corning gave an illustrated lecture at Hardman Hall, Fifth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, yesterday afternoon on "Mortality and Its Symbols in Pagan and Christian Art." It was the third discourse in a course of five by Prof Corning on "Art Studies in Comparative Religions."

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 5 -- The officials of the Carnegie Steel Company positively refuse to make any statement concerning the charges that workmen were implicated in a conspiracy against the corporation. Question after question has been asked Chairman Frick and Secretary Lovejoy, but the only reply from either gentleman was, "I have nothing to say."

W. Shinn, a citizen of Picua, Ohio, has made a claim for $1,000,000,000 against the City of New-York. His claim is made in a letter received by the Corporation Counsel yesterday. The letter is as follows:
ALBANY, N.Y., March 5 -- A sub-committee of the Finance and Ways and Means Committees met this afternoon and began the investigation of the State Commissions.

At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, to be held in Philadelphia to-day, the forty-seventh annual report will be presented. From advance sheets of this report it is learned that for the year 1893 the gross earnings of all Pennsylvania lines, east and west of Pittsburg, were $135,059,787, operating expenses $95,491,558, and net earnings $39,568,228.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- What is generally regarded as the first move of the Republican Senators to delay action in the Senate on the tariff bill was made to-day.

"Mrs. Dascot," by Lloyd Bryce, editor of The North American Review, and Stanislaus Stange, an actor, is an ill-conceived, ill-made, frittering, tedious, and offensive play, that was produced by Kathrine Clemmons, with the help of two capable actors and some others, at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night.

The evangelistic meetings being held in the large hall of the Young Men's Christian Association, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, were started upon the third week yesterday, under the most flattering conditions. The hall was filled with an earnest and attentive audience. On the platform were seated many of the city pastors and the singers.

The Kearsarge naval court of Inquiry is rapidly nearing the end of its labors. Today will probably see its final adjournment. So far as public interest is concerned, it has neared the end by steps progressively diminishing. The latter part of the investigation has been little more than a series of repetitions of what has gone before.

TROY, N.Y., March 5 -- The political prestige of "Boss" Murphy is trembling in the balance. To-morrow will decide his fate, and the indications are that he is doomed to defeat. For years he has ruled with an iron hand, and any man in public life who dared to go contrary to his wishes has been promptly marked as a fit subject for political slaughter.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 5. -- G.M. Rollins and Capt. Sturgis of the Norwegian steamship Santuit died from yellow fever to-day.

The Rev. Dr. David H. Greer's newly established "loan bureau" is now certain of at least a year's life. If things go as smoothly as the doctor feels certain they will, this year of life will be extended indefinitely, and the "loan bureau" will become one of the great established institutions of New-York, out of which the working people will derive much comfort and profit.

BERLIN, March 5. -- In the Reichstag today there was an interesting debate on the Military Supply bill. In the course of the discussion Gen. Bronsart von Schellendorf, Minister of War, took occasion to defend Gen. von Kirchoff from the attacks of the Socialists. Gen. von Schellendorf declared that if Gen. von Kirchoff had been tried by a jury instead of by a military court, whose proceedings were secret, he would have been acquitted.

During the examination of the jurors in the McKane trial the fact leaked out that the prosecuting attorneys believed most of, if not all, the jurors summoned had been called upon after they had been served with the jury notices. The jurors were asked if they had been visited by any person after they had received their notices.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 5 -- When the United States Circuit Court was convened by Judge Bruce to-day, District Attorney O'Neil made a motion to quash the Grand Jury venire because illegally drawn. The motion was not granted. The same motion is expected when the petit juries are organized in the morning.
Information was received from Berlin yesterday by the Northern Pacific Bondholders' Committee on Reorganization that German holders of $7,049,000 bonds had signed the preliminary agreement.

Several Republican State Senators, including Mr. Lexow, Chairman of the special committee appointed to investigate the Police Department of this city, were in consultation with Thomas C. Platt at the Fifth Avenue Hotel on Sunday. After the conference it was announced by those who professed to know what it was about that the passage of the Bi-Partisan Police Commission bill was "assured beyond doubt."

A newspaper that cannot obtain and retain subscribers on its merits as a newspaper isn't worth buying or worth reading. How many persons who buy a newspaper to obtain some kind of a coupon take the pains to read the paper itself? How great a value to advertisers has a newspaper circulation founded on its premium, list?

CHICAGO, March 6 -- There was hope in the hearts of the wheat bulls at the opening to-day that a cold wave which was discerned on the weather map in the neighborhood of Mennedosa would succeed in making its way into the Winter wheat belt, but when the Government Weather Bureau sent out indications for warmer weather they experienced disappointment.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Ex-Speaker Sulzer this morning introduced a "personal registration" bill in the House. It is essentially like the one which was considered at length, passed by the Assembly, and killed by the Senate last Winter. It applies to the entire State providing that all voters shall register before each election.

Manager Dexter of the Boston Grand Opera House, whose stock company is to present "Rosalie" at the Star Theatre next week, advertised in The New-York Times on Sunday for sixty "society ladies and gentlemen" to appear in the ballroom scene of the play. Applicants were to report on the stage of the Star Theatre at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

Messrs. J.R. Keene and J.O. Donner and Col. Thompson of the Jockey Club, and B. L. Kirkman, President of the Western Turf Congress, and L.P. Tarlton had a conference in the club's rooms in the Cumberland, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, yesterday afternoon. The object of the conference was to try and arrange that the new club should be a National Jockey Club, and should govern the racing on the tracks East and West.

The murder or a Republican watcher at the polls in the Thirteenth Ward in Troy yesterday was an extreme but natural consequence of Senator Murphy's principles and practice in politics. He is the "Boss" of that town and a person of authority in the State machine.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- For an hour and a half before business began on the Stock Exchange to-day, strong Eastern, quotations denoted the bullish feeling in New-York, making it obvious that local prices would be stimulated thereby. The first sale in West Chicago was at 148, the second at 143 5/3, and the third at 144.

TRENTON, N.J., March 6 -- The House Committee on Elections this afternoon began the work of investigating the election of William J. Thompson familiarly known as the "Duke of Gloucester," who represents the Third District of Camden County in the House of Assembly. His seat is contested by Jacob C. Lippincott, Republican, who alleges that Thompson's election was the result of fraud and corruption at the polls.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The wonderful flurry in sugar in New-York to-day caused a good deal of excitement among speculators in this city, some of whom have had their eyes on sugar in the last week, though none of them is known to have been heavily loaded up with that commodity.
When Dr. Chauncey M. Depew waxes sarcastic, it is well worth a man's while to listen attentively. Yesterday was one of the occasions.

Col. George B. McClellan, President of the Board of Aldermen, who is Acting Mayor during Mayor Gilroy'a absence, received a ten-thousand-dollar check from William Waldorf Astor yesterday. The check was Mr. Aster's contribution to the Citizens' Relief Fund for the unemployed poor, and it and $200 sent by J. Ottman were turned over to J. Pierpont Morgan, Treasurer of the Citizens' Relief Committee.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 6 -- Four men out of a gang of mine-shaft sinkers were killed in the Richmond shaft, in the northern part of the city, this morning at 5 o'clock. The accident was caused by the fall of a shelf of rock from the side of the shaft, near the bottom, and a consequent explosion of a blower of gas.

Secretary Sullivan of the Amateur Athletic Union and Chairman Raymond of the League of American Wheelmen have settled the question regarding the Class A ride at athletic meetings. Mr. Raymond wrote to the Amateur Athletic Union Secretary, saying that clubs giving bicycle races at their athletic games could take their choice as to whether the events would be open to Class A or Class B.

Mayor Schieren appears to have given extensive offense to the representatives in Brooklyn of several Irish societies and to the societies represented by hesitating to comply with their demand that the Irish flag should be hoisted on the City Hall on St. Patrick's Day. The Mayor has added to this offense by declining to attend, in his official capacity, the dinner arranged in celebration of the day.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The House to-day debated the Pension Appropriation bill under an agreement to close general debate at 3 o'clock to-morrow. Speeches were made by Messrs. Sickles and Coombs, (Dems., N.Y.,) Milliken, (Rep., Me.,) Grosvenor, (Rep., Ohio,) Blair, (Rep., N.Y.,) and Mahon, (Rep., Penn.)

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- There continues to be considerable doubt regarding the exact time when the Tariff bill will be reported. The Democratic members of the Senate Finance Committee have put in another day on the measure, but they are apparently no nearer a conclusion than they were last night.

[From The Metropolis, New-York.] Dr. Robert Hunter, the prominent New-York physician, of 117 West 45th Street, as born at Headon, England, June, 14, 1826, and is descended from the LongCalderwood branch of the Hunters of Hunterson, Ayrshire, Scotland, which gave to the medical profession the famous surgeons, John and William Hunter of England.

Walter Fisher, sixteen years old, who was on the box seat of the cab which ran over Mrs. Esther Knapp of 251 West Forty-second Street on Monday evening at Fortyfifth Street and Eighth Avenue, was held for trial without bail, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning.

Julius C. Lulley, who succeeded Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan as Secretary of the Aqueduct Commission, and who was a protege of Senator David B. Hill, committed suicide some time between 12 o'clock Sunday noon and midnight on Monday, in his room, at 34 West Twenty-fifth Street, a boarding house.
TROY, N.Y., March 7 -- Returns of the election from all districts are in and show Malloy's plurality to be 528. It is likely a contest will be made by Mayor Whelan on grounds of gross frauds.
The following plans of new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, March 6 -- P.M. Temptation to take profits after yesterday's sharp rally was too strong to be resisted to-day. The natural reaction did not set in, however, until afternoon, when it spread throughout the active list. It resulted in the loss of only part of yesterday's good work, and had apparently exhausted itself before business for the day closed.

BRUSSELS, March 6 -- The suit of Col. Lee, an American inventor of firearms, against Herr von Mannlicher, whose rifle is in use in the German Army, is about to be reopened. Col. Lee brought suit against Herr von Mannlicher in 1891, claiming that the Mannlicher gun was an infringement upon patents of his own. Owing to the Colonel's refusal to pay the required security to carry on the suit, the action was dropped.

Maurice Firestone, a switch cleaner, of Madison, Kan., began hiccoughing about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and the spasms, at the rate of thirty hiccoughs a minute, racked his body until at a late hour last night Dr. Matthias Nichol succeeded in stopping them in the Chambers Street Hospital.

The Superintendent of Immigration recently made a curious discovery in Massachusetts, where it was found that several insane and pauper immigrants, who had been insane when they arrived this country, were being supported in the asylums of the State at the expense of the Federal Government, although they had been in this country for nearly a year.

BOSTON, Maroh 6 -- Our market has been in a measure paralyzed by the Sugar pyrotechnics. Excepting that stock, Bay State Gas has been the most active, with fluctuations between 13 1/4 and 14. Chicago Junction preferred sold at 95, with no quotation on the common. There has been some movement in Mexican Centrals at slightly advanced figures, based on the better net results from President Robinson's management.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 6 -- Detective McNally found two more "green-goods" victims here this afternoon. They were discovered at the usual trysting place, the New-Jersey Central Railroad Station, and were anxiously fondling a common pasteboard box.

"You had better put me out if you do not want me," said Superintendent Byrnes sharply to President Martin of the Police Board yesterday, while Capt. Frederick W. Martens of the East Thirtyfifth Street Police Station was being tried for neglect of duty in not suppressing disorderly houses in his district.
Pocketbook dropping was revived in Harlem yesterday, but all of the principals came to grief and were paraded in the Harlem Police Court before Justice Simms.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The question whether the Bland bill shall be referred to the Finance Committee or be taken up without that formality and discussed will probably be decided by the Senate to-morrow. It was expected that the test would come to-day, but owing to the desire of Mr. Teller to discuss the financial situation, the question was postponed.

A motion in behalf of Timothy Sullivan, a plumber, was made yesterday before Judge Ingraham, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, for a resale of the Hotel de Logerot, at Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street. This hotel was sold on Jan. 26 last in foreclosure proceedings, for $437,000, and it is claimed that a much higher price could be got at a resale.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners met yesterday at their rooms, 22 William Street. Among those present were Lawyer Albert L. Lauterbach, who made a proposition two months ago to secure the franchise for a syndicate of American and English capitalists, and Lawyer John Murray Mitchell, who was sent to present a protest on the part of property owners in Fourteenth Street against running the proposed road through that street.
Wheat advanced with the West and on better cables, fell through local realizing, rallied on covering, and closed steady at 1/4 @ 1/2 c advance, with trading quiet.

Ida Van Etten, the first Secretary of the Working Women's Society, died of cardiac trouble in the Continental Hotel, Paris, on Monday. The report of her death adds that her end was hastened by privation. Her remains have been placed in the mortuary chapel of the American Church, by direction of Mr. Eustis, the United States Ambassador, who has notified Miss Van Etten's friends and awaits their action.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Ex-Congressman Rufus S. Frost of Massachusetts died suddenly this afternoon in a private car in the Santa Fe station. Mrs. Frost, a physician, and a business representative were the only ones present.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Owing to the lack of a quorum and to the wide divergence of sentiments expressed, the Democratic caucus, which was called to-night, met and adjourned without definite action being taken upon the proposition to devise some method by which a quorum may be maintained in the House.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 6 -- At the city election here to-day Eron C. Vankirk, Republican, polled 1,275 votes for Recorder against 1,246 cast for the Democratic candidate, and 98 for the Prohibitionist. Fred L. Clock, Republican, polled 1,369 against his Democratic opponent's 1,168 for City civil Justice.

A general lack of bidding marked the sales yesterday in the Trinity Building Salesroom. Only two of the sales, by Adrian H. Muller Son, were voluntary offerings. These included the five-story brick double tenement 532 West Ftftyeighth Street, between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues, 25 by 100.5, which sold for only $9,400 to A.W. Seaman.

Judge Truax, in Part II. of the Special Term, Supreme Court, heard part of the arguments in the triangular contest over the will of Daniel B. Fayerweather yesterday. The evidence was submitted a month ago.

Augustus C. Fischer, the Independent and Republican candidate for Supervisor of the Eighth Ward, Brooklyn, was elected yesterday by a plurality of 125 votes over Charles A. Krombach, the "regular" Democratic candidate.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The House Committee on the Judiciary gave a hearing to-day on the resolution of Mr. Morse which declares that God should be recognized in the Constitution. Many were present from Ohio, Pennsylvania. New-Jersey, New-York, and Massachusetts. The most of these were women and clergymen.

There was a discussion yesterday before Surrogate Fitzgerald over the request of George Wilkes to be made guardian of the person and estate of his sister, Alicia Wilkes, who is about thirteen years old. They are the adopted children of George Wilkes, who was proprietor of The Spirit of the Times, and who died about ten years ago, leaving a large estate.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6. -- A noisy reception was accorded the battle ship Indiana this morning as she left Cramps' shipyard for her preliminary or builders' trial trip. Every whistle afloat and ashore in the vicinity of the shipyard was tooting and bells were clanging their loudest. The din continued until the war ship was beyond the city limits.
[From The London Lancet.] By H. Melville, M.R.C.S.E., late Professor of Surgery, Trinity College.

Mrs. Frederick Glasson was suffocated last night by smoke from a fire which did considerable damage to the top floor of the four-story tenement house at 433 West Thirty-sixth Street. One of her children was found unconscious by her side. Her husband and their four other children were rescued.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- There was a good tone to the market at the opening and a disposition on the part of traders to bid prices up. The jump in Sugar alarmed the shorts somewhat, and when it was selling, according to the tape, at 90, an order was sent to New-York to sell 500 at the market price, and the price realized was 93.

ALBANY, March 6 -- If some resolutions adopted by the committee which is charged with the New-York City Police investigation mean what they seem to mean, the investigation will begin promptly, and be a thorough one.

SING SING, March 6 -- While Car 11 on the Assining Trolley Railroad was coming down Central Avenue this morning, having on board half a dozen passengers, the brakes failed to hold. As the grade was steep, the heavy car ran down it at a high rate of speed. At the foot of the hill the car left the rails and ran into an awning.

The election for Supervisor in the Eighth Ward of Brooklyn yesterday resulted in the election of Mr. Fischer, the candidate of the anti-machine Democrats, by a small but sufficient plurality. It was a most important victory, because in the struggle was practically involved the last stronghold of the McLaughlin ring in Kings County politics -- the Board of Supervisors, which would have fallen into its hands had its candidate been successful.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The report of the State Civil Service Commission for 1893 has been submitted to the Legislature. It reviews the operation, of the civil service law for the past ten years, and shows that the practice since the commission has been organized of changing positions from the competitive to the non-competitive class has been general since the administration of the law by the first commission.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 6 -- The officials of the Carnegie Steel Company, Limited, decline to talk about the conspiracy alleged to have been the final cause of its payment of $140,434.31 to the Government as damages for delivering inferior plate. When the names of the supposed conspirators were shown the officials to-day they would not say whether they were correct or otherwise.

The recently-elected Executive Committee of the American Hunt and Pony Racing Association held its first meeting yesterday at the offices of the organization, 32 Broad Street. The new Chairman, S.S. Howland, presided, and the others present were Secretary F.M. Ware, E. Willard Roby, F.T. Underbill, J.R. Wood, J.T. Hyde, E.C. Potter, C. Pfizer, H.A. Buck, Frank Mather, and E.N. Nichols.

The unprecedented fluctuations in the price of Sugar stock yesterday created an unusual stir in Wall Street. Inside of fiftyfive minutes quotations on the stock of the American Sugar Refining Company went up from 88 to 100, and then dropped to 91. No such fluctuations have ever been recorded on any stock in the same length of time.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Cleveland is back in Washington again, looking hearty and ruddy, and showing in many ways the good effect of his outing in the Violet. The little vessel reached her wharf at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon, having been absent nine days.

Mrs. Mary Hemenway. Mrs. Mary Hemenway, widow of Augustus Hemenway, died yesterday in her home, 40 Mount Vernon Street, Boston, Mass. She was the daughter of Thomas Tileston, a wealthy merchant of this city. Her husband, who died more than ten years ago, was one of Boston's greatest business men.

Here is a story about a wedding journey that was attended by great good luck. Willis Holly, Mayor Gliroy's private secretary and chief clerk, and his bride left this city Feb. 3, the day of their marriage, and in the course of their journey they had many narrow escapes from accidents, train robbers, landslides, and snow blockades.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 6 -- At the baseball conference between Yale and Harvard representatives in Springfield, Mass., yesterday, an agreement was entered Into by the two colleges which absolutely disposes of all the questions about the series of games for this year. It was decided by the representatives present not to divulge the proceedings of the convention till the athletic committees of both universities had been consulted.
Permits have been granted for the erection of the following new buildings and for the making of the following alterations to buildings in Brooklyn:
If you are getting thin, you are sick, though you may not know it.

CULLMAN, Ala., March 6 -- The destruction of this town by fire was prevented early this morning by a heavy rain. The fire started at 10 o'clock last night in York's livery stable, and before the flames were extinguished the entire business portion of the town, including McMinn's Opera House and twenty stores, was destroyed.
The Loan Relief Association held its seventeenth annual meeting last night at the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifty-filth Street and Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The Senate had its liveliest incident of the session since the unseating of Mr. McCarty, in an exchange of personalities between Mr. Bradley and Mr. Coffey of Brooklyn this forenoon. The outbreak occurred over Mr. Bradley's bill, which proposes to legislate out of office the present Brooklyn Bridge Trustees.

The latest returns from the election in Iroy, though imperfect, indicate the election of Malloy, Murphy's candidate for Mayor, by a plurality of some 581. There is not much room for doubt that this is fraudulent. The normal Democratic majority in Troy is not easily calculated.

The commercial exchanges which are instrumental in marketing the great staple products of the country are once more trying to defeat that compound of ignorance and demagogy, the Hatch Anti-Option bill. The bill now in the hands of the House committee is not quite the same as that which passed the House and was postponed in the Senate during the last Congress, but it is based on the same fallacious notions.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- The closing argument in the examination of the Rice petition for the removal of the Reading receivers was heard to-day before Special Master Crawford. Mr. Dickson, counsel for the receivers was not present, the duty of watching the interests of the receivers devolving upon Mr. Thomas Hart, Jr., his associate.

For more than a month the Wilson bill has been withheld from the Senate by the Senate committee to which it was referred. This committee has already consumed more time in the consideration of a measure which came to it in complete form and with the general purpose of which it was in sympathy than was consumed by the House in the debate which preceded the passage of the bill by that body.

There was much discussion in Brooklyn yesterday over the charges of "jury fixing" published in a local newspaper Monday. The charges, as printed, were very, circumstantial. They professed to be founded on something besides vague rumor. Their author, in the article containing them, put them in the following form:

From The Brooklyn Citizen of yesterday. We see that one of our local contemporaries which has been systematically engaged in the work of bulldozing jurors and judges, pretends to have evidence that an attempt was made to tamper with the jurors in the McKane case, and, that there was successful tampering with the jurors who recently refused to convict Sutherland.

FAYETTEVILLE, West Va., March 6 -- Interest in the coal miners' strike centres in Fayettevllle. It is believed that an attempt will be made by the strikers to-night or to-morrow to rescue friends confined in jail here and to get possession of Wyant, the official whom they have sworn to kill. In anticipation of an attack, two Gatling guns have been brought here, one from the armory at the State House and one from Moundsville.

The Central Committee of ministers who are conducting evangelistic meetings in Association Hall began yesterday morning a campaign of outdoor meetings in the square in front of Dr. Parkhurst's church, in Madison Avenue. Before the meeting was begun, members of the Workers' Band went through Madison Square Park and invited all whom they met to attend the services.

LONDON, March 6 -- Lord Rosebery to-day took possession of the offices in the official residence in Downing Street set apart for the use of the Premier. Mr. Gladstone was present when Rosebery arrived at the rooms and gave him a cordial welcome.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- There was a particularly ridiculous performance in the Chamber to-day which illustrated perfectly the sensitiveness of public men to criticism, no matter how absurd that criticism may be. A New-York paper with more enterprise than knowledge of public affairs printed this morning the pictures of nine Democratic Senators whom it represented to be standing in the way of the speedy report of the Tariff bill to the Senate.

-- Gorgo, the pride of the late Senator Hearst, foaled a colt to the speedy Racine, and has been bred to the unbeaten English horse Ormonde. Should the foal prove a colt, Mr. Macdonough, who owns the sire, will have it, if a filly the Stanford estate will keep it. This is according to an arrangement by which these Palo Alto mares, Fairy Rose, Flirt, Amelia, Cornelia, Getaway.

BOSTON, March 7 -- The case of the American Bell Telephone Company, on the petition for an increase of capital to $30,000,000, was presented to the legislative Committee on Mercantile Affairs by exGov. Long to-day. Mr. Long said the company had outgrown its capital stock.

ALBANY, March 7 -- There was another breeze in the Senate to-day when Senator Bradley's (Ind. Dem., Kings,) bill legislating the Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge out of office came up for passage. Senator Coffey (Dem., Kings,) wanted the bill recommitted, and Senator Cantor (Dem., NewYork,) objected to removing men from office upon charges of dishonesty unless the charges were shown to be true.

The blanket-ballot bills were recommitted in the Assembly yesterday, and the Judiciary Committee was empowered to report them back at any time. The object is to tinker over the paster provision some more. There seems to be a disposition on the part of the Republican majority in the Assembly to discard the whole paster business and provide simply for an official blanket ballot upon which the choice of the voter must be marked.
Quarter Back Vail of the Pennsylvania University team recently witnessed a "tie" game of association football between the Cosmopolitan and Philadelphia Clubs. He wrote a report of the game, and said:

BOSTON, March 7 -- Alderman Martin B. Lomasney was shot at noon to-day just outside the Aldermanic chamber in the City Hall by James H. Dunan. Dunan fired five shots from a revolver. One shot took effect in the Alderman's leg. The other bullets went astray. Dunan was immediately arrested.

BOSTON, March 7 -- Local securities were inactive and there was no special feature to the market. There was little talk on the street, and no interest was shown in the purely local stocks. Bell Telephone was steady at 169, with New-England Telephone at 49 1/2. Lamson Store Service sold at 18, an advance of 1/4 over the last sale.

Senator McPherson of New-Jersey declares with commendable frankness that he is responsible for the delay in reporting the Tariff bill to the Finance Committee of the Senate. He appears equally frank as to his motive. He thought "certain duties" too low, and he has been trying to get them made higher.

The annual report of President Seth Low to the Trustees of Columbia College, covering the work of the college in all its departments during the academic year ending June 30, 1893, has just been issued. In connection with it are the reports of the heads of the various departments of the college and the report of the Librarian.

A large audience, entirely filling the assembly hall of the Academy of Medicine, in West Forty-third Street, last evening listened to a lecture in the interest of "The Modern Portia" by Miss Phoebe W. Couzins before the woman's law class of the University of the City of New-York.
Adolf Albin of Vienna beat Eugene Delmar in the seventh and final game of the chess match at the Manhattan Chess Club, and, as the winner thereby registered his fifth victory, he won the match.

Whether the fatal shot at the polling place in Troy on Tuesday was fired by a Republican watcher or by a Murphy "worker," a point which seems to be in dispute, there is no doubt about the cause of the disturbance which resulted in manslaughter. It was due to the efforts of repeaters to get in fraudulent votes, and was instigated by a Murphy "heeler" named Shea.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- The market continued its upward course. West Chicago opened at 145 and advanced to 146 1/2, without much stock coming out. At 147 1/2, however, transactions were very heavy, but when demand ceased the price eased off to 146 1/2. In the afternoon it moved up to 149 3/4. North Chicago was moderately traded in at 5 points over yesterday's figures.

-- At a meeting of the colored cyclists of Boston letters were read by the Secretary of the meeting from various other colored members of the League of American Wheelmen, all of whom expressed extreme indignation at the League of American Wheelmen. The club commended Representative Robert T. Teamoh for the resolutions presented by him to the Massachusetts Legislature, which deprecate this discrimination on the part of the League of American Wheelmen.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Herman Clarke, who made a name for himself which no one begrudged him, as a principal in the firm of La Montagne, Clarke Co., which dissolved last Summer after the smash in National Cordage, was in urgent demand yesterday by his associates in his new firm of Hunter, Clarke Jacob, brokers, at 51 Exchange Place.

TROY, N.Y., March 7 -- Hoosick elected the entire Repubican ticket to-day. This will give the Republicans 17 of the Board of Supervisors to 12 Democrats. Last year the Board was: Democrats, 18; Republicans, 11.

BOSTON, March 7 -- Charles O.F. Norlander, alias Carl Norlander, alias Charles N. Gylenhammer, a Swede, wanted by the Brooklyn (N.Y.) police to answer a charge of larceny of $1,300, is under arrest in this city, and will be detained until the arrival of police from New-York.

A notable purchase of real estate announced yesterday was by the American Tract Society, which has bought the building of Banks Brother on Nassau Street, adjoining its own property. The price paid for the property was about $75,000. The plot acquired measures 21.1 by 47 by 22.11 by 46.10, or about 1,000 square feet, making, therefore, a rate of about $75 per square foot.

Within a week some rather peculiar transactions affecting trial juries have been brought to notice. In the Donnelly case, where murder was charged. It was asserted that when the jury retired the twelve men indulged in considerable frivolous talk, and some of them acted in a manner not in keeping with the serious task they had sworn to perform.

Col. Tom Ochiltree, carrying a ponderous cane with a sweeping crook, was complainant in the Court of General Sessions yesterday against James F. Lynch, his former nurse, whom he charged with appropriating a lot of property, including a gold watch, a betting book, a roll of bills, an overcoat, and an umbrella that cost L5 in London.

-- The Pennsylvania University will have a grand athletic field. Plans have been announced which provide for the inclosing of the square known as Franklin Field, bounded by Thirtysecond, Thirty-third, Marsten, and Scott Streets, Philadelphia. The property to which the athletic grounds are to be moved was given by the Trustees to the Athletic Association, and is valued at $150,OOO.

The game of whist has been having a quiet but unmistakable, revival not only in this city, but in other parts of the country, this Winter. The youngest organization in New-York which devotes itself entirely to the game is the Knickerbocker Whist Club, whose rooms are in the Hotel Wellington Annex, at Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street.
All the arguments in the triangular contest over the residuary estate of Daniel B. Fayerweather were finished yesterday before Judge Truax in Part II. of the Special Term, Supreme Court.

The trial of Policeman Hugh McPartland of the West Thirtieth Street Station, who created a disgraceful scene in the Continental Hotel on Friday night by appearing in the dining room helplessly drunk, was postponed yesterday by Commissioner MacLean until to-day. Capt. Schmittberger stated that since McPartland reported sick on Friday night he could not be found at his home, and the papers containing the charges could not be served upon him until Monday night.
NEW-YORK, Wednesday, March 7 -- P. M. Sugar, although it fluctuated widely and was heavily traded in as compared with yesterday, was comparatively quiet to-day.

At a meeting of the Brooklyn Temperance League, held last Sunday in the Union Assembly Rooms, in South Third Street, near Bedford Avenue, John Wagner Pritchard, who was introduced as the editor and publisher of The Christian Nation, a weekly religious newspaper, attacked the Sunday press of this city with surprising vigor.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- General debate on the Pension Appropriation bill was closed at 3 o'clock to-day, and for two hours longer it was considered under the fiveminute rule. Then, at 5:15 o'clock, it was passed substantially as reported by the Committee on Appropriations. The most notable feature of the discussion was a denunciation of ex-Commissioner Black by Representative Henderson of Iowa for his speech of last Saturday.

An interesting contest between a druggist and a saloon keeper came up yesterday before the Brooklyn Board of Excise. Mrs. Mary Eccies, proprietress of a drug store at Atlantic Avenue and Smith Street, and George E. Ludemann, who wants to keep a saloon on the opposite corner of Atlantic Avenue, were the parties to the contest.
Have Tammany Hall and Mr. Thomas C. Platt come to an understanding?

Now that the gymnastic exhibits of the Eighty-sixth Street Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association are over, the athletic members are turning their attention to the coming gymnasium and indoor athletic contests, which will practically close the work of the Winter season. The gymnasium contests will take place March 26.

American railway securities reacted a fraction in the London market. The principal changes were: Declined -- St. Paul, 5/8, to 62 1/4; Lake Shore, 1/2, to 130 1/2; Louisville and Nashville, 3/8, to 47 3/4; Northern Pacific preferred, 3/8, to 18 3/4; Erie, 1/4, to 17 1/8; Atchison, 1/8, to 13 1/4; Reading, 1/8, to 11 1/4, and Kansas and Texas, 1/8, to 13 5/8.

The Dry Goods Merchants' Association of New-York has taken up the work of collecting funds for the relief of the suffering poor, and the first contribution, which was received by J. Pierpont Morgan, Treasurer of the Citizens' Relief Committee, through William T. Evans, has added $1,400 to the fund.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 7 -- The Democrats of Yonkers have almost unanimously nominated John Kendrick Bangs for Mayor. Mr. Bangs is the well-known litterateur and humorist, being the editor of the humorous department of Harper's Bazaar and also in charge of the "Drawer" in Harper's Magazine.

The Culinary Trades' Council of NewYork and Vicinity was organized last night at the International Labor Exchange, 257 East Tenth Street, by delegates from crats' unions whose members have, directly or indirectly, to do with restaurants, halls, and parks.

Frank M. Vernon, a clerk, nineteen years old, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of swindling Eugene Kelly. Jr., the banker. He was held for trial in default of $1.000. Vernon is tall and good-looking. and has frequently received assistance from Mr. Kelly.

PARIS, March 7 -- The best sources of information agree that the death of Miss Ida Van Etten, the American writer and the First Secretary of the Working Women's Society, was due to syncope, hastened by excessive privation. Miss Van Etten was indebted to the proprietors of the Hotel Continental, where she died, to the amount of $120 for room rent.

It is well that Police Justice Patrick Diwer is coming home from the Pacific slope. We have rarely known the fences of a statesman to be in a condition more urgently demanding his immediate personal attention than the fences of this same Diwer in the Second Assembly District.

SAUGERTIES, N.Y., March 7 -- Belief that John E. Yager, whose body was found in a building adjoining his home several days ago, was murdered, is widespread. District Attorney Westbrook will be asked to investigate the matter. Yager's body was horribly mutilated. He was shot in the stomach with a shotgun, which was found lying near him.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Secretary of State received a dispatch to-day from Minister Baker, in Nicaragua, stating that the American Consul at Greytown reported that fifty men had been landed from a British ship to preserve order at Bluefields. The Secretary does not attach great importance to the matter and will take no action until details shall be obtained.

LONDON, March 7 -- The Admiralty Office is in receipt of dispatches from Bathurst, Gambia, this morning, reporting another engagement between British troops -- a detachment of the British West India Regiment -- and a strong band of followers of Chief Fodisilah.

-- At Montclair, N.J., the local club opens to-night an art and loan exhibition for afternoons and evenings, closing on Monday, the 12th. Admission is by card of a member of the Montclair Club. American painters represented include George Inness, senior and junior; Miss Clara McChesney, F. S. Church, Harry Fenn, W.H. Howe, the late Alexander Wyant, Manley, L.C. Earle, and others.

Patrick Whalen of 516 East Fourteenth Street called at the office of The New-York Times yesterday to contradict the statements published in the newspapers to the effect that on Monday night he headed a gang of rowdies that assaulted Detective Bush while attempting to rescue Louis Becht.
The evangelistic meetings in Association Hall. Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, and in many of the city churches, are gaining impetus daily, and promise to spread throughout the city.

ALBANY, March 7. -- The State Senate today took cognizance of the political murder in Troy yesterday. Senator Saxton (Rep., Wayne) introduced a resolution which called forth considerable discussion, and then was adopted without opposition. The preamble and resolution were in these words:

BABYLON, L.I., March 7 -- Lindenhurst School Commissioner C.W. Fordham was here to-day and held an informal examination of the charges preferred against Principal George Zoellner of the Lindenhurst Public School by the Rev. August Bertram of the Lutheran Church and the Rev. John Koebell of the Roman Catholic Church, who allege that the Principal is an atheist, a drunkard, and generally for his position.

The Knickerbocker Bowling Club had its weekly meeting yesterday afternoon at 212 West Forty-first Street. It was the largest meeting of the season, 125 members and guests being present. Admiral Gherardi was on hand again, and seemed thoroughly to enjoy himself. He bowled, but did not make a remarkable score, and was too modest to say what he did make.

No action was taken yesterday by the Police Commissioners with reference to the complaints by Superintendent Byrnes against Captains Price and Martens, who were tried before the board Tuesday. If it were not so serious a matter, involving as it does the very essence of proper discipline, the trial of these two Police Captains might be looked on as a farce, with Police Commissioner-District Leader Martin in the role of the principal low comedian.

The annual meeting of the Corinthian Yacht Club was held last night at the house of Fleet Captain M. Roosevelt Schuyler, 252 West Forty-sixth Street. Admiral August Belmont was absent and Mr. Schuyler occupied the chair. The following officers were elected: Admiral -- Charles H. Tweed; Fleet Captain -- M. Roosevelt Schuyler; Secretary -- George A. Cormack; Trustees -- Charles H. Tweed, M. Roosevelt Schuyler, E.M. Padelford, August Belmont, and S.M. Schuyler.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Negotiations were begun this morning between the Presidents of the Atchison. Topeka and Santa Fe and the Southern Pacific Railroads with the object of settling their differences and restoring rates. President C.P. Huntington of the Southern Pacific submitted a proposition as the basis of a settlement of the troubles.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 7 -- Gov. Poster to-day received the resignation of United States Senator E.C. White, to take effect on Monday, March 12. The Governor accepted the same, and appointed Representative Newton C. Blanchard to succeed him.

As a result of a dispute over the possession of the Hotel Balmoral, a family hotel at Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, between two sets of lessees, matters have been lively for the past few days, with promise of more exciting times still.

There is every indication that the competition invited by the Municipal Art Society of New-York for the decoration of the courtroom of Oyer and Terminer to the new Criminal Courts Building, for which purpose the society will devote the sum of $5,000, will produce results creditable alike to the society and to the city.

Roland Redmond. Mr. Roland Redmond died at his residence, 3 East Twelfth Street, this city, Sunday, March 4, and his funeral will take place al Grace Church this morning. He was a son of the late William Redmond, who for many years was an importing merchant in this city, conducting business under the firm name of William Redmond Son.

STONEHAM, Mass., March 7 -- The new Durkee Building, in process of construction on Main Street, fell with a crash at 6:10 this evening, causing the death of Nathan Loud, seventy-two years of age, and Injuring several others. Mr. Loud was passing along the street at the time of the collapse and was caught in the falling debris.

An adjourned meeting of the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation was held yesterday afternoon to hear the report of the Special Committee on Rapid Transit regarding the Wilson plan of rapid transit and other propositions. After some discussion the Hewitt plan was adopted unanimously.

The now St. Matthew's Protestant Episcopal Church, in West Eighty-fourth Street, near Central Park, was opened last night with appropriate services. Bishop Coleman of Delaware officiated. He was assisted by the Rev. Henry Chamberlaine, rector of the church.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 7 -- Trial began to-day of the suit against the New-York Central Railroad brought by John J. Bagnall, as administrator of the estate of his son, John R. Bagnall, who was killed in the wreck at Hastings Dec. 24, 1891. The suit is for $3,000. John R. Bagnall was editor of The Poughkeepsie Evening Star.

The following article, reprinted nearly in full from The Spectator of London, gives a view of the origin and consequences of the German-Russian treaty of commerce that obtains among many of the best observers in England:

John Y. Hallock was lodged in Ludlow Street Jail Tuesday night in default of $10,000 bail on the charge of embezzling $65,839.26 from Theodore Pabst Co., importers of glassware, 26 Barclay Street. The order for his arrest was granted by Justice Lawrence of the Supreme Court Tuesday morning in an action brought by Lawyer Lorenz Zeller to recover the amount as assignee of Theodore Pabst Co.
Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 7 -- The schooner Transit arrived from Honolulu at 11 o'clock this morning, bringing advices up to Feb. 20.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A most important ordnance trial will take place this week probably, if the plans of the officers be not interfered with. Arrangements have been perfected for firing the thirteeninch, the largest gun of the navy, at the Indian Head Naval Proving Ground. It probably will take several days to complete the trial.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The President to-day sent to both Houses of Congress the following communication:

TROY, N.Y., March 7 -- The ruffian who shot Robert Ross because he protested against corruption at a ballot box Tuesday will meet swift justice if the decent men in Troy can secure that end. If his blood can make so hideous a stain on the Murphy system of carrying an election that it is forever wiped out, all that is decent and honest in Troy will rejoice.
LONDON, March 7 -- Mr. Gladstone is confined to his bed to-day. He became chilled by the raw winds yesterday, and is suffering from a severe cold.

Not without a long and at some points acrimonious debate the Board of Education decided yesterday to call on the Controller for an accounting as to the payment to Arthur Berry and Rollin A. Morgan of $52,000 as special counsel to the board. Mr. Wehrum, who offered the motion, said the money was paid out of an appropriation to the board, for which the board was held responsible.

At the end of the hearing on the AntiOption bill before the House Committee on Agriculture Chairman Hatch declared that his desire was to put an end to the gambling on puts and calls and options and futures, -- the "bucket-shop" practices -- without affecting the legitimate trading of properly-organized boards and Exchanges.

Harvard intends to make a good showing at the indoor athletic meeting for the championships of New-England on Saturday next. The men who are to compete in the different events have been selected during the past week by trial heats on a broad running track, and only those have qualified who have reached a certain standard in their trials.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The sub-committee of the Senate Finance Committee has completed its work, and will make its report to the full committee at 11 o'clock to-morrow morning.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I. March 7 -- The sloop Mary F. Duryea of Keyport, N.J., was found drifting off Rockaway Point this morning by Capt. Smith Foster of the LifeSaving Station. Capt. Foster boarded the sloop, and in her cabin found the body of Capt. John Duryea, her owner. His skull was crushed in, and there were several wounds on his face and neck.

Funeral services over the body of Joseph B. Coe, Deputy Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas, who was found dead on Monday morning in a vacant lot near his residence, 18 West One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, were held last evening in the Lexington Avenue Baptist Church, in One Hundred and Eleventh Street.

The residents of Brook Avenue and vicinity express much satisfaction with the promptness with which Louis T. Haffen, Commissioner of Street Improvements in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, has completed the preliminary arrangements necessary for the opening of Brook Avenue from Westchester Avenue to One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Street.

The Twenty-sixth Assembly District State Democracy held a meeting last night at Kohring's Hall, One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Second Avenue, for temporary organization. The hall was crowded to overflowing, and before the business part of the meeting was gone into several prominent speakers gave their views on the best means for making the organization a success.

The Custom House authorities are trying to solve a mystery connected with a large lot of antique furniture now at the Barge Office. It was imported from Holland in August, 1891, and has not since been claimed. It has just been unpacked preparatory to the public sale March 20 of unclaimed goods.

The second annual exhibition drill and reception of the naval cadets of the Port of New-York was held last evening at Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street. About 500 spectators were present when at 8:30 o'clock the proceedings were opened under the supervision of Capt. Wells Naughton by the salute of the entire corps to the officers and flags.

Prizes for the best landscape or figure piece at current exhibitions of the fine arts have their upholders and their critics. The former point to the nearly universal custom of giving prizes wherever funds are available, and set forth with considerable truth the good they do in stimulating artists to send their best work.

A story is being circulated among politicians to the effect that the appointment of William H. McDonough as Under Sheriff was advised by Mayor Gilroy and made by Sheriff Sexton only temporarily, to last until Richard Croker and the other big Tammany leaders who are now away return to this city and look over the ground.
There are three lions in this town to-day which could tell a woful story of the troubles of a traveler if they only knew how to talk.

The Washington correspondent of one of our Republican contemporaries publishes a report of the argument made by Senator Brice of Ohio in support of his demand for the retention of a high duty on coal, a report which appears to have been given to the correspondent by the Senator himself.

Secretary Sullivan says that the boxing and wrestling championships of the Amateur Athletic Union this year promise to be close and interesting. He claims that the followers of boxing can rest assured that the entry will contain the names of the leading boxers and wrestlers of several of our larger cities, something that has not heretofore been a feature.

The Evening Post disputes our statement that Lord Rosebery is the first English peer who hag found his peerage a drawback to political preferment. In support of its contention it cites the familiar case of politicians who have been "shelved" by taking peerages, as they might have been shelved by taking the Chiltern Hundreds.
Over 600 men employed by the StreetCleaning Department struck suddenly yesterday morning because of alleged grievances, and during the day the department's work was severely crippled.

Herman Clarke, who disappeared and left the brokerage firm of Hunter, Clarke Jacob, of which he was a member, to settle various stock privilege accounts in Sugar which he had negotiated in the firm's name for his personal benefit and without the knowledge of his partners, is still missing. No one seems to know where he may be found.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

With the advent of good weather, the lovers of racing in this vicinity are talking about the coming races, and the trainers are looking over the material in their charge. Lamplighter has been tried, and is said to be in fairly good condition. He is looked upon as a good thing for the Brooklyn Handicap.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. T. A. Kerrigan sold to William V. Young for $12.925 the three four-story brick double flats 394 to 398 McDonough Street, south side, 213 feet east of Stuyvesant Avenue, 60 by 100. To William H. Reynolds, at $11,000, he sold the two two-story and basement brick dwellings 266 and 268 Prospect Place, south side, 298 feet east of Vanderbilt Avenue, 36 by 331.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Lucas S. Van Allan argued this afternoon before the Cities Committees of the two houses in favor of the Coggeshall bill regrading the members of the New-York police force and increasing their salaries. He said the salaries had not been increased in twenty years. He wanted the bill reported, so that action could be taken in each house and the members could be put on record.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Higher prices continued to prevail this morning, the boom being on in full force. West Chicago opened at 149. Before the market had fairly settled itself, however, there were sales at 148 3/4, but from this point there was a steady advance to 150. Here offerings fell off entirely.

The Republican majority of the Kings County Board of Supervisors is determined that the interests of the people shall be cared for. It is desirous that all bills coming before it shall be certified by the proper authorities before the board allows the County Treasurer to pay them.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, March -- P. M. Sugar was again the feature of stock speculation, being more active than on Tuesday last, when it fluctuated so widely. The opening price was anywhere between 94 and 92. Fuliy half the brokers in the room were in the crowd, and the trading was so excited that is was impossible to fix the price within 2 points.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

After an unconscionable delay the terms of the House Tariff bill as modified by the sub-committee of the Senate Finance Committee have been laid before the full committee and given to the public. Every one knows to what the delay was due, and the cause of it was in the highest degree discreditable to the little cabal of McKinley Democrats that brought it about.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Boston Tow Boat Company will probably have the contract of saving the Kearsarge, wrecked on Roncador Reef. The funds for the work were made available to-day, and Secretary Herbert immediately made preparations for sending the wrecking party to the scene of the wreck.

The potato race at the sports of the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn on Wednesday evening proved to be of an interesting character. Signor Philip del Bosco, the riding master, had charge of the entertainment. There were four heats and a final. In the latter, C. Luckenbach, Pirie, Cadenas, and Walsh were the contestants.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- There was some disposition this morning to get out of long stocks, as the market had been strong for some days. This probably caused the slight concessions in price which were recorded at opening. There was an increased volume of business, and Reading and St. Paul again monopolized most of the day's transactions.

Pigeon shoots this year are remarkable for the closeness of the matches rather than for any big scores or skillful shooting. Several big matches where more than 4OO birds have been shot at have been won by two or three kills, and yesterday the team of the Riverton Gun Club defeated the team of the New-Utrecht Gun Club by 161 to 158, just three birds.

There is a fine tangle in the affairs of the State Senate committee appointed to investigate the Police Department of this city. This committee will begin work in Part III. of the Common Pleas Court at 10 o'clock this forenoon.

ALBANY, March 8 -- It was the Assembly's chance this morning to pass its verdict upon the political murder in the home city of United States Senator Murphy on Tuesday. A row among the Republicans over the Inspectors of Election Conference Com- , mittee had hardly quieted down when the representative of the Governor appeared.

PUTNAM, Conn., March 8 -- The Putnam Woolen Company's mill resumed this morning, after having been closed nearly seven months. The agent states that the prospects are much brighter, and the mill will soon be running regular time. It employs 365 hands.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- The Government crop report, which will be issued on Saturday, and which will treat of farmers' reserves in wheat and corn, is at the present the unknown quantity in the markets for those commodities. Outside trade is keeping very quiet and leaving the operations in the hands of professionals. To-day's market opened with every appearance of steadiness, but soon flattened out upon selling by Baldwin Farnum.

Mr. C.F. Hoffman, Jr., has purchased the five-story brick building, 218 Pearl Street, with lot 28.6 by 124, for a little less than $50.000. The building contains an elevator and other improvements, and is leased for a term of years to one tenant at $3,500.

The good that is being done by the Industrial Christian Alliance in its effort to relieve the needs of the suffering poor is becoming more evident every day. A visit to one of the cheap food kitchens controlled by this organization would be enough to convince the most skeptical that the managers of the alliance have achieved wonderful results.

PORT NATAL, Africa, March 8 -- Though the details of the encounter which has taken place between the British and the Portuguese on the Zambesi River are very meagre, they are adequate to show that the matter has a much more serious aspect than the first reports indicated.

A jury in the City Court yesterday not only disagreed, but made the disagreement known In an alleged poetical effusion, and incidentally afforded a glimpse of how jurors amuse themselves during the weary hours when they are locked up for the night. The jury had under consideration the case of Leo Owshowitz against the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to recover $2,000 damages for false arrest and imprisonment.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 8 -- Receivers Platt and Perry of the New-York and New-England Railroad, arrived in this city to-day on a tour of inspection of the road. They were accompanied by Director Vaughan of Providence, General Manager Odell, Master of Transportation Dewey, Division Superintendent Quigg, and General Traffic Manager Randolph.

Thousands of tourists have viewed the great ice bridge at Niagara Falls this Winter. The bridge, which extends from shore to shore just below the cataract, is still intact. The mild weather of the past ten days has not reduced the thickness of the ice. Although the banks bordering the river are clear of snow, the bridge is apparently as firm as when the mercury was below zero.

Our Police Justices get a great deal of abuse for negligence, obtuseness, and unfairness, and doubtless they richly deserve all they get. But the theory that all the evils of New-York police courts and the lack of discrimination shown in imposing penalties for petty offenses are due solely to the prevailing system of appointments is not entirely warranted.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- The new battle ship Indiana, the first of her class in the new navy, and the largest battle ship ever built in this country, returned this afternoon from a most successful preliminary trial trip. Her average speed was 15.6 knots, six-tenths better than the speed called for by the contract.

It is always gala night at the Irving Place Theatre when they begin to play Bavarian rustic comedies, those Muenchener Volksschauspiele which are as peculiar to Southern Germany as Munich genre pictures and Munich beer. Subtle stage play and the finer shades of acting are not needed; dialect, Tyrolese costumes, and peasant fun render such things unnecessary.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 8 -- Insurance Commissioner Mansfield has issued Part I. of the twenty-ninth annual report of the Connecticut Insurance Department. Important suggestions are made in regard to revision of the insurance laws, and it is likely that radical Changes will be made in Connecticut insurance affairs if laws are made in line with the Commissioner's suggestions.

Controller Fitch prepared a statement yesterday, which he will submit to the next meeting of the Board of Estimate, on the application of the Board of Education to have the Legislature appropiate $2,500,000 for building schools, annexes, rooms for the Board of Education, repairs, , for the ensuing year.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The "long member with a short name" from Putnam caused a ruffle in the Assembly at the opening of the session to-day. Mr. Thornton, (Rep., Orange,) from the joint conference committee on the O'Connor Non-Partisan Inspectors of Elections bill, handed in the report of the committee.

Mayor Schieren and his official associates have determined to deal vigorously with the street-cleaning problem. The subject was considered at last evening's Cabinet meeting, and to-day work on the streets will be resumed.

In the Court of Special Sessions yesterday, Emma Cook, the proprietress of the house in Lexington Avenue which was raided recently by detectives from the Central Office, under orders from Superintendent Byrnes, was found guilty of keeping a disorderly house and violating the excise law.

A tall, beautiful brunette, known as Rose Mansfield to Mrs. Bertha West, who keeps a boarding house at 103 East Thirtieth Street, was removed in an unconscious condition from there yesterday afternoon to Bellevue Hospital. She died about 7:30 o'clock, and last night her body lay in the Morgue.

Michael Murphy, the well-known trainer and sprinter and brother of the Yale College ball player, has been engaged by the New-York Athletic Club this year to look after the runners of the Mercury Foot Club. Murphy is one of the most successful handlers of short-distance runners in the country, and the chances are that he will improve the New-York Athletic Club sprinters so that they will be able to do yards better than heretofore.

The Salvation Army met last night in Association Hall, and the members filed into it not in platoons, but marching by battalions. A concourse of plain civilians also came to attend the gathering, and before 8 o'clock every seat in the spacious hall was taken. The stream of later arrivals overflowed into the gallery and aisles.

BOSTON, March 8 -- Local stocks showed some activity to-day, and the market was generally strong. Bell Telephone opened at 169 and advanced to 177, closing at 173. New-England Telephone held its own -- 49 1/2. Dominion Coal opened at 20 1/4 and closed at 20, the preferred selling at 93. Boston and Albany declined 1/2, to 20 1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- At last the mantle of secrecy has been removed from the Tariff bill. The much-discussed measure was reported to the full Committee on Finance of the Senate this morning, and simultaneously printed copies were distributed to the members of the press and to Senators.

Howard Bills, formerly United States Consul at Rotterdam, appeared at the Custom House yesterday as the owner of the antique furniture, paintings, and other household valuables which had been posted for sale at auction a week from next Tuesday. The goods had been in Public Stores since Mr. Bills returned from Rotterdam in 1891.

A full meeting of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association will be held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in this city on next Tuesday for the purpose of considering the troubled condition of affairs among the Southern railroads.

MADRID, March 8 -- The Cabinet sat for seven hours to-day discussing financial questions and the difficulties arising from the resistance to taxation in the provinces. Eventually all the Ministers resigned.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Daniel Coughlin is a free man to-night. For the first time since the morning of May 25, 1889, when he was stripped of his detective's star and placed under arrest by order of Mayor Creigrier, he enjoys the precious boon of personal liberty.

Work has been begun preparatory to breaking the ground for the Lexington Avenue cable line. A small gang of men is now employed between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets moving the Croton mains out of the way. As soon as the obstructions are removed for a few blocks, 1,000 men, now employed in Columbus Avenue, will begin breaking ground for the new road.

Ellen Collins, who, at 41 West Eleventh Street, has been collecting money for the relief of the cyclone sufferers of South Carolina, askes The New-York Times to make her acknowledgment of the following subscriptions:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 8 -- Walter Camp has undertaken to gather statistics of injuries, fatal and slight, received at football in this country since the introduction of the game. He has just sent out the following letter to all the old American players:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 8 -- The second presentation of the now celebrated Winfield passion pantomime will take place in the Queens County Court House, in this city, Saturday morning at 10 o'clock. It will be a private performance for the benefit of District Attorney Daniel Noble.

The news that the State Senate had passed Senator Daniel Bradley's bill removing from office the present Board of Trustees of the bridge was hailed yesterday in Brooklyn with expressions of satisfaction on every side. The Trustees have rendered themselves Intensely unpopular by their secret and procrastinating methods, by their inefficient management, and by their almost total disregard of the convenience and wishes of the public.

Prof. Robert Foster. Prof. Robert Foster died at his home, 290 Adelphl Street, Brooklyn, Tuesday, of pneumonia. He was sixty-eight years old, and was born in Bath, Me. He was graduated from Princeton College in 1847. In 1856 he became connected with the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.

MOBILE. Ala., March 8 -- Six young men were enjoying a ride on a hand car on the Davis Railroad, near here, yesterday. They started down a steep incline with poles for brakes. The car got beyond their control and soon attained a fearful velocity.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The following memorial was presented to both branches of the Legislature to-day:

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., March 8 -- The British schooner Ada, Capt. Leaman, from Figuera Jan. 20, which arrived here this morning, reports that on Tuesday evening at 6 o'clock she spoke the British steamer Briscoe, Capt. Soares, from Hamburg Dec. 6 and Queenstown Jan. 30, for New-York, forty miles off Cape Race.

Much fraternal feeling was shown by the members of the Union College Alumnl Association at their reception last night at the Waldorf in honor of the Rev. Dr. Andrew V.V. Raymond of Albany, President-elect of the college.

TROY, N.Y., March 8 -- A public meeting of citizens, to protest against the irregularities practiced on election day and to denounce the murder of Robert Ross, was held here to-night. The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was filled to the doors and an overflow meeting was held in the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., March 8 -- Word has been received here that "Tom" O'Brien, the noted "bunko steerer," is doing soldier duty in Haiti. O'Brien created a sensation in Utica a year ago last May by escaping from his keeper, James B. Buck., who brought him to Utica from Dannemora Prison on a writ of habeas corpus.

ROME, March 8 -- About 6 o'clock this evening a terific explosion, resembling the detonation of a large cannon, startled everybody in the vicinity of the Chamber of Deputies. Persons were hurled to the ground by the force of the explosion, while others, able to keep their feet, ran in all directions in their endeavors to escape from the unknown danger.

Edward F. McSweeney, Assistant Superintendent of Immigration, said yesterday that there must be some mistake about the Washington dispatch to the effect that the Federal Government is supporting foreign paupers in the Massachusetts hospitals who were insane when they came to this country.

Oliver Sumner Teall thinks that at least 250 of those persons who profited by Horace Greeley's advice, and "went West," ought to be willing to contribute $10 each and raise the $2,500 required to complete the Horace Greeley statue fund.
