Funeral services were held yesterday over the body of Julius C. Lulley, Secretary of the Aqueduct Commission, at Scottish Rite Hall, Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, by members of the Masonic orders to which the dead man belonged.

Miss Mary Hetherton early yesterday morning was aroused from her sleep to find the house where she lived, 628 Eighth Avenue, on fire. A few minutes afterward she was balanced on the sill of a third-story window, clinging to a stout rope, which dangled to the ground from the floor above, the only means of escape from the flames that filled her apartment.

MOSCOW, Idaho, Starch 8 -- The party organized at Post Falls for the rescue of the cook of the Carlln party, the unfortunate George Colgate, are on their return journey down the Clearwater River, and are expected to reach Kendrick within a day or two, having been out over sixty days.

Thomas F. Foley, appropriately and better known as "Big Tom," could not be found yesterday, either at his saloon, in South Street, or in places he is accustomed to visit; but Police Justice Patrick Divver's constituents in the Second Assembly District are anxious to hear from him. It was stated that he had gone to Albany to confer with Morris Tekulsky.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 8 -- On the night of Tuesday, March 6, a barge, loaded with bacon, flour, and cylinder oil, belonging to the firm of Levering Co. of Baltimore and Rio de Janeiro, was stolen from the side of the Hamburg steamer Catania, to which she was moored. The theft was the work of the insurgents, who are ever on the alert to obtain food and other supplies.

Lawyer Samuel D. Levy was retained some time ago by Victor Lipman to bring a damage suit against the East Broadway and Dry Dock Railroad. The case was set down on the calendar of the Supreme Court, before Judge Beach, Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- An annoying error has been discovered in the distribution of the tariff speeches of ex-Speaker Reed and Chairman Wilson of the Ways and Means Committee. They were printed at the same office, and the usual care was exercised in their preparation and circulation.

Mr. Edward Murphy, Jr., has at last made his mark in the Senate of the United States. We do not mean to intimate that Mr. Murphy is restricted by early disadvantages from doing more than making his mark. On the contrary, our information is that Mr. Murphy can not only write his name, but can write many other equally simple statements; has, in point of fact, a remarkable and tolerable commercial education.

The trouble with the special committee of the State Senate appointed to investigate the Police Department of this city is that its course thus far gives no evidence of a purpose to make such an investigation as would lead to an improvement in the administration of the department.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The amended Wilson bill as submitted to the Senate Finance Committee differs materially from the original bill in respect to sugars, iron ore, lead ore, the free list, and other particulars. The changes made by the Senate sub-committee are exhibited in the following summary:
The most important of the Senate committee's changes in the tariff schedules of the Wilson bill are those which relate to sugar, iron ore, coal, woolen goods, crockery, glass, and fruit.
James McGowan, ex-Secretary of the Brighton Beach Racing Association, died at his home, 23 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. He was seventy years old.
Complete victory. Masterly and exhaustive opinion reviewing whole case on merits. Strong vindication and approval acts of Sutro, Lowengard, and Trustees. Aron scored roundly.

The Democratic members of the Board of Supervisors of Kings County have given up their fight. Two of them meekly appeared in the board chamber yesterday to attend the first meeting of the Committee on Law, of which Supervisor Dike is Chairman.

Graduates of Amherst College will be interested in the latest development of the trouble between the Faculty and College Senate, composed of undergraduates, which for some years has had a hand in the government of the student body. Under date of March 6 the Senate writes to the Faculty as follows:

Having performed successfully for several days the initial function of a rocket. Sugar turned about yesterday and dropped like a sticK. News of the Senate sub-committee's report explained the movement. As this news was common property, no special excitement attended the break, although the volume of sales was the largest since Sugar took the lead in the stock market, and the net change for the day also overtopped previous recent records.

The Brooklyn Revenue Reform Club, which had beeb actively and earnestly engaged for a year in the effort to secure legislation which will wipe the personel-taxlas from the statute books, gathered a considerable number of its memeber and friends at the Pouch Mansion, on Clinton Avenue, last evening to considre how best to bring about the desired legislation. There were men present from all political parties.

In the public exhibition of the progress made by his pupils, at the Empire Theatre yesterday arternoon, Mr. Nelson Wheatcroft put forward two several Lady Macbeths -- or should it be Ladies Macbeth? This was a good many murderous ladies for one artistic banquet -- when there were pippins and cheese to come, too.

PATERSON. N.J., March 8 -- A mob of about 2,000 men assembled in front of the Murray Silk Mill at 6 o'clock to-night for the purpose of assaulting Frank Newkirk, a ribbon weaver who refused to go on strike with the other operatives of the factory. Newkirk left the mill, and was followed by the crowd of angry men.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Dr. Millbank of Albany, member of the State Board of Health, testified to-day before the commit- tee which is investigating the board's meth- ods. He said the work of the board might be more efficiently conducted if a Secretary more in touch with the Commissioners was in charge, one who would not throw obstacles in the way, or as he put it, "build fences for the board to tear down."

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The tariff bill as reported to the Senate Finance Committee to-day seemed to be generally satisfactory to the Democrats of the House. Mr. Bynum of Indiana, who is one of the Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee, said to-day:

OIL CITY, Penn., March 9 -- A freight train on the Western New-York and Pennsylvania Railroad ran into a landslide seven miles east of here this morning, causing the death of Fireman Martin and the destruction of fourteen cars. The other members of the crew escaped by jumping and swimming across the Allegheny River.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A United States war ship will probably be ordered to Bluefields, Nicaragua, within a day or two, now that a British ship has landed marines on the Mosquito Coast. Advices indicate that the Mosquito Chief asked the English Consul that a protectorate be established. The situation becomes more interesting and the State Department people are beginning to take on an air of secrecy usual to all diplomatic questions pending.

The Interesting feature of the fifth public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society, which took place yesterday afternoon at Music Hall, was the production of Victor Herbert's concerto for violoncello, No. 2, Opus 30. The word "interesting" is employed because curiosity stimulates interest and novelty excites curiosity.

Reuben L. Armstrong went into the store of Strasburger Co., 907 Broadway, about 5:30 yesterday afternoon and made a trifling purchase, offering in payment a check for $20 on the National City Bank of Brooklyn. The check was pronounced a forgery by one of the firm of Strasburger Co.

Out of the complication concerning the lease of the Hotel Balmoral, Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, the tenants in the building have in a way the worst of the controversy. They are in doubt as to whom they shall pay rent to.
Two policy dealers have at last been Indicted in Brooklyn. The Kings County Grand Jury has found a true bill against Joseph Montague and Joseph Gray.

The Board of Studies for the Champlain Catholic Summer School met yesterday at the call of the Chairman, the Rev. Thomas McMillan, Paulist, and arranged the programme of lectures, addresses, and conferences for the session beginning July 14 in Plattsburg. In this programme the various sections of the country, the religious and secular clergy, different professions, have received full recognition, while the needs and tastes of the students have been carefully consulted.
William S. Hook of Jacksonville, III., has addressed a circular letter to the holders of bonds of the Chicago, Peoria and St. Louis Railroad Company, in which he says:

Seven dwellings and lots on West Forty-sixth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, have been purchased by Mr. George R. Read for a syndicate. The street numbers are 133 to 137 and 141 to 147. The price paid is about $17,000 each, and the front measurements are 16.8 feat for three and 18.9 feet for four.

NEW-YORK. Friday, March 9 -- P. M. There was a decided drop in the volume of business to-day. The total sales were 169,172 shares, against 376,148 yesterday. The heaviest falling off was in Sugar, but the entire list was much less active than yesterday.

Edward Grosse is a well-known lawyer of this city and is very popular in the German community. He was born in Germany in 1845, and in his early youth learned the art of printing. He subsequently studied stenography and became an expert German stenographer.

TRENTON, N.J., March 9 -- The arguments in the quo warranto proceedings to-day developed a number of interesting incidents. The time was exhausted by Samuel H. Grey, who, for twenty-five years, has had the reputation of being one of the best constitutional lawyers in the State, and Allan L. McDermott, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, who is counsel for Senator Adrain.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 9 -- The schooner J.C. Southard of New-York, from Cienfuegos for New-York, sugar laden, and the British bark James L. Harway of Picton, from Matanzas for Liverpool, sugar laden, collided last night off Sombrero. The Harway lost her lower topsall, foresail, and jibs, sprung the bowsprit, and was cut down five streaks.

The President yesterday sent to the Senate the nomination of Walter Macfarlane for District Attorney of the Southern District and Edward Grosse for Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District. They are both good selections.

"While we are doing all we can to relieve the sufferings of the poor during this emergency," said Charles D. Kellogg of the Charity Organization Society to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday, "some of the newspapers which have started relief funds for their own aggrandizment hamper us considerably in our work.

CATSKILL, N.Y., March 9 -- A determined effort to influence the people of Greene County to the support of women's suffrage is to be made by the New-York Women's Suffrage Association next week. Arrangements have been perfected for a series of meetings for general discussion of this subject.

Assemblymen J.F. Terry and Henry McNemee were in Brooklyn yesterday to hear testimony in the contest of William Dwyer against William J. Plant. Mr. Plant is the Democratic Assemblyman from the First District of Kings County. The Common Council chamber was crowded with politicians from the First and Second Wards.

OTTAWA, March 9 -- Acting upon the advice of Dr. Selwyn, Chief of the Dominion Geological Survey, the Dominion Government nearly a year ago sent a special expedition to explore the interior of Labrador. The expedition was in charge of A.P. Low, one of the most energetic engineers of the Geological Survey.

In the course of some comments upon the changes made in the Wilson bill by the Democratic majority of the Senate Committee on Finance, one of our tariffreform contemporaries remarks that the proposed "duty on coal is of much less consequence" than the proposed duty on iron ore, "as it affects only a corner of New-England."
Zella Nicolaus and her husband. Al Runman, are looking for a new boarding house.

The New-York City Association of Union ex-Prisoners of War held a meeting last night at the Colonnade Hotel to elect officers and enjoy a supper. About fifty members were present. Gen. Alexander Shaler of Bridgefield, N.J., was elected President, William M. Abbott Vice President, Charles F. Wilson Treasurer, Frank A. Rowe Secretary, and the Rev. D.H. Hannabaugh Chaplain.

The writings of Caesar and Tacitus, the Bayeux Tapestry, the Domesday Book, archaeology, the inferences of students of the history of law, commerce, learning, costumes, and customs, and an infinity of details, dispersed in poems, chronicles, and traditional narratives, are intelligently interpreted in this first volume of a work which will be valuable.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 9 -- A meeting of representative Democrats of New-Jersey was held at Taylor's Hotel this afternoon for the purpose of bringing about a change in the local leadership in some of the counties, and a change in the methods of the party in the State, particularly as regards the action of the Democrats in the State Senate.

A well-dressed, fine-looking, pleasantspoken man about thirty years of age rang the bell about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon at 5 East Forty-fourth Street, the residence of H.B. Barnes, the publisher, of Eleventh Street and Broadway. Kate Whalen, a bright, wide-awake young waitress, answered the bell.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 9 -- Alter a three weeks' tour through the South and West, George Gould returned here yesterday. Mr. Gould's trip was for business and pleasure, and such as he usually makes two or three times a year to look over his various properties in that section of the country.

Th bill introduced in the Assembly by Mr. Stadtfeld of this city, prohibiting the sale of liquors after 8 o'clock P. M. on excursion boats leaving this city has given rise to much comment among those interested in the business of Summer excursions. No other city in the world offers such facilities for pleasure trips during the heated term as New-York.

The American Line steamship Chester, which sails for Southampton this morning, takes out among her steerage passengers forty-two negro emigrants to Liberia. All are well advanced in years. They are from Southern cotton fields and speak in the dialect which Thomas Nelson Page is so fond of reproducing.

It was learned yesterday that the man who on Wednesday night went to the Mount Morris Hotel and registered there as A. Lauz of Hartford, Conn., and who was found dead in his room at 10:30 Thursday night, was Abraham Lieberman of Scholfleld Co., real estate dealers, at Eightyeighth Street and Columbus Avenue.

BOSTON, Mass., March 9 -- Abbey, Schceffel Grau are projecting alterations in Mechanics' Hall which will produce a fullyequipped opera house. Mr. Schoeffel says that the scheme includes the extinction of the second balcony, which will be taken out and the walls built up. The organ will also be removed, and the building made square in the rear, thus giving ample stage room.
The Irish societies of the city decided, at a meeting held at 229 East Forty-seventh Street last night, the order of their parade on St. Patrick's Day. Patrick Costello will be the Grand Marshal.

It is suspected in Brooklyn now that President Seth Keeney and the other indicted Commercial Bank Directors have agreed to buy the worthless Grening mortgages, and that Judge Moore of the Court of Sessions may toe disposed to quash the criminal proceedings against them. It is not believed they would have taken up the mortgages if they had not had some assurance that such action would result in their discharge.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Mr. Peffer threw a bomb into the Senate Chamber this morning in the shape of a resolution calling for an investigation of the widespread charges that Senators have made use of their official knowledge to operate in sugar on the New-York Stock Exchange and that several of them have made huge sums out of their transactions.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The taking of evidence in the suit of Miss Madeline V. Pollard against Congressman W.C.P. Breckinridge for breach of promise of marriage was begun to-day. Miss Pollard was present, and several times interrupted the examination of her witnesses.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 9 -- The "Populite-Kolbite" combination, which has shown many signs of disintegration since its State Convention, almost went to pieces to-day. J.M. Whitehead, editor of The Living Truth of Greenville, a "Populite" paper, came out in a statement in which he said that the Weaver Electors from this State in 1892 were pledged to vote for Harrison in the Electoral College in case Weaver could not be elected.
Cardinal Thomas. Mgr. Leon Benoit Charles Thomas, Archbishop of Rouen, died yesterday.

BOSTON, March 9 -- The market for local stocks was not so active to-day, and the tone was somewhat mixed. Wisconsin Central 5s sold down 1, to 73, and the incomes were off 3/4, to 16 1/2. Bay State Gas was active again to-day, opening at 13 3/4, advancing to 14, and closing at 13 3/4. Bell Telephone opened at 174 1/2 and advanced 1 point, to 175 1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary Herbert finds the annulment of the contract of John Gillies of Brooklyn, who is building the dry dock at the New-York Navy Yard, to be quite a task. It Is likely that the subject will be referred to the Attorney General for opinion on points which the law officers of the Navy Department do not feel competent to deal with.

The religious question was introduced at a lively meeting of the Interscholastic Athletic Association held at the Berkeley School yesterday. The association is composed of those in attendance at private schools in New-York City, and the purpose of the meeting was mainly to prepare rules for the interscholastic championship contests, to be held May 5.

With the picture of a beautiful child clasped to her heart, Mrs. Minnie Creamer was found lying dead on the bed in her apartments, at 213 East Eighty-first Street, yesterday morning. The gas in the kitchen was turned on full, the windows were all closed, and every crevice was stuffed with paper or rags.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- The market was not so active to-day, and an easier tone prevailed, with the exception, of North Chicago, which scored another advance of 3 1/4, from 244 3/4 to 248. It is reported that the management is considering the advisability of dividing the big surplus known to be held by the company.

BOSTON, March 9. -- There was a good attendance of tariff reformers at the dinner of the New-England Tariff Reform League in the United States Hotel to-night. Mr. William Lloyd Garrison presided and made a speech in opening the after-dinner exercises.

CANNES, March 9 -- The pasage of the Prince of Wales from Marseilles to Cannes on board his yacht, the Britannia, has been the subject of a good deal of comment eulogistic of his Highness's pluck, on the one hand, and condemnatory of his foolhardlness on the other.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

The career of the Bland Silver bill in the Senate is a curious instance of the levity with which finance is treated by our legislators and the unscrupulous fashion in which business interests are subordinated to the schemes of politics. The proper and decent course with regard to such a bill was to refer it to the Finance Committee, to debate it reasonably when reported, and above all to defeat it.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- "Buck" Kilgore of Texas probably does not possess any proof to sustain the charge he made to-day in the House against the press of the country. He said it was corrupt, and not to be depended on as an educator or guide.

The third week of the evangelistic meetings being held in Association Hall and the city churches closed yesterday. Interest is increasing with such rapid strides that the whole city seems liable to be fired with the revival spirit. Next week the number of churches holding meetings in the evening will be largely increased and the day meetings will be doubled.

-- Charles Scribner's Sons issue the second volume of the Pasquier Memoirs, which deals with the years 1812 to 1814, and thus with many of the most impressive events in the life of Napoleon. Pasquier, as a writer of memoirs, has not only a charm, but great value. His testimony must be accepted as of the highest worth.

George L. Fox, rector of the Hopkins Grammar School, New-Haven, Conn., delivered the third lecture of his course of illustrated lectures on "The Great Schools of England," at the Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre last night. The subject of his lecture was "Dr. Arnold and Rugby School." Mr. Fox prefaced his stereopticon views with a character sketch of Dr. Arnold and a history of Rugby School.

It was reported at the Custom House yesterday that Col. L.M. Montgomery, Chief Special Treasury Agent, would be detailed to Paris to take charge of the work of United Sates Treasury agents in Europe. This rumor sprang from a visit of Charles P. Hamlin, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who came from Washington to make inquiries into customs methods with the view of reporting upon proposed changes.
R.G. Dun Co.'s Weekly Review of Trade will say to-morrow:

ALBANY, March 9 -- In the House this morning Mr. Fish called up Mr. Lawson's bill providing for placing horse manure in barrels or bales in New-York City below One Hundred and Thirtieth Street and for its removal once in every twenty-four hours. Mr. Fish said the bill had been laid aside in his absence.

Getting measured before a fight appears to be a popular fad with pugilists. Sullivan, Corbett, Mitchell, McAuliffe, and others have been measured carefully by physicians, and now Peter Jackson, who is matched to fight Corbett in June, has succumbed to the craze.

Major William Nevans, the veteran military bandmaster, died in Chicago yesterday afternoon. He was sixty-one years old. He was born in Brooklyn, and led a life of activity and adventure. When ten years old he enlisted and served as a drummer boy through the Mexican war, and was severely wounded at the battle of Vera Cruz.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Having gained their point and placed the Bland bill where it could be passed at any time they saw fit, the Senators who favor that measure grew magnanimous to-day, and agreed to give its opponents until Thursday to formulate their objections, and endeavor to bring about amendments.

NEW-HAVEN, March 9 -- Yale track athletes have finished their lone Winter training for the annual indoor games, which are scheduled to take place here in the Second Regiment Armory Monday night, March 12. Like all Yale Winter meets, this includes entries from all the leading athletic associations and colleges, and competition is liable to be spirited.
The McLaughlin "machine" is still engaged in a desperate attempt to hoodwink the Democrats of Brooklyn and Kings County Into participating m its pretended scheme of reorganization.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Mr. Cleveland sent to the Senate to-day the nominations of Wallace Macfarlane of New-York to be United States Attorney for the Southern District of New-York, and Edward Grosse of New-York to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District of New-York.

The New-York State Democracy of the Twenty-fourth Assembly District held an enthusiastic meeting at 247 East Eighty-fourth Street last night. Herman Ritter presided, and speeches were made by exMayor William R. Grace, Francis Scott, Col. Robert Grier Monroe, Deputy Collector Henry De Forrest Baldwin, John J. Quinlan, and James J. Dailey, President of the Tile Layers' Union.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 9 -- A motion was made in the Federal court Thursday to disbar Lee Cowart, the attorney who, as special assistant to Examiner Chalmers of the Department of Justice, aided in the investigation into the conduct of North Alabama Federal Commissioners and Deputy Marshals, resulting in the searching report made to the department.

CALCUTTA, March 9 -- Advices from the British column commanded by Capt. Max- | well, which is operating in Assam against the Abors, show that it has sustained serious losses at the hands of the tribesmen, and is retreating on Sadiya.

Surgeon A.T. Weston of the Twelfth Regiment has resigned, owing, it is said, to his dissatisfaction with an order by Col. Heman Dowd. The resignation was handed in after the review last Tuesday night, and Surgeon Weston very brusquely informed Col. Dowd that he would not serve any longer.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 9 -- One of the old towns in Wyoming County, Penn., known as Vosburg, has been brought into considerable prominence during the past week in this locality by the fact leaking out that it has been for fifty years the undisturbed resting place of a genuine wheel-lock gun that has come down from the sixteenth century.

A loan collection of three score paintings greeted the members of the Union League Club Thursday night. They were borrowed and hung by Messrs. R.W. Van Boskerck, Edward H. Wales, J. Howard Ford, Henry T. Sloane, and Clarence Andrews, a committee which shows commendable adroitness in persuading owners of fine pictures that they must lend them for this occasion at any rate.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 9 -- The first art loan exhibition under the auspices of the Montclair Club was opened in the club hall and parlors Thursday, with a reception to club members, about 300 of whom were present.

The reproduction of "The Midway Plaisance" in Madison Square Garden is attracting much attention from the people of this city and from strangers in town. Crowds wander through the villages and theatres and streets of Cairo, looking at the sights which were presented at the World's Fair last Summer. Every performance is introduced by Oriental dances by Fatima and Alima.

The services in memory of Henry Ward Beecher, which was held last evening in the lecture room of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, was marred near the close by a personal controversy between Thomas G. Shearman and Henry Davis as to the propriety of remarks which the latter had made.

The Engineering and Mining Journal, in its issue of March 10, 1894, says: "The Engineering and Mining Journal is enabled, through the hearty co-operation of State Inspectors of Mines and various State officials, and the willing assistance of the operators themselves, to present at this early date complete returns of the coal production of the United States during 1893.

John A. Taylor, ex-Corporation Counsel of Brooklyn, used some pretty sharp language last night regarding New-York's political rule. Mr. Taylor, with ex-Judge Noah Davis and John Sabine Smith, had been invited to address the March meeting of the Patria Club, at Sherry's, on "The Greater New-York."

ALBANY, N.Y., March 9 -- Gov. Flower summoned District Attorney Kelly of Troy before him to-day and conferred with him relative to the prosecutions of the persons concerned in the election crimes committed in Troy last Tuesday. The Governor informed the District Attorney that he desired the matter investigated thoroughly and all guilty persons punished, no matter who they might be.

LONDON, March 9 -- Christopher Furness, member of Parliament for Hartlepool, acting on behalf of the British residents and owners and commanders of British merchant vessels at Rio, has addressed a letter to the Earl of Kimberley, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, requesting him to instruct Capt. John Pipon, senior officer of the British fleet at Rio, to assist in the removal of yellow fever patients from the infected port.

TROY, March 9 -- The funeral of Robert Ross, who was shot in this city election day while trying to prevent repeaters from violating the purity of the ballot box, took place this afternoon. Services were held in the Second Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Although the provisions of the Tariff bill have been made public, there is a possibility that the bill itself may not be reported promptly to the Senate. There is to be a meeting of the Finance Committee to-morrow, and the Republican members have indicated their intention of taking as much time as possible in their examination of the bill.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary Herbert has offered the Boston Towboat Company the chance to attempt the raising of the Kearsarge on the terms prescribed by Congress, which provide for a payment of $45,000 if the vessel is delivered at the Norfolk Navy Yard, or $10,000 if the department is satisfied that no ordinary effort is spared by the company in the attempt.

Harry C. Wiltshaw, the absconding book-keeper of the United States National Bank, was brought to this city from Buffalo and arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday. He was held in $20,000 bail for trial at the next term of the United States Circuit Court in this city. Unable to get bondsmen, Wiltshaw was taken to Ludlow Street Jail.

At last the secret is out. There need no longer be any mystery about the reason for the appointment of the Senate Committee to investigate the Police Department of this city. The committee was appointed to bolster up the Platt-Milholland faction of the Republican Party in this city and further to furnish an excuse for the passage by the Legislature of the Bi-Partisan Police Board bill which Mr. Platt caused to be introduced.
Permits have been granted for the erection of the following new buildings in Brooklyn:

ROME, March 9 -- One of the men injured by the explosion yesterday of the bomb in front of the Chamber of Deputies died in the hospital this morning. It was suspected at first that it was he who threw the bomb, but the suspicion was unfounded. The search of the police for Anarchists last evening and this morning was fruitless. None was found upon whom suspicion rested.

There is something essentially fresh and cheerful about the latest lottery dodge that has been sprung upon a confiding public. Like all other lottery schemes, this new venture, which has its headquarters in Wichita, Kan., is founded on the broad conviction immortalized by "Hungry Joe," that a fool is born every minute in this country.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- All the arrangements for the coaching run between Philadelphia and New-York are now complete, and at 8 o'clock on the morning of Wednesday, May 2, the first four-in-hand will take the run. Starts will be made simultaneously from the Hotel Waldorf, New-York, and the Hotel Bellevue, this city, reaching Princeton together about noon, where luncheon will be served.

The weekly shoot for the Larchmont cups at Larchmont is becoming very interesting. The leaders for the prizes are making a very close race, and missing a bird will now materially change the order of the leaders. The prizes are two cups, valued at $300 and $200 each, for the shooter making the best average during the season.

Services in memory of George W. Childs will be held under the auspices of Typographical Union No. 6 in the Fifth Avenue Theatre at 2 P.M. to-day. An elaborate programme has been prepared, and Bishop Potter and other church dignitaries will take part in the exercises, which promise to be unusually impressive and interesting.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- The market was steady where it was not higher, with one conspicuous exception. New-York Biscuit advanced 2 1/4 points, from 38 to 40 1/4; North Chicago and Alley Elevated sold at about yesterday's figures, 248 and 27, respectively. City Railway was formerly held at 327. West Chicago was quiet between 148 7/8 and 148 3/8.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Postmaster General Bissell made a record for rapid work this afternoon in regard to the plans for the proposed public building at Buffalo, N.Y. The original plans for the new building did not meet with the approval of the board appointed for that purpose, and changes were recommended.

This is primarily a family history, told in letters that were written between 1801 and 1890 by the Countess of Hardwicke, the grandmother; Lady Stuart de Rothesay, the mother; Charlotte, Countess Canning, and Louisa, Marchioness of Waterford, the daughters, and others who were friends of the four.

The play now on at the Lyceum is a significant object lesson. If the dress reformers of the day have their way they will rob women of all the fripperies and chiffons, the fancies and fol-de-rols of costume, and if they succeed a large occupation will be gone. There are not only the agreeable processes of choosing frocks and wearing them, but there is also, often, the pleasure of writing about them.

It is one of the misfortunes of the Government of this city that it is so largely dependent upon the Legislature of the State. Many of the requirements and restrictions of its administration have been laid down by men who would have no adequate understanding of its interests and conditions, even if they were controlled by proper motives.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The West Virginia debt resulation, was defeated in the Virginia Legislature because it would have tied up the certificates under terms fatal to progress, Ventilating its features insured its defeat, and at the same time vindicated the "Baltimore plann." The strength of the Baltimore undertaking lies in the fact that it is vouched for by gentlemen known to and trusted by the people of both States.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 10 -- "Now, ladies, will you keep closer together? There, now; that's better. Forward by twos. Gentlemen in the centre."

The football committee appointed by the University Athletic Club held a session in the clubhouse last night for the purpose of making changes in the playing rules. There were present Chairman Alexander Moffatt of Princeton, Secretary Walter Camp of Yale, and J.C. Bell of the University of Pennsylvania.

An effort will be made to secure the passage of the act to incorporate the Provident Loan Association, now pending in the Legislature at Albany, in essentially the form in which it was first presented. The amendment to which the Assembly agreed limiting the life of the corporation to three years is not acceptable to the men who are thus organizing.
STONY BROOK, L.I., March 10 -- Postmaster William Gould of this town has disappeared. Many regret him, because $15,000 in trust and other funds will have to be accounted for.

NORTHPORT, L.I., March 10. -- David Hendrickson, an old boatman, left here Friday in a small rowboat for Duck Island, three miles out toward the Sound. When he was ready to leave the island the wind had shifted to the south.

To discuss the stock market as it has been the past week is to discuss the movements of Sugar. Outside of this, one may note that while the general list is not specially active it is strong, with an advancing tendency, creeping up a few fractions and holding the advance; while certain of the more speculative stocks, like Chicago Gas and Distillers', seem to be preparing for firework performances.

A curious Welsh wedding custom survives among the peasantry of that country -- that of the "bidding." When a young man and woman become betrothed, a circular, known as a "bidding letter" is printed, and distributed at market and outside the churches on Sunday, that all may know of the event. There is a regular form for this letter, which runs as follows:
The clergymen of Brooklyn intend to make a strong effort to defeat the bill introduced by Senator Owens, legalizing the opening of side doors of saloons on Sundays for the sale of liquor.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The case of Caleb Huse is interesting all army officers, who remember him as a graduate of the Military Academy, as a professor of chemistry in that institution, and subsequently the purchasing agent of the Confederacy in Europe. Mr. Huse, who is a Massachusetts man, and who now lives in New-York, is the subject of a bill for the removal of his political disabilities.

From The Edinburgh Statsman. An experiment is being made at Besancon in France, with a substitute for silk, which will be watched with interest. The invention, that of Count de Charliomet, is to convert wood pulp into soft, silken thread, durable, luminous, and elastic. The "silk" threads produced from the wood pulp were first shown at the last Paris Exhibition, when they enjoyed a good deal of attention among those interested in the silk Industry.

It is many years since Messrs. Manby Wilson got the French hands in their Charenton foundry to eat as much meat as their English hands, and found, as they had hoped, that as soon as the better diet had time to tell, they did nearly as much work as the English, too. Irishmen have long been notoriously poor workmen in their own country.
TROY, March 10 -- The flag which shows that Edward Murphy, Jr., is still in control of the political field in Troy is still flying, but it is dripping with human blood.

The dog pound is abolished, and brutal dog catchers are a thing of the past. Said John P. Haines, the President of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, yesterday: "You Will not read any more complaints in the newspapers that Mrs. or Miss So and So has been knocked in the breast and has had her pet dog taken away from her by force."

[Copyright, 1894, by the United Press.] SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 -- The steamer Australia arrived from Honolulu at 7:30 o'clock this morning, bringing advices to the 3d inst. Since the last dispatch, per Transit, Feb. 20, important movements have been developed.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 10 -- Experts were at work on the books of the New-Jersey Mill and Lumber Company, for which Senator Henry S. Terhune of Matawan was appointed receiver yesterday. James Cunneen of Brooklyn, President of the company, was arrested Wednesday and placed under $600 bail.

At a recent meeting of a society where doctors and lawyers congregate to disagree with one another on medico-legal subjects, the topic discussed was the always pertinent one of suicide. The paper of the evening contended that suicide is in evidence of culture, noting that suicide is almost unknown in undeveloped Arabia, and most common in cultured Paris, and that cultured man commits suicide about three times as frequently as relatively uncultured woman.

That Cecil Rhodes's achievements have been splendid, we should be the last to deny. His amalgamation of all the diamond interests, which was his first success, was a splendid commercial coup, showing, among other thing's, a far-sighted confidence in the naturalness and universality of the human desire for what reason pronounces to be useless gewgaws.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Although the Navy Department has been prompt to offer the reward of $45,000 authorized by Congress to any one who shall bring the Kearsarge back to port, and although the Boston company has lost no time in preparing to send its big steamer to Roncador Reef, no naval officer, not even Lieut. Brainard, who represents the Government on the expedition, has any idea of success.

George, the Count Johannes, was fond of saying, "Ye cannot worship Art and Mammon." And yet he seldom went to the opera. The children of Mammon assemble there and make a pretense of worshipping art, but the simple truth is that they refuse to take art as a serious thing. To them it is an amusement which they attend in its season, precisely as they attend the Yale-Princeton football game or the dog show.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 10 -- Gov. McKinley's second term as Ohio's Chief Executive has thus far proved no improvement upon his first from a strict business standpoint. An atmosphere of scandal continues to hang about a number of the State institutions where McKinley office holders have been enjoying their easy places without much regard for the public welfare.

Like the Lone Fisherman of a famous burlesque. Senator Daniel Bradley of Brooklyn bobs up in a picturesque way from time to time in the investigation which the Senate committee is making into the question of police interference at the polls in this city to oblige Mr. Platt and to bolster up his Milholland faction of the Republican Party and his Bi-Partisan Police Board bill.

Arthur Ballue. The death is announced in Paris of Arthur Ballue, formerly Deputy for the Department of the Rhone and an officer of the French Army. He was born in Conty, Dec. 16, 1835. He was the great-grandson of the member of the convention, Dufriche-Valaze, who committed suicide with a dagger at the revolutionary tribunal when the Girondins were condemned.

By a calculation made a year or two ago by an American statistician, it seems that seventy citizens of the United States possessed among them an aggregate wealth of L540,000,000. That gives an average of about L7,500,000 pounds apiece. To come to particulars: There was one estate -- we refrain here from mentioning names -- returned as worth no less than L30,000,000.

Mr. Murphy's power in Troy is due to three or four prominent reasons. He has business interests which would make any man powerful. He has been in politics, holding public offices, which he has used for his own advantage, long enough to have entrenched himself among that class of people which makes itself felt on election day, and he controls absolutely the so-called "Murphy machine."

THURSDAY, March 15 -- By James S. McQuillen of D. Phoenix Ingraham Co., auction sale, 243 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, north side, 300 feet east of Eighth Avenue, 16.8 by 50 by 100.11, three-story and basement brownstone dwelling.

While the various chraritable institutions of this city have been carrying on the work of feeding and clothing the needy during the present emergency, the Provisional Committee for the Relief of the Poor has been helping men to help themselves by procuring for them suitable employment at which they can earn enough to support their families.

TROY, N.Y., March 10 -- Francis J. Malloy, Mayor-elect, was asked to-day what had been Gov. Flower's purpose in sending for him. He said that the Governor wished to confer with him in regard to the Thirteenth Ward outrage, and that the Governor demanded the punishment of the criminals, whoever they were.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., March 10 -- There was general disappointment to-day when it was announced that the trial of the case of Comings against Walters, for the recovery of 25 cents, was to be adjourned. George Comings is a well-known liveryman, and he was made foreman of a jury which Walters, who is a constable, impaneled a few days ago.

The suppression of the Passion Play in Winfield, L.I., suggests several reflections. When it was proposed, a few years ago, to represent the Crucifixion as a theatrical entertainment under the ordinary conditions of the theatre, all decent people joined in denouncing the attempt, which was abandoned.

HICKORY BUSH, N.Y., March 10 -- While attempting to save the lives of two fellowworkmen who were overcome by coal gas in a kiln of the Lawrence Cement Company here late yesterday afternoon, Thomas Dunleavy and Edward Van Gaasbeck lost their lives. Five other men who tried to rescue them were also overcome, and at one time it was feared all of them had lost their lives.

An Englishwoman suggests a revolt of the brides, purely, let us hasten to add, in the matter of their conventional toilet. "We have long enough borne the burden," she says, "of the hard, white satin gown, with its limitless length of train, unbecoming tulle veil, stiff, wax-like orange blossoms, and ponderous bouquet."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The House of Representatives to-day passed the District of Columbia Appropriation bill after a prolonged debate. Several subjects of great local interest were disposed of during the consideration of the measure, the most important one, perhaps, being that of withdrawing from the District the half of the whole support that has hitherto been borne by the Nation.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The joint commission appointed to investigate the subject of the personnel of the navy held another meeting this morning and listened to the statements of Chief Engineer Melville, Chief Constructor Hichborn, Paymaster General Stewart, and Medical Director Gorgas.

Buckstone -- the "good old Buckstone," the delight of our boyhood -- made a visit to the bright Haymarket something akin to enchantment. Oh, for those days of pure, unalloyed, theatrical pleasure! You went to see not the play, but Buckstone lui-meme. He would figure in some unpretending but satisfactory character in the important piece of the night, and where he aided the others.

The twenty-third ladies day entertainment of the New-York Athletic Club was given yesterday afternoon in the clubhouse, 104 East Fifty-fifth Street. The ladies had possession of the clubhouse from noon until 7 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Secretary Herbert to-day had a dispatch from Admiral Benham, at Rio, regarding the condition of Assistant Paymaster George W. Slmpson of the Detroit, who some time ago was shot in the leg by the discharge of his pistol, which went off as he fell accidentally on the deck of his ship.
Channing sprang to his feet. "You can't mean what you've just said, Carroll!"

The sales at auction of realty in Brooklyn during the past week footed up $187,350, as against $205,700 for the corresponding week last year. The mortgages recorded during the week were 272, for $1,182,337, of which 108, for $752,830, were at 5 per cent. or less. In the similar week last year, 251 mortgages, for $1,038,633, were recorded, of which 135, for $726,410, were at 5 per cent. or less.
