In the preface to his first volume, Chancellor Pasquier expressed his realization of the fact that the term "memoirs" was hardly broad enough to cover the book he purposed to write, but, with somewhat unnecessary modesty, he declared that "history" was a word as much too pretentious as the other was inadequate.

LONDON, March 10 -- The experiment of British politics without Gladstone, which is to enter upon practical operation next Monday, will have a national audience full of eager curiosity as to the performance and all alive with interest in the performers. One cannot help feeling, however, that with American readers it is different.

The authorities of the Presbyterian Hospital have as a patient a mysterious young woman, who was found wandering about aimlessly in Central Park late Friday night on the west side of the reservoir bank opposite Eighty-ninth Street. She was well dressed, and her appearance gave indications of refinement.

If Shakespeare's Portia suffered the pangs of jealousy generally supposed to be a weakness of the feminine mind and heart she would have undergone untold agonies had she witnessed the gathering of modern Portias in the Academy of Medicine, this city, last Wednesday evening.
There is one way of reaching Gettysburg from Gotham which is not down on the charts.

UTICA, N.Y., March 10 -- There has been a great deal of speculation here this week as to the outcome of next Tuesday's proceedings in the Common Council, for on that day the new Council will be organized and the new Mayor will take his seat.

Policeman John Masters, forty years old, of the Union Market Police Station, became insane at his home, 446 Third Avenue, shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning, and for a time his shouts created a great deal of excitement.

At the Berkeley Lyceum next Thursday night, the pupils of the American Academy of the Dramatic Arts will give a unique performance, under the direction of Franklin Sargent. The most interesting features will be the presentation of scenes from "The Contrast" and "Eurydice," which will carry the audience back to the birth of the American drama and of the Italian opera.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- By the acquittal of Daniel Coughlin on his second trial of the charge of being an accomplice to the murder of Dr. P.H. Cronin more mystery bas been thrown about the case. If he was not guilty, were his associate defendants in the first trial guilty? If they were not the murderers, who were?

It ts not an uncommon sight to see a lad too big for his years, with broad, bulky shoulders and precocious beard, and voice rumbling into the cellar. People laugh at him, but in a kindly way, and he blushes and laughs, too, for both they and he realize that each hour he lives is a step toward uniformity.

In the logic of this romance we must bear in mind all the peculiarities of curried mutton. But we are led to inquire why a stable boy should eat curried mutton, for it seems not to be the usual food of those who clean horses. Mutton is expensive meat for the lad who attends to that famous racer, Silver Blaze.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 10 -- Unusual interest centred in the monthly meeting of the Board of Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, which was held this afternoon. It was the first meeting of the Directors held here, and its purpose was to enable them to thoroughly inspect the new office building of the road, just erected at a cost of $500,000.

LONDON, March 10 -- The marriage of Miss Virginia Bonynge, daughter of the California millionaire, Charles William Bonynge, to Viscount Deerhurst took place in the Church of All Saints, Kensington, at 2:30 P.M. to-day. The weather was perfect. Large crowds of men and women were attracted to the vicinity of the church to catch a glimpse of the bride and groom and study the magnificent costumes of the bridal party.

ELLSWORTH, Me., March 10. -- About 4 o'clock this afternoon a construction train on the Maine Central Railroad ran into a team at Gravel Pit Crossing, about two miles east from this station, throwing the caboose and six cars off the track, and severely injuring nine railroad employes. The names of but three of the injured men are known.

A copy of the somewhat famous protest of Rear Admiral da Gama of the Brazilian insurgent fleet to Rear Admiral Benham, following the latter's still more famous order to the revolutionists not to interfere with American vessels in the port of Rio, nas just been received in this city. The following is a verbatim translation of the protest:

In spite of Gunsberg and Hoffer, the principal English chess journalists, who succeeded in influencing English chess amateurs not to send any backing to Lasker, in spite of sneering remarks in Wochenschach, in spite of attempted ridicule from several sources, the match between Steinitz and Lasker will so on.

BOSTON, Mass., March 10 -- Jerome K. Jerome's new comedy, "The Way to Win a Woman," had its first presentation in America at the Hollis Street Theatre tonight by E.H. Sothern and his company, under the direction of Daniel Frohman. A large and select audience assembled to pass judgment on the play, and the general verdict was that it was a success.

Mr. Nathan Straus's undertaking of providing a lodging house in which needy and unemployed men can obtain a bed and a breakfast of coffee and bread for 5 cents has now been in full and successful operation for ten weeks, and it will be continued as long as the emergency which called it into being exists.
The Murphy machine is still rolling on but its wheels are red -- red with the blood of men.

Of the many important features at the meeting of the Vassar College Alumnae Association in New-York recently, one of the most interesting was the singing of the college glee club. The balcony in one end of the salon in which the meeting was held was filled with a charming collection of the "maiden fair" known the length and breadth of the land by the eulogistic appellation of "the Vassar girl."

A flood of white light streams from the walls of the South Gallery at the Fine Arts Building as one enters the sixteenth exhibition of the Society of American Artists. From the line well up the walls this blinding, dazzling whiteness springs to the eyes like the reverberation of the sun on long whitewashed walls in France or Italy.

Under a scientific garb this book treats an old question from a somewhat original point of view. We have heard for some time past of the essential equality of man and woman and of the positive right of the latter under civilized institutions to equal representation with the former and to freedom of action in different fields of labor.
Reports were current in Brooklyn yesterday that John Y. McKane was a defaulter to a large amount.

BERLIN, March 10 -- In the Reichstag tolay Herr Moeller, Chairman of the committee in charge of the Russian-German commercial treaty, reported that measure to the Chamber, and discussion on the question of its second reading was begun by Dr. Hasse, (National Liberal,) who advocated the immediate passage of the treaty through its second stage.

The unusual spectacle of a "cave-in" on Broadway attracted a great deal of attention yesterday, and caused a large crowd to gather around a chasm 40 feet wide and 20 feet deep which had opened in the roadway at Tenth Street. Fortunately, the "cave-in" occurred in the early hours of the morning, when the neighborhood was comparatively deserted, and was not attended with serious results.

Mrs. Annie Dorris, twenty-eight years old, who was found wandering about the streets late Friday night with her two little babies in her arms, was committed temporarily into the custody of the Gerry Society by Justice Voorhis in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday pending an investigation of her story.

The Laetare Medal, which the University of Notre Dame of Notre Dame, Ind., decided last Sunday to bestow this year on Augustin Daly, theatrical manager of this city and London, was established in 1883 by the Trustees of the university as a means of recognition of the services of distinguished laymen of the Catholic Church.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 10 -- Anthony Schmitt, Peter Hammer, Miss Mary Kelly, and Miss Barbara Becker, members of the company that presented the Passion pantomime in St. Mary's Hall, at Winfield, on Sunday night, appeared before District Attorney Noble in this city this morning, in response to the summonses served upon them.

Assemblymen Terry and McNames continued, in the Common Council Chamber Brooklyn, yesterday, the hearing in the contest of William Dwyer against Willlam J. Plant Assemblyman from the First Assembly District of Kings County.

George V.N. Baldwin of the Committee on Education of the City Club has just made public the report submitted to the Board of Trustees of the club about a year ago opposing the demand of the alumni and friends of the College of the City of New-York for money from the Legislature for the purchase of a new site and erection of new buildings for the college.

The big stage of the Central Opera House, Sixty-fifth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, was transformed into a miniature fairyland last night. For two hours little children danced to their heart's content, and to the infinite delight of 2,000 spectators.

Vertical handwriting promises to be the chirography of the rising generation, as its advocates are, by indisputable facts and actual results, successfully demonstrating its advantages over the slanting penmanship so long taught in our schools.

The special Rapid Transit Committee of the Chamber of Commerce has prepared a bill embodying the spirit of the recent meeting of that body, when the views of ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt for the municipal construction of an underground road were formally approved in place of the Wilson plan.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Representative Bartlett filed this afternoon the minority report from the Committee on InterState Commerce on the amended New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill. The report says the new bill, although ostensibly drawn to conform to and meet the objections urged by the President in his veto message against the original bill, does not, in point of fact, do so.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- There are a number of important bills before the House Committee on Civil Service Reform. It is the purpose of the Chairman, Mr. De Forrest of Connecticut, to get the committee together and remain practically in session until the more important of these measures shall have been considered and acted upon.

Commissioner F.W. Wurster ended the contest for Chief Engineer of the Brooklyn Fire Department yesterday by appointing Assistant Chief James Dale to the position. The place has been vacant since the retirement of Thomas F. Nevins, who resigned at the close of Mayor Boody's administration, after thirty years' service. Engineer Dale has commanded the uniformed force of the department in the interval.

The little fruit steamer Premier arrived in port yesterday morning from Bluefields and other Central American ports and brought some interesting information about the trouble in the Mospuito territory and the reported landing of British troops there.

Mr. Drysdale selects the nicest of situations, for they are sure to carry his heroes, Larry and Ferd, through all kinds of adventures. Larry is the New-York lad, but Ferd, his cousin, was born in Port of Spain, Trinidad. Benjamin Kirkwood, Ferd's father, is a planter who cultivates bananas by the shipload.

Edward Murphy has lived in the City of Troy all his life, and for the last twentyfive years has been actively engaged in politics. During all that time he has made his business arrangements of such a character as to strengthen him in his political life. Everything that he has done has helped to give him power as a "boss."

The conferrees appointed by the "machine" Democratic General Committee of Kings County to consider the question of party reorganization met secretly yesterday afternoon at Major James D. Bell's office in the Phoenix Building on Court Street, Brooklyn, Chairman Bell presided. There were present, representing the "regulars," ex-Alderman George M. Nichols, Thomas C. Harden, Ferdinand Munch, John H. Bonnington, Charities Commissioner Charles J. Henry, and Alfred E. Steers.

WEDNESDAY, March 14 -- By Bryan L. Kennelly, resale under foreclosure, Frederick J. Winston, referee, 155 West Seventy-third Street, north side, 250 feet east of Amsterdam Avenue, 20 by 102.2, four-story brownstone dwelling was sold at $23,600, to J.M. Tappen recently, but not taken, because damaged by fire. Due on judgment, $21,175.
ORANGE, N.J., March 10 -- Cards are out for a subscription dance, to be given in Decker Hall Easter Monday evening.

Several thousand visitors inspected the new building of the Brooklyn Warehouse and Storage Company yesterday afternoon. The structure, which was then thrown open to the public, is situated on Shermerhorn Street, near Third Avenue. Part of the site was formerly occupied by the Brooklyn Tabernacle.

The margay, or American tiger-cat, is a little smaller than the ocelot, and not quite so handsome. The legs and feet are spotted in true leopard fashion, but the shoulders, sides, and back are plentifully besprinkled with small, irregular rosettes, or else big, black blotches, which on the shoulders are lengthened into semi-circular bands.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I was grateful to learn by your valuable editorial of the 15th of February that The Times was taking an interest in the Armenian question. Since it would be unjust to expect an outsider to understand the subject in its true light, will you kindly allow me to make a few corrections?

Mme. Marie Roze believes in early dinners on singing days for singers, but not necessarily a meagre diet, which seems to be the shibboleth of most vocal artists who consent to give their opinions on the subject to the press. She advises discretion in the choice of food, however, vetoing pastry, nuts, almonds, raisins, sauces, and pickles.

The geographical term, Eastern Washington, includes that portion of the State that lies east of the summit of the Cascade Mountains. Western Washington is the comparatively narrow strip of land that lies between the summit line and the Pacific Ocean.

Here is a young woman who has the right idea of occupation. She is evidently one of the superfluous women that the statistician is worrying about, such as may not marry and must not become wage earners. This woman plans for neither; she has plenty of time; she writes and shows much skill with the needle.

Major Henry Chauncey, Jr., commander of the Eighth Battalion -- the historic Washington Grays -- was born in Newport, R.I., Aug. 6, 1856. He is a grandson of Henry Chauncey, the organizer of the Panama, the Ohio and Mississippi, and the Illinois Central Railroads and the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.

-- At the Knoedler Gallery, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, some of the color sketches by R.L. Newman are finding favor with buyers. One was sold to the painter Alexander Harrison. A crowd hangs round the front window of this gallery, examining Julian O. Davidson's new marine, "The Sinking of the Congress by the Merrlmack." their sympathies much excited by the sailors in the water.

An experiment made by Nicholas Hoffman, thirteen years old, of 233 Troutman Street, Williamsburg, with a lighted match and a black substance in Bushwick Park yesterday morning gave rise to startling stories, which were published in several afternoon newspapers, about Anarchists' bombs.
"Police Justice Divver will not, in my opinion, come back so soon, if he ever comes back, and if he comes back it will be to abandon his constituents in the Second Assembly District."

YONKERS, N.Y., March 10 -- In nominating John Kendrick Bangs for the office of Mayor of this city the Democrats made a very popular selection. He is a young man, and well and favorably known to the people of Yonkers, where he was born and has grown up. He is fully equipped, intellectually, physically, and morally, to perform the duties of the office for which he has been named.

NORWALK, Conn., March 10 -- A decision handed down yesterday by the Supreme Court of Errors in the celebrated Norwalk case of Lizzie T. Barnes against William H. Starr and others, reverses the finding of ex-Judge John M. Hall, who, after holding the case under advisement for more than six months, rendered judgment for the plaintiff.

The destructive action of the returning electric current in a trolley railroad system upon the gas pipes, water mains, and other pipes lying under the surface of the streets is now the subject of careful inquiry on the part of electrical engineers, gas companies, and the experts employed by City Governments.

A pretty child, with long golden curls, was found crying in the waiting room at the Grand Central Station on Friday evening by Policeman Fox. She said she was Rose McLaughlin, nine years old, a daughter of John McLaughlin of Gravesend, L.I., the horse trainer, and a niece of James McLaughlin, the jockey.

The past week has been a fairly good one among real estate men. Transactions in the way of sales and leases have been more numerous than since the beginning of the year, although much is still to be desired to bring business up to what it should be at this season of the year. There is, however, an actual demand for property and a great deal of seeking for the desirable kinds.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- If the Tariff bill is reported to the Senate before next Thursday the Republican members of the Finance Committee will be very much surprised. They say that they ought to have at least a week to examine it, but that they may possibly conclude their scrutiny by the last day of next week's session.

Much bitterness of feeling exists in the fashionable Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Ignatius, in Fortieth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, over the fact, which has just become generally known, that Bishop Henry C. Potter has left the church off his list for visitation for the administration of the rite of confirmation this ecclesiastical year.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Secretary Herbert to-day sent to the House of Representatives his reply to the Boutelle resolution calling for information as to the authority by which the Secretary of the Navy placed the armed naval forces at Honolulu under the orders of Commissioner Blount.

The field of the struggle against bossism, which a few weeks since was in Kings County, has changed for the present to Troy. The change was made by Senator Edward Murphy, Jr. When the election for Mayor was approaching, the Senator left the arduous duty of seeking protection for collars and cuffs at Washington and proceeded to take charge of affairs in Troy, where his rule was threatened.

Much bitterness of feeling exists in the fashionable Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Ignatius, in Fortieth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, over the fact, which has just become generally known, that Bishop Henry C. Potter has left the church off his list for visitation for the administration of the rite of confirmation this ecclesiastical year.

JAMAICA, March 10 -- The steam yacht Natalie, which was purchased in New-York and which sailed from Savannah Jan. 19 with arms and ammunition to be used by Gen. Manigat in an attempt to overthrow President Hippolyte of Haiti, has been captured by the Haitians and taken to a Haitian port.

Mr. Balestier's posthumous novel is rather disappointing, for it is an ambitious work and it has positive merits, the author's style being clear and graceful and his descriptive powers, so far as inanimate nature is concerned, ample. But with the portrayal of human character he is much less successful, and that is a sad fault in a novel.
Gloom has settled permanently over Wil loughby Street. Not a ray of hope appears to relieve the depression which has fallen on the deposed "boss" and his former fol lowers.

The situation is strange, lurid, and in a sense humiliating. Armed Europe waits upon the ultimate mandate of one man. "The heaven for height," says Solomon, "the earth for depth, and the heart of kings is unsearchable." Czar Alezander III. has two ruling emotions -- a horror of war and a hatred of Germany.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 10 -- At the hotels many people are expected for Easter, with booking lists that date well into April. Socially, the week has been a quiet one, with all interest centred in the coming of the Princeton Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs, which will give an entertainment at the Lakewood Hotel next Friday night.

Preparations are already being made for a relay bicycle run from Washington to Denver, the biggest affair of the kind ever attempted. Amateur wheelmen two years ago took part in a relay race from New-York to Chicago, a distance of 1,000 miles. Nearly all the wheeling was in a driving rain, over roads that could not well be worse, but the result proved the practicability of using bicycles in military courier work.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Treasury Department will begin business on Monday with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

The trade and manufactures of the Christian realm in Palestine were regulated. Moslem caravans were protected by treaty, and merchants of Mosul were established in Acre. The imposts on every Kind of merchandise were fixed, and Custom Houses and toll bars were established along the roads or at the city gates.

Grieg is always true to the Norwegian coloring, and the freedom of gesture and motion characteristic of peasant life is in his music. The strong contrast produced by marked emphasis and rythm combined with syncopation, the constant recurring effects of light and shade through proper attention to dynamics, are very marked.

Carl and Theodor Rosenfeld begin their term at the Fifth Avenue Theatre to-morrow night, producing a three-act farce called "Love's Extract." This treats of the adventures of a New-England farmer and his family, who came to New-York to live, the daughter of the farmer being engaged to marry a young New-Yorker, whom she has never met, (not a very likely story, by the way.)

Representatives of the fruit trade gathered in large numbers at the New-York Fruit Exchange yesterday to discuss the advisability of organizing all the fruit interests in this city into one Exchange. Among those present were a number of importers, members of the New-York Fruit Exchange, the Fruit Buyers' Union, the Fruit and Produce Dealers' Association, and the local branch of the National League of Commission Merchants.

If it were possible to shut off from a boy all the influence of home, and to confine him absolutely to public-school life and university life, the resultant pure product of what we call "education" would be such a barbarous cub or insufferable prig as we can only conceive by carefully observing the approaches to these types which are occasionally produced at present.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, March 10 -- P.M. Trading was fairly active for a Saturday, but more than 50 per cent. of it was in three stocks -- Sugar, St. Paul, and Chicago Gas. The opening prices were firm, and the market continued to advance under the lead of Sugar during the first hour.

There was a mysterious explosion last night in front of 95 Park Street. Fortunately no person was injured, but all the houses in the vicinity were jarred and windows were blown out, while many tenants felt the shock of the concussion. Some were thrown from chairs in their apartments.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed a decrease in reserve of $145,525. The banks now hold $75,633,375 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans of $646,100, a decrease in specie of $162,500, an increase in legal tenders of $357,600, an increase in deposits of $1,362,500, and a decrease in circulation of $106,300.

The present is the second volume of a series of three on the Book of Psalms, and forms part of "The Expositor's Bible." It contains Psalms xxxix. to Ixxxix., with a revised critical translation and illustrative comments. Dr. Maclaren is a distinguished Scotch Baptist clergyman, and has ministered for more than thirty years to the people of Union Chapel, Manchester, England.

The wreck of the old Kearsarge on the Roncador Cay is answerable for still more than the loss of the most honored and famous ship we had in commission. It has involved anxiety also on account of the lack of a vessel to look after American interests upon the Mosquito coast.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11 -- The 'Varsity crew has been narrowed to thirteen, and the following men sat at the training table last Wednesday for the first time: Bullard, Fennessey, Blake, Townsend. Murchie, A. Brewer, Purdon, Richardson, Cameron, F. Davis, Derby, C. Brewer, and Beals.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- There has been an active demand here to-day for copies of The New-York Times containing the history of Senator Murphy and details of his long and troublous political career in Troy.

Justice of the Peace Kenneth F. Sutherland of the town of Gravesend, indicted by the Extraordinary Grand Jury for oppression, who was tried before Justice Cullen a week ago, the jury disagreeing -- nine for conviction, three for acquittal -- will be Placed on trial again to-day.

It has been definitely decided that all recitations and examinations in the old university building are to be finished by Thursday, May 17. In view of the early closing of college, the Spring vacation of one week will be given up in order to give the professors sufficient time to finish their respective courses. The old building is to be torn down immediately after the 17th inst.

PROVIDENCE, March 10 -- A slightly better demand and an increased number of transactions in the better class of stocks are the characteristic features of the week in the local stock market. This demand is more noticeable, and the majority of transactions have been in the bank-stock list, which is regarded as a favorable feature.

When The New-York Times a few weeks ago alluded to the fact that the higher and better class of theatrical organizations were boycotting San Francisco and the Pacific coast and explained it by the well-established fact that for the past three or four years the citizens of the coast have shown little appreciation for high art, a howl of indignation swept over the continent from San Francisco.
Some enterprising marine novelist may find in the experience of Capt. Dauphney of the British bark J.H. Hamlen, now moored at Pier 11 East River, a subject for his pen.

Gustave Ruppert, forty-four years old, attempted to commit suicide at 20 Dey Street yesterday with arsenic. He lived until last September at 220 West Madison Street, Chicago. Last August he wrote to the widow of his brother Francis, who has a restaurant at 20 Dey Street, saying that he could get no work and was so despondent that he would commit suicide.

NEW-MARKET, N.H., March 11 -- A fire started at 11:45 o'clock last night in a tenement occupied by Ned Bideaux and situated over F.D. Durgin's drug store. The block, which was owned by Mr. Durgin, was totally consumed. The fire spread to the building on the north owned by B.F. Haley and occupied by J.M. Caswell, dealer in Yankee notions, the Lamprey Club, and the Grand Army of the Republic Hall.

The Fifth Avenue Theatre was crowded to its fullest capacity yesterday afternoon on the occasion of the memorial services held for George W. Childs under the auspices of Typographical Union No. 6. Many prominent public men were present. The services were opened by Bishop Potter. The musical programme was very elaborate, and was carried out successfully under the direction of Frank Damrosch.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 11. -- Arrangements for the Eastern trip of the Cornell Glee and Banjo Clubs have been completed. The clubs will leave Ithaca March 26, and will give twelve concerts, one in each of the following cities: Erie, Penn.; Dayton, Indianapolis, St. Louis, Chicago, Madison, Duluth, St. Paul, Minneapolis, Milwaukee, Detroit, and Buffalo.

BOSTON, March 11 -- The annual scratch games and the New-England indoor championships of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Athletic Club, held in conjunction with the First Regiment Athletic Association, were held in the South Armory last night. The events were well contested and afforded considerable excitement, but no records were broken.

A suit to recover $1,000, which will come up in the April term of the Supreme Court, is likely to affect millions of dollars worth of real estate in this city. The property concerned once belonged to the Rhinelander estate, most of which has now passed into other hands.

NEW-YORK, Monday, March 12 -- A.M. The week on the Street was full of speculative interest, due principally to the wild fluctuations in Sugar stock. On Saturday last it closed at 84 7/8, on Monday sold between 85 5/3 and 90, and on Tuesday, after early weakness, during which it sold at 88, it jumped to par within a few minutes and on small transactions.

TROY, March 11 -- The "special Troy edition" of The New-York Times, containing a sketch of Edward Murphy, Jr., has been in great demand here. No New-York paper has ever sold in this city as The New-York Times sold to-day. Troy newsdealers were telephoning to Albany long before noon for spare copies of the paper.
"Why Church Property Should Be Taxed" was the subject of the Rev. Madison C. Peters's sermon last evening in the Bloomingdale Church, Boulevard and West Sixty-eighth Street. Mr. Peters said:

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 -- The number of candidates for the 'Varsity baseball team has, during the past week, been reduced to twenty. Twelve of these are candidates for the battery, and these men are under the supervision of Coach Terry, and are being submitted to vigorous training. They are as follows: For Pitcher -- Altman, '97; Bradley, '97; Forsythe. '94; Hetzrot, '97; Nelson, '97, and Jayne, '97.

We publish this morning a long and interesting letter on the American situation sent to The London Times by Mr. J.W. Cross. The editor of The Times explains its publication by the remark: "Well-considered opinions which run counter to a general belief always deserve attention, and in this case we think the general belief is rather too hopeful, though not so oversanguine as Mr. Cross maintains."

Patrick Divver, in the heydey of his success and popularity, was never more talked about in the Second Assembly District than yesterday. His constituents, in spite of the lowering, foggy weather, appeared to have gossip for their sole recreation, and the absence of the leader, the revolt in the district, and the fate of the election officers who did "The Judge's" bidding were discussed at nearly every street corner and in many a doorway.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 11 -- There was a secret and decidedly mysterious meeting of railroad men in this city yesterday afternoon, but the efforts of the interested parties to keep the matter from the public failed. Hereafter, Eastern business from this city will be pooled between the Pennsylvania, Baltimore and Ohio South-western, and Big Four.

Psychology, which used to be called mental or intellectual philosophy, is a department of philosophy to which of late years much and careful study has been applied. In the generation now passed, or passing away, the names of President Porter of Yale, President Walker of Harvard. Dr. McCosh of Princeton, Dr. W.D. Wilson of Cornell, Francis Bowen, and others in America have attained well-deserved distinction.

Thomas G. Shearman spoke last evening before the Manhattan Single-Tax Club, at Chickering Hall, Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, on "Morality and Taxes." The speaker said that taxes had a direct petition, and encourages great combinations bearing on morality. The excise tax, he continued, breeds rascality, destroys competition and encourages great combinations of capital.

BERLIN, March 11 -- The debate on the Russian treaty yesterday disappointed the crowded House. It was begun with vigor, but lost interest rapidly after Chancellor von Caprivi and Freiherr Marschall von Bieberstein made their short, businesslike replies to the attacks of the opposition.

This volume is a creditable addition to popular musical literature. The author has in less than 300 pages written accounts of the lives, works and tendencies of Ambroise Thomas, Gounod, Massenet, Reyer, Saint-Saens, and Bruneau, and has given brief notices of Joncieres, Dubois, Widor, Godard, Paladhile, D'Indy, Faure, and Chabrier.

Those who note reports made by ship Captains are, doubtless convinced that any marine happening of importance must occur in the vicinity of Cape Hatteras. Nearly every voyager who passes that tempestuous region has something to chronicle about his journey. Whales have been run into there, ships dismasted, St. Elmo's lights have been seen in lurid abundance, and now comes Capt. Coull of the steamship Castilian Prince, who has something to say about Hatteras waterspout.

Nothing that has appeared in the newspapers for years has created so much excitement among Irish-Americans of the extreme class as the article on the Cronin murder which appeared in The New-York Times of yesterday. It is a topic of conversation wherever members of any of the Irish revolutionary societies met.

The bomb thrower who, Saturday night, amused himself or gratified malicious or revengeful propensities at 95 Park Street had escaped arrest up to last night. The miscreant shattered into fragments the large plate-glass window in front of the banking house and saloon of A. Defeo, at 95 Park Street, and broke nearly every pane of glass there and in houses opposite.

The new edition of The Coal Trade, the annual compendium issued by The Coal Trade Journal, will be published in a few days. It has been prepared by Frederick E. Saward, who has been an authority for years on this subject, and contains information on the coal business in this and foreign countries, collected from official and other reliable sources, conveniently arranged for reference.

NORWALK, Conn., March 11 -- Yachtsmen residing along the shore, between this city and Bridgeport, are interesting themselves over an innovation in aquatic sport that promises to furnish considerable amusement when the season opens.

ORANGE, N.J., March 11. -- George O. Mowbray, a dentist, died in the Orange Memorial Hospital to-day in peculiar circumstances. He was found Saturday afternoon in his office in an unconscious condition, and taken to the hospital where he died without recovering consciousness. The doctors at the hospital diagnosed the case as apoplexy.

During the past Winter a wonderful work for religion and charity has been done in East New-York by the evangelists Ferdinand and George W. Schiverea. Not only have the preached to multitudes, but they have, in fact, clothed the naked and fed the hungry.

OXFORD, Penn., March 11 -- The United Presbyterian congregation's new church in Oxford was dedicated to-day. The Rev. T. W. Anderson of New-York preached the dedicatory sermon and presented the new church to the Trustees. The pastor, the Rev. Adolphus Power Hutchison, made the acceptance speech.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11 -- In the course of his work upon the literary bequests of James Russell Lowell, Prof. Charles Eliot Norton has found much matter of interest to present students and graduates of Harvard. Accordingly he has put the college in his debt by sending the following letter to The Crimson:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 11 -- The management of the Yale Glee and Banjo Clubs an- nounces that this Spring a Southern trip will be taken as far as Richmond and Old Point Comfort. The usual forty-five men will be taken along, and concerts given as follows: March 22, Baltimore; March 23, Washington; March 24, Old Point Comfort; March 26, Richmond, and March 27, Washington.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 11 -- The report of the landing of the British at Bluefields, in the Mosquito reservation, was confirmed to-day upon the arrival at this port of the steamer Elliott, Capt. A. Brown. The Elliott, which is a British steamer, left Blueflelds March 4. She arrived there Feb. 27, just one day too late to witness the arrival of the Nicaraguans at Bluefields.

Rabbi Joseph Silverman lectured in Temple Emanu-El yesterday on "The Mistakes of Ingersoll" in response to "The Mistakes of Moses." Dr. Silverman treated Col. Ingersoll's views separately for disposal, first showing how passages in the Bible were misconstrued, and Dr. Silverman declared that Ingersoll's interpretations were those of a lawyer to help his case against Moses.

Youthful Garrison, or "Garry" Ball, as his intimates and former fellow-students in the Bellevue Medical College call him, who distinguished himself by eloping with and marrying Mrs. Florence Myrsinger, a young widow, who afterward sued him for separation because of desertion, and his father, David Ball, the millionaire broker, for alienating her husband's affections, is back in town with his wife, and says a reconciliation has been effected with his parents.

To-night the Outing Athletic Club of Brooklyn will give a boxing tournament at the Flatbush Academy, and some interesting bouts are promised. The hall is just over the city line, and, on that account, out of the jurisdiction of the Brooklyn authorities. The entry list is long. "Snapper" Garrison will act as referee, and Frank D. Creamer of the Seawanhaka Boat Club and W.H. Roberts of the National Athletic Club will do the judging.

Columbia College will celebrate the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of Christian Diez, the founder of Romance Philology, this week. Prof. Diez was born at Gelssen. In Kesse Darmstadt, on March 15, 1794. He studied at the university in his native town, and, after study in Italy, filled the chair in archaeology and Greek literature in his alma mater.

The subjoined letter is worthy of careful study, although, or rather because, it takes a less favorable view of the prospects of a speedy recovery of business in the United States than is generally accepted here.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Representative Boutelle of Maine is not satisfied with the answer to his Hawaiian resolution which was laid before the House of Representatives yesterday. Speaking on the subject to-night, he said:
PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 11 -- The bitter struggle for the Postmastership of Plainfield is practically ended. John Hetfield undoubtedly will get the place.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., March 11 -- At noon to-day a life boat was descried making for the Cape Race Signal Station, which, two hours later, proved to be one belonging to the steamer Briscoe, containing First Mate Mackey and four men, in an exhausted condition. They reported the Briscoe lying about sixty miles south-southwest, off Cape Race.

The crack military regiment of Brooklyn, the Twenty-third, turned out a goodly number of militiamen Saturday evening, when Col. Alexis C. Smith paraded at the head of the organization for the first time since he became Colonel.

"The Modern Saint " was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's lecture yesterday before the Society of Ethical Culture, in Music Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue. He was listened to with interest by a large and appreciative audience.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 -- An effort is being made to arrange a debate with Harvard. Tha failure to do so will be very disappointing to nearly all Princeton men, as they ore deeply interested in these contests. A letter containing an ultimatum in regard to this debate was recently sent to Harvard by the joint committee of the two Princeton literary societies.

Justice Charles D. Long of the Michigan Supreme Court is unable to see that the history of his pension exhibits some of the most objectionable features of the pension, system as it exists to-day, or that this history, together with his public utterances and appeals to the courts, ought to deprive him of the respect of fairminded and unbiased men.
One stolen can of milk recovered. Two milk thieves, who were chasing the thief who stole the can, captured.

From The Washington Star. President Washington, always a strict economist in household matters, and in the management of his vast landed interests, expended large sums for the times in which he lived for horses which drew his coach and for those which he used, under the saddle.

Mr. Bah Thaw is in town; also Mrs. Bah Thaw. Also Mr. Hpa Min and Mrs. Hpo Min and their children, and Messrs, and Mesdames Mano Singho, Jusaj Bottiggu, Mariawilan, Podi Nona, Thoomas Perera, and others.

Capt. Anthony Salinas, who commanded the steam yacht Natalie, the vessel which was said to have been fitted out by Haitien revolutionists, and whoso crew was recently reported to have been shot by Hippolyte's orders, was a passenger by the steamship Alps, which yesterday arrived from Port au Prince.

United States Deputy Marshal W. Dow is on the high seas on board a Cromwell Line ship bound for New-Orleans, having in custody Chin Ah Loi and Chin Ah Sing, whom he is under orders to deport, while Chinatown is blandly smiling because one of Dow's prisoners, Chin Ah Juna, slipped away from him at the pier in this city.

At the monthly dinner of the Republican Club last evening, at the clubhouse, 450 Fifth Avenue, the subject of municipal reforms received paramount consideration. It was discussed by Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn and ex-Secretary of the Navy Benjamin F. Tracy, who is now under serious consideration as the next Republican candidate for Governor of the State.

The three-act farce called "Love's Extract," produced by the Messrs. Rosenfeld at the Fifth Avenue Theatre, last night, turned out to be a version of a lively and indecent French piece called "Les Petites Voisines," which was acted here in German by Mr. Amberg's company, in April, 189O, under the title of "Die Nachbariunen," In French the piece is probably gay and sparkling.

The lovers of good boxing and wrestling will be given a rare treat at Madison Square Garden on March 19 and 21. On these two evenings the Amateur Athletic Union will hold its annual boxing and wrestling championships, and from present indications it will be the most successful entertainment of its kind ever given in America.

The contest over the will of Frederick A. Lovecraft, late manager of Palmer's Theatre, which began yesterday before Surrogate John H.V. Arnold, may unravel the mystery which surrounded the testator's suicide on Oct. 6, 1893, and disclose the reasons that induced him to leave his entire fortune to his friend, Col. Henry S. Kearney, without making provision for his mother and sisters.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate has decided that it is not worth while to investigate the charges so freely made in the last fortnight that some of its members speculated in sugar on the strength of their knowledge of the Finance Committee's prospective action on the Tariff bill. The Peffer resolution calling for an official inquiry into this matter was to-day laid on the table.

Several hundred lovers of the fistic art gathered at Schwalbach's Flatbush Academy last night, when some of the trial bouts of a boxing tournament got up by the Outing Athletic Club were decided. The entry list included several well-known amateurs in the 110, 125, and 140 pound classes. The bouts without exception were interesting and occasionally exciting.

TRENTON, N.Y., March 12 -- The argument which is to lead to a determination concerning the constitutional status of the two Senates of New-Jersey was continued before the Supreme Court to-day. Allen L. McDermott, counsel for Robert Adrain, President of the Democratic Senate, finished his address and ex-Judge Stevens of counsel for the State began his address.

In spite of the delays and other drawbacks incident to a first performance, "The Girl I Left Behind Me," by David Belasco and Franklin Fyles, had a strong presentation last night at the Academy of Music. The sweeping scenic effects possible on a stage of such capacity were calculated, perhaps, to dwarf the actors at first, for a few persons set before a stretch of mountain and wide horizon cut but small figure.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 12. -- Track athletes held their annual indoor carnival at Yale to-night. It was the Winter meet of the Yale Athletic Association, and a list of 500 entries, including leading men from Boston, New-York, New-Jersey, New-Haven, and Worcester athletic associations and Harvard, Dartmouth, and Columbia Colleges, made the most imposing array of visiting talent ever presented here.
The Rapid-Transit Committee of the Chamber of Commerce put the last touches yesterday afternoon to the bill which it will send to Albany this week. Its main features have been published.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Edward Douglass White of Louisiana was to-day installed as an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court. The company which witnessed the installation included Mrs. Harlan, Mrs. Shiras, and Mrs. Brewer, wives of members of the court; Mrs. Carlisle, Mrs. Bissell, Frederic R. Coudert, John K. Cowen of Baltimore, and ex-Attorney General Garland.
It was at the Star Theatre last night, and the curtain had fallen on the last act of "Rosedale." The large audience was slowly making its way toward the exits.

The Bridge Trustees, smarting under the severe lashing they received at the hands of Senator Daniel Bradley in the Senate last week, are now trying to put themselves in a better light by voluntarily asking for an investigation.

VICTORIA, B.C., March 12, per steamship Warrimoo, Honolulu, March 4 -- Since the departure of the Australia on the 3d inst., no item of public interest has transpired, except that in the Circuit Court yesterday the five cases of criminal libel against Walter A. Smith, editor of The Star. were dismissed, no indictment having been prepared.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent throughout the day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 12 -- An elaborate criticism of the Yale crew has been prepared by Capt. Johnson and the coaches who have had charge of the oarsmen recently. It is based upon the work of the candidates during the entire season of indoor rowing in the tank, and is probably the last criticism to be issued till the crew leaves for New-London in June. It is as follows:

BALTIMORE, March 12 -- Arthur L. Reese, chief electrician of the Maryland Steel Company, was killed this afternoon. Reese was to have delivered a lecture on electricity before the Epworth League of the Methodist Episcopal Church at Sparrow's Point this evening, and was preparing his apparatus when the accident occurred.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 12 -- Superintendent Crooker's annual report of the Department of Public Instruction was laid before the Legislature this evening. Mr. Crooker strenuously opposes the present dual-headed system of distributing the public school funds, by which private educational estabments share with the common schools. The report says:
The New-York Exchange for Woman's Work, 329 Fifth Avenue, opened an Easter sale yesterday for the benefit of poor women who have supplied the articles offered for sale.

It was said at Assemblyman Callahan's place in Park Row, last night, that Police Justice Patrick Divver, whose whereabouts have been a matter of great solicitude for some time to his followers in the Second Assembly District, would return to New-York on Friday night.

Four proprietors of east side hotels were arrested yesterday on warrants procured in the Yorkville Police Court by Capt. Wishart and Detective Lennon of Dr. Parkhurst's Society. All the arrests were made in the precinct commanded by Capt. Martens, whose case on charges of dereliction of duty is still pending.
Mr. F. Zittel has sold, for Richard Deeves, to J. Baldwin, the four-story stone-front dwelling 9 West Eighty-first Street, fronting on Manhattan Square, 23 by 90 by 102, for $90,000.
The first and only public concert of the Musurgia of New-York will be given for charity in the Carnegie Music Hall next Thursday evening.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- St. Paul, Reading, and Philadelphia Traction were all quite active to-day, but the transactions in Reading were more than half of all the business done. An attempt was made to advance Lehigh Valley, and it was bid up to 41 1/4. This price seemed to bring out a fair amount of long stock, and the quotation receded to 41 again.

A burglar who has been causing a great deal of trouble in Harlem during the last three weeks was captured early yesterday morning while he was attempting to pry open a door leading into the cellar of the residence of Bernard Goodstein, 203 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street. He had with him a valise, which contained a burglar's complete outfit.

The fourth week of the evangelistic revival meetings being held in Association Hall and in many of the city churches began yesterday, with an increased representation of churches and a larger attendance than at any meeting heretofore. The services opened yesterday with a conference of ministers, composing the Central Committee, in the parlore of the Young Men's Christian Association.

J.W. Goff made the following statement last night before the Bar Association, in East Twenty-ninth Street, concerning his connection with the Senate Committee on Cities investigating the affairs of the Police Department in this city:

Mr. Alexander Harrison has twice before made a showing of his finished works and sketches at the galleries of the American Art Association, but this year he offers nearly fourscore paintings, which prove the steady progress he has made on the technical side of his profession, as well as his increased power of production.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Senator O'Connor's Bi-partisan Election Inspectors bill is as far away from the point where it may become a lew as ever. The conference committee which was appointed to adjust the amendments last week reported to-night that they could not agree. They asked to be discharged from further consideration, and that a new committee be named. This was agreed to by the two houses.

Prof. J. Leonard Corning gave the fourth lecture of the course on "Art Studies in Comparative Religion" at Hardman Hall, Fifth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, yesterday afternoon. The subject was "The To-morrow of Death as Symbolized in the Art of the Ages."

The finding of three dynamite bombs and nine paper dynamite cartridges, all fully charged and primed and capable of doing terrible execution, created a big sensation in the Police Department and kept Police Inspectors. Captains and detectives hunting about all day yesterday for information as to the purpose for which they had been made.

John Pomeroy Townsend was elected President of the Bowery Savings Bank yesterday at the annual meeting of the Trustees of that institution. Mr. Townsend is the eighth President of the bank since it received its charter in 1834. He succeeds Edward Wood, who died a couple of months ago, and who had held office since 1880.

Commissioner Andrews of the Department of Street Cleaning desires to have the law of 1892, regulating the administration of that department, so amended that he can accomplish the object for which it was passed. One of the important recommendations of the Advisory Board whose efforts secured the legislation of 1892 was that the department should be permanently equipped with the plant and appliances necessary for its work.

The second trial of Justice Kenneth F. Sutherland of Coney Island for oppressing the Gaynor copyists at the Gravesend Town Hall Nov. 5 last, was begun yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, Brooklyn.

BERLIN, March 12 -- Consideration of the second reading of the Russian-German commercial treaty was resumed in the Reichstag to-day. Count von Mirbach, Conservative, denounced the Government for giving away under the provisions of Article XIX., the right of an autonomous railway policy.

TROY, N.Y., March 12 -- Assistant District Attorney Fagan said to-night: "I was summoned to-day at 3 o'clock to a conference with Gov. Flower with regard to election crimes committed last Tuesday, and, after a long consultation with the Governor, I was intrusted with full charge of the prosecution of these crimes and urged to use every effort to bring the guilty parties to justice.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The American Consul at Maracaibo reports to the State Department that the Motilone Indians, who are noted as the most barbarous people on the American continent, have resumed atrocities. They live on the River Catutumbo, in Venezuela. It is said that they have resorted to such measures that civilized persons have been driven from the rich districts recently settled.

Sir James Fitzjames Stephen. The death is announced in London of Sir James Fitzjames Stephen, the eminent jurist and Judge of the Exchequer Division of the High Court of Justice. He was born in Kensington, Gore, London, March 3, 1829. His father was Sir James Stephen. He was graduated from Trinity College, Cambridge, in 1852, and two years later was called to the bar at the Inner Temple.

Patrick Walsh, thirty-six years old, who kept a little cigar store at 6 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, died at noon yesterday from an overdose of morphine which he took at 9 o'clock Sunday night while suffering from melancholia. About six months ago Walsh, who was addicted to the morphine habit, was discharged from his position as clerk in Mills Gibb's house in Lower Broadway because he neglected his duties.

LONDON, March 12 -- A meeting of the Liberal leaders was held at noon at the Foreign Office. There was a full attendance. Mr. John Morley, Lord Rosebery, and Sir William Harcourt made speeches which elicited prolonged cheers.

The insurrection began the night of Sept. 5, 1893, when Admiral de Mello attempted to repeat the coup de main by which he had driven President da Fonseca from power. While the high Government officials were at the opera he seized all the Brazilian war vessels in the harbor of Rio de Janeiro and demanded President Peixoto's resignation.

In the Court of Common Pleas yesterday Judge Pryor gave a decision in the action brought by Giuseppe Gentilesco against the Excise Board to compel the board to transfer his license from 19 Cherry Street to 100 Bayard Street. The case was brought to test the act of 1893 relative to the transfer of a liquor license to within 200 feet of a church or schoolhouse.
Chauncey M. Depew last night delivered a lecture on his last trip to Europe, and his interview with the Pope, in the lecture hall of the Catholic Cub, in Fitty-ninth Street, before nearly 700 people.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Counsel engaged in the Pollard-Breckinridge breach of promise suit came to blows today. W. G. Johnson of counsel for plaintiff was slapped in the face, and Calderon Carlisle, with whom he is associated, was hit on the back of the head. The encounter took place immediately after adjournment.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Gov. Flower was informed to-day that the gentlemen suggested by him as special counsel in the prosecution of election crimes committed in Troy last Tuesday were not entirely satisfactory to the committee of citizens. He thereupon summoned Assistant District Attorney Fagan and told him that he should depend upon him to make a vigorous and thorough prosecution of all those violations of law.

A bill has been introduced in the Senate at Albany by Mr. Bradley of Kings County and in the Assembly by Mr. Sulzer of this city, which provides for submitting to a vote of the people at the next general election the question of issuing State bonds to the amount of $12,000,000 for the improvement of the Erie. Champian, and Oswego Canals.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Bland bill will undoubtedly pass the Senate, but not until all its objectionable and dangerous features shall have been pointed out to the country. The truce patched up on Friday has given the opponents of the bill a good opportunity to dissect it, and the dissections do not reveal any good reason why Democratic Senators should fall over each other in their efforts to help Senator Harris pass it.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. T. A. Kerrigan conducted eleven sales, with the following results: To William B. Boulton, for $2,100, he sold the two-story frame dwelling 1,701 Dean Street, north side, 516.2 feet east of Rochester Avenue, 16.8 by 107.2%. To Teunis S. Remsen, plaintiff, he sold, for $5,100, the three-story and basement brick dwelling 463 Kosciusko Street, north side, 75 feet east of Lewis Avenue, 17.6 by 100.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- There is no diminution of effort by different interests to secure increased protection in the Tariff bill, which will be reported to the Senate probably at the end of a week. Senators on both sides of the Chamber are being importuned by representatives of the different trusts and of private concerns to ask for greater concessions than the Democratic members of the Finance Committee were willing to grant.

BOSTON, March 12 -- It was a busy scene this morning at the Boston Towboat Company's wharf at East Boston, where the wrecking steamer Orion was getting aboard stores and wrecking machinery preparatory to starting for the scene of the wreck of the Kearsarge on Roncador Reef. Work has been carried on night and day without once stopping, ever since she came into the dock on Saturday.

NEW-YORK, Monday, March 12 -- P. M. For the first time in many weeks the speculation in Sugar did not overshadow the remainder of the market. The trading in it amounted to only a little more than 25,OOO shares, while that in St. Paul exceeded those figures by a couple of thousand shares.

PITTSBURG, March 12 -- Signs of returning confidence in manufacturing circles continue. All the departments of the Cambria Iron Works, at Johnstown, which have been idle, resumed business this morning. The Johnstown Steel Works, at the same place, also started up after an idleness of three months.
A thief broke into the Zion Baptist Church, 451 Seventh Avenue, a week ago and stole an overcoat owned by J.B.K. Butlar, the sexton.

The second half of the "team of five " match was decided on Saturday night at the range of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-seventh Street and Park Avenue. The conditions of this match are: Open to one team of five men from each company, one from the field staff, and non-commissioned staff, and one from the veterans.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The State Department received two important dispatches from Minister Thompson at Rio this evening. The first one stated that Admiral Saldarha da Gama had offered, through the Portuguese naval commander, to surrender on condition that he and his followers should be guaranteed safety.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- The local market presented a rather tired appearance, and most of the trading was between brokers, with an entire absence of any outside inquiry. Business was chiefly done In West Chicago, Diamond Match, and Alley "L," and in the two former many of the sales were of small lots.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 12 -- The Coroner's jury in the Newtown Creek Bridge disaster of Jan. 12, which resulted in the drowning of nine men, to-day returned a verdict censuring Engineer John McLaughlin, under whose supervision the bridge was constructed. The verdict virtually makes the counties of Queens and Kings responsible for the nine deaths.

ROCKLAND, Me., March 12. -- The Star Publishing Company has been incorporated for the publication of a daily morning paper in this city. The officers are: President -- W.B. Nash; Treasurer -- F.B. Nichols. The Directors are the above named and S.D. Graves. The editor in chief will be W. R. Farrington.

Mrs. Louis Zehner, principal witness in the case for arson against Julius Raschdorf of 44 Division Street, created considerable excitement when she left the stand in Part III., General Sessions yesterday. She accused Louis Marks, janitor at 44 Division Street, of having given information about her to the attorney for the defense, and then soundly boxed his ears.
LONDON, March 13 -- The reference to home rule made by Lord Rosebery last night in the House of Lords, which has occasioned so much comment, was as follows:

The special committee of the Chamber of Commerce has prepared a bill for carrying out the plan of rapid transit suggested by ex-Mayor Hewitt, that is, the plan which involves raising the money for construction on the credit of the city and having the work of building, equipping, and operating the system done by a corporation under a contract with the municipality.

English appetite for American mutton is improving, as appears by the manifests of nearly all the freight ships to Liverpool that can carry live stock. One ship alone is taking out 1,600 head of sheep this week. Formerly, the English market was open only to prize winners. The stock going over this season goes not only in droves, but it consists of fine, robust specimens from the great ranches of the West.

The session of the Board of Aldermen yesterday was the liveliest one that has been held in some time. The liveliness was caused by the quarrel which broke out a couple of weeks ago between the Aldermen and the Park Board because the Aldermen were refused patronage under the $1,000,000 appropriation.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 13 -- Justice Paul had before him to-day three of the boys who tied Charles Berry to a stake and started a fire at his feet to torture him in Indian fashion. The names of the boys are James Dugan, Thomas Brown, and James Eldridge. The boys tearfully protested that they were "playin' Injun," and merely started the fire for fun.

TROY, N.Y., March 13 -- The Committee of Public Safety held a special meeting this evening. There was a large attendance of prominent citizens of both parties, and considerable business at an executive character was transacted.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, March 13 -- P.M. After a rather quiet morning, during which prices were somewhat heavy, the stock market in the afternoon took on new animation and a higher range of prices was established. London bought St. Paul, as well as some of its other specialties, more freely than for some time, and it was noticeable that the buying continued up to the close of business

The Platt-Milholland movement had an enrollment day yesterday, and all those who want Mr. Platt, whose residence is in Tioga County, to run the Republican Party in this city, and who had not already put their names on the lists, were enrolled.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 13 -- The forty-seventh annual meeting of the stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company was held this morning in Musical Fund Hall, and for the fourteenth consecutive time William E. Lockwood assumed the role of chief objector. Mr. Lockwood's varied resolutions were customarily defeated; and so quickly did the assemblage do this that the meeting adjourned at 11:4O o'clock, after having been in session but forty minutes.

A debate on pensions in the House is welcomed with delight by all the demagogues. During such a debate, a few days ago, a Representative from Virginia ventured to say that his State was paying in taxes part of the money expended by the Pension Bureau. Whereupon a demagogue from Iowa, named Hepburn, made some assertions which have since been approved by many Republican papers that must know how false they were.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 13. -- The body of William Martin of 197 Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn, one at the victims of the Newtown Creek bridge disaster Jan. 12, was found to-day floating in the creek opposite the Queens County Oil Works. The finding of Martin's body completes the list of nine men missing.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 13 -- John Scanlon, a lodger in the Second Precinct Police Station, this city, attempted suicide at 2 o'clock this morning. He would have bled to death had not Policeman Cosgrove entered the corridor to lock up a prisoner.

The remainder of the boxes and seats for the charity concert to be given by the Musurgia of New-York to-morrow evening in Music Hall will be sold at auction this afternoon at the office of the Knickerbocker Trust Company, 3 Nassau Street, at 3:15 o'clock.
TRENTON, N.J., March 13 -- The argument before the Supreme Court in the proceedings to determine which of the two Senates of New-Jersey is the legal body was resumed this morning.
The New-York College of Dentistry held its twenty-eighth annual commencement exercises last night in Chickering Hall.

To correct an error entertained by some people, that because there was a larger cotton crop this year than last, In consequence there must be more of the staple in the world, and that the surplus accounts for the dull market and low prices, Alfred B. Shepperson, a member of the Cotton Exchange, in an interview yesterday, said:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In your Issue of the 11th is an article entitled "Primitive American Drama," in which the writer assumes that "The Contrast" was the first play written by an American author that was ever acted. It seems a pity to let such a historical error pass any longer unchallenged. The Dunlap Society was primarily responsible for this mistake.

Nobody really knows what has happened in Rio Bay during the last fortyeight hours except the parties in interest immediately present, and we doubt whether they have more than a dim and shadowy motion of what has been going on. But that is not the worst of it. The wonder is how any Brazilian, insurgent or loyal, can possibly know what to do next.

ST. LOUIS, March 13 -- Ex-Mayor James H. Britton of this city, now a resident of New-York City, was arrested at the Union Station last night and remained a prisoner at one of the hotels until this morning. The arrest was made by Deputy United States Marshal W.W. Mail on a capias warrant from the United States District Court of Texas.

Mr. Plunket Greene gave his third song recital at Music Hall yesterday afternoon. The chamber music room in which the entertainment took place was crowded to its utmost capacity, the audience being composed chiefly of ladies. There was an abundance of applause, not always judicious, but always enthusiastic.

Hamlin Garland, George W. Cable, and Hamilton Mabie entertained an audience of about 400, consisting of members of the Nineteenth Century Club and invited guests, at Sherry's last evening. For two hours they carried on an interesting triangular discussion upon "The Realistic and Romantic Schools in Literature."
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, published this morning, consists of TEN PAGES. Among other features it contains:

John P. Townsend, who has accepted the Presidency of the Bowery Savings Bank, tendered his resignation as President of the Knickerbocker Trust Company at a meeting of that company yesterday afternoon. Mr. Townsend's letter of resignation read as follows: To the Board of Directors of the Knickerbocker Trust Company:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 -- The United States man-of-war Marion, which should have been on her way to this port, is at Yokohama undergoing extensive repairs. About a fortnight ago a Table message was received here from Yokohama saying that the vessel had sailed, but had been obliged to return for repairs.

LONDON, March 13 -- Continuing the debate on the address, in the House of Commons, to-day, Mr. John Morley, Chief Secretary for Ireland, insisted that there could be no injury to Ireland through a temporary suspension of the Home Role bill. If he had supposed that the reconstituted Ministry would not be in accord with his views on the Irish question, he would not be a member of that Ministry.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 13 -- Francis E. Shober, to whose wife, Helen E. Shober, Judge McAdam of New-York yesterday granted an absolute divorce, has had a unique career. He is a Southerner by birth, and came North a number of years ago to attend St. Stephen's Episcopal College at Annandale.

JERSEY CITY. N.J., March 13 -- The Directors of the Central Railroad contemplate making a trip over the road Thursday. For this purpose, the parlor car Monmouth was thoroughly renovated at the Elizabeth shops. This morning the Monmouth was brought to the yard in this city and run upon a siding.

The withdrawal of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad from the Southern Railway and Steamship Association formed the sole topic of discussion at a meeting of the Executive Committee of that association held in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Diligent efforts were made to placate the Louisville and Nashville people and induce them to remain in the organization.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The Senate Finance Committee gave a hearing this afternoon to the Capitol Appropriation bill. Commissioner Perry explained the progress of the work and showed by plans how the Capitol will look when finished. The tower, he said, will be of copper and iron, as stone walls would be heavy.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 13 -- In the Senate to-day Senator Mullin (Rep., Jefferson,) called up his resolution extending until April 10 the time allotted for the report on the investigation of the State commissions. Senator Cantor (Dem., New-York,) offered an amendment providing that the so-called labor bureaus be exempted from investigation.

Mrs. Lilian Farlee Dana, the wife of Dr. Charles L. Dana, Professor of Neurelogy in the Post-Graduate Medical School, died on last Saturday in Bermuda. Her death was caused by injuries received by jumping from a carriage to rescue her little daughter, who had fallen from the vehicle.

FORT WORTH, Texas, March 13 -- R.W. Page, formerly President of the Merchants' National Bank of this city, shot and instantly killed A.B. Smith, formerly cashier of the bank, at 10 o'clock this morning. Page was alone in a private room of the bank when Smith entered. What took place between the men is not known.

Another victim of McKaneism turned up yesterday in the person of William J. O'Neill, a tailor of 2,148 Third Avenue. O'Neill, through his lawyer, Charles D. O'Connell of 62 Wall Street, has sued Justice R.V.B. Newton of Gravesend for malicious prosecution, laying the damages at $10,000.

Harry Thomas, the English oarsman, who rowed at the Centennial regatta, in 1876, is dead. Twenty years ago Thomas was one of the most prominent scullers in England. Since he retired from racing, he has been proprietor of the Cottage Inn, Cole Hill Lane, Fulham, and was also one of the Queen's watermen.

Two very significant facts and two new witnesses were brought forth yesterday at the second trial of Police Justice Kenneth F. Sutherland of Coney Island, in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer, for oppression of the Gaynor copyists.
The Citizens' Committee of Gravesend held a conference yesterday afternoon with George F. Elliott as to the investigation of the town books and accounts.
Four resolutions were unanimously adopted at the meeting of the Harlem Republican Club last night.

BERLIN, March 13 -- In the Reichstag today Dr. von Frege, Conservative, offered an amendment to the Russo-German treaty imposing a duty on rye and wheat imported from Russia of five marks, and upon oats of four marks. Herr Standy, Conservative, and Count von Arnim, Reform Party, supported the amendment.

The American steam yacht Natalie left Savannah about two months ago. Nothing was heard of her for a time, and it was supposed that she was lost. Then came news that she was seen anchored off Fortune Island, in the Bahamas. A month ago she was observed close inshore taking on wood and water.

The Rev. Madison C. Peters, pastor of the Bloomingdale Reformed Church, lectured last evening in the church, West Sixty-eighth Street and the Boulevard. His subject was "The Pope in American Politics." He touched upon the foreign-flag question, and, among other things, said:

Superintendent Byrnes has won a substantial victory in his war upon delinquent and negligent Police Captains. The Police Commissioners yesterday sustained his charges against Capt. Price of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station, and against Capt. Martens of the East Thirty -- fifth Street Station.

Arthur D. Robins, twenty years old, physical instructor of the Riverside Athletic Association, 359 West Sixty-ninth Street, was found by a policeman at 9 o'clock last night wandering aimlessly in Sixty-ninth Street, between West End and Amsterdam Avenues.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- Lehigh Valley stock is usually rather uninteresting, but semi-occasionally it treats the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to a veritable sensation. The bears had a good one to-day. The stock opened at 41 1/2, an advance of 3/4 over the last sale of yesterday, and scored a further advance of 2 1/2 per cent. on transactions of only a little over 2,000 shares.
RIO JANEIRO, March 13 -- The Government forces began active operations against the insurgents at noon to-day, the fortyeight hours notice given by President Peixoto having expired.

Under orders from Washington to relieve Naval Officer Willis and omit his name from the March pay roll, the roll was made out for the Naval Office yesterday by H.W. Gourley, Controller of the Naval Office. As a question of law is involved in this order, Mr. Willis holding that he is entitled to the salary of the office while performing its duties.

BOSTON, March 13 -- The Boston Towboat Company's steamer Orion, which is to go to Roncador Reef to raise the Kearsarge, came out of the dry dock at 3 o'clock this afternoon, and after taking aboard an anchor and two surf boats, sailed, at 3:25 P.M., for Newport News, Va., in charge of Capt. Smith, with Wrecking Master Burgess and a crew of forty men on board.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

BOSTON, March 13 -- The annual meeting of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company, held in the office of the corporation to-day, was exceedingly brief and correspondingly barren of results. Among those present were T. Jefferson Coolidge, Jr., member of the Reorganization Committee; F.H. Prince, J.S. Waterbury, James Armstrong, T.C. Platt, and Vice President Odell.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- When the Senate Committee on Finance adjourned yesterday it was with the expectation that to-day an agreement might be reached as to the time when the Tariff bill would be reported to the Senate. This expectation has not been realized, however. The Democratic members of the committee submitted several propositions to-day to this end, but the Republicans did not accept them.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- The attack made on Alley "L" stock yesterday afternoon was continued with renewed vigor this morning. Opening 3/8 below the final sale of yesterday, 25 5/8, it was persistently hammered down to 24. Lake Street was easier at 22 1/2, acting in sympathy with Alley. West Chicago was moderately active, from 148 to 147 1/2, although many of the sales were of small lots for immediate delivery.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Senator Bradley's bill legislating out of office the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge and authorizing the Mayors of New-York and Brooklyn, respectively, to appoint other Trustees, came up for a hearing before the Assembly Cities Committee this afternoon.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., March 13 -- The steamer Virginia Lake arrived here this morning towing the British steamer Briscoe, Capt. Seares, from Hamburg and Queenstown, long overdue at New-York. The Virginia Lake came across the Briscoe yesterday morning about seventy miles off Cape Race, and displayed rockets and blue lights.

PATERSON, N.J., March 13 -- The strik- | ing silk dyers and ribbon weavers resorted to acts of violence to-day. They marched to the works of Simon & Augrer, broke down the doors, and forced the workmen out of the establishment. They threw the unfinished silk on the floor, turned on the steam in the tubs, and burned a large quantity of material.
Alfred Leblanc has disappeared. His companions, of whom he was the pride, the commonsense, the smiles, and the comforting irony, are persuaded that he has killed himself.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day
Justice Patrick Divver's whereabouts and the date of his return were Conundrums unsolved last night by his family and the acting leader of the Second Assembly District, Alderman Nicholas T. Brown.

Messrs. Frederick Southack Co. have sold for William Hyams to John T. Williams the property, 50 by 50. at the northeast corner of Broome and Mercer Streets for $87,500. The plot is now covered by old buildings, which will be removed to make way for a seven-story fire-proof store building.
LISBON, March 13 -- Official dispatches from Rio de Janeiro confirm the reports that the insurgent Admiral da Gama has left his flagship and taken refuge on board the Portuguese corvette Mindello.

The Rev. Dwight L. Moody, eloquent, magnetic, forceful, and as strong in evangelistic power as when, years ago, he held weeping, repentant thousands in Madison Square Garden attentive to his appeals, spoke yesterday in the Broadway Tabernacle, Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street, to the largest audience that has gathered at any of the revival meetings.

The bill which provides for dividing equally between the two political parties all boards of election officers in towns, villages, and cities of this State, excepting New-York and Brooklyn, is tied up in a conference between the Senate and Assembly on account of difference over an amendment of very small consequence.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Democratic members of the Senate this morning agreed upon the reassignment at the committees made necessary by the resignations of Senators Walthall and White. In accordance with the action of the caucus, Mr. Peffer withdrew from the Committee on Improvement of the Mississippi River, Mr. Martin from the Select Committee to Investigate the Geological Survey, and Mr. Caffery from the Committee on Pensions.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 13 -- The British cruiser Cleopatra is still lying at anchor off the bluffs outside of Bluefields harbor, but within a few days will be relieved by two smaller vessels. The Nicaraguan Government has yielded to the demand or the commander of the British ship, and ordered all the native troops out of Bluefields and marched them to Rama, fifty miles up the river.

The New-York Health Department has issued a most astounding edict on consumption, which I regard as unsound in doctrine, unwarranted by facts, and certain to inflict misery and injustice on thousands of citizens, without benefiting any. It declares:
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The State Department is advised that Peixoto began to bombard the insurgent ships to-day, and that the fire was not returned.

The Ladies' Health Protective Association met yesterday morning in the Trustees' room of the United Charities Building to consider action to be taken to further the passage of their bill for the baling of stable refuse. There was a large attendance and a great deal of interest manifested.

A tired, pale, and emaciated, yet pretty woman, about thirty years old, wrapped in a clock that nearly swept the ground, and carrying under it a dying baby girl, entered the East Twenty-second Street Station at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, and with feeble voice asked for shelter.

ALBANY, March 13 -- At the Albany County Woman's Suffrage convention this afternoon a committee was named to effect a county campaign organization, twelve representatives from the city and additional ones from the country towns being placed upon it. Mrs. Sarah B. Hitt is the Chairman.
