Henry Romeike, who conducts a pressclipping bureau at 110 Fifth Avenue, has Just completed a collection of 3.500 newspaper comments on the life and works of George W. Childs, and in only one of them is there an unkind remark about the great philanthropist.

CANNES, March 13 -- The yacht racing was continued to-day. The events decided were the races for the cups offered by Mr. James Gordon Bennett. Mr. Ogden Goelet, and Baron Hoffman. These contests are the most important of the yachting carnival, and considerable interest was taken in them.

HOBOKEN, N.J., March 14. -- The strike among the silk weavers at Schwartzenback's mill, at West Hoboken, became general to-day. There are now 450 men out, and only 60 are at work. The men demanded an increase of 40 per cent. last week and were told that they could have but 17 per cent. advance.
LONDON, March 14 -- The House of Commons was crowded with members and visitors to-day.

The evangelistic meetings in this city are taking on new strength daily. Yesterday there were seven meetings, two in the street and three in large public halls up town, and two at noonday down town. Besides, at least fifty churches are now holding evening meetings in their own edifices or uniting in union meetings in other church buildings.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- The action in wheat today was confined within a very narrow limit. There was a scarcity of news, a scarcity of orders, and a marked indisposition to trade. Even scalpers showed but little interest. For once in a long time there were no new statistics on the visible or any of the other known or unknown quantities that have been lately figured.

The committee of the Republicans of the Assembly which has been working over the Sheffield Blanket Ballot bill, with a view to making a party measure of it, has agreed upon a form which eliminates all paster provisions and leaves the illiterate voter without any assistance except what may be afforded by an unofficial sample ballot.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 14 -- The papers in a suit involving a large and valuable tract of land on the north side of Long Island have been filed in the office of the Clerk of Suffolk County. The plaintiff is Mrs. Kate B. Snow, a granddaughter of the late James B. Taylor of New-York, and his only surviving heir.

BOSTON, March 14 -- Local stocks were dull, but strong, though there was little interest shown in the specialties, except, perhaps, in Mexican Central, which exhibited unwonted activity and advanced to 8, the highest point it has reached lately. The 4s sold at 53 and the incomes at 11 1/2. There would seem to be absolutely no reason for the advance in these securities, especially with Mexican dollars at 48 1/2 c.
The Brooklyn Excise Board yesterday gave a final hearing on the application of George E. Luderman for a saloon license at 290 Atlantic Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- There was some disposition to-day to sell long stock and such bears as were active hammered at the market all day. Lehigh Valley and Reading were especially weak, the former declining to 40 3/8 on less than 1,000 shares. The Lehigh Valley Coal Company bonds were quite active at 102.

The commission appointed under the act of 1893 to prepare and report to the Legislature a comprehensive revision of the laws affecting common schools and public education in the City of New-York, including such alteration in existing laws and such new enactments as they might deem necessary, has just made public its report.
The story of Mrs. Kate Nobles's married life as told by her friends yesterday is a most pathetic one. She is a woman of education and refinement, but wretchedly poor.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 14 -- The session of the Dominion Parliament, which opens to-morrow, is likely to be a long one. It is possible that Parliament may manage to adjourn by Dominion Day, July 1, but those who are best posted say that the end will be probably a month later. For, although the Government will again meet the House with an overwhelming majority, the Liberals are in excellent fighting trim.

Tammany was the object of some severe attacks at a large meeting of the NewYork State Democracy of the Ninth Assembly District at 16 Abingdon Square last evening. The General Committee now has a membership of over 500, and its financial condition is excellent, the dues reaching a rate of nearly $5,000 a year.

The annual meeting of the Adirondack League Club was held Tuesday in the club's office, 203 Broadway. Reports were read which showed the club to be in good condition and its property increasing in Value. The following Trustees were elected to serve for three years; Mills W. Barie, D.L. Snyder, Harry E. Howland, Robert N. Alexander, and Spencer Aldrich.

ALBANY, March 14 -- John I. Platt of Poughkeepsie appeared before the Codes Committee of the Assembly this afternoon and explained the purpose of the Ainsworth Libel bill. The committee decided to change the bill so as to allow the newspapers in libel cases to prove that malice did not exist in the publication of the article.

There has been filed at White Plains a report by the Commissioners of Appraisal of the land seized by Commissioner of Public Works Michael T. Daly in the Croton watershed, of a portion of their work, covering land in Kensico and Pines Bridge. A copy of this report has been sent to Corporation Counsel Clark.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Though the list of stocks traded in was rather narrow, the market showed a healthy appearance this morning. With the exception of Alley "L," all the conspicuous issues were strong, and the buying was very fair. Diamond Match, West Chicago, and Lake Street "L" all sold at higher prices, while Alley "L" continued its downward course.

The Rev. Maltbie D. Babcock, D.D., pastor of the Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church of Baltimore, is to be asked to succeed the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton as pastor of the West Presbyterian Church. At a meeting of the West Church last evening it was decided to extend a call to Dr. Babcock.

RICHMOND, Va., March 14 -- The Sheriff of Allegheny County, North Carolina, has made such vigorous search for the fifteen men who lynched Daniel Slaughter that they have fled. Rose, who was shot in attempting to take Slaughter out of jail, has made a confession, and offers to testify if called upon.

Mary Dunn, a woman about thirty-five years old, is on trial in the Court of General Sessions, before Recorder Smyth, charged with murder in the first degree in killing her husband, Frank, in their home. 106 West Twenty-sixth Street, last October.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14 -- The change in the make-up of the Harvard 'Varsity crew which has for some time been expected has come at last, and the result is that there has been a general shaking up of the men. During the Winter Fennessy, '96, who did so well at stroke last year as a freshman, has been rowing at No. 7, and a new man, Bullard, '96, has been rowing at stroke.

Messrs. Hoffman Brothers and E.A. Cruikshank have sold a five-story building on the west side of Broadway, near Houston Street, 25 by 100, for about $130,000. It rents for $9,000. They have also sold the five-story brick building 218 Pearl Street at an advance over the price for which it was purchased last week.
The New-York College Settlement was the subject of an interesting address by Dr. Jane E. Robbins in the Assembly Hall of the United Charities Building yesterday afternoon.

Police Justice Divver's whereabouts were disclosed yesterday by his son, James P. Divver, who made a circumstantial statement about his father. He said a telegram received by him from his father on March 5 led him to believe that his father had left Los Angeles for San Francisco with his brother Joseph.

Justice Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday rendered a decision refusing to set aside the sale, under foreclosure, of the Hotel de Logerot property, at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street. At the outset of his opinion the Justice says that statements as to the value of the property made by Mr. Coudert, who acted for mortgagors and mortgagees, should not bind the purchasers.

Here was the camp. All its denizens were at the mercy of the enemy, now in possession, when, hark! the sound of clattering hoofs! On they come, the party of rescue, gallantly led by a dashing trooper in command of twenty sturdy cavalrymen.

FLEMINGTON, West Va., March 14 -- A few months ago James Robinson, a prosperous farmer, living near Tyrconnel, Taylor County, sold his farm to Hunphrey McDonald, the wealthiest man in the county. Possession was to have been given to-morrow. This morning Robinson sent for McDonald, and he called.

Smarting under the disgrace brought upon his name by the arrest of his son on a serious charge, Frank Paolo Triori, a druggist, fifty-five years old, committed suicide on Tuesday night at his home, 24 James Street, by taking strychnine. He was a widower until about four months ago, when he married a young woman.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The adjourned hearing upon Senator Owens's "side-door" bill was given by the Judiciary Committee of the Senate in the Senate library this afternoon. The hearing of last week was adjourned at Senator Owens's request, as he announced that a prominent clergyman from Brooklyn desired to speak in behalf of the measure.

NORFOLK, Va., March 14 -- John Dwight of the firm of John Dwight Co. of NewYork City, a millionaire, seventy-four years old, was married to-day to Mrs. Clara L. Freeborn in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.
The methods adopted by the henchmen of John Y. McKane, especially the Justices of the Peace of Gravesend, are causing great surprise in law and political circles.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The Republican Senators have been seriously troubled today because of the break in their ranks which occurred over the party bills yesterday. The revolt of five of their number has left them all at sea. It has placed all party legislation in a somewhat precarious position.

The Committee on Provident Habits, which consists of Charles S. Fairchild, Robert W. de Forest, Abram S. Hewltt, Charles C. Beaman, George E. Dodge, Walter Jennings, and Miss Marian Messmer, Secretary and Cashier, and otto T. Bannard, Chairman and Treasurer, has just made public the annual report of the Penny Provident Fund for the year ending Jan. 31, 1894.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 14 -- At 9 o'clock last night George Dundear took five ounces of laudanum, with suicidal intent. A physician used all ordinary means for resuscitation, but with no avail. As a last resources, Dundear was removed to the Homeopathic Hospital. Notwithstanding the fact that the would-be suicide was blue in the face and his nervous system paralyzed, Drs. Moreland and Gregg resolved to try the newly-discovered antidote, permanganate of potash.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Democrats who are supposed to be making the Tariff bill ready for the Senate seem to have been taken possession of by their Republican associates, and to be more or less doughy in their hands. That the Committee on Finance is not making rapid progress with the Tariff bill is generally conceded even by the committee.

TROY, N.Y., March 14 -- The inquest relative to the death of Robert Ross was begun this morning, at 10 o'clock, at the Court House. An immense crowd was present, and the courtroom did not begin to accommodate those who clamored for admission. The witnesses alone made up a considerable portion of those present, there being more than 100 in all.

The first intimation of the intention of Dr. Paxton to resign the pastorate of the West Presbyterian Church, which he had held for twelve years, was made public Nov. 12 last. The reason given for the intended resignation was ill health. Dr. Paxton had previously tendered his resignation on account of failing health, but the congregation had refused to accept it, and had given him a long vacation.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Controller Ashbel P. Fitch of New-York is In Washington to-night and will remain here until to-morrow. While here he will bring to the attention of Congress the claim of NewYork City upon the General Government for furnishing troops In 1861. The claim now amounts to more than $1,000,000, but Mr. Fitch says the city is willing to compromise on an even million.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- It was expected that the motion to reconsider the vote by which the Bland bill was advanced to its third reading in the Senate would be defeated, and, also, that a majority of the Senators would refuse to recommit the bill for amendment. These points were made clear last week.

Big as New-York is and varied as its industries are it is growing every day, and the genius of its people is developing new schemes for the benefit of humanity. Among the latest inventions brought out in this city is a baby incubator.

It seems rather strange that so clever a racing manager as is President Lawrence of the Coney Island Jockey Club should have imagined for an instant that any race could take the place of the Suburban among non-professional racegoers. That race, though it has had an existence of but ten years, has made for itself with the American people a place very much akin to that which the Derby has among Englishmen.

Frederick A. Lovecraft, business manager of Palmer's Theatre, was practically a lunatic Aug. 29, 1893, when he executed his will leaving everything he possessed in the world to Col. Henry S. Kearney, his friend. This was the substance of the testimony given by Dr. Thomas S. Robertson yesterday, before Surrogate Arnold, in the contest over Mr. Lovecraft's will.

PATERSON, N.J., March 14 -- There was no disturbance at any of the silk mills here to-day. All the boss dyers except Bamford Brothers have agreed to adopt the schedule of prices of their employes, and this will be the means of taking from the ranks of the strikers the most turbulent element.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

W.E. Roberts and his father were dispossessed of their quarters in the Balmoral Hotel, One Hundred and Thirteenth Street and Lenox Avenue, yesterday morning, and their personal effects were set upon the sidewalk. The hotel property is now in the possession of Julius Lippman, owner; William Cohen and Edward Steers, Trustees, and McDowell Boggs, the new lessees and managers.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 14 -- A forecast of the report of the naval stability board will make upon its examination of the battle ship Indiana, which is now rearing completion at Cramps' ship yard, was announced to-day. The report will show that the vessel is perfectly seaworthy.

Saldanha da Gama was never a dashing rebel, and his escapade ends fittingly in his desertion of his own flagship to seek safe asylum on board a foreign man-of-war. "Don't shoot; I'll come down," exclaimed Capt. Scott's 'coon. Da Gama's caution surpassed that of the 'coon, for he came down, not into the hands of his enemy, but upon neutral ground, and from that refuge proceeded to treat for the integrity of his precious neck.

Mrs. F.J. de Peyster gave two prizes for the members of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club to struggle for yesterday afternoon. One was a handsome rosewood five-o'clock tea table, and the other was a clock. Every bowler wanted the table, and Mr. Theodore P. Cooper was particularly anxious to win it.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., March 14 -- Passengers on the steamer Arawa, which has just arrived here from Honolulu, tell a strange story. They say that a subject of Japan was recently arrested in Honolulu for a trivial offense and placed in jail, and that he escaped and swam to a Japanese war ship.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 14 -- Some of the candidates who aspire to succeed Senator Colquitt seem through their friends to be trying to cast aspersions on that Thomasville meeting which formally put Judge Turner in the race. The Judge's great ability and strength are universally recognized, and it may be knowledge of this fact which inspires the efforts to belittle the meeting.

Among the passengers who arrived on the La Champagne on Sunday was M. Jacques Inaudi, the "Lightning Calculator," who for the past twelve months has been engaged in astounding the mathematicians of Paris and London, as well as the medical fraternity. A peculiarity of his anatomy which has puzzled the doctors is a soft tissue, two inches in width, which extends from the back of his head to his forehead.
Police Justice Kenneth F. Sutherland of Coney Island was yesterday found guilty of oppression in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer. It was his second trial.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Fifty additional pages of the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill were considered in Committee of the Whole in the House to-day. On motion of Mr. Coombs, (Dem., N.Y.,) $250 of the appropriation for national cemeteries was authorized to be expended for marking the grave of Capt. Samuel Chester Reid, whom he designated as "the designer of the American flag and a veteran of the war of 1812."

TROY, March 14 -- The Committee of Safety, appointed in response to the sentiment against Murphyism that awoke when Robert Ross was murdered on election day, has struck its first blow at the corrupt machine which has long dominated this city. It has made a radical move to secure a police force which shall not be composed of slaves to the present boss.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 14 -- Floriano Peixoto is triumphant. The insurgent vessels surrendered last night without having answered with a single shot the cannonade from the Government's hilltop batteries. The report that Admiral da Gama had fled was confirmed this morning. He has sought safety on the French cruiser Magon.

There is plenty of evidence that the people of Troy have been greatly stirred up by the incidents of last week's election, in which Murphyism culminated in manslaughter, and it is to be hoped that full advantage will be taken of the public interest which has been aroused to secure vigorous action for the vindication of law and justice.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 14 -- Senator Saxton's amendments to the ballot law were a special order on second reading in the Senate to-day. Senator Saxton explained briefly the amendments to the present law -- the blanket ballot, the party emblems, and the individual paster. The individual paster, he said, would satisfy the constitutional provision for the protection of the illiterate independent voter.

Miss Marie Louise May, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. May, and William Browne Randolph were married last evening at the home of the bride's parents, 2 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, near Mount Morris Avenue. The house was garnished with Easter lilies, and there was a large attendance of the relatives and friends of the bride and bridegroom.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Capitol Commissioner Perry to-day dropped eighty men from the construction force, leaving only a little over 250 men now employed out of the 1,700 who were at work before March 1. The funds are running low.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Large delegations of business men from New-York City and Buffalo attended the joint hearing given to-day by the Senate and Assembly Committees on Miscellaneous Corporations on the bill which proposes to reduce telephone charges. The bill was introduced by Senator Persons and Assemblyman Gerst of Erie County.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- If the Administration of President Cleveland was one that was seeking occasion to celebrate itself and to claim for a party the credit that is due to a part of the national service, it would be justified in making much more than it has done of the incident of Jan. 29, in the Harbor of Rio de Janeiro.
Cornelius Vanderbilt and Seth M. Milliken, a wealthy dry goods manufacturer of 990 Madison Avenue were badly shaken up and narrowly escaped injury while driving on Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon.
It was a varied assortment of passengers which the White Star Liner Majestic landed here yesterday. The number carried was not unusually large, but it was unusually diversified.

John T. Ford, manager of Ford's Grand Opera House, in Baltimore, the oldest theatrical manager in the country, died at his home, 1,536 North Gilmore Street, in that city, yesterday morning. The cause of his death is thought to have been heart disease, superinduced by the grip. He leaves a wife and ten children.

CANNES, March 14 -- The yacht races sailed to-day were the Prix du Ville de Cannes and the Prix de Monte Carlo. The Prix du Ville de Cannes was for yachts of twenty tons and upward. The first prize was 2,500f. and a gold medal, the second prize 800f. and a silver medal, and the third prize 300f. and a bronze medal.
Further evidence of the kind of "harmony" that exists in the Republican Party of this city was furnished yesterday.

The Committee of Five, which has charge of the distribution of the Mayor's fund for the relief of the unemployed contributed by the employes of the city departments, made appropriations yesterday amounting to $14,000. Including the appropriations made yesterday, the committee has already distributed $56,000.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 14 -- Buckra, sire of Buckwa and other good thoroughbred performers, is dead at the home of his owner, Thomas Stevens, in this county. He was valued at $5,000. He was sired by imp. Buckden, out of Marshra, by Planet.

Policeman Michael Brady of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Police Station was on trial before Commissioner Martin yesterday on a charge of taking $75 from William Fink as part of a consideration for securing the latter's appointment on the police force. No decision was rendered in the case, and it will go to the full board.

The charges are still being made that John Y. McKane has appropriated to his own use thousands of dollars that belonged to the town of Gravesend. McKane's friends claim that when the proper time comes they will be able to show that, instead of his owing the town, it will be found that the town owes McKane.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Postmaster Dayton of New-York arrived in Washington to-night and registered at the Shoreham. He said to a correspondent of The NewYork Times that he had come to consult with Representative Dunphy concerning the bill for the classification of clerks in first and second class Post Offices which Mr. Dunphy recently reported from the House Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads.

LONDON, March 14 -- The Exchange Telegraph Company has advices from Brazil that Admiral Mello, with the war ships Aquidaban and Republica, has arrived at Santa Catharina. The same advices say that there is good authority for the statement that the insurgents in the harbor of Rio have been totally defeated and routed.
LONDON, March 14 -- The Standard. Conservative, says of the Government's course in the House of Commons yesterday:

TRENTON, March 14. -- The argument in the quo warranto proceedings brought to decide which of the two alleged Senates of New-Jersey is the lawful body closed today. The day was made interesting by reason of a controversy between counsel occasioned by the partisan allusions made by Thomas McCarter of counsel for the Republicans.

DEDHAM, Mass., March 14 -- The will of Mrs. Mary Hemenway, widow of Augustus Hemenway of Milton, Mass., whose estate is valued at about $15,000,000, was filed this afternoon. It is dated Jan. 25, 1894, and in it her son, Augustus Hemenway of Canton, Charles J. Morrill, and Reginald Gray of Boston are named as executors and trustees.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- The three-story brick building of Haney White, manufacturers of builders' and hardware supplies, at 2,730, 2,732, and 2,734 North Broad Street, was burned this evening. The loss on stock and building will amount to $100,000, nearly covered by insurance. The lumber yard of B.F. Taylor Co., which adjoins Haney White's building, was damaged to the extent of $6.000.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Upon resumption to-day of the Pollard-Breckinridge breach of promise suit Sister Cecilia of the Norwood Foundling Asylum again took the stand. She could not say whether Miss Pollard had been an inmate of the asylum, but she said she had known two patients at the asylum who had worn veils to escape recognition.

Lord Rosebery's Ministry, though as yet it is of a few days, is full of trouble. It is in trouble with the Irish members and with the English Radicals. The latter trouble is not very serious, since Mr. Labouchere has but nine thoroughgoing sympathizers in the House of Commons.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., March 14 -- Mrs. Josephine Marie Whitney has brought suit against her husband, William Whitney, son of O.B. Whitney, a wealthy basket manufacturer, for a divorce, alleging abandonment and cruelty. Mrs. Whitney's maiden name was Josephine Marie English. She lived in Brooklyn until she was married, about two years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Secretary Herbert to-night received a cablegram from Admiral Benham at Rio, dated to-day, stating that yesterday at 3 P.M., the city opened fire on the insurgent forts and vessels. The fire was not returned. The insurgent forts, position, and vessels have been abandoned.

Ex-Mayor Grant, receiver of the St. Nicholas Bank, began the payment of dividends yesterday. He paid out 207 checks, amounting to $290,000. It was said that claims against the bonk are coming in rapidly. All legitimate claims the receiver promises to settle on a basis ot 40 per cent.

Armed with a warrant issued by Police Justice Taintor, sitting at the Tombs Court, Anthony Comstock, the Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, invaded the Tenderloin Club's house, in West Thirty-second Street, yesterday and seized a number of alleged improper pictures displayed there.

Whether it would be more advisable to make changes in the Police Department of this city before thoroughly investigating its management or to wait until the investigation is completed before taking any action depends entirely on the character and motive of the change to be made.

Seldom has a more remarkable case been presented in the New-York courts than the contest over Frederick A. Lovecraft's will which is going on before Surrogate Arnold. All the elements of romance and tragedy seem to have been combined to make Lovecraft's life and death the central features of a series of episodes beside which the most fantastic imaginings of the novel writers are pale and insignificant.

Police Justice Kenneth F. Sutherland of Coney Island, whose absence from the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer Wednesday, when the jury found him guilty of oppression, created such a stir, turned up in that city yesterday and then vanished as suddenly and mysteriously as he had come to sight.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Mr. Butts this morning secured enough votes in the Assembly to take the Five-Cent-Fare bill from the Committee on Railroads, which had delayed action on it so long that Mr. Butts was weary.

The defense in the case of Mary Dunn, on trial in the Court of General Sessions, before Recorder Smyth, charged with killing her husband Frank with a hammer, in their home, 106 West Twenty-sixth Street, last October, was begun yesterday.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 15 -- The fourth session of the Seventh Parliament of Canada was opened this afternoon. Following the usual custom. Lord Aberdeen was escorted in state from Rideau Hall to Parliament Buildings, the Princess Louise Dragoon Guards acting as escort. On arriving at the main entrance his Excellency was received by a guard of honor from the Governor General's foot gruards, the band of that regiment playing.

BROCKVILLE, Ontario, March 15 -- C.J. Pusey has returned from Washington, where he submitted plans and specifications of the proposed international bridge across the St. Lawrence from Brockville to Morristown, N.Y., to Secretary Gresham. They were accepted. The plans have yet to be submitted to the authorities of Ottawa, but this will be merely a matter of form.

TROY, N.Y., March 15 -- The men who follow Edward Murphy's lead, the men to whose lawless methods was due the death of Robert Ross, are trying to dodge and shift the responsibility that murder put upon them. Public clamor has frightened them.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15 -- The Americans who helped man the Government's war ships were paid off to-day. They will leave the city on the first ship sailing from this port for New-York. F.A. Brinley, who commanded the crew of the dynamite gun aboard the Nictheroy, was disrated at Bahia because he kept the gun out of order.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 15 -- Henry George, in response to a resolution of the State Assembly, delivered an address in the Assembly Chamber to-night. Hamilton Fish presided. The Chamber was filled. Mr. George said, among other things:

In an endeavor to make their attractive store still more attractive to ladies, Messrs, Hllton, Hughes Co. have so entirely rearranged their main floor that one would scarcely recognize it as the same place.

The Rev. Edward H. Van Winkle, pastor of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Comforter at 814 Greenwich Street, where he has officiated for fourteen years, announced to his congregation at the services last evening that he vacated his position as their pastor.

Five sales at auction of real estate were held by Mr. T. A. Kerrigan in Brooklyn yesterday. At $9,005 he sold to James Osborne, the plaintiff, the four three-story frame tenements at the northeast corner of Eastern Parkway and Sackman Street, 81.3 by 100. To Mary A. Lane, at $2,425, he sold the two-story frame dwelling 306 Schenck Avenue, west side, 250 feet south of Glenmore Avenue, 25 by 100.

ALBANY, March 15 -- The Committee of Safety from Troy came to this city this morning to see Gov. Flower. The committee proposes to secure help in enforcing the law, in investigating election frauds, and in placing the responsibility for the death of Robert Ross precisely where it belongs. The committee would like some assurance that "Murphyism" will not dominate the men who are supposed to be prosecuting the case.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Francis Edwin Brownell, who was a private in the Ellsworth Fire Zouaves of New-York City, and was with that company when it went to Alexandria, Va., in the Spring of 1861, died here this morning.

From The Shoe and Leather Reporter, March 15. "The Widow Refused a Pension" was the caption of a dispatch from Washington printed in The New-York Times of March 9. On reading the paragraph it appeared that, so far from its being a fact that the widow refused a pension, the House refused to grant a pension to the widow of Major Ethan Allen Hitchcock.
DENVER, Col., March 15. -- The political fight waged by Gov. Waite culminated today in most exciting scenes, and mob violence was imminent many times during the day.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 15 -- Lawlessness and violence of marked criminal type characterized a tie-up of the trolley-car system of this city, which began at 1:45 A.M. to-day and ended in submission to arbitration this evening, without the police having arrested one of the miscreants who planned the lawless scheme or who carried out the orders of the conspirators.
An order was issued last night by Superintendent Byrnes to all the Police Captains that the nickel-in-the-slot gambling machines now operated in so many liquor saloons must be taken away.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March, 15 -- The finals in the tennis tournament at Magnolia Springs, Fla., were played to-day. In the singles Mr. Bryan of Bridgeport, Conn., won first prize. Mr. Morton second prize, and Mr. Swain of Philadelphia third. In the mixed doubles Mr. Bryan, having Miss Reynolds for a partner, won the first place.

About two score of persons assembled at Koster Bial's yesterday afternoon to witness a performance of M. Jacques Inaudi, lightning calculator. The audience was composed mostly of instructors and others interested in extraordinary mental development.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 15 -- Mrs. Ellen White of Bayonne this evening went before Justice Levering and swore out a warrant for the arrest of Peter H. Dolan, a rich contractor of this city, on a charge of threatening her life. Mrs. White said she met Mr. Dolan at the house of a friend, when he drew a revolver and drove her into the street.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. HONOLULU, March 8, (via San Francisco, March 15.) -- Nothing eventful has occurred since the Australia and Warrimoo sailed, on the 3d and 4th. In a conversation on the 7th, President Dole strongly reasserted the opinion attributed to him that the cession of Pearl Harbor to the United States was only temporary.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- It took the Senate only a few minutes to-day to pass the Bland bill, in exactly the shape in which it came from the House. This bill has traveled on schedule time ever since it reached the Senate. The Republicans endeavored to give it the right of way over the Tariff bill, their ideas being to retard the progress of the latter measure for an indefinite time.

Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day. Time money was unchanged. There was ample supply from many sources. The demand was not active. Rates were unchanged at 2 per cent. for thirty to sixty days, 2 1/2 per cent. for ninety days to four months, and 3 per cent. for six months.

The annual exhibition ride of the Central Park Riding Academy, the proceeds of which are devoted to charitable purposes, was given last evening. The galleries at either end of the tanbark arena, and the boxes at the side, were more than comfortably filled by friends of the patrons of this popular riding school.

A curious application has within the last week been made to, and refused by, two eminent jurists. One was Judge Pryor of the Common Pleas; the other was Judge Fitzsimons of the City Court. The latter, indeed, at first granted the application, unaware that it had been refused by the former.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- The performance of "The Crust of Society" in the Schiller Theatre came to an abrupt termination tonight on account of a fire which started in the four-story brick building adjoining the theatre on the east. Just as the curtain dropped on the third act, smoke from the burning building began rapidly to fill the stage.

TRENTON, N.J., March 15 -- The State Democracy organized March 8 in Jersey City to purify the Democratic Party has addressed the voters of New-Jersey for a second time. The Committee on Organization appointed at that meeting met here today and prepared a concise statement of its principles.
The bill prepared by Assemblyman Lawson is undoubtedly the outgrowth of the agitation in this city and Brooklyn in regard to the display of Ireland's green flag on St. Pattrick's Day.
Brig. Gen. John L. Otis of Northampton, Mass., died yesterday morning, at his Winter home in Tarpon Springs, Fla. He was sixty-seven years old.

The last will and testament of Richard S. Ely of Avon, Conn., was filed with Probate Clerk Jackson yesterday. The will makes bequests to Yale University. St. Luke's Hospital, the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, and other organizations.

Lawyers representing John Y. McKane made an ineffectual attempt in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, before Judge Lacombe, to have their client released from Sing Sing Prison on ball pending an appeal in his case. They declare that they will make a further appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

In England the cycling authorities claim that they will never recognize the Class B rule recently passed by the League of American Wheelmen. The definition of an amateur over there is very strict, to which Messrs. Zimmerman, Schofield, Harris, and others will testify if necessary. Here is what Sport and Play has to say on the subject:

LONDON, March 15 -- The three days' session of the McCarthy section of the Irish party in Parliament resulted in a victory for the Dillon faction, and, while the outcome has healed some old wounds, it has undoubtedly created new feuds. The principal object of the conference and discussion was to choose a new Advisory Committee of eight, to act with Justin McCarthy, Chairman of the Irish Parliamentary Party.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 15 -- Samuel L. Moore, head of the S.L. Moore Sons Company, owners of the Crescent Iron Works, where the cruiser Bancroft was built, is lying very ill with pneumonia, and his recovery, on account of his great age, is not expected. Mr. Moore last November celebrated his ninetieth birthday, and was fifty-five years married yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- It was a slow market, values showing an extremely narrow range. Outside orders were scarce, and brokers saw very little inducement to trade on personal account. In volume of trade, there was very little to choose between the elevated and the cable stocks. Offerings of North Chicago were rather less restricted than yesterday, and, as a consequence, most of the trades were a little lower.

Chairman Lexow and Senators O'Connor and Pound of the special Senate committee appointed to investigate the affairs of the Police Department in this city, arrived at the Hotel Metropole at 9:30 last night, and they, with the other members of the committee will resume the farcical investigation in Part III. of the Court of Common Pleas at 10:30 A.M. to-day.

Many persons who remember the great religious revivals conducted in this city by Finney, the Oberlin evangelist, in 1857, the great revival which followed the civil war, and the Moody and Sankey revivals of eighteen years ago predict that this city is now at the beginning of one of the greatest religious awakenings ever known.

Charles H. Tweed, counsel for the Southern Pacific Railroad Company, yesterday explained the application of that company to the Stock Exchange for the listing of some bonds as follows: "The application was not for the listing of bonds of a new issue, but for listing additional bonds of an issue a portion of which were listed in December of last year.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Miss Pollard was in the courtroom this morning when the trial of her suit against Col. Breckinridge was resumed. The first witness, Sarah Guest, colored, of Lexington, Ky., identified both plaintiff and defendant. She said that about ten years ago Col. Breckinridge brought Miss Pollard to her house, asking her to receive her as a boarder, Col. Breckinridge, she said, frequently called to see her evenings.

Harry Wright, the chief of the baseball umpires, is at work making changes in the instructions to the staff, and wording some of the rules so that they cannot be misinterpreted. He points out that the change in the rules in relation to being hit by a pitched ball, and bunt hits, will throw more responsibility upon the umpires. Everything is now left to the judgment of the umpire.
"Cross Keys," a comedy in three acts, by Edith Carpenter, was read at the Waldorf last evening.

Lawyer Lewis S. Marx of 167 Broadway has got himself into considerable trouble by what is termed "irregular practice." and the chances are that the General Term of the City Court may be asked to investigate his action.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- George Work of New-York met his match at pigeon shooting in A.C. Macalester of this city at Riverton to-day, and was defeated by seven birds. The shoot was for $2,500 a side, 200 birds each, thirty yards' rise, and fifty yards' boundary.
Supplementary proceedings in the case of Isidor Mehrbaec, the race-horse owner, against Frank H. Partridge, bookmaker, were resumed yesterday before Maurice Meyer, referee.

James Corbett, the California youth who has won fame and dollars with his brawny right hand, is the recognized champion of the world. He has gained signal victories over Boston's pride, John L. Sullivan, and the British champion, Charles Mitchell, and if he is successful over Peter Jackson he will be the undisputed holder of the title.

The great match for the championship of the world and 52,000 a side between William Steinitz, champion of the world, and Emanuel Lasker, the great German exponent of the game, commenced at the Union Square Hotel, in this city, yesterday afternoon. There was a large number of spectators present.

Justice Barrett, in the Supreme Court, was engaged yesterday in the trial of an action brought by the receivers of the Madison Square Bank, Messrs. Miles M. O'Brien and James G. Cannon, to recover the value of two notes for $50,000 each from R.G. McDonald, who was a Director of the bank at the time of its failure, and the Fort Wayne Electric Company, of which he was Treasurer.

"Jupiter," the well-known English authority, is in Paris watching the bicycle races there. He writes: "The English division at present in Paris are getting gradually fit, and I anticipate big things from them out in the open. Edwards, Harris, Schofield, Linton, Warwick, Lumsden, Hewson, Delancy Dodds, Don Lacaille, and Golliver form the 'British' lot, while Wheeler and Martin represent the 'Stars and Stripes.'

Harry La Verne has ridden from San Francisco to Galveston, Texas. The distance is 2,184 miles, and he covered it in ninety-two days, an average of nearly twenty-four miles daily. He made the trip for pleasure, and used twenty-eight horses on the journey.

Episcopalians who have heard that the only part of the great Protestant cathedral so far finished is a crucifix made at OberAmmergau are recommended to visit the Irving Place Theatre to see what a Herrgottschnitzer looks like. The German troupe is playing "The Crucifix Carver of OberAmmergau" this week and will present it for the last time on Monday.

Alexander Elsberg, Carl Abresch, and Alfred Samuel were indicted yesterday by the Grand Jury on a charge of forgery in the third degree. Elsberg and Abresch were employes of the State Bank, 378 Grand Street, Elsberg being a bookkeeper and Abresch receiving teller.

PARIS, March 15 -- A bomb was exploded at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon just inside the main door of the Church of the Madeleine. One person, supposed to be the author of the explosion, was killed, and several others were wounded. The explosion, which was evidently premature, mutilated in a horrible manner the man who was carrying the bomb.

The absence of Leader Patrick Divver of the Second Assembly District was explained in The New-York Times yesterday by his son, James P. Divver, and the story was partly corroborated by a dispatch from California, which said that Mayor Gilroy was within hailing distance of "the Judge."

Warrants were executed last Monday at the instance of the Society for the Prevention of Crime on John Magie of the Delaware House, Thirty-fourth Street and Third Avenue; Jacob Caweiss of the Columbia House, 441 Third Avenue; D.E. Fowler of the Irocuois House, 613 Third Avenue, and Alexander C. Sherman of the Sherman House, 152 East Forty-second Street.

Suit was begun yesterday before Judge McAdam in the Special Term of the Superior Court regarding the settlement and distribution among the heirs of the estate of Joseph C. Beers, formerly a broker of this city, and of the estate of Lewis Curtis. Both had been men of large wealth.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, March 15 -- P.M. The knowledge that the Bland Seigniorage bill would be passed by the Senate was a damper to-day not only on the local market, but on London. The foreigners sold a few thousand shares at the opening, and as a result the general market was irregular.

When the majority members of the Senate Committee on Finance decided to impose a duty on sugar, their action was taken, of course, with the understanding that all imported sugar would be subject to the duty. Their estimate of the amount of revenue that the duty would yield shows that.
ALBANY, March 15 -- The Bi-Partisan Police Commission bill for New-York City came out of the Senate Cities Committee this afternoon backed by a favorable report.
Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. SAM FRANCISCO, March 15 -- The United Press correspondent at Apia, Samoa, writing under date of Feb. 28, says:

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Secretary of the Navy to-day cabled orders to Admiral Benham at Rio, directing him to proceed at once with one ship to Bluefields. No particular ship is mentioned, but it is understood that the San Francisco, upon which the Admiral now has his flag, will execute the order.

The tranquillity of the Union League Club has been disturbed by the action of the Executive Committee in limiting the credit to be allowed to about forty members. Each of these members has received a letter, of which this is a sample:
PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., March 15 -- The strike among the mill hands in this city continues to-day with more threatening aspects. At least 1,000 men, women, and girls are now out.

The reported lynching of a negro brings several reflections forcibly to the mind. One of the first reflections that thus come thronging is the reflection how easy it must have been, in exciting times, to write "editorials" for the Republican press. It is true that so far as the substance or the style of the articles was concerned no great difficulty attended the composition of them in off years.
A spirited mass meeting of the Independent County Organization of Anti-Tammany-Ites of the Ninth Assembly District was held in Caledonian Hall, Thirteenth Street and Eighth Avenue, last night.

A carefully prepared opinion on the rights of the holders of the Erie Railway second consolidated mortgage bonds has been furnished by Evarts, Choate Beaman to the Messrs. E.H. Harriman, Henry Budge, John J. Emery, and Sidney Webster, who comprise the Erie Bondholders' Protective Committee, and who are opposed to the reorganization plan.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- That the Democratic members of the Senate Finance Committee are very much embarrassed over the prevailing difference of opinion regarding the effect of the sugar schedule of the Tariff bill is plain. So long as raw sugar remained upon the free list, there was only the opposition of the Louisiana Senators, backed by the sugar planters of their State, to contend with.

Law and justice have gained a triumph in the conviction of Justice of the Peace Sutherland in Kings County which is of very great value and promise. Sutherland was an important part of the McKane machine in Gravesend. He was one of the agents through which that machine used the power of the law to punish and coerce decent citizens who resisted it, and protected the lawless instruments of McKane's political and personal schemes.

BOSTON, March 15. -- Henry Irving addressed the students of Harvard University in Sanders Theatre, Cambridge, this afternoon, there being a large and appreciative audience present. In the course of his address, he said:

Wheat declined 5/8 @ 3/4c on a bearish report from Cincinnati, together with fine weather and lower markets West, and some local liquidation, with the close firm at 3/8 @ 1/2c under yesterday, and a fair trade; May made a new low record to-day, selling: as low as 61 13-16c, or 3/8c under the previously-recorded low price.

The business of the American Academy of the Dramatic Arts is the instruction of young persons in the rudiments of the art of acting. Why the institution should have undertaken a reproduction of a part of Peri's opera, "Euridice," might, therefore, appear to be a problem were it not for the fact that the work is primitive in every respect and possibly suited to primitive effort.

The one hundredth anniversary of the birth of Friedrich Christian Diez, founder of Romance philology, was celebrated yesterday by the department of Romance languages and literature in Columbia College. Diez was born in Giessen, Hesse-Darmstadt, on March 15, 1794. The exercises consisted of the reading of papers by representatives from several colleges.

Several days ago the Treasury Department notified the immigration authorities here that a certain Charles Templeton was coming to this country in violation of the alien contract labor law, to act as Assistant Secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association in Chicago. The department directed that the man be detained for examination upon arrival.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., March 15 -- Richard Puryear, the negro who murdered Christian Ehlers, near Tannersvllle, Monroe County, escaped from the county jal this morning. He was captured by a mob and hanged to a tree.

BOSTON, March 15 -- The market for local stocks was dull and featureless, the only exception being Bell Telephone, which advanced 3 1/2, to 182 1/2, and closed at 180 1/2. Nothing new has been developed in regard to this company. The opposition at the State House to the proposed increase in its capital has almost subsided, and the impression is that there will be rights for the stockholders.

LONDON, March 15 -- At the meeting of the Directors of the Bank of England today a statement was submitted by David Powell, the Governor of the bank, in which he expressed regret at the necessity for the removal of Frank May, the Chief Cashier. Mr. May, he said, was removed, though allowed to resign, for exceeding his authority and committing great irregularities in regard to making advances to certain customers.

Strenuous efforts are made by organs of the Murphy machine to divert from it the odium of responsibility for the Ross murder at the Troy election. All manner of statements are made, which are not consistent with each other or with known facts, but which, if true, would not affect the main issue.

BOSTON, March 16 -- The market for local stocks was very dull and with few features of interest. Mexican Central showed some activity, and quite a little stock was sold at 7 1/2. The 4s declined 1 point, to 52, later recovering 1/2, to 52 1/2. The continued low price of silver is against any immediate rise in these securities.

DENVER, Col., March 16 -- Gov. Waite today reconsidered his determination to take the City Hall by force and arms. He has sent a letter to Gen. McCook requesting him to withdraw the Federal troops, and in it practically accused the General of having joined the faction opposed to the Governor's supporters.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 16 -- Men running from women wishing to kiss them agitated the County Court here today. Judge Garretson was on the bench. A jury had just announced a verdict of "not guilty" in the case of Anna Wonzowlaska, a pretty Polish girl, sixteen years old, charged with a criminal offense.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16. -- A largely-attended meeting in the interest of municipal reform was held in this city to-night, under the auspices of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, in the assembly hall of the new Century Club. The principal address was made by E.L. Godkin of New-York, and he was followed in a brief discussion by the Rev. Leighton Williams of New-York and others.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senata Committee on Finance has not River any indication to-day that the difficulties incident to the discovery of defects in its amendments to the Tariff bill have been overcome. The members of the committee a few days ago bound themselves to secrecy concerning their actions.

There is every reason why the Chamber of Commerce should make a plain and strong statement of facts regarding the Bland silver inflation bill to the President, in whose hands the fate of the bill now rests. He may not need them to guide his course, but they are facts of the greatest public interest, and the whole country will be benefited by a statement of them from an authoritative source.

Secretary Carlisle has terminated the controversy between the Treasury Department and the American Institute of Architects in regard to open competition for plans for Government buildings by sending the following brief but expressive letter to the President of the institute:

LONDON, March 16. -- In the House of Commons this evening H. Campbell-Bannerman, Secretary of State for War, made a general statement as to the army policy of the Government. He maintained that it was best to have one army organization for the United Kingdom, the colonies, and India. At home the Government should maintain a force of two army corps, with a total numerical strength of 80,000.

Mr. Dawson writes of the Germans and of their Fatherland as one who, if he does not ardently love them, desires above all things to make Englishmen and Americans better understand and appreciate them. We can discover nowhere in his two octavos a trace of prejudice toward them, or toward the Jews, or toward France.

Lovers of scientific boxing ought to be well represented at the Grand Central Palace to-night, when the limited-round contests of the Columbia Athletic Club will be decided. There are eight bouts on the card. The star event will be between those old-time rivals, "Billy" Ernst of Brooklyn and "Billy" Vernon, the "Haverstraw Brickmaker."

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Col. and Mrs. Henry entertained at breakfast this morning at Fort Myer quite a company, who drove over to the for in time to witness the drill. Among the guests were Mrs. Joseph Carey. Mrs. and Miss Blackburn. Senator and Mrs. Manderson. Mrs. Logan, Mrs. Tucker, and Senator Squire.

Cooper Union Hall was crowded to its doors at the evangelisitic revival mass meeting yesterday afternoon. The meeting began with a service of song, and for half an hour the Creole Quartet and otters sang until the great hall rang with melody.

NEW-YORK. Friday, March 16 -- P.M. Trading was even less active than yesterday, but the hope of the market was decidedly stronger. In only three stocks -- Sugar. Chicago Gas, and Distiling and Cattle Feeding -- did the transactions exceed 10,000 shares.

The action of the Legislature on the bill creating a bi-partisan Police Board for this city will afford a test of Platt's power in that body. A majority of the Senate Committee on Cities has already shown its subserviency by reporting the bill favorably, immediately after going through the form of listening to protests from representatives of the city's interests.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 16. -- The rate war situation was somewhat modified by the expressions of C.P. Huntington, President of the Southern Pacific Company, last night. Said Mr. Huntington: "This war is sure to end sooner or later. When the time comes the companies will agree to a settlement.

It was rumored last night that Justice Sutherland, who was found guilty of irregularities in connection with the recent election, and who left suddenly to escape imprisonment, was in Montreal, Canada. Thorough search was made in that city for him, but no trace of him could be found.

ALBANY, March 16. -- "Paddy" Magee, the man who escaped from Detective Hiram Ford of Troy, was seen on the street here to-day in the vicinity of the Post Office by a representative of a Troy paper, who pointed him out to an officer. The officer followed Magee and arrested him at the Union Station.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 16. -- The arbitration of the differences between the employes of the Steinway Railway Company and Alfred D. Moulton. the General Manager, commenced this afternoon before Mayor Sanford in the City Hall.
The back parlors of Mrs. T.M. Ludlow Chrystle's home at 216 West Forty-sixth Street became flower bowers yesterday afternoon and were filled with the freshest and sweetest of young American Beauties.

ALBANY, March 16 -- In the Assembly to-day, on the order of second reading, the bill of Mr Sheffield, providing that the Mayor of New-York City shall have the power to appoint and remove heads of departments, came up. Mr. Sulzer said he had obtained the consent of Mr. Sheffield that the bill be laid aside, and it took that course.

A peculiar phase of the so-called "Gerry act" was brought out before Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, by lawyers Alien and McManus. They argued for the release of Aimee Renout, for whom they had obtained a writ of habeas corpus.

The work of reorganizing the Democratic Party in Kings County, under the supervision of the Committee of One Hundred, is proceeding with a rapidity that insures complete success. At a recent meeting of the ward and county towns Chairmen most encouraging reports of the condition of the work in the various wards and county towns were received.

The course of the Attorney General of the State in declining to take charge of the Troy election fraud cases, under the condition imposed by Gov. Flower, that he should appoint as his deputy the Assistant District Attorney of Rensselaer bounty, is entirely reasonable. The Governor may have made the proposition with good intention, but it was not a proper one to insist upon.

Merchants in this city, Philadelphia, and Boston, who are Interested in furnishing the Government with supplies for the Indians, are indignant at the threatened removal from New-York City to Chicago of the Indian Supply Warehouse, which has been located here for nearly thirty years. They have entered a vigorous protest against it, and will endeavor to Induce the Secretary of the Interior to abandon the proposed change.

Col. William C.P. Breckinridge and Louise R.S. Wing were secretly married in this city, April 29, 1893, by the Rev. John R. Paxton, then pastor of the West Presbyterian Church, at his residence, 51 West Forty-sixth Street, at 8 o'clock in the evening. The witnesses were Mary L. Paxton, Dr. Paxton's wife, and Eleanor M. Collier.

Thomas W. Marshall died in July, 1892, leaving an estate estimated to be worth $100,000. He had three daughters, Mary K. Marshall, Rebecca M. Marshall, and Penelope A. Luttgen, who, by the will, received equal shares in the estate. Mary K. Marshall was made executrix.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 16. -- The courtroom in Ithaca was crowded at the afternoon session to-day. One case had just been concluded and the jury sent out to consider a verdict, when Judge Forbes, without rising in his chair, began addressing the members of the Tompkins County bar, a great many of whom were seated in the inclosure.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Miss Madeline Pollard came early to the Criminal Court this morning to the trial of her suit for breach of promise against Col. W.C. P. Breckinridge. Miss Ellis, her motherlylooking companion from the House of Mercy, was with her as usual, and arranged her chair for her.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Gov. Flower and the Attorney General do not agree as to the manner in which the Troy election crimes should be prosecuted. They had a conference to-day, and the Governor asked Mr. Hancock to take charge of the Troy prosecutions, making Mr. Fagan his assistant. The Attorney General declined to undertake the task under dictation as to whom he should associate with him.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The cruisers New-York and Charleston will remain at Rio for some time, but the Detroit is under orders to bring home the naval cadets of the fleet and land them at Norfolk not later than April 15 unless hostilities should be renewed, necessitating her continued presence in Brazilian waters.
A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce has been called for Tuesday for the purpose of asking President Cleveland to veto the Seigniorage bill.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., March 16 -- Trouble was averted at the Standard Silk Mill this evening by the presence of Judge Morrow of Belvidere and Prosecuting Attorney Stryker of Washington, N.J., who appeared at the mill just before it shut down for the day.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- On the strength of the report to the effect that the two elevated roads now in operation had agreed on a scheme which it is hoped will solve the problem of a down-town loop, the elevated stocks appreciated considerably. The scheme mentioned is one by which the two roads will meet on Wabash Avenue, the Lake Street Line reaching that thoroughfare by way of Lake Street.

RONDOUT, March 16. -- There is a possibility that the Republican majority of ten in the Board of Supervisors of Ulster County will be wiped out by the Democrats, who claim that six of the Republican Supervisors elected are ineligible. All of these six Supervisors, it is alleged, are School Trustees and cannot, therefore, qualify for the office.

The gymnasium of Pratt Institute was crowded last evening with the friends of the girls belonging to the high school connected with the institute, who came to witness the girls skill in the manipulation of Indian clubs and fencing foils and prowess in athletic exercises. It would have been an exacting public that would not have been satisfied with the graceful evolutions performed in perfect unison by pretty young freshmen, Juniors, and seniors.

MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., March 16 -- The Haskell Barker Car Works have secured a contract for 1,500 cars, and the immense plant, employing 1,000 men, will resume operations within a few days, after six months of idleness.

Sister M. Rosina Superioress of the order of the Sisters of Charity in the United States, died yesterday afternoon at the mother house, Mount St. Vincent, Westchester County, N.Y. Thursday night, while seated at the supper table, she was stricken with paralysis, and remained unconscious until her death.

A meeting of delegates to the convention of Irish societies was held last evening at Central Hall, 229 East Forty-seventh Street. The object of the meeting was the repetition of instructions previously given, in order that the details of the procession of to-day might be fully understood. President Jeremiah Driscoll of the convention was in the chair.

John Williams, manager of a stranded farce-comedy company, was a defendant yesterday in Justice Goetting's court, in Lee Avenue. Brooklyn, for falling to pay the board of his company, as he had agreed to do. Mrs. Mary Carmine of 328 Bedford Avenue was the complainant. She said that Williams became responsible for the board of the members of his company, but fled Saturday night without paying her.

Another all-day session of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday failed to bring about a satisfactory settlement of existing differences between Southern railroads. The sub-committee which was appointed to promote harmony if possible submitted a report which was received with favor.

Mrs. Mary Dunn was found guilty of manslaughter in the second degree by a jury in the Court of General Sessions last night. She was charged with murder in the first degree for having killed her husband in their home in West Twenty-sixth Street last October. Dunn, it was said, had been given to drink, and frequently abused his wife, who had threa-tened to leave him.
Miss Beaston delivered the second lecture of her course on "The Drama" yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf.

Brooklyn may have two candidates for Governor before the next Republican State Convention. The name of Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy has already been brought forward by his friends. Now the name of Mayor Charles A. Schleren is being actively discussed. Many Kings County Republicans usually well Informed say that Mr. Schieren's candidacy for the head of the ticket in the Fall is by no means an impossibility.

Police Captain Josiah A. Westervelt of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station was before the Commissioners yesterday to answer to a charge of neglect of duty in falling to suppress certain policy shops in his precinct. The charges against the Captain are brought by Superintendent Byrnes, who specifies thirteen places in the precinct where policy slips were sold.

Georgre L. Fox, rector of the Hopkins Grammar School, New-Haven, Conn., delivered, in the Manhattan Club Theatre, last evening, the last of his four illustrated lectures on "The Great Schools of England." The school of which he spoke was Harrow-on-the-Hill.

Reports yesterday of a suit in Duluth by Alfred and Leonldas Merritt against the American Steel Barge Company, for the purpose of enjoining the sale of certain stock deposited by the Messrs. Merritt as collateral for notes which they have failed to meet, excited interest down town, because of the persons and property involved.

The Senate committee appointed to investigate the State Board of Health met yesterday at the Hotel Metropole. Dr. Cyrus Edson of the local Health Board and Dr. William T. Jenkins, Health Officer of the Port, were examined at some length regarding the workings of the State Board, of which they are both members.

copyright. 1804. by the United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO. March 16. -- Admiral da Gama and his eight officers are still on the Portuguese corvette Mindello, to which they were transferred from the French cruiser Magon.

The members of the Country Club gave an entertainment at the clubhouse, at Westchester, last night that attracted the members of the hunting and polo circles in large numbers. The clubhouse and the cottages were crowded with guests, and many who went out came back to the city on the special train that left Westchester at 11:15 o'clock.

In adopting resolutions indorsing the Wilson Tariff bill and denouncing the course of Senators Camden and Faulkner, the Hickory Democratic Club of Parkersburg, West Va., has performed a service of great value to its party. The value of the service does not consist in the fact that the action taken was favorable to the Wilson bill, but in the fact that any action at all was taken.

Lafayette Post, No. 140, G.A.R., presented to Gen. George Edward Gouraud a medal of honor last night in Masonic Temple, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue. The stage was artistically draped with national emblems and the State standard. In the centre sat Gen. John P. Hatch, on whose staff Gen. Gouraud served as Captain and aide de camp at the battle of Honey Hill, South Carolina.

It is quite probable that the Senate Committee on Finance will insert in the Tariff bill a paragraph directing the President to terminate the commercial agreements, sometimes called treaties of reciprocity, which were made by the Harrison Administration, with the assistance of the retaliatory legislation contained in Section 3 of the McKinley Tariff act.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The House today voted not to direct a special investigation of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, as provided for in an amendment to the Sundry civil Appropriation bill proposed yesterday by Mr. Enlop. (Dem., Tenn.)

ALBANY, March 16 -- Assemblyman Lawson introduced his bill to-day, prohibiting the flying of any foreign flag on any public building in the State. While he was introducing the bill the noise of hammer and saw could be heard directly under the windows of the Assembly Chamber, where a platform was being erected from which Gov. Flower will review Che St. Patrick's Day parade to-morrow.

The Grand Army Mission Committee, which consists of Killaen Van Rensselaer. President and Treasurer; Alexander S. Webb, James Talcott. O.O. Howard, Ira M. Hedges, William T. Wardwell, Samuel H. Hadley, Wager Swayne, Frank C. Loveland, and John S. Huyler, has sent out an appeal to pastors and churches within 300 miles of New-York City asking for aid.

TROY, March 16 -- Under the Murphy system of conducting elections, and with Murphy policemen as the sole guardians of the peace, it appears to have been thought necessary for those opposed to Murphy who cared to survive election day in Troy to carry clubs in their pockets as they wended their ways to the polling places.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Instructions were telegraphed to Gen. McCook late this afternoon by order of President Cleveland. Secretary Lamont states that they were, in substance, as follows:

Dun's Review will say to-morrow. Week by week it is found possible by an increasing number of concerns to revive production with a general range of prices the lowest ever known. As old stocks give out, orders for replenishment are first for cheaper goods than have before been chosen, traders therein representing consumers who are compelled or desire to live more cheaply.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Mr. Hewitt makes a great mistake in singling out one section and one set of men for his criticism. Ignorance in economic matters is not sectional. It extends throughout the nation and, perhaps, is not more dense in the Southern than in the Northeastern States.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 16 -- The "Industrial Army" was told last night by Quartermaster O'Brien that he would issue orders for them to leave for Washington on Saturday morning.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 16 -- The Governments of Manitoba and the Northwest recently passed legislation abolishing Roman Catholic separate schools, thus virtually compelling all children of Catholics to attend the public schools. The Catholics appealed to the Privy Council of England, but that tribunal declared the Government had power to pass such legislation.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

The oratorical contest between the senior and junior classes of Manhattan College for the Grady Memorial Medal was held in Madison Hall, at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon, and was well attended. The medal was awarded to James P. Larkin of the senior class, whose subject was, "The Disturbance Bill."

NEW-YORK, Saturday, March 17 -- P.M The stock market was fairly active for a Saturday, but was somewhat irregular owing to the taking of profits. Sugar was quite active compared with recent days, and after selling at 92 1/3, closed unchanged at 91.

Although the prospect of getting any kind of reform legislation from the present Legislature of this State does not seem to be very good, the Excise Reform Association does not remit its efforts in behalf of the high-license policy. For some reason there appears to be lesa interest in this subject now than was shown several years ago, when these efforts were first begun.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore gave his weekly illustrated lecture to the teachers of the City and State of New-York, at the American Museum of Natural History, yesterday morning. His subject was the Midway Plaisance of the Columbian Exposition.

The Bushwick Avenue Congregationalists in Brooklyn are confidently looking forward to the time in the near future when they will occupy their handsome new church on the corner of Busnwick Avenue and Cornelia Street. The plan of the new edifice, which will soon be under way.

There are far worse places than a country inn after a hard day's struggle through a snowstorm on horseback, especially if that inn be situated in the heart of a picturesque region much beloved by Summer tourists, if the host has been taught thereby the art of making comfortable, and is inclined through leisure, to exercise it.

A great deal has been written upon art in general, and the arts in particular, and much of it is weary reading because of the narrowness of the view. To be a philosopher concerning art requires a cool head and a mind fixed steadily on the contemplation of enduring principles. To construct a theory concerning art requires something more than this.

In the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday Charles J. Patterson moved before Justice Cullen for writs of mandamus to compel City Clerk Joseph Benjamin to reinstate as clerks in his office Joseph V. Scully and William L.D. Grady. The ground set forth is that the former is a veteran fireman and the latter is a war veteran, and, under the statutes, they could not be removed without cause.

ORANGE, March 17. -- The Orange Athletic Club will put a strong baseball nine in the field this Spring, captained by Beall. Yale, '93, and now of the New-York Law School. He will play second base and Lansing will catch. Buell will play first base. Murphy third, Hutchinson of Princeton left field, Place centre field, and Babcock right field.

The Cactus Club of Baltimore is a unique organization. It is composed of men and women who unite in a company solely for the purpose of studying cacti. They have found much of interest in these curious desert plants, and their periodical exhibitions are much esteemed by such as are invited to be present.
The French Line steamship La Champagne, which sailed for Havre yesterday, carried $1,000,000 in gold, shipped by Lazard Freres. It is going to Paris.

LONDON, March, 17. -- Lord Rosebery's definition of his attitude toward the question, of Irish, home rule, as given in his speech at Edinburgh to-night, certainly ought to be sufficient to defeat the purposes of the malignant misrepresentations of the Premier's remarks in the House of Lords.

LONDON, March 17. -- The fifty-first race between the crews of the universities of Oxford and Cambridge since 1829, when the present series began, was rowed this morning, and Oxford won by three and a half lengths, in 21:39.

In "Sowing the Wind," which is now nearing its one hundredth performance at the Empire, the picturesque possibilities of men's dress, under some adaptations, are very apparent. How full these possibilities are is not quite realized until, after the play, one stops in the lobby to look at the pictures of different scenes of the performance there framed and presented.

I was given instances of what local rates are at Pallanza. At the Albergo di Milan, a small, but well-kept place on the quay, they come to 3,000 lire or franca a year. National taxes were, to put it roughly, paid on nearly everything, and the money raised by them was shamefully wasted by a cumbersome, ill-paid, and swarming civil service.

St. Patrick's Day was celebrated yesterday in due and proper form. The green flag floated from between two poles on the City Hall; every other man on the streets wore a piece of shamrock or a bit of green ribbon, and the grass In the parks made an extra effort to get far enough above ground to show its appreciation of the day.

James P. Diwer, son of the absent leader of the Second Assembly District, appears, of all his relatives and friends, to be the only one who has any news of the missing leader. He said yesterday: "Father just now is in San Francisco, but I don't know at what hotel.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., March 17. -- The American flag was hauled down from the staff on the Town Hall here this afternoon and the green flag of Ireland hoisted in its place. The incident caused excitement and came near ending in a riot.
ORANGE, N.J., March 17. -- Dr. Joseph W. Stickler entertained the members of the Orange Mountain Society at his home in Centre Street last evening.

The deliberations of the Executive Committee of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association in the Fifth Avenue Hotel came to a successful conclusion yesterday. The report of the sub-committee in favor of restoring harmony among the railroads of the South was adopted soon after noon, and the meeting, which had lasted five days, adjourned sine die.

With the nautical drama In the harbor of Rio de Janeiro over, and the curtain, already rung down, it will not take long for the onlooking foreign squadrons to go their ways. Among these spectators our own fleet has held a most prominent place -- to say the truth, at one critical juncture, it was even obliged to appear on the stage and take a hand in the play.

In the old days or wooden sailing vessels the United States held a leading place in the industry of shipbuilding and in the carrying trade of the world, in spite of antiquated laws and a contracted policy. We had an unlimited supply of the best timber and the materials of shipbuilding cost us less than they cost any other maritime nation, and consequently the navigation laws had no effect.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 17. -- Howard Rouviere, forty-three years old, committed suicide to-day in Mrs. Francis Mittag's boarding house, 114 State Street, by taking laudanum. A letter addressed to the suicide and signed "Mother" was found. On the back of the envelope was penciled "Mrs. L.B., 65 Laurel Street.

TROY, N.Y., March 17.-The Ross inquest was continued this morning. Paul Emery testified that he saw a man lying on the ground, and saw him fired at twice, but he was so far distant that he could not identify the man who fired the shots.
