Flint, whose business relations with Brazil qualify him to speak intelligently of the revolution which has just been quelled in that republic, in conversation with a reporter of The New-York Times yesterday, had this to say of the triumph of the Government on the arrival of the dynamite fleet at Rio de Janeiro:

NAPLES, March 17. -- Several Socialists were put on trial here yesterday for various seditious utterances and acts. During the proceedings to-day one of the lawyers, who had conducted the defense, declared that his professional liberty had been violated by police agents, who followed him constantly.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. WASHINGTON, March 17. -- While Col. Breckinridge has declined to be interviewed for publication respecting the future course of his trial, the United Press can state authoritatively, from sources which are thoroughly reliable, that the plans and views of the defendant have been practically determined upon as here outlined.

The auction sales of realty during the past week in Brooklyn footed up $98,870, as compared with $315,654 for the corresponding week last year. The mortgages recorded last week were 208, for $826,351, of which 72, for $505,927, were at 5 per cent, or less. During the similar week in 1893, 294 mortgages, for $940,968, were recorded, of which 149, for $638,300, were at 5 per cent, or less.

In a little more than two months the yachting season of 1894 will have opened. Usually, at this time of the year, the yachtbuilding yards are very busy places, and gangs of workmen are hard at work, trying to get the new boats ready for the Spring regattas. This year the yards are comparatively dull places.

GLOUCESTER. Mass., March 17 -- The most destructive fire since the conflagration of 1864 occurred in this city to-day. It originated in the rear of the Ferguson Block, in Rogers Street, and, despite the rapid work of the Fire Department, is made such headway that the whole building was soon in flames.

Each year the celebration of the Easter festival becomes more general and more marked. Not very many decades ago its observance was confined almost exclusively to two of the Christian Churches. Now, however, nearly every Church, family, and individual shares the joy in the Resurrection and the Life. The season's beauty and significance cannot keep itself to any one sect or creed.

The correspondence printed yesterday between the Secretary of the Treasury and the American Institute of Architects makes it tolerably certain that no action will be taken during Mr. Carlisle's administration under the act passed last year, empowering him to institute competitions for the design of public buildings.

Many leaden bullets used for slings have been in comparatively recent times picked up near Ascoll, (the ancient Asculum.) and these remind us of the final stage in the last grand hopeless struggle which the Italian towns waged against the overmastering tyranny of Rome. In this case we have Inscribed bullets of both sides. "Feri Pomp."

EDINBURGH, March 17. -- Lord Rosebery was received in this city to-day by cheering crowds. Thousands filled the streets on his route from the railway station to the Corn Exchange. More than 5,000 Liberals had Bothered at the Exchange to hear him speak, and they greeted him with thunders of applause as he entered the hall.
XI. Carroll plunged his hand into a finger bowl with an impatience he very rarely showed.

The performance of a part of Peri's "Euridice," by Mr. Franklin Sargent's pupils, at the Berkeley Lyceum on Thursday night, was stiff, ungraceful, and unnatural, yet it was interesting, because of the historical associations surrounding the work. It did not require much skill to discern that in the hands of competent dramatic singers, the first opera would, even at this day, hold the attention of an audience of persons of good taste.

Now that Justice Sutherland, John Y. McKane's henchman, has failed to appeal in court to receive his sentence, and is said to be a fugitive from the United States, it will prove of interest to know who of the McKane cohorts are still under indictment and who are their bondsmen.

On Tuesday, March 20, Gen. Neal Dow, the "Father of Prohibition," the "Grand Old Man in the Temperance Cause," as Miss Willard calls him, will have completed his ninetieth year. The day is to be made one of rejoicing wherever the Woman's Christian Temperance Union has carried the blue ribbon, and this includes not only the United States, but England, Canada, Japan, China, India, and the Sandwich Islands.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Mr. Baldwin's report on the City College reminds one, by contrast, of the story of the Quaker who subscribed for a church organ. The Friends remonstrated with him, but he replied: "If they will praise God by machinery, I prefer they should have a good Instrument."

One of the most interesting and important modern examples of geological research is afforded by the recent discovery of coal at Dover. As long ago as 1855 the question of the possible extension of the coal measures beneath the newer rocks of the southeast of England was discussed by an able geologist, Mr. Godwin-Austin.

The testimony taken by the Senate committee during the last two days certainly shows dereliction of duty on the part of a number of policemen at polling places in this city on the last election day. It Indicated a disposition on the part of these men to connive at fraud when it was countenanced by Tammany Inspectors, and to wink at violations of the law which they permitted.

BOSTON, March 17 -- The principal feature of the market for local stocks was the strength of West End Street Railway. which advanced to 49 and closed at 48 3/4. President Little of this road is reported as saying that its floating debt was reduced last month by 25 per cent, and that the company has already made plans for the extension of its electrical system to be prosecuted the coming Summer.

To guard against accidents of the tariff, the Sugar Trust is gathering in large stocks of raw sugar. Special steamers for this purpose have been chartered from English. German, and Norwegian owners, and several ships of the Southern Pacific Company are also engaged in this service. Receipts last week reached nearly 57,000 tons, an increase of 13,000 tons over the corresponding week of last year.

The Ladies' Club closed its course of Monday morning meetings for the season last week. Another musicale was on the programme, but, owing to the change of arrangements, was postponed. One of the latest acquisitions at the clubhouse is a pretty little ebony chess table, the squares inlaid with mather-of-pearl.

An old and crippled woman, suffering from sickness that must soon end her earthly career, and her daughter-in-law, with five children, were found yesterday on the third floor of the tenement house at 317 East Seventy-first Street, mourning the death of son and husband, who in a moment of despair, committed suicide.

Dr. Fabricius, ship surgeon of the steamship Vega, which arrived here yesterday from Lisbon, via the Azores, brought a detailed account of the battle with a storm of the bark Montgomery Castle and the loss of her three officers and seven of her crew.

A well-attended meeting of TwentiethWard Democrats Identified with the Provisional Committee of One Hundred was held last evening in Philosophic Hall, Adelphi Street, Brooklyn. J. Hampden Dougherty presided. He congratulated the meeting on the excellent progress which the reform movement is making.

The managers of the Field Columbian Museum of Chicago have purchased for $100,000 the Tiffany collection of gems and precious stones exhibited at the World's Fair. This collection is regarded as one of the most important additions that has been made to the Museum.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, March 17. -- The ratification of the Russo-German treaty by the Reichstag has left the Government complacent and the Conservatives bitter. The men who led the Opposition in the fight against the new grain tariff do not acknowledge that they have been permanently defeated, but threaten ultimately to brine the Chancellor to terms.

Old mansions, with tales to tell, line the East River front in Ravenswood, Long Island City. Separated by extensive grounds, which were once well-kept parks, these relics of past grandeur stretch along Vernon Avenue, from sooty Hunter's Point quite into Astoria. Not more than twenty years ago famous families of that period filled these great houses with life and fashion.

When Corporation Counsel McDonald of Brooklyn alluded to Mayor Schleren at the St. Patrick Society's dinner last evening-, thirty or forty men hissed vigorously. The hisses were Intended as a rebuke to the Mayor for prohibiting the hoisting of the green flag on the Brooklyn City Hall, and also for failing to attend the banquet.

A dispatch received from Montreal yesterday says Kenneth F. Sutherland, the convicted Gravesend Police Justice, is known to be in that city, and detectives are aware of his whereabouts, but had received no instructions to arrest him. Lawyers here say he cannot be extradited for the offense for which he was convicted.

Isaac Cahn of 1,045 Fifth Avenue was directed by Judge Martine, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, to pay $20 a week to each of his daughters, Rose, twenty-six years old, and Emma, ninteen years old. The action was brought on the claim made by the daughters that they had been driven from home by their parents.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 17. -- Attendant Michael Killeen declared to-day that he can, if the State Commission in Lunacy orders him to do so, reveal a terrible state of affairs in the Buffalo State Hospital. Irritated beyond endurance by the fact that his colleagues in the asylum are seeking to put on him all the blame for Patient Felton's death, he suddenly arose during the investigation and exclaimed:

More than 250 members of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick dined last evening at Delmonico's, to celebrate the one hundred and tenth anniversary of the society. John D. Crimmins presided, and among others present were Recorder Smyth, Judge Morgan J. O'Brlen, ex-Mayor Grant, Howard Carroll, and James S. Coleman.

CANNES, March 17. -- The grand review of the yachting fleet to-day was a brilliant affair, judged from a spectacular point of view, but was somewhat disappointing in respect of the number of spectators which it attracted. The weather was delightfully clear and warm. All the yachts from the different parts of the Riviera were included in the review.

Mr. Maccallum's work, a study of the minds of ages reflected in literary appreciation of an epopeia, is one of the most delightful that could be written. Its theme had its source in antique Celtic tradition, and passed into mediaeval France, where it apparently slept like a crystal brook under large leaves in hours of indifference to poetry.

PARIS, March 17. -- The Gaulois asserts that the life of Vaillant, the Anarchist who was executed a short time ago for throwing a bomb from the gallery of the Chamber of Deputies, was insured for u8,000, and that the money has been paid to the Anarchist propaganda in London, for whose benefit the policies were taken out.

DENVER, Col., March 17. -- The contest for the offices in the Fire and Police Board is now safely in the courts without bloodshed, and troubles among the miners of Cripple Creek solved for Gov. Waite the question as to the disposal of the militia in the interval of court proceedings.

The United Irish Societies of Brooklyn celebrated the anniversary of the birth of St. Patrick by a big parade yesterday. It was the first time in years that the two wings of the Irish societies united in a parade.

By an odd chance, old "Rosedale" was actually the play of the week. Nothing else in the new bills of last Monday caused so much talk about town, and the old Wallack play on the old Wallack stage drew large audiences. It brought out the old playgoer -- him with the long memory, the controversial spirit, and the fluent speech.

From the time of the ancients until the middle of our own century the phenomena of earthquakes had been observed and described on countless occasions. But If any one will look over the pages of Humboldt's "Cosmos," (published in 1844) which summarize the then existing knowledge on this subject, he will find almost no sign that earthquakes are to be studied like other mechanical motions.

The action expected of the Chamber or Commerce at the meeting called for Tuesday, urging the President to veto the Seigniorage bill, promises to be reinforced by resolutions to the same effect by other bodies in this city and by petitions to the President extensively signed.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor. The New-York Times." Hatter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Four times a year an army assembles in Washington. It has no officers, no uniform, no weapons, no standards. Its entry is unheralded, and the public has no knowledge of its presence until it stands revealed with its right resting on the front porch of the Pension Agency Building and its rear guard far away in the adjoining reservation.

From The Rochester Post-Express. The Dansville Advertiser adds several names to our list of editors of country newspapers in this State who have been In the harness for twenty-five years or more, though we made no attempt to make a complete list.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- The local stock market was given up almost wholly to the elevated certificates. The trading In bonds even was insignificant, compared to the activity in Alley "L" and Lake Street. Opening at 25 1/2, the former stock advanced rapidly to 27, where transactions were numerous and large.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 17. -- The Abe Stein Company of New-York City was to-day incorporated to import and export hides, skins, leather, rubber, coffee, and general merchandise. The capital is $50,000 and the Directors are Abe Stein, Virginia Stein, and Theodore Minzesheimer of New-York City.

Here are six stories, with "Friend Barton's Concern "the longest. Generally Mary Hallock Foote describes the free life of the West, but in "Friend Barton" she takes a Quaker family living in New-England during the first quarter of this century. The story describes the struggles of Dorothy for spiritual freedom, and how she finally gained her liberty.
LONDON, March 17. -- One week ago men's minds were occupied with nothing but the glowing forecasts of enthusiasm and halcyon omens under which the splendid new Rosebery ship was to be launched.

The Senate Committee on Finance will be asked by persons representing a considerable number of merchants and importers to substitute for the sugar schedule which the majority members of the committee have framed another one in which the maximum duty is the same, but in which the gradation upward from raw sugars of low quality is differently arranged.

OCEANIC, N.J., March 17. -- William Abbett, employed by William J. Parsons at Locust Point, N.J., and Miss Ethel Robinson, a young woman of considerable means, were to have been married here Thursday night. A minister from Fair Haven was present. There were flowers in abundance, an elegant supper prepared, music, and everything required for a wedding party.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 17. -- Cornelius Vanderbilt made a flying visit to his farm in South Portsmouth on Friday. He did not come to Newport, his private car stopping at the railroad station near Mr. Vanderbilt's place.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 17. -- The dinner of the Buffalo Republican League, held in Concert Hall to-night, was attended by all the leading Republicans of Buffalo and Western New-York. Mayor Charles A. Schleren of Brooklyn was the principal speaker of the evening.

An exciting contest for class honors has just terminated in the class of '94 of the University of the City of New-York. The contending factions were represented on one side by the secret societies, Phi Delta Phi and Delta Chi, and on the other by a company of students calling themselves "neutrals."

An Englishman deplores in The Saturday Review the lack of knowledge among his countrywomen in the matter of gravies and sauces, those embellishments of meat and fish, without which the finest flesh or the most flavored fish has lost much of its relish.

Lady Sidmouth, who died in her hundredth year in January last, was "a link with the past," In a specially Interesting sense. As a girl she had lived In the Speaker's house, and had a vivid recollection of hearing debates In which Pitt and Fox took part-those great oratorical duels which Byron has so well described in "The Age of Bronze."

We were in the absolute wilderness of upland Ceylon, where the virgin beauty and freshness of nature unspoiled by man instills a new sensation into every soul which vibrates to her mysterious voice. The rolling green patenas are cut off sheer and straight from the encircling belts of jungle as though measured off by human hands, a striking feature of these elevated regions which has never been satisfactorily explained.

A club which bears the proud distinction of being the only one of its kind has just been established in Washington. Eligibility to membership is ability to do independent work of some sort, a definition which does not apply to women merely holding clerkships.

BUFFALO, March 17. -- There was a small riot at East Buffalo this afternoon which, but for the prompt action of the police, might have attained serious proportions. The trouble was the result of the shooting of Bernard Renkowski Wednesday night by Louis Gertzman, whose store Renkowski and several companions were attempting to rob.

At the first concert of the St. Petersburg Imperial Musical Society on Oct. 16 has the programme consisted of the following numbers: Overture, "Carmoaine," Laroche; larghetto and gavotte from "Idomeneo," Mozart; piano concerto. No. 1, Tschaikow sky; symphony in B minor, No. 6, Opus 74, Tschaikowsky, first time.

"Free Ships" was the subject of discussion at the monthly meeting of the Reform Club last night. There was a dinner at which 125 members were seated, and the tables were spread in the banquet room, the main table being laid at the end on a platform.

The promise of good business among real estate men was not borne out by the transactions of the past week, although several notable sales and deals were made, which are not yet in shape for publication, and quite a number are hanging fire. A little more confidence is shown and builders are beginning to give signs of activity.

How far James W. Ridgway, District Attorney of Kings County, went last Summer to save Mayor David A. Boody and the thirteen members of the Board of Aldermen of Brooklyn from indictment is made manifest by a decision just handed down by Justice Cullen of the Supreme Court.

The former adherents of John T. McKane are quarreling among themselves. Two of them, John H. O'Rourke and Michael J. Dady, have begun a suit against a third, Willliam G. Pierson, for $60,000 damages. The parties to the action are all intimate friends of the Gravesend "boss."

From The London Daily News. An unfortunate gentleman named Voisin has been the victim of a strong resemblance he appears to bear to some one else. Walking along the Rue de Vaugrirard, he suddenly saw a woman rush in his direction and throw something at him.

-- A novel addition will be made to the features Of "1492" at the Garden Theatre Tuesday night, in the form of reproductions by living figures of famous paintings. The exhibition, which was invented by Herr von Kilanyi, an artist of Buda-Pesth, has been received with great favor in Leipsic, Berlin, Paris, Madrid, and for the last eight months in London.

SPENCER, Mass., March 17. -- Isaac Prouty Co., boot and shoe manufacturers, have made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors to Isaac L. Prouty, N.A. Young, and H.B. Endiott Co. of Boston. The firm gave employment to 2,000 persons when running regular time. It was one of the largest boot and shoe firms in the world.

BOSTON, Mass., March 17. -- The Exile, one of Boston's fastest 21-footers has been sold to Vice Commodore F.M. Randall of the Pavonia Yacht Club of New-Jersey, and will be raced in the "cabin sloop" class of that and other clubs, a light trunk cabin being added to bring her within the rule.

BALTIMORE, March 17. -- Russell Sage, Logan C. Murray, E.H. Perkins, and George P. Rowell, the committee appointed by the West Presbyterian Church of New-York to tender a call to the Rev. Dr. Maltbie D. Babcock of Brown Memorial Church to fill the pulpit made vacant through the resignation of the Rev. John F. Paxton, called on Dr. Babcock this afternoon.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

To the Editor The New-York Times: Your courageous course in exposing the Brooklyn ring thieves in the Elevated Railroad Orphan Fund, the Long Island water steal, the veteran burial robbery, and electric light steal, has endeared The Times to all who love Brooklyn as their home and place of abode.

An auction sale of fast trottera on a street adjacent to the wharves on the east side of this city is calculated to astonish a horseman, or to inspire him with Incredulity as to the merits of the animals to be sold. Yesterday an advertisement in a city newspaper announced such a sale, and it induced a reporter for The New-York Times to visit the place.

The rise of the sentiment of equality has debarred gentlemen in Western Europe from a general use of ornament, and has induced them even to declare the wearing of jewelry by a man a vulgar pretension: but whenever they dare, that is whenever usage justifies the practice -- say, when wearing orders or at a fancy-dress bull-they exult In their bedizenment as much as ever.

The market is quiet and averages strong, though one or two weak spots have developed in the past few days. These are due to causes special to the stocks affected. On the whole, it may be said that the market is not sensibly touched by bad news. The announcement of gold exports and the passage of the Bland bill had no effect.

ALBANY, N. Y., March 17 -- St. Patrick's Day was honored in this city to-day as it never has been before. Several thousand strangers were here to witness the celebration. Over 3,000 men took part in the parade, in which were many delegations from visiting- Irish, societies.

BOSTON, March 17 -- A driver of one of the United States mail wagons of the Boston Post Office to-day decorated the wagon with green flags while It was carrying the United States mail. The wagons are not owned by the Government, but when a complaint about the matter reached the office of Postmaster Coveney.

Mr. Montague has been a soldier as well as a hunter. He writes interestingly of South Africa, and, having occupied a civilian's position under the English Government in Borneo, also tells of adventures in that savage land. "I am sick," he says, "of experiences of sport and adventure conveyed in the form of transcript from a diary.

Policeman Broderick of Brooklyn early yesterday morning saw a man in the saloon of Christian Gebbard. 580 Fulton Street. As the saloon was closed for the night, the policeman took the man to the station house. He said he was Frederick Buckingham of 188 Fifteenth Street, an assistant civil engineer in the employ of the Brooklyn Department of City Works.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Gov. Flower gave a hearing to-day on the bill providing for the Dr. Clark method of selecting municipal officers in Oswego. In favor of the bill appeared George T. Clark, E. B. Powell, the Rev. B. W. Bacon, Mayor John D. Hlggins, ex-Mayor W. J. Bulger. L. L. Sherman, W. T. Henderson, and B. Lynch.

The early kitchen vocabulary is a curious one. A recipe was formerly called a "nym," from the Saxon word nym or "take," with which it generally began. To give a pot a "walm" meant to let It boil up, from the Saxon verb veallan, to boll or bubble. To "swing" eggs meant to beat them. Currants and raisins were distinguished respectively as "raisons of Corrance" and "raisons of the sun."
Few sales at auction are scheduled for the present week. What there are, with, the exception of one by the Sheriff, take place at 111 Broadway. A detailed list is subjoined:

BOSTON, March 17. -- George W. Neville, an actor, was in the Roxbury District Court to-day, as also were two women, both of whom claim to be married to him. One acted as plaintiff and the other as witness. Both women produced certificates of marriage. The plaintiff, Ella T. Neville, testified that she was married to the defendans in Trenton, N.J., in 1892.

Powell, the Rev. B. W. Bacon, Mayor John D. Hlggins, ex-Mayor W. J. Bulger. L. L. Sherman, W. T. Henderson, and B. Lynch.

Currants and raisins were distinguished respectively as "raisons of Corrance" and "raisons of the sun."
Few sales at auction are scheduled for the present week. What there are, with, the exception of one by the Sheriff, take place at 111 Broadway. A detailed list is subjoined:

BOSTON, March 17. -- George W. Neville, an actor, was in the Roxbury District Court to-day, as also were two women, both of whom claim to be married to him. One acted as plaintiff and the other as witness. Both women produced certificates of marriage. The plaintiff, Ella T. Neville, testified that she was married to the defendans in Trenton, N.J., in 1892.

It was a veritable schooldboys' afternoon yesterday at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory, Sixty-ninth Street and the Boulevard. The occasion wag the indoor scholastic athletic meeting of the Berkeley School Athletic Association, and representatives of schools within fifty miles of this city.

Martha J. Fuller, a handsome typewriter, was killed shortly after 5:30 o'clock last evening by a pistol bullet, in the office of William M. Mullen, a lawyer, who occupies Rooms 203 and 204 on the second floor of the Nassau Chambers, 114 Nassau Street, In the office at the time was Mullen's assistant, Joseph T. Magee of 54 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street.

Americans, as a rule, know little about systems and methods of government in England. Comparatively few read understandingly the English news which each year encroaches more and more upon the columns of their newspapers. The majority are more or less bewildered as they peruse cablegrams containing reports of proceedings of the British Parliament and other bodies.

Perhaps the chief sign of progress in the domain of art In America is seen in architecture. It is probably no exaggeration to declare that the United States possesses more fine specimens of modern architecture, both in city and country, than can be found in any other part of the world. The average may be inferior to that of Europe, but the good is better.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The New-York Times has helped Brooklyn so much during the past year that I venture to call for your assistance in the protection of our children from trolley-car accidents.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The letter of J. W. Cross to The London Times, which you reprint in your issue of the 12th, is a note of warning in the right direction, but I think Mr. Cross's estimates as to the foreign balances against this country are misleading, and not a fair statement. He says:

The Lone Fisherman of the Special Senate Committee, Senator "Dan" Bradley, surprised those who attended the session of the committee yesterday in the room of the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas by not wearing a sprig of green in his buttonhole. This was not the fault of the Lone Fisherman.

-- A novel suggestion, brought about by the recent discussion in the French press concerning the stability of such vessels as the Hoche, Magenta, Neptune, and others, has been made by M. Marc Landry. As reproduced in The United Service Gazette, (British) M. Landry proposes that in order to transform the seagoing into the fighting iron-clad, the heavily-armored turrets of the vessel, as well as the guns, be organized on the disappearing system.

Indian scouting proper is scouting for Indians with Indians, as practiced in the southwest of the United States, or in Arizona, New-Mexico, and across the frontier into Mexico. Any principles laid down, and any ideas given, are the result of close observation and deduced from personal experience.

Office American Horse Exchange Company, Broadway and Fiftieth Street, New-York City. To the Public: The undersigned desires respectfully to inform his numerous customers, the general public, and his friends that he has entered into business relations with the American Horse Exchange, Broadway and Fiftieth Street, which he founded and formerly managed, and that all sales by that company will in the future be conducted and managed solely by him.

--The English market for American trotting stock la likely to be considerably improved by the projected visit to that country of W.B. Fasig, manager of the trotting department of Tattersails. For some time past Mr. Fasig has been corresponding with a wealthy Englishman, who proposes to invest over $100,000 in a breeding farm for trotting horses.

The Times has recently undertaken an inquiry into certain abuses of the pension system. In the preliminary chapter of its report, published this morning, the nature of the abuses is set forth and the plan of investigation described. The specific instances which carry the proofs of the charges made will appear in further installments of the report The Times has to make of the results of its investigation.

Those who advocate building up our shipping interests on the ocean by a policy of restriction upon the ownership and registry of seagoing vessels overlook one absolutely essential consideration. It is impossible to apply a "protective" policy by restriction to the ocean-carrying trade itself.

The Rev. C. Venton Patterson, pastor of the Central Park Baptist Church, in East Eighty-third Street, has created a sensation among the members of his congregation by calling in a policeman Friday night to arrest Lawyer W.R. Spooner for standing up to defend the rights of a young member whom the pastor ordered out of the church.

George R. Malby, Speaker of the NewYork Assembly, has been in New-York for a day or two in conference with Thomas C. Platt on matters which are of importance in the Legislature. The Republican majority in the Assembly has recently been showing signs of an independence which is not pleasing to Mr. Platt, and the problem of driving the "team of wild colts" is worth some consideration by the "boss."

Police interference with "crap" players in East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street caused a riot in "Little Italy" yesterday in which a dozen policemen were hurt, two of them seriously. The reserves from the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station were sent out by Capt. Westervelt, and fifty arrests were made.

Theodore Thomas, who is spending a few days at the Murray Hill Hotel, has already attended two meetings of people who are endeavoring to make arrangements to have him give a series of concerts in this city next Winter.

SCHENECTADY. N.Y., March 17. -- The second annual midwinter meet of the Union College Athletic Association was held in the State Armory last evening before a large and appreciative crowd. There were sixteen events, and they were all closely contested. The banner offered by the alumni to the class winning the most points was an incentive to class rivalry.
At the little French Church of St. Vincent de Paul, in West Twenty-third Street, at high mass. Father Plessis is preaching a Lenten sermon.

According to the testimony of Dr. Stanton Coit, the girls of New-York are giddy butterflies, possessing about as much stability as that bright-winged insect, and as changing as the colors of the chameleon. The doctor delivered an address yesterday morning in Music Hall, before the Society for Ethical Culture.

The Harlem Regatta Association will hold two meetings at the Grand Union Hotel to-morrow evening. The Regatta Committee will meet at 7:30 o'clock and the association at 8:30 o'clock. The Regatta Committee will organize at this meeting and consider the details for this year's regatta. The association will meet to receive the report of the Regatta Committee and to amend or ratify the new constitution and by-laws of the association.

Whim rather than reasoning seems to preside over the making and the naming of a large majority of the pictures at the exhibition of the Society of American Artists. In this art circle definite subjects are out of fashion, and the fear of being caught in an anecdote or being literary seems really to oppress the guild.
The decision of Supreme Court Justice Cullen, to the effect that the Kings County Grand Jury can find indictments for misdemeanors, will have a most important and far-reaching effect in Brooklyn.

Two hundred and forty-seven office editors and specialists, nearly 500 readers for quotations, besides some hundreds of other men and women who have rendered service in various ways, four years of time, and an expenditure of nearly a million dollarssuch, in mere numerical outline, is the story of the genesis of another great dictionary.

Many of the largest property owners in the town of Westchester are interested in an independent political movement which will probably result in indorsing a separate ticket for the town election to be held Tuesday of next week. A meeting will be held In the Town Hall Thursday evening to bring the matter to a head.
Under the operation of the laws and the departmental rulings and ratings, the number of pensioners and the amount of money paid for pensions each year since 1865 has been this:

Tale has reversed her decision or not contesting in the coming intercollegiate fencing tournament, to be held in New-York City in a few weeks. She had refused on the ground that she could not set together a representative college team within the prescribed time. Still, she has decided to make the attempt, and the contest will be held between the representatives of Yale, Harvard, and Columbia.

The Independent taxpayers of Gravesend are sanguine that the exposures in that town since election day will have the desired effect of upsetting the plans of McKane's henchmen and defeating the ticket nominated by Kenneth F. Sutherland.
There has been a great stir in the Union League Club since the Executive Committee took action limiting the credit of thirty or forty members to sums varying from $10 to $50.

PROVIDENCE, March 17. -- The week in the local stock market, while extremely dull, exhibits the strength, particularly in the bank stock list, which was noticeable last week, and a number of transactions in this class of securities have taken place at prices closely approaching the asked prices as they appear in the official quotations of our local board.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Local securities remain quiet, with no news of Interest to affect prices. There has been an absence of Investment orders, and holders of stocks are making moderate concessions In prices to Induce purchasers. It has been noticeable for some weeks that the investment demand was mainly for bonds, and the prices for them held firm.

The evangelistic revival inaugurated by the Central Committee of Christian Ministers took another great stride forward yesterday. It spread to the theatres, three of the largest in the city throwing open their doors to accommodate the crowds who were rushing to hear the Gospel preached.

Frederick Browne, twenty-two years old, who refused to tell where he lived, was arrested Saturday night on complaint or Arthur B. Fulton, who has a grocery store at 187 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn. He charged Browne with having passed a worthless cheek for $20 on him in payment for $1.87 worth of groceries.
FIRE ISLAND, March 18 -- La Bretagne, which sailed from Havre March 10, was ashore at midnight, twelve miles east of Fire Island. Her signals were heard by a patrolman on the beach at that hour.

The ex-Confederate Association of the Maryland Line has chosen Mrs. Bradley T. Johnson an honorary member of its body in recognition of her work in arming, clothing uniforming, and equipping with tents and camp equipage the First Maryland Confederate regiment, in May, 1861, and afterward aiding in nursing those who were ill.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 18 -- The Easter vacation will begin Friday, March 23, at noon, and will close on the evening of April 3.

NEW-YORK, Monday, March 19 -- A. M. The passage of the Bland bill by the Senate created some uneasiness, not that such action was wholly unexpected, but rather because it marked a distinct retrogression from the lines of safe currency legislation. Wail Street has been disturbed since the passage of the measure as to the action Mr. Cleveland may take on it.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 -- A murder and suicide occurred this morning in the Church of the Immaculate Conception In Oakland, while the congregation was present. John Brady, a house painter, shot and killed his wife Mary, while she was telling her beads in front of the altar. Then he turned the revolver on himself and put a bullet in his brain.

The communicabllity of pulmonary tuberculosis has been so thoroughly established, and is now so generally recognized by the medical profession throughout the world, that the State Board of Health has determined to take such active measures as may be consistent and possible for the prevention of the disease in this State.

The Milholland wing of the Republican Party in this city has been making Its headquarters In rooms at 202 Fifth Avenue. The Republican State League, of which George Greene of Blnghamton is President, has its headquarters in the same rooms. They were established there last Summer and the State League is supposed to pay the room rent.
The big five-story brick building in which S.A. Ilsley manufactured decorated tin cans, at York and Adams Street, Brooklyn, was destroyed by fire yesterday afternoon.

-- Mrs. Margaret Stanton Lawrence is going to perfect herself in wheeling this Summer. She inherited from her mother, Mrs. Elizabeth Cady Stanton, a dislike to petticoats. Out she hasn't the courage of a reformer, she says, and until a largo majority of women have taken a stand for a more convenient style of bicycle costume, she will follow the conventional styles.

JAMAICA, L.I., March 18 -- Mrs. Henry Bauman, wife of Excise Commissioner Henry Bauman, has adopted a novel method to collect money she alleges Anthony Armbruster, a saloon keeper, owes her. The claim is one of several years' standing.

In the opinion of the Rev. C.H. Eaton, the pastor of the Church of the Divine Paternity, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, women should have Just as much to say about the government of the State and Nation as the men.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 18 -- A dozen new baseball uniforms arrived at Yale a couple of days ago, and their distribution tells graphically the tale of the result of the long Winter's training and crowns with success the efforts of as many aspirants for 'Varsity glory on the Yale diamond this year.

The second of what are called "class" shoots was decided at the range of the Seventh Regiment on Saturday evening. The prize winners are the men making the highest scores in each of five classes, into which the competitors are divided. The first five names in the following list are those of the winners :
BRUSSELS, March 18 -- King Leopold's remarkable disappearance from his country house, in the Province of Namur, some ten days ago, is still the subject of much comment and surmise.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 18. -- The open season for trout In this State will begin April 1. The ice Is out of most of the trout streams at present, with the exception of the mountain courses in Litchfleld County, where the snow still lingers. The best trout streams In the State are situated In Litchfield and Windham Counties, with here and there a well-stocked brook along the shore line in New-Haven and Middlesex Counties.

Hoyt and McKee have decided to close their season at the Madison Square Theatre March 31. "A Trip to Chinatown" will remain the attraction during the two remaining weeks of the season, and the seven hundredth performance of the play will be given next Monday night, when souvenirs of an unusually attractive nature are promised to the audience.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., March 18 -- A conference was held to-day in the Palace Hotel at which about fifty persons were present. C.G. Hathaway, President of the Bimetallic Bank, occuped the chair. The militia was represented by Adjt. Gen. Tarsney and Col. E.J. Brooks. The sentiment of all the speakers was in favor of a military movement against the organization that seems now to have some purpose beyond making eight hours' labor a day's work.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, March 18 -- Count Schouvaloff celebrated the ratification of the reciprocity treaty with a dinner at the Russian Embassy last evening. The list of his guests proves that, as Chancellor von Caprivi said in the Reichstag, the Ministers stood shoulder to shoulder behind him in the struggle against the Agrarians.

Although Henry Irving has visited this country on several occasions, it was not until yesterday afternoon that he ever viewed the worKs of art and articles of virtu gathered in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga., March 18 -- While the family or John Johnson were gathered together at supper time to-night at their house, four miles from here, a storm, came up and the lightning struck the house and killed two of its inmates -- Mr. Johnson's wife and his six-year-old son. The shock knocked Mr. Johnson senseless, and he remained so for more than an hour.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 18 -- In the preliminary sheets of the annual catalogue of the Yale Theological School, which were issued yesterday, a significant change is noted in the list of new courses added to the curriculum. They are all political economy courses, and the additions are strictly in accordance with the policy of the Faculty of the Divinity School.

The entries for the boxing and wrestling championships of the Amateur Athletic Union to be commenced in Madison Square Garden to-night are considered the best ever received for these events. For the first time in years the West and the South will be represented. P.J. Donohue will be referee and E.W. Kearney and Arthur Moore judges.

A meeting of the Municipal Council of the Irish National Federation was held yesterday afternoon at Room 22, Cooper Union. J. J. Walsh, the Chairman, attributed the slim attendance to the fact that many had not fully recovered, from the wearying effects of St. Patrick's Day.

-- Capt. Hollister of Pennsylvania says that he has abandoned all hope of getting Ramsdell to play short and will cover the position himself. He wants to play either Avil or Blakeley on third. Avil is the better man of the two for the position, but, under Pennsylvania's new rules, will not be eligible until he has passed all his first year's examinations, and this will not be until May 12.

STAPLETON, S.I., March 18 -- Martin McNamara, a quiet and respectable young man, died at his home on Second Street, Clifton, this morning, from Injuries sustained in a fight. Harry Keeley, Gustave F. Scheidmantel, and Philip Hagelstein are locked up at Police Headquarters here, chargred with having caused his death.

The bullet that killed Martha J. Fuller in Lawyer William M. Mullen's office in the Nassau Chambers Building Saturday evening came from Lawyer Joseph T. Magee's pistol, when it was held close to or pointed at her left temple.

Recorder Smyth has in his possession a bottle of liquid, which is supposed to be laudanum, which was taken from Mrs. Mary Dunne, convicted last Thursday of manslaughter in killing her husband. A report reached Recorder Smyth's ears that in case she was convicted of murder in the first or second degree she would try to kill herself.

-- There is a probability that W. H. Forbes of Boston may decide to have the great English horse. Meddler, which he purchased from the estate of the late Abingdon Baird, trained this Fall. He was the best two-year-old in England in 1892, and would almost certainly have won the Derby last year but for the fact that his owner's death made the nomination of the horse void in all events.

Lord Dunraven is going to find out by practical experience what the centreboard is worth. He has purchased the twentyrater Dragon, and is going to change her into a centreboarder. The Dragon was the best boat in her class last year. She was designed by W. Fife, Jr., and it will be interesting to watch how she will sail with her model changed.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Treasury officials say there is one phase of the controversy between Secretary Carlisle and the American Institute of Architects that has not figured in the recent acrid correspondence, as made public.

PRINCETON. N.J., March 18 -- Less than two weeks remain before the openinggame of the season for Princeton's ball nine and much hard practice must be indulged in in order that the university may be creditably represented. Capt. McKenzie announces that the team will go to the training table at the university clubhouse next Wednesday.

CAMBRIDGE. Mass., March 18 -- The event of the week was the address by Henry Irving Thursday afternoon in Sanders Theatre before an immense audience. It was something more than the students' tribute to Mr. Irving, for many members of the Faculty sat upon the platform, and the great actor was introduced by Prof. Briggs, Dean of the college.
The prolonged absence of Police Justice Patrick Divver continues to cause discussion of the liveliest sort in the Second Assembly District, where he is the Tammany leader.

From, the present outlook baseball this year will be on the boom. Since the Brotherhood fight of 1890 the teams have made but little money to speak of, but last season nearly all made expenses, and some had a surplus at the end of the year. On that account the magnates feel that the game will once more be in popular favor when the warm weather makes its appearance.
The amount of money asked to pay pensions this year is $160,000,000.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 18 -- Public opinion in the South on the currency question has been grossly misrepresented by those newspapers which, while professing to be Democratic, are among the most virulent and reckless assailants of the policy of President Cleveland's Administration.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 18 -- The changes in Harvard's crew have strengthened it, and since Tuesday the men have been rowing in better form than before. It was pretty well understood, long before the change took place, that Fennessey would go back to his old place at stroke, since last year's performance showed that he is one of the best strokes Harvard ever possessed.

LONDON, March 18 -- The Trades Unionists' demonstration in favor of the Employers' Liability bill and against the House of Lords was in progress all this afternoon. It transformed London, between the Thames Embankment and the further side of Hyde Park, into an indescribable bedlam.

Such keen Interest and excitement have never been evinced before over a chess match as over that now in progress between Steinitz and Lasker. The first game brought out a goodly number of chess players, and each move was watched with the utmost care. While the skill of Lasker was admired, still the spectators were on Steinitz side.

-- The spandrels of the inner dome of St. Paul's, London, were decorated with Salviati glass mosaic, in designs by Watts, Stevens, and Brittan, the time consumed being thirty-one years. During the last year work has progressed on the apse, the bay of the sanctuary, and the easternmost bay of the choir, and the scaffoldings may be removed by Easter.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The advocates of the passage of the Bland bill for the coining of the seigniorage are confident that it will become a law, and some of them believe that the President will approve it. A few of those who supported it are doubtful about its getting the President's signature, but they do not believe he will veto it.

It is a very melancholy announcement that the bill making a special appropriation for the putting into a decent and habitable condition the Post Office of this city is likely to encounter serious opposition in the House. The animus of the opposition is simply that whatever NewYork may desire ought to be denied, without any reference to the reasonableness of the application.

The law originally provided pensions for "total disability." For many specific disabilities, such as the loss of a hand or foot, special acts of Congress were enacted. For other inferior disabilities, the amount of pension was left to the discretion of the Pension Commissioner, and authority for the exercise of this discretion was specifically given by law.

District Attorney Ridgway in June of last year instructed the Grand Jury of Kings County that it could not bring an indictment against Mayor Boody and the Board of Aldermen for improperly granting street railway franchises, Mr. Ridgway holding that the Grand Jury could not take cognizance of misdemeanors, the proper proceeding under the statute being to arraign before Police Justices persons guilty of that class of offenses.
Messrs. Redmond, Kerr & Co., 41 Wall Street, in their letter on the bond market of Saturday, say:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 18 -- In the United States Court for the Northern District of Alabama yesterday, District Attorney Emmett O'Neill made a motion that the Grand Jury be discharged. He represented that he had brought cases before them in which the guilt of parties was not only presumptive, but conclusive, that they had refused to make Investigation and find true bills.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed an increase in reserve of $1,668,925. The banks now hold $77,302,300 more than the legal requirements. The changes In the average show an increase in loans of $3,108,6OO, an increase in specie of $1,219,200, an increase in legal tenders of $2,24O,40O, an increase in deposits of $7,162,700, and a decrease in circulation of $224.800.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 18 -- The death of Senator Leland Stanford happened at an inopportune time for the Southern Pacific Railroad Company. Since the arrival of C.P. Huntington in California, there have been rumors of differences between the railroad and Mrs. Stanford, representing her husband's estate.

The last week of fine weather has worked wonders In the condition of all the driving roads in the city. It did not matter yesterday what direction the drivers took, they found excellent going everywhere. Even the roadways in Central Park, which many horsemen have recently grumbled about, shared the improvement.

The tenth game of the chess match between A.B. Hodges and J.W. Showalter was played at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, when the former opened the game with P -- Q4. Everything went on all right up to the twenty-first move, when black missed a chance of improving his position. A few moves later on Showalter committed a blunder which ought to have lost the game.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The trial of the Pollard-Breckinridge breach of promise suit having been resumed to-day. Miss Pollard, the plaintiff, took the stand. Before Mr. Butterworth continued his cross-examination. Mr. Carlisle, plaintiff's own attorney, asked her some questions, in response to which she said Mr. Breckinridge was father of her child born in Cincinnati, and the cause of her trouble in May. 1893.

NEW-YORK. Monday, March 19 -- P.M. Sugar was more active than for some time, the trading in it amounting to about 30 per cent, of the day's business. It was strong all day, selling up to 93 7/8, but closing at 93 1/5, a net gain of 2 1/8 points. The advance was due to concessions made in the sugar schedules of the Tariff bill.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Secretary Hoke Smith was again seen to-day by Representative Straus in relation to the removal of the Indian supply agency from New-York to Chicago. Mr. Straus renewed the arguments he had made last week against the wisdom of the change from a business and economical point of view.

School Commissioner Randolph Guggenheimer has bought of Herter Brothers the seven-story brick and terra cotta. business building at the southwest corner of Third and Wooster Streets, 72.5 by 75 feet. The building has just been completed, and is partly rented, the full rental being between $19,000 and $20,000 per year.

DENVER, Col., March 19 -- Gov. Waite this morning ordered the troops back from the Cripple Creek district to their respective armories. This action was the result of a telephone conversation held by the Governor with Adjt. Gen. Tarsney, who reported that the miners were ready to arbitrate, and would not go out in battle array in any event.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- The five-story brick building at Palethrop and Huntington Streets, occupied by four textile manufacturers, was destroyed by fire this morning. The loss aggregates $200,000, of which $50,000 is on the building. The insurance is partial. The firms occupying the building were: G. Rumpf Brother, owners of the building and manufacturers of bed coverlets; Brown Brothers, L. Aperle, and S.A.H. Kauder Co., manufacturers of knit goods.

The one legislative investigation in this State which has made substantial headway is that concerning the State Board of Health. The chief trouble with that body seems to be that the only person connected with it who has shown much zeal or activity is its Secretary, Dr. Balch, and some of the members of the board have complained that his activity was not always well directed.

TROY, N. Y., March 19. -- The Ross inquest was resumed this morning, and another crowd of spectators clamored for admission to the Court House. Most of the testimony given at the morning session was unimportant, but that of Augrustus H. Loeble caused quite a sensation. The witness swore positively that he saw "Bat" Shea fire two shots at Robert Ross, and that the second shot struck Ross in the head, producing the fatal wound.

A Washington dispatch, that has apparently been Inspired from the office of the Supervising Architect of the Treasury, gives an explanation of the controversy between the Treasury Department and the American Institute of Architects that is by no means creditable to the architects.

LONDON, March 19. -- A dispatch from Rio de Janeiro confirms the report that Admiral da Gama and about seventy of his officers are on board the Portuguese war ships Mindello and Alfonso du Albuquerque, which left Rio yesterday afternoon. No protest or other opposition was made to the vessels leaving the bay with the insurgent leader and his followers on board.

There was a new bill of surprising length at Tony Pastor's Theatre last night. The three Lynn sisters, from the London Music halls, are engaging cockney girls, who dance nimbly and sing in the accustomed way. Other new comers. Lina and Vanl, also from London, are doubtless quite as clever, but were not appreciated,

Judge Truax, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, has given a decision for the defendants in the suit brought by Margaret B. Edson, the widow and executrix of Marmount B. Edson, to establish a will made by his sister, Mary A. Edson, on May 2, 1884, in preference to a will executed by her on May 2, 1890, which has been admitted to probate.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. John T. Eno. as referee, sold plots in Flatbush, with two-story and attic frame cottages on them. One, on the west side of East Eleventh Street, 160.6 1/2 feet south of Avenue C, 40 by 80, went to the plaintiffs, W.J. Kaiser and others, for $2,250. The Similar one, adjoining to the south, sold for $2,700 to Charles H. Gallagher.

There was a scene of light and warmth, flowers and music, at Sherry's yesterday, the rustle of soft gowns, and the murmur of softer voices. Depressing weather could not dampen the spirits of Sorosis as she sat down to her twenty-sixth annual breakfast.

A collision which created consternation among the passengers of the Central ferryboats Fanwood and Communipaw but injured no one occurred at the foot of Liberty Street yesterday morning at 9:45. The Fanwood was lying in her slip waiting for the Communipaw to arrive, a dense fog prevailing at the time.

Police Justice Kenneth F. Sutherland of Coney Island has chosen exile for life in preference to one year in stripes in the penitentiary. He was not present yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer when called to be sentenced for oppression.

The Coney Island Jockey Club has issued its programme for stakes to be run at its Spring and Fall meetings. The stakes for the Spring meeting are the Suburban and June Handicaps, for three-year-olds and upward; the Zephyr, Spring, and June Stakes, for two-year-olds; the Vernal Stakes, for two-year-old fillies, and the Swift and Spindrift Stakes, for three-year-olds.

CAPE MAY, N.J., March 19 -- The condition of affairs at Woodbine continues critical this evening. Superintendent Dayton arrived with reinforcements of seventyfive men for the West Jersey. He inspected the barricades at the crossing and placed them in charge of Supervisors Stubbs and Nichols.

A poorly-dressed woman jumped into the North River at the foot of West Twenty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon in the presence of a number of longshoremen. A rope was thrown to her, but she would not grasp it.

-- The amateur athletic clubs in Long Island City that have always held reputable boxing exhibitions and kept within the law are going to ask Mayor Sanford to modify his order prohibiting such competitions in that city. The Mayor's order was the result of his being imposed upon by the Hell Gate Athletic Club, which represented a prize fight gotten up by it as a benefit for a poor bricklayer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19 -- Harvard students are at present much exercised over an order of the President and Fellows prohibiting punches on Commencement Day. Although the order was passed upon Feb. 5, yet it was not made public till Saturday, when a copy was left with each, student in the college buildings.

Hoadley B. Ives of New-Haven, Conn., who became insane about ten days ago, died in his home yesterday. Though not entirely unexpected, his death came rather suddenly. Last Wednesday he had so far recovered us to be able to direct his various business interests, and was with difficulty kept in the house by his physician and nurses.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- The week opened with a dull and uninteresting security market. There were very few buying orders for cable stocks, and the boom in elevated seems to have at least temporarily subsided. Alley L opened at 26 7/8, declined to 25 1/4, and, rallying, closed at 26. Lake Street did not yield so much, but did break from 24 5/8 to 23 7/8, and closed at the latter price.

Many of those who draw pensions of $13 a month, which is the maximum under the act of June 27, 1890, because of disabilities "which Incapacitate them from earning a support at manual labor," are earning a support at manual labor precisely as they have done for the last twenty-five years.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The President, with a brief message of transmittal, sent to Congress to-day some additional correspondence between Minister Willis and President Dole in Honolulu. The correspondence is mainly of an explanatory character. Mr. Willis speaks of it as "the final correspondence touching the attitude of the diplomatic agent of the United States in regard to the use of force."

The office of Secretary of State was offered to Chauncey M. Depew by President Harrison in June, 1892, immediately after Mr. Blaine's retirement from the Cabinet. The offer was declined, and Mr. Depew's reasons for his declination reflect as much credit upon him as would the holding of the high office he rejected.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- A member of the Philadelphia Committee of Chicago and Northern Pacific bondholders stated today that he and his fellow-committeemen were not disturbed by the recent ultimatum of the Simmons Committee of New-York, to the effect that after March 21 the latter will only receive further deposits of bonds upon terms and penalties.
Commodore William D. Whiting, retired officer of the United States Navy, died yesterday morning at his home, 38 West Thirty-fourth Street.

-- At a meeting of the Crescent Wheelmen of Plainfield the plans and specifications of their proposed bicycle track, prepared by Civil Engineer F.A. Dunham, were accepted. The contract for the grading is to be given out at once, and will call for the completion of the work by the first week in May. The land, a plot of eleven acres on Randolph Road, near Park Avenue, is an ideal site for the purpose.

From The London Economist. Now, as to this bill, it is evident, in the first place, that it is not called for by the present position of the Treasury. True, that was very unsatisfactory indeed a iittle while ago, but immediate requirements have been provided for by the recent issue of bonds, and the Government is now quite able to pay its way for some time to come.

La Bretagne of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, which went ashore on a sandbank twelve miles from Fire Island Sunday night, came up the bay yesterday morning and landed her passengers at the dock at the foot of Morton Street just before noon. The steamship was not injured when she ran aground, but near her dock she lost twenty-five feet of her starboard rail in collision with the giant Campania.

Those who have scrutinized recent issues of the North Atlantic Pilot Chart will know that an immense field of ice has been drifting toward the path of transatlantic steamships. Officers and crew of the British steamsip Carlisle will not need to be informed of its existence. They made the discovery for themselves and under circumstances which they are not likely to forget.
Allan Campbell, who died at his home, 125 Lexington Avenue, Sunday evening, had been for thirty-six years active in behalf of New-York City's interests, and prominent in its political affairs.

The events attending the recent municipal election in Troy, as well as the inquiries of the special committee of the Senate in this city, show the important relation which the police force necessarily holds to the conduct of elections. Those who are trying to see that elections are conducted fairly and honestly depend upon the police for protection and support.

Only a fair-sized crowd assembled in Madison Square Garden last night to witness the preliminary boxing and wrestling bouts for the amateur championship of the United States. Some of the bouts were good, some bad, and some indifferent, but the spectators were in a jolly mood and appeared to enjoy the variety.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

W.F. was a musician in Company C. One Hundred and Forty-second New-York Infantry. His application on which a pension was granted was filed July 31, 1890, and the pension certificate was issued June 20, 1892. He was granted the maximum limit of $12 a month. This case has some curious phases.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Secretary Herbert has announced the result of target practice held by ships in commission the last Quarter. There were five ships on board of which practice with the main battery was conducted, the vessels being at anchor. Their order of merit was: Monocacy, Yorktown, Ranger, Marion, and Bennington.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Secretary Herbert has ordered all the American war ships away from Rio.

Until the President shall have announced his action, or his intended action, regarding the Bland silver inflation act, it is inevitable that there will be constant discussion and frequent prediction as to what that action will be. It is equally inevitable that the friends of the measure will express and to some extent feel more confidence that the President's action will be favorable to the bill than its opponents express in the opposite sense.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- An application was made in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day for a writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to bring up for review the judgment of the Court of Appeals in the case of Leonora A. Arnold and husband against Charles A. Chesebrough and others.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following message:

LONDON, March 19 -- The House of Commons was crowded when Lord Randolph Churchill rose to move that Lord Rosebery had infringed upon the privilege of the House of Commons, as embodied in the sessional order that no Peer shall concern himself in the election of a member of the House of Commons.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 19. -- The news of the disappearance from New-York City of Clarence Littlefield of Providence and Block Island was received here to-day. Littlefield was one of the most popular of Brown University graduates. Besides being a leader of social festivities at Brown, and also a promoter of athletics at the college, he was conspicuous in the assemblies at the dancing academy in this city.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 19. -- Judge Woolworth of Omaha and Attorney General Hastings, acting for the State of Nebraska, to-day filed briefs with the Supreme Court in the case against ex-State Treasurer Hill, from whom it is sought to recover $236,000, money lost in the Capital National Bank. The action was originally begun in the courts of Douglas County, but was dismissed on the ground of non-jurisdiction.

An almost complete change of programme was made at Koster Bial's last evening, and the large audience present decided unanimously with emphasis that the performance was good from beginning to end and that three or four of its features were of rather uncommon merit.

ST. LOUIS, March 19. -- Chief of Police Walsh and Detective Kenney this afternoon arrested E.E. Picking on a warrant charging him with embezzlement of $15,000 from Browning, King Co. of New-York. The arrest was made at the East St. Louis track. Picking acknowledged that he owed the firm $5,000.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 19. -- The freight house of the Fort Dodge Branch of the ROCK Island Railroad has been burned. The building was partially filled with freight. Loss, $20,000; fully covered by insurance.

The fifth week of the evangelistic revival meeting's, despite disagreeable weather, began yesterday at noon in Association Hall under the most flattering circumstances. The hall was crowded, and the meeting was thoroughly enjoyed by those present.
The City Club, at a meeting in its clubhouse, 677 Fifth Avenue, last evening discussed the question "For a Greater NewYork." About 400 members were present.

C.C.A. was a private, Company I, Fourteenth New-York Heavy Artillery. He applied for a pension Aug. 1, 1890, and on Nov. 28, 1892, was granted $12 a month for the alleged disabilities of "rheumatism, ventral hernia, and hemorrhoids." He is a tinsmith, who has the reputation in Gouverneur of being a good workman.

The score or more of pension cases circumstantially described in The Times this morning belong, each and every one of them, to the fraudulent class. Yet the recipients of these pensions are for the most part honest, hard-working men. They have become fraudulent pensioners, not of their own motion, but through the enticements of pension agents and the magnanimity of local political demagogues.

TRENTON, N.J., March 19. -- Two hours of the time of the House to-night was devoted to a warm debate on corporal punishment in schools. The debate was precipitated by a Newark bill. Assemblyman Eisele of Orange was the spokesman for the bill. He had much to say about Newark bad boys.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- In regard to the complaint of French art exhibitors at the late World's Fair that their pictures had not been returned, Vice Consul Verstraete said to-night to a reporter for the United Press:
M. Mounet-Sully, the tragedian of the Theatre Francais, who is to begin next Monday an engagement at Abbey's, arrived by the French Line steamer La Bretagne yesterday.

If every body in New-York and vicinity had visited the World's Fair it might not be worth the while of a newspaper to engage in the laudable task of putting it in the power of people to pleasantly learn in detail what the great exposition looked like. The statistics show, however, that but a small proportion of the Eastern people went to Chicago.

Patrick Divver, the absentee leader of the Tammany Hall organization of the Second Assembly District, was yesterday supposed to be still in San Francisco. At least, his family believed him to be there, but he has been chary of information about himself since he went West with his son Joseph, and his relatives have known little more of his movements than have his constituents.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Senator Call of Florida is very much worried because Mr. Cleveland has appointed George W. Wilson Collector of Internal Revenue for the District of Florida and H. W. Long Register of the Florida Land Office. Mr. Call did not support these gentlemen. In fact, he had other candidates for the places.

The Legislature of this State has entered upon the eleventh week of the session, and it would be difficult for any ordinarily attentive reader of the news to recall a single important act that it has performed. The bills introduced in the Assembly considerably exceed 1,200 in number, and about two-thirds as many have made their first appearance in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Having been successful in preventing the President from getting a Justice of the Supreme Court from New-York, Senator Hill is now presuming to veto the selections of the President to fill several other offices, and he finds a sufficient number of Democrats on the Judiciary Committee to enable him to make his opposition effective.

BOSTON, March 19. -- West End Street Railway was the point of interest among local stocks to-day, opening at 49, and advancing to 50, 1 1/4 above Saturday's close. Buying by the shorts is the alleged cause of this rise, and with the uncertainty of its franchise and prospects of adverse legislation it looks like the most probable.

ROME, March 19 -- During a performance in a theatre at Lucca, in the province of that name, last evening, a gentleman upon entering his box found in the doorway a bomb with a lighted fuse. He seized the burning fuse and by crushing it in his band put out the fire. The bomb was turned over to the police authorities, who had its contents analyzed.

Fully half a hundred institutions in this city and Washington, and probably twice as many lawyers, are interested in the result of a suit brought to trial yesterday in the Supreme Court before Judge Russell, for the construction of the will of Mrs. Lizzie H. Perkins, who, while temporarily residing in Paris, France, died on Sept. 23, 1891, leaving a large fortune.

When the third trial of the suit of Esther Jacobs against Henry B. Sire for $50,000 for breach of promise was called before Justice Sedgwick, in the Superior Court, yesterday, counsel for the defense asked for a further adjournment, which was denied.

William T. Evans, Secretary of the Dry Goods Merchants' Association, sent a check yesterday for $850 to J. Pierpont Morgan, Treasurer of the Citizens' Relief Committee, to cover the following additional subscriptions:

The Board of Health received a letter yesterday from a woman living at 39 West Twentieth Street who complains that her slumbers, as well as those of others, are disturbed at night by inharmonious but vigorous voices of cats.

-- S.H.H. Clark. President and co-receiver of the Union Pacific Railroad, has maintained a friendly attitude all along toward the employes of the company, and he is quoted as saying: "If the other Union Pacific receivers, by any action they may take, shall place me in a position antagonistic to the views I have hitherto entertained in regard to the interests of the men on the system.
The Hotel New Netherland, Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, owned by William Waldorf Astor and managed by Gen. Ferdinand P. Earle, will be closed Thursday.

It is believed that Superintendent Byrnes has in his possession some important information that may go far to clear up the mystery surrounding the death of the young woman type-writer, Martha J. Fuller, who died of a pistol wound in her head, having been found unconscious, Saturday evening, in the office of Lawyer William Mullen, 114 Nassau Street, where she had worked.

A more battered and sorrowful-looking lot of men than the Italian rioters of Harlem when they were arraigned in the Harlem Police Court yesterday would be hard to imagine. Every one of them bore marks of the fight with the police. The mouths of some were terribly cut and swollen and several of them were so badly battered that they could not see.
STEELTON, Penn., March 19. -- All the departments of the Pennsylvania Steel Works resumed operations to-day for the first time in three months. More than 4,000 men went to work.

Business men of the largest affairs and professional men whose study has given them rank among the ablest in the consideration of public questions have expressed a belief that President Cleveland will be doing a patriotic thing if he vetoes the bill now before him providing for the coining of the seigniorage.

If one can make one's self and somebody else both happy at the same time, such an opportunity should not be neglected, because life is short and we are told to do as much good as we can in its brief span. Of course whether we want to be happy and have another share our happiness depends a great deal on the cost.

-- The First Church of Quincy, Mass., has extended a call to the Rev. Benjamin R. Bulkeley of Concord, Mass., to become its pastor, and has fixed his salary at $2,000 a year. The Church is Unitarian, and Congressman William Everett has frequently preached to it since the resignation of the Rev. Mr. Wilson.

The war between the Committee of Thirty, which has been authorized by the Republican County Committee to reorganize the party in this city, and Thomas C. Platt, who wants to reorganize it himself, through his Milholland movement, goes bitterly on. The thirty are scoring on Platt sharply, and it looks now as if Platt was willing to secure aid, if possible, from Jacob M. Patterson.

ALBANY, March 19. -- A petition and memorial was presented in the State Senate to-night by Senator Saxton from the Civil Service Reform Association of New-York City, signed by Carl Schurz as President and William Potts as Secretary, and indorsed by Sherman S. Rogers of the Buffalo association, William G. Low of the Brooklyn association. Dr. E.M. Moore of the Rochester association, and Judge F.O. Mason of the Geneva association.

ITHACA, March 19. -- Contrary to general expectation, Judge Forbes said nothing at the opening of court this morning in relation to his recent charge to the Grand Jury concerning the freshman banquet tragedy, his submission of the editorial attacks upon the court to the Tompkins County bar, and the bar's failure to take action in the matter.

Hugh Hamilton, a marine architect, living at 65 Columbia Place, Brooklyn, was knocked down and hurt by a cable car in Broadway, opposite Rector Street, at 4:15 yesterday afternoon. Mr. Hamilton wished to cross from east to west. A cable car bound up town was passing as he stepped from the sidewalk.

W. Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker resumed play in the great chess match at the Union Square Hotel yesterday in presence of a very large gathering of chess players. It was Steinitz's turn to open the game, and he selected a Ruy Lopez, which Lasker defended with 3. Kt -- KB3. White played a beautiful attacking game right through, while black showed great skill in the defense.
The lawyers prosecuting the indicted Gravesenders evidently do not propose to allow others to follow Justice Sutherland's example and run away after conviction.

ALBANY, March 19. -- The State Board of Charities has unanimously adopted the report of the special committee of the board which has spent several months in investigating the administration of affairs at the Elmira Reformatory and the charges of cruelty preferred against Superintendent Brockway.

FLUSHING, N.Y., March 19 -- The fourth contest for the cup presented by George A. Barker of the Flushing Shooting Club to the member who wins it three times took place on the grounds of the race track near Whitestone, L.I., on Saturday. There was a large crowd present, the weather being fine, and a band of music in attendance.
The steamship El Norte sailed from NewOrleans on March 14, and arrived in the port of New-York yesterday. Up to the time she reached Cape Hatteras there was nothing unusual in her voyage.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19. -- The buying of the local stocks is much better than the selling, and such traders as have been able to make profits are beginning to feel more confident that there will be a further advance in prices. Philadelphia Traction was very strong, and sold at 98 1/2, the highest price it has reached this year.

Members of the Meadowbrook Hunt enjoyed a good run with the hounds yesterday afternoon. The scent was strong, and the fox a good, sturdy " dog." He led the chase a merry dance for nearly forty minutes from the " throw-off," at Jericho Toll Gate.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- Business in wheat was principally local to-day, and was confined to transactions by room traders and scalpers. A firmer feeling than was exhibited yesterday permeated the market at the opening and was ascribed to the rather small shipments from Baltic and sundry ports and India to the United Kingdom and Continent of Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Commander Heyerman is to be tried by court-martial at the Brooklyn Navy Yard on Thursday for suffering a vessel of the navy, through his negligence, to run upon a reef and be stranded and for culpable inefficiency in the performance of duty.

A novel reception and entertainment is to be given in Tony Pastor's Theatre next Sunday night. For many years Mrs. Pastor, " Aunt " Louisa Eldridge, Mrs. Fernandez, and other ladies of the stage have given a Christmas reception to the stage children in this house, at which the little ones have been given Christmas presents, and at different times receptions and teas have also been given to the children.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- Superintendent O. C. Bosbyshell of the Philadelphia Mint was to-day directed by Mint Director Preston to turn over the institution to his successor, Dr. Eugene Townsend, on April 2.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Tariff bill amended in many particulars, but still bearing a close resemblance to the measure which came from the Finance Committee a fortnight ago, is now on the Senate calendar.
-- A twenty-mile race between horses and cyclists, the riders of both horses and wheels to be amateurs, and the prize a medal not worth more than $50, has been arranged at Jacksonville. Fla.

BOSTON, March 20. -- The market for local stocks was quite active to-day and showed decided strength. West End Railway advanced 21/2, to 521/2, on covering of shorts, closing at 513/4.
