Some people have marketed their stock to advantage and will very likely be able to get it back at lower prices, if, as is said on the Street, the shorts have largely covered.
ALBANY, March 20. -- The Bi-Partisan Police bill will come up in general orders in the Senate without amendment on Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- Most of the business of the day was done in the last two hours, and, although the volume of trading was small, stocks closed, higher than yesterday. The friends of the tractions and their following bought and bid up Philadelphia and Metropolitan. The former sold up to 99 and the latter to 1041/4.

The Edwin Booth Shakespeare League was organized Monday in Philadelphia. Thomas Shayne was elected President and Henri Morris appointed editor of the Journal which will be the league's official organ. The journal will be known as The Shakespeare, and the first number will be issued on or about April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The President admitted to-day that nothing to which his attention had been directed since his inauguration had given him greater solicitude or concern, except the proposition to call an extra session of the Fifty-third Congress, than the Bland bill to authorize the coinage of the seigniorage.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Senator Colquitt of Georgia has again, been stricken with paralysis, this time in his throat, and his condition is serious. Senator Colquitt was in his committee room yesterday in his usual health, and just prior to his departure for home dictated a number of letters to his clerk.

One of the most serious elements of the situation is that there is a certain, number of the men who are pushing this scheme who, if they told the truth, would regard repudiation with complacency. So far from fearing the placing of the currency of the United States upon a silver basis, they desire it.

ALBANY, March 20. -- The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed, with costs, the Judgment of the lower court in favor of Thomas Fortune (colored) against James Trainor, appellant, tooth of New-York City. The appeal was from a decision made by the General Term, First Department, affirming a judgment of the Circuit Court in favor of plaintiff for $1,016.23.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 20. -- There are evidences of the revival of trade in this city. A train of fifty cars, drawn by two locomotives and loaded with farm machinery, left here this afternoon bound for New-England States. Three weeks ago a similar train of thirty-one loaded cars went east.

A meeting of the Distributing Committee of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association was held yesterday at 3 o'clock in the Mayor's office. Acting Mayor McClellan presided. There were also present the following committeemen. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Morris K. Jesup, Charles S. Smith, and Postmaster Dayton.

ALBANY N. Y., March 20. -- Before the Assembly Committee on Agriculture this afternoon a hearing was given on the Kerr bill providing for the construction of roads by local assessment, county and State aid. Mr. Kerr explained what his bill provided for. It was the only way to bring about good roads.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Soon after the reading of the Journal, Mr. Voorhees, (Dem., Ind.,) Chairman of the Finance Committee, reported the Tariff bill to the Senate.

TRENTON, N. J., March 20. -- A lively tilt occurred at the breakfast table of the Hotel Windsor this morning between Speaker Holt of the House of Assembly and Mr. McEwan of Hudson, the Republican leader on the floor of the House. Their relations have not been cordial at any time since the session began.

The opening of the sale of seized and unclaimed goods at the Barge Office yesterday drew a large crowd, composed mainly of bargain hunters and dealers. A few women were present. Bargains proved scarce, for bidding was so eager that in almost every sale the price obtained was greatly in excess of the estimated value. Liquors commanded top prices throughout.
This is a story about eggrs. Therefore it may be of interest to dyspeptics and consumers of phosphate mixtures.

UTICA, N. Y., March 20. -- The March terms of the United States Circuit and District Courts were docketed to begin in this city to-day. At the time fixed for the opening of the court United States District Judge A. C. Coxe spoke as follows:

There was much speculation about the future of the Pierre Lorillard mansion, at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, at the time of its purchase by Mr. Havemeyer. This has now been settled by the lease of the property to M. Durand-Ruel for an art gallery and other business uses.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- There is no single proposition in the army appropriation bill, recently completed by the Committee on Military Affairs, that excites mope comment in this city among those who are interested in the service than the provision that proposes to allow the senior Major General of the army to have the brevet rank of Lieutenant General, and that the pay and allowances of the grade shall go with the brevet rank.

J. W. Reinhart, President and co-receiver of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, authorized an official announcement yesterday that the Southern Pacific-Atchison rate war was ended. He Issued directions to restore rates immediately. The relative positions of the two companies are put back to the understanding existing prior to the 1st of last September, and which remained the same up to March 1.

Thomas C. Platt held his first primary election last night. It was supervised by John B. Milholland. The primary is to be made the basis of the " bluff " which Mr. Platt will make before the next Republican State Convention to get his faction recognized as the only Republican organization in this city.

From The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times, March 18. There never was so little justification for the further coinage of silver dollars as now. The bullion value of them has been around 48 cents for nearly a month, and the tendency of the bullion in the two great markets, London and New-York, is downward. The country now has a surfelt of money.
There were three sensational disclosures yesterday in connection with the trial of Constable Andrew Scott Jamieson of Coney Island for perjury in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer.

Detectives fairly swarmed over the Twentieth Police Precinct yesterday hunting for a clue that shall lead to the discovery of little Susie Martin's murderer. In all the criminal history of New-York no such horrible crime has ever been perpetrated as that of which the eleven year-old Martin girl was the victim.
Governor -- DAVID S. BAKER of North Kingstown.

-- It is expected that a Chicago syndicate will buy the St. Louis Fair Grounds track when it is put up for sale on April 2. George V. Hankins of the racing firm of Hankins Johnson, and interested in at least one of the Chicago race tracks, has been down to St. Louis to inspect the property and see about securing a charter for the proposed racing association he will organize.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The closing scenes of the day's proceedings in the Pollard-Breckinridge trial consisted of a succession of remarkable incidents from the time court reconvened after the noon recess until it adjourned at 3 o'clock, with Miss Pollard weeping for her children, her head bowed on the rail of the witness box.

The committee appointed toy the President of the Chamber of Commerce to visit Washington and present the memorial against he Bland bill adopted yesterday by the Chamber will not go. Its members have been notified by Mr. Smith that it will be unnecessary to do more than forward the memorial.

There are countless beautiful things to be seen to-day at Lord Taylor's annual Spring opening. Of course, special attention at this season is bestowed on the millinery department. The first thing one notices on entering the store are masses of flowers in bright Spring tints. Mauve, pink, and yellow are the prevailing colors.

The Inter-City League for Amateur Driving was formed at a meeting between delegates from the three clubs interested Monday at the Turf Club in Philadelphia. Conditions were drafted and signed by the delegates, who were: For Fleetwood Park, S. McMillan and Fred Gerken; for Belmont Park, Frank Bower and Daniel Strouse, and for Pimlico, Baltimore, E. D. Crook and H. B. Holton.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. J. A. Kerrigan sold, at $3,500, to Helen E.W. Sauier, plaintiff, the lot 234 Chauncey Street, south side, 350 feet west of Ralph Avenue 25 by 100. The adjoining lot, of similar dimensions, at 236 Chauncey Street, was sold to Sarah H. Powell, for 53,000. To Elizabeth B. Hall, plaintiff, at $7,750.

PALM BEACH, Fla., -- Just as the special vesituled train over the Jacksonville, St. Augustine and Indian River Railroad, bearing the members of the American Association of General Passenger Agents to their annual meeting, reached Fort Pierce this morning, system witnessed the driving of the last spike in the extension of the road to Lake Worth.

BERLIN, March 20. -- Count Schouvaloff, Russian Ambassador, called upon Baron Marschall von Bierberstein, Minister of Foreign Affairs, this morning, when formal ratifications of the Russian-German commercial treaty were exchanged. The treaty goes into effect to-day.
Norman La Grange, Lieutenant Colonel of the Queen's Guards, retired, with a residence in Portland Square, London, and a membership in all the London clubs, sounds well.

"Sowing the Seed by the Daylight Fair," sang a little band of men and women who stood in front of Dr. Parkhurst's church, in Madison Square, just after 11 o'clock yesterday morning. It was the band of outdoor workers in the evangelistic revival meetings which are being held in Association Hall.

TRENTON, N. J., March 20. -- The expectation has been almost general to-day in the State House and among the heads of the departments that the decision of the Supreme Court to-morrow in the Senate case will favor the Republicans, and that the Democratic Senators will join with the Republicans at once and break the deadlock.

TURIN, March 20. -- Louis Kossuth, the Hungarian patriot, died at 11 o'clock tonight. He passed a very bad night, and this morning began to fail rapidly. His temperature was above 102. At 3 o'clock his physicians announced that he was sinking rapidly, and that the end was at hand.

DENVER, Col., March 20. -- In the face of a blinding snowstorm, footsore, tired, and hungry, the 300 members of the Colorado National Guard arrived at Midland Station at noon to-day, and took the special train for Colorado Springs. The miners gave three hearty cheers as they left the camp, while the citizens deplored their departure.

The members of the Harlem Regatta Association met last night at the Grand Union Hotel and transacted some important business. The Regatta Committee met at 7:30 o'clock and arranged all the details for the Decoration Day Regatta. This committee then reported what they had done to the delegates, who met after the committee adjourned.

MEMPHIS, Term., March 20. -- The damage to property in the Mississippi Valley by storms and floods in the last forty-eight hours is at present beyond calculation. Bridges have been washed away, houses wrecked, railroad tracks displaced, farm lands " flattened out." especially in the bottoms, and crops have been delayed where before every prospect has been favorable for an early and highly-favorable season for farmers and planters.

The Evening Post has given its readers occasion for surprise by coming out in favor of a Park Board that shall be not only bi-partisan, but bi-membral. There is a bill pending at Albany providing for such a readjustment of the department, and of this measure The Post is in favor.

Indications of a gradual improvement in railroad traffic are clearly apparent in the reports of earnings of various railroads throughout the country for the second week of this month. While the figures, in a majority of instances, show diminished incomes as compared with the business of one year ago, they show an advance over the earnings of the preceding week.

What makes some people plump and fleshy and others thin and bony? Is the human body run and shaped in an invisible mold? And what strange effects this difference produces. Beauty always demands curves -- it never allows angles. A woman may be thin and graceful but not thin and beautiful.

ALBANY, March 20. -- The Republican City Convention swallowed the bait put up by the Hill Democrats and nominated to-night a ticket which contains three Democrats and two Republicans, as follows: For Mayor -- Oren E. Wilson, (Rep.;) for Aldermen at Large -- Robert H. Moore. Patrick H. McCann, (Dems.;) for City Court Judge -- George Addington, (Rep.;) for Police Court Judge -- Daniel Adler, (Dem.)

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the " City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

"Martha J. Fuller was killed by a bullet that entered the right side of her head and made its exit at the left temple," was the decision of Deputy Coroner Frank J. O'Hare yesterday after he had performed a second autopsy at 633 East One-Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street.

Edward M. Field, who has been confined in Ludlow Street Jail since his release from the insane asylum in Buffalo, was set free yesterday afternoon. He had been held in custody on account of various claims which had been filed against him. Several weeks ago he furnished bonds to the amount of $50,000 to cover the claims which had up to that time been entered.

There were a number of happy little Hebrew maidens at 209 East Broadway yesterday afternoon. With masks, songs, dances, and feasting they had an experience of " Merry Purim " in a mild imitation of the grand two days' carnival with which the feast is celebrated in Europe.

-- It has been decided to sell the Bale des Chaleurs Railway, about which so much has been said in recent sessions of the Canadian Parliament. The Atlantic and Lake Superior Railway Company is given the preference to purchase, the offer to be left open for six months. The price fixed is $500,000 cash and $400,000 in shares of the company, the cash amount to be deposited in the hands of a syndicate.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- It is intimated that the President is disposed to use at least a portion of the fund of $250,000 placed at his disposal to establish coaling stations for the specific purpose of establishing a coaling station in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Should he do this, the Hawaiians would get practically what they most desire next to annexation itself.

The adoption of resolutions in favor of Sunday liquor selling by the Board of Aldermen has created widespread comment in Brooklyn. No action of the present Common Council since its members took office is regarded as so sharp a departure from the reform policy as their declaration in support of the " side-door " bill.

In the exposures of pension frauds which have already been published in The Times, and which we shall continue to publish hereafter, sample cases are presented, drawn from communities that may be regarded as representative. There is nothing exceptional about these communities or the cases which they furnish.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The House of Representatives did a wise thing to-day when it adjourned over until Thursday. Some of the members were disposed to criticise the majority for this action, because it followed a resolution to revoke all leaves of absence in the effort to bring in a quorum of Democrats to dispose of a contested election case.

Within two weeks the people of Rhode Island will have a chance to undo the tangle in which their public affairs were left by the election of last year, for this time a plurality will elect not only the State officers, but members of the Legislature.
The crusade inaugurated by the New-York Board of Health against consumptives I consider one of the greatest outrages ever perpetrated on the affiliated since the foundation of the Art of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- As was considered probable, the Committee on Naval Affairs brought in an appropriation bill today that did not make any provision for the extension of the navy. This was not because the Chairman, Mr. Cummings, is not favorable to liberal expenditure for the building up of our navy, nor because he thinks that the navy has ships enough.

American railway securities were slightly irregular but generally higher in the London market Northern Pacific preferred was a strong feature. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Northern Pacific preferred, 11/8, to 211/8; Erie, 1/4, to 183/8; Illinois Central, 1/4, to 95; Union Pacific, 1/8, to 191/4; Canadian Pacific, 1/8, to 692/4, and Wabash preferred, 1/3, to 155/3.

The final bouts of the Amateur Athletic Union's annual boxing and wrestling championships, that are to be held this evening in Madison Square Garden, will be without doubt, the finest amateur tournament ever given by the organization. The preliminary trials given Monday evening were interesting.

The feeling aroused among business men even by the remote possibility of the Bland coinage bill becoming a law is very strong, but it is perfectly reasonable and springs from the knowledge of facts as to which there is no room for doubt. The bill is dreaded because it is known that it would empty the Treasury of gold and would make it impossible to replenish it.

The Rapid-Transit Commission met yesterday afternoon at 22 William Street and after remaining in executive session for over an hour it was announced that their report on the Bushe plan had been postponed for a week.
At a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday a memorial was adopted urging President Cleveland to veto the Bland Silver bill.

The Chinese merchants of this city are much incensed over a scheme to compel the payment of $30 tor identification certificates by all of their kind wishing to go to China and to return, and of $60 for similar certificates entitling a Chinaman to return here after visiting Havana. They say that heretofore all necessary certificates were supplied by the Chinese Consul gratis or for a merely nominal fee.

-- The Trustees of the New-York Normal College yesterday accepted an offer from William steinway to give to the scholar most proficient in the German language his option of $150 in money in gold, or the same sum in the form of a gold watch suitably inscribed. The prizes to be offered annually. A check for $150 for the first prize accompanied Mr. Stelnway's offer.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- The police received word to-day that the Drexel pier across the right of way claimed by the Lincoln Park Commissioners had been destroyed by dynamite. News of the destruction of the pier caused injunction proceedings pending in court to-day to be hastily adjourned.

From The Trenton Free American, March 20. The New-York Times. in an article covering five columns of that journal, makes some astounding statements in regard to the pension rolls, which cannot fail to attract public attention and to give serious apprehension in regard to the ability of the Government to keep up the annual expenditures on this account without proceeding to unusual methods of taxation in order to do so.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 20. -- The Hon. Lynde Harrison made application today to Judgre Wheeler for the appointment of a receiver for the Newport News and Mississippi Valley Railroad Company. The application was made at the instance of Collis P. Huntington of the Southern Pacific, in behalf of the creditors.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., March 20. -- The election this afternoon for three School Trustees in the Second District resulted in a big fight between two faction nominees -- A. T. Wooley and D. B. Baremore. Wooley was supported by 600 women, representing all the churches here, and he was elected by a large majority.

Matters are now taking such shape in the Second Assembly District Tammany Hall organization, owing to Leader Patrick Divver's line of conduct, that it looks as though one of the first things that Richard Croker will have to do upon his return to this city will be to call the Executive Committee or Committee of Sixty together to take action.

At the meeting of the Police Board last week a resolution was introduced by Commissioner MacLean requesting the Superintendent to report all the facts connected with the raids made by Central Office men in the Twenty-second Precinct, commanded by Capt. Haughey. The resolution was adopted.

Stockholders of the Texas and Pacific Railroad, which is a part of the Gould Southwestern system, held their annual meeting in this city yesterday. There was no election. Directors having been chosen last year for two years. The annual report, which was submitted by President George J. Gould, showed, for the year ended Dec. 31 last, gross earnings, $7,452,063; operating expenses and taxes, $5,421,530; net earnings, $2,030,533.

Blair, meaning Blair of New-Hampshire, Henry W. Blair, is a man of woeful experiences. The enthusiasm with which people avoid him, after they have once become really aware of him, has undoubtedly repressed his erstwhile yearning ambitions and active desires for the good of the species.

The occupants of the villas and cottages that crown the wooded slopes in the neighborhood of King's Bridge were startled yesterday morning by the news that an unknown man had been found hanged on the old cherry tree that stands beside the road leading to High Bridge about a quarter of a mile distant from the railroad station.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Some startling disclosures were made this evening before the sub-committees of the Ways and Means Committee of the House and the Finance Committee of the Senate touching the contract made on the part of the State, through Edward Hannan, Superintendent of Public Works, and the Cataract Electric Company to conduct electric wires along the canal under the canal electric experimental law.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday. Mr. Jacob Cole sold, at $11,800, to Thomas E. Higgins, the three-story brick dwelling and store 1,017 Fulton Street, north side, 60 feet southeast of Grand Avenue. 20 by 53.11 by 20 by 41, and the three-story and basement brownstone dwelling at 16 Putnam Avenue, south side, 75 feet east of Grand Avenue, 20 by 36.4 by 40 by 32.1.
The trial of Constable Jamieson of Coney Island for perjury came to an end yesterday afternoon in the Brooklyn Court of Oyer and Terminer.

WASHINTON, March 21 -- This was a day of exhibition and experiment at the Naval Ordnance Proving Ground, on the Potomac River. The features comprised the firing of the largest gun ever made in this country, an attack with new shell on a heavy armor plate, and the use of smokeless powder.

The plight of the Gravesend conspirators would move a feeling heart to pity if that emotion were not contrary to public policy in the case of offenders against the election laws. McKane is probably the happiest of the lot, for he knows the worst and has had time to sink into the dull, despairing indifference of the long-term convict.

BOSTON, March 21 -- A radical change in the Board of Directors of the New-York and New-England Railroad was made to-day at the annual meeting of stockholders. Mr. McLeod, F.H. Prince, C.H. Prince, Samuel Heilner, Charlemagne Tower, James Armstrong, and four other members of the McLeod board were dropped, and some entirely new blood was introduced.

Joseph Reon, or Rheom, lives in Ogdensburg, sometimes in rooms in the stone block at the corner of Lake and River Streets, and at other times with some of his relatives on New-York Avenue. He is a French Canadian, ignorant, of dissolute habits, and now broken down by age and the results of dissipation.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- There were no exciting scenes, either tragic or comic, during to-day's hearing of the trial of Madeline V. Pollard's suit against Representative W.C.P. Breckinridge for breach of promise of marriage. The interest centred in the disclosure of the line of defense to be pursued, which was found to be exactly as foreshadowed several days ago.

The mystery surrounding the death of little Susie Martin, whose body was found in a tenement-house cellar, is as great as ever. The efforts of the police to discover the child's murderer have not been successful thus far.

ALBANY, March 21 -- The Committee on General Laws of the Assembly reported adversely the bill of Mr. Stadtfeld. (Dem., New-York,) permitting Sunday fishing in the Counties of New-York, Kings, Queens, Suffolk, Westchester, and Richmond. But for the influence of Speaker Malby and Leader Alnsworth, the House would have supported Mr. Stadtfeld's motion to disagree with the report of the committee.

The discovery of fraud upon the State of Louisiana by which bonds amounting to hundreds of thousands of dollars supposed to have been destroyed according to law many years previous were afterward found to be in the hands of innocent investors, both here and abroad, was made in September, 1889.

The most important fact in the tariff situation is that the reform bill is now before the Senate. It is, therefore, in one of the concluding stages of legislation. It has been got out from behind the closed doors of the sub-committee and the full Committee of Finance. Its proposed provisions are known to all whom it may concern.

Only Simon-Pure amateurs took cart in the final boxing and wrestling bouts for the championship of the United States in Madison Square Garden last night. On Monday several shady boxers managed to escape The vigilance of the committee, but when they appeared last night they were confronted with incontrovertible evidence regarding their status, and as they failed to make satisfactory explanations they were told to withdraw.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Before the Assembly Insurance Committee this afternoon a hearing was held on the Wray bill, providing that 85 per cent. of the total unearned premiums of the policies in force shall be allowed as liabilities in examinations into the affairs of fire insurance companies.

HOTEL, ROYAL POINCIANA, PALM BEACH, Fla., March 21 -- The thirty-ninth annual convention of the Association of General Passenger Agents of America was called to order by President Francis Chandler at 11 o'clock this morning. After the usual order of business, three invitations for the next meeting of the association were presented -- one from Lookout Mountain, in Tennessee; one from Duiuth, and one from Quebec.

"Queen Isabella's Art Gallery," Introducing living pictures by the Kilanyi troupe of men and women, mostly the latter, was the salient, if not sensational, feature of last night's performance of "1492" at the Garden Theatre. It was the introduction of the Art Gallery to America, and it obtained quite as proud a triumph here as it is reported to have obtained in Paris, London, and other European capitals.

NEW-HAVEN, March 21 -- The receivership proceedings here in the Newport News and Mississippi Company matter are authoritatively explained as follows: The company is a syndicate corporation formed under a Connecticut charter to secure leases of roads, operate them, and thus control a system which was established with terminals at Louisville, Memphis, and NewOrleans, and connecting with the Southern Pacific system.

Mrs. Charles Russell Lowell, who has done so much this past Winter in assisting needy women with employment, gave a lecture upon "The Evils of Investigation and Relief " In Assembly Hall. United Charities Building, yesterday afternoon. The lecture was one of a course upon social topics given under the auspices of the Charity Organization Society.

We move to amend the Rapid-Transit bill of the Chamber of Commerce by substituting the name of John H. Starin for that of Alexander E. Orr. Mr. Orr is an upright, public-spirited, and useful citizen -- of Brooklyn. He could not be so useful a member of a Rapid-Transit Commission for New-York as a resident of this city, made familiar by daily experience with the hardships, delays, difficulties, and needs of intra-urban travel.

NIAGARA FALLS, March 21 -- Robert Sutherland, brother of Kenneth F. Sutherland, the Gravesend Justice of the Peace who is now a fugitive from justice, came here last night. He had no baggage, but stopped at a hotel for a short time, refusing to register.

LONDON, March 21 -- Mr. Gladstone artived in London from Brighton this morning. He is much stronger than he was when he went to Brighton, but he is still troubled with hoarseness and catarrh. The condition of his eyes is about the same as it was a fortnight ago. Mrs. Glanstone is not at all well.

Several hundred chess players watched the third game of the championship chess match between W. Steinitz and E. Lasker at the Union Square Hotel yesterday, and those present seemed to thoroughly enjoy the game. It was opened by Lasker with another Ruy Lopez, in which the champion altered his tactics from those adopted in the first game of the match.

Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for the estate of Philip Van Volkenburgh to Henry Oppenheimer five lots, each 25 by 100. on the south side of West Seventy-second Street, 100 feet west of West End Avenue, on private terms. Hign-class dwellings will be built on the lots.

Nearly all the overhead wires along feroadway, between Cortlandt and Wall Streets, were cut down yesterday afternoon by employes of the Board of Electrical Control. The board recently decided that overhead wires crossing Broadway, between Twenty-third Street and the Battery, should be removed, and notices to that effect were served on the telephone companies.

BOSTON, March 21 -- Capt. "Hank" Haff, best known of American yacht skippers, arrived in town this morning from his home in Islip, L.I. As was announced same time ago, he has been engaged by Gen. Paine to sail the Jubilee, should she be in commission the coming season, and his visit is now to superintend the painting of the topsides of the boat and a general overhauling which will be given her.
MADRID, March 21. -- A dispatch received from Santander this evening says that ten men were killed and thirty were injured by an explosion of dynamite in the harbor today.

This document, written with lead pencil, in a neat, round, businesslike hand, will hereafter be most carefully treasured among the heirlooms of the family of Gen. Ferdinand P. Earle, proprietor until 10 o'clock to-day of the Hotel New Netherland. It was a simple luncheon order, put in at the cafe of the hotel on Tuesday, and the author is unknown, but Gen. Earle says he wouldn't part with the original for a good deal.

The Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday adopted a resolution offered by E.P. Martin, approving the bill before the Legislature appropriating $1,000,000 for a park in the Adirondacks, but protesting against the sale of felled or burned timber in the mountains, on the ground that it would be a menace to the soil, and subject the outlying country to damage by floods.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 21 -- There is every reason to believe that Major E.A. Burke, the defaulting ex-State Treasurer of Louisiana, who has been a fugitive in Honduras for the last six years, will soon be brought bark to New-Orleans to account for the millions of dollars which he embezzled from the State by his gigantic bond fraud.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Only eight nominations of New-York Postmasters have been confirmed by the Senate since the beginning of the present session of Congress. There are now pending before the committee to which they were referred forty-eight nominations, ten of which were sent to the Senate on the assembling of Congress.

The Second Assembly District was in a state of expectancy all day yesterday because it was thought that Patrick Diwer would return home. People were wondering what the Tammany leader of the district would have to say for himself when he got here, and where were not a few members of his committee who wanted him to show some cause why he should not be "turned down."

The Lexington Avenue Opera House. East Fifty-eighth Street, near Third Avenue, presented a gay scene last evening, when a grand entertainment and ball was given by the Arlington Club in aid of the Lebanon Hospital, at One Hundred and Fiftieth Street and Westchester Heights. The opera house was handsomely decorated with bunting and many-colored banners.

BOSTON, March 21 -- The market for local stocks was dull and lacked features. Wisconsin Central 5s advanced to 75, with only small sales. Bell Telephone sold in small lots at 183, a point off from yesterday's highest. Lamson Store Service rose 1/2, to 22. West End Street Railway was dull and heavy at 50.

The banks, corporations, and firms which saved the recent Government bond issue of $50,000,000 from failure by subscribing for 95 per cent, of the issue at the expiration of Secretary Carlisle's call for bids, added their protest yesterday to those already sent to Washington against the Bland Seigniorage bill.

The storm interfered to some extent with the attendance at the evangelistic revival meetings yesterday. At the noon meeting in Association Hall the audience numbered about 500, and about 2,000 people met in Cooper Union Hall at the 3:30 meeting. The noon meeting was for Hebrews. About fifty Christian Hebrews, most of them recent converts, were present.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 21 -- The Hudson County Grand Jury this evening presented indictments against all the members of the Board of Street and Water commissioners for malfeasance.

Frank Booth Goodrich, late of this city, who died in Morristown, N.J., March 15, was a regular contributor to The New-York Times more than forty years ago. Mr. Goodrich was the son of Samuel Griswold Goodrich, so widely known about the beginning of the century as "Peter Parley." On his mother's side he came of good English stock, and through his father was connected with such New-England families as the Chaunceys, Griswolds, Greenoughs, and Lowells.

TURIN, March 21 -- The Municipal Council has offered to provide a suitable tomb for the burial of Louis Kossuth in this city and to accompany the interment with appropriate honors. The family of the dead patriot have replied that they cannot accept the offer until they have learned the decision of the Hungarian Parliament as to what honors that body is disposed to pay to Kossuth's memory.

Among the points established by our revelation of pension frauds, which is continued to-day, is the fact that desertion from the army has been practically no bar to a pension claim. Nominally pensions can be granted under the laws only in case of an "honorable discharge" from the service.

For the forty-second time the Abeel Trophy is in competition at the range of the Seventh Regiment Armory. Company C, the present holder of the trophy, opened the match last evening, rolling up a score only 9 points behind the record. The scores:

TRENTON, N.J., March 21 -- The NewJersey Senate dead-lock was broken to-day by a decision of the Supreme Court, which declared the Republican body presided over by Mr. Rogers the Senate of New-Jersey. Gov. Werts has accepted this decision, and has issued commissions to the State officers chosen by the concurrent action of the Republican Senate and the House, and these officers will be installed on April 2.

GENESEO, N.Y., March 21 -- The wedding of Ferdinand Ward of New-York City and Miss Belle Storer of Staten Island took place in this village at 7 o'clock this evening. The Rev. George Ward of Danville officiated.

Another application to punish Controller Fitch for contempt of court in not obeying a writ of mandamus issued by Justice Lawrence about three weeks ago was made in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, by Henry Keteltas, as trustee of the Gardner estate. The writ ordered the Controller to show cause why he should not issue bonds to pay for the land set aside for Corlears Hook Park.

The names of deserters are on the pension roll. That this is the fact arouses indignation in the breast of many honest soldiers whom the reporter for The New-York Times has found who staid with their companies at the front and faced bullets until their time of service had expired.

Holy Week is not prolific in musical entertainments. Perhaps for that reason it was a good thing that one of Mr. Plunket Greene's song recitals was set down for Tuesday afternoon in the Chamber Music Room at Music Hall. A large audience was present, and Mr. Greene's singing was enthusiastically applauded, as usual.

At the meeting of the Excise Board yesterday, the case of Clark's all-night restaurant, 504 Sixth Avenue, and of the Alhambra Concert Hall, in Eighth Avenue, which was raided by Superintendent Byrnes's men, and for falling to suppress which Capt. Price was flned five days' pay, were considered.

An educational and religious centre is being established at Sherman Park, in Westchester County, which is attracting much attention, and bids fair to give a new impulse to the development of the place. The French Dominican Fathers of Lyons have just purchased the Hotel Tecumseh and adjoining property, in all 115 lots.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The experts who were engaged to figure out the amount of revenue which the revised Tariff bill would produce have not yet finished their work. In the absence of authentic figures, some of the Senators who have a taste for mathematics have tried their hands at the bill.

The so-called bomb found on a Sixth Avenue elevated train at the Fifty-eighth Street station on Tuesday evening caused the trainmen, the police, and members of the Bureau of Combustibles, who had to handle it, a great deal of anxiety.

Good Government Club E's rooms, at 338 East Twenty-third Street, were inadequate last night to accommodate the members who were anxious to hear John W. Goff speak on election frauds. An adjournment was taken to the larger hall of the Te-To-Tum Club down stairs, which was well filled.

The bondsmen of seven of the indicted Gravesend Election Inspectors, fearing that the men for whom they were sureties might follows the example set by justice Kenneth F. Sutherland and leave for parts unknown, have surrendered the men.

The decision which by present indications the President has reached, to interpose his veto to the Bland silver-inflation bill, cannot have been reached without careful and candid consideration of the arguments in its favor. Nor have those who have urged this decision failed to consider whatever has been said, or could be said, in support of the measure.

If everybody in New-York and vicinity had visited the World's Fair it might not be worth the while of a newspaper to engage in the laudible task of putting it in the power of people to pleasantly learn in detail what the great exposition looked like. The statistics show, however, that but a small proportion of the Eastern people went to Chicago.

"We could help a great many deserving persons," said President Washington of the 6-15-99 Club to a reporter for The NewYork Times yesterday, "if citizens who have old clothes suitable for men, women or children to wear, in groins to work would send them to my office at 145 Broadway.
"Hello, Chicago!" This was the conventional manner in which a conversation was begun last evening between J.J. Carty in New-York and Angus S. Hibbard in Chicago.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 21 -- The lower house of the General Assembly, by a vote of 53 to 45, to-day passed what is known as the Martin Mulct Tax bill. In effect it provides a restricted local option for the cities and towns of the State. It allows the assessment of a tax of $600 against any real estate upon which liquor is sold.

If one can make one's self and somebody else both happy at the some time, such an opportunity should not be neglected, because life is short and we are told to do as much good as we can in its brief span. Of course whether we want to be happy and have another share our happiness depends a great deal on the cost.

In the town of Ogdensburg lives a veteran soldier who lost an eye from a fever which he contracted while lying in the trenches in front of Petersburg. He was a good soldier, and he began to draw, some years ago, a pension of $17 a month -- the regular allowance for soldiers who had suffered as he had.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -- Reading and St. Paul were the most active stocks on to-day's list, but there were larger transactions in the Pacifies than for some time. Nothing is definitely known here yet as to what is up in Northern Pacific, but it looks as if some of the large interest had gotten together and were likely to come to an understanding in regard to reorganization.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- The local stock market was even narrower than yesterday. Up to noon there was but one price for West Chicago, 147 1/2, while the fluctuations in Lake Street Elevated were only 1/8, followed later by a further decline of 1/8, to 23 5/8. Diamond Match likewise moved in close limits -- 116 @ 116 1/8, closing at 116.

The decision of the Supreme Court of New-Jersey sweeps away the contentions by which the "hold-over" Democrats in the Senate of that State sustained their right to organize that body and determine its membership, even though they were a minority at the opening of a session.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Secretary Hoke Smith has arrested the business of transferring the Indian Supply Agency from New-York to Chicago. He had nearly completed the transfer, but acting upon the protests sent to him from New-York, Philadelphia, and Boston, he has withheld his signature from the lease of the Chicago premises, for which the negotiations are about closed, and has ordered the matter held for further consideration.

The London Financial Times of March 8 has an article on "Reading Fours," which, after referring to the work of the committees of Atchison and Erie security holders, has this to say of Reading matters:

The Executive Committee of the German-American Union recently met to make final arrangements for the thorough organization of Assembly district associations of the union. The meeting was held at the residence of Oswald Ottendorfer. Arthur Von Briesen presided. A constitution and bylaws were adopted.

ALBANY, March 21 -- The fight between the Platt and anti-Platt forces broke out to-night in the Assembly with a vengeance. Just before the hour of adjournment this afternoon, Leader Alnsworth recalled from the Senate the O'Connor Election Inspectors bill, which had already passed both houses with amendments, upon which an irreconcilable difference existed between the Senate and Assembly which a conference committee had failed to overcome.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Ambassador to this country, recently transmitted to his Government a document which he said was of special interest and value at the present time." The Foreign Office considered it of sufficient importance to publish it. It is the report by Arthur Peel, Second Secretary of the British Embassy, on the coal mines in West Virginia.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, March 21 -- P.M. Speculation to-day was in the hands of the room traders, and was thoroughly professional. Sugar was once more prominent in the trading, and it was irregular. It sold down to 88 1/8, but closed at 89 1/8, a net loss of 1 1/2 points. The other industrials were not active, And were only fractionally changed.
PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -- The banks of the Clearing House Association of Philadelphia to-day tent this letter to President Cleveland:

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Among the men who have known President Cleveland best and have never been disappointed in any expectation that they have formed of his action in important public matters there is a strong conviction to-night that the Bland bill will be vetoed. This conviction does not proceed from any communication that the President has made to any one here as to what he intends to do.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 22 -- Ithaca is again concerned in the Cornell chlorine poisoning case by the commitment to jail this afternoon by Judge Forbes, of F.L. Taylor, a Cornell sophomore, who was a roommate of C.L. Dingens, who is suspected of having prepared the chlorine.

The bill for the establishment of a National Bureau of Health which has been framed by the committee of the New-York Academy of Medicine was introduced in both houses of Congress early in the session and referred to suitable committees. A hearing will be given on March 28 to the advocates of the bill and others who may have suggestions or criticisms to offer.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Secretary Hoke Smith said to-night that he has read with the greatest Interest the articles that have appeared in The New-York Times on the frauds committed, in New-York State under the pension laws, and that he will follow the series to the end with, the closest attention.
Laws relating to libel will not be changed on the lines laid down in the Ainsworth and Saxton bills if the wishes of the Bar Association have any weight fifth the members of the Legislature.

BOSTON, March 22 -- The strength of Wisconsin Central 5s was the principal feature of the market for local securities to-day. They opened at 75 1/8, 1/8 higher than last night's close, and advanced to 75 3/4, closing at that figure. There is nothing new said about Wisconsin Central securities. Friends of the company claim a growing investment demand.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 22. -- The following telegram was sent to the President to-day: ...

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Not until the last ten minutes at the session did wheat display any activity to-day, and then the trade was for the purpose of liquidation by those who had bought yesterday on the prospective cold wave and who, growing disheartened at the failure of prices to advance, threw their holdings overboard. At times during the day business was practically at a standstill, with the pit almost deserted.
BERLIN, March 22 -- The evening newspapers give extracts from the speech made by Chancellor von Caprivi at the dinner of the Danzig Boerse, on Tuesday night. The Chancellor said:

Miss Mary Argenbau, the daughter of Mrs. Daniel Argenbau, who lives with her mother at the Hotel St. George, in Brooklyn, is the victim of a series of runaway accidents yesterday afternoon on the Prospect Park Plaza.

There are now pending in the Legislature at Albany a bill to increase the pay of policemen of New-York City, a bill to pension physicians and employes of the Health Board, a bill to pension clerks of the Police Department, and a bill to pension school teachers. A bill providing for the retirement and pensioning of firemen has been passed and signed by the Governor.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- There was a ripple of excitement in the Senate Chamber during the morning hour to-day when Senator Higgins of Delaware presented a memorial and petition "of the business men of New-England" addressed to the Congress of the United States. Mr. Higgins announced that the memorial had been sent to Mr. Hill, but that the latter was out of the city and had requested him to introduce it in his absence.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Regarding the question of the debt of the various Pacific railroads to the Government, Mr. Reilly of Pennsylvania, Chairman of the House Committee on Pacific Railroads, said to-day:

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Local stocks, with one exception, were decidedly improved in both volume and tone. There was a heavier trade and wider range on Diamond Match than in anything on the list. At the start it looked like a determined raid, but the depression was short lived. In the morning two brokers began offering the stock 1/2 point below the close of yesterday, or at 115 1/2, selling it down to 112.

Justice Gaynor in Brooklyn yesterday made permanent a temporary injunction against W.H. Coombs, a constable of the Twenty-first Ward, restraining him from levying on the property of Mrs. Catherine L. Sickles, proprietor of a notion store which was seized on attachment. Mrs. Sickles's store is at 709 Gates Avenue.

BOSTON, March 22 -- The body of a man about thirty-five years old was found on the Charles River flats this morning at low tide, about 200 feet from the Harvard Bridge. The body was clothed in the best quality of goods, made in the latest style. A bruise made by some blunt instrument was found on the head.

To-morrow will be a great basket-ball day for the Washington Heights Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. Both the junior and senior teams will play match games. In the afternoon the juniors will play the team of the St. Thomas Chapel Athletic Club in their gymnasium, in East Fifty-ninth Street.

TURIN, March 22 -- The family of Louis Kossuth has expressed the desire that the body of the Hungarian patriot shall be removed to Buda-Pesth on Friday, and that the final funeral services shall take place in the Hungarian capital next Tuesday. It is understood that the body will be taken to Hungary by the way of Venice and Flume in order to avoid its passage over Austrian soil.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. T. A. Kerrigan sold at $3,290 the two and a half story brick dwelling 62 Kosciusko Street, south side, 339.8 feet west of Nostrand Avenue, 18 by 100, to Alois Lazansky. To Arthur Winnington, at $3,025, he sold the two three-story frame tenements 9 and 11 Lawrence Street, 38 by 52.4 by 38 by 51.7.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Ohio appointments sent to the Senate to-day are victories for Senator Brice. Harlan Cleveland, nominated for Attorney of the United States for the Southern District, was indorsed by Senator Brice, but his nomination was opposed by the President on account of the relationship existing between them.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The deeper the Interior Department delves into the proposition to remove the Indian Supply Agency from New-York to Chicago the more doubtful it becomes whether the notion was properly considered before it was half decided that the change should be made.

J. Henry Martin, an ex-member of the Brooklyn Board of Education, was arrested yesterday and taken before Postmaster Sullivan for stealing papers from the tops of mail boxes. As he appeared to be demented and hardly responsible for his acts, Mr. Sullivan released him, with a warning not to repeat his offense.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Two ballot-reform bills were passed to-day, the Senate sending to the House the bill of Mr. Saxton, (Rep., Wayne,) the House to the Senate the measure of Mr. Sheffield, (Rep., New-York.) Both bills provide for the blanket ballot. The main point of variance is that, while Senator Saxton's permits an individual paster, Mr. Sheffield's prohibits the use of any kind of a paster.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The sub-committees of the Committee on Finance of the Senate and the Ways and Means of the House continued the investigation this morning into the contract made by Edward Hannan, Superintendent of Public Works, representing the State, and the Cataract Company for the propulsion of boats along the canal by electricity.
Many prominent citizens and friends attended the funeral of Allan Campbell yesterday morning at 11 o'clock, in Trinity Chapel, in West Twenty-fifth Street.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The statement made in the dispatch sent out from Poughkeepsie on March 20 that the examination of cattle supposed to be infected with tuberculosis has been transferred from the State Board of Health to the State Agricultural Department is false.
CHICAGO, March 22 -- Prendergast, who was sentenced to be hanged to-morrow for the murder of Mayor Harrison, has been respited, by an order of the court, until April 6.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, March 22 -- P.M. Speculation was dull, and was once more controlled by the professional element. There was no special feature to the market, and the undertone was strong. To-morrow being a holiday, traders were indisposed to carry contracts, fearing developments unfavorable to their position.

The handsome Hotel New Netherland presented a forlorn appearance yesterday afternon. Where a few hours before there had been all the animation and activity of a large hotel, there were dark rooms, dimly-lighted halls, and a general air of gloom and desertion. In conformance with the legal proceedings instituted by Charles A. Peabody, Jr., agent for William Waldorf Astor, owner of the hotel, Gen. Ferdinand P. Earle, the landlord, vacated the building yesterday.

The Knickerbocker Whist Club of this city is still keeping up its record of winning games. Last week the Montclair Whist Club was defeated by 26 points. Saturday a team of four will go up to Albany to play the crack whist club of that city. This contest is looked forward to with considerable interest, as there are some first-class players in the Albany club.

TRENTON, N.J., March 22 -- There were interesting scenes in the consolidating of the two Senates this morning. Senator Adrain was one of the first of the Democratic group to enter the chamber. He was in excellent humor and cordially shook hands with the Republican Senators and the officers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 17, via Montevideo, March 22 -- President Peixoto has revived the imperial decrees of 1838 and 1851. These decrees authorize the execution, without formal trial, of all persons who have taken up arms against the Government, as well as those who have aided or abetted, directly or indirectly, the cause of an insurrection.

"Divver's home again!" "When the bright sun chased the lingering shadows out of the nooks and corners of the Second Assembly District yesterday, this was the cry that rang along Park Row, echoed through the windings of Pearl Street, woke up the residents of James Slip, and penetrated every section of the district.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- It is believed in well-informed naval and diplomatic circles that the Bering Sea matter is assuming an aspect of grave and serious importance, and that recent sudden changes in the assignment of naval officers are ascribable to this cause.

Pension Commissioner Raum's notorious "Order 164," which operated to give the maximum amount of pension provided by the act of June 27, 1890, to so many men who are not "incapacitated from earning a support at manual labor," gave results essentially the same in all the plucks embraced in the investigation by The New-York Times.
One man pleading guilty to conspiracy and another convicted of perjury were yesterday's outcome of the prosecution of the Gravesend election conspirators.

Messrs. C.R. Gregor Son have sold for William Rhinelander and Lispenard Stewart, for improvement, the four lots on the north side of Eighty-ninth Street, beginning 195 feet west of Third Avenue, 100 by 100.8, for about $80,000.

The only substantial difference between the blanket ballot bill passed by the Senate yesterday and that passed by the Assembly lies in the omission by the latter of all provision for the use of pasters. The Senate bill does not allow what is generally known as the "paster ballot," but only pasters bearing single names of candidates for certain offices, such as have been common under all our methods of voting in the past.

James D. Leary, the speedway contractor, appeared before the Park Board yesterday and asked for a modification of his contract in regard to the size of the stone to be used. Mr. Leary has two scowloads of stone lying in the Harlem River. It is what is called "inch and a half stone," and under the original form of contract could not be used in building the walls, being too large.

A decree has been signed by Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court, upon the report of Sumerville R. Tuck, as referee, directing Elizabeth de Talleyrand Perigord, or Bessie, Marquise de Talleyrand Perigord, to turn over to her brother, George Washington Lewis Curtis, all his property, which was deeded to her in 1880, so that he may be restored to the full enjoyment of his rights.
An attempt was made early yesterday morning to burn down the large rear tenement house at 302 East Eleventh Street, in which about sixty-five persons were asleep at the time.

DENVER, Col., March 22 -- The Champa Building, occupied by the Champa. Furniture Company, was totally destroyed by fire to-night. In less than an hour all the walls had fallen outward, crushing the adjoining buildings.

Several pretty women, a wealthy physician, and a well-known dentist figured in a dramatic incident in the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning. Justice Welde presided and listened patiently to what proved to be a public airing of a series of household difficulties.

Jacques Pacheteau, a Bleecker Street wine merchant, went to the Jefferson Market Police Court a few days ago and made an affidavit against Herman L. Cohen of 159 East Seventy-fifth Street and Thomas C. Brewer of Pontiac Bank fame, charging both with grand larceny.

The increase in the number of fires in flat houses recently has caused much uneasiness among insurance men, and they expected that the Rate Committee of the tariff department of the New-York Board of Fire Underwriters would increase the insurance rates on such buildings at its meeting yesterday.

In the Supreme Court, Chambers, Wednesday, Judge O'Brien denied the motion made in behalf of Robert Mantell, the actor, to modify the injunction granted some time ago restraining him from playing under any other management than that of Proctor Turner. The Proctor Turner company closed its season last week, and under this ruling Mr. Mantell will have to remain idle until his legal managers choose to send him on the road again.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Yale College and Young Men's Christian Association baseball teams crossed bats here to-day. Shortly before the game a terrific rainstorm set in, and as a result the grounds were in wretched condition. The local club surprised the spectators by putting up a brilliant game in the field and at the bat.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- There are very few persons in Washington who now look for approval of the Bland bill. During the last three days the doubt among the friends of sound money as to what will become of the measure in the President's hands has about disappeared, and even among the men who supported the bill its approval would be a surprise.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Chilean Claims Commission handed down several important decisions to-day, all of them except one being against the United States claimants.

Robert J. Rykoff, a pale-faced young man who recently came to this city from Chicago, where his relatives reside, was arrested in the dry goods store of Stern Brothers on Tuesday for stealing a silverheaded cane. He was taken into custody by Detective Casey and turned over to Central Office Detective Trainor.

TROY, N.Y., March 22 -- Bartholomew Shea, accused by the Coroner's jury of killing Robert Rosa on election day, was formally commuted by Justice Donohue to-day on the charge of murder. John H. Boland, upon whom the police sought to fasten the crime, was discharged by the court. His friends formed a procession and escorted him to his home, carrying an American flag.

C.P.B. was a Corporal in Company B of the Sixteenth New-York Volunteer Infantry. His application for a pension under the act of 1890 was filed July 21, 1890, and from this date he received $12 per month, the full rate, by certificate issued June 3, 1892. His disabilities are "chronic diarrhea, with resulting diseases, and disease of the heart."

Bradstreet's, in its issue of this week, will say: "Increased observance of Good Friday in business circles serves to check the volume of trade. Notwithstanding there being practically one less business day this week than last, continued Spring-like weather has further stimulated sales of staples at nearly all larger cities in Eastern, Middle, and in some of the Western States, comparatively fewer Southern distributing centres reporting corresponding gains.

A collection of American landscapes and marines has been brought together at the Lotos Club by Mr. William T. Evans, who has drawn liberally on his own private galery fur the purpose and borrowed pictures of other members of the club and of the artists. It is the first of three monthly exhibitions.

SANTANDER, March 22 -- Much excitement has prevailed here to-day in consequence of last night's explosion of dynamite in the submerged wreck of the steamer Cabo Machichaco. The people believe that the explosion was due to carelessness, and their rage has reached that height that only the application of harshly repressive measures has sufficed to avert rioting and bloodshed.
Martha J. Fuller's death in Lawyer William M. Mullen's office in the Nassau Chambers Building Saturday was not explained by any discovery that the police made yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The candidates for West Point cadetships will know to-morrow of the result of the recent examinations held in different parts of the country convenient to their homes. The papers have been gone over at West Point and the board has reported the result to the War Department.

A most extraordinary sight was witnessed at the evangelistic revival meeting in Cooper Union yesterday afternoon. All but a few seats in the large hall were occupied. The Rev. Henry M. Wharton, Ferdinand Schiverea, and the Rev. James O'Connor had finished speaking, when the Rev. Father A. Lambert, the Redemptorist priest whose renunciation of the Roman Catholic priesthood and the Church of Rome was announced in The New-York Times yesterday morning, was introduced.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- The market was a sale practically from the opening. Most stocks declined steadily through the day. The principal weakness was developed in Reading, and, though nothing is positively known, it was said that somebody must have seen the Little report and started to get out ahead of the Street.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 22 -- The Post Office authorities have seized a number of copies of The Congressional Record containing the speeches of Tom L. Johnson on the Wilson bill, and Henry George's address on protection and free trade. The Records were addressed to O.M. Hudson, a prominent local advocate of the single tax theory.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The new Chinese convention, which had been negotiated by Secretary Gresham and Minister Yang Yu, is receiving vigorous opposition from Senators, and there seems a strong probability of its rejection. When the matter was brought before the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate, it was in the nature of a surprise.

If Mme. Patti is well enough to sail tomorrow she will say good-bye to New-York without the usual farewell concert. She was advertised to sing at Carnegie Music Hall yesterday afternoon, but she was ill.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Secretary Carlisle to-day compiled with the Senate resolution directing him to furnish the report of the investigation recently made in regard to the Appraiser's office at Boston.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Senate is behaving very cuitously about the bill to provide a site for a row planting others. It has begaved curiously before in the same matter. One before to-day an attempe was made to decide upon a site and when the property owned by the same one rise that "Billy" Mahese was set is on was overturned, and the bashess postponed.

The Harwkins Zouave Association has applled to the Legislature for an appropriation with which to erect a monument at Antietam to the memory of its comrades of the Ninth New-York Volunteer Infantry who fell in that battle on Sept. 17, 1862.

The Avery Galleries, at 368 Fifth Avenue have a dozen paintings by Thomas Hovenden, N.A., that show him in another light from the one under which he is usually seen. Mr. Hovenden has made his mark as a painter of American genre, rivaling J.G. Brown and Seymour Guy. And, oddly enough, like them, he is of foreign birth, having come at an early age from the British Islands.

While the number of applicants by homeless men for meals and lodgings has been falling off, calls for cheap groceries at the stores of the Industrial Christian Alliance do not show any decrease whatever.

-- Attorney General D.P. Pride of Idaho died yesterday in Boise City. He was private secretary to Senator Hale of Maine, and through him secured the position of Register of the Land Office in Boise City in 1888. In 1884 he was appointed Territorial Secretary by President Arthur, and in 1885 he was confirmed First Attorney General of Idaho.

The conviction of Constable Jamieson and the pleading guilty of Justice Newton, with his sentence to prison, mark the complete rout of the Gravesend gang. Jamieson was an ignorant, stupid tool of the main conspirators, doing their dirty worK as it was laid out by them and taking the mean pay doled out to him.

The second general meeting of the New-York Yacht Club was held in the clubhouse, 67 Madison Avenue, last night. As usual on such occasions, Commodore E.D. Morgan was absent and Vice Commodore Brown presided.

The finances of the town of Gravesend are in such a muddled condition that the Town Board of Audit, at its meeting yesterday, afternoon, in the Coney Island Police Headquarters, was unable to arrive at any conclusion regarding John Y. McKane's shortage in the accounts.

About the time of the failure of "Plunger" F. Theodore Walton, the Tattersalls of New-York, Limited, which had a claim against him for the feed and keep of some of his horses, secured an attachment against his property in an action in the Supreme Court, and under it the Sheriff seized the imported stallion Hopeful.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 22 -- Grand Commander Jacob S. Coxey left Pittsburg this afternoon for his home in Massillon. He stated before leaving that he was satisfied that his army would have a very considerable acquisition in this city and would, in addition, receive the cordial support of many of Pittsburg's best citizens.

Auspicious results attended the first formal meeting of the State Board of Arbitrators, held yesterday in the Murray Hill Hotel. The meeting was to settle the dispute between Hilson Co., cigar manufacturers at Thirty-seventh Street and First Avenue, and the striking employes.

A wagon driven by R.H. Eggleson of 66 East Eighty-fifth Street and a coach driven by H.F. Fairweather came into collision on the East Drive in Central Park, at Eighty-first Street, yesterday afternoon, and Mr. Eggleson was thrown to the ground. He was not seriously hurt, but his wagon was broken.

DULUTH, Minn., March 22 -- A March blizzard began yesterday, with wind of forty miles velocity, and rain which has turned to a drifting, blinding snow. Electric wires, which were ice-covered by the early rain, have given way before the wind. The city is practically without telephone, police, or fire alarm systems, and a majority of the electric lights are out.

An important effect of the New-Jersey decision in support of the Senate organized by the Republican majority is to give validity to all the laws passed by the Assembly, with its concurrence. Among these are acts repealing the racetrack measures which were forced through the Legislature last year and all the licenses granted under them are rendered null and void.

The competition for the Abeel Trophy, between teams of ten men from each company, was continued last night at the armory range of the Seventh Regiment, on Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. The junior and third teams of Company C shot late on Wednesday night. Company I began the shooting last night, their score being only 4 points behind the top score, 627, made by the team of Company C.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 22 -- Marsden J. Perry, one of the receivers of the New-York and New-England Railroad, says that the story to the effect that the Board of Directors elected yesterday was set up in the interests of the Consolidated Railroad management is not true. The board, he says, will act in the interests of the New-England only.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The Senate Cities Committee gave a hearing this afternoon on the Brooklyn Wallabout Market Land Lease bill introduced by Senator Reynolds and Assemblyman Burtis.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The appearance of Secretary Gresham before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on the seal question in Bering Sea, and the brief and indefinite report of what he said, as given out to the press, though he spoke for a whole hour without interruption on the subject, has probably brought the question of the protection of seals up sharply for settlement.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: No party in this country ever assumed control of the Government with such braod and favorable opportunities as those of the Democratic Party In 1893. The Sherman law, a Republican measure, menaced the country with panic; the McKinley law, another extreme Republican measure, hindered commerce, glutted the home markets, fostered monopoly, and oppressed the people.

CORTLAND, N.Y., March 23 -- The Cortland Howe Ventilating Stove Company will resume work in its foundry with nearly its regular force next Monday, after having been closed since early last December. The industry is one of the most important in Cortland, and starts up again to fill orders already received for the Fall trade.

Moritz Kepes and his family have had a far from pleasant experience since last June in conducting a saloon at 1,684 Avenue A. All the trouble is laid at the door of Joan Fuchs, who has a saloon at 1,680 on the same avenue. Fuchs tried to prevent Kepes from getting a license, but it was granted, and the Hebrew started in business, soon building up a fair trade.

Controller Fitch has prepared a bill which Assistant Corporation Counsel Blandy has taken to Albany and which will, if passed by the Legislature, extricate the Controller from the dilemma in which he has been placed by his inability to sell the Corlears Hook Park bonds.

As the Aquidaban and Republica are still at large, the Brazilian Government is probably very glad to have on hand its little improvised fleet for future contingencies. Indeed, even the moral effect of extemporizing a squadron here, as accomplished by Peixoto's able Minister, Mr. Mendonca, and his other representatives, was most salutary; while it was well, also, to make up the fleet as was actually done.

From The Jacksonville (Fla,) Times-Union, March 22. Eighteen hundred and ninety-four, up to the present time, has been the warmest of any corresponding period since the establishment of the United States Signal Station in this city.

A "live-bird race" was decided yesterday on the grounds of the Cartaret Gun Club, at Bergen Point. It was a match between Fred Hoey and L.S. Thompson and George Work and C.A. Macalester. The match proved interesting from the time it was made, and yesterday many who take an interest in pigeon shooting went to watch the contest.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The President has been receiving all day long advice from all sections of the country to guide him in his disposition of the Bland Seigniorage bill. They came along while the Cabinet was in session, and the members of the President's official family were enabled to see how many of their fellow-citizens are willing to help them in bearing the burdens of the Executive.

Entries for the Durland Riding Academy Horse Show, which closed March 1, have been made public. Nearly 600 horses are entered in the thirty-two classes. No entrance fee was charged, and the classes, with the exception of the driving and the jumping classes, were only open to the patrons of the school.

With the approach of the annual election of officers at the Stock Exchange, talk of opposition to the regular ticket is heard. The contest, should there be one, will apply to candidates for the Governing Committee and probably not to those named for the principal offices.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- The State's Attorney will produce at the investigation into Prendergast's present mental condition, which begins to-morow before Judge Chetlain, medical testimony to prove that the condemned murderer is as sane as he ever was. It is not expected that much time will be occupied in getting a jury.

RONDOUT, N.Y., March 23 -- Two young men who are thought to belong to a gang of counterfeiters that has recently been flooding the Hudson River towns with spurious silver coin, came to this city yesterday and disposed of a large quantity of their goods. The coins are counterfeit half and quarter dollars of the latest design and are dated 1893.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 -- A man who gave his name as Frederick Bonnemant, but subsequently was shown to be William Fredericks, a desperado and friend of "Chris" Evans, shot and killed William Herrick, cashier of the branch bank of the San Francisco Savings Union, about 9:30 o'clock.

The Montgomery (Ala.) Advertiser prints and strongly indorses an able letter from, the Hon. W.H. Lawton of that State, in which he appeals to the reason and the patriotism of all the Democrats of Alabama. In the course of it, he says:

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., March 23 -- The Trustees of this village are having trouble over the contract for lighting the village with electricity, which was awarded last week to Charles H. Ingalls, who lives here. His bid was $17.50 for incandescent lamps of 32 candle power and $100 for 1,200-candle-power arc lights.

The undisturbed solemnity with which the Bar Association discussed proposed changes in the law of libel at its meeting on Thursday evening might well make one skeptical as to the sense of humor which common repute attributes in more than an average degree to members of the bar.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 23 -- Well matured plans to swindle St. Louis banks were executed this week by three clever forgers. A dozen banks were victimized, the amount secured aggregating $20,000.

The city was heavily shrouded in fog for several hours yesterday, making transit by land uncomfortable and by water dangerous. Schedules on the elevated railroads suffered early in the morning. Since nearly as many persons as usual wished to travel, the annoyance of trains packed more closely than usual in the busy hours added to the discomforts of the atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The question of transferring troops is before Gen. Schofield, and he will announce his decision in a few days. The funds for transportation are limited, and few changes can be made this Spring. It has been decided to materially strengthen the force at Plattsburg Barracks.

The Dilettante Library, to which this volume belongs, has a special object, aptly exemplified here. The book conveys the generally accepted but not an individual opinion of the work of Dr. Holmes. It is well written, from trustworthy sources in relations of incidents, with accurate knowledge in reviews of works, and when one has read it, one has not the least inclination toward profound analysis, which is fatal to dilettanteism.

Charles Devine, his wife, and eight children live in a cottage on the shore front, under the big hank at the foot of Ninety-sixth Street, Fort Hamilton. His sixteen-year-old daughter, Mary, left home March 3. Her father ascertained that she was stopping at 25 State Street, Brooklyn. He took her home.

Mr. Crawford has begun a brand-new "history of his contemporaries" with these two volumes which comprise his twenty-second novel, and judging by the immense amount of material he has at hand and the small quantity of it he has put to use in 670 pages of print, more or less, he intends to devote the remainder of his life to it, and he must hope for a long life, too.

PANAMA, March 15 -- At Valparaiso about 5:30 o'clock Thursday afternoon. March 1. a group of fifty men, many of whom alighted from a tramcar, with revolvers and daggers, to the cries of "Viva Balmaceda! Viva la Dictadura! " made a rush at the entrance to the barracks, discharging their revolvers as they went along.

Living in an upper tenement in Oliver Place are a couple who are undoubtedly the oldest married couple residing in Rhode Island. Golden wedding anniversaries occur frequently, and it sometimes happens that a couple will live to receive their friends after sixty years of married life, but the "diamond" wedding anniversary is a rare occurrence.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Secretary Gresham says he knows nothing of any concerted action on the part of the Governments of the United States. Great Britain, and Italy requesting President Peixoto to grant clemency to Brazilian rebels now on board the Portuguese war ships. It is regarded as inconceivable that Minister Thompson could have joined with other powers in such action without instructions from Washington, and no such instructions have been asked for or given.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Before proceeding to a renewal of the effort to secure the vote of a majority of the membership upon the question of considering the O'Neil-Joy contested election case, on motion of Mr. Cummings of New-York the House this morning voted an expression of its regret at the death of Kossuth, the Hungarian patriot, and instructed the Speaker to communicate to the family of the deceased the sympathy of the House.

The Duke of York has won in Rome the honorable reputation of being le desespoir des rastacuoueres. Endless have been the intrigues of the Midases of the Riviera to secure a prospect of getting at him. A certain class of American belles is dispirited at the reputation he is earning for being domestic and taking the duties of his station seriously.

During the viva voce examination in one of the metropolitan colleges the teacher asked where the battle between the Duke of Cumberland and the Pretender took place. The first boy answered "Cull-oden," putting the accent on the first syllable, which may be taken as the accepted cockney pronunciation.

Police Justice Patrick Divver, recently from San Francisco, did not make any statement yesterday in reference to the charges of alleged violation of the Corrupt Practices act or the alleged desertion of some of his followers when they were in trouble. To a friend he said he had turned over all the newspaper clippings he had obtained to his lawyer, who would prepare a statement.

"Civil service" is the politician's slang for civil service reform. In the enforced economy of words due to a congenital constriction of ideas in persons of this class, the word "reform" is dropped, but all the detestation and alarm aroused by civil service reform is expressed by the shorter term.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 23 -- Congressman W.L. Wilson spent a restless night, and is in a weak condition to-day, but Dr. Underwood, his medical attendant, reports that no unfavorable conditions have arisen and that his patient is no worse off than when he arrived here yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- It is reported that arrangements for a combination of sewing-machine manufacturers, with assets of more than $5,000,000, are in progress here. The combination will, it is said, absorb the business of the White Sewing Machine Company of Cleveland, the Davis Sewing Machine Company of Dayton, Ohio, and the Domestic Sewing Machine Company of Newark, N.J.

James Caulfield, a reporter on a Brooklyn newspaper, has suddenly become totally blind in an extraordinary manner. He lost his sight Thursday afternoon through a flash of light of dazzling intensity from a trolley car of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company.

There was no falling off in the attendance at the Cooper Union evangelistic meeting yesterday. Nearly every chair was occupied. The platform was crowded with singers and a chorus choir.
