The noon meetings were thinned out somewhat by the Good Friday services in the churches and the rain, yet they were, considering all, well attended.

A telegram from Boston yesterday afternoon announced that the body of the suicide found on the Charles River flats Thursday had been identified by his friend, Willlam H. Balkville, as that of Charles Brun, the cataloguer of the Mercantile Library in this city, who disapeared on Wednesday, Feb. 28.

During some of the peregrinations of the Sheffield Blanket Ballot bill before it was passed by the Assembly an amendment was injected into it which provides for preserving the ballots voted at elections for a year, instead of destroying them at once on the conclusion of the canvass by the District Inspectors.

The Dutch steamship Bremerhaven, which yesterday arrived in port, became involved in that immense ice field which is now a menace to transatlantic voyagers. The vessel had several of her bow plates stove in and started leaks through which 100 tons of water reached her hold within twenty-four hours.

When the managers of the Platt-Milholland movement tried to get Senator Saxton and Speaker Malby to make speeches at their Cooper Union mass meeting, members of the Committee of Thirty said that this was going away from home for talent.

MASSILLON, Ohio, March 23 -- Two weary travelers, with bundles swung across their shoulders, arrived here overland from Twinsburg, Ohio, at dusk this evening, and took up their quarters in an abandoned freight car on the outskirts of the town. They constitute the advance guard of Coxey's great Commonweal Army, and are as yet all there is to it.

If one can make one's self and somebody else both happy at the some time, such an opportunity should not be neglected, because life is short and we are told to do as much good as we can in its brief span. Of course whether we want to be happy and have another share our happiness depends a great deal on the cost.

The examination of about seventy-five witnesses in the inquest into the death of Martha J. Fulier, that will be held before Coroner Fitzpatrick Monday morning, may result in clearing up the mystery that still envelops the shooting of the unfortunate young typewriter.

NORWICH, Conn., March 23 -- The new Masonic Temple has received its last touches, and was opened this evening for the inspection of the incorporators and their wives. It will be dedicated March 27. It is a handsome three-story building, situated in Broadway, and cost $40,000. There is an ample kitchen and a banquet room in the basement for the accommodation of 150 persons.

The D. M. Chauncey Company has sold for C.E. Donnellon to L. Mordem a plot on the north side of Second Street, Brooklyn, 198 feet east of Seventh Avenue, 200 by 100, for $44,000. Ten three-story dwellings are to be built on the site.

We believe that it was Gen. Hawley, United States Senator from Connecticut, who originated the term "pension shark," or at least gave it a certain official sanction by the famous exhortation (graphic, if not elegant) to the Senators "not to let themselves be stampeded by the pension sharks."

In the Parliament of 1874 there was a gentleman named Dr. O'Leary -- William Haggarty O'Leary, member for Drogheda. The doctor was a very small man, with gestures many sizes too big for him, and a voice that on accasion could emulate the volume of Major O'Gorman's. It was pending the division on the third reading of the Empress of India bill that Mr. Disraeli won over this irate Irishman.

JAMAICA, L.I., March 23 -- There is feeling among the Christian Endeavor societies in this township over their treatment by their fellow-workers in this village a few nights ago. It was to be the annual convention of the societies in the town, and was to be held in the chapel of the Reformed Church here.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Senator Mullin's bill providing for the Dr. Clark system of selecting municipal officers in Oswego. The Governor says the bill proposes a step backward in the science of government, and is founded upon the assumption that the people cannot be trusted to govern themselves.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The navy will have a new machine gun. Secretary Herbert will in a few days invite inventors and makers of this type of ordnance to send machine guns to Indian Head for trial. This test will be distinct from the search for a small-caliber rifle, which is intended for the arming of sailors and marines.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The action of the Canadian Government in seizing and refusing to deliver copies of The Congressional Record, under frank, containing incorporations from publications on the single tax theory, is consistent with the course pursued by the Canadian Post Office officials a year ago when a Government publication containing the book of Henry George was seized and held at the Toronto Post Office.

Controller Fitch of this city has addressed to the Senators of New-York at Washington a forcible protest against that feature of the income tax provision of the Tariff bill which includes in taxable incomes "the value of any personal property received by gift, devise, or inheritance."

SANTANDER, March 23 -- The authorities, though convinced that there is no more dynamite remaining in the hull of the sunken vessel in which there was an explosion day before yesterday, have ordered the destruction of the wreck by means of petards. This has been done to satisfy the general demand that no more lives be endangered by attempting to remove what may remain of the ship's cargo.

The New-York Board of Fire Underwriters yesterday conferred on Patrolman Owen Daily of Fire Patrol No. 3 the Underwriters' Medal for gallant service in life saving. The medal is conferred only for saving life at the risk of the rescuer's own. Daily rescued a woman from a burning building, at 613 Eighth Avenue, on the night of Jan. 20. He is a sinewy man, about twenty-four years old.

One of the finest exhibitions of association football ever given in this country is promised to-day at the meeting of the Philadelphia and New-York teams in the former city. The match is under the direction of the Pennsylvania Football League, which has got together the most powerful team possible.

Miss Isabel Irving, who lately returned to New-York from London, yesterday signed a contract for an engagement of three years with Mr. Daniel Frohman, manager of the Lyceum Theatre. For the first time in her short career on the stage Miss Irving has a contract which stipulates that she shall have "leading business."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- When Citizen Coxey, mounted on his white palfrey and bearing the olive branch of peace in his hand, rides into Washington on May 1 at the head of the Army of the Commonweal, provided, of course, that all this will happen, he will discover some peculiar things about the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Discussing the proposed Chinese treaty to-day, Senator Perkins and other Western men agreed that the provision for the admission of "merchants" is loosely drawn and opens the door to frauds of all sorts. Senator Perkins received the following telegram from San Francisco:
Commenting on the state of trade for the last week, Dun's Review, issued to-day will say:

For the third time in thirty-six hours Otto Koester was arraigned before Justice Welde, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday, on different charges. On Monday, Koester, who is employed as a grocery clerk at Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-fourth Street, was sent to the house of Mrs. Charles Havens, at One Hundred and Fifty-second Street and the Boulevard, to take an order.

BLACK'S RUN, Penn., March 23 -- Two explosions occurred this morning at the Acme Powder Company's works, resulting in the death of five persons, the injury of another, and the destruction of five buildings and 10,000 pounds of dynamite. The monetary loss is about $12,000. The dead are:

It is no wonder that Senator Stewart of Nevada objected to the immediate consideration by the Senate of Senator Sherman's resolution for an inquiry whether any legal offense had been committed by some astute persons in Nebraska who are reported to have been irregularly "coining the seigniorage" on their own account.

The athletic members of the Young Men's Institute, the Bowery Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, have been having a very active Winter in the gymnasium, and are now preparing for a lively season out of doors. The last contest in the series of six gymnasium competitions will be held April 4.

BELLMORE, L.I., March 23 -- John Baldwin died here, at the home of his brother Lorenzo, two weeks ago. The body was buried in a private yard near the dead man's late home. The brothers had been devoted to each other in life, and since the death of one the other has done little else than mourn for him.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Senator Vest and his associates of the Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds are hopeful that the action of the Senate yesterday in voting to purchase the ground which Gen. Mahone has for years been trying to sell to the Government as a site for a new public printing office will be reconsidered, and that Gen. Mahone will have to find another purchaser for his property.

Good Friday was more generally observed in this city yesterday than usual, and many churches of all denominations were open for song and special services. Although the day is not a legal holiday in this State, the Stocks and other Exchanges and many business houses were closed. The theatres were open, as usual, last night, with the exception of the Lyceum.

Dr. William H. Hanford of 84 Lee Avenue, Brooklyn, complained to the police yesterday that workmen were erecting a big pole in front of his house. He was requested to make a complaint to the Mayor. He will do so to-day. Dr. Hanford says there is an electric light pole, a large tree, and an Iron trolley pole in front of his house, and now the Fire Department has put the big fifty-foot pole there.

There is a grave crisis now in the career of the West End clubs, as at most of them it is found that the receipts are diminishing while the list of candidates is steadily shrinking. At one of the best-known service clubs 1,800 less meals were served in 1893 than in the previous year, which conveys some idea of the acuteness of the crisis.

The fourth of the series of entertainments given under the auspices of Mrs. William J. Scanlan, for the inmates of the Bloomingdale Asylum, was given yesterday afternoon in the pretty little theatre attached to the asylum. A number of volunteer professional entertainers appeared. Augustus Pitou managed the entertainment, and Charles Pratt was the pianist.

Secretary Kellogg of the Charity Organization Society said yesterday that during the past week 985 men were employed by the society in cutting wood and doing other work at the Wayfarers' Lodge, 516 West Twenty-eighth Street. Of this number 198 were married.

At the meeting of the Indian Section of the Society of Arts Mr. John A. Gray put his life with the Ameer into a narrative of engrossing interest, beginning with his journey thither. Four-fifths of the country, he says, are rocks and mountains. The mountains vary from 15,000 feet to 10,000 feet, except in the Hindu Koosh Range, where some peaks are over 20,000 feet.

If everybody in New-York and vicinity had visited the World's Fair it might not be worth the while of a newspaper to engage in the laudible task of putting it in the power of people to pleasantly learn in detail what the great exposition looked like. The statistics show, however, that but a small proportion of the Eastern people went to Chicago.

BUDA-PESTH, March 23 -- An immense crowd assembled in front of the Parliament House this afternoon, awaiting the issue of the debate in the Diet on the question of paying honors to the memory of Louis Kossuth. The police were present in large numbers, but they were powerless to preserve order.

Naval courts-martial are belies which move in a mysterious way. Long before daily newspapers began to chronicle their doings a regulation was framed which enjoined secrecy upon every member and ordered that witnesses be cautioned never to reveal any part of the testimony they gave. Members are still sworn to secrecy, and witnesses are admonished about the silence which is golden.
James Dolan of Watertown has prosecuted many hundreds of claims through the Pension Bureau. He explained in detail the method of procedure.

Naval men must be amused at the terrible explosions on paper caused to war ships as portrayed in the recent editions of "penny dreadfuls." A torpedo discharged from a torpedo boat is supposed to have blown Her Majesty's steamship Narcissus, a vessel of 5,600 tons, into twain, which ship "then plunged stern foremost into the sea, and with the union jack still flying, disappeared without a soul on board being able to save himself."
The claim agent has been responsible for a large share of the abuses which have grown up in the distribution of the pension money.

Experiments of the National Fish Commission in breeding foreign varieties of fish in the United States waters have been most interesting to fish culturists, if not altogether successful. Some of the European fish seem to thrive readily, while others will not take to the waters of the Eastern coast.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- If the Administration was subject to responsibility for all of the reports and surmises that have been set in motion by the changing of orders for Admirals Kirkland and Walker, it would have to fill a pretty big bill of sensations in order to make good all of the conjectures founded upon the sending of Admiral Walker to the Pacific.

Notwithstanding that yesterday was Good Friday, the indicted Gravesend officials did not have much time for religious meditation. They were chiefly employed -- such of them as were still out of prison -- in hunting for new bondsmen.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 23 -- Charles Rawn, eighteen years old, of good family connections, last Saturday night tried to set fire to the large hardware establishment of Steinman Co. of this city, where he was employed. He made a full confession, but could give no motive for his crime.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The House Committee on Agriculture to-day perfected the Hatch Anti-Option bill and directed Mr. Hatch to report it to the House favorably. The vote on the bill was 12 to 2.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 23 -- Mrs. Flora Hertzig, who some time ago was convicted of libeling Frederick Herbert, a young broker, by writing him letters claiming him as her husband, was this afternoon placed on trial before a jury as to her sanity. Prosecutor Winfleld produced 200 letters written by Mrs. Hertzig, in all of which she claimed Mr. Herbert as her husband.

OLEAN, N.Y., March 23 -- J.C. Emmons, a prominent druggist of Allegany, attempted to commit suicide at noon to-day at the residence of Mrs. George Blessing in this city. He had been at Mrs. Blessing's house several hours, and had frequently visited her before.

The unpopularity of the Paris concierge has been exemplified in a curious way. A M. Faucon, who owns a large house in the Rue Bellefond, in Paris, appointed a concierge, who soon got into hot water with the occupants of the various floors. Letters were delayed, it was said, and visitors were sent away when the people were in.

That hasty contract of Superintendent Hannan with the Cataract Electric Company, giving it the exclusive right to furnish power for a trolley system on the canals for fifty years, has awakened many and various suspicions. Any official act done in a hurry and in a half surreptitious way is open to suspicion.

NORFOLK, Va., March 23 -- Money Island, a suburb of this city, was almost entirely destroyed by fire to-night. A spark from the engine room of the Roanoke Lumber Company ignited the inflammable material and the fire soon destroyed the plant. The Old Dominion Creosotin Works next caught fire.

The appointment by the Pope of Cardinal Rampolla as Archpriest of St. Peter's, announced by The New-York Times Thursday, naturally caused excited comment everywhere, and The Moniteur de Rome, which habitually emphasizes reasons of the Vatican for complaining of the Italian Government, is doubtless accurate in the explanation which it gives of the appointment.

There is no doubt that there are pension abuses as well as abused pensioners, and that must of them can be traced to the disability law of June 27, 1890. So long as The Times or Commissioner Lochren confine themselves to the displacing of ablebodied men from the invalid pension rolls The Bulletin will commend their work.

Mary Galvin, forty-two years old, was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for trial on charges of assaulting her employer, Mrs. Frank P. Connolly of 136 West Fifteenth Street, and Estella Stevens.

There was some remarkably good shooting at the range of the Seventh Regiment last night, when the competition for the Abeel Trophy was concluded. The average all through the match is an improvement on former competitions, but it was the shooting of the team of Company F that made this the "blue-ribbon" shoot for this coveted trophy.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 23 -- The Captain of the steamship William G. Hewes of the Southern Pacific Line, which ar- rived here to-night from Bluefields, says the condition of affairs in Bluefields, Nica- ragua, when he left was as unsettled as ever. The English were still in control of the public protection of the city, and were, in fact, in practical control of the entire reservation.

"When a desperado gets the drop on you the only thing for a sensible man to do is to throw up his hands," said James Skaggs of Coffeyville, Kan. "To throw up your hands is no reflection upon your bravery out in the wild West. To attempt to draw your weapon when a man has pulled down on you is to invite a verdict of 'Came to his death for being a fool.'

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest the remarks in your issue of yesterday on the production of silver. It is, in my opinion, the moat impartial and the clearest exposition of the underlying causes why all attempts to maintain the value of silver which have been made during: the last twenty years proved failures.

William H. Dorris, collector for the Kings County Trust Company, who lives in a modest little house on Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, came near sharing the fate of Lyman S. Weeks and Christian Lucca, in that city, some years ago.

At Mollwitz the Prussians lost 18 per cent., the Austrians 28 per cent. At Kolin Frederick's force suffered to the extent of 37 per cent., while his victory cost his enemies only 14 per cent. At Zorndorf, the bloodiest battle of which we have any record that we may rely upon, the proportion of loss to the total forces engaged rose to the enormous total of from one-half to one-third.

LONDON, March 24 -- The draft of the Registration bill, which is about to be introduced in the House of Commons, confirms the impression which has lately obtained, that it is the intention of the Government to bring about a dissolution of Parliament next Autumn. The bill is a much briefer measure than was expected.

With a degree of vigor that showed how deeply they felt on the subject, the members of the National Christian League for the Promotion of Social Purity, at a meeting of the league yesterday, discussed the case of Congressman W.C.P. Breckinridge of Kentucky, who is being sued in Washington by Miss Madeline Pollard for breach of promise of marriage.
FALL RIVER, Mass., March 24 -- The cloth market has been firm and active during the week, and to-day the mill situation is much improved, as compared with that of two weeks ago.

Moses B. Harris had a narrow escape from death by a holdup's bullet while he stood behind the counter of his dry goods store early last evening. His life was saved by a gold badge no bigger than an ordinary coat button.

J.C. Palmer and L.T. Davenport shot a match at Larchmont yesterday. The conditions called for 100 birds each, Palmer 29 yards' rise, Davenport 30 yards' rise, 50 yards' boundary. The match was for a substantial stake. It was watched with considerable interest, as both men are good shots.

Russell B. Biddlecom is a man of prominence and wealth. He has investments in real estate and manufactures, and is reputed to be worth about $75,000. He is now a gentleman of leisure, but in his busy life of sixty-five years has been an active business man, a railroad organizer and trustee, and engaged in paper manufacture.

Ex-Justice Richard V.B. Newton sat in a barber's chair at the Kings County Penitentiary yesterday afternoon. A convict barber lathered his ruddy face and proceeded with the operation called at the prison a "Crow Hill shave."

Peter the Great said of his country, and said truly: "Russia is rotten before she is ripe." To realize the true meaning of these words and the fullness of their implication, one must study in detail the reigns of Elizabeth and Catherine II. In Russia, during the eighteenth century, were to be found side by side the vices alike of savagery and civilization.

James Caulfield, who was stricken blind by a flash from a Brooklyn trolley wire Thursday afternoon, has recovered his sight. The manner in which he regained his eyesight is almost as extraordinary as the way in which he lost it.

ALBANY, March 24 -- A story came from Troy on Thursday that a big deficit had been found in the books of the State Controller in the Tax on Corporations Department. This same story was circulated last Fall during the campaign. A correspondent of The New-York Times waited on Controller Roberts on Thursday and asked as to the truth of the matter.

Surely a little enthusiasm is allowable here. Never was there a volume which has caused so much controversy and argument. It has been measured up by eighths of an inch, counted in lines, reckoned by page, by letter, nay, even, by stops and omissions, and made the subject of thick treatises which try to prove it something different to what it is, and its author a myth.

An ignorant blacksmith having been elected Mayor of Oswego, the people of that city desired to amend their charter in such a way as to provide that the officers of the city should henceforth be chosen by a committee of citizens elected by the people. In vetoing Senator Mullin's bill thus amending the charter of Oswego, Gov. Flower says:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24 -- The Republican campaign managers have arranged for meetings from now until election evening. Roswell G. Horr. ex-Speaker Reed, and Gov. McKinley are among those engaged to speak.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- The trial that is to determine the mental condition of Patrick Eugene Prendergast, Mayor Harrison's murderer, announced for 10 o'clock this morning, was continued until Tuesday morning, owing to the absence in Hot Springs of A.S. Trude, who had been retained as counsel by the family of the late Mayor, and Assistant State's Attorney Todd, who conducted the original trial, being at present engaged in a murder case.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 24 -- The World, (Conservative,) commenting on Representative Chickering's retaliatory measure against Canada, which refuses Canadian railways the privilege of carrying goods in bond through the United States, says:

"Mrs. Jarley's Celebrated Wax Works" will, no doubt, attract many to Hardman Hall, at Fifth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, next Wednesday, because the entertainments are given to provide funds for the depleted treasury of that excellent institution, St. Michael's Home, Mamaroneck. There will be a presentation of the "wax works" at 3 P.M. and another at 8:30 P. M.
John Y. McKane's blind son, George N., yesterday issued a statement to the public, through the United Press, on behalf of his father. The statement was dated Sheepshead Bay. It is as follows:

AUBURN, N.Y., March 24 -- Theodore J. Kosters, a popular mail carrier, was arrested to-day on the charge of robbing the United States mails. Ever since last November complaints of losses of sums of money have been made at the local office, and suspicion seemed to point to Kosters. Two Secret Service detectives came here a month ago, but failed to fasten the crome on him.

The beauty of dress depends much upon the harmony of colors. This is affected by a combination of the three primaries, either pure or in combination with each other. Colors are modified in tone by the proximity of other different colors. By ordinary gaslight blue becomes darker, red brighter, and yellow lighter.

The New-York Times has started on a crusade which has as its object the exposure of fraudalent possessors of pensions for services in the late war. The Times gives arrays of facts, figures, and names which cannot be gainsaid. One disabled pensioner is shown to be the athlete of his native village.

A policeman found a tall, emaciated woman, with bare feet, and her soiled clothing tied about her waist with a tape, rambling on Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, a few days ago. She appeared to be demented, and was taken to the Classon Avenue Station House.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The City Improvement Society is aiming to have the sidewalks of the city put in good condition. With this view, we are causing the main streets and avenues to be examined by our own inpectors, and as it is impossible for us to do this thoroughly with the side streets we call upon the public to report to us cases of defective sidewalks in the same.

Some of the very choicest real estate in Potsdam is owned by the Ives brothers, Martin V.B. Ives and his brother Alien. Each has a fine residence. The new residence of Martin V.B. Ives, on Pierpont Avenue, with its well-kept lawn, spacious veranda, and plate-glass doors and windows, is pointed out to the visitor in Potsdam as an object of local pride.

Eleanor Holmes weaves a vast fabric of fiction, with innumerable entrances and exits and long suites of rooms. For the perfect understanding of the plan of it, you are obliged to explore the building from cellar to attic. Pearl Merryweather is the daughter of the Archdeacon of Fingall, and the Archdeacon, who is too busy a man to care for Pearl, confides her to a worldly female relative, Lady Dairymple.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- Philadelphia has taken kindly to association football, and the college experts who witnessed the game here to-day between the Cosmopolitans of New-York and All Philadelphia have given out the opinion that there is a future for the game in this country, and, while it is not likely to supplant intercollegiate football, it is sure to gain a foothold in the colleges.

The only new piece announced for Easter Week is the new Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, "Utopia, Limited," which will be presented at the Broadway Theatre to-morrow night by a company organized in England by D'Oyly Carte, manager of the Savoy Theatre, London, and agent of the composer and the librettist.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- There has been another test of cast steel shells at the Naval Proving Grounds, and the results fully sustain the excellent showing which has been made by this class of projectiles hitherto. Isaac G. Johnson, whose company at Spuyten Duyvil, N.Y., makes these shells, is in this city, and was present during the firing of two shells.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24 -- The Republican managers are going to make the fur fly next week about the State House. Orders have gone out that the general Republican programme must change. The basketful of partisan bills referred to in the polite Republican vernacular as "reform measures" are not to be rushed through the legislative mill and run through the Executive Department, and then to the Secretary of State's office.

"It would be clearly a breach of good faith on the part of the Government if the Seigniorage bill became a law," said ex-Gov. William R. Merriam of Minnesota to a reporter for The New-York Times, who asked him yesterday how he regarded the Bland bill. Mr. Merriam is at the Plaza Hotel.

Encouraged by the signs of an early Spring, the local tennis players are forming plans for a season of unusual activity. Work is going on at most of the courts, and it is expected that most of the earth courts will be fit for play within a fortnight.

The great establishments have set a standard of good, and humane treatment by which the London horse has greatly benefited. Better and larger stables, good food and litter, and steady work, with regular days of rest, have lengthened the life and improved the physique of the London horse. A good brewer's horse, standing 17.2, was weighed by Mr. Gordon and tipped the beam at just over the ton.

DENVER, March 24 -- The Supreme Court this morning bunded down a written reply to the question asked by Gov. Waite last week as to who are the legal members of the Fire and Police Board. The decision was by Chief Justice Goddard. It was substantially against the Governor.
Polling places as they are to be when the reins of government are not monopolized by the sterner sex are typified by the weekly receptions now being held at Sherry's on Saturdays.

A correspondent who signs himself "Pen" writes in reference to an account of the introduction of vertical writing in some schools, recently printed in The Times: "The gentleman whom your reporter interviewed labors under a grave misapprehension when he asserts that the slanting hand necessitates an 'unhygienic' position at the desk.

MASSILLON, Ohio, March 24 -- Nearly 100 recruits for Coxey's Commonweal Army arrived to-day from different points. Most of them are tramps who camped in the woods surrounding the town during the night. A number of them slept in the lock-up, but were rehersed this morning. Among the arrivals is lass M. McCallum, who represents Mrs. Lease, and who asked permission to have her address the army at Pittsburg, which Coxey refused.

Lorenzo Smith is one of the leading citizens of Gonverneur, well to do, well known, prominent in business and in politics. He is the proprietor of a livery stable. Some years ago he was Sheriff of St. Lawrence County. Since then he has been active in the party councils. He is a man of considerable property, and is even rated wealthy In the town where he lives.

Important disclosures are expected from an investigation to be begun this week by a special committee of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen. The committee was appointed several weeks ago by President Wallace on motion of Alderman Clark, who was named as Chairman.

Mr. Warner furnishes some pictorial illustrations to show what you can buy in England and in Tunstall neighborhood in the way of housefurnishing stuff, in order to supply a comparison with the figures sent in March, 1893, by Mr. Burgess. Mr. Burgess did not send any illustrations, but he sent his price list to show that everything in the way of furniture is more expensive in England than in the more highly-taxed United States.

The seventh annual exhibition of photographs will be held at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, in Fifty-seventh Street, from April 16 to 28, under the auspices of the Society of Amateur Photographers of New-York. The display will be a notable one. It will comprise the productions of the Society of Amateur Photographers of New-York, the Boston Camera Club, and the Photographic Society of Philadelphia and other American and foreign photographers.

Police Justice Patrick Divver is yet keeping close to his home, at 7 Madison Street, and still refuses to see any reporters and to discuss in any way the charges that some of his own followers in the Tammany Hall organization of the Second Assembly District have been making against him relative to the desertion of election workers when they got into trouble and the courts.

BOSTON, March 24 -- The paper manufacturing trade has caused a movement for a great national trust, to include all the mills. The plan is to form a fixed schedule of prices, which all members shall observe in selling their output. The schedule, it is proposed, shall go into effect upon the first day of next January.

To know good silk from bad is, the experts tell us, among the few things that are easier done than said. But here are a few simple rules, derived from the knowledge of one of these same experts, that may help to save the inexperienced from the goodly outside which so often falsehood hath in silk, especially black silk, the dear delight of the economist, the wildest extravagance of the spinster.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Senator Colquitt, through still very weak, rallied perptibly this evening, and his condition is so improved as to warrant renewed hope of his ultimate partial recovery. Yesterday hope had almost been abandoned, and the Senator's death was momentarily expected.

LONDON, March 24 -- The Times makes a strong protest against the action of President Peixoto of Brazil in reviving the imperial decrees of 1838 and 1851 authorizing the execution without trial of persons who have engaged in or aided and abetted a revolt. Aside from the danger that the revival of these decrees might be applied to innocent British subjects, The Times says: "Peixoto's own record is not sufficiently clean to justify such action."
ORANGE, N.J., March 24 -- The third and last of the Orange assemblies will be given in Music Hall next Friday evening.

It will be very interesting and instructive to note the effect upon British politics of the rumors of a projected "matrimonial alliance" between the Prime Minister of Great Britain and the granddaughter or his royal mistress. Certainly the rumor of the engagement has some plausibility, since it tends to clear up several opaque places in politics.

BERLIN, March 24 -- Count von Caprivi's speech at the dinner of the Danzig Bourse is the chief topic among politicians. None of the Berlin editors has yet found a conclusive interpretation of the Chancellor's mysterious words as to a coalition of the nations of Europe. The United Press correspondent obtained yesterday a statement on the subject from a high official in the Chancellerie.

The 6-15-99 Club is still keeping up its good work in relieving poor families. The appeal for clothing printed in The New-York Times last week has been responded to by many people, and a large number of donations have been received by the President of the club at his office, 145 Broadway.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article in a recent number of The Times on the name of the old battle ship Kearsarge is of more than ordinary interest to me. I was born in Warner, N.H., eighty-two years ago. and passed my girlhood in the shadow of old Kearsarge Mountain, familiar with all of the traditions of the locality.

Holy Week was devoid of musical incidents. The only thing that happened was, to use a Hibernian mode of speech, something that did not happen. Mme. Adelina Patti was to have given her positively last and utterly final farewell on Thursday afternoon, and she did not. It seems as if Fate had taken revenge on the "diva," as she is called.
With the advent of mild weather and the assurance of an early Spring, the canoeists in this city and the immediate vicinity are beginning to look forward to and prepare for an active season.

Senator Bradley was the only member of the State Senate committee appointed to investigate the affairs of the Police Department in this city to appear on time in the General Term room of the Court of Common Pleas at 10:30 yesterday morning. Senator Lexow came in shortly afterward, but it was after 11 o'clock when work was begun.

The success of King Richard Lion Heart, though not complete, was all the more remarkable. When he landed at Acre in 1191 he already had in his gift a kingdom nearly as large as that which King Gay had lost -- the Island of Cyprus, conquered by English soldiers sailing in an English fleet, which the Latins had never before attempted to take from its so-called "Emperor," Isaac Comnenus.

Bread, milk, butter, and cheese were the staple articles of food, bread being the chief. "A domestic was termed a man's 'hlafoetan,' or loaf-eater." A lady was a "hlafdig," a loaf-giver. Bacon was the principal flesh-food, and other meats were also salted. Hence boiling was the common form of cooking.

Walter Wadman is a very bad man, if his wife, Myra, is to be believed. M.r. Wadman contents on the other hand, that he is a much-abused husband, the victim of a sister-in-law's malice. Judge Giegerich of the Court of Common Pleas will determine who is right in adjusting a divorce suit which Mrs. Wadman has begun.

Exactly fifty years to the month have passed since Capt. Siborne first published this standard work on those events in the field which led to the overthrow of Napoleon. He then called it a "History of the War in France and Belgium in 1815, Containing Minute Details of the Battles of Quatre Bras, Ligny, Wavre, and Waterloo."

Over twenty years ago the Home for British and American Young Women was founded in Paris. Miss Leigh, whose name is known throughout the world in connection with the institution, has been the wife of a Canadian Archbishop for some years, but has never lost her interest in nor stopped her labors in behalf of the work whose pioneer she was.

Not many notable sales of real estate, either at auction or by brokers, were reported during the past week. The auction offerings were especially few in number. Such as there were obtained fair prices.

Daniel J. Whitney of Gouverneur was a private in Company C. New-York Cavairy. He received a gunshot wound in the shoulder while in the service. He was a good soldier, who always did his duty so far as record or tradition goes to show. When he reached home, after the war, he had no thought of a pension.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 24 -- Easter Sunday promises to be the banner day of this season at this resort. Two hotels, the Laurel House and the Laurel-in-the-Pines, have turned away people for the past week, and the largest hotel in the village, the Lakewood, already well filled, promises to be crowded over Easter.

Charles Heaton is a jeweler and watchmaker in Potsdam, and has a well-stocked store on a principal street in a building left him by his father. At the other end of the same street stands his snug residence, with stable and lawn. Mr. Heaton is worth about $25,000, which makes him a rich man in Potsdam.

On the maps of Scotland the name of Galloway is given only to the small southeastern peninsula of Wigtounshire, which, indeed, is the extreme southeasterly point of the whole country, but to all Scots Galloway means all of Wigtoun and all of Kirkcudbright as well, and there is a legend that in the olden times it included a much larger extent of country.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 24 -- The case of Frances A. Dimmick against J. Alden Weir, as executor, was tried before Justice Charles F. Brown in the Supreme Court, Chambers, to-day. The plaintiff is the daughter of a deceased hotel keeper of Milford, Penn. The defendant is a New-York artist, the executor of the will of Henry Ten Broeck Grmmage, who died two years ago, leaving 250 paintings.

Folk-lore stories impress the public in different ways. There are readers and students. The first search for what may be interesting and amusing; the second throw entirely aside what gives pleasure, and are only bent on the discovery of certain analogies between the folk-lore just presented to them and the folk-lore derivable from far or remote parts of the world.

NEWTOWN, L.I., March 24 -- A trolley wire charged with a strong current of electricity routed the Deputy Sheriffs guarding the Bridge over Newtown Creek, at Grand Street, Maspeth, to-day. It was a short, sharp fight, and ended in a complete victory for the railroad men.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24 -- The annual dinner of the Commercial Club of this city is always a notable event. The club, which embraces i nits membership all the substantial citizens of the place, always invites some gentleman prominent in the commercial affairs of the country to make an address.

Those whose flesh is strong but whose spirit is weak, can generally advance with success through a world of pretense. Appearance, untried, is the equal of efficiency, and a sense of fitness will make way for the qualities which prudence can counterfeit. But a virile temper in a frail tenement admits of no conditions of easy living.

An immense crowd collected in the vicinity of Madison Square Garden last night. It was there to witness the start of Barnum Bailey's annual parade. Sidewalks were blocked and doorsteps were at a premium.

Competition for the egg of the Great Auk offered yesterday at Stevens's Auction Rooms proved very keen. It is believed that there are but sixty-eight specimens of this egg in existence, and the bird itself, it is to be feared, is extinct. It was met in the Orkneys down to 1812, and the very last survivor of its race perished, it is thought, on one of the islands off the coast of Iceland in 1844.

The bee is but one of several plagues that have to be set off per contra in the ledger of Terai joys. The fly is another -- that common nuisance which infests the Terai country as an entomological anomaly -- i.e., a house fly where houses there are none.
The naval court-martial, which is trying Commander Heyerman, who commanded the Kearsarge, for the loss or that vessel, resumed its work in the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday.

One of the most unique circles of King's Daughters is that which has its chapter house in the Home for Aged Colored Women in Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. Not a member of the circle is under seventy years of age, and its venerable President, Aunt Jane, whose name the circle has taken, has loitered in this vale of tears over 101 Winters.

PART XI. About the middle of June Carroll resolved to leave Southmeadow and go abroad. He staid three days Ii his New-York house before departing, and when he had come to town notified Channing of his presence there. But almost his first words to his friend were these:

A speech of unusual interest and significance was made by Chauncey M. Depew, President of the New-York Central and the West Shore Railroads, at the recent meeting of the Presidents and Managers of the Trunk Line Association. The demoralization of rates, both passenger and freight, was the theme of the eloquent speaker's remarks.

A prominent grocer of Watertown to whose resources the Government contributes is George McComber. He does an extensive wholesale and retail business in the McComber Felt Building, a substantial business structure on a principal street, and owned by Mr. McComber and his son-in-law.

No one could walk abroad through the last week and not be conscious of some stir in the city. The shops have been gay with Easter favors and Easter buyers, the florists have vied with each other in their display of blossoms, and trying on Easter bonnets at the milliners has been as prevalent as practicing Easter anthems in the churches.

Martha J. Fuller's death by shooting in William M. Mullen's law office in the Nassau Chambers Building on the 17th inst, remains a mystery. The police did little in the case yesterday except to serve subpoenas for the inquest and to clear up the latest "rumors" and "clues."

Mayor Schieren is evidently a match for the mischief-making Aldermen. They have not been able, so far, to fret him in the slightest degree. Their latest attempt to embarrass him has fallen flat. When the resolutions approving the "side-door" bill at Albany were prepared, the members who supported them undoubtedly hoped to annoy the Mayor.

The foreign exchange market displayed a tendency to ease. Posted rates for sterling were $4.88 for sixty-day bills and $4.89 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.87 @ $4.87 1/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.88 1/2 @ $4.88 3/4 for demand, $4.89 for cable transfers, and $4.86 1/4 @ $4.86 1/2 for commercial.
Le Peuple, a dally paper published at Port au Prince, Haiti, in its issue of March 8, publishes the following account of the arrival of the steam yacht Natalie from NewYork via Savannah:

After B.B. Taggart had resigned his Captaincy of Company K of the Tenth NewYork Volunteer Heavy Artillery, then in garrison duty along the Potomac, Philander B. Grant became Captain. During the term of his service the regiment, orat least that part of it in which he served, did some fighting, and Capt. Grant made a good record.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- In the trial of the Pollard-Breckinridge case objection was made last Thursday by counsel for Miss Pollard to evidence contained in depositions presented by the defense concerning Miss Pollard's age, conversations regarding her had with James C. Rhodes, who paid for her education, and with reference to her conduct before she became acquainted with Col. Breckinridge.

In Summer the caribou feeds chiefly on common plants; it is especially fond of a broad-leafed grass, growing in wet places and around the barrens which are so numerous in various places in the interior of New-Brunswlck. In September you will find them on these barrens, feeding on the reindeer moss, (Cladonia rangiferina,) of which they are very fond.
Some of the wealthiest men in the communities where they live are pensioners.

Music and flowers have been lavishly provided by the churches of all denominations for the celebration of Easter to-day. The musical programmes in some of the churches are very elaborate, and the decorations exceed in beauty those of former years. At Old Trinity, St. Patrick's Cathedral, St. Thomas's, the Church of the Ascension, the First Presbyterian, St. Stephen's, and many other churches the programmes are especially inviting.

All the Lushal smoke inveterately, even children of five years of age, and their clothes reek with rank tobacco smoke. The men use short pipes made of bamboo: the women use a more elaborate one, the bowl of clay communicating by a stem with a receptacle for water, through which the smoke passes to a long, slender mouthpiece of ornamental metal.

For a time it might indeed have seemed as if Mohammed was but the founder of a new Jewish or Christian sect. Not only did he distinctly represent the religion which he preached as the old religion of Abraham, but he spoke of the Old and New Testaments as the Word of God, and he spoke of Jesus in even higher terms than of Abraham.

"There is nothing about a residence plumbing system," says an authority, "that a child may not understand, and there is ever reason why a housewife should be able to make her own periodical inspection of all the fixtures in her home." There is a great deal of bad plumbing throughout the land, especially in private dwellings built some years ago, where inspectors have hesitated to intrude.

The ceremonial bathing in the Ganges forms the great morning act of worship, and the bathing ghats belong to different races, so that each pilgrim band possesses an accredited status in the holy city. Long flights of crumbling steps descend from the towering shrines to the water's edge.

It was recently announced that the new catalogue of the Yale Theological School indicated a distinct liberalizing tendency in the courses of study at that institution. It was said that courses formerly regarded as indispensable by the exponents of conservative orthodoxy had been dropped or relegated to the elective list, and that their places had been taken by others more modern in their scope.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Tunstall, England, has had two American Consuls since President Cleveland was inaugurated. The first was William Burgess of NewJersey, who was appointed by President Harrison in 1890. The second, who was appointed by President Cleveland, is Wendell C. Warner of New-York.

The Seventy-first Regiment will occupy its new armory. Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, on Saturday afternoon of March 81. This new building (one of the most magnificent and solid structures of its kind in the United States) will also be the headquarters for the First Brigade Staff. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald commanding. The Second Battery will also be provided with quarters.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Everything to-day that was active was strong and higher. West Chicago and North Chicago, Lake Street, Alley "L," and Diamond Match were all active. There was considerable short covering, but there was more investment buying. Shorts filled in on West Chicago.

LENOX, Mass., March 24 -- The prospects for the coming season are quite as good as usual. There are many applications for good cottages to lease for the Summer, and nearly all who own cottages here will occupy them. Building operations have been active all Winter on the Stokes, Sloane, and Cook places.

A match at live birds between G. Coulston and "Chris" Meyer was decided at Woodlawn on the grounds of the NewUtrecht Gun Club yesterday. After the match several sweeps were shot, in which ex-Champion J.R. Elliott of Kansas City and C. Furgueson, Jr., took part.
The trouble existing between the employes and the officers of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company has been amicably settled. The strike threatened will not take place.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 24 -- Augustus A. Brush, ex-Warden of Sing Sing Prison, who was stricken with apoplexy yesterday at his house in Hopewell Junction, recovered consciousness and talked a little this afternoon. There are slight hopes of his recovery. He had a similar attack about a year ago.

Philenzo Norton is one of the well-known residents of Watertown. He owns property worth about $10,000, and receives a yearly salary of about $1,500 from the Jefferson County National Bank, where he is head bookkeeper.
Mayor Gilroy, his wife, and six children, returned home last night from their extended Western trip. The Mayor left New-York three weeks ago yesterday, his family having gone three weeks before.

H.A. McGlenen, for many years the business manager of the Boston Theatre, died in Boston yesterday morning. He was well known throughout this country as one of the most genial and efficient men in the theatrical business. His death was a surprise, as he was supposed to be in fairly good health.

The Sheriff's office in Kings County is a gold mine. Its occupant is a nabob. His annual income exceeds that of the President of the United States. His remuneration is five times as large as the salary paid to the Governor of New-York. The Mayor of Brooklyn gets only about one-sixth as much as the Sheriff.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 24 -- A severe windstorm began late last night, and the wind has kept up at a high rate all day, sometimes reaching a velocity of sixty miles. It is from the northwest and very cold. The mercury has fallen 20 within the past twelve hours. To-night the storm shows no signs of abatement, and it is becoming a genuine blizzard.

It is almost worth all the vexation and bother that the passage of the Bland silver-inflation bill has inflicted to have the evidence of the past week as to the growth of sound financial opinion in the South and West. These sections have been claimed as the home of the inflation sentiment.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The House to-day, in Committee of the Whole, discussed the Postal Appropriation bill for four hours. Two items only disclosed any general difference of opinion -- the appropriation of $196,000 for special and necessary facilities on the trunk lines from Springfield, Mass., to Atlanta and New-Orleans, and the allotment of $20,000 for experimental free rural delivery.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- The statement of claim in the suit brought by Terence V. Powderly against James R. Sovereign, the General Master Workman, and the General Executive Board of the knights of Labor to recover a balance of $3,818.11 as back salary for the services rendered by Powderly while General Master Workman, was filed in Common Pleas Court No. II. to-day.

Sixty years ago New-Orleans was what it still is, the most picturesque and romantic city of the United States. It had features peculiar to itself. The African, not many years removed from the banks of the Congo, still danced and sang the songs of his native land in Congo Square, under the light of the Southern moon.

"As sure as eggs is eggs," said a member of the New-York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, quoting a common expression, "we are going to have the largest sale of Easter eggs this year that this city, or any other city, has ever before seen. We shall beat the record of the world. The entire country seems interested in the business, and is sending the poultry product here for sale and distribution."
Each Consul has an opinion about the cost of clothing. Mr. Burgress, in his report, says:

Senators Hill and Murphy, who opposed the nominations of Hornblower and Peckham because they were not strict Democrats, are now engaged in an enterprise that, in the full view of all the Democrats of the State, puts to the test the sincerity of their professions and the strictness of their Democracy.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- J.W. Ady of Kansas, the Republican who is contesting the seat of John Martin in the United States Senate, left for home to-day. This was the last day in which evidence in the case could be submitted, and Mr. Ady filed the last of his papers several hours before the limit expired.

Peter J. Ames of Ogdensburg is one of the richest men in that city. He has made his money in the liquor business. He owns the largest wholesale liquor store in the place, and there la a bar attached where the goods are sold at retail. This store is a two-story frame building at 64 and 66 Isabella Street.

Neither Oxford nor Cambridge is strong in fiction, but Cambridge possesses two names of the first rank, Sterne and Thackeray. The majority of our great novelists graduated in the rougher school of the world, and probably acquired there a better equipment for their work than any university could give them.

Harriet Decalyo was acting very strangely at One Hundred and Tenth Street and Madison Avenue Thursday night when a policeman passed. She had with her a bright-eyed little girl of five, and the woman was kneeling on the stone flagging. Her head was bowed and her hands were uplifted, and she was prayine fervently.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The following is the full text of the Chinese convention agreed upon March 17 and sent to the Senate as a confidential document March 19:

As has already been stated in The Times, the series of trials for violations of the election laws, and offenses connected with these, in the town of Gravesend will probably come to a close this week. They leave the representatives of the people in complete and signal triumph.

Patrick Commiskey, who was serving a two and a half years' sentence in the Kings County Penitentiary for attempted burglary, and who had only six months more to serve, escaped from that penal institution yesterday afternoon.

Of all the pensioners in the city of Watertown, the first and foremost in point of wealth and prominence is the Hon. Byron B. Taggart, paper manufacturer, bank Director, corporation and steamboat magnate, landlord, prominent politician, ex-Mayor, and semi-millionaire.

A novel swindling scheme came to light in Harlem on Saturday night, through the arrest of a bright-looking; little woman, who said she was Alice Webster, twenty-eight years old. She refused to tell Detectives Foy and McCabe of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station, who arrested her, where she lived.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 per cent, throughout the week.

W. Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker met at the Union Square Hotel Saturday afternoon to contest the fourth game of their chess match for the championship of the world and $2,000 a side. The room in which they played was crowded to its utmost capacity, and the spectators greatly enjoyed the game, which was opened by Steinitz with a Giuoco Piano.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 25 -- There is no truth in the story sent out from Pittsburg that Gov. Pattison has issued orders to certain organizations of the Second Brigade, National Guard, to hold themselves in readiness to repel the threatened invasion of the State by Coxey's Commonweal Army. The Governor thinks the Pittsburg police force is abundantly able to handle the invaders.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 25 -- After a good deal of deliberation on the part of the Faculty it has finally been decided to abolish the course in letters and again raise the requirements for admission to the university; and also to place some restrictions upon the methods of elective work in the junior and senior years in the other courses.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 25 -- Prince Besolow, the African Prince, who is a member of the class of '97 in Williams College, has received a call from his people in Africa to return to his native land and take possession of the kingdom, which heretofore has been under the control of an uncle.

CANTON, Ohio, March 25 -- Coxey's Army of Commonweal moved out of Massillon today on schedule time, there being perhaps seventy-five stragglers in line at the start, and twenty-five less when Canton, eight miles away, was reached. Carl Browne, Chief Marshal, headed the procession, mounted on a white horse, and was followed by a half-dozen aides, all mounted on horses belonging to Coxey.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Bonks issued on Saturday showed an increase in reserve of $1,775,350. The banks now hold $79,077,639 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans of $2,516,300, an increase in specie of $69,400, an increase in legal tenders or $2,755,700, an increase in deposits of $4,190,000, and a decrease in circulation of $65,900.

Dodd, Mead Co. have just published a catalogue of Americana, in which is included an autograph letter of Nathan Hale of unusual interest. Autograph letters of Hale are among the scarcest existing manuscripts of the Revolutionary period, and they are as costly as they are rare. Only three, including the present one, have been offered at public sale, so far as known.

Eight young men entered a Sixth Avenue elevated train at South Ferry about 9 o'clock last night and began to sing ribald songs and swear. There were many ladies in the car, and they became frightened. Guard Henry C. Campbell of 11 West One Hundred and Fifteenth Street tried to quiet the young men, but without success.

The Rev. Father A. Lambert, the exRedemptorist priest who recently left the Roman Catholic Church, made his first public address since he left his old faith at Christ's Mission, 142 West Twenty-first Street, at 8 o'clock last night. About 153 people were present.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Without a dissenting voice, and in a spirit of cordial sympathy with the proposition, the House of Representatives has passed the bill to protect the insignia and the name of the Red Cross Society.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- If President Cleveland were to decide the fate of the Seigniorage bill to suit the preferences of a majority of the members of Congress, he would certainly approve it, but his approval would be secured for political reasons alone, not because he was convinced that it was wise or sound to sign it.

Lemuel Ely Quigg, Congressman from the Fourteenth District, was in this city yesterday. He came from Washington Saturday, and, after engaging a room at the Windsor Hotel, he went on a hunt for William Leary, manager of Mr. Quigg's recent campaign, to whom he wished to submit a report of his doings in Congress up to date.

A dinner was given on March 6 by the British Empire Club in honor of Ambassador Bayard, at which Arthur H. Pollen, a prominent young London barrister, had many pleasant thing's to say of America in proposing the health of the club's guest. Mr. Pollen has often visited this country, and has an immense admiration for everything American.
There was no special Easter service at the Central Park Baptist Church yesterday morning. It was postponed, of necessity until last evening.
Although the weather was threatening rain early yesterday morning, a large crowd went down to Gravesend to catch a glimpse of the Brooklyn Jockey Club Handicap horses at work.

The marksmen of the Seventh Regiment are shooting so well with the old fifty-bore rifles, and showing such continuous improvement in competition, that when they get the improved thirty or thirty-two calibre magazine ritie, "highest possibles" are expected to be the rule, instead of the exception.
Prof. Richard L. Garner, who went to Africa to increase the world's information about simians, was a passenger by the steamship Etruria, which yesterday arrived from Liverpool.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 25 -- The Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the Congregational Tabernacle, this evening gave, as the prelude to his sermon, a political discourse entitled "The Day of Judgment Has Come." Mr. Scudder was particularly severe upon what he denominated "ruffian politics at Trenton."

From The Rochester Union, March 24. Miss Martha J. Fuller, whose mysterious death in New-York last Saturday has been the sensation of the week, had many friends in this city, where she frequently visited. She was a guest of Mrs. Edwin McKnight of 31 South Goodman Street last June. She was related to Mrs. McKnight by marriage.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Game bill, which passed the Assembly on Wednesday, consists of a number of amendments to the game law, grouped together into one bill by the Committee on Fisheries and Game of the House. No objection was made to its consideration, and it passed without a dissenting vote.

Worcester oarsmen want the big Eastern regatta held at Lake Quinsigamond, and with that object in view a proposition will be made to the New-England Rowing Association at its next meeting. It will be an offer to contract for the Spring regatta of tHe association for a period of five years and to hold it on Lake Quinsigamond either on Decoration Day or the Fourth of July, as the Worcester people may elect.

ALTOONA, Penn., March 25 -- W.S. Confer, who conducts a general store at Bens Creek Station and is besides Postmaster and Adams Express agent, was robbed this morning. Six masked men got upon a back roof immediately under the window of the room occupied by Confer, his wife, and some of his children, and began firing with revolvers through the window into the room.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Whenever a serious breach occurs between the newspaper correspondents and some prominent member of the Legislature, some one of the superserviceable upstarts who enjoys temporary notoriety by virtue of the fact that he is drawing a salary at the people's expense, immediately starts a movement to put the newspaper men on duty at the Capitol in the gallery.

To judge from the attendance during the first three games, the championship chess match between W. Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker is creating a widespread interest, and deservelly, because of the high quality of the games hitherto contested Of course errors were committed by both players; still they were not of a palpable nature, and it required the skill of a Steinitz or a Lasker to make use of them.

In the Bureau of Pensions at Washington the reports of The Times's inquiry into the frauds and abuses under the pension laws are followed with close attention. An officer of the bureau declares that the method of investigation we have employed is practically the only one through which conclusive evidence of fraud can be obtained.

Inequalities in the distribution of pensions are subject of common complaint among old soldiers. A few statements as to the methods of carrying on business which Commissioner Raum enforced will show that these inequalities were inevitable.

From The Atlanta Journal, March 22. There was a regular old-fashioned stump speaking at Griffin yesterday. Fully a dozen counties were represented by delegations which had come to witness the first tilt between the two candidates for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 25 -- Late advices from Blueflelds say: "The English war ship Cleopatra has been relieved by the Canada, and the marines from the Cleopatra have resigned their positions as city police to the marines of the newly-arrived English cruiser. Lacayo is still in command of the reservation, and the establishment of a Government is on an absolute standstill.

HOMER, Ga., March 25 -- J.F. Willis was killed last week by his daughter Lillian and his wife. The news of the tragedy did not leak out for several days, when a son, Francis, eleven years of age, told it to some neighbors. The daughter and mother were arrested, brought to Homer, and given a preliminary trial.

One hundred spectators saw the first round in the chess match between New-York and Brooklyn on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Chess Club. Kach side was represented by twelve players. Among the competitors for the local club were J.W. Showalter, E. Kemany, and H.G. Voigt of Philadelphia, and K. Hymes of Newark. while H.N. Pillsbury, Philip Richardson, A. B. Hodges, F.M. Teed, and William De Visser were the backbone of the Brooklyn club.

WEST POINT, March 25 -- Out-door drills and exercises, which had been suspended during the Winter months, have begun again. These consist of cavalry, artillery, and infantry field practice. The lower classes are first instructed in the "setting-up" exercises. The higher classes are drilled in cavalry tactics. Dress parade, which was also suspended during the Winter, takes place every evening on the parade grounds.

Despite the threatening aspect of the weather the Music Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, was crowded yesterday morning by members of the Society of Ethical Culture and their friends to listen to Prof. Felix Adler's lecture on "The Belief in Immortality."

The Committee of Thirty, which is trying to reorganize the Republican Party in this city, will make an effort to undo the Platt-Milholland wing of the party this week. The campaign they propose to make has been the result of considerable study, accompanied by some anxiety.

PARIS, Mi-Careme -- A new kind of carpet was invented to-day on the boulevards. The confetti made a velvet soft to the feet, picturesque to the eye, and novel even to the most advanced taste. Paris never does anything half way, and the Mi-Careme of 1894 will point and illustrate many a grandma's future tale.

D.M. was a private in Company M of the Fourteenth New-York Volunteer Heavy Artillery. His application for a pension was filed Aug. 7, 1890, and his certificate was issued Nov. 6, 1891, granting him, from the former date, $10 per month, $2 less than the full rate. His disabilities are "left varicocele, disease of heart, liver, and spleen."

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The joint commission appointed to investigate the personnel of the navy has examined Admiral Walker, Lieut. Colwell, Lieut. Stanton, and Ensign Key, all officers of the line. Secretary Herbert notified the commission that he desired to make some modifications to the bill he had previously submitted, and he was requested to be present Thursday next, at which time Commodore Ramsay will also appear.

Madison Square Garden swarmed with clowns, bareback riders, magnificent horses, brilliantly-clad foreigners, and wild animals last night. The arena was like a kaleidoscope, changing in colors with such rapidity that it tired the eye to watch it. On a platform was a gorgeously-uniformed military band, and on all sides were life and animation.

BERLIN, March 25 -- Chancellor von Caprivi has had his inning and has won. The heaviest burdens of Ministerial work have now devolved upon the shoulders of Dr. Johannes Miquel. In the coining sessions of both Landtag and Reichstag the l'russian Finance-Minister will lead the Government's advance guard against a powerful opposition, embittered by its recent defeat at the Chancellor's hands and roused by the new tax bills to increasing activity.

The defeat of Harry wheeler, the American fast rider, in France caused no end of comment in bicycle circles here. It was thought that he would win all his match races at the French capital with ease. One account of the race says that Wheeler's defeat was accomplished by superior riding, and was owing in no way to undue advantage in tactics or position.

The new Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, was dedicated yesterday morning with imposing ceremonies. The formal dedication was immediately after the sormon, which was preached by the Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler of Brooklyn, who officiated at the morning service, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Charles A. Stoddard, the Rev. Dr. Thomas Lyle of Belfast, Ireland, and the Rev. Dr. Francis H. Marling.

John Delmore, forty-eight years old, of 502 East Eighty-first Street, a veteran of the civil war, was shot and killed yesterday afternoon either in the saloon of Thomas Hunt, at the northwest corner of Avenue A and Seventy-ninth Street, or in the hallway in the rear of the saloon. Several persona saw William Powers, alias "Bull" Powers, twenty-eight years old, an East River dock watchman, running away.

"It is time to prove that a great principle should rule in affairs of religion, in order to put an end to absurd quarrels and to appease all minds. The Government will be inspired in its policy as to religion by this higher principle of toleration and liberty, which it will apply in a new spirit."

ALBANY, March 24 -- There was a little more activity to the local security market this week. This was due to the revival of the Investment demand. The feature of the market was the strength In both bank stocks and railway bonds. First National Bank stock advanced 5 per cent, to 165, a sale having been made at those figures.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 25 -- Although Yale closed its Winter term last Wednesday and 2,000 of the members of the university immediately departed for their homes, the 'Varsity and freshman crews, the freshman baseball nine, and about twenty of the leading candidates for the track athletic team remain here to train for the season, which has been prematurely ushered in by the delightful weather of the last fortnight.

A number of women of the United States, feeling that it was a national reproach that no suitable testimonial existed to the memory of the mother of Washington, organized the Mary Washington National Memorial Association, their purpose being to erect a monument. Though they encountered many unexpected difficulties and embarrassments, they have continued to labor devotedly in the cause, and have made gratifying progress.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24 -- During the past week a better feeling has shown itself in the local stock market. There have been a number of sales at good prices and all stocks are in better demand, while the offerings still continue light. American National Bank has sold at 47, and is in good demand, with 46 1/2 freely bid.

A committee composed of representatives of Hungarian societies met at Liberty Hall, 257 East Houston Street, last night, to take action concerning the death of Louis Kossuth, Marcus Schnitzer, President of the Hungarian Society of New-York, presided at the meeting, and there were present Joseph Grossner, Morris Cuckor, Ignatius Wellner, George Pohr, E.O. Gottlieb, and a number of other well-known Hungarians of this city.

Mrs. Barbara Miller died at her home, 648 German Place, in the annexed district, Saturday, in such circumstances that the police are making a searching investigation. Her husband, George Miller, has been arrested on suspicion of having caused his wife's death by poison. The charge against him is made by his son.

MASSILLON, Ohio, March 25 -- Coxey's army was organized last night. In the afternoon and evening a lot of tramps, cranks, and a few men who doubtless would work if they could find work, arrived here from various parts of the country and placed their names, or names that they claimed were theirs, upon the registration slips provided by Chief Marshal Browne.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 25 -- There is general rejoicing at Yale over the material addition to the endowed professorships of the university through the liberal bequests of the late Richard S. Ely of Avon, Conn. Mr. Ely died recently in New-York City, and by the provisions of his will three scholarships, amounting to about $100,000, are left to Yale.

So popular has basket ball become at the Young Men's Christian Association that its admirers have resolved not to abandon their favorite sport with the close of the indoor season, but to continue the game in the open air. A fine basket-ball court, with all the requirements, is now being prepared at the association grounds at Mott Haven.

Mrs. Dana's excellent volume of a year ago, telling us how to identify the wild flowers, has enjoyed a popularity somewhat better proportioned to its merits than most good books obtain. We have not at hand the figures which show the many thousands that have been called for, but the record must considerably exceed that of the most popular novels of the day.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Notwitstanding the active preparations being made by the navy and the Revenue Marine Service for establishing an unusually large patrol force in the Bering Sea and in the Northern Pacific to protect the seals from poachers, there is little doubt that diplomatic negotiations will render most of the preparations unnecessary.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 24 -- The pastoral changes to be made in the New-Haven District of the New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at the annual session in April will not be as general as in past years. There are only two five-term pastors at present in the district -- the Rev. W.A. Richard of Birmingham and the Rev. A.J. Smith of St. Andrew's Church, in New-Haven.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- There are strong probabilities of a new international monetary conference being called together, this time on the invitation of the Republic of Mexico. The last conference, which met in Belgium, and was called by the United States, adjourned subject to the action of the Government that called it together.
Charles Leonard Fletcher, who styles himself "Director of the Fifth Avenue Theatre School of Acting," and who for several months has been living in Brooklyn, disappeared several weeks ago.

From The London Daily News. A case heard the other day before the Kupyansk Court, in the Government of Kharkoff, goes to show that the custom of selling wives still obtains among the Russian peasantry. In this instance, a peasant named Maxim Litvinoff sold his wife, a young woman of twenty-five years, to his bachelor neighbor, Kalina Lukyanoff, for 160 rubles.

CANNES, March 25 -- Capt. Wilton, an aeronaut, went up in a balloon to-day from a spot near the seashore. After ascending about 1,500 feet the balloon was caught in a strong wind and blown seaward. Wilton opened the valve, but apparently was unable to close it, as he neared the surface of the water.

A few members of the Capitol City Club of Washington, D.C., an organization which is famous for its whist experts, are going to make a flying trip to this city to-day, and in the evening a match game will be played with the Knickerbocker Whist Club, at the latter's rooms, in the Hotel Wellington Annex, Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street.

RED BANK, N.J., (March 25 -- The indications are that the coming season will be one of the liveliest ever known in these parts for yacht racing. A number of new yachts are being built, and the owners of the old vessels are getting them in readiness for racing. Most of the old yachts will have new racing rigs.

The growing popularity of Columbia Law School and the increasing opportunities which it offers to earnest students have determined the Trustees of the college to make an important increase in the teaching force of that department. The Faculty has heretofore consisted of four professors of law, whose work has been supplemented by the services of several lecturers upon special topics.

The seclusion of the Hon. Patrick Divver remains unbroken, save by the visits of his confidential friends and his "lawyer," The statement which his son reported him to be "setting on" has not as yet been produced. It is possible that his legal adviser has given him the counsel, not uncommon in such cases, to "say nothing."

Martin Kenny, sixteen years old, of 325 East Fifty-fourth Street; Henry Jordan, fifteen years old, of the lodging house at Forty-fourth Street and Second Avenue, and John Murphy, sixteen years old, of 225 Bast Fifty-fourth Street, were held by Justice Koch in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for examination as suspicious characters.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 25 -- Wesleyan students are rejoicing over the liberal action of the college Trustees at their annual meeting Friday. On the recommendation of the Faculty, the Trustees voted that hereafter astronomy, geology, and physiology shall be elective for juniors, and the Constitution of the United States for seniors.

The President is said to have shown some impatience at the argument presented to him by some of the advocates of the Bland bill on Saturday, that if he vetoed that measure the Republicans and the Populists would in several States unite successfully against the Democrats and probably reduce the latter to a minority in the next Congress.

Six of the ten days during which the President may retain a bill passed by both houses of Congress before reaching a decision as to what course he will pursue have now elapsed since the Bland bill was sent to Mr. Cleveland. It is reported from Washington that he will probably delay until Thursday, the 29th, which is the last day.

NEW-YORK. Monday, March 26 -- A.M. Steadiness, with an undertone of confidence, was the characteristic of the market last week. The strength was due to the almost universal belief that President Cleveland would veto the Bland bill. London bought more freely than usual, and its purchases caused foreign exchanges to weaken, the danger of gold imports being thereby lessened.

Richard V.B. Newton, late Coney Island Police Justice and swaggering prize fight manager, awoke yesterday morning in a small stone-walled room, with whitewashed sides and ceiling and an iron-grated door. It was probably the smallest room he had ever passed a night in and the most gloomy.

The Central Office detectives are in possession of what is believed by them to be a clue in the case of twelve-year-old Susie Martin, whose dismembered body was found in the cellar of 517 West Thirty-ninth Street.

The Columbia College baseball team opened the season with the Southern colleges last week. The team starts in with better prospects for a successful season financially and otherwise than has been had for many years. This year there are members on the team from almost every department of the university.

CONCORD, N.H., March 24 -- When, two weeks ago, Col. W.S. Pillsbury of Derry, heretofore generally regarded as a leading candidate for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, announced his withdrawal from the canvass it seemed as though Ramsdell of Nashua was destined to have a pretty clear field in his campaign for that distinction.

EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio, March 25 -- John W. Martin, Treasurer of Columbiana County, has confessed to a shortage in his accounts of over $8,000. The shortage may amount to more. Estimates, based on statements of persons in official positions, make it as high as $75,000. The deficit in the County Treasury was discovered by an examining board.
Redmomd, Kerr Co., in their bond letter of Saturday, say:
