If we were asked to what particular class of Christians or Jews this volume is addressed, we should say only the cultured of both creeds. As it must be conceded that higher culture is not general, the power of appreciation can be only limited. The volume being an appeal directed to a minority it might be scarcely understandable to the majority.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- "Have we reached the maximum appropriation for pensioners?" This question was addressed to Representative Black of Illinois, who for four years held the office of Commissioner of Pensions under the former Cleveland Administration.

For a nation supposed by the rest of the world to possess at least that amount of cleverness that is indicated by the word 'cute, we Americans have a singular fashion of buying a pig in a poke. We permit architects unknown and untried to design gigantic Federal buildings all about the Union, and give our Legislatures license to stuff the Senate of the United States with cranks, loose fish, and old fogies.
The handsome edifice of the Temple Israel, Bedford and Lafayette Avenues, Brooklyn, will be the scene of a unique entertainment during the present week. A "Kirmess and Flower Fete" Is to be held.

From The London Daily News. At the Bicetre Hospital, in Paris, the well-known surgeon M. Landry has performed a curious operation on a workman of Belgian nationality. The Belgian sot drunk a short time ago, and was taken to the police station at Gentilly when in a state of utter helplessness.

SING SING, March 25 -- The annual town elections in Westchester County take place Tuesday. The only exception is in the town of Mount Vernon, where the Supervisor was elected last Spring for two years.
Silver bullion certificates were not quoted during the week.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Chairman Springer of the House Committee on Backing and Currency does not believe any bill to repeal the 10 per cent. State bank tax can pass through this Congress. He says:

MONTREAL, Quebec, March 25 -- It is predicted that a concerted move will be made soon by the Roman Catholic Bishops of Quebec in connection with the Manitoba school question. The Bishops have been studying the question, and have decided to issue a joint pastoral letter dealing with the school question in Manitoba and throughout the Northwest.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 25 -- The second of the series of lectures in the Spencer Trasit lecture course was delivered before the students and residents of Princeton on Monday last by F. Hopkinson Smith.
The end of the prosecution of the Gravesend election conspirators has been reached. By to-night the doors of the penitentiary will probably have closed on the bulk of the gang.

WATKINS, N.Y., March 26. -- Attorney General Hancock, who is in Watkins to-day attending Supreme Court, in an interview made the following statement in relation to the corporation tax rebate sensation at Albany:

The Kearsarge court-martial drags along. That spectacular body met yesterday forenoon, pursuant to its adjournment of Saturday, but, contrary to expectation, it did not finish the work before it, and consequently there will be one more day's session before the case is ended.

It is clear that the public mind in all parts of the country has now settled down to the conviction that a veto of the Bland bill will be sent in. Those who have been most strongly opposed to a veto, as well as those who have urged one, have ceased pressing their views upon the President.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

A large bronze casting of the figure of a Confederate soldier from the waist down, for the Sailors and Soldiers' Monument which is to be unveiled in Richmond, Va., next May, was made in the works of the Henry-Bonnard Bronze Company yesterday. The height of the statue will be 10 feet and its weight 5,600 pounds.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Montifiore Isaacs of New-York entertained an audience of 700 or 800 this afternoon at Metzerott Hall with a performance of sleightof-hand tricks. Richard King of New-York accompanied Mr. Isaacs, and acted as his assistant throughout the performance. Mrs. Bissell, who occupied a seat in one of the boxes, took an active interest in the entertainment, and was among the number of those who chose certain cards, and once lent her ring.

LONDON, March 26. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times, in reference to the recent utterances of Chancellor von Caprivi, which are assumed to indicate that Emperor William is enleavoring to bring about a relation of the military expenditure of the powers, says:

This is the jubilee year of the New-York Yacht Club. Fifty years ago next July the club was organized on board the Gimerack, when that yacht was at anchor off the Battery. Seven yachts, the entire squadron of the club, then started on a cruise up the Sound. Every year since that time the yacht squadron has cruised, and nearly all the cruises have been to Newport and to the eastward.

--Likenesses of Actors. -- The publishers of The Illustrated American have issued, as the first of a series, a handsome quarto pamphlet entitled "The Gallery of Players." It contains twenty-two full-page portraits of well-known actors and singers, including Booth, Irving, Jefferson, Barnabee. Macdonald, Eugene Cowles, Mansnfield, Modjeska, Ellen Terry, and Ada Rehan.

The beautiful apartments of Mrs. Daniel Youmans, at the Madrid, 180 West Fifty-ninth Street, were the scene of a pleasant reception and testimonial to Miss Phoebe Couzins. the first woman admitted to the bar in the United States.

ALBANY, March 26. -- The Senate Railroad Commission will give a hearing on Friday afternoon at 2 o'clock, at the Chamber of Commerce, in New-York City, on a proposed law prepared by the commission doing away with grade crossings of steam railroads.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- At the Schiller Theatre to-night a new farce called "Charley's Uncle " was produced. This is the piece which made a hit at Terry's Theatre, London, as "The Noble Arl." The motive is decidedly original, the exercise of that mysterious force, hypnotism, contributing to secure several excessively comical situations between the principals of the cast -- Charley's uncle, Charley, his wife, and a decidedly bright and attractive young lady, Charley's sister-in-law.
About 150 members of the St. Nicholas Society held their annual dinner at the Waldorf last night.

The inquest to determine how Martha J. Fuller, Lawyer William M. Mullen's stenographer, came to her death by a pistol shot wound in the Nassau Chambers Building on March 17 was begun yesterday by the impaneling of a jury by Coroner Fitzpatrick. Testimony will not, however, be taken until next Monday. The jury are:

CHICAGO, March 26.--Operators in wheat have been disappointed so frequently in their expectations of a freeze-up that the Government indications of Saturday were quite generally disregarded. Those who put faith in them were, however, rewarded in a substantial gain at the opening to-day, without the worry and anxiety incident to an uncertain and irregular advance.

ALBANY, March 26. -- While the friends of the Democratic machine are vociferous in their remarks that "there is nothing in the probing Controller Roberts is giving the administrations of his predecessors," more or less concern is manifested over disclosures that may be brought forth, and the effect upon the election next Fall.

There seems to be very little basis for the sensational report put out by a former clerk in the office of the State Controller about what have been called "defalcations" in that office. The present Republican Controller is not likely to cover up any real delinquencies on the part of his predecessors, and the statement which he has made public sets at rest most of the alarming reports.

The plant of the United Electric Light and Power Company, at the foot of East Twenty-ninth Street, was seriously damaged by fire yesterday, and the lighting of the district extending from Fourteenth to Fifty-ninth Street, and from river to river, was interfered with slightly. The fire, which started about 9 o'clock A.M., resulted from the burning away of the insulation of the wires at the main switchboard.

The evangelistic revival meetings still engross much of the attention of religious people in this city. Yesterday two large eetings were held by the evangelists working with the Central Committee to Bvangelistic Work, one in Association Hall at noon and the other in Niblo's at 3:30 P M.

BERLIN, March 26. -- The police this morning discovered a large red flag on which was inscribed in white letters "Lebe Anarchie, Hoch Revolution." suspended from a wire which extended from the roof of a house in Holzmarkistrasse across the Spree to Engeiufer. A large crowd gathered in the vicinity and watched the efforts of the police to remove the flag, commenting freely on the occurrence.

The police of Troy has undoubtedly been exhibited in a very unfavorable light, not only in connection with the frauds perpetrated at the late election, but in connection with the inquiry into the murder of Robert Ross. It seems to have been infected through and through with the depravity of Murphyism.

ALBANY, March 26. -- The unusual spectacle is afforded in Albany of the Democratic Governor of the State and the two Democratic United States Senators combining with the Republicans to destroy the regular Democratic organization of Albany City and County. The offense with which the organization is charged is a refusal to join the discredited machine, which was smashed at the polls by the people last Fall.

DENVER, Col., March 26. -- The rebuke of Gov. Waite by the Supreme Court last Saturday was not equal in severity to the decision of Judge Glynn in the District Court this morning on the proceedings for contempt instituted by Police Commissioners Martin and Orr under the writ of injunction issued by Judge Graham against Mayor Van Horn and the new members, Mullins and Barnes.

If every ex-soldier of the war of the rebellion had the same temperament, the same degree of honesty, the same disposition as regards the question to work or not to work, and had started with the same degree of physical strength, then the pension law of June 27, 1890, might have been enforced with some equality as regards the beneficiaries of that act.

William B. Hornblower was the principal speaker at a meeting of the Presbyterian Union of this city in the banquet hall of the Hotel Brunswick last evening. The attendance was unusually large, as it had been announced that Mr. Hornblower would speak on "The Integrity of the Suffrage Vital to the Existence of the Republic," and that he probably would touch upon Tammany Hall and its methods.

To the Editor of New York Times: As a war veteran, having entered the service in May,1861, I desire to thank The New-York Times for the noble stand it has taken to purge the pension roll of fraud and to make it what it should be a roll of honor. But politics has controlled it by the influence of money sharks called pension agents.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The term of Mr. Colquitt as a Senator of the United States from Georgia, began March 4, 1883, and would have ended March 4, 1895, that being the close of his second term. Gov. Northen will be called upon to fill the vacancy by appointment, and of course, the successor to the vacancy will be a Democrat.

ALBANY, Mo., March 26. -- A panic was created in the Circuit Court room this morning when Frank B. Earl and Jacob Miller, two brothers-in-law, drew pistols and began firing. Miller was defendant in a divorce suit, and he accused Earl of causing the trouble.
Easter elections for Wardens and Vestrymen were held yesterday in many Protestant Episcopal churches in this city and vicinity. The results are given herewith:

It is expected that the seven five-cent restaurants operated by the Industrial Christian Alliance will be kept running up to June 1, and in order to insure their maintenance, a reserve fund of $6,000 has been established. The combined daily receipts of these restaurants average about $300, and this sum just covers expenses.

The production of a new operetta by Gilbert and Sullivan is always worthy of serious consideration, because, whether the attempt of the co-laborers be successful or not, it is sure to be artistic. Mr. D'Oyly Carte of the Savoy Theatre in London attempted some time ago to produce a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta in New-York by proxy.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., March 26. -- As Miss Elsie Tice of this place left her home last night. Intending to call on her grandparents before attending church, she was seized by a man who sprang upon her from behind a tree. She fought her assailant as long as her strength lasted, and then she cried for help.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26. -- The local stocks have been very strong all day. The advances promised and predicted in Philadelphia and Metropolitan have been fulfilled more quickly than the Street looked for. On comparatively light transactions, Philadelphia sold up to 103 1/2 and Metropolitan to 108, and both closed strong, with very little stock for sale.

TURIN, March 26. -- The arrivals of Hungarians to pay respect to the memory of Kossuth increase daily. Every train brings hundreds of these members, and it is estimated that at fast soon of them will be present at the funeral services, which take place here Wednesday at 2.30 A.M.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., March 26. -- A large number of men and boys, who had been seal hunting on the ice near the shore Saturday, were carried out to sea by drifting ice. All but nine of the hunters escaped in the course of the night by swimming ashore. Of the nine two boys froze to death; the others were rescued this morning.

Some life was injected yesterday into the investigation which the Senate committee is conducting, bearing' upon the affairs of the Police Department of the city by the examination of Morris Tekulsky, President of the State Liquor Dealers' Association. It made Senator Daniel Bradley, the Lone Fisherman of the committee, smile, but it did not add very much to the Senate committee's store of knowledge.

James McGay of 61 East Fifty-fourth Street, who died on Sunday of pneumonia, was born in 1815, near Cookstown, in the North of Ireland. He came to New-York in 1836, and at once engaged in business with his brother, the late Isaac McGay, who preceded him to this country by about three years.

BOSTON, March 26. -- Some activity was shown in local stocks to-day, and the market generally was strong. The shorts that still remain in West End Street Railway were squeezed again, the stock advancing 2 /34 points, to 51 3/4, closing at 51. The recent fluctuations in this stock are so evidently manipulated that it is a safe thing for conservative investors to let alone at present.

The "Divine right" of Kings covers a good many extraordinary privileges, one of which seems to be the right to leave one's Heaven-granted dominion to take care of itself in the midst of a grave crisis. King Leopold of Belgium has evidently made a study of the limitations of the Divine right, and has concluded that it invests him with the privilege of doing about as he pleases, irrespective of the interests of his people.

TRENTON, N.J., March 26. -- Gov. Werts returned to the House Bill 106, with his objections thereto. This bill repeals what is known as the Guttenberg race-track Justice of the Peace law. That law gives persons arrested the right to a hearing before the nearest magistrate. It was framed and enacted for the benefit of law violators at the Guttenberg track.

Dr. Henry C.F. Mayer's trial before Recorder Smyth, for the alleged poisoning of Ludwig Brandt, alias Baum, was set down by Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, to take place on April 12. Meyer was in the prisoners' pen, in the rear of the courtroom, and was not arraigned at the bar.

LONDON, March 26. -- The breakdown of Cloister, who was the favorite for the Grand National Steeplechase, which is to be run at Liverpool on Friday, has resulted in his being scratched for that event. The horse has been examined, and his kidneys were found to be seriously affected.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 26. -- The committee which is investigating the methods by which William J. Thompson was elected to represent the Third District in the New-Jersey Assembly had a curious experience to-day with a witness who called himself James C. Smith. He said he voted at the last election from race-track stable No. 2.

LONDON, March 26. -- The Lancashire Handicap Steeplechase, over a three-and-a-half-mile course, for a purse of 3,000 sovereigns, of which 2,000 sovereigns and a cup valued at 200 sovereigns goes to the winner, 500 sovereigns to the second, and 200 sovereigns to the third, and 100 sovereigns to the fourth, was run at Manchester to-day.

Mayor Schieren's promised appearance at the Cooper Institute mass meeting to-morrow night has awakened lively interest in Brooklyn. His consent to address a gathering under the auspices of the New-York Republican Committee of Thirty is regarded by well-informed observers as a declaration of hostility on his part toward the leadership of Thomas C. Platt.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Representative Hainer of Nebraska, one of the members of the House Agricultural Committee, says there is no doubt, in his mind, that the Anti-Option bill will pass the House.

WATKINS, N.Y., March 26. -- F.L. Taylor, the Cornell student who on March 23 refused to testify before the Grand Jury at Ithaca in the chiorine-gas case and was sent to jail by Judge Forbes for contempt, was before Judge Smith of the Supreme Court, in watkins, this afternoon, on a writ of habeas corpus.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 26.--The six corset factories in this city report an unusually good line of trade for this season of the year. Altogether, these concerns employ about 4,000 operatives in a season such as the present. Mayer, Strouse Co. started with over 500 employes, after six months ed to-day on regular time, with over 500 employes, after six months of half-time.

A bill is pending in the Legislature which fixes the salary of the Sheriff of this county at $15,000 a year, and requires the fees of the office to be paid into the Treasury of the city and retained there. It is a bill that ought to become a law, so as to complete the process of putting an end to the evils and abuses of the fee system, which was begun ten years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The answer of Secretary Herbert to the resolution asking for information respecting the imposition of a fine against the Carnegie Steel Company for failure to furnish armor plate in accordance with the terms of its contract was laid before the House to-day, and referred to the Committee on Naval Affairs.

BUTLER, N.J., March 26. -- Prof. Claude A. Wiseman has been reinstated Principal of the Butler Public School, and took charge again this morning. A little over a week ago he was tried by the School Trustees on a charge preferred against him by Miss Lillie Haycock, one of his pupils, of unbecoming conduct.

The property owners in Seventy-first Street, west of West End Avenue, have determined on an improvement which is to help the value of realty materially on the block. The street, as is well known, forms a cul-de-sac, ending at a stone wall. To get out persons have to retrace their steps to West End Avenue.

CANTON, Ohio, March 26. -- When the sun rose on Camp Lexington this morning not a soldier of the Commonweal Army was visible. The cold weather had driven them all out of their big teat during the night. Fifty-eight of them weat to the police station, where they were given lodgings on the cold stone floor.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Secretary Lamont and his wife, Quartermaster General Batchelder, Dr. Bryant and his wife, and Capt. George W. Davis, the Secretary's aide, left Washington this morning in a private car for a tour of inspection of some of the army posts in the South. They will make their first stop at Fort McPherson, near Atlanta, Ga.

A wedding gift for the daughter of J. Pierpont Morgan, the banker, will reach its intended owner with special interest attached to it, apart from its intrinsic value and the good-will of its donor. Mr. Morgan was summoned to the Custom House last Friday, where Collector Kilbreth showed a package addressed to him.

Smallpox is spreading in Brooklyn. The health authorities have declared the disease epidemic. They have taken extraordinary precautions to prevent the spread of the contagion, which has been rapidly gaining on the during the past few days.

William T. Zell, the defaulting Treasurer and Secretary of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company, and Treasurer of the New-York Athletic Club, whose disappearance from this city in January last was a great surprise to the officers of the company which he had robbed, walked into Police Headquarters yesterday and surrendered himself to Superintendent Byrnes.

The competition for the prize of $50,000 offered last December by the Metropolitan Traction Company for a system of street railroad motive power superior to the overhead trolley system and equally cheap in respect to operating expenses is likely to result in the substitution of an underground trolley system on some of the company's lines.

TRENTON, N.J., March 20. -- Nearly fifty bills were introduced to-night in the House. Among the most important was one by Assemblyman Eisele of Essex County, to create a Court of Parole, to be independent of the Court of Pardons, but to include the same officers, with the keeper of the State Prison as an ex-officio officer.

ALBANY, March 26. -- By common consent, the Non-Partisan Election bill of Mr. Lexow (Rep., Rockland,) was put over in the Senate to-night until a week from tomorrow. A general opinion prevailed in the Senate that before the week was out an understanding would be reached between Mr. Platt and the Committee of Tairty in New-York, by which all existing differences would be overcome and a satisfactory solution reached.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The trial of the Pollard-Breckinridge case dragged wearily to-day. It was a day of depositions, mostly intended to establish an alibi on behalf of the defendant as to certain dates testified to by the plaintiff.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 26. -- A petition made by a committee representing about $2,000,000 of the $8,000,000 bonds of the Savannah and Western Railroad to remove H.M. Comer as receiver of that road was heard before Judge Don A. Pardee here today. The case is pending in the Circuit Court for the Middle District of Alabama.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Senator Colquitt of Georgia, who was stricken with paralysis for the second time about a week ago, died at his home in this city at 7:10 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The trial of the Pollard-Breckinridge case dragged wearily to-day. It was a day of depositions, mostly intended to establish an alibi on behalf of the defendant as to certain dates testified to by the plaintiff.

The National Sangerfest, which will begin its musical festival in Madison Square Garden on Saturday evening. June 23, has now assumed gigantic and Interesting proportions, Mme. Materna has been engaged as one of a large number of vocal soloists, and Maud Powell as one of the instrumentalists. An enormous orchestra of the best musicians, under the combined direction of Heinrich Zollner and F. Van der Stucken.

The one thing with which the Republicans of this State seem to be perturbed this year is Plattism. But for that their prospects would be rather promising, at least from their own point of view. There is no mistaking the fact that the Democratic Party is suffering from a reaction, which may last, and the effects of which are not unlikely to last, over the Fall elections.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- New-York Biscuit was unusually active. Something like 1,500 shares were handled, an amount which is considered phenomenal during this stagnancy in industrials. Yesterday it was freely offered at 39, while to-day it found a host of takers at 39@40. There was no special reason, so far as could be learned, for the advance, and the general impression was that the stock was receiving support from the insiders.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Judge Knapp of the Inter-State Commerce Commission appeared before the Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce this morning and addressed that committee for two hours and a half. In a general way, he favored Mr. German's bill providing for pooling, but thought it ought to be amended in some respects.

PEEKSKILL, March 27 -- Walter D. Cole. Democratic candidate for Overseer of the Poor; Lew B. Travis, a Republican worker; Abram Field, and John Lynch were arrested at the town election here to-day charged with bribery. They were released on $500 bail by Judge Barton to await the action of the Grand Jury.

"Evening Dress," one or the so-called "farces" that Mr. Howells occasionally contributes to monthly periodicals, was acted, or, to say better, performed, (for the verb "to act," in a dramatic sense, implies more than good actors can do with such a thing as this,) at the Empire Theatre yesterday afternoon as an item in a special entertainment given for charity.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Brig. Gen. Palmer C. Ricketts of Troy, Engineer in Chief on the general staff, took his resignation in his hand and practically threw it in the face of Gov. Flower to-day. Gen. Ricketts is the director of the largest educational institute in Rensselaer County. He could not, however, submit to action taken by his chief, Gov. Roswell P. Flower.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.}

ALBANY, March 27. -- Gov. Flower has sent the following answer to the request of the Troy Committee of Safety that he (the Governor) designate the Attorney General to have full charge of the elections prosecutions in Troy:

LONDON, March 27 -- The distinguished African explorer, Commander Verney Lovett Cameron, was fatally injured by being thrown from a horse yesterday, and died a little more than three hours later. He was hunting with Baron Rothschild's staghounds at Soulbury. In Bedfordshire, when, his horse becoming unmanageable, he lost his seat and fell heavily to the ground.

ALBANY, March 27 -- In spite of the efforts of a number of New-York representatives, Mr. Sheffield (Rep., New-York,) to-day advanced his bill in the Assembly with reference to the removal and appointment of heads of departments in New-York City. The bill was in the order of second reading on the calendar.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Gray Casey, daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Silas Casey, to the Rev. Clarence Wyatt Bispham, rector of St. Michael and All Angels' of this city, took place at noon to-day in St. John's Church. The Right Rev. Bishop Paret officiated. The church was decorated with palms and there was a profusion of lilies and white blossoms within the chancel.

ALLIANCE, Ohio, March 27 -- The Coxey army reached Alliance at 12:50 to-day, hungry, cold, tired, but enthusiastic. It is spending the night here in Camp Bunker Hill. It came here from Louisville, fourteen miles away, where the privates slept last night in the Town Hall, Coxey and his aides comfortably lodging in a hotel.
YONKERS, N.Y., March 27 -- The municipal election here to-day resulted in a Republican victory. Capt. John G. Peene (Rep.) was elected Mayor over John Kendrick Bangs (Dem.) by 207 majority.
Horace F. Burroughs, "merchant and wholesale lumber dealer " at 136 Water Street, is apparently a gentleman with a "pull" of no mean dimensions, even if it is rather expensive.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Cincinnati, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and the Raleigh, at the Norfolk Navy Yard, sister ships, will not go into commission as soon as anticipated. There was some talk of placing both on the active list by April 2, but the date is now postponed until the 15th.

Two women, two men, and a boy were arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on trivial charges by Detective Hay of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station. All of them declared that Hay was intoxicated when he arrested them, and that he beat, kicked, or otherwise illtreated them.

Broooklyn permanent water bonds, asphalt repavement bonds, and sewer bonds, aggregating $493,000 in value, were sold yesterday by Mayor Schleren and Controller Corwin at premiums which showed that the present administration has already secured the confidence of the business men.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Secretary of the Interior to-day disbarred M.D. Eills of Worthington and Indianapolis, Ind., from practice before the Interior Department and its branches. Ellis conducted a concern entitled "Union Comrade Company," and charged an admission fee of $1 to pay the cost of securing restoration to the pension rolls of the names of persons dropped through rulings of the present Administration.

Arrangements were made yesterday by the General Passenger Agents of the railroads in the Trunk Line Association to restore rates to their normal condition and put a stop to irregularities which have been rapidly tending to demoralize passenger business both east-bound and west-bound. There was a very full representation of the trunk line passenger departments, every road being represented except the Ontario and Western.

The suit by which William R. Laidlaw expects to mulct Millionaire Russell Sage in $50,000 because, Dec. 4, 1891, in the Arcade Building, he "Didn't' resist his gentle pressure" and was forced to become Mr. Sage's aegis when Henry L. Norcross threw a dynamite bomb in Mr. Sage's office, was advancd a stage yesterday before Judge Patterson, in the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Congressman Dunphy presented to-day another North River Bridge bill, which he expects to substitute for the one now pending. It embodies all of the four amendments which were submitted to the original bill while it was in the Commerce Committee by Representative Quigg.

ALBANY, March 27. -- The special committee appointed to examine into election frauds resumed its hearing of the Troy election cases to-night. A large number of witnesses testified to alleged irregularities in last Fall's election. Several witnesses related the exploits of one "Red" Moen, who voterd on several names in several districts in the Tenth and Thirteenth Wards.

LONDON, March 28 -- A dispatch to The Daily News from Buda-Pesth says: "The prospects are that quiet will prevail during the funeral of Louis Kossuth. The better Independents have organized a body of volunteer constables, mainly students, to co-operate with the police.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala,, March 27. -- In reply to Gov. Jones's telegram of inquiry, Senator George F. Hoar has answered that he did write a letter to Albert Clarke, Secretary of the Home Market Club of Boston, indorsing Reuben F. Kolb, conglomerate candidate for Governor of Alabama, and stating that Kolb was with the Republicans in spirit.

HAVANA, March 27 -- The wrecking steamer Orion, which sailed from Boston March 13 for Roncador Reef for the purpose of saving the stranded war ship Kearsarge, has arrived here. The Orion reached Roncador Reef at 5 o'clock last Thursday morning, March 22.

The freight steamship State of Georgia, which sailed from Aberdeen on March 4, arrived in port yesterday, more than a week overdue. The vessel encountered that field of ice which has been drifting across the path of the transatlantic mariners, and when she emerged from it, after a four days' imprisonment, both of her bow plates had been stove in.

LONDON, March 27. -- The Lincoln Spring meeting opened to-day with the Lincolnshire Handicap of L1,000, added to a sweep-stakes of L20 each, for three-year-olds and upward. The weather was fine and the attendance good. The race was won by Baron Rothschild's four-year-old Le Nicham. Mr. Daniel Cooper's Juvenal (five years) was second, and Sir J. Blundell Maple's Macready (five years) third.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Here is an instance of the sort of fraud with which the Commissioner of Pensions has to deal in his efforts to purge his rolls," said Secretary Morton this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- The marriage of M. Jules Patenotre, French Ambassador to the United States, to Miss Eleanor Louise Elverson, daughter of James Elverson, publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Golden Days, and Saturday Night, took place this afternoon at Mr. Elverson's residence, 2,024 Walnut Street.

NUTLEY, N.J., March 27 -- Three hundred boys and girls thoroughly enjoyed themselves this afternoon at the amateur circus, and this evening a great crowd of their elders laughed at the antics of amateur clowns, applauded the fancy riding, bareback feats, ground and lofty tumbling, trained dogs, and all the other things that go to make up a first-class circus.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- In accordance with a resolution passed by the Senate, Vice President Stevenson to-day forwarded by mail the following to the family of the late Hungarian patriot, Kossuth, at Turin, Italy:...

It must strike all disinterested readers as very curious that Mr. Sheffield's bill, empowering the Mayor of New-York summarily to remove the heads of departments, should have been supported by the Republicans in the State Assembly, and opposed by the Tammany Assemblymen.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 27 -- The Springfield Daily Republican to-day observed its fiftieth birthday by the publication on its new press of a twenty-two-page number, several pages of which are devoted to a history of the growth and progress of the paper and the community in which it has wielded for half a century so great an influence.

Among the arguments that were urged upon Mr. Cleveland against the veto of the Bland bill there was one which not only appeared very strong to those who pressed it, but which they were confident would prevail with the President. It was that in the policy of the Administration and in the legislation of the Democratic Party there should be "something for the West."

The auditorium of Niblo's Garden was filled to overflowing again at the evangelistic revival meeting yesterday. The first gallery held at least 100 persons who could no find seats down stairs. So successful have the meetings in the theatres been that next week the noon meetings will probably be held in Niblo's Garden instead, of in Association Hall.

William T. Zell, the former Secretary and Treasurer of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company, who disappeared a few months ago, just before it was discovered that he was a defaulter, was brought before Justice Ryan in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning, charged with having forged a check for $6,000 on Aug 4, 1893.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 27 -- In the Dominion House of Commons this afternoon, G.E. Foster, Minister of Finance, commenced the delivery of the budget speech. The house was crowded, and the keenest interest was manifested, as important tariff changes were expected.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 27. -- In the Court of Sessions this morning, Mrs. Josephine Whitney of Marlborough begged Judge Clearwater to release her husband. William R. Whitney, from jail. Whitney, who is a son of one of Marlborough's most wealthy and influential citizens, was committed a few days ago for refusing to support his wife.

CATSKILL, N.Y., March 27 -- At the Catskill charter election to-day the Democrats elected their candidate for Village Trustee for the first time in nine years. The remainder of the ticket was divided, and, for the most part, very close.
It was fortunate for John Y. McKane, Richard V. B. Newton, and Kenneth F. Sutherland that their cases were disposed of before the Gravesenrt Election Inspectors agreed to turn State's evidence.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

WEST POINT, March 27. -- That the cadets are still hopeful of a game with Annapolis is shown by their selection of Graves, who trained Lehigh's team last year, for their coach. Mr. Graves's work for Lehigh was very satisfactory. His system of training is entirely different from that practiced by Laurie Bliss.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The funeral of the late Senator Colquitt of Georgia took place in the Senate Chamber at 9 o'clock this morning, occupying only three-quarters of an hour, after which the Senate adjourned till to-morrow. The services were of the simplest and most impressive character, consisting only of a prayer by the Chaplain of the House, a short address by the Chaplain of the Senate, and the benediction.

Senator Colquitt's career was distinguished by no great achievement, but it is of large exemplary value in contemporary politics, since it shows how a public man may go fatally wrong in discarding sound and settled principles to take up fantastic popular whims in order to get the favor and the votes of the light-headed multitude.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, March 27 -- P.M. The market to-day was even less active than yesterday. Sugar was almost neglected, and closed unchanged at 90. The only stocks which were at all active were St. Paul, Reading, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, and Lead. Pt. Paul held its own. Reading lost 3/4, Whisky declined 5/8, and Lead advanced 1 1/4.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Expert testimony to prove that Madeline Pollard made the advances which resulted in the long intimacy between Col. Breckinridge and herself was the feature of the breach of promise suit to-day.

Those people in this city who are proprietors of what are commonly called "dives," where men and women get intoxicated together, will learn with Interest that the Excise Board has begun to revoke saloon licenses for places of this sort, and has a long list of resorts of the kind on hand.

The Police Commissioners yesterday investigated the charges which they ordered Superintendent Byrnes, to make against Capt. William R. Haughey of the Twenty-second Precinct. More than usual interest was felt In the trial on account of the position the Superintendent occupied in connection with the complaint.

The headquarters of the New-York State Democracy of the Second Assembly District at Worth and Mott Streets were so crowded last night at a public meeting that many could not obtain admittance. Vice Chairman T.F. Driscoll presided.

The Police Commissioners yesterday investigated the charges which they ordered Superintendent Byrnes, to make against Capt. William R. Haughey of the Twenty-second Precinct. More than usual interest was felt In the trial on account of the position the Superintendent occupied in connection with the complaint.

The headquarters of the New-York State Democracy of the Second Assembly District at Worth and Mott Streets were so crowded last night at a public meeting that many could not obtain admittance. Vice Chairman T.F. Driscoll presided.

MACON, Ga., March 28. -- The body of Senator Alfred H. Colquitt was buried in Rose Hill Cemetery here to-day with impressive ceremonies. The body arrived here in a special train over the Central Railroad, accompanied by the Congressional Committee. Gov. Northen, with a detachment of the Governor's staff, and a portion of the Fifth Georgia Regiment, joined the party at Atlanta.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Judson Lawson of New-York, having read that the ensign of Hungary would be placed over the City Hall in memory of Louis Kossuth, amended his American Flag bill in the Assembly to-day so as to prohibit the flying of any foreign flag or emblem over any public building in any city or town of the State.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- Of late some of the industrials that have been almost dormant have become prominent. Milwaukee Brewing preferred and common were conspicuous, 2,000 shares changing hands at 34 and I7 3/4 @ 18, respectively. The other stocks were generally firm. West Chicago and Lake Street monopolized the interest in railroad shares.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 28. -- Judge Hudspeth of the General Sessions Court was in an exceedingly angry frame of mind this morning, when he issued a capias for the arrest of Ernest Wolfe of Hoboken. Wolfe is a professional purveyor of bondsmen for unfortunates who cannot furnish security for their appearance in court.

NEW-YORK. Wednesday, March 28 -- P.M. While to-day's market as a whole was not active, the buying was unusually good, and was not confined to any particular group of stocks. There was some irregularity in the morning, but as the day advanced srtrengrth became the feature, and it continued up to the dose of business.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 28. -- The annual meeting of the State League of Republican Clubs took place here to-day, and this evening the league held a public meeting in Exposition Hall, which was addressed by Gov. McKinley of Ohio. The Governor arrived in the morning, and was a hero from the time of his arival until he went to bed.

An enormous canvas painted by Louis David, the acknowledged head of the classical French artists during the first quarter of the present century, is shown by Sypher Co. in a vacant shop at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifteenth Street. The scene is the coronation of Napoleon I., but the artist chose that part of it when Napoleon placed the imperial crown on the head of his new wife, the Austrian Princess.
The indictments for forgery and grand larceny against Horace F. Burroughs, the Water Street lumber dealer, were not dismissed yesterday.

ALBANY, March 28. -- Senator Saxton has thrown additional safeguards around that section of the Penal Code relating to elections. By the stupidity of the Statutory Revision Commission, which was supposed to have codified the election laws, corruption could have driven a four-in-hand through various divisions of its work.

Yesterday's sales of realty at auction were numerous and exceedingly well attended. The Trinity Building salesroom, where all except one took place, was crowded, so that moving about was very difficult. Eight auctioneers were selling at the same time Twenty-nine separate pieces of property were disposed of, and the aggregate of the sales was more than $500,000.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The President was not ready to-day to send to the House his message disapproving the Bland bill "to authorize the coining of the seigniorage and for other purposes," but it is ready, and it will reach the House to-morrow or Friday. The friends of sound money have hoped for this, and the advocates of extended silver coinage under the objectionable provisions of the Bland bill have feared this adverse result.

It is at the first sight rather curious that Spain, which is politically and intellectually one of the most backward of European countries, should be that one in which Anarchism should be most formidable. Upon second thought it is not curious at all, but quite what is to be expected.
There has been some doubt about the real purpose of Baron Erlanger's visit to this country. The following authorized statement explains the situation very clearly:

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Secretary Herbert had no additional news to-day about the failure of the Boston Tow Boat Company to win the thirty-five thousand-dollar premium for bringing the Kearsarge into Norfolk, beyond that in the United Press cable from Havana, except a brief dispatch from Lieut.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Col. Breckinridge wall take the stand to-morrow, unless the unforeseen should happen, to testify in his own behalf against the accusations of Madeline Pollard. To-day several witnesses for the defense were examined, and nearly all the remaining depositions were read, leaving only a few of the latter to be disposed of.
Frederick E. Edgar, for nineteen years discount clerk of the Tradesmen's National Bank, 291 Broadway, is short in his accounts nearly $17,000.

Capt. Ward, Fuller, Davis, Doyle, Stafford, Connor, Wilson, Tiernan, Clarke, Westervelt, and Burke of the New-York Baseball Club were hard at work practicing on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. A raw wind swept across the vast inclosure, making outdoor work anything but comfortable, but the Giants were prepared for this.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The Executive Committee of the National Democratic Committee to-night gave a reception at its headquarters in the Wormley Hotel Annex. About 400 invitations were sent out -- to the President, Vice President, members of the Cabinet, Senators, and Representatives in Congress, heads of the various bureaus in the executive departments, and prominent Democrats outside the city.

The court-martial of Commander Heyerman of the Kearsarge, who was charged with culpable neglect in allowing his vessel to run on Roncador Reef Feb. 2, was concluded yesterday afternoon, and the papers were sent to Washington. It may be a week or two before the decision is made public.

At the Knickerbocker Bowling Club yesterday there were 144 members and guests present. This is the largest meeting of the club this year. The bowlers were in good form and Mr. G.B. Nicholas scored 266. This is the highest score made this season. It made Mr. T.P. Cooper sad, especially as he was only able to score 218.

At the Metropolitan Opera House last night the serious old days of grand opera in German seemed to have returned. For the benefit of the University Settlement Society and the New-York Kindergarten Association a performance of the final drama of "Der Ring des Nibelungen," namely, "Die Gotterdimmerung," was given.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Postmaster General Bissell this afternoon personally supervised the opening of the sealed proposals for furnishing stamped envelopes and newspaper wrappers to the Government for the four years beginning on Oct. 1 next.

BOSTON, March 28. -- Local stocks were extremely quiet to-day. The advance in Bell Telephone Company was the only feature of interest. This stock opened at 183 1/2, the same as last night's close, and advanced to 185. Yesterday's favorable statement was the cause of the strength, together with the fact that but a small quantity of stock is offered for sale.

ALBANY, March 28. -- The election for Regent of the University to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Bishop McNierny of Albany will be held to-morrow at noon by the joint session of the Legislature.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

SING SING, N.Y., March 28. -- The complete returns from the election in the towns of Westchester County give the Republicans the same majority in the Board of Supervisors that the Democrats had last year-17 to 10. The towns which the Republicans gained were Green burgh, Lewisboro, Mount Pleasant, Nev.-Rochelle, Poundridge, and Yonkers, with Westchester Independent. The list of Supervisors is as follows:
ALBANY, March 28 -- The Senate General Laws and Assembly Gas and Electricity Committees gave a second hearing this afternoon on the Gerst bill regulating telephone rates.

W. Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker agreed upon calling the fifth game of the chess match a draw without resuming play yesterday. Lasker not even caring to know what move Steinitz had left sealed in an envelope, when the game stood adjourned on Tuesday evening. Steinitz had left the move P -- R7.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Sixteen young women, representing different New-England industries, were at the Capitol to-day, under the leadership of Mrs. J. Ellen Foster, President of the Woman's Republican Association of the United States. The object of their visit was to endeavor to secure a hearing before the Senate Finance Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The chapters in The New-York Times exposing some of the frauds that are being practiced under the pension regulations of the country have attracted much attention in Congress, and are beginning to provoke the comment that the work deserves.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- A committee known as the National Quarantine Committee of the New-York Academy of Medicine appeared before the House Commerce Committee this morning with reference to the bill to establish a Bureau of Public Health within the Department of the Interior, to consist of a Commissioner and an Advisory Council.

NEW-HAVEN, March 28. -- William Murphy, the Yale Captain of last year left bare this evening to spend a week at his home in Westborqugh, Mass., before reporting for his initial season as a League player. He will join the New-York Club Saturday week and take part in the practice games of the team.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- A determined attempt at murder, and an equally determined attempt at lynching on the part of thousands of furious citizens, turned the leading business corner of the city into a turmoil shortly after noon to-day. The victim of the tragedy was William L. Clifford, a letter carrier, and his assailant was Guy T. Olmstead, an ex-substitute carrier.

About 100 graduates, representing thirty-three colleges, each wearing the gold, pearlset shield, and many of them with little knots of lavender and pink ribbon, were in the corridors and parlors of the Savoy last night. They were delegates to the biennial Grand Arch Council of the Phi Kappa Psi college fraternity, which began a three-days' session yesterday.

The Executive Committee of the Business Men's Relief Committee of the Industrial Christian Alliance held a meeting yesterday afternoon at the office of Vermilye Co., 18 Nassau Street, with George D. Mackay in the chair. It was found that, while contributions to the committee's fund are not now as liberal as they were earlier in the season, the calls upon the committee for assistance are still very urgent.

DENVER, Col., March 28. -- At the opening of the Supreme Court this morning Platt Rogers, for the Governor's party, filed a plea claiming that the Supreme Court has no jurisdiction to listen to the complaint of the City Hall party, wherein a writ of injunction against the Governor's party is asked.

The Bluefields Messenger of March 16 gives a concise account of the troubles there. Blueflelds is the capital of the Mosquito Territory, Nicaragua. When Gen. Carlos A. Lacayo, the Nicaraguan commissioner, and Gen. Rigoberto Cabezas, Inspector of the Atlantic coast, arrived at Blueflelds they were warmly received by the Government and the people.

There were sensational rumors in Brooklyn yesterday in relation to the forthcoming Extraordinary Grand Jury for May and the disclosures made to the counsel for the people by the Gravesend Election Inspectors.

The Board of Audit of Gravesend, to whom was submitted John Y. McKane's accounts for 1893, as they were published in The New-York Times of yesterday, is unable to obtain from his statement any clear idea of the condition of the town's finances. Instead of enlightening the members of the board, McKane's statement has bewildered them so that they know now very little more about his bookkeeping than they knew when they began their inquiry.

BERLIN, March 28. -- It is formally announced that Chancellor von Caprivi will take no part in the discussion in the Reiehstag of the proposed programme at finance reform but will leave the advocacy of that project entirely to Dr. Miquel, Prussian Finance Minister; Count von FosadowskyWehner, Secretary of State for the Imperial Treasury, and Herr von Rledel, Bavarian Minister of Finance.

TURIN, March 23. -- The body of Louis Kossuth was removed last evening to the Evangelical Church, where the funeral services took place at 9 o'clock this morning. 'Accompanying the body to the church were a civic guard of honor and a squadron of the Municipal Guards of Turin.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- The people of Chicago were treated to a mild reminder of last month's blizzard to-day. The snowfall, which began at an early hour this morning, continued all day and seriously interfered with traffic. About 4 inches fell, and the forty-mile-an-hour wind drifted it badly.

Seven copies of the petition sent out by the Chamber of Commerce in favor of the new Rapid-Transit bill were returned to Secretary George Wilson yesterday filled with signatures. They contained about 5,000 names. There remain in circulation thirty-three copies, which will probably be turned in within a week.

Of all the charitable vaudeville performances, concerts, amateur theatricals, and social benefits which have been given this year, few have been as cleverly arranged and as successful as the exhibition of "Mrs. Jarley's Celebrated Wax Works," given at Hardman Hall yesterday after-noon and evening for the benefit of St. Michael's Home, Mamaroneck.

ROME, March 28. -- Queen Margaret probably will receive on Saturday the women delegates to the International Medical Congress. Russia, Austria-Hungary, and Spain are competing for the next congress. The Russian delegates offer either St. Petersburg or Moscow as the place of meeting, and it is thought probable that one of these cities will be selected.

The police reserves of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station were called upon last night to suppress a disturbance at 417 West Thirty-fifth Street, which at one time assumed the proportions of a riot.

An action was tried yesterday in the Supreme Court, before Justice Andrews, brought by Alexander Mackenzie Jones and William E. Jones, sons of William Ogden Jones, against their aunts, Caroline Ogden Jones and Frances Ogden Jones, to compel them to render an accounting of trusts which were created for the sons' benefit under the will of their grandmother, Caroline Ogden McCagg.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 28 -- There may be another revolution in Spanish Honduras in a short time -- at least, that is what several Hondurans say who have just arrived on the City of Dallas from Belize. It seems that the people are dissatisfied with Bonilla. They allege that he is unjust and overtaxes the people.

This word, which has been staring everybody in the face for the past years, and is now getting into nearly everybody's month, is a preparation for cleansing, beautifying, and preserving the teeth, sweetening the breath, and arresting the progress of decay.

At the home of Mrs. Gerald Jackson, 72 West Forty-seventh Street, Tuesday evening, the question of striking the word "male" as a qualification for voting from the Constitution was discussed by a number of prominent speakers.

Dr. Moreau Morris presented a report to the Board of Health yesterday concerning the primary department of Grammar School No. 7, in the old Essex Market, which he says is in such bad sanitary condition that the health of 900 children is endangered. He urges that the school should be closed at once.

A British nobleman who was sued for breach of promise is reported to have declared that it was impossible for him to contradict a lady, and that therefore he would not deny that he had made the promise. But he insisted that the lady had exaggerated the value of his affections, and that that value was a fair question for a jury.

A theatrical company has found it profitable to add to a very generous bill of fare a series of pictures in which the figures are living women who simulate sculptures or paintings of more or less renown which contain figures more or less draped. Tableaux-vivants are at least as old as the miracle plays of the Middle Ages, and artists as well as fashionable young people to-day find them an unfailing amusement.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 28. -- Under the management of Mrs. George J. Gould and others, a benefit performance was given at the Lakewood Hotel to-night for the purpose of raising money for the Lakewood Fire Company, a volunteer association. The farce-comedy of the "Three Hats" was presented by the members of the Gilbert Dramatic Society of Brooklyn, of which Mrs. Gould was a member previous to her going on the professional stage.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 28 -- It is rumored here to-day that Reuben F. Kolb's real scheme is not to be elected Governor of Alabama, but that, giving that up as impossible, he has cast his eye on Senator Morgan's seat, and will try to succeed him. All his energies will be bent to electing State Representatives and Senators, so that he may control the next State Legislature.

To judge by the tone of his speech at Minneapolis last evening, Gov. McKinley of Ohio is in a great hurry for a purely revenue tariff. He laments that the Democratic Party has "so far failed to redeem a single pledge it made to the people," and has particularly failed to give the people a tariff for revenue only.

The railway mortgage market was more active than on any other day in many months. The foreign buying was particularly good. Among the issues which were largely dealt in were Atchison seconds. Chesapeake and Ohio 4 1/2s, Colorado Midland 4s, Kansas and Texas seconds. Northern Pacific 5s, Reading thirds, St. Louis Southwestern firsts, and Texas and Pacific seconds.

One more name was added yesterday morning to the long list of young American society women who have married foreign noblemen. Miss Annie Seabury Brewster being wedded to Count Henri de Frankenstein in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The wedding ceremony was performed by Archbishop Corrigan, assisted by the Rev. James M. Connelly and the Rev. Henry T. Newey.

The contest over the will of Frederick A. Lovecraft, late business manager of Palmer's Theatre, who committed, suicide on Oct. 26 last and left his entire estate, estimated to be worth $150,000, to his friend, Col. Henry S. Kearney, without making any provision for his seventy-year-old mother or his sisters, Mrs. Robert H. Salmons and jars. Chase, was resumed yesterday before Surrogate John H.V. Arnold.

Thomas C. Platt's name was not even mentioned at the remarkable Republican meeting in the Cooper Union last night, held under the direction of the Committee of Thirty appointed by the Republican County Committee to reorganize the party in this city. Except when some reference was made to bosses and bossism, Platt was totally ignored.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- Wheat bears were made to dance to the tune of a quick advance of 3c per bushel to-day. The bulge was not expected, but the force and suddenness with which it came about nearly took away the breath of the -- of late -- complacent shorts. Ever since Sunday, when the cold wave enveloped the Winter wheat belt, fears were entertained that harm had been wrought to the growing plant.

The large hall of Cooper Union was well filled yesterday afternoon at the evangelistic revival meeting. The audiences in Cooper Union and the theatres are growing In size, but seem to be falling off slightly In Association Hall. This is accounted for by the fact that the noon meeting is away from the centre of travel.

ALBANY, March 29. -- Politics have suddenly been injected into the Brockway case. Efforts have been made to induce Gov. Flower to remove the Board of Managers of the Reformatory for their failure to remove Brockway, but the Governor has declined to resort to such a radical step. The managers could demand their right to be tried, and a trial would mean months of delay.

STAPLETON, S.I., March 29. -- The nineteenth annual ball for the benefit of the S. R. Smith Infirmary, Staten Island's charity hospital, was held to-night in the German Clubrooms here. It was the first society event of the post-Lenten season on the island and was largely attended.

ALBANY, March 29. -- The Assembly Cities Committee this afternoon took up the Lawson trill to allow wharf construction and improvements in New-York City to be done by contract, without interference by the Board of Docks.

BOSTON, March 29. -- The rise in Bell Telephone and the strength of Fitchburg preferred were the only features of the local market. In fact, there were no other local securities traded in to-day to any extent. Bell Telephone opened at 186, 1/2 above the close of yesterday, and advanced, without any retrogression, to 190.

COLUMBIANA, Ohio, March 29. -- Tel miles of the worst journey yet made by Coxey's tramps were covered to-day. It was a triumphal march, the day's incidents being numerous. After a hot breakfast at Camp Diggs, Salem, tents were struck and the nondescript organization set out in the teeth of a driving snowstorm for this town to establish Camp Trenton.

Sir James Hannen. The Right Hon. Sir James Hannen died yesterday in London. He was born in 1821. He was the eldest son of a very wealthy retired London merchant, James Hannen, who owned, an extensive estate in Kingswood, Surrey. The younger Hannen was entered at St. Paul's School, where he remained until his father sent him to the University of Heidelberg.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29. -- The market started off with a pretty good feeling all around, and, although. It reacted slightly, prices were well maintained until the veto of the Bland Seigniorage bill was announced, when a sharp selling movement set in. A special drive was made at Reading, and it was sold down to the equivalent of 20 7/8.

It seems that the National League for the Promotion of Good Roads, if that be its proper style, must have instigated "General" Coxey and his "army" to undertake a journey from Ohio to Washington at the end of March. This is one of the toughest seasons for the ordinary American highway, and the more the highway is traveled the worse it becomes.

ALBANY, March 29. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee this afternoon took up the memorial of the New-York Civil Service Reform Association alleging violations of the civil service law. The purpose of the hearing was to see if the facts were sufficient to warrant an investigation.

BABYLON, L.I., March 29. -- Fred Hoey and L.S. Thompson defeated George Work and Charles Macalester in a live-bird shoot on the grounds of the Westminster Kennel Club here to-day. The score was 190 to 187. The match was at thirty yards' rise, fifty yards' boundary, 100 birds each man, for a substantial stake.

The fourth day of the trial of the suit of William R. Laidlaw, Jr., to recover $50,000 from Russell Sage for exposing him to the force of Norcross's dynamite bomb, presented the most interesting phases of the case, and attracted a larger number of auditors than before in Part II. of the Supreme Court.

The death of Barton Harper, the four-year old grandson of Col. Henry B. Beecher of Yonkers, from tuberculous meningitis caused by drinking the milk from cows that have tuberculosis, was the subject of discussion in the Health Department yesterday. Health Commissioner Cyrus Edson and Sanitary Superintendent Roberts agreed in saying that tuberculosis could easily be contracted from animals.

The annual report of the Norfolk and Western Railroad, issued yesterday, makes a gratifying showing for the year 1893. The company had in operation 1,556 miles of road, which was kept in excellent condition. The gross earning were $10,032,617, the operating expenses and taxes $7,199,460, and the net earnings $2,833,157.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 29. -- When the Court of Oyer and Terminer reconvened this morning Judge Forbes asked District Attorney Jennings for an explanation in regard to the removal of Student Taylor to the Watkins jail. The District Attorney said that Judge Walter Lloyd Smith had granted a writ of habeas corpus.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.
Wheeler H. Peckham delivered an address last night before the Good Government Club at its rooms, 70 West One Huridred and Fourth Street, his subject being "Bribery in Municipal Politics."

CHICAGO, March 29. -- From the opening of the first session to the end of the call, the market was strong and higher. The most marked advance was in West Chicago. Opening at 152 1/2, it advanced to 154 1/2, and closed strong. Sympathetically North Chicago moved up 1 1/4 points. Offerings of both stocks were very light, and buyers had to bid the market up to get them.
For the first time in the history of college fraternities, one of such bodies has put itself upon, record as opposed to hazing.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The question who will be the successor of the late senator colquitt on the Senate Committee on Post Office and Post Roads is attracting considerable attention at the Capital. Although Mr. Colquitt was Chairmain of the Committee, he had been unable to attend to his duties for many months, thus leaving the committee with ten working members five Democrates and five Republicans.
With flying colors and beating drums and splendid martial parade, the Seventh Regiment last night celebrated its emancipation from debt.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 29. -- Gov. Northen has appointed Speaker Charles F. Crisp to succeed the late Senator Alfred H. Colquitt.

ABBAZIA, March 29. -- The Emperor of Germany, wearing the uniform of the Austrian Hussars, and the Emperor of Austria, in the uniform of the Prussian Grenadiers, met this morning at Mattuglie, the railway point nearest to Abbazia. They embraced and kissed each other affectionately, and conversed together for several minutes.
In the investigation as to who draw pensions a reporter for The New-York Times found:

The movement for honest Democratic reorganization in Brooklyn is still progressing favorably. Compared with it, the socalled enrollment under direction of the Willoughby Street "machine" is a flat failure.
NEW-DORP, S.I., March 29. -- The Eastertide has not brought joy to the congregation of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Comforter, at Eltington, a village near this place.

HARRISON, N.J., March 29 -- While frenzied with rage this afternoon, John Washington, a laborer, shot and nearly killed his wife on the sidewalk opposite their home, 39 Searing Avenue. The woman is now hovering between life and death in St. Michael's Hospital, Newark. Washington was angered because when he returned from work his wife could give him nothing to eat but bread, and butter.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- In the early part of the day members had only derived their knowledge of the contents of the veto from a few copies that had been privately circulated. The continuing order on the election case had prevented the message being openly read when presented.

The State Civil Service Commission met in this city yesterday, and began what promises to be a long and important work in the way of improving the system by which appointments are made under the civil service law.

ALBANY, March 29. -- The admissions which, were made before the Committee on Miscellaneous Corporations of the Senate yesterday toy Frank Gardner, Secretary of the Board of Trade and Transportation, in the course of the hearing on the Telephone Reduction bill, were brought before the Senate this morning by Senator Kilburn, (Rep., Franklin,) Chairman of the committee.

We have repeatedly urged during the last eight years, since the condition of the notorious Berliner-Edison "interference" in the Patent Office was first disclosed to the public by testimony taken in this city, that there should be a thorough investigation by Congress of the methods and rules of procedure which made such jobbery possible under forms of law.

LIVERPOOL, March 29. -- In addressing the Society for the Relief of Foreigners, the Mayor this evening complained of the expense caused the city toy cattlemen from the United States. Almost constantly, he said, these men were being left penniless and friendless in the dock districts, and were saved from starvation and returned to America by the municipality.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29. -- Vice Chancellor Van Fleet was this morning engaged in hearing the application made by Thomas A. Edison and Co. George E. Gouraud for the appointment of a receiver for the Edison United Phonograph Company. A.Q. Keasbey represented the company, and Mr. Edison is represented by Cortlandt and R. Wayne Parker.

The saloons of New-York received attention at the Amity Building, on West Fifty-fourth Street, last evening. The occasion. was another of the series of conferences of those interested in good municipal government.

There is one subject of importance in the hands of a committee of Congress which has no politics in it and upon which there is little room for difference of opinion among intelligent citizens. It affects the interests of all classes of our people alike, and is wholly for their benefit. We refer to the bill for establishing a Bureau of Public Health at Washington as an appendage to the Department of the Interior.

An entertainment and ball was given last night at the Lexington Opera House, Fifty-eighth Street, near Third Avenue, by the agents of Sherman Park, to the lot owners and their friends. The commodious hall was crowded. The Sherman Park agents have an association, the officers of which are: President -- A.A. Lazarus; Vice President -- M. Blankensee; Secretary -- Henry Lichtenstein; Treasurer -- Henry Meier.

ALBANY, March. 29. -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Assemblyman Burtis's bill relating to the purchase of supplies by the Department of Police and Excise and the Department of Fire in the City of Brooklyn, without advertisement, when the expense thereof shall not at any one time exceed the sum of $1,000. In his veto the Governor says:

ST. PETERSBURG, March 29. -- The efforts of the Russian life insurance companies to secure a decision against the American companies transacting business in Russia has failed. The Russian Minister of Finance announces that the American life companies will be relicensed, with the proviso that dividends shall be declared annually to policy holders desiring that mode of settlement.
The New-York Times is now able to publish the full and astounding truth in relation to the great election conspiracy in the town of Gravesend last Fall.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, March 29 -- P.M. The veto of the Bland bill by President Cleveland had been so confidently anticipated that, when it came to-day it had little or no influence on the stock market. The kicker was frequently silent for long intervals after the fact of the veto was announced, trailers seemingly standing aloof to see how others would take the news.

The prompt and heroic work of Brooklyn firemen, at a fire at 115 Kent Avenue, yesterday morning, probably prevented the loss of two lives. The building is a three-story brick tenement. It was occupied by three families. Mr. and Mrs. Kelly lived on the second floor, and John Brady and his mother occupied the top floor.

TROY, N.Y., March 29. -- Attorney General Hancock was asked to-day in regard to the Governor's interview with that official relative to taking charge of the Troy election cases. The Attorney General said that Gov. Flower distinctly informed him that Assistant District Attorney Fagan should not only be appointed a Deputy Attorney General but that he should be given charge of the prosecution.

WASHINGTON, March 29 .-- Much interest is manifested by Treasury Department officials, particularly those connected with the Revenue Marine, in a resolution introduced Monday by Representative Lockwood of Buffalo which authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to make partial payments on all contracts for the construction of vessels for the Revenue Service.

At auction yesterday, by order of the Nassau Trust Company, as trustee, Mr. William Cole sold a number of pieces of property in the Seventh and Twenty-first Wards of Brooklyn. J.H. Rowland bought at $11,600 the two-story brick building, with store, 252 Franklin Avenue, southwest corner of De Kalb Avenue, 21.6 by 45.1 by 76.8. He also bought at $4,500 the-two-and-a-half-story and basement brick dwelling 254 Franklin Avenue, 19.1 3/4 by 36 by 76.8.
CHARLESTON, West Va., March 29. -- John Wilt's residence, at MacKendree, was burned this morning. His eight children and Miss Mollic Hemrick, a servant, were burned to death.

He looked as if he had walked a long distance. A hole was in his left shoe, through which a white cotton stocking could be seen. A fringe was about the bottoms of his trousers, the overcoat, from which most of the buttons were gone, was pinned tightly up around his neck. A beard of several days' growth gave his face a soiled appearance.

People who hold to the old-fashioned notion that a picture ought to tell a plain but not unvarnished tale, suited to intellects unlearned in the inner mysteries of the painter's craft, may sally forth to their sixty-ninth annual Spring: exhibit at the Academy of Design with a calm, assurance possessing their souls.
WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Col. W.C.P. Breckinridge faced Madeline Pollard, his accuser, in the Circuit Court of the District to-day, and told part of his version of their acquaintance.

ALBANY, March 29. -- The Bradley bill to legislate out of office the present Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge was the subject of a hearing by the Assembly Cities Committee to-day. A favorable report was ordered. There were present James C. Bergen, counsel for the Bridge Trustees; President Howell, Chief Engineer Martin, Trustee Henriques, and Secretary Bean.

The analysis by the President of the provisions of the Bland bill and of their operation should the bill become a law is very clear and cogent. It is marked by that firm and comprehensive grasp of the essential facts of a complex question which is with him a natural power highly trained, and the same unusual excellence is shown in the orderly and effective arrangement of his statement.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- A new and important weapon is ready for trial at the Washington ordnance shops. It is a six-inch rapid-fire gun. The rapid-fire system has gradually extended, until it has embraced a calibre undreamed of even, by those who were enthusiastic supporters of the method.

Twenty-five distinct pieces of property were sold at auction yesterday in the New-York Real Estate Sasesroom in the Trinity Building. The attendance was large, the Interest shown was quite marked, and the prices obtained were rather ercouraging.

ALBANY, March 30. -- The absence of two committees that are eng-ag-ed in special work prevented the presence of a quorum in the Senate to-day Gen. McMahon presided for the few minutes the session lasted.

The persons who are implicated in the Confessions of the Gravesend Election Inspectors, it was learned yesterday, in Brooklyn, are making the utmost effort in their power to prevent the calling of another Extraordinary Grand Jury in May to continue the investigation into the ballot frauds of last Fall.

The pugilist James J. Corbett has purchased, in the name of his father-in-law, George Lake, the three-story brownstone dwelling 146 West Eighty-eighth Street, from John Gillie, for about $25,000. The adjoining similar house. 148 West Eighty-eighth Street, has been sold to a Mr. Krooss at the same price.

HAMBURG, March 30 -- The celebration of Prince Bismarck's seventy-eighth birthday, which will fall on next Sunday, began at Friedrichsruh to-day. Fifteen women from Hesse-Nassau and Baden left the city this morning for Bismarck's home with a case of Palatinate wine, vintage of 1811, on the train with them.
The third of a series of conferences on subjects to be brought before the Constitutional Convention which is to meet in May was held at the City Club last evening.

OMAHA, Neb., March 30 -- A proposition from General Sollcitor Thurston of the Union Pacific Railroad to refer the wage question to a commissioner instead of the court has not been favorably met by the representatives of the employes.
NEW-ORLEANS, March 30 -- A letter from a special correspondent at Bluefields, Nicaragua, written on March 23, says:

WERNERSVILLE, Penn., March 30 -- Sheriff Fahrenbach and Police Sergt. Quackenbos of Reading stopped a prize fight in the Methodist Church here at an early hour this morning. They drove from Reading, which is eight miles away, and had some difficulty in locating the place selected for the fight.

The large dining room on the second floor of the Hotel Imperial, Broadway and Thirty-second Street, was the scene of a merry dinner, given by the New-York Association of the Alumni of Philllips Exeter Academy, last evening. Most of the prominent alumni residents of this city assembled around the board, and the greatest good fellowship prevailed.

Dun's Review will say to-morrow: "The President clears away one grave uncertainty with his veto. For some days it has been expected, and in speculation perhaps fully discounted. The more confident tone observed this week is partly due to the belief that no disturbance of the currency will be permitted, but other causes help forward improvement.

TROY, N.Y., March 30 -- The special committee of the Senate appointed for the purpose of investigating the election frauds in the different cities of the State began its deliberations in the Common Council chamber, in this city, this morning. Senators Mullin (Rep.) of Watertown, Stapleton (Rep.) of Morrisville, and Kilburn (Rep.) of Malone of the committee were present, besides the following counsel: Frank S. Black, E.W. Douglas, and W.J. Ludden.

Paul Dana has resigned as a member of the Park Board. His letter of resignation, explanatory of his course, readied Mayor Gilroy just before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. It is the result of the long-continued controversy between Mr. Dana on the one side and President Tappen and Commissioners Clausen and Straus on the other about the Harlem River Driveway.

RICHMOND, Va., March 30 -- Capt. James Pollard, Assistant Superintendent and Adjutant of Lee Camp, Soldiers' Home, was found dead in his bed yesterday. He was made famous by being in command of the squadron of cavalry that killed Col. Ulric Dahlgren in his notable raid around Richmond in the Spring of 1864.

AUCKLAND, March 30 -- The steamer Alameda brings news of disturbances in Samoa which threaten serious consequences unless they shall be checked. The trouble, which has assumed the proportions of a war, grew out of the action of the new Supreme Judge, Ide, in imposing fines upon Some of the minor chiefs for disorderly conduct, and imprisoning and compelling them to work on the public roads in default of the payment of the fines.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Samuel A. Beardsley, Michael Rickard, and Alfred C. Chapin, comprising the State Board of Railroad Commissioners, met a few railroad representatives in the Chamber of Commerce rooms, in this city, yesterday, and discussed the advisability of seeking legislation looking to the abolition of grade crossings in this State.

Mr. Joseph H. Choate had a Pisgahsight of the Republican Palestine on Wednesday evening and told the Thirty and their followers how the place looked. In his vision it was a land of pleasant places and green pastures, where the lean kine of his party might hope to come into excellent condition.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- There was some attempt made to hammer stocks soon after the opening, and the room traders, most of whom were bearish, selected St. Paul and Reading. Lehigh Valley also was depressed on transactions in odd lots. As soon as the raiding was over, the market became dull, but very firm.

The trout streams and ponds on Long Island will be well whipped to-day by enthusiastic fishermen. The anglers departed in large numbers yesterday, by the outgoing trains, for their favorite grounds, with every prospect of excellent sport.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The State Department, while aware of the lawless state of affairs in the Mosquito territory, declares that nothing can be done until the arrival of Admiral Benham with the San Francisco, which can hardly be for ten days yet. That ship is daily expected at St. Lucia, where she must spend at least two days taking coal, when she will continue her voyage across the Caribbean Sea.
