ATLANTA, Ga., March 30 -- Gov. Northen was disappointed at Speaker Crisp declining to accept the Senatorship. Gov. Northen, however, appreciates his position. He has not yet decided upon another appointment.

The taking of testimony before Surrogate Arnold in the proceedings brought to set aside the will of Frederick A. Lovecraft giving his entire estate to Col. Henry S. Kearney to the exclusion of his mother and two married sisters was resumed yesterday.

The seventh International convention, of the railroad branches of the Young Men's Christian Association reassembled last night in the railroad building, Forty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue. There were delegates present from all over the country.

The investigation into the question of police interference at elections which the special Senate committee is conducting dragged along yesterday in the General Term Room of the Common Pleas Court. It made Senator "Dan" Bradley, the Lone Fisherman of the committee, look tired.
BUDA-PESTH, March 30 -- The bodies of Louis Kossuth, his wife, and his daughter have arrived in Buda-Pesth. They are lodged in the Museum, where they will lie in state until to-morrow noon.

From The Petersburg (Va.) Index Appeal, (Dem.) We cannot think that the Northern people will always submit to the shameless robbery for which our pension system is responsible. As for the South, It is muzzled. It cannot afford to open its mouth for the fear of malignant misrepresentation of its motives.

On Thursday, when it was known that the Bland bill had been vetoed, the enterprising gentlemen in "Wall Street who make a business, more or less profitable, of betting mi the state of each other's minds, took the view that prices would be depressed. Heaven knows why. Perhaps because the veto had been "discounted."

Mr. Griffis says in his preface that he has written this book "in simple language for the young folks of America." It is not clear that youthful minds will be able to read it understandingly. Mr. Griffis writes neither on the lower line of youth nor on the higher level of scholars. It is rather the medium ground that he traverses -- the ground wherein walks the vast army of average readers.

MONTEVIDEO, March 30 -- The new Ministry selected by President Bordas is as follows: Minister of Foreign Affairs -- Piniero Campos; Minister of Finance -- Senor Vidiella; Minister of War -- Gen. Diaz; Minister of the Interior -- Herrera Obes; Minister of Public Works -- Senor Castro. Senor Herrera v Obes is a brother of the former President of that name.

The proceedings in the Lyman court-martial had an abrupt interruption yesterday. The interruption was caused by George Edward Kent, counsel for the accused. Mr. Kent is a member of the New-York bar and a Lieutenant Commander in the State Naval Reserves. On behalf of his client, he said that he felt obliged to use his right of challenge.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 30 -- It is seldom that millionaires are tried in the Bergen County Court at Hackensack for such a small amount as $60, but such was the case when Mrs. Susie Anderson, a boarding-house keeper of Hoboken, sued Mrs. Bella Miller, who, with her husband, is occupying Joseph Jefferson's old house near Saddle River, Bergen County.

The announcement made yesterday that Koster Bial were to sue Mr. Kilanyi for $50,000 damages for breach of contract in producing his living pictures at the Garden Theatre was received by the management at the Garden with smiles of incredulity. A.M. Palmer, with whom Mr. Kilanyi's contract was made, spoke very freely on the subject to a reporter for The New-York Times.

BONDSVILLE, Mass., March 30 -- Ludwig Copocz, thirty-three years old, to-day shot Agnes Nicodem and then himself. The girl is eighteen years old. Copocz has a wife living in Poland. Since coming to Bondsville he has boarded in the same house with Miss Nicodem. Both were employed in the mill of the Boston Duck Company.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- Exporters of oil doing business at this port think they have good reason for believing that the Standard Oil Company has absorbed or in some way secured, control of the most formidable of its few remaining rivals, and now has absolute control of the seaboard.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 30 -- President Van Horne, Vice President Shaughnessy, and Directors E.B. Osler and R.B. Angus of the Canadian Pacific Railroad arrived at the Canadian side of the Falls yesterday and were met by General Manager Grant of the Niagara Falls Park and River Railway and Mr. Ross Mackenzie, who will succeed Mr. Grant next month.

LONDON, March 30 -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir James Whitehead called attention to the statement alleged to have been made by the King of Denmark that he knew that Russia, Austria, and Italy were willing to considerably reduce their military establishments, and asked if the Government would co-operate in such a step.

Mrs. Jane P. Austin, author of "A Nameless Nobleman," "Standish, of Standish," "Dr. Le Baron and His Daughters," "Betty Alden," and other works, died yesterday in Boston, Mass. She was born in Worcester, Mass., fifty-five years ago. From 1860 to 1870 she lived at Concord, where her closest friend was Louisa M. Alcott.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Col. Breckinridge was called to the stand this morning to resume his testimony in the suit brought against him by Miss Pollard. He had not concluded his evidence when the time for adjournment arrived.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Herman Clarke, of the firm of Hunter. Clarke Jacob of New-York, was arrested in this city late last night, word having been received by the police that he had been indicted for forgery. He was found at the Victoria Hotel, where he had registered with his wife under his own name.

Commencement exercises of the New-York Evening High Schools were held in Music Hall last evening. There were 161 graduates -- 57 were from the East Side School, 41 from the Harlem School, 34 from the NewYork School, and 29 from the Central School.

PEORIA, Ill., March 30 -- While workmen were engaged in making some repairs on the standpipe at Boarland and College Streets shortly after 10 o'clock this morning the great structure gave a lurch, broke squarely off at the base, and fell to the ground. It was 120 feet high and 20 feet in diameter and contained 1,000,000 gallons of water.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Bering Sea affairs absorbed the attention of the Cabinet to-day almost to the exclusion of everything else, and at the end of the meeting active steps had been commenced looking to thy protection of the fur seals and the apprehension of poachers, regardless of the flag they fly.
Russell Sage was assessed $25,000 yesterday by a heartless jury, simply because he used William R. Laidlaw, Jr., as a shield to save his gray hairs from being brought prematurely to the grave.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- So far as can be learned there is no movement under way here looking toward retaliatory measures by Congress as the result of the decision of the Russian Minister of Finance that American life insurance companies doing business in Russia must declare annual dividends to Russian policy holders desiring that mode of settlement.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. T. A. Kerrigan sold, at $7,300, to Edward E. Pearce, as executor, plaintiff, the five-story brick flat and store, 336 Flatbush Avenue, 28.11 by 82 by irregular. To the Thomas Roberts Stevenson Company, plaintiff, at $7,350, he sold the four-story brick double flat, 194 Tenth Street south side, 113 feet west of Third Avenue, 28 by 100.
BARRY, Ill., March 30 -- The Opera House caught fire after a dance early this morning. The flames spread quickly, and in a short time destroyed the business district of the city.

ALBANY, March 30 -- David B. Hill, Roswell P. Flower, and Edward Murphy, Jr., are in trouble because their friends and followers in this city are threatening to defeat the regular organization at the municipal election to be held a week from Tuesday.

DARLINGTON, S.C., March 30 -- A fight occurred to-day between the citizens and State constabulary at the station as the constables were about leaving. Constables Pepper and McLendon and Frank Norment and L.S. Redmond, citizens, were killed.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 30 -- Two shots were fired last Sunday at the Armenian Patriarch as he was leaving the cathedral. The man who fired the shots was promptly arrested, and six other persons have since been arrested as his accomplices.

The attendance at the various revival meetings yesterday was much larger than on previous days during the week. Cooper Union Hall was crowded to overflowing. To-morrow, at 4 P.M., meetings will be held in the Thalia, and Niblo's Theatres, and the Academy of Music.

The Democratic Party has of late years made great progress despite great difficulties. Like every party of sufficient strength and vitality to become a national party, it has been made up of many varying and sometimes conflicting elements. This was as true of the Republican Party ten years ago, when it lost its hold upon the National Government, as it has been at any time of the Democracy.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- West Chicago opened 1/4 and North Chicago 1 1/4 points lower as compared with the last sales of yesterday. A few bears considered this indicative of an off market for the day. Accordingly they began to sell, but their offerings were promptly accepted by brokers whose cards were replete with investment orders.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- There has been more or less discussion in the last twenty-four hours of the question whether the veto of the Seigniorage bill would have any effect upon the prospects of the Tariff bill. This question has been asked to-day of a number of Senators and Representatives who are supposed to keep accurate watch of the situation.

It is pretty nearly twenty-nine years now since the last soldier of the civil war was mustered out of service, and there are few of the survivors who have not passed the age of fifty. There are not many men past that age who are not afflicted by some physical defect or ailment which would be revealed by a close medical examination.

NEW-YORK, Friday, March 30 -- P.M. The stock market was somewhat irregular at the opening, selling by the trading element more than offsetting the strength which the moderate London buying would have induced under ordinary circumstances. The bear interest was particularly active in the first hour, and the short interest was materially increased.

LIVERPOOL, March 30. -- The Grand National Steeplechase of 2,500 sovereigns, (Including a trophy valued, at 100 sovereigns,) the second to receive 300 sovereigns and the third 200 sovereigns from the stakes, was run to-day, and was won by Capt C.H. Fenwick's Why Not, (aged.) Mr. J. McKinlay's Lady Ellen II. (six years) "was second, and Mr. John Widger's "Wild Man from Borneo (six. years) was third.

WASHINGTON, March 30.-- The reports of investigations into the abuses practiced under the pension laws, as published in The New-York Times, are attracting the attention of members of Congress by their interest and thoroughness. It is inevitable that the result of these publications must be action to correct some of the irregularities and inequalities pointed out, and perhaps a purging of the lists.

The Dock Department plan for the improvement of the North River water front from Charles Street to West Twenty-third Street is a great undertaking, since it will cost, according to the estimates, many millions, but it is an undertaking already demanded by the commerce or the port, and long before it can be completed the demand for additional dock facilities will have become imperative.

It seems hard work for some owners of race horses to come to the conclusion that the racing of thoroughbreds in the State of New-Jersey during the present year is an impossibility. They affect to believe that the expression of opinion of the people at the polls last Fall was not what they said it was.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 31. -- After the quiet of Lent the days of this week have been unusually full of life. The Easter Monday dance at the Laurel-in-the-Pines was a brilliant success by reason of the large number of young people sojourning at that house, to whom were added Carasaljo Club members and a number of students from Princeton.

-- The late J. Brand of London made a collection of modern Dutch paintings and old and modern British, which has been dispersed at Chrystle's. Joseph Israels was represented by "Coming Ashore," a marine, that went for $1,415; "Children Sailing a Boat," that sold for $840; "Girl and Youth In Country Lane," $760, and "Two Children at Door of Cottage," $765.

Only within the past few years has the physical development of the deaf-mute been regarded as a prime necessity. The movement, however, has spread among all the leading schools, and it is now the aim to turn out deaf-mute graduates as sound bodily as they are perfect in other educational lines.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 31. -- While being given a fast trial here the filly Elizabeth L., in W.H. Laudeman's stable, broke down in her right fore leg, and may not be able to race this season. She won the Produce Stakes at Morris Park last season and other great events.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Spring is the season of hope, good resolutions and fish lies, rejected pictures, big exhibitions of painting's, and taking stock on the part of art societies. All these seasonable joys point this out as the time when a somewhat gloomy subject may be advanced with the least strain upon the nerves.

Before Carroll saw Charlotte she had met and talked with Channing. Carroll asked for "the ladies" when he presented himself at the well-remembered home of Mrs. Chadwick and her daughter on the following day. It was a day full of really vernal sunshine, and whatever cruel hurts may have been dealt to buds and grasses were forgotten by casual wayfarers in the repentant blandness of breeze and sky.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Representative Thomas J. Strait of Lancaster, S.C., expressed the opinion to-day that the people will stand by the Governor in the enforcement of the dispensary law, if it requires 50,000 men to do it. He asserted that the sentiment of the State upheld the Governor, and that a small clique, who wanted to continue the "moonshine" whisky traffic, is at the bottom of the whole trouble.
DARLINGTON, S.C., March 31. -- The constables who fled to the swamps after the riot in the station yesterday are at Syracuse, hemmed in by a mob that absolutely refuses to give quarter.

Conjecture strayed into many channels yesterday to account for the continued absence of the Bremen liner Ems. The vessel touched at Southampton, her last port of call, on March 18, and, under ordinary circumstances, should have been this side of Sandy Hook before Tuesday night.
TUESDAY, April 3. -- By Adrian H. Muller Son, executor's sale, 16 East Thirty-third Street, south side, 225 feet east of Fifth Avenue, 25 by 98.9, four-story brownstone dwelling.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 31. -- Princeton's venerable ex-President, Dr. James McCosh, will reach the eighty-third anniversary of his birth to-morrow. The students are somewhat disappointed that the anniversary falls on Sunday. This defeats the programme of the usual student celebration.
Masonic Hall, Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, was crowded last night with Democrats, intent on honest party reorganization. The gathering was under the auspices of the Committee of One Hundred.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 31. -- A law forbidding tontine insurances has received the approval of the Council of Ministers. The measure was desperately opposed by the American companies doing business in Russia, against which it was principally directed, and it is feared by Americans that the example of Russia will be followed by other nations.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore gave his concluding lecture in the Spring course yesterday morning at the Museum of Natural History, under the auspices of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction, on "The Races and Foreign Buildings at the Paris Exposition of 1889."

Yesterday marked the beginning of a new epoch in the history of the Seventyfirst Regiment, N.G.S.N.Y. Escorted by its old-time friend, the Seventh Regiment, the Seventy-first was installed in its new armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue. When the Seventh Regiment moved from old Tompkins Market to the armory it now occupies it was escorted by the Seventy-first.

LONDON, March 31. -- Nothing in recent years has so excited sportsmen here as the scratching of Cloister for the Liverpool Grand National Steeplechase. The horse won the same race easily in 1893, handicaped at 12 stone 7 pounds. When it was announced that he had been put into this year's race at the same weight the betting public backed him enormously.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 31. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners approved the application of the Brooklyn, Queens County and Suburban Railroad Company to change its motive power from horses to the electric trolley system on that portion of its road on Metropolitan Avenue beginning at Brooklyn City Avenue and ending at St. John's Cemetery in Newtown.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, March 31 -- P.M. While there was undoubtedly considerable profit taking to-day, the market readily absorbed all offerings without showing signs of weakness. This was due mainly to the tree buying, not only for the foreign account, but for that of local investors. The prevailing sentiment was decidedly hopeful at the close of business.

THURSDAY, April 5. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, George B. McClellan, referee, 260 West Thirty-ninth Street, south side, 182 feet east of Eighth Avenue, 20.6 by 98.9, four-story brick dwelling. Due on judgment, $5.650.

Police Commissioner Martin testified before the special committee of the Senate yesterday, and made some admissions which were none the less valuable because he was not conscious of their significance. He professed not to know that policemen belonged to political clubs, and yet he admitted talking to Superintendent Byrnes about it and agreeing with him that it was "not right for policemen to belong to these clubs to such an extent."

The trout exhibitions in this city will be on April 16, as the New-York State law is "up" on the 15th, which is Sunday, and legislation has not, as in the case of Long Island, "turned back the hands of the clock," so as to legalize fishing for Salvelinus fontinalis on Saturday, April 14.

Albany, March 31. -- Another of the landmarks of this ancient city has disappeared. Within the last eight years four of the oldest structures have been torn down. These included the Staats house, built in 1668, the Lansing house, built in 1710, and the Van Rensselaer manor house, built in 1786.

SING SING, March 31. -- Eben S. Allen, the former President of the Grand and Fortysecond Street Railroad, in New-York, walked out of Sing Sing Prison at noon to-day, a free man. H. W. Coates and William Merritt, old friends, of Poughkeepsie, brought to the prison a new and stylish suit of clothes for Allen, who, when they arrived, was attending to his duties in the prison, preparatory to going away.

"F.G.H." -- The British war ship Canada is an unarmored, partial deck-protected cruiser of the third class. She was built at Portsmouth, where she was launched in 1881. Her engines were made by Rennie. She has a composite steel hull. Her displacement is 2,380 tons; indicated horse power, 2,430; draught of water, 19 feet 1 inch; length, 225 feet; beam, 44 1/4 feet.

TROY, N.Y., March 31. -- Evidence is being collected with a view of contesting the election of Francis J. Molloy as Mayor. The contestant will be Dennis J. Whelan, who was the Republican and independent candidate, and it is stated that he will bring quo warranto proceedings.

The Bland Seigniorage bill will come tip in the House on Tuesday, when a vote will be taken on the question whether it shall pass notwithstanding the objections of the President. The House originally passed the bill by a majority of thirtynine. To pass it over the President's veto a two-thirds vote would be required.
LONG ISLAND CITY, March 31. -- The Long Island Railroad Company is making a desperate fight to prevent the Legislature passing the bill reducing fares on its system from 3 to 2 cents a mile.

LONDON, March 31. -- One week ago it seemed as if Europe's interest in the Kossuth obsequies would be confined principally to the excited pranks of the students and riffraff of Buda-Pesth; but as the day of the funeral approached it was impossible not to be profoundly impressed by multiplying evidences how the whole of Hungary was stirred to the depths of her national being by the event.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 31. -- William B. Hopkins, Charles H. Burnett, and Dennis J. Lowney, three of the best-known students at Brown University, were in the District Court to-day on four complaints each, one for drunkenness, and three for breaking windows and stealing white enameled letters from store windows.

Among the supposed purposes of the "People's Party" is that of protesting against the exercise of arbitrary power by those in authority. The complaint of those who set it on foot was that the rights of the people were violated or disregarded by those who were chosen to carry out the popular will.

The activity of policemen in political clubs like the Pequod, which is run by Police Commissioner-District Leader-Contractor John C. Sheehan, a matter with which the public is already familiar through The New-York Times, was made the subject of inquiry yesterday by the Senate committee that is investigating the Police Department.

Though Corneille's deservedly famous drama, "Le Cid," is most frequently classed among historical tragedies, it is neither a tragedy nor historical. At the time of its production, and for a considerable period afterward, it was called a "tragi-comedy." The name is sufficiently expressive of the play's rather indeterminate form, its inconclusive ending -- or no end -- and its general insistence upon sentiment, frequently at the expense of dignity, as a motive for action.

DOLGEVILLE, N. Y., March 31. -- Carl F. Kloetzler, who had worked for several years in the factories of Alfred Dolge, and who has been brooding over the loss of his place for several weeks, last night carried out a threat he has frequently made, and killed his wife, four children, and himself. Two of the children were poisoned with arsenic.

"Politics" is not necessarily a losing game. The discussion of Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy as a candidate for Governor shows that there are leaders who survive, as well as "bosses" who succumb. Gen. Tracy figured for years as a "practical" politician in Kings County. He was the chief member of the famous trio, the "Three Graces," the most influential group in its day that ever took part in Brooklyn affairs.

BOSTON, March 31. -- The market for local stocks was generally dull, though Mexican Central securities showed some activity and strength, the 4s selling at 54 1/2, 1 above the last sale, and the stock 1 higher at 8 3/4. The earnings of the road are reported to be improving, and the local business is said to show a gratifying increase.

QUINCY, Mass., March 31. -- In a fire, which early this morning destroyed the house of Charles M. Driver, at Squantum, Mr. Driver, Cornelius Murphy, and Timothy Meara, plumbers, were burned to death. The fire was discovered by a neighbor, who was awakened by the glare of the flames. The house was then about to fall.
BOSTON, March 31. -- Writing from Glasgow under the date of March 20, a yachting correspondent says:

Fifty men live in Ogdensburg who are drawing pensions under the act of June 27, 1890. To entitle them to places on the pension roll, they need not have incurred their disabilities during the war. All they must have proved is that they are incapacitate from earning a support at manual labor, to some extent, and that this condition is no the result of their own vicious habits.

A little cloud of smoke corkscrewed its way up the spiral staircase from the second to the eleventh floor of the Hotel Savoy at about 3 A.M. yesterday. It crept into a room where one of the chambermaids was sleeping. Presently she awoke. She smelled the smoke, and knew that the hotel was on fire.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- Nothing declined in to-day's market. Some stocks closed precisely where they did yesterday. Many more, especially the industrials, advanced several points. Canal and Dock was liberally handled, and went up to 57 1/2, or 1 1/2 better than the final trade of yesterday. New-York Biscuit, on a narrow range of trading, rose to 41, an improvement of 1 point.
Prof. Robertson Smith, Librarian of the University of Cambridge died in Cambridge yesterday. He was forty-seven years old.

Some light is shed upon the internal trouble of the Austro-Hungarian Empire by the action of the Government with respect to the funeral of Kossuth. Kossuth is the real founder of the empire. It is quite true that he did not mean to found it, and that he was very much disgusted to find that he had founded it.

LONG ISLAND CITY, March 31. -- More trouble has grown out of the public works contracts held in this city by District Leader-Police Commissioner-Contractor John C. Sheehan of New-York. He is building an immense brick sewer in Broadway for the General Improvement Commission. It is to cost $359,408.

United States Deputy Marshal Grant arrested, yesterday afternoon, Charles B. Bartholomew, publisher, at 22 College Place, and took him to the office of United States District Attorney Platt on a warrant charging him with being a party to a gigantic fraud practiced upon the American Exchange National Bank of this city.

ORANGE, N.J., March 31. -- A party of Orange, New-York, and Brooklyn young people chaperoned by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander De Rosset went to Englewood last evening at the invitation of Mr. and Mrs. William H. H. Roberts, and surprised their daughters, the Misses Roberts. Mrs. and the Misses Roberts were assisted in receiving by Miss Vout of Brooklyn, Miss Mead and Miss Crogan of Orange.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Attorney General Olney said to-day, that the South Carolina trouble had not been officially brought to his notice. He could not give an opinion off hand on so important a subject.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Secretary of the Navy has issued all necessary orders for gathering the seal patrol fleet, and one vessel, the Mohican, is already on the way from San Francisco to Port Townsend, Washington, proceeding leisurely, and keeping a close lookout for the appearance of the herds, which are expected near the Oregon coast about the present time.
If the Brooklyn Civitas maidens are not now ardent advocates of free trade for the whole world it is not the fault of Frederick W. Hinrichs, Register of Arrears.
There were two large political meetings at Coney Island last evening.

Champion Zimmerman is still an amateur, but his agent is still in Paris trying to make suitable arrangements for the speedy New-Jersey rider to cast his lot with the professionals. As an amateur Zimmerman is sure of at least one more successful season, and unless some world-beater makes his appearance he may go on undisturbed for several seasons.

A new life of Jesus Christ has been discovered in a monastery of Thibet by a Russian traveler, and has just been translated into French. This book of Jesus Christ, reports the London Daily News, is held in no less reverence by certain Buddhists than the Rig-Veda by the Brahmins.

The Seventh International Conference of the Railroad Department of the Young Men's Christian Association, which closed last evening after a two days' session in the Railroad Men's Building, 361 Madison Avenue, assembled railroad officials and employes from all parts of the country, and as far West as Denver.

It was to be expected that during a period of commercial and industrial depression on both sides of the Atlantic the "foreign unclaimed estate" industry would languish and even suffer great injury by reason of the embarrassment of some who had promoted the growth of it, but the reverses which it has experienced have been exceptionally severe and paralyzing.

MADRID, March. 31. -- Advices have reached here from Mindanao, capital of the island of that name in the Malay Archipelago, showing that further trouble has occurred between the Malays and the Spanish troops. A strong force of Malays, armed with modern weapons and led by the Sultan of Ate, made an attack upon the Spanish military station at Lepanto, on the island of Mindanao, and captured the place.

The strike in the new building of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company, which was ordered by the Board of Walking Delegates on Friday, and the lock-out of the Brotherhood carpenters in the buildings of the Postal Telegraph Company and the Home Life Insurance Company, which were effected at the request of the same board, were continued yesterday.

The compositors employed on three of the Brooklyn afternoon newspapers went out on strike yesterday. The three papers affected are The Brooklyn Daily Times, The Stand- ard-Union, and The Citizen. For a time there was doubt about the three papers being published yesterday. The Times and Standard-Union, however, came out on time, but The Citizen was several hours late.

TARRYTOWN, March 31. -- This old town, rich in historic scenes and memories, has within its bounds one of the oldest and most beautiful cemeteries in the vicinity of the metropolis. The Superintendent says it is over 250 years old. The storm-beaten old red sandstone tombstones marking many of the graves seem to verify the statement.

FRIEDRICHSRUH, March 31. -- Count Herbert Bismarckand his wife, born Hoyos; the Count and Countess William, and Count Rantzau and his wife, born Bismarck, are here helping the old Chancellor receive deputations and read messages of congratulation. Vast quantities of flowers were received by express to-day, and numerous more substantial presents have been brought by every train.

George Hendrickson, Captain of the Flatlands police force, who was indicted by the Kings County Grand Jury Friday for oppression, was arrested by Detective Bagnarello of the District Attorney's office yesterday.

The professor of the Royal College of Surgeons here makes no pretensions to writing a history of chemical science. His volume consists of brief biographical sketches, treating of the specific labors of Robert Boyle, Joseph Priestley, Carl Wilhelm Scheele, Henry Cavendish, Lavoisier, Graham, Wohler, Jean Baptiste Andre Dumas, Kopp, and Mendeleef.

"It takes brains for two people to live in New-York on $20 a week," remarked a well-known literary woman not long ago, and she might have added that such brains would be exercised in attempts to increase that limited income.

BERLIN, March 31. -- When the Reichstag resumes work on Thursday, the opponents of Dr. Johannes Miquel's finance reforms will find themselves face to face with an unexpected crisis. During the parliamentary recess, the position of the Prussian Finance Minister has been strengthened immensely by the Emperor's granting him free hand to deal with the Opposition.

WEDNESDAY, April 4. -- By George R. Read, foreclosure sale, William B. Andersen, referee, 176 West One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, south side, 225 feet east of Seventh Avenue, 25 by 99.11, five-story brick flat. Due on judgment, $4,560; on prior mortgage, $22,000.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Secretary Hoke Smith has decided not to close the New-York warehouse for Indian supplies. His decision is embodied in the following letter to the Commissioner of Indian Affairs:

Bonnie McKay was a type of many young girls who are pretty, winsome, winning, and thoroughly in love -- with themselves. She was as thoughtless as her Christian name, which surely must have been bestowed in a spirit of prophecy. Outside of dress and good cheer, for she was ethereal enough looking to be greedy, her tastes were few and simple.

HAMBURG, N.Y., March 31. -- The Bank of Hamburg was broken into by burglars shortly after 2 o'clock this morning. The front door of the bank was forced open and the drawers rummaged. Nothing but a bundle of stamps was taken. It is said there was $800 worth of stamps in the bundle, which had not been opened for use.

BORDEN, Ind., March 31. -- Six stores and eighteen houses were destroyed by a fire which started at 3 o'clock this morning in Burns's flour mill. Two engines were sent from Albany on a special train, and a fire steamer was also sent from Salem, Ind., but they arrived too late to be of service. The total loss is $125,000.

A meeting of the Colonial Dames of the State of New-York was held at the residence of Mrs. Howard Townsend last Wednesday. An interesting paper was read upon Hendrick Hudson and the earliest voyagers and discoverers of America. The society lays great stress upon the fact that its work is not social but historic and patriotic.

"The last time we left Harlem," said "Phil" King of the Princeton baseball team to a throng of students from Nassau Hall last night, "we were the happiest beings on the face of the earth. But tonight it is different," and he smiled one of his prettiest half-back smiles.

Prof. Robertson Smith has died at an age, still under fifty, which seems surprisingly young for the termination of the career of a polemical scholar, who has been so much in view for many years. In most cases, such a scholar does not attain until ripe years the position of an authority.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 31. -- By the laws of Maryland the season for catching and selling terrapin expired at midnight tonight. It had continued since the 1st of last November, and, as far as prices are concerned, it has been profitable. The highest prices ever known have been reached -- $90 a dozen.

PARIS, March 4. -- Black and white, white and black. What, again? Toujours. Encore? Yes, again, but full of lace, jet, and embroidery. Nothing is more becoming and nothing half so economical. People forgot it, while blue, pink, or yellow make an indelible impression upon the minds of our best friends.
There are some things of importance that were said at the discussion last evening on "New-York's Saloons" which the newspaper reports do not fully bring out.

At the semi-monthly conference of those interested in municipal government at the Amity Building Thursday night, at which New-York saloons were discussed, Robert Graham Secretory of the Church Temperance Society, used some rather strong language in describing the saloonkeepers. Mr. Graham was selected to reply to a speech of Morris Tekulaky, a liquor dealer at 113 Park Row, and President of the Liquor Dealers' Association, of the State of New-York.

"He will never do it; no, Sir, he will never do it. He's going to Washington, and Platt nor nobody else could get him to do it," said the battered and dusty individual who claimed the other day that he was a Captain here in the interests of Coxey and his army.

Mayor Schieren does not want to run for Governor. His declaration to that effect will be a disappointment to the politicians who were bent on making him a candidate. They do not even accept his disclaimer as final.

There is little talk of yacht racing just now, and yacht clubs seem to have a mania for tinkering with their constitutions. The New-York Yacht Club has made several changes to facilitate the management of its affairs. The New-York Yacht-Racing Association has been grievously troubled with some amendments to its rules all the Winter, and now the Atlantic Club is going to tackle its constitution and by-laws.

A writer recently contributed a paper to a magazine on the subject of "Child Study," advocating its incorporation into the curricuil of our colleges and universities. The writer has been forestalled by eight years in the Mothers' Club of Milwaukee, which, sprang into being and has existed for n6 other purpose than to comprehend the child in all his phases, physical, mental, and moral.

PARIS, Saturday, March 10. -- Alas, alas! Another Parisian restaurant landmark is passing away. This makes the third within a few months. Tortoni, Cafe Riche, and now Bignon. Bignon of the Avenue de l'Opera, of course.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The report that Thomas E. Benedict of Ellenville, N. Y., is to receive the appointment of Public Printer is confirmed. There have been a number of candidates for the place, three of whom, Messrs. O'Donnell, McAdee, and Ulrica, were from Chicago. Others were A. S. Edwards of Wilmington, Del., and F. A. Crandall of Buffalo, N.Y., all of whom were conspicuously well indorsed.

The Kossuth Memorial Committee has decided that on Wednesday, April 4, the different societies assemble at 12:30, on the side streets below Fourteenth Street, between First and Second Avenues. The head of the column, composed of fifty Hungarians on horseback, to be on Thirteenth Street and Second Avenue.

LONDON, March 31. -- The reported marrlage of Lord Francis Henry Hops, the presumptive Duke of Newcastle, to May Yohe, the American actress, cannot be verified. The Windsor Peerage is responsible for the statement that such a marriage has taken place, but the announcement lacks the elements of verisimilitude, in that it is not accompanied by the usual details as to the date and place of the ceremony.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- The stock market has been strong all day; practically everything advanced, in price. There was further covering on the part of the traders in St. Paul, but there is still a fairly goodsized short interest in that stock. Pennsylvania and Reading were both steady and dull, at about yesterday's prices. Lehigh Valley was dull, but steady, around 40 to 40 1/4.

Up to this time there has been no sign of unloading in the way indicated, and the market shows an unyielding strength despite the unvarying tale from the railroads of decreasing earnings. The speech of Mr. Depew at the trunk line meeting told the feeling over the business situation among the leading men there.

A curious phase of McKinleyism has manifested itself in Russia. The steps taken by the Imperial Government to restrict the business of American life insurance companies, or to exclude them altogether from the Russian Empire, have been professedly prompted by a paternal regard for the Czar's people, but it is pretty well established that the real motive is a desire to protect the "home industry" of the Russian insurance companies.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 1 -- Lambert W. Jackson confessed to-day that he recently attempted to cremate the family of John D. Connett. The confession was made hi the Freehold Court, the accused retracting his former plea of not guilty.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- South American diplomats in Washington believe that the political situation in Peru, owing to the death of President Bermudez, is critical. Gen. Canevaro, the Peruvian Minister, has not been officially informed of the death of Bermudez, the press dispatches announcing the fact being the only information he has regarding the event.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 1 -- The fourth annual dual meeting between Yale and Harvard athletes will be held in New-Haven on May 14, and, as a result of the selection of this date, the annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Track Athletic Association will take place in New-York on May 26, probably on Manhattan Field.

PRINCETON, April 1 -- Plans are being prepared, under the direction of Trainer Goldie, for a new college gymnasium. The crowded quarters of the present one have long emphasized the need of a now one. This Winter the number of track candidates was so large that it was necessary for them to report in squads.

HALIFAX, April 1 -- The steamer Stockholm City, of the Furness Line, which arrived to-day from London, reports having encountered heavy head gales, during which her deck was swept, after rail and cattle pens on starboard side smashed, and quarter boat and derrick carried away.

NEW-DORP, S.I., April 1 -- The story of the troubles of the little Episcopal Church of the Holy Comforter in Eltingville, told in The New-York Times, has gained wide circulation in this vicinity. As a result, the church was crowded this morning. Many persons had come expecting that something sensational would occur, but they were disappointed.

The recent unfavorable remarks respecting the Freeland expedition to Mount Kenia have induced the Secretary of the Berlin section of the Freeland Society to send a letter to the papers, in which, among other things, he writes as follows: "The assertion that England has given us the necessary land is erroneous, for it does not belong to England, but only to the British sphere of interest.

The movement referred to in our London dispatches yesterday morning for the passage of a law giving to the inheritors of a seat in the House of Lords the privilege of seeking election to the House of Commons is a most significant one. Such A law would do more to reduce the House of Lords to an entirely harmless position than any change in the rights of its members.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 1 -- William D. Bishop one time President of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, a former Congressman and State Senator from the district which includes this bustling manufacturing city, is fully in sympathy with the movement for Constitutional reform in this State.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senator Irby, the Populist, received the following telegram this evening from John Gary Evans at Columbia, S.C.: "We are in command of the situation. The country militia have responded promptly, and the law will be enforced at all hazards. The people still rule."

The chasm between the warring divisions of the building trades has not been bridged. Pursuant to the understanding arrived at Saturday, the delegates from the Board of Walking Delegates presented themselves shortly after 2 P. M. yesterday at 139 East Fifty-ninth Street. They found the District Council of the Brotherhood of Carpenters in executive session.

The Methodists of Brooklyn are busily preparing for the forty-sixth assembly of the New-York East Conference, which open in the Nostrand Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, in that city, to-morrow. There are several hundred ministers in the conference.

We give this morning a number of instances investigated by The Times of pensioners who are drawing money from the Treasury for "disabilities" incurred in the service, the peculiarity of which is that they were not officially discovered until from twenty to twenty-five years from the date of their alleged origin.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- President MeCoy, ruler of the famous little community on Pitcairn Island, has arrived here on the missionary brig Pitcairn. McCoy is a descendant of Boatswain McCoy, one of the mutineers of the Bounty who settled on Pitcairn Island many years ago. The community comprises 128 people.

DARLINGTON, S.C., April 1 -- Mayor Dargan last night sent telegrams to the heads of all posses in pursuit of the constables who, after their conflict with citizens, took refuge in the swamps, to come back to town, as they were needed here. This, it was thought, would bring all the men back, and so it happened -- by this morning all the constables were free to go where they pleased.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 1 -- Perparations are being made for the ninth annual convention of the American Association for the Advancement of Physical Education, which will be held at Tale April 5, 6, and 7. The meetings will take place in the gymnasium, and word has been received from nearly all the leading college and athletic club Directors of the country stating that they will be present at the session.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Laredo, April 1 -- Congress opened this evening. The President's message is, in fact, as follows: In regard to the invasion of Mexican territory by Texas police a month ago, while searching for a presumed criminal, friendly explanations have been made, and the matter has been terminated.

LONDON, April 1. -- The rates of discount last week were 1 1/2 for three months and 1 3/4 for thirty days. The influx of gold at the bank continued, and there was no sign of a strong demand abroad. The price of silver was firmer and higher. Business of the Stock Exchange increased in volume and an animated and confident tone was noticeable.

"Bremen Line steamship outside of bar -- cannot distinguish signal." This message was flashed from Sandy Hook at 11:50 last night. As overdue steamships are wont to make their appearance off the bar about the midnight hour, there were at once some hasty calculations as to how long it would take the longlooked-for Ems to reach Quarantine.

MADRID, April 1 -- In view of the recent Malay attacks on Spanish troops in Mindanao, the Government has decided to establish in the heart of the island a system of strong forts communicating with Rio Grande Bay and Illana. At the latter place a large garrison will be stationed.

JAMAICA, L.I., April 1 -- The Spring elections in Queens and Suffolk Counties take place Tuesday. In nearly all the towns in both counties there are three tickets in the field, and the balloring promises to be lively.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The River and Harbor Appropriation bill, the preparation of which has occupied the attention of the committee for the past four months, carries an appropriation for the fiscal year ending June, 1895, in round numbers, of about $9,500,000, which is $12,000,000 less than the appropriation for the current fiscal year, and $30,000,000 less than the estimates submitted by the United States engineers.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 1 -- Eleven companies of State troops left here at 5 o'clock this afternoon for the scene of disturbance. It Is said that they are first to toe taken to Florence. What they will do next Is a mystery. Gen. Richbourg, the commander, would not say anything about his orders.

Copyright. 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, April 1 -- The Bismarck birthday celebration, which began on Friday, monopolized public attention during the last days of the week. To-day's newspapers give prominence to the old Chancellor's speech at the reception of the Rhineland women's committee.

The Right Rev. Dr. William Paret, Bishop of Maryland, delivered a lecture in St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon on the subject: "St. Peter and the Primacy of the Roman See."

The Engineering and Mining Journal has collected some valuable statistics of the mineral and metal production of the United States in 1893 for its second volume of "The Mineral Industry; Its Statistics, Technology and Trade," which is now in press. Notwithstanding the depressed condition of trade during the last half of 1893, the mineral industries have maintained in most cases the maximum output of prer vious years.

There were three successive revisions of the Wilson bill in the Senate Committee on Finance. The original revision, made by the sub-committee, retained the House bill's free list and slightly reduced the House bill's duties. The second revision was that which the sub-committee prepared after the conferences at which the McKinley Democratic Senators made known their demands.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 1 -- The atmosphere about the college is decidedly theatrical. Attention is of course centred upon the Latin play, but there is also much curiosity over the forthcoming Hasty Pudding and Delta Upsilon theatricals. The Deutscher Verein play, "The Portrait," was successfully given in Brattle Hall last Monday evening.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., April 1 -- The confession of Nicholas Nagle, in Amsterdam, N.Y., yesterday, in which he said that he killed his wife here ten years ago, has produced a decided sensation. Though it bids fair satisfactorily to clear up a New-Jersey murder mystery of long standing, it presents a hard knot for the police to untangle.

NEW-YORK. Monday, April 2 -- A.M. While the stock market has not been active, it has enjoyed a very firm undertone, and its condition is regarded as satisfactory by close observers. The veto of the Blanad Seigniorage bill was the important event of the week.

The family of the late Abbe Faure, who was for seven years Chaplain of the Roquette Prison, and in this capacity saw a great deal of the murderers who were sentenced to the guillotine, is bringing out a volume of his "Reminiscences," to which he was putting the finishing touches when he died.

There was no disturbance at the Central Park Baptist Church, East Eighty-third Street, yesterday. Services were held morning and evening. At the first service no policemen were on duty, as has been the case at every meeting held in the church for several weeks. But at the night service a policeman stood guard at the door, as if expecting that there might be trouble.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- To-morrow, at about 2 o'clock, when Mr. Voorhees, Chairman of the Finance Committee, calls up the Tariff bill in the Senate and makes the opening speech, he will begin a debate the end and outcome of which no man can foretell. Mr. Voorhees confidently expects the final vote to be taken within six weeks, but Mr. Voorhees's expectations on other occasions have not always been realized.

The Rev. J. F. Carson, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, last evening delivered a second sermon on the McKanes and Breckinridges in the Church, in the course of which he again denounced he Congressman, in severe terms.

John Wanamaker's life is insured for $1,700,000, by far the largest amount of insurance carried by any American, and, with one or two exceptions, probably the largest amount carried by anybody in the world. The premiums on this enormous sum amount to $90,000 annually, which of itself would be a pretty good line of insurance for the ordinary mortal.

The evangelistic campaign was continued yesterday with meetings in three theatresNiblo's Garden and the Thalia, under the direction of the Central Committee for Evangelical Work, and the Academy of Music, under the direction of the Metropolitan Hall Forward Movement.

BUDA-PESTH, April 1 -- Louis Kossuth was burled to-day. Enormous crowds had gathered from all parts of Hungary to attend the funeral and mourn with the people of the capital. The streets were filled almost from wall to wall until sunset. The police and military had prepared for disorder, and even riot, but nothing happened to disturb the solemnity of the day.

The rates of pension for different disabilities are fixed by law or rulings of the Bureau of Pensions, authorized by law. The application of these rates to the cases of the many claimants for pensions la made by the Medical Division of the Bureau. This acts through its local agents, the Boards of Examining Surgeons, who, in most cases, actually examine the claimant and recommend a rating to the Medical Division.

ALEXANDRIA, Ind., April 1 -- The Whiteside Block, on Main Street, was demolished just before midnight last night by an explosion of natural gas, resulting from a leak in the basement. Seven men were buried in the ruins, of whom four were burned to death and three were taken out badly injured. The killed are:

BEAVER FALLS, Penn., April 1 -- This has been a red-letter day for Coxey. One hundred and fifty recruits joined the army here, and, besides this, the people of Braver Valley tendered the Commonwealers the biggest reception received since the march was taken up. Mr. Coxey, Carl Browne, and "Unknown" Smith to-night are in a jubilant frame of mind, and more than ever believe that their undertaking will be an unequivocal success.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Owing to the prolonged contest in the House over the O'Neill-Joy election case, the Committee on Military Affairs has not had the chance that might have offered by this time of bringing up the Army Appropriation bill, which will be the first measure of much importance to be disposed of at the request of the Chairman.

From The Buffalo Express. A Washington Street Chinaman changed his sign the other day, name and all. Every one has the sign fever nowadays, and he thought he would he in line with the Melicanmen. One of his customers stepped in to see if a new Chinaman had taken possession of the place.

WEST POINT, N.T., April 1 -- A circular has been sent to each surviving member of the class of 69 inviting them to hold a reunion at the Military Academy on the twenty-fifth anniversary of their graduation, which will be next June. It is announced that besides the pleasure of renewing old associations, there will be other important events to interest the members.

From The American Missionary. The congregation came, walking in the mud and rain from five to sixteen miles. One mother, a widow with, seven children, came without shoes and poorly clad and gave 15 cents, all she had. When she hobbled up to the table she gave the congregation an earnest look and said:

The Legislature will do nothing With the Chamber of Commerce Rapid-Transit bill unless compelled to take action by the force of public opinion. Tammany opposes this bill apparently because it wants something else. The Republicans at Albany will not willingly authorize a public work that might conceivably give aid and comfort to their opponents in this Democratic city during the next four or five years.

The Rev. Alexander Irvine, pastor of the Church of the Sea and Land, at Henry and Market Streets, gave very free expression last evening to his opinion of Police Justice Patrick Divver and Morris Tekulsky, President of the Liquor Dealers' Association. Mr. Irvine is a Scotchman bred in the most rigid school of Scotch Presbyterianism, and he does not hesitate to tell what he thinks.

BABYLON, L.I., April 1 -- The trout-fishing season opened, on Long Island yesterday. The weather was unfavorable for trout fishing. A cold, raw wind was blowing, and the water was very rough. The forty odd members of the South Side Club, at Oakdale, were out as early as 5 o'clock this morning, well bundled up to protect them from the cold wind.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 1 -- Gen. Frye and his industrial army, winch arrived from California last night at 7 o'clock, left at 9:30 o'clock to-night for Washington, via Memphis, taking possession of an Iron Mountain Railroad train. The army numbered 600 on its arrival, and was reinforced this evening by 150, who arrived from Texas in stock cars, and at the roll call to-night the number was 810.

SING SING, April 1 -- Every village has its proverbial "oldest inhabitants," who are always consulted when anything out of the ordinary happens, to see whether they knew of anything similar in the days long past and almost forgotten.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, April 1 -- Ex-Chancellor Bismarck's assurance, in his address to the women, that everybody is loyal has been contradicted unexpectedly in the last few days from a quarter where the traditional defenders of the monarchy hold full sway.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The speech of Representative W. J. Talbert of South Carolina, delivered Friday night at the session devoted to the consideration of private pension bills, appears in The Congressional Record to-day, carrying the first chapter of the exposures of The New-York Times of the fraudulent practices carried on in the State of New-York under the pension laws in the name of patriotism.

Charles. E. Bartholomew, the College Place publisher, who was arrested Saturday afternoon by Deputy United States Marshal Grapt on a warrant issued by United States Commissioner Shields, on an indictment found March 12 by the United States Grand Jury, took care, when he was lodged in Ludlow Street Jail, to insist that he should be protected from questioners.

The action of the railroad Presidents and managers of the Trunk Line Association, Inspired by the plain and vigorous speech of President Depew of the Central, seems to have had a bracing effect. At all events, it averted what threatened to be a disastrous rate war, and it must have left an enduring impress upon the minds of railroad managers beyond the domain of the association.

The three Brooklyn physicians who refused to attend the colored minister, the Rev. George E. Smith, Wednesday night, when he was dying, were vigorously denounced at the clergyman's funeral yesterday. The funeral services were held in the afternoon in the Zlon African Methodist Episcopal Church, South Third and Hooper Streets, Brooklyn, of which Mr. Smith was pastor.

WASHINGTON. April 1 -- The story that was sent out from here to-day to the effect that Gov. Northen had offered the Senatorship from Georgia to Clyde Shropshire is stated to be entirely unauthorized and unfounded. Neither Speaker Crisp nor any other member of the Georgia delegation had any information on the subject whatever and gave no credence to the story.

The gymnasium members of the Young Men's Christian Association at Twenty-third Street are making active preparations for their last grand public exhibit, which will be held Friday evening, April 20, in the gymnasium. Dr. J.H. McCurdy, the physical director, and his assistant, L.E. Ballard, have arranged an excellent programme, which will include something of practically all the various branches of gymnasium work.

Music Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, was crowded to its fullest capacity yesterday morning to hear Prof. Felix Adler's lecture before the Society of Ethical Culture on "The Influence of Woman."

Much interest is now taken in the work of the horses entered for the Brooklyn Jockey Club Handicap. At Gravesend yesterday the threatening weather did not deter a large crowd from journeying to the track. They had a fair day, after all.

LONDON, April 2 -- The Times announces this morning the death of Major Le Caron, who was once employed by the British Government as a spy upon Irishmen in America. The Times says: "He died yesterday afternoon, after suffering some time from a painful malady. He bore the pain with the fortitude and iron resolution, characteristic of his whole career."

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., April 2 -- General Improvement Commissioner William H. Williams of this city, a brother of Police Inspector Williams of New-York, learned to-day of the fatal injury of his sister, Mrs. A.K. Irving of San Francisco, and the death of a niece and her babe in a fire in their home in that city.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Tariff bill its at last the subject of debate in the Senate. At 2 o'clock to-day Mr. Voorhees, Chairman of the Finance Committee, fired the opening gun of the discussion which is to precede action on the measure. He was accorded the compliment of an attentive Senate and crowded galleries.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The official comparative statement of receipts and expenditures of the United States for the nine months of the current year, issued to-day, shows that the expenditures have exceeded the receipts $55,432,000. In March the expenditures exceeded the receipts $6,295,000.
The reorganized Democratic Party of Kings County will hold its first formal meeting to-night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The assemblage will be called the County Reorganization Committee.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 2 -- The wheat in this part of the State has stood the Winter well, not being materially damaged by the blizzard last week.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 2 -- Gov. Northen this morning appointed Patrick Walsh, editor of The Augusta Chronicle, United States Senator to succeed Senator Colquitt.

The final debate on the Tariff Reform bill entered on its first stage yesterday with the elaborate speech of Senator Voorhees, Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Senate. We give this morning a very full abstract of the speech. It was a clear exposition of the purposes of the committee and an able argument for the bill.

An enthusiastic meeting of the anti-Tammany Democracy of the Second Assembly District was held at 80 East Broadway last night. John J. Hoffman presided. John J. Murphy, who was formerly a member of the Tammany General Committee from the Eighteenth District, was the first speaker.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- The demand for West Chicago stock was brisk. It opened at 156 1/4 and advanced rapidly to 157 8/4. It then reacted to 156 1/2. Offerings of North Chicago were exceedingly light, the sales aggregating only about 500 shares, at 257@ 258 1/2. Lake Street opened at 24 7/8, but later fell off over a point.

LONDON, April 2 -- The North German Lloyd steamer Ems, which sailed from Bremen for New-York on March 17, was towed into Fayal, Azores, this morning by the British steamer Wild Flower. The propeller frame of the Ems broke a few days after the steamer left Southampton, on March 18, and the big ship was obliged to proceed as best she could under canvas, until the Wild Flower was sighted and took her in tow.

There has been for some time much gossip and discussion among the officers of the National Guard in reference to a reported conflict of authority between Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald and Adjt. Gen. Josiah Porter. It was reported that Gen. Porter claimed to have given orders March 24 to Gen. Fitzgerald, as commander of the First Brigade, to notify Lieut. McCrystal of the Sixty-ninth Regiment that he had been selected to form a new company.

James Gray was found dead by a policeman at the side of Joseph Flanigan's saloon, Thirty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, at 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning. There was a small hole on the top of Gray's head from which blood was flowing.

NEW-YORK, Monday, April 2 -- P.M. Stocks usually classed as active, closed fractionally lower to-day, and on greatly restricted business. The opening was marked by free selling by houses which usually do business for foreign operators. Louisville and Nashville, Atchison, and St. Paul were all offered down, and for a time it looked as if the good feeling had exhausted itself.

Aubrey Tanqueray in Pinero's play describes his second wife as "a good woman -- maimed." Presumably the tuberculous heroine of "La Dame aux Camellias" is also "a good woman -- maimed." These female persons are always "more sinned against than sinning." Clara Morris, in the character of the last-mentioned "maimed" woman, began a short engagement at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last evening.

When the Hon. Patrick Walsh of Georgia takes the vacant chair of the late Senator Colquitt the eyes of the country will for a time be fixed upon him. He is already well known in the world of politics as a gentleman of marked ability, as the editor of a very good newspaper, and as a member of the Democratic National Committee.

LONDON, April 2 -- The Bering Sea bill recently introduced in the House of Commons by Sir Charles Russell contains eight clauses and two schedules. The first clause provides that the arbitration award as set forth in the first schedule shall have effect as enacted by this act, and that any one contravening this act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor within the meaning of the Merchant Shipping act of 1854.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Col. Breckinridge's direct examination in the suit brought against him by Miss Pollard ended at noon to-day. After recess, the Kentucky Congressman was surrendered to the mercies of Judge Wilson for cross-examination.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The President set at rest a good deal of gossip to-day by appointing Thomas E. Benedict of New-York to be Public Printer, James D. Yeomans of Iowa to be Inter-State Commerce Commissioner, and Charles H.J. Taylor of Kansas to be Recorder of Deeds in the District of Columbia.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- The Phillies and the University of Pennsylvania boys met again this afternoon and the collegians were again defeated, the score at the end of the seventh inning being 16 to 9. Boyle signed a contract to-day and covered first base for the Phillies. The score:

"Excellent," "Up to date," "Full of wit," were some of the expressions of approval given by the fashionable and large audience that filled the Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre last evening to see the Columbia College Musical Society's new musical extravaganza of "Joan of Arc; or, the Monarch, the Maid, the Minister, and the Magician," Guy Wetmore Carryl, '95, Arts, the author of the burlesque, scored a success.

ANNAPOLIS, April 2 -- The naval cadets have waked up in baseball. This sport has not been played with much skill by the academy teams for some years past, but it is evident that this year the team will give a god report of itself. It has now what it has not possessed for some seasons -- a pitcher.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- For the first time since the death of Associate Justice Lamar, in January, 1893, the Supreme Court of the United States convened to-day with a full membership on the bench. Associate Justice Jackson returned to the city last week from Florida, where he had been sojourning for a time for the benefit of his health. He still bears evidence in his appearance of the illness through which he has passed.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 2 -- A thousand Polish laborers surrounded a number of the Barber Asphalt Company's employes in Lothrop Avenue this morning and threatened to stone them to death. Several were injured by the stones that were thrown. A twenty-five-thousand-dollar machine used for grading was also badly damaged.

"There may be another inquiry. The defense must not imagine that there is only one theory as to the death of Miss Fuller and lay aside the theory of the people. Their theory is suicide. Our theory is murder."
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughput the day.

The most obvious comment upon the troubles in South Carolina is to recall the recent remarks of Mr. Hewitt about the crass ignorance of the Southern politicians of our day. There is an inexhaustible fund of ignorance in the South of to-day, and it is coming to be represented, to the exclusion of everything else, in the State Governments of several Southern States and at the national capital.
BOSTON, April 2 -- Eight women were arrested to-day on charges of shoplifting in one store. Most of the women were detected stealing at the glove counter. The women were evidently not associates.

W.R. Grace Co. yesterday received a cablegram from their representatives in Lima stating that President Bermudez was dead, and that Second Vice President Justiniano Borgono had assumed the reins of power. The dispatch ran as follows: "President dead, Borgono assumed power, Everything quiet here."

Charles Edouard Brown-Sequard, the physiologist and physician whose report of experiments made in the treatment of debility, by the new method, four years ago, was one of the sensational scientific events of the time, died in Paris Sunday, of congestion of the brain.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 2 -- Yale defeated Williams at baseball this afternoon by the score of 9 to 6. College enthusiasm to witness the opening game of the season on the home grounds attracted a large crowd of spectators, who roundly applauded the Yale players as they trotted on the field for preliminary practice.

LONDON, April 2 -- The newspapers, commenting on the revenue returns for the financial year which ended on Saturday, without exception express surprise and gratification at the change in the economic situation which is disclosed.

RONDOUT, April 2 -- The Delaware and Hudson Canal, running from this city to Honesdale, Penn., was opened for business to-day. Twenty boats were locked into it, and started on their way to the coal fields. Loaded boats will begin to arrive here in about a week. The price of coal was reduced here by the company to-day from 40 to 85 cents a ton.

ANNAPOLIS, April 2 -- There will be no Gloucester or Guttenberg in Maryland. The bill to prohibit poolselling, except for thirty days in a year, on legitimate events to be decided in the State, passed the House to-day. It will probably receive the Governor's signature.

The regular monthly meeting of the Young Women's Christian Association was held in the parlors of the association building, 7 East Fifteenth Street, yesterday morning, and full reports of work accomplished during the past month was read by the heads of the committees.

The doings of the Lyman court-martial yesterday were marked by the usual tameless which is a characteristic of such proceedings. George E. Kent was there as a civilian attorney for the accused, and Commander Heyerman, whose trial for the loss of the Kearsarge preceded that of Lieut. Lyman, was also in attendance.

T.C. Platt had some more fun last night. Through the aid of John E. Milholland he organized the Platt Republican County Committee. He based the right to do this on the curious primary elections which were held not long ago according to his orders.
CINCINNATI, April 2 -- John. W. Caldwell won a victory to-day in the Mayoralty election. Returns now in are as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Morgan, from the Committee on Foreign Relations, reported a bill on the subject of preservation of seal life in Bering Sea, which was read at length. Mr. Morgan said he would ask the Senate to consider the bill after Senator Voorhees should conclude his opening speech on the Tariff bill.

BOSTON, April 2 -- Local stocks were quite active and showed decided strength. Mexican Central securities rose sharply and were strong on the advance. The 4s opened at 54 3/4, 1/2 above Saturday's close, and closed 1 3/4 higher, at 56 1/2. The incomes gained 1 point, selling at 15 1/2, and the stock rose 1/2, to 9, remaining steady at that figure.
DARLINGTON, S.C., April 2 -- Gen. Farley, in command of the troops here, is acting as censor, and will allow no news dispatches of an inflammatory character to be sent out from this place.

The fact of wholesale frauds in obtaining or granting pensions cannot be denied, and almost the only answer to the charge that is attempted is the plea that the country owes so much to the soldiers of the civil war that it should not be particular about the basis of their claims to a pension.

It is so rare that any serious accident occurs to a modern, well-built and well-found steamer that we have come almost to ignore the possibility of such an event. But the Ems is eminently such a steamer, and it is evident that by some comparatively slight injury she has been completely disabled and has lain a helpless hulk upon the waters.

The project for a street 35 feet wide west of West End Avenue, below Riverside Park, has been enlarged. Originally, the idea was to have this street extend from Seventy-first Street to Seventy-second Street. Now it is proposed to have it continued down to Seventieth Street. Most of the owners affected by the extension to Seventy-first Street have consented to bear their share of the expense attaching to the plan.

LONDON, April 2 -- The floor and galleries of the House of Commons were crowded to-day when Sir George Otto Trevelyan, Secretary for Scotland, rose to move the bill creating a Scotch standing committee, composed chiefly of Scotch members, to which it is proposed that all Scottish legislation shall be submitted for consideration.

ALBANY, April 2 -- While the Republican leaders of the Legislature are declaring against heavy appropriations and resorting to a "cheese-paring" policy that has not been seen in Albany in a great many years, Gov. Flower this evening served notice that office holders looking for an increase of salary can expect no favors from the State's Chief Executive.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Congress of the United States, for the first time in many years, is showing a determination to force the Central and Union Pacific Railways to a settlement of their indebtedness to the Government. Several efforts have been made in the past to secure this result, but they were generally abortive.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 2 -- A petition was heard in the Probate Court here to-day for the appointment of a guardian of the person and estate of William H. King, the aged millionaire, confined in the Somerville Insane Asylum, in place of his late guardian, David King, who died recently in Washington.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 2 -- James Owen O'Connor, who has been actor, preacher, and lawyer, by turns, and almost a doctor, died at Morris Plains Asylum on Saturday. It is alleged that death was not due to paresis, but Mrs. O'Connor says it was caused by an ailment of the kidneys.

TRENTON, N.J., April 2 -- The Right Rev. Michael Joseph O'Farrell, Bishop of the Diocese of Trenton, died suddenly at 6 o'clock this morning at the episcopal residence. Vicar General McFaul was at his bedside.

The important State issue in Conneeticut is that of so revising the Constitution of the State as to permit an equitable representation of the people in the Legislature. The Democratic Party in the State is committed to this reform, and the Republican Party has shown itself inimical to it, though it has not had the temerity to declare against the principle of equal representation.

The Governor has signed the bill to extend the term of the Board of Electrical Control for three years. This board has done the greater part but not all of the work for which it was created, and has done it, probably, in as short a time as was possible under the conditions which confronted it when it came into existence.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 3 -- Typhoid fever is epidemic in this place. Forty cases have been reported and at least two have resulted fatally. The first cases appeared early last week. Investigation showed that the origin of the epidemic was in the family of George Gould, a dairyman in Verona, two miles west of here.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- As the San Francisco cannot reach Bluefields in all probability before the 9th inst., a day before Admiral Benham will retire, the Navy Department has informed him that he may use his own discretion whether to accompany the ship to the Mosquito coast or return to the United States by the first steamer from St. Lucia.

The Board of Excise yesterday revoked the license of Dwight E. Fowler, the proprietor of the Iroquois Hotel, 613 and 615 Third Avenue. The complaint was made against the place by Capt. Martens of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station, who alleged that the hotel had become the resort of disorderly persons.
Major Edward Duffy of the Sixty-ninth Battalion has probably seen the handwriting on the wall. He evidently realizes that he may be relieved of his duties as an officer in the National Guard.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- In an impromptu speech; which consumed two hours and was not finished, Mr. Allison to-day began an attack on the Tariff bill and the methods of the majority members of the Finance Committee, and in a general way set the pace for the Republican opponents of the measure.

The regular monthly meeting of the Ladies' Health Protective Association was held yesterday morning in the Trustees' Room of the United Charities Building. The principal business was the announcement by Mrs. Ralph Trautman, Chairman of the Legislative Committee, that the association's bill for the baling of stable refuse had not been passed.

There is an encouraging unanimity about the reports of improved business prospects which are received almost daily from the Presidents and managers of Western railroads. Such reports come not only from Western men, who might naturally be suspected of desiring to paint the situation in as bright colors as possible; they come also from Eastern men who have taken the trouble to travel through the West and study the condition of affairs.

ALBANY, April 3 -- Controller Roberts to-day made public the report of D.J. Dewon, who has been conducting an investigation of the books of the Tax Department of the Controller's office. The report states in substance that a careful reading of the facts presented will show four grave errors, to call them by no harsher name, in the conduct of the affairs of the department and in its system of bookkeeping.

TROY, N.Y., April 3 -- In the police court in this city this morning Magistrate Donohue heard the examination of a large number of persons charged with having violated the election law at the city election, March 6. The number included several Inspectors, who were charged with knowingly and willfully permitting repeaters to vote.

For his second triumph in this city, as for his first, Mounet-Sully is indebted to Sophocles. After seeing last night's performance of "Antigone," at Abbey's Theatre, remembrance of Hernani, the Cid, and Ruy Blas is effaced, for a time, at least, and only Oedipus and Creon, two pictures simply arid yet royally grand, remain as measures of the French tragedian's art and proofs of his power.

Only one new point was brought out in the Lyman court-martial yesterday, and that was the establishment of the fact that when those notable observations were taken the Kearsarge was rolling so deeply that accurate sights could not be had Lieut. Hood, one of the deck officers of the vessel, testified that the vessel was rolling about 10 degrees.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 3 -- As a Jersey Central train to-day rounded the curve and approached at a high rate of speed the bridge over the Lackawanna River near Minooka Junction, the engineer was horrified to see a little girl walking on the ties and about half way across the bridge.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Col. Breckinridge and Miss Pollard were each on the stand to-day, and both gaye testimony relating to the alleged letter which the plaintiff claims was written to her in 1886. This is the letter alleged to begin "My Dear Sister Louise," and by which the plaintiff's counsel seek to impeach the testimony of the defendant.

ALBANY, April 3 -- Frank W. Hawley of Pittsford Farms, near Rochester, was sworn to-night before the special committee of the Senate which is inquiring into the letting of contracts for furnishing electric motor power on the canals. Mr. Hawley is the Vice President of the Cataract General Electric Company, which secured the permit.

WHITE PLAINS, April 3 -- On the train on the New-York and Harlem Railroad which left the Grand Central Station at 11:55 last night for White Plains was a good-looking, well-dressed man, thirty-five years old, who appeared to be excited and nervous.

Poor Mr. St. Gaudens must feel that he has fallen among the Philistines. He might even search the Scriptures for a more appropriate and disrespectful comparison and declare that after the manner of artists he has fought with beasts at Ephesus. The trouble is that he and his official supervisors are applying to his work standards that are incommensurable.

TRENTON, April 3. -- A bill making a complete change in the Judiciary of the State is now being considered by the Advisory Committee of the joint caucus and probably will be introduced to-morrow. This bill proposes to do away with the Court of Common Pleas and wipe out all the lay and law Judges in the State.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Republicans of the House as a body are not prepared to take the consequences of refusing to vote on the motion to pass the Seigniorage bill over the veto of the President. Some of them are willing, however, to do so. Gen. Grosvenor of Ohio, who said this morning that he thought he should not vote at all, believed that about twenty Republicans would vote to sustain the veto.

The State Controller has made public the report of Accountant Dewan, formerly a clerk in the Corporation Tax Bureau of the Controller's office, on the rebates made to various corporations during the terms of Messrs. Chapin, Wemple, and Campbell.
