There is a distinct implication all through the report that these rebates were without legal justification and the result of corrupt collusion, front which somebody besides the corporations profited.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The President to-day granted a pardon to a man who was serving the extraordinary sentence of imprisonment for life "and five years." Henry Williams was one of a gang that robbed the United States mails in Northern Texas in 1879. The leader of the gang was the notorious Contrell, who was under a similar sentence until 1892.

ROME, April 3 -- Dr. Bacelli, Minister of Public Instruction, gave a banquet this evening to the French delegates attending the International Medical Congress. The French Ambassador was present, and many cordial toasts were exchanged.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The bill to carry out the award of the Paris Tribunal of Arbitration on the seal fisheries question was passed by the Senate to-day without division.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 3 -- The ill feeling which characterized a part of the municipal campaign in this city was intensified at the election held to-day, and in the Fifth Ward, at 2 o'clock this afternoon, the bitterness culminated in a hand-to-hand conflict and murder.

MONTREAL, April 3. -- The annual report of the Minister of Railways of the Dominion, which has just been made public, shows that during the last fiscal year there were sixty-five main lines of railway in operation in Canada. The number of miles of completed railway was 15,320.

FLUSHING, L.I., April 3 -- A delicate operation was successfully performed, at the Flushing Hospital last evening by Drs. Hicks, Bloodgood, and Lawrence on the twelve-year-old son of Peter Wilson, Superintendent of the Flushing Gas Works. In July the boy became ill from an abscess that had formed between his heart and lungs.

The Chi Psi college fraternity began a three days' business meeting at the Holland House yesterday. Arrangements for the convention were made by the Alumni Association of this city, of which Elbridge T. Gerry is President. He opened the meeting, and will preside at the banquet tomorrow evening at the Holland House.
"It is surprising what great advance are being made in the world."

The material part of the Sheffield bill increasing the powers of the Superintendent of the Police of this city was patched into the Lexow Bi-Partisan Commission bill in the Senate yesterday, without opposition, and then the latter was ordered to a third reading and made a special order for to-day.

Nothing could be more comic than the position in the Republican Party of this city of the Milholland and Platt sketch of a reorganization. The better element met at Cooper Union last week and resolved, as usual, that the saints should inherit the earth, and that it comprised the saints.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 3 -- Contrary to public expectation, the whisky constabulary who reached here on Sunday night in their retreat from Darlington did not resume their raiding here to-day. They took an early morning train out of the city and proceeded to Orangeburg, about ninety miles north of here, where they are resting at present.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 3 -- The election held here to-day resulted in the election of the Democratic ticket. J.W. Blackwood was chosen City Attorney and H. Clay Jones City Clerk.
PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- Though the market was fairly strong all day, at times it had almost a "toppy" look.
Niblo's Garden was, with the exception of the upper gallery, crowded again yesterday with people who had come to attend the evangelistic revival meeting and the concert which preceded it.

The seventh game of the championship chess match between W. Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker was played at the Union Square Hotel yesterday. Lasker opened the game with a Ruy Lopez, and won after forty-six moves.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 3 -- Judge Lippincott's charge to the new Grand Jury of Hudson County was unusually long. In relation to gambling in various forms it was unusually severe. Judge Llppincott arraigned the last Grand Jury for not indicting Sunday liquor sellers arrested in this city, and called the attention of the new jury to the encroachments of the trolley car companies.
CHICAGO, April 3 -- The municipal election held in this city, which probably resulted in success for the Republicans, was attended by rioting such as had not been known here before in many years.

NEW-HAVEN, April 3. -- Representatives of the various street railway companies of the State met to-day and formed an association, which is to be known and incorporated as the Connecticut Street Railway Association, the object of organization being mutual protection and the advancement of kindred interests.

Earnest Democrats from all parts of Kings County crowded the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. Over 4,000 citizens in favor of honest party reorganization attended the mass County Convention called by the Committee of One Hundred.

ALBANY, April 3 -- In the language of a well-known Senator, any quantity of meat is on the bone of the bill of Senator Reynolds, providing that the Exempt Firemen's Fund Association, of New-York City shall receive, until 1907, the tax on foreign insurance companies doing business in New-York City, except in the annexed district.
Gravesend and New-Utrecht were yesterday redeemed from the corrupt rule of their "bosses."

The great meeting at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn last evening has very much more than local interest or significance. It is the most advanced and vigorous effort made in this State to restore to the mass of Democratic voters the control of their own affairs, of which the machine and the bosses have for so long deprived them.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 3. -- The Central Trust Company of New-York is making another effort to oust J.B. Glover from the receivership of the Marietta and North Georgia Railway. A petition to this effect was filed in the United States court this morning by Judge Henry B. Tompkins, who represents the trust company.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Charles F. Joy of Missouri ceased to be a member of the House to-day, and John J. O'Neill, who had contested the right of Joy to hold the seat, was voted into his place. Joy is a Republican, and O'Neill is a Democrat.

CRACOW, April 3 -- The period of celebration of the centennial of the occasion of the taking of the oath by Thaddeus Kosciusko, the last Commander in Chief of the Republic of Poland, which began on March 24, ended to-day. The principal scene of the celebration was the Rang Platz, where Kosciusko swore to fight to the death for the freedom of Poland.

Park Hill, N.H., April 3. -- The old store building and two residences belonging to Fred Pierce, and the residences of J.W. Lord and Eiija Farr, with barns attached, with contents, have been destroyed by fire. It was only after desperate efforts that the new store and Post Office were sayed. The loss will probably be from $15,000 to $20,000, and there is but little insurance. The fire was caused by children playing with matches.

HOBOKEN, N.J., April 3 -- Gustave Lenchal's bakery, 528 Washington Street, was burned at 2:15 this morning. John Taylor of TrucK No. 1 and Charles Suffield and Michael Shanley of Engine No. 1 were badly injured by a ladder which fell upon them. The loss by the fire was $1,500.

Mr. John N. Golding has sold for Mrs. Margaret Heenan, at $125,000, the north-east corner of Liberty and Washington Streets, 50 by 72.4 by 49.8 by 64.3, with five-story brick building. The price is considered reasonable in view of the recent transactions in the neighborhood, where property is coming more and more in demand.

ALBANY, April 3 -- Before the House Cities Committee this afternoon the bill of Mr. Sheffield (Rep., New-York,) abolishing the fees of the Sheriff of New-York and fixing the salary at $15,000 was brought up. Mr. Blandy, the Deputy Corporation Counsel of New-York, appeared against the bill. Mr. Sheffield appeared for it.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, April 3 -- P.M. London traded on both sides of the market to-day, but probably bought more than It sold. Prices from that city came lower, and that fact encouraged the room traders to hammer the market at the opening. Weakness was not developed, however, and within half an hour the closing out of short contracts induced strength.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., April 3 -- The United States revenue steamer Grant arrived at this port late Sunday night from Callao, Peru, to take on board coal and supplies. The cutter is to go from here to San Francisco, and from there to Port Townsend.

It was a decidedly unsavory procession that wended its way into the Tammany Hall Assembly Room during the late hours of Monday night and the early ones of Tuesday morning. The disreputable resorts along the Bowery, in Bond Street, Houston Street, Bleecker Street, and Fourteenth Street were denuded of their frequenters.

The new passenger, agreement entered into by the railroads in the Trunk-Line Association went into operation last Sunday, and, so far as the Commissioners are informed, it is being carried out in good faith by all of the lines interested. The legally-binding contract, containing the $10,000 penalty clause, has not yet been signed, for the reason that it has not been put in proper shape.

The Police Commissioners yesterday fined Capt. Josiah A. Westervelt of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station five days' pay, and Capt. William R. Haughey of the West Forty-seventh. Street Station ten days' pay.
The Professional Woman's League summoned all its members and friends to the Garden Theatre yesterday afternoon to be enlightened upon the subject of the "Twentieth Century Woman."

PRINCETON, N.J., April 3 -- Capt. McKenzie has ordered the following men to continue practicing for the 'Varsity baseball nine, thus reducing the number to fifteen, as follows: Forsythe, Allman, Hitzrot, Bradley, Williams, Otto, King, Brooks, P. Ward, Gunster, W.D. Ward, Payne, Small, and Lindsay.

Nothing has done so much, to breed disrespect for law and to make its enforcement difficult and uncertain as the multiplication of laws which do not accord with the common sense of justice. In all communities laws which are clearly intended for the protection of individual rights and the general welfare are cheerfully obeyed, except by a small class of the grossly ignorant or the criminally lawless.

ALBANY, April 3 -- In the Senate to-day Senator Saxton moved that the vote by which the Smelzer resolution, providing for the appointment of a special committee to investigate the Elmira Reformatory, was passed be reconsidered. Senator Cantor opposed the motion on the ground that all the newspapers in New-York City were in favor of the reinvestigation and because it injected politics into the management of the reformatory.

Ex-Assistant District Attorney Purdy, who astonished Judge Cowing, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions on Monday, by asking to have a case marked as "settled out of court," on the ground that the complainant had been paid not to appear as a witness, renewed his motion before Judge Cowing yesterday morning.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

At the meeting of the Old Guard last evening in the armory, Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, a trip to California during the Summer was proposed. As only a partial representation of the battalion was present, the matter was postponed until a special meeting to be called during the week.

ALBANY, April 3 -- The caucus of Republican members of Assembly, held this evening, decided to unseat two Democratic members, William Hughes of the Seventh Kings District, and Michael McGuire of the Richmond District, in favor of the two Republican contestants, Stillman E. Kneeland and Michael Conklin.
"Has the bottom fallen out of the people's case?" "What does it mean?" "Are they going to spring a trap?" "Can it be that after all the mystery of the prosecution they hadn't a leg to stand on?"

The second day's convention of the Chi Psi Fraternity opened yesterday morning, with Charles P. Emmerson of Amherst in the chair. The business of the morning session was opened with a discussion of matters relating to the fraternity magazine.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- There was a lively exchange of views in the Senate Chamber this afternoon in the Tariff bill debate, which gave the galleries a good idea of the scenes sure to be enacted before the measure shall be disposed of.
The banquet of the New-York Commandery of the Military Order of the loyal Legion was held at Delmonico's last night.

The life and death, the deeds and principles of Louis Kossuth, the great Hungarian patriot, were commemorated last night at an overflow meeting in the great hall of Cooper Union. The demonstration which greeted Kossuth when he landed on these hospitable shores forty years and more ago was not more splendid and impressive.

Boys from Phillips Academy, Andover, and old boys who were Phillips boys once filled the rooms of the Aldine Club, 20 Lafayette Place, between 3 and 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The occasion was the annual reunion of those who have or who have had any connection with the celebrated academy. A banquet is held in NewYork or Boston every year.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., April 4 -- Chief Engineer Joseph H. Paddock of the H.C. Frick Coke Company was brutally murdered by 200 riotous Hungarians at the Davidson coke works at Connellsville, about 3 o'clock this afternoon.

Mr. Frank L. Fisher has sold, for Edward Kilpatrick, to James C. Cahen, the fourstory brownstone dwelling, 354 Central Park West, 20 by 50, at about $25,000, and to Julius Cahen the adjoining similar dwelling, 355 Central Park West, at the same price.

Thomas J. Ahearn, Chief of the Fourth Battalion of the Fire Department, is in the Gouverneur Hospital, grievously burned and injured, but lauded by comrades and citizens for conspicuous heroism at a fire in Rivington Street early yesterday.

CHEBOYGAN, Mich., April 4 -- The propeller Minneapolis, one of the grain fleet which left Chicago Sunday, was sunk in the Straits of Mackinac early this morning. The crew managed to escape, and were brought here on the Santiago and Red Wing. The Minneapolis had a cargo of 48,517 bushels of wheat, which was insured at Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- Almost all the tractions were active to-day, and contributed the bulk of the business done at the Exchange. People's was bought, and bid up to 29 5/8, at which price stock seemed to come out and it reacted afterward and closed at 29 3/8. Even at the concession in prices it looked as strong as it did at the top.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 4 -- John Gregorson, a well-known builder of this place, while crossing Wheelman's Field last night on his way home, was attacked by three men, beaten into unconsciousness, and robbed of $960.

The subject for discussion at the monthly meeting of the Architectural League of New-York last evening was "Is it or is it not desirable that a law should be passed restricting the height of buildings?"

Mr. Bland's Silver bill came before Congress for the last time yesterday when the motion to pass it notwithstanding the objections of the President failed to receive the necessary two-thirds. The vote stood 144 yeas to 114 nays. On the 1st of March the bill was passed by 168 to 144.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., April 4 -- Camped in Everson Grove, near town, to-night, are 1,500 strikers, mostly Hungarians, Poles, and Slays. They are huddled around 100 large wood fires, and sympathizers supplied them provisions for a good meal this evening and breakfast in the morning. They marched to-day from Leisenring and Dickerson Run districts, a distance of twelve miles, and held meetings at Broadford and Moyer on their way here.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., April 4 -- The Oppostion to-day presented a document to the Governor opposing the dissolution of the Legislature asked for by the Government. The Governor's reply probably will be given out to-morrow. The general opinion is that some arrangement will be arrived at before the close of the week by means of Which, the political crisis will be settled.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 4 -- Absolute quiet and peace prevail in the capital just now. The intense excitement of the lastfour days is a thing of the past. There is every appearance that the threatened war and shedding of Wood which seemed so imminent a few days ago will be averted.
The forecast made by The New-York Times as to the Presidential election in Costa Rica has been confirmed by cable. Senor Don Rafael Iglesias, Minister of War and Finance, has been elected President.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Some pensioners whose payments have been stopped by the present Administration have been found by The New-York Times's reporter in Watertown and Potsdam, where the investigation has been carried on. The suspended ones have not been those which are notorious as frauds throughout the communities where the pensioners live.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 4 -- Quarantine flags float over the coffee barks Josephine and Julia Rolling, anchored off the Hawkins Point Quarantine, and passing craft are giving the vessels a wide berth. The vessels arrived from Rio this morning.

The forty-sixth annual session of the New-York East Conference of the Methodit Episcopal Church was begun yesterday in the Nostrand Avenue Methodist Episcoal Church, Brooklyn. About 375 clergymen occupied seats in the body of the church, and the rest of the edifice was crowded with visitors and interested members of the congregation.

Mr. Mills in the Senate yesterday showed the Republicans the difference between the manly way in which a conscientious legislator approaches a serious question and the shuffling of the politician. Mr. Aldrich, in a moment of thoughtless smartness, challenged the Senator from Texas to explain the inconsistencies in the Tariff bill as to the application of ad valorem duties.

The Church of Zion and St. Timothy, West Fifty-seventh Street, was the scene of a pretty wedding last night, when Miss Frances Cythera Twombly was married to J. Monroe Taylor Pope. The bride is a daughter of the late John Fogg Twombly. Mr. Pope is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clarus Pope of 310 East Fifteenth Street.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 4 -- A division of Byron McClelland's thoroughbreds will be sent to Sheepshead Bay Tuesday. Henry of Navarre is much improved, and good judges here believe him the highest class three-year-old out this season, with the possible exception of Senator Grady and Domino.

Traders worked for a reaction to-day, and they met with partial success. The tenor of the news favored their operations, covering, as it did, rate disturbances, rumored further injury to the crops, and decreased railway earnings. The bears were particularly aggressive against General Electric, on the ground that the showing made in the annual report of the company was unfavorable, notwithstanding the large decrease in debt reported.
PARIS, April 4 -- The International Sanitary Convention was signed to-day, the United States and Great Britain making reservations as to a few minor details.
There is great rejoicing in Brooklyn over the success of Democratic reorganization.

EL RENO, Oklahoma, April 4 -- A battleoccurred Sunday between the Indians of Whirlwind's band of Cheyennes and the whites who hold possession of the vacant lands on the old Cheyenne Reservation. A number of men were killed.

A large number of society people attended the wedding of Misa Letitia Blanchard Herbert and Byron Wightman Green, Jr., at the Church of the Divine Paternity yesterday afternoon. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bridges Herbert of 152 West Seventy-third Street. Mr. Green is a well-known member of Company I, Seventh Regiment.

"We find that Martha J. Fuller came to her death on the 17th day of March, 1894, at 114 Nassau Street, Room No. 203, by a pistol-shot wound, but from the evidence we are unable to determine who fired the shot."

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Local stocks were heavy for a brief period during the early hours of the first session, but at the low prices there was evidence of a general disposition, to accumulate securities, and the demand brought about a quick advance. The opening on West Chicago was 156@156 1/2, a point off from Monday's closing.

The rain which fell in torrents yesterday had little effect on the audiences at Niblo's Garden and Cooper Union, where the evangelistic revival meetings are being held. At Niblo's the auditorium was well filled, and at Cooper Union the audience was probably one-fourth smaller than on the previous bright and fair day.

Much surprise is expressed in Brooklyn at the failure of the Legislature to progress the bill to reorganize the management of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge. Thousands of citizens are anxious for the passage of the measure, which removes the members of the present Board of Trustees and authorizes the Mayors of the two cities to appoint their successors.

BOSTON, April 4 -- Local stocks were dull to-day and the market was featureless, even the late specialties being neglected. Sales were all small, with hardly quotations enough to make a market. Mexican 4s sold at 56, with the incomes at 15 and the stock at 9. The falling off in earnings for the last week in March is explained by there being three holidays in the week.

WASHINGTON, April 4 Col. Breckinridge ended his testimony to-day, after having been on the stand almost continuously since Thursday. To-morrow the defense may submit some additional testimony, but it is more likely that the rebuttal of the plaintiff's evidence will begin. There is every indication that all the evidence will be before the jury when the court adjourns Friday until Monday.

RAHWAY, N.J., April 4. -- The Union County Roadsters, known throughout NewJersey as most hospitable entertainers and in the cycling world as the winners of The New-York Times's loving cup at Trenton, N. J., on July 1, 1893, gave a large long table and banquet to the club members, their friends, and the officers of the league in the smoking room of the clubhouse, on Main Street, last night.

Although the naval militia organizations of the States are extending and flourishing remarkably, considering how recently they have been formed, a project already appears in Congress for establishing still another body of reserves.

John D. Townsend, a lawyer, who is active in the Steckler-MoCrea-Harvier "Independent County Organization," one of the anti-Tammany movements, recently issued a long statement attacking Mayor Gilroy and Tammany Hall. At a meeting of the Stockler followers in the Seventh Assembly District Tuesday night Mr. Townsend made a speech following up his first attack in about the same strain.

MONTREAL, Quebec, April 4 -- The thir- teenth annual meeting of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company was held here today. The statements submitted showed the affairs of the company on Dec. 31, 1893, to be as follows:

PARIS, April 4 -- A bomb was exploded at 9:15 o'clock this evening on the windowsill of the Restaurant Foyot, in the Rue de Conde, near the Luxembourg. The restaurant was two-thirds full of late diners.

The movement for a collegiate debating union, which was put on foot a few months ago by Harvard, now looks as if the organization would soon become permanent. A meeting was held yesterday afternoon in the Trustees' room in Columbia College, which was attended by representatives of the debating societies of Harvard, Yale, Columbia, Princeton, and the University of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Third Auditor has sent to the House Committee on War Claims a history of the claim introduced in the House by Mr. Cummings to reimburse the City of New-York for money expended in arming and equipping militia during the war of the rebellion.

ALBANY, April 4 -- The Lexow-Sheffield Bi-Partisan Police bill, whose provisions were published in to-day's New-York Times, passed the Senate unamended this morning, after a three hours' debate, and is now before the Assembly. It is certain to pass the lower house. Democrats who are close to Gov. Flower predict that the bill will be vetoed.

Has been used for over fifty years by millions of mothers for their children while teething, with perfect success. It soothes the child, softens the gums, allays all pain, cures wind colic, and is the best remedy for diarrhea. Sold by all druggists in every part of the world. Twenty-five cents a bottle.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The sentence of the naval court-martial in the case of Commander Heyerman of the Kearsarge is two years' suspension on waiting orders, Heyerman to retain his number and rank. The court recommended clemency. The Secretary of the Navy has not yet approved the sentence.

The annual meeting of the City Club for the election of Trustees and the transaction of other business was held, last evening in the clubhouse, 677 Fifth Avenue. About sixty members were present. W. Bayard Cutting presided.

OIL CITY, Penn., April 4 -- Joseph Kollas, a German, his wife, and three children, living in the northern part of the city, were killed to-night, the result of an explosion at Kollas's home. The whole rear end of the house was blown away and Kollas's body was found dismembered, lying beneath the debris.

COLD SPRING HARBOR. L. I., April 4. -- The large residence belonging to the Charles B. Moore estate, which is occupied during the Summer by the Moore and Bleecker families of New-York, was burned this morning. The fire is supposed to have been of incendiary origin. It was discovered by the superintendent of the estate, Charles Elward, who organized a bucket brigade, but their efforts were useless.

The Annual New-York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, was formally opened yesterday morning in Calvary Church, Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street. Three hundred delegates attended. They were cordially welcomed by the Rev. James R. Day, D.D., and the Rev. F.H. Carpenter, pastor and associate pastor, respectively, of Calvary Church.

The New-York Board of Fire Underwriters, representing all the regular fire insurance companies doing business in this city, has, it is charged, started a fight for the establishment of one of the greatest trusts ever formed in this country.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 4 -- Gov. Tillman's proclamation, taking charge of the police forces of the municipalities is rather laughed at here, although the municipal authorities refuse to speak on the subject.

BERLIN, April 4 -- The court of honor before which the army officers implicated in the Hanover gambling scandal have been tried has sentenced fifteen of the offenders to periods of enforced retirement from military life. The scandal involved more than a hundred military officers of all ranks from a Major General to a Lieutenant.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- Major Gordon W. Lillie, "Pawnee Bill," the famous leader of the Oklahoma boomers, has signed a contract with King Leopold of the Belgian Government to furnish realistic frontier and war scenes, as they actually appeared in the days of '49, to be given in connection with the International World's Fair at Antwerp, Belgium, during the entire Summer, beginning May 5 next.

The application of the Third Avenue Railroad Company for permision to extend its lines was to have had a public hearing before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday. The date was fixed more than a month ago, nevertheless on Tuesday last the Aldermen decided to hold a special meeting of the board yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Great disarrangement of the lineal rank list and many changes in the places of officers would be made by the adoption of the Artillery and Infantry bill now pending in the Military Committee of the House. The bill is an annual effort to reorganize those branches of the service, and it is either approved or condemned by officers as they are to be affected.

"Appendicitis, Strictly a Surgical Disease," was the subject of a paper read last night before the Academy of Medicine by Dr. J.A. Wyeth. Dr. D.B. St. John Roosa presided, and interest in the subject chosen by Dr. Wyeth was manifested by a large audience

BERLIN, April 5 -- Advices from Samoa concerning the recent troubles there and their causes state that the American Chief Justice, Ide, summoned before him seventeen of the discontented chiefs, and compelled them to withdraw all of the complaints they had made against the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- This was a red-letter day in the tractions, the volume of business being much larger than yesterday. Philadelphia opened at 108 1/4, advanced, with hardly a reaction, to 111 1/4, and closed at 110 3/8, offered at 110 3/4. It is whispered around that there is to be a new allotment on Philadelphia Traction.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Mr. Dunphy (Dem., N.Y.,) introduced in the House yesterday a bill authorizing the President to appoint a commission of four persons, one each from the War, Agricultural, Post Office, and Interior Departments, to examine into and report upon the feasibility and desirability of constructing a boulevard from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean.

TRENTON, N.J., April 5. -- The funeral of Michael Joseph O'Farrell, Bishop of the Trenton Diocese, took place this noon, the cermonies commencing in St. Mary's Cathedral at 9:30 A.M. The cathedral was densely thronged throughout the impressive services. Archbishop Corrigan of New-York celebrated a pontifical requiem mass at 10:30 o'clock, and the Very Rev. Thomas Campbell, S.J., President of St. Francis Xavier's College of New-York preached the funeral sermon.

That part of the law of June 27, 1890, which is intended to keep from the pension rolls men who are incapacitated from earning a support at manual labor because of "their own vicious habits" has been ignored by some of those who have had a personal interest in giving pensions to all comers.

PARIS, April 5 -- The excitement caused by the explosion of a bomb in the Restaurant Foyot last night has not abated, but rather has increased, and the fact that the bomb was exploded in front of the Palace of the Luxembourg convinces many that the original intention, was to blow up the Senate Chamber, which shows traces of the explosion.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 5 -- The report of the Dominion Artillery Association, read at the annual meeting this afternoon, contained a paragraph stating that the silver cups promised by the Earl of Derby had not been received by the winning team for 1892. It has been always customary for the Governor General, to give these cups.

The reports of railroad earnings for the fourth week of March indicate a rapid Increase in traffic. There is always a steady growth of railroad business in the Spring, which is usually accompanied by an equal increase in operating expenses, but the successive weekly reports for March show an extraordinary increase in earnings considering the slow recovery of the country from its period of business depression.

BOSTON, April 5 -- Local stocks were generally dull to-day, though a little activity was shown in Lamson Store Service and in Mexican Central. The former advanced 7/8, to 25 1/4. It looked as if the buying was mostly by insiders. Mexican Central was off 1/4, selling at 8 3/4, with the 4s at 65, 1 point below yesterday.

ALBANY, April 5 -- When the State Board of Charities determined to investigate the charges against Z.R. Brockway, General Superintendent of the State Reformatory at Elmira, three Commissioners were named to conduct that work. These Commissioners were Oscar Craig, the President of the board; Dr. Stephen Smith of New-York, ind Edward H. Litchfield of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A telegram has been received in this city announcing that Kim Oh Kun, a Corean political refugee of some note, had been assassinated by a fellow-countryman at Shanghai. About the same time an attempt was made upon the life of Pak Yong, another Corean political refugee, in Tokio, the assailants being three Coreans.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, April 5 -- P.M. After an irregular opening, in which Distilling and Cattle Feeding showed the greatest weakness, declining 2 points within a few minutes, the market became firm and continued so throughout the remainder of the day.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- In the House to-day Mr. McCreary (Dem., Ky.,) asked unanimous consent (which was granted) for the present consideration of the bill to enforce and give effect to the recommendations of the Paris tribunal of arbitration for the preservation of the fur seals. The bill was read and Mr. McCreary explained its provisions.

FRISCO, Utah, April 5 -- The Horn Sliver concentrator works and ore houses were destroyed by fire this morning. The burning timbers fell into the mine, and the fire was communicated to the timber and shafting, so that every level was soon a roaring furnace. The mine is feared to be badly damaged on account of the numerous caves which must have resulted.
The most fashionable hotel in Brooklyn is the Regent, in Clinton Avenue. A suit begun yesterday against the management of the house will make a stir in club, social, and political circles.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 5 -- The children of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould were christened here this afternoon. The ceremony took place at their residence, Gray Gables, and was conducted by the Rev. G. H. McClellan of the Presbyterian Church in the presence of all the members of the Gould family excepting Miss Anna, who is in Europe, and some friends.
"Oh, wise young Judge! Oh, learned Judge!" might have been the cry in a great volume from the audience that filled the beautiful hall of the Mendelssohn Glee Club last evening.

LONDON, April 5 -- Sir George BadenPowell, (Conservative,) M.P. for the Kirkdale Division of Liverpool, and formerly Commissioner to the Bering Sea, questioned the Government in the House of Commons this evening as to the bill providing for the execution of the Paris award. He wished to know whether or not the bill had been fully approved by the Canadian Government.

The trial of Capt. William S. Deyery for willful omission of duty while in charge of the Eleventh Police Precinct was continued in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Justice O'Brien and a jury, yesterday. The proceedings were confined to a further presentation of the case for the people, and much matter of a documentary character was introduced.

The most obvious reflection upon the coke strike in Pennsylvania is the reflection how curious it is that that region of the United States which is supposed to have thrived most by protection, ostensibly in the interest of American labor, should be the region in which "labor troubles" are most frequent and most violent.

A large collection or furniture, porcelains, enamels, engravings, and etchings belonging to George Moreau of Canada is on sale at auction in the Silo Art Galleries, 43 Liberty Street. To-day at 1 P.M. his oil paintings and miniatures will be sold, his colored English sporting prints, engravings, and etchings.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 5 -- The Mallory-Wheeler Company, manufacturer of locks and light hardware, has given notice that, beginning Monday, April 9, the concern will run six days a week and nine hours a day. The employes in all departments have been told of a 10 per cent., reduction in wages.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I have nothing but sympathy and respect for the humane impulse of those sensitive souls who are stirred to protest against the alleged abuses of discipline at the Elmira, Reformatory. I have only severe condemnation, however, for the extra judicial and illegitimate way in which a biased public sentiment has been worked up for months, from sensational and mercenary motives.

FREEHOLD, N.J., April 5 -- It is not definitely settled that Arthur Zimmerman, the champion amateur bicycle rider of the world, will turn professional. He is undecided as to his future movements and will not decide what course to pursue until he has a conference with his manager, Willis B. Troy.

FLORENCE, S.C., April 5 -- This was the last day of the militia occupation of this place, and preparations for breaking camp occupied the day. Gen. Farley returned to town on the early morning train, having arranged for the conveyance of Constable McLendon.

The Ice Dealers' Association of New-York met yesteraay in the Grand Opera House Hall to ratify the advanced scale of prices for ice which was adopted at the preceding meeting and to adopt measures to sustain the scale through the Summer.

The facts of the new Fire Insurance Trust and the efforts of the New-York Board of Fire Underwriters to wipe out the Loyds insurance companies of this State in order to promote the interests of the trust, as published exclusively in The New-York Times yesterday, caused general interest among persons who carry fire insurance.

ALBANY, April 5 -- Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt took hold of the Lexow-Butts Rapid Transit bill this afternoon and punched it full of holes. The speech he made was one of the most able and thorough that a legislative committee has listened to for the last decade.

DARLINGTON, S.C., April 5 -- Dress parade was held on the public square this afternoon, all of the military taking part, Major Westfield of the Hampton Guards commanding. At the conclusion of the parade the soldiers offered three cheers for Mayor Dargan and the citizens of Darlington, which were given with spirit and enthusiasm.

"If I travel from court to court, as I Old to-day," said Lawyer Joseph T. Magee, in his cell, in the Tombs, yesterday afternoon, "I shall have to provide myself with a pedometer to discover what exercise, I am taking."

Much interest was manifested at the sale yesterday in the Trinity Building of the business property at 405 Broadway and 60 Walker Street. The sale was in partition proceedings, and was largely attended, many well-known operators feeing among the spectators. The bidding was especially good, and the prices were satisfactory.

Property owners in the vicinity of Sixty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue held an indignation meeting last evening at the home of A.M. Palmer, 25 East Sixty-fifth Street, and discussed various plans to prevent John Jacob Astor from building a stable at Sixty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue. The meeting was in response to a call sent out to property owners in that vicinity, signed by A.M. Palmer, Frank Russak, Dr. H.W. Mitchell, and Dr. B. Sachs.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Judge Gibbons of the Circuit Court to-day sustained the demurrer interposed by Attorney General Moloney to the pleas submitted by the Whisky Trust as a reply to the application of the Attorney General for leave to institute quo warranto proceedings against the concern.

The announcement that Edward Atkinson would address the Chamber of Commerce drew an uncommonly large attendance to the monthly meeting yesterday. Mr. Atkinson was presented after routine business had been finished, and for more than an hour interested his audience in a talk upon the financial outlook.

ALBANY, April 5 -- The investigation into the affairs of the State Board of Health by the Senate special committee having been concluded last week, Senator Smelzer, the Chairman of the committee, to-day introduced a bill reducing the membership of the State Board of Health from nine to three, to hold office one, two, and three years, respectively.

ALBANY, April 5 -- Superintendent James F. Pierce of the State Insurance Department has completed his annual report for the year 1893 on life and casualty insurance companies doing business in this State. The report shows that the gross assets of the life insurance companies on Dec. 31 last were $971,857,223, an increase of $68,122,686, as compared with the previous year.
ALBANY, April 5 -- The Senate to-day took up the Lexow bill appropriating $25,000 for the expenses of the New-York police investigating committee, and Senator Lexow explained the necessity for it.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I regret to see that The Times is laboring under a misapprehension with reference to the contest now going on in Albany. The facts of the case are very simple. At the last election the fraudulent voting and repeating were so open and notorious that popular indignation was aroused to an extent almost unprecedented in that staid old city.

Although Consul Seat and Mr. Weil, as delegates of the little American colony at Bluefields, have had an audience with Secretary Gresham on the perturbed condition of the Mosquito coast, yet the arrival of the San Francisco at that port will doubtless be eagerly looked for both by the State Department and by the people concerned.

The result of the election in Rhode Island shows how difficult it is in a time of political reaction for State issues to exercise anything more than a modifying influence upon the vote of the people. The same thing has been illustrated in every direction by the city and town elections that have recently taken place, as it was also illustrated in several State elections last Fall.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Col. Breckinridge formally closed his defense to-day. The witnesses called in his behalf were examined apparently with a view of disproving the statement of the plaintiff that she baa given birth to a child in Washington Feb. 3, 1888. Then the rebuttal testimony for the plaintiff began, and continued until adjournment.

DARLINGTON, S.C., April 5 -- Every precaution has been taken to prevent further trouble here. The constables have been kept away from the streets, and under military escort at all times. The people of the country adjoining Darlington are holding conventions and mass meetings in their churches and schoolhouses in which they pass resolutions commending the course of the Governor, and pledging him their support in any emergency.

Princeton and Columbia met on the baseball diamond at Manhattan Field yesterday, and after a lively game the Tigers won. Princeton started off with a good lead, but the Columbia youths never lost heart; on the contrary, they appeared to play with rare vim and determination. Finally in the third inning they touched up Aultman's pitching in a lively manner, and, assisted by errors, scored enough runs to make the game even.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., April 5 -- Coxey's army marched out of Pittsburg to-day, and was cheered by a great crowd for three miles on the tramp to this place. At Beck's Run the Homestead delegation, headed by Elmer Bails, met and conducted the army along Eighth Avenue to the location of the camp of Homestead.
ALBANY, April 5 -- The legislative services in memory of Hamilton Fish took place in the Assembly Chamber to-night. The chamber was beautifully decorated with flowers.

Congressman Breckinridge and John Y. McKane, the convict "boss" of Coney Island, played twin parts yesterday in the New-York Methodist Episcopal Conference, which is in session in Calvary Church, One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue. They were held up as examples of a class of men the Methodist Church does not want, even though one was a Sunday School Superintendent at Gravesend and the other an active figure in church work in Kentucky.

ALBANY, April 5 -- Miss Catherine Barnard Walsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A.H. Walsh, was to-day married to John De Witt Peltz, a prominent lawyer of this city and cousin of Judge William H. Learned. The marriage was celebrated in St. Peter's Church by the Right Rev. William Crosswell Doane, Bishop of Albany, assisted by the Rev. G.H. Walsh of Philadelphia and Dr. Battershall of this city.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- The feature of the market was a phenomenal spurt of activity and a sharp advance in prices for Canal and Dock. At the annual meeting yesterday the old officers were re-elected, and the action of the Directors in purchasing a certain amount of stock at the low prices current during the panic was approved.

"The cheap food stations and five-cent restaurants scattered over the nt parts of the city are doing a great amount of good," said Superintendent Arthur Milbury of the Industrial Christian Alliance to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday, "for the emergency is by no means at an end, and the poor are still in need of help.

ALBANY, April 5 -- John A. Hennessy (Dem., Kings,) was in hot water in the Assembly twice this morning. He arose to a question of privilege and took exception to an article in to-day's New-York Times, which he said charged that he was lobbying against the Bradley bill, which proposes to legislate the Bridge Trustees out of office.
United States Supreme Court. WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Following is the record of to-day's session of the United States Supreme Court:

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The abstract of the reports of the condition of national banks in the United States on Feb. 28 last was to-day made public by Controller Eckels. As compared with a similar report made Dec. 19, 1893, it shows an improved condition of the banks in nearly all respects.

LONDON, April 5 -- A by-election was held to-day in the Middle Division of Lanarkshire to fill the seat which J.W. Philipps, Liberal and Home Ruler, resigned on account of ill health. The candidates were: James Caldwell, Liberal, but opposed to home rule; Col. Harrington Stuart, Unionist and opponent of Mr. Philipps in 1892, and Mr. Smellie of the Labor Party.
BALTIMORE, April 5 -- The Manufacturer's Record, in its weekly review of the business situation in the South, says:

UNIONTOWN, Penn., April 5 -- What was designed to be the greatest strike ever known to the Connellsville coke region will probably prove a complete failure. In some sections there is not now left enough of the recent uprising of the discontented foreigners to make even a struggle in the labor dispute.

CAMPELLO, Mass., April 5 -- John J. Newman, who was arrested last week on a charge of setting fire to the Goodall Building March 27, and whose trial was begun yesterday, hanged himself in an unused carhouse about 11 o'clock this morning. The circumstances of the fire caused great indignation, because of the fact that six persons who occupied the upper part of the block had narrow escapes from death by fire and suffocation.

Bitterness of spirit and stubbornness were displayed last night at an exciting meeting if the Holland Reformed Church, One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street and Elton Avenue, which was called for the purpose of finding out the feeling of the members and attendants of the church on the question of the further connection with it of the pastor, the Rev. George H. Miller.

The business of the New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which is now in session in the Nostrand Avenue, Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, was resumed yesterday morning. It is believed that the conference will be ready to adjourn on Tuesday afternoon.

BOSTON, April 5 -- The Boston Towboat Company's big steamer Orion arrived at her dock at East Boston last night after her unsuccessful trip to Roncador Reef to attempt to float the stranded Kearsarge.
COLUMBIA, S.C., April 5 -- Orders were issued to-night recalling the troops from the seat of trouble in this State. The following proclamation was made by Gov. Tillman:
ALBANY, N.Y., April 5 -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Assemblyman Southworth's bill relating to practicing attorneys in Queens County. In his veto, the Governor says:

The Lyman court-martial was finished yesterday. The beginning of the end was the reading of a statement prepared by the accused. Then Lawyer G.E. Kent summed up for his client, followed by Judge Advocate Kelley, who presented to the court the Government's side of the case.

J.F. Starbuck, the speedy long-distance bicycle rider from the West, will sail from this city to-day to join the colony of American racers in France. Starbuck has been following the races on the other side with great care, and he has come to the conclusion that the stands a good chance to carry off some of the big prizes.

Democrats may as well admit, and mostly do admit, that in the Spring elections the people have passed a vote of want of confidence, in their party. The Republican gains and victories are altogether too sleeping, too general, to be explained by any other theory.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Senator Walsh of Georgia defined his position upon public questions with tolerable clearness in a brief speech at Augusta made after he had accepted his appointment to the Senate. We quote the Senator's speech as printed in his own paper, The Augusta Chronicle:

NEW-YORK, Friday, April 16 -- P.M. The stock market to-day was again strong, most stocks scoring material advances. Sugar was the most active, and closed a point higher than yesterday, the principal buying being for the account of insiders. The bull point was that further protection was assured in the Tariff bill as it will finally pass the House.

The New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday morning placed itself on record as opposed to State aid for parochial schools in the following memorial and petition to the Legislature, which was introduced by Secretary George P. Mains:

LONDON, April 6 -- The defeat of the Government in the House of Commons last evening, when it was beaten by a vote of 228 to 227 on a private bill, has been a leading topic of discussion in political circles to-day, and the prediction has been made that the Rosebery Government cannot exist much longer.

About 200 men, members of the five disbanded companies of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, met at Ledwith's Hall, Forty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, last night at the invitation of Lieut, Col. James Moran, Capt. Ryan, one of the company commanders, presided. He said that the object of the meeting was to assist Lieut.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- The trading in Milwaukee Brewing common was one of the features of the day, something like 1,500 shares changing hands. It opened at 21, then sold down to 20 1/4, and rallying, closed firm at 22 1/8. The preferred sold at 36 3/4. American Strawboard came in for a share of the attention, with a good demand and advancing prices.

VENICE, April 6 -- Humbert, King of Italy, and William, Emperor of Germany, will meet in this city to-morrow, and the meeting will be signalized by a grand celebration, for which elaborate preparations have been made. King Humbert is already here. William will come in the morning.

The trial of Police Captain Devery was resumed yesterday morning in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Justice O'Brien. Capt. Devery is charged with failing to suppress a disorderly house in the Eleventh Precinct, of which he was in charge. The evidence against him was supplied by the Parkhurst society, whose witnesses wont before the Grand Jury.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 6 -- Assistant Adjt. Gen. John Gary Watts arrived in this city this morning and made formal requisition on Gen. T.A. Huguenin of the Fourth Brigade for the arms belonging to the State. A general order was issued this afternoon to all the Captains requiring them to turn over to Gen. Watts the property of the State.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 6 -- The State Guards arrived at the capital from Darlington at noon to-day, and were addressed by Gov. Tillman on the grounds fronting the penitentiary. The speech of the Governor was brief, and intended to be conciliatory. He thanked the guards in the name of South Carolina for the prompt and efficient services rendered by them.

When, six weeks ago, the campaign of the evangelists began in New-York its success became at once apparent, and the promise of its continuance and continued success was most strongly manifested. Weeping women then thronged forward at the call of preachers; young men and women rallied about the exhorters; those whose years have borne them almost to the limit of life were as fervent and active as the youngest.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Consistent with what were known to be his intentions. President Cleveland did not let any time elapse before signing the Bering Sea bill when it was, in due official course, presented to him this afternoon.

The Vigilant, the successful cup defender of last year, has not been sold, in spite of the reports published to that effect yesterday, but it is very likely that she will be purchased by Mr. James Gordon Bennett, to race against the Prince of Wales's cutter, the Britannia.

Mrs. Louis Vanderhoef's statement, at the recent convention of the Kings County Woman's Christian Temperance Union, concerning the use of narcotics by girls has attracted considerable attention in this city. She said a member of the union had discovered that the practice of taking hypodermic injections of narcotics is very prevalent among shopgirls in this city.

The last day of the auction sale of the paintings, furniture, statuary, bric-a-brac, and other household effects of ex-Collector Thomas Murphy took place yesterday afternoon at 77 Cedar Street. The articles were of rare value, and Inspired brisk bidding, none of them selling at give-away prices.
John Y. McKane may, perhaps, take off his striped suit, put away his shirt-cutting shears, and come out of Sing Sing, after all.
The Gravesend trade is being thoroughly renovated by Superintendent Brush. The grass lawn looks as green as an emerald from the recent rains.

BUDA-PESTH, April 6 -- The gallery reporters in the Reichstag intend to strike immediately after the reopening of the session. Their grievance is that the President of the lower house blocked the corridors between the newspaper galleries and the lobbies, with a view to punishing a few indiscreet reporters, and thus condemned all the newspaper men to reach their desks by way of underground corridors and dark staircases.

NORTHPORT, L.I., April 6 -- Charles Fisher, a tramp in tattered garments, applied to Mrs. Jacob Speicht, a widow residing on a farm near here, for something to eat and a night's lodging about ten months ago. The widow granted his request, being urged to do so by her sister and the latter's husband.

McKEESPORT, Penn., April 6 -- The inarch of the Coxey forces through the centre of the coal and iron industry in Western Pennsylvania was continued to-day, the route being from Homestead to a borough on the outskirts of this city.

In matters religious, social, and political it is always important to know one's friends. Just where to place Senator Hill of New-York in respect to measures and policies approved by his party has been a matter of doubt among the Democratic leaders at Washington. There may still be doubt as to Mr. Hill's attitude in respect to the Yellowstone Park or the rebuilding of the Kearsarge.

Merry college songs, catchy banjo airs, and the pleasing tones of guitars and mandolins attracted large audiences of fashionble folk to the ever-popular concerts of the Yale Glee and Banjo Clubs and the Dartmouth Musical Clubs last evening. Receptions and dances were few, and other entertainments were almost unattended, for society had gone to the concerts.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- The best pigeon-flying speed of the season was made yesterday in a journey against time from Odenton, Md., to the Charles Mehler loft in West Philadelphia. The entries were the three birds Trainer, Red Devil, and Laura M. The start was at 10 o'clock. The returns were: Trainer and Red Devil at 11:57 A.M., Red Devil getting the lead by being first to pass the bobs.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Those who predicted that Mr. Hill would place obstacles in the way of the Tariff bill are pointing to his performance in the Senate to-day as proof positive that their assertions were based on accurate knowledge of his intentions.

The discussion at the meeting the other evening of the Architectural League upon the limits of tall building was interesting and important. It was especially interesting and important because among those who took part in it were Mr. Post of this city and Mr. Burnham and Mr. Adler of Chicago, three of the chief offenders, if the erection of extravagantly tall buildings is an offense.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 6 -- Mrs. Bella Miller, whose husband was a brother of the wife of Jay Gould, last week circulated a remonstrance against the hotel of Joseph Estephe, at Hohokus, on the Erie Road. Lawyer Cornelius Berdan of this place argued the case before Judge Van Valen to-day.

The naval court-martial which was convened by order of the Secretary of the Navy to try Capt. E.M. Shepard for conduct prejudicial to good order and discipline met at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday, and after an hour's session finished the case before it and adjourned.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Without particular objection from any one, the House this afternoon adopted an amendment to the Post Office Appropriation bill which will give great satisfaction to many persons who have been endeavoring for years to induce the postal authorities to give a broad construction to the law relating to second-class matter.

ALBANY, April 6 -- In the House this morning Mr. Sulzer (Dem., New-York,) made a motion to discharge from the Ways and Means Committee his bill which provides that the State shall issue $12,000,000 bonds to enlarge the Erie, Champlain, and Oswego Canals, after the matter shall have been submitted to the people at the next general election.

There was a flutter in the fashionable Hotel Regent, in Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday, over the report in The New-Times of yesterday of trouble in the financial management of the hotel. Charles D. Burwell, director of the house, had something to say last evening of the suit brought against the Brooklyn Hotel Company, owners of the house, by George Schmidt, the former chef and manager.

Miss Harriet Hosmer has been stirring up the artists of San Francisco by some remarks about local sculpture which she did make and others which were put in her mouth. In her valedictory on April 1, she remarked: "Our ideas of art are apparently confined to portraiture -- ideal art is vanished. Poetry in art, as poetry in practice, is little in accord with our too utilitarian age."

It requires actual contact with the people in some of the smaller places in the State before one can understand how thoroughly aroused they are on the subject of pensions. The granting of a pension of $8, $10, or $12 a month is a matter of neighborhood gossip, which absorbs them until some fresh item of interest takes its place.

SOUTHAMPTON, April 6 -- G. Van Iderstine, formerly chief engineer of the dynamite cruiser Nictheroy, arrived here to-day from Rio de Janeiro on the steamship Nile, accompanied by his assistant engineers, Alonzo Alien and Jefferson Smith. Messrs. Van Iderstine, Smith, and Allen will sail for New-York to-morrow. There were also on board the Nile fifty of the former crew of the Nictheroy.

A vigorous contest for proxies to be voted at the anaual election of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company has begun. The issue is whether the proposed $5,000,000 of new stock, the proceeds of which are to retire an equal amount of bonds, shall be distributed among the stockholders at par or at 75 cents on the dollar.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The final evidence in the Pollard-Breckinridge case was submitted to the jury to-day. Col. Breckinridge was the last witness of the trial. He denied almost everything Miss Pollard and her witnesses had said, just as she passionately denied all his leading statements and those put forward on his behalf.

There is a very familiar air about the report of the hearing before the joint committee of the Legislature upon the Butts-Lexow bill, as it has come to be called, which purports to promote rapid transit and in fact hands the city over to the confirmed and unchallenged control of the Manhattan Railway Company.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., April 6 -- Peace once more prevails throughout the coke regions, but no one can tell how long this condition of affairs will continue. The operators say the strike has been broken and the end is only a few days ahead.

The most important real estate purchase called to notice yesterday was that of the Clearing House Association, on Cedar Street, adjoining its recent acquisition to the westward. The details are elsewhere given.
The Holland Society held its annual meeting at Sherry's last night and elected the following officers:

NEWPORT, Ark., April 6 -- James L. Wyrick, J.T. Hill, alias Albert Mansker, and Thomas Brady were hanged this morning. While on the scaffold they made statements attributing their downfall to drink and bad company. They said also that George W. Padgett, who had turned State's evidence, planned the robbery and had previously tried to rob a train on the 'Frisco Road.

The subject of tobacco brought about a peculiar scene yesterday in the Methodist Episcopal Conference of New-York, in session in Calvary Church, One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue.

Fifty ladles and gentlemen were present at the dinner of the Political Science Club, at the Hotel Savoy, last evening. There was an interesting after-dinner discussion of the subject, "Should the tariff question be taken out of politics?"

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Naval Appropriation bill will soon be reported to the House from the Naval Appropriations Committee. Representative Cummings will submit with, it an interesting report explanatory of the measure. It is an economical bill, making no provision for new ships, except in the way of allowing the Secretary to use existing funds set aside in previous years for specific purposes in certain ways.

VICTORIA, B.C., April 6 -- Yee Lee, Yee Chung, and Fong Chong Yuen deported from the United States and shipped to China on the steamer Tacoma, were landed here yesterday on writs of habeas corpus sworn out before Justice Drake.

OMAHA, Neb., April 6 -- Attorney George L. Hodges, who represents the engineers, said of Judge Caldwell's decision in the Union Pacific case: "It is the greatest judgment in vindication of the rights of men pronounced by any court since the historic judgment of Lord Mansfield in the Somerset case."

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- Notice was to-day served by counsel for Mr. Isaac L. Rice on Mr. Samuel Dickson, counsel for the Reading receivers, that a supplementary petition would be presented to the United States Circuit Court on Monday next, asking that the receivers be ordered to furnish further information concerning the state and condition of the Reading Company than that produced in the recent proceedings before the Master.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- John B. Riley of Plattsburg, United States Consul at Ottawa, registered at the Shoreham tonight. Mr. Riley has come to confer with the State Department regarding several matters which he considers of sufficient importance to warrant a trip to Washington at this time.

Dun's Review will say to-morrow: "Improvement in business has continued since the President's veto, which has been sustained in the House. But the best news of the week is the great decrease in number and importance of failures, of which full returns are given for the first time by months in the quarterly statement on following pages.

The writer of this journal was a daughter of Lewis Pintard of New-York, the son of a French Huguenot who arrived in America some years before the Edict of Nantes was revoked. Miss Pintard became the wife of Samuel Bayard, also of Huguenot descent, and with him, a few years after her marriage, went to London, where the years embraced in the journal were spent.

Military matters have been exceedingly quiet for the last week, with the exception of a little flurry in the Sixty-ninth Battalion. There was a little disturbance there last Monday night, but the smoke of battle has cleared away. Those who are in a position to know say that momentous changes are to be made in that old and historic organization.

The auction sales of realty in Brooklyn during the past week footed up $153,508, as compared with $304,685 for the corresponding week in 1893. The mortgages recorded during the past week were 340 for $1,086,442, of which 191, for $730,539, were at 5 per cent. or less. In the corresponding week in 1893 there were recorded 377 mortgages, for $1,490,898, of which 61, for $1,019,755, were at 5 per cent, or less.

There is a picturesque little Episcopal chapel on Long Island's sea-washed shore, at Southampton. It stands amid the sand dunes with the wild, tossing Atlantic on one side and a peaceful fresh-water lake on the other. There in the Summer time the colony of wealthy people who find enjoyment in staid old Southampton worship.

SING SING, N.Y., April 7 -- The subject of good or better roads for Westchester County is now occupying the attention of the town authorities throughout the county, any very shortly work will be begun on the lines and plans laid out with this end in view.

When the Rev. Gedney Just had been inducted -- this word is submitted with a pride perhaps pardonable -- into the office of assistant at St. Simon's Church, there was a distinct rise in charitable fervor. This increase, of course, was feminine in quality; for the average man has one invariable way of loving his neighbor as himself -- he growls and puts his hand into his pocket.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 7. -- Fire at about midnight to-night in the Green Building, at the corner of Main and North Division Streets, destroyed Dingen Brothers' stock of groceries, the Progressive Cigar Store, Van Norman's photograph gallery, and Brinkworth's engraving establishment.

Archbishop John Ireland, who was formerly Chaplain of the Fifth Minnesota Regiment, was the guest of the United Service Club last evening. He was escorted from Archbishop Corrigan's residence to the clubhouse by Gen. McXibben and Paymaster Barton of the United States Army. A large number of officers of the United States Army and Navy were present at the clubhouse, 16 West Thirty-first Street.

The first series of the great chess match between W. Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker is over, and it is generally admitted all around that the games played in this contest have been of a very high order. Those who have played over the games will have found that the champion has done remarkably so far, although he is two points behind his rival.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- When, at the conclusion of the routine morning business to-day, Mr. Morgan moved an executive session, everybody knew it was for the purpose of taking up the Chinese treaty, but after the doors were closed it was found that there was sufficient business on the calendar to consume the time for over an hour, and it was 3 o'clock, when the treaty was finally laid before the Senate.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 7 -- The police say that David McAdams, a sporting man and son of a former Excise Commissioner, who keeps the Red Jacket Hotel here, was arrested to-day for complicity with thieves.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 7 -- There is bright promise for the Spring season at this resort. Although the Lakewood Hotel will close its doors, as usual, on the 1st of May, he Laurel House and the Laurel-in-the-Pines anticipate a large number of people for the remaining two months of the Lakewood season proper up to the 1st of June.

William Rooney, one of the recently-convicted Election Inspectors, died yesterday afternoon in the penitentiary hospital on Blackwell's Island, in the presence of his aged father, who had come to visit him. He was twenty-seven years old, was unmarried, and lived with his parents at 53 East Houston Street.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 7 -- "Miss Pollard is an actress, equal, I may say, to Clara Morris or Sarah Bernhardt," said Ben Butterworth at the Burnett House this evening. "I never saw anything like it. She can simulate any passion or emotion`, and it is my opinion that this is but the prelude to her going on the stage.

The close of the week among real estate men was marked by two rather notable sales, following a series of transactions which indicate the presence of investors. One of these sales, that of the property at 83 Cedar Street by the Clearing House Association, was referred to in The New-York Times yesterday.

The cozy clubhouse of the Alpha Delta Phi Club presented a merry scene last evening, when its members held an enjoyable "smoker." From 9:30 o'clock until midnight there was a vaudeville performance. It was a clever variety show, and the audience was kept in great good humor throughout the evening.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Richard Croker of New-York was in town to-day, but his stay was brief. His party arrived in a special car over the Northwestern from Omaha at 9:30 o'clock. The car was at once switched to the Michigan Central, to be attached to an eastern train, and the newspaper men had but a minute to interview the Tammany leader.

The New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in session in Brooklyn yesterda, in the Nostrand Avenue Church, rejected, by a vote of 89 to 4, the proposition submitted to it by the General Conference to amend the Church discipline so as to give the laity equal representation with the clergy in the General Conference.

LONDON, April 7 -- The best-informed English politician whom I know today says that the Rosebery Ministry will go to pieces within a fortnight. Other English Radical members do not give such an explicit form to their forebodings, but it was impossible not to catch in the lobbies of the House last night an all-prevailing spirit of a smash near at hand.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- It is not likely that the present indictment of Col. F.C. Ainsworth of the army will stand in the courts of the District. The indictment holds him responsible for the accident to the old Ford's Theatre building last June, when the floors collapsed, killing and injuring a number of the clerks of the record and pension division of the War Department.

CHAPTER I. A LETTER FROM THE DEAD. There were great black masses of cloud in the cold gray above, and a misty darkness brooded over the shoulder of the moor as the barouche, with its fine, up-standing grays, came swinging round the curve of the road leading to Dunluce Castle.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., April 7 -- Nothing, so far, has been done toward settling the disturbed political situation, but it is understood that the Governor is waiting instructions from the English Ministry. Telegraphic correspondence is continually taking place between them. It was rumored last night that the Ministry instructed the Governor to grant a dissolution.

The conclusion stated last week that, from the appearance of the market, a continuance of the advance was probable, has been justified by the event. The market has continued strong. Nor is there yet any sign of that culmination of the rise which several days of abnormal activity in the trading generally marks.

A visit to a Georgia cotton field last season showed that the last picking had been done, and, although there were blooms left, they would not pay for the picking, and were abandoned to the weather and decay. Their purity had departed. The fibres were draggled and stained and drooped, dripping with the last shower.

ROCKLAND, Me., April 7 -- The Daily Star, Rockland's new morning paper, has secured in its first week of existence a circulation of 3,200 in a limited field. The Star has the following to say of its news service:
The old theory of the pension laws that a woman who has a husband living is sufficiently provided for was abandoned by the act of June 27, 1890.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

CONEY ISLAND, April 8 -- The Bowery, comprised of a number of dance halls, saloons, merry-go-rounds, bathing houses, c., along Surf Avenue, is burning and it is believed that the whole of that famous resort will be destroyed.

The Athletic Committee of the New-Jersey Athletic Club has made all arrangements to give a monster set of games at the club grounds on Decoration Day. On July 4 there will be bicycle races, a few athletic events, and the all-round Championship of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A bill was introduced in the House to-day which exactly falls in with certain statements made by well-informed Treasury officials as to a projected Administration measure combining authority to issue 3 per cent, bonds to protect the gold reserve and to proceed with the coinage of the silver seigniorage.

BOSTON, April 7 -- The market for local stocks was quiet, but prices generally held firm. Mexican Central stock shows some indications of weakness, selling off to 8 1/2 to-day. This, however, is but a natural re- action after its rise; the bonds held their own, selling at 55 1/2, only 1/2 below the highest.

BRADDOCK, Penn., April 7 -- Three men were killed and three seriously injured by a premature explosion of giant powder and dynamite near the new works of the Westinghouse Electric Company, now in course of construction at Brinton Station, on the Pennsylvania Road, near Braddock, at 7:30 o'clock this morning. Their names are;

CONCORD, N.H., April 7 -- The programme of exercises and entertainment arranged for the twenty-fifth annual reunion of the Society of the Army of the Potomac, which is to be held here June 21 and 22, is as follows:

BERNE, April 7 -- The Nationalrath has passed the Anti-Anarchist bill, which also provides severe penalties for the unauthorized manufacture or concealment of explosives, and for incitement to crime by any publication.

It may very well be that the notable change in the bank statement for the past week is not proof that a turning point has been reached in the course of business, but it is a striking indication of the approach of that turning point. It is precisely the kind of change that must take place sooner or later, and, though the current may be again reversed, it must be temporarily.

The final concert of the Philharmonic Society, which took place at Music Hall last night, was a very delightful entertainment for those to whom the personal element is the chief attraction. Not content with yielding to that curious public demand which insists on the presence of a soloist at a concert where the orchestra ought to be the prime consideration, the "potent, grave, and reverend signers" last night gave their patrons two soloists.

About forty years ago leprosy first attracted serious attention in the Hawaiian Islands, and in the short period of ten years it had gained such a deadly hold upon the native race that the Government began to make efforts to stamp out the scourge by segregation. It had become a struggle for the preservation of the aboriginal race.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, April 7 -- P.M. The taking of profits, both for foreign and domestic accounts, gave a reactionary appearance to to-day's stock market. The trading was unusually well distributed, and, although, the majority of stocks declined, there was no particularly weak spot in the market, Furthermore, notwithstanding the slight set-back, the undertone of the market was distinctly firm.

WEST POINT, April 7 -- Trophy Point is the most interesting spot on the Hudson's banks. A few hundred yards north of the Military Academy, it commands a view of the river as far north as Newburg. Towering Cro' Nest and Storm King rise above it to the left, while Mount Laurens and Breakneck look down upon it from the right.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The United States Geological Survey, as if in protest against the charge that it has outlived its usefulness, is now engaged in making topographical and geological maps of the United States. These maps are to be constructed on a scale so immense that they will show local details, and it has been found necessary to divide them.

BERLIN, April 7 -- The day the Reichstag resumed work the opponents of the Government Financial bill were predicting freely in the loby that the whole Miquel plan, would come to naught. The tax projects, they said, would be defeated by a large majority, and the Government would be glad to send the Deputies home at Whitsuntide.

BALTIMORE, April 7 -- The marriage of Miss Marie Yates Stirling with J. Lee Tailer, son of Robert Tailer of New-York City, took place in Brown Memorial Church, Park and Lafayette Avenues, at noon to-day. The Rev. Maltbie D. Babcock performed the ceremony. A large number of guests from New-York, Philadelphia, and Richmond were present.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- To-morrow night a large company of invited people will go to a hall in this city to listen to music by the Carlisle Indian School Band and Choir. There will probably be other exercises of an interesting character, presented to illustrate the proficiency of the scholars after they have been in the school for longer or shorter periods.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 7 -- Yale tied the Boston League nine in the second baseball game of the series this afternoon. Despite the chilly temperature, a large crowd cheered on the Yale players.

President James J. Martin of the Police Board was again the principal witness yesterday before the Senate committee appointed to investigate the Police Department in this city, at its session in Part II. of the Superior Court. The session was rather dull and uninteresting, and gave force to the suggestion that some one was trying to kill time.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 6 -- A bill to enable New-Jersey to take advantage of the provisions made by the Federal Government for the establishment of a naval reserve is now pending in the legislature of that State, and is expected to come up on final passage either on Monday night or Tuesday morning.

The cadet corps of Troop A gave an interesting exhibition last night at Dickel's Riding Academy. It was the first of a series of games which the corps intends making an annual event. The programme included head cutting and tent pegging with the regulation cavalry sabre, a potato race, a fight to a finish with singlesticks between two teams of five, mounted hockey, and a grand melee.

It is a little amusing to see the various explanations in the English and in the American papers of the recent firm act of the French Prime Minister, M. Casimir-Perier, with reference to a Colonial Minister. It will be remembered that the Chamber of Deputies having adopted a law creating the office, the Senate postponed action on it until after the Easter recess, and then adjourned.

The all-absorbing topic of interest in cycle circles just now is the proposed jump of Champion Zimmerman from the amateur to the professional ranks. A lot of guessing has been done by some writers, who went so far as to state that the action of Zimmerman in sending a representative to France to talk with the promoters of professional racing would debar him from competing as an amateur.

There is a loud cry going up from the active political workers attached to the Republican ward organizations that the new administration is not doing anything for them. They believe that every Democrat should be turned out of office and Republicans given the places.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The present is the earliest moment I have had at my disposal to reply to the strictures contained in an editorial in your issue of Sunday last, in which you refer to the publication of a report having reference to the College of the City of New-York, made by myself and others, and also to the letter of Mr. Everett P. Wheeler, which appeared in the same issue.

Hermann Schmiele, thirty-five years old, of Stapleton, S.I., who was being taken to the Hudson River Hospital for the Insane at Poughkeepsie, jumped from the bridge which crosses the elevated structure at Forty-second Street and Third Avenue yesterday afternoon. He died soon afterward in the Flower Hospital.
