Ex-Mayor David A. Boody of Brooklyn has withdrawn from his offices as Chairman of the Board of Trustees and Deacon of the Memorial Presbyterian Church. When his name came up for re-election at the annual meeting Friday night he announced that he could not consent to serve. He spoke of his pleasant relations with his fellow-members, and expressed his thanks for the aid they had given him in the performance of his duties.

TRENTON, N.J., April 7 -- The extension of a trolley road past the State Capitol to the westerly part of the city was the occasion of much excitement here this afternoon. State Street, the principal business thoroughfare, was crowded with people watching the gang at work erecting poles and wires, and the efforts of the police to arrest them and bring the labor to a stop.

At a meeting of the New-York Mathematical Society, held yesterday afternoon in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, two very interesting papers on mathematical subjects were presented. The first, read by Prof. Woolsey Johnson, was entitled. "Gravitation and Absolute Units of Force."

Addressing a company of persons interested in philanthropic effort the other day in Buffalo, Miss Grace Dodge spoke of a principle that is coming more and more into these discussions -- the need for the helped and the helpers to understand each other.

LONDON, April 7 -- The Engineer publishes a letter from America stating that the drawings of the machinery of Yarrow's new torpedo destroyer Havock, which were stolen some time ago, have been offered for sale in the United States.

Coxey's army is not more forlorn than the ring politicians of Brooklyn. They have little hope of again getting back into power. Until last week they were confident of recovering, at no distant date, the ground they lost in November. All signs now point to the utter collapse of their efforts to galvanize themselves into political life.

Mr. J. Harvey Ladew's steam yacht Columbia is not only the fastest yacht of her size in the world, but is the most complete as far as accomodations and conveniences go, and the most handsomely decorated of any American yacht. Her decorations are not elaborate, but are very rich.

BOSTON, April 7 -- Fire started this afternoon in the large lumber yards and dry houses in East Street, East Cambridge, owned by Holt Bugbee. The property, with wharves, covers an area of about three acres, flanked on two sides by the tracks of the Lowell Railroad. The fire gained great headway before the arrival of the firemen, and before it was under control caused a loss estimated at from $75,000 to $100,000.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The advance guard of Coxey's army, forty-one in number, got within two miles of Washington this evening, and were taken in charge by the police and locked up.

The rooms of the Seventh Regiment Veteran Club, 751 Fifth Avenue, were crowded yesterday afternoon from 2 to 6 o'clock with the fairest of fair women, who had donned their most fetching gowns in honor of the occasion.

MOBILE, Ala., April 7 -- The Norwegian steamship Sunniva arrived, here this morning. Theodore Bockman, a well-to-do planter of Rama, was a passenger, and from him was learned the detailed account of the killing of an American at Rama two weeks ago to-night. Mr. Bockman left Bluefields on Sunday, about 1:30 P.M.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 7 -- Transmission of telegraphic messages in Rio Grande do Sul has been suspended by the military commander there.

Austin Dobson in The Illustrated London News. "Finding him this evening in a very good humor," writes Boswell of Johnson, one Sunday in 1779, when, after dining at Strahan's, they went home to 8 Bolt Court and "had a long, quiet conversation," "I prevailed on him to give me an exact list of his places of residence since he entered the metropolis as an author, which I subjoin in a note."

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- There is naturally deep and unconcealed anxiety among the Democrats here about the situation in the Senate on the tariff question: The vote taken on Friday on the motion of Senator Hill for an adjournment has excited much comment, and the comment goes further than opinion as to the immediate effect of the success of the motion.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 20 -- Nassau has been indulging in the luxury of an election during the last week. The occasion was the choice of a successor to represent the city district in the House of Assembly, a vacancy having occurred by the departure of Henry M. Jackson from the colony.

POLTA, Austria, April 7 -- Emperor William of Germany dined with, the Austrian and German naval officers in the Casino last evening. He proposed a toast to the health of Emperor Francis Joseph, and in doing so alluded to the Austrian. Emperor as his best friend. He hoped that whenever Emperor Francis Joseph should summon the Austrian fleet, the summons would be responded to with full steam ahead.
This being the season of marrying and giving in marriage, some study or the customs and practices of antiquity in relation to the ceremony is not perhaps unsuited to the moment.
An important reform is promised for Brooklyn in a bill which passed the Assembly on Friday. The measure, if it becomes a law, will give the Mayor sole power to appoint Police Justices.

LONDON, April 7 -- The political situation has taken an unexpected turn, and the Conservatives confidently predict that Parliament will be dissolved within the present month. The Tories may be oversanguine, but their prediction is by no means an extravagant one, in view of the present aspect of things political.
Here is a pension which a New-York Times reporter investigated, and in which a mistake was made by the Pension Office at Buffalo, or there has been stealing from the Government.
John Scott, a baker, living at 30 North Oxford Street, Brooklyn, fractured his wife's skull with a heavy hammer yesterday afternoon. He then cut his throat and died in a few minutes.
Yesterday's outgoing fleet carried, many voyagers to foreign lands. A glance at the passenger lists of the big liners will show that the annual Spring exodus of tourists has fairly commenced.

Carriagemakers have no reason for complaint just at present. Gentlemen who own fine turnouts, and who pay as much attention to the equipment of their stables as to any other part of their establishments, are haying the general overhauling of their stables just now. Such traps as need it, preparatory to the Summer outing, are being overhauled by the trimmers and painters.

The unemployed man is invariably pathetic. Sometimes he is tragic, and sometimes he is comic. At present he seems to be tragic mainly in Europe, where his helplessness induces him to kill somebody, or at least destroy somebody's property by way of compelling attention to his woeful state.

At the session yesterday of the New-York Methodist Conference, in Calvary Church, Harlem, Bishop Vincent gave his interpretation of St. Paul's advice to Timothy: " Use a little wine for thy stomach's sake and thine often infirmities."

Amid the joyous shouts of interested spectators, the clapping of tiny gloved hands, and the strains of fast music, the Seventh Regiment athletes won honors last night The twenty-fifth games of the Athletic Association were contested, and the large hall of the armory was crowded with members of the regiment and their friends.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 7 -- Upon application of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company and the National Bank of Commerce of New-York, Judge Caldwell, at Omaha, has appointed J.B. Watkins receiver of the J.B. Watkins Land Mortgage Company. The assets are $7,000,000 and the liabilities $5,550,000.

The other day there was before the Senate a measure for coining some silver coin similar to Mexican dollars for use in the Oriental trade. Mr. Lodge of Massachusetts, who gracefully sustains in that august body the reputation of Massachusetts for Senators of scholarly tastes and literary habit, supported the bill in a speech characteristically elegant in language and shapely in form.

The Japanese uchiwa, or flat fan, at home and in history is a very much more interesting object than the modern specimen of its kind in an English room. One of its most curious varieties is the iron war fan, invented in the eleventh century for the use of military commanders, either for direction and signaling, or as a shield for defense.
Daniel Frohman, manager of the Lyceum Theatre, smiled and rubbed his hands in apparent glee when asked what he thought of the proceedings of Ticket Speculator Alfred B. Sullivan against him.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Months ago there was a considerable amount of Canal and Dock picked up around 45 to 48. Some of the fortunate buyers of that period concluded to realize to-day, and by doing so caused a two-point slump. Considering the large number of shares sold, it is surprising that the stock was so well taken.
PETERSBURG, Va., April 7 -- Eleven men were killed and nine seriously injured by explosion to-day in the fireworks factory ot C.N. Romaine and Brother in Blandford. Their names are:

The proposed purchase of the victorious cup defender Vigilant by Mr. James Gordon Bennett has given rise to some talk of the possibility of a race across the Atlantic between her and the Valkyrie. It is no news that the British challenger is soon to go home, and that a crew is now on the way over to man her.

Four large theatres and the large hall of the Masonic Temple were crowded at the evangelistic meetings yesterday. The Rev. A. Lambert preached at Masonic Temple in the evening to a crowded house, including many members of the Roman Catholic Church, which faith he so recently renounced.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 8 -- The famous Charter Oak Stake, guaranteed to be not less than $10,000, will be offered this year for the twelfth time for a 2:16 class trotting race for horses eligible May 7, to be trotted at Charter Oak Park the week proceeding the Grand Circuit meeting at Fleetwood.

The Nairnshire called as usual at Las Palmas, and there a hyena, which had been sent from Cape Juby and consigned to the London office of the West Africa Company, was taken on board. It was confined in a wooden box, or cage, 3 feet long, 3 feet broad, and 2 feet 6 inches high.

NEW-YORK, Monday, April 9 -- A.M. The only event of the week of real importance was the defeat of the silver men in Congress in their attempt to pass the Seigniorage bill over the veto of the President. It is now generally thought that the silver question has received its quietus until the end of the Cleveland Administration at least.

BUFFALO, April 8 -- One of the boldest bands of opium smugglers in the country was broken up this morning by the arrest of Charles Kennedy, George Henderson, and Edward Patterson. The United States authorities and the police of this city, Detroit, Cleveland, and Erie have been looking for them for over six months.

There is the shadow of an excuse for the consideration of nominations by the Senate in executive session, instead of publicly. Personal charges are likely to be made in the heat of political argument which, if made in public, might unjustly stigmatize the character of a nominee.

Many, many years ago an eminent person, who had reflected long on the notoriously profligate character of the eagle, a bird which is in the habit of loafing about until it sees that horny-billed son of toil the osprey loaded with a nice fish and then forcing the honest worker to surrender its prey, announced that the eagle was no symbol for us.

"Passengers are sometimes subjected to a good deal of annoyance by having distinguished men as fellow-passengers on their train," remarked Wilson F. Turner. "About two months ago I happened to be on the same train that was carrying ex-President Harrison, who was on his way to California.

Richard Croker returned from his Western journey last evening, after an absence of two months. He was accompanied by Mrs. Croker, his boys, Frank and Herbert; Miss Kiernan, a friend of Mrs. Croker, and a retinue of servants.

Many interesting anecdotes of the late Sir Harry Verney have been told within the last few days; but one which Mr. Alexander Devine contributes to The Manchester City News will proably be new to most readers. One of Sir Harry's famous exploits was his riding across Argentina, and thereby hangs the tale.

COLOMBIA, S.C., April 8 -- A correspondent read to Gov. Tillman to-day an extract from a letter from a Populist, in which the writer said that the only thing he did not admire about the Governor's political course so far was that he did not have the moral courage to come out squarely and call himself a Populist.

Five Australian aborigines, four men and one woman, now with Barnum Bailey's circus, gave an exhibition, in throwing the boomerang on Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon, before twenty or more persons who had been invited to be present.

Women who want the ballot have found an eloquent champion in the Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman of the Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street. Tester day morning he spoke on "The Rights of Women," treating the question not so much as one of politics, but rather as one of morals.

A situation of unusual interest confronts the stockholders of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company. At the annual election next month they will be called upon to cast their votes for or against the present conservative management of the company on an issue that is seldom raised in business corporations.

Lawyer John Graham has been lying ill of gout and a gangrenous affection of his right foot and leg at the Metropolitan Hotel. At 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon the affected limb was amputated four inches above the knee. The operation was performed, as a last means of saving the patient's life, by Dr. William T. Bull, who was assisted by Drs. William E. Forest and Sayre.

LONDON, April 8 -- The rate of discount last week was 1, both for three months and thirty days. Gold flowed in steadily, and there was no sign of any demand for export. The rise of the silver price ceased. The consensus of opinion is that the American sales are likely to depress the market.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 8 -- The work upon the new Alexander Commencement Hall is rapidly nearing completion. The little work necessary to finish the interior will be hurried forward. The contract for the carving on the facade has been awarded, and work was begun this week. It is expected that the building will be completed in time for the graduating exercises of the present senior class, in June.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: It would seem that the Democratic majority in the United States Senate were either ignorant of the harm they were doing their party throughout the country by their inexcusably slow action regarding the Tariff bill, or else that they were deliberately and willfully betraying the trust imposed in them by their constituents.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Benson Sherman died of black smallpox to-night in a cell at the Harrison Police Station, the largest in the city. A score or more of policemen and forty-five prisoners were exposed to the dreaded disease.

ALBANY, April 8 -- There are thirty-two "straight" life insurance companies doing business in New-York State. Twelve are home companies, and last year took in as premiums $123,559,156. The twenty companies of other States are credited with premiums of $69,147,682 for the same period. The dividends of the New-York companies to stockholders aggregated but $257,277, while those of the foreign companies amounted to $511,285.

The Democratic leaders in Minnesota have addressed their party in terms of the most outspoken protest against the disloyal behavior of the McKinley Democratic Senators at Washington. They have set an example that should be followed in every State in the Union. The Democratic Party can compel the obedience of its servants at Washington if its commands are now repeated in tones stern enough and loud enough to reach the dull Senatorial ear.

Archbishop Corrigan presided at the quarterly meeting of the conference of the St. Vincent de Paul Society, held in the Cathedral School Hall, III East Fiftieth Street, last night. Nearly 500 members were present. This society is the greatest charitable organization in the Catholic Church. The Archbishop made a short address, congratulating the society on the work performed by the members during the past Winter.

BELLMORE, L.I., April 8 -- A well-made cave was discovered in a patch of woods about a quarter of a mile south of the Long Island Railroad tracks near this village this afternoon. The place showed evidence of recent occupancy, and the authorities believe that it is the headquarters of the burglars who have been committing robberies in villages in this section of the island.

Ex-Mayor William R. Grace spoke earnestly of the scope of the Anti-Spoils League and, incidentally, of civil service reform as he paced his handsome library at Madison Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street last evening.

ALBANY, April 7 -- The most important event of the week affecting the local security market was the reduction in the price of gas to consumers from $2 to $1.70 per 1,000 feet, made at a special meeting of the Directors of the Troy Gas Company. This action had no effect on the price of the stock, as it was favorably received and generally expected.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 8 -- A tenement building on the corner of De Soto and Beale Streets collapsed this morning. It is known that four persons were killed and five injured, and it is believed that there still are bodies in the ruins of the building. The killed and injured are colored persons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A clause of the pending Army Appropriation bill in the House provides for a reduction of the Medical Corps in the grade of Assistant Surgeon from 125 to 90. The effects of such a sweeping reduction would be felt most seriously in the military service, as there are now barely sufficient Surgeons to properly perform the many and important duties pertaining to the Medical Department.

Hardly a week passes that one of the huge transatlantic freighters does not arrive at her dock in the North River with a varied consignment of wild animals that have taken the ocean trip not from choice, but for the delectation and instruction of the American public.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 8 -- Probably the most remarkable political address of the year was that issued this afternoon by the Democratic leaders of Minnesota through the Democratic Association of Minnesota. It says:

PROVIDENCE, April 7 -- The local stock market during the last week has been rather narrow owing to the fact that so few stocks are offered. The inquiry for local investments still seems to tie on the increase, and there is undoubtedly less disposition to sell. The brokers are now looking for sellers rather than buyers, and higher prices will probably follow.

CONEY ISLAND, April 8 -- The attraction, at Coney Island to-day was a blackened area about an acre in extent in the central part of West Brighton. A lot of ashes, some shriveled sheets of tin, a few pieces of twisted wire, and the wrecks of two cooking ranges, were all that the show afforded.

MOUNT PLEASANT, Penn., April 8 -- While everything is quiet at all the works in this part of the coke region, it is rumored that a large crowd of Hungarians and Slavs will arrive here from Fayette County to-morrow morning, bent on forcing the men working here to quit.

VENICE, April 8 -- Emperor William went aboard the war ship Moltke at 10 o'clock his morning to attend religious services. In the afternoon he visited the ducal palace and the museums. After his return from this sightseeing tour the Emperor had an, hour's conversation in private with King Humbert.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8 -- The 'Varsity crew is now practicing twice a day and will continue its morning and afternoon work until the Spring vacation is ended next Tuesday. No changes have taken place, except that Blake is rowing at No. 7 and Waters at 5. Keyes, Adams, and Mayor Bancroft are the coachers.

NEWARK, N.J., April 8 -- The broadsword contest between Capt. Duncan Ross and Generoso Pavese at the Shooting Park grounds to-day ended in a dispute. There was a large crowd present, and, as there were no ropes or barriers to mark off a fighting space, spectators were in imminent danger of being trodden under the horses.

VICTORIA, B.C., April 8 -- The Canadian sealer who urges the lack of warning for the evasion of the new sealing regulations will have no moral claim for consideration, for the sealers were all told before departing by Collector Milne that the regulations of the Paris arbitration tribunal would certainly be put into effect this season.

It is becoming fashionable for burglars to chloroform their victims in the hope that their work will be the more easily and effectually done. As the plan is to administer the anaesthetic while the patient sleeps, it is no wonder that failure attends the effort. Happily, it is one of the most difficult feats to accomplish, requiring the greatest care and the highest degree of skill.
DENVER, Col., April 8 -- Alexander Watson is being conducted back to Grand Rapids, Mich., by a detective. He has at least five wives. He was arrested last Thursday in Florence, Col.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 8 -- At a meeting of the Republican students of the university held to elect delegates to the American Republican College League, which met at Syracuse on Friday and Saturday of last week, a committee was appointed to draw up a constitution to establish a permanent student organization in the university.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 8 -- Mackenzie Bowell, in the Senate has introduced the principal act promised in the speech from the throne, namely, the Insolvency act of 1894. There has been no insolvency law in Canada, since 1875. The matter of bankruptcy has been dealt with since 1875 by the different provinces, and as a consequence a good deal of conflict has existed.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The American Consul at Bradford, England, reports to the Department of State that an endless amount of gossip has been caused there during the last six weeks by the offering for sale of large quantities of American wool. Several lots of Ohio wool, aggregating 50,000 pounds, were reported among the purchases.

The Paris correspondent of The Glasgow Herald has teen dwelling on the strange taste for the horrible and gruesome which at the present moment characterizes the performances at cafe concerts in "the gay city." The culminating point in this direction seems to have been reached at a eabaret just opened in the Boulevard Rochechouart, (an outer boulevard,) which goes by the name of the Cabaret de la Mort.

BALTIMORE, April 8 -- The cathedral this morning was the scene of one of the most august ceremonies of the Catholic Church. With solemn rites and magnificent music, the Rev. P.J. Donahue was consecrated Bishop of Wheeling. Cardinal Gibbons conducted the services and performed the consecration in the presence of distinguished prelates and hundreds of the laity.

Unless there comes a very speedy change in the temperature, the boating crews along the Harlem, from One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street up, will be "soft" for the Decoration Day regatta. The first real practice of the season it was expected would begin yesterday. Many of the men were on hand at the different boathouses, bright and early, but little or nothing could be done.

JACKSON, Miss., April 8 -- C.O. Summers, the train robber and desperado, again made his escape from the penitentiary today. This is the second escape within the last six months. The one to-day was as adroitly planned and skillfully executed as the other. In his escape a few months ago he fooled the guard by telling him the Sergeant wanted to see him, and he had instructed him to act as guard until his return.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 8 -- President Dwight's annual report to the Trustees of the university, published last week, has caused an unusual amount of criticism among Yale alumni. Both what was said and what was left unsaid has been the cause of general comment.

LONDON, April 8 -- The United Press correspondent in Paris obtained an interview on the Bering Sea question last evening with Baron de Courcel, the French diplomatist who presided over the tribunal of arbitration. The interview concerned mainly the difference between the English and American bills and the following paragraph in the English bill:

There are Highlanders in New-York City who are as loyal to their clans as were their ancestors in the days of "Bonnie Prince Charlie," and who used all the means within their power to preserve the language and traditions of their native land. Yesterday afternoon they had a treat in the form of a sermon in the Gaelic tongue by the Rev. Lachlan MacLean of Chicago in the Cavalry Baptist Church, on West Fifty-seventh Street.

The Nostrand Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, in which the NewYork East Conference is holding its sessions, is one of the largest edifices in the city, but it was too small to hold the crowds that thronged it three times yesterday to hear Bishop Charles H. Fowler preach. Many were unable to get within the doors.

Mr. Ulick Ralph Burke, in his just published "Life of Benito Juarez," President of the Republic of Mexico, tells, somewhat hurriedly, the story of the capture and execution of the ill-fated Emperor Maximilian, and does his best to make it clear that Juraez heartily wished Maximilian had escaped; and that it was only under an overwhelming sense of what he thought necessary for Mexico that he assented to the Austrian Archduke's murder.

The situation in the Senate with reference to the Tariff bill was set forth very clearly and in detail in our Washington dispatches yesterday morning. In brief it is this: Giving the votes of Hill, Murphy, Brice, and Irby to the protectionists, with whom they voted, or for whom they were paired on Hill's "test" vote on Friday, there are in a full Senate 42 votes for the Tariff bill and 41 against it.

BERLIN, April 8 -- It was expected that yesterday would bring with it the culmination of the struggle over the Boerse tax. Many persons gathered in the galleries, in the hope of witnessing a hot contest, but their hope was vain. While the Government's supporters came in solid phalanx, the ranks of the opposition parties showed such, large gaps as to suggest doubts of their earnestness in combating Dr. Miquel's financial reforms.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 8 -- Writing from Bluefields under date of April 1, a correspondent sums up the situation, on the Mosquito coast. He says:
I doubt whether Mr. Balfour is right in thinking that the French dislike us. But it is hardly surprising that they are not excessively enamored of us politically.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The burlesque features of the Coxey tramp march on Washington disappeared as more or less trustworthy accounts reach the capital that bodies of men, called into existence by the Coxey manifesto and the publicity given it, are actually likely to arrive here within the next few days, some of them having, in fact, already arrived, and now cumbering the vagrant wards of the respective police stations.

The Roman Catholic Pro-Cathedral, Kensington, was crowded, to the doors yesterday afternoon, the great congregation having been attracted by the announcement that the Cardinal Archbishop of Westminster would perform the ceremony of "The Washing of Feet," which is gone through in the Roman Catholic Church on Holy Thursday in commemoration of the washing of His disciples' feet by the Saviour.

BROWNSVILLE, Penn., April 8. -- Coxey's Commonwealers marched in at 8 o'clock this evening. They at once established Camp Chicago, but left it almost immediately, as the Town Councils of Brownsville and Bridgeport, just adjoining, had secured two halls in which to quarter the men.

Bishop Vincent, President of the NewYork Methodist Episcopal Conference, now in session at Calvary Church, occupied the pulpit in the church yesterday morning, and his sermon on "The Ministry of Power" moved his congregation to laughter and tears, alternately. The Bishop is a keen, active man of sixty-two, and he has a dry way of telling a story which brings out the humor of it and drives the point home every time.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 8 -- Residents of Marget and Williams Streets and Wayne Avenue, in the northern portion of this city, were startled last night by a noise that resembled the rumble of an earthquake. When they arose from their beds this morning they discovered that there were huge cracks in the earth's surface near their homes.

The Government bond market continues strong, and with every evidence of increased demand and higher prices in future, since there is but little probability of a new issue of bonds for some time to come. Many national banks are buying for use against bank-note circulation, and there is some demand from savings banks.

ALBANY, April 8 -- This is the year for the reappearance of the seventeen-year locusts. It is an event in the insect world which will be of interest to the farmer and the scientist. The insect with a life history more wonderful than that of any other of the 3,000,000 species on the globs is due this year.

The first practical examination into the actual abuses of the Pension Bureau has been made and is now being conducted by The New-York Times. Any one can see that an investigation of this kind is singularly well adapted to the painstaking enterprise of the great American newspaper.

SAVANNAH, Ga., April 9 -- The British steamship Elliott, with a cargo of bananas, arrived to-day, bringing copies of the last issue of The Bluefields Sentinel, with a supplement issued by the special Commissioner from Nicaragua, Senor Don Jose Madriz, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Nicaragua, who has arrived and assumed control of affairs.

The caucus to be held at Washington on the subject of State bank circulation will show a marked and healthy change in the sentiment of the Democratic Party on this matter. When Congress met in December there was evidence of extreme and unreasonable feeling in two different directions.

The business of conducting the affairs of the Tammany organization from Tammany Hall was resumed yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, when Richard Croker walked in, took his overcoat, and settled down to business.

BUDA-PESTH, April 9 -- The lower house of the Reichstag discussed to-day the grievance of the newspaper reporters, who have been banished from the lobby and the restaurant by order of the President. Dr. Wekerle, Premier, warmly espoused the cause of the reporters, and demanded that they have every possible privilege.

Commissioner Andrews of the Street-Cleaning Department repeats the old complaint, that he cannot keep the streets of the city clean because the Board of Estimate and Apportionment has not allowed him the funds necessary to establish an adequate "plant" for the removal of sweepings and refuse.

It was a quiet day in the horse market yesterday. There were two public sales, one at Fiss Doerr's, in the morning, where some forty head of general-purpose horses, principally consignments from the West, were disposed of, and the other at Tattersalls in the afternoon. The attendance was light at both sales, and the city speculators, who were about the only buyers, managed to pick up some good bargains.

There were some important conferences relative to Delaware and Hudson matters yesterday, and at the close of the day the situation looked blue for the minority Directors, who sought to measure strength with President Olyphant's administration on the stock dividend question.

NEW-YORK, Monday, April 9 -- P.M. To-day's market reflected the strength of the feeling in stocks and bonds which has lately found exuberant expression in bounding prices. If the market were moving in the usual way, a reaction, with declining prices, would now be due.

Up to last night the members of the Polytechnic Baseball Club of Brooklyn were under the impression, that the '94 team was a good one. They met Capt. Foutz's men at Eastern Park in a friendly game yesterday afternoon, and the result of the contest will forever be remembered by the "Polys." Brooklyn scored runs in every inning, and on two occasions ran into double figures before three men were retired.

The trap-shooting carnival at Dexter Park came to an end yesterday with an important match at 200 birds a side for a stake of $2,000. Four crack shots, representing four States, competed. The sides were: W. Wolstoncroft, Frankfort, Penn., and Neaf Apgar, Plainfield, N.J., against Rollo Heikes, Dayton, Ohio, and Thomas Peacock, Westfield, N.Y.

The Brooklyn and Brighton Beach Railroad Company failed yesterday to secure from the Brooklyn Common Council the privilege of connecting its road by an overhead track with the Kings County Elevated Railroad, and thus securing a continuous and conected service between the bridge and Coney Island.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- The reaction predicted in the stock market, which was expected for several days by all but the most rabid bulls, showed itself to-day. It appeared shortly after the opening, especially on West Chicago. For a time all the offerings at 157 were taken, but gradually the orders were filled, and prices broke to 156, recovering again to 156 1/2, and closing firm at 156 3/4.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- The opening all along the line to-day was highly satisfactory to those who are long of stocks. Reading and Lehigh Valley were both very dull, and there was a good deal of bear talk on the coal stocks. It is said that the rates charged per mile on anthracite coal to Philadelphia are very much higher relatively than those to other points, and that the tolls must be reduced.

BUENOS AYRES, April 9, (via Galveston.) -- The insurgent Admiral da Gama made his escape from the Portuguese war ship Mindello at 2:15 P.M. yesterday, and arrived at the Buenos Ayres quarantine station last evening. The Portuguese sailors made no resistance to his leaving the war ship.

ST. JOHN, N.B., April 9 -- Gibbs, the "reformed" actor and evangelist, who eloped from Brooklyn a year ago with Mrs. Angelo Frost, has been forced to leave this city to escape arrest. He came here six months ago from Halifax with Mrs. Frost and her ten-year-old child. He registered at the hotel as the Rev. J.W. Garrison, and in a few days became on friendly terms with a number of St. John clergyman.

Ex-Senator Cattell. Alexander Gilmore Cattell, who served the State of New-Jersey for one term in the United States Senate, died in Jamestown, N.Y., Sunday night. He was born in Salem, N.J., Feb. 12, 1816. He received an academic education, and when a boy was a clerk in his father's store.

The Central Committee having in charge the evangelistic revival meetings made a new departure yesterday. The Cooper Union meeting, held at 3:30 P.M., was abandoned, and in its place afternoon meetings were held in five churches in different parts of the city. These meetings were all well attended, while the noon meeting at Niblo's Garden crowded the lower portion of the house and part of the first gallery.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 9 -- The Tennessee Derby to-day was an upset for the talent. It was won by E.T. McLean's colt Jamboree, a 25 to 1 chance, riflden by J. Davis. Buckrene, 4 to 1, ridden by Thorpe, was second, and Vassal, even money, ridden by Martin, was third. The time was 2:04 1/2. Bedford, Follow Day, Rhett Goode, and Satellite also ran.

ALBANY, April 9 -- By a combination of certain Republicans and Democrats who were well managed, the bill of Mr. Sheffield, (Rep., New-York,) to permit the next Mayor of New-York to apppoint his own heads of departments, was beaten to-night in the Assembly, thus advancing another conclusive argument that a satisfactory understanding has been made on the part of Mr. Thomas C. Platt and the controlling powers in New-York.

The elephant's sense of humor will not be doubted after a visit to the circus this week. A herd of them, filling two of the three rings, was out for sport last night, if what they did was any indication of the way they felt. Two of them rolled spheres across the rings to the music of a handorgan which another ground, while several others waltzed, two big fellows jingling sleigh bells in excellent time.

BOSTON, April 9 -- The local stock market, outside of copper stocks, was dull, and there was no feature of importance. Bell Telephone declined 2 per cent., to 187, on small sales. There was no reason except apathy for the decline. Erie Telephone recovered 1 3/8, to 45, but sales were very light. Lamson was steady around 26.

ELMIRA, April 9 -- The Rev. Thomas K. Beecher was in the parlors of the Congregational Church, where he has preached for forty years, when a reporter for The NewYork Times asked him for his opinion as to the management of the State Reformatory by Superintendent Brockway, the methods of discipline which prevail there, and the value of the investigation which has recently been conducted under authority of the State Board of Charities.

LONDON, April 9 -- The Bering Sea bill passed its third reading in the House of Commons this evening. It passed without amendment, Sir Charles Russell having accepted Sir Richard Webster's suggestion that the clause to which the United States Government is said to object be altered in the House of Lords.

Champion Zimmerman laughs at the statements made by Sanger, Tyler, Bliss, Dirnberger, and other aspirants for cycling honors relative to his chances with the other cracks this year. They say that Zimmerman will be able to beat Wheeler and all the French and English riders, but hint that if he remains in the amateur ranks, he will have to play second fiddle to the other fast men here.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The beginning of the second month of the Pollard-Breckinridge trial this morning witnessed the beginning of the end in the commencement of argument before the jury. There were few persons present when the court convened, but the plaintiff was among the spectators, much to everybody's surprise.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- By reason of his antagonistic attitude toward the Tariff bill in the last six weeks and the small margin of legislative power possessed by the Democratic majority in the Senate, there has been a general desire to know what ground Mr. Hill will occupy with relation to the final dispositipn of the bill.

Mr. Hill's speech is commonplace. It contains no surprises. It is tame even in its attack on the Democratic Administration. It is perfectly sound and orthodox in its two main positions -- that tariff reform must be cautious and moderate and that the income tax is an abominable impost.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 9 -- Senator Saxton's bill amending the election law so as to provide that one Election Inspector may order an arrest for violation or attempted violation of the election law, or for disorderly conduct about the polls, which was signed by Gov. Flower this afternoon on his re- turn from Avon, contains several important provisions.

The sessions of the New-York East Conference in the Nostrand Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, yesterday were mainly devoted to discussions of three questions, involving proposed changes in the customs of the conference. They were all voted down.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 9 -- In the Dominion Senate, Mr. McInnis of British Columbia called attention to the published dispatches giving accounts of the discussion in the British House of Commons on the bill providing for the execution of the Bering Sea award. He asked if it were true that Canada had made unconditional assent to the agreement and had not asked for compensation.

The sale was reported yesterday of the West End and Columbia seven-story apartment houses, corner of Hicks and Pineapple Streets, Brooklyn, by School Commissioner Randolph Guggenheimer, to the Hartman estate, part payment being made in lots near Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Second Street.

ALBANY, April 9 -- After the exposure which ex-Mayor Hewitt gave the ButtsLexow Rapid-Transit bill, which passed the Assembly last week without a dissenting vote, and after it had been proved that the bill was drafted plainly in the interest of the Manhattan Elevated Railway, it was fully expected that the parents of the measure would have something to say.

HIGHLAND LIGHT, Mass., April 9 -- The bark Belmont of Boston, with sugar from Trinidad, went ashore this morning on Peaked Hil Bars, and of a crew of nine men only three are saved. The vessel is a total wreck.

WHITE HALL, Mich., April 9 -- The logging train at Staples Covell's logging camp, north of here, was wrecked this morning. Augustus Anderson, fireman, was instantly killed, and six others were fatally injured, all of whom have since died. A correct list of the dead is as follows: ANDERSON, AUGUSTUS, fireman. CRITCHETT, ALLEN. CRITCHETT, LORAINE. LYNCH, MARTIN, brakeman. SHELLANDER, OTTO, engineer. SHIPPY, FRANK. STERNS, EMORY.

Bridget or Hilda or Katie will press the button; electricity will do the rest. That is the substance of what Br. Lucy Hall-Brown told the members of the Brooklyn Woman's Club at their regular meeting in the Young Woman's Christian Association Building yesterday afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- The United States revenue steamer Grant reached this port shortly after midnight last night. The officers report a rough passage up the California coast. For two days the vessel was scarcely able to make headway in the face of a strong northwest gale. On one occasion the Grant was hove to for a period of several hours.

LONDON, April 9 -- The floor and galleries of the House were packed with members, diplomats, peers, and others this evening, when Sir William Harcourt, Chancellor of the Exchequer and the leader of the Liberal Party in the House, arose to move the resolution of which notice was given last week by Mr. Morley.

The New-York Presbytery met yesterday in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street. The special work before the Presbytery was the election of Commissioners to the one hundred and fourth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, to be held at Saratoga, May 17.
Miss Grace Dodge's Association of Working Girls' Societies held its tenth annual meeting in Copper Union last night.

PARIS, April 9 -- The Figaro to-morrow morning will contain an interview which, the editor says, was had with King Humbert of Italy by a person connected with The Figaro staff. While unwilling to show the proofs of the interview, the editor grave the substance of it to the United Press correspondent.

Mayor Schieren was somewhat disappointed yesterday when he learned that Chief Engineer Martin of the Brooklyn Bridge had not prepared a report of the cost of lighting the bridge cars with electricity. Mr. Martin had an entire month to make his report, and the best he could do yesterday was to report progress.

Dedbeete -- My dear Sir, before you ask me for an immediate payment of this account I wish you to consider a few facts which will doubtless redound to your own good. I want to ask you if you do not regard with some degree of satisfaction the prospect of having money coming to you.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 9 -- Wesleyan defeated Amherst here to-day by a score of 10 to 8. Wesleyan was completely outplayed up to the eighth inning. Gregory was in the box for Amherst and Wesleyan was unable to do anything with his delivery.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- One pupil was killed, one fatally injured, and fifteen others hurt at noon to-day during a panic at the Von Humboldt Public School, Rockwell Avenue and Hirsch Street. The mad rush of the children was caused by the bursting of a steam cock on the radiator in one of the rooms and the subsequent crying of "Fire" by the frightened boys and girls.

TRENTON, N.J., April 9 -- The State Re- publican Committee held a meeting this aft- ernoon and transacted considerable important business. Its action was somewhat in- dependent, more so than at any of the numerous meetings.

MILWAUKEE, April 9 -- At 4:20 o'clock this morning flames were seen breaking out from the rear of the Davison Theatre and Hotel, a structure valued at $300,000. An alarm was promptly responded to, but not until the roof was a sheet of flames.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- A motion was made to-day in the Supreme Court of the United States by Carroll McKenney on behalf of the people of New-York to advance for argument the case of John Y. McKane, who appealed from the judgment of Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York, which refused his application for release from Sing Sing on a writ of habeas corpus.

John Graham died at the Metropolitan Hotel at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, less than twelve hours after Dr. William T. Bull amputated his right leg in the presence of Drs. L.T. and R.H. Sayre, W.E. Forest, and C.A. Powers.

Probably few persons recalled yesterday that the day was the anniversary of the surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia at Appomattox. No general celebration of that event has ever been established, although its recurrence may long bring commemorations among some old comrades.

FLORENCE, April 10 -- King Humbert and Queen Margherita arrived here this morning and paid a visit to Queen Victoria, at the Villa Fabbricotti. They were cheered the entire distance to the villa, and were similarly greeted by the people on their return. The streets and roadways were lined with humanity.

William Van Brunt Bennett yesterday occupied the place that John Y. McKane once held in the Kings County Board of Supervisors. Mr. Bennett was the triumphant candidate of the Citizens' League at last week's town election in Gravesend. His credentials were presented by Supervisor Ryder of Flatlands.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- In the Senate to-day a resolution heretofore offered by Mr. Dolph (Rep., Oregon,) to discharge the Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds from the further consideration of bills for public buildings in Oregon, and to bring those bills before the Senate for consideration, provoked much discussion and some rather unpleasant personalities.

The customs officers have landed in the seizure room at the Barge Office a trunk and valise for which they would like to find an owner. All they know is that some one exercised more than ordinary ingenuity in trying to smuggle through fine costumes and dressmakers' supplies, and made a failure of it.

Mayor Gilroy is quite too positive in his assertion that the underground rapid-transit railway provided for in the Chamber of Commerce bill would cost $100,000,000. Competent engineers estimate the cost at about half the sum mentioned in the Mayor's letter laid before the Senate yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Republicans of the Senate were in good humor today over their success in opposing the plans of the Democratic leader, Mr. Harris.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- In the House to-day the motion to discharge the order of arrest of absentees made March 26 was held in abeyance until to-morrow, in order to allow the Speaker to examine the rule and precedents governing the situation.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

Twelve young men were examined yesterday by the New-York Presbytery as to their qualifications to preach. The candidates coming from the Union Theological Seminary, it was to be expected that they would be closely questioned on points of doctrine, having in part received instruction from Dr. Briggs.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- The bid for National Railway stock to-day was 118 1/2, exactly 3 1/2 points above the closing price of yesterday, but this was not at all an indication of the trend of the rest of the list. It was, on the contrary, one of the exceptions that proved the rule of a dull, uninteresting, and weak market.

Messrs. Hoffman Brothers and William C. Walker's Sons have sold, for the Josiah Belden estate, the block front on the east side of Mercer Street, between Canal and Howard Streets, at $350,000 cash. The plot measures 118.9 by 75.11 by 132.8 by 75.3, and is covered by a five-story stone building.

COHOES, N.Y., April 10 -- The election to-day was very orderly. Henry A. Strong, (Rep.,) was re-elected Mayor by 800 majority, and the Republicans elected Aldermen and Supervisors in four of the five wards, as well as both Police Justices. Four wards last year elected Democratic Aldermen and Supervisors, and both Police Justices were Democratic.

The Rev. John W. Chadwick's subject on Sunday morning was "Social Judgments," the text taken being "Judge not that ye be not judged." In the course of his remarks he made allusion to the case of the Superintendent of Elmira State Reformatory, and the adverse report of the State Board of Charities upon his conduct.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The President to-day issued the Bering Sea proclamation. It bears the date of April 9. The proclamation reads:

With the collapse last night of a two-story frame building at 140 McKibbin Street, Willlamsburg, came the horrors of death, maiming, and fire. By the accident two lives were lost, and eight persons were more or less injured.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 10 -- The National Convention of the United Mine Workers of America was called to order this morning In Wirthwein's Hall by President John McBride, who immediately read his annual address.

The Knickerbocker Whist Club of this city will start this week a handicap tournament, the first held since the club was incorporated last Fall. The members have shown great interest in this test of whist skill, and twenty teams have entered. The scratch teams will be made up of Col. Buffington and A.E. Taylor, H.S. Williams and Carpenter, Hatch and Donald, Hopper and Otis, Foster and Dickerman, J.L. Taylor and Watson.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, April 10 -- P.M. The stock market hesitated again to-day, although there was no very decided weakness in any quarter. Chicago Gas, St. Paul, and Sugar were the features at the opening, and all displayed some weakness. Chicago Gas was sold by the Westerners, and local traders followed their example.

Controlled Fitch wrote yesterday to Senator Cantor and Hamilton Fish opposing the Vandervoort Claim bill, and to Assemblyman Sulzer asking him to oppose the Hobbie bill to amend the existing insurance laws of the State. This bill says that a bond executed by one surety company is a compliance with the law.
The expectation of seeing John Y. McKane drew a crowd yesterday to the Special Term of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, presided over by Justice Calvin E. Pratt.

An audience of considerable size gathered yesterday afternoon in the Chamber Music Room, at Music Hall, at the invitation of M. Henri Marteau, the distinguished young French violinist, to listen to some of the chamber music of the modern French school. M. Marteau has issued invitations for three of these entertainments, for which tickets cannot be bought.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- In accordance with the notice he gave last week, Senator Lodge addressed the Senate this afternoon on the subject of the tariff.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The United States Chilean Claims Commission completed its deliberations last night by approving the final statement of its six months' work. Of the forty-three cases presented for consideration, forty of which were American, only eighteen remain undetermined by the commission, and these are left without prejudice for the action of a subsequent commission, which it is confidently expected the two interested Governments will provide for by a new treaty.

The horse market was quiet yesterday, with only one auction sale at Van Tassel Kearney's, where some sixty head were disposed, of. The offerings were mostly general-purpose horses and roadsters that were a little the worse for wear. Prices were generally low, the climax being reached when a pair of chestnut geldings, standing 16 hands and eight years of age, sold for $65.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I inclose herewith $1 for a year's subscription for The Weekly Times and your collection of World's Fair pictures.

One of the most comfortable-looking, jolly, picturesque pensioners of Ogdensburg is a dancing master who began to draw three years and a half ago his pension under the old laws for disabilities incurred in the service.

"I claim that the police force from the Commissioners up -- I was going to say down -- to the patrolmen is anarchial. It enforces only so much of the law as it chooses for its own maintenance and at its own behest and, as I thoroughly believe, for the benefit of its own pockets."

The law of 1893 empowers the Forest Commission to sell from the forest lands of the State standing spruce and tamarac trees of not less than twelve inches in diameter three feet from the ground. The commission received from a lumbering company an offer of 30 cents a market log for the spruce timber on a certain tract, to be cut in accordance with the law.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 10 -- The situation in Bluefields seems to be but little changed, excepting that the relations between Nicaraguans and Americans are becoming more strained every day. This morning the steamship Hewes arrived in port, and Capt. Morgan reported that matters were to all outside appearances quiet in the tropical city.
NEWARK, N.J., April 10 -- Among the appointments made to-day by the Methodist Episcopal Conference were the following:

The society women of New-York want to vote. Having reached this determination, they have set about accomplishing their desire in the energetic manner characteristic of them on all occasions. Without any particular display of flags or brass bands, they organized themselves for action, and the Constitutional Convention, when it meets May 8 at Albany, will be confronted with the results in no uncertain manner.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- A belief that the Government report would not be a bullish one on wheat had many advocates on the floor to-day. An easier market resulted from selling on this theory. Just why this impression became popular cannot be satisfactorily explained. Some said that a compilation of statistics by a private crop-reporting concern composed of ex-employes of ex-Statician Dodge were responsible for the premature report.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Rainy weather and the prospect of nothing more interesting than argument before the jury kept away the crowd to-day from Circuit Court No. 2, where the Breckinridge case is in progress. Besides the lawyers, the jury, and others whose attendance was necessary, not more than twenty people were present.
Richard V. Harnett Co. sold the following securities at auction to-day at the Real Estate Exchange:

James A. Herne's domestic play called "Margaret Fleming" has been put forward at the Fifth Avenue Theatre, to remain on view there two weeks. It is a well-known work, and has been the subject of much unprofitable discussion which no sound-minded person would care to have revived.
The experiment of placing the finances of a republic in the hands of a private firm is a success, according to C.W. Wells of the firm of Brown Wells, 36 Wall Street.

Work on the Lexington Avenue cable line is progressing rapidly, and already at three different places ground has been broken to lay the ironwork. The work oh the power houses is also being pushed forward. Masons are at work on the foundation of the down-town power house, which will be situated on the site of the old Brewster carriage factory, in Twenty-fifth Street, near Third Avenue.

New-York Yacht Club members are talking of various ways to properly celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the organization of the club. A committee has been appointed especially for this purpose, and will at the next meeting of the club, which will be held next month, suggest to the club members a way to celebrate.

The evangelistic revival meetings went on yesterday with increased attendance. At Niblo's Garden the noon meeting was attended by nearly 2,000 persons, while fully 1,200 more heard the Gospel preached in the five churches thrown open for the afternoon meetings. Next week the number of churches holding afternoon meetings will probably be doubled, and the great hall of Masonic Temple, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, added to the meeting places.

The two evening entertainments in aid of the Relief Fund at the Berkeley Lyceum closed last night with the plays "The Open Gate" and "The Dowager," presented toy the Amateur Player's Club, to a crowded house. Two points were demonstrated -- that a substantial sum had been realized for a worthy charity, and that the club presenting these pretty little comedies contains a number of talented players.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., April 10 -- Coxey's Commonweal Army is still encamped in a grove just outside of this town, and is likely to remain there some time unless the severe mountain storm prevailing subsides by noon to-morrow.

Fifty members of the Quill Club attended its fourth annual meeting at Clark's, in West Twenty-third Street, last night. After dinner the following officers were elected: President -- The Rev. Dr. F.H. Marling; Vice President -- Clark Brooks; Secretary -- James E.H. Nichols; Assistant Secretary -- Amos Parker Wilder; Treasurer -- Thomas O. Conant.

The Police Commissioners had quite a discussion at their meeting yesterday over the case of Patrolman Michael Griffen, who was caught by Mr. MacLean in the Common Pleas Court with his coat open and smoking a cigar while on duty. For this Griffen was removed from the detail and assigned to a precinct.

The Congregation B'nai Jeshurun and the residents in the neighborhood of Madison Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street began their legal battle yesterday to restrain John Jacob Astor from building a stable at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, adjoining the synagogue. Judge Gildersleeve granted a temporary injunction in the Superior Court, and arguments on the motion will be heard on April 17.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The condition of Winter wheat on the first day of April, as reported by the statistician of the Department of Agriculture averages 86.7 per cent. for the entire country. Last year the average was 77.4; in 1892 it was 81.2, and 96.9 for the year 1891. The corresponding average for rye is 94.4 per cent.
Resolution Adopted in the Republican Assembly at Albany Yesterday. Mr. Alnsworth, (Rep., Oswego) offered the following:
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- There are twelve proposed amendments to the Tariff bill, outside of those which the Committee on Finance has given notice that it will offer.

ALBANY, April 10 -- The publication in to-day's New-York Times of the story showing the methods of Superintendent Brockway of the Elmira Reformatory, and giving a history of the reformatory, was very favorably received in this city, and was generally regarded as a deserved piece of justice to a persecuted public officer.

Play was resumed yesterday afternoon in the Prospect Heights Tennis Club's invitation tournament on the club's courts, on Union Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, Brooklyn. W. Gordon Parker forged to the front with three victories, though he kindly allowed McGowan and Alfred Taylor to give him a close fight.

Lizzie Koch, three years old, slept yesterday on the knees of her father, Fritz Koch, a saloon keeper at 625 Ninth Avenue, while he testified in Part III. of the Court of General Sessions against Louise Jackson, a colored woman, who on March 22, it was alleged, kidnapped the child.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 10 -- In the Senate to-day Lieut. Gov. Sheehan handed down a communication from Mayor Gilroy of New-York opposing both rapid-transit bills now before the Legislature. The letter of Mayor Gilroy is as follows:

Most of the morning session of the New-York Methodist Conference yesterday was taken up in receiving formal reports from the various committees, but when the mem- bers adjourned to luncheon, which has been served daily by the women of Calvary Church, there were two warm debates, which came to many of the delegates as a surprise.

The Government, under the working of a series of complicated laws, is presenting artificial legs and arms to certain pensioners who still have the original members and who could not be hired to have the natural members amputated to make use for these gifts.

An important wedding yesterday was that of Miss Janet Sheldon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac E. Sheldon of 17 West Fiftieth Street, to Arthur Outram Sherman, son of Mrs. Edward Standish Sherman, and brother of Reginald Pelgrave Sherman. St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, where the wedding was celebrated at noon, was crowded with many friends of the bride and bridegroom from Boston, Washington, Philadelphia, and this city.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 10 -- The Senate Railroad Committee this afternoon gave a hearing on Senator Coggeshall's bill limiting the speed of the trolley cars in Brooklyn to six miles an hour. Edward Lauterbach, representing the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad, said that the laws had never contemplated street railroads in cities doing a rapid transit business.

PRINCEPTON, N.J., April 10 -- The appointment of Philip King, '93, as field coach for the football eleven next Fall is a very significant fact, as it denotes an important change in the policy of Princeton's management. During past years the coaching has been purely voluntary and Princeton has suffered greatly from the lack of efficient coaching.

While Coxey's army is marching eastward to carry its complaint of unemployment to the capital, another army is pouring westward in an unending stream. This is the army of immigrants, which lands in the various immigration bureaus and disappears at once in the various walks of life.

ALBANY, April 10 -- The Republican House made a peculiar exhibition of itself when, following Leader Ainsworth, who had been overcome by a spasm of enthusiasm, it passed a resolution indorsing the speech which David B. Hill delivered before the United States Senate yesterday.

If the spirits of the departed great are allowed to watch the acting of those who succeed them on the stage, there must yesterday have been an uncommon stir of interest among the shades of the illustrious leaders of the late Birmingham School of Political Economy when the Massachusetts Scholar-Senator gravely devoted hour after hour to contesting the doctrines toy him alleged to have been taught by them.

Interest in the contest for the control of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company is still very keen. A circular to the stockholders explaining the grounds on which a minority of the Directors advocate issuing the $5,000,000 of new stock at 75 cents on the dollar was issued late yesterday afternoon.

The New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which was in session in the Nostrand Avenue Church in Brooklyn, finished its labors last evening, when Bishop Charles H. Fowler announced his appointments for the year.

Announcement was made yesterday by Chairman Steinway of the Rapid-Transit Commission that a new syndicate wished to treat with the commission for the construction of an underground road. Commissioner Inman was the medium of communication between the syndicate and the commission. All the Commissioners, Mr. Steinway said, were convinced of the financial responsibility of the syndicate and were disposed to begin negotiations.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

On a recent Sunday afternoon the writer gave interested attention to the narration which follows. It is here reproduced almost exactly in the words of the lady from whose lips it fell -- Mrs. S. B. Cook of 250 Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. Her husband, Mr. S.B. Cook, has for many years held a responsible position in the Registered Letter Department of the New-York Post Office.

A well-attended meeting of the National Sculpture Society was held last night at 37 West Twenty-second Street, President J. Q.A. Ward in the chair. Mr. Nathan F. Barrett, landscape engineer, described the flower shows which have been held in the Madison Square Garden, with regard to the possibility of making a sculpture exhibition in the same place in combination with a show of flowers, shrubs, and trees.

The last exhibition of the season of the Umpire Theatre Dramatic School was given it the Empire yesterday afternoon under the direction of Nelson Wheatcroft. The theatre was crowded to overflowing by Mends of the pupils and actors and actresses interested in the progress of the school.

ALBANY, April 10 -- The Hill wing of the Democratic Party, by means of a coalition with Republicans, succeeded in accomplishing to-day what they have been trying to do for eight years -- the overthrow of the regular Democratic organization of Albany.

Joseph T. Magee, managing clerk for Lawyer William M. Mullen, has been in jail since the evening of March 17, when Martha J. Fuller, Mullen's typewriter, was found dead in his office in the Nassau Chambers Building.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 10 -- The election to-day was a repetition of the uprisings against bossism of last year and two years ago, when Reuben Simpson was elected President of the Board of Aldermen and Peter F. Wanser was elected Mayor. If anything, the Republicans, with whom the friends of good government allied themselves, made a cleaner sweep than in either of the previous elections, carrying five of the six Aldermanic districts.

ALBANY, April 10 -- The Supply bill was a special order. Senator Mullin offered some amendments, and the bill was passed unanimously. The amendments add about $70,000 to the total. Among the additions is $5,000 for the care of the State exhibits at the World's Fair. Senator Bradley had the appropriation for the Brooklyn Subway Commission stricken out.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- Some of the smarter traders thought they detected clique brokers yesterday selling Philadelphia Traction, and, judging by the volume of transactions, there is probably some foundation for the suspicion. Those who had nerve enough to back their opinions sold what the market would take, and then hammered away and tried to get it down.

BOSTON, April 10 -- The market for local stocks was more active to-day. Mexican Central and the Telephones and the Coppers were the features. Bell Telephone advanced to 189 1/2 and there appeared to be a good demand for the stock. Erie Telephone opened at 46, 1 point above last night's close, declined to 45 3/4, rose to 46 1/2, and settled back to its strating point.

Manager Willis B. Troy, who went to France to make arrangements for Arthur Zimmerman's debut as a professional cyclist, is due to arrive here to-day on the Majestic of the White Star Line. If all the arrangements made are satisfactory, Zimmerman will to-day announce his retirement from the amateur ranks and henceforth race for cash only.

George Storner some years ago became converted to Christianity under the preaching of the Rev. William T. Eising, pastor of the De Witt Memorial Church. He had been paying attentions to a young woman of the name of Emma Ribber. Friends and relatives understood that they were to be married.

At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, Alderman Rogers offered a resolution indorsing the bill introduced in Congress by James G. Maguire of California, guaranteeing to every letter carrier a hearing before dismissal, such as is granted to policemen and firemen in this city. This bill will have the effect.

The Sinking Fund Commission yesterday confirmed the terms of sale drawn up by Controller Fitch for the leases of the Bay Ridge and Staten Island Ferries. The leases will be advertised, probably during the present week.

United States Judge Jenkins, in denying a motion for a modification of the injunction restraining the employes of the Northern Pacific Railroad from striking, rendered a long decision at Milwaukee last week which contains a thorough discussion of the unlawfulness of strikes in general.

BUENOS AYRES, April 10 -- One hundred and twelve Brazilian insurgent officers and sailors who escaped, from the Portuguese war ships Mindello and Affonso de Albuquerque on Sunday afternoon, have landed at the Buenos Ayres quarantine station. Admiral da Gama, who was reported yesterday to be among those who escaped, is now said to have refused at the last moment to leave the Mindello.

Cracksmen blew open the safe in the office of T. Altschult Co., wholesale liquor, dealers, 58 and 60 College Place, Monday night. The robbers took away a package of valuable papers. Including warehouse receipts, life-insurance papers, and a will. The members of the firm will not acknowledge that any money was taken.

There is trouble ahead over the proposed production at the Imperial Music Hall next week of a burlesque on "Utopia, (Limited,)" entitled "Unlimited Utopia." Manager Kraus has been announcing the burlesque as the work of "W.S. Silbert and Sir Arthur Gullivan, under the management of Doyle (Mc) Carty."
SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 -- Ex-President Harrison, in the course of an address at a reception given him by the Union League Club last night, said:

EMPORIA, Kan., April 11 -- The latest news from the tornado in Coffee County indicates that the storm came up from the southwest and whipped around into the north. Most of the damage was done when the wind met at the turning point.

COLUMBUS, April 11 -- Representative Doty, Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Ohio House of Representatives, has introduced a bill to permit the issue of $600,000 in certificates of indebtedness. In presenting the bill he said the State had for years exceeded her receipts, and the income for the present year was now virtually mortgaged for $500,000.

The athletic members of the Washington Heights Young Men's Christian Association, suddenly left without a physical director for the coming Summer months, are not going to let their Interest. In outdoor sports lag. Mr. Trevanion J. Cook, who was recently appointed physical director of the Deaf and Dumb Institute, to take charge of the new gymnasium, begun his duties in his new home the 1st of the month.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 11 -- Gov. W.J. Stone left here this evening for Hot Springs, Ark., where he will remain for two weeks for the benefit of his health. To a United Press reporter he was outspoken in his denunciation of Senator Hill for his speech opposing the Tariff bill. He said:

Miss Bertha Sarah Mills Seymour, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Allen Seymour, and Jefferson De Ment Thompson were married yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock in the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Howard S. Duffield officiated.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, April 11 -- P.M. The storm to-day curtailed business, and the total transactions -were less than 100,000 shares. Telegraph wires were down in Beveral directions, and outside orders were consequently few; Brokers' offices were almost deserted, few people coming down town who could avoid doing so.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Senator Hill enjoys the congratulations of the Republicans who have commended him for his speech quite as much as any other Democrat in the Senate would appreciate the good opinion of his own party friends. He does not show the dispatches of disapproval, although he yesterday admitted that he was not receiving compliments alone.

It is a matter of great gratification to the managers of the Harlem charity ball that the sum realized from the sale of boxes on Monday evening will cover the expenses of the affair. The proceeds from the sale of all other tickets will go directly to the non-sectarian charities, for which the ball is given, not over 1 per cent, being deducted for any purpose.

As it stands now, the case of Mr. Brockway, the Superintendent of the Elmira Reformatory, is a striking exemplification of the dangers of "trial by newspaper." A report, has been rendered which is called and which is in form, the report of the State Board of Charities, but is in fact the report of a single member of that board.

The protest raised throughout the city against the attempt at Albany to deprive co-operative fire insurance companies of a legal standing in the State has been taken up by business men. It found expression yesterday through a commercial body when the Board of Trade and Transportation declared itself opposed to the pending bills.

ALBANY, April 11 -- The Provident Loan Society bill has passed both houses, on the acceptation of the report of the conference committee, and is now in the hands of Gov. Flower. In the House ten members voted against the adoption of the report, one Republican, Kelsey of Liyingston, and nine Democrats, Butts, Davidson, Keleher, Marrin, and Stein, of New-York; Cahill, Finnigan, Melody, and Plant, of Kings.

PATERSON, N.J., April 11 -- The live pigeon match between T.W. Morfey of this city, winner of the great American handicap contest last week, and Lever of Elizabeth took place at Willard Park this afternoon in a blinding snowstorm. The match was $100 a side. Twenty-five birds were shot at by each man.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- In the Senate to-day Senator Hale (Rep., Me.,) presented an argument against the Tariff bill. An interesting feature of the speech was as to the effect of the bill upon the annexation sentiment in the Dominion of Canada, Mr. Hale contending that its passage would postpone indefinitely any prospect of such annexation.

RONDOUT, N.Y., April 11 -- Snow has fallen heavily all day in the Hudson River Valley, and the wind has blown with great violence from the northwest. The snow is six inches on the level in this city, and is still falling. The tide this morning was the highest of the year, and flooded same of the down-town streets.

The new syndicate which is said to be ready to negotiate for a franchise to build an underground rapid-transit road still keeps under cover. Rapid-Transit Commissioner John H. Inman, through whom the syndicate was brought to the attention of the Rapid-Transit Commission, said yesterday that the names of the persons interested would not be made known pending the consideration of the Chamber of Commerce bill at Albany.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., April 11 -- The three-masted schooner Benjamin B. Church, which came ashore last Saturday, drifted off this morning, was driven west by the storm, and is now out of sight. The storm is severe along the coast, and, with the blinding snow and hail, renders the patrolling of the beach almost impossible.

The New-York Times continues with great vigor and with much circumstantial detail its exposure of the abuses of the pension laws in New-York State. In this it is ren- dering a great service to the Pension Department, in the matter of pointing out the abuses that exist and where the persons implicated are located.

LONG ISLAND CITY, April 11 -- The heavy northeast storm that broke over Long Island early this morning continued all through the day. The driving wind was accompanied by a thick fall of snow. The wind played havoc with telegraph and telephone wires in this city. Out on the island many places were isolated through the breaking of the wires.

TRENTON, N.J., April 11 -- The sweeping Republican victory in the local elections in this State yesterday is another tremendous blow at the ring politicians and race-track gamblers, who, previous to their defeat last Autumn, held undisputed sway in the principal cities and towns of the Commonwealth.

The "machine" Democratic politicians in Brooklyn -- were busy yesterday computing the results of Tuesday-night's primary elections. Although long lists of delegates and election district officers were sent to the police the primaries were to a large degree either farcical or fraudulent.

One of the most important weddings of April was celebrated at Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday, when Miss Elizabeth Remsen Le Boy was married to Henry Dale, by Dr. Henry Yates Satterlee, rector of the church, assisted by the Rev., Dr. J.S. Spencer, rector of St. John's Church, Tarrytown.

CONEY ISLAND, April 11 -- The storm which swept down on Coney Island did touch damage along the beach. The tide at noon to-day was the highest registered for several years. The wind blew a gale all last night and to-day up to 6 o'clock.

MIDDLEPORT, Ohio, April 11 -- A terrible accident occurred this afternoon at the steel plant of King, Gilbert Warner, by which ten men were fearfully burned by the upsetting of a mass of molten metal. Four of the injured will die. The list of injured is:

ALBANY, April 11 -- During a discussion, in the Assembly on the bill introduced, by Mr. Ainsworth (Rep., Oswego,) this morning to extend the powers of the Superintendent of insurance, John A. Hennessy, (Dem., Kings,) declared that it was folly for the House to give Mr. Pierce additional power, because he was now trying cunningly to wipe the American Lloyds out of existence.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Senator Morgan, (Dem., Ala.,) by courtesy of Mr. Hale, who held the floor, made a personal explanation in the Senate to-day. He read an extract from an article in a New-York paper of a recent date commenting upon the manifesto of the Minnesota Democracy against certain Democratic Senators for their supposed opposition to the Tariff bill.

Paintings collected by the late John Wolfe will be sold to-night at the Art Galleries of Messrs. Ortgtes, 366 Fifth Avenue. It is the third collection to which Mr. Wolfe's name has been attached, and slums clearly enough his preferences in fine art.
The meeting of the Park Board yesterday was the first attended by Edward Bell, appointed to succeed Paul Dana. Mr. Bell and his associates gave most of their attention to the Castle Garden Aquarium.

Pensions have been granted for all manner of disabilities. A New-York Times reporter found one man who has a great deal of experience with the Pension Bureau, because, as he alleges, he wore shoes during a part of his army career which hurt the third toe of his right foot.

Over 200 women braved the storm yesterday afternoon to attend a conference, under the auspices of the New-York Asociation of Sewing Schools, in the hall of the Young Women's Christian Association in East Fifteenth Street. Most of those present are interested in industrial work from philanthropic motives, and the principal religious and industrial institutions of New-York and Brooklyn were represented.

The history of the local epidemic of typhoid fever in Montclair, N.J., not only shows once more the value of effective sanitary supervision of the sources of milk supplies, but also directs attention to the culpable and inexcusable failure of a sanitary officer to take measures for the protection of consumers whom he was asked to guard.

The heavy storm was responsible for the stagnation in the horse market yesterday. Travel was unpleasant, and there were but few visitors to the marts. The few parchasers who did visit the stables were mostly in search of horses suitable for use at the Summer resorts during the coming season, and at present the dealers are catering to this class of patrons.

Senator Hill will not get the indorsement of the Board of Trade and Transportation which one of his admirers planned for him at yesterday's meeting, when Thomas Barrett injected into the peaceful routine of proceedings a resolution to thank the Senator for his speech of Monday. A chorus of protest met Mr. Barrett at the outset.
HIGHLANDS, N.J., April 11 -- Eight sailors were drowned by the wrecking of the three-masted schooner Kate Markee on the Jersey coast near here this morning.
