The Kings County Bank of Brooklyn sued Edward J. Dougherty yesterday in the Supreme Court, before Justice Truax, to recover $5,500 on a note Issued by Mrs. Giulia Brandeis, and indorsed by the defendant. The jury returned a verdict for the bank for the full amount, including interest.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., April 11 -- Four hundred strikers swooped down upon the Youngstown works of the Frick company early this morning, completely surprising guards and employes. The men at work did not lake a second look at the attacking forces, but, dropping their tools, ran to the company's store, taking refuge in the second story of the building.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 11 -- St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, in Sussex Street, the oldest religious edifice in old Jersey City, which long ago ceased to be a centre of fashion, was crowded with a large and fashionable assemblage this evening. The occasion was the marriage of Miss Mary Briggs Abbett, only daughter of Justice Leon Abbett, to Andrew Jackson Post, Jr.

Antwerp, April 11 -- Within a few days five serious fires have occurred at Boom, about ten miles from here. The town is the centre if the brick and the making. business of Belgium, and the brickmakers are on strike. The fires have been attributed to them, and the police and military are patrolling the streets enforcing an order prohibiting the assemblage of more than ten persons.

The Republican place hunters yesterday drove Mayor Charles A. Schieren out of the Brooklyn City Hall, Unable, to withstand longer the protests and supplications of the hordes of importunate office seekers, the Mayor, in desperation, first spoke his mind vigorously to a delegation from the Tenth Ward and then picked up his hat and coat and hurriedly left his office.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
The Board of Supervisors of Kings County will make a thorough investigation of the St. Johnland county farm. The people's money has been wasted by thousands.

Spring masqueraded yesterday. The "trumpet winds" had not "sounded a retreat," for "ruffian blasts," with, a velocity of forty-two miles an hour, prevailed. The "infant blossoms" were snowflakes, and an appropriate greeting would have been "White Christmas, Isn't it? Bather sloppy, though."

From The Elmira Advertiser, April 11. Yesterday's issue of The New-York Times contained an entire page of articles from various pens and interviews with a number of persons in condemnation of the disgraceful conspiracy against the Elmira Reformatory and in defense of the managers and Superintendent Brockway.

On the second day of the fighting in the battle of Gaines's Mill, Virginia, June 27. 1862, James C. Skinner, a private in Company D of the 16th New-York Volunteer Infantry, stood in the front rank, carrying a musket. He was tall, shapely, intelligent, with keen black eyes, in which flashed the spirit of a soldier.

Archibald S. Tucker, or "Squire" Tucker, as he is generally called, is the best-known pensioner of West Stockholm, a little village about five miles from Potsdam. Squire Tucker is a Justice of the Peace and a prominent citizen. He receives the substantial pension of $17 per month for a disability incurred in the service.

A pretty wedding yesterday was that of Miss S. Antoinette Southack to David Bennett King at 3:30 o'clock P.M., at the bride's home, 444 Madison Avenue. The ceremony took place under a bower of palms and roses, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Brooks officiating. Only the immediate members of the family were present.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- A banking bill, which was introduced in the House to-day by Representative Sperry of Connecticut, is designed to establish a complete banking system for the future needs of the country, and gradually to supplant the present national banking system as the United States bonds mature and the present basis of circulation is destroyed.

Members of the newly-formed Good Government Club C were not deterred by the severity of the weather from helding their meeting last evening at 151 West Seventieth Street. The object of the meeting was to consider the report of the committee appointed at the last meeting to prepare a constitution and by-laws for the club.

The upper three floors, of the five-story building 102, 104, and 108 Wooster Street, occupied by a number of manufacturing concerns, were burned out at an early hour yesterday morning and the lower floors of the structure were deluged with water. The loss on the structure and its contents was nearly $100,000.

CHALK HILL, Penn., April 11 -- The Common-weal Army to-day marched twelve miles over the mountains, and most of the way through from eight to six inches of snow. It is encamped to-night at an old Continental mansion within a mile of this point.

The examination of Joseph T. Magee was continued yesterday before Police Justice Taintor, in the Tombs Police Court. Lawyer Riley was the first witness called to the stand. He told of Magee's explanation to the boy Denninger about picking up the pistol. Justice Taintor questioned the lawyer, closely about this point, and in regard to the exact position of the body, but received no definite answers.

It is announced that an affluent of Coxey's army of tramps is about to flow from Boston and to join itself to the main stream at Washington. It is still in doubt in what channel it will flow. The weight of opinion at present seems, or, rather, a day or two ago seemed, to be in favor of a coal schooner from Boston direct to Washington.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- This order was received by Secretary Carlisle this morning from the President:

With the advent of Spring and the prospect of better times for the workingman, the philanthropic work of Nathan Straus in furnishing coal to the unemployed at cost price and cheap lodgings to the homeless has about come to an end. Mr. Straus does not pretend to pose as a philanthropist, yet the good he achieved is worthy a philanthropist.

Two members of the Art Club of Boston have offered to share alike in the sum of $5,000 as a prize for one painting by an American to be awarded to a work, never shown before. The club had just voted the usual $1,500 for the next exhibition, to be divided into $500 for the purchase of pictures, $500 for a first prize, $300 for a second, and $200 for a third.

LONDON, April 11 -- Sir Charles Russell, the author of the Bering Sea bill, which has just passed the House of Commons and will pass its second reading in the House of Lords to-morrow, has made an explanation of the measure which effectually removes any doubt as to the exact meaning of Clause 7, concerning which there has been some discussion in the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- "Clear this room! Clear these people out!" marked one of the dramatic periods in the very dramatic speech delivered by Major Ben Butterworth to-day in defense of Col. Breckinridge. He had just told the jury that he came into the famous breach of promise case because "Ben Butterworth would not desert in adversity the man he had known in prosperity."

Politics and business are incompatibles. They should be kept strictly apart. A party that is engaged in politics cannot safely engage in business at the same time. If it take a business partner or link its fortunes closely to a business enterprise, it will for that reason sooner or later go to smash.

Perhaps the most interesting gossip among real estate men yesterday concerned the triangular plot bounded by Pearl, Hanover, and Beaver Streets. The rumor, which lacked confirmation, was that the whole of the plot, except the tip of the triangle facing Wall Street to the north, had been sold for $550,000, and that the block itself had been offered at $800,000.

The funeral of John Graham, the famous criminal lawyer, who died on Monday at the Metropolitan Hotel, after the amputation of one of his legs, was held at 11 o'clock yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Sherloclc Austin. Sherlock Austin, one of the best-Known lumber merchants in the State, died at his home, 117 Taylor Street, Brooklyn. Tuesday night of apoplexy. Mr. Austin was sixty-six years old, and was born in Cairo, Greene County, N.Y. He went to Brooklyn when sixteen years old.

"Dr. Parkhurst said what is untrue, and what he knows is untrue, if he has any memory worth speaking of, in his remarks made at the meeting of the Methodist Social Union Monday night," said ex-District Attorney De Lancey Nicoll to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday.

ALBANY, April 11 -- When Mr. Ainsworth's concurrent resolution congratulating Senator Hill for his attack on the Senate Tariff bill came up for adoption in the Senate to-day Senator Cantor moved to amend by confining the congratulation to Senator Hill's "exposition of the effect of the income tax."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 11 -- The National Miners' Convention to-day resolved that, on and after 12 o'clock noon, Saturday, April 21, 1894, no coal should be mined in any State or Territory where the organization had control, until authorized by the national officers or the Executive Board.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Republicans in the House refused to vote to-day upon the motion to discharge the order of arrest of members, made March 26, to aid in securing the attendance of a quorum to dispose of the then pending contested election cases. This left the House without a quorum, and at 1:40 an adjournment was taken until to-morrow.

From the present outlook the chances are that this bicycle season will surpass all others. The dealers report large sales, and from the applications made to Chairman Raymond for sanction of dates, the prospects of a very lively racing season are first-class.

MILWAUKEE, April 11 -- Indications are that the sub-committee sent here to investigate Judge Jenkins will make a majority and minority report. Mr. Spooner made this Interesting statement to a United Press reporter this morning, contradicting his own testimony, given before the committee yesterday: "When the committee finds that the question of the court's integrity is not involved, it will then report to Congress that the law be changed.
MANASQUAN, N.J., April 11 -- The storm has raged here with great force, and it is impossible to tell exactly what damage has been wrought.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 11 -- The revenue cutter McLane has arrived here from Miami, Biscayne Bay, with two small English sloops which were seized a short time ago at Lake Worth, near Palm Beach, for violation of the revenue laws. The boats are the Estella and the Chiquita, and they were owned in Nassau, N.P.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Business on the local Exchange could not well have been more inert and unattractive; it was well-high, lifeless. Alley "L" was neglected to an extent where not a trade of any kind was made in it, although 24% was bid and 26 asked. Lake Street did a little better in point of volume, but closed soft at 22 3/8 .

The four-story brick building in course of erection at Third Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was partially demolished by the wind yesterday. The wall on Thirty-seventh Street toppled over about 3 o'clock, but luckily no one was injured. The front wall is still standing, but it is in a dangerous condition.

The session of the New-York Methodist Episcopal Conference was brought to a close yesterday, and the list of ministerial appointments under the conference, which had been so anxiously awaited, was made public. As usual in such cases, there are doubtless many disappointments, but there were no protests offered.

Myer J. Stein has teen made defendant in a novel action for damages growing out of supplementary proceeding's in which he was the referee. The defendant in that action was Harry Phillips. Mr. Stein said last night that Philllps was arrested in a civil suit and lodged in Ludlow Street Jail until released on bail.

WASHING-TON, April 11 -- The question whether hostilities Shall begin in the Senate next Week, is attracting attention. Under the truce entered into yesterday, there can be no serious conflict over the tariff until next Monday, at least.

Chairman H.P. Walden of the Roads Record Committee of the Century Road Club has prepared a table of best performances of 1893, and It is printed below. Blank forms to be used in making applications for road records may be obtained from Mr. Walden. When a record is made over a surveyed course, a certificate from the surveyor, stating the exact length of the course, should accompany the application.

VIENNA, April 11 -- Prince Windischgraetz, the Premier, spoke to-day in the lower house of the Reichsrath in defense of the Cabinet's Electoral Reform bill. It was very difficult, he said, to extend the franchise to several classes hitherto excluded from it, and at the same time preserve to the State the needed influence of the conservative political elements.

ALBANY, April 11 -- As exclusively announced in The New-York Times last Saturday, Gov. Flower to-day carried out his determination to send to the Legislature a special message on the Adirondack Park question.

That snow-laden April storm has taken itself seaward, and, according to the weather prophets, is now making itself objectionable to transatlantic voyagers. It out-staid what little welcome it had here, and there were none to regret its departure.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 12 -- The severe northeaster of the last two days has caused much, damage along the water front here. Vessels were, torn from their moorings, haystacks were floated away by the high tide, and quantities of lumber and other portable property were washed away.

Chairman Lexow and Senators O'Connor and Pound of the Senate committee appointed to investigate the affairs of the Police Department of this city reached the Hotel Metropole last night. The investigation will be resumed at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Senator Lexow said that he believed that the examination of President James J. Martin of the Police Department would be continued.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12 -- Three safe-breakers attempted to blow open the safe of the Irvington Post Office early this morning. It is believed they inserted dynamite and exploded it. The charge was insufficient, and a second trial was made. The whole front of the safe was blown out, and the windows in the office were shattered.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 12 -- In pursuance of the decree of the United States Court made last December, the South Carolina Railroad was sold at public auction to-day. A large number of prominent financiers attended the sale, but little excitement attended the bidding. The road was sold to Wheeler H. Peckham of New-York, who represented a syndicate of first mortgage bondholders, for $1,000,000.

Commissioner Andrews has submitted to the Mayor a very favorable report of the work of the Street-Cleaning Department for the first quarter of the present year. So far as the claim of economy is concerned, it is sustained by figures, if comparison with last year is to be accepted as a criterion.

Few weddings have been of greater general interest than that of Miss Juliet Morgan, the second daughter of J. Pierpont Morgan, to William Pierson Hamilton, which took place yesterday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church. Bishop Whipple of Minnesota performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford, rector of the church.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, April 12 -- P.M. There was even less business done to-day than yesterday, and what little movement there was was downward. The bear leaders professed to be doing nothing, awaiting events. They admit that their attacks on the market have not brought out long stock, and they now say that they intend to wait until the bulls attempt to realize on their holdings.

Only one sale at auction was held yesterday in the Trinity Building. This was by Mr. Charles A. Berrian, under foreclosure, of the Sailor's Snug Harbor leasehold of 762 to 766 Broadway, east side, 70.6 3/4 feet north of Eighth Street, 70.10 3/4 by 97 by 67.10 1/4 by 101.6, with five-story brick and iron store buildings.

BOSTON, April 12 -- A dinner commemorative of the birth of Thomas Jefferson was given at the Quincy House this evening by the Young Men's Democratic Club of Massachusetts. Nearly 200 members and guests were present. The leading speakers were J. Sterling Morton, Secretary of Agriculture; James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency; John E. Russell, and Charles S. Hamlin, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.
If Edward M. Grout's idea is carried out, John Y. McKane will be brought from Sing Sing Prison to testify in the case of Catharine and Kate Bauer against the "exboss" of Coney Island.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Ex-Senator Wade Hampton, the Commissioner of Railroads, has prepared a paper embodying his views on the subject of Pacific railroads' indebtedness to the Government, which he has laid before the House Committee on Pacific Railroads.

There have been many discussions and conflicting opinions regarding the breaking off of the engagement of Miss Odette Tyler, the actress, and Howard Gould, son of the late Jay Gould. The friends of Miss Tyler say that she broke off the engagement, while others, many of them friends of the Goulds, say that the trouble is all due to the opposition of George J. Gould, Howard Gould's elder brother, to the match.

The weather of the past few days has been discouraging to the dealers in horses and carriages. Buyers do not get about in such weather, for there is no opportunity to try the horses on the road, and buying a horse at an auction sale without a chance to see what sort of action he has is very like "buying a pig in a poke."
The Right Rev. Horatio Southgate died at his home in Astoria, L.I., yesterday morning, after a lingering illness of eighteen months. He was in his eighty-second year.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, April 12 -- An east-bound Union Pacific train of twenty-six empty cars, was boarded at Uinta, the first station east of Ogden, last night, by over 1,200 of the Industrial Army. An attempt was made by the trainmen to put the leaders off, but they were unsuccessful.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- The order of the President directing the detail of all available revenue cutters on the Pacific coast for duty in Bering Sea was received here to-day. Immediately upon its receipt the work of fitting out the revenue cutters Rush, Bear, and Corwin was undertaken. These three craft are now in this port along with the revenue cutter Grant.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 12. -- The United States Grand Jury, which closed its deliberations in this city Tuesday, paid much attention to pension cases. Yesterday three well-known physicians were arraigned in the United States District Court on charges of fraud and bribery. They were Dr. G.A. Love of Preston, against whom are three indictments, one for accepting a bribe; Dr. Henry Jones, also of Preston, and Dr. W.L. Hollister of Austin.

C.W. Horr of Wellington, Ohio, a butter and cheese manufacturer, and President of the newly-formed National Dairy Union, addressed the Conference of the New-York Auxiliary Association of the union in the Mercantile Exchange yesterday morning.

Capt. William Cranfield and his jolly crew arrived on the steamship Majestic yesterday morning. He brought twenty men with him, and they are to take Lord Dunraven's yacht, the Valkyrie, back to England in a few weeks.

The evangelistic revival meetings being held in Niblo's Garden and various churches were poorly attended yesterday, owing to the cold rainstorm and cutting winds. The speakers and singers were none the less earnest in their work, however, and a large number of persons asked for prayers.

Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews made his report to Mayor Gilroy yesterday, showing the work of the department for the three months ending March 31. It contained items that were evidently a source of pride and satisfaction to Mr. Andrews. One of these was that which showed the total saving in the cost of operation to be $21,050.58, as compared with the first three months of last year.

The New-York Times has long enjoyed enviable fame as a Titan among political ring smashers, and it is just now doing some Titanic work in this line among the pension rings, great and small. Day by day for some time past The Times has been making an expose of pension cases which should make plain to the dullest comprehension some of the typical kinds of fraud that have been perpetrated on the Government.

Why is the English girl of the upper and middle classes four inches taller than was her predecessor, forty years ago? This new and interesting question is now attracting the attention of English scientific men, who are busily collecting data and framing theories with as much boldness as if the subject of their investigations were a fossil reptile, instead of a "soaring human" girl.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Kansas Republicans who come to Washington these days are full of enthusiasm over what they consider to be the fine prospect for the overthrow of Populism in the coming State elections. They declare that the whole State is up in arms against the third party, and that there will not be anything left of it in the State except its name after the polls are closed in November next.

The parlors of Good Governement Club B, at 70 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, were well filled last night with members and friends of the club, who listened to an address by Everett P. Wheeler on "Civil Service Reform, as Applied to Municipal Government." President H.R. Elliot presided.

BUFFALO, April 12 -- The American Grape Sugar Works, Scott and Chicago Streets, one of the largest concerns of its kind in the country, was destroyed by fire to-night. All but twelve of the sixty men employed in the building have been accounted for. It is feared they are in the ruins.

A pretty wedding took place at 1,014 Dean Street, Brooklyn, last evening, when Miss Florence A. Beal, daughter of Byron A. Beal, was married to Frederick Willets. The Rev. Dr. R. Marshall Harrison of the Bedford Heights Baptist Church performed the ceremony. The maid of honor was Miss Mabel Bridge, and the best man was Walter A. Willets.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Gen. John M. Palmer, who is Chairman of the Committee on Pensions in the Senate, said to-day that he had read with great interest all the articles relating to pension frauds published in The New-York Times, and perused especially the contents of the supplementary sheets of the weekly paper.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Democrats have a majority in the House, over Republicans and Populists together, of eighty-four votes. They have so many members that forty-one of them may stay away all the time and leave a quorum to stop Reed's filibustering. And yet, for several days, it has been impossible to get a quorum of the 220 Democratic members, or to do business.

Lower Fifth Avenue is divided in sentiment in regard to the measure introduced in the Assembly by Patrick H. Hoche of the Fourth New-York District, which, if it became law, would authorize the construction of "a railway" on Fifth Avenue, south of Twenty-third Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 12 -- The National Miners' Convention to-day decided that the wage scale and conditions adopted at the convention one year ago should be demanded as the object of the strike to be inaugurated April 21. This is the 70 cents per ton basis. It means an increase of from 20 to 25 cents per ton on wages now paid in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois.

The construction of the cable road in Lexington Avenue, which is now assured, is a fact of much significance in relation to intramural transit. There is no hope of any real and comprehensive system of rapid transit within a year or two, while this road will be in operation within seven or eight months.

All arrangements made by Willis B. Troy, the manager of Arthur Zimmerman, have proved to be of a satisfactory character, and the American champion bicycle rider will probably never again be seen as an amateur. On Wednesday next Zimmerman will sail for France, and accept the offer made by the Union Velocipedeque Francais to ride in professional races.

There was a large gathering of prominent Brooklynites in the Supervisors' Chambers in the Kings County Court House last evening, when the County Farm Committee gave a hearing on the proposed transfer of the County Farm at St. Johnland, and the care of the insane patients to the State authorities.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Rear Admiral Walker has complained to the Secretary of the Navy of the apparent disregard of the department's instructions at the navy pay offices at San Francisco. It appears that Pay Inspector Edward Bellows was instructed to procure passage on the steamer Mariposa, sailing from San Francisco for Honolulu, for Admiral Walker and his staff, Lieuts. Wood and Staunton.

The bill providing that the question of issuing bonds for the improvement of the canal system of the State should be submitted to a vote of the people at the next election has been defeated in the Senate at Albany by Republican votes. Only two Republicans, Lamy and Persons of Erie County, voted with the Democrats in favor of it.

Ten o'clock Saturday night the sixteenth exhibition of the Society of America Artists will close its doors. They opened at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, in the Fine Art Building, on Monday, March 12, to a public very glad to examine and perhaps admire the novelties and audacities on the walls; but not prepared to bad up their curiosity and admiration with purchases.

A large audience amused itself very well last night at the German Theatre on Irving Place with a three-act comedy by OberstLieutenant Davis called "Das Heirathsnest." The author is the editor of an Austrian military paper, Die Reichswehr, and his methods are not unlike those of John Strange Winter, except that the military, instead of being British, is a mixture of Germans, Poles, and Hungarian.

The old New-York Bicycle Club, one of the earliest organizations of the kind in the city, was reorganized in October, 1891, under the name of the New-York Tourist Wheelmen, with headquarters at 55 West Forty-second Street. This is one of the few bicycle clubs that admit ladies to membership.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Lieut. William F. Fullam, who has finished a tour of service at the Naval Academy, where he has been an assistant in the Department of Ordnance and Gunnery, has been ordered to the new cruiser Raleigh. Lieut. Fullam has made an impression upon the cadets of the academy who have come under his charge that will be productive of good.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The President and Mrs. Cleveland contemplate occupying their comfortable country house on the Woodley Lane Road. The place has been put in order and every arrangement made for the comfort of the family. If the present cold weather moderates sufficiently the President's family will move by Saturday.

The Chamber of Commerce Committee on Rapid Transit gave out yesterday its reply to Mayor Gilroy's letter to the Legislature in opposition to the loan of the city's credit to any rapid-transit project. It was only it Wednesday's meeting that a reply was decided upon. The committee naturally assigned its preparation to ex-Mayor Hewitt.

The preposterous suggestion of the sapient Denniston of Utica that the present Legislature continue its session at intervals throughout the year is said to be seriously considered by the "Republican leaders" of that body, lest the State receive some detriment while they are not on the watch tower at Albany.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I am pleased to find The Times on the righti side of the reformatory question, and you take just the right line of argument when you print the uniformly complimentary report of the State Board of Charities. If every charge of its recent report were true, then the Board of Charities is quite as deserving of removal as the Reformatory Board of Managers, whom the report especially chastises.

Creditors of the fashionable Hotel Regent, in Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, crowded the offices of Johnson Lamb, in the Real Estate Exchange, in Montague Street, yesterday afternoon. They assembled in response to an invitation from Charles S. Burwell, President of the Brooklyn Hotel Company, issued with the view of adjusting the indebtedness of the corporation.

BALTIMORE, April 12 -- The Manufacturer's Record says the steady improvement in the business interests of the South is shown in the total bank clearings for the first three months of 1894, as compared with the same period of 1893. Out of seventy-seven cities reported, only five had an increase in clearings, and of these three were in the South.

FREEPORT, L.I., April 12 -- Stranded on the mud flats off this place to-night are three yachts which were supppsed to have foundered in the Great South Bay during the storm yesterday. The boats have on board parties of duck hunters, whose friends had given up all hope of again seeing them alive.
ALBANY, April 12 -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Senator Sullivan's bill incorporating the Metropolis Finance Company of New-York City. In his veto the Governor says:

ALBANY, April 12 -- When Senator Saxton's Non-Partisan Troy Police bill came up for passage in the Senate to-day Mr. Collins offered an amendment giving the power of appointment of the Commissioners absolutely to the Mayor of the city instead of the majority and the minority of the Common Council.

NEW-HAVEN, April 12 -- An American sprinter is winning laurels in England. Stephen Farrell of Rockville of this State has just won the Sheffield handicap and the Easter championship, and word from his trainer states that ovations are accorded the victorious runner everywhere now. Farrell is the first American to win the Sheffield handicap twice and also the first to win both the Sheffield and the Easter championships.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 12 -- Over sixty cases of typhoid fever have so far developed here. Two deaths occurred to-day, making five in all since the first case was discovered, Harding A. Taylor died to-day. He was the milkman to whom G.M. Gould turned over his customers after the State Dairy Commissioner had quarantined his farm.
M. Mounet-Sully did not lecture in the hall of the Academy of Medicine, before invited guests of the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures of Columbia College, yesterday afternoon.

The series of indoor athletic contests which were begun by the gymnasium members of the Young Men's Institute, at 220 Bowery, last-November have been lately finished. Six contests of three events each have been held as follows, the event, name of winner, and distance or time being given:

The Rev. Herman Paul Faust, Ph. D., a converted Jewish Rabbi, has established a Presbyterian Hebrew Christian Mission and Home at 128 Forsyth Street for the conversion of his former co-religionists, and his description of its working was the principal attraction at the seventy-eighth anniversary of the Female Auxiliary of the American Bible Society, held at the Bible House, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street, yesterday.

Madison Square Garden will be turned into a farmyard for four days, beginning May 1. The spacious amphitheatre will be made into a veritable farm, being divided into numerous yards, specially devoted to cows with calves, ponies, donkeys, ewes, lambs, bulls, calves, pony mares, goats, fowls,, turkeys, peacocks, pigeons in cages, pheasants, litters of puppies, broods or young chicks, ducks, rabbits, and guinea pigs.
Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court yesterday denied the motion argued before him on Friday last by the lawyers for John Y. McKane for a writ of habeas corpus.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- There was a noticeable lack of interest in the Senate proceedings to-day. Under the truce agreed to between the Republican and Democratic leaders, Mr. Peffer was permitted to hold forth on the tariff question without being disturbed to any extent, and still his speech is not finished.

ALBANY, April 12 -- The Senate Railroad Committee has appointed Senators McMahon and Lexow and Assemblyman Butts as a sub-committee to confer and see if same agreement cannot be reached whereby a rapid-transit bill for New-York City may be passed during this session.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 12 -- The Washington express due in New-York at 3:30 this morning was at that hour about passing through this village on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, when a switchman turned a wrong switch and sent it into a siding, upon which a freight train was standing.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The marriage of Miss Marguerite Estelle Huyck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Van Ness Huyck, to Lieut. Juan S. Attwell of the Argentine Navy and an attache of the Argentine Legation, took place at 7:30 o'clock Wednesday evening at the home of the bride's parents on I Street.

In the Special Term of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, application, was made to Justice Pratt, in behalf of Isidor Schwartz, for the appointment of a receiver for the Triennial Benefit League. Mr. Schwartz has been a member of the order since 1891, and possessed a certificate, which on maturity, was worth $400.

The Albany dispatch in The New-York Times of yesterday quoting Mayor Gilroy as saying to a friend while in Albany Wednesday that he would not be a candidate for re-election this Fall attracted an unusual amount of interest in this city among the politicians yesterday.

There is a legend of an English monk who died at the monastery of Aremberg, where he had copied and illuminated many books, hoping to be rewarded in heaven. Long after his death his tomb was opened, and nothing could be seen of his remains but the right hand, with which he had done his pious work, and which had been, marvelously preserved from decay.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- It was a pronounced bear day on the Stock Exchange, and lower prices were established without any difficulty. The labor situation is such as to make operators careful, and until the outcome of the strike or lock-out has been settled which is brewing here, there will be no great revival either of speculation or investment, nor is there anything on which to base judgment as to the importance of the trouble.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Gov. Flower to-day received the answer of the Board of Managers of the New-York State Reformatory at Elmira to the charges recently preferred against the board. In concluding their answer the managers ask that the charges against them be dismissed.

The Russian Spring Flower Festival, held in the beautiful studio of Louis C. Tiffany, at Seventy-second Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon and evening, was in every way an artistic and financial success. Its most charming feature was the appearance of Mme. Lineff's choir, which was so successful in its performances at Chicago, in full Russian costumes.

Stockholders of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company are taking an earnest interest in the contest for control now going on between the present management and Le Grand B. Cannon and his friends. Each side has issued its request for proxies, and each side feels confident of the strength of its position.

BAY HEAD, N.J., April 12 -- The three-masted schooner Susan H. Ritchie of Leesburg, bound from Portsmouth, Va., for St. John, N.B., with oak timber, went ashow at Bay Head at 9 o'clock last night, with a crew of eight men on board.

Reports from Washington that another issue of bonds was contemplated on the terms of the issue of $50,000,000 of 5 per cent. bonds in February excited only mild interest down town yesterday. It has been supposed all along that if heavy disbursements and threatened large deficiency attended the Treasury operations a new bond issue would be projected.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Pollard-Breckinridge case will go to the jury Saturday. A verdict will probably be rendered that day, for Washington jurymen dislike being locked up over Sunday. The jury in this case undoubtedly will be locked up if its members fail to come to a conclusion before midnight.

Harlem elite danced last night at its Charity Ball in the Harlem Opera House Hall. The proceeds of the ball, which amounted to nearly $3,000, are to be distributed among these institutions of Harlem: Silver Cross Day Nursery, Harlem Relief Society, Convalescent Home for Women, Manhattan Hospital, Harlem Exchange for Women's Work, St. Andrew's Infirmary, the Eye, Ear, and Throat Infirmary, and the Harlem Dispensary.

The cry for municipal patronage is still sounding among the Republican politicians of Brooklyn. Mayor Schieren's rebuke to visiting delegations of spoils hunters and his assertion that they prevent him from transacting public business have provoked much comment.

LONDON, April 12 -- The steamer Faraday, with a part of the Commercial Cable Company's new cable, sailed from here today. The cable is to be laid from Waterville, Ireland, to Nova Scotia. The entire cable will be about 2,000 miles long.

Bishop Potter last evening attended a "parlor meeting" arranged by the society women who have taken up the campaign for equal suffrage. The Bishop did not speak at the meeting, but it was taken for granted that he meant to put himself formally on record in favor of the movement by his presence at a gathering called especially to promote the cause.

The discoveries made by the French Director of Excavations in Egypt. M. de Morgan, near one of two ancient brick pyramids not far from Cairo, are exciting the deepest interest in London and Paris, as well as among the tourists and European residents on the Nile. Brief allusions were made early in the month in the current news of the fine arts, but these finds are so important that further notice is necessary.

MONTREAL, Quebec, April 12 -- Judge Doherty, sitting in the Superior Court, today heard the last of the evidence in the cause celebre of The Canada Revue vs. Mgr. Charles Edward Fabre, Archbishop of Montreal. This case, from a civil and ecclesiastical point of view, has been, perhaps, the most important called before a Canadian court since the famous Guibord Montreal Seminary case.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The War Department has decided that it ought to direct attention to a business carried on in New-York, at 82 Nassau Street, apparently by John B. Ketcham, and which upon investigation does not strike the officials of the department as entitled to be protected by the high-sounding name it bears.

The taking of testimony in the case of the New-York Associated Press against the Western Associated Press was continued before Commissioner Shields yesterday. Henry W. Odion's examination was continued. He produced a number of original contracts and copies of contracts made between the Western Associated Press and newspapers in the far West, between Jan. 1, 1883, and Jan. 1, 1893, which had been turned over to him by the Chairman of the joint Executive Committee.

BALTIMORE, April 12 -- The tenth annual tournament of the Baltimore Gun Club began to-day, and, notwithstanding the bleak, chill wind, and snow and mud covered grounds, was eminently successful. A number of the crack shots of the Bast are here, and took part in the sport. There were nine events on the card.

Gold will be shipped to Europe to-day both from this city and Boston. La Gascogne will carry $3,200,000, and by the Gallia, from Boston, $500,000 will be exported. Hoskier, Wood Co. sent abroad $250,000 yesterday. Although these shipments are larger than those of any other week in the present year, the condition of foreign exchange which induced them had prepared the security market.

Another juror for the second trial of Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer, who is charged with poisoning Ludwig Brandt, was obtained yesterday. The juror accepted yesterday is Otto A. Wiedner, of 15 East Eleventh Street. He is a salesman for the University Press Publishing Company. The juror chosen the day before is John W. Wersebe of 2,254 Seventh Avenue.

Now that Zimmerman has decided to quit the amateur ranks, interest in the question as to who will succeed him as champion has been renewed, and the followers of the sport are figuring on the past performances of the candidates for the coveted honors. The champion yesterday received letters and telegrams from all parts of the country wishing him success in his new departure.

In the riotous proceedings which disgraced the Assembly at Albany on Thursday and were renewed in a milder form yesterday the Republican majority appeared in much the worse light, because its conduct was conspicuously unfair to the minority. To demand a detailed statement of the vote on the motion to reconsider the Factory Inspectors' bill was a right of any member, if there was a doubt about the correctness of the announcement.
David Dudley Field, the eminent jurist, died at the residence of his brother, the Rev. Henry M. Field, 22 Gramerey Park, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

ALBANY, April 13 -- Both House and Senate adjourned this morning out of respect to the memory of David Dudley Field. In the House Mr. Sulzer made the announcement of Mr. Field's death and moved that the House adjourn and that the Speaker appoint a committee of nine to take suitable action to show the regard in which it held Mr. Field.

The Rapid-Transit Committee of the Chamber of Commerce intends to follow up the advantage given it in respect to the controversy with Mayor Gilroy, by its letter to the Legislature published yesterday. To that end, it has called a special meeting for this afternoon at the rooms of the Chamber. The suggestion for the meeting came from Senator Lexow, who seems to desire more information than the committee has yet furnished.

If any of the invited guests who dined with the Thirteen Club in the Hotel Marlborough last night had faith in popular superstitions, his or her nervous system sustained a series of severe shocks. It was the club's fourth annual "ladies' dinner," and, to begin with, it was held on Friday, the 13th of the month.

The cessation of the high winds, the disappearance of the rain and snow-laden clouds, and the coming again of the warm and cheerful sunlight had a marked effect on the evangelistic revival meetings yesterday. The attendance was much larger than it has been during the days of wind, rain, and snow.

BOSTON, April 13 -- The market on local stocks was sluggish and without any feature of interest. American. Bell Telephone sold off 1, to 188, but later recovered and closed at 189. Lamson Store Service was dull at 24 1/2. Boston and Albany is still the favorite, and stays strong at 208, and Boston and Maine reached 150.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- The market was dull, and inclined to weakness most of the day. Toward the afternoon, however, it rallied, in sympathy with the advance in New-York prices. More than one-half of the business was in Reading. The traders hammered that stock hard, and tried to work the price lower, but the decline seemed to be stubbornly fought, and it closed at almost the highest prices of the day.

John H. Nagle, warrant and bond clerk in Mayor Gilroy's office, has been ailing since Wednesday. Yesterday afternoon a telephone communication from the Board of Health, notified those in the Mayor's office that Mr. Nagle had been removed from his residence, 158 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, suffering with a well-developed case of smallpox.

The sixth annual meeting of the Home Hotel Association was held yesterday at the house of Mrs. A.I. Ludlow, 118 East Fifty-fourth Street. The object of the association is to establish a free home for the needy who have devoted a lifetime to literature, art, or to any of the professions.

In stating his objections to the bill giving the next Mayor of this city the power to remove the heads of departments and making their terms thereafter conform to that of the Mayor who makes the appointments, Mayor Gilroy asks: "Would a man who was made head of a great business corporation change at one time all the heads of the various departments?"

Stephen R. Post sent word to the Produce Exchange before business opened yesterday that he was unable to meet his obligations. As he had been dealing heavily of late in grain, both here and in Chicago, the announcement made something of a stir. He had been working the two markets in opposite ways, believing that the differences in prices could not be maintained.

Dun's Review will say to-morrow: "Business improvement meets many obstacles, and is scarcely as distinct as it has been in recent weeks. Strikes have checked the improvement in building and same other trades, and scarcity of coke has caused closing of some iron works, while a strike of all bituminous iron workers is ordered, and may prove serious.
VIENNA, April 13 -- Emperor William of Germany arrived here at 11 o'clock this morning. He was met at the station by Emperor Francis Joseph, who was accompanied by a brilliant staff.
The New-York Times is rendering the country excellent service in an earnest and vigorous effort to sift the pension roll in this State, and to bring to the surface some of the most glaring frauds.

Gen. Joseph B. Kershaw died in Camden, S.C., yesterday. He was born in that place Jan. 5, 1822. He was educated in South Carolina academies and was admitted to the bar in 1843. He was a member of the State Senate from 1852 to 1857.
The four-story brownstone dwelling 180 West Thirty-fourth Street, 25 by 100, has been bought for $56,500 by Alexander Fraxer, who will remodel the property for business purposes.
Mr. Stoddard writes a plain, straightforward account of his journey across the continent, furnishing many practical hints as to the climate and accommodations to be found on the way.

ALBANY, April 13 -- The bill of Senator Coggeshall of Oneida County, which regrades the members of the New-York City police force and increases their salaries, was reported from committee and ordered to a third reading in the Senate to-day.

An entertainment was given yesterday afternoon at the Bloomingdale Asylum, under the direction of Mrs. W.J. Scanlan. Charles E. Pratt acted as accompanist, and Mr. Hindley, musical director of the Fifth Avenue Theatre, led the orchestra. The stage was under the direction of Augustus Pitou. This is the last entertainment which will be given at the asylum under Mrs. Scanlan's direction before the removal of the patients to their new home at White Plains.

The Central Park Riding Academy, Fifty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue, was ablaze with lights and decorated with flags and bunting last night, on the occasion of the closing ride for the season of the Park Riding Club. From the centre of the celling over the tanbark ring a large canopy of streamers extended to the side walls.

The General Term of the Supreme Court in an opinion written by Justice O'Brien, has set aside the judgment of the Special Term of the Supreme Court on an appeal taken by the Mayor, Commonalty, , in a suit brought against the city by the United States Trust Company to recover $130,756.71 paid as personal taxes during 1S87, 1888, 1889, and 1890.

The National Saengerfest which is to be held in the Madison Square Garden in June promises to surpass all previous efforts in vocal and instrumental music. It is the first time in twenty-five years that a musical celebration of such magnitude has been attempted. It is estimated that at least 10,000 voices will be lifted up in song during the four days of the Saengerfest.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- It will always be a matter of doubt which of the two Senators, Peffer or Mitchell of Oregon, delivered his tariff speech to the smallest audience. Both of these Senators spoke to-day for several hours, and there was but a corporal's guard on the floor and in the galleries while they were speaking.

NEW-YORK, Friday, April 13 -- P.M. That prices show no disposition to decline, notwithstanding the great dullness of the market, is regarded as very good evidence that there has been about all the reaction that is coming. It is certain that there is no stock pressing upon the market, and it is also pretty well established that the short interest has been covered.

The New-York State Democracy of the Fourteenth Assembly District met in the hall of the Lyceum Opera House, Thirty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue, last night, and began the work of organization. There was a large attendance. George Walton Green called the meeting to order and made a speech outlining the policy of the organization and denouncing Tammany Hall.

Those who teach habits of observation make no mean contribution to the sum of happiness. There is a class of people, to be sure, who hold that they get more pleasure out of paintings, music, and nature than the painter, musician, or naturalist can, but we are inclined to think that these are they who find study uninviting and idleness satisfying.

There was an innovation yesterday in the work of the Senate committee appointed to investigate the Police Department of this city. John W. Goff. the counsel who, with the assistance of John Brooks Leavitt, W. Travers Jerome, and Frank Moss, is to conduct the branch of the investigation which will have to do with the alleged charges of corruption and neglect on the part of the Police Department, stepped in for the first time.

Ex-Secretary Charles S. Fairchild, as executor, , of the late Mary H. Edson, appealed to the General Term of the Supreme Court in an action against Margaret B. Edson, as executrix, for the purpose of determining the validity of certain provisions of the will of the decedent as modified by one of the codicils executed by her.

The prospects for the Reform Democratic primaries in Brooklyn are very promising. There is every probability that a large vote will be polled at the election on April 27. Applications for membership in the district associations have been pouring into the headquarters of the Committee of One Hundred on Montague Street ever since the call was issued.

The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage, D.D., will complete in May the twenty-fifth year of his pastorate in Brooklyn. The anniversary is to be suitably celebrated by his fellowcitizens. The following correspondence has passed between Dr. Talmage and his friends on the subject:

The Wilkestarre players of the Pennsylvania State League were the victims of the Giants on the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was too one-sided a game to warrant description. The New-Yorks took the lead in the opening inning, and won with apparent ease.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Pollard-Breckinridge case will be given to the jury to-morrow. Judge Bradley said this afternoon that if the jury did not reach an agreement before he left the Court House he would instruct it to render a sealed verdict, to be opened Monday morning.

The course of the active Republican politicians in Brooklyn as to Mayor Schieren's refusal to give the offices to them for party reasons is extremely foolish, to say the least. Their folly is so complex, and they are, to quote a well-known judgment, "so many kinds of fools," that it is hard to know where to begin in exposing their folly.

ALBANY, April 13 -- For the first time this session there was a full attendance in the Assembly on a Friday. Every Republican and every Democratic member was in his seat early in the day. The second day's fight between the Republicans and the Democrats was expected to take place.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In the Senate to-day, after Mr. Mitchell's speech, Mr. Chandler (Rep., N.H.,) made a motion to adjourn, and called for the yeas and nays. The vote resulted: Yeas, 9, (all Republicans;) nays, 27 -- no quorum. Then there was a roll call, which showed the presence of forty-three members, exactly a quorum.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- The Erie Eastern League team was outclassed to-day by the Phillies, and met defeat by the score of 14 to 0. Score:

At the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday Controller Fitch reported his inability to sell the bonds for the Corlears Hook Park property. He said that the bill passed by the Legislature omitting the objectionable maturity clause would probably remedy the difficulty. He was authorized to issue $1,370,421 worth of bonds at 3 1/2 per cent. interest and payable in twenty years.
An important decision for wage earners was given yesterday by the General Term of the Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Business improved to-day. A wider range of securities was traded in at higher prices than ruled yesterday. Trade disturbances did not develop to the extent expected, which fact was considered sufficient reason for taking back some of the short lines, especially in West Chicago, put out yesterday.

The beautiful structure erected for the Hebrew Congregation Shaaray Tefila, or Gates of Prayer, in West Eighty-second Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, to be known as the West End Synagogue, was consecrated last evening, with impressive ceremonies. The building was filled to its utmost capacity by a representative gathering of the members of the Jewish community.

Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day. Time money was quiet and unchanged. Offerings were liberal, and the demand was only fairly good. Rates were unchanged at 2 per cent. for thirty to sixty days, 2 1/2 per cent. for ninety days to four months, and 3 per cent. for six months.

When the St. Nicholas Bank failed in December last, the banking firm of Levi C. Lathrop Co. had $279,255 to its credit in the bank. On the day of the failure the firm delivered $86,324 in checks for deposit to its credit. At the same time it drew for certification or payment checks amounting to $86,201, the certified checks alone amounting to $74,741.

Capt. R.H. Pratt and his band of seventy Indians from the Carlisle Indian School, Carlisle, Penn., arrived in New-York yesterday morning. Through the courtesy of Major Gen. O.O. Howard, the Indians were taken to the Statue of Liberty and thence to Governors Island, where they gave a concert.

The Board of Education decided yesterday that the recent nominations of school Principals came under the old law, and not under the, new law which compels the board to confirm the appointments of the School Trustees. The new Principals are: William Friedverg, Grammar School No. 83; Mrs. Frances A. Pond, Girls' Department of Grammar School No. 44, and Bridget Armstrong, Primary School No. 34.

TROY, N.Y., April 13 -- The Senatorial investigating committee held another session in this city to-day, and listened to testimony relative to the methods employed at the recent Spring election in the Thirteenth Ward, which is the ward where Robert Ross was killed.

The work of the Salvation Army was explained by Capt. Barter of the New-York Headquarters to the women, connected with the Women's Missionary Union of Brooklyn, at a meeting held yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of the Reformed Church on the Heights.
BUENOS AYRES, April 13 -- A dispatch from Rio Grande do Sul says the Federal troops have completely routed, the insurgents in that State.

Capt. Foutz's men had an easy victory over the Binghamton Club yesterday after- noon at Eastern Park. They outbatted and outfielded their rivals and won with many runs to spare. For three innings both sides failed to score, but in the fourth the Brooklyns went to the front and were never headed.

The Stars and Stripes were hauled down on Fort Sumter thirty-three years ago yesterday -- April 13, 1861. Only a few of the Union Generals are alive to tell the personal story of the great events of the civil war, which opened, at Sumter and closed at Appomattox.
The following plans of new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 13 -- A word of warning to Senator McPherson for his attitude toward the Wilson bill was given at the regular meeting of the Democratic Tariff Reform Club of East Orange, when the following resolutions were adopted:
The northwest corner of Bridge and Water Streets, Brooklyn, 95 by 100, with cooperage buildings, has been sold by John F. James Son, to A.S. Kirkman.

There is prospect of more trouble in the Sixty-ninth Battalion. This time Companies D and K, commanded, respectively, by Capts. Desmond and Lynch, are at war, and so bitter was the controversy last night that the members of the two companies were with difficulty kept from personal encounters.
The fleet which sails to-day for Europe will carry out a large number of saloon passengers. Those who will sail by La Gascogne for Harve are:

LONDON, April 13 -- In the House of Commons to-day, John Morley moved the first reading of the Registration bill. The measure provides for a half-yearly registration, with a three months' residence qualification, and that all elections shall take place on the same day, instead of spreading over several weeks, as is now the custom.
PATERSON, N.J., April 13. -- A coachman in the employ of William Strange, President of the Silk Manufacturers' Association, found a bomb this morning under the side porch of his employer's residence.

RICHMOND, Va., April 13 -- Judge Goff, in the United States Circuit Court to-day, entered a decree for the foreclosure and sale of the Richmond and Danville Railroad. The title of the case in which the proceedings were taken is the Central Trust Company of New-York against the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company.

ALBANY, April 13 -- Assemblyman Sheffield's bill incorporating the Provident Loan Society of New-York City, which, created so much, discussion on its passage through the Legislature, reached Gov. Flower to-day, and he signed it immediately.

There was little doing in the horse market yesterday, the only sale being the regular semi-weekly affair at Van Tassell Kearney's. This brought a fairly-good crowd of searchers to the mart, but the biddings for the offerings were slow, as a rule. Yet there was a good demand for horses that were offered with a warrant that they were "sound, kind, and true in all harness," as the vendors put it.

Mr. Edward Atkinson and other statisticians have lately expressed the belief that the pension roll has already passed its point of greatest expansion, and that we shall now see from year to year a diminution in the annual appropriation for pension payments. We observe that Gen. John M. Palmer, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Pensions, does not accept this view.

Nearly every seat in every part of the Star Theatre was sold for the Actors' Fund benefit, under Daniel Frohman's management, yesterday afternoon, and all the standing room was occupied. The entertainment began at 1:20 o'clock and lasted four hours. The receipts were about $2,500.
The death is announced in Paris of Henri Charles Georges Pouchet, the naturalist, professor of comparative anatomy in the Museum d'Histoire Naturelle.

British service journals are making sarcastic comments on the names selected by the Admiralty for its new vessels. The Gazette offers a selection of names, among them being Montague, Foudroyant, and Prince George for battle ships, and Devonshire, Breda, Portland, Kent, and Monmouth for cruisers. These names were formerly borne by English ships, and The Gazette advises that the names be perpetuated.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- At last the sensibilities of the absent members of Congress appear to have been reached. Reports of the lack of a quorum sent out from day to day have had no effect upon the vote for more than a week. When the House instructed the Sergeant at Arms to send for members by telegraph, as he did on Thursday, most of the dispatches were unheeded.
The auction offerings for the present week are given in the accompanying list, the sales to take place at 111 Broadway, except as otherwise stated:

VALPARAISO, Chile, March 20 -- In 1891, when it looked for a few weeks as if there might be serious trouble between the United States and Chile as a result of the assault upon the sailors of the Baltimore in the streets of this city, the Chilean war ship which gave our naval authorities the most concern was the Capitan Prat.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 14 -- The New-York colony of cottagers at Newport this season and the owners of the houses they will occupy, as far as now Known, will include the following:

The annual concert of the Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs of Princeton University, held at Music Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, last evening, was attended by a, very large crowd of fashionable people, who Showed great enthusiasm and admiration for the singers and players from "old Nassau."

ST. JOHNS, N.F., April 14 -- The Goodridge Cabinet was completed and sworn in this morning. Augustus Frederick Goodridge is Premier, William J.S. Donnelly Receiver General, Donald Morrison Attorney General, Lawrence O'Brlen Furlong Chairman of the Board of Works, Alfred B. Morine Colonial Secretary, James S. Pitts Representative of the Government in the Legislative Council, and Charles Dawe is a member without a portfolio.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A report which was heard at the Capitol to-day to the effect that the Democratic Senators had reached an agreement, whereby, no obstruction would be offered on the Democratic side of the chamber to the progress of the Tariff bill, naturally attracted considerable attention.

TRENTON, April 14 -- A bill has been introduced in the Senate by Senator Skirm of Mercer which places on the retired list of the National Guard J. Watts Kearney, son of "Little Phil" Kearney. There is considerable comment over this attempt to place J. Watts Kearney upon the retired list of the National Guard, with the permanent title of Brigadier General.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- It was a rather dull but decidedly strong market to-day. Nothing was especially active, but almost everything on the list was handled in a moderate way. North Chicago picked up steadily from 251 to 252. It required no little effort to raise West Chicago 1 point, from 155 1/2 to 156 1/2, but it was gradually accomplished by demanding the stock and offering none.
Alfred Remsen hesitated a moment after he had paid his matriculation fee to old Dr. Cusack, curator of the Metropolitan Medical School.

An account of the official trial of the new British torpedo boat destroyer Hornet, which recently took place in the estuary of the Thames, Shows that that craft is the fastest vessel of her type afloat. During a three hours' trial the average speed per hour was found to be 27.628 knots. This considerably eclipses any previous performance of any vessel of the Hornet's class.
Exit the Senate Committee appointed to investigate the New-York City Police Department -- for the present, at least it adjourned yesterday until after the adjournment of the Legislature.

If a copy of "Oliver Twist" possesses the canceled and the substituted plate of "Rose Maylie and Oliver," the result, when it comes to selling, will be very different from what it would be without that poor plate. "The Memoirs of Joseph Grimaldi," edited by Boz, is quite a different book in the eyes of a collector when the plate of the "Last Song" is with the pantomimic figures around the etching.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- The news on wheat to-day was all more or less calculated to cause disappointment to holders. The most depressing feature of the market, however, was the large amount of long wheat that was for sale at the opening. It was a self-evident fact that yesterday's buying had been overdone, and those who had the wheat were looking around for somebody equally as anxious to buy as they were twenty-four hours before.

Because of the comparative failure of his two latest plays, "The Charlatan." by Robert Buchanan, land "Once Upon a Time," from the German of Fulda, Beerbohm Tree has given up his idea of bring- ing the company of the Haymarket Theatre to America next Fall. After the run of H. A. Jones's new play at the St. James's is finished.

BOSTON, Mass., April 14 -- Writing from Glasgow under date of March 31, a yachting correspondent says: "The cutter in which most interest is centred on the Clyde is the forty-rater building at Messrs. Henderson's Meadowside yard, Glasgow, for Admiral Victor Montague, from designs by Mr. G.L. Watson.

PALERMO, April 14 -- At the trial of the Socialist Deputy Gluseppe de Felice and others implicated in the recent Anarchist uprisings in Sicily to-day, one of the defendants, Pico, testified that de Felice had worked diligently to organize an Italian revolution. A Frenchman had informed him that de Felice only awaited the arrival of quantities of dynamite which had been purchased in London, when an outbreak would be made in Sicily.

The most notable feature in the local chess world was the defeat of A.B. Hodges by J.W. Showalter at the Manhattan Chess Club on Tuesday last. As has already been stated in The New-York Times, this victory secured Showalter the puree of $100 given by the Manhattan Chess Club, but it really did not decide the championship, as the players, before contesting the seventeenth game, agreed to play a new match of five games.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator Zebulon B. Vance of North Carolina, died at his home, 1,627 Massachusetts Avenue, at 10:45 to-night.

There was a "scratch" exhibition of Wild and cultivated brook trout, or rather Salvelinus fontinalis, on Eugene G. Blackford's stands at Fulton Market yesterday, but neither in scope nor variety did the display compare with those of other years.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 14 -- For the fourth or fifth time since it was built the dormitory of Rutgers College has been robbed. Last night John Van Duser of Warwick, N.Y., lost $135, a diamond pin, and a suit of clothes. He was awakened by some one in his room, but could not distinguish who the intruder was.
Gen. Henry Warner Slocum died yesterday morning at his residence, 485 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. He had been ill two weeks. Death was caused by heart failure, following an attack of pneumonia.

"Nothing," says a woman whose housewifely skill and experience are coupled with an authoritative knowledge of sanitation, "makes a better dishcloth than no cloth at all, but a whisk brocm. The practice of using any old rag, an old stocking cut open, which is a traditional country cloth, or any similar thing in sinks is well known to be foolish.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 14 -- George E. Bissell, the sculptor, of this city, is working on a model for the bronze statue of Col. Abraham de Peyster, which is to be presented to the city of New-York by Gen. J. Watts de Peyster, a descendant of the distinguished magistrate of nearly two centuries ago.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., April 14 -- To-morrow will be a determining day in the coke strike. The strikers will hold many meetings, and they will either decide to give up the contest at once, or commence a vigorous effort Monday morning to get the men out who are now working. A prominent leader of the strikers said this evening:

Following is the list of horses named for the famous Suburban Handicap of the Coney Island Jockey Club, the most popular race of the year with the great majority of racegoers. The entries number fifty-eight, and include all the best horses in training, being particularly strong in the three and four year-old divisions.

"To begin with," said the society woman, severely, in reply to a question, "I object to the word 'fad.' I am sick of the phrases one meets constantly in print -- 'fashionable fads,' 'charitable fads,' 'fads' al the time. I wonder the word does not sink out of existence, crushed beneath the burdens laid upon it.

The single interruption to the week's sluggish market occurred yesterday, when Sugar stock broke out with one of its characteristic dynamite movements, and rose four points to 99 in about fifteen minutes. Then it fell back again as quickly, retaining at the close only a fraction of its first gain.

Gen. Henry Warner Slocum was born on Sept. 24, 1827, at Delphi, Onondaga County, in this State. For three generations his an- cestors resided in Newport, R.I., whence his father removed to Albany in 1812. From Albany the elder Slocum went to Delphi, where he engaged in mercantile pursuits until his death, in 1853.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., April 14 -- The social world of southampton, Quogue, the Shinnecock Hills, the other Hamptons, and other villages in this locality will lose little of its gayety this Summer. Many society people who have cottages here say that in all their sojournings in country places near New-York they have never found so enjoy- able a climate and so many pleasant, in- formal entertainments as in this part of Long Island.
ALBANY, April 14 -- Gov. Flower to-day, in approving Senator Ahearn's bill relative to a public school teacher's retirement fund in New-York City, filed the following memorandum:

The auction sales of real estate in Brooklyn during the past week footed up $177,678, as compared with $197,796 for the corresponding week last year. During the week there were recorded 309 mortgages for $900,231, of which 138 for $488,035 were at 5 per cent, or less. During the corresponding week last year there were recorded 305 mortgages for $1,227,188, of which 181 for $951,087 were at 5 per cent, or less.

-- Election of Colonial Dames. -- The National Society of Colonial Dames of America met in council at Washington, D.C., during the past week. Mrs. Howard Townsend, President of the Colonial Dames of New-York, was elected President of the National Society, which now has members in all of the thirteen original States and the District of Columbia.

MILWAUKEE, April 14 -- The petition of the President and Directors of the North- ern Pacific Railroad for the appointment of two special Blasters in Chancery to take testimony looking to the removal of the receivers was to-day denied by Judge Jenkips of the United States Court.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Fifteen thousand dollars' damages for Miss Pollard was the verdict given this afternoon by the jury which for more than six weeks has listened to the voluminous maps of evidence in Miss Pollard's suit against Col. W.C.P. Breckinridge for breach of promise. The jury was absent from the courtroom one hour and twenty-eight minutes.

-- A new dramatic star is rising in the West. The name of him is Col. William Johnson Fife, a good name, of mighty dramatic remembrance, for it was the name of the house of Macduff who "laid on." We get news of Col. Fife from a copy of The Union, newspaper, of Tacoma, wherein it is marked with red ink. The Union remarks: "To-day the life-work of the great dramatist is in suspense.

The first trip -- a complimentary one -- of the public coach Tempest, which is to run daily (Sundays excepted) between the Hotel Brunswick and the Country Club, Westches- ter, was made yesterday, with Francis T. Underhill and J. Clinch Smith on the box, and F.K. Sturgis, Col. Edward Morrell, Neilson Brown, Col. William Jay, Dr. W. Seward Webb, Frederic Bronson, and Reginald Rives as guests.

Meekin and Farrell, the battery purchased from the Washington Club, played their first game as members of the New-York Club yesterday. Both showed up in good, form, particularly Farrell, whose throwing was greatly admired. The Binghamtons were the Giants' victims, and they failed to score a run.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- For a short day the market was fairly active. The traders again made an attempt to hammer Reading, but did not succeed in making any great change in the price. Lehigh Valley was very inactive around 40, and Pennsylvania was dull and firm at about 51 3/4. Some attempt was made to bid up Baltimore Traction, and it sold at 16 3/4.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Treasury Department will begin business on Monday with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 14 -- The armor plate informers are still anxious to have the Government make a further investigation of the armor-plate scandal. Edward Sill, one of the informers, said: "Equity will cause to be reopened an award which has been arrived at through the concealment of material facts by the defendants.

The fair of the Working Girl's Vacation Society began very successfully Friday afternoon in Sherry's large ballroom and ended yesterday afternoon. The doors were opened at 3 o'clock, disclosing the preparations which had cost the charitable women who are the life and soul of the society many weary hours.

Col. W.C. Oates, Representative in Congress from the Third District in Alabama, and a leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of that State spoke in Greenville on the 11th inst., and in the course of his address, said:
BOSTON, April 14 -- It was a dull market, even for a Saturday, and no interest was manifested in even local specialties. The tone, what little there was, appeared fairly strong, however.

The association football team of the steamship Majestic was beaten yesterday afternoon by the Union Athletic Club at Cosmopolitan Park, Newark, by 4 goals to 0. The Majesties have only once before suffered defeat in this country, and that was also at the hands of the Unions. Fully 1,000 people saw the game.

Sugar Trust certificates, in which dealings recently have languished, came to the front again in the stock market yesterday. Rumors were abundant to incite activity in the stock, but the impulse that carried the market was the presence on the floor of the Exchange of a representative of the Wormsers, who had buying orders apparently without limit.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The cruiser Concord left Hongkong this morning for Yokohama, where she will take on stores and coal preparatory to sailing for Bering Sea. The Petrel reached Shanghai yesterday, and will at once proceed to Yokohama to join the Concord and accompany her to Unalaska.

Practical work toward pushing a rapid transit bill through the Legislature will probably be undertaken to-morrow, as the result of a conference held yesterday afternoon at the Chamber of Commerce. As was announced in The New-York Times, the Chamber of Commerce committee invited representatives of various active interests in this matter to meet Senator Lexow and discuss with him the situation.

Miss Mary L. Walker, daughter of the late Francis T. Walker, was married at noon yesterday to Charles Grenville Peters, son of the late Dr. John C. Peters, at her home, 179 Madison Avenue. The Rev. Dr. John Hall officiated. Robert Center was the best man, and the ushers were Center Hitchcock and William H. Eldridge.

At its coming commencement in June Harvard will celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of President Eliot's administration of the university. That it has ample ground for congratulation on its progress since 1869 is shown by statistics of the changes that have occurred. At the beginning of this period of a quarter of a century the invested endowment funds of the institution amounted to $1,754,147.

Odette Tyler, the actress, whose engagement to marry Howard Gould was so suddenly broken off, started Friday night for Sharon Springs, Va., where, she hopes to recover from the nervous prostration which has resulted from the strain to which she has been subjected, through the publicity given to her engagement and its subsequent cancellation.

BERLIN, April 14 -- Count von Kanitz-Podangen has suddenly become the most conspicuous politician in the empire. His proposal in the Reichstag that the Government monopolize the foreign grain trade has excited a sensation far beyond its practical importance and has caused a heated discussion throughout the country concerning agrarian Socialism.

TRENTON, N.J., April 14 -- There are a number of important messures pertaining to the public schools of this State now pending in the Legislature. The one that has attracted the most attention is the bill introduced by Dr. Wilbur, a member from the First District of Mercer. His bill provides for pensioning both male and female teachers, and meets the approbation of the members of the State Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator Hill has not abandoned his determination to amend the ridiculous rules of the Senate at this session. Late this afternoon he introduced three of the amendments proposed by him during the extra session.

Now that Zimmerman has quit the amateur ranks, and announced his intention of racing for cash, and "Willie" Windle has taken to the church and will not race any more, every person interested in cycling is trying to solve the championship problem, or, in other words, to name the man who is to take the place vacated by Champion Zimmerman.

It is not worth questioning the fact that there is much injury and injustice done by wills, but Mr. West has a humorous way of considering that wills have had the same devastating effects as wars. He has written the amusing work under notice to show up the blindness and mistakes of testators. It is not a treatise on wills, nor has it pretense of being either profound or original.

The great practical charities of Nathan Straus, the philanthropist have been closed. The Winter has gone, the Spring is here, and the hard times which called these splendid benevolences into existence are greatly alleviated by the approach of pleasant weather.

Because our trade relations with Australasia have not yet been important from the Atlantic side, we are not as familiar with Australasia as are people on the Pacific side. Of late, however, marked attention has been directed toward political conditions as they exist in Australia. Many social complications are now in process of solution there.

The Prospect Heights Tennis Club continued its invitation tournament yesterday afternoon on its courts, in Union Street, near Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn. The grounds were in first-class condition, and the playing was at times remarkably good, as the contestants are gradually getting into something like good form.

From the first notes played and sung by the United States Industrial School Band and Choir of Carlisle, Penn., to the last number on the programme of their concert at the Lenox Lyceum last evening, the keenest interest in all the selections was shown by the audience.

A local musical paper, usually well in formed, recently said that Emil Paur would not be retained as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra next season. This statement aroused the ire of those Boston newspapers which devoted a good deal of misplaced energy to heating the atmosphere of the Hub until it was intolerable to Mr. Nikisch, and they proceeded to produce an array of stubborn facts.

The coming of Spring, with its joy of budding leaf, soft breezes, and cheerful skies, is just as surely foretold in the city streets as in the country lanes. In the country we hail the first silvery gray of the pussywillows, the delicate cups of the hepatica, and the other heralds of nature with a delight that the annual transformation of field and woods renews.

The bank statement for the week, though it shows a slight increase in the surplus reserve, shows also another very decided advance, practically the same as that of last week, in the loans. This increase is $6,512,800, the increase in specie and legal tenders is $2,285,400, and that in deposits is $9,009,500.

George Work won the big pigeon shoot at Tuxedo Park, and secured the first prize, $495, and a cup, Edgar Murphy and Charles Macalester tied for second place, and agreed to divide, taking $108.75 each.

As usual, the coming season at the Meadowbrook Hunting Club promises to offer to the members and their friends a most enjoyable list of amusements.
