With the expiration of next week the regular hunting season will come to a close, and then the members will begin preparations for the entertainment of their guests during the polo tournament, which opens on June 4.

The reservation of the Yellowstone National Park was a wise and provident act. It was instigated, as all such acts are, by the urgency of some of the very few persons who really concern themselves with what will happen, except to their own families and immediate dependents, after they themselves are dead.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- The United States revenue steamer Grant endeavored to clear from here to-day for Port Townsend, but was compelled to give up the attempt, owing to a heavy gale blowing outside. The officers of the Grant say that from their experience with the vessel during the cruise just ended from New-York they are satisfied toe steamer could not make more than 4 knots per hour against the sea now running.

The funeral, of David Dudley Field will be held this afternoon at 4:30 o'clock in the Calvary Episcopal Church, 273 Fourth Avenue. Bishop Potter will officiate. He will be assisted by the Rev. Dr. Henry Y. Satterlee, rector of Calvary Church; the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, and the Rev. Dr. C. C. Tiffany.

LENOX, Mass., April 14 -- The coming season at Lenox promises to be very interesting. The cottagers are so impatient to get here that many of them have already been up to see about opening their houses. Next month will find a large contingent here from New-York, Boston, and other cities.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The proposed reduction in the medical force of the army will be determinedly opposed by army Surgeons. The Military Committee of the House has threatened to reduce the number of Assistant Surgeons from 125 to 90. A Surgeon of wide experience and long service said to-day to the correspondent of The New-York Times:

The superstition formerly prevailed in Brooklyn that club life and domestic felicity were incompatible. That superstition has been thoroughly dispelled by modern experience. Brooklyn has become a city of clubs without sacrificing its right to rank as a city of homes and churches. The growth of the club spirit has, in that respect, worked a complete revolution.

The decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court, reported yesterday morning, reversing the order of the lower court, which directed ex-Mayor Grant, as receiver of the St. Nicholas Bank, to pay in full to Levi C. Lathrop Co. $74,741, for which amount the bank had certified checks for the firm on the day before the bank's failure, did not involve any departure from banking methods.

WASHINGTON April 14 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations made today, through its Chairman, Mr. Morgan, a favorable report on the bill to amend the act of 1889, whereby the United States agrees to become indorser for the payment of the bonds of the Maritime Canal Company of Nicaragua.

All the world loves a lover and a newlymarried couple. This perhaps explains why the bulk of the crowd at Barnum Bailey's menagerie are always to be found stationed before the bridal bower of Chiko and Johanna, the gaint chimpanzees. The honeymoon of this interesting pair was passed in Central Park, to which Mr. Bailey loaned them last Winter.

Having published volumes devoted to the humor of France, Italy, and Germany, the projectors of this series now have ready the present work, giving examples of the American article. Mr. Barr's selections are perhaps fairly representative, numbering about ninety, and Illustrating nearly as many writers.

"Oh! -- Ah! -- He won't be elected again," That was the prolonged cry that came from the many women gathered at a political equality meeting at the home of Mrs. Russell Sage, 506 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. Gov. Flower is the man who is to suffer for what they consider an inconsiderate act.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 14 -- The severe storm of the last week showed only its mild side at this resort, and a few broken branches are the only result of the gale and rain. A week of gayety was opened by the ball given by the manager of the Laurel-in-the-Pines in the pink ballroom last Saturday night.

There, is a new book by Tolstoi, unknown except in Russia, untranslated, published for the instruction of the little moujlks in the primary schools, which has elicited the observation of a delicate moralist, Arvede Barine, that farry tales are the safest tales for children.
"Municipal Reform" was the topic of discussion at the dinner of the Reform Club last evening. Everett P. Wheeler presided, and there was a good attendance of the members of the club.

The two handsome sterling silver prize, cups and two bronzes presented by Col. Henry W.T. Mali of the Seventh Regiment Veteran Association, for competition in rifle matches by members of the Veterans' organization, were delivered by Messrs. Tiffany Co. yesterday (Saturday) afternoon.

SING SING, April 14 -- The session of the toothsome shad having arrived, the fishermen have, for the past few days, been setting their nets for them. So numerous are these obstacles to their passage up the river that it seems almost a miracle that any shad should, escape, and eventually arrive at the spawning grounds at Albany.

FROSTBURG, Md., April 14 -- Revolt in the ranks of Coxey's army to-day Jeaves the Commonwealers in a state bordering on riot. Chief Marshal Carl Browne of California was deposed as Marshal, and Louis Smith, "The Unknown," is in full charge.
A Strong odor of sulphur permeated the corridors of the City Hall yesterday, and about the Mayor's office and the rooms of President McClellon of the Board of Aldermen was an air of activity.

The Larchmont Yacht Club has always been a progressive one, and some of the best racing has been furnished by its members, who are always ready to make matches or arrange regattas. It looks now as though the Larchmont Club would save the coming local season from being a big failure, and some very lively sport will be seen at this favorite resort on the Sound.

Mr. Gosse four years ago presented to lovers of literature and of books an edition of the poetical works of Beddoes, illustrated with exquisite etchings, which the present publication of the poet's correspondence invests with new interest. Mr. Swinburne has said of this correspondence that it is "brilliant on poetical questions."

Titles were examined for years before title insurance was thought of, by lawyers of special training and known standing in the community and among their professional brethren. Their record was open to rigid scrutiny, and their, means of livelihood depended upon their public reputation for care, ability, and honesty.

Gen. Slocum was a typical specimen of the West Pointer of the period before the war. Like most graduates of his time who had much ambition, he felt that the array of the United States in time of peace, with its exiguous traditions and its remote possibilities of national usefulness, offered nothing in the nature of a career to an activeminded man.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., April 14 -- New-London society people are not fickle and never have been. They one and all love New-London, and Summer after Summer come back to their cottages to enjoy the glorious yachting, the gay dances at the Casino of the tennis matches, and the unsurpassed drives.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $8,398,794, of which amount $1,436,992 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $548,972, and the exports of specie were $4,481,143.

The package of valuable papers stolen by burglars from the safe in the office of T. Altschut Co., wholesale liquor dealers, at 58 and 60 College Place, either on last Monday night or Tuesday morning, has been recovered by the firm through a letter received from one of the burglars. The package contained warehouse receipts, bonds, notes, a will, and insurance papers.

An interesting organization meting at different churches in New-York and Brooklyn is the New-York League of Unitarian Women. It has some 500 or 600 members of all denominations. The discussions cover a wide range of general topics, and the speakers are always well worth hearing. Meetings are held the first Friday in each month.

Relatively to its area, Europe is much better furnished with railway facilities than any other of the world's Continents, and even in Europe, where the railway system had its origin, and where it attained to its vigorous adolescence at a much earlier period than elsewhere, unless we except the United States, the rate of growth during the last decade has been considerable.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 14 -- When the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club holds its regatta here, about June 1, the Oyster Bay season will open in earnest. It promises to be a very enjoyable one this year, None of Long Island's towns can surpass Oyster Bay for unceasing enjoyments. Yachting is its charming feature, and sail- ing parties are the most popular entertain- ments of the season.

LONDON, April 14 -- After all the perturbation and prophecies of evil with which the Parliamentary week opened, nothing whatever has happened. The Ministry has obtained quite its normal majority on a test vote, and the crisis has disappeared as suddenly as it had risen.

In North America, leprosy seems to have acquired such a small hold that the limited number of cases which have occurred there are well suited to study this question of contagion. I extract notes of a few of these cases from a book which I have recently published, and to which I refer for further details of these, and many other cases.

When that amiable and clever writer, Dr. Conan Doyle, created Sherlock Holmes, he doubtless had no malevolent intention. Now, however, that Sherlock Holmes is devastating all England, and rendering life a burden to every plain and sensible man, Dr. Doyle undoubtedly recognizes the terrible mistake he has made.

Gable ends have a significance that few people realize now. The carved ridge tiles and representations of animals, such as horses and horsemen, and the stone balls, all possess a meaning. Horses' heads are common in Germany on the points of gables, and are found in Russia, while chamois's heads occur in the Tyrol.

Yale's team is making a creditable record this season. The boys played a tie game with Boston, afterward defeated the champions, and yesterday they won from the Brooklyns. This proves that the Boston games were not "flukes." In the game at Eastern Park yesterday the Brooklyns made the larger number of hits and fewer errors, but failed to bunch their hits.

In the second cabin of the steamship NewYork, which arrived yesterday from Southampton, were thirty-five men from the dynamite cruiser Nictheroy, which was fitted out at this port for service under the Brazilian flag. They left Rio de Janeiro March 18 on the steamer Nile, and embarked on the NewYork at Southampton.

PARIS, Saturday, March 24 -- Was it only the Easter day of the morrow that so blossomed the trees in the Guignard farm, outrivaling the chestnut flower celebrity of the Tuileries, and dashing the premature hopes of the Champs-Elysees veteran? Or was it the inborn love of art or the superior skill and science of the head gardener?
ORANGE, N.J., April 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fenton Taylor of South Orange gave a dinner at their home on Tuesday evening in honor of the eleventh anniversary of their marriage.

CHAPTER II., (Continued.) CORA'S DIARY. How deeply sad was Lady Dunluce's face while she spoke of Africa. Yes, that is the charm. Her lover must have been a wanderer in those wild pathways. The next time I found myself alone in her morning room I made a further examination of her African collection.

A careful survey of that vacant nest convinced my wasp at once that it afforded the exact combination of advantages she was then in search of; and as soon as she had satisfied herself by a course of watching that the hole was not now in possession of any stronger and more aggressive wasp-eating animal, she abandoned at once her digging operations, and took up her abode in the ready-made cavern.
The following plans of new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

Renting in anticipation of May moving, and the making of loans have been the features of the real estate business during the past week. The first is not altogether satisfactory, except for the cheaper kind of flats leased at from $25 to $50 per month. Dwelling's have been in fair demand, but original asking prices have not been strictly adhered to, except in the choicest neighborhoods.
Mr. John Jacob Astor has written a book which is to be published by D. Appleton Co. next Friday.

To mount a camel for the first time is, for a Howadji, until he gets the hang of it, a complicated and anxious process. The first risk is that the animal will rise while the rider is climbing into the saddle. This he will inevitably do if the attendant has forgotten to place his foot on the camel's knee.

Capt. Abram E. Wood of the Fourth United States Cavalry died yesterday in San Francisco, Cal. Capt. Wood was born in Iowa, and entered the West Military Academy July 1, 1868. He was graduated in 1872, and was promoted Second Lieutenant of the Fourth Cavalry. From 1872 to 1888 he was engaged in frontier duty, and during that time was twice promoted.

The notion for dressing tables made out of soap boxes and easy (?) chairs fashioned from barrel staves does not so much obtain now as formerly. Occasionally, however, a really good suggestion for developing furniture is met with, one that is practical and yet honest artistically. Such a one is that of utilizing mahogany bureaus or old-fashioned bureaus of other woods in the way described below, and it is taken from The Decorator and Furnisher.

TUXEDO, N.Y., April 14 -- Tuxedo people say that the general exodus of society folk from New-York to Europe will hardly affect the pleasures of the coming season at Tuxedo, as nearly all of those who had cottages in that modern Eden last Summer will return to them this season.

A Philadelphia dispatch to the New-York News Bureau, published to-day, says: "It can be stated authoritatively that the report that the Reading receivers have decided to abandon the reorganization of the property is not correct. That action may be decided upon later, but nothing has yet been done.

MONTEVIDEO, April 14 -- The Brazilian rebellion has collapsed completely. The military forces of President Peixoto have driven the insurgents out of the State of Rio Grande do Sul, and the defeated and discomfited Admiral de Mello has disembarked 1,500 insurgent troops on the frontier of Uruguay and surrendered himself and his command to the Uruguayan authorities, who have disarmed them.

Le Grand B. Cannon, Vice President of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, and the leader of the opposition to President Olyphant's administration, departed for Havre on the steamship La Gascogne yesterday. The venerable capitalist has been troubled with symptoms of sciatica of late, and this European trip is taken on the advice of his physician.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Gen. Slocum's death was reported at the headquarters of the army this morning. No official action can be initiated by the War Department, except the customary letter of condolence, which will be signed by Secretary Lamont, Gen. Slocum not being in the regular service.

BUFFALO, April 14 -- The American Glucose Company to-day succeeded in getting its books out the ruins of the main building, on the north side of Scott Street, and now have a complete list of the men who worked in that building. It is said that the checking-off shows the total number of missing men to be twenty-two.

The steamship New-York surprised her agents by arriving here early yesterday morning from Southampton, after the fast Winter run of 6 days, 21 hours, and 51 minutes. The record from Southampton is 6 days, 9 hours, and 37 minutes, made by the Paris over a shorter course in Summer weather.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The death of Senator Vance robs the Senate of so much of individuality as to greatly emphasize the loss. Since the death of Mr. Beck, no Senator has died who deprived the body of so much of that quality -- a quality of which there has been a diminishing quantity since men began to reach the Senate for other reasons than great political ability and character.

ALBANY, April 15. -- The Schillinger incident in the Assembly last week discloses the carelessness with which legislation is conducted and the ease with which a really important bill can be killed by one member. The bill under consideration was inspired by a Democratic Governor, it was introduced by the Democratic leader, supported by the Democratic organization, local and State, and indorsed by many labor organizations.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- While Mr. Peffer and his fellow-calamity howlers in Congress are filling The Record with tales of the hard times, the hotels of this town, are receiving the best of evidence that there is plenty of money in the country. The richest harvest known to local hotel men in years is now being reaped.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., April 15. -- To-morrow will demonstrate whether or not the strike in the coke, region is at an end. At all of the plants mass meetings were held to-day, but the proceedings were kept secret. At Lemont, part of the strikers decided to go to work to-morrow morning. The strike leaders, however, finally persuaded them to remain out until the strike shall be sertled.

From The St. Paul Pioneer Press, April 12. Yesterday three well-known physicians were arraigned before Judge Nelson in the United States District Court in Minneapolis, on charges embracing not only fraud, but bribery. The prisoners are among the most prominent physician of Austin and Preston, and are examining surgeons.

SEVIERVILLE, Tenn., April 15. -- John Mullendose has been devoting himself for a year or two to Mary Montgomery, daughter of Capt. Robert Montgomery. The girl's father took his shotgun to-day and went after the young man. He met him in company with his father. "Marry my daughter or I will kill you," the girl's father said. Young Mullendose said he would not.

The policies of the Republican and Democratic Parties as regards pensioning deserving soldiers of the war of the rebellion, so far as those policies have been expressed by the national platforms, have been much alike. Both have been liberal to the deserving, soldier. The first that was said on the subject was by the National, Conventions of 1864, while the war was still in progress.

Bicyclists have not had such a day as yesterday for road runs and suburban trips so far this year. The air was just right to make a spin through the Park or on the country road enjoyable, and thousands of wheelmen took advantage of the fine weather. The thoroughfares in the city were at times almost crowded with wheels.

The kindergarten room of the Teachers' College, 9 University Place, presented a scene of the liveliest animation Friday afternoon, when the annual "Public Day" of the Department of Physical Training was opened under the direction of Mrs. Margarets Stanton Lawrence and her assistant, Miss Mary Belle Hervey.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A cablegram has been received by the Secretary of the Navy announcing that Lloyd Phoenix, while cruising in his yacht Intrepid, accompanied by John Schuyler Crosby, has visited the Cayman Islands, where they found in possession of the islanders the Kearsarge's bell, part of the memorial tablet commemorating the engagement with the Alabama, and the logbook of the ship.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 15. -- The Congressional contest in the Third District, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of the late George W. Houk, is rapidly assuming very interesting proportions. The special election is to be held May 1, and the Democrats have strengthened their lines in Butler County, where both candidates reside, by deciding to hold their county primaries on the same day.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Nothing is more unfortunate for an individual, or a party than extravagant expectations. When the news of the election of November, 1892, came in, and it was seen that the Democrats had not only elected their President, but had carried the Senate and the House, it seemed to many that a political, millennium was at hand.

ALBANY, April 14. -- A number of good advances have been made in the local bond market this week. Troy Gas 5s are 1 per cent, higher for the bid price, with no bonds offered for sale. A considerable amount of Westchester Electric 5s have been absorbed, and sales at 96 and Interest have been made.

Jethro Brozo, 6 feet 2, old, grizzled, blind in one eye, deaf in both ears, and otherwise disabled, stood on an old cart, shoveling dirt, in the village of Natural Dam, when a New-York Times reporter called to talk with him about pensions. His neighbors call him "Uncle Jet." He is seventy-four years old.

There has been but little change in the investment market during the past week, with the exception that it has been somewhat duller on account of the felling off in the demand. Government bonds, however, have been strong and higher, the new 5s selling at 118 3/4, the highest price yet reached, and the 4s at 114 1/4.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 15. -- Two feet of snow on Percy field for the last three days seriously interfered with baseball practice. Johnson, who played on third base last year, returned to Cornell University about a week ago. He registers in the Law School, entering up from the Cincinnati Law School, where he has been pursuing like work.

The President of the senior class has just announced the Senior appointments. They are: Class Day -- B.G. Paskersz, Chairman; J.W. Ehrich, I. Feesner. L. Green. B. Naumberg, M. R. Walsh, C.J. Derleth. Jr., J. Douglas, D.J. Fox, L.J. Frey, and A.L. Herzog. Class Dinner -- W.J. Rosenstein, Chairman; A. Haas, L.B. Meyer, A. Michaells, A. Rosenbaum, J.R.P. Savage, J.W. Brandies. E.A. Eising, W.F. Kurz, and E.J. Martin.

CUMBERLAND, Md., April 15. -- The oncefamous "Unknown" of Coxey's army was stripped of his veiled glory to-day and likewise of His honors as a Commonwealer. Carl Browne, the deposed leader of yesterday, has entire charge of the body to-night.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 15. -- The Princeton Track Athletic Association will hold its annual Spring open-handicap games May 5, Just before the Harvard baseball game. The following will be the events: 100-yard dash, 220-yard dash, 440-yard run, 880-yard run, one-mile run, one-mile walk, 220-yard hurdle, two-mile bicycle, pole vault, high jump, throwing 16-pound hammer, and putting 16-pound shot.

NEW-YORK, Monday, April 16 -- A.M. While the upward tendency in prices has continued, the market has been sluggish. The storms in the early part of the week prostrated most of the private wires leading into Wall Street, and thus materially reduced the volume of business.

M. Flourens contributes to a Parisian contemporary rather a strong article on the "Question of Disarmament," recently raised in certain quarters. There is no doubt, as I have lately had occasion to point out, that such a project is not seriously entertained toy any of the Powers; nor, indeed, is it easy to understand how this Idea can have originated at the present juncture.

Following are the returns of foreign commeres at the port of New-York for the week ending Friday last, and since the beginning of the year, compared with the returns of the corresponding periods of last year:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 15. -- Less than a month remains before Yale and Harvard hold their annual dual-track athletic meet. Under the conditions governing competition for the cup, the annual contests are held alternately at Cambridge and New-Haven, and the college winning it the greatest number of times in ten years becomes its permanent owner.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 per cent, throughout the week.

The seventh conference in the interest of good municipal government, arranged by S. J. Batten, William Scudamore, William Howe Folman, and Leighton Williams, was held in the Amity Building, 312 West Fifty-fourth Street, Thursday evening.

Half a century ago Theophile Gautier remarked the survival in Spain of two minor forms of bourgeois amusement, the keeping of cicadas and quails in cages, the insects for their song, the birds for their fighting qualities. Both amusements were known to the ancients and both are found to-day on the other side of the globe, in Japan.

PROVIDENCE, April 14. -- Considerable activity has manifested itself during the week in the local stock market. The demand is Wholly of an investment nature, and, were the offerings sufficient,'some large, blocks would undoubtedly change hands. American National Bank is in good demand and some sales have taken place.

The annual prize match for veterans of the Seventh Regiment was decided on Saturday night at the armory range, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. The first three named in the summary are the prize winners. C.H. Eagle, the second man, was a prize winner at Creedmoor as far back as 1873.

There seems to be a good deal of unsophisticated Democracy in some parts of Indiana. On Saturday a County Convention was held at Brazil, Clay County, which adopted a resolution censuring Senator Hill for his opposition to the Tariff bill, and, going further, censuring Senator Voorhees for defending the Senate amendments to the Wilson bill.

William Barnes, Jr., of Albany, a member of the Republican State Committee, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. He met there numerous other Republicans and told them about the great change in the local political situation, brought about by the recent election, when the Republicans chose a Mayor. Among those who were with him were Speaker Malby and William Brookfield, Chairman of the State Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- A memorial and resolutions, indorsed by the Women's Christian Temperance Union and the Women's National Press Association, will be presented to the House of Representatives to-morrow, asking it to consider the case of W.C.P. Breekinridge of Kentucky, whose conduct is declared to have been unbecoming a legislator.

The Crimmins Memorial Chapel of the Corpus Christl Monastery of the Dominican Nuns of the Perpetual Adoration, at Hunt's Point, was formally consecrated yesterday by Archbishop Corrigan, assisted by several priests. The ceremony of consecration began yesterday morning at 7:30 o'clock.

A visitor in New-York for a few days is one whose name is full of interest to the English-speaking world, a woman whose magnificent life work has endeared her to every citizen of this Republic and won her fame and respect in every land where such work is known -- and where is it not? -- Miss Clara Barton, President of the Red Cross Society.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- With the exception of the naming of the Congressional committees to accompany the body to its last resting place, the arrangements for the funeral of the late Senator Vance have been made. The Congressional committees will be named at noon to-morrow, upon the assembling of the two houses of Congress.

About forty of the officers and sailors of the Nictheroy arrived here yesterday by the steamship Coleridge, which sailed from Rio de Janeiro March 22, after the defeat of the rebel forces. Among the officers were Assistant Surgeon Armor, who was formerly associated with Dr. Sweeney of 147 Greenwich Street, this city, and Chief Gunner Cameron.

ERIE, Penn., April 15. -- William, Smiley lies in the Hamat Hospital dying as a victim of a Sunday morning sortie in the eastern part of the city. He and three others assaulted the house of Michael Emling, on account of some real or fancied grievance, and, after battering in doors and windows, fired into the house.

Pleasant weather Saturday and yesterday was very welcome to the traders in horses and carriages who have been in the dumps since the touch of Winter that has injected itself into April. Riders and drivers in the parks here and in Brooklyn were more numerous on the two days just past than they have been for over two weeks. With a continuance of such weather, they Will be even more numerous in days to come.

" Peace under a civilian administration, is assured in Brazil for five years, at least," said Charles R. Flint, on his return from Washington last night. "I passed the day with Salvador de Mendonca, the Brazilian Minister, and he received dispatches which fully confirm the news of the surrender, of Admiral Mello to the Uruguayan Government.

The report from the committee of the New-York City Mission in the case of George Storner, the young divinity student who jilted the young woman to whom he had been engaged for eight years, was not read from the pulpit of the De Witt Memorial Church yesterday.
The Brooklyn Temperance League held another public meeting, in Bradbury's Mission Hall, Willoughby and Raymond Streets, yesterday afternoon, and there was a good attendance.

The raving of Gov. Tillman of South Carolina about a coalition of Southern Democrats and Western Populists against what he calls the "combination of the moneyed interests," consisting of "Northeastern Democrats and Republicans," is in keeping with a spirit of sectionalism that a certain class of Southern and Western demagogues have been fostering for some time.

ALBANY, April 15. -- Some of the bestknown artists of the old and modern school are represented at the Albany Club loan exhibition for the benefit of the Childs Hospital. The different committees having the matter in charge have been indefatigable in their efforts to gather the finest works of art in the vicinity, and that their efforts have been crowned with success is attested by the remarkably large attendance during the past week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15. -- Latin plays have been given in this country and in England, but never with the elaborateness and careful study of detail bestowed upon the "Phormio" of Terence, to be produced by Harvard students in Sanders Theatre this week.

The following letter, written in 1883, by Theodore de Banville to Paul Meurice, one of the authors of the French version of "Hamlet" which Mounet-Sully is playing, interestingly raveals a great French poet's impressions of "Hamlet," and of French players of the part, including Mounet-Sully:

PHILADELPHIA, April 15. -- The ninth game of the chess match between W. Steintiz and Franklin Chess Club yesterday, resulted, after forty-nine moves, in a win for Lasker, who had opened the game with a Ruy Lopez. The score now reads: Lasker, 5; Steinitz, 2; drawn, 2.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 15. -- Three prisoners at the Hackensack Jail made a desperate attempt to escape this morning. Two of them -- August Gadeka and Morris Stevens -- got away, but Henry Durkes, the third member of the party, failed. Durkes is a noted horse thief. He attempted this morning to kill Sheriff Bogert.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15. -- President Eliot has made another practical suggestion to the students which will probably have a far-reaching result. This time he has spoken through the medium of the Graduate Club, and has outlined the plan for the so-called "Student's Day." That is, the President has suggested what he considers the right method in which a student should plan his daily work.

In the days when Hendrick Hudson went sailing up and down, the North River, the woods were full of Indians hereabout. New-York was a very small place then, and as the Dutch and the English began to move in in larger numbers, the redskins moved out. They were driven further and further from Manhattan Island by the growing settlements of the white men, and long ago they ceased to live here at all.

One of the most eventful ocean voyages that was ever made was ended yesterday when the British steamship Briscoe, four months out from Hamburg, arrived in this port. She came into harbor with her iron sides rusty and every yard stripped from her masts. The wonder is that the vessel did not join the flect of derelicts or plunge to the bottom of the ocean.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 15. -- Typhoid fever, which broke out here two or three weeks ago, is still raging. The number of those who are suffering from the disease is variously reported, and no two members of the Board of Health agree in their figures on this point. One member told a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday that the number of cases was "about forty."

From The Bedford (Penn.) Gazette, (Dem.) The New-York Times, with characteristic enterprise, has investigated nearly 1,000 pension cases out of a list of 8,000 in its possession, and lias from, time to time been giving the facts in detail to its readers. An appalling number of fraudulent cases has been unearthed, and it is clearly proved that the Government has been plundered, systematically, on a gigantic scale.

The services at the Brick Church, corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, were of particular interest yesterday morning, first, because the Rev. Dr. Henry J. Van Dyke preached for the first time since his return from Europe, where he has been for many months in search of health, and, second, because the services were the first held since the Church of the Covenant was consolidated with the Brick Church.

Evangelistic revival services were held in four theatres yesterday. Three of the meetings were under the auspices of the Central Committee for Evangelistic Work. The fourth, in the Academy of Music, was under the auspices of the Metropolitan Forward Movement.

George McAneny, Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Civil Service-Reform Association, has just Issued his monthly report. In it he refers to Senator Morgan's bill, introduced in the Senate April 3, providing for the reorganization of the Department of State as regards the home and foreign service, arranging all the officers in grades, making provision for promotion, and for removal and dismission only on proof of misconduct or inefficiency, as a step in the right direction.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, April 15. -- Dr. Miquel, Prussian Finance Minister, will give on Wednesday the last official dinner of the present Parliamentary session. It will be a grand function. Chancellor von Caprivi, all the Prussian Ministers, and a host of Imperial Deputies have been invited, and hardly a tendency of modern political life will be unrepresented.

TRENTON, N.J., April 15. -- The differences that appear on the surface to exist between the two branches of the New-Jersey Legislature admit of an interesting analysis. The eighty members of the Legislature are divided in the desire to serve their party and the public. Some are apparently partisans and others are reformers, and until these men strike the happy medium the wheels of legislation will continue to grind out new measures slowly.

J.W. Ehrich, '94, the crack short-distance runner of the College of the City of New-York, and Captain of the intercollegiate team, and Lyon, '97, who bids fair to make very fast time, have been ordered by their physicians to give up running. This is a severe blow to the college's prospects in the intercollegiate games, as both of these men had chances for a place.

The Rev. E. Spruille Burford, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Intercession, One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Street and the Boulevard, who has been suffering from blood poisoning, resulting from a carbuncle on his neck, died at the Manhattan Hospital at 3:20 o'clock Sunday morning.

LONDON, April 15. -- Justin McCarthy adaressed a large meeting in London this evening under the auspices of the St. Pancras Branch of the National Liberal Association. He had much to say of the charge made by some anti-Parnellites and all the Parnellites that home rule was not receiving sufficient consideration from the present Cabinet.

The McKaneites, who were completely routed by the independent citizens of Gravesend at the Spring election, have not as yet recovered from their surprise, but there are greater surprises in store for them.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The Brazilian Minister received this afternoon, a cablegram from his Government confirming the latest news of the collapse of the rebellion in Brazil. The cablegram is as follows:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15. -- Good prizes are awakening interest in track events, and the managers of the Spring track games are preparing an attractive programme. From Monday, April 23, outdoor sports will be constantly going on, and on that day the inter-class games will be held.

Senator David B. Hill's name was vigorously hissed last evening in Chickering Hall, Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street. The occasion was a meeting under the auspices of the Manhattan Single Tax Club, and the hisses were called forth by a speech from Congressman Tom L. Johnson of Cleveland, Ohio, who arraigned Mr. Hill for his tariff speech.

The great interest which many prominent women of this city are taking in the plan to bring before the Constitutional Convention to be held in Albany in May the question of granting to women by constitutional enactment the right of suffrage recalls the efforts made to influence the Constitutional Convention which assembled in Albany in June, 1867.

ROME, April 15. -- The Spanish preacher and theologian, Juan d'Avila Diego, who was known to his contemporaries in the sixteenth century as the apostle from Andalusia, was beatified at St. Peter's today in the presence of 7,000 Spanish pilgrims and forty Bishops.

In the prelude of his sermon in the Bloomingdale Church, Sixty-eighth Street and the Boulevard, last evening, the Rev. Madison C. Peters talked about the insolence of Mgr. Satolli's mission to this country and the American Protective Association movement.

HAZLETON, Penn., April 15. -- A serious railroad accident took place at Silver Brook, near Hazleton, at noon to-day. A Pennsylvania Railroad freight train ran into a Lehigh Valley express train, killing one man and injuring many others. The man killed was DAILEY, PATRICK, of Milton, Penn. He was riding on the freight train.

CONEY ISLAND, April 15. -- Twenty thousand pleasure seekers came to Coney Island to-day to open the season, earlier than it was ever opened before, and at nearly every familiar place found evidences that John Y. McKane is in Sing Sing and that the reformers have taken the empire of the Czar.

Receipts of $823 in 1820 and of $1,231,669 in 1893 tell, the wonderful story of the growth and work of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church of the United States. In the historic Forsyth Street Church, where the society was organized in 1819, its seventy-fifth anniversary was celebrated yesterday afternoon.

The students who have been interested in the production of "Joan of Arc," the burlesque presented by the Dramatic Club during the week of April 2 to 7, at the Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre, have reason to congratulate themselves on the success which has crowned their efforts. On Saturday, April 7, the club went to New-Haven and gave a matinee and an evening performance.

David Dudley Field, jurist and scholar, was honored in death yesterday when the burial services of the Protestant Episcopal Church were read over his coffin in the presence of the largest assemblage of representative men and women Calvary Church, at Twenty-first Street and Fourth Avenue, has ever held.

PITTSBURG, April 14. -- Speculative feeling, referred to as improving a week ago, was added to materially during the past week, and local stock markets display more buoyancy than for two years past. In keeping with constantly increasing demand prices are appreciating, and in a few instances the records are the test in the history of the concerns in interest.
The race tracks where the Brooklyn Handicap horses are being made ready for the big race were crowded yesterday by racegoers, who went down to see the horses worked. It was like a race day.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 15. -- The election of an alumni Trustee for Cornell University is soon to take place, and is attracting considerable attention both from the local and the non-resident alumni. The nominations already made by the alumni are: Charles Edward Van Cleef, class of '71, Ithaca; John De Witt Warner, class of '72, New-York City, and Charles Francis Wheelock, class of '73, Albany.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 15. -- The Spring term opened on the evening of April 3. With its preparations for the celebration of Founder's Day on April 27, the semester examinations in the first week of June, and the commencement exercises June 10-13, it will be well filled with work.

Charles Terront, the Frenchman who rode from Paris to St. Petersburg, was given receptions in various places along the route. On one occasion, however, he failed to receive the looked-for recognition, and the cause has leaked out.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 15. -- Business on the Great Northern and Montana Central Railways, from the Red River of the North to Spokane, Washington, was at a complete standstill to-day. Brief dispatches from North Dakota points indicate that the men are quiet but determined.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 15. -- William Walsh, Fred Young, Thomas Davis, and several others whose names have not been given out, none of them over twelve years old, have been organized for some time for purposes of thievery. In their characters as newsboys they have entered offices from which the occupants had stepped out for a few minutes.

The Rev. Minot J. Savage of Boston spoke in Music Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday morning, under the auspices of the Society for Ethical Culture. His subject was: "Religion as Affected by Modern Thought." Mr. Savage assailed what he termed "the old theological systems."

A statue to the memory of the late Rev. John C. Drumgoole was unveiled in the presence of 5,000 people at the corner of Great Jones Street and Lafayette Place yesterday afternoon. The Rev. James J. Dougherty, who succeeded Father Drumgoole in charge of the mission, introduced Judge Morgan J. O'Brien, who eulogized Father Drumgoole and the work he did.

Members of the rowing clubs on the Harlem enjoyed their first really pleasant practice yesterday. In the forenoon, when the tide was flowing against the wind, the river was a trifle lumpy, but later on, at the top of the flood, and during the early ebb, the conditions for sharp, clean work were excellent.
After saying some unkind things about the champion when it was hinted that Zimmerman was going to leave the amateur ranks, the official organ of the League of American Wheelmen goes on in this style:

Delia Hughes, said to have been graduated from the New-York Hospital Training School for Nurses, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday with Fred Hughes Lloyd. They were charged with kidnapping six-year-old Charles Kuni from the Half Orphan Asylum in Chicago. The woman was graduated as a trained nurse in 1888.

The New-Yorks won an easy game from the Binghamtons yesterday. Rusie simply tossed the ball at the Eastern Leaguers, but in spite of that fact they only made four hits. With the exception of Doyle, every one of the Giants made one or more hits, securing fifteen, for a total of nineteen bases, off the delivery of Dolan.

Mayor Gilroy may be quite justified in resenting aspersions upon his motives in the attitude he has taken on the question of providing rapid transit at the expense of the municipality, but it is hard to reconcile his treatment of the question at once with mental clearness and entire candor.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Secretary Gresham will appoint Edward J. Renick of Georgia Chief Clerk of the State Department, to succeed William W. Rockhill, promoted to Third Assistant Secretary of State. Mr. Kenick has been Chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the State Department for the last year.

CUMBERLAND, Md., April 16. -- While the heads of the Commonweal Army have been pushing preparations for the coming exodus from Cumberland, the army has been resting and living luxuriously. The Spring sunshine has been, a tonic to the frost-bitten travelers. Many of the soldiers went into the river, where, stripped to the waist, they bathed in the ice water, to-day, with a liberal allowance of soap from the great stock contributed at Alliance.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 16. -- The steam-ship George Sealey arrived to-day from Bluefields, Wearagua, bringing news to April 12. On the evening of the 6th inst, a small schooner arrived from Greytown, bringing mall advices and several Nicaroaguan aguan officials. Among these, to the great surprise of even Lacayo, was the Wilson murderer, Norbut Arguello late Acting Governor of Rama.
The annual election of the Tammany Society or Columbian Order took place last night in the great hall of the Wigwam. It was an event of importance in Tammany circles for various reasons.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16. -- The second annual meeting of the cycling department of the Roseville Athletic Association was held at the clubhouse, corner Seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, on Saturday. The meeting was held for the purpose of electing department officers for 1894. The annual reports of the various officers showed the division to be in good condition.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16. -- Harvard beat Technology to-day 26 to 8. The batteries were Perry and Scannell for Harvard, and Hay-ward and Thomas for Technology. Harvard batted finely. In case of a tie with Princeton, Harvard will play on June 2 on Yale's field at New-Haven.
The following communication has been received from the Rev. Amory H. Bradford, pastor of the First Congregational Church in Montclair, N.J.:

BOSTON, April 16. -- If the shade of Benjamin Franklin indulges in the habit of peering over the battlements of heaven and observing the goings-on on this mundane sphere, he must derive more satisfaction therefrom than falls to the lot of many of his brother ghosts, for the great and good philosopher must see the fruit of his wise planting ripened and nurturing the youth of generations which were in his day yet unthought of.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The sub-committee of the House Committee on Indian Affairs to-day completed the Indian Appropriation bill. The bill carries an appropriation of $6,455,866, being $537,890 less than the estimates, and $669,530 less than the appropriation for the current fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Secretary Herbert, referring to publications alleging wholesale frauds in Carnegie armor furnished the navy, said that several weeks ago he received a letter from James K. Wallace, a Pittsburg attorney, offering to put the department in possession of new evidenee regarding irregularities at the Carnegie works, and replied that if Wallace had any reliable evidence, and would bring it to Washington, it would be considered.

A supplementary season of two weeks of grand opera in French and Italian began last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with an admirable performance of Gounod's "Faust." The Seats in the auditorium were all occupied, and most of the standing room was filled. More than that, the enthusiasm was as great as if it had been the opening night of the Fall season.

The will and codicil of Henry A. Cram, the father of Dock Commissioner Cram, were filed, for probate yesterday. The estate is valued at $400,000. To the widow is bequeathed all the personal property in the family residence and an annuity of $20,000. The rest of the income of the estate is to go to the five children of the decedent in equal shares.

The caucus of the Democratic members of the House of Representatives on the question of the repeal of the tax on the notes of State banks was inconclusive. The Republican organs and some of the more stubborn of the opponents of repeal are Inclined to regard this fact as settling the fate of the repeal policy for this session, and to rejoice that it is settled adversely.

The rapid-transit conference yesterday at the Chamber of Commerce, at which it was thought a compromise measure would be proposed involving only the withdrawal of the names of Commissioners from the Chamber of Commerce bill, resulted, after a session of two hours, in no change in the situation.

The coaching season of the Spring of 1894 was ushered in yesterday with bright skies and delightful weather, and when the coach Tempest started on its first public trip from the Hotel Brunswick at 11 A.M. every one of the dozen coaching enthusiasts who were passengers felt in fine fettle.

NEW-YORK, Monday, April 16 -- P.M. Chicago Gas and Sugar were the only features in to-day's stock market. In the former more than 83,000 shares changed hands, and in the latter over 48,000, so that nearly 60 per cent. of the day's business was done in those two specialties. In the remainder of the list St. Paul was the only stock which was fairly active.
"Municipal Reform" was the subject for discussion at the meeting of the Congregational Club at the St. Denis Hotel, Broadway and Eleventh Street, last night.

From the present outlook the annual road event, which Newark and Philadelphia wheelmen look forward to each year with unbeunded interest -- that Is the Newark-Philadelphia century run-will not take place this year, as practically nothing has been done about the matter so far, and in previous years by this time many of the details were well under way.

"Tommy" Burns, the old Chicago player, and one of the most popular managers in the country, pitted his team-the Spring-fields-against the Brooklyns at Eastern Park yesterday. The boys from Massachusetts showed the result of lack of practice in fielding and team work at times, but on several occasions they hit the ball in a most vigorous manner.
The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen took appropriate action yesterday on the death of Gen. Henry W. Slocum. President Jackson Wallace was in the chair. All the members were present.
Mayor Gilroy made the following reply yesterday to ex-Mayor Hewitt's letter on the Chamber of Commerce Rapid-Transit bill.

BOSTON, April 16. -- Assistant Secretary McAdoo visited the Charlestown Navy Yard to-day for the purpose of seeing what it contained in the shape of plant and in what condition the Government property might be. Upon his return he was questioned concerning the likelihood of opening the yard for naval construction.

The first performance of "Rush City," a three-act farcical comedy toy Gus Heege, was given last night in the new Bijou Theatre, in Brooklyn. William A. Mestayer was the chief actor in "Rush City," and under the impulse of his momentum the play rushed along, slap! bang! from start to finish.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 16. -- No trains are running on the Great Northern Railway between Crookston, Minn., and Seattle, Washington. The strikers gained a little ground this morning, suspending traffic between Fargo, N.D., and Crookston. All branches of the line are tied up, except the St. Paul, Breckinridge and Barnesville and the St. Cloud and Fergus Falls.

The first primary election under the Committee of Thirty, which was authorized by the Republican County Committee, to reorganize the Republican Party in this city, was held last night in all the election districts of the city in which it was practical.

A bunch of white double tulips stood in a dull-gold vase on a small table under the arch of the handsome parlors of Mrs. George H. Fox, 18 East Thirty-first Street, yesterday afternoon, and near it sat, in close ranks, women eager to hear again of he subject which is stirring society as it has not recently been stirred -- the political quality of the sexes.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 16. -- The railway Chiefs, by their attorneys, have formally appealed from Judge Jenkins's recent decision on the strike question. The matter will come up before the United States Court of Appeals at the term which opens in Chicago on May 1. That court, instead of deciding the case itself, will probably certify it to the Supreme Court, and it will be a year before the questions involved are finally settled.

LONDON, April 16. -- The budget was introduced in the House of Commons to-day by Sir William Harcourt, Chancellor of the Exchequer. Sir William stated that the fact that the total revenue for the last year was only u507,000 under the estimates, proved the solidity of the national finances, in view of the depression of trade.

NEBRASKA CITY, Neb., April 16. -- The ejectment case of Bishop Bonacum against Father M.J. Corbett was tried before Judge Eaton to-day. This is a case growing out of the now celebrated trouble between Father Corbett and his Bishop, wherein the latter seeks to eject his subordinate from the parsonage at Palmyra.

G. Van Iderstine, Chief Engineer or the Brazilian ship Nictheroy, gave to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday an interesting account of his experiences. Mr. Van Iderstine lives in Passaic, N.J. He was formerly Chief Engineer under Capt. Baker in the Brazilian Mail Service.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., April 16. -- The burial of David Dudley Field took place in the Stockbridge Cemetery this afternoon in the presence of many of his relatives and friends, including some of the older residents of Stockbridge, Lenox, and the surrounding towns.

Dr. David Crary, Sir., probably the oldest physician in connecticut, died fo old age yesterday in Hartford, Conn. He was born in Wellingford, Vt., April 18, 1806, and-he practiced medicine there and in Hartford for more than fifty years. He was present at the first administration of ether by Dr. Horace Wells, the discoverer of anaesthetics.
Barnum Bailey's Greatest Show on Earth will go into camp at the end of the week, leaving New-York for Brooklyn.

A wave of Grand-Napoleonism has been riding over France lately, but there is no sign yet that America takes any greater or any less interest in le Petit Caporal than before. Nevertheless, it seems that some French people imagine New-York a better, market for paintings, colored prints, lithographs, bronzes, porcelain, and knicknaeks connected with the First Empire and the Bonapartes than Paris.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- "Do I want to be President? Why, certainly, but I have not as yet become a candidate for the nomination," said Chauncey M. Depew, as he sauntered up and down the platform alongside his private car in the Lake Shore station this morning.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Assemblyman Sheffield's bill authorizing the procuring of new grounds and the erection thereon of buildings for the use of the College of the City of New-York. In his veto the Governor says:

The Rev. A. Lambert, who recently left the Church of Rome, delivered an address before the Congregational Clerical Union of New-York at the Bible House in Astor Place, yesterday morning, on the subject. "Why I Left the Church of Rome." He said, among other things:

There was a private view yesterday of the seventh annual exhibition of photpgraphs by the Society of American Photographers of New-York, the Photographic Society of Philadelphia, and the Boston Camera Club at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

BOSTON, April 16. -- A unique celebration of the new holiday (April 19) has been arranged by the towns of Medford, Arlington, and Lexington, in the shape of a reproduction of the ride of Paul Revere. It will take place on Wednesday night, and will adhere as closely to historical accuracy as shall be consistent with picturesque effect.

A rousing reception was given to Vesta Tilley, from, the London music halls, at Tony Pastor's last night. The house was jammed, and "society" was not without its representatives in the attentive and enthusiastic audience. The new "character" singer and "change" performer faced a heavy storm of applause when she first came into view, midway in the long programme.

The family of Jacob Sarasohn, who live in a tenement house at 138 Madison Street, were poisoned Friday night by eating aconite root for horse radish. Those affected, besides the head of the family, were his wife. Ida, forty-eight years old; three children, Annie, twenty years old; Harris, sixteen, and Sarah, fourteen, and a boarder named Abraham Cohen.

ROME, April 16. -- The Radicals in the Chamber of Deputies caused much, disorder this afternoon by demanding persistently a discussion of Baron Sonnino's financial proposals and their own policy of military retrenchment. Premier Crispi declared that the estimates must have precedence over all else and that the whole budget must be disposed of, as it was impossible to discuss intelligently any section of the financial proposals without regard for the rest.

Arthur Augustus Zimmerman, the peer of all bicycle riders, who Is to sail for France to-morrow to try conclusions with the best professional racers in the world, was entertained at dinner last evening by a coterie of friends and admirers, at the Hotel Bartholdi. The big smooth-faced champion never looked better in his life, and during the festivities he was as happy as a youngster who had just captured first prize in a novice race.

Senator William Lindsay of Kentucky was at the Marlborough Hotel yesterday afternoon. He discussed the future of the Tariff bill as he viewed the situation, and, while talking of the probable speechmaking which will occupy the time of the Senate, said something as to the new Chinese treaty which will be under consideration during the next few days.
Gen. Oliver Lathrop Shepherd, United States Army, (retired,) died at his home, 2,013 Lexington Avenue, yesterday. He was born in Clifton Park, Saratoga County, N. Y., on Aug. 15, 1815.
LONDON, April 16. -- The Bering Sea bill passed its committee stage in the House of Lords to-day, and it will be called up for its third reading to-morrow.

John C. Barkley, one of the most famous characters of Wall Street, died yesterday at his residence, 210 West Tenth Street, in the seventy-second year of his age. Mr. Barkley was known on Wall Street as the "gold truckman," and his honesty was as sterling as the yellow metal which he carted.

The orchestra of Niblo's Garden was crowded again yesterday at the noon concert given by the singers and musicians of the evangelistic campaign. The Rev. A.C. Dixon, after the concert, delivered a sermon on "How to Save Our Cities," and Ferdinand Schiverea conducted an after meeting.

'An important step toward the reorganization of the Atchison system of railroads has been taken by the formation of a committee which represents practically all of the important interests in that great property. This committee is one of the strongest combinations of financial interests ever formed to aid a railroad company.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Senator McMahon called the attention of the Senate to-day to the death of Gen. Henry W. Slocum. He briefly reviewed his career as a soldier, and paid a high tribute to his ability.

Two of the anti-Tammany organizations held meetings last night, one headed by ex-Sheriff James J. O'Brien, and named the Anti-Tammany Democracy, and the other headed by the Steckler-McCrea-Harvier combination. The O'Brien meeting at the Lyceum Opera House, in Thirty-fourth Street, was made up from O'Brien's followers from the Twelfth, Sixteenth, and Fourteenth Assembly Districts.
WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The following announcement, argument, and decisions were made in the United States Supreme Court to-day:

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., April 16. -- William Wright and Furman Velsor, two well-known residents of this place, were speeding their trotters on the Oyster Bay Turnpike Saturday evening. As they tried to pass, their vehicles became locked together.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 16. -- The Government is advised that Admiral Mello did not surrender himself to the Uruguayan authorities, but remained on board the Republica. It is said that it was his intention to surrender and that he offered to do so on condition that the authorities would not turn him over to the Brazilian Government.

CONEY ISLAND, April 16. -- "The name of Coney Island shall no longer stand as a synonym for all that ia immoral and vicious, but for a real pleasure resort, where men and women may go without risking their reputations and their valuables."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 16. -- The disclosures concerning the typhoid fever epidemic here, published this morning in The New-York Times, have caused widespread discussion, particularly among medical men and officials.

COBURG, April 16. -- A furious fire started here this morning in a building facing the royal palace. The flames were finally subdued, but not until the burning building had been nearly destroyed. The Duke of Saxe-Coburg (Duke of Edinburgh) gave active assistance to the firemen in putting out the blaze.
Mr. F. Zittel has sold for Alfred G. Mason, to a. Mr. Raynor, the four-Story twenty-two-Soot-front dwelling 47 West Seventy-sixth Street, for $50,000.

The "gentlemanly burglar," he of the "arched eyebrows" and "soothing, mesmeric voice," a six-footer, who terrorized Stockbridge, Mass., in the Autumn of 1892 and last Summer, may be Michael Sherlock who is in the custody of Inspector McLaughlin at Police Headquarters.

Members of the Gentlemen's Driving Club be Buffalo have decided to hold matinee races at the track in that city every pleasant Saturday afternoon during the driving season. These races, in which amateur drivers will handle the horses owned by themselves or their friends, have the savor of true sport about them, for there is rarely any hippodroming business.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Health Commissioner Emery of Brooklyn is determined to put a stop to the use of soft coal in Brooklyn factories. Yesterterday he instructed his inspectors to canvass the city and report the factories and their location where soft coal is used.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- In the presence of his former associates in the Senate, members of the House, the President and his Cabinet, the members of the Supreme Court, representatives, of foreign nations, and hundreds of friends and admirers, the body of Senator Vance of North Carolina lay in the Senate Chamber this afternoon while the brief funeral ceremony was being performed.

It is amusing to observe the wide divergencies of opinion between Col. George Bliss and John E. Milholland, Esq., on the question of the most suitable, moral, and efficacious way of reorganizing the Republican Party in this city. The question whether the party shall be reorganized by Assembly districts or by election districts seems to the outsider to be only a detail, which might be discussed between statesmen without exciting temper.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- After a discussion which brought out the fact that the opponents of the Tariff bill were very well satisfied with the present rule, under which, according to Mr. Harris, a Senator may discuss any subject under the sun until doomsday if he so elects, an agreement was reached to-day that general debate on the Tariff bill shall close next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The weekly crop reports of the Weather Bureau, suspended during the Winter months, have been resumed. The report for the week ending April 17 is in part as follows:

The most obvious, pressing, and constant need of business in any country is reasonable certainty as to the laws affecting it. This need has not been satisfied in the United States for any considerable period for the last third of a century, and the great progress the country has made has been in spite of that fact.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- The market opened rather weak, and lacked strength almost through the entire day, rallying a little before the close. Reading was hammered by the traders on the rumor that Little's report had been held back, and that the general mortgage bondholders had taken a position which would compel an assessment on the common stock and the preference bonds.

A story has been circulated to the effect that there is a deal between Richard Croker and Thomas C. Platt to have the Bi-Partisan Police bill, now pending in the Legislature, so amended that the Police Board could remove the Superintendent at will, the object in view being the ousting of Superintendent Byrnes.

But a short time ago some eminent scientists made a great discovery. They discovered that fats and oils didn't fatten thin people. Everything seems simple after some one else has found it out. If we had thought, we would have remembered that for ages doctors have forbidden STARCH foods to people who wanted to get thin. It follows they ought to recommend STARCH foods to people who want to get fat.

LONDON, April 17. -- The newspaper comments on the budget take a wide range. Everybody expects a long and bitter discussion of its details, and it is possible that the Government may be defeated on the measure, though this is not the general belief. The Parnellite members will surely oppose the increase of the tax on spirits.

An order was signed by Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court yesterday denying a motion for an injunction to restrain the Chicago and Great Western Railroad Company from holding possession of or operating the property of the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Railway Company under a lease executed several years ago.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, April 17 -- P.M. The bears apparently tested the market in the early trading, and, finding that some long stock came out, increased materially the short account. There was liquidation in Sugar and St. Paul, and the general list lacked firmness. The news of the day favored the bear side, although nothing really bad was developed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 17. -- At the headquarters of the United Mine Workers of America, in this city, preparations for the strike, of next Saturday are being completed rapidly. By reports from the fifty organizers in the field, President John McBride estimates that there will be 200,000 men go out next Saturday.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Owing to the failure of a number of Republicans to vote, the bill of Senator Bradley, (Ind. Dem., Kings,) to legislate the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees out of office failed to get the necessary number of votes when it came up on final passage in the Assembly this morning, and it was declared lost.

The Rev. Undsay Parker, rector of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, and a member of the Atlantic Yacht Club, has had a small sloop yacht built, which he intends to cruise in this Summer. The boat was designed by Mr. Henry J. Glelow, and has been built by J.T. Logan of New-Brunswick.

John Koetpnickger, thirty-four years old, of 42 Scholes Street, Willlamsburg, attempted suicide yesterday morning by cutting his head with an axe. He only succeeded in inflicting a scalp wound. He was taken to St. Catherine's Hospital.

This afternoon at 2:30 o'clock begins the sale, at the American Art Galleries, of the Chinese porcelains collected by E.O. Arbuthnot, a well-known dealer and connoisseur of Shanghai, who has sent many an invoices of porcelain to New-York. The collection embraces a few decorated pieces belonging to the estate of T.E. Davies of Hongkong, and some that have figured in recent sales here.

Now that open antagonism has been declared between the advocates of rapid-transit measures before the Legislature, the Chamber of Commerce committee intends that its opponents shall come out from under cover. Suspicion is already at work. The one thing of which the committee feels sure is that it will not have to waste powder firing at Charles B. Stover, the ostensible advocate of the Lexow-Butts bill.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 17. -- The Assembly Judiciary Committee room was crowded when the hearing on the resolution to investigate the vote of Adolph Schillinger on the reconsideration of the vote on the Factory Inspectors bill was opened this afternoon. Chairman Thornton presided. Mr. Ainsworth examined for the Republican side, which contends that Mr. Schillinger did not vote, while Mr. Sulzer asked questions for the Democratic side.

TAMPA, Fla., April 17. -- The United States Government has begun war in earnest on the Honduras Lottery Company, the old Louisiana company. Since the establishment of the Graham printery at Port Tampa City and the putting on of a Steamer between this port and Honduras the lottery company has kept aboard of its vesesl a lot of printing presses and material.

BOSTON, April 17. -- The market for local sticks was dull, and inclined to heaviness, West End Street Railway being the point of particular depression. It declined from 49 to 46 1/2, Where it closed. The Aldermanic order of yesterday requiring feed wires to toe buried was used, as a club by the bears, and it took but little selling to knock the stock off 2 1/2 points.

We give this morning the speech of Senator Smith of New-Jersey, delivered yesterday in the Senate. As we have from time to time severely and sincerely condemned the course of the little group of Senators with whom Mr. Smith has been, in the public opinion, associated, it is only fair that he should be allowed to speak for himself in our columns.

In the easiest possible manner the Brooklyns won from the Interscholastic League team at Eastern Park yesterday. It was a contest in which the Brooklyns had an opportunity to practice base running tactics.

ALBANY, April 17. -- In the Assembly today Mr. Sheffield stood up, grasping with both hands a bound book containing a petition signed by New-Yorkers, which prayed for the passage of the Chamber of Commerce Rapid-Transit bill. Mr. Sheffield asked to be allowed to present the petition. Messrs. Sulzer and Roche objected.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 17. -- William A. Sutherland returned to his home in this city to-day. Mr. Sutherland made the following statement of the trouble which has resulted in the open breach between himself and Lawyer Goff:

The New-Yorks had an easy victory over the Springfield team yesterday. Manager Burns's boys failed to do batting of any account, while the Giants hit fairly well. Van Haltren, Ward, and Nadeau made some pretty catches.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., April 17. -- Miss Caroline Ruth Colden Tracy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Colden Tracy of this place, was married this evening to Frederick William Corse of Philadelphia, in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church. The bride is a descendant on her father's side of an old New-York family, while her mother is a descendant of the Brisbane and Lowndes families of South Carolina.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 17. -- The regular Spring meeting of the Presbytery of Westchester, which embraces the Counties of Westchester, Putnam, and the State of Connecticut, began this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church here, and is attended by about fifty pastors and Elders. The Rev. Alexander Miller of Mahopac Falls, the retiring Moderator, delivered the sermon.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 17. -- Clifford, Leigh Rose's Brooklyn Handicap candidate, ran his first race this season here today, winning the sixth race in an absolute canter from Jim Lee. He simply had to gallop, and then he covered the mile in 1:44 3/4. There were seven events on the card, they being captured by two favorites and five second choices:
Honey on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

A large number of men and women in society gathered in the parlors of Dr. and Mrs. Egbert Guernsey, 528 Fifth Avenue, last evening and listened with great interest to a political-equality discussion. All the speakers were in favor of the equal-suffrage movement, which has not been the case at a majority of the parlor meetings.

The Women's Guild of the New-York Homeopathic Medical College and Hospital held its annual donation at Flower Hospital, East Sixty-third Street and Avenue A, yesterday afternoon. It was a very pleasant event socially. Mrs. William Tod Helmuth, President of Sorosis, who is also President of the Women's Guild, welcomed the guests.
Three additional Jurors were obtained in the Court of General Sessions for the trial of Dr. Henry C.P. Meyer, who is accused of poisoning Ludwig Brandt. Half the jury is now complete.

The fourteenth performance of "Carmen" for the current musical season toot place at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It was the second night of the supplementary season, and the audience while not as large as that of the previous evening, nor as large as those which attended the earlier performance of the same work, was, nevertheless, one of considerable size and great warmth of feeling.

The coming season promises to be one of the most interesting and important that has ever happened among cricketers of this country. The local schedules have been enlarged beyond all former years, and the rivalry between the prominent organizations of Philadelphia has resulted in the arrangement of international matches, which will throw completely into the shade the former visits of teams like Lord Hawke's eleven and the famous Australians.

Tattersalls' Repository, on Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, was crowded last night, when W.D. Grand began selling the Kentucky saddle horses consigned by C.L. Railey of Springhurst, Ky. The lot was an unusually small one, only nineteen head, but every horse was of high class, perfectly broken to all gaits, and good in harness.

The body of Major Gen. Henry Warner Slocum was yesterday laid at rest in Greenwood Cemetery. The funeral ceremonies were worthy of his high reputation, his sterling qualities, and his illustrious career. All Brooklyn united to honor his memory. Thousands of visitors from other places joined in the throng which spoke his praises and viewed the pageant in his honor.

RAHWAY, N.J., April 17. -- The Union County Roadsters proved to their friends to-night that whatever they undertake proves successful, both financially and socially. To-night a marked departure was made by the club, when they gave a musicale at the clubhouse, on Main Street. The spacious smoking room was transformed into a miniature theatre, with raised stage.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., April 17. -- Experiments were made at the point here this afternoon to prove that, with proper fulminate, the primers, or detonating fuses of the pneumatic dynamite gun cannot fail of igniting the charge in the shells.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 17. -- Naval Cadet William Pitt Scott of Pennsylvania has won the gold medal for the best marksmanship in rapid-fire, great-gun practice. The guns were fired at a regulation target in the Chesapeake Bay from the steamer Standish while the ship was under steam crossing the base of a triangle whose sides were 1,000 yards from the target.

Dr. Edmund H. Walsh, pastor of the Reformed Catholic Church, Cumberland Street and Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, who has been attracting much attention during the past twelve years, came into police court prominence yesterday. Together with Emil L. Perhacs, the assistant pastor of the Reformed Church, Dr. Walsh was arrested Monday night, charged with petty larceny.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Counsel for Congressman W.C.P. Breckinridge to-day filed a motion, for a new trial of Madeline Pollard's suit against their client. The reasons given in the motion, are as follows:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 17. -- There were two more deaths here from typhoid fever last night, and to-day Mrs. A.H. Siegfried, wife of the advertising manager of The Ladies' Home Journal, died of intermittent fever. There are in the town several cases of diphtheria and scarlet fever, and a few new cases of typhoid, which developed this week.

ALBANY, April 17. -- At 11 o'clock Senator Lexow's resolution extending the time of the Police Investigating Committee was taken up. The vote by which the resolution was lost last week was reconsidered, and the amendment offered by Mr. Stapleton authorizing the Elections Investigating Committee to investigate Buffalo and the departments in New-York City other than the Police Department was stricken out.
"The average man is mentally lazy. Deep down in his heart he does not want us to be learned, for then he cannot make us believe that black is white when our knowledge tells us it is black."

The passage by the State Senate on Monday of the bill affecting the condemnation proceedings of the Manhattan Railway Company has given great encouragement to the friends of that measure in this city. The bill was drawn by Evarts, Choate Beaman, and is intended to prevent the elevated roads from abandoning their condemnation proceedings, except by permission of the courts.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 17. -- Ex-Attorney General Miller's law office in this city, over which appears the sign "Miller, Winter Elam, Attorneys," was the scene at noon to-day of a shooting affray in which Addison C. Harris, a prominent lawyer of this city, and William H. Bruning of New-York were wounded, while Mr. Miller miraculously escaped.

In the Board of Aldermen yesterday Mr. Flynn asked permission to call up ten general orders authorizing the paving of streets in different parts of the city. Vice President Noonan had also a number of resolutions to the same effect. It was decided to pass all the resolutions in regular order.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 17. -- A reception was given here to-night to the Confederate Veterans of New-York by the Veteran Zouaves of this city. Fully 5,000 persons greeted the visitors at the Broad Street Station, and the march from the station to the armory was a continuous ovation.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- To the great delight of Mr. Reed and the Republican side of the House, the Democrats to-day carried through, with Republican help, a rule for the counting of members present and not voting to make a quorum.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Mr. Thomas C. Platt's followers in the Assembly, headed by Speaker Malby and Leader Ainsworth, went into caucus this evening, and were routed, horse, foot, and dragoon, by the independent Republicans, under the lead of Hamilton Fish of Putnam, James M.E. O'Grady of Rochester, S. Fred Nixon, and the Belden men from Central New-York.

Major Clifton Comly was stricken with paralysis at the Sandy Hook Proving Station yesterday afternoon. He was taken to his quarters on Governors Island, where he lies in a precarious condition. The attack was so severe as to make it improbable that the Major will recover.

It is amusing to remark that there are wide and apparently irreconcilable differences among the Wagnerians upon the subject of interpreting Wagner. Mr. Walter Damrosch, who is to be classed, if at all, as a Wagnerian, seems to be upon one side of the controversy, and all the other Wagnerians upon the other.

LONDON, April 17. -- An odd action is being tried in the courts here against the Earl of Abingdon at the instance of Scott Hall. Some time ago Mr. Hall entered into a contract with the Earl's agent for the purchase of the Cumner Place, the agent, Mr. Hall claims, representing it to be the house in which Amy Robsart died.

ROME, April 17. -- Immediately after the reading of the minutes of yesterday's proceedings in the Chamber of Deputies today, Signor Imbriani, Radical, rose and protested against the manner in which Premier Crispi "had menaced the people's representatives" in his speech on Monday.

S.H.H. Clark, President and co-receiver, John M. Thurston, and E.L.
