Lomax, General Passenger Agent of the Union Pacific Railroad, are all in this city, Mr. Clark and Mr. Lomax were asked yesterday for information concerning the alleged cutting of rates by the Union Pacific on immigrant passenger traffic from New-York to the Pacific slope.

Henry S. Ives's career as a financier was rapid, brief, and bewildering in its reckless daring. Rising suddenly from obscurity to the ranks of the millionaires, he for a short time posed as one of Wall Street's noted men. His audacity and nerve, aided by the temporary success of some of his railroad schemes, invested him for a while with a degree of importance that completely overshadowed the ordinary conservative capitalist of that day.

Niblo's Garden was well filled again yesterday noon with an audience of earnest worshippers at the evangelistic revival meeting. The Rev. Dr. John Hall, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, was the speaker.
Mayor Gilroy sent the following letter to Senator Jacob A. Cantor yesterday:...

RALEIGH, N. C., April 17. -- The special funeral train bearing the remains of the late Senator Zebulon B. Vance arrived here at 9:30 o'clock this morning. Thousands of the Senator's old comrades and followers were at the station to receive the body.

John McEntegart, formerly Superintendent of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of this city, and now with the Prudential Life Insurance Company, attempted to murder his wife, Rose, at her home, 414 Fifth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

Dr. E. Cornell Esten, Philadelphia, Penn., says: "I have met with the greatest and most satisfactory results in dyspepsia and general derangement of the cerebral and nervous systems causing debility and exhaustion."

ALBANY, April 17. -- When the Senate Judiciary Committee met to-day to continue its investigation of the memorial of the Civil Service Reform Association as to alleged violations of the civil service laws by the Governor, the following letter was read by the Chairman:

There is a small-sized war in progress between the members of M. Mounet-Sully's company, which is playing at Abbey's Theatre, and the stage hands. It was begun during the performance of "Hamlet" Monday night. Two members of the company, during the last act, became involved in a quarrel With Stage Carpenter James Derby Derby struck M. Louis Maffeo, one of the leading men, in the eye.
Rapid transit is just now in a condition that might move a cynic to mirth and a good citizen to indignation or despair, according to his temperament.

PATERSON, N.J., April 18. -- While the police to-night were escorting a number of non-union workmen home from the Vermorel Dye Works, they were attacked by a crowd of strikers. The officers turned on the riotous strikers, heat them back with their clubs, and arrested John Pazzettl and Joseph Matti, the leaders of the mob.

ALBANY, April 18. -- Following the action of the caucus of the Republican members of Assembly last night, the House this morning passed the Lexow (Rep., Rockland.) Bi-Partisan Police Commission bill for the City of New-York, with the amendments which were printed in to-day's New-York Times.

The Railroad Committee of the Board or Aldermen gave a public hearing yesterday afternoon on the application of the Third Avenue Railroad Company for permission to extend its tracks from One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and St. Nicholas Avenue north to the city line, and from the same point south to One Hundred and Sixteenth Street.

A gentleman for many years a resident of Guatemala City, and familiar with Central American affairs, said yesterday that Central America as a whole -- five republics -- never had been more prosperous. Crops are excellent and prices for coffee are high.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Sefior Manuel M. Peralta, the Minister from Costa Rica in Washington, denies, in a note to the United Press, the statement in a cable dispatch from Carlsruhe that a student there named Rodriguez, who mortally wounded a fellow-student Monday, is the son of President Rodriguez of Costa Rica.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- The movement in west Chicago Street Railway stock this morning showed that it possessed considerable firmness. The stock opened a little lower, at 154, and the bears started in to hammer it. Their success was not great, for after selling 1,000 shares the market had declined only to 153 3/8.
Money on call loaned at 1 per pent. yesterday.

President Bartow S. Weeks of the New-York Athletic Club is authority for the statement that his club is contemplating taking a decisive stand against Class B cyclists. The club, he says, will not promote any competitions among such semiamateurs, and as a matter of fact, does not want any of them among the riders of the Mercury-foot organization.

At the continuation, of the hearing before United States Commissioner Shields in the suit between the New-York Associated Press and the Western Associated Press, yesterday, most of the time was occupied in putting in evidence statements made from the original books of the Western Associated Press by Henry W. Odion, in substantiation of statements previously made by him in the course of the trial, from copies of the original books.

In reporting the tests of the eight-inch pneumatic gun at Sandy Hook on Tuesday, the statement was made that experiments with the projectiles on the Nictheroy at Port Royal found the primer faulty because of deteriorated commercial fulminate. This would be correct if for Nictheroy Vesuvius were substituted and the date or the tests given as eighteen months ago.
Here are a few don'ts to be regarded in City Hall etiquette the next few days:

BANGOR, Me., April 18. -- Fire started in the Merchants' Hotel at 1:30 o'clock this morning. The flames went up through the four stories to the roof very quickly. The guests were panicstricken and many jumped from the windows. Seven were Injured.

Mr. George J. Gould has purchased the Vigilant. The gentlemen, who had the yacht built last season to defend the America's Cup against the Valkyrie met yesterday afternoon and decided to accept the terms offered by Mr. Gould. Mr. Gould is to pay $25,000 for the boat. This will be a big surprise to yachtsmen, as Mr. Gould's name was never thought of in connection with the famous cup defender.

American Railway securities were weak in the London market. The principal changes were: Declined -- St. Paul, 1 1/8, to 63 1/2; Louisville and Nashville, 5/8, to 51 1/2; Union Pacific, 5/8, to 20; Illinois Central, 1/2, to, 95 1/2; Canadian Pacific, 3/8, to 70 3/8; Atchison, 1/4, to 15 1/4; Northern Pacific preferred, 1/4, to 20 1/4; Ontario, and Western, 1/8, to 16 3/4, and Kansas and Texas, 1/8, to 16 1/4.

The terrible misery and degradation and crime that must come-upon any community in which political bosses and bossism hold sway was pictured in graphic manner last evening by Seymour Van Santvoord of Troy. Mr. Van Santvoord is a pale-faced young man, with, a dense, coal-black mustache and black eyes, deep set, that shine, when he speaks, with a brilliancy that is almost overwhelming.

The eighth annual all-around gymnastic and athletic contests by members of the Young Men's Institute Gymnasium were held at 222 Bowery on Tuesday evening. The lecture hall, in which these contests are given, was crowded to the doors.

In a suit on trial before Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, George P. Wiechers of Puerto Rico is attempting to hold the Central Trust Company responsible for eighteen certificates of Sugar Trust stock, worth about $225,000. Mr. Wiechers's son, John F. Wiechers, was a member of the firm of Field, Lindley, Wiechers Co.

ORANGE, N.J., April 18. -- About 100 delegates from all parts of the country were present at to-day's session of the twentysixth annual meeting of the Congregational Association held in Trinity Congregational Church, Bast Orange. In the morning the Rev. J.B. Clark spoke on "What Israel Ought to Do." Mrs. H.S. Caswell gave "Fresh Observations and Experiences in the Field."

LONDON, April 18. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. John P. Nolan, member for North Galway, moved the second reading of the bill to repeal the Coercion act, passed at the instance of Mr. Balfour in 1887. The motion was seconded by Mr. William Redmond, member for East Clare.

The women in charge of the political equality petition book at Sherry's are delighted with the increased interest and enthusiasm manifested in their work. A number of new signatures were added yesterday, and several visitors secured petitions for circulation.

Murder followed a robbery in Henry Heide's candy factory, 179 Franklin Street and 14 Harrison Street, Tuesday night. The victim was August Loeffler, the watchman. He was sixty-three years old, a widower, and lived, with his five children, at 251 Water Street.

The Treasury Department has not only ordered that any printing material and machinery brought by the lottery company from Honduras to Port Tampa, Fla., shall be landed and subjected to the payment of duty, but it has ruled that the company must pay duty upon the face value of all tickets that are brought into the country.

The Hon. Don Cameron did his best in the Senate yesterday to promote the passage of a tariff reform bill by a speech in opposition. He declared that he desired to retain the McKinley tariff, but that he wanted to do more than this. The tariff alone was not sufficient to make a strong national policy.

Capt. Ward and his band of pennant seekers left for Baltimore on the 2 o'clock train yesterday afternoon to open the season there to-day. According to a Baltimore dispatch this will be regarded as a gala day in the home of the Orioles. The players of both teams will parade from the Eutaw House at noon and traverse the principal streets of the city.

Five thousand dollars was the value William Wahl put on a fine pair, of bronze-colored Dundreary whiskers which he possessed prior to Aug. 8, 1892. That is as much as a railroad company can be made to pay the heirs of a man killed in an accident. This does not prove human life cheap, but only that William Wahl's whiskers were of superlative excellence.

ALBANY, April 18. -- Unless Speaker Malby and Lieut. Gov. Sheehan crush the lobby and drive its representatives from the floor, the Chamber of Commerce Rapid-Transit bill will be beaten before the Legislature reads it. A more brazen and audacious exhibition on the part of the lobby has not been seen within the past decade.

The account of the pneumatic dynamite gun tests at Sandy Hook on Tuesday, published exclusively in The New-York Times yesterday, excited a great deal of discussion. Any lingering doubts as to the efficiency of these great engines of war, if they have proper detonating fuses, have been dispelled by the tests, as described in The New-York Times.

From The Utica Observer, (Dem.) Let the veterans read the exposure of The New-York Times of the pensioners in Northern New-York. Does any one believe that St. Lawrence County could be so covered with pensioners of doubtful legality or plain illegality without the Industrious co-operation of the pension agents?
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 18. -- Brooklyn easily defeated the Springfield team here to-day with a score of 18 to 6.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Although it has been believed generally by those who nave been watching the tariff situation that the Louisiana Senators would make no objections to the Tariff bill in its present shape, there has been a rumor afloat that both Senators Caffery and Blanchard have been much dissatisfied and likely to join the opposition.

Within a semicircle of calla lilies and palms in Grace Church, Miss Edith Kip, only daughter of Col. and Mrs. Lawrence Kip, was married to Richard McCreery yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock. Society people from Boston, Philadelphia, Washington, Baltimore, and even from Paris and London filled the church to its utmost capacity.

"All ashore's goin' ashore!" shouted the big Quartermaster of the New-York yesterday afternoon, a cabin boy beat a tattoo on a gong, and the fog whistle of the ocean greyhound broke, forth in an ear-splitting screech. The deck of the big steamer was crowded with friends of the passengers, but more than half were on hand to wish Champion Cyclist Zimmerman bon voyage and success in his new venture.

COBURG, April 18. -- The ex-Empress Frederick, Prince Henry and his wife, Princess Irene of Prussia, and Duke George of Saxe-Meiningen and several members of his family arrived here this afternoon. They were met at the railway station by the Duke and Duchess of Saxe-Coburg. The royal visitors were heartily cheered by the crowds at the station and en route to the ducal palace.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Commodore Skerrett, whose nomination to be Rear Admiral was sent by the President to the Senate to-day, has had an interesting and eventful career. He came of Philadelphia stock, although the family had removed to Ohio and was living at Chillicothe when he was born.
The meetings of the evangelistic revival were unusually well attended yesterday, fully 1,400 persons gathering at Niblo's Garden and 1,000 more at Masonic Temple in the afternoon.

ORANGE, N.J., April 18. -- There is a slight unpleasantness in the congregation of the Dutch Reformed Church of East Orange, and already a number of its young and most active workers have withdrawn, among them John Leonard Merrill, Jr., and several members of the East Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

The movement which, has been, on fool among a number at prominent clergymen to form a free employment society resulted in a meeting at the Waldorf last evening, which was well attended. After some discussion for and against the founding of a society, it was resolved to organize one under the name of the Mutual Employment Society of New-York.

Samuel L. Clemens ("Mark Twain") and Frederick J. Hall, composing the book publishing firm of Charles L. Webster Co. of 67 Fifth Avenue, filed an assignment without preference, to Bainbridge Colby of 40 Wall Street, in the County Clerk's office late yesterday afternoon. The deed was signed by Mr. Clemens in this city, and stated that his residence is in Hartford, Conn., and Mr. Hall's at Far Rockaway, L.I.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 18. -- A meeting of the officers of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company was held in this city to-day. The Boston contingent, consisting of Vice President Kendrick, Counsel Benton, and about 100 others, arrived at 1:10. There were altogether about 200 subordinate officials present President Charles P. Clark addressed them as follows:

DETROIT, Mich., April 18. -- In a fight which took place about noon to-day in Grosse Point Township, just over the easterly county line, between a force of Polish laborers seeking employment on city waterworks extension, Sheriff Collins was probably fatally Injured, two Polish rioters were shot dead, and half a dozen more were seriously injured, at least three fatally.

LONDON, April 18. -- The City and Suburban Handicap, of 20 sovereigns each, with 1,000 sovereigns added, for three-year-olds and upward, was run at Epsom to-day, and was won by the Duke of Westminster's Grey Leg, (three years.) Mr. D. Hollis's Xury (three years) was second and Baron de Rothschild's Le Nicham (four years) third.

The Spanish Consul has begun a search for E.L. del Castillo, whose shipment of arms and ammunition to Cuba was seized at the port of landing. Judge Shipman's decision on Tuesday in the case of the South Portland having established for the time that a vessel is entitled to carry arms as merchandise without violation of the neutrality laws, the Consul will press no charge except that of perjury against the consignor.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 18. -- A crisis has come in the Great Northern strike.

The procession of elegantly-appointed and well-horsed eauipages on the Central Park roads during the afternoon from 4 to 6 o'clock has been on the increase since Saturday, and the crowd that passed through the gates yesterday afternoon was larger than on any preceding week day so far this Spring.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 18. -- About 4,000 people to-day saw the Peabody Handicap, the star feature of the events, won by Vassal, Ed Corrigan's three-year-old crack, who ran third in the Tennessee Derby. Strathmeath was the favorite, and was heavily played by the talent. Linda cut out the running, attended by Oliver, until the stretch was reached, when Vassal and Strathmeath came out, and, leaving the others, made a magnificent fight down the stretch.

There is a bitter war on between the Board of Education and the Trustees of the Twelfth Ward. It is all the result of the Ahearn act. Both sides claim that they are right, and are disposed to fight the matter to the bitter end.

The will of David Dudley Field was filed yesterday in the Surrogate's office. Most of the estate is left to Lady Jennie Lucinda Musgrave, Mr. Field's only surviving child, and he children. No inventory was filed, but the estate is believed to amount to about $500,000.

At the annual meeting of the Associated Press of the State of New-York, which was held at the Holland House yesterday, important action was taken toward cementing the relations of this important news association with the United Press. The Western Associated Press has made repeated endeavors to win this association away from the United Press, but without success, and, falling to do that, it devoted its energies to disintegrating it.
ALBANY, April 18. -- Gov. Flower announced the following order to-day appointing Commissioners to take testimony in the charges made against the Board of Managers of the Elmira Reformatory:

The Riverside Wheelmen have determined to make this year the most important one in their history, and are doing everything they possibly can to increase their membership and to get more good riders in their ranks. The constitution of the club has been amended now so that there are four classes of membership.

George E. Wellington of Troy, N.Y., a member of the Committee of Safety in that city, addressed the members of Good Government Club E, 338 East Twenty-third Street, last evening on the recent election frauds in Troy and the murder of Robert Ross. He said the Committee of Safety is determined to purify the ballot in that city, even at the risk of valuable lives.

The strike on the Great Northern Railroad, the threatened strike on the Northern Pacific, and various judicial decisions lately rendered affecting the relations of railroad workmen to the employing corporations, suggest that there is here a problem demanding solution by some authority higher than the corporations or the labor organizations.
Mrs. Mary E. Mumford of Philadelphia lectured yesterday afternoon before the Woman's Health Protective Association of Brooklyn on "The Relation of Woman to Municipal Affairs."

Four of the Brooklyn Handicap candidates, Carlsbad, Clifford, Eloroy, and Maid Marian, have won races in the West since the opening of the season at Memphis, the latter having: also been beaten in two races. The operations or these candidates have been watched with much interest, but the contests have been of a character that did not amount to much.

HANCOCK, Md., April 18. -- There was a lively time after the Commonweal Army reached Hancock. It was said that Pizarro Smith and Childs, formerly the advance agents of the Commonweal, had reached Hancock together yesterday, and representing themselves as authorized agents had raised a considerable sum of money and had left for Williamsport, the next town on the route.

The class of '94 of the University of the City of New-York celebrated Founders' Day yesterday. The exercises were begun in the old building in Washington Square, which is soon to be torn down, and were ended at University Heights, near Fordham Station, where the University's new building will be opened in the Fall.

Retired Admiral A.E.K. Benham, who issued the famous order in Rio Harbor for the protection of American shipping, returned to this, city on the Red D steamship Philadelphia, from Curacao yesterday. He was accompanied by Flag Lieut. William Kilburn and Secretary William K. Faust.

Major Clifton Comly, U.S.A. The attack of paralysis with which Major Clifton Comly, President of the Ordnance Department of the Department of the East, was seized while recording the tests of the Crozier-Buffington disappearing gun carriage at the Sandy Hook Proving Station on Tuesday resulted fatally.

No progress was made yesterday in the trial of Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer, accused of poisoning Ludwig Brandt. Recorder Smyth, had ordered a new panel of 100 talesmen to be called. Of these, 65 were examined, but no one was found to take the seventh seat in the jury box. The examination of talesmen will be resumed this morning.

The real sentiment of the Democratic Party on the tariff question is finding expression, and the expression is having its effect. The first manifestation that forced itself upon the unwilling ears of the "conservative" Senators at Washington was from Minnesota. This was peculiarly effective because it took the form of a resolution naming the Senators who, by common report or by their own utterances, were believed to be "obstructionists."

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Senate Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads has now under consideration fifteen additional nominations of New-York State Postmasters which the President sent to-day to the Senate.

The Fourth Presbyterian Church property on the south side or Thirty-fourth Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, has been disposed of to a syndicate, of which Neil Burgess, the actor, is a member. The property has 75 feet frontage. It is not yet determined to what use It will be put.

BOSTON, April 18. -- Massachusetts is to celebrate her new holiday with great zest to-morrow. As yet it is a holiday without name. The 19th of April is a day thrice memorable in Massachusetts history -- in the contest of the colony against the Crown, in the struggle for independence, and in the war for the Union.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- The market was somewhat less active to-day than yesterday, especially in the number of bonds sold. During February and March there was a constant and large demand for all first-class bond issues. The investors seem to have been pretty well filled up, and now the demand is very light.

Fire Commissioner Wurster of the Brooklyn, department is desirous of showing his appreciation when commendable work is performed by the members of the Fire Department. Yesterday he issued the following circular:

The stock market yesterday was dull and thoroughly professional. The principal trading was in Chicago Gas, St. Paul, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, General Electric, and Sugar, and at the close of business Chicago Gas, St Paul, and Sugar were unchanged. Whisky was up 1/4, and General Electric was 3/4 lower.

We have recently compared the duties imposed by the McKinley tariff upon refined sugar, white lead, and linseed oil with those imposed by the Wilson, bill -- as passed by the House and as reported by the Senate committee -- upon the same products, having in mind the absurd assertion of The New-York Tribune that the Wilson bill is "pre-eminently a Trust bill" and the similar assertions of other Republican journals.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 19. -- After thrashing all the local teams, around home for the last few weeks in a manner that caused the critics in New-York to believe that they had a club well nigh invincible, Capt. Ward and his New-York baseball team opened the season here to-day and suffered defeat in a fashion that caused the enthusiasts who journeyed from the metropolis to look on with surprise.

The reported decision of the Grand Army authorities of this State to reinstate Farnham Post is an excellent sign. It will be remembered that the post was expelled last year because, without submitting it to the National Council and contrary to the rules of the Grand Army, it published and sent to other posts a protest against the existing evils of the pension system.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Brazilian Minister, Senhor Mendonga, this afternoon, received a cablegram dated at Rio de Janeiro, April 19, officially announcing the rebellion ended. The dispatch is as follows: To the Brazilian Minister, Mendonca, Washington:

ALBANY, April 19. -- Senator Hill arrived in town this afternoon, and at once repaired to his residence. Here in the course of a few hours he was waited upon by Francis B. Delehanty, Judge Andrew Hamilton, and the half dozen other young, energetic Democrats who made a coalition with Republicans to destroy the regular Democratic organization at the municipal election held a few weeks ago.

TRENTON, N.J., April 19. -- The bill to make college hazing a crime, and punishable as such, caused a lively debate in the House of Assembly this morning. The bill was defeated some weeks ago, but was revived to-day by Mr. Carroll of Hudson, who had a motion adopted to reconsider the vote by which the measure was lost.

Justice Truax in the Supreme Court, directed a verdict yesterday for $167,625 in favor of George F. Wiechers of Puerto Rico against the Central Trust Company of this city. The suit was to recover the value of Sugar Trust stock deposited with the trust company at the time of the Sugar Trust reorganization.

RALEIGH, N. C., April 19. -- Gov. Carr this afternoon offered the appointment of United States Senator, to succeed Senator Vance, to ex-Gov. Thomas H. Jarvis. Mr. Jarvis at once wrote Gov. Carr a letter of acceptance.

The Young Men's Christian Association of Orange held its anual gymnasium exhibition last night. There was a large audience present. "Gus" Ahl of Newark, the amateur champion on the parallel bars; J.H. Dougherty, the ex-amateur champion club swinger; E.B. De Groot, gymnastic instructor of the Mont-clair Military Academy, and Charles F. Werner were tie special attractions.

-- The ship Coringa of Windsor, N.S., made this port Wednesday evening in a badly-battered condition. She left Dunkirk sixty-five days ago, bound for St. John, N.B. April 12, when off Mount Desert, she was struck by a blizzard from the northeast. It lashed her till the 16th. The storm was so severe that the ship was unable to proceed.

One of the placards that ornament the woman suffrage booth at Sherry's, where signatures to be sent to the Constitutional Convention are received reads. "Arguments. Each envelope 5 cents. Buy, Read, Give to Your Friends."

LONDON, April 19. -- A great audience witnessed the one-hundredth performance of "Twelfth Night" at Daly's Theatre this evening. The Duke and Duchess of York, Duke of Teck, and Princess Mary of Teck and suites occupied the royal boxes. The American Ambassador and the Consul General were also in boxes.

Evangelistic revival meetings were well attended yesterday, there being about 1,200 present at Niblo's Garden and a crowded house at the Masonic Temple, where the Rev. James A. O'Connor, the Rev. A. Lambert, and Evangelist Ferdinand Schiverea spoke.

The horse market was dull yesterday so far as public sales went. The only offerings were triage at a miscellaneous sale at Fiss Doerr's, where a lot of very commonplace animals was disposed of at very commonplace prices.

It was announced yesterday that the liabilities of the publishing firm of Charles L. Webster Co., composed of Samuel L. Clemens ("Mark Twain") and Frederick J. Hall, are not so large as has been reported. The liabilities are said to be about $80,000, and the assets nearly as much. It is probable that a plan will soon be submitted to the creditors with a view of resumption of business by the firm.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. yesterday.
Railroad bonds of the face value of $50,000 are in the possession of the police of this city. They were found in a Gladstone bag, together with passes for almost every railroad in the country.

Few weddings of the season have been of greater interest to New-York society people than that of Miss Emily Lentilhon to John P. Gllford in Trinity Chapel yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, rector of Trinity Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Brooks, rector of the Church of the Incarnation; the Rev. Dr. William Vlbbert, rector of Trinity Chapel; the Rev. Dr. Bauman, and the Rev. Albah Richey.

LONDON, April 19. -- Lord Salisbury, addressing an audience composed of members of the Primrose League in the Coyent Garden Theatre this afternoon, said the Government majority in Parliament was composed of men who had been adjudged enemies of the nation by an impartial tribunal.
ALBANY, April 19. -- The Assembly, at its morning session, passed three measures of great interest to the taxpayers of New-York City.

BOSTON, Mass., April 19. -- The opening championship baseball game at the South End Grounds, between the Bostons and Brooklyns, was played this afternoon, with the best weather of the month and an attendance of nearly 8,000 people. The contest began in a manner that assured a close and small score, but in the fourth inning the champions struck their gait and pounded Kennedy at will.

The very air about the Hotel Waldorf was pervaded with patriotism yesterday afternoon. The General Society of the Daughters of the Revolution was celebrating the anniversary of the battle of Lexington with a luncheon, patriotic toasts, and music.

The run of one hundred consecutive nights in London, of Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night" has finally established firmly the new theatre of Mr. Daly in Leicester Square. It is no secret that his battle for success there was long and obstinate and that, for some time, the chances seemed to be against him.

ALBANY, April 19. -- Superintendent C.M. Preston of the State Banking Department, in response to a resolution of the Senate, to-day transmitted to that body copies of the official examinations of that department into the affaire of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, which is now in the hands of a receiver.

The alumni of the Law Department of the University of the City of New-York held their tenth annual reunion and banquet at Delmonico's last evening. About fifty were present. Judge Willard, Bartlett, the President of the association, was unavoidably absent, as was Elihu Root, Vice President. In their absence Secretary W.A. Purrington was master of ceremonies.

American railway securities were generally higher in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Union Pacific, 1, to 21; Northern Pacific preferred, 3/8, to 20 5/8 Erie, 1/4, to 17; Louisville and Nashville, 1/4, to 51 3/4; St. Paul, 1/4, to 63 3/4; Atchison, 1/8, to 15 3/8, and Canadian Pacific, 1/8, to 70 1/8.

There was no bloodshed yesterday at Grammar School No. 83, East One Hundred and Tenth Street, between Acting Principal Joseph J. Casey and William B. Friedberg, the newly-appointed Principal of the school.

The members of the Brooklyn Temperance League who have been holding public meetings every Sunday since the new year, and who have been urging Mayor Schieren to see that the Sunday law is enforced, should be happy, as Mayor Schieren has said that he will see that the law is enforced. Mayor Schieren made a significant declaration at the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday regarding the closing of saloons on Sunday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 19. -- There is a prospect that the Great Northern strike will be settled within a very short time. President Debs of the American Railroad Union stated this morning that, in company with Vice President Howard, he would call upon President Hill of the Great Northern and find out if that official would receive and treat with a committee from the union.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 19. -- The famous dispensary law has been declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court. For two years the question has been the all-absorhing and dividing question in South Carolina. The court by a vote of 2 to 1 says that every feature of the law is unconstitutional.

John J. McGinniss is the executive, member of the Kings County Republican General Committee from the Eighth Ward, and as such is the accredited leader in that ward. He has a salary of $2,000 a year as clerk to the Supervisor at Large, and, although Mr. Fitchie is delighted with him, there are many of the Supervisors who are opposed to him and who desire him to be on the outside of that office.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- Wheat was weak at the start, strong in the centre, and weak at the end to-day. No outside business to speak of was transacted, and the principal feature and the one around which the action revolved was the very large export clearances at the seaboard. These shipments amounted to about 800,000 bushels in wheat and flour, toward which Baltimore contributed largely.

Many spectators were present at Durland's Riding Academy last night to witness the animal finish ride of the New-York Riding Club: but an accident which almost resulted seriously to Henry Claus, one of the members of the club, marred the pleasure of the evening.

TRENTON, N.J., April 19. -- The bill to remove the Boards of Freeholders in Camden, Mercer, and Passaic Counties was advocated by President Rogers, at the night session of the Senate. He described the financial condition of Camden County at the present time as the worst in its history, owing to the extravagance and recklessness of its Board of Freeholders.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Secretary of the Navy is awaiting with some interest an explanation from Commander Caspar F. Goodrich of the Concord. A report of certain circumstances on board that ship was made six weeks ago by Engineer in Chief Melville to the Secretary, and immediately the commanding officer was invited to make a statement.

The purchase of the Vigilant by Messrs. George J. and Howard Gould, which was told exclusively in The New-York Times yesterday morning, caused yachtsmen to feel very happy. The outlook for the season was anything but good, but now, as Mr. Gould says he bought the boat to race, there is promise of very lively sport in the eighty-five-foot class.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Inasmuch as the friends of Mr. Theodore Thomas are distributing a circular suggesting a series of classical concerts under his leadership, I beg, through your columns, to state some serious drawbacks to the scheme as now presented.

At a meeting of the Archaelogicail Institute of America in the Columbia. College Buildings last night, President Merriam made an interesting report on the recent explorations in the Island of Crete, to the Mediterranean, under the auspices of the institute.

BOSTON, April 19. -- "Phormio," the eagerly expected Latin play, which was written by Terence and first performed in old Rome some twenty centuries ago, was presented on the stage of Sanders's Theatre, Cambridge, to-night, by a company of Harvard Latinists, under the superintendence of the Latin professors of the university.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the Steeplechase, Hunt, and Pony Racing Association was held yesterday afternoon at the office of Assistant Secretary James H. Wood, 32 Broad Street. The meeting was called for the purpose of adopting the new rules, by which race meetings held under the auspices of the association are hereafter to be governed.

BUFFALO, April 19. -- Judge Lambert today approved the report of the referee in the suit for divorce brought by Conductor Sidney King against his wife, which report found in King's favor. The case is a unique one, in that while the divorce was pending King was killed in the Lehigh Valley accident at Batavia two weeks ago, and the question arose whether a divorce could be granted to a dead man.

LONDON, April 19. -- John Morley, Chief Secretary for Ireland, introduced to-day in the House of Commons the Evicted Tenants bill. Mr. Morley said it was proposed to establish a Board of Arbitration, whose term of existence would be three years. This board, would be empowered to issue orders reinstating tenants upon being petitioned to do so.

The attempted formation of a Fire Insurance Trust, as reported by The New-York Times, continues to excite discussion in insurance and business circles. The charge that the joint stock companies are trying to crush out the Lloyds, and that they have banded together to take an unfair advantage of the present situation, is denied.

The funeral of the late Brevet Brigadier General Oliver Lathrop Shepherd, United States Army, retired, took place yesterday morning from the Church, of the Annunciation, Broadway and One Hundred and Thirtieth Street. The body was conveyed from his home, 2,013 Lexington Avenue, to the church, with a military escort, consisting of detachments of the Fifteenth Infantry and the First Artillery, under Major Haskins.

Smith M. Weed of Plattsburg, who was one of the party which recently visited San Domingo to discuss with President Heureaux a new scheme of finance for that republic, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. He left the others of the party, which included representatives of the firm of Brown Wells and Prof. Laughlin of the Chicago University, when they reached Florida, and has just returned.

Henry T. Gallup, the veteran General Superintendent of the Boston and Albany Railroad, has resigned, and William R. Robeson, Superintendent of the Western Division of the road, with headauarters in East Albany, has been appointed to succeed him. Mr. Robeson will assume his new duties on May 1.

Interests hostile to the Chamber of Commerce Rapid-Transit bill are wasting money if the paid lobby in their behalf is maintained in large numbers because of fear that gencies of that kind may be employed to lid for votes in the Legislature agains't them. Yesterday's disclosures in the Albany dispatch to The New-York Times in regard to the lobby excited only contempt among members of the Chamber of Commerce.

ALBANY, April 19. -- The Governor transmitted to the House a communication, regarding State reformatories, in which, he asked for the passage of a law authorizing the Governor to remove Superintendents of reformatories and other State institutions upon the formal presentation of charges, and after an opportunity to the accused to be heard in his own defense.

The fact that an apparent deficit of $21,643.15 exists in the accounts of the County Treasurer of Kings County was made public yesterday at the meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors, in the Court House, Brooklyn, and it was unanimously decided to engage an expert accountant to examine the accounts entered in the books prior to Oct. 31, 1893.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 19. -- Henrietta Purcell, twelve years old, who injured herself April 9 by rope-skipping, died late last night in the Mount Vernon hospital. Her death was due to collapse following the operation of laparotomy, necessitated by peritonitis.
ALBANY, April 19. -- The Senate has passed Senator Robertson's bill repealing the law of 1892 providing for the removal of New-York City Hall from New-York City Hall Park.

Open war was declared yesterday between the English steamship lines and the companies composing the Continental lines. For a long time there have been strained relations between the two organizations, brought about, It is alleged, by efforts of the English companies to encroach upon the Continental traffic of the others.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 19. -- This afternoon the following notice was posted on the window of a Bloomfield Avenue drug store: "Two new cases of typhoid fever have been reported to the Health Board since April 14, one on Sunday and one today. J. S. Brown." One of the new cases is Miss Jennie Noyes of 163 Union Street, an aunt of the infant who died at that address Tuesday.

Chauncey M. Depew reached home yesterday morning from Albany, having been absent from this city about eight days. During that time he has traveled, with Cornelius Vanderbilt, over nearly 3,700 miles of railroad, those two gentlemen having inspected the Chesapeake and Ohio, the Big Four system, part of the Nickel Plate, the Liake Shore, and the New-York Central Roads. Mr. Depew spoke of his trip as follows:

The news of the passage by the Assembly of the Bradley bill, removing from, office the present Board of Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, was received yesterday in Brooklyn with satisfaction. On every hand were heard expressions of surprise and pleasured .

The passengers of the disabled steamship Ems yesterday completed their interrupted voyage to this port. The Ems sailed from Bremerhaven March 17, disabled her machinery four days later, and was subsequently towed to Horta, Fayal, where the passengers were re-embarked on the Kaiser Wilhelm II., which landed them at this port yesterday.

Mrs. Philomena Hayes, the former housekeeper of the Pierrepont House, in Montague Street, Brooklyn, was in the Adams Street Police Court yesterday, and explained to Justice Walsh where she got the diamond ring which she turned over to at Pinkerton detective. She said that Daniel J. Cote, who was arrested in Rochester, N. Y., charged with stealing more than 200 diamond rings, was her brother.

ALBANY, April 19. -- If the plans of the Republican leaders can be carried out, the Legislature will disperse next Thursday. Leader Saxton in the Senate and Speaker Malby are of the opinion that all the important work of the session can be cleared off by that time.

BOSTON, April 19. -- In honor of Patriots' Day, the new Massachusetts holiday, informal demonstrations were begun in this city and in the Various towns more immediately interested shortly after midnight, and were of the usual Fourth of July and Bunker Hill Day character. At daylight the bells in all the steeples were rung, and a sunrise salute was fired.

PERRY, Oklahoma, April 19. -- A battle to the death was fought yesterday between six members of the notorious Dalton band of outlaws, headed by "Bill" Dalton, and a force of Deputy United States Marshals. The bandits were killed by the bullets from the rifles of the posse, which has been trying to effect their capture for some time.

COBURG, April 19. -- The Grand Duke Ernest Louis of Hesse was married to-day to his cousin, the Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg. The marriage ceremony took place in the palace chapel just after noon.

Probaoly the last stated monthly meeting of the Republican County Committee as it is now constituted was held last night in Grand Opera House Hall. Not many knew of it unless they knew the by-laws of the organization very well, and not more than 100 members were present. Possibly, it was thought best not to send out the usual notices, so that only a chosen few should be present.

The announcement that the Messrs. Gould have bought the Vigilant is a fact of excellent augury for the coming yachting season. Of course the new owners have bought the boat to race her. To buy such a craft for any other purpose would be the act of a lunatic. Ever since "big single-stickers " came into fashion it has been recognized that they were simply racing machines.

We are wont to congratulate ourselves that we do not have to maintain a great standing army at the expense of the resources and industries of the land. The impressive figures printed in our columns yesterday show that our army of pensioners exceeds in number the soldiers at any one time in the service during the civil war, and is far in excess of the number mustered out in 1865.

Ex-Senator Thomas W. Palmer of Michgan, President of the World's Fair Commission; has been in this city two or three lays deeply interested in watching the progress of the movement in favor of striking the word "male" from the State Constitution. He is an ardent champion of the women who have instituted the series of "suffrage teas" and other fashionable gatherings where this topic is discussed.

It Is gratifying to note that the reports current in Wall Street for the past day or two, to the effect that the Eastern trunk lines are planning to make general reductions in the wages of their employes, are promptly denied by the Presidents and managers of most of the railroads concerned.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The religious portion of Washington society has become interested in the American Society of Religious Education. Its anniversary was held on Sunday, April 8, and other meetings have since been held. The society originated in Indianapolis, and its operations, extended from city to city and from State to State, have been carried on chiefly in the West.

The interest in the match between Fischer and Parker drew a good number of spectators to the courts of the Prospect Heights Tennis Club yesterday afternoon. The rivals had met twice last year -- at Orange and in the Knickerbocker Handicap, and both times Parker proved victorious. Fisoher reversed the decision yesterday afternoon in two well-played sets, and won his eighth successive match and the tournament.

The pamphlet report of the business of the Southern Pacific Railroad for 1893 will soon be issued. In it President C.P. Huntington says: "The results of the gross operations are satisfactory, considering the exceptional conditions under which they were obtained. In no year in the history of the company were such determined efforts made as in the year just closed to wrest from it the business, which it had been years in building up.

The Lenox Wheelmen are a hustling crowd, and during the past Winter they have given more dances, entertainments, and stags than any other wheel club in this vicinity. Now they intend to make the Summer season just as enjoyable a one as the Winter was. A big stag racket is being arranged for Saturday evening, April 28.

BOSTON, April 19. -- The Boston Athletic Association held an open handicap meeting on the Irvington Oval to-day, which was attended by about 2,500 persons, and more enthusiasm was shown than has been the case at any outdoor meeting held by the club. The new men, Kane and Stinzel, showed up well, considering that both are scratch men in their respective specialties.

Once upon a time a season at the Metropolitan Opera House began with the performance of an opera never before heard in America by a company including three principal singers, who made their debuts here that evening, and of whom one -- the tenor -- sang the leading role in the opera for the first time in his life.
"Upon the assumption that Mayor Gilroy will absolutely decline to be a candidate for renomination for his present office, who in your opinion will be named by Tammany Hall for the nomination?"
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Coxey's army has been considered a little too seriously in the national capital, in the estimation of some of the conservative men here.

John Masterson, a "ticket chopper" at the South Perry, complained to Inspector Conlin at Police Headquarters yesterday that Sergt. Thomas F. McCormlck of the Old Slip Station had caused his discharge through malice.

Commonly a decision of the New-York Legislature to take an early adjournment is approved as virtuous and becoming, for rarely does public interest plead for a long session. But the present Legislature evidently intends to adjourn befors it has passed the most important and necessary measures it has had before it, and to adjourn unseasonably for the very purpose of preventing their enactment.

A pretty wedding yesterday was that of Miss Amy Hewitt Brooks, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Hewitt Brooks, to John J. Gordon. Miss Sadie J. Brooks, the bride's sister, was maid of honor, and the best man was Robert L. Gordon, a brother of the bridegroom. The ushers were John J. Brooks, William E. Schaster, Ignatius Radley, Jr., and Charles Taylor.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., April 19. -- Six thousand five hundred miners in the sixth, bituminous district, comprising eighty mines, principally along the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad, and in Northern Cambria County, are expected to strike Saturday next and demand the restoration of the old rate of 45 cents per ton.

ALBANY, April 19. -- Mr. Ainsworth's bill providing for a commission to investigate the New-York City tenement house Question was passed in the Senate to-day. Mr. Guy offered an amendment, including the Superintendent of Buildings as one of the committee, but the amendment was defeated.

Messrs, Douglas Robinson Co. have sold, for Charles Steele, to Max Herzog, the fcur-story high-stoop brownstone dwelling 74 East Fifty-sixth Street, 18 by 55 by 100, at $29,000. To J.B. Hendrickson they have sold the four-story high-stoop brownstone dwelling 1,037 Madison Avenue, east side, 42 feet north of Seventy-ninth Street, 20 by 80.

A dozen landscapes and marines by George H. Bogert are to be seen in the larger gallery of Boussod, Valadon Co., 303 Fifth Avenue, till the second week in May. The artist has already flown to his Summer haunts in France and Holland; but he leaves behind him proofs of the steady improvement of his hand.

From The Westminster Gazette. It is scarcely correct to say, writes a correspondent, that the Rev. T.H. Wellesley Wesley, who has just been appointed tutor to the Duke of Albany, is a lineal descendant of the celebrated John Wesley, who married a widow with four children, but was himself childless. The names Wellesley Wesley are a somewhat curious combination.

Some of the "ring" contractors who have been hanging around the City Works Department in Brooklyn, in the hope of picking up a few crumbs from the Schieren administration, were seized with cold chills yesterday when they read in The New-York Times that the Grand Jury might be called on to investigate the circumstances of the suit of E.J. McKeever Co. against ex-Street Superintendent George H. Sterling for a dissolution of partnership.

BOSTON, April 19. -- The Mosquito Fleet Yacht Club opened Its eastern yachting season to-day by a race off its clubhouse at City Point. The race was for boats of fifteen feet over all, and brought out half a dozen starters. A fresh westerly breeze made small-boat sailing very lively sport, and caused several mishaps.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club Handicap horses at Gravesend, Sheepshead Bay, and Brighton Beach are making rapid progress in their work for the first big Eastern event. Yesterday, at Gravesend, Dave McCoun's famous old horse Loantaka covered a mile and a furlong in faultless style in 2:03 1/2.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The Senate, in spite of the opposition of the Democrats and the lobbying of Lieut. Gov. Sheehan, who seems to have taken command of the Democratic forces in the upper house for the time being, advanced Mr. Sheffield's bill to permit the Mayors of New-York hereafter elected to appoint their own heads of departments and also the Assembly bill to turn the fees of the Sheriff's office into the County Treasury.

"Hannele," a play translated from the German of Gerhart Hauptmann, is underlined for production at the Fifth Avenue Theatre for four weeks, beginning Monday next, under the management of Carl and Theodor Rosenfeld. The play has never been produced in English.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Secretary Herbert signed the instructions to commanders of vessels of the fur-seal patrol fleet this afternoon, and they were at once sent forward to the rendezvous at Port Townsend. Identical instructions were mailed for the Mohican, Yorktown, Alert, Albatross, and Corwin, as well as a copy for the Pinta, now at Sitka.

The combination sale of harness horses, saddle hacks, hunters, and cobs, the property of A.H. Moore, Isaac Straus, D.T. W. Lowes, William Flood, and others, at Tattersalls yesterday afternoon, was well attended, and the prices brought indicated a strong market.
Clinton Furbish, who is connected with the State Department at Washington, lectured before the Liberal Club, at 220 East Fifteenth Street, last evening, on "The Truth About Hawaii."

ALBANY, April 20 -- Mr. Gerst of Erie, who introduced the general bill reducing the telephone rates in the cities of the State, found to-day that the favorable caucus action of Tuesday was repudiated by the House. The instant he made his motion to discharge the Committee on Electricity, Gas, and Water Supply from further consideration of his bill there was a great rush of members from the chamber.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- "There is no present indication of any attempt to foreclose the Government's mortgage on the Pacific railroads," said Senator Brice, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Pacific Railroads, this morning. "Of course," said Mr. Brice, "the future may see such proceedings begun, and much depends on what the security holders behind the Government agree to do.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 20 --The Neptune Democratic Society, the largest and most flourishing club in Monmouth County, unanimously passed the following resolutions at a meeting to-night, at which not only the regular members were present, but also many prominent Democrats of the township:

The evangelistic revival meetings in Niblo's Garden at noon and the Masonic Temple in the afternoon yesterday were well attended. The meetings of this week have been the most fruitful of the series, and there is a prospect that they will be continued until June 1 or later.

The boys of the athletic, baseball, and bicycle sections in connection with St. George's Club are looking forward to a busy and successful season. The funds at their disposal were materially augmented by the minstrel entertainment given by members of the club a few nights ago.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 20 -- The following letter has been received from a correspondent at Bluefields, Nicaragua, under date of April 13:

The stock market yesterday was dull, and more in the hands of the professionals. Prices, as a rule, were higher, and little was heard of rate disturbances and labor troubles, two matters which, on Thursday, were considered to have great bearing on the value of stocks in the immediate future. The volume of business was still small.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, yesterday.

The silk ribbon weavers and dyers of Paterson, N.J., who have been on a strike for several weeks, marched to this city yesterday, to return the visit paid them a week ago by the New-York strikers in the same trade. They arrived tired, but cheerful.

Guncilliano Baez, a Spaniard, who has been under treatment in the Charity Hospital on Blackwell's Island, was taken into custody yesterday by the United States Marshal on the application of the Spanish Consul General at Washington for his extradition on a charge of forgery while acting as a Government official in Cuba.

The Brooklyn League nine will open the home season this afternoon at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, with the Boston team. The grand stand will be decrorated and the grounds made attractive. Conterno's Band will furnish music, beginning shortly after 2 o'clock. The game will commence at 3:30. The teams will probably be made up as follows:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 20. -- To-day's races at Montgomery Park were well attended. There were seven races on the card, one of them being the Luchrmann Selling Stake at one mile. Vassal was the favorite in the event, with Buckrene and Chant second choices. Ed. Corrigan's colt had no trouble in winning, while Buckrene and Chant ran a dead heat for the place.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- There were very few outside orders, and, as has been the case for some days past, it was practically a room traders' market. West Chicago Street Railroad stock opened at 153, was firm for a time, and then dropped to 152, where the bulk of the transactions were made.

American railway securities were irregular in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Louisville and Nashville, 3/8 to 52 1/8; Northern Pacific preferred, 3/8 to 21, and St. Paul, 1/4 to 64. Declined -- Canadian Pacific, 3/8 to 69 3/4; Kansas and Texas, 1/4 to 16, and Union Pacific, 1/8 to 20 7/8.

The Lexington Wheelmen to-morrow intend to run to Coney Island, and if it is pleasant it is expected that a large number of the members and their friends will turn out. Last Sunday seventeen members took part in the ride.
NEWTOWN, L.I., April 20 -- Two strangers entered the Post Office here this afternoon. One of them bought a postal card and when they departed they took with them about $400 in cash and stamps.

Saturday and Sunday are the special days for road runs by bicycle clubs. Business prevents many from taking suburban trips, except on Sunday, but not a few during the Summer get a chance for a good long ride a-wheel on Saturday afternoons. One of the most popular runs is over Staten Island roads, which bicyclists have found most excellent.

The Seventy-first Regiment last night celebrated the thirty-third anniversary of its departure for the war, and also opened its new armory, at Park Avenue and Thirty-Fourth Street, to the public. For the entertainment of the thousands of guests, Pratt's "Allegory of the War in Song" was given.

Besides being a diamond merchant Simon Leopold has dabbled in stock speculations. As a diamond broker he has done quite a business buying goods pledged with pawn brokers, repledging them and selling the tickets. As a speculator he has operated through Isaac Borger of the Consolidated Exchange.

BALTIMORE, April 20. -- The late train for New-York to-night had among its passengers a half hundred broken-hearted baseball enthusiasts. They came here to witness the slaughter of the Baltimore innocents at the hands of the Giants. When the latter got their setback in the opening game, they took the defeat philosophically, and ventured to remark that the NewYorkers would even up things to-day.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used for the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Owners of race horses are complaining considerably about the lethargic fashion into which the new Board of Control, or the Jockey Club, has fallen. The racing season is but a month away, and as yet no one has been able to discover by what sort of rules racing is to be governed or what sort of men are to govern it.

Charles Banner, a lawyer having an office at 62 Wall Street, was arrested yesterday and arraigned before Judge Cowing, in the Court of General Sessions, charged with grand larceny. He pleaded not guilty, and was released on $7,500 ball. An indictment was found against Mr. Banner last Wednesday, on complaint of Mrs. Abbie E. O'Brien, wife of ex-Sheriff James O'Brien.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 20 -- The Coxey camp at Cullom's Station has been named after Lieut. Brangan of the police force, who met the party to-day on its arrival. Planting a flag which had been given them by the school children of Los Angeles, Cal., the Commonwealers surrounded it and gave three cheers for Camp Brangan.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The Governor's veto of Senator Saxton's bill amending the code of civil procedure so that the remarks made by Judges may be subject to review by higher courts gave rise to a proposal in the Senate to pass the bill over the veto. Senator O'Connor said that evidently the Governor was no lawyer, or he would not object to giving lawyers the right to take exception to the remarks of Judges.

BOSTON, April 20 -- Judge Colt of the United States Circuit Court to-day rendered his decision on the petition of the receivers of the New-York and New-England Railroad against the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad for alleged discrimination in the transportation of freight East and West.

It is inevitable that there should be more or less friction at a World's Fair between the representatives of foreign exhibitors and the representatives of the nation which acts as the host of the occasion. That has always happened. It seems rather odd that there should have been more irritation created between France and the United States by the exhibition at Chicago than between the United States and any other nation.

READING, Penn., April 20. -- Actor E.H. Sothern, who was taken ill while on his way to Reading last evening, with neuralgia of the stomach, and was obliged to cancel his engagement, is confined to his bed at the Mansion House. He has canceled his Lancaster and Wilmingon dates, and Will go to Philadelphia, where he is billed to open a week's engagement next Monday.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Before it is removed the Ferris wheel will be given one more turn upon its axle, the last whirl it will make in Chicago. Superintendent L.V. Rice said yesterday that he expects to get up steam for the purpose of making this revolution either Wednesday or Thursday of next week, immediately after which the work of tearing down the wheel will be begun.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Assemblyman Tobin's bill in relation to the compensation of laborers or employes in the Department of Public Parks in New-York City. In his veto, the Governor says: "The Park Commissioners of the City of New-York have now authority to fix the compensation of laborers or employes at such amount as may seem to them just.

The Blanket Ballot bill now goes into the hands of a conference committee, and whatever may become of the rest of the "reform" measures at Albany, it ought to be an easy matter to save this one. It is a curious fact that the difference between the two houses has been wholly a Republican disagreement.

Dun's Review will say to-day: "Extensive storms checked improvement in business only for a time, and numerous strikes have not yet arrested it. Distribution of products to consumers seems larger, for more people are earning, and, therefore, more are able to buy. But it is less clear that the increase of working force continues, or that orders for products will further expand.

A rather absurd story was exploited yesterday concerning the purchase of the Fourth Presbyterian Church property, in West Thirty-fourth Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue. This property, as was exclusively announced in The New-York Times on Thursday, has been acquired by a syndicate, of which Mr. Neil Burgess is a member.
COLUMBUS, April 20 -- President McBride of the United Mine Workers, made the following estimate of the number of miners that will go out at noon to-morrow, and their distribution among the States:

A dispatch from Albany yesterday stated that Mme. Emma Calve, the dramatic soprano, had resigned from the Abbey Grau Opera Company, and would not sing here next season. This was the final outcome of an exhibition of personal pique by the singer on the stage of the Opera House on Tuesday evening.

The Chamber of Commerce Rapid-Transit Committee did not take much comfort to itself yesterday over the news that its bill had been made a special order in the State Senate for next Tuesday. It is believed that a show of sincerity will be made in behalf of the bill, but the committee is not disposed to take anything for granted.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 20 -- More than 1,000 unemployed men gathered in the public square this morning, and, after listening to a number of inflammatory speeches, delivered in foreign tongues by representatives of the striking laborers, a raid was made on a gang of men at work on a sewer in St. Clair Street. About 100 men were compelled to stop work and join the strikers.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- It has taken some of the Navy Department people a long time to discover the faults in the cruiser New-York that were all described in The New-York Times months ago, before she left for Rio.

Mayville, N.V., April 20. -- Henry E. Barden, a grocer of this village, committed suicide this morning by cutting the areeries in his heels with a razor, then shooting himself through the heart with a rifle.

Gold to the amount of $3,000,000 will be sent to Europe to-day by the French steamer. The markets have been prepared for what happened by Thursday's reports, which were duly published yesterday morning. Shipments could hardly have any present effect upon prices, for the reason that gold usually goes abroad in the first quarter of the year in much larger amounts than have been taken up to this time.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A third Senator has deemed it proper to reply to the charge which the Democracy of Minnesota made some weeks ago as to the hostile position which certain Democratic Senators are supposed to hold, or to have held, toward the Tariff bill.

The Atchison Reorganization Committee, of which Capt. R. Somers Hayes is Chairman and Herman Kobbe is Secretary, has established headquarters in the new part of the Mutual Life Building, in Liberty Street. A meeting will be held next week, and doubtless a plan of action will soon be marked out.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The report of the special Senate committee which investigated the State Board of Health was submitted to-day. It is on a line with the bill reorganizing the board which was reported from the committee, and which has already passed the Senate.

The will of the late Gen. Henry W. Slocum was filed in the office of the Surrogate of Kings County yesterday. The value of the estate is not stated, but it is believed that Gen. Slocum was worth at least $500,000.

"Who are you?" "What have you done?" "What dive did you graduate from?" "How many dives are you running now?" These are a few of the questions the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst declared last evening would be asked of candidates at the election next Fall.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 20. -- Two weddings were to have taken place here last night. The ceremonies were to have been performed by the Rev. Patrick McKenna, pastor of the Catholic Church here. The young people and their friends waited several hours for the priest, but he came not. He resides at Fenhurst.

Ex-Gov. William E. Russell of Massachusetts has contributed an article to the May number of The Forum on "A Year of Democratic Administraion." He clears the way for a frank statement of what has been done by explaining the proper point of view to judge the success of the party.

From The Philadelphia Record, (Dem.) The New-York Times, which has been showing up in detail the fraudulent character of a great deal of the pension business, rendered especially valuable service to the country yesterday by turning a flood of light upon the system as a whole, and thus revealing its deformities in a glaring way that cannot but arrest the attention of even the most indifferent and incredulous.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Secretary of War Lamont has not been long home from his tour of inspection of army posts, but he has been in his office long enough to approve a plan for the reduction of expenses in the office of the Secretary of War that has been in contemplation for some time.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 20. -- The case of the National Water Works Company of New-York City against Kansas City, Mo., was decided by Justices Caldwell and Phillips, in Chambers, to-day.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- In the Senate to-day the Peffer resolution relating to the Coxey Army was again taken up and a strong denunciation of it and of the speech of the Populist Senator from Nebraska, Mr. Allen, yesterday, was made by Mr. Hawley, (Rep., Conn.) He said, among other things:

At the meeting of the Police Board yesterday, Commissioner McLean preferred charges of neglect of duty against Captains Frederick W. Martens of the East Thitryfifth Street Station, and Edward Slevin of the Oak Street squad. The charges were based on alleged failure to close disorderly houses.

Investigation of the Brooklyn city departments is at last in sight. A conference was held yesterday at the Mayor's office to arrange for the work. There were present Mayor Schieren, Commissioner of City, Works White, and Aldermen Clarke, Leich, Roeder, Haubert, Hess, Wallace, and Cohn.

Controller James H. Eckels of the Treasury Department, at Washington, met the bankers of New-York City for the first time formally yesterday afternoon at the rooms of the Clearing House Association, Pine and Nassau Streets. It has been customary for years to have such a meeting at the beginning of each Administration at Washington.

Clearness, which is always a special merit of the style of Mr. Leland, has in this manual of practical instruction in the craft of the metal worker an unexpected effect. It tempts one to read the book for lessons in the art of writing.
The general impression that Mayor Gilroy will not accept a renomination has aroused interest on all sides in the question of Mayoralty candidates at the next election.

Gen. Joseph B. Carr of Troy, ex-Secretary of New-York State, who underwent a surgical operation for cancer of the mouth on Thursday at St Luke's Hospital, will probably be able to return home in a few days.

Very often there is a sense of disappointment in reading the life of a famous writer. We have surrounded him with an atmosphere of distinction that belongs only to a creative spirit, but has no outward and visible sign in his daily action. We may experience a feeling of bewilderment at discovering the apparent contradiction between the commonplace of his action and the royalty of his thought.

Major Gen. Oliver O. Howard, commanding the Department of the East, told the school children of Brooklyn yesterday all about the first battle of Bull Run -- the battle of Manassas, as the Confederates called it -- how it came to be fought, how it was fought and why, and the reasons for the defeat of the Union soldiers.

Alice Morton, the young English girl who was removed as a smallpox patient from the New-York Hospital to North Brother Island April 13, was found wandering in a dazed condition in Harlem yesterday. She met a woman, who returned her to the Wetmore House for Friendless Girls, 49 South Washington Square.
COBURG, April 20 -- The betrothal of Grand Duke Nicholas, Czarowitch of Russia, to the Princess Alix of Hesse, youngest sister of the Grand Duke Ernest Louis of Hesse, is announced.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 20 -- S.M. Prevost, General Manager of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, issued to-day his report of the operations of the company in the year ending Dec. 31, 1893. It is a comprehensive exhibit of the business and earnings of the lines east of Pittsburg and Erie, which are divided into three divisions -- the Pennsylvania Railroad Division, the United Railroads of New-Jersey Division, and the Pennsylvania and Erie Division.

The story of the Nun Alferez was written by its heroine, Catlina de Erauso, and published for the first time in 1625 at Madrid and Seville. It has the adventurous and picaresque air of a cape and sword novel, but it is a true story.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 20. -- In the South Carolina dispensary matter everything has been amicably settled. Gov. Tillman has decided not to fight any further the decision of the Supreme Court declaring the dispensary law unconstitutional, and tomorrow every dispensary in the State will be closed.

Prompted by the adverse decision of the Clearing House Committee upon the proposition of the Sherman State Bank to substitute the United States National Bank for the Central National Bank as its clearing agent, Bank Examiner Judson spent yesterday looking into the affairs of the Sherman Bank.

-- A granite bracket six feet long, weighing nearly half a ton, broke from the stone gallery in the third floor of the Custom House yesterday morning and fell fifteen feet to the floor. It smashed the flagging of the second floor, and the force of the blow knocked the glass out of some of the windows. Only watchmen and porters were about.

The pink dining room for women in the Metropolitan Club, Sixtieth Street and Fifth Avenue, was a scene of a dinner last evening at which James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, and Mrs. Eckels were the guests of honor. Their hosts were a number of prominent bankers of this city.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., April 20. -- The Executive Council has sent petitions to the English Government to appoint a royal commission of five men from the English Treasury Department to hold an investigation of the condition of the colonial finances.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- There was a further decrease in the volume of business to-day. The bond market was also less active. Pennslyvania sold off fractionally from 51 to 50 3/4, but recovered its decline later in the day, Lehigh Valley was somewhat stronger, advancing on small transactions to 39 5/8, which was bid at the close, with only a small lot for sale at 39 3/4.

When the Westchester County bowling tournament was concluded a few days ago there were left two ties. That for first place was between the Yonkers and A.B.C. Clubs, and one between the Terrace City and Young Men's Christian Association Clubs. After an exciting game on Thursday evening the tie between the Yonkers City and A.B.C. Clubs was decided in favor of the former by a score of 803 to 801.

Much interest was shown by Brooklyn real estate men yesterday at the offering of the "Universal" Building, at the southeast corner of Washington and Tillary Streets, 98.9 1/2 by 129.11 by 107.6 by 129.9. The building is two stories high, and built substantially of brick and stone, with walls heavy enough to support a ten-story building.

LONDON, April 20 -- Alpheus Cleophas Morton, Liberal for Peterborough, moved in the House of Commons this evening that the annuity of L10,000, drawn by the Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha in his capacity of Duke of Edinburgh, be forthwith abolished.

The Municipal Art Society has brought out a good deal of talent from unexpected quarters in its competition for a wall painting to be presented to the city. The courtroom of Oyer and Terminer, in the Criminal Courts on Centre Street near the Tombs, is about 60 feet long and about 38 broad. At one end is the tribune for Judges.

WASHlNGTON, April 20 -- Immediately upon the assembling of the House to-night for the consideration of private pension bills, and after the first bill had been taken up, Mr. Talbert of South Carolina addressed the Chair, and, during the course of his remarks, referred to the supplement of The New-York Weekly Times, which paper was the subject of a good deal of discussion.

While many prominent clergymen have joined heartily in the crusade for the amendment of the State Constitution in favor of woman suffrage, it has been remarked that the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, although an active worker on some other lines in public affairs, has not signed any of the petitions so numerously circulated recently by those who think women should have the right to vote.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., April 20. -- Before the body of Richard Miller, the telegraph operator at Port Reading, was taken to his parents' home, a man died in the Wells Memorial Hospital in New-Brunswick, who, it is thought, might have been connected with young Miller's death. The man's name was unknown.
OMAHA, Neb., April 20 -- Gen. Kelly has proved his claim to be the leader of an army or peace, as he to-night emphatically refused to accept a train token to Weston by his Omaha friends.
ORANGE, N.J., April 21. -- Mrs. J.G. Brown of East Park Street gave a pink tea at her home on Friday afternoon.

American railway securities were irregular in the open market. The principal changes were: Declined -- St. Paul, 7/8, to 64 7/8; Reading, 1/8, to 10 3/8, and Ontario and Western, 1/8, to 16 1/2. Advanced -- Louisville and Nashville, 5/8, to 52 3/4; Union Pacific, 5/8, to 21 1/2; Canadian Pacific, 1/2, to 70 1/4; Wabash preferred, 1/4, to 18; Illinois Central, 1/4, to 95 1/4, and Atchison, 1/8, to 15 1/2.

In the fashions for the opening season the throat bows and scarfs continue the reign of popularity which has been theirs through the Winter. Some of the handsomest imported costumes shown at exclusive houses have a tiny mantle as wrap, which is fastened at the neck with six-inch moire ribbon, tied in a straight bow from which lace-edged ends fall to the very hem of the skirt.

The Twelfth Regiment held its second annual reunion dinner in the rooms of the Manhattan Athletic Club last night. The dinner was in commemoration of the date when the regiment marched to the front at the outbreak of the civil war.

In speaking of the early chapters of Genesis, Prof. Sayce emphasizes the presence in them of a strong Babylonian element. The tablets, containing the Babylonian cosmogony, which were first brought to light, now nearly twenty years ago, by Mr. George Smith, are quoted, and it is shown how the narrative of the first chapter of Genesis is dependent upon it.
BOSTON, April 21. -- A former official of the New-York and New-England Railroad says in regard to the alleged reorganization plan, reported to have been obtained from reliable sources:
"Yachtsmen are like snakes, I think," remarked Rear Commodore A.P. Ketcham at the Atlantic Yacht Clubhouse yesterday. "A little sunshine makes us wake up."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 21 -- Information received at the headquarters of the United Mine Workers this afternoon indicates to President McBride that at least 130,000 miners dropped their picks at noon to-day in obedience to the order of the National Convention two weeks ago.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. yesterday.

From The Westminster Gazette. The Liverpool-owned ship Fulwood arrived at Queenstown yesterday from San Francisco with a cargo of wheat, after a passage of 148 days. Her experience amid iceberge in the South Atlantic has possibly been the most trying and dangerous of those recently heard of.

WASHINGTON, APRIL 21. -- Democratic prospects are looking a little better in Alabama than they did a few weeks ago, but there is still much left to be done to put the party in good fighting shape. It is evident that the Republicans are again encouraging the hope of a division among the Democrats so serious that the Alliance-Republican opposition may step in and win with Kolb as a candidate for Governor.

When the Winter months ensued the river was closed with ice during a season, which commenced with December and ended with March. It was a season of gayety. The merchants were not busy, fur trading was suspended, and festivities of one kind or another succeeded; dancing parties were frequent, and dinner parties, where much wine was drank, are stated to have been of regular occurrence.

From The Naval and Military Record, (British.) It will be welcome news to mariners to know that the graceful United States war sloop, the Vesuvius, has been for a month cruising to and fro in the Atlantic seeking out derelicts. These huge hulks of wreckage have, during the last twenty years, increased in such numbers that the great waterway between Europe and America has become dangerous to an extent never dreamed of.

The old method of demonstration by insurrection is inconsistent with modern conditions, five Maxim guns and 5,000 Winchester rifles being stronger than any amount of undrilled and huddled men, and, besides, insurrection would stop wages, which is precisely what the hypothetical insurgents do not want to do.

Col. Albert E. Lamb appeared before Justice Gaynor in the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday, representing himself, Edward M. Shepard, Gen. B.F. Tracy, and Jerry A. Wernberg, who have applied for compensation for their services in the prosecution of the Gravesend election fraud cases.

BOSTON, April 21 -- The positive statemeat of Gen. Paine that he would not put the Jubilee in commission next Summer has been received with the regret which was anticipated, for to many Eastern yachtsmen the question of superiority between the Jubilee and the Vigilant was by no means settled by last season's racing.
