The Governor's appointment of a commission to inquire into the charges against Superintendent Brockway's management of the Elmira Reformatory receives the cordial approval of those who have protested against the indecent movement to secure Mr. Brockway's immediate removal on the charges passed upon in the one-sided Litchfield report.

If a Scottish maiden desired to summon the image of her future husband, she read the third verse, seventeenth chapter of the Book of Job, after supper, washed the supper dishes, and retired to bed without uttering a single word, placing underneath her pillow the Bible, with a pin thrust through the verse she had read.

WASHINGTON, Aprll 21. -- The "Industrials'' from Philadelphia, who appropriated Coxey's idea, and came to Washington prepared to march in a body to the Capitol and demand of Congress that the Wilson bill be smashed, have been treated by the District authorities precisely as Coxey and his following will be treated when they get here.

Several school records were broken at the Berkeley Oval yesterday at the fourth annual field meeting of the Cutler School Athletic Association. Friday's rain and yesterday's sun put the track in good condition, and in every respect the meeting was very successful. There was a very numerous and fashionable attendance, many young women being present.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- What little activity there was in to-day's wheat market was crowded into the last half hour of the session. It was not very significant nor important, however, and the entire day was without the least indication or unusual action. There is a great deal of gossip going the rounds touching the extent of the lines of May wheat, both short and long, still remaining open.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- There is some talk of making a wholesale release of military prisoners at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., where accommodations for 550 men are occupied by 643 culprits. This overcrowded condition gives the administrative officers much concern, as new men are continually being sentenced to the place, and the releases are not sufficient, even by the average remission of sentences, to relieve the condition.

In a very short time the hum of the wheel will be heard on many tracks and the riders of both classes will be struggling for their 1894 laurels. Already in England racing has begun, and from reliable sources it has been learned that the attendance there is larger than ever before. On two days, at different tracks, 34,000 persons paid to see the racing.

In order to appreciate the impression made upon the Queen by Peel, it is necessary to picture him as he then was in the prime of life, a man of great vigor, tall and manly, in his fiftieth year only, but with almost thirty years of Parliamentary and official life marked on his face. His political career commenced when he was a lad of twenty-two.

The funeral of Thomas W. Ludlow was held on Friday afternoon at his home, Cottage Lawn, Ludlow-on-the-Hudson. He was the son of Thomas W. Ludlow, Jr., and his family has long been identified with the history and growth of Yonkers. Mr. Ludlow received his degree of Bachelor of Arts from Harvard in 1882 and the degree of Master of Arts from Columbia in 1893.

CINCINNATI, April 21 -- A telegram from Jobs, Ohio, says that all the mines there closed at noon. Indications point to trouble if the strike lasts long, as the miners are in a bad condition to stand a lock-out.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- Metropolitan and Philadelphia Traction stocks led the market to-day. Excited trading prevailed in both stocks, and there were sales of 3,000 Metropolitan and 4,000 Philadelphia. The morning newspapers had announced a probable new issue of Philadelphia Traction bonds, variously estimated at from $200,000 to $5,000,000.

OMAHA, Neb., April 21 -- Everything is comparatively quiet in Omaha to-night after the excitement of the last two days, but those who are well informed are inclined to the belief that it is the lull before the storm.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 21 -- Car burglaries of importance were committed last night between Buffalo and Angola on the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad. Several box cars were broken open and cases of dry goods, clothing, and general merchandise were thrown from the train and their contents appropriated.

From the Memphis (Tenn.) Appeal-Avalanche, (Dem.) The Appeal-Avalanche protests strenuously against the supposition that the Southern business men are confused as to the right Governmental policy relative to the currency. They are in favor of a single standard.

The story of Miss Alice Morton, the young English girl who says she was kept in the hospital on North Brother Island with smallpox patients, then set adrift without having developed any signs of the disease. Is denied by the health authorities. Chief Inspector Doty of the Division of Contagious Diseases said yesterday that it was ridiculous to pretend she did not have the smallpox.

The Building Committee of the New-York Clearing House yesterday decided upon plans for a new building at 79, 81, and 83 Cedar Street. Seven architects submitted plans, and after they had been considered for several weeks those of R.W. Gibson were accepted.

LONDON, April 21 -- For weeks past there has been apparent that something big was maturing itself beneath the surface commotion of hurried royal visits and an exceptional activity of royal letter carriers.

The only new things in the New-York theatrical market last week were exhibited in the music halls. Vesta Tilley, a sprightly singing woman from London, has drawn crowds at Tony Pastor's Theatre, the manager of which prides himself upon the support of the fashionable few, as well as that of the big multitude.

Many women of New-York, prominent in social life, want the State Constitution amended so that they can vote. In Brooklyn there are several organizations of women struggling for the acquirement of the suffrage.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- An early adjournment of Congress is regarded as a political necessity by many members of the House, and especially by those from the South who voted for the repeal of the Sherman Silver Purchase act. Some of these gentlemen have already been apprised of the fact that their opponents at home are endeavoring to secure their defeat because of their position on that measure.

Hanover, N.H., April 21. -- The annual cane rush between the sophomores and the freshmen of Dartmouth College tools place last night. The feeling between these two classes is probably as strong as any that ever existed between two lower classes. After a long contest, as near as could be decided, the freshmen came out ahead.
In a parlor up town the other afternoon a group of women were assembled and the talk ran, as the talk will run these days, on the question of political equality.

ATHENS, April 21 -- Five Shocks of earthquake were felt here this morning, but they were very slight in comparison with those experienced last evening. The village of Nespille, on the Gulf of Atalanta, was destroyed by last night's shocks.

The growth of Brooklyn is nowhere more strikingly illustrated than in the Bedford district. The avenue from which the section derives its name has become, next to Fulton Street, the principal thoroughfare of the city. On Sundays it is as crowded as any street on Manhattan Island. From early morning until long after nightfall the smooth asphalt pavement, fine and level as a parlor floor, acts as a conduit for a perfect torrent of humanity.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 21. -- The Great Northern strikers resumed their tactics of cutting and sidetracking trains to-day. The scene of their operations was Barnesville, and the Sheriff of Clay County refused to interfere. Both passenger trains Nos. 2 and 4 were stopped and sidetracked at that point, in spite of the fact that there were a number of United States Marshals on board.

The first week of the supplementary season of grand opera was one of great interest. The performance of "Faust" on Monday evening, although it contained not a single new feature, was decidedly refreshing after the dullness of the closed season. The artists, in spite of the fact that they had just arrived from St. Louis after a long and arduous journey, were in capital voice, and they sang with splendid fire.

Extensive and costly improvements along the line of the New-York Central Railroad have been made during the past year. Important work now under way, such as the new four-track bridge over the Harlem River and the elevation of the tracks in Upper Park Avenue, will probably be completed within the present year, and plans are under consideration for improvements in Syracuse and Buffalo which will cost about $3,000,000.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 21. -- The Seventh Regiment men made a journey to West Point to-day, and attacked the cadets in their stronghold with baseball bats and balls. The cadets were ready to receive them, and from the commandant down to the messroom boy all were anxious to see the game.

Almost every Indian river is deemed sacred, and some spiritual benefit is supposed to be derived from bathing in it. In any large town or village there is usually a bathing ghat, with convenient flights of steps leading down to the water. Here the people assemble in great numbers. The women of the higher classes creep down before daylight, and hope to get back to their houses before they can be seen.

The growing disposition to have legislative acts referred to a vote of the people for approval, before taking effect as laws, implies a loss of confidence in the principle of representation. Theoretically, under a Government like ours, the citizens choose men to represent them and to make laws for them, because they can thereby use the best knowledge and talent extant for that kind of work.

A stirring event of the week in military circles was the celebration of the thirty-third anniversary of the Seventy-first Regiment's departure for the war, on April 20, 1861. On Friday night the new armory was the scene of a most brilliant gathering. The production of the allegory. "The War in Song," and the reception which followed it will long be remembered by those who attended or participated in them.

RONDOUT, N.Y., April 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould, William M. Harriman, J. Borden Harriman, and W.S. Mallett, Mr. Gould's private secretary, came up from New-York yesterday and went to Furlough Lodge, in the Catskills. They will pass a few days at Mr. Gould's mountain home to enjoy fishing in Furlough Lake, which is stocked with large trout.

The Revolution was singularly barren in people who had even a rudimentary knowledge of art; we are thrown on the mercy of amateurs like Col. Jonathan Trumbull for some idea of what the heroes of that struggle resembled at the time it occurred. After it was over Trumbull took up the career of artist seriously and went abroad to pursue that purpose.

Mr. Frank Damrosch's new choral organization, the Musical Art Society, is an assured success, and it thoroughly deserves to be one. The second concert was given at Music Hall last night, and a large audience was present to applaud music which commanded hearty approval. The avowed purpose of the organization is to perform the choral music of the mediaeval and early modern composers.

Depositors at the Sherman Bank, Broadway and Eighteenth Street, made a run on that institution yesterday. About 100 persons stood in line before the cashier's window shortly after noon, withdrawing a whole or a part of their deposits. Most of those who wanted their money were small depositors, and in every instance they got their money.

The Naval and Military Record (British) says that arrangements are being made at the Royal Naval Barracks, Keyham, for carrying out experiments with carrier pigeons, with a view to training them for the transmission of dispatches. Commander W.G. White, who has voluntarily undertaken the arrangements, has secured four pairs of homers, which will be kept for breeding purposes only.

"The whole subject of the proper way to keep provisions is worth investigating," said a housekeeper recently. "Since I have become a member of a class of domestic sci- ence I have been surprised to discover the number of kitchen traditions I have proved false. Only this morning, on opening the icebox, I found the steak for dinner lying directly on the ice, unprotected by plate or paper.
Wheat lost 1/4@3/8c with the West, and on small local realizing, with trading very dull.

The older inhabitants of that part of Brooklyn which was known as the village of Williamsburg fifty years age are just now indulging in reminiscences of the days when Broadway was a country road, houses were few and far between, and the children played on the grassy banks of the river.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your editorial of to-day very properly calls attention to the fact that public bodies of our citizens should assist the Chamber of Commerce in its laudable endeavor to gain for the city a new method of rapid transit, more particularly from the nature of the opposition, which does not appear to come from those who have the true interests of the city at heart.

About 1,000,000 meals given at 5 cents per meal within the space of four months to poor unemployed persons is what the Industrial Christian Alliance, supported by the Business Men's Relief Committee, can boast of having done during the season of business depression and consequent want and destitution among many thousands of unemployed workingmen of this city.
The Society of American Fakirs held its fourth annual exhibition and sale of pictures yesterday afternoon in its rooms in the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

To-morrow night in all the Assembly districts of this city the Committee of Thirty's organizations will meet in convention, and will select delegates to the new Republican County Committee. It will be an interesting event in local politics, for the results of these various conventions will be the establishment of a new "machine."

Millions of capital, years at experience, and all the energy of legitimate enterprise are represented in a powerful industrial organization recently formed in Brooklyn. The body is known as the Manufacturers' Association of Kings and Queens Counties. Although less than three months in existence the association is already on a flourishing basis.

It has been currently reported the last week that ex-Mayor William R. Grace was willing to become the candidate of the New-York State Democracy for Mayor of this city. The following question was asked of Mr. Grace yesterday:

BALTIMORE, April 21. -- To-day's contest was remarkable in many ways, principally because the New-Yorkers were defeated for the third successive time. The home club put in a patched-up team, because of the illness of two men, and tried Inks in the box. The grounds were wet and slippery, yet but one fielding error was made.

NEW-CANAAN, Conn., April 21. -- On the pleasant tree-bordered highway known as Oenoke Avenue, in New-Canaan, is the Summer home of Dr. E.W. Lambert and his son, Dr. Alexander Lambert, of New-York City. The grounds surrounding this house are entensive and beautiful. One feature of the place in which father and son take particular pride is the stock of 250 lively little guinea pigs.

From The Troy Times, April 14. The prevailing opinion of the collar manufacturers is that trade is improving considerably, although not as good as that of last year at the same time. A prominent manufacturer said this morning that the falling off in the collar trade began about last June, and at present the trade is better than at any time since the dull period began.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 21. -- Vice President Robert Harris of the Northern Pacific Railway died in this city at noon to-day. Mr. Harris reached Rochester from the West at 9:20 this morning on the Chicago limited train. When the train arrived Mr. Harris was too ill to proceed further and he was removed to the City Hospital.

From The Chicago Tribune, April 13. Controller Ackerman expects to receive soon from the World's Fair corporation $245,595. Of this $20,000 is for water furnished to the fair by the city since the time the construction of the buildings was begun. The city's portion of the forthcoming fair dividend, at $1 a share, would be $500,000.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., April 21 -- The three-masted bark Elmiranda, 822 tons, coal laden, of Portland, Me., Capt. John Williams, came ashore off Wainscott, about one mile and a half west of Georgica life-saving station, about midnight. She is filled with water, and will be a total loss. The crew of ten men and the Captain's son were taken ashore in the breeches buoy by the life savers of Georgica and Meco.

The Secretary of the Health Board of the town of Montclair, N.J., has issued an official statement regarding the cases of typhoid fever in that town. Although he says that this is justified by a "misapprehension of all the facts" and "a willful distortion of some," the statement is a substantial confirmation of all that has been reported in our columns in regard to the matter.

"About this time" the wives of farmers in the Eastern, Middle, and Western Stated, although there is no admonition in the family almanacs to that effect, begin to "look out for tramps." It is perhaps a little early. As a rule the tramp hibernates in towns, and his hibernation continues until the Spring rains are over and the mud has dried so as to make walking feasible.

Do you know, for instance, what "jackaling" is in New-York? A jackal is a man generally of good address and capable of a display of good-fellowship, combined with much knowledge of literature and art, and a vast and intimate acquaintance with writers, musicians, and managers. He makes it his business to haunt hotels, theatrical agencies, and managers' offices, and to know whenever, in his language, "a new jay comes to town."

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Quotations were fairly steady during the single session, although trading, as usual of late, was restricted to West Chicago, Lake Street, and a few of the industrials. West Chicago opened 3/8 off, at 153, and closed 1/8 lower, at 152 7/8. Lake Street was firmer, and sold liberally at 21 3/4, but weakened toward the close to 21 1/2.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- A conference took place at the Treasury Department this morning on Bering Sea matters between Sir Julian Pauncefote and Secretary of State Gresham and Secretary of the Treasury Carlisle. The conference lasted about two hours.

A fine scope for the use of the critical faculty is offered by subjects so diverse as Charles Sumner and Robert Burns, the battle of Gettysburg, and President Garfield. Had our confidence in Mr. Curtis's power to cover such a range with adequate knowledge and fullness of resource needed reinforcement, we should find it provided in the fourteen selections from his addresses that comprise this volume.

The plan of the present rulers of the Hawaiian Islands for the establishment of a permanent Government is an exquisite illustration of their ideas on the subject of "popular institutions." It will be remembered how the present provisional Government was set up. There was and has been no popular vote.

The long-talked-of "Cinderella," the fairy extravaganza by Oscar Barrett and Horace Lennard, which ran through the Winter at Henry Irving's Lyceum Theatre in London, will have its first production here at Abbey's Theatre to-morrow night. In all 196 persons are used in the piece, of whom 140 have been brought from London by Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, including all the principals and most of the chorus and ballet.

New-York's Old Guard covered itself with glory yesterday. It was the sixty-eighth anniversary of the organization of the body which has been known under various names, but since 1868 as the Old Guard of the City of New-York.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 21. -- The Masonic bodies in this city have adopted plans for the largest and handsomest hall belonging to the order in this State. The structure will occupy an eligible site two blocks east from the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford station, and will be five stories in height, the ground dimensions being 60 by 100 feet.

The annual Spring renting is practically, though not entirely, a thing of the past, and, as far as this city is concerned, does not compare favorably in results with last year. Busines stagnation has been manifest in this direction as in others, and, besides this, recent events have induced a streak of economy even on the part of those having fixed incomes which remain in amount what they have hitherto been.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 21. -- About 3,000 people saw Yo Tambien defeat King Lee in a mile race here to-day. The race was an exercise gallop for her, and an easy gallop at that. King Lee came in second. Summaries:

The American Line steamship Paris, which arrived from Southampton yesterday, had a large number of passengers on board. It is the vessel's first trip since the one she began in January and did not complete. On that occasion she broke her rudder post soon after leaving port, and put back to Queenstown disabled.
"J.S. Coxey, Massillion, Ohio, Room 271," on the register of the Sturtevant House recorded yesterday the arrival in this city of the leader of the Commonweal.

The "local politics" of Troy have got into a bad way under the rule of the Murphy machine, but it is largely the fault of its own citizens, and they can apply the remedy under a sound system, if they will. It is a bad principle to legislate in haste to meet local and temporary, exigencies, and the effort to get sound methods applied in municipal government is hindered by making exceptions in such cases.

The opening trip of the coach Commonwealth, which is to run between the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club, on the Prospect Park Plaza, Brooklyn, was made yesterday, with Howard Gibb on the box. The start was made from the Riding and Driving Club at 3 P.M., and the coach was scheduled to return to the club and put the passengers down at 6 P.M.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 21. -- Four distinct thefts have taken place at the Yale gymnasium the last fortnight. Each time a watch and a pocketbook have been taken. Several articles of valuable jewelry have also been missed. To-night Boyd McLane, a sophomore, was arrested while trying to open one of the combination lockers.

NORTHPORT, L.I., April 21 -- J.H. Flagler's steam yacht Isolene of the New-York Yacht Club fleet was completely destroyed by fire in Northport Harbor this morning. The fire was discovered at 3 o'clock and continued until 10, when, burned to the water's edge, the yacht sank. All visible now are the masts, pilot house, and smokestack.

One boy, plus one gun, plus one spirit of teasing mischief, equals one dead girl. That is the way a sad tragedy of the past week could be stated algebraically, and that is the way more than one similar sad tragedy might have been stated many times in the past. Boys don't seem to learn by these awful happenings that a gun is to be approached as if it were an electric battery.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 21 -- A petition is being circulated asking for the pardon of John P. Trumpbour, who was sent to Auburn Prison for life in 1870 for the murder of Elijah Jones at Cold Spring. The crime was committed on July 27, 1870. Trumpbour was one of a gang of bandits who had their headquarters about Cold Spring.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- If the Senate Committee on Military Affairs should be called upon at this time for a report on all the bills in its possession it would find itself confronted with a serious task. There are many bills in its pigeon holes, some of them important, but the majority of no particular consequence to the country or to the army.

A demand for very high traps is the special feature that carriagemakers have had to comply with to suit a very finikin trade this Spring. Each driver of a cart that comes under the head of a "fancy turnout" seems to be possessed of a mania for getting up in the air as high as he can conveniently and at the same time drive a horse.

Herkimer, N.Y., April 21. -- Fire this morning did considerable damage to several places of business situated in a block owned by W.H. Prouse. The building was damaged $2,000. The Herklmer County Record plant was nearly ruined, and was Worth $5,000; Prouse Thomas, grocers, have $2,000 loss, and the American Order United Workmen lodge will lose $200.

The thirty-fourth Ladies' Day and eighth annual Art Loan Exhibition of the New-York Athletic Club was held yesterday afternoon. The clubhouse was crowded from noon until 8 o'clock in the evening. Forty-seven pictures were on exhibition, and were greatly admired. At 3:30 o'clock an entertainment was given in the gymnasium.

Senator Daniel Bradley does not despair of the passage of his bill to reform the management of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge. He believes that it will not only get through the Senate, but that it will secure the approval of Gov. Flower.

PARIS, April 4 -- Another Ibsenian performance at the Bouffes du Nord. "Solness le Constructeur," translated by the Count Prozor, was given last evening by M. Lugne-Poe and his company. To this came Mile. Wissocq, from the Odeon Theatre, for the part of Hilda.

HANOVER, N.H., April 21. -- Dartmouth College's baseball team was beaten by Harvard's nine here to-day by a score of 4 to 3. Rain fell just before the game, so that the diamond was slippery. The game, however, was a good one, and well played throughout. Dartmouth outplayed Harvard at almost every point, but the crimson boys had the good fortune to bunch their hits in the first inning.

Staten Island is enjoying a "boom." The exact reason for it not even the oldest inhabitants are able to decide. All agree that is well founded and long deserved, but why it has come just now or why it did not come long ago is the question in dispute.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 21 -- The swift advance of the Spring season brings the usual number of tourists, and it is not unusual to see upon the hotel registers the names of far Western and Southern cities side by side, with those of the Atlantic coast, while Canadian and European capitals are well represented.

GOSHEN, N.Y., April 21. -- The family of James Mapes live a mile from the limits of the town. Their father is an invalid veteran and has been cared for by the Grand Army of the Republic. This week a minister calling in the neighborhood stopped at the house and found a pitiable condition of affairs.

The ubiquitous newsboy and the patient and persevering New-York street car are going to part company. It will be a long, sad parting for the newsboy, but the street cars will go bowling gayly along without him.

From The Wilmington (Del.) Journal, (Dem.) In the current issue of The Weekly Times, New-York, appear further articles in the remarkable series of disclosures of Pension Frauds and abuses found by the representatives of The New-York Daily Times. These articles have aroused the widest interest, and to those who have read the previous "Pension Supplements" of The Weekly Times, it need hardly be said that the articles published this week are well worth, perusal.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 21. -- Of the 17,000 miners employed in the river and railway coal pits of the Pittsburg district, at least 15,000 quit work at noon to-day in compliance with the general strike order, and by Monday it is confidently expected that work throughout the entire district will be at a standstill.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., April 21 -- The opinion of leading men in all three parties regarding the situation in this State may startle the overconfident Republicans. The municipal elections this Spring are taken as an indication that there has been a revolution in political sentiment, that the voters are returning to the Republican fold.

Copyright, 1894, by S.S. McClure, Limited. The recurrence of Gen. Grant's birthday never falls to recall to the minds of those who were associated with him the many admirable traits of his character. A number of these traits, if not absolutely peculiar to him, were more thoroughly developed in his nature than in the natures of other men.

The many deaths in Brooklyn through the carelessness of the motormen running the deadly trolley cars has stirred up an intense feeling, and last night, when a great crowd of pedestrians witnessed the killing of a ten-year-old boy, they gave vent to their feelings and threatened to lynch the motorman.

CHAPTER IV -- FROM THE "FAR-OFF LAND." Sibyl's own particular retreat was in a tower at the southern angle of Ellerslie House, and it was one of the prettiest rooms in a house where beauty and harmony of furniture and decoration had been carried out regardless of cost and with the aid of all the new lights which high art have cast upon our household gods.

The resistance of the air is the one allsufficient fulcrum or basis on which every flying machine must rely. In the investigation of its laws something has been done by the study of the flight of birds, and the analysis of the results of instantaneous photographs of them, especially by modern French writers.

The Montauk Club of Brooklyn celebrated the birthday of Chauncey M. Depew at its clubhouse, in Eighth Avenue, last evening. This is the third year that Mr. Depew has been honored by the Montauk Club, and there were 200 guests who participated in the dinner after the informal reception that took place in the club's parlors.

The great coal strike begun at noon yesterday will, in the course of the next ten days, deprive nearly 200,000 coal miners of employment, besides thousands of persons in business dependent upon the coal trade.

It is a common saying that some people don't know when they are well off, common enough to be faulty for a better form would be that some people do know when they are well off, since the vast majority are included under the former statement. And certainly among these Harold Hendricks was numbered when a disquiet spirit of indefinite ambition not his own moved him to write a novel.

The most sanguine and ardent admirers of Lasker did not expect that he would break all records by winning four straights from Steinitz, and the supporters of the champion have now given up all hopes that he will retain the championship. From an analysis of the Teuton's games his forte has been simply taking advantage of mistakes made by Steinitz.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 21. -- At Corona, Walker County, this morning, 500 more miners joined those now on strike in this district. The situation at Blue Creek remains unchanged. One hundred imported negro laborers are still at work under the protection of Deputy Sheriffs, and the operators are making efforts to get more negroes.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- Steinitz lost his fifth consecutive game to Lasker in their chess match at the Union League Club to-day. Lasker opened with a P -- Q4, developing into a queen's gambit, which Steinitz declined. The game was very rapidly played.

Just because the hat and jacket of Miss Emma C. Everson, typewriter, hung in the office of Guy C. Dempsey, lawyer, Miss Lavinia Dempsey, sister of the lawyer, lost her temper quite, and as a result she is defendant in a suit for $10,000, brought by Miss Everson.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- General debate on the Tariff bill will close next Wednesday, and visitors to the Senate chamber will be very glad. Every day this week the spectacle has been presented of members of the upper house reading from manuscript to an array of empty seats. Yesterday Mr. Gallinger had an audience of three or four Senators, and at one time not a single Democratic Senator was in the chamber.

-- Mr. Gill of Springfield, Mass., has made another active and successful campaign in that city with paintings by American artists. His late exhibition had work by 90 artists, of whom 30 sold pictures. More than one-third of the 127 pictures in the gallery found purchasers. "Not in It," by J.G. Brown, went for $1,500, and his "Sunday Morning" for $1,200.
The weekly bank statement issued yesterday showed an increase in reserve of $1,177,025. The banks now hold $82,008,025 in excess of the legal requirements.

This work, though not new to print, will be new to most readers. Published originally in Washington by Tone's son about seventy years ago, it has always been known to students of the period which it covers, but to the great body of readers it long since ceased to be a familiar book. Mr. O'Brien's title page does not read exactly as it should.

County Treasurer Henry H. Adams of Kings County is still unable to explain the deficit of $21,643.15 in the accounts of his office. He has, so he claims, been endeavoring to get at the fact since the death of the late Deputy Treasurer James Gardiner, who, by the way, died at the residence of Mr. Adams.

From Advance Sheets of the May Forum, by Permission. Confidence returns with the vetoof Bland's measure, but stagnation of business continues. It is reflected by an increasing accumulation of idle capital and rates of interest lower than ever prevailed in this country for so long a time.

The auction sales of real estate in Brooklyn during the past week amounted to $138,326, as compared with $134,895 for the corresponding week in 1893. The mortgages recorded were 212 in number, for $722,266, of which 105, for $441,934, were at 5 per cent, or less. In the corresponding week last year there were recorded 834 mortgages, for $1,141,525, of which 261, for $832,597, were at 5 per cent, or less.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 21. -- A mysterious case is being settled at the Tontine Hotel here. Leila M. Bronson of Adams, N.Y., and Mary McNellis of Chicago arrived there at different hours last night. To-day Miss McNellis said that she came to collect a bill of $400 for services rendered Miss Bronson.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Theodore Davenport of Stamford, Conn., late disbursing officer of the Post Office Department, owes the Government $3,841.01, and the sureties have been notified to make good the amount. Mr. Davenport ceased being disbursing officer of the Post Office Department in May last, having occupied the position for several years prior to that time.

The lobster does not range far south on our Atlantic coast, because it is sandy south of New-Jersey, and does not afford protection for them when in the soft state, even if other conditions were favorable. Large individuals are sometimes taken on the coasts of Delaware and Maryland, and they range as far north as Labrador, the best lobster grounds of the Atlantic being Nova Scotia and Maine.

This is not a particularly happy year for demagogues. The industrial and political conditions of the country for the most part concur toward the exposure and rejection of demagogues. Of all the demagogues none is put in a worse plight than Gov. Tillman of South Carolina.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 21. -- The bondholders' representatives of the Ashley faction finished the business of what they hold to be the bona fide meeting of the stockholders of the Ann Arbor Railroad to-day. They elected a Board of Directors, as follows: Amos N. Eno, John Jacob Astor, George N. Quintard, Edward Simons, Robert M. Gallaway, Ernest Dickman, H. Livingston Rogers, Alfred De Cadova, Charles E. Quincy, T.W. Childs, and E.S. Kisham.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., April 21 -- About 200 Hungarians and Italians employed in the woolen mills here refused to return to work, and have threatened violence to all who attempted to take their places. Richard Cody was sworn in to protect from violence the operatives who remained at work.
Henry E. Schwarz has purchased the Eldorado grounds, buildings, and appurtenances at Eldorado, and is making arrangements to give a series of attractive entertainments there this Spring and Summer.

We are told that steamships cannot imitate the movements of the porpoise, that his motion is a question of fluid displacement and "stream line" action or effect, due to the sinuous inflections of his body, and of his tail especially. This is partly true, and it is not here contended that we can make ships with flexible backbones like a fish, and give them a fish-like motion.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., April 21 -- An exciting race took place here this afternoon between a runaway horse owned by J.W. Willetts, a baker, and Ray Wells, a sixteen-year-old telegraph messenger. Wells was monuted on his bicycle. In the wagon was the baker's three-year-old child.

BERLIN, April 21. -- The decision of the Parliamentary Commission against the wine and tobacco taxes is not conclusive, although Dr. Miquel's opponents have hastily pronounced it to be so. The Government was disappointed but not disheartened by the adverse verdict of the majority.

PARIS, Monday, April 2 -- Always a pretty sight, the annuel concert of our delightful New-Orleans pianist and composer. Edouard Dejan. After a Winter of many lessons and constant musicales, in the early Spring of violets and fresh green leaflets, he gives one recital. Only one, and that one crowded and perfect in every respect.

ORANGE, N.J., April 21 -- The people of Orange and vicinity are much interested at present in the scheme for the establishing of public parks. A bill is now being prepared for presentation to the Legislature creating a non-partisan commission, to whom this great public improvement shall be intrusted.

Carl and Theodor Rosenfeld yesterday addressed an open letter to Elbridge T Gerry, President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, protesting against his strictures on "Hannele," the play scheduled for production at the Fifth Avenue Theatre to-morrow night. The Messrs. Rosenfeld deny emphatically that the play is "impious, blasphemous, and immoral," as alleged by Mr. Gerry.

From The London Telegraph. Prof. Herkomer, R.A., the distinguished painter, etcher, carver, lecturer, actor, musician -- what, Indeed, is he not? -- has discovered that there is a "very evil thing" abroad. It looks beautiful in the shop windows; it is, as a matter of fact, extremely attractive in its way, but it is cheap, and it has taken the place of the artist.

When President McMillan and Fred Gerken of the Driving Club of New-York went over to Philadelphia last Friday to meet Frank Bower of the Belmont Club of Philadelphia and Robert Hough of the Pimlico track of Baltimore they took with them designs for the four silver challenge cups to be given as prizes in the inter-city races for amateur drivers, for approval.

Whether office holders shall be excluded from party committees and nominating conventions is a question that seriously disturbs the Republican politicians of Kings County. The sub-committee of the County Committee on Rules and Order is considering resolutions to that effect, and they will be reported to the full committee at its next meeting, on May 8.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Librarian Spofford, with the enlarged visions of usefulness opened up by the prospect of the completion, in the near future, of the new Congressional Library -- by far the finest building of the kind in the world -- has suggested the transplanting to American soil of a scheme analogous to that under which the "Immortals" of the French Academy hold sway in France in literature and art.

ALBANY, April 21 -- There was an abun- dance of news in the last week relating to local securities. The most important was the announcement that the Union Railway Company of New-York, as lessees of the Westchester Electric Railroad, had completed the negotiations for franchises which will enable it to run trolley cars from One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street to New-Rochelle.

Some very interesting chapters in the history of sugar tariffs have been overlooked recently by our Republican friends. While sharply criticising the treatment of the sugar schedule by the Democratic tariff makers of the Senate they have conveniently forgotten the shameful record made four years ago.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $1,177,025. The banks now hold $82,008,025 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans of $2,130,000, a decrease in specie of $1,178,900, an increase in legal tenders of $3,864,100, an in- crease in deposits of $6,032,700, and a decrease in circulation of $369,000.

CONEY ISLAND, April 22 -- The newly-appointed Chief of Police, James Eustace, presided at Police Headquarters to-day. There was little for him to do aside from the routine duties, as the 15,000 people who came here were very quiet and orderly.

As was exclusively announced in The New-York Times yesterday, newsboys will hereafter not be allowed to ply their calling on the surface cars of the First, Second, Third, and Fourth Avenue lines, nor will they will be allowed on the cars of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company.

When Mayor Schieren was interviewed the other day by George F. Elliott, representing the Brooklyn Temperance League, he said he would see that the excise laws were properly enforced. At the meeting of the league, held in Bradbury Mission Hall, Willoughby and Raymond Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday, the speakers said they wanted the law enforced, and that was all.

TRENTON, April 22. -- The military court of inquiry which has been ordered by Gov. Werts to investigate charges made by former members of the First New-Jersey Brigade will be convened on Wednesday afternoon next, at 5 o'clock, in the armory of the Fourth Regiment, in Jersey City.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 22. -- Walter L. Bragg, son of the late Inter-State Commerce Commissioner, and Dr. Jesse Naftel had a misunderstanding last night at the theatre, where Senator Morgan spoke. They did not know each other, but had seats close together. Naftel spoke to Bragg, claiming that he was obstructing his view of the stage and speaker.

Seventy lives might have been imperiled by a fire which was discovered in the cellar of the five-story tenement 28 East Broadway early yesterday morning. The police of the Seventh Precinct say that the fire came of criminal scheming, and that Hyman Blumenthal, a peddler, who is twenty-nine years old and of 204 Forsyth Street, who is under arrest, is the incendiary.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 22. -- The mysterious Miss McNellis-Miss Bronson case developed another sensation to-day. Miss McNellis, the private detective at whose instigation Miss Bronson was yesterday arrested on the charge of fraud, to-day remarked to a newspaper man: "I'll shoot the next reporter who tries to interview me."

Of all the decorations at the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, East Third Street, near Avenue A, the Stars and Stripes were most prominent yesterday, on the occasion of the celebration of the church's golden jubilee. With the red, white, and blue was displayed also the German flag.

When Capt. Hardy was entertained by the ingenuous youths of St. Ambrose he speedily let loose the information that in his old age he had studied Greek, and a moment later he propounded his favorite riddle, namely, the handling of triremes. He could not for the life of him see how speed enough for ramming was obtained with such cumbrous oars as these vessels must have had.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 -- The commencement exercises of the Princeton Theological Seminary will be held Tuesday, May 8. One of the largest classes which has yet been in the seminary will be graduated then. Sixty-three are expected to receive diplomas, seventeen of whom are Princeton men. The preliminary exercises will be conducted on May 6, Sunday, by the Rev., Dr. Gosman of Lawrenceville, N.J.
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, April 22. -- Gen. Kelly made an address to his forces last night, in which he prophesied that blood would be shed before the army should reach its destination.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22 -- There has been a great boom in bicycling in this city his Spring. Never have so many wheels been out pleasant days, and not before has there been so much preparation for road runs and racing meets.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22. -- It is reported here to-night that a reconciliation has been effected between Princess Colonna and her husband and that the Princess will soon sail for Europe to rejoin the Prince.

Our Albany dispatches this morning contain interviews with two delegates to the State Constitutional Convention from the extreme Western end of the State, exSenator McMillan and Mr. Tracy Becker, both of Buffalo, in which they give some interesting opinions of what will or ought to be done at the convention.

"Gen," J.S. Coxey, Commander-in-Chief of the "Army of the Commonweal," gave evidence that the dime museum managers of this city have not yet added him to their assortment of freaks by making preliminary arrangements yesterday to depart from the metropolis this afternoon.

Nelson Jarvis Waterbury died last evening at his home, 13 West Fifty-sixth Street, of pneumonia, after an illness of three days. He caught cold Wednesday while attending to business at his law office, 32 Nassau Street, and it settled in his lungs. Dr. Loomis and Dr. Bartholow of Philadelphia were called to attend him.

The Thirteenth Regiment will assemble in the armory, at Flatbush Avenue and Hanson Place, Brooklyn, at 8:20 to-night and be reviewed by the veterans of the regiment. Then the Thirteenth will march out of its old home, never to return. It will go through Hanson Place, Cumberland Street, Lafayette Avenue, to Throop Avenue, and up Putnam Avenue to its new armory, in Sumner Avenue.

The students from Hampton School, Virginia, an Indian and four negroes, who are in this city, accompanied by Dr. H.B. Frissell, Principal of the school, held their first meeting at the Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday afternoon. They are to be in the city for a week, during which time similar meetings will be held in different churches.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 22. -- Both junior and senior argumentative societies held debates April 14. The junior "T. and M. House of Commons" decided, by a close vote, that woman suffrage be established in New-York State, while Qui Vive decided by a large majority that "higher education unfits man for matrimony."

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The War Department has heard from Mr. John B. Ketchum, to whose business of "aiding" the United States Army at 82 Nassau Street, New-York City, the officials have objected. He does not ener into any correspondence with the department, but sends two marked copies of newspapers.

BOSTON, April 22. -- Pandemonium raged on the Common to-day, pademonium that ran dangerously near the verge of full-fluedged riot. During its height the New-England delegation of the Industrial Army made its escape from the midst of 50,000 excited men and singly started for Roxbury. This was not, however, until their banner had been torn to fragments and several of them had been pretty severely handled.

The prevalence of cholera in Constantinople may induce the Sultan to follow the suggestions of the Sanitary Conference recently held in Paris as to the reorganization of the Turkish sanitary administration and to pay some little attention to the resolutions of the conference relating to the Turkish lazarettos or quarantine stations on the Red Sea.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 22 -- A new effort is being made by the different classes of Cornell University to raise money for the erection of an athletic clubhouse. The plan was first originated by the class of '92, which left some $500 as a class memorial fond. This sum has been increased from time to time, and on the death of George Witherbee a memorial fund was started for a Witherbee memorial clubhouse.

PROVIDENCE, April 21. -- The local stock market has shown few sales during the week. Stocks are still closely held, but the demand has in a measure fallen off. The bank stock list shows but little change. Rhode Island National Bank has been sold at 27 1/4, and for the rest of the list no sales were reported.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 22. -- The headquarters of the United Mine Workers of America here were locked up to-day, and there were no signs that under the direction of the organization the greatest strike in the history of the coal-mining industry of this country had just been inaugurated. President John McBride was found by the United Press representative at his home, reading newspaper accounts of the strike.

The only Sunday night concert of the Metropolitan Opera House supplementary season took place last night. The large auditorium was crowded to the doors, and those present had armed themselves with a large supply of enthusiasm. It was an audience of most catholic taste, and showered its applause on all kinds of music from the most old-fashioned aria di bravura, to Wagner of the extreme period.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 22. -- A novel arctic expedition is to be undertaken the coming Summer. It is to be a combined exploration and pleasure trip to Greenland and the north seas by a shipload of college men, for the most part undergraduates. The number will be selected from the leading universities of the country and will be under the direction of Dr. F.A. Cook, ethnologist of the Peary expedition.

What is practically the opening of the Spring horse market takes place to-day. The sales back in the Winter months have been for breeders and seekers after horses for track purposes. Now comes the chance for persons who wish to obtain horses for driving and riding, for work in light or heavy harness, on the road, in the park, or for general use in the country, as well as for track purposes.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Interesting statistics given below tend to show the extent to which Americans own or charter vessels under foreign flags. Two hundred circulars of inquiry were sent out, and seventy-five replies have been received. Besides the nine ports named, San Francisco and Port Townsend were requested to furnish information, but have not yet replied.
CHICAGO, April 22. -- Ground will be broken for the Chicago and St. Louis Electric Railroad, it is said, on May 1. Twenty miles of the road from Alpine Heights into this city are to be built.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., April 22. -- Coxey has gone from the army, and Browne is quietly preparing, with very ill grace, to re- ceive him when he returns. The most im- portant development of the day was the proposed change of the route. As originally laid out, it carried the army from Frederick to Rockville by way of Ridgeville, twenty miles longer than by the old National Pike directly from Frederick to Rockville.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22 -- The Latin play, after a year of preparation, is a thing of the past as far as Harvard is concerned. Much stress has been laid upon the fact that the first production took place Thursday before a very distinguished audience, but in reality the dress rehearsal of Wednesday evening was as perfect as the performance of the following night, and was fully as public.

Last week's stock market gave operators on both the long and short accounts some employment, without effecting material changes in prices for the active securities. Chicago Gas, having been subjected to special manipulation, put buyers at an ad- vantage, netting them 5 1/2 per cent. advance for the week.
ATHENS, April 22. -- Reports from towns which suffered from the earthquakes of the last two days show that the loss of life and property is much greater than was at first supposed.

William D. Lohman, the defaulting ex-cashier of the Brooklyn Excise Department, was arrested in Toronto yesterday by Chief Constable William J. Gassett. He has been missing for three months. Lohman will probably arrive in Brooklyn to-morrow in charge of Detective Zundt.

PALATKA, Fla., April 22. -- The American Protective Association has been trying to get a foothold here for some time, and the attempt culminated in an affray this morning in which its agents were roughly handled. George Dunford, a Canadian, has been here several months representing the American Protective Association, and made remarks about the Catholic Church which aroused quite a prejudice against him.

Two thousand persons crowded into Niblo's Garden yesterday afternoon to hear the Rev. A.C. Dixon of the Hanson Place Baptist Church, Brooklyn, speak on "The Morals and Methods of Robert G. Ingersoll." The speaker's attack on the famous infidel evoked frequent and prolonged applause.

Last Monday evening the Columbia College Musical Society gave the last presentation of the musical burlesque entitled "Joan of Arc," in the Academy of Music, in Brooklyn. After the conclusion of the performance, the members of the cast were entertained by the Crescent Athletic Club.

The full text of the decision of the Supreme Court of South Carolina declaring the dispensary law unconstitutional enables us to get a clear idea of the grounds upon which it rests and which are of more than local interest and importance. We will endeavor to state these grounds as concisely as possible.

BALTIMORE, April 22. -- Mary Felber was arrested and given a hearing to-day and is held for the New-York authorities. She is charged with having stolen from Mrs. Dreyer, at Sea Cliff., L.I., diamonds, jewelry, and money to the amount of $1,000, most of which was recovered.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 22. -- Morristown, the home of many of New-York's best-known business men, is to have a Country Club, thus following the lead of those places which aim to be much gayer, but do not succeed in being as pleasant a place of residence as this old-fashioned town in the hills of New-Jersey.

"I am told," said Oscar Barrett, the composer of "Cinderella," as he sat in one of the offices of Abbey's Theatre yesterday, "that the American notion of a pantomime is entirely different from the class of entertainment to which 'Cinderella' belongs. I am told that the word pantomime is used here to express simply action, with no dialogue and no singing.

PARIS, April 22. -- Strenuous but vain efforts have been made all day to get bail for Count Elie of Talleyrand-Perigord, who was arrested for embezzlement. The story of his crime is substantially as follows:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 22 -- Spring athletics are fairly launched at Yale. Ball mine, crew, tennis players, and track athletes are practicing daily, and even a football squad is training for next Fall's games. Saturday the University of Pennsylvania players meet Yale for the first championship contest of the year.

Portsea, the Australian galloper that reduced the world's three-mile record to 5:23 1/2 in winning the championship stakes at Melbourne last month, is a small but strongly-made five-year-old horse, and in this race carried 131 pounds. He won by half a length from the three-year-old Light Artillery, 110 pounds.
"Science and Ethics" was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's lecture before the Society for Ethical Culture at Music Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, yesterday. He said:

The organized opposition by prominent women of Brooklyn Heights to woman suffrage has brought the campaign for that cause to a point which promises to have the effect, between now and the time of the meeting of the Constitutional Convention, in May, of ranging every thinking woman in the State openly on one side or the other of the question, "Shall woman vote?"

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22. -- The surprises of the week in baseball have been the fine batting of Paine and the steady fielding of McCarthy. Last year Paine was unable to get on the 'Varsity team on account of his poor work with the stick. This year, however, he has led the team in batting, and with Whittemore, the second baseman, has saved tie team from defeat in the Woven Hose and graduates games.

ALBANY, April 22. -- As soon as the Legislature shall leave the Capitol, the Assembly Chamber will be prepared for the use of the Constitutional Convention, which will begin its work on Tuesday, May 8. Places will have to be found for forty-seven more desks in order to assure accommodations for the 175 delegates.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 22. -- Edward L. Bryan picked up a corked bottle on the beach to-day, inside of which was a piece of paper with the following inscription:

The Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur preached last evening to a large and deeply-attentive congregation, in the Calvary Baptist Church, West Fifty-seventh Street, near Sixth Avenue, of which he is the pastor, on the subject of female suffrage. His text was Second Corinthians, viii., 14: "That there may be equality."

Ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt was as busy yesterday as is becoming a political "boss" who sees a half dozen of his pet measures awaiting action at the hands of Senators unbound by caucus action only a week before the session closes.

Heavy roads and gloomy, threatening skies spoiled many of the bicyclists' projected club runs yesterday. At all the clubhouses the men congregated early in the day, and many an anxious glance searched for some break in the gray mantle of fog and cloud. Rather than go entirely without a spin of some sort, the members stole away in twos and threes, though even when the weather cleared no long runs were attempted.

PITTSBURG, April 21. -- The local stock trade rounded out the best week in some years to-day. Money continues easy, and all signs point to further easement for margin purposes as Summer approaches. Prices are higher, not alone for stocks, but bonds, and in some instances the records are the best in the history of the corpora- tions.
Silver bullion certificates were not quoted during the week.

ELMIRA, N.Y., April 23. -- The man who wrote the report which Commissioner Litchfield signed and which the Board of Charities adopted at the end of the State Reformatory investigation, put evidence into it which is strongly in favor of the management of the institution, although it was not so intended.

LONG ISLAND CITY, April 23 -- The General Improvement Commission of this city, that awarded nearly $500,000 worth of contracts for public improvements to District Leader-Police Commissioner-Contractor-Lawyer John C. Sheehan of New-York, is not having plain sailing in the prosecution of the work.

Since last Winter hay, fuel, blankets, harness, , valued at $2,000, have been stolen from Henry Freeman's moving van stables, at 358 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street, but no clue to the thieves was discovered until Sunday night. Detectives saw Constantus Heoty, otherwise "Dead Eye Dick," carrying three bags of oats into an Italian grocery, in a basement on Third Avenue, near One Hundred end Ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- In the absence of news bearing on the tariff situation, the rumor mungers have been quite active in the last week. The reference by Mr. Hill to the Mills bill gave them a new topic, and since then there has been more or less talk about the possibility of the Mills bill being substituted for the one now under discussion.

LONDON, April 23. -- The usual St. George's Day banquet was given this evening at the Mansion House. Many colonial and Indian representatives were present. The Lord Mayor proposed a toast to United States Ambassador Bayard.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Local stock values suffered a further decline to-day. At the opening the market was extremely dull, but with the close of the early call a brisk selling movement developed, which quickly carried down quotations. West Chicago, as usual, was the most active stock of the day. Opening sales were made at 155 1/2, against a close on Saturday of 152 7/8.

This city has a brand new Republican "machine" with which T.C. Platt has nothing to do. It came into existence last night, when under the direction of the Committee of Thirty the regular Republicans in every Assembly district held conventions and elected delegates to the new Republican County Committee.

The trip on the public coach Tempest, between the Hotel Brunswick and the Country Club, Westehester, was made yesterday by the guests of C.A. Baldwin. The start was made promptly at 11 A.M., and the return to the Brunswick at 5:30 P.M. Among those on the coach were Mr. and Mrs. K. Riggs, Alexander Taylor, Jr., Elisha M. Fulton, Jr., Mrs. Laudenburg, Mr. Pooten, and Mr. Baldwin, Francis T. Underhill was the whip.
The investigation of the accounts of the Sherman Bank, Broadway and Eighteenth Street, was practically finished yesterday afternoon.
ROME, April 23. -- The Bishop of Autun, France, has been elevated to the Cardinalate.

BLUEFIELDS, M.R., Nicaragua, April 18, via New-Orleans, April 23, per steamship Clinton. -- Since the departure of the San Francisco for Port Limon to coal and send a report to the Navy Department of the situation here, there have been some exciting events which, although no bloodshed has yet been precipitated, has caused a great deal of uneasiness.

LONDON, April 23 -- Emile Carnot alias Guiseppe Fornara, the Anarchist, who was arrested on Sunday, was arraigned in the Bow Street Police Court this morning. Carnot admitted that he was an accomplice of Francis Polti, and upon being further questioned, made a full confession of the plots in which he and Polti were engaged.

BOSTON, April 23 -- The market was weak and inactive to-day, in sympathy with New-York. Some of the land stocks reappeared at a little lower figures. Boston and Albany and the other investment stocks were the only strong features. The Treasurer of the Chicago and West Michigan denies that the road has taken in the Toledo and South Haven, as reported from the West.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Stocks were pressed for sale to-day throughout the active list. Lehigh Valley suffered from the bad condition of the coal trade. Reading, from the mass of figures submitted in regard to its affairs in place of the enlightenment desired, and Northern Pacific, from reports of earnings.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Much amazement has been expressed here to-day by those who have read the speech made by Senator Morgan at Montgomery on Saturday night. His business was supposed to be to stir up the Democrats of the State, so that they would enter upon the campaign for the Governorship and the Legislature with more unanimity of feeling.

The polo players are making extensive preparations for the coming polo season, and at present all of the teams in the vicinity are hard at work at practice play. The polo ground at the Meadowbrook Club is being rolled and put in condition, and at the Wetchester Country Club the same thing is going on.
The Board of Governors of the New-York Stock Exchange yesterday decided to prohibit that variety of business known as "arbitrage."

LONDON, April 23. -- A dispatch from Buenos Ayres says that Jabez Spencer Balfour, the absconding ex-Member of Parliament and ex-official of the Liberator Building Societies, has been taken before a Judge at Salta, Argentina, and released on nominal bail. It is expected that he will endeavor, to get out of the country, and English detectives are watching him.

Efforts are being made by the wheelmen of Philadelphia to revive the interest in the Newark-Philadelphia century run, and the event may take place this year. The Time Wheelmen, one of the most enterprising of the younger cycling organizations, feeling that the great annual event was about to be permitted to die out, have determined to make an effort to retain it as one of the features of local cycling.

The chief obstacle in the way of those who are striving in Brooklyn or else-where to have all liquor saloons closed on Sunday is the lack of a strong public sentiment in support of their efforts. There is, however, one point in our present excise law which they seem to have overlooked, when they report indignantly that they have found people passing in and out at the doors of Saloons.

"This is one of the most remarkable cases that has been brought to my notice since I have been in office," said Fire Marshad Mitchel, yesterday, referring to the attempt to fire the tenement house, 28 East Broadway, at midnight on Saturday, "and I hope to be able to convict all the persons concerned.

Special Customs Inspectors Brown and Donohue were at the pier when the passengers from the Tourraine, from Havre, were landed Saturday evening. As one of the passengers, who subsequently gave his name as Mr. Alexander, stepped, from the gang plank, he unbuttoned his coat to reach for the keys to his trunks.
ALBANY, April 23. -- In response to a resolution of the Senate, State Controller Roberts submitted to-night a statement showing the condition of the State Treasury, in which he says:

Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for J.D. Butler two lots on the north side of Seventy-second Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, for $90,000. The purchasers, one a well-known dry goods merchant and the other a banker, will build mansions on the lots.
TROY, N.Y., April 23. -- The following communication from the Committee of Public Safety of Troy was delivered to Gov. Flower this afternoon by a special messenger:

SCOTTDALE, Penn., April 23 -- Forty-five delegates, representing every work in the coke region, met in convention here to-day and voted to join in the general strike ordered by the United Mine Workers Sat- urday last.

Edward S. Stokes and his cousin, William E.D. Stokes, were of a party of lawyers and other interested persons who went before Sheriff Sexton in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday afternoon, when the legality of a Sheriff's jury, drawn from the third panel on April 16, was to be determined.

The trial of Ward Detective George T. Sheridan of the Church Street Station, who is charged with assaulting John J. Lynch and William Smith in a Cortlandt Street hotel on April 3, and who is also accused of neglect of duty in failing to suppress poolrooms which it is alleged were operated in Capt. O'Connor's precinct, was resumed before the Police Commissioners yesterday.

William D. Lohman, the absconding ex-cashier of the Brooklyn Excise Department, who was arrested in Toronto, Canada, on Sunday, is expected to arrive in Brooklyn in custody of Detective Sergeant Zundt today or to-morrow.

Absence of news rather than anything distinctly unfavorable operated upon yesterday's market. This condition suited the bears well enough, devices having failed them in open contests with facts as weapons. Their skill in rumor spreading, developed by long experience, was trained upon all subjects likely to affect prices.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The battle ship Indiana, although recently reported by her builders, the Cramps of Philadelphia, to be ready for her trial trip, in the opinion, of Capt. Bradford of the Inspection Board is not in such condition as to warrant her acceptance by the Government.

An ordinary Irish play, with eviction under the tenantry law as its text, and abundant filling of peasant wit and merriment, was brought out last night at the Fourteenth Street Theatre. It bears the title "Rory of the Hill," and as the author produces it with his own company, taking the chief part himself, his ideas of what the stage requires would seem to be in a fair way of expression.
CORONADO BEACH, Cal., April 23 -- Jesse Seligman of the firm of J. S. Seligman, bankers, of New-York and London, died at the Hotel del Coronado this morning.

CHICAGO, April 23. -- At a conference today of Mayor Hopkins, Health Commissioner Reynolds, and Chairman Madden of the Council Finance Committee, the Commissioner was given almost unlimited power to incur expense for the purpose of exterminating the threatened smallpox scourge.

The First Unitarian Society of Brooklyn will celebrate its semi-centennial in the church on Pierrepont Street to-day. The church was dedicated April 24, 1844, and the Rev. F.A. Farley was installed as the first pastor the following day. The special feature of the services will be the presence of the Rev. Dr. W.H. Furness, who is ninety-two years old, who preached the installation sermon for Dr. Farley, fifty years ago.

During the progress of certain plays the beholder laughs at frequent intervals, and often with considerable energy, but after it is all over he gravely decides that really, there was nothing funny about what he has seen and that to laugh was an altogether undignified and unnecessary proceeding; that most of what had for the moment the effect of wit was only folly, more or less antique, or vulgarity, considerably more than less manifest.

Good Government Club B, 70 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, passed resolutions last night protesting against the proposed cable railroad on One Hundred and Sixth Street, between Columbus and Manhattan Avenues, and on Manhattan Avenue between One Hundred and Sixth and One Hundred and Tenth Streets.

BOONESBOROUGH, Md., April 23. -- The Coxey army reached Boonesborough, Md., at 2 P.M., after an easy march down the pike from Hagerstown. A mile outside of town they were met by "Col." A.E. Redstone of Washington, who had come up to meet and consult with Browne.
The development of the movement in Brooklyn in opposition to the granting of the suffrage to women has brought out the fact that many women of New-York have been actively at work on the same line.

Neilson Browne's coach, the Vivid, having on board Col. and Mrs. Edward Morrell, J. Neilson Browne, B. Rittenhouse Miller, Harrison Canner, Edward Browing, and John C. Groome, who made the trip from Philadelphia to this city on Saturday, started on the return trip to Philadelphia from the Waldorf Hotel at 7:55 A.M. yesterday.

Lamplighter, the handicappers' favorite for the Brooklyn Handicap, reached the Gravesend track on Sunday afternoon, and yesterday had a five-furlong trial, going the distance in 1:08, and making the first half mile in 0:52 1/2. Lamplighter galloped with his legs bound up in red flannel, and showed no signs whatever of lameness.

ALBANY, April 23. -- Two incidents occurred in the Assembly this evening which would indicate that the closing days of the session are apt to be attended with scandal. They likewise indicate that the Manhattan Elevated Railway, through its lobby, can obtain whatever it pleases from the Assembly, either in killing measures detrimental to its plans or smothering them.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Senator Voorhees, Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Senate, who has been criticised in his own State for granting concessions in the pending Tariff bill, has just replied to some of these criticisms in a long letter to John B. Stoll of South Bend, Ind., in the course of which he says:

BOSTON, April 23 -- The Harvard inter-class track athletic games for the Wells Cup took place this afternoon on Holmes Field, Cambridge, in the presence of many spectators. The cup was held by '94 this year, and the interest among the classes as to the winner to-day was quite intense.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- There is much comfort to Senators and those whose duties call them to the Senate chamber in the fact that at 5 o'clock to-morrow the agreement by which general debate has been had upon the Tariff bill will cease to be in effect, and the bill will become then subject to amendment.

The opening sale of Tattersalls trotting department at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, was not a brilliantly successful one. The trouble was that the horses were not up to the marks for animals to sell in the New-York market. That applies to the consignment as a whole, and not to all the individuals, for there were some good animals in the lot, and they fetched good strong prices.

There has been nothing more pertinent said or done concerning the threatened convergence upon Washington of the "armies" of tramps than the proclamation of the Commissioners of the District of Columbia, nor is any such thing likely to be said or done. It is an admirable, dignified, and lucid exposition of the ground which all reasonable men and good citizens must occupy in respect to the demonstrations of the armies.

-- One of the foremost and most enthusiastic yachtsmen of Yonkers is Commodore Alanson J. Prime, who was the prime mover in the organization of the Yonkers Corinthian Yacht Club, which was made up of old members of the Yonkers Yacht Club, which is also still in vigrous life. The Corinthians, however, have the most complete clubhouse on the Hudson River front of Westchester County.

The report that reached New-York two or three days ago that there would undoubtedly be a reconciliation between the Princess Colonna and her husband was emphatically denied by Princess Colonna's father, John W. Mackay, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- President Cleveland's enemies do not hesitate to make capital against him, even out of the discussions touching the coming of that aggregation of persons known as "Coxey's Army." He has been described to-day as very much concerned about the coming of Coxey and his crew, and as being about to issue a proclamation against them, impelled by fear of personal danger.

The Linscott road race this year promises to be one of the big events in Boston cy- cling. Preparations are being made for a most successful race, and entries are expected from all parts of the country. There will be three special time prizes, the first being a one-hundred-dollar diamond to the man making the fastest time; a fifty-dollar-diamond for the second, and a twenty-five-dollar diamond for the third fastest time made.

LONDON, April 23. -- The House of Commons debated the budget this evening. After approving the increase of the income tax by 1 penny on the pound and a few other details of the Government proposals, the House adjourned the debate.

At the meeting of the New-York Presbytery yesterday in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, the appeal of the Scotch Church against the decision of the Session declining to permit the election of four Elders of the church came up for trial. The Rev. Dr. Howard Duffield was in the chair as Moderator.

Jesse Seligman came to this country in the steerage of a sailing vessel, landing at Castle Garden on July 6, 1840. In an address delivered in 1891 before the Board of Directors of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum of this city, of which he was the President, Mr. Seligman gave a picturesque description of his first day's experience on American soil.

The Anti-Compulsory Vaccination League of Brooklyn, which was recently formed in that city, will hold a meeting on Friday evening, at 515 Fulton Street, when measures will be determined upon to fight against the authority of the Health Department. The members of the league, who number about fifty, and among whom are many physicians, claim that the Health Department violates the American Constitution when it forcibly compels persons to submit to vaccination.

PARIS, April 23 -- The National Society of Fine Arts has stolen a march on the Society of French Artists this year, and the Champs de Mars Salon opens a week before the old, or Champs Elysee Salon. The public will be admitted to the new Salon on Wednesday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 23 -- After having been in the possession of one family nearly two hundred years, the George Clark lands, in the town of Pine Plains, will be sold at public sale to-morrow, the property to be disposed of including about 1,300 acres. This is the last of the George Clark land in Dutchess County.

There are two great events in the year for the Players Club -- Founder's Day, which they celebrate in true Bohemian style, and Ladies' Day, with which the Players do honor annually to the birthday of Shakespeare. Ladies' Day was omitted last year on account of the illness of Edwin Booth, the honored founder and President of the club, who passed away within a short time.

Petersburg, Penn., April 23. -- The general stores of J.J. Gillam Co. and R.A. Laird, and the new house of Calvin Bell were destroyed by fire early this morning, together with all their contents. The fire was started by burglars, who, after robbing Gillam Co.'s store, applied a lighted match to a barrel of coal oil. Total loss, $16,500; insurance, $7,500.

The financial community was much interested in the analysis of the figures of the Reading reports presented in The Times yesterday. It afforded an insight into the management of the property which the average reader could not possibly extract from the mass of confusing figures which go to make up the reports.

The London Lyceum Christmas Pantomime was very popular this year, because the Lyceum had not had a pantomime, or Christmas fairy play, since Irving has been its manager. A pantomime on the stage reserved, above all others, for Shakespeare and the poetic drama, was a new thing for the new generation.

If a large increase in the number of riders and drivers seen in Central Park is indicative of a proportionately increased interest in these pleasurable outdoor exercises, then it may be said that riding and driving in New-York have taken a great stride forward. Scarcely a fine day has passed during the past few weeks that the roads in Central Park have not been filled with well-appointed equipages, and the bridle paths with stylishly-mounted equestrians.
"This is the Cold Thirteen," said Alderman Leich in the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Maryland and Virginia oyster war was decided by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day, Justice Field announcing the opinion. The case under consideration was the appeal of Robert L. Wharton vs. John H. Wise, Sheriff of Accomac County, Va.

ALBANY, April 23 -- The Republican Senators held a caucus in the Senate Library this evening, Which lasted until after mid-night. All the Senators were present. The bills discussed were the Sheriff's Salary, the Bi-Partisan Police Commission, and the bill allowing the Mayor to remove all the heads of departments.

ALBANY, April 24. -- If Thomas C. Platt expected to get, by the appointment of a conference committee on the New-York City Non-Partisan Police bill, what his trusted lieutenants in the Assembly failed to secure, his disappointment over the result of the meeting of this committee this afternoon must indeed have been great.

Improbable and even revolting as it may appear, the Tammany Dock Commissioners are right and the Good Government Clubs are wrong in regard to the bill making the contract system compulsory in Dock Department work.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Senate Committee on inter-State Commerce this morning ordered a favorable report to be made on the nomination of James D. Yeomans of Iowa to be a member of the InterState Commerce Commission. This action was taken on a unanimous vote. The nomination has been hanging in the air for some weeks, and it was said that there were charges filed against Yeomans.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The market opened weak all along the line. Trading, however, was active from start to finish, with interest again centred principally in West Chicago. This stock closed last night at 148 1/2 and first sales this morning were made at a decline of 1 1/2 points. The bears started in to raid the market, offering the stock down half a point at a time, until 145 1/2 was reached.

The Sherman Bank has passed through the ordeal of examination successfully, and this morning it will resume business, retaining the Central National Bank as its agent at the Clearing House. This was settled yesterday, when Bank Superintendent Preston finished his work.

Umpire O'Rourke did not play any important part in the Brooklyn-Philadelphia game yesterday. The Brooklyns made the errors, and the Philadelphias did the rest. From the first inning it was evident that the Quakers would win. They began by hitting the ball hard, and never stopped until the last inning.
