Both Kennedy and Korwan were pounded lively, particularly the latter.

-- The competition for a wall painting to be given to New-York by the Municipal Art Society stirs The Philadelphia Times to remarks concerning the shortcomings of that city in the matter of the fine arts. It is true that Philadelphia is well off for industrial schools, and has in the Pennsylvania Academy and the Art Club two organizations that do much for art.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- A mass meeting of Commonweal recruits was held to-day in the barracks at North Avenue and Ralston Street. Company officers were elected and it was decided to start on the journey to Washington next Saturday morning.

ALBANY, April 24 -- One of the most interesting disturbances developed by this session of the Legislature is that which has brought to the front Louis F. Payn of Chatham Four Corners, Columbia County, and Hamilton Fish of Garrison's, Putnam County. Formerly Mr. Fish was in the Senatorial and Congressional districts which Mr. Payn, with the assistance of Gen. John H. Ketcham of Dover Plains and Thomas C. Platt, regulated.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The selection of Senator Mills to make the closing speech in the general debate on the Tariff bill was fully justified by the superb effort made to-day by that capable advocate of tariff reform.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The death today of William McGarrahan, who for forty years has been endeavoring to secure, by the aid of Congress, the recognition of his claim to the lands Panoche Grande, in California, and who has met every reverse with a steadfast confidence in eventual success that has won for him almost general admiration and sympathy, is mourned by every person of the thousands who have known him in this city.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Tariff bill will enter upon the amendment stage tomorrow at 1 o'clock. When Mr. Mills concluded his speech to-day general debate ceased by common consent, and the Senate turned its attention to other matters.

There was a happy little gathering at Christ's Mission, 142 West Twenty-fifth Street, yesterday morning, when the Rev. Edward J. Parker of London, England, known as the Singing Evangelist, was married to Miss Jennie A. Forsyth of White Plains, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Secretary Herbert to-day received a cablegram from Capt. Watson of the San Francisco, dated at Port Limon, Costa Rica, yesterday, stating that he would return to Bluefields at once. It is said that a dispatch was sent to Capt. Watson Saturday acknowledging his first message, but giving him no additional instructions.

The Police Board decided yesterday to try Capt. Edward Slevin of the Oak Street Police Station, under charges made by Commissioner MacLean of neglect of duty in failing to suppress disorderly places in his precinct. Friday was fixed as the date of the trial. Similar charges made by Mr. MacLean against Capt. Frederick W. Martens of the East Thirty-fifth Street Police Station were disapproved.

Five years ago, through the exertions of Frank R. Lawrence, at that time Grand Master of Masons in the State of NewYork, the Masonic fraternity of the State was freed from the burden of an enormous debt which for years had borne heavily upon the fraternity and hindered its prosperity.

BOSTON, April 24 -- The trading here today in local specialties has been somewhat larger than for a little time back. Bay State Gas bonds; firsts and seconds, were slightly higher. The Lamson Store Service Company will hold its annual meeting on May 17. The stocks, which has lately been quite active at advancing prices, acts a little as though any favorable action which may be forthcoming at the annual meeting had been fully discounted.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 24 -- Business in local manufactories continues to improve. Yesterday morning L. Candee Co., manufacturers of rubber goods, started their factory after five weeks' idleness. A thousand hands obtained work, and in about a fortnight it is expected that the entire force of 1,500 operatives will again be at work.

From The Hudson Register, (Dem.) The New-York Times, which has been showing up in detail the fraudulent character of a great deal of the pension business, rendered especially valuable service to the country yesterday by turning a flood of light upon the system as a whole, and thus revealing its deformities in a glaring way that cannot but arrest the attention of even the most indifferent or incredulous.

The joint auction sale of trotting horses by the trotting department of Tattersalls was continued at Madison Square Garden yesterday, and, with the produce of R.S. Veech's Indian Hill Farm and John E. Green's Glenwood Farm under the hammer, it was expected that good prices would be realized. The bidding was not up to the expectations of the consignors, however, and, with few exceptions, the prices brought were only moderate.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- With Neilson Brown of Philadelphia as whip and John C. Groome on the box seat alongside him, the coach Alert of the Suburban left the Walderf Hotel at 7:48 this morning for the run of 110 miles to this city. It was an invitation trial trip made for the first time in the schedule that will hereafter be adhered to so long as the coach runs.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Lieut. W.H. H. Southerland, United States Navy, has received a deserved compliment from Secretary Herbert and Assistant Secretary McAdoo. He has been on duty as Naval Aide to the Assistant Secretary of the Navy since July, 1889. His tour of shore duty expired some months ago, but he had been so valuable to the Assistant Secretary that Mr. McAdoo asked that he be continued on duty in the department.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24. -- On a wet field to-day Harvard beat Dartmouth 5 runs to 2 at baseball. Huff made a home run for Dartmouth, and Highlands a twobagger for Harvard. Stevenson played poorly at short. Dartmouth fielded well, but could not hit Highlands. Score:

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Executive Committee of the National Republican League held a secret session of about three hours to-day, after which the leading members left for New-York City, where a meeting will be held Thursday, which the principal officers and members of the State Leagues throughout New-England and the Middle States will attend.

Mr. Spofford, the amiable and accomplished Librarian of Congress, desires, very naturally and properly, to signalize the completion of the new building for that collection by founding an "institution," and he desires that this institution should take the form of an American analogue to the French Academy.

Ludgar Laroche, a clerk in the civil service of the French Government, was found asphyxiated by gas in his room at the Hotel de Paris, 75 Christopher Street, yesterday morning. The Consul, who has read his papers and sealed them, the Coroner, M. Matson, the hotel keeper, and guests of the hotel are persuaded that M. Laroche turned off the light and, accidentally, turned on the gas, while groping in the dark for his bed.

ST. PAUL, April 25 -- 2 A.M. -- The United States Government has resolved to employ the stern hand of repression upon the 500 Coxey cranks who are flying through Montana on a train they stole from the Northern Pacific Railroad at Butte last night. If there is any resistance there will be bloodshed.

FREDERICK, Md., April 24. -- Coxey's army to-day marched into Frederick 340 strong, in spite of the declaration by Mayor Fleming three days ago that as an organization they should never set foot within the city limits.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- "When are we going to win a game?" is the question that is puzzling the members of the gigantic team from the metropolis. They arrived here yesterday; had a good night's rest, and went out this afternoon to play good ball. They did this, but failed to win, after outbatting the Senators and playing an errorless game.

One of the most enjoyable dinners of the season was given by Gen. and Mrs. Thomas L. James in honor of James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, and Mrs. Eckels at the Murray Hill Hotel last evening.

LONDON, April 24. -- In the House of Commons to-night Sir George Baden-Powell inquired whether it was proposed that NewZealand should administer the government of Samoa, and whether the United States and Germany had been consulted in the matter. If so would the Government make a statement as to the attitude assumed by Germany and America?

BLUEFIELDS, M.R., Nicaragua, April 19, via New-Orleans, April 24, per steamer Hispania. -- Since the sailing of the Clinton yesterday morning 150 Nicaraguan troops have reached here on a schooner from Greytown, but Locayo, the Commissioner, fearful of a clash with the natives and Americans, marched them out to the bluffs, where they are now encamped.

A.M. Palmer, manager of the Garden and Palmer's Theatres, will sail for Europe this morning on the Paris, accompanied by Mrs. Palmer. He expects to be gone about two months, which is an unusually short time for him to spend on his annual trips across the Atlantic. In talking to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday regarding his plans, Mr. Palmer said:
It was so cold at Sheepshead Bay and Gravesend yesterday that several of the Brooklyn Handicap horses were not worked till the afternoon.

The evangelistic meetings in Niblo's Garden at noon and in Metropolitan Hall yesterday afternoon were largely attended. The committee trusts that money will be forthcoming from some source this week to continue its good work. Otherwise the meetings will close on Friday.

At the Metropolitan Opera House last night the familiar combination of Mascagni's powerful one-act opera, "Cavalleria Rusticana," and Leoncavallo's equally interesting work, "Pagliacci," was presented. Although this bill is by no means new, it is some time since it has been offered to the public, and no doubt many persons were glad to have an opportunity to see and hear Mme. Calve in something besides the perennial "Carmen."

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- The counting of 50,000,000 of silver dollars at the Philadelphia Mint, 33,000,000 of which have been stored there since Feb. 7, 1890, and 17,000,000 since May 26, 1891, was begun to-day. The bolts in the huge iron door of the vault were so rusty that the door had to be forced open with a chisel and a sledge.
The exposure of frauds on the pension roll made by The New-York Times has awakened a lively interest in the various life insurance companies of this city and country.

The woman suffragists and anti-woman suffragists, as represented by New-York society women, are actively engaged in advancing the interest in the petition to the State Constitutional Convention on the one hand, and the protest on the other.

"As it looks to-night, I think there will be no legislation on the Bi-Partisan Police Commission or on Rapid Transit," said President Charles Stewart Smith of the Chamber of Commerce to a reporter for The New-York Times last evening.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 24. -- There was great disappointment to-night over the announcement that general resumption of traffic on the Great Northern Railway had not yet come about. The responsibility for the failure to run trains to-day rested with the employes of the company.

Members of the Loyal Legion who are also members of the Union League Club gave a dinner last evening at the Union League Clubhouse, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, to honor of Archbishop Ireland of St. Paul, who is a member of the Loyal Legion, on account of having served through the civil war as Chaplain of the Fifth Minensota Volunteer Regiment.

The Grand Council of the Royal Arcanum of the State of New-York, numbering 400 delegates, began its annual session yesterday morning in the Johnston Building, Brooklyn. The morning session was taken up with the reading of reports.

Fifty years ago, when the Unitarian Church of the Saviour was dedicated, Brooklyn was a small place. That was long before the City Hall was built, and the prominent and fashionable people all lived on or near the bluff overlooking the East River, in the section of the city now The Church of the Saviour was built at known as Brooklyn and Columbia Heights.

From The Leavenworth Times. The United Press is anxious to preserve the English language pure and undefiled. Yesterday the following dispatch was sent out from Chicago to all correspondents in the Western division:

WALNUT, Iowa, April 24. -- Kelly's army drilled into Walnut with twenty-three companies, representing 953 men, in a state of mutiny, so far as the Sacramento division is concerned. Gen. Kelly and Col. Speed had some trouble this morning, which may result in a disruption.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The act creating the Department of Docks gave the Commissioners power to build all permanent construction provided for in the act with the employes of the department, and not by contract. This power was given because the work, being largely under water, offers great inducements to fraud on the part of contractors, and because the department could do the work more quickly and more substantially than, by contract.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., April 24. -- The 5,000 men in this section of the coke region are expected to stop work to-morrow. The Cambria Iron Company's men, numbering 2,000, are expected to lead the strike. A large meeting was held at the Morrell works to-day, the men voting to join the strike and force all others out who should refuse to quit work.

Horace E. Deming addressed Good Government Club A, on "City Government from a Business Point of View," at the clubhouse, 722 Lexington Avenue, last night. He said a city had nothing to do with the framing of political policies or party principles. These were matters that should appertain solely to the State.

A determined effort for rapid transit will be made to-day at the Chamber of Commerce, where a meeting will be held at noon under the direction of the City Club and the Council of Good Government Clubs. Arrangements for the meeting were made yesterday afternoon. Those in charge had time only to send out a few special invitations, but it was decided to issue a general call and welcome all who may wish to attend.

The Williams College Alumni Association of New-York met last evening at the Hotel Brunswick to hear the report of the committee appointed to draft suitable resolutions upon the death of David Dudley Field, who was graduated from Williams College and ever afterward gave it his hearty support.

ALBANY, April 24. -- The objections that are pouring in against the compilation of the costitutional convention manual have considerably disturbed those having the matter in charge. Under the law that was passed last year the Democratic State officers selected during the last week of December, 1893.

The Trustees of the Twelfth Ward, who refused to accept William B. Friedberg as Principal of Grammar School No. 83, who was nominated by the Board of Education, appeared yesterday afternoon before the Committee on Teachers at the Board of Education Building, 146 Grand Street, in answer to a formal call to consider the question under dispute which has been fully told in The New-York Times.

BOSTON, April 24. -- Louis Rondelle has accepted the challenge of Regus Senac of New-York at fencing. He announces that he will pay the expenses of any New-York fencing master to meet him at the Boston Fencing Club, Saturday night. The club has subscribed a purse to go to the winner of the contest.

Miss Eleanor Forrester Peck of NewHaven was married to Eugene Kinnaird McEnroe of this city at noon yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by Archbishop Corrigan, and the nuptial mass was celebrated by several of the clergymen connected with the cathedral.

A Samaritan manuscript of the Pentateuch is exhibited at the Lenox Library. The British Museum has one of A.D. 1356, the Vatican Library has one of A.D. 1227, this manuscript at the Lenox Library is dated A.D. 1232, and the latter contains thirty chapters of Genesis which are not in the former.

The past year may have been a hard one financially, but it has been a great one for inventions and discoveries. Edison, the wizard, who has done so much to advance the cause of modern science and improvement, has now given us the Kiteograph, which shows scenes from actual life in real operation.

Three pistol shots were fired in the Equity Term of the Common Pleas Court yesterday morning by Michael Donnelly, a dealer in iron at 597 Washington Street, in an attempt to kill his former employer and brother-in-law, Patrick J. McArdle of Albany. Only one bullet did any injury. It grazed McArdle's left ear.

The Inter-State relay cycle race from this city to Philadelphia for the gold medals offered by The New-York Times promises to be one of the big events of the year. Heretofore relay or team races have been on a straight road with a view of making the best time possible between the two points.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- The market to-day was irregular. A drive was made at Pennsylvania, Reading, and Lehigh Valley on the ground that the strike of the coal miners would very seriously affect the earnings of the companies; Lehigh Valley dropped 2, to 37, but at that point struck good buying orders and quickly advanced to 37 5/8. That price was bid for 1,000 Shares in the last half hour.

The Bridgeport (Conn.) Democratic Association has recently issued an address to the Democratic members of the Senate, urging upon them the necessity of prompt action upon the tariff legislation now pending. This appeal is of peculiar interest, since it comes from one of the largest manufacturing centres of Connecticut. The address is, in part, as follows:
ALBANY, April 24. -- Gov. Flower has transmitted the following message on ballot reform to the Legislature:

ALBANY, April 24. -- The Senate this afternoon passed the bill increasing the salaries of the patrolmen of New-York. Last year it was the current belief, from the number of lobbyists interested, that $40,000 was ready to be used to send this bill to Gov. Flower. This year the figures are placed at $60,000.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 24. -- To-morrow there will be the best race of the Memphis meeting, the Montgomery Stakes, at one and one-eighth miles. The new Memphis Jockey Club has added $1,000 to the original amount of added money, and the winner will carry off something like $2,500. The starters, as sold to-night in the pools, will be Clifford, Yo Tambien, Carlsbad, King Lee, and Hawthorne.

Brooklyn is a city that has made some important contributions to the cause of good government. It was in Brooklyn that the Young Republican Club forced upon its party the nomination of Seth Low for Mayor, and for four years committed that party to a higher standard of political action than any party had attained in that city, or, for that matter, in any other in the State.

William D. Lohman is expected to arrive in Brooklyn with Detective Sergeant Zundt at 11 o'clock this morning. Police Superintendent Campbell received a dispatch from Zundt saying they had left Toronto at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

The auction room in the Trinity Building was very much crowded when the sales of real estate were begun at noon yesterday. Bidding was quite brisk, good prices were, in general, obtained, and in one instance -- that of the sale of the Edward Fitzpatrick estate by Mr. Bryan L. Kennelly -- the total realized was more than $6,000 above the appraised values.

The industrials were the prominent features of yesterday's stock market, Distilling and Cattle Feeding being the most active, with Chicago Gas a good second, and Sugar a poor third. The latter, however, was strong, while the other two were notably weak. The railway list was dull, and although the tendency was toward lower figures, the losses were not important.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The dance given last night by the Secretary of the Navy and Miss Herbert on board the Dolphin was enjoyable in every way. Mr. and Mrs. Leiter, Mr. and Mrs. Howland, Mrs. Sargent, and Mrs. Colwell were among those asked by Miss Herbert to be present as chaperons. The music for the dances was furnished by the Marine Band.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 24. -- Seven firemen were severely injured by falling timbers in a burning building at 185 Main Street, in this city, to-night. The injured are:

The pension "shark" and his pursuit of the veteran soldier may some day make the basis for an important chapter in the history of this country. He has been chasing the veteran in these latter, years with a zeal that is born of a desire for cash, which liberality of law and laxity in rules of procedure have made it easy to get.

The process of reorganizing bad "boys" and bad methods out of the Republican machine in this city seems to be attended with difficulty. The Assembly district conventions for the selection of members of the County Committee were held on Monday evening under the plan of "The Thirty."

Representatives of various retail grocers' associations and unions in the State of NewYork met at Retail Grocers' Hall yesterday afternoon to discuss matters of interest to the trade, but more particularly to take steps looking to a more complete system of organization throughout the State. The convention is held under the auspices of the Central Association of Retail Merchants of New-York and vicinity.

There were two performances at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday, one in the afternoon and another in the evening. At the matinee "Carmen" was performed to a good-sized audience. Indeed, considering the fact that the cast was not to be compared with that which aroused public interest early in the Winter, the audience was remarkably large.

Gen. Robert S. Granger, United States Army, retired, died early yesterday morning in Washington. He was born in Zanesville, Ohio, May 24, 1816. His father was a cousin of Gideon Granger, and his mother was a sister of Attorney General Henry Stanbery.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The New-Yorks played superior ball against the Senators to-day, and won their first championship game of the season. They fielded badly, but German's good work in the box offset the fumbles of his fielders. Up to the fifth inning the home team held a good lead, gained principally on errors and Joyce's hitting.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 25. -- The letter of James H. McNaught, on which the impeachment of Judge Jenkins, which the Boatner investigating committee will probably report to the House to-day, was based, was handed to Judge Jenkins by his brother-in-law, George P. Miller. Mr. Miller admitted, to the investigating committee that it was this letter which was the basis of the injunction.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Sir: Recently there appeared in certain newspapers a paragraph in which it was definitely stated (authority not given) that Mr. George F. Parker, United States Consul at Birmingham, England, had succumbed to "a complication of diseases," rapid consumption among others being mentioned, and that, consequently, there would soon be a vacancy in the foreign Consular Service.

The Madison Avenue Baptist Church, Thirty-first Street and Madison Avenue, was the scene of a beautiful wedding yesterday afternoon at 4:30 o'clock, when Miss Annie Louise Lamont was married to Henry Harkness Flagler. The Rev. Dr. Henry M. Sanders, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

When in his annual message Gov. Flower recommended the adoption of the blanket ballot, "with the names upon it so arranged and printed that the elector can easily vote for the candidates of his choice," he gave no intimation that he favored, the continued use of the "paster ballot" in the form of a blanket paster.

The sole interest in yesterday's market centred in Chicago Gas, and after the first hour the trading in that was hardly more than normal. The decison of the Attorney General of Illinois of institute quo warranto proceedings against the company, which was announced on Tuesday afternoon after the close of the Exchange, induced large selling at the opening.

Gobble, gobble," "Ba-a-a," and many other rural sounds will usher in the Farm Show at the Madison Square Garden tomorrow. The amphitheatre will be transformed into a veritable bucolic delight on the designs of Stanford White of McKim, Mead White, and Thomas H. Terry will exhibit everything that is choice in the way of live stock, poultry, c., that his Hempstead Farm produces.

A concurrent resolution was adopted by the Senate and Assembly yesterday for an adjournment of the Legislature sine die at noon to-morrow. The Republican majority will leave Albany without the credit either of a short or a useful session. It has not been sufficiently subservient to the party boss to do his bidding promptly nor sufficiently independent of him to devote itself to the public interests.

Major Duffy of the Sixty-nintn Battalion and Inspector General Thomas McGrath have been brought into conflict by an interview published in some local newspapers about two weeks ago, in which Major Duffy was quoted as saying that Gen. McGrath was working against him in the interest of an officer of the old Sixty-ninth Regiment who was rendered supernumerary last Fall.

The sixty-fourth animal commencement of the College of Pharmacy of the City of New-York was held last evening in Music Hall, when 128 graduates received their degrees from Samuel W. Fairchild, President of the college.

There are two items from opposite sides of the tariff fight in this morning's news. A letter is published in Columbus, Ohio, in which Mr. Brice says: "So far as I am concerned, I have not taken up the income tax, as it may be in the end forced in the bill, and I would have to be content with it."

A comprehensive and well systematized report of the business of the Union Pacific Railway for 1893 was submitted to the stockholders at their annual meeting in Boston yesterday. Nothwithstanding the appointment of receivers during the year and the consequent change in the actual control of the property, the report includes the operations of the entire year.

William B. Burnett, ex-United States District Attorney of Cincinnati, was arrested in this city yesterday by United States Deputy Marshal Trautfield for refusing to obey the order of the United States Circuit Court of Ohio requiring him to deposit with the Clerk of the court in Cincinnati $9,000 of the bonds of the Covington Water Works, Kentucky, the property of his client, Eliza J. Bennett of Wisconsin.
Switchmen employed by the Manhattan Elevated Railway will be required, on and after May 1, to work ten hours a day instead of eight. There will be no increase of pay.

The result of making "party measures" by caucus action of three of the so-called anti-Tammany "reform" bills is that they are sent to the Governor by substantially a party vote. It is to be hoped that the Republican caucus stamp and the practically united Democratic opposition will not prevent Gov. Flower from exercising a calm and Judicious discrimination with regard to them.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Commander Heyerman and Lieut. Lyman will each lose their rank and pay on suspension for one year for the loss of the frigate Kearsarge on Roncador Reef. Secretary Herbert has acted on the findings and sentences of the court-martial which tried these two officers, and his decision was announced this morning.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., April 25. -- The General Improvement Commission of this city has rejected 1,500 barrels of cement intended for use in brick sewers now in course of construction. The cement did not come up to the requirements set forth in the specifications. The contracts for the work are held by District-Leader-PoliceCommissioner-Contractor John C. Sheehan of New-York.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- Three hundred Commonwealers were at the cooper shop barracks to-day, and 100 more came with tickets of admission and membership in the army during the night. Four additional companies were organized by the Adjutant General, H. H. Hoefler, in the absence of Commander Randall.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The entrance of the Tariff bill upon the amendment stage in the Senate to-day was marked by much repetition of the Republican tales of woe, by successful attempts to draw Democrats into the discussion, and by an exhibition of filibustering which would accomplish an admirable result if it should push the Democrats to the point of making a change in the rules.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 25. -- For over twelve hours to-day and to-night, without a single recess, the 1,700 delegates to the Republican State Convention devoted themselves to the making of a party ticket to be voted on in November. This extraordinary session was due to the fact that there were no less than forty-three candidates for the ten nominations, and the belief that the Republicans will carry the State.

LONDON, April 25. -- Sir Thomas Esmonde has given notice that in the House of Commons to-morrow he will ask the Government to give its assent to the annexation of the Samoan Islands to New-Zealand, the Samoans themselves having repeatedly given expression to their approval of such administration of their Government.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26. -- The Coxeyites were arrested at 12:30 by CoL Page's troops at Forsythe, Montana.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The denial by Mr. Vest of the charge made by Mr. Aldrich in the Senate to-day that negotiations were in progress designed to remove all Democratic objections to the bill is regarded with surprise by all who are conversant with the situation.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 25. -- The third games of the Tenth Battalion Athletic Association occurred at the State Armory this evening. About 1,500 spectators witnessed the games, which were exciting.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 25. -- More than 20,000 visitors were in Birmingham in attendance upon the fourth annual reunion of the United Confederate Veterans, which convened here to-day.

The smart set of Brooklyn turned out in full force at the Church of the Pilgrims, Remsen and Henry Streets, Brooklyn, last evening to witness the marriage of two of its prominent members, Miss Ada Miriam Dike, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Camden C. Dike of 194 Columbia Heights, and Murray Boocock, son of Samuel W. Boocock of Joralemon Street.

After examining over 550 talesmen, a jury was finally secured yesterday, before Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions, to try Dr. Henry Meyer, for the murder of Ludwig Brandt by poison. The work of getting a jury was begun a week ago last Monday. As matters stand, the trial itself will probably consume the better part of the May term of the court.

MEMPHIS, Tenn, April 25. -- Yo Tambien, the speedy daughter of Joe Hooker, was beaten disgracefully by Clifford in the Montgomery Stakes to-day. The only other starter in the event, which was at a mile and an eighth, was Peytonia, who ran for third money. Clifford was a hot favorite in the betting at odds of 2 to 5, while Yo Tambien was quoted at 13 to 5.

Beginning this morning, until the Legisture shall adjourn, the efforts of the lobby at Albany against bills designed for the welfare of this city will be watched and checked, as far as possible, by a committee of citizens chosen yesterday to represent is cause of good municipal government. The committee consists of Gustav Schwab, Edmond Kelly, H.R. Elliott, J.N. Hayes, R.W.G. Welling, J.P. Faure, Preble Tucker, J.B. Leavitt, Horace E. Deming, and Isaac H. Kline.

ATLANTIC, Iowa, April 25 -- The day spent at this place has been a notable one in the history of the Industrial Army. Internal dissensions, which for a time threatened to disrupt the army, have been settled, and Cols. Speed and Baker have again assumed their old positions.

Lawyer De Fere, representing the proprietor of Noah's Ark and several property owners, called at the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday in order to get Mayor Schieren to reconsider his decision closing the ark, so that the animals could be displayed. Mayor Schieren said he could not, as a church complained of the show.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25. -- Harvard was beaten by Amherst at Daseball to-day through failure to bunch hits and execrable fielding. A more miserable game was never played in Cambridge.

ALBANY, April 25. -- This has been the banner day of this Legislature. The Senate passed, at the morning session, three bills that had been agreed upon by the Republican caucus -- the Sheffield bill to allow the next Mayor of New-York and his successors to appoint their own heads of departments within sixty days after taking office, the Sheffield Sheriff's Salary bill, and the Saxton Dock Contract bill.

J. Edward Simmons has tendered his resignation as Chairman of the Committee of General Bondholders of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, and Gen. Louis Fitzgerald will be elected his successor. Mr. Simmons will remain a member of the committee, but he says that his time is so thoroughly occupied that he is unable to give to Reading matters the attention that the duties of Chairman of the committee demand.

Lillian Russell and Canary Lederer rested yesterday from the arduous labors of making and breaking contracts. Mr. Lederer busied himself about general theatrical matters, and received sympathizing friends. Mlss Russell attended the performance of "Cinderella" at Abbey's Theatre in the afternoon.
COLUMUBUS, Ohio, April 25. -- John W. Winn, leader of the Democrats in the House of Representatives here, has received a letter from Senator Brice in which he says:

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Mr. Harris caused a lone and uninteresting discussion by asking to-day in the Senate for unanimous consent that the Tariff bill be taken up each day this week, except Saturday, at 1 o'clock and considered until 6 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Secretary Lamont has settled the quarrel between Col. Graham and Lieut. Col. Young of the army. Both officers are of the Fifth Artillery and are stationed at the Presidio of San Francisco, Cal., the commandant of the post being Col. Graham.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The fourth class Postmasters appointed to-day for New-York State were: Brainard Station -- Frank P. Larkins, vice A.V. Kellogg, removed: New-Hartford -- John Ganey, vice C. O. Jones, resigned; North Hector-Warren S. Thayer, vice W.R. Welding, dead; North Nassau -- S.P. Waterbury, vice J.L. Mann, removed.

Peter Fitzpatrick is a professional nurse. He lives in a house in the rear of 201 Clifton Place, near Franklin Avenue, in the Fourth Precinct, Brooklyn. A man who, it is said, was Frederick Lloyd, thirty-five years old, but whose residence is not made public for some reason best known to the officials, was sent to the hospital from Fitzpatrick's house in an ambulance yesterday afternoon.

FREDERICK, Md., April 25. -- Camp Lafayette was the scene of excitement tonight. Two telegrams that were sent to the men by Browne threw the camp into commotion. One was from Henry Vincent of Chicago, announcing that 1,000 striking iron molders had secured accommodations from the railroads and would be in Rockville to meet the army of the Commonweal on Sunday next.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 25. -- Three places at the South End were entered by burglars last night, the last store being that of Frank L. Henderson, on William Street. It was entered about 2 A.M. Henderson was sleeping in a rear room. Hearing the men in the store he arose and went out. The burglars assaulted him with canned goods and two made their escape.

BOSTON, April 25. -- Local stocks were exceedingly dull and the market was without special feature. American Bell Telephone was strong, and sold in small lots up to 190 1/2, with New-England Telephone at 55 and Erie Telephone at 46 3/4. The reason for the strength of the telephone stocks is undoubtedly on account of the favorable showing in the last statement of the American Bell Telephone Company.

The delegates to the sixteenth annual convention of the Grand Council of the Royal Arcanum are enthusiastic over the grand time given to them in the City of Churches, and the manner in which they and their wives have been entertained by the Brooklyn members of the flourishing order.

The Sherman Bank resumed business yesterday according to announcement. Its checks were received at the Clearing House under the protection of its former agent, the Central National Bank. Some of the depositors who closed their accounts at the Sherman Bank when trouble was talked of replaced their money yesterday.

The Stalwart Club of the Third Assembly District, which is the Platt social organization in that district, had a "housewarming" last night at 33 Delancey Street. John E. Milholland, Joseph Wilkinson, and Frank J. Martin, President of the club and the Platt leader of the districts, were among the speakers.

Both the local clubs won yesterday. Down in Washington the Giants hod a day's outing with the Senators, and at Eastern Park the Brooklyns won from the Philadelphias with many runs to spare. In consequence, both teams are still on even terms.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25. -- James S. Holmes, Jr., Chief Consul of the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen, is very enthusiastic over the prospects of success of the 150-mile interState relay race for the gold medals offered by The New-York Times. He was at the meeting of the Atalanta Wheelmen at which the preliminary arrangements were made.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 25. -- Delegates of employes from every division of the Great Northern Railway met the officials of the company in conference to-day. A few minutes before adjournment President Hill submitted a proposition looking to the settlement of all difficulties by arbitration, with the proviso that the men immediately return to work.

Jacob M. Patterson and his "crowd," and two or three other Republicans that have for years been active in manipulating the politics of New-York County, are attempting to "do business at the same old stand," now that the Committee of Thirty is about to perfect its organization.

A concert by Mrs. Curtis's orchestra always fills Chickering Hall to overflowing, and the one given there last night was no exception. The programme was an interesting and varied one. The steady growth of this organization, which is drilled once a week duping the Winter by Mr. Theodore John, shows how admirably he does his work.

ALBANY, April 25. -- The Manhattan Elevated Railway Company has won another victory, and the lobby which it established here through Byron Traver has every reason to congratulate itself. By the action of the Senate to-night, the great issue of rapid transit for New-York City has been deferred for another year, at least, and the Manhattan.

It was announced on Tuesday that the evangelistic revival meetings which have been going on in this city for the past ten weeks would probably close to-morrow unless funds were forthcoming to carry them on. Yesterday the Rev. Dr. A.C. Dixon and other members of the Evangelistic Central Committee received material encouragement to keep the meetings going.

William D. Lohman, the defaulting cashier of the Brooklyn Excise Department, arrived at Police Headquarters in that city at 10:30 yesterday morning, in company with his friend, Detective Sergeant Zundt, who was sent to Toronto for him, and his wife and son, who met him at the West Shore Railroad Station in Hoboken.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. yesterday.

Park Commissioner Bell visited One Hundred and Fifty-third Street and Seventh Avenue, Tuesday, to see how the work of excavating the gore of rock there was getting along. The rock is used by James D. Leary, who has the contract for the first section of the Speedway. Mr. Bell found the workmen apparently enjoying themselves.

JAMAICA, L.I., April 25. -- The advocates of woman suffrage are not meeting with much success in their efforts to prepare a list of the women paying taxes. In Queens County, to be presented to the Constitutional Convention. They desire the information, to support one of their strongest claims, that a large percentage of the taxes in this State are paid by women.

Banker B.C. Benedict, Vice Commodore of the New-York Yacht Club, planned to give a dinner to his friends at his residence, 10 West Fifty-first Street, one night last week. When the time came for setting the table, the butler, Andrew Ziloth, who had been in the service of the family for three years, was absent.

The reopening combination auction sale of saddle, coach, and light-harness horses at the American Horse Exchange, Fiftieth Street and Broadway, was begun yesterday, and, with so good an auctioneer as William Easton on the box, the good qualities of the animals offered did not lack a thorough description.

The auction offerings in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday were numerous, but, with few exceptions, commanded little attention. Perhaps the most satisfactory of the sales in results was that held by Mr. James L. Wells, in partition, of the estate of the late Adam Harrmann. The chief interest in this sale concerned property on the other side of the Harlem River.

The body of Charles H. Todd, managing agent of the Robert L. Cutting estate, was found lying on a lot of disused machinery in a shed in the rear of the factory building 733 First Avenue, at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The factory belongs to the Cutting estate.

Brooklyn Handicap horses will be worked several seconds faster than they are doing now in a few days. Leonawell was the first to appear on the track for work yesterday morning, under guidance of Simms. He ran the mile and a furlong in 2:02 3/4, and finished the latter part of the journey very strong.

MADRID, April 23. -- Gen. Martinez Campos had a long interview with the Queen Regent to-day on the subject of the recent operations in Morocco, which ended in the conclusion of a convention with the Sultan the terms of which are extremely advantageous to Spain. Gen. Campos spoke very highly of Sultan Muley Hassan, who, he said, possessed more than ordinary ability and was serious and sensible in all his public acts.

Col. Fred D. Grant accompanied his wife and daughter to the Knickerbocker Bowling Club yesterday afternoon. The Colonel was afraid to show what he could do with the pins before so many expert bowlers, and could not be induced to bowl. When nearly every one had left, though, he rolled down one ball, and was rather surprised by making a ten strike.

NEW-HAVEN, April 25. -- The games of the Yale Track Athletic Association this afternoon were highly satisfactory. The feature of the contests was the showing of the dark horses Ceveland in the sprints, Thompson and Wade in the jumps, Kershaw in the pole vault, and Sanford in the quarter-mile run.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- As the boycott of the Governing Committee of the New-York Stock Exchange has completely killed trading in New-York stocks, the traders have taken up the tractions with real good will. The recent decline in Philadelphia and Metropolitan Traction was helped by the bears, and quite a fair-sized short interest was developed.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 25. -- The united Press Honolulu correspondent, writing under date of April 9 by the schooner Aloha which arrived this morning, says:

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- In addition to the request of the Judge of the United States Court, the United States District Attorney, and the United States Marshal for the District of Montana, for Federal aid in arresting the Hogan contingent for seizing a train at Butte, Mon., against the mandate of the United States Court, President Cleveland has received the following from the Governor of Montana:

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, April 25. -- The United States revenue steamer Corwin and the United States coast survey steamer Patterson reaped here this morning from San Francisco. The Patterson will proceed in a few days to the waters of Southeastern Alaska. She has on board a party of surveyors of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey Service, who will undertake to determine accurately the southern boundary line of Alaska.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 25. -- Williams defeated the Massachusetts Institute of Technology team this afternoon at baseball by a score of 60 to 1. The game was uninteresting. Williams batted hard and ran bases well. The "Techs" were weak all around, and made inexcusable errors, making their ony run on an error.

ALBANY, April 25. -- In the Assembly today Mr. Ainsworth announced that the Annual Appropriation bill was now in the House, having been recalled from the Governor. It had been recalled because it was understood that the Executive objected to the insertion of the item compelling minor State departments to apply to the Attorney General for legal services.

A large meeting of Brooklyn women who have arrayed themselves against the woman suffragists, in opposition to the amendment of the Constitution, was held yesterday morning at the house of Mrs. John E. Leech, 94 Remsen Street.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Application was made for receivers this afternoon for the Commercial Loan and Trust Company, at 1330 Arch Street. The company is incorporated under the laws of West Virginia. The application was made by the bondholders. It is alleged that the company, though its authorized capital was $300,000, only had $1,000 actual capital, and that its assets consisted only of the contribution of the bondholders.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 25. -- Miss Annie Muxlow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Muxlow, and William Henry Hobby MacKellar were married this evening at the home of the bride's parents, 416 North Division Street. The Rev. W. Fisher Lewis of St. Peter's Church and the Rev. Robert MacKellar, Jr., of Red Bank, N.J., a brother of the bridegroom, officiated.

Nothing that Mr. John D. Townsend may say interests me," said ex-Mayor Grace yesterday, after he had read a synopsis of a letter from the lawyer which criticised what he characterized as a "suggestion" from Mr. Grace that the local political contest this Fall may be a threecornered one, and that the Hanover Square merchant-millionaire may be a candidate for Mayor.

LONDON, April 25. -- The London Anarchists sent a letter to Herbert Gladstone, First Commissioner of Works, asking permission to erect platforms in Hyde Park Similar to those put up by the labor leaders in 1893 for the May Day celebration of the "international solidarity of labor."

About fifty New-York women interested in making a protest against having the word "male" stricken from the State Constitution met at the house of Mrs. Francis Lynde Stetson, 576 Madison Avenue, yesterday morning.

ALBANY, April 25. -- The policy of the Legislature on ballot reform was only determined to-day, and then by a mere accident. After reading the Governor's message on the question, which was promulgated last night, the Republican leaders concluded to dispatch to New-York the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the House, Commodore Thornton of Newburg.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25. -- At the opening baseball game of the series with the University of Pennsylvania, at the Varsity grounds, this afternoon, the Princeton team won, owing to the star playing of Capt. MacKenzie. Pennsylvania scored in the second inning on two bases on balls, hit by Thomas, and an error by P. Ward.

Counsel in the Gravesend prosecutions have not yet been adequately compensated for their work. Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court has their claims under advisement, and will soon render a decision fixing the amount of fees and disbursements.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 25. -- The miners' strike has spread to the mines along the Kiskiminetas River. Three thousand miners in this district stopped work yesterday and decided to assist the United Mine Workers' Union in the national movement. A big mass meeting of the miners was held at Leechburg to-day, at which an organization was formed.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., April 25. -- The contingent of Coxey's army under command of Gen. Louis C. Frye forcibly took possesion of another freight train this afternoon. They went as far as Brazil, where they are encamped to-night.

The first round of the team chess match between the Brooklyn and Newark Chess Clubs was played at the rooms of the former club on Wednesday evening, and, after three hours' play, the home team won by eight games to two. The Brooklyn club was well represented, as such players as Hodges.

The report of the Charity Organization Society of the United States, of which Charles D. Kellogg of this city is Chairman, furnishes much valuable and interesting information respecting the history and progress of charitable associations during the past twenty years, and of the character and scope of the work they have accomplished for the relief of distress in all the great centres of population.

President Luscomb of the League of American Wheelmen is having considerable trouble with the Michigan Division. Steele was recently appointed Chief Consul of Michigan, but his opponents have refused to recognize him, and question the right of President Luscomb to Interfere, and refuse to turn over the funds to him.

Capt. Foutz's men put up a poor game of ball against the Philadelphia team yesterday, and the result was the latter won with ease. It was ladies' day, and the grand stand was crowded with the fair sex, all anxious to see the Brooklyn boys win, and when the game was over expressions of regret could be heard from the fair admirers of the local team.

Among the important bills that have gone to the governer with the label of "reform" is that providing for a bi-partisan Board of policce in this city in place of the present commission. Notwithstanding the Superintendent, we do not think it ought to become a law. It is desirable that the assign and transfer the officers under his command, and to impose the minor penalties for enforceing discipline.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The resolution offered yesterday by Mr. Allen permitting Coxey's army to act in Washington according to its will was to-day made the means of a severe denunciation of the Nebraska Senator and his methods by Senators Vest, Wolcott, and Gray. It was as severe as the most caustic critics of the new commune might desire.

Messrs. De Selding Brothers have sold a plot of ten lots on the south side of Canarsie Avenue, between Twenty-second and Twenty-third Streets, In the new Twentyninth Ward of Brooklyn, formerly Flatbush. The purchaser, Mrs. J. H. Bergen, intends to improve the property at once by the erection of small dwellings.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- As the project for a canal across Nicaragua develops, the military aspects of the enterprise are being studied. The commercial benefits of the canal have been voluminously treated, and now the War Department has accumulated some Information on the strategic value of the canal.

The reopening sale at the American Horse Exchange, Fiftieth Street and Broadway, was concluded yesterday. During the sale a number of good animals were sold at fair prices. William Easton, who has taken the management of the Exchange, was in the auctioneer's stand, and he had disposed of the entire stock by 4 o'clock.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 26 -- The little town of Troutdale passed an anxious night. About 8 o'clock Portland's contingent of the Industrial Army went into camp there, and this morning took possession of the Union Pacific station, ousting the operator and agent.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 26 -- Abram Corrant, who lived in Charlton County, Ga., just across the line, died to-day, aged ninety-four. He was a veteran of the Mexican and Indian wars, had been married twice, and was the father of forty children.

From The Waterbury (Conn.) American, April 21. This, too, is April. Within ten days we have had a foot of snow and immense drifts that blocked roads, several inches of dust that rose in clouds and powdered everything, and now gentle showers that refresh nature and eaten humanity unawares, and under the stimulating influence of which the grass grows visibly. By and by we Shall get something else.

The West Side Republican Club held its seventh annual banquet last night, at the Hotel Endicott, Eighty-second Street and Amsterdam Avenue. It is the custom of the club to commemorate the birthday of Gen. Grant, and each mention of his name by the speakers last night drew forth long applause.

BOSTON, April 26 -- The market on local stocks was quiet and the tone was somewhat mixed. There Is little or no news to trade on, though there are again some bull statements going the rounds on Lamson Stores Service Company. The stock sold off on small sales to-day, declining 1 point to 24.

The work for 1893 of the Margaret Strachan Home for Fallen Women is briefly sketched in the reports of its Secretary, Mrs. George B. Satterlee, and the Superintendent, Miss Maria Sibthorpe. The institution was founded by a seamstress, whose name it bears, at 103 West Twenty-seventh Street, in 1883, and it was then modestly called the Faith Home Mission.

ALBANY, April 26 -- At the evening session of the Senate, after Lieut. Gov. Sheehan had lobbied for several hours, Senator Ahearn moved to reconsider the Vote toy which the Huckleberry bill was killed. Senators O'Connor and Saxton spoke against the motion, and Gen. McMahon for it.

The Senate and Assembly conference committee finally agreed yesterday upon the Chamber of Commerce Rapid-Transit bill, with the Commissioners named, but with the referendum attachment of the Butts-Lexow bill, and in that form it passed both houses. It differs from the bill as originally introduced in omitting the name of Samuel D. Babcock and adding those of william Steinway and John H. Starin of the present commission.

TACOMA, Washington, April 26. -- A resident of this city who was at Billings yesterday when the fight between the deputies and Coxeyltes occurred has returned here. In speaking of the fight, which he witnessed, he said:

The opening League championship baseball game in this city to-morrow promises to be one of the sporting events of the season. This morning the Giants will arrive home from Washington and practice during the afternoon on the Polo Grounds. Now that Capt. Ward's men have struck a winning streak, the enthusiasts here feel confident that they will rapidly forge to the front.
PORT JERVIS, N. Y., April 26 -- Judge Brown has decided the will case of Henry T. B. Gamage, giving half of the estate to Miss Fanny Dimmick of Milford, Penn., and the rest to the Gamage heirs.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 26. -- The preliminary contests in Whig and Clio last night resulted In the selection of the following men to compete in the junior oratorical contest June 11:

The athletic members of the East Eightysixth Street Young Men's Christian Association are going to have better facilities for sports this season than ever before. Besides having the regular association grounds at Mott Haven, which are In better shape this year for field events than In any previous year, they will also have the use of grounds nearer home.
Mayor Gilroy, when told last night that the Rapid-Transit bill had been sent to the Governor, with the referendum clause in it, and asked what his opinion of the bill in this shape was, said:

The fifth performance of Donizetti's "Lucia" was given at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. AS usual, the audience was not large, in spite of the fact that Mme. Melba's name was at the head of the cast. As we said after file first performance of the work this season, it is not the prima donna's fault that there was not a crowded house.

The fifth annual meeting of the Actuarial Society of America was begun yesterday morning in the Directors' room of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, in Madison Square. About sixty members were present. The meeting was opened with an address of welcome by the President, Howell W. St. John.

School athletics are rapidly growing In public favor. The boys of Trinity School held their fourth annual competitive games at the beautiful grounds of the Berkeley Oval, above the Harlem, yesterday. There was a good-sized crowd of young men and not a few girls present, and, as usual, the girls were the more demonstrative In their excitement and interest.
BERLIN, April 26 -- The North German Gazette devotes a prominent place In this morning's Issue to an inspired article on the subject of the proposed annexation of the Samoan Islands to New-Zealand.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The funeral of William McGarrahan was held In St. Peter's Catholic Church here at 9:30 o'clock this morning. A large number of members of Congress and employes of the Capitol followed the body to the church and thence to the grave. The pall bearers were Senators Teller of Colorado and Hunton of Virginia, Representatives H. D, Money of Mississippi.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26 -- A settlement of the strike on the Great Northern Railroad is to-night further away than at any time since the trouble began. President Hill and the Conference Committee having failed to agree.

FALL RIVER Mass., April 26 -- The annual statement of the Osborn Mills made yesterday is attracting unusual attention, because of the contention of the manufacturers that they must cut wagres in order to make money enough to keep their plants in operation, and in view of the recent conferences on the question of cutting wages.

The biggest steam yacht building in this country this season is the Eleanor. She is for Mr. William A. Slater of Norwich, Conn., a memoer of the New-York and Eastern Yacht Clubs, and she is being built at the Bath Iron Works, Bath, Me. She was designed by Charies Ridgeley Hanscom. She will be launched on May 8 and completed by the Fall.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 26 -- Divisions of Gen. Frye's branch of the Commonweal army arrived to-day from Terre Haute on a Vandalia freight train which they had seized at Brazll. The command comprises 300 men. To-night Frye and the local labor leaders held a conference.
LONDON, April 26 -- Herbert H. Asquith, Home Secretary, moved in the House of Commons this evening the disestablishment of the Church In Wales.

The debate in the Senate yesterday upon the demagogic resolution introduced by a Populist Senator, providing for the entertainment of the tramps who are to appear at Washington as petitioners, was very encouraging. What was most encouraging about it was the denunciation of this proposition by Senators who might have been expected, from geographical considerations, to connive at it by their silence if not by their speech.

Considerable interest was shown yesterday at the offering in the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, at 111 Broadway, by Mr. Peter F. Meyer of the property at 168 Centre Street, east side, 176.1 feet south of Hester Street. This property was sold last month in the partition of the Govin estate, but the purchaser refused to take title, claiming that he did not understand the status of the property.

The annual Spring games of the College of the City of New-York will take place on Saturday, May 12, at Berkeley Oval. Besides the regular closed events, there will be a 300-yard dash, open to all amateurs, handicapped by the official handicapper of the American Athletic Union. E. W. Allen of the New-York Athletic dub has promised to start in this event, and try to break the world's record.

From The Boston Journal. Some time ago the Rev. H. R. McCartney of Georgetown was fined $15 on a charge of cruelty to animals In killing a skunk in his hencoop. The prosecution was made by an agent of the society with long name, but there were reasons for thinking that it was prompted by malice occasioned by the activity of Mr. McCartney against the illegal liquor traffic.

James E. Sullivan, Secretary of the Amateur Athletic Union, has compiled "Spalding's Official Sporting Rules," and it will be issued to-day. It contains Amateur Athletic Union general rules, athletic rules, archery, basket ball, badminton, betting, the new bicycling rules for 1894, bowls, skittles, bowling: boxing -- Amateur Athletic Union rules.
TRENTON, N. J., April 26 -- The following communication was sent to the Republican Senators to-night. It was signed by the leading Republicans of the House:

The steamship Santiut, which left this port on Dec. 7, 1893, for Brazil, having in tow the torpedo boat Pirating, (Destroyer,) returned here yesterday morning, under the commmand of Chief Officer Doane, and anchored off Bedlow's Island. The steamship and her tow arrived at Pernambuco Jan. 20, and later went to Rio.

Manager H. C. Miner and Managers Carl and Theodor Rosenfeld are at war. Attorneys for Mr. Miner applied yesterday to Judge Dugro of the Superior Court for an Injunction against the Messrs Rosenfeld prohibiting them from engaging in any other theatrical business at the Fifth Avenue Theatre, except such as is called for by their contract with Mr. Miner.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- There has not been any material change in the tariff situation in the last twenty-four hours. The Democratic Senators who are working upon, the bill to deprive the "conservatives" of any excuse for opposing it are still far from the end of their labors.

Senator Reynolds of Brooklyn introduced in the Legislature a bill which is now in the Governor's hands, and which Mayor Schieren, City Works Commissioner White, and other Brooklyn, officials think does not, on its face, indicate its meaning. The bill is considered to be a very suspicious measure. This bill provides for the building of a pier to extend 250 feet into the East River and to be 40 feet wide.
PORTLAND, Oregon, April 26 -- The troops at Vancouver Barracks received orders tonigrht to proceed to Puyallup, on the line of the Northern Pacific Road.
The State Banking Department closed the Harlem River Bank, Third Avenue and One Hundred and Tenth Street, yesterday, pending an examination of its condition.

There is a dearth of accommodations in this city for poor people suffering from consumption and from incurable diseases. This fact has become so apparent to people interested in medical work and in charity that it has resulted in the organization of an association of some of the leading women of the city for the purpose of the maintenance of a hospital where consumptives can be treated at small expense to themselves.

James G. K. Lawrence, Herbert C. Pell, A. H. Morris, Michael F. Dwyer, and Philip J. Dwyer, representing the Coney Island, Brooklyn, and New-York Jockey Clubs, met at the rooms of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday morning and arranged a schedule of dates for the Spring and Fall meetings of these clubs.
LISBON, April 26 --There were reported yesterday 225 fresh cases of cholera.

By the Interference of the Hoboken police with detectives of the United States Secret Service Tuesday night, the detectives say, an important capture of counterfeiters was in part thwarted. The Secret Service officers were themselves arrested and held for five hours before they could convince Capt. Hayes of the Hoboken force that he had made a mistake. Nevertheless, three of the suspected counterfeiters were arrested in this city Wednesday night.

The action taken by many prominent Brooklyn women last week in opposing the proposed amendment striking the word "male" as a qualification for voters from the State Constitution was received as a valuable suggestion by many New-York women. A meeting was held Wednesday morning at the house of Mrs. Francis Lynde Stetson, a committee was appointed, and a protest drawn up, which was issued yesterday.

ALBANY, April. 26 -- The Manhattan Elevated Railway suffered a reverse in the Assembly to-day when it attempted to kill a meritorious measure which the beat lawyers in New-York City and many taxpayers had called for, and which the corporation opposed.

Troubles accumlate in the Sixty-ninth Regiment. It leaked out last night that a squad of men from Company I assaulted J. B. Gray, the Chief Engineer of the Armory and Sergt. Major of the Battalion, a few nights ago, and that he has not been out since.

Recent cable advices report a settlement of the difficulties between Spain and Morocco. Spain has a settlement on the coast of Morocco. It Is surrounded by a neutral zone, or "buffer State." On the territory of the Sultan of Morocco -- opposite the Spanish settlement of Melilla -- there is a cemetery in which Arab women were in the habit of meeting to pray.

There was intense excitment in the Fourteenth Ward, in Williamsburg on Wednesday and yesterday over a report that Maggie Dempsey, the little daughter of Thomas Dempsey, a sailmaker living at 54 Havemeyer Street, had been kidnapped.

Police Justice Watson, who presides over the destinies at the Ewen Street Police Court, Brooklyn, has the reputation of being a wise man. Indeed, some of his friends, of whom it is claimed he is one, believe that he is far ahead of "Solomon in all his glory."

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Mr. Cooper (Dem., Fla.) offered in the House to-day a bill to provide for the free coinage of silver dollars of value equal to gold dollars. Before the mints are opened to the free coinage of the silver dollars the Secretary of the Treasury is to proclaim the average commercial ratio of value of silver to gold, and fix the weight and fineness of the dollars to be coined.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 26 -- The repon regarding the sale of Nicaragua Canal machinery at Greytown has been confirmed. In Greytown there was a man of the name of Walker, who operated the Nicaraguan Canal Construction Trading Company. This man became indebted to a firm of Spaniards known as E. L. D. Souze Brothers for $8,000.

There was a large gathering of the German-American residents of the Twenty-fourth Assembly District at La Marsche's Hall, In East Eighty-sixth Street, last evening, for the purpose of organizing the district for the German-American Reform Union, of which Oswald Ottendorfer is the President The hall was filled to overflowing, and a great deal of enthusiasm was shown.

William D. Lohman, the defaulting excashier of the Brooklyn Excise Department, still refuses to tell who was associated with him in stealing $19,400 of the excise funds. It Is believed that after he has remained in jail a few of these beautiful Spring days, he will divulge the names of the persons who took the money he stole.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 27 -- This is known as the cleanest city in the world. It is also said to enjoy greater immunity from disease than any other city In the Western Hemisphere. It is Taunt upon the easy-rising slope of a mount. The base of this mount is exposed, for the greater portion, to strong tidal effects, supplemented by the natural current of the Rio de la Plata River.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., April 26 -- The Monmouth Park Race Track Association has been notified by the Eatontown Township Commissioners that the personal property of the association will be sold In two days unless the association pays the taxes of 1893 levied, on Its property, amounting to nearly $4,000. Mr. L. O. Appleby, a member of the association, has advanced $1,800 on account of the association.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- At last the Giants have struck a winning streak, and they left for home to-night in a cheerful mood. The game put up by the New-Yorkers to-day proves that they can play an uphill game. Meakin pitched his first game as a New-Yorker, and before he got warmed up the Senators had tallied 4 runs.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 26 -- The closing scene of the Republican State Convention, which adjourned shortly before 4 o'clock this morning was one of the wildest excitement.

The fight between the opposing factions in the Central Park Baptist Church has been taken into court. It appeared on the calendar of Civil Justice McKeon, in the Seventh District Court, yesterday as "The Central Park Baptist Church vs. C. Vinton Patterson et al."
The item in the report of Mr. Stephen Little on the affairs of the Reading Company which has attracted more attention than anything else in the pamphlet is this one:

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Attorney General Olney to-day sent to the House Committee on Pacific Railroads and to Senator Brice for introduction in the House and Senate copies of a bill prepared by the Administration to reorganize the Union Pacific Railway Company, and to readjust and secure the claims of the United States against the company.

Romantic and self-assertive Lavinia H. Dempsey, cast Into Ludlow Street Jail by Emma C. Everson, typewriter for Miss Dempsey's brothers, Guy C. and John A. Dempsey, on Tuesday, reached her home. Mrs. G. Cooper's boarding house, 37 West Thirty-ninth Street, shortly before 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO. April 26 -- The market fell back to-day into the same tiresome rut that obtained for a fortnight up to Tuesday last. It was dull, featureless, entirely uninteresting, and altogether heavy. What few changes occurred were not the result of a general movement in any particular direction. Some stocks were weaker, while others remained stationary.

An unusually large meeting of the Presidents and General Managers of the railroads in the Trunk Line Association was held in this city yesterday. The subject under consideration was the new agreement to maintain rates. That agreement is now ready for signatures, but it has not yet been signed, in consequence of the hesitancy of the Brie and the Wabash Roads.

The German theatre season at the Irving Place Is drawing to its close. To-nigihit and at to-morrows afternoon and evening performances there will be repetition of last night's comedy--" Ein Schritt vom Wege."

The meeting's of the evangelistic revival field yesterday at Niblo's Garden and Metropolitan Hall were largely attended. With the prospect of the meetings being continued, the attendance is increasing. Another check for $100 was sent to the Rev. A. C. Dixon yesterday, and the outlook for continuing the work is growing brighter.

The various bills affecting the interests of New-York City passed by the Legislature this week are regarded in almost a instances by the local officials and politicians as purely partisan measures of the Republicans, and the general belief among them yesterday was that Gov. Flower would veto all of them.

More than 100 brewery employes In Brooklyn are likely to lose their employment on Saturday unless they conform to the requirements of their employers. The disaffection is confined to four of the eight breweries which are not in the "brewers' pool." The other four have conformed to the wishes of the men, and are not affected by the fight.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- The market all day was very narrow and dull. The continuance of the New-York boycott has tended to diminish the volume of business. Many of the local traders felt very indignant about it at first, but they now say that they can trade In their own securities more freely Mid with probably much greater safety to themselves.

The Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church, in West Fourth Street, was crowded to the doors last night with guests who were present to witness the marriage of Miss Edna Virginia Piercy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clay Piercy of 130 West Eleventh Street, to Mr. George S. Groesbeck of Springfield, Mass.

A proposition is now before the House of Representatives to abolish the position of Superintendent of Indian Schools. We publish in another column a letter from Mr. Herbert Welsh, giving a plain, succinct, and accurate statement of the facts. As an effort at economy, which is probably what Mr. Holman of the Appropriations Committee believes it to be, it is absurd.

The trial of Dr. Henry Meyer, accused of killing Gustav Baum fey poison, was finally begun yesterday before Recorder Smyth, after ten days consumed In getting a jury. Assistant District Attorney McIntyre opened the case for the people as soon as court was called to order.

Odd Fellows, members of lodges in the Sixth District of this city, celebrated the seventy-fifth anniversary of Odd Fellowship by an entertainment at Tammany Hall last night. The lodges in the Sixth District are Tompkins, No. 9; Greenwich, No. 40; Guiding Star, No. 262; Pyramid, No. 305; Metropolitan, No. 33; Eureka, No. 177, and Good will, No. 280.

St. Louis, April 26 -- The fire in the Jefferson Barracks last night was confined to the commissary department and two other small buildings. The total loss on building and supplies will not exceed $30,000. Quartermaster's Clerk Piper and family were asleep in the building when the fire started, and a daughter twenty years old wag overcome by smoke and narrowly escaped suffocation.

Capt. Nil O. Nelson and the crew of the Norwegian steamship Breidablik have commenced suit in Brooklyn against the bark Vila to recover the salvage share of the 8,000 for which the bark was sold and which is now In possession of the United States District Court. The steamer sighted the bark Aug. 30, 1893.

ORANGE, N. J., April 26 -- The students of Seton Hall College, South Orange, have placed a strong baseball nine in the field for this season. The club is always known as the Alerts, and has in past years defeated some of the strongest amateur and semi-professional teams in the field, and this year the management thinKs the personnel of the nine is stronger than ever.

ALBANY, April 26 -- Gov. Flower and his private secretary, Col. Williams, are making great efforts this evening to get back into the Executive Chamber the copies of a message vetoing the Blanket-Ballot bill which he expected to send to the Assembly this afternoon, but has not sent because the bill he wished to veto has not reached him.
ALBANY, April 26 -- The following local bills were passed in the Senate to-day: F. E. Clark -- Bill dividing the City of Brooklyn into five Civil Justice districts.

ALBANY, April 26 -- The total amount of the Annual Supply loin as sent to the Governor last year was $3,159.031. Of this amount, $17,337 was reappropriation, $116,-200 was refunded by corporations, and $542,582 was vetoed, making the net appropriation which had to be raised by taxation $2,482,910.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 26 -- Insurance Commissioner Burton Mansfield's report on life Insurance was issued to-day. There are thirty life insurance companies. doing business in this State, six domestic and twenty-four of other States. The grain in assets in 1893 was $64,641.996, or nearly 71/4 per cent. The assets aggregate $958,530,612, and if equally distributed among the thirty companies, would give to each one nearly $32,000,000.

Thieves despoiled a shrine of St. Joseph during a fire which started at 3:30 A. M. yesterday at 56 Mulberry Street, in "the Bend," and imperiled the lives of several persons besides frightening many. Besides the ornaments on the shrine, a sum of money was stolen.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

There is some difference of opinion, apparently, among Republican Senators as to the tactics which they would do best to employ in the matter of the Tariff Reform bill. They are all agreed how that a bill will ultimately be passed by the majority. On this point there is, indeed, very little room for doubt.

ALBANY, April 26 -- The Sheffield Chamber of Commerce Rapid Transit bill was sent whizzing through both houses of the Legislature to-night after an agreement as to amendments by a conference committee of the two houses this afternoon.

"The action of the State Banking Department in closing the doors of the Harlem River Bank was a complete surprise to me," said Robinson Gill, President of that institution, to a reporter for The New-York Times last evening. Some time ago we heard informally that the Garfield Bank desired us to get another clearing agent.

The new steamship of the Old Dominion Line, the Yorktown, arrived here yesterday from Roach's shipyard, at Chester, Penn., and will go into commission in about two weeks. She is 342 feet long, has 40 feet beam, and 26 feet depth of hold. She is schooner-rigged, with two masts of steel. She has accommodations for 100 first -- class passengers and forty in the steerage.
BALTIMORE, April 26 -- The Manufacturers' Record, in its weekly review of Southern business conditions, says:

TOPEKA, Kan., April 26 -- George H. Shonewaldt, after serving nine of the twenty years for which he was sentenced for murder, was pardoned by Gov. Lewelling, and he is now a free man. There is a story connected with this pardon that is, at least, curious, and which illustrates a phase of human nature not frequently encountered in State officials.

VANCOUVER, B. C., April 26 -- The British ship Pheasant left here this afternoon to warn the coast fleet of sealers to cease killing seals after April 30. The orders for the Pheasant to start were received late last night from the Admiralty, and the vessel was coaled and two months' provisions put aboard.

CLIFTON, S. I., April 26 -- St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church was the scene this afternoon of a wedding which New-York and Staten Island society had long looked, forward to with great interest. Miss Faith McNamee, daughter of James McNamee of Gryme's Hill and grand-daughter of the late Capt.

Seventy-five horses lost their lives last evening by a fire in Stevedore Richard Fitzpatrick's stable, 452 and 454 West Nineteenth Street. Most of them were on the second floor, tied in their stalls. A dozen, which had been freed by the stableman, met death in a struggling heap in the runway, leading to the ground floor.

The keen rivalry between the Richmond and Danville "Florida Short Line," which now has the Government contract for carrying the Southern mails, and the Atlantic Coast Line, which formerly enjoyed that privilege, culminated in an exciting race between two special trains over those roads from Jacksonville to New-York, yesterday, the Richmond and Danville train winning by an hour and twenty-four minutes, despite a handicap of thirty-five minutes at the start.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The brief of the appellants in the McKane case was submitted to the Supreme Court of the United States to-day, and the full case is now before the court. The application in the case will go on the court record of Monday. The brief for McKane was signed by "Thomas A. Atcheson and Robert H. Griffin of counsel."

There is very little doubt that the Vigilant will cross the ocean and race for some of the English prizes against the Britannia, the Valkyrie, the Satanita, and other big yachts in British waters. George Gould has been corresponding with several gentlemen interested in yachting, and the arrangements are very nearly completed.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Secretary Gresham took Capt. Watson's Bluefields report to the Cabinet meeting to-day, and afterward spent an hour in conference with Admiral Ramsay and Assistant Secretary McAdoo in the absence of Secretary Herbert.

Sugar again overshadowed the speeulation in the stock market yesterday, the transactions in it amounting to more than 45 per cent. of the whole day's business. It opened 3/4 higher at 100 3/4 and within a minute advanced another point. All the room traders appeared to be purchasers, and at noon the price had advanced to 103.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The suggestion of last Friday night that, in the absence of a quorum at to-night's session, a resolution would be offered and passed to bring a quorum by the arrest of members, apparently lost its force, for when Speaker Pro Tem. Brookshire called the House to order at 8 o'clock to-night there were not more than sixty Representatives in their seats.
