Buyers of horses had a lively day of it yesterday, for, with two auction sales going on at the same time, and the private sale dealers as eager as ever to cater to their patrons, there was no lack of business for either purchaser or dealer. The prices brought at the auction sales were remarkably good, and were indicative of a strong market.

A fire was discovered in the two-story frame stable in the rear of 49 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn, shortly after 8 o'clock last night. The stable is occupied by S. Soumenstahl and William Fellis, wholesale groceries, and Mrs. Soumenstahl of 162 Ryerson Street, is the owner. The loss was $500.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Ex-Speaker William Sulzer, the Democratio leader in the Assesembly, had a few remarks to make to-day touching the record of the Legislature that had just adjourned. Among other things, he said:

The new cruiser Marblehead, which was recently commissioned at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, will leave the yard this morning and proceed to the lower bay, where her compasses will be adjusted. When the deviation has been ascertained, the vessel will go to an anchorage in the North River, where she will remain until Tuesday morning, when she will trip anchor again and go out to sea for a forty-eight-hour trial.

Judge Gildersleeve of the Superior Court rendered a decision yesterday denying the application to continue the temporary injunction in the suit brought by the Congregation of B'nal Jeshurum against John Jacob Astor, George Lord Day, Philip Kissam, and William Cruikshank, as executors under the will of William Astor, restraining the erection of a stable at Sixty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, almost adjacent to the synagogue.

Col. Tomkinson's diary covers those parts of Napoleon's wars which must always possess for Englishmen the greatest degree of interest -- the parts in which Wellington had his potent share. Col. Tomkinson went out to the Peninsula with his regiment, and, except for Sir John Moore's campaign, he served through the entire period of English operations in that field of war.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- An interesting question is before the War Department now that the criminal courts have acquitted Lieut. J. A. Maney, Fifteenth Infantry, on the charge of killing, at Fort Sheridan, Ill., Capt. Hedberg, an officer of his regiment.

The annex to Grammar School No. 68, in Arthur Hall, in Lenox Avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-sixth and One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Streets, was condemned by the Board of Health on April 9, the building being declared to be unfit for school purposes. The fact of the condemnation did not become public until yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The House Committee on Agriculture to-day completed the Agricultural Appropriation bill for the coming fiscal year. The bill will carry an appropriation of about $2,50,000, being about $148,500 less than the appropriation for the current fiscal year, and about $215,000 above the estimates submitted.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A policeman went to the National Hotel, where George Francis Train is staying, and arrested him this morning on the charge of conducting an unlicensed entertainment here last night. He gave a lecture at Masonic Temple without procuring a preliminary permit from the authorities.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 27 -- Precisely at noon to-day the Great Northern strike went into effect at St. Paul and Minneapolis, and at all points on the line from this city to the coact. The Eastern Minnesota is also involved.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Ex-President Benjamin Harrison recently received a visit from a gentleman who desired to retain his services in the prosecution of certain charges, more or less malicious, against Superintendent Brockway ot the Elmira Reformatory, in New-York State.

The tracks at Gravesend and Sheepshead Bay were in perfect Condition yesterday, having been watered sufficiently to allay the dust. The trials of horses during the morning were numerous, and it took nearly until noon to get them through.

The Directors of the Harlem River Bank, which was closed Thursday by State Bank Examiner Judson, are trying to avert a receivership by raising money to pay depositors at once. If they can clear this debt before the Examiner shall finish his work they will be permitted to take their own time to gather together something for the stockholders.

The people of Montclair should place the blame for their typhoid epidemic where it belongs. There has been a disposition to lay it wholly upon the State Dairy Commissioner, who visited the dairy farm of Gould, the milkman, about a month before the first cases of fever among the consumers of the infected milk were reported, and did not use his authority to prevent the sale of milk from the farm thereafter.

Townsend, Vt., April 27 -- The village of Townsend, seventeen miles north of Brattleborough, suffered severely from fire yesterday afternoon. More than half the business centre of the town, the Baptist Church, the Leland fend Gray Seminary, and a hotel were burned, involving a loss of about $40,000. The loss is partially covered by Insurance.

At auction, in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday, Mr. Peter F. Meyer sold, under foreclosure, at $10,000, to William P. Woodcock, the plaintiff, the three-story brownstone dwelling 6 West One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, south side, 135 feet west of Fifth Avenue, 17.8 by 100.11.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- There is some complaint among army officers about the list of brevets conferred for gallantry in Indian campaigns. It was expected that there would be some faultfinding, but it appears that there have been several conspicuous omissions from the list, and an inquiry has been instituted to discover why certain prominent officers have not been mentioned.

The Commissioner of Public Works yesterday sent to the Mayor a report of the working of his department for the first three months of the present year. It showed the expenditures to be $1,240,786.52; number of contracts entered upon, 106, the estimated cost of which was $482,917.05. The number of contracts completed was 66, the cost of which was $401,732.09.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Republicans exposed to-day their lack of seriousness and also their lack of unity of purpose to defeat the Tariff bill by their puerile performance in the Senate.

There was another fight at the Sixty-ninth Battalion Armory on Thursday night. It began in the armory and ended in a brawl in a saloon on Sixth Street, just across from the armory. The cause was a debt of $68 for printing, owed by Lieut. John E. O'Brien to George Forster, a former member at the Sixty-ninth Regiment.

ALBANY, April 27 -- The Republicans are in a great state of jubilation over the low tax rate, and are pouring congratulations upon Chairman Joseph Mullin of the Finance Committee of the Senate and Danforth E. Ainsworth, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the House, for their great success in keeping down appropriations.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The State Department has received a report from United States Consul O.O. Eckford, at Kingston, Jamaica, describing his search for relics of the Kearsarge on the Cayman Islands. The story of his recovery of relics and their return on Lloyd Phoenix's yacht has already been published.
Dun's Review, in its Issue to-day, will say:
The great evangelistic revival is practically ended. Only one more meeting will be held, and that will be in Niblo's Garden on Sunday afternoon. It will be in the nature of a thanksgiving meeting.
Mayor Gilroy said yesterday it was not in his province to take steps to stop the production of "Hannele." If the performance violated the law, it was for the police to act.

The gentlemen who are interested in the project to give a series of German opera performances next season under the direction of Anton Seidl are much encouraged. Their committee waited on Mr. Henry E. Abbey on Thursday and learned that he and his partners had no objection whatever to such a series of performances in the Metropolitan Opera House either before or after the regular season of grand opera in French and Italian.
LONDON, April 27 -- In the House of Commons to-day the Scotch Local Government bill was introduced by Sir George O. Trevelyan, Secretary for Scotland.

About 100,000 tons of Bessemer pig iron were sold at the furnaces of the Pittsburg and Eastern Ohio districts last week, and the price paid for one lot of 10,000 tons at Pittsburg was $10 per ton. "It is 'claimed," says the Pittsburg correspondent of The Iron Age, "that $9.75 at valley furnace was the lowest price touched in the transactions and $10 the highest."

The last night of the opera was a genuine fete. The auditorium of the Opera House was packed last evening to its utmost capacity. The number of persons who stood up was so great that it was almost impossible to get in or out of the house after the performance had once begun. Society was out in full force and the boxes gleamed with satin and glittered with Jewels.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., April 27 -- Another Adirondack hotel, making the third within ten days, has been destroyed by fire. This time it is the Mountain View House, at Bloomingdale, which was filled with city guests. The fire started in the kitchen about noon, and a strong wind caused the flames to spread.

The annual dinner in celebration of the birthday of Gen. Ulysses S. Grant, which was arranged by a committee consisting of Gen. Grenville M. Dodge, George H. Taylor, Gen. Horace Porter, Gen. Charles H.T. Collis, and others, took place last night in the state dining room of the Hotel Waldorf. There were about 120 persons present.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Democrats of the Senate are now so well united on the Tariff bill as to leave little reason to doubt early and favorable action on that measure. The Republicans admit as much in every controversy which now arises in the chamber. That they are greatly disturbed is evident to all observers.

Annexation of the Kings County towns to Brooklyn is practically an accomplished fact. The first great step toward the creation of "The Greater New-York" is assured by the action of the Legislature which has just adjourned.

The Chamber of Commerce Rapid-Transit Committee will meet this morning to consider the status of the bill at Albany. A call was issued for the meeting late Thursday afternoon, before the Legislature had acted. It was then thought that it might be desirable to reinforce the delegation at Albany, and possibly to arrange, for a hearing before the Governor in case an acceptable bill should be passed.

ATHENS, April 27 -- A heavy shock of earthquake was felt here at 9:20 o'clock this evening. It lasted fifteen seconds. The weekly Epitaphion procession was in progress and the Cathedral was crowded. The windows of the edifice shook ominously, and several objects fell to the floor. Women screamed and somebody shouted that the building was falling.

ADAIR, Iowa, April 27 -- The weather and wagons were both against the movement of the Industrial Army this morning. The Transportation Committee announced that 150 teams would be ready this morning to carry the army, but only about twenty wagons appeared. Then it began to rain, and the men in the Sacramento division, numbering 120, started down the railroad track toward the east singing "Drill, Ye Terriers, Drill."

Henry Newman Co., wholesale dealers in clothiers' supplies at 628 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Nathaniel Myers of the firm of Anable Myers of 45 Wall Street, without preferences. The failure follows the extension of credit given by the firm's creditors last September. At that time the firm owed $1,500,000, and it gave notes for the amount, one-third to be paid in eight, twelve, and fifteen months, respectively.

The Protest Committee of the Brooklyn Women's Anti-Suffrage League met yesterday afternoon, at the residence of Mrs. William A. Putnam, 70 Willow Street, and decided to engage official headquarters without further delay.

At auction, in Brooklyn, Mr. Jacob Cole has sold to John H. Waydell, at $75,000, the one-story brick warehouse 99 to 109 Plymouth Street, northeast corner of Washington Street, 115 by 414.11, to bulkhead line, by -- by 397.9. To the same purchaser, at $15,000, he sold the lumber yard, two-story brick store, and stable at 104 to 116 Plymouth Street, 115.5 by 100.

Rumors of an attempt to bribe Grand Jurymen flew about the corridors of the General Sessions Building yesterday afternoon. They were caused by a vague report that a policeman picked up an envelope in the Grand Jury room which contained "between $1 and $500." It was said that the envelope dropped from a Grand Juryman's overcoat, which was carelessly thrown over a chair.

GAITHERSBURG, Md., April 27 -- Gen. Coxey's army reached this place at 2 P.M. to-day, after a dry and dusty march, and under the direction of a citizen's committee, camped a quarter of a mile east of the town.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 27 -- At the request of Superintendent Peabody of the Midland Railway, Gov. McKinley to-night issued a special commission to John Mahoney, Chief of Detectives of this city, to organize a posse to go to Mount Sterling and rescue a train that has been captured there by Galvin's army.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 27 -- Nine men have met violent deaths in Madison Parish in the last week, and eight of these have been lynched by infuriated citizens. The last four were hanged last night, the news just reaching this city.

This afternoon the New-York and Baltimore Baseball Clubs will play the opening game of the series scheduled for this city, and from the present outlook the Polo Grounds will be taxed to their utmost capacity. The Giants arrived home from Washington early yesterday morning and spent the afternoon in practice at the grounds.

The first regular monthly meeting of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs since the annual election of officers was held at the Columbia, Fourteenth Street, near Broadway, last night. President A. Edmund Hildick presided. There was a large attendance of delegates, and some important business was transacted.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Acting Governor Gill countermanded his order to send the First Regiment of the Illinois militia to Toluca. The dispersion of the striking miners after they had been addressed by the Governor, made the presence of troops unnecessary.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Sparks flew in both houses of the Legislature just before final adjournment to-day. For an hour the Senate was tied up on the Huckleberry Railway bill, owing to the filibustering tactics of the Democrats, who seemed to be able to do as they pleased.

The plan of reorganization of the New-York and New-England Railroad, prepared by the committee of which John I. Waterbury is Chairman, was made public yesterday. It provides for the creation of a new company, which is to be invested with the title to the railroad and other property, and, so far as possible, with the franchises of the present company, or an existing company or companies, or charters, or both, will be made use of.

A great deal or the ill-health of our delicate girls arises from repression of their young energy. The boys, too, would be hysterical if their youth were hedged in with so many conventional restraints that there would be no room left for self-restraint, if everything they wore, every word they spoke, every youthful grace and beauty, every intellectual endowment, were habitually looked upon and openly spoken of as making them more salable articles.
PARIS, April 28. -- At 7:40 P.M. Emile Henry, the Anarchist, was found guilty and sentenced to death. When the sentence was pronounced, he shouted: "Comrades, courage! Vive 1' Anarchie!"

Thirty members of the Young Ladies' Charitable Society appeared as minstrels last evening to raise funds for distribution among deserving families, irrespective of race or religion. The yourig women had their faces and hands blackened and wore dress coats and other details of gentlemen's evening dress, except that they had black skirts.

Mr. Cleveland made no mistake in nominating to the Senate Mr. Hugh R. Smith for Postmaster of Petersburg. Indeed, he could not have more faithfully fulfilled the wishes of the business people and of the Democratic people -- in fact, or all the people of this city, irrespective of party, than he has in this nominataion.

Many roots are tolerably rich in sugar; everybody must have noticed its presence in carrots; from which, indeed, it has even at times been commercially extracted. But sugar is still more abundant in the beet, whose juice contains about 15 per cent. of crystalljzable sucrose. As an industry, the production of beet-root sugar has a curious history.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Brooklyn started in to-day's baseball game by batting Petty out of the box, and thereby gained a lead which, it was belived, the Senators could not overcome. Three two-baggers, a single, a base on balls, and battery errors netted the visitors 7 runs, and they added another in the second on a triple and a single.

LONDON, April 28. -- It is just twenty-five years since the last measure to disestablish an official Church was introduced to Parliament by a responsible Minister. Many reflections on the methods of British politics are suggested by this fact: that it has taken Wales a quarter of a century of bitter agitation, to reach even the first stage of relief given to Ireland in 1869.
A young woman, a Latin enthusiast, who journeyed 600 miles to see the Latin play in Cambridge, last week, writes of her trip:
The annexation of more county towns to Brooklyn is expected to be followed by much activity in real estate in those towns. Evidences of this as regards,Flatbush are already apparent.

BABYLON, L.I., April 28. -- Sixty prominent sporting men witnessed the closing pigeon shoot at the Westminster Kennel Club to-day. They arrived on a special train at about 10 A.M., and were driven directly to the grounds, where the fun commenced at once.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The members of Congress from the agricultural States take great interest in the weather reports which are daily received in the lobbies of the Senate and the House. These reports are now so comprehensive that it is possible to tell the exact state of the weather each day in every part of the United States.
The following is a detailed list of the property scheduled to be sold at auction during the present week, the sales to take place at 111 Broadway, except in the two instances mentioned for Thursday:

BENNINGTON, Vt., April 28 -- The 1st of May will see about every manufacturing establishment in this town in full operation. The Bennington woolen mill, the largest establishment of any kind in the State except one, is run night and day. The knitting mill of William Campbell is running on full time with its regular force, and it is the only one in which wages have not been cut.

TUESDAY, May 1-- By Smyth Ryan, foreclosure sale, John Delahunty, referee, 142 to 150 Worth Street, extending through to 3 and 6 Mission Place, 116.5 by 61.1 by 31 by 81 by 24.3 by 82.5 to Mission Place by 66.9, five-story brick store buildings. Due on Judgment, $106,707.

In the lovely mornings of the late Spring days as the sun rises above the horizon he decks the dew-laden foliage with glittering gems, sends gleams of golden light far into the woods, and wakes up all to life and activity. By this time old Sol has been journeying with such great rapidity that he has completed about two-thirds of his route from the equator to his highest point north for the year.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The army ordnance officers have heard with some interest the account of the accident to the Woodbridge wire-wound gun at the Sandy Hook Proving Ground. It appears that the gun was ruptured after the twenty-first round, although the conditions of the test were not abnormal.

A meeting will be held at 8 o'clock this evening at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, in the interest of Hampton Institute. The company of colored and Indian students who have been North with their Principal, Dr. Frissell, for a week, will take a prominent part in the exercises, while advocates of the industrial education of the two races will deliver addresses.

BOSTON, April 28. -- The interclub fencing between teams of the Boston Fencing Club and the New-York Fencers' Club, which had been announced for to-night, was declared off to-day. The New-Yorkers telegraphed that they could not come, without, however, giving any reason. M. Vauthier also declined to come on and fence M. Rondelle. Invitations had been distributed freely, and the flasco is deeply regretted by the officers of the Boston fencing Club.

ROCKVILLE, Md., April 28. -- The Coxey army marched into town at 10:30 o'clock this morning. The Philadelphia contingent, known as "Jones's army" threw their support to the Commonweal, and refused to recognize the Smith crowd. Jones is in Philadelphia, gathering more men, and the army was in the hands of Thomas G. Clinton, a carpenter by trade, and a very intelligent-looking man.

The cricket team of the Stately Island Athletic Club had every preparation made for the opening of the season yesterday at West New-Brighton, and, although the rain somewhat interfered, with its arrangements, it played its scheduled game with the Somersetshire eleven and succeeded in carrying off the victory by 5 runs.

"I don't believe in eternally compromising," said Dr. Mary Putnam Jacobi, with considerable asperity, at a meeting of the Fifth Avenue Political Equality Committee, at the home of Miss Harris, 56 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon. She was referring to the women representing the anti-suffrage protest, who have headquarters at the "Waldorf.

"And what is the name that you say all the fellows call Miss Monica Abercrombie when they speak of her in that expansive locality 'behind her back'?" asked James Winn, the practical man, of his friend, Cyrll Creighton, the dreamer.

It is interesting to note as the Spring advances the striking differences between the items of the bank statements and those reported a year ago. Yesterday the total average reserve was brought up to $226,881,400, an increase of nearly $2,500,000 during the week, leaving the surplus reserve at $83,417,950.

MOUNT STERLING, Ohio, April 28. -- All of Galvin's army of Coxeyites, which has been in possession of a stolen train for nearly two days, surrendered to Col. Coit this afternoon, as soon as the troops were drawn up in line.
The number of good whist players among women has increased of late years to an extent that will mike the following account of a new method for the game interesting to women readers:

Henry Newman Co., wholesale dealers in clothiers supplies at 628 and 630 Broadway, have received many letters from their creditors expressing sympathy for their misfortune. The firm hopes to be able to make a speedy arrangement with its creditors for a resumption of business, and some of the creditors yesterday expressed the opinion that a compromise might be made at 50 or 70 cents on the dollar.

This house is in a street which leads one in a direct line to the dock of the French steamer. There are flowers in rectangular boxes painted blue at the windows. There are white bobbinet curtains against the small window panes. The floor is waxed, the walls are bare, and the waiter has taken the white tablecloths from the tables, thus transforming a restaurant into a cafe.
THURSDAY, May 3 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., executor's sale, 144 Goerck Street, east side, seventy-five feet south of Houston Street, 25 by 100, two-story brick and frame stable.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- A call issued by Joseph B. Buchanan of New-York, formerly, a prominent member of the Knights of Labor, brought representative trades unionists to-day to Woodman's Hall to consider a proposition to form a new national trade organization, which would absorb the Knights of Labor, the American Federation of Labor, and all kindred organizations.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 28. -- The old war Secretary of State in Connecticut, J. Hammond Trumbull of this city, is one of the most picturesque figures now left of the times of Gov. Buckingham. Some time ago he gave up the exacting duties of librarian in the Watkinson Library of Reference here and the Yale Lectureship on Indian Languages, but he is still a busy and thoughtful man.

The opponents of the movement to procure suffrage for women by endeavoring to induce the forthcoming Constitutional Convention to strike out the word "male" in the Constitution as a qualification for voters have placed a new "catechism" in circulation. It is taken from last week's issue of The American Woman, and is in part as follows:

Adolph Noekel, a young bookkeeper, said to belong to a wealthy German family, was committed to the Tombs yesterday by Coroner Dobbs to await the action of the Grand Jury. Seven members of the Coroner's jury were agreed that Mrs. Noekel died of natural causes, five that she died from injuries received from causes unknown to them.

The bulk of the horses lived in so sorry a fashion that it was a mere farce to divide their poor carcasses into the three categories of first quality, second quality, and "filet." They fell dead of debility and leanness on their way to the slaughter houses. It is easy to imagine that the "bouillon" and cutlets from such steeds were not strong in nourishing qualities.

American railway securities were weak in the London market. The principal changes were: Declined -- Union Pacific, 1 1/3, to 19 1/4; St. Paul, 7/8, to 62 3/8; Louisville and Nashville, 5/8, to 50 1/8; Northern Pacific preferred, 1/2, to 19 1/8; Canadian Pacific, 3/8, to 68 1/2; Kansas and Texas, 3/8, to 15; Atchison, 1/4, to 14 1/8; Erie, 1/4, to 16 1/4, and Ontario and Western, 1/8, to 16.

Felix Mendelsshon was possessed of dual qualities, for, aside from his musical genius, he had a special literary talent. Mr. Alexander has collected thirty-three of his letters. Familiar as we may be with Hensel's "The Mendelssohn Family," the volume brings a renewal of pleasure. "There are still," writes Sir George Grove, "many who, much as they enjoy his music, do not know Mendelssohn in his almost equally attractive character as a letterwriter."

The monthly dinner of the Democratic Club of the City of New-York was held last night at the clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue. Gov. Flower, Frederic R. Coudert, ex-Speaker William Sulzer, Congressman Benton McMillin of Tennessee, and State Senator Jacob A. Cantor were invited to the dinner, but they sent letters of regret.

The new Democratic organization in Kings County is now prepared for active work. The reports yesterday at the Montague Street headquarters from the primary elections of Friday night were very satisfactory to friends of honest and efficient party management.

PARIS, Monday, April 9. -- Circumstances twice took me yesterday into a crowded horse car. Be It said for the better undertanding of those who do not know, that the interior of the cars here are never jammed. Law forbids. The people have the three-cent privilege of standing, either on the front or the rear platform, and a good joiting time they have of it, even if the fresh air is sometimes cheering.

There were reported at the Bureau of Vital Statistics during the week ended at noon yesterday 781 deaths, 1,056 births, and 234 marriages. The death rate in an estimated population of 1,945,873 was 20.94. Of the deaths, 499, were in tenement houses and 170 in public institutions; 309 were of children under five years and 92 of persons sixty-flve years and over.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- With a range of 1/4c in May and 1/8@1/4c in July it can be easily understood that the character of to-day's market was dull. The May was changed into July in small lots, and so equally divided were the long and short lines that the spread did not widen more thaw 1/8c from, the difference ruling at the close yesterday.
Senator Charles L. Guy in The Mail and Express. I think the Legislature of 1894 has been principally distinguished by two very opposite characteristics -- personal integrity and political hypocrisy.

The operatic season which has just closed at the Metropolitan Opera House was significant in more ways than one. In the first place, in spite of some absurd and prejudiced attempts to demonstrate that it was a pecuniary failure, it was a great success, and Messrs. Abbey, Schoeffel Grau have made a good round profit.
The new North German Lloyd steamship Wittekind made her first appearance in this port yesterday. Her maiden voyage, which was from Bremen, was accomplished in fourteen days.

Palm sugar, or jaggary, which is probably one of the earliest forms of crystalized sugar known to humanity, is procured from the sap of the cut flower stalk. By a singular provision of nature -- very obnoxious, no doubt, to Sir Wilfrid Lawson, but dear to the souls of unregenerate humanity -- whatever produces sugar for one's toddy produces also on the same stem the toddy to put it in.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., April 28. -- The coke region is controlled by the strikers. Of eighty-six works the only plants in regular operation are Moyer, Fort Hill, Paul Rainey of the Rainey Company, Pennsville of the Pennsville Coke Company, and Southwest of the Southwest Connellsville Coal and Coke Company.

Owing to the carelessness of the brakemen on a train on the bridge yesterday morning, there was a rear-end collision which resulted in one passenger being injured, a damage of $50 to the cars, and the dismissal of four brakemen.

"I'll kill you, you're drunk!" was part of the language used by Barach Kahn, a real estate agent at 784 Greenwich Street, to Mme. Lina Lockwood, music teacher, of 19 Bethune Street, Thursday evening at Kahn's home. Other testimony against Kahn at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday was that the murderous threat was made while he held Mme. Lockwood by the throat, and was accompanied by foul words and profanity and brutal violence.

To the accompaniment of exhilarating music and the air-shattering shouts of thousands of rain-defying cranks, the New-Yorks yesterday afternoon took partial revenge from the mortifying defeats suffered at Baltimore on the opening of the league season. The Orioles flew down upon the New-York coop with loud chirps of exultation, but they left bedraggled with Harlem mud and with drooping feathers.

Mrs. Henry Ward Beecher, kindly and gracious, known and loved as the wife of the great Brooklyn preacher, respected and revered for her own strong personality, bears well her many years of active life.

That suggestion of a possible marriage bad stirred the waters of Marah in Brandon Mountford's memory. In every man's mind there is some Marab pool which needs but a breath to disturb its bitter waters. With him the pool lay still and deep, yet he had an ever-present consciousness that it was there, a silent sorrow, which made his life different from, the lives of other young men.

A man who was not identified was killed yesterday at Ninety-second Street and Third Avenue and eight-year-old Emily Tauz seriously injured by a runaway horse belonging to Julius Ditcher, keeper of a delicatessen store at 219 East Thirty-eighth Street. The horse ran on to the sidewalk. The wagon's wheels knocked Emily down, and she was severely bruised and cut.

Over the ocean blue go the song birds. The grand opera season has just closed, gone out in a blaze of glory, and following it many operatic stars made their exit yesterday. They go to Europe, but have promised -- some of them -- to return in the Fall.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of the well-known dry goods firm of James McCreery Co., at Eleventh Street and Broadway, was celebrated last evening at the St. Denis Hotel by a banquet and reception tendered to Mr. James McCreery by his employes.
Few women have had a life history containing so many thrilling experiences as a little Englishwoman who is just now making her home in the city and lecturing on India.

On Thursday and Friday a committee of Virginians examined the statue of the Confederate soldier just cast at the Henry Bonnard Bronze Company in West Sixteenth Street. They were accompanied by the designer of the statue, Mr. William L. Sheppard, whose work as an Illustrator for the press has been seen in New-York for the past thirty years, but who now lives in Richmond.

BERLIN, April 28. -- German politicians and officials are asking what shall be done with Samoa. The question is regarded with profound indifference by the general public, but, as it is the only political topic of any present importance, it has been little less than a godsend to the Berlin editors, who have been driven to their wits' ends for high politics during the even dullness of the last week.

That the horse market is in a thoroughly healthy condition was shown by the sales of the past week, which have been numerous and of the most varied character. Values have found something like a commonsense basis. Inflated and absurd prices for horse flesh, such as were the rule three years ago, have vanished.

The author of "Ships That Pass in the Night" has here collected seven short stories and sketches to which the title she has chosen scarcely applies. Miss Harraden, in truth, seems always to be in the same mood. It may vary as to its degrees of intensity, but is always sombre and melancholy. Sickness and misery and vice and suicide, social inequality and spiritual discontent, are ever her themes.

NEW-HAVEN., Conn., April 28. -- Extra police precautions are being made here to prevent any demonstration resulting from the march of the New-England Coxeyites, who will pass through here Monday. This city will prove a rallying place for several bands of recruits for, the Coxey cause.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- One of the Washington papers has been supplying its readers with accounts of the advance of the Coxey Army of "wanderers from choice," and at great length and with careful minuteness has described the campings and the marchings of the body.

In the modern trade of story telling there ate still a few unskilled workmen here and there, perhaps, but a far greater number of artisans who know the tricks of their trade completely, and can fill a required number of printed pages with good "salable matter" at any time. The seed has been scattered far and wide, and the harvest is plentiful.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, April 28. -- Two vessels of the Bering Sea fleet -- the revenue cutter Corwin and the Fish Commission steamer Albattoss -- left here this morning to take on coal and stores for the coming cruise. The Corwin proceeded to Seattle, and the Albatross to Whatcom. Orders for the sailing of the Bering Sea fleet are expected by Monday next.

An enterprise which foreshadows success by reason of the broad basis upon which it is conceived is the Pan-American Commercial Exhibit, which seeks to found in this city a permanent commercial museum. Its chief object is the fostering of commerce between this and other countries, especially, with those of the South and Central American republics.

The junior, sophomore, and freshman eights of Columbia College rowed their annual race on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon. The sophomores rather surprised those present by winning. It was expected that the freshmen would win, as they have been training very carefully for some time.

The part played by bees on a certain occasion was, if the Abbe della Rocca is to be believed, equally effective. "Amurath, the Turkish Emperor," says our authority, "during one of his sieges, had made a breach in the wall, and was about to storm the town, when he found that about the breach the inhabitants had placed numerous hives of bees.

Sorosis has made an Innovation in the order of exercises at her business meetings. Hereafter some well-known person will speak upon an interesting topic. Last Monday, Mrs. Olive Thorne Miller, of bird lore fame, addressed the meeting. Art is the topic announced for the next social meeting, May 7.

Steinitz and Lasker will meet on Tuesday at Montreal, in order to contest the final series of games. The young expert leads the champion with seven to two wins, two games having been drawn. Steinitz said to a reporter for The New-York Times: "Give me sleep, and I don't see why I could not score eight straights, since Lasker has scored, five."

President Charles Stewart Smith, Cornelius N. Bliss, J. Edward Simmons, and John A. Stewart of the Special Committee on Rapid Transit front the Chamber of Commerce held a meeting yesterday morning and decided to ask Gov. Flower for a hearing before he determines what shall be the fate of the rapid-transit measure now before him. They desire to speak for the bill.

LONDON, April 28. -- First nighters rarely hear such an outburst of enthusiastic cheering as greeted the close of the third act of Henry Arthur Jones's "The Masqueraders" at the St. James's Theatre this evening. So assured did success appear that there were even then cries for the author, but there followed a brief fourth act to complete the play, and when, the curtain fell on this the enthusiasm had very largely evaporated.

For many years he meditated a heroic poem on the Siege of Jerusalem by Titus, and among other projected works were a "Treatise on the Corn Laws," a "History of German Belles-lettres," a "Book of Morals," in answer to Godwin;
A group of brokers standing near one of the "boards" on the Stock Exchange was interrupted yesterday by the cry of "One ball."

A spectacular fairy play, in which the scenery is the work of good artists, the costumes are all of the richest fabrics, and the music is taken from Weber, Schubert, Rubinstein, Mendelssohn, Delibes, and Rossini, not to mention Tosti, Edward German, and the composer of "Daisy," or the creditable melodies of Oscar Barrett, is worth a second word or two.
Marsena Pulford, what time the village of Octavius knew him, was a slender and tall man, apparently skirting upon the thirties, with sloping shoulders and a romantic aspect.

There is no paper more thoroughly enlisted in behalf of the interests of the true soldier and the worthy pensioner than The Times. It would be the last paper in the world to discredit any pensioner or any applicant for a pension who is deserving, but it is against the multitude of pensioners who are not worthy, who do not need Government aid, and who would not deserve it if they did need it.

Republicans have figured out a beautifully-plain course for Mayor Gilroy, as regards a Police Commissionership. The term of Police Commissioner MacLean will expire to-morrow. He is a Democrat. He was appointed as a representative of the County Democracy, and has been counted an anti-Tammany member of the Police Board.

Lorenzo Ritto of 60 Spring Street walked into Chambers Street Hospital yesterday afternoon, and asked for treatment. He was sent to Bellevue Hospital on suspicion of having smallpox, but was allowed to remain in the male examining room while waiting for Dr. Benedict, the Board of Health examining physician.

From The Railroad Gazette. However much esteem Mr. Harris merited for his ability as a railroad manager, and he had long been counted among the first, probably every man who knew him at all well, whether a humble railroad employe or an influential Director, will agree that his chief distinction was in his character.

It was learned yesterday in Brooklyn that the April Grand Jury has been investigating the management and the circumstances of the failure of the Commercial Bank, which closed its doors on Aug. 12, 1893.

Justice Calvin E. Pratt of the Kings County Supreme Court was prostrated with a slight stroke of paralysis on Thursday while on his way from his home, at 1,483 Pacific Street, to his physician's, Dr. Charles M. Bellows, Nostrand and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn.

Stated concisely, this volume shows the relations of wages and work time to production, for Mr. Brentano believes that an understanding of these various factors, and of the lessons they teach, will tend to the betterment of social conditions.

BOSTON, Mass., April 28 -- The fine weather of the past week has set yachtsmen to thinking about getting afloat, and the result has been a rush in the yards in the work of fitting out. All the yards are very busy, and the launching of yachts will soon be a matter of daily happening.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., April 28 -- Port Jefferson is one of those sleepy old towns on Long Island that one often reads about, but seldom sees. It was settled in 1820, and seems to be in about the same condition now as it must have been when the old shipbuilders first set up their shops here.

R.C. Haff, who has charge of the small coin division at the Sub-Treasury, and several of his associates were kept busy yesterday by a crowd of coin collectors; who formed in line before their desks and asked to be allowed to inspect a mass of old-fashioned copper pennies which had been received there.

Thousands of citizens in Brooklyn are indignant at the failure of the State Legislature, which adjourned on Friday, to pass a "cat-tagging" law such as was passed for New-York City. In many quarters it is alleged that this discrimination against Brooklyn was due to certain people in Brooklyn itself, people who did not scruple to use all the influences at their command to prevent the application of the law which New-Yorkers enjoy.

The biographers of Lincoln, Messrs. Nicolay and Hay, have done well to follow up their biography with an edition of Lincoln's speeches, letters, and state papers. The publishers have issued the work in binding uniform with the biography, but in the printed page it differs widely from it.

ORANGE, N.J., April 28. -- The Fresh Air Fund benefit performances of the Tableaus Phantasma, given in Music Hall last night, this afternoon, and to-night, under the auspices of the Hakuai Circle of King's Daughters, were most successful. Among the 100 or more people who took part in the entertainment were the members of Company H, Second Regiment, and the Orange Athletic Club football team of 1893.

SING SING, N.Y., April 28. -- The Finance Committee of the Village Board of Trustees has presented its report for the fiscal year which has just expired, and it makes the following exhibit: During the year the roads cost $11,384.02; gas and water, $12,834.57; fire, $1,558.72; police, $1,663.45; sidewalks and crosswalks, $580.21, and other minor expenses, making a total of $20,682.83.

A movement is on foot to get together a number of representative riding and driving men of this city and have them form a club, to be known as the Suburban Club. Steps have already been taken to insure the success of the enterprise, and to-morrow evening, at 8:30 o'clock, a general meeting will be held at the Plaza Hotel.

No laurels await the returning Kings County legislators in Brooklyn. Considered collectively, their work has been disappointing to enlightened citizens. Neither in Senate nor Assembly have they measured up to the expectations of the public. An expression of opinion from men who have attentively watched their work would be far from nattering to them.
A unique organization about to be formed in Washington, D.C., is a bachelor girls' club for the purpose of determining and maintaining the position of unmarried, women in society.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 28. -- All the southern ports of the republic have been occupied by the Government troops and navigation along the whole coast has been declared free to Brazilian steamships. The Government commanders encountered virtually no opposition at any of the coast cities. In most cases not a shot was fired.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The Republicans of the Senate continue to advertise the fact that the Democrats are fast nearing an agreement upon the Tariff bill Mr. Aldrich made that point pretty, clear yesterday, and to-day Mr. Hale, speaking for the Republicans, devoted some time to strained criticisms of the Democratic plan of making agreements, to the end that every Democratic vote in the chamber may be cast for the bill.

The Texas State campaign was opened with a great Democratic rally at Gonzales Saturday, April 21, at which the leading address was delivered by the Hon. George Clark, the opponent of Governor Hogg in the last campaign. In the course of his remarks Judge Clark said:

Those Democratic members of the Assembly who have returned to this city from Albany bring confident prediction that the Republican Legislature's work has made excellent capital with which the Democrats of this State can go before the public in the election next Fall.

Beginning with the first services in May there will be an entire change in the music in Grace Church, of which Dr. Willlam R. Huntington is rector. About a year ago considerable dissatisfaction was expressed with the music, and the charge was made that it was antiquated. For many years a double quartet has been employed under the direction of Organist Samuel P. Warren.

Green is the meadow, a tenderer green marks the larch boughs; the coppice trees are in bud; the thrush warbles from the elms, the chiffchaff sings from the ash boughs; the early trout are rising at the first insect life, and ignoring that imitated by the enthusiastic angler, who utters the only jarring note in the concert.

A historian of music in America has said that three great factors have been at work in spreading a love for the tone art in this country. These factors are the Church, the stage, and the German choral society. The Church manifested its influence mostly in New-England, the operatic stage in New-York and its neighborhood, and the German Gesangverein in the North-west.

Those who visited the White City when the great show was on will doubtless remember the imperial Persian exhibit, wherein were shown in warp and woof the choicest specimens of Oriental art. The exhibition was under the direction of H.H. Topakyan, the Acting Commissioner General for the Shah of Persia. It was given seventy-two awards, which was the highest number received by any one exhibit in the exposition.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., April 28. -- Over 1,100 industrials, who left Oakland yesterday afternoon on the steamer Alvira, landed at New-Hope this morning, and marched to Walnut Grove, on their way to Sacramento. They will arrive late to-night, or early tomorrow morning.

The Chamber of Commerce committee proposes to urge strongly upon the Governor the approval of the Rapid-Transit bill, as it was finally extorted from the Legislature. Presumably they will be prepared with arguments in support of the validity of the referendum provision, and it is to be hoped that they will be able to make that clear.

Taking out my glass, I made out an Ibex climbing the cliff and another on the face of a rock, at the base of which the dogs were vehemently baying it. It was only a female, and G., who got up to it first, declined to shoot, but climbed 2,000 feet higher in the vain hope of catching sight of the other, which was a young male.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., April 28. -- Charles Clement, a Cuban, was released from the First Precinct Police Station, this city, to-day, where he had been for two days recovering from the effects of a plunge into Hell Gate and a beating at the hands of two officers of the tramp steamer Highfields of Liverpool.

The title to a great deal of the property which the now defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn too from Paul C. Grening, through Elbert Snedeker, in part return for the large sums of money advanced to Grening, is coming into dispute in the Brooklyn courts.

A new form of marine boiler, which is attracting much attention just now, is the Yarrow water-tube boiler. It was fitted in the British torpedo boat destroyer Hornet, and, according to a recent cable dispatch, that craft attained the phenomenal speed of 28 knots per hour on her trial trip, which took place March 1.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 28. -- A hardfought ball game was partly played here to-day by the Yale and University of Pennsylvania baseball nines. An hour before the time scheduled for the beginning of the match rain began to fall. Several hundred persons, however, assembled to witness the contest, which was begun despite the shower. Considering the slippery ball and field, some great catches were made.

For the last twenty years the Allan and State Line steamers to New-York have sailed from Glasgow on a Friday, and no evil consequences have been found to follow. It has lately been decided to change the sailings from America from Thursday to Friday. Thereupon one of the American agents of the company forwards a protest that it will be impossible for him to get his party to sail on that day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read in your issue of April 21 the extracts from Gen. O.O. Howard's lecture. Without attempting to discuss the relative merits of the Confederate Generals as criticised by the General, it seems to me curious that a soldier of his reputation should have made such glaring errors, if his remarks have been correctly reported.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- John K. Cowan, the general counsel of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, appeared before the House Commerce Committee to-day and made an argument which elicited the warm commendation of the committee.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Secretary Herbert has prepared several propositions as a relief to the stagnation in the line of the navy, and he will shortly submit them to the Joint Committee on Naval Personnel. They are amendments to the original suggestion furnished by the Secretary some time ago.

LONDON, April 28. -- Lord Rosebery's policy is finally assuming the semblance of definite shape. The Premier's speech at the meeting of the City Liberal Club last Tuesday evening forewarns his party and the country that the new course of the Government will be vastly different from that of Mr. Gladstone.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The New-York Times has figured a good deal in several of the recent Friday-night sessions of the House of Representatives, and again on Friday night last it came up to vex the men who cannot stand the exposures of unworthy pensioners, as made by The Times after careful investigation.

The tennis players of the preparatory schools in and around New-York will display their prowess on May 7 at the Columbia Athletic Field at William's Bridge. The Columbia section of the preliminary tournaments for the interscholastic championship will be decided. Any pupil attending a collegiate school in New-York City or the neighborhood is eligible, and the pupils of private tutors may compete.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

Chief of Police Eustace of Gravesend will undertake a gigantic job to-day, one that John Y. McKane would not have undertaken under any circumstances -- that of closing up the dives in the west end of Coney Island. It is not Chief Eustace's intention to close the hotels or legitimate places of business, but he will concentrate his work in closing the dance halls and dives that have flourished, especially in the Bowery, for years.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 28. -- A Week of perfect Lakewood weather has delighted the guests at this resort. A revival of out door sports has come with the pleasant days. Boating and tennis, with the usual walking and driving, go to fill the time, while the baseball games played on the athletic grounds of Lakewood Heights School are of absorbing interest to the cottagers.

At the funerals of great personages, the old chronicles tell us, "his lively effigy," dressed to imitate life, was carried in a chariot before the corpse to the grave, then there set up under a "hearse" or a temporary monument in the church; such effigies were often left in a glass case standing over the vault where the interment had taken place.

Because their fathers could get no work. so say Gussie Jacobs, ten years old, of 39 East Broadway; Annie Marks, eleven years old, and Annie Blum, eleven years old, of 96 Henry Street, the children sold newspapers on the Bowery. They were arrested Saturday night and taken to the Essex Market Police Court yesterday.

JAMAICA, L.I., April 29 -- The mysterious death of Mrs. Mary J. Smith, whose body was found early Saturday morning in the Woodhaven Water Works reservoir, a few blocks from her home, in Brooklyn Hills, remains unexplained. Mrs. Nellie Cadwell, her demented daughter, who is supposed to have accompanied her mother to the reservoir, is closely guarded by the family.

ALBANY, April 28 -- The local security market for the past week was not as prolific of events as the previous one. There was, however, a fair inquiry and a somewhat diminished amount of offerings for local stocks and bonds. There were numerous changes in quotations and the general tendency of prices was toward a higher level.
PORTLAND, Oregon, April 29. -- Marshal Grady returned to Portland at 5:20 o'clock this morning with 435 of the 507 Coxeyltes who left Troutdale on a stolen Union Pacific train yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29. -- The changes in the nine on Thursday were important, because they show the solution of a problem which has been bothering the Captain and coaches for weeks. Having proved himself absolutely inefficient at short, Stevenson has been a load upon the team, yet there seemed to be no available candidate for the position.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The engineer officers of the navy are again wrought up over the action of a naval retiring board in the case of one of their associates. Chief Engineer R.I. McNary. That officer, while on the Philadelphia at Honolulu, attempted to take his own life as a result of ill health, brought on by overwork.

The business men of New-York will ask the national Senate to pass the Tariff bill with as little delay as possible. More than 100 of the most substantial firms in this city have united in a call for a mass meeting which may voice their sentiments in this matter.

LYONS, April 29. -- The exhibition of arts, sciences, and industries was opened here tolay. A throng of conspicuous men attended the ceremonies. The whole Cabinet was present, but the President, as was predicted some time ago, was unable to come.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Those members of Congress who have been inclined to believe that there is lack of liberal sentiment in New-York on the question of merchant-marine development ought to be reminded that there is a law on the books of the State exempting all vessels in the foreign trade from all State and local taxes.

Danforth E. Aisworth of Oswego County, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly and leader of the majority on the floor, said yesterday that he thought the Legislature which adjourned last week had been the best he had ever seen. Mr. Ainsworth was at the Park Avenue Hotel.
Dr. O.G. CILLEY, Boston, Mass., says: "I have used it very extensively, and with the most remarkable success in dyspepsia, and in all cases where there is derangement of the liver and kidneys."

WILMINGTON, Del., April 29. -- At the Republican primaries held throughout New-Castle County yesterday afternoon, Senator Anthony Higgins won a substantial victory It was the first of a series of battles that Higgins must win to succeed himself as United States Senator from Delaware, in the event that the Republicans gain control of the next Legislature, and the result indicates that, as far as New-Castle County is concerned, he will come out a sure winner.

Prof. Goodyear has accepted the appointment of lecturer on the history of arts before the Teachers' College. The date of the course is to be determined upon and announced at the close of the allege session. Prof. Goodyear is well known as in authority on historic arts and as the author if "The Grammar of the Lotus."

The bond market for last week was devoid of special features, outside of the continued demand for securities of the highest grade, as was strongly evidenced by the prices and number of bidders for several new loans awarded. The one-million-two-hundred-thousand-dollar City of Providence 4 per cent. loan was awarded at 111,119, and there were twenty-one bids received.

The recommendation by the Common Council of Brooklyn in favor of the introduction of the German system, of calisthenics and gymnastics into the public-school curriculum of that city is hailed by its friends as a most important victory, and one that presages the not-far-distant success of the agitation which has been going on in behalf of school gymnastics in the City of Churches.

There is no modern country in the politics of which what may be called ordinary finance plays so large a part as in Great Britain, and this despite the immense wealth of the nation and the capacity which it has shown from time to time to yield an almost indefinite revenue when required.

The County Committee of the Committee of Thirty will hold its first meeting at Grand Opera House Hall to-night, Contests for membership from two districts, it is expected, will prevent the selection of a permanent Chairman, and about all the business which is likely to be transacted is the election of a temporary Chairman, and the appointment of committees to decide the contested elections.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $1,177,025. The banks now hold $82,008,025 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans of $2,130,000, a decrease in specie of $1,178,900, an increase in legal tenders of $3,864,100, an increase in deposits of $6,032,700, and a decrease in circulation of $369,000.

Last week's market for securities, while not devoid of feature, was quiet, compared with the recent movement in prices. Uncertainty in regard to tariff legislation had something to do in bringing about apathetic conditions. Trust stocks benefited by existing circumstances, because they were in the hands of manipulators, and rumors from Washington in regard to them were evidently to be had for the asking.

DUCKTOWN, Tenn., April 29. -- Day before yesterday Charles Livingstone, who is building three miles of railroad for the Pittsburg and Tennessee Copper Company, brought in fifty-three negroes and put them to work, after waiting in vain two weeks for white labor to do the work.

This will be a particularly lively week for the dealers in harness horses of all grades. The market is brisk and the offerings plentiful. Special sales are on at all the repositories in the city, and about 1,000 animals will pass under the hammer of the auctioneers at the several salesrooms during the coming week.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 20. -- Deputy Warden Playford of the State Prison, who retires to-morrow, the Warden having refused to re-appoint him, attempted to say a few words of farewell to the prisoners at chapel exercises to-day. Warden James seized him and tried to make him sit down, but he would not do so.

ATHENS, April 29. -- The latest reports from Atalanta say that on EWday 865 shocks of earthquaike were felt there in eight hours. For two hours the trembling of the earth was almost continuous. For a radius of three and a half miles on every side of the town the fields and highways have been torn with deep fissures.

CHARLESTON, West Va., April 29. -- It is believed to-day that the greater part of the striking miners will be at work by the middle of the week in both the Kanawha and New-River districts, as the operators have about determined that the strike was gotten up by the Ohio and Pennsylvania coal operators in order to injure the interests of the operators in this territory.

Pomeroy Ladew, Ph.D., Assistant Professor of Mathematics of the University of Michigan, will next year fill the now vacant position of Acting Professor of Mathematics caused by the death, of Prof. George Coakley last Summer. Prof. Daniel Murray has occupied the assistant professorship for the last four years. He is to leave the university this year.

PROVIDENCE, April 28 -- The strength in the local stock market continues, with prices about the same as last week. American National Bank is still sought for, and has sold at 49 3/4. Commercial National Bank has shown an advance over last week's prices, and together with American, will probably show still higher figures.

George F. McAfee and Mrs. A. S. Quinton told the members and friends of the New-York City Indian Association at the Central Baptist Church last evening what should be done to ameliorate the condition of the Indian. The church was crowded.

NEW-HAVEN, April 29. -- The first of the departments of Yale to hold its graduation exercises will this year, as usual, be the Divinity School. The commencement programme has been decided upon. On Sunday evening May 13, the Rev. Frank W. Gunsalus of Chicago will deliver the sermon before the graduating class in Marquand Chapel.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 29. -- The make-up of the Varsity crew at Cornell is to remain the same as it has been for three weeks past. The crew continues its daily practice on the "Rhine " every afternoon at 4 to 6 o'clock. It has not yet ventured out on the lake, but will do so next week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29 -- The embarassments arising from the present crowded, condition of Memorial Hall have been, partially settled by the adoption of a plan for next year. Beginning with October, three men are to be added to all the club tables now having fourteen-seats, and two men to each table of twelve seats.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 29. -- The imposing front of the St. Charles Hotel, on St. Charles Street, with its spacious portico, surmounted by a dome of majestic dimensions, and classic architecture, in the centre of the block, are all that is left standing of probaly the most famous hotel in the United States.
Prof. Felix Adler lectured on "Authority and Reason" yesterday before the Society for Ethical Culture, at Music Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. He said:

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Secretary Carlisle, before his departure for his brief holiday trip across to Fort Monroe, was asked whether the report was true that he had been taking part in conferences in regard to amendments to the Tariff bill. He replied:

BOSTON, April 29 -- Senator Hoar has written a letter to Morrison I. Swift, the labor agitator, in which he discusses the Coxey movement. He opens, as might be expected, by attributing the hard times to tariff agitation. Mr. Hoar never allows an opportunity to slip which he may use for partisan purposes.

John Ryan of Hackensack and T. W. Morfey of Paterson shot one of the finest one-barrel gun-below-the-elbow exhibitions ever given, at Erb's grounds, Newark, Saturday. It was a find, trap, and handle match, and each man shot at 25 birds, 21 yards rise, 80 yards boundary. Morfey made the world's record of 24 kills, and won the purse of $100. Ryan killed 18.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 29. -- The anti-Breckinridge people of the Seventh Congressional District have issued a pamphlet containing 12,000 words, written by Prof. J. B. Jones of Hamilton Female College, here. The book is entitled "An Appeal to the People of the Ashland District for Purity in the Home and Morality in Public Life."

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Some interesting ordnance maters have been disposed of by the Board of Ordnance and Fortification it the War Department. It has had a number at important sessions lately and has examined the devices which come from all quarters of the globe as "improvement" in gunnery.

The Brooklyn Temperance League has temporarily given up its fight to close saloons in Brooklyn on Sunday. This course was pursued because, as it claimed. Mayor Schieren refused to perform his sworn duty in enforcing the excise laws, and had adopted as his policy the open side door, with restrictions.

Henry Gyselmann, an American District Telegraph messenger, made a desperate attempt to rob Peter Gugelmann last evening, in the parlor of Mr. Gugelmann's house, at 117 East Twelfth Street. He snatched $22 from Mr. Gugelmann, but the old man seized him and there was a struggle in which much of the furniture in the room was wrecked.

The opening ceremonies of the golden jubilee, celebrating the half centennial of the Church of St. Francis of Assisi, in West Thirty-first Street, near Sixth Avenue, were held yesterday. The church wag finely decorated. The columns were festooned with evergreens, and flags floated from adjoining buildings.

Winchester, Va., April 29. -- The greater part of the best business block in town was burned today by a fire of incendiary origin. The total loss is $80,000. The principal losers are Solenberger Stouffer, stoves and hardware; John Vilwig, furniture; C. W. Hensell, dry goods; William Hardy, saddler, and Horsey Atwell, clothiers. Evans Brothers lose $20,000 on a building, and Charles A. Heller $10,000 on another building.

NEWARK, N. J., April 29. -- The trouble in the Pedd'ie Memorial Baptist Church reached an unlooked-for stage to-night, when, after the Rev. Dr. W. W. Boyd had preached his farewell sermon, there was a meeting of the Caecllian Choir, presided over by A. B. Gardner. Prof. E. M. Bowman, who is organist and choirmaster, made a motion to disband the choir, and, to the surprise of all, it was carried.

Trip to Flushing and Willet's Point -- Training for Races. Good roads and pleasant weather tempted many of the local cycling clubs to extend their usual Sunday runs. The clubhouse of the Riverside Wheelmen, on One Hundred and Fourth Street, was thronged yesterday morning with members preparing for the road.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., April 29. -- The action of the Brotherhood of Engineers last night, who met and decided to go to work at once on the strength of the proposition offered by the company and the return to the old schedule of wages, has been followed today by the Brotherhood of Firemen.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Jacob Coxey's ragged and foot-sore Army of the Commonweal marched into the District of Columbia to-day without molestation from the authorities, and is encamped to-night on Federal territory within a few miles of the Capitol.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 29. -- The assassin of Montgomery Gibbs, who was shot down on Delaware Avenue last night, is still at large and unknown. The whole detective force of the city has been at work on the case to-day. The most valuable testimony obtained was the evidence of Waiter Kennett and William Willis, two young boys employed in the delivery department of a shoe store.

One thing which the Republican majority of the Legislature seems to have kept in mind throughout the recent session as a means of acquiring cheap party capital with which to "so before the people" in the State canvass is a low tax rate. They indulged in the annual cackle of the legislative majority over the incubation of a more diminutive rate than that of the previous year.

Miss Georgians French of Saratoga, a daughter of Gen. French, ex-United States District Attorney, who has been a guest of Mrs. Henry Parker at 22 West. Eighty-seventh Street, found a ring which had contained a diamond valued by Miss French at 1500, lying on the floor in her bedroom a few days ago.
DENVER, April 29. -- In an interview concerning Senator Wolcott's speech on the Coxey movement, Gov. Waite says:

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The revised regulations to be observed at foreign ports and at sea, and at maritime quarantines of the United States, and also on the Canadian and Mexican, borders, prepared by Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service, have been approved by the Secretary of the Treasury.

Standing at Washington and Horatio Streets last evening, Policeman Perry of the Ninth Precinct saw a horse coming at full gallop with a hansom cab. The driver was urging the animal to a reckless speed.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Two medical officers of the navy have narrowly escaped the disfavor of the President. They were members of the retiring board, and made up two of the five officers who compose that important board, which passes upon the necessity for transferring officers from the active to the retired list.

The St. Charles Hotel was the representative building of the American or modern New-Orleans, as the cathedral is the representative building of the ancient New-Orleans, the City of Blenville, and of Carondelet.

In a prefatory note the author of the verses contained in this volume states that they have been selected from his contributions to several well-known weeklies and one magazine, to the editors of which he gives thanks for permission to republish them. If Mr. Hall were wise in his day and generation he would be more sparing of his gratitude.

Mr. McCulloch's book is very pretty to look at with its olive green cover and its bordered title page, designed, by Mr. Pierre La Rose. And it is not so bad to read, either, for it discloses a mind tuned to vibrate with a joyous appreciation of many things that are good to know. Yet it would be a rash judgment that should at once vote to award Mr. McCulloch a seat among the immortals.

Michael Sarsfield Coleman, engineering contractor and railroad builder, whose residence was at 38 East Sixty-ninth Street, this city, died of heart failure at Old Point Comront, Va., yesterday morning. He was fifty-three years old.

PARIS, April 29. -- At the Old Salon, which opens this week, it is evident that members of the Society of French Artists have been put upon their mettle by the successes of their rivals of the Champ de Mars. The consequence is that the Salon of 1894 contains a better display of pictures than have been brought together for several years before at the Palais de l'Industrie.

?ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 29 -- The local Commonweal Regiment paraded 255 strong on Lucas Market Square to-day. Speeches were made and recruits taken in. Not a policeman was in sight, and the meeting was orderly. Gen. J.K. Morrison is in command. He succeeds Jacob Meyer, whose wife has issued an order to her husband to remain at home.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 29. -- The revised academic entrance requirements which some time ago were passed by the Faculty and sanctioned by the Board of Trustees go into effect in the June entrance examinations which begin June 14 at Princeton and simultaneously in other cities throughout the United States. The standard of admission is both simplified and raised, and the important principle of maximum and minimum requirements is introduced.

When Mr. Patrick Walsh was actively engaged in editing The Augusta Chronicle a great deal of attention was attracted toward him by an order which he issued as the executive officer of the Southern Associated Press directing that greater discrimination should be employed in the collection and distribution of the news of the South by its correspondents.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The controversy between the ordnance officers and the Constructors over the ammunition hoists for ships of war has been settled by Secretary Herbert. He decides that the work of designing and constructing these features of the modern war vessel shall hereafter belong to the Bureau of Construction.

If Gov. Flower had possessed greater breadth of mind and political sagacity, he would not have been guided by Senator Hill, the arch enemy of ballot reform, in dealing with the blanket ballot question, and he would not be in the position now of having to veto an excellent measure to avoid a ridiculous back-down.

BERLIN, April 29. -- Herr von KiderlenWaechter, Chief of the Press Department a the Foreign Office, and for several weeks putative successor to the Prussian Embassy in Hamburg, has virtually ruined his political prospects. His duel with Dr. Polstorff, editor of the Kladderadatsch, is justified only by a certain, military clique on the ground that the attacks of that journal were unendurable for any man of honor.

Charles Gaffney, thirty-three years old, son of Richard Gaffney, a wealthy retired leather merchant, living at 127 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, was put under $1,000 bail by Police Justice Burke, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday, on a charge of stealing a pocketbook, $85, and a number of railway passes, the property of William Hoey, Superintendent of the Adams Express Company.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 29. -- Kelly's California Industrial Army is comfortably housed to-night in a vacant stove foundry east of the town, and has provisions for two days. At the end of that time the citizens expect the army to continue its journey. Gen. Kelly declares that his men will remain until railroad transportation shall be furnished, and expresses confidence that it will be forthcoming.

Madison Square Garden has become for a time a big farmyard. The lowing of kine, the cackling of hens, the bleating of sheep, and other sounds which greet the ear of people in the country resound through the building.

The trainers at Fleetwood began moving he trotters and pacers along in earnest ast week, and yesterday some of them vere able to show quite a little speed. In unticipation of this there was more than he usual number of members present, and from now on in fine weather the clubhouse will be well patronized.

About 500 members or the Seventh Regiment attended service yesterday afternoon at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. Forty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue. The Chaplain of the regiment is the Rev. Dr. David H. Greer, rector of the church. The members of the regiment occupied pews in the centre of the church.

SAN BERNARDINO, Cal., April 30 -- A party of fifty-five Industrials captured freight train on the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad at Barstow at midnight last night, and Deputy Sheriff Prindle arrested the whole party and released the train. The men were discharged, and went into camp near the station at Barstow.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- The strength, of today's market was wholly concentrated in West Chicago cable stock, as indeed was most of the business. It opened at 149 3/4, advancing gradually to 151, and reacting slightly at the close. The earnings are said to be very liberal, and the success of the new cable loop greater than expectations.

A symposium on woman suffrage was held yesterday at the residence of Mrs. Horatio C. King, 46 Willow Street, Brooklyn. The discussion was participated in by members of the Long Island Chapter of the Daughters of the Revolution, of which Mrs. King is the Regent, and the prominent women who are in the organized movement against woman suffrage.

Thanks to the promptness and good faith with which the British Parliament has supplemented by a similar statute of its own the recent act of Congress for the regulation of seal hunting, the decision of the Paris tribunal will doubtless be duly and fully enforced. Last Thursday the British gunboat Pheasant left Vancouver to warn the sealing schooners that had sailed from Victoria before the enactment of the new law of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Canadian Government is dissatisfied with the agreement reached, by Secretaries Carlisle and Gresham, representing the United States, and Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Minister, and Mr. Dawson, representing Great Britain, regarding the Bering Sea regulations and license forms.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, yesterday.

Sugar led in activity yesterday in the stock market, but various other stocks called for attention and received it. In early trading it might have been supposed from a reading of the tape that Sugar comprised the stock list. Rumors from Washington were again brought out to the cheerful effect that the Trust had but to ask for what it wanted to make sure of getting it.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club book programme for the Spring meeting was issued yesterday. The meeting, which begins Tuesday, May 15, will continue daily, excepting Sundays, up to and including Tuesday, May 29. Dates for the running of the several stakes have been fixed as follows:

-- Receiver Hugh J. Grant of the St. Nicholas Bank has received permission from the Supreme Court, through Justice Lawrence, to pay the creditors of the defunct bank 20 per cent, on all claims proved thus far. Mr. Grant reports that thus far there has been collected $1,725,939.99, of which $478,725.88 is retained for preferences, and 40 per cent, paid in dividends or reserved, amounting to $191,490.35, leaving a balance of $1,438,704.46.

The United States training ship Portsmouth, on board which young apprentices are schooled, reached the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday from her annual cruise in West Indian waters. The trip was made exciting by two heavy gales which were encountered. One was met off the Bermudas on the outward voyage, and the other off the Atlantic Cape of Storms lengthened the homeward trip by nearly two weeks.

-- The semi-annual conference of the Westchester Chapter of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, which was held in Yonkers all day Sunday, was largely attended by delegates from many parts of the county. The Rev. Charles F. Canedy of New-Rochelle delivered an excellent sermon in the morning. At the afternoon session there was a business meeting, at which several addresses were delivered by members of the brotherhood.

-- "Shenandoah" at the Academy. -- Charles Frohman has signed a contract with Gilmore Tompkins, under the terms of which he will make a grand revival of Bronson Howard's war play, "Shenandoah," at the Academy of Music Sept. 1. The play originally ran over 300 nights in this city, and the revival is to be spectacular in its nature, like that of "The Girl I Left Behind Me," now running at the Academy.

The following jury was drawn from the first panel of the Sheriff's jury last evening to decide what damages should be awarded to Edward S. Stokes, on decisions by Justice Lawrence and the General Term of the Supreme Court that a letter written by W. E.D. Stokes and published was belous:

Patrick J. McArdle told his story in the Tombs Police Court yesterday of how Michael Donnelly, his brother-in-law, attempted to shoot him in Part II. of the Court of Common Pleas last Tuesday. Police Justice Martin ordered the attending Sergeant of Police before the hearing began to examine both the plaintiff and the defendant to see if either carried a revolver.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- This day has been wasted by the Senate, owing to the desire of the Republicans to kill time and the willingness of the Democrats to enter the trap for them, the only object of which was delay in the consideration at the Tariff bill.

An attempt on the part of opponents of the pending Tariff bill to find an argument against proposed tariff changes in some recent large sales of woolens in this city is not based on facts as they are understood by leading merchants in this city. The prices received for the woolens, which were sold at public auction, were low.

Fifty years ago to-day the first "news dispatch" was transmitted over a telegraph wire. It should have been the message, "The world do move," because the world never before moved at so rapid a pace, in the consciousness of its inhabitants, as it has since May 1, 1844.

The new Republican County Committee was temporarily organized last night. The Committee of Thirty, which was appointed at the November meeting of the old County Committee, to investigate and if necessary, to reorganize the party in this city, brought this new County Committee into existence, and the Thirty, as a committee, went out of existence last night just as soon as the new committee was called to order.
