Probably never before has the cozy little Berkeley Lyceum Theatre been so crowded with a fashionable gathering as at the amateur dramatic entertainment given by The Strollers last evening. When the organization began a week of playing in behalf of charity. It seemed as if all the smart set who had not left town were present at the play.

-- "Hannele" Surely To-night. -- They had a dress rehearsal of "Hannele" at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night, and the first public performance in America of Gerhardt Hauptmann's vision play will surely be given to-night. The English version has been made by Mr. Charles H. Meltzer, who not only knows German, but can write English as well, so that the Rosenfeld brothers have not repeated their mistake with "Olaf."

BOSTON, Mass., April 30. -- It will doubtless be a surprise to yachtsmen to know that the famous cup defender Puritan is for sale, after being in the possession of Commodore J. Malcom Forbes for nearly ten years. Yet such is the fact, and the yacht will be offered at public auction in this city about the middle of May, unless disposed of at private sale previous to that time.

Several persons narrowly escaped death or serious injury yesterday when workmen for the Herring-Hall-Marvin Safe Company were hoisting a safe weighing 5,000 pounds to the twelfth floor of 68 Nassau Street through an elevator shaft. When the safe had been raised 130 feet one of the cog wheels of the windlass on the truck broke.

It is announced that Gov. Flower will give a hearing to-morrow on the important measures in his hands relating to this city, and with that exception he will give no hearings on the "thirty-day bills." There will be arguments both for and against what are called the municipal "reform" measures, and the Governor will be subjected to "influence" from two opposite directions.

"Tom" Eck, the celebrated trainer, who has charge of a string of racing men this season, stopped over in this city yesterday on his way to Syracuse, where he is going to prepare the half-mile track on the fair grounds in that city for the training school of about thirty of his pupils from all over the country.

The Long Island Trotting Association, before which, a week ago, there appeared nothing but plain sailing, has come to grief, and that through the somewhat selfish action of the Pearsalls Association. About six weeks ago John Bacon, Treasurer of the Queens County Agricultural Association. Mineola, and Messrs. Crandall and Moore, representing the Parkway driving Club of Brooklyn, met at Jamaica and formed the nucleus of a circuit for the island.

The second annual convention of the Open-Air Workers' Association of America met in the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church at 10:30 yesterday morning. Delegates were present from this city, Brooklyn, Boston, Mass.; Washington, D. C.; Bridgeton, New-Brunswick, and Newark, N.J.; Philadelphia, Penn.; Syracuse, N.Y., and many other places.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The marriage of Miss Harriet Blaine, youngest daughter of the late James G. Blaine, to Truxton Beale, ex-United States Minister to Persia, took place at 1 o'clock to-day at the Blaine mansion, on Lafayette Square. The ceremony was performed in the drawing room, which extends across the entire front of the historic house.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Prices were well maintained throughout the day, and at times quite strong. Pennsylvania fluctuated between 50 5/8 and 51, and was not offered below 51 at the close. A drive at a small lot of Lehigh Valley depressed the price fractionally, and it closed at 37 5/8 bid, offered at 37 7/8.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- Lafayette College played the best ball of any team meeting Pennsylvania on the home grounds so far this year, although they suffered defeat by a big score. In the main the fielding of the Lafayette players was clean and hard, but at the bat they were completely at Schoeabut's mercy, twelve out of a total of twenty-four put-outs being on three strikes.

They were the same old Giants yesterday. On Saturday Ward's men won a creditable game from the Baltimores, and sent a thrill of joy to the hearts of 18,000 enthusiasts who watched the contest. In the field they were like a lot of well-trained athletes, and at the bat they behaved themselves in a manner befitting a champion team.
BOSTON, April 30. -- The Board of Aldermen, acting as Trustees of the Franklin Fund, returned to this city this morning, after a fourteen days' journey over the Eastern and Middle Atlantic States.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

QUEBEC, Quebec, April 30. -- The inhabitants of the quiet little village of St. Alban, situated forty-five miles from here, in the County of Portneuf heard at 8 o'clock Friday morning a noise resembling the roll of thunder in the distance. The earth began to vibrate, and then a panic ensued.

BOSTON, April 30 -- Local stocks were somewhat more active than of late, but there was no feature of special interest in the market. Bell Telephone opened at 191 1/2 and declined to 190 1/2. Small lots only were sold, and the fluctuations were of little significance. Lamson Store Service seems rather weak, selling around 23 1/4.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Frank Hatton, editor of The Washington Post and President of the Gridiron Club, died this afternoon, after a week of unconsciousness, following a stroke of paralysis. He was one of the best known men in the country, and was almost as well liked as he was known.
The battle waging on woman's suffrage goes merrily on in this city. Those in favor of a constitutional change and the party opposed to the movement are drawing the lines tightly.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Gen. Coxey, Commander in Chief of the Army of invasion, was at the Capitol this afternoon, and immediately upon his arrival went to the room of the Sergeant at Arms to have a conference with that official. Col. Bright, the Sergeant at Arms, was not in his office, and while awaiting his return Mr. Coxey was surrounded by a number of persons drawn there from curiosity, among them several Senators.
HANOVER, N.H., April 30. -- These provisional appointments for Dartmouth College commencement were made this evening:

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Senators put up a poor game of ball to-day, and Brooklyn won rather easily. Mercer started in to pitch, but was so wild and ineffective that the visitors piled up nine runs in three innings. Daub did good work up to the fifth inning, when he went to pieces, and before the Senators had been retired seven runs crossed the plate.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- While some Democratic Senators are going out of their way to deny that any attempt is being made to reach an agreement by which the full Democratic vote may be cast for the Tariff bill, those who are trying to bring about such an agreement are not relaxing their efforts to that end.
One of the most interesting incidents connected with the trial of Dr. Henry Meyer for poisoning Ludwig Brandt developed yesterday shortly after the opening of the morning session.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Serious structural defects have developed in the battle ship Texas, and the Secretary of the Navy has ordered a board, of which Capt. Miller, commanding the Raleigh, is President, to investigate the matter and report to the department. This ship was built at the Norfolk Navy Yard, on designs purchased in England, and they have caused more trouble to this Government than those of any other vessel in the service.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 30 -- A general tie-up of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific may be the result of the refusal of that road to transport Kelly's army free, or to make special rates. The leading members of the local union of the American Railway Union have held a meeting to consider the matter.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- In response to a call issued by a number of prominent citizens, a meeting was held in the Mayor's office at noon to-day for the purpose of considering the expediency of the construction of a ship canal between Philadelphia and New-York.

LONDON, April 30. -- In the House of Commons to-day H.H. Fowler, Secretary for India, in reply to a question asked by Mr. Samuelson last Friday, said there was no foundation for the report that it was proposed to reopen the Indian mints to free coinage of rupees.

Safely locked in cells in Police Headquarters are five men, who have been systematically burning stables in this city during the last two years. Hundreds of poor, broken-down horses have been incinerated in the burned stables in order that these men might grow rich in plundering the insurance companies.
Gin Sing, who is charged with attempting to kill Ah Poy on Mott Street, Saturday, escaped from custody for a short time yesterday, after being arraigned in Part I., General Sessions.
John D. Rockefeller, of the Standard Oil Company, was the object for several hours yesterday of the attentions of a man supposed to be a dangerous crank.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- Francis Browne Stockbridge, United States Senator from Michigan, died in this city to-night a few minutes after 7 o'clock. The end came suddenly, although the Senator had been confined to his bed almost all the time since coming to Chicago from Washington April 2. He died at the residence of his nephew-in-law, James L. Houghteling, Astor and Banks Streets.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- The taking of testimony relative to the administration of Thomas F. Oakes, one of the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad, ordered by Judge Jenkins, in Milwaukee, last week, began to-day before Master in Chancery A. L. Cary, in Judge Jenkins's chambers in the Monadnock Building.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 30. -- At a brief meeting of the committee appointed at Saturday's meeting of the Citizens' Association to wait on Gov. Flower relative to the Commissioner of Juries bill, held in the Merchants' Exchange this afternoon, a strong letter, which the members unanimously approved, was sent to the Governor.

CROTON FALLS, N.Y., April 30. -- The body of five-year-old Robert Gibson, son of the Rev. R.P. Gibson of the Presbyterian Church here, was found this morning in the Croton River about a mile below this village. The little fellow was last seen alive on Tuesday of last week playing on the bank of the river.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Washington News, which was the first customer of the Western Associated Press east of the Alleghanies, to-day makes the following announcement:

-- The State Railroad Commission at Albany yesterday granted an application of the Fonda, Johnstown and Gloversville Railroad for leave to lease the Cayadutta Electric Railroad for a term of 999 years. The Cayadutta Road runs from Fonda to and through Johnstown and Gloversville.

An iron pot containing a collection of old coins was found last week under eight feet of earth by workmen who have been making excavations at 139 Cedar Street for an addition to the Electrical Exchange. The place where the pot was found was the site of the old Sheffield Hotel, which was torn down to make room for the new building.

In the Senate on Friday last Mr. John Sherman said that the duties on iron and steel and manufactures of the same had been reduced by the McKinley tariff, and his further remarks on this subject warranted the inference that in his opinion this reduction of duties had compelled the manufacturers of iron and steel to cut down the wages of their workmen because it had "reduced their business" by increasing imports.
Congressman Timothy J. Campbell is not being nicely treated by some of the folks over in his Congressional district. He was "waked" and buried in effigy Sunday.

Reports have been circulated that the Manhattan Bicycle Club has disbanded, and that the organization is dead. Judging by the run to Pompton Plains, N.J., last Sunday the Manhattan is the liveliest dead club in the city. Eighteen members took part in this run, and all thoroughly enjoyed the day's outing.

The most striking feature of the auction sales had yesterday at the New-York Real Estate Salesroom in the Trinity Building was the offering, in partition, of the Van Voorhis property by Mr. William Kennelly. This property was well protected by parties interested in the estate -- rather too much so if they had any desire to have outsiders buy it -- and so these persons in interest purchased several of the parcels.

From The Watertown (S.D.) Journal, (Dem.) The New-York Times is doing good service to this and every honor-loving community in the United States. It is putting in print in its columns the names, addresses, and occupations of the men who constitute our fraudulent pension list. No genuine patriot.

"Gentlemen of the legal profession, I may say our manifold brothers-in-law, behold the coming day which wise men and prophets have so long foretold! We are a 'voice crying in the wilderness,' and already we have fed upon the Invigorating pabulum of locusts and wild honey. Tonight we represent, not only that much-debated 'coming woman,' but the woman who is here."

LONDON, April 30. -- The majority and minority reports of the Royal Labor Commission have been issued, and, as predicted, show that the commission has done absolutely nothing toward the settlement of the questions it was appointed to consider. The majority report, signed by the politician employers, and economists, is mainly a negative document.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 30. -- The passenger train on the Philadelphia, Reading and New-England Road due here from Millerton at 11:55 this morning ran into an open switch near Albany Avenue, just as it entered the city. The engine collided with, a repair train of five cars standing on the siding, and was somewhat damaged.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

M.B. Curtis had a prodigious welcome at the Standard Theatre last night, when he made his first appearance on the stage since his unhappy experience in San Francisco. The house was crowded long before the performance began by an audience that was in demonstrative and receptive mood. The play was all followed with respectful attenion, and Mr. Curtis's part of it was accompanied by incessant laughter.

Even in the most occupied season of anniversaries, the fiftieth anniversary of the practical use of the electric telegraph must take a commanding place. In fact, it was fifty years ago to-day that The New-York Herald announced that Prof. Morse's telegraph was in operation for a part of the distance from Baltimore to Washington.

LONDON, April 21 -- The annual exhibition of the Royal Academy of Arts will be open to the public in the well-known galleries at Burlington House on Monday, May 7. The accustomed "press view" will be given on Wednesday, May 2.

Between the hours of 5 and 6 in the afternoon is the fashionable time to ride or drive in Central Park, and between these hours yesterday the bridle paths and the drives were well filled. The day was one to entice all lovers of riding or driving on the roads, for there was bright sunlight, green sward on either side of the roads, and the air was just nipping enough to make it invigorating.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Coxey's army of tramps, after braving all the dangers of a march to the national capital through a country region notable for determined farmers, unsympathetic Sheriffs, and faithful watchdogs, threatened at one time today to take to its heels and leave the Massillon commander alone to fight his battle.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 30 -- Coxeyism is epidemic at Yale to-night. A score of recruits to the cause arrived here, and since have been the lions of the Yale campus.

The coach Tempest was not in service on the trip made between the Hotel Brunswick and the Country Club, Westchester, yesterday, but a private black and yellow coach owned by Francis T. Underhill, who tooled it, was used in the Tempest's stead. One of the springs of the Tempest was strained on the trip made Saturday, and is now being repaired at Brewster's.

The Suburban Driving Club is now an assured fact. Prior to last night it was a project only. For three or four months past a number of gentlemen, members until recently of the old Jerome Park Club, have talked about forming a social driving club, but it was not until last weak that the one difficulty in the way of organizing was removed, the acquisition of some suitable house.
The Rev. Charles H. Parkhurst was the guest of the City Vigilance League at the St. Denis Hotel last night.

An interesting question was raised yesterday in reference to the bill passed by the last Legislature providing that, within sixty days after he takes office, the Mayor of this city may remove the heads of any of the city departments.

Buyers of high steppers had a grand chance to secure some bargains at Tattersalls yesterday, when a consignment from the farm of Joseph E. Widener of Philadelphia was disposed of. W.D. Grand acted as auctioneer in his usual placid and listless manner, which is not at all inducive to enthusiasm.

BUFFALO, April 30. -- The strained state of affairs existing between owners of the soft coal mines and their employes may change somewhat this week -- at least that is the expressed opinion of Col. D.R. Stowits, Manager of the Fairmount Coal and Iron Company, the Northwestern Coal and Iron Company, and the Buffalo Coal Company.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- In accordance with the decision of the union painters 2,000 of them, went out on strike to-day. The movement is aimed at all employers who locked out the union building trades men recently. Nearly half the entire force of painters in the city are involved. The plan of the strikers is to remain out until all the demands of the union shall be conceded.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- A bill introduced in the Senate to-day by Mr. Chandler, (Rep., N.H.,) for the establishment of a free port at Fort Pond Bay, or elsewhere in the waters of Long Island Sound, authorizes Austin Corbin and his associates of the Long Island Railroad Company to establish such a port, with the approval of the Secretary of the Treasury.

Some time ago the Erie Railway sent a request to the Board of Rulings of the trunk lines and the Central Traffic Associations that certain changes be made in the arrangement of differentials on passenger business between New-York and points west of Buffalo. The Erie, being a differential line itself, desired that all the differential lines Should be placed on an equality.

Most people imagine that Anarchism is of European growth, and that it is the result of ages of misrule and oppression. Nothing could be further from the truth. Anarchism was born and bred in Chicago, for it was in that somewhat unnecessary town that wood pavements were first used.

Mayor Schleren said yesterday that the changes in the City Government necessitated by annexation of the county towns would receive early consideration from the authorities. The subject, he added, had been taken up only in the most general way because the annexation acts had not all been signed.

Among the passengers of the Atlas Line steamship Alene, which yesterday arrived from Kingston, were nine naval cadets who were attached to the cruiser New-York, and who are on their way to Annapolis to stand their final examination.

NEW-UTRECHT, L.I., May 1 -- The Particular Synod of New-York of the Reformed Church met this afternoon in the Reformed Church at Van Pelt Manor, of which the Rev. Alfred H. Brush is pastor. This synod includes the eight Classes of Southern NewYork.
BERLIN, May 1 -- Dr. Ahlwardt, the Jewbaiting Deputy, has been condemned to three months' imprisonment for slandering Government officials.

Only women are allowed to sign the antisuffrage protest, but its champions are very well satisfied with the number of names they are accumulating, even with this limitation and the short time the work has been going on.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The protest which Coxey vainly attempted to read from the Capitol steps was as follows:

Art and publishing circles of New-York have lost a notable figure by the death of Julian Oliver Davidson, the painter and draughtsman. He was a nephew of the literary ladies Lucretia Maria and Margaret Davidson of Plattsburg, who, after precocious childhoods, became authoresses of note in the early half of the present century.

Thomas Stevens, the bicyclist, is on his way to America. A letter was recently received from him by J.T. Douthitt of the American Tapestry Company, 286 Fifth Avenue, which explains why he went East, and gives promise of some interesting news about the Mahatmas when he returns. The letter bears the date, Matheran, India, April 4, 1894.

The value of an advertisement, if once it has been committed to type, is very peculiarly shown in the experience of Mr. Frank Howe, son of the late historian. For many years the historian was a resident of Cincinnati, engaged in the publishing business on mail Street.

Nobody imagines that it was the intention of the framers or the supporters of the act giving the Mayor of this city power to remove the heads of departments within sixty days after coming into office that it should apply to any elective officer, and yet the language of the bill is that the Mayor "may remove from office any head of department and appoint his successor."

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 1 -- The strike on the Great Northern Railroad, which involved its 5,000 employes on its 3,700 miles of line, and which has suspended traffic, both freight and passenger, for two weeks, is over.

Latham, Alexander Co., fiscal agents of the State of Tennessee, sola yesterday to Blair Co., Wall Street bankers, $1,000,000 4 1/2 per cent. Tennessee State bonds at par and interest. These bonds were authorized by the last session of the Tennessee Legislature to refund the outstanding $1,000,000 of 5 and 6 per cent, bonds.

-- Postmaster Dayto announces that the experiment tried during April of closing all outgoing domestic and Canada mails between the hours 5 to 8 P.M. thirty minutes earlier has been found to give entire satisfaction to the public, and has contributed in producing an improved service through insuring absolutely the dispatch by the night trains of all mail deposited in the Post Office for forwarding thereby.
With or without an income tax the Tariff bill will be promptly passed if Congress has the regard it should have for the business interests of the country.

Messrs. Hoffman Brothers have sold, for Jefferson M. Levy, to Warren E. Dennis, the south-east corner of Liberty and Church Streets, 26 by 54, with an old building which rents at $8,000 per year. This disposes of the last of Mr. Levy's holdings on the block bounded by Liberty. Cedar, end Church Streets and Temple Place. The Cedar Street front was recently sold to the Fidelity and Casualty Company.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1 -- Brown defeated. Williams to-day in a fairly good grame. Score:

PARIS, May 1 -- The Socialists and students' demonstration in the Salle Barrat was a miserable failure. Only eight students made their appearance in the hall where the delegates of the Socialist organizations were assembled, and, including the eight students, the total number of persons present aid not exceed forty.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., May 1 -- The shooting season of 1894 opened to-day under the personal supervision of Brig. Gen. B.M. Whitlock, assisted by Major D. Crocker, Inspector of Rifle Practice of the First Brigade staff. A detachment of the Ninth Regiment, under the command of Lieut. Col. Rand, occupied the range.

"I am delighted," said Fire Marshal Mitchel yesterday, "to know that Inspector McLaughlin has in custody a band of incendiaries. I know of all the prisoners, They have all been under suspicion and surveillance for years, and of their guilt in the present instance I have no doubt.

CLYDE, N.Y., May 1 -- The citizens of Clyde tendered Senator Saxton a reception to-day on his arrival home from Albany. The village was decorated, with bunting, and the Senator was met at the station by a large delegation of citizens and townspeople. A meeting was held in the Town Hall, presided over by James Dunwell of Lyons, and music was furnished by the Clyde Apollo Club.

The examination of Michael Donnelly for attempting to kill his brother-in-law, Patrick J. McArdle, in the Court of Common Pleas on Tuesday of last week, was resumed before Police Justice Martin in the Tombs Police Court yesterday.

Otto Frass, a shoemaker, sixty-four years old, hanged himself in his shop in the basement of 64 Beaver Street Monday night. He had done business in the basement for over twenty years, and had among his customers many of the prominent brokers on the Produce Exchange. Some months ago his wife became ill and it was necessary to send her to a hospital, and recently a married daughter died.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 1 -- Morrison I. Swift of Boston, of the New-England Industrial Army, to-night discussed at length the letter of Senator Hoar of Massachusetts made public last Sunday. Mr. Swift said:

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A dozen or more gentlemen, representing the varied interests associated with the Union Pacific Railway and its branch lines, had a hearing to-day before the House Committee on Pacific Railroads. Not only were these gentlemen distinguished in a personal sense, but they were equally distinguished in the financial and legal world.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

-- Col. A.J. Drexel's steamer, Margarita, formerly the Semframis, left Philadelphia yesterday on a cruise to Bermuda. The party on the cruise includes Col. and Mrs. A.J. Drexel, Mrs. Charles Platt, Miss M. Tyson, Miss E. Tyson, Miss M. Houghton of Baltimore, Mr. Charles E. Etting, Mr. E.J. Etting, Mr. Edward Roberts, Mr. Charles T. Stewart, Lieut. Andre Brewster, Mr. W. Fisher Lewis, and Mr. S. Wynne Foulkes.

LONDON, May 1 -- Though the weather was cold, damp, and disagreeable all day, the Socialists, according to programme, gathered their supporters on the Thames Embankment at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The gathering was not a large one, but the enthusiasm, as evinced by the cheers and shouts, was of a high order.

Stevens was defeated by the Crescent Athletic Club lacrosse team to-day by a score of 3 goals to 1. The features of the game were the running of Jewell and Jennings and the "tipping" of the Crescent attack. The goals for Crescent were shot by Miller (two) and Patterson, and for Stevens by Whitman.

A fairly well-dressed young man of melancholy mien was observed wandering about the corridors of the City Hall yesterday afternoon. He seemed to have no particular object in view, but finally he drifted into the Mayor's office and said he wanted to get married.

President Charles S. Smith of the Chamber of Commerce, J. Edward Simmons, the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, Marcus A. Bettman. A.B. Hepburn, Constant A. Andrews, Jacob Wendell, Silas M. Giddings, Henry R. Beekman, and William H. Robertson will go to Albany to-day in behalf of the Rapid-Transit bill.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, yesterday.
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, published this morning. consists of TEN PAGES. It contains:

-- The City Treasury has been enriched by $100 because the swindlers, Sutton and Moore, who were arrested for trying to sell Coroner Miles special tips on the Troy races, forfeited their bail. They told the Coroner a beautiful story of how he could, with their assistance, beat the poolrooms at Troy. The Coroner informed the police and the two men were arrested.

BERLIN, May 1 -- The police have been wonderfully alert to-day in carrying out the May Day programme of the authorities, and, consequently, there have been no notable disturbances. An Anarchist meeting was held in the Ressource Rooms, where a strong detail of police was assigned. One of the speakers declared that workingmen must be prepared to fight for their rights with staffs and rifles in hand.

The American flag was as conspicuous by its absence as the emblems of Socialism were ostentatiously glaring and obtrusive in Union Square last night, when the Central Labor Federation, the Socialistic labor organizations and the Hebrew trades societies had their May-Day celebration.

-- At the request of Alderman Charles Smith the Board of Aldermen yesterday gave consent to L. Meyer to erect a soda water stand in front of 13 Allen Street, provided it is within the stoop line, not more than four feet from the house, and not more than six feet in length, and that the consent of the property owner is obtained.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 1 -- Patrick McBryde. National Secretary of the United Mine Workers, arrived from Columbus, Ohio, early this morring, on a tour of the important sections of the coal regions. In reply to a question, Mr. McBryde said:

The fifty-third annual commencement of the medical department of the university of the City of New-York took place last evening at the Carnegie Music Hall. Ninety-six members of the graduating class were presented with diplomas, and the degree of Doctor of Medicine was conferred upon them.

The commencement exercises of Queen's University at Kingston, Ontario, which, a week ago, conferred the degree of LL. D. upon Mr. Charles Macdonald, Vice President of the American Society of Civil Engineers, were classic and conservative to those familiar with ancient Oxford ceremonies, but strange and inexpressibly modern to the most modern of Americans.

Our pension system is like a biting satire on democratic government. Never has there been anything like it in point of extravagance and barefaced dishonesty. Everybody knows this; but the number of men in public life who have courage enough to admit that they know it is ludicrously small.

Carl Muller learned yesterday that the role of an informer is not the most pleasant thing in the world. Under direct examination by the prosecuting officers in the trial of Dr. Henry Meyer for poisoning Ludwig Brandt, Muller had an easy enough time of it.

The events of yesterday have in effect put a quietus upon the whole industrial army, and upon the movement to which it relates. When Coxey was "fired" from the Capitol steps the tramp army business received a fatal blow. Coxey's own particular army is, thus far, the only army that has come within gunshot of the capital.

Thomas E. Pearsall, counsel for the estate of Daniel McCabe of Brooklyn, has made application to the Supreme Court for a partition and sale of the valuable real estate belonging to that estate. Mr. McCabe was a prominent citizen of Brooklyn, and was at one time President of the Fulton Bank.

Mrs. Caroline Clarke, the sister of Tony Pastor, and who died recently, has left the bulk of her estate to her brother. The real estate is valued at $15,000, and the personal estate is fixed at $4,000. Among the bequests to the brother are the two houses 447 West Twenty-seventh Street and 246 East Fortieth Street.

Superintendent C.M. Preston of the State Banking Department did not give out a statement of the Harlem River Bank's troubles last night, as was expected. He said that late in the afternoon all parties concerned had agreed to place the affairs of the institution in the hands of a receiver.

BOSTON, May 1 -- Sales of local stocks were few and far between, and there was really no feature of interest in the market. Stocks sold mostly in such small lots that quotations signified very little. Bell Telephone was steady around 190 1/2, and Erie Telephone a little stronger, at 46 1/2. Boston and Albany did not hold its advance of yesterday, failing back 1 1/2, to 210 1/2.

-- Manager Brooks in Town. -- Joseph Brooks, manager of W.H. Crane, is in the city for a few days, having left his star in order to attend to pressing business here. He says that Mr. Crane's tour is proving very successful, considering the financial depression, which has affected theatres, as well as all other branches of business. "The fact is," said Mr. Brooks, "there is no money among the people to spend."

The Bl-Metallic League will meet in London, England, to-day. Henry W. Cannon, President of the Chase National Bank, was invited to be present as the delegate from the United States. The following letter from Mr. Cannon will be read at the league meeting:

LONDON, May 1 -- The correspondence exchanged between the Board of Agriculture and the Colonial office concerning the admission of Canadian cattle into Great Britain was made public to-day by the Board of Agriculture.

Modest Michael Tiernan played an important part in the game of ball on the Polo Grounds yesterday. Besides scoring 1 of the 7 runs credited to the local players, his opportune batting sent four men across the plate, so that the right fielder was instrumental in tallying 5 runs.

The recommendations of Mr. William H. Maxwell, Superintendent of Public Instruction in Brooklyn, are this year, as usual, extremely sensible, but it seems unfortunate that there should be any need of making some of them. Among these is one for the "weeding out of inefficient Principals, heads of departments, apd teachers."

NORTHPORT, L.I., May 1. -- Jacob Hunter, colored, eighteen years old, employed by Michael Benson, a farmer of Commack, is under arrest here charged with attempting to poison his employer. Hunter admits his guilt, and says a neighbor named Sterling was concerned with him in a plot to kill Mr. Benson and secure a large sum of money he had in the house.

G.A. Gronlund, President of the Scandinavian and Finlanders' Emigrant Company (Limited,) which made an assignment to Arthur S. Lurria of 195 Broadway last Saturday, is absent from this city. He is supposed to be in Chicago. Vice President Ketonen of The Surtolainen, a newspaper which Gronlund published, said yesterday that he thought the latter would return today, and that the company would pay 50 or 75 cents on the dollar.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 1 -- Riotous demonstrations have been the order of the day, and several persons have been injured, while a number have had very narrow escapes from death. A meeting attended by between 10,000 and 15,000 men was held in the publis square this forenoon.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A perfect day, with brightly-shining sun, which Citizen Coxey took as a propitious omen, greeted the Army of the Commonweal this morning. The drooping spirit of the Commonwealers revived considerably.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 1 -- Ex-Senator and Mrs. Henry L. Dawes celebrated their golden wedding to-day. Letters and telegrrams and congratulations and many valuable tokens of remembrance were received from all parts of the country. Senator Hoar sent a pair of beautiful candlesticks. Ladies of Pittsfield sent $100 in gold.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Trading was dull and little interest was shown in the market. The passage by the City Council of the ordinance granting the North and West Chicago Companies the privilege of using trolley wires on the streets now traversed by their horse-car lines, excepting those on which "L" roads are constructed, had some effect on the stocks of both the cable roads directly concerned.
ALBANY, May 1 -- A week from to-day the Constitutional Convention will assemble in Albany. Preparations are already being made for the comfort of the 175 delegates.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- The examination of witnesses who are expected to throw light on the administration of Thomas F. Oakes as one of the Northern Pacific receivers was continued to-day before Master in Chancery Gary of Milwaukee. The testimony related to the cost of the Chicago terminals purchased by the Northern Pacific.

The time made by the Brooklyn Handicap horses yesterday showed vast improvement over that of last week. Don Alonzo and Banquet were again pitted against each other, and the big fellow showed, a decided superiority over the famous handicap gelding Messrs. P.J. Dwyer, M.F. Dwyer, Richard Croker, Mattie Corbett, George Sterling, James Reed, Joe Vendig, and several others watched the horses and timed them.

The administration ticket to be voted for at the annual election of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company next Tuesday is as follows: James Roosevelt, Robert M. Olyphant, William H. Tillinghast, Alfred Van Santvoord, James A. Roosevelt, Alexander E. Orr, Cornelius Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew, John A. Stewart, James W. Alexander, James R. Taylor, Benjamin Brewster, and Horace G. Young.
The second vegetarian dinner of the V Club was held at the St. Denis Hotel, Broadway and Eleventh Street, last night. About fifty members were present.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 1 -- Village Farm will be represented on the turf by another fast team this season. In all probability the pair will be sent an exhibition mile at the Buffalo Grand Circuit meeting. The team will be composed of Pansy, 2:17 3/4, and Cora, 2:22, both by Hamlin's Almont, and Geers will soon begin to drive them double.

The annual Spring sale of high-class hacks, hunters, and carriage horses, the property of S.S. Howland, attracted a large number of hunting and pony racing men to the American Horse Exchange, Fiftieth Street and Broadway, yesterday. The consignments sent annually by Mr. Howland to the New-York market contain good crosscountry horses, and the hunting set is aiways well represented at the sales.

Fall River, Mass., May 1 Fire was discovered in fifty bales of loose cotton in the opening room in Osborne Mill No. 1 at noon to-day, and a general alarm was sounded from the private box on the mill property, but the automatic sprinklers at the mill had the fire under control before the city apparatus arrived. The loss will be about $1,000 and is covered by insurance.

VIENNA, May 1 -- A heavy fall of rain prevailed during the entire morning, but it had no effect whatever in preventing enormous crowds from gathering at the various places where mass meetings had been called. The meetings were mostly attended by strikers, and, although speakers and auditors were drenched to the skin, their enthusiasm remained at white heat.

Members of the Mechanics and Traders' Exchange held their regular quarterly meeting yesterday, in the rooms of the organization, 289 Fourth Avenue. One object of the meeting was to further stimulate the efforts which are being made to secure a fitting home for the building trades of New-York City.

ROME, May 1 -- The police this morning destroyed a large number of Anarchist handbills lauding the deeds of Ravachol, Vaillant, and Henry. The city is quiet. The Socialists held their mass meetings in the country, in consequence of the order prohibiting such gatherings in the city. Troops were sent to the scene of these meetings to preserve order.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Dockery Commission of expert accountants began the work of examining into the methods employed in the office of the Supervising Architect of the Treasury this afternoon. It will make a thorough and exhaustive examination of the workings of this important bureau.
Police Commissioner MacLeans term of office having expired with April there was great interest yesterday as to whom Mayor Gilroy would appoint to succeed him.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Talk about a change in the rules of the Senate has been revived through the preparation by Senator Berry of a paper reciting that the Republicans mean to filibuster, and declaring, in effect, that closure is the only means of securing the passage of the Tariff bill.

Indications yesterday seemed to point to the culmination of the speculative movement in the industrials, for the time being, at least. The trading in Sugar, for instance, was nearly 100,000 shares less than on Monday. The price moved, between 104 and 105 1/4, and closed at 105 8/5, a net decline of 1/4. Lead was also less active, the trading in it amounting to only 3,300 shares, against more than 15,000 on Monday.

Work on the first twenty-one-footer for the class to race at Larchmont this Summer has begun at the Herreshoff yards at Bristol. It is a fin keel for W. Butler Duncan, Jr. The Herreshoffs will build at least four of the boats for this class, proliably for C. Oliver Iselin, August Belmont, and Royal Phelps Carroll.
ATHENS, May 1 -- A severe shock of earthquake was felt here at 2:25 o'clock this morning, and was followed at brief intervals by several lighter shocks. None of the shocks did any damage.

Washington, May 1 -- Fifty clerks were dropped from the records and pension office of the War Department last night, and of the 150 employes remaining probably not one will remain the first of next month. The discharges are due to the practical completion of the work of the office.

The United Press Local News at a general meeting yesterday effected a permanent organization. The membership of the association is composed of The New-York. Herald, The New-York Tribune, The New-York Times. The New-York Sun, The New-York Recorder, The New-York Morning Journal, The New-York Journal of Commerce and Commercial Bulletin, The New-York Mail and Express, The New-York Evening Telegram, The New-York Evening Sun.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- John Riss Landers of Chicago, aged thirty, who married Mrs. Catherine M. Shacklett of Alexandria, Va., aged sixty-five, at the Hotel Andover, in this city lost Saturday, was arraigned before Magistrate Eisenbrown today on the charge of conspiracy. He and his alleged partner in the conspiracy, W. L. Brown, were each held in $2,000 bail.

The Democrats in the Senate are naturally resentful at the way in which they are treated by the Republicans. Did it ever occur to them that they deserve all they get, and more? They show a child-like surprise that their political foes, having them in a tight place, take advantage of it, having, in the old sporting phrase, their "heads in chancery," go on punching them unmercifully.

Mr. James Gordon Bennett has given an order to the Herreshoff Manufacturing Company for a big sloop yacht. This is in fulfillment of his promise to the yachtsmen of France, made during the Cannes regatta, that he would have a yacht next season to beat the Britannia.

The opening of Public School No. 6, at Madison Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, yesterday, was marked by a brief but animated row between Superintendent John Jasper and the School Trusteas of the Nineteenth Ward, headed by Lewis M. Hornthal. Superintendent Jasper was on hand bright and early with Thomas S. O'Brien, to install him as the Board of Education's appointee as Principal.

There are some significant features in the Treasury statements issued yesterday. The gold reserve was $202,008 above the limit of $100,000,000, and some $920,000 of Treasury gold will be shipped to-day to Europe, thus encroaching on that reserve for the first time since the proceeds of the 5 per cent. loan were received.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Jacob S. Coxey's much-advertised demonstration on behalf of the "Commonweal of Christ." in favor of good roads and the repudiation of national obligations to pay interest on bonds, ended to-day in a fizzle quite as ridiculous as the principles enunciated by the leaders of the movement.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 1 -- Entries closed last night for the Yale-Harvard track athletic games here on May 14. The official list is as follows:

Unusual interest is being manifested in the tri-State relay race to take place on June 2. Riders in all sections are looking forward to the novel race. The Race Committee, composed of Whitefleld W. Smith, Ernest F. Millar, E. Alien Smith, Charles B. Vaughan, and Wiliam Belknap, has issued the following circular:

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., May 1 -- William Waddell of New-York, an expert accountant engaged by the Citizens' Committee of Twenty-five last Fall to examine the Richmond County road account and the general county accounts, reported to the committee last night.
In the matter of the widening and extension of College Place, Justice Beach of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision, saying:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The question of wages plays an important part in the discussion of the times. It is chief in importance in the tariff question. But it seems to be entirely misunderstood, and so much so that I do not believe that I can be called presumptious if I ask space in your columns for endeavoring to make clear the cardinal point of error from which most differences arise.
ALBANY, May 1 -- The municipal control of Albany passed from the Democracy to a coalition styled the "Honest Election Party," composed of Republicans and Hill Democrats, to-day.

JERSEY CITY, May 1 -- If the teachers in the Lafayette Baptist Sunday School do not succeed in forcing out Superintendent S.J. Stephens's wife, they may decide to leave in a body and take their pupils with them. They will decide what to do tomorrow evening.

Edward La Montagne, Jr., a well-known member of the Stock Exchange, and formerly head of the firm of La Montagne, Clarke Co., 15 Broad Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon on a warrant issued by Justice Taintor in the Tombs Police Court. He was arraigned on the charge of grand larceny, and was held for examination to-morrow morning, bail being fixed by Justice Taintor at $10,000.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The weekly telegraphic crop report of the Weather Bureau, published to-day, gives details by States, as follows:

JERSEY CITY, May 1 -- Edward F.C. Young, President of the First National Bank of this city, has filed his answer to the demand of William Y. Johnson, receiver of the Somerset County Bank at Somerville, N.J., requiring Mr. Young to disclose what securities his bank holds belonging to James N. Pidcock.

LONDON, May 1 -- A meeting of the Queen's Privy Council was held at Windsor yesterday, at which Lord Rosebery and Lord Justice (Sir Charles) Russell were present. At the meeting the council adopted the order specified in the following paragraph of the Bering Sea bill:

The new quarters of the Boys' Free Reading Rooms, 68 and 70 University Place, were opened with appropriate exercises last evening. Anthony Comstock addressed the boys, extending to them a cordial invitation to spend their evenings in the rooms. Dr. Mallerson, who was the Superintendent of the reading rooms ten years ago in their old quarters, 8 West Fourteenth Street, also spoke.

The annual report of the operation of the Grand Rapids and Indiana Railroad for 1893 shows that, while suffering from the general business depression in common with other roads, that company was especially unfortunate in not being able to derive any benefit from the Chicago fair. Freight earnings decreased $245,566, and passenger earnings decreased $78,064.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., May 1 -- It is reported in this city that a syndicate composed of English capitalists has subscribed $8,000,000 to complete the tunnel under the East River connepting this city with New-York. The work was started about two years ago and abandoned after an explosion of dynamite that killed five persons, injured many others, and destroyed several buildings.

PEORIA, Ill., May 1 -- Blue Blood, 2:22 3/4, the bay stallion belonging to C.T. Luthy of this city, died yesterday afternoon at the latter's stock farm near Washington. He was six years of age, and was valued at more than $15,000.

Stockholders of the Washington National Bank, which went into voluntary liquidation in April, 1892, are dissatisfied with the action of the liquidators, and intend to hold a meeting to force a settlement of the bank's affairs. Cashier J.T. Granger and Siddell Tilghman were intrusted with the task of closing the bank's accounts.

The steamship Yucatan, of the New-York and Cuba Mail Steamship Line, came into port yesterday with her cargo in the afterhold on fire. It had been burning since 8 o'clock the previous evening, and at a late hour last night was still burning.

The various art eddies, circles, and art worlds about the globe will breathe a long sigh of content to learn that the symbolical, esthetical, mediaevel, hermeneutic, and theosophical brethren of the Rose + Cross have opened their theosophical, hermenerutic, mediaevel, esthetical, and symbolical show of pictures in Paris once more.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Senator Brice's face assumed a pleased look to-day when the result in the Third Ohio District was mentioned.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspordents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Although a great many conferences have been held by Democratic Senators in the last few days, the promised agreement on the Tariff bill has not yet been reached. There are not lacking indications, however, that the work of the tariff "fixers" will soon be accomplished.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Major Moore, the Chief of Police, had a long conference to-day with Private Secretary Thurber with reference to the police arrangements for the protection of the White House during the stay of Coxey's Army in Washington. It was decided to keep the additional policemen on duty in and about the mansion for the present.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 2 -- The twelfth annual meet of the New-York State Division, League of American Wheelmen, will be held in Lockport, June 15 and 16, under the direction of the Lockport Wheelmen. The programme for the first day, just issued, calls for a road race to Olcott, a distance of twelve miles; sports, games, and amusements at that point, and an excursion to Niagara Falls, with an illumination of the Falls by electricity.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, yes- terday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 2 -- General Superintendent Dunlap and other Rock Island officials who are here express themselves as not at all alarmed at General Master Workman Sovereign's threat to tie up their road in case of a continued refusal to make special transportation rates for Gen. Kelly's army.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- The volume of business to-day was about on the basis of a midsummer Saturday half holiday. The brokers arbitrating with the Consolidated Exchange did most of the business that was offering. The room traders who contributed the bulk of the business at the Philadelphia Stock Exchange are for the time being bottled up.

Sheep shearing was the special feature at the Farm Show at Madison Square Garden last night. On a platform in the centre of the arena three sheep were relieved of their thick coats of wool. A gaping crowd surrounded the contestants. It was something the average New-Yorker has not seen since he came to town from the old farm.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- There was a hearing to-day before the Postmaster General of the persons interested in getting the contract for the printing of stamped envelopes for the Government. When Mr. Bissell advertised for bids some time ago, he refrained from specifying that the bidders should be regular manufacturers of envelopes.

The strikes that are going on in the West seem to be strikes against industry and law and order for the most part. In most cases the employers whose service has been abandoned were losing money or would lose it by compliance with the demands of "Labor," and there is no inducement for them to yield.

Dr. Mary Putnam Jacobi is still on the war path for woman suffrage. She said so yesterday at one of the largest parlor meetings that has been-held in this city since the interest in the subject of political equality began, to focus itself upon a petition to the State Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- What to do with the Coxey army is the problem which now confronts the local authorities, Col. Snow, the Sergeant at Arms of the House, confessed this morning that he could not determine what disposition would be made of the Commonwealers now in the city.

Receiver Trumbull of the Union Pacific, Denver and Gulf has left Denver for New-York to hold a conference with several people interested in the Gulf bonds and interest charges now past due. In spite of dull times, the Gulf Line is netting a good surplus every month, and now has over $400,000 in the treasury to be disbursed in the payment of interest charges and in other ways to be decided later.

SALT LAKE, Utah, May 2 -- Gen. Carter, with his 300 rough followers, remained all day at Murray Station, seven miles out on the Rio Grande Western, trying to capture a train. This band is composed of desperate men, who talk treason and violence. Before leaving this city Gen. Carter said that within six weeks there will be armed men marching to the aid of the Industrial Army.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., May 2 -- Fire started this afternoon on land owned by Thomas D. Jackson. It made great headway before the strong southwest wind. Land on the north aide of the West Ponds was burned over, then the fire crossed the Federal Furnace Road and burned to the shore of Billington Sea. Between 1,500 and 2,000 acres of woodland were burned over, which is partly covered with oak and pine wood.

Again the Giants lost a game. This time the gilt-edged team of the metropolis were taken into camp by their old foes the Philadelphias. This year the Quakers are not being handled by Harry Wright, but they are being skillfully piloted by Arthur Irwin, and they are playing better and stronger than ever before.

EATONTOWN, N.J., May 2 -- The Township Committee here has ordered the seizure and sale of the grand stand and other personal property of the Monmouth Park Association for the payment of the taxes, now in default, and amounting to something over $2,300, on Monday next, at 10 A.M.

The ridiculous end of the Coxey "movement" illustrates anew the wisdom or the good fortune of the founders of our Government in establishing the political capital in a city that was not destined to be the commercial capital. No doubt Washington was selected not without reference to what is called nowadays a "real estate boom," and was expected to be a more important place than it has become.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2 -- Harvard redeemed the defeat of April 14 by beating Williams at baseball to-day, 10 to 4. The weather was so warm that neither team put up its best game, and Williams was hampered by the absence of her best pitcher. Clark was fairly effective, except in the first inning, when he gave Whittemore, Winslow, and Stevenson bases on balls.

At a meeting of the Amity Wheelmen at 262 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, E.D., Tuesday night, the following officers were elected for a year: President -- G. Fowden; Vice President -- Ed Tappan; Secretary -- Harry Kellock; Treasurer -- W. Finch; Captain -- Oscar Chambers; First Lieutenant -- E. Bunn; Second Lieutenant -- Lowell Yost; Colorbearer -- J.S. Stevenson; Bugler -- G. Conneally.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- In the House to- day, rising to a matter of privilege, Mr. Johnson (Dem., Ohio,) offered the following resolution:

NIAGARA FALLS, May 2 -- A woman giving the name of Georgia Hughes, thirty-three years old, of Buffalo came here shortly after 3 o'clock and took the identical course to reach the rapids that Mrs. Prosser of Buffalo took last week, reaching the rear of the Cataract House about 3:30 P.M.

The Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States met last night at Delmonico's to elect officers. Considerable interest attached to the election. There was a split in the ticket for some of the offices. More than 400 votes were cast. The result of the balloting was as follows:

BOSTON, May 2 -- Local stocks, apart from the coppers, were dull, and the market was thoroughly lifeless, though it held fairly well. Bell Telephone sold in small lots at 190 1/2 and Erie Telephone at 46 1/2. Mexican Central securities show no change from the last quotations, the fours selling at 55 and the stock at 7 3/4.

The committee of Reading general mortgage bondholders has called for bondholders to deposit bonds, with a view of beginning foreclosure proceedings. This was determined on two weeks ago, but deferred until J. Plerpont Morgan could confer with the bondholders in Europe. Matters will be pushed, and bondholders are requested to deposit their bonds with the Mercantile Trust Company, 120 Broadway, or the Commonwealth Title, Insurance, and Trust Company, 813 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- There was a special meeting this afternoon of the Sen- ate Judiciary Committee, at which the nominations of F.C. Peck to be Marshal of the Northern District of New-York, J.L. Bennett to be United States Attorney for the Brooklyn District, and Wallace MacFarlane to be United States Attorney for the Southern District of New-York were considered.

One of the neatest-looking and fancy-taking small boats which the writer has seen this season is the thirteen-foot centreboard building at Lawley's for C.F. Lyman, owner of the Fancy, from designs by Stewart Binney, says The Boston Globe. The new boat is intended for afternoon sailing, single-handed or with possibly one companion, and has a hinged arrangement for lowering her mast, so that she may be towed behind the larger boat.

TRENTON, N.J., May 2 -- An "Independent State Convention" was held here to-day by a handful of men dissatisfied with social, business, and political conditions as they exist, who want all the "reforms" demanded by the People's Party and kindred organizations.
Unless Tip, the big Asiatic elephant in the Central Park Zoo, mends his manners and controls his vicious temper he will be killed and his bones set up in the American Museum of Natural History.

Not the least remarkable feature of the civil war was the large number of foreigners who enlisted in the Union Army. At the beginning of the contest the natives of almost every foreign country resident here organized companies and regiments and offered their services to the Government. In this city, in 1861, regiments were formed by the Irish, Germans, Italians, Englishmen, Poles, Hungarians, Highlanders, Spaniards, French, Austrians, Scandinavians,

The annual budget for 1895 of the Brook- lyn Board of Education is complete, and was sent to Mayor Schieren yesterday. The Finance Committee asks for $2,949,158. In 1894 the board asked for $3,359,074, but the Board of Estimate scaled down the amount to $2,331,924.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The leader of the mob of tramps now in Washington-Coxey by name -- was himself placed under arrest to-day to answer for his violation of the law yesterday in attempting to speak on the steps of the Capitol.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 2 -- The labor troubles in Cleveland came to a crisis to-day, when 4,000 men, armed with clubs and stones, marched through the low-lying manufacturing districts, in the heart of the city, known as "The Flats," closing down each factory as they came to it. There were few English-speaking people in the crowd.

The woman suffragists of Brooklyn have stolen a march on their opponents. They have arranged a reception, to be held in Wilson's Hall, on Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, next Saturday afternoon, at which all the delegates to the Constitutional Convention from New-York, Kings, and Queens Counties have been invited to be present.

Manager Eck thinks that Johnson this year will ride faster than ever before. Judging from the manner in which the smooth-faced youth from Minneapolis is reeling off fast quarters, halves, and miles down South, he feels justified in believing that his boy will lower the colors of Sanger, Tyler, Taylor, Dirnberger, Bliss, and the other cracks this season.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -- The official closing quotations for mining stocks to-day were as follows:
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Mr. Sibley, referring to the suggestion that the Populist Party of Pennsylvania had intended at its convention yesterday to nominate him for the Governorship, said:

Yesterday was a good one for horse trainers who are preparing their charges to run in the Brooklyn Handicap, as it made the animals ambitious to race, and forced them to sweat profusely, which was just what was needed.

Brooklyn society, or at least the feminine portion of it, donned its most fetching costumes last night for a social function which is to Brooklyn what the National Horse Show Association's annual exhibition at Madison Square Garden is to New-York. The occasion was the second annual horse show of the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club held in its club house on the Prospect Park Plaza.

RONDOUT, May 2 -- The 800 laborers employed in the brickyards between this city and Glasco went on a strike this morning, and all the yards were shut down. The strike was the outcome of a cut of 20 cents a day in every man's wages, irrespective of his position.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Marinus Dyer, an employe in Huyck Argersinger's felt mill at Kenwood, a suburb of this city, discovered fire in the "picking room" when he opened the door this morning. His alarm was responded to by about fifty men. A small hose was brought into use, but was of no avail against the rapidly-advancing flames.

Mrs. Laura Gillespie, a widow employed at the General Post Office in this city as a scrubwoman, was badly injured yesterday morning while climbing into a moving elevator on the ground floor. She was caught between the car floor and the wall of the shaft. Her head was severely injured, her left jaw being broken and her left eye being torn from its socket.
The weekly meetings of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club came to an end yesterday. Mrs. Isaac Lawrence won the Championship Bowl for the second time, and Mr. W.G. Eliot won the Knickerbocker Cup.

LONDON, May 2 -- The International Bimetallic Conference was formally opened in the Mansion House to-day, Lord Mayor Tyler presiding. The opening address was delivered by ex-Lord Mayor Sir David Evans. A large number of delegates were present, including some of the best-known of British and foreign financiers.

The veto of the Chamber of Commerce Rapid-Transit bill would be an act of Executive recklessness of which we deem Gov. Flower scarcely capable. This bill was forced through a Legislature very reluctant to pass it by a public sentiment which the Senators and Assemblymen at least thought it prudent to obey.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Almost without opposition there was passed in the House this afternoon a bill reported by Mr. Dingley from the joint commission to inquire into the status of the law organizing the Executive departments, providing for a reorganization of the present accounting system of the Treasury Department.
A new and most interesting figure was introduced yesterday in the trial of Dr. Henry Meyer for poisoning Ludwig Brandt in the person of Mr. John Gardner of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Among the documents transmitted to Congress to-day by the President was the ninth annual report of the Commissioner of Labor, Carroll D. Wright, relating to building and loan associations. It has special interest in connection with the income-tax discussion.

Reorganization of the Reading Railroad Company has been blocked, for a time at least, by the action taken yesterday by the general mortgage bondholders, who demanded that the bonds be immediately deposited, with a view to the foreclosure of the mortgage. This latter step has been decided upon provided there is a continued default in interest.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 2 -- Much of the property stolen in Stockbridge by the "gentleman burglar" has been recovered, and the police announced to-day that evidence has been discovered which points to Michael Sherlock, who was held for the Grand Jury last week for the robbery or the Episcopal rectory at Lenox, as the thief.

Another serious accident occurred on the Academy of Music stage yesterday afternoon. The matinee attendance was large, and the audience had been aroused to that high pitch of expectancy which always precedes the rescue scene in "The Girl I Left Behind Me," when, with the rushing on of the thirty horses, one of the riders was seen to drop from his saddle and disappear under the hoofs of the animals.

BATAVIA, May 2 -- Dr. Ward B. Whitcomb, physician of the New-York State Institution for the Blind, located in this city, has made charges of cruel and inhuman treatment of pupils by Frederick R. Place, the Superintendent.

Yesterday's midweek gold export will be followed to-day by the shipment on the Augusta Victoria of $500,000, which was taken from the Sub-Treasury yesterday, and probably of $1,000,000 additional, notice of the intended withdrawal of which was sent to the Sub-Treasury yesterday afternoon. This notice may be modified, but as far as was known at the close of business the Sub-Treasury will be called upon for the money.

GREENPORT, L.I., May 2 -- When the steamboat Montauk was crossing over from Shelter Island Heights to Greenport this evening on the way to New-York, the pilot, William Henry Winters, who was at the wheel, fell backward to the floor of the pilot house. He had been stricken with apoplexy.

MOUNT PLEASANT, Penn., May 2 -- The first attempt to introduce dynamite in behalf of the coke strikers was frustrated here to-day. Superintendent Ramsey of the Southwest Coke Company received reliable information a week ago that the strikers intended to blow up his company's "A" shaft at Morewood.

There is every reason to believe now that a season of grand opera in the German language will be given next Fall at the Metropolitan Opera House. The labors of Mr. Anton Seidl on the one hand and Mr. Walter Damrosch on the other are not to be in vain. If the season is assured on a sound basis, lovers of opera in German will have Mr. William Steinway to thank for it.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Postmaster General Bissell has practically determined that no saloon keeper shall be appointed Postmaster. He was asked to-day if it was to be understood that this rule applied to hotel keepers who, while not directly interested in the liquor business, leased their bars to others. Mr. Bissell replied:
Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities at auction yesterday at 111 Broadway:

The stock market was less active yesterday as a whole, but there was considerable interest in some of the specialties. Sugar was the most active stock, but the trading in it was not excessive. It was weak in the early hours on reports from Washington that there was a "hitch" in the arrangement which is to give greater protection to the product.

Death came to a man and a woman and three were seriously burned yesterday afternoon through benzine exploding in the basement of 61 East Twelfth Street, a five-story double building occupied by C. Jolly Son, dyers and scourers.
Natural foods are as a rule insoluble. They must be dissolved before they can be absorbed.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Mr. Peffer (Pop., Kan.,) speaking to-day of Coxey's arrest, said that he could not discuss the matter from a legal standpoint until he knew the facts and the charge upon which Coxey was apprehended. Lafe Pence, a member of the House from Colorado, said he believed his arrest to be absolutely unjustifiably and unwarranted.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Some decidedly interesting testimony was adduced this afternoon in the hearing before Master in Chancery Cary of Milwaukee in the petition for the removal of Thomas F. Oakes from the receivership of the Northern Pacific Road. According to the financial reports of the road, the acquisition of the Chicago Terminal involved an outlay of $20,000,000 in bonds and assumed indebtedness.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Gov. Flower gave the best part of to-day to hearings on eight New-York bills, namely: The Chamber of Commerce Rapid Transit, the Dock Contract, the Bi-Partisan Police Commission, the Bi-Partisan Park, the Police Surgeons' Increased Salaries, the Patrolmen's Increased Salary, the Mayor and Heads of Departments, and the Butts Five-Cent Continuous Elevated Fare.

Representatives of almost every creed and nationality attended the funeral in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, yesterday morning, of Jesse Seligman, the banker, who died on April 23 at Coronado Beach, Cal. Among the 2,000 persons present were hundreds of leaders in the social, financial, and political life of the city.

Building Inspector Kipp has granted a permit to M.H. Thompson to erect a two-story cottage on Chestnut Street. Also, a permit to Mrs. John Whalend for a two-story frame building on Morris Street. Alderman John Schlobohm has begun the erection of two flat houses on the east side of Warburton Avenue. These are daily examples of the rapid growth of Yonkers.

When the American Hunt and Pony Racing Association changed its name and constitution, calling itself the Steeplechase, Hunt, and Pony Racing Association, a committee was appointed to frame a set of rules governing cross-country events. The Coney Island Jockey Club and the new Jockey Club agreed to accept these rules and to give the officers of the Steeplechase, Hunt, and Pony Racing Association control of steeplechase and hurdle races run over their tracks.

Deputy City Chamberlain John H. Campbell received a message from the Importers and Traders' National Bank yesterday noon asking him to call there at once. When he reached the bank he was told that two men, one who gave his name as "Mr. Young," had called there with a subscription paper of what purported to be the Protective Order of American Firemen.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 2 -- The Boston branch of the New-England Industrial Army, under the leadership of Gen. Fitzgerald, arrived here about 4:30 o'clock. The men looked fatigued, and marched languidly through the principal streets of the city. They made their quarters at Aurora Hall, where a union meeting was held to-night.

Assistant District Attorney Francis L. Wellman yesterday confirmed the report of his engagement to Miss Emma Juch. Mr. Wellman said no date for the wedding has been fixed. Miss Juch, is now at her country home in Stamford, Conn.

The New-York Society Library has elected the following Trustees: Charles E. Strong, Frederick Sheldon, Henry Drisler, Frederic J. de Peyster, Johnston L. de Peyster, George V.N. Baldwin, Edward King, Albert Matthews, James William Beekman, John A. Hardenbergh, Charles B. Curtis, F. Augustus Schermerhorn, R. Fulton Cutting, Charles H. Marshall, and Frederic de P. Foster.

There is no reason that is very easily assignable why the first day of May should be looked forward to all over Europe with dread, or why it should have been selected as the day on which the dissatisfied classes of society shall make "demonstrations" and "show their power."

The conference between Anton Seidl and Walter Damrosch at the Liederkranz Hall on Wednesday night, which lasted till the small hours yesterday morning, ended as those who knew both men expected it would. After Mr. Steinway arrived with peace in his eye and a deep desire in his heart to bring about an understanding between the two men, the real conference began.

The baseball team of Wesleyan College visited Fordham yesterday to play their old opponents, the St. John's College team. Fortune at first smiled on the Connecticut players, for at the end of the second inning the score stood 4 to 1. In the third inning of the Fordham team two of their men got home, and the shouts of the spectators took a more jubilant tone.
SANDY HOOK, N. J., May 3. -- The sloop yacht Alga of Boston went ashore on the point of Sandy Hook this evening. She is in no immediate danger, and will probably be floated at the next high water.

The majority of the Democratic Senators have yielded to the minority in regard to the Tariff bill. It would be unreasonable to ask and useless to expect any stronger evidence of their disposition to heed the country's demand for the prompt passage of the measure.

BOSTON, May 3. -- The market for local stocks was inclined to Weakness in spots, but trading was light. Mexican Central 4s dropped 1/2, to 54 1/2, althoug the stock held well at 7 7/8. Erle Telephone was off 1/2, to 49, and Bell Telephone was firm, at 190, the same as last night's closing. Boston and Albany dropped 1/2, to 210.

In the action of ejectment brought by the newly-appointed Board of Trustees of the Central Park Baptist Church against the Rev. Mr. Patterson and the old Board of Trustees, a decision favorable to the petitioners was rendered yesterday by Justice McKeon, in the Seventh Judicial District Court.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 3. -- There was very little trouble here to-day with the rioters who yesterday inarched from factory to factory, destroying property and compelling men to abandon work. Extensive preparations were made in anticipation of an outbreak, but the day passed in comparative quiet, and the use of military force was not necessary.

Edward La Montagne, Jr., Elisha M. Fulton, Jr., and Herman Clarke, composing, the brokerage firm of La Montagne, Clarke Co., who were arrested on complaint of Florance M. David of Montreal on charges of embezzling $75,000 from him, were arragined before Justice Taintor at the Tombs Police Court yesterday for examination.

-- That the people of this city are entirely honest is shown by the way they bring "found articles" to Police Headquarters to await owners. Sometimes the most curious articles are lost -- things which must have been missed if of any use to the owners. As an example, one crutch was brought in to await ownership. The owner will find it there if he is able to get there.

At the decent sale, in partition, of the Levy property, the four-story brownstone dwelling 205 West Fourteenth Street, 25 feet front by half the block, was knocked down to Hugh Slevin, the lessee of the adjoining building, at $27,500. The purchaser has announced his refusal to take the property, on the ground that the whole of the restrictive covenant affecting it was not read at the time of sale.

DULUTH, Minn., May 3. -- A telegram was received at Virginia to-night by Sheriff Sharvey requesting him to proceed at once to Mountain Iron as there was shooting going on there, the striking miners toeing determined to carry out their threats.

Lord Dunraven's cutter, the Valkyrie, is now on the ocean heading for home. She started from the Erie Basin, South Brooklyn, shortly before 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The tug Pulver, her tender during the cup races last Fall, towed her out of the basin and as far as Sandy Hook.
Dr. O.G. CILLEY, Boston, Mass., says: "I have used it very extensively, and with the most remarkable success in dyspepsia, and in all cases where there is derangement of the liver and kidneys."

A trolley system is likely to be introduced in this city before many months are past. For some time the Metropolitan Traction Company has been paying close attention to various plans for underground trolley systems, which, it is claimed, have all the advantages of the overhead wire system, without sharing any of its bad features.

Judge Cowing, in the Court of General Sessions, tried the experiment yesterday of letting a prisoner sentence himself. It didn't work well. John L. Smith was the prisoner. He had pleaded guilty of stealing a wagon, saddle, and bridle. Two and one-half years in Sing Sing was Judge Cowing's first sentence.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 3. -- The Triangle Club of Princeton gave its first performance of the season this evening in University Hall, presenting a farce-comedy, entitled "The Hon. Julius Caesar; or, The Kind King, the Keen Konspirators, the Kute Kids, the Krafty Kops, and the Killing Klimax."

Thomas C. Brewer, the young bank promoter, whose several ventures landed him in Ludlow Street Jail, came into prominence again yesterday, when the suit brought by his wife, Martha M. Brewer, for an annulment of their marriage, came up before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Special Term of the Superior Court.

The best fishing seems to be for flounders off Canarsie, where they are caught in abundance, running in weight as high as two pounds and even over. Numbers of boats are hired by eager anglers, crowds of whom find good sport and ample catches, the fish running larger and being more plentiful than in Hell Gate and the Sound.

The public abandonment by the Reading receivers of their plan for the reorganization of the property under their temporary control was a step which had to come sooner or later, owing to the entire loss of confidence in the chief financial centres of the world in the ability of the receivers to rehabilitate the company successfully.

LONDON, May 3. -- H.H. Gibbs, President of the British Bimetallic League, presided over the second day's session of the International Bimetallic Congress in the Mansion House to-day. Sir William Houldsworth, M.P., read a paper on "The Effects upon Agriculturists, Manufacturers, Wage Earners, Merchants, Bankers, and Investors of the Fall in the General Level of Prices."

Having completed the work of reorganizing the Republican Party of this city, and placing it on a new basis without the permission, advice, or assistance of Thomas C. Platt of Tioga County, but acting under the authority conferred upon it by the Republican. County Committee at its meeting in November last, the Committee of Thirty had a dinner at the Waldorf last night.

Low-priced railroad stocks and industrials furnished chief interest in the stock market yesterday. Sugar held its lead in volume of sales, contributing 86,100 shares to the day's, total of 233,917 shares. Reports from Washington still govern this stock. They are sustained not alone by plausible general dispatches, but by bounding quotations.

Witnesses fairly sped across the witness stand yesterday in the trial of Dr. Henry Meyer, charged with poisoning Ludwig Brandt. The prosecution had about closed the main part of its case, with the exception of the expert testimony, which will probably consume nearly a week, and the witnesses called yesterday were merely produced to corroborate certain details of the evidence of Muller, the informer.

Agitation over the woman suffrage question, continues to increase in Brooklyn. The anti-suffragists have developed unexpected strength. More women sign petitions against extension of the suffrage than sign in favor of it. The signatures obtained from men are, on the contrary, more generally favorable to the enfranchisement of women.
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 3. -- Col. Thomas Galvin's regiment of Gen. Frye's Army of the Commonweal arrived in and departed from Pittsburg this evening.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- The great strength developed to-day in the traction stocks saved the local market, which was inclined to sell off in sympathy with New-York prices, as indicated by the stock ticker. The arbitrage houses have concluded to make no further attempt to influence the Governing Committee of the New-York Stock Exchange.

MONTREAL, May 3. -- W. Steinitz, the champion of the world, and Emanuel Lasker of Berlin, to-day resumed play in the championship chess match for $2,000 a side at the Cosmopolitan Club rooms in this city. There was one of the largest chess gatherings ever held in this city. One of the prettiest features of the scene was the extraordinarily large number of Women, who seemed to follow the game with considerable interest and excitement.

Brooklyn politicians are already pulling wires for control of the delegation to the next Republican State Convention. There will be eighty-eight delegates from Kings County in that body.
