If they act as a unit they will exercise a weighty influence on results. If they divide, as they heretofore have done, they will count for little in making the nominations.
The Alumni Association of the New-York Homeopathic Medical College and Hospital held its twelfth annual meeting and dinner at Delmonico's last night. The menu was as follows:

Joseph. T. Magee, who has been locked up in the Tombs for several weeks, charged by the District Attorney with the murder of Miss M. J. Fuller, yesterday walked out of court a free man. After two days of deliberation on the case, the Grand Jury yesterday announced, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, that the charges had been dismissed and no indictment found.

ALBANY, May 3. -- The managers of the Craig Colony for Epileptics met in the Executive Chamber to-day and appointed Dr. Frederick Peterson of New-York, President, and George S. Ewart of North Sparta, Living'ston County, Treasurer. The Governor expressed regret that the Legislature, while making an appropriation of $140,000 for the colony, had provided that only $12,000 of this amount should be immediately available, while the remainder should not be available until July, 1895.

It is probable that suit will be brought to-day or Monday by the City of Brooklyn against ex-Police Commissioner Henry I. Hayden, for the recovery of $19,400, which William D. Lohman stole from the Excise Department.

BALTIMORE, May 3. -- The Brooklyns were outplayed and dropped the second game to the Orioles to-day. Brodie was again a tower of strength at the bat, making four hits, for seven bases. Brouthers, too, was good, securing a triple and a double. Brodie's error was an excusable muff after a hard run.

ALBANY, May 3. -- Gov. Flower within the next twenty-five days will be called upon to act upon 527 bills which, the Legislature which adjourned last Friday be queathed him. Out of this lot are the following that affect New-York, Long Island Staten Island, and Westchester County, and the general bills of importance.

Police Inspector Williams and Capt. Slevin, assisted by several Central Office detectives, yesterday made a careful investigation into the mysterious killing of Gotlieb Grob, at 221 William Street. Grob was a cook in the restaurant of William Buckelmein, at 433 Broome Street. The man lived alone in a room in the rear tenement at the William Street address.

The women of the Baptist Social union met at the Windsor Hotel last evening. Dr. Wendell C. Phillips presided, and among the guests were the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, State Senator Charles T. Saxton, and Wheeler H. Peckham.

"Now, don't you propose by this bill to put all the departmental offices up at a raffle next Fall, when you vote for Mayor?" This question was addressed by Gov. Flower to a representative of the City Club who was urging his approval of the bill giving the Mayor of this city the power to remove the heads of departments within sixty days of coming into office.
Charles S. Fairchild, ex-Secretary of the Treasury, in calling the meeting to order, and in introducing Oscar S. Straus, said:

Mr. John J. Peoli, who has been for so many years the owner of a studio in the Young Men's Christian Association Building, and who died in Cuba in 1893, was a singularly good type of a New-Yorker on whom his American surroundings made little or no impression. He was born in this city in 1825, and had lived here a great part of his later life.

-- Mayor Gilroy, Corporation Counsel Clark, and President Martin of the Police Commission had a long talk in the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon. All the politicians who knew about it wondered what this "important conference" was about. Inasmuch as it was held in lull view of everybody who desired to go into the Mayor's public office, it is not likely it was any more important then such talks usually are.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 3. -- The three contingents of the New-England Crusaders, under the command of Fitzgerald, Sweetland, and Murray, have met and parted. They left town this morning, much to the gratification of the people of this city. Fitzgerald and his 56 Socialists spent the night in Aurora Hall, and were given a substantial breakfast provided toy the local Socialists.

By the will of Mrs. Olivia Phelps Atter bury, filed for probate yesterday, a number of charitable bequests are made. Mrs. Atterbury's real estate is valued at $75,000 and her personal estate at $65,000. The executors are her husband, Benjamin B. Atterbury, Boudinot C. Atterbury, her son, and W.B. Dodge, Jr. Among the public bequests are:

JERSEY CTTY, N. J., May 3. -- Chief of Police Murphy has begun a crusade against the New-York "green-goods" men, who use fictitious addresses in this city to cover their transactions. These are Thomas Jefferson, 37 York Street, which is a vacant lot; Henry Butler, and George Milligan, 288 Hudson Street, which is in the Pennsylvania Railroad freight yard, and Thomas Hunt, 240 Hudson Street, which is where the train shed stands.

BOSTON, May 3. -- It is stated that the special investigating committee of the United States Treasury Department, which has been examining the affairs of the Boston Custom House, has discovered shortages in the merchandise in the Government storehouses in this city. At one storehouse, it is said, the deficiency amounts in value to $18,000.

The Architectural League of New-York held a dinner at its rooms, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, Wednesday, at which Edwin H. Blashfleld, who made the decorations for one of the domes of the Liberal Arts Building at the World's Fair, read a paper on "Decorative Art in the Renaissance Period of Italy."

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Frank Hatton, late editor of The Post, was buried to-day with demonstrations of affection and esteem such as have seldom accompanied a private funeral in Washington. The services were held in the home which he had recently built and fitted up in Hillyer Place, in the northwestern part of the city.
ALBANY, May 3. -- Gov. Flower has signed the bills annexing Flatlands, Gravesend, and New-Utrecht to Brooklyn. The Governor has signed also:

TRENTON, N. J., May 3. -- Carroll's TwoCent Ferriage bill was defeated by the House this morning, whereupon McEwan of Hudson, the Republican leader, announced his resignation from the leadership and from the Chairmanship of the Committee on Ways and Means.

Gen. John C. New of Indiana, Consul General to London during the Harrison Administration, manager in chief of the Harrison forces at the last Republican Convention, and close personal friend and political ally of the ex-President on all occasions, stood before the Gilsey House bar drinking an unstrained lemonade yesterday afternoon.

The following are some of the reasons influencing the women who will send a "protest" to the Constitutional Convention against striking out the word "male" from the Constitution of New-York State. Copies of this and of the protest can be obtained at Cooper Union, 15 Third Avenue; at Brancard's, 150 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, and at the Waldorf. The protest can be signed at these places.

TOMS RIVER, N. J., May 3. -- Reflections from five different forest fires could be seen last night at this place. One was between here and Barnet Park. Much valuable timber was swept away. The house of Mr. Worth, a farmer, was burned. Another fire prevailed on the south side of Toms River, jusit opposite Island Heights, but the wind was blowing toward the bay.
The Chamber of Commerce held its one hundred and twenty-sixth annual meeting at 32 Nassau Street yesterday and elected the following officers for the year which ends May 2, 1895:

It appears that the Populist Senators in Washington who have been giving what aid and comfort they could to the gangs of tramps who are traversing the country have not misjudged the sentiments of their supporters at home. There is a Secretary of State in Kansas who is even more malignant and senseless than Alien himself.

Col. A.B. Steinberger. Col. A.B. Steinberger, who became well known during the Presidency of Gen. Grant from his connection with missions to the Samoan and Hawaiian Islands, died in Dorchester, Mass., Wednesday night. He was born 54 years ago in Pennsylvania, but during most of his life, when he was not traveling, he made his home in this city.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. Robert B. Bach, as referee, sold to Emilie Huber, plaintiff, the three-story frame tenement 265 Humboldt Street, west side, 20 feet south of Maujer Street, 20 by 60; and the property 784 to 788 Grand Street, south side, 75 feet east of Humboldt Street, 50 by 100, consisting of similar tenements, with stores, for $19,985.89.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- One of the results of the miserable Coxey movement is the feeling of insecurity which this tramp migration has given to all suburban residents.

Incoming Steamships. DUE TO-DAY, (FRIDAY,) May 4. -- Amalfi, Hamburg, April 18; Britannic, Liverpool, April 25; City of Rome, Glasgow, April 24; Edwin, Gibraltar, April 19; Habana, Havana, April 30; Normannia, Hamburg, April 26; Olympia, Gibraltar, April 18; Persian Monarch, London, April 17; Peruvian, Glasgow, April 21; Virginia, Christiansand, April 21; Wieland, Gibraltar, April 22.

Employes at the arsenal in Central Park think that Tip, the big elephant, got some indication that the Park Commissioners contemplate killing him because of his viciousness. Yesterday his demeanor toward Keeper Snyder was positively lamblike. This is not taken, however, as an indication that he will mend his evil ways.

The steamship Persian Monarch of the Wilson Steamship Line ran aground on the inner bar near Eastport, L.I., sixty-five miles east of Sandy Hook, about 9:30 o'clock Wednesday night. The weather was perfectly clear, and the water was comparatively calm when the vessel struck. The life-saving crew stationed near Eastport boarded the ship immediately, but Capt. Bristow, commander of the Persian Monarch, declined their assistance.
Never in its history has Sherry's seen such a gathering of people as Socked there last evening to hear a discussion of the subject of woman suffrage.

ROME, May 3. -- The debate on the budget in the Chamber of Deputies to-day was directed especially to questions of the Government's foreign policy. The needs of the army and navy, the position of Italy in the Triple Alliance, and the expediency of her holding fast to Austria and Germany were discussed at length.

A case involving some very curious features will be called for trial in the Jefferson Market Police Court to-day. It appears that about twenty years ago a tract of land, containing 2,000 acres, and situated in Suffolk County, was sold by the Sheriff at an execution sale and bought by one William Williams, a resident of Brooklyn.

ALBANY, May 3. Ex-Chamberlain Crain of New-York City appeared before the Attorney General to-day in favor of the application made to the Attorney General on the petition of the Central Labor Union and other organizations in New-York City, asking him to apply to the Supreme Court for leave to begin an action against the Standard Oil Company of New-York to vacate its charter.

-- The Successor of "Utopia." -- "Utopia, Limited," will close its New-York season at the Broadway Theatre with next week's performances. It will be succeeded. May 14, by Thomas Q. Seabrooke, who will present Barnet and Chadwick's new burlesque operetta, "Tobaseo," now playing at the Boston Museum. In addition to Comedian Seabrooke, the cast will include Otis Harlan.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

LONDON, May 3. -- Lord Salisbury speaking in Trowbridge this evening on the Government's attitude to the House of Lords and Irish home rule said that as far as he could see the country regarded the House of Lords as a very good institution for checking the errors of the House of Commons.

The gentlemen of various nationalities who have met in London to urge upon the Government of Great Britain the acceptance of an international bimetallic agreement are clearly within their rights, and are, moreover, pursuing a rational course. During the period since the adoption of a gold standard by Germany there have been repeated conferences of official delegates from the chief commercial nations of the world to discuss the question of bimetallism.
The few following names are selected from a long list who have been my patients from seven to thirteen years, and from whom permission to use their names has been obtained or voluntarily given:

Such of the earnest culture of this town as has not within the past few weeks been devoted to the discussion of woman suffrage has been largely bestowed upon German opera. It has seemed for several years that there was little chance of one season of German opera; but it seems suddenly to have dawned upon a number of persons that there might nevertheless be two.
The few following names are selected from a long list who have been my patients from seven to thirteen years, and from whom permission to use their names has been obtained or voluntarily given:

If the time-honored custom of playing nine innings had not been lived up to yesterday, the Giants would have won a game. For eight innings they were in the lead, and when the enthusiasts who have not lost faith in the team's ability to win games were congratulating themselves on the good prospects of another victory, the Philadelphias began pounding the curves of young Westervelt in a most alarming manner.

The Larchmont Yacht Clubhouse will be formally opened on Saturday, May 19. The Trustees, in a circular, say: "The flag will be formally hoisted and saluted at 4 o'clock P. M., on the arrival of the 3:03 train from New-York. Other trains leave New-York at 1:03, 2:02, 4:08. 4:33, 5:05, and 5:30 P. M. Members desiring to return to New-York the same evening can do so by the 9 and 11:20 P. M. trains.

The business men of New-York raised their voices to the United States Senate last night in protest against further delay and in prayer for speedy action on the Tariff bill. With an earnestness that could not be misunderstood, and an emphasis which was commanding, some of the best-known and most influential men of the city spoke.

With the beginning of warm weather, the canoeists are actively preparing for a busy season of racing and cruising in their stanch, tiny craft. In nearly all of the canoe clubs in this vicinity the boats are being brushed off, cleaned, and newly varnished for the coming regattas and cruises.

-- Fifteen members of the athletic section of St. John's College, Fordham, are training for the intercollegiate games at Berkeley Oval. Kiernan, W. Boyle, and Vaughan will run in the long-distance events. Quinlan, Rafferty, Ellis, and Malone will represent the college in the 100, 220, and 440 yard dashes, and M. E. Doran and Robinson in the high and broad Jumps.

John L. Cook, twenty-two years old, who is employed, at 217 West Forty-fourth Street, was found unconscious, at 4:45 yesterday morning, by Policeman Kelly of the East Fifty-first Street Police Station, in East Forty-third Street, just west of Madison Avenue. There was a wound on the top of his head, and three of his teeth were gone.

There was a fairly good attendance at the Farm Show in the Madison Square Garden last evening. Interest in the show appears to be increasing, and a very large attendance is expected this evening, when the show will come to an end.

M.D. Fitzgerald, leader, and about fifty soldiers of the New-England contingent of the Coxey Army arrived yesterday on the C.H. Northam from New-Haven. When the Northam reached her East River pier and the gangplank was run out, Fitzgerald marshaled his men.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. yesterday.

-- Bicyclists visiting Manasquan, N. J., are advised to keep off the sidewalks. A clergyman recently rode twelve feet on the sidewalk, when, a Town Marshal arrested him. He was fined $5 by the Mayor. Being short of funds, the minister was obliged to accept a loan of the amount from a by-stander. The penalty for riding on the sidewalk at Ocean Grove is $10.

Hearty good will, but very little formality was shown at the reception by the United Service Club last evening to Admiral A.E. K. Benham. About 100 guests were present. Admiral Benham, though the central figure of the gathering, was the most retiring. His bashfulness is well known, and the necessity of making a short speech to a circle of sympathetic hearers brought a blush to his well-tanned face.

Police Commissioner MacLean's term expired with April, but Mayor Gilroy has not yet appointed his successor. Yesterday afternoon, after Mayor Gilroy had left his office, it was reported that Mr. MacLean had sent his resignation to the Mayor. Commissioner MacLean refused to discuss the matter.

Rowing men belonging to the boat clubs along the Harlem River, from One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street to Macomb's Dam Bridge, are making the most of the fine weather. Many of the raeing crews are now taking dally spins. According to statements of the Captains of clubs, the number of entries for the Harlem Regatta will exceed that of last year.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Jacob S. Coxey, commander of the "Commonweal of Christ"; Carl Browne, its Chief Marshal, and Christopher Columbus Jones, leader of the Philadelphia contingent of the Army of Peace, were tried in the City Police Court to-day on the charge of violating the United States statutes in unlawfully displaying a banner or device in the Capitol grounds and in breaking shrubs and plants there.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 4 -- All sorts of rumors are afloat as to the intentions of the Mexican Government in connection with the question of the depreciation of silver. One thing is certain, the next coupons for the interest on the foreign debt will be duly met in full. In fact, the money is all ready for the purpose.

Contrary to general expectation the Giants won a game yesterday. But they did not have a soft snap by any means. On the contrary, the victory was secured after a nip-and-tuck contest in which both teams played good ball. Both Judge Cullom and Director Wheeler were absent, and the cranks want to know which is the Jonah.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 4 -- Ida Laws, fourteen years old, whose father, Charles M. Laws, has for many years kept a restaurant on Newark Avenue, opposite the Hudson County Court House, was waylaid this afternoon while passing through the Marion district, near where Miss May Barrowcliff was beaten into unconsciousness on the night of Dec. 29, 1893.

The Massachusetts Industrial Delegation, as the band of sixty men which reached New-York Thursday from Boston, styles itself, passed a quiet day yesterday, resting for the march toward Washington, which will be resumed this morning. They took breakfast at the headquarters of the People's Party, 50 East Tenth Street.

From Dow-Jones's Wall Street Journal. Mr. Nathan Bijur, counsel of the Hartshorne committee and for Mr. Rice, who has just returned from Philadelphia, has this to say regarding the question of foreclosure of Reading:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 4 -- For over a month the Yale class crews have been practicing for the annual Spring regatta, which will take place at Lake Whitney to-morrow. There has been an unusual abundance of material in the candidates for the class boats this year, and some low time is expected to be made in the contests to-morrow.
HOMESTEAD, Penn., May 4 -- Col. Thomas Galvin's division of the Commonweal Army is now here, and the prospects are that it will remain until Monday morning.

The receiver of the Commercial Bank claims that there is enough money available to pay in full the amounts due the depositors of that institution. The Directors who were indicted on Thursday -- Seth L. Keeney, Robinson Gill, and Elbert Snedeker -- assert that they were not permitted to go before the Grand Jury and state their side of the case.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., May 4 -- The Spring tournament of the Peeksklll Gun Club, which has been held the present week on its inclosed grounds on Union Avenue, this city, ended yesterday after three days of glorious weather, excellent scores, and large money receipts. On Tuesday 3,200 clay birds were liberated from the traps, and on Wednesday 4,100 more.
ALBANY, May 4 -- Gov. Flower in giving his reasons for vetoing the bill giving Mayors of New-York City power to remove heads of departments says:

The defeat of the malcontents in Samoa by the Government forces is now followed by news of greater quiet. But there is something lacking in the governmental system founded by the combined efforts of the diplomats of three great nations, and sustained, when required, by their war ships.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 4 -- Five students in St. Paul's School here have been sent to their homes for breaking an ironclad rule of the institution. They left their apartments after hours and repaired to a neighboring village, where they played pool for the remainder of the night. They returned to the school about the time the students are expected to arise in the morning.

Gen. Henry W. Slocum, had he lived, would have lectured to the public-school children of Brooklyn in All Souls' Church, South Ninth Street and Bedford Avenue, yesterday, on "The March to the Sea." His sudden and untimely death made a blank in the series of addresses on the civil war by the great Generals who took part in the struggle.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Mr. McPherson, from the Committee on Naval Affairs, to-day made a favorable report to the Senate on an amendment to the Neval Appropriation bill, authorizing the President to have constructed by contract twelve torpedo boats, at a cost, exclusive of premiums, of not more than $2,400,000.

In one respect the pending annual supply bill for the navy is more remarkable for what it does not than for what it does contain. It not only makes no provision for a new battle ship, but it does not furnish a single dollar of appropriation for any new construction of vessels whatever.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The final meeting of the board appointed by Secretary Herbert to investigate the allegations of fraud made by John McLuckie, ex-Burgess of Homestead, Penn., and a number of others who have worked in the Carnegie Steel Works, with reference to steel armor plates manufactured for the navy, was held at the Navy Department to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 4 -- Joseph E. Bishop, a well-to-do farmer in North Haven, was awakened this morning shortly after 4 o'clock by a man who refused to give his name, but is believed to be a deserter from Capt. Sweetland's contingent. The tramp demanded breakfast, and not having this granted, threw heavy stones through the windows, breaking valuable furniture.

Shortly after the Northern Pacific property was placed under the protection of the court last Summer, "The Financial World" article in The Times of Sunday, Sept. 24, was largely devoted to showing what a complete financial wreck the company had become. In the demonstration only the Northern Pacific proper, its earnings and fixed charges, were taken into consideration.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 4 -- An immense woodland fire is burning along the post road between Wakefield and Westerly, in Washington County, and the most valuable timber in Charlestown has been destroyed. The fire started in the woods owned by Wanton Carpenter, near Matunick, and swept the broad woods due west to the farm of Senator Joseph Church.

Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court has granted leave to the Attorney General of New-York State to bring suit for the dissolution of the Central Stamping Company. The suit is to be brought on the ground that the company is an illegal trust or monopoly.

The farm show at the Madison Square Garden will close its gates for the last time to-night, and the husbandmen and handmaidens there will be distributed over the outlying rural districts from which they came. Probably they will less regret the change to normal conditions than will the many friends they have made in their visit to town.

The ninth number for this year of the Summary Statement of Imports and Exports has just been issued by the Bureau of Statistics. It contains comparative tables for the month of March and for the nine months ending March 31, corrected to April 26. Thanks to the intelligence and skill with which the statistics are arranged and presented under the present Chief of the bureau, these summaries are extremely interesting and instructive.

Fifty disappointed relatives of Mrs. Cornelia F. Coster have been cited to appear June 28 at the Surrogate's office and show cause why her will should not be admitted to probate. The will has not yet been offered. Citations were issued on application of Frederick N. Seymour, who alleges in his affidavit that in it he is named as executor and residuary legatee.

ALBANY, May 4 -- Ex-Lieut. Gov. Thomas Gold Alvord ("Old Salt") of Syracuse, who began his public career as a member of Assembly fifty years ago last Winter, when William C. Bouck was Governor, came to Albany to-day and at once acknowledged it to be true that his friends had put him in nomination for the Presidency of the Constitutional Convention.

Some significance attaches to the sale made yesterday by Mr. Dwigat H. Olmstead of six lots at the northwest corner of Morningside Avenue and One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, 150 by 100.11. A large hotel is to be built on the site, which is near the new Columbia College grounds, the remainder of the block on One Hundred and Seventeenth Street is owned by Mr. Olmstead.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 4 -- The sixth annual May music festival of the Hampden County Musical Society, held in Springfield, came to a brilliant end this evening with a fine performance of "The Messiah," under the direction of Mr. Chadwick. The chorus numbered about 250 voices, and the soloists were: Soprano, Miss Antoinetti Trebelli; contralto, Mrs. Carl Alves; tenor, Dr. Mandeville, and basso, Max Heinrich.

NEWARK, N.J., May 4 -- Newark's great aquatic event, the Memorial Day regatta, under the direction of the Passaic River Amateur Rowing Association, is only a month away. That this year's regatta will be a great one is almost an assured fact, for, in spite of the opposition of the Harlem River Association, which holds its regatta that day, Newark will get many outside entries.

Gov. Flower seems to have considered himself called upon to explain his approval of the bill putting the Sheriff of this county on a salary and requiring him to turn over all the fees to the City Treasury. His explanation has the tone of an apology and the substance of an excuse for the opposition that was made to the measure.
There are fewer saloons in New-York now than there were one year ago, notwithstanding the growth of the population of the city within that period.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Secretary Herbert to-day appointed a board to consist of Chief Engineers J.W. Thompson, C.A. Roelker, J.A. Smith, and a number of junior engineers to conduct the dock trial of the machinery of the battleship Texas next Wednesday, at the Norfolk Navy Yard. The misfortunes of the Texas since her construction was begun and the criticisms recently made concerning her machinery make this trial particularly interesting.

There is one aspect of the question raised by Coxey that has not been sufficiently considered. It is natural that it should not have been considered. It may be even a little temerarious to bring it into the public view; but nevertheless it is worthy of consideration. All the protests against the Coxeyites have been from the side of law and order and established institutions.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 4 -- Twenty Conservative members of Parliament waited on Sir John Thompson to-night and pressed upon him to place an export duty on logs shipped from Canada to the United States. They told the Premier that over 500,000,000 feet had been sent to the United States from Canada during the past year.

The members of the Young Men's Association of the Society for Ethical Culture listened to three addresses on the subject of good municipal government, in a hall at 144 East Eighty-sixth Street, last evening. The speakers were Prof. Felix Adler, who presided, W. Harris Roome of the City Reform Club, and John Brooks Leavitt.

The New-Jersey Yacht Club house, at the foot of Tenth Street, Hoboken, is in commission, and several of the yachts will be ready in a few days. Commodore F.S. Ketcham's sloop Charm will be ready by Decoration Day. She has been thoroughly overhauled and a new suit of sails has been made for her.

Justice Patterson of the Supreme Court yesterday overruled the demurrers interposed by the Directors of the Madison Square Bank, impleaded with Frederick A. Kursheedt in the suit brought against them by the receivers of the bank to recover $750,000 for their alleged negligence in conducting the affairs of the bank.

GRATZ, May 4 -- The efforts which have been made to rescue the tourists who have been imprisoned in a cave near Souriach for the last six days have thus far been unsuccessful. Three divers from Trieste endeavored to penetrate the mouth of the cave, but were unable to do so, the aperture being choked with beams, huge stones,

-- The Catholic Club of New-York and the United States Catholic Historical Society have united in the preparation of the "Columbus Memorial Volume," just published by Benziger Brothers. The text is instructive, enthusiastic, and well worthy of the beautiful form in which it is presented. The paper is white and of good quality.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- There has been no question before the House at this session in which members have evinced the same personal interest that they are now showing in the enforcement of the old law which requires that Representatives Shall lose their pay for every day they are absent except in case of sickness.

Jared Flagg, Jr., a real estate dealer of 242 West Twenty-third Street, who is agent for over 400 furnished flats on the west side, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday charged by Capt. Donohue of the West Twentieth Street Station with renting flats to undesirable tenants. After hearing the testimony Police Justice McMahon ordered a complaint taken.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The sub-committee of the House Committee on the Judiciary which was appointed to investigate the circumstances attending the issue of an injunction enjoining the Northern Pacific employes from striking and to inquire as to whether Judge Jenkins, who issued the injunction, had extended his judicial power and used his office to intimidate the employes of the railroad company, made its report to the full committee to-day.

Another chapter in the trials of Carl Muller, the informer against Dr. Henry Meyer, in the celebrated poisoning case, came to light yesterday in the shape of a letter written by Muller from the House of Detention. The letter was dated Feb. 25, 1894, and was addressed to Lewis S. Chanler, who is associated with Mr. Brooke and Dr. O'Sullivan in the defense of Meyer.

Justice Gaynor in the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday decided that Health Commissioner Emery was overstepping his authority when he quarantined houses because the inmates refused to be vaccinated.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- Fred Hoey, the crack pigeon shot of the Westminster Kennel Club, again showed his superiority at the traps to-day in winning the Riverton Challenge Plate at the shooting match at the grounds of the Riverton Gun Club, Riverton, N.J.
Hardman Hall was filled to its utmost capacity with a fashionable audience last evening during the amateur concert and dramatic entertainment given for the benefit of the Baby Fresh-Air Fund.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., May 4 -- The fourth day of the season for rifle practice at Creedmoor, L.I., was opened this morning by the Sixty-ninth Batalllon, under the command of Major Edward Duffy, with Lieut. Patrick Farrelly Acting Inspector of Rifle Practice, under the supervision of Brig. Gen. B.M. Whitlock. The weather was very chilly, especially in the afternoon, the sun being obscured by heavy clouds all day.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Secretary Herbert has perfected the plan of reorganization of the navy outlined in these dispatches a week ago. Its details will be of great interest to the officers, who hope for some cure for stagnation. There are some novelties in the plan not found in others that have been presented. With the suggestions heretofore offered to the Joint Committee on Organization it will be considered carefully.

Mrs. Charles A. Schieren, wife of the reform Mayor of Brooklyn, has signed the petition asking the Constitutional Convention to strike out the word "male" from the State Constitution. The woman suffragists of Brooklyn are happy in consequence. In fact, they are jubilant, for they are almost sure that wifely influence will not be tediously taxed before the name of the chief Executive of the City of Churches is affixed to their fervent prayer.

Philadelphia coaching men will, no doubt, "pause and consider," in future, before wagering against what the crack whips of the New-York four-in-hand brigade can or cannot do. Members of the coaching fraternity, like ail other sporting mortals, are prone to add to the excitement of their particular sport by making little bets, from hats to checks on their bank accounts.
ALBANY, May 4 -- Gov. Flower vetoed tolay the bill which proposed that Mayors of New-York should have power to remove from office heads of city departments, filing a long statement with the veto.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 4 -- Mary E. Axtell of this city, formerly of New-York, has brought a suit against Thomas Axtell of this city and Waterbury for divorce. The grounds given are desertion and intolerable cruelty, and the plaintiff asks that alimony to the amount of $25,000 be given her. The defendant is a leading Waterbury physician enjoying a practice of over $10,000 a year.

SEDALIA, Mo., May 4 -- The First National Bank of this city, one of the oldest financial institutions in Central Missouri, failed to open its doors for business to-day. A notice signed by the officers and Directors was posted on the doors notifying depositors of the suspension. The bank has a capital of $250,000, and was supposed to have a reserve fund of $25,000.
Arbor Day was celebrated in the schools all over tine State yesterday toy appropriate exercises in the schoolrooms and by tree planting where it was possible.

WASHINGTON, D.C., May 4 -- Richard Croker is still in this city as the guest of Senator Murphy. He is spending much of his time riding in the suburbs behind Mr. Murphy's handsome team, and is enjoying the Spring attractions of the capital.
Judge McAdam made some interesting remarks about uncles, aunts, owls, and cats at a hearing before him in the Special Term of the Superior Court yesterday concerning the play " Charley's Uncle."

Some ill-feeling was caused yesterday between the District Attorney's office and the Court of General Sessions on one side and the Department of Charities and Correction on the other because the Charity Commissioners discharged Thomas O'Garry, who drove one of the city hearses. O'Garry testified in the recent murder trial of David Hampton.

The news that Gov. Flower had signed the Sheriff Office bill and the Dock Department bill was received by the city officials yesterday with some surprise. The first bill cuts off the Sheriff's fees and fixes his salary at $20,000; the second compels the Dock Commissioners to contract by public letting for all work involving an expenditure of $500 or more.

"He doth protest too much," was one of the comments made yesterday on the refusal of Thomas C. Platt to help along the confirmation of Dr. W.T. Jenkins as Health Commissioner, when John W. Goff asked the Tioga statesman to do so during the last days of the Legislature.

-- Macmillan Co. issue the first volume of Walter W. Skeat's edition of "The Com- plete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer." It con- tains a biography, with references to authorities for the incidents that it records, the "Romaunt of the Rose," the minor poems, a special introduction, and illustra- tive notes.

-- Mr. and Mrs. E.R. Leland's Celebrations -- Mr. and Mrs. E.R. Leland received the congratulations of many friends at their temporary apartments at the Grand Hotel on Thursday evening. The occasion was the tenth anniversary of their marriage. The day was also Mrs. Leland's birthday, and, in addition, was celebrated as a day of rejoicing over the recovery of Mr. Leland from a very critical illness.

The tone of yesterday's stock market refected a decided improvement in confidence in the future. The action of the Democratic Senators in agreeing to hasten the passage of the Tariff bill was largely responsible for the improved feeling. The effect was particularly noticeable in the industrial group, especially in Sugar and Lead. Distilling and Cattle Feeding was only fairly steady, but the others advanced sharply.
The Wilson Line steamship Persian Monarch, which was stranded near Eastport, L.I., Wednesday night, was floated last sight at 7 o'clock.

Ex-President Benjamin Harrison, carrying strapped together a cane and an umbrella, both with silver ornaments, walked into the corridor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel a little before 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Farson, Leach Co., who purchased the entire issue of Corlears Hook Park bonds, amounting to $1,307,431, have paid the money to the City Chamberlain. As soon as the Controller was notified of the payment he made out a warrant for the amount due Henry Keteltas, as agent of the Gardner estate, who has been making all the fuss in the courts about the delay of the city in paying the awards.

Bradstreet's will say to-day: The movement of general merchandise throughout the country is smaller in volume. Spring trade is finished, and orders for Fall delivery are, with few exceptions, not meeting expectations. Jobbers in leading lines at almost all larger cities report sales, almost without exception, as of a hand-to-mouth description.

United States Marshal Henry I. Hayden of Brooklyn went about yesterday with an air of abstraction. The prospect of being sued by the city for the amount of William D. Lohman's defalcation -- $19,400 -- troubled him.

The fifth annual Spring field meeting of the New-York University Athletic Association was held at the Berkeley Oval, Morris Heights, yesterday. The attendance was unusually large, and the clubhouse was fairly overrun with college men. Though most of the events were hotly contested, no phenomenal time was made.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., May 4 -- The Cambria Iron Company officials here are rather jubilant over what they consider is practically the ending of the present strike. Today there were over 150 men employed in the company's mill mine, a much larger number than at any time since the trouble began. This, too, in the face of the fact that a local assembly of the United Mine Workers had been formed this-week, with nearly 300 members.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Senate is talking finely, but it is not doing anything, nor is it manifesting a purpose to get out of its habit of dallying with the Tariff bill.

Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. yesterday. Time money was quiet and unchanged. Offerings were liberal, but the demand did not increase. Rates were 2 per cent, for thirty to sixty days. 2 1/2 per cent. for ninety days to four months, and 3 per cent. for six months.

The complicated case mentioned in The New-York Times yesterday in which William Williams of 259 Union Street, Brooklyn; William Williams of 100 Court Street, Brooklyn; Edwin S. Stafford of 24 West Ninth Street, George C. Courtright of Philadelphia, 2,000 acres of land, a team of white Arabian horses, and a medicine wagon figure, came up in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.
At auction, in Brooklyn, yesterday, Mr. Jacob Cole sold to Sarah Mead, at $2,650, the two-story frame dwelling 21 1/2 Stockton Street, north side, 198 feet east of Nostrand Avenue, 17 by 87.9.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 4 -- In anticipation of Col. Breckinridge's campaign for renomination for Congress, this city is rapidly filling up with politicians and newspaper correspondents. The excitement is intense, and there are already signs of serious trouble among the factions. It was rumored to-day that Senator Hodges, editor of The Observer, had threatened to hold Editor Moore responsible for any attack his paper contained on Hodges's defense of Breckinridge.

Dr. Mott began the gigantic task of compiling and editing this work two years ago, and the result of his labors will be highly appreciated by yachtsmen and by all who take an interest in the sport. It is an encyclopedia of matters pertaining to yachting and is a record of all yachting events that have ever taken place in these waters.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Secretary Herbert to-day settled the Brooklyn dry dock matter by agreeing to let the present contractor, John Gillis, continue the work under certain conditions. It was reported to the Secretary that Gillis had failed to perform the work with sufficient rapidity, and that it was doubtful whether he could carry out the contract within the specified period, if at all.

Horse owners who took the preliminary steps to call into being the Jockey Club, even if it has not been just the club they expected it would be, have been complaining ever since the publication of the first Racing Calendar about the cost of the thing. This seems to the outsider rather strange.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., May 4 -- A riot occurred at the Painter Works of the McClure Coke Company, two miles from this place, at 5 o'clock this morning, in which three strikers were wounded by rifle shots. Sanford White, Assistant Superintendent of the works, was so severely beaten that he may die. E.B. Roddy, bookkeeper for the company, was slightly hurt.

One of the most important patent suits ever tried in this country is now before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in this city, where Judges Wallace, presiding, and Lacombe and Shipman, associates, are in session. The litigation concerns the validity of the patent rights of nearly all the air brakes in use on the railroads of the United States, and involves several millions of dollars.

To have made 100 round trips across the Atlantic is a triumph that comes to few mariners. That, however, is the record that was yesterday established by Capt. A. Barends, when he brought his fine command, the "express" steamship Normannia, into this port. Another fact of which Capt. Barends is proud is that all the hundred round trips across the Atlantic were made without accident.

Robert Fereuson, the well-known ex-baseball player, died at his home, 691 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, on Thursday night of apoplexy. He was about fifty years old. In the sixties he was a member of the famous Atlantic Club of Brooklyn, and was also at one time on the old Mutual Club, which used to play on the old Union grounds in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- On motion of Mr. Catchings (Dem., Miss.,) the House to-day went into Committee of the Whole for the further consideration of the River and Harbor Appropriation bill. Amendments were adopted as follows:

The attendance at the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club's horse show last night showed a large increase over that of the preceding night, but there were still plenty of vacant seats in the house, in spite of the fact that every seat had been sold a week in advance.

There are no more one-dollar Columbian stamps that the insatiable philatelists may obtain without paying a premium. The philatelists are not glad. This is not extraordinary, but they have a grievance, and a philatelist with a grievance is interesting.

MONTREAL, May 5 -- The roams of the Cosmopolitan Club, fn which w. Steinitz and E. Lasker are playing the championship chess match for $2,000 a side, were uncomfortably crowded this afternoon, when the latter opened the thirteenth game. Lasker selected the Spanish attack for his leading motive, so to speak.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 -- The steamer Australia arrived at 8 o'clock this morning from Honolulu, bringing advices to the 28th ult. All is quiet Admiral Irwin, who was relieved by Admiral Walker, and Paul Newmann were passengers on the Australia.

Annexation is the order of the day. Incorporation of the county towns with Brooklyn has given an impulse to the discussion of the "Greater New-York." Revival of too consolidation question is not attributable to the Consolidation League. That body appears to have been stricken with something nearly resembling paralysis.

Senator Alien of Nebraska, who holds a chronic brief in the Senate for tramps and lawbreakers and lunatics in general, has appeared in, a police court for Coxey in particular. He appeared, as he took pains to say, without any special retainer, but only in the capacity of what may be called an inimicus curiae, a general friend of lawlessness and disorder.

The announcement that Buffalo Bill's Wild West and Congress of Rough Riders of the World will begin its long Summer season at Thirty-ninth Street, South Brooklyn, next Saturday, May 12. at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, will be welcome news to lovers of outdoor amusements, whose expectations have been aroused by the reports of the magnitude of this always popular entertainment.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Board of Ordnance and Fortification has just closed another interesting session, at the War Department. The meeting was the first which has been held since the death of Major Clifton Comly of Governors Island, and appropriate action was taken by his former associates of the board, in which Major Comly did much valuable work.

CHATTER VIII -- IN THE PINE WOOD. Brandon Mountford had tallied of leaving Ellerslie several times before his final resolution to fly from danger; but on each occasion Sir Joseph had urged him to remain.

Now that the twenty-one-foot class is an assured thing here, there Is promise of lots of good sport on the Sound, and especially at Larchmont. At least eight of these small boats will be built and raced, and there is a likelihood of several more being built by the time the first race is called.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 5 -- The Juniors won the class championship of Tale this afternoon in the Spring regatta. The freshmen beat the sophomores by a length in 7:13. The Varsity crew beat the juniors by two and a half lengths in 7:17, and the juniors beat the freshmen by a length in 7:08. Capt. Simpson, stroke of the freshmen, broke his oar.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Showman Coxey took out his third day's license for the exhibition of his Commonweal Army to-day. He seems to find the present location sufficiently convenient to induce him to continue at the same spot. He is preparing to remove some of the objections which would bring down upon, him the strong hand of the sanitary authorities within forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- This has been a busy day for the Senate tariff fixers. With, the appointed time for reporting the proposed amendments only forty-eight hours away, and many paragraphs remaining unrevised, Mr. Jones and his associates went to work early this morning, determined to bring their task to an end to-night if possible.

HARTFORD, May 5 -- The oldest railroad man in New-England, Samuel Nott of this city, who began his career on the Boston and Worcester in 1833, win observe his eightieth birthday the last of this month. The event will be of considerable interest in railroad circles. At the time Mr. Nott began his life work there were less than fifty miles of railroad constructed in the United States.

The latest from M. de Morgan's excavations at Dashur near Cairo is a find of the mummy of a King of the Twelfth Dynasty unknown to Egyptologists. He was named Horus, from the great god of that name, and likewise Rafouab. In the same tomb was found an ebony figure, about 4 feet high, and, what is more important, a number of rolls of papyrus.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Secretary of War has detailed for the command of the New-York Arsenal Major Frank H. Phipps of the Ordnance Department, one of the best-known officers of the army. He has been on duty as an ordnance officer of the Department of the Missouri, under Gen. Miles. He will report at Governors Island as soon as he returns from, his leave of absence.

ALBANY, May 5 -- Speaker Malby, who is Ill at the Delavan House, has not yet signed the Huckleberry Railway bill. He obtained a decision from the Attorney General today on the question whether he should do so or not, in view of the irregularities involved in its passage in both houses of the Legislature.
Mrs. Charles A. Schieren, wife of the Mayor of Brooklyn, has signed the petition which asks that the word "male" be stricken from the State Convention.
POUGHKEEPSIE, May 5. -- Aquiline Filler shot himself to-day by his sweetheart's grave, which laborers connected with the German Catholic Cemetery were filling up, and around which mourners lingered.
MONROEVILLE, Ala., May 5 -- A posse of citizens in pursuit of Wyatt Tate, a negro desperado who recently murdered Sheriff Foster and Deputy Iknon, surrounded him in a swamp early this morning.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., May 5 -- Chris Schmidt, a longshoreman, caught three black sea bass recently, weighing 221, 337, and 376 pounds, respectively. After hooking his game, he tied the end of the line to a powder keg, and let the big fish run around in the bay until exhausted, when he pulled it in and killed it.
The question has often been asked. "What characteristics must a sail possess to set well?" and " How can you tell a good-setting sail? "

Until the last half hour of business yesterday the stock market was exceedingly dull and uninteresting. There had been a fair amount of trading in the industrials at about Friday's level of prices, but the stocks showed little disposition to advance. The room traders thereupon came to the conclusion that an effort was being made to realize by the insiders, and in a short time they were free sellers of the specialties.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A new system of illumination in lighthouses is on trial in Boston Harbor. When Capt. F. A. Mahan of the army engineers was on duty with the Lighthouse Board, he devised a method of distinctive lights for lighthouses along the coast, so that each station would be immediately recognizable.

LONDON, May 5 -- The reduction of the Government's majority in the House of Commons on nearly every important division must be accepted from any but the most extreme partisan point of view as an omen of an early dissolution, and few persons are to be found who regard the situation in any other light.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 5 -- "Henry VIII." is the title of the play which will be given by the two junior societies of Yale this year. It is a burlesque in two acts on Henry Irving's version of the play, and was prepared for presentation at Yale by Edward Boltwood, '92; Ralph D. Paine, '94, and F.C. Perkins, 94, who arranged last year's play by the same societies.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 5 -- Latest advices from Blueflelds are to the effect that, in answer to the demand of British Minister Goslin, Nicaragua has canceled her withdrawal of British Consul Bingham's exequatur. Bingham refused to receive the exequatur unless accompanied by ample apology on the part of Nicaragua, and coming to him through the hands of Minister Goslin.
The Catholic Summer School of America will hold its third session at Pittsburg, N. Y., from July 14 to Aug. 12. 1894.
LONDON, May 5 -- Lord Rosebery's Ladas continues the favorite in the betting on the Derby, but there has been a grave set-back in pools on that nobleman himself being in office on Derby Day.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Lighthouse Board hopes to secure some appropriations this year for public works under its charge which are greatly needed in the interest of commerce. Estimates for works in the vicinity of New-York aggregate nearly $100,000. The largest item is $75,000 for continuing the construction of the sea wall, rebuilding the soutih wharf, and dredging the basin at the gemeral lighthouse station at Tompkinsville, S.I.

The steamship Persian Monarch, which was floated Friday evening off the bar where she had stranded, was brought to the city in tow of three tugs yesterday. The vessel reached her Brooklyn pier shortly before 6 P.M. As soon as her cargo is discharged the ship will be placed in dry dock and an examination of her injuries made.

The disdain of the Romans for the Jewish Sabbath, because it was not accompanied by any tumult or noisy and joyful demonstrations, perpetuated itself throughout all ages. Rutelius, who was the Prefect of Rome under Honorium, says, in speaking of the Jews: "They are very much attached to the cold Sabbath, but their heart is colder than their religion.

NEWPORT, R. I., May 5 -- Many cottagers have arrived during the week for the season. Among them are George L. Rives. Mrs. Andrew C. Zabriskie, Henry A. Rice, Mrs. David King, Samuel Coleman, L. Q. Jones, Mrs. M.L.R. Goodridge, Thomas F. Cushing, Miss Cushing, Josiah O. Low. William G. Weld, and Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Wysong.

ALBANY, May 5 -- The story that appeared in a sensational Albany paper this morning in relation to the orgies of certain Republican legislators has created somewhat of a sensation, primarily for the false and disgusting details given in the story, and, secondly, because so eminent and devoted a churchman as Gov. Flower is reported to be financially interested in the paper and to pass judgment upon the editorials before they are put in type.

The old Coney Island is a thing of the past. Beginning with to-day, the resort will feel the wave of reform as never before. Orders have been issued by the Brooklyn authorities to enforce the laws as efficiently as they are enforced in the city, inspector William J. McKelvey will assume command of the police force at noon.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5 -- The second of the games for the Intercollegiate championship was decided here to-day. Princeton defeating Harvard 12 to 5. Though the playing on both sides was loose at times, the game was intensely interesting: and exciting throughout, the phenomenal fielding of Brooks and Gunster for Prtnceton and Whitmore for Harvard being the features.

MALDEN, Mass., May 5 -- The third annual Linscott road race was held here this afternoon, and was one of the largest attended and the most succesful of any that has been held. There were 164 men entered for the race, among whom were a large number of prominent bicycle riders throughout New-England and the West.

The Seventy-first Regiment had a field day at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. About 1,000 persons from the city accompanied the regiment to the park, and there were many spectators from the neighborhood.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 5 -- The formal announcement of the engagement of Miss Hope Goddard, heiress to the Goddard millions, and C.O. Iselin, the New-York millionaire and well-known yachting man, was made this afternoon. Mr. Iselin was a guest at Col. William Goddard's home week before last.

The Memorial and Executive Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic in Brooklyn yesterday decided upon the programme for the Memorial Day celebration in that city. There will be memorial services in all the cemeteries Where soldiers are buried, including Greenwood, Holy Cross, the Evergreens, and Lutheran.

Lord Rosebery is reaping the natural reward of the policy which he has been pursuing since, for no reason that is publicly apparent, he was chosen, to succeed Mr. Gladstone as the leader of the Liberal Party. Within a week after he was so chosen he gave away the whole Liberal case on home rule, although he had declared that he would make no change in, the party programme.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: For nearly fifty years past most of my waking hours have been spent within the bounds at the Presbytery of New-York, where I have many personal friends, and which body I represented in General Assembly nearly thirty years since. Take the Presbytery for all in all, there is perhaps no finer array of talent in the world in a Church court of its size.

Activity in the trial of Dr. Henry Meyer was transferred yesterday from Recorder Smyth's courtroom to the Tombs. In the corridor of the gloomy old prison Dr. Meyer held a long consultation with Dr. O'Sullivan of his counsel, availing himself of the lull in the court proceedings caused by the half holiday to go over the evidence put in by the prosecution.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 5 -- Col. W.C.P. Breckinridge spoke in the Opera House this afternoon to advocate his re-election to the House of Representatives. The auditorium was crowded to the doors by friends and opponents.

PARIS, April 16 -- You must all remember the triumphant success of M. Henri Lavedan's "Prince d'Aurec" at the Vaudeville Theatre two years ago. It pictured in strong, emphatic color the subjection of royalty to the modern money kings -- the Jews. In "Deux Noblesses," given at the Odeon last night, M. Lavedan brings to life again the wife, the son, and the grandson of the Prince.

The dream of the dying Hanneie, which has lately absorbed some of the attention of a part of the theatregoing public, very accurately illustrates a recognizable phase of human character. The child's visions of glory only dimly comprehend a future existence. Her view of Heaven itself is gorgeous but extremely vague.

William H. Webb's aim to be the foremost shipbuilder in the world was attained more than a quarter of a century ago. Yesterday another ruling desire, to care for a past generation of shipbuilders and to educate young men in the construction of nineteenth-century craft, was gratified in the dedication of Webb's Academy and Home for Shipbuilders, at Fordham Heights.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 5 -- Cornell won a game of baseball from the University of Pennsylvania, to-day by a score of 13 to 10. It was one of the most exciting games ever played on Percy Field. Everything seemed to be in favor of Cornell until the beginning of the sixth inning. By a fortunate bunching of hits in this inning the Pennsylvania men secured 8 runs.

Interest in the organization of the new Democratic General Committee of Kings County is growing. A very large attendance is promised for the first meeting of the body at the Criterion Theatre next Friday night. Every ward will be represented by active men. They will come together with a firm resolution to revive the party and build it up along real reform lines.
John Jay died yesterday at 12:45 o'clock, at the Hotel Savoy. He had been an invalid for a long time, and during the last two or three weeks had been sinking rapidly.

The Electrical Engineer of May 2 prints an exceedingly interesting article, prepared by Edwin J. Houston and A.E. Kennelly, entitled "An Estimate of the Distance to Which Niagara Water Power Can Be Economically Transmitted by Electricity." The Engineer says, editorially:

After being warmed by the Washingtons, thrashed by the Philadelphias, and whipped by the Baltimores, it was with fear and trembling that the Giants faced the Bostons on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. About 15,000 persons paid admission to see the contest, and it is safe to predict that the majority looked for another defeat.

A story to the effect that Archibald Clavering Gunter, the playwright and author, had been blackballed by the Authors' Club was published yesterday in an afternoon newspaper. A non-committal interview with Mr. Gunter lent an air of contemporaneous interest to the narrative.

"How very pretty! I never saw anything like it. Just like your good taste," exclaimed a young woman in evening dress, as she entered the dining room of her married friend. The young housewife naturally was a little nervous in this her first season as a married woman, and had smuggled her best friend into the dining room half an hour before dinner to judge of the looks of her table.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- One of the worn-out, but still used, campaign complaints of the money-hunting pension agent, adopted for platform use by bombastic Republican orators, is that of charging the Democrats when in power with penuriousness in the allowance of pensions upon applications made in the regular way.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With interest I have read what the newspapers (World, Sun, Times.) had to say to-day about the opera question in New-York. I could not get The Herald and Tribune, and the Staats-Zeitung made no reference to the matter. It seems necessary that I should offer a few remarks in order to make plain the point of view which I occupy in the matter.

LENOX, Mass., May 5 -- The new country houses of Anson Phelps Stokes, John Sloane, and H.H. Cooke are to be lighted with gas, and machines of 300 light capacity have been placed in them this week. Work is progressing rapidly on these places, and the owners hope to occupy them in June or July.

We here may read, in Mr. Davis's story called "His Bad Angel," what was said about Thorold. "They" said it was such pity so nice a young man had allowed himself to be spoiled, "and the crities and paragrapbers, who had stumbled over one another in their haste" to recognize a new and an able hand at the beginning, became very fault finding after a while and wrote.

Richard Bulkley, M.D., or, as he was generally known in his native town of Pergamos, "young Mr. Dick," was a skillful and successful physician, well liked and respected by his fellow-citizens, with one exception; but oh, what a mighty test of the rule that exception was!

CHICAGO, May 5 -- The wheat market had lost all the enthusiasm that was so noticeable yesterday by the opening this morning. Expectations regarding the clearances from both coasts as reported by Bradstreet's were far from being realized. Over 3,000,000 bushels was the minimum figure looked for, whereas the report only gave 2,775,000 bushels, which was but a trifle more than the shipments of the previous week.

Property owners and residents of the north side have been a good deal perturbed of late by the many conflicting rumors of proposed street-car extensions in that section of the city. All sorts of reports have been circulated during the past few weeks. One was that the overhead trolley lines were to be placed in an indefinite number of streets to connect with those already built.

Woman suffrage in school elections has been tried in the Third School District of Flatbush. known as Windsor Terrace. With the recent incorporation of the town of Flatbush with the City of Brooklyn the control of the local Boards of School Trustees passed away, and with them woman suffrage, as there will be no more voting for school officers.
BOSTON, May 5 -- Writing from Glasgow of Lord Dunraven's experiment with the Dragon, a yachting correspondent says:

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The trial of Coxey, Browne, and Jones, the leaders of the Commonweal Army, upon charges of trespassing upon the Capitol grounds and displaying a banner there was resumed before Judge Miller, in the police court, this morning.

It is to be hoped that the procedures of the "armies" will open the eyes of many worthy people to the true inwardness of a number of recent events. When a large body of unemployed persons undertake to make their way from the extreme West to Washington in search of employment, thing's seem, to be greatly unsettled and even reversed.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 5 -- Gov. Rich this afternoon appointed John Patton, Jr., of this city, United States Senator, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of F. B. Stockbridge. He will serve until January next, when the Legislature will elect.
II Next to the war, the chief topic of interest and conversation in Octavius at this time was easily Miss Julia Parmalee.

The best thing that could have happened in the interest of the plans to give a season of grand opera in German next Winter was the withdrawal of one of the projectors from the field. That two projects could have lived is quite impossible. That either of them would ever have lived to see the light is highly improbable.

BERLIN, May 5 -- The political lull which followed the adjournment of the Reichstag is ceased. The Provincial Parliaments of the Federal States have shown sudden activity since national affairs have dropped into the background, and long reports of new combinations and measures are telegraphed daily from the smaller capitals.

The death is announced at Lindhelm, in the Duchy of Hesse, of Leopold Sacher-Masoch, whose avowed sympathy for Pan-Slavism was profound. He was born at Lemberg, Jan. 27, 1835. He studied law in the Universities of Prague and Gratz, and went to Paris after fighting a duel with an Australn officer whom he had insulted because the officer vociferously applauded In a street of Salzburg the news of the Sedan victory.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Representative Reilly, the Chairman of the House Pacific Railroad Committee, believes that some measure looking to the settlement of the indebtedness of the Pacific railroads to the Government will be laid before Congress early in June. A sub-committee, consisting of Mr. Reilly and four members of the committee, now have the matter in hand.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $8,860,103, of which amount $1,589,677 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $602,781, and the exports of specie were $6,043,316.

Referee F.X. Donoghue has sold the three parcels of land which were in litigation between Louise Livingston Hunt, as trustee, against Ada. C. Hoppock und others, for $14,500. It was bought by John W. Alexander, counsel for the plaintiff, who was the only bidder. This property is a part of the Bechstein land, and is situated in Hawthorne Avenue and Valentine Lane.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 5 -- The invitation handicap meeting of the Harvard Athletic Association was held this afternoon on Holmes Field. The track was in fine condition, but no good times were made except by Garcelon in the low hurdles. Over 300 athletes were entered in the competition.

The higher education of woman has not robbed her of her fondness for feminine fripperies and furbelows. She is as interested to-day in the gown in which she will take her degree as she was twenty-five years ago, when at least one wise old professor felt called upon to write a book declaiming vigorously against a college education for girls.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 5 -- The Supreme Court of Kansas to-day decided a railroad case that has attracted widespread interest. The suit was instituted by the people of Ford County for the purpose of preventing, if possible, the present owners of the socalled Montezuma Railroad from tearing up the tracks and removing their property.

Taking everything into account, real estate brokers and dealers are prepared to call this Spring's business disappointing in its results. There has been a marked absence of the active buying and selling which have hitherto been characteristic of this season of the year. On the other hand, however, there has been no such decided lack of persons wishing to buy.

Interest is growing in the annual election at the Stock Exchange, which will be held a week from to-morrow. Open opposition so far is confined within the Governing Committee, but talk is heard about the office of the Secretary, and, if plans develop to nominate some one against George W. Ely, who holds that place and is a candidate for re-election, arbitrage and other issues will be subordinated to that contest.

The Spanish man-of-war Nautilus, Capt. Fernando Villamil, now in in this harbor, is one of several training ships in the navy of Spain. She has a crew of 183 officers and men, made up as follows: Nine officers and 32 midshipmen, including two Chileans. The seamen are of two classes, ordinary seamen and naval apprentices.

BERLIN, May 5 -- A German-American named Kneebs has been arrested here on a charge of foul play at the race tracks. He came to Germany with several trotting mares, and won some $600 worth of prizes. He changed the name of his mare Bethel to Nellie, declared falsely, it is charged, that she had never won a race, and secured several prizes with her in races intended only for novices.
Sanchez Co., dealers in objects of the fine arts on West Twenty-third Street, exhibit a bas-relief of the Rev. Robert Collyer, of which the accompanying' print gives some idea.

Last week was one of unusual quiet in military circles. All the organizations booked for camp this Summer are beginning to arrange for that event, and members are putting in their applications for vacations to tally with the week their organizations are in camp. Practice at Creedmoor for the week will open to-morrow with the Eighth Battalion, which Major Chauncey expects and surely hopes to make a record with this season.

Society people were much interested yesterday in the report that the Russian Consul had refused last month to vise the marriage certificate of the wedding of Henri de Franenstein and Miss Annie Seabury Brewster because the bridegroom was called "Count" in the document.

Two things in the way of legislation promise to help the values of Brooklyn realty. The first of these is the new building law modeled on that of this city. The other is the series of acts annexing the county towns. The latter promises to lead to considerable speculative buying and developing.

The past week has been a very lively one in the horse market, and dealers have been selling good stock for remunerative figures. This has been the case with the individuals who traffic in horse flesh, as well as with the concerns that have been selling at auction.

ANTWERP, May 5 -- The World's Exhibition was formally opened here at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon by the King and Queen of the Belgians. The weather was delightful, and the display of troops and gorgeous official costumes was magnificent. Handsomely-uniformed officers and soldiers, gorgeously-attired diplomats and splendidly-dressed ladies were to be seen everywhere, and strains of music and the booming of cannon filled the air.

Whale hunting off the Eastern, end of Long Island is not attended by the long absences from home and the hardships met with in a cruise in the arctic regions after he monsters of the deep. The Long Island whale hunter usually captures the game within sight of his own dooryard. The village of Amagansett is whaling headquarers on Long Island.

In amending the "town law" last year the Legislature of this State authorized any town, by a majority vote of the Town Board, to " determine upon, purchase, and order the use of one or more of Myers automatic ballot cabinets at elections of town officers in such town." This provision went into effect on the 1st of March, and a number of towns adopted the voting machine for the Spring elections then ensuing.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 6 -- The fifth annual handicap games of the Princeton University Track Athletic Association were held at the 'Varsity grounds this morning. The games were open to all amateurs, and were governed by intercollegiate rules. The only record broken was in the mile run. G.W. Orton of University of Pennsylvania lowered the collegiate record by 1 1-5 seconds, making it from scratch in 4:28 3-5.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Attorney Silas Pettit, who represents the Brayton Ives interest in the Oakes-Northern Pacific investigation, said to-day: "I am well satisfied so far as the inquiry has progressed. We have proved everything which we set out to prove. I said it was a ten-million-dollar steal, and I think we have proved it to be a million more than that.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 5 -- The Atlanta Chamber of Commerce to-day passed resolutions urging upon the Senate the immediate passage of the Wilson bill, indorsing the repeal of the purchasing clause of the Sherman act as the first step necessary to restore prosperity to the country, and declaring that the passage of the Wilson bill is the next necessary action.

The police of the Charles Street Station are searching for a daring ruffian who, on one of the most crowded thoroughfares in the Ninth Ward, at 9 o'clock last night, deliberately cut a braid of hair from a girl's head.

PHILLIPSBURG, Penn., May 5 -- At Munson's, a mining village near Philllpsburg, to-day, during the observance of a Hungarian holiday, a riot between a number of Slavs took place, in which Andrew Hoyodrik was fatally shot by Paul Baker. Baker made his escape, but while crossing the river at Cataract in a boat which he had stolen, the boat capsized and he was drowned.

Nyack, N.Y., May 5 -- A large number of employes of the Knickerbocker Ice Company at Rockland Lake struck this morning for $1.50 per day. They have been receiving $1.25. They were induced to go to work until the company in New-York could settle the matter. The trouble may result in a general strike.
HOMESTEAD, Penn., May 6 -- Col. Thomas Calvin moved his army to Duquesne today, a distance of two miles. As a parting contribution, the people of Homestead supplied two large wagons filled with food.

The arrangements for the funeral of John Jay will not be perfected until to-day, when the pall bearers will be selected. The funeral will be from Trinity Chapel at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning, and the interment in St. Matthew's Churchyard, at Bedford, Westchester County. Among those who called yesterday at the Hotel Savoy were Dr. J.N. Field, President of the National League Club; Judge Peabody, and Joseph H. Choate.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 6 -- "Henry VIII," is the title of the play which will be given by the two Junior societies of Yale this year. It is a burlesque in two acts on Henry Irving's version of the play, and was prepared for presentation at Yale by Edward Boitwood, '92, Ralph D. Palne, '94, and F.C. Perkins, '94, who arranged last year's play by the same societies.

Prof. Goldwin Smith of Toronto was a passenger on the Umbria, from Liverpool, yesterday. He has been abroad about six months, chiefly for his health. A portion of that time he spent at Oxford, and the remainder, until about three weeks before he sailed, when he was in London, he was on the Isle of Wight.

The little blue-eyed daughter of Congressman Timothy J. Campbell was christened yesterday. The ceremony was that prescribed by the Catholic Church and was performed by the Rev. Father McGinley of the Church of St. Rose of Lima, in Cannon Street.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 6 -- The Vassarion, the college annual published by the senior class, appears this year in good season. It opens with a picture of President Taylor, (private study,) to whom the book is dedicated.

The French Line steamship La Champagne, which left Havre April 28, arrived on a bar off Fort Hamilton shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday morning. She reached that point during a dense fog. The vessel slid her keel so far up on the shelving bank that all immediate efforts to float her into deep water proved futile.

ALBANY, May 6 -- The Constitutional Convention which will meet in this city Tuesday will be the sixth since the Declaration of independence was promulgated. Under the law it should consist of 175 delegates 5 from each of the thirty-two Senatorial districts, and 15 delegates at large, but the deaths of three delegates and the resignation of another, whose vacancies have not yet been filled, will reduce the number to 171.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 6 -- A collection of seventeen fac similes of Greek statuettes has been received by the archaeological department as a present from Mrs. Andrew D. White. The pieces are made of terra cotta, and are imitations of the originals contained in the collections of the Imperial Hermitage, at St. Petersburg; the Royal Museum and Laufmann collection, at Berlin, and the Louvre, Paris, and the British and South Kensington Museums, London.

The Rev. Isaac M. Haldeman, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Seventy-ninth Street and the Boulevard, preached last night to a large congregation against woman suffrage. Yesterday, for the first time, the new quartet rendered the hymns. The singers were: Soprano, Mrs. Schilling; contralto. Miss Pratt; tenor, Mr. King; bass, Mr. Harper.

BERLIN, May 6 -- Prince Bismarck's speech to the Holstein Veterans on Thursday was more closely related to current politics than any utterance he has made since his fall. It also indicated that he has consented to act unofficially in harmony with the Government in affairs where both can stand on common ground.

Although Tip, the big elephant in the Central Park menagerie, has not grown sweeter tempered since the question of killing him because of his inclination to commit murder has been under consideration by the Park Board, a doubt has arisen as to the Commissioners' power to execute him.

CONEY ISLAND, May 6 -- The City of Brooklyn spread the blue coat of its police authority over Coney Island to-day, and for the first time in its history John Y. McKane's Sodom-by-the-sea became a respectable Sunday resort. The wooden elephant looked down on the wonderful transformation in utter astonishment and dismay.

ALBANY, May 5 -- The industrials were the favorites among the local securities traded in during the past week. There was a good demand for both Consolidated Car Heating and Celluloid stocks. The former took the lead and advanced steadily on light transactions from 55 to 61. The public are just awakening to the importance of the decision handed down three weeks ago in the United States court favorable to this company.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 6. -- A severe wind and rain storm, accompanied by thunder and lightning, swept over the Wyoming Valley this afternoon. The rain came down for several hours in torrents, inundating cellars and flooding many of the streets, causing considerable damage. At Forty Fort, Simpson Watkins's massive coal breaker was badly damaged by the wind, and the Sturmersville Breaker, near Pittston, was also injured.

The tennis players of the metropolitan district have begun the season earlier this year than usual. One tournament has already been played, and to-morrow will be the opening day of another. On the courts of some of the more enterprising clubs play has been going on for three weeks, and there are but few clubs which have not at least one court ready for play.

Indications are that the issue which the Knights of Labor have forced on a Brooklyn brewing firm, to compel it to employ only Knights of Labor, will lead to another general lock-out of brewery hands by the Master Brewers' Association, such as took place in 1888, when thousands of journeymen brewers and brewery drivers were suddenly thrown out of employment.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 6 -- The political situation in this State is becoming interesting from a number of points of view. That acute political observer, Judgre Lynde Harrison, in a talk here to-day, gave his ideas in a way that will excite general interest and comment.

The arrest Friday night of Eugene Renard of 130 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and Philip Young of the same address for acting suspiciously in the Secnd Collegiate Reformed Church of Harlem, at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and Lenox Avenue, was important, in that it exposed a system for robbing churches, not only in Harlem, but in other cities, the robberies extending as far as Boston.

The exhibit of the Catholic schools at the Grand Central Palace. Forty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, which is to open next Monday, will include the departments of drawing, painting, clay modeling, and sewing, and no branch of instruction will be omitted. The scope of the exhibit and the arrangements were decided on last week.
