BERLIN, May 6 -- Sporting circles here are excited over the action taken by the new Berlin Trotting Union against R.F. Kneebs. an American trotting-horse breeder, who is charged with foul play in racing horses here. The officials of the union allege that Kneebs, in entering for the races here, gave false names to horses that had won races in America, besides giving them false pedigrees, or saying that they were without records.

WHITESTONE, L.I., May 6 -- A small single-pulley block, fastened to the bough of an apple tree, a clothesline, a butter tub, and a spade and a pick, are the implements used in sinking a well in a piece of high ground on the outskirts of this village. The well digger is Peter Nelson, a Swede, who never saw a well sunk.

LONDON, May 6 -- English workingmen, as usual, made their eight-hour demonstration tills year on the first Sunday after May Day. The embankment, as early as noon, was densely packed, from Blackfriars' Bridge to Charing Cross, with workingmen of all trades and conditions, with here and there a vehicle carrying leaders and speakers, with hundreds of banners.

The bond market last week was dull and distinctly easier with the speculative class of bonds, Reading, Northern Pacific, and Atchison bonds especially having been affected. The former broke badly on the threatened foreclosure of the general mortgage of the company. In the Northern Pacific issues there were few transactions, with concessions on all classes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 -- The removal of the enormous stands from Jarvis Field to make room for the proposed tennis courts has caused opposition to the plan for devoting the whole fleld to tennis. Two or three weeks ago the Tennis association secured permission for the use of the field during the Summer, particularly during this month and next, when the interscholastic tennis tournament takes place.

We are in love with The Times. My husband took it all his life, and thought there was no paper like it. I quite agree with him. and think it is the best literary paper there is in the world. The revival news afforded me a great deal of pleasure, and all my friends agree with me that The Times is improving, and that its Brooklyn news is very fine. -- Mrs. E.N.M.

The Church Extension Association will, in future, control the school for girls which has, since 1864, been conducted by Mrs. Sylvanus Reed, at 6 East Fifty-third Street. The new managers are a scholastic order of women, whose headquarters are in London. The association was incorporated in 1890, and in England is regarded as an important educational movement.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Treasury Department has made a demand upon the North American Commercial Company, which has the contract for The exclusive right of taking fur seals upon the Pribilov Islands, in Alaska, for about $230,000, and the matter will be argued to-morrow before Secretary Carlisle and Assistant Secretary, Hamlin by the Hon. J.C. Carter and N.L. Jeffries, attorneys for the company.

MUNCIE, Ind., May 6 -- The William N. Whitely Reaper and Mower Works, the largest manufacturing establishment in Eastern Indiana, which was moved from Spring-field, Ohio, two years ago, was destroyed by fire this afternoon. The loss is estimated at $245,000, with no insurance. Two thousand machines were ready for shipment and over 15,000 were partly completed.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 6 -- Interest is almost at fever heat here over the annual Yale-Harvard dual track athletic games, which will be held at the Yale Field May 12. The closeness of the contests, the fact that they will be held in this city, and the almost certainty that several intercollegiate records will be badly broken make the coming meet the most attractive which has been held here in years.

Early work among the Harlem River oarsmen yesterday was hindered by the mist, but directly that lifted the crews got out their boats and turned to with a will. From noon till almost dusk the river from One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street up to High Bridge was alive with craft, from the single shell to the pleasure barge.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 -- The refusal of the Overseers to allow the buildings of the university, especially Sanders Theatre, to be used for political purposes has brought about much excitement and vituperation among the young Republicans of the college. As a result, the Overseers and President Eliot are now under a steady fire of uncomplimentary adjectives from the young politicians.

Max Meyer, a dry goods merchant of Selma, Ala., jumped from a fourth-story window of the Graham apartment house, at Eighty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, and was killed.

The impression, which prevails at Honolulu, according to the news just brought from, that port, that Admiral Walker is about to take formal possession of Pearl River Harbor is probably well founded. Our Government has long had the right to do this, and recent circumstances have prompted its exercise.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 6 -- At the solicitation of a prominent Presbyterian gentleman, Col. Breckinridge to-day confessed his sins before the officers and pastor of Mount Horeb Presbyterian Church of this county, which was founded by his father, Robert J. Breckinridge.

NORWALK, Conn., May 6 -- Connecticut's yachting season will open in a week or two and by Memorial Day, when a number of regattas are sailed, will be in full blast. Norwalk is the centre of this section of Connecticut's shore where this aquatic sport is very popular, and since early in April there has been a general overhauling of sailing vessels, and owners are impatiently waiting for a sail.

The Ross Street Presbyterian Church, in Ross Street, between Bedford and Lee Avenues, Brooklyn, of which the Rev. J. E. Adams is pastor, has completed the thirtieth year of its existence, and is celebrating the event with appropriate services.

The most violent and reiterative denunciators of the income tax, we observe, are persons who are more or less justly suspected of strong leanings toward the doctrine of protection and McKinleyism. The coincidence may be accidental.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 6 -- A new building is to be erected soon at Princeton, called the Casino, which will provide accommodations for the annual dances. Glee Club concerts, and dramatic performances, besides having two covered tennis courts for Winter use. Such a building will satisfy a long-felt need in Princeton, as all events of a social nature have been severely handicapped on account of the lack of suitable accommodations.

PITTSBURG, May 5 -- Money has ruled plentiful enough all the week. In the absence of demand from parties with acceptable collateral bankers invested large lines of funds in bonds of local corporations, and without advancing prices for the latter. In stocks the tendency of prices was downward, but the only losses are scored in such of the natural gasers as are expected to abandon the natural for coal gas.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 6 -- There is a livelier interest in the crews, and aquatics generally at Cornell. The crews now take their daily spin on the lake. During the past week there have been several races for short distances between the first and second freshman crews. Once the second crew was declared the winner, but in the second race the first crew won by a small margin.

"Thou shalt not steal" was the text of a sermon on Coxey's army which was delivered last evening at the Church of the Divine Paternity, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton.

The eighteenth anniversary of the foundation of the Society for Ethical Culture was celebrated at the Music Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, yesterday morning. There was an attendance of about 1.200, including many interested in the ethical movement. In addition to the members of the society.
In his sermon yesterday on "Appropriations from the Public Funds Un-American," the Rev. Madison C. Peters of the Bloomingdale Church said:

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Eckert of the Western Union Telegraph Company has issued a statement in answer to the charge that a combination exists between the Western Union Telegraph Company and the press associations, by means of which the newspapers that are members of those associations get special advantages that enable them to prevent the establishment of rival newspapers, and thus deprive printers of employment which they would otherwise be able to obtain.

The Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage preached his twenty-firth anniversary sermon to a very large congregation in the Brooklyn Tabernacle yesterday morning. His subject was "The Generations," and he took for his text Ecelesiastes, i., 4: "One generation passeth away, and another generation cometh," He said:

LONDON, May 6 -- The United States cruiser Chicago is expected to arrive at Gravesend to-morrow or Tuesday. Lord Brassey, Earl Spencer, and the other heads of the Admiralty, together with several eminent naval and military officers, are arranging to give the flagship's officers a warm welcome.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- If a stranger could have been permitted to look into the room of the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs to-day, he might have secured an erroneous idea of the habits of United States Senators, for he would have seen a half dozen of them sitting at the long table, working industriously.

We present elsewhere a history of the several Constitutional Conventions of this State and of their work. This history gives an interesting view of the development of our State Government, always in the direction of an extension of popular power and the curtailment of delegated authority.

A translation of the three-act French conversational drama by Maupassant and Normand, called "Musotte," was tested, after a fashion, at the Star Theatre last night. In the first act a middle-aged artist has just married an advocate's pretty daughter. He sits by her, on a sofa, and tells her how much he loves her.

SPOKANE, Washington, May 7. -- Three hundred Coxeyltes from Western Washington have arrived here. The leader is Jeffries, an agitator. About 200 of the Puyallup band were caught at Pasco by a force of Deputy United States Marshals under Samuel Vinson. They are angry over their detention, and Vinson telegraphed for reinforcements.

ALBANY, May 7. -- Some months ago the Metropolitan Traction Company of New-York City offered a prize of $50,000 for the best invention for street-car propulsion. Last week the Governor signed a bill authorizing the State Railroad Commission to be the judge of the various inventions submitted and to award the prize.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Supervising Architect O'Rourke, after a personal examination, and after a report by Inspector Clarke, to-day ordered timbers to be placed under all the granite brackets supporting the balconies in the court of the New-York Custom House. The work will be begun at once.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 7. -- Commander J.A. Watrous of the Wisconsin Department of the Grand Army of the Republic this afternoon made the sensational statement that tens of thousands of dollars sent to two Southern Grand Army posts during recent years by Northern veterans only a small portion was ever devoted to the purpose for which it was given, namely, the decoration of the graves of Union soldiers buried in the South.

The greatest Young Men's Christian Association athletic contest of the year will be the annual State games. These will be held Sept. 22. probably at Utica. The present State champion is William D. McMonigie of the Twenty-third Street branch, this city. His score last year was 372 points, just 8 below the gold medal standard, but he is working like a beaver now and intends to capture a first prize next September.

VIENNA, May 7. -- The rescue of the Lugloch tourists has thrown Gratz into a ferment of excitement. Residents, mutually unacquainted, embraced one another and wept in the streets. There was hardly less excitement in Vienna. Everybody was asking for or giving information of the rescue. The Emperor immediately telegraphed congratulations to the rescued and rescuers.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The trial of the Commonwealers -- Coxey, Browne, and Jones -- was resumed this morning in the District Police Court. The courtroom was filled to its capacity. Proceedings were opened by Mr. Heylman, in argument for the defense, who said that he would prove by prominent citizens that the arrest of the defendants was one of the most brutal affairs ever heard of.

The stock market yesterday was extremely dull and was thoroughly professional. One-third of the trading was in Sugar, and the only other stocks which were even moderately active were St. Paul and General Electric. In Lead the transactions were 8,300 shares. in Chicago Gas 6,600, in Whisky 6,00, and in Western Union 5,500.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 7. -- The strikers have gained their point of a complete shut-down in the coke region. Hainey's men were nearly all brought out this morning, leaving only a few at work at Paul and Moyer. Fort Hill, Hainey, Elm Grove, and Mount Braddock are closed. When the other operators learned that Halney had been closed down they concluded to remain idle.

The New-Yorks played their first 1 to 0 game of the season against the Bostons yesterday, and to the discomfiture of the 7,000 enthusiasts who witnessed the contest the Giants were credited with nothing. In seasons past a score of this kind would attract widespread attention, but such is not the case to-day.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 7. -- There was a large gathering of lawyers and representative men in the Court House here this morning when the large portrait in oil of ex-Chief Justice Joseph F. Barnard, which hang's in the courtroom, was formally presented to the County of Dutchess and was accepted by Chief Justice C.F. Brown of Newburg, who was appointed by Gov. Flower to succeed Judge Barnard as the Presiding Judge in the Second Judicial District.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

LONDON, May 7. -- Col. Malleson, who is recognized as an eminent authority on Indian affairs, has written an open letter to the newspapers on the subject of the anticipated uprising of the natives in India, which was treated of in a very serious way by The Spectator on Saturday. Col. Malleson says that The Spectator's estimate of the gravity of the situation is not one whit exaggerated.

GRATZ, May 7. -- The detachment of sappers and miners endeavoring to release the imprisoned tourists from the stalactite cave at Lugloch succeeded this morning in forcing a narrow passage into the cavern. All the members of the party were found alive, but very much exhausted, and the physicians attending them believe that they will survive.

The fate of Tip, the "rogue" elephant, who on April 30 tried to kill his keeper, William Snyder, in the elephant house in Central Park, will not be decided until to-morrow, when the attention of the Park Commissioners will be drawn to Tip's murderous propensity.
The woman suffragists had such a mass meeting in Cooper Union last night as they would not have dreamed a year ago could have been within the range of possibility.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 7. -- The second annual meeting of the stockholders of the Allegheny Valley Railway Company was held in the general offices of the company at noon. The annual report shows the earnings for 1893 to have been $2,336,815.98, and the net income $877,027.22. Deficiency of income to meet interest, $277,047.97.

For President -- Joseph H. Choate of New-York. For Vice President -- Thomas G. Alvord of Syracuse. For Second Vice President -- William H. Steele of Oswego. For Clerk -- Charles E. Fitch of Rochester. For Stenographer -- George H. Briggs of Buffalo. For Sergeant at Arms -- W.W. Bennett of Saratoga.

RED BANK, N.J., May 7. -- A sale took place at Monmouth Park Hotel to-day consisting of hotel furniture, wagons, mules, horses. , belonging to the Monmouth Park Association, to pay the taxes and costs due the township of Eatontown for 1893. A warrant was issued by Squire John C. Edwards April 9 to issue a levy, which was executed by Constable George Morris on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- For three hours this afternoon Secretary Carlisle listened to an argument made by J.C. Carter in opposition to the claim of the United States for $400,000 against the North American Commercial Company for rent under its lease. Mr. Carter took up every point in the dispute, alleging that not only did the Commercial Company owe the United States nothing, but that the United States was a debtor to the Commercial Company.

The Sands Street Methodist Church of Brooklyn has almost rounded out a full century of existence. The centenary of the dedication of this pioneer of its denomination in that city will occur on the first day of June and is to be fittingly celebrated.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your editorial in yesterday's Times, "Tariff on Pacific Coast," can be applied to the entire United States. Trade journals are quoting letters like this:

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The announcement by Mr. Croker that the duties which he now individually performs in the interest of Tammany Hall must hereafter be divided among committees of that organization is taken here to mean that Mr. Croker will soon retire altogether from the leadership which he has held so long.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- The Directors of Lehigh Navigation surprised the Street by reducing the semi-annual dividend from 6 per cent. per annum to 5 per cent. per annum. Of course, every one knows the anthracite coal business is in very bad shape, but this company is leased to the Jersey Central, and was believed to derive a much greater proportion of profits than any of the other coal-mining companies.

The reader of the daily paper who sits in his cozy home and is informed of what is transpiring in every quarter of the globe seldom realizes the amount of actual labor necessary to ascertain, collect, write, transmit, and print this wonderful mass of news.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., May 7. -- The sixth day of the season for rifle practice at Creedmoor was opened this morning by the Eighth Battalion, under command of Major H. Chauncey, Jr., Lieut. O'Connor of Company F acting as inspector of rifle practice. The weather cleared off nicely, with a moderate 8 o'clock wind in the morning, increasing to almost a gale in the afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- Philadelphia and Brooklyn played an exciting game this afternoon, the Phillies winning in the ninth inning. The home team hit the ball hard in tie last inning, Delehanry opening with a three-bagger. Thompson following with a double, and Cross and Clements making singles. Hamilton hurt his arm while sliding to second, and retired from the game.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Secretary Carlisle to-day directed that all the customs bonded warehouses in the United States be examined in detail by checking off the contents by warehouse ledgers without regard to the accounts of storekeepers. This action was taken by Secretary Carlisle in view of the recently-discovered irregularities in the Boston (Mass.) Custom House.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 7. -- Wesleyan, defeated Colgate this afternoon in a well-played baseball game. The Colgate men showed up surprisingly well. Tirrell pitched a star same for Wesleyan. The score:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Any one who has followed the arguments, for and against woman suffrage must be sometimes plunged into a state of perplexity as to what woman really is, and what is its function in the body politic. One can hardly say her function, if it is true, as is so constantly asserted with abundant Scriptural backing, that woman is only an imperfect part, incomplete until joined to man.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A report was submitted to the Senate to-day by Messrs. Teller, Platt. and Roach, of the Committee on the Five Civilized Tribes, as the result of their recent tour of investigation through the Territory belonging to those tribes. They unfold conditions of life of which the general public has small knowledge.

The well-known Hamilton Fish property at the northwest corner of Second Avenue and Seventeenth Street, facing Stuyvesant Park, has been Bold. The mansion, which was the scene of many a noted gathering during the lifetime of the late Secretary of State, occupies the southern portion or the lot. The land fronts 84 feet on the street and extends along the block front on Second Avenue to Eighteenth Street, 184 feet.

The cutting of steerage rates to Europe still continues between the Hamburg-American, North German Lloyd, and American Steamship Lines. The rate to Queenstown is $14 and to Liverpool $18, a commission of $4 being paid. On the German steamers, this means board for nine or ten days, irrespective of transportation, or something like $1 a day for food and transportation.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Retaliation against Canada for her discriminations against the United States in the use of certain of her canals is the purpose of a bill introduced in February last by Representative Chickering of New-York. The bill is intended to amend the act to enforce reciprocal commercial relations between the United States and Canada, approved July 6, 1892.

A detective story of more than usual interest developed yesterday in connection with the trial of Dr. Henry Meyer for the poisoning of Ludwig Brandt. It related to the manner in which Muller, the informer, was brought into the position where he had to tell the story of the conspiracy engineered by Dr. Meyer.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The source of hope for this country is not to increase the number of voters. I believe in women thoroughly, and in women's rights to a certain extent, but think that before women have the right of suffrage there should be restrictions for men, the same to apply to woman when she is made a voter.

The racing associations of this State got about as black an eye yesterday as did those in New-Jersey last Fall when the people decided at the polls that the high-handed operations of the race-track ring bad gone further than the law allowed or public decency permitted.

Candidates for places on the Republican State ticket are multiplying in Brooklyn. The latest addition to the list is Silas B. Dutcher. A large number of Kings County Republicans think he should be nominated for Governor. They are considering seriously a scheme to unite the delegation in his support.

VIENNA, May 7. -- The striking masons, carpenters, and other workmen in the building trades assembled in and about the Burger Platz to-day and endeavored to compel the men who were still at work to join them. The mob assailed the police with stones, and the police charged upon the rioters with drawn swords.
WASHINGTON, May 7.-The tariff "fixers" of the Senate have at last made public the result of their efforts to secure a united Democratic vote for the Tariff bill.

The Vigilant will be launched from Mather Wood's yard at Port Jefferson to-day. Her new owners, Messrs. George and Howard Gould, will witness the crack yacht take her first plunge of the season. Mr. Howard Gould yesterday gave the first statement of what it was proposed to do with the yacht this Summer. He said:

There was great surprise among local politicians yesterday. Richard Croker, for nine years the successful and undefeated leader of Tammany Hall, announced that he could no longer attend to the multiplicity of duties connected with that place, and that he would be obliged to surrender the routine work into other hands and to give his time in future to his own private affairs and to his family.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 7. -- Registration for the August election commenced to-day, and will continue for thirty days, in accordance with the Sayre election law, which will have its first illustration in the present campaign.

Paris, May 8. -- The Matin is authority for the assertion that the Government insists upon the extradition of Dr. Cornelius Herz. the Panama Canal lobbyist, notwithstanding the acceptance by the courts of his offer to reimburse the liquidator of the Panama Canal Company in the sum of 1,500,000.

HALIFAX, N.S., May 8. -- Bermuda advices of May 1, by steamer Alpha, which arrived this morning, give particulars of a fire at the dockyard there. The store belonging to the ordnance store department, to the north of the dockyard, on Ireland Island, was discovered on fire the night of April 25.

The fiery attack of Senator Hoar on the Democratic majority yesterday was received with a resentment that betrayed sensitiveness. Undoubtedly the attack was in bad taste, for the senior Senator from Massachusetts, when his aged blood is up, does not stop to consider the proprieties.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 8. -- Princeton found no difficulty in defeating Cornell at baseball here to-day. The score was 17 to 7. Cobb was knocked out of the box in the third inning. Smith taking his place. But Smith was wild, and a combination of six bases on balls, an overthrow by Affield and four hits brought in 8 runs in the fourth. After this inning.

The bicycle members of the New-York Athletic Club are a very busy lot of men at present, and activity is the characteristic feature at the cycle clubhouse at 26 West Sixtieth Street. Every pleasant day a score or more of the members start out for suburban rides, while Sundays a number of squads of half a dozen men and over go out for long cross-country rides.
WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Another day gone in the Senate, and still no progress!

Emerson, in his " Conduct of Life," justly pays a tribute to wealth. A dollar, according to the Concord philosopher, means to man just what a dollar can bring. On an uninhabited coral reef a cocoanut is worth more, for a dollar there brings nothing. In New-York a dollar is worth more and more every year.

JERSEY CITY, May 8. -- The Grand Jury of Hudson County this afternoon made to the Court of Oyer and Terminer a presentment concerning the "green-goods" business and the connection with it of the Western Union Telegraph Company, whose local office is managed by John B. Bartholf.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The jury which has heard the trial of Coxey, Browne, and Jones, the leaders of the Commonweal Army of tramps, decided this afternoon that they were guilty of the first count, which charged them with carrying banners designed to bring the Coxey Army, into prominence in the Capitol grounds.

The repeal of the anti-pooling clause of the Inter-State Commerce act is now urged by the railroad managers in a way that should not fail to secure for that subject prompt and careful consideration on the part of Congress. Never since the law was enacted have the protests against the section forbidding the pooling of railway earnings been so numerous and so urgent as at present.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The twelfth thirteen-inch gun for the navy was successfully jacketed to-day at the Washington Ordnance Shops, in thirteen minutes. This completes the lot of guns of this calibre for the navy. Of the total number completed, ten will be ready for distribution to the ships after they shall have been proved.

It seems to be tolerably clear that Mr. Richard Croker has tired of being a boss, in spite of the temptations that influential trade offers to a man who is fond of power. There is no doubt that Mr. Croker has wielded power. Why he should cease to be a boss when apparently he might continue to be a boss is an interesting question.

The funeral of John Jay, who died May 6 at the Hotel Savoy, took place at Trinity Chapel yesterday morning. The officiating clergymen were Bishop Potter, the Rev. Morgan Dix, the Rev. W.H. Vibbert, and the Rev. Lea Luquer of St. Matthew's, Bedford, N.Y., where the Interment was made.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 8. -- State Bank Commissioner Breidenthal to-day sent a circular letter to all State and private banks in Kansas in which he forbids them to sign notes obligating themselves to pay their obligations in anything except the legal tender of the United States. In the letter he says:

PUEBLO, Col., May 8. -- Gen. J.S. Sanders and his army of Commonwealers, who have been encamped on the "Vacant Lot" here for several days, seized a switch engine standing on the Denver and Rio Grande track to-night, moved it up to the Missouri Pacific switch, and backed down on ten empty coal cars standing on the Missouri Pacific side track, belonging to the company, and started east.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 8. -- Two slender Southern boys have been heroes in the town to-day. They attend the Riverview Military Academy. By their courage and presence of mind they probably have put an end to the career of a burglar. They are H.B. Lewis, eighteen years old, of Atlanta, Ga., and Hugh Bullock, nineteen years old, of the same place.
WASHINGTON, May 8. -- This afternoon the French Ambassador and Mme. Patenotre welcomed their friends for the first time to Clifton, and the invitations were responded to almost without exception.

The yacht Intrepid, with Lloyd Phoenix on board, arrived here yesterday morning from her three months' cruise in southern waters. As has already been told, the yacht brought north the bell and logbook of the wrecked corvette Kearsanre.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 8 -- The address of President Skilton of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, which will begin its annual session in New-York City to-morrow, will show that the aggregate losses of the fire companies in this country in 1893 exceeded the amounts paid during the year 1871 by all joint stock companies then transacting business in the United States, including the amounts paid on account of the Chicago conflagration.

ALBANY, May 8. -- If the patriotic words uttered by Joseph H. Choate upon taking the office of President of the Sixth Constitutional Convention of this State are kept in mind and heeded by the delegates, the work of the convention will be conspicuous for the absence of all partisanship, and consecrated to what is best for the interests of the people of the whole State.
Sugar comprised practically the whole of yesterday's stock market. There was desultory trading in other stocks, but it was insignificant compared with the movement in the leading industrial.

BATH, Me., May 8. -- Mr. William A. Slater's new yacht, the Eleanor, launched from the Bath Iron Works to-day, is not only the largest steam yacht ever built in the United States, but is especially designed to meet the requirements of her owner in a two years' cruise around the world and as the home of his family for that time, is to be furnished with regal magnificence.
The battle of experts began yesterday in the trial of Dr. Henry Meyer for murder Nothing but expert testimony was offered by the prosecution during the entire session.

"Think what it would be if we had the suffrage," said a Brooklyn "antl" yesterday morning, as she mingled her sigh of weariness with those of a half dozen of her sister protestants after a meeting in the home of Mrs. Henry F. Wardwell, 800 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn.

SPRAGUE, Washington, May 8. -- This part of the State is filled with Coxeyites, and their ranks are being constantly swelled. They have been interfering with the Northern Pacific Road by spiking rails on the heavy up-grades and getting on the cars in the yards. One of them hid on the trucks of a cattle train last night, setting the air brakes when the train arrived here, preventing it being rushed through.

The number of consecrated Catholic Churches in this city is to be increased to six. There are only four churches that have been thus honored. They are the Church of the Immaculate Conception in East Fourteenth Street, St. Peter's in Barclay Street, St. Patrick's in Mott Street, and St. Brigid's in Avenue B.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 8. -- Judge Gilbert Robertson of Troy and Edward Feeney of Brooklyn, members of the State Board of Arbitration, are in this city, endeavoring to settle the strike between the brick-yard laborers and their employers. This strike has been in progress for a week, and a thousand men are out of work. It was declared because the manufacturers reduced wages 20 cents a day.

-- Col. Croford Alien died Monday in Providence, R.I., after a lung illness. He was Captain in one of the first Rhode Island batteries and for gallant services was made Colonel by bravet. He traveled extensively, and on his last trip to South America he shot and killed a native of some prominence. Only by the most earnest efforts on the part of Senators Anthony and Burnside did he escape the death penalty.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The sixth annual convention of the Railway Commissioners' Association was called to order at the Inter-State Commerce Commission this morning by the Hon. James H. Paddock of Illinois, Chairman of the committee appointed to call the convention. There were about forty delegates present from all over the country.

BUDA-PESTH, May 8. -- The opening of the trial on a charge of treason of twentythree members of the Executive Committee of the Roumanian National Party in Hungary at Klausenburg yesterday was attended with great excitement. The indictment against the men on trial charges them with causing the publication of a document in several languages, and widely distributing the same, denouncing the Act of Union of Austria and Hungary.

The biggest real estate transaction reported yesterday was the sale by Mr. John Pettit to Mr. Theodore A. Havemeyer of the Bennett Building, on Nassau Street, between Ann and Fulton Streets. The brokerage firm in the matter was Richard V. Harnett Co., Mr. Herbert A. Sherman of that firm haveing had entire charge of the transaction.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Members of the House who have examined the Tariff bill as amended by the Gorman sub-committee to secure an agreement, and say anything about it, are disgusted with the " thing " that has taken the place of the Wilson bill.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 8. -- The Cornell Lacrosse Team was defeated here to-day by the Stevens Institute team by a score of 4 to 1. The playing by the Stevens team was characterized by rapidity in passing. They also put up a very strong and skillful game on the defense, and so ably defended their goal that only once did the Cornell attack succeed in scoring.

Hammondsport, N.Y., May 8. -- The Hammondsport Herald office and contents, the house and barn of L.H. Brown, the editor; the Steuben House and barns, the Harry Layton block of stores, the Myrtle tenement-house block, containing seven families, and the barns of Harry M. Champlin and H.H. Stobbins, in Hammondsport were burned at an early hour this morning.

The appetite for office among Brooklyn Republicans is growing. A brick thrown in the vicinity of the Union League Club would almost certainly hit a candidate for Governor or Lieutenant Governor. The list of men who would like to adorn the State ticket is steadily growing. Not one of them is striving to hide his light under a bushel.

CREEDMOOR. L. I., May 8. -- The seventh day of the season for rifle practice at Creedmoor. L. I., was opened this morning by a battalion of the Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn, composed of Companies A, K, G, H, I, and a few men from other companies, all under the command of Major A. O'Crane, and under the supervision of Major Babcock, Inspector of Rifle Practice.

Mayor Gilroy and Corporation Counsel Clark returned from Albany last night, where they had spent the day in conference with Gov. Flower in relation to the bills affecting this city, passed by the Legislature and now in the hands of the Governor awaiting his approval. The Mayor said last night:

New Columbia College will be ready for partial occupation some time next year and finished in 1897 or 1898. It will be a great university on the German model, and, as told in The New-York Times, will occupy eighteen acres on the plateau bounded by One Hundred and Sixteenth and One Hundred and Twentieth Streets and Amsterdam Avenue and the Boulevard, which is known as Bloomingdale, or Cathedral Heights.

PARIS, May 8. -- The Chamber of Deputies was crowded with visitors and members today when M. Millerand read the report of the committee, of which he was Chairman, to which was referred the matter of considering the advisability of prosecuting M. Toussaint, Socialist Deputy for the Eleventh Arrondissement of Paris, for insulting the police on the occasion of the strike of the workmen in the Trignac Iron Works.

TRENTON, N. J., May 8. -- The Mercer County Wheelmen's minstrel entertainment last night was a great success. Trenton's big Opera House was crowded from pit to dome. The wheelmen have been giving entertainments of all kinds during the Winter, but their efforts in minstrelsy have been the most successful. They gave a street parade yesterday afternoon, headed by the Seventh Regiment Band.

Mrs. Emma S. Hart, a widow living at 199 Lenox Avenue, has been robbed by a butler of diamonds and jewelry valued at $3,500. The robbing occurred many months ago, but the police kept it quiet until yesterday.

The committee of the universities to revise the football rules met last night at the University Athletic Clubhouse. Those present were Alexander Moffatt, Princeton; Walter Camp, Yale; J. C. Bell. University of Pennsylvania; Dr. W. A. Brooks, Harvard, and Dr. P. J. Dashiel, Lehigh. The committee has finished its work, and the changes proposed by the Rules Committee and approved by the University Athletic Club are as follows:

But a short time ago some eminent scientists made a great discovery. They discovered that fats and oils didn't fatten thin people. Everything seems simple after some one else has found it out. If we had thought, we would have remembered that for ages doctors have forbid, den starch foods to people who wanted to get thin.
ALBANY, May 8. -- In accepting the Presidency of the Constitutional Convention, Joseph H. Choate addressed the delegates as follows:

The twenty-ninth anniversary of the National Temperance Society and Publication House was celebrated last evening in the Broadway Tabernacle, Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street. Major Gen. O.O. Howard, President of the society, presided. There was a large audience present.

BOSTON, May 8. -- The dedication of the Booth Memorial at the grave of Edwin Booth at Mount Auburn took place to-day. The Rev. Dr. Edward Everett Hale made an exceedingly interesting address, in which he brought forward the beautiful simplicity and generous character of Mr. Booth. After these remarks he read Scripture passages from the poetic Psalms and Revelation.

On the ceilings of the private dwelling 1,045 Fifth Avenue are five paintings on canvas, the work of a French artist, Dupanais, representing, respectively, "Science and Art," "Music," "Spring," "Autumn," and "Winter."

"No betting, no racing," is the opinion of the bookmakers on the situation brought about by the decision of Judges Pryor and Daly, at a General Term of the Court of Common Pleas, that the Ives Pool bill of 1887 is unconstitutional.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., May 8. -- The acceptance test for eight-inch armor-piercing Midvale-Holtzer steel projectiles manufactured by the Midvale Steel Company of Philadelphia, by its secret process, was finished to-day, and was considered very satisfactory by Capt. Frank Heath, in charge of the proving ground. Two shots were fired from an eight-inch breech-loading rifle, and both penetrated the nine-inch oil-tempered and annealed plate furnished by the Bethlehem Steel Works.

LOGANSPORT, Ind., May 8. -- The octogenarian race that has attracted so much attention in Northern Indiana took place here yesterday for a purse of $100 and the championship of the State. A large crowd went to the fair grounds, where an admission fee of 10 cents was charged. Hannibal Purcell of Logansport, Daniel Reeder of Peru, K.G. Shryrock of Rochester, and Benjamin Simons, living north of here, were entered for the race.

GRATZ, May 8. -- The tourists who were rescued from the stalactite cave at Lugloch yesterday are much improved physically and mentally to-day. Their recovery has been a great deal more rapid than was expected, and the effects of their sufferings will have disappeared intirely within a few days.

DENVER, Col., May 8. -- Special trains from both East and West arrived in this city last evening and this morning, bringing large parties from the leading cities of the country to attend the annual Joint meeting of the Hotel Mutual Benefit Association and the United States Hotel Association.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 8. -- At the combination sale of thoroughbred yearlings held here under the management of Tattersalls last evening fiftyone head were disposed of for a total of $20,665. Considering the financial depression and the uncertainty regarding racing in the East in the future the prices obtained were considered very good.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8. -- The Brooklyns fell before the Phillies this afternoon because of the terrific manner in which the home team pounded the ball. After the first inning the result was not in doubt. Haddock had plenty of speed and pitched a good game against his old comrades. Grady, the Philadelphia Club's new catcher, caught the last half of the game and did well, both at the bat and behind the plate.

The new building of the New-York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, at Second Avenue and Twentieth Street, was opened yesterday and receptions were given In the afternoon and evening to the friends of the Institution. Physicians who have visited the great hospitals of Europe pronounce the new building as second to none In Its equipments for advanced medical work.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Although the time for the study of the latest amendments to the Tariff bill has been short, some of the tariff experts of the Senate and House have made what they consider to be a pretty accurate estimate of their effect.

Whenever the women make up their minds that they want to vote, laws and Constitutions will be amended to give them that privilege. But we think that they must agree about it. It is right that they should be required to agree about it before the change is made. Their united demand for the suffrage would be irresistible.

The big arena at Madison Square Garden looked more like a meeting ground for the members of New-York society last night than it did like the show ground for a lot of horses that were to be auctioned off to the highest bidder. The horses were the offerings of E. D. Morgan, and a grander lot of horses, taken collectively, it would be hard to find.

Richard Croker's proposed partial retirement from the work and responsibilities of the leadership of Tammany Hall furnished the politicians with plenty of gossip yesterday, but with very few new facts.

An important step toward harmonizing the interests of the New-York and NewEngland second mortgage bondholders with the reorganization plan reported by the Waterbury-Cannon-Coolidge committee was taken yesterday. Formal notice was issued by the committee as follows:
WASHINGTON, May 8. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Manderson gave notice of an important amendment to the River and Harbor bill, bearing upon a provision relative to the New-York Harbor.

Newark, N. J., May 8. -- Adam Gindling, seventy-two years old, of 22 Lewis Street, committed suicide at his home to-day by drinking carbolic acid. Before drinking it he tried to induce his wife, who is seventy-one years old, to also drink of the poison, but she refused. He had been out of work for some time.

MONTREAL, May 8. -- The fourteenth game of the chess match for the championship of the world, and $2,000 a side, was contested between W. Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker at the Cosmopolitan Club this afternoon, many spectators being present. The champion opened the same with P -- Q4, which led to a regular queen's gambit declined.

The Tammany Hall General Committee of the First Assembly District held a meeting at the Hickory Club, 174 Hudson Street, last night. Col. Michael C. Murphy, the leader of the district, was in the chair. A resolution, as follows, was unanimously adopted:

The reported sale of the Bennett Building to Mr. Theodore A. Havemeyer was a fertile source of comment among real estate brokers yesterday. They were agreed only in the statement that the transaction was a good one for the broker, and each was rather sorry that he was not the particular broker.

About a year ago, Don Manuel Amador, an ex-Governor of the State of Panama, sent his son Raul to this country with the idea of making a doctor of him. The young man, concerning whose age there is a diversity of opinion, was placed by Edward La Fevre, his guardian, in the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Fifty-ninth Street and Tenth Avenue, as a medical student.

The sale of trotting stock, the property of John H. Shults, Charles Backman, W.B. Dickerman, and David S. Hammond, by Auctioneer Peter C. Kellogg Co., at Madison Square Garden, yesterday, attracted a large number of prospective buyers.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The persistency of the owners of several building sites, each, owner with a number of influential backers to work for him, has for many years prevented the selection of a site for a Government Printing Office.

Henry S. Boutell, formerly Secretary of the Chicago and Northern Pacific Railroad, was the only person examined yesterday in the Northern Pacific conspiracy hearing before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary. The hearing was conducted in Room 3, on the fourth floor of the Mills Building, and was attended by a large number of lawyers.

"It would be a shame to kill Tip. I want to plead for him," exclaimed a welldressed young woman, with tears in her eyes, who was in a tremor of emotion, when she entered, unannounced, the office of Charles De F. Burns, Secretary of the Department of Public Parks, yesterday afternoon.

CHIVINGTON, Col., May 9 -- The Sanders Industrial Army, which started out of Pueblo last night on a stolen Missouri Pacific train drawn by a Denver and Rio Grande engine, came to a sudden halt four miles west of this city about 4 o'clock this afternoon, 126 miles nearer Washington than it was last night.

M. Jacques de Morgan continues to corrode the souls of French and British archaeologists With envy by discovering yet more antiquities at the brick pyramid of Dashur, a day's journey from Cairo. The late Director of Egyptian excavations, M. Maspero, investigated this very pyramid in his time, but was not so lucky, or perhaps was not so systematic as M. de Morgan.

While Sugar was much less active yesterday than in several days it was still the leader in point of activity. The price was fairly steady, moving as it did within a paint all day. The impression was that the manufacturers were acquiring all the stock they could without advancing the quotations.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- The story was in the mouth of every operator on the Stock Exchange this morning that a firm of lawyers had been retained by the Sugar Trust, and this was taken as indicating that, despite the denials of Attorney General Moloney, the trust had information or belief that quo warranto proceedings would be instituted against it.

Boston's champion ball players have not proved very successful on their trip to this vicinity. After losing two of the three games to New-York, they went to Brooklyn yesterday confident of victory, but the boys across the bridge were in fine trim, and put up a game of ball that astonished the bean eaters.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., May 9 -- The line of Thursday's procession, which is to be one of the features of the dedication of the Mary Washington monument, is already marked with a great profusion of flags of every hue and description. The town is rapidly filling up with visitors, but the great bulk of them will arrive Thursday morning.

There was more talk yesterday of letting the jurors in the trial of Dr. Henry Meyer for poisoning Ludwig Brandt, view the body of the man who was burled April 2, 1892, from the flat occupied by the alleged insurance conspirators, at 320 East Thirteenth Street.

At the Gas Engine and Power Company's shops, at Morris Heights, several new yachts are being turned out as rapidly as possible. Two big boats are being built, and several from fifty feet in length to yacht tenders. The biggest boat is a steam yacht for Mr. Christopher Meyer.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- "Coxey's here!" shouted a small page at the House side of the Capitol this morning as the clock was striking the hour of 10. As the boy spoke the leader of the Commonwealers, whose figure is now a familiar one in Washington, came into the chamber, in company with Representative Pence of Colorado.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In one of your editorials on Monday morning you called attention to a story of mine, entitled "The Exiles," in which I describe one of the characters, an American Consul General at Tangier, as a most disreputable person.

Superintendent John Jasper has prepared for the Board of Education his annual report of the condition of the public schools for the year ending Dec. 31, 1893. It makes a large pamphlet, and deals comprehensively with the important features of school work. There were 312 schools in operation last year, of which 141 were primary schools or departments, and 111 grammar schools.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Those who heard to-day the denunciation by Mr. Sherman of "Coxeyism" felt repaid for the time lost in listening to the wild assertions of Mr. Allen of Nebraska, the self-appointed defender of Coxey.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 9 -- In a farmhouse in the town of Scarsdale, on the old Boston Turnpike, four miles south of White Plains, William Schilling, a respectable old German farmer, has resided for the past thirty years. His family consisted of himself and wife, and his son John, the latter's wife, and two small children.

AMHERST, Mass., May 9 -- The first game of the championship baseball series of the New-England College Triangular League resulted in a thorough victory for the home team over Williams. With the exception of a bad fumble by Landis, Amherst played an errorless game. The heavy hitting of the team won the game. Gregory pitched in good form, and received perfect support.

The Rev. Dr. H.M. Field, editor of The New-York Evangelist, exploded a bombshell at the sixty-ninth anniversary meeting of the American Tract Society yesterday in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street, of which the Rev. Dr. C.H. Parkhurst is pastor.
LONDON, May 9 -- Lord Rosebery's Ladas won the Two-Thousand-Guinea Stakes at Newmarket to-day. Lord Arlington's Matchbox was second, and Sir J. Blundell Maple's Athlone third.

The trial trip yesterday of the Priscilla, the new steel passenger steamer of the Fall River Line, was in every way successful, and even the sanguine expectations of her builders were exceeded. Her speed is estimated at 20 knots an hour, and her cost was $1,500,000.

San Francisco, May 9 -- A cablegram from Hakodate, Japan, confirms as probable the reported loss of the schooner Matthew Turner. It is believed all on board, twenty-three in number, were lost. The Turner was a new schooner of its first sealing venture.

NEWARK, N.J., May 9. -- At the May meeting of the Newark Presbytery in the First Presbyterian Church, this afternoon, the Rev. C.T. Haley of Roseville gave notice of his bill of complaint against the Rev. Dr. Paul F. Sutphen, for the latter's utterances on the inerrancy of the Scriptures at the March Presbytery.

LONDON, May 9 -- The National Liberal Club gave a reception to the Ministry this evening. About every Liberal and Radical of any reputation or influence was among tne 4,500 persons present. The speech of the evening was made by the Premier. He said:
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The Senate bar surprised itself and the country by voting, on two amendments to the Tariff bill.

NEW-DORP, S.I., May 9. -- The Grand Jury for the May term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer for this county was sworn in at Richmond to-day. In charging the jury, Justice Edgar M. Cullen referred to the charges of frauds at the elections last Fall. He alluded to the fact that he had heard some of the evidence in the Senatorial contest, and added:

BOSTON, May 9. -- It is announced that foreclosure proceedings will be immediately ordered by the New-York and New-England Reorganization Committee, suit being started upon coupons defaulted. A second default will be made upon the first mortgage bond interest July 1, and the Reorganization Committee will make an offer to the first mortgage bondholders which it is understood will be better than that to the second mortgage bondholders.

Secretary George W. Archer of the Grand Trotting Circuit has Issued a call for a meeting of the Stewards of the several tracks comprising that circuit to be held at Rochester on Wednesday, May 30, at 11 A.M. The principal business is announced to be the arrangement of classes for the meetings at the several tracks, which include the more important ones in this State.
NORWAY, Me., May 9. -- Fire was discovered about 1:30 P.M. in the box shop of C. B. Cummings, originating from a hot journal. The shop was situated on the west end of Main Street.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Public Printer Benedict is taking hold of his office firmly. Circumstances over which he has no control have forced him to attempt to reduce the number of employes in his office by temporarily increasing the number.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- A long letter from the Secretary of State in answer to Senator Gray's resolution concerning the present condition of Samoan affairs was sent to the Senate to-day by the President. The conclusions drawn by Mr. Gresham from his review of the Samoan situation are summarized in the last paragraph as follows:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: As an American who not only reveres the memory of Tennyson, but who is also during part of each year a resident of Freshwater, I have been honored by an appointment to the committee having in charge the erection of a memorial to the late Poet Laureate in the place where he made his home for upward of half a century.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 9. -- The adoption in the Senate Tariff bill of the Fall River schedule for cottons and cotton yarns is regarded by manufacturers in this city and New-Bedford with a great deal of satisfaction.

OMAHA, Neb., May 9. -- The Indian company of United States soldiers at Fort Omaha, which has attracted so much attention as an experiment in civilizing the red man, is now a thing of the past. The soldiers have been formally discharged, have started for their reservations, and the experiment is considered a failure.

AMHERSTBURG, Ontario, May 9. -- The Government revenue cutter Petrel. which last night seized two iron passenger boats, the Visitor of Put-in-Bay and the Leroy Brocks of Bass Island, for violation of the Fishery act, has brought them to this port. They had on board a party of American gentlemen who were fishing with pike and line Just east of Pelee Island.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this, office not later than Thursday evening.)

The Madison Square Theatre was Crowded in every part last night. There is magic in the name of Rose Coghlan. Her new play, however, has no magical qualities. "The Check Book" is a comedy in three acts, of an antique type, a light comedy of love and intrigue with a slender plot long drawn out.

The interscholastic tennis players finished their tournament yesterday afternoon on the courts at William's Bridge. The second match in the semi-flnal round and the final match were played, and, as was expected, Parker proved an easy victor. Besides taking first prize, he will represent the preparatory schools in and near New-York in the final contest for the interscholastic tournament, which takes place at Newport during championship week, next August.

It is remarkable how the appearance of Coxey and his "army" in the flesh has destroyed the possibility of maintaining illusions about them. Even Senator Alien of Nebraska has manifested some shame and some disposition to wash his hands of them, if, as a good Populist, he could be guilty of washing his hands of anything.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- It was the unexpected that happened in executive session this afternoon. It was considerably after 5 o'clock when Mr. Harris moved the session. A number of nominations against which there were no objections were acted upon, and then Mr. Morgan, Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, called up the Russian treaty.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 9. -- Ernestine Dittmar claims that in October, 1860, Ludwig Carlvoltbrecht came to her house as a boarder, and promised to pay a reasonable sum for his board. She went before the Circuit Court here and declared that Ludwig had never paid a cent, although he has lived in her house during this long time.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- "I find that the bill before us is not the Wilson bill, but a bill that ought perhaps to bear the honored name of the senior Senator from Maryland, Mr. Gorman, or the name of the Senator from Ohio, Mr. Brice.

BOSTON, Mass., May 9. -- Over 100 official delegates were present at the opening to-day of the second annual convention of the Working Girls' Clubs. They represented New-York, Philadelphia, Brooklyn, Cincinnati, Richmond, Hartford, New-Haven, Baltimore, Troy, Chicago, Woonsocket, Chicopee, Central Falls, R.I., and Wilmington, Del.

MASSILLON, Ohio, May 9 -- "Gen." Coxey has capitulated before Mrs. Coxey No. 1. The "Goddess of Peace" of the May Day parade returned home unannounced this noon to obviate the abduction proceedings, newspaper reports of which had alarmed the commander in chief. Miss Mamie brought a peace offering in the shape of $20, which she laid upon the lap of her mother, who is far from satisfied.

Two members of the Prospect Park Police Department, among under instructions from Park Commissioner Squier, at a late hour on Tuesday night endeavored to prevent employes of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company, the successor of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, from erecting trolley poles on Ocean Avenue, which is under the control of the Park Department.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- In opposition to news of a ecidedly bearish character, the market for wheat showed wonderful strength to-day. On the curb yesterday afternoon the reported revolution in Argentina had the effect of advancing prices, but at the opening to-day there was an easier feeling on the failure to confirm the rumors, combined with weak and lower English cables and fine weather.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 9. -- Three hundred and twenty-five delegates from thirty-seven States and 500 other women were present in the drawing room of the New Century Club this morning when the second biennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs was called to order by the President, Mrs. Charlotte Emerson Brown of East Orange, N.J.
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The President sent to Congress to-day a dispatch, from Minister Willis to Secretary Gresham, dated at Honolulu, April 14. In his dispatch Mr. Willis says:
AKRON, Ohio, May 9. -- Akron has been under martial law to-day, and will remain so for several days.

C.F. Cutter, who has charge of the Daily Noon Prayer Meetings at 113 Fulton Street, received the following request from a "wicked Elder" in South Carolina: "Will you pray for me, a wicked Elder in the Presbyterian Church of this place?" This was only one of a large number of petitions for prayers which Mr. Cutter's mail brought to him yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Dr. Guzman, the Nicaraguan Minister, has received, information, which he has communicated to the State Department, that the Nicaraguan Government has restored the exequatur of Sigmund C. Braida, the United States Consul at Grey-town, or, more properly, San Juan del Norte, who with Mr. Bingham, the British Consul, fell into the bad graces of the local authorities for the part taken by him in the Bluefields affair.

Richard Croker will retire absolutely to-day from the leadership of Tammany Hall, which he has held for the past nine years, the most successful period the organization has had in its history. The Committee of Sixty, or Executive Committee, will meet at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, and then Mr. Croker will resign his leadership.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 9. -- Victor Harburg and three other workmen at Hill Farm plant were beaten almost to death this morning. The attack was made so suddenly that the deputies were unable to protect the men before the mob swooped down on them and had beaten the men into insensibility.

The annual meeting of the National Academy of Design was held yesterday afternoon at the Academy building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. The principal business was the election of the following officers: Council, Thomas W. Wood, President; H. Robbins, Vice President; J. C. Nicoll, Corresponding Secretary; George H. Smillie, Recording Secretary; James D. Smillie, Treasurer; members of the council, Edwin H. Blashfield, H. Bolton Jones, Thomas Moran James M. Hart, O.L. Warner, and Walter Sheldon.

From The Macon (Ga.) Telegraph, (Dem.) The New-York Times has recently made an investigation, covering a few towns only, which shows that a very large proportion of the pension money is paid to rich men, in no need whatever of help from the Government, for ailments or injuries of which their closest friends are ignorant.

There were any number of depressing stories current in Wall Street yesterday, but the market nevertheless showed more strength than it has for some time. This condition of affairs was regarded as pretty fair evidence of the existence of a short interest of considerable dimensions. It was also additional proof of the indisposition of investors to part with their holdings at prevailing prices.

ALBANY, May 10 -- The special commission appointed by Gov. Flower to reinvestigate the administration of affairs of the Elmira Reformatory will convene in Elmira to-morrow morning and arrange for the prosecution of the investigation. F.R. Coudert of New-York City and ex-Deputy Attorney General F.B. Gilbert will represent the parties who make the charges against the institution and its officers.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Representative Robert F. Brattan of the First District of Maryland is dead. The announcement of his death came in the following dispatch:

Ordinarily, a trip by water from Washington to this city is not one likely to excite comment. Such trips are usually made via the Atlantic Ocean, Chesapeake Bay, and the Potomac River. But the torpedo boat Gushing, which arrived yesterday, succeeded in finding her way here from Washington without having touched Atlantic waters.

Regina, Manitoba, May 10 -- Antonio Lucanic was hanged this morning for the murder of Yerolla Relivalla, an Italian scissors grinder, at Grenfell, in June last. On the scaffold, he declared his innocence of the crime, but said he had confessed to save his companion, D. Egidio, from death. Egidio's sentence has been commuted to imprisonment for life.
Mayor Schieren's stiff backbone yesterday led him to make three declarations of great interest to the people of Brooklyn as to his future policy. He announced that he would allow:

ALBANY, N.Y., May 10 -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Senator Robertson's bill providing for a Park Commission in New-York City to consist of two members, one a Democrat and the other a Republican. In his veto the Governor says:
Permits like this were issued last evening: Department of Public Works. -- Admit bearer to execution of Tip. G.R. BURNS.
By the verdict of a jury in the Supreme Court, before Justice Patterson, yesterday. Mrs. Paran Stevens must pay $125 to Col. Edward Gebhard for legal services.

LONDON, May 10. -- The Pall Mall Gazette publishes an interview with Capt. Alfred T. Mahan, commander of the United States cruiser Chicago, now lying at Gravesend. Capt. Mahan declined to discuss the naval programme of Earl Spencer, First Lord of the Admiralty, but expressed the opinion that the naval supremacy of Great Britain was more vital to tier now than ever before in her history.

NORWAY, Me., May 10 -- Two-thirds of the town was laid waste by yesterday's fire, and many of the people who could not find shelter in the two hotels which were saved or in unburned dwelling houses spent the night in tents or shelters made of cloth from stores or sheets from beds.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- There is a proposition on foot to bridge or tunnel the Niagara River between some point oh the mainland between Buffalo and Tonawanda and Grand Island. A few days ago a party composed of Tonawanda and Grand Island men came to Washington to advocate the passage of the bill recently introduced by Mr. Lockwood of Buffalo, calling for the construction of a bridge or tunnel.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. Jacob Cole sold, at $3,700, to Lucinda Pettit, the three-story brick dwelling 232 South Fifth Street, north side, 150 feet east of Roebling Street, 20 by 91.9 1/2 by 20 by 92.4. To J. Kingston, at $2.400. he sold the two-story frame dwelling, with store, 447 Hudson Avenue, east side, 273.6 feet south of Lafayette Street, 23.6 by 100.

Incipient booms for ex-President Harrison and for William McKinley met at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon. It was delightfully entertaining to those who were permitted to witness the encounter, which developed some very skillful work on the part of a few friends of each of the alleged aspirants for Presidential honors.
BALTIMORE, May 10. -- The Manufacturers' Record, in its weekly review of Southern business interests, says:
CINCINNATI, May 10. -- A gang of desperate tramps attempted to capture a Big Four passenger train at Lockland last night.

The Long Island Chapter of the Daughters of the Revolution celebrated the anniversary of the capture of Ticonderoga and the battles of Long Island last night at Wilson's Pierrepont Assembly Rooms. Three hundred members and guests were there, Mrs. Horatio C. King, Regent, occupying the chair and making the address of welcome.

Why the Senate committee now proposes that the duty on steel beams shall be six-tenths of a cent a pound (or $13.44 per ton, which is exactly the McKinley duty on steel rails,) we do not Know, but there are many good reasons why this increase of the Wilson bill's rate should not be made.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -- The United Press correspondent at Honolulu, writing under date of the 3d inst., per steamer Alameda, which arrived this afternoon, says:

BOSTON, May 10. -- Local stocks were even duller than they have been, lately, and there was absolutely no feature of interest. Dominion Coal was steady at 23. Bell Telephone improved a little, selling at 190 1/2 for small lots. Mexican Central stock weakened 1/4, to 7 1/4, in sympathy, probably, with the decline in the 4s yesterday.

Mr. Anthony Comstock is a very well-meaning person, and on the whole he is a very well-doing and well-deserving person. There can be no doubt that his efforts for the suppression of vice have resulted in averting a great deal of mischief from the young, and in preventing the poisoning of a great many minds.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The May report of the statistician of the Department of Agriculture after consolidating the returns, places the condition of Winter wheat at 81.4, as against 86.7 the previous month, being a falling off of 5-3 points. In 1893 at the same date, the condition was 75.3, a little over two points lower than the previous month.
ALBANY, May 10 -- Gov. Flower has appointed Nehemiah Osborne, Esq., as Trustee of the New-York State Institution for the Blind, at Batavia, to succeed Jacob B. Whiteman.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 10 -- The coal operators of the Plttsburg district are more at sea now than at any other time since the suspension of work. The result of to-morrow's conference between river and rail operators cannot be foretold. The railroad operators favor a uniform rate for mining and a settlement of the strike as soon as possible.

In his estimates for the next fiscal year the Secretary of Agriculture asked that $700,000 should be appropriated for the use of the Bureau of Animal Industry. The House Committee on Agriculture has added $100,000, to be expended in preventing the spread of tuberculosis among cattle.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 10 -- The riots of last week have had good effect upon some of the unemployed foreigners. Yesterday thirty-five people took passage for the old country, to remain. Others are leaving for their homes in Poland, Hungary, Bohemia, and Italy. They say conditions are better in the old country than here.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- According to the order issued yesterday by the District Commissioners, Gen. Coxey would have to remove his camp by Saturday morning, but this order was modified to-day by the Commissioners. Coxey had a hearing before them at noon to-day, and explained that it would be impossible for him to get his men out on so short a notice.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- "Coxeylsm" again occupied the attention of the Senate for two hours to-day. The Allen resolution, which calls for an investigation of the methods employed by the Capitol police in subduing Coxey May 1, came up again, and served as the basis of a lecture on paternalism by Mr. Gordon of Georgia.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Curator of the Smithsonian Institution is anxious to give the valuable publications of that establishment wider distribution. He has been confined to lines of strictest economy in publishing the scientific works of his office. The edition of 3,000 copies now printed is only sufficient to supply, in limited measure, the urgent requests from public libraries, educational institutions, and scientific investigators in the United States and throughout the world.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 10 -- The United Press correspondent at Apia, Samoa, writes as follows, under date of April 25, per steamer Alameda:

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The cornerstone of the new home of the Corcoran Art Gallery, on the corner of Seventeenth, Street and New-York Avenue, opposite the State, War, and Navy Building, and looking out upon the White House grounds, was laid this afternoon. On account of the recent death of one of the Board of Trustees, who had taken much interest in the building, the ceremonies were very simple.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., May 10. -- The weather being propitious, there was nothing in the way to-day of a most successful celebration of the event to which patriotic women, and the people of Virginia particularly, have looked forward for so many months -- the dedication of the monument to Mary Washington, the mother of the first President.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I ask the favor of addressing your readers for the purpose of making a plea for assistance in protecting the grass and flowers of our parks. During this month and a portion of the next most of the flowering shrubs and vines come in bloom. Now is the time for the lilacs and the wistarias, and their equally beautiful companions.

MONTREAL, May 10 -- Play in the championship chess has been postponed until Saturday, inasmuch as Lasker claimed a day off on account of a slight indisposition. Steinitz, who feels pretty good, seemed also pleased at the postponement, as each off day gives him additional rest.

All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, at Madison Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, was the scene of an important wedding: at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when Miss Elizabeth Lewis Newton and William Wells Bosworth, formerly of Boston, and nephew of the Rev. Dr. W.R. Huntington, rector of Grace Church, were married.

Fire insurance was discussed at length yesterday at the Mutual Life Building, where the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters was held. About seventy-five companies were represented. President D.W.C. Skilton's address was the most important paper presented.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 11 -- Fire started early this morning along the canal front and before the flames were extinguished property was damaged to the extent of $60,000.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- The General Federation of Woman's Clubs this morning squelched a proposition to join forces with the National Council of Women.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: There can be no question that a considerable section of the opposition to the granting of the franchise to women rests neither on prejudice, selfishness, ignorance, fear of competition, pride of power, nor conceit, but on fear of the results to the people; in other words, upon distrust of popular self-government -- distrust of government of the people, by the people, for the people.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- There were a few moments of activity at the opening of the wheat market to-day, and a few moments at the close, but the remainder of the session was as dull as it was featureless. The monthly blockade to business, which usually presents itself about this time and which arises from the uncertainty surrounding the Government report, was on.

The two-day national and International reception to the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage arranged by a committee of distinguished public men of Brooklyn in honor of the completion of the twenty-fifth year of his pastorate at the Tabernacle drew to that spacious sacred edifice last night a brilliant audience, which was limited in size only by the capacity of the great church.

OMAHA, Neb., May 10 -- At the open meeting of the Ancient Order of Hibernians' convention, held at Exposition Hall last night, Congressman Weadock of Michigan, who brought the attention of Congress to the American Protective Association, scored that organization severely. He said: "This is a country where none of our civil rights can be impaired because of our religious beliefs.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Secretary Lamont has approved the plan of Gen. Casey, Army Chief of Engineers, for the improvement of Yellowstone National Park. Gen. Casey's scheme includes the repair, maintenance, restoration, and construction of roads, bridges, and paths necessary to reach objects of interest in the park. The work of road construction is of such a nature that it is impossible to accurately describe it without expensive preliminary surveys.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 10. -- The Trustees of Williams College met here to-day, there being present Charles A. Davison, New-York City; James M. Barker, Pittsfield; Horace E. Scudder, Cambridge; James White, Williamstown; Justin Kellogg, Troy, N.Y.; Justin Dewey, Springfield; Charles B. Hubbell, New-York City, and President Carter.

The inquiry into alleged irregularities in the past management of the Northern Pacific Railroad was resumed yesterday in the Mills Building before the Master in Chancery, Alfred L. Cary. W.D. Searies, Vice President of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, was the first witness examined. It was on the application of that company, acting as the trustee for the bondholders of the Northern Pacific Road, that the present receivers were appointed.

BOSTON, May 10 -- James A. Garland of New-York has chartered the schooner Hope Leslie, through Waterhouse Cheseboro of this city. The yacht is now at Lawley's, and will be fitted out at once and sail for New-York by the 1st of June. Capt. Rand will be in command. The Hope Leslie has been remodeled within a year or two and has been given a modern bow and stern.

The Governor has vetoed the Bi-Partisan Park Commission bill, which he justly observes was a political measure whose sole object was a "division of the spoils in the Park Department of New-York City, demanded at the point of the legislative bayonet." It provided for the appointment of two Park Commissioners of opposite "political faith and opinion" in the place of the present board.
Richard Croker, leader of Tammany Hall for the last nine years, resigned his leadership and everything that can be regarded as connected therewith yesterday afternoon.

MOUNT VERNON, Ind., May 10 -- A tornado visited this city about 2 o'clock this afternoon, doing much, damage to property. Trees were blown down, fences scattered to the winds, and many buildings were unrooted. The storm came from the northwest, and was very rapid in its flight.

There was a sensation in the murder trial Of Dr. Henry Meyer yesterday. It lasted only a few hours, when explanations were made that dissipated it, but while it lasted it caused more interest than almost anything else that has so far some to the surface in the trial.

LONDON, May 10. -- Herbert Henry Asquith, Secretary of State for Home Affairs, was married in St. George's Church. Hanover Square, at noon to-day to Miss Margot Tennant, daughter of Sir Charles Tennant of Glasgow. The ceremony was a most brilliant affair.

BOSTON, May 10. -- The second day's session of the second annual convention of Working Girls' Clubs opened in Parker Memorial Hall this morning at 9:30. The hall was filled with the delegates and visitors.

There has been a pretense all along that The Jockey Club was an organization in the interest of horse owners and the public. The selection of John Hunter as Chairman of the Board of Stewards tended considerably to shake this belief, as Mr. Hunter had been Chairman of the Board of Control, which The Jockey Club was organized to supersede.
The New-York women interested in making a protest to the State Constitutional Convention against woman suffrage have announced the following additional signatures to their petitions:

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 10 -- Mrs. William Schilling, who was shot twice on Tuesday evening by her husband's brother-in-law, Joseph Schnellback, was very much improved to-day. This morning she walked down stairs to breakfast, although there is still a bullet in her body. Dr. Curtiss of White Plains, who attended her, said the bullet had not struck any dangerous part and that be thought Mrs. Schilling would recover.

From The Boston Saturday Evening Gazette. A would-be humorous writer in a weekly paper devoted to the instruction of young people points out what he calls the fact that a straight line between two towns may not be as short as a crooked line, if the straight line runs up and down over the bills and the crooked line runs around the hills.

New-Yorks won an easy game yesterday. The Senators are here from Washington to be the guests of the Giants for three days, and if they do not make a better showing than they did in the first of the series, the chances are that Capt. Ward's men will have an excellent opportunity to make up for lost ground.

The Fine Arts Society does not intend to let its galleries on West Fifty-seventh Street remain unused during the hot months; it is about to open a permanent exhibition of paintings -- "The Group Exhibition by American Painters" -- which are to be for sale, and may be renewed from time to time as contributors may elect.
BLUEFIELDS, Mosquito Reservation. Nicaragua, May 6, via New-Orleans, May 10 -- A sensation was created here yesterday by the arrival of Robert Henry Clarence, chief of the Mosquito Indians.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10 -- There was an interesting revelation to-day of how things are sometimes done in the New-Jersey Legislature. It was in connection with the bill for the division of Monmouth County, which passed the House on Tuesday, receiving 31 votes, every one of which was necessary.
