SOMERS CENTRE, N.Y., May 10 -- The one hundredth anniversary of the Mount Zion Methodist Episcopal Church of this vlllage is being celebrated by its members with appropriate services. The church building is the oldest frame church in Westchester County. It is a historic building in many respects, having been described in Cooper's "Spy," together with many interesting incidents with which it has been connected.

LONDON, May 10. -- The House of Commons this evening ordered the second reading of the Budget bill. The vote was 308 to 294. The result gave great satisfaction to the supporters of the Government, for it bad been felt that there was danger that their representatives in the House would be outnumbered by the Opposition.

The highest price ever paid for lots between avenues for dwelling purposes has been obtained for the two, together 50 by 100 feet, in the north side of Sixty-eighth Street, 200 feet east of Fifth Avenue. The broker in the case was Mr. John N. Golding, who has sold the lots for Dr. C.M. Bell to John J. Emery. A handsome residence will be erected on the lots.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The tariff situation in the Senate has not changed materially in the last twenty-four hours. Each side appears to be waiting to see what the other side proposes to do. The Republicans have apparently adopted the plan of offering one or more amendments to every item in the bill, and the Democrats are not informed whether that plan is to be followed until the last schedule is reached.
The Rev. Dr. Henry M. Field, editor of The Evangelist, has not changed his mind about the Rev. Dr. George L. Shearer, Financial Secretary of the American Tract Society.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- This was probably the dullest day for many weeks. The tractions again furnished most of the business done. Although Lehigh Valley was inactive, it was firm around 37 1/4, with no stock for sale below 38 at the close. Pennsylvania vibrated between 49 1/2@49 7/8, but very little was done either way.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The people who are clamoring for haste in the disposition of the Tariff bill, and those who hope that the bill will be out of the way by June 1, will be interested in knowing that a single item of the chemical schedule was to-day disposed of by the Senate. There are over 200 pages of the Tariff bill and more than 80 pages of committee amendments.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- State Senator Jacob A. Cantor of New-York registered at the Arlington to-night. Mr. Cantor has been in Washington several times lately in connection with certain schedules in the new Tariff bill, some of his clients being interested in the changes made by Mr. Jones's committee of revision.

Daniel Frohman's Lyceum Theatre Stock Company will remain next season practically the same as now, as far as the leading artists are concerned. Two members of the company whose contracts expire with this season, E.J. Ratcliffe and Eugene Ormonde, will not be seen with the company again.

NEWARK, N.J., May 11. -- Capt. Sweetland's division of the Commonweal Army, numbering sixty-one men, arrived nere today. They secured sleeping quarters in W. Csernick's saloon. The men say they are determined to continue their tramp until they reach Washington.
BOSTON, May 11. -- At the convention of the Working Girls' Clubs this afternoon, Miss Grace H. Dodge of New-York read a paper on "Domestic Circles."

The eighteenth annual Spring games of the Columbia College Athletic Union took place at the College Oval, at William's Bridge, yesterday. The weather was favorable, and as a result good time was made in roost of the events. In the bicycle race H.K. Bird clipped 2 1/2 seconds off the best collegiate record.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The House today considered the Naval Appropriation bill in Committee of the Whole.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Senator Jones of Arkansas was asked yesterday what foundation there was for the intimation or statements that the amendments recently proposed by him, as is understood, on behalf of the Democratic members of the Finance Committee, are not materially below the rates in the McKinley bill.

It does seem rather absurd that all the scientific acumen at the command of this municipality should have been employed, from early morn until dewy eve, upon the problem how painlessly to remove a superfluous elephant, and should finally have attained a solution, a solution of cyanide of potassium, after some eight hours of hard labor.

Richard Croker's resignation as leader of Tammany Hall led to the General Committee of that organization taking no action with reference to resolutions regarding the Tariff bill. The committee met last evening.

BOSTON, May 11. -- The market for local stocks was dull almost beyond comparison, and there were hardly enough quotations to make a market. Bell Telephone was quoted at 190. Lamson Store Service sold in small lots at 23 3/4. Wisconsin Central 5s sold at 72 1/4, with the stock at 6 15-10. Boston and Albany was steady at 206 3/4, and Old Colony at 175.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs elected officers at noon to-day. The following, who were chosen by the Nominating Committee, were elected:

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 11. -- Gov. Flower's new investigating committee charged with finding out the real facts in the management of the reformatory and the alleged inhuman treatment of inmates by Superintendent Brockway and the misconduct of the gentlemen of the local Board of Managers met at the institution at 11 A.M. to-day.

It is many months since there was such a dull, undisturbed stock market as that of yesterday. The total transactions were only 88,954 shares, and in only two stocks. Sugar and Chicago Gas, did the trading exceed 10,000 shares. The total in Sugar was 21,500 shares and in Gas 15,200. It seemed to suit the books of the manipulators of Sugar to permit the stock to decline, and it dropped 1 1/8 points.

The action of Gov. Flower in signing the Greater New-York bill has now brought the question of consolidation with the metropolis squarely before the people of Brooklyn as a great issue, to be decided by the ballot. From this time until the election next Fall there will be a lively campaign in the City of Churches for and against consolidation.

From The Sun of Yesterday. Mr. Whitelaw Reid arrived from San Francisco two days ago, having Come through direct in five days. The next morning, when a Sun reporter tried to find him at his town house, he had already gone out to Ophir Farm for the day.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 11. -- United States Marshal Neely's special train, bearing, the Cripple Creek legion of the Coxey Industrial Army, under command of Gen. John Sherman Sanders, arrived in Topeka over the Missouri Pacific Road this afternoon at 2 o'clock. The men were locked in the cars, the doors of which were guarded by Deputy Marshals armed with rifles.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The strange spectacle was presented to-day in the Senate chamber of Democrats and Republicans voting together for amendments to the Tariff bill presented by Mr. Jones's committee on revision.
Dr. Henry Meyer's defense to the charge of poisoning Ludwig Brandt was begun yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, before Recorder Smyth.

Lord Rosebery's technical escape from defeat by a majority of fourteen in favor of the Ministry on the Budget bill is really a defeat. A majority of that size is very far from being a working majority. When the returns showed that Mr. Gladstone could muster a majority, including all the Nationalists, of but thirty-nine, the Conservatives insisted that this was not a working majority.

JERSEY CITY, May 11. -- Gov. Werts has been sick since last night with a slight cold. A report had been circulated that he had pneumonia. Gov. Werts said this evening that his throat was slightly sore, but he expected to be out to-morrow as usual.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Coxey's army of tramps will leave its present unwholesome quarters to-morrow morning and establish camp at Spa Spring, near the historic dueling ground at Bladensburg, just over the Maryland line.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The Navy Department expected to-day to hear of the arrival of the United States cruiser New-York at Colon, but no telegram came bearing this information.

Dun's Review will say to-day: "The strikes begin to have a serious, though it is assumed only a temporary, effect. The number of works depending upon supplies of bituminous coal or coke for fuel is large, and quite a considerable proportion of them has already been compelled to stop operations.

It was by an amendment of the Constitution of this State adopted in 1874 that it was provided for the first time that the Governor should have thirty days after the close of a session of the Legislature in which to consider measures that had passed, but had not been approved at that time, and that no bill which he failed to approve within that period should become a law.

Malcolm W. Ford, at one time probably the best-known athlete in the United States, and who was disinherited by his father, Gordon L. Ford, because of his fondness for athletic sports, was yesterday defeated in his suit to compel his brothers and sisters to carry out the provisions of an agreement which he alleged they made with him, by Which he was to share in the estate.

Fred Hoey added the Lachmont Cup and sweepstakes to his winnings in pigeonshooting matches yesterday. The cup was a handsome piece of silver, and the sweepstakes amounted to a good sum. As soon as he won Fred had the cup filled with Edgar Murphy's wine, and every one had to drink with him.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 11. -- The second division of the sophomore class, Scientific Section, at Rutgers College has been suspended until the Faculty shall fix punishment for its mischievous pranks. The division has made the life of Prof. W. Loehr, Instructor in Modern Languages, a burden this term by its continued insubordination.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- It would be strange if a feeling of helplessness should not come over Mr. Harris, the Democrat in charge of the Tariff bill, when he considers the obstacles in The way of expeditious action on that measure.

TRENTON, N.J., May 11. -- Gov. Werts's secretary to-day reported that the Governor was confined to his home in Jersey City with a severe cold. Should he be too Ill to consider and act upon the bills now being passed by the Legislature, the session may be prolonged.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The German Ambassador, early in the morning after the compromise Tariff bill was presented, sent a special messenger to the Capitol for a copy of the amendments, and it is quite certain that before that night the German Foreign Office was familiar with the text of the sugar schedule.

Mrs. Mary A. Lavelle jumped up before Judge Ingraham, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, yesterday, and demanded justice before there was any diposition of the case brought against her by the College of St. Francis Xavier to compel her to carry out an agreement made for the transfer of certain property to the college.

MILAN, Mo., May 11. -- Augustus Meeks, his wife, and two children, were murdered last nignt near Browning. Another child was so badly injured that it is not expected she will recover. She is seven years old. The excitement is so intense in the neighborhood, that the murderers will be lynched if they are identifled by the enraged citizens.

But little progress is being made in Brooklyn in forming such a society as that of which the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst is the President. It Is said, however, by some of those who have been engaged in the movement to secure the closing of all the liquor saloons in Brooklyn on Sunday, that an organization will be perfected within a few days.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The publication in The London Tablet of circumstantial statements relating in a way to the reestablishment in the priesthood of Dr. Edward McGlynn after his excommunication by the Pope, and incidentally to the relations of the Apostolic Delegate and Archbishop Corrigan in connection with that case, was brought to the attention of Mgr. Satolli to-day by a United Press representative.
Tip is dead. The big elephant that had been for years the playmate of the children in Central Park, and the terror of Snyder, who was his keeper, was put to an agonizing death yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- The market has narrowed to a point where the transactions amount to practically nothing. Less than 1,000 shares of Reading, no Northern Pacific common, and only 24 shares of Northern Pacific preferred changed hands to-day. St. Paul was the most active stock, traders hammering it as the New-York market weakened.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- An army officer has treated the War Department to a novel exhibition of modesty. Some of the officials consider his action peculiar; others regard it as unwise.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 11. -- The largest meeing in the history of the coal interests of Western Pennsylvania was held behind closed doors in the County Court House to-day. One hundred and twenty-five operators, representing 200 mines -- river and rail -- were present.

DENVER, Col., May 11. -- The protest in the form of a memorial by ex-Gov. Evans to Congress, arguing at length against the Gulf Railroad being included or authorized to be included in the proposed organization of the Union Pacific Road, was read before the Denver Chamber of Commerce and Board of Trade.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 11 -- Gov. Flower approved of the usual number of acts of the Legislature to-day. Just before leaving the Capitol, at 5 o'clock, he stopped for a few minutes to speak with Lieut. Gov. Sheehan, who stopped off on his way to Buffalo from New-York to see how certain measures in which he is interested stand.

DALLAS, Texas, May 11. -- The forty-ninth session of the Southern Baptist Convention was called to order in the Sam Jones Tabernacle at 10 A.M. to-day by President Jonathan Haralson. There were present between 6,000 and 7,000 people. The meeting was opened with devotional exercises by the Rev. Dr. F.H. Pritchard of North Carolina.

Brooklyn Tabernacle was crowded again last night at the second reception to the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage in honor of the completion of his twenty-fifth year as pastor. The affair was international in its character.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Officials of the Navy Department are emphatic in saying that the presence of the United States steamship Michigan at Amherstburg, Ontario, where the two American steamers seized by the Canadian patrol ship Petrel are in custody, has no bearing on the seizures.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The question whether Postmaster Dayton of New-York can hold his seat as a member of the Constitutional Convention and at the same time perform his Federal duties as Postmaster of New-York has not yet been officially brought to the attention of either the President or the Postmaster General.

Several sales of note were reported yesterday. The one of most general interest was that of a site for the St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, which has been without a home for nearly three years. Its property at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, known for many years, and sometimes inveighed against, as the most expensive Methodist Church edifice in the city, was sold to the United Charities, whose building now graces the site.

Immediately upon the resumption of the Northern Pacific inquiry before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary, in the Mills Building yesterday morning, Vice President Searles of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company testified that he could find no official record of the authorization of the issue of $2,000,000 of stock of the Rocky Fork and Cooke City Railroad.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries to-day ordered favorably reported the bill of Mr. Berry of Kentucky, amending the statutes so as to authorize the Commissioner of Navigation to issue a register or enrollment to vessels of foreign build wrecked and purchased and repaired in the United States by a citizen of the United States, provided the repairs on the vessel are equal to three-fourths of its cost.

Major Edward Duffy of the Sixty-ninth Battalion, was a proud officer last night when he saw the soldiers of his command make the best appearance they have presented at any public review for several years. While the soldiers marched and countermarched, wheeled and charged in Madison Square Garden, fully 3,000 persons looked on and applauded.

CREEDMOOR. L. I., May 11. -- The tenth day of the season for rifle practice at Creedmoor was opened this morning by a detachment from the Thirteenth Regiment of Brooklyn, composed of Companies B, F, G, and K, under the command of Major C. H. Luscomb. The weather was clear until noon, with very light showers in the afternoon.

NORTH YAKIMA, Washington, May 11. -- Another collision occurred near here this morning between Deputy Marshals and Commonwealers. The latter had captured two freight cars, were fired upon, and two of them wounded, but not seriously. One hundred and twenty of the Coxeyites were taken prisoners and locked up in the county jail.

LONDON, May 31. -- A meeting of the committee on the banquet to the Chicago's officers was held this afternoon, with Gen. Lord Roberts in the chair. After some discussion the members decided to hold the banquet in St. James Hall on May 24, Queen Victoria's birthday.

For five innings yesterday the New-Yorks looked like losers, but in the sixth they began scoring runs, and finally tallied enough to win by a single point. It was a well-played and hard-contested game throughout, and the Senators only lost because of their inability to bat Westervelt at critical points.

The great 150-mile relay road race from New-York to Philadelphia, promoted by The New-York Times, is attracting unusual interest. Cyclists in all quarters are favorably impressed with the new rules governing the contest, and if it is a success, the chances are that big runs in the future will be decided by the points gained at the end of each relay.

Among the ritual furniture of the different seets of Buddhism in China, and Japan, vessels for incense of every variety of shape are found, and in our collection at the Burlington Fine Arts Club the incense burners held among the bronzes the same place of importance that the boxes for holding the incense took among the lacquer.

The third annual track athletic games between Princeton and Columbia will be held at the Columbia Field. William's Bridge, next Saturday. These games were organized in the Spring of 1892 by Lloyd Collis and Peter Vredenburgh, Captains of the Columbia and Princeton athletic teams, respectively.

From The London Daily News. It cannot be said of the horse, as Heine said of the monkey, that it does not talk for fear of being put to work. Probably the ultimate degree to which the training of animals may be carried is readied in the case of the talking horse that literally made its bow to the public recently at the Crystal Palace.

The stock market showed less animation yesterday than is usual even on a Saturday in midsummer. The stocks which were prominent were Chicago Gas, Sugar, St. Paul, and General Electric, in the order named. The first named was particularly strong, and the upward movement in it gave character to the general market.

A number of Laplanders, who have been engaged by the United States Government to Instruct Alaskans in the art of driving and herding reindeer, arrived here yesterday on board the Thingvalla Line steamship Island. The party numbered sixteen in all. It comprised five families, two single men, and four children.

We do not see that the opinion of Corporation Counsel McDonald of Brooklyn makes any clearer the question of the constitutionality of the Ives pool law. Very likely the decision of the Court of Common Pleas in this city in a civil suit cannot be taken as implying an obligation on the part of the authorities to assume that poolselling under the act of 1887 would be an infringement of the criminal law.

The most striking feature of the missionary work at Kaisarieh is the education of the Armenian women, whose social position seems to be even more degraded than that of their Turkish sisters. With the native Armenians, as with the Turks, fleshiness adds much to the price of a wife. The wife of a missionary is to them an object both of wonderment and contempt.

This narrow track between the fir trunks was not the most frequented way across the woods, but it was the nearest way from the river to the gardens, and it was the path which the salmon fishers had generally used.

Opinion in Williamsburg is divided as to whether Mrs. Kate Bradford of 658 Bedford Avenue is a suicide or a fugitive, but all opinions agree that, whether dead or alive, her financial transactions show her to have been a very clever woman indeed.

In aspect he was indifferent or insensible to every passing sight or sound. One day the snow from a roof fell upon him as he went to his house.

Hydrogen occupies a unique position among terrestrial substances. Although the lightest of gases, it possesses unmistakable metallic properties. Like metals, it is strongly electro-positive; like metals, it is a conductor of heat and electricity, improving in this respect with increased density, while other gases conduct worse the more closely their particles are concentrated.

ELMIRA, May 12 -- The proceedings of the first day of the reformatory investigation here made it evident to the enemies of the institution, who rode rough-shod over everything at the first alleged investigation, that the tribunal which is now trying the case is far different from the first. The court gave evidence that it intends to proceed upon the proper theory.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, May 12 -- The torpedo boat Ericsson, the first war vessel ever built on inland waters, was successfully launched this afternoon in this city from the docks of the Iowa. Iron Works, amid salvos of artillery and the plaudits of 20,000 people who lined the shores of the Ice harbor and, crowded the neighboring buildings for blocks around.

Among the many loyal friendships formed in the class of '71 at Pierson there was not one so fervent and enduring as that between Harold Markham and Alfred Jermaine. I, on the part of Germaine, my humble self, can vouch for its unfeigned sincerity, and as for Markham, why, I would, of course, vouch even the stronger for him.

From The Boston Saturday Evening Gazette. In a little book treating of the social conditions of Western Massachusetts in the early part of this century, some amusing differences are noted in the manner of living. In the families of well-to-do people in such a town as Northampton, bread and milk was the regular diet for breakfast and supper, while the poor, who could not afford wheat flour and milk, made two meals on bean porridge.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 12 -- The season is fast drawing to a close, and in a fewdays Lakewood will look back upon one of the most successful seasons in its history as a resort. The Laurel House, which will remain open until the 1st of June, has a good booking until that date, while nearly or quite all the cottagers remain to enjoy the fine weather of May.

"Buffalo Bill's" great Wild West Show opened at Ambrose Park, South Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, in a blaze of glory, and amid a shower of ringing coin thrown, by the 20,000 people who occupied seats in the grand stands.
In order to reply to the reporter's question, Prof. Glardon, the wise man of New-Rochelle, quitted his atlas and his celestial spheres and interrupted for a moment his profound calculations.

The past week has been one of exceptional interest to breeders and vendors of horses, for the market has been one most varied in character. Horses of all kinds have been Under the hammer of the various auctioneers, and the sales have followed one another so rapidly as to test well the power of the market to absorb the offerings.

"This is what I call hard luck." said Manager Schmelz of the Washington Club yesterday, after his team had been beaten in three successive games by the New-Yorks. "We are playing good ball, but for some unaccountable reason we can't win. During all my experience, I never saw a team play so unfortunately.

BERLIN, May 12 -- The Prussian Landtag will reassemble on Thursday, and probably will sit a month before the close of the session. The Conservatives, meantime, are likely to negotiate an entente with the National Liberals concerning the Constitution of the Chambers of Agriculture, the subject of the most important measure of the session.
ALBANY, May 12 -- Gov. Flower to-day vetoed twenty bills. Among them were:

There are a certain number of cynical persons who maintain that the world is growing much too small for them. We are all, they say, coming down to the same gray level. Everybody is pursuing money, and pursuing it by the most prosaic and Hebraic methods. It is the same everywhere.

LIVERPOOL, May 12 -- The annual convention of the Irish National League of Great Britain was opened here this morning, T.P. O'Connor, M.P., President of the leagrue, presiding. There was a full attendance of the leaders of the Irish Party, among them John Dillon, M.P.; Timothy M. Healy, M.P.; Arthur O'Connor, M.P.; Timothy D. Sullivan, M.P.; Thomas J. Condon. M.P., and others of lesser note.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- The fourth annual race meeting of the Philadelphia Country Club on the club's half-mile course near this city, this afternoon, attracted an assemblage of 2,000, in which society was well represented. The races were exciting, the last one, the Belmont Steeplechase, particularly so. In this event Passmore stumbled over the first hurdle, and the horse and Jockey Griffin fell in a heap.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Wheat -- The trade opened to-day with the same feeling of depression and discouragement that was so prominent yesterday. The only demand came from shorts, and they were not eager to buy, while the selling was general and was mostly of long wheat. To the bulls the outlook appears very gloomy. There was not an argument to-day which could by any means be twisted into favoring better prices.

From The Boston Journal. Charles P. Jenney, the parrot, is the property of Mate William F, Jenney, United States Navy, now curator of the Lyceum in the Charlestown Navy Yard. Mr. Jenney is an old sailor. He began service before the mast when but fifteen years of age, and has followed the sea ever since.

SING SING, N.Y., May 12 -- The County of Westchester has been the home of some of the most illustrious lawyers this country has produced. At the present time it is the place of residence of a very large number who practice occasionally in the County Courts, but whose offices are in the metropolis.

TACOMA, Washington, May 12 -- Sympathizers with the Coxey movement here are much excited over the news of the fight between tramps and Deputy Marshals in Eastern Washington. P.C. Egbert, a prominent Populist, is said to have stated that he has 1,000 men ready to release the Coxeyites who are now being brought front Yakima under arrest.

Sunol's reproduction of his statue of Columbus, which is on the Prado at Madrid, was unvelled to the Mall in Central Park yesterday afternoon, under the auspices of the New-York Genealogical and Biographical Society, by Vice President. Adlai E. Stevenson, in circumstances rendered agreeable by the delightful weather, and impressive by the presence of many distinguished persons, a large al fresco audience, and several addresses of note.

AUBURN, N.Y., May 12 -- For two hours this afternoon Frank L. Wilson visited his brother, "Dink" Wilson, the convicted, murderer of Detective Harvey. The conversation, which was held in the corridor outside of the condemned man's cell, was for the most part in relation to the trial before Justice McLennan, which each of the brothers claims was unfair.

LENOX, Mass., May 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes, their entire family and several guests are here at the Cliffwood Street cottage, and are watching with much interest the progress made on their immense new cottage near Stockbridge Bowl. Over 100 men are now at work upon the place.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- A graphic account of the difficulties encountered in arresting opium smugglers in the Puget Sound district of Washington is contained in a report sent to the Treasury Department by Capt. W. D. Roath of the revenue cutter Wolcott, stationed at Port Townsend. Suspecting smuggling operations at Deption Pass, near Port Townsend, Capt. Roath had a cabin built there and put Seaman Julius Ipsen in charge.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- The Presidents of the Eastern lines have signed the east-bound freight pool. The document is now in the hands of Aldace F. Walker, who has been selected as sole arbitrator in deciding the proportion of tonnage each line shall carry. It was decided, after much discussion, that there should be a division of tonnage pool until Congress changed the inter-State commerce law so as to admit of all kinds of pooling.

NORTHPORT, L.I., May 12 -- The steamer Mystery, owned by Dexter K. Cole of North port, L.I., went ashore about 200 feet west of Baton's Neck Life-Saving Station this morning. The steamer was on her way across the Sound from South Norwalk, Conn., having aboard a party of twenty-five members of the Federation of Free Thinkers of America.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: My attention has been called to certain lying statements that have appeared in the press, and upon the basis of which I presume your editorial of this morning was written.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 12. -- The many streams of water on the south side of Long Island that supply the reservoirs of the Brooklyn water system, have recently been subjected to a careful inspection and survey. The entire watershed has been renovated, and all objectionable buildings and outhouses removed.

SARATOGA. N.Y., May 12 -- The one hundred and sixth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church North will open in this city Tuesday next. The chief business of the opening session will toe the sermon by the retiring Moderator, Willis Green Craig of McCormick Theological Seminary, Chicago, and the devotional exercises that follow.

Philadelphia, June 7, 1837 Dear Sir: I with pleasure, reply to your letter of yesterday. The exposition alluded to in my letter to the President of the 10th of July, 1883, was the one which Mr. McLane delivered to the President in March or April of that year -- the same paper that is alluded to in my third letter to the people, dated Feb. 22, 1834, as Mr. McLane's opinion on the deposit question.

From London Truth. The county gentlemen are up in arms against Sir William Harcourt's assimilation of death dues on realty and personalty, and by the dues being made progressive. In a few generations, they say, our estates, if large, will pass out of our families by the operation of this estate duty.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 12 -- Mrs. Carrie S. Plumb, widow of Senator Preston B. Plumb, through her attorneys, to-day filed suit in the Lyon County District Court, at Emporia, against Calvin S. Hood, for twenty years the business partner of Senator Plumb, demanding an accounting of profits realized from the Orion Lode mining claim, in Lake County, Colo., which was owned jointly by the two men.

BUDA-PESTH, May 12 -- The Pesther Lloyd publishes an inspired article, in which it is demanded that Emperor Francis Joseph shall give to Prime Minister Wekerle some conspicuous assurance of his confidence as a refutation of the published statement that the courtier members of the Hungarian House of Magnates voted against the Civil Marriage bill in accordance with the wish of the Emperor.

The "one hundredth half-yearly general meeting" of the Midland Railway Company was held at Derby in February this year, but the actual date of the Jubilee of the great corporation is a little later, for it was on the 10th of May, 1844, that the Midland Railway was formed by the amalgamation of the Midland Counties, the North Midland, and the Birmingham and Derby systems of lines.

CUMBERLAND, Md., May 12. -- The situation in the George's Creek coal region to day is about the same as yesterday. Very few of the mines are working. This morning 800 striking miners from Lonaconing, the largest mining town in the county, swooped down on the village of Eckhart, where is located one of the principal mines operated by the Consolidation Coal Company, and attempted to prevent the men from going to work.

Edward Edes, Treasurer and Assistant Secretary of the Oregon and Transcontinental Company, continued his testimony in the Northern Pacific hearing before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Gary, in the Mills Building, yesterday. At the request of Lawyer Pettit, representing the Northern Pacific management, he produced, memoranda showing who paid over the money for the Chicago and Northern Pacific bonds, giving the names and dates of each payment, the total payments aggregating $9,491,000.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- Before a gathering of fully 10,000 persons, the University or Pennsylvania team to-day administered the worst defeat probably ever suffered by a Tale baseball nine. The attendance at the game was the largest ever seen on the University grounds, and in noise-producing qualities certainly capped the climax.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 12 -- The following companies were, incorporated to-day with the Secretary of State:

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The net result of the work to-day of the Senate on the Tariff bill is the adoption of two of the amendments proposed by the Committee on Revision. One makes the duty on tannic acid, or tannin, 60 cents a pound, and the other gives tartaric acid an ad valorem rate of 20 per cent.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12 -- Not until this morning did it leak out that ex-Mayor Joseph E. Haynes had stolen a march on his successor and on the Republicans of Newark just prior to the end of his administration by filling the vacancy in the Board of Street and Water Commissioners caused by the expiration of the three-year term for which Commissioner Ferdinand Albert Hahn had been appointed.

From London Truth. The Healthy and Artistic Dress Union has recently been holding a meeting for the propagation of the views of its members on reforming the present style of costume worn by both men and women, but especially the latter. Their object, if not worthy of the highest encouragement, does not, on the other hand, challenge any very great amount of opposition.

The dramatic season wanes very slowly. In the middle of May nearly all the theatres of New-York are still open, and no less than four plays, new to this city, will be produced to-morrow and Tuesday nights. "The Passing: Show," produced at the Casino last night, and described in another column of The New-York Times to-day, must be added to the list of new plays of this week.

When the commission was created four years ago to revise the judiciary article of the State Constitution, one of the subjects to which it devoted a good deal of attention was the expediency of consolidating the several courts of concurrent jurisdiction in different parts of the State, especially those in this city.

For the mother's gowns fashion lays down rigid lines, which she and the women she meets everywhere follow.

From The Washington Post. The ornithologist of the Agricultural Department has issued his annual appeal for the destruction of the English sparrow. He says by far the best way to fight the pest is by the destruction of its nests and young. Full 90 per cent, of the nests may be reached by means of a long pole with a hook on the end.

From The London Globe. At the annual meeting of the Zululand Mission, which was held at the Church House, Westminster, recently, Mr. Rider Haggard said he concurred with observations previously made by the Bishop of Cape Town with reference to the heavy responsibility which rested upon England as the outcome of the unjustifiable war which she waged upon the Zulus a few years ago.

WEDNESDAY, May 16 -- By James a McQuillen of D. Phoenix Ingraham Co., foreclosure sale. Perry J, Fuller, referee, southwest corner of Laight and Collister Streets. 25 by 87.6. six-story brick store building. Due on judgment, 58,530.

Recently the press announced that Thomas Adamson of Cedartown, Ga., had received from the Emperor of China the star and insignia of the Order of the Double Dragon. Mr. Adamson's life has been a most interesting one. Until recently he was Consul General of the United States at Panama, and perhaps the most experienced officer in the service.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The vacancies in the Congressional delegation from Maryland, caused by the death of Representative Brattan and the appointment of Representative Compton as Naval Officer of the port of Baltimore, will not be filled until November, when elections will toe held for the unexpired terms of these members and for the full term of the Fifty-fourth Congress.
The reporter counted nine May queens in eleven blocks, of Amsterdam Avenue, and he said to himself: "It is true, it is May."

One of the features of the cycling season will be the 150-mile relay road race, for which The New-York Times offers handsome gold medals. The start will be made in front of The Times office at 8 A.M. on June 2, and the course to Philadelphia will be a roundabout one, already published in these columns.

The Cafe Savarin, in the Equitable Building, at the corner of Broadway and Pine Street, which has become one of the most celebrated restaurants in the world, is not satisfied with its past achievements, but has a number of changes in contemplation which will tickle the palates of its customers and enhance its prestige still more.

Thomas Q. Seabrooke and his comic opera company begin a four weeks' season at the Broadway Theatre to-morrow night, presenting; for the first time in this city, "Tobasco." by Barnet and Chadwick. The scene of the new opera is laid in Tanglers, and the story is woven about the abnormally-developed appetite for condiments of the Bey of that country.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- It begins to look as though Washington would be one of the best-represented of American cities abroad during the present Summer if but half of the number of Continental trips at present under contemplation are finally carried out.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The report of the sub-committee on the action of Judge Jenkins of Milwaukee in restraining the employes of the Northern Pacific Railway from striking was not considered by the Judiciary Committee yesterday, owing to the absence of the Chairman of the sub-committee making the investigation.

TRENTON, May 12 -- There are many interesting bills among the several hundred now on the calendar in the New-Jersey Legislature, but none invites so much comment as that introduced during the week by Assemblyman Watson of Camden, which is aimed against the multiplication of millionaires.

Assistant District Attorney Mclntyre had a conference yesterday with Recorder Smyth regarding the story of the alleged drugging or attempted drugging of Dr. Henry Meyer's wife, given out on Friday by Charles W. Brooke and Dr. O'Sulllvan of the counsel for the defense.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Secretary Gresham has directed Mr. Pierce M.B. Young, United States Minister to Honduras, to investigate charges of atrocity made by Mrs. Emma G. Reuton of New-York. If Mr. Young finds that the allegations are correct he is to demand the punishment of the guilty parties.

From The London Telegraph. London is, beyond all question, the most marvelous city that ever existed. Tons of volumes have been written about its mysteries and curiosities, and yet every day, brings to light something fresh and novel. Who, outside the borders of Kennlngton,, ever heard before of the "Hlgh-Hat Musical Society ? "

LONDON, May 12 -- Among the most persistent supporters of the Government the question is being seriously debated whether immediate dissolution is not the very best policy to be pursued in the present circumstances.

BOSTON, Mass., May 12 -- A probable murder and a suicide were committed at 7:40 o'clock this morning in Lustin's stable, at 122 Hudson Street, South End, when Edward Cahill shot James T. Flood and then killed himself.

We did not wait for daylight on the morning of Feb. 16, 1865, for the final movement against Columbia, but awoke to find the rain and bombarding had both ceased. The reason we awoke was because the bugler had been ordered to blow, and we only had time to drink some coffee and eat something that had been left over from the night before, when the order to "fall in" came.

Twenty-five years ago the Right Rev. Abram Newkirk Littlejohn was consecrated as the first Bishop of the Long Island Diocese of the Episcopal Church. Since that event under his wise administration the diocese over which he maintains sway has increased in property value hundreds of thousands of dollars, while its communicants have kept pace with its material prosperity.

PUNTA ARENAS, Straits of Magellan, March 1 -- The most southern town in the world is Punta Arenas, Straits of Magellan. Among English-speaking people Punta Arenas is commonly known as Sandy Point. Sandy Point was the objective point of the United State squadron lying at Montevideo at the time of the threatened trouble between the United States and Chile.

From The Westminster Gazette. Yesterday, at the London Hospital. Mr. Wynne E. Baxter held an inquest respecting the death of Owen Williams, aged about forty-three years, late of 19 Brick Lane, Spitalfields, a common lodging house. Mary Ann McAulift'e, deputy of the lodging house, deposed that the deceased had been a lodger on and off for seven years.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 12 -- The citizens of Topeka are highly indignant at the Government officials and the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company for having brought the Sanders industrial Army to this city. They will be kept here until Wednesday, when the preliminary examination of the men will take place.

Gen. Robert Porter Dechert. Gen. Robert Porter Dechert died in Philadelphia yesterday, after an illness of several months. By profession he was a lawyer, but politics and military affairs engaged much of his attention and won for him great popularity in his State. Gen. Dechert was born in Reading, Penn., Aug. 16, 1842.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 12 -- To-day Yale broke the spell with which for three years Harvard has surrounded track and field, winning the dual championship and the University Cup with a total score of 59 points to Harvard's 53. It was a day for crushing records, six association, three intercollegiate, and two world's records being improved.

From The Chicago Tribune, April 27. Preliminary work incident to taking down the Ferris Wheel on the Midway Plaisance was begun yesterday. This consists of placing false work, engines, and hoisting apparatus. Some day next week the big wheel will turn for the last time in Chicago. At that time several Ferris Wheel Company officials will ride around on the struts that are still in place.

The Fortnightly Shakespearean Club gave its annual dinner at Clark's. In West Twenty-third Street, last night. A feature of the occasion was the presentation to the President. Mrs. Anna Randall Diehi, of a beautifully bound and illustrated copy of the Bankside edition of Shakespeare. Miss Jessie F. O'Oonnell read an original poem on "Shakespeare's Flower Maids."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 12 -- The fourth annual Harvard Interscholastic lawn tennis tournament was begun here to-day on the college courts. There were seventy entries from fourteen schools belonging to the association. This being the largest entry list this event has ever received. Joseph T. Whittelsey, the well-known Secretary of the National Association, acted as referee, while R.D. Wrenn, champion of America, and J.B. Read, Secretary of the college club, assisted him.

An extraordinary story is told by the Paris correspondent of The London Standard. The trial of M. Bertrand, President of the Betting Club, which was recently closed by the police, and of MM. Edouard Robert, banker at Cateau, and Charles Lefevre, a business agent, commenced on Monday, and is leading to scandalous disclosures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: English yachtsmen and yachting journals are building rather formidable obstacles for the Vigilant out of the conditions of yacht racing in English waters. For one thing, they seem to believe that English weather will bother the American boat. That belief can be based only on the assumption that the Vigilant is a distinctively light-weather craft.

To the Editor of The New-York Times The unwarranted use of my name in the editorial column or The New-York Tribune leads me to depart from the general rule of my life and to ask you the courtesy of this public denial.

NEWTOWN, L.I., May 12 -- Rival Boards of Health -- one Democratic and the other Republican -- are -- are making things lively for each, other in this township. Each claims to be the legally constituted body, and both intend to transact the business of the department.

The twenty-one-footers that are to race at Larchmont this Summer are all progressing satisfactorily. The Herreshoffs are building four of them. The one most advanced of this lot is W. Butler Duncan's Hourl. The others that will come from the famous Bristol yards are for C. Oliver Iselin, August Belmont, Royal Phelps Carroll, and J. Lorlllard Ronalds. Mr. Ronalds recently purchased the steam yacht Riva of Pierre Lorillard and is going in for yachting extensively.

All is not peaceful in the Republican organization of Kings County. Ripples of discord are running through the party from one end of the city to the other. They culminated in the contest over direct district representation in the County Committee last week. The defeat of the proposed reform was a resrerse, not only for the prominent party leaders, but for Mayor Schieren as well.

From The London Daily News. The movement is, in great part, a political dodge, a last effort of Protectionist hostility to the Tariff bill. But before the Republicans could use their men in buckram for this purpose they had to have them ready to hand. Our correspsondent tells us how this was contrived.

This is the central county of Scotland in more senses than one, and has the natural and hereditary right to be regarded as queen of the land, it was the first to draw attention hitherward, and still remains the chief attraction. When the Southron talks of the Highlands he means Perthshire; when he starts for the Highlands he arrives in Perthshire.

BOSTON, May 12 -- There was little change to-day in the situation, and the tale of the market for local stocks is but a repetition of that for many days past. Little or no interest was shown, and fluctuations were very narrow, with a tendency to lower prices. Bell Telephone sold at 190 with no sales of other telephone stocks.

The past week has been rather more fruitful in large operations in real estate than many of its predecessors. Among the transactions, furthermore, is one which stands out in relief, not altogether because of the amount involved, but rather because it served to direct renewed attention to the personality and the work of a man who has become a power in his way.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 12 -- Primaries of the Democratic Party were held in the bulk of the counties of this State to-day to select a nominee for Governor. There are only two candidates in the field -- W. C. Oates, present member of Congress from the Third District, and Capt. Joseph J. Johnston of Birmingham.

From The Westminster Gazette. A report upon insanity in Ireland, which has just been issued, enumerates, among the causes of mental failure, the innutritious dietary of the poorer population, tending to produce anaemia and constitutional weakness which favor the development of scrofulous and neurotic disease, and the immoderate use of certain nervous stimulants, particularly tea and tobacco.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 12. -- The city was filled with people from this and surrounding Counties to-day to attend the races, and a careful investigation showed that Col. Breckinridge will have more opposition than was at first supposed.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 12 -- The week's arrivals include Col. and Mrs. Addison Thomas, who have been abroad for two years. Dr. and Mrs. Leyba, and Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Sheldon of New-York, all of whom have opened their cottages.

ALBANY, May 12 -- The most humane work ever undertaken and maintained by the State, the care of the insane poor, is now thoroughly and firmly established on a permanent basis. This end has not been attained without encountering and overcoming the most determined opposition.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- It was with no little chagrin that Mr. Harris, who is in Charge of the Tariff bill, was forced to agree to an adjournment to-day at 4 o'clock, by reason of the lack of a quorum. There had been a struggle for some time to Keep a quorum in the Chamber, but one by one the Senators slipped away, until finally the roll call showed that only thirty-five could be mustered.

There have come to the notice of the authorities of the United States Treasury the most gross and glaring frauds in Chinese registration under the Geary law. It is believed from evidence in the possession of the authorities that there have been issued in this city alone several hundred, perhaps a couple of thousand of fraudulent certificates.

ORANGE, May 12 -- In the shoot between the Maplewood and Brighton Gun Clubs at Maplewood this afternoon the Brighton Club was worsted by 3 birds. To each man were given 20 birds, and the resultant score was:

In most cases, then, where we find, considerable quantities of sugar conspicuously massed in any part of a plant organism, the sweet juice is placed there on purpose to be eaten. In comparatively small masses, it is stored in flowers or elsewhere for the use of insects. In larger amounts, it is stored, in fruits for the use of birds and mammals.

This reptile reaches a length, it is said, of twelve feet, and for beauty, agility, savagreness, and venom is excelled by none in Brazil. The old Dultch settlers gave it the name of the "Bushmaster," a title it well deserves. The beautiful glints of light on this reptile's scales excel those on a humming bird's breast.

Interview in The Westminster Gazette. "Leaving Aden in November last, we proceeded by steamer to Makellah, the nearest point to the Hadramaut Valley, and after journeying for about three weeks, in the course of which we covered some 150 miles, we reached the interior district, our intended goal.

The Queen Street Hall, in Edinburgh, was packed with an audience that had an unusually large sprinkling of distinguished citizens, whose presence obviously deepened the general hush of expectation. Eight o'clock struck, and instead of the lecturer an official appeared, who intimated that, according to a telegram just received, the train in which Mr. Emerson traveled from Newcastle was some minutes late.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 12 -- The collection of firearms which has been made by A.E. Brooks of this city does not include a single specimen invented since the war. The inventive genius of the last thirty years has not been given any place in the unique work which Mr. Brooks has spent his life in accomplishing.

CORVALLIS, Oregon, May 12. -- The shooting of Charles Kenyon by Dr. J.M. Applewhite yesterday afternoon was highly sensational. The affair grew out of Applewhite's attentions to Mrs. Kenyon. He was her physician, and that he might visit her more easily induced her husband to join a secret society which brought him to Corvallis one night in the week.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 12 -- Stevens beat Johns Hupkins to-day in a championship game of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse League. The game was the most exciting seen this stason. the score being tied several times. Stevens outplayed the Baltimore men, but at times the defense was somewhat weak, and to this is due the size of the Johns Hopkins score.

The Brooklyn suffrage headquarters, at 153 Pierrepont Street, has a deserted appearance. The pleading placard, "Please Sign the Petition," still occupies one of the windows, and another hangs on the knob of the locked door, with a petition book in which are three names written with a pencil.

Congressman W. Bourke Cockran has not been a Sachem of the Tammany Society or Columbian Order for the last year. This Is a fact that not even all the members of the society know. All of last year Mr. Cockran, although elected as a Sachem, did not qualify, and unless a man who has been selected to that office does so qualify he cannot take office as a Sachem.

This English theory of every man for himself has worked wonders for the Irish people -- wonders of blight and calamity such as the world has seen nowhere else. The Celt is a clanman. It is in his blood, and in the traditions and human atmosphere about him, which are stronger than blood, and which made the Geraldlnes of the thirteenth century and the Cromwellian colonists of the seventeenth more Irish than the Irish themselves.

The new gun mounts for the battery of the cruiser Cincinnati, which were made necessary by the change in that vessel's armament, have been received, and within a short time the vessel will Be ready for active service. Her sister ship, the Raleigh, which was built at the Norfolk Navy Yard, has already been commissioned.

The entire costume of the Parsee symbolizes the mysteries of religion. The gauze shirt, bound with the sacred cord of Kusti, must be woven with seventy-two threads to represent the chapters of "Izashni," and the twelve knots of the heavy tassel signify the twelve months of the year, and represent the perpetual obligation of sacred duties.

A suit involving $500,000 was instituted yesterday in the United States Circuit Court. Gordon R. Badgers and Charles Bruen of Sioux City, Iowa, are plaintiffs. The suit is brought against the Manhattan Trust Company and against Amos T. French individually as the executor of his father's estate.

The Mohican Rod and Gun Club of Glens Falls, N.Y., has commenced a campaign to secure fishways in the Upper Hudson, in order that salmon may have open passage to and from the sea. A.N. Cheney is President of the club and C.H. Baxter is the Secretary. Both of these gentlemen are working hard to secure the necessary legislation, and they invite the co-operation of all sportsmen.

TUESDAY, May 15 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., sale by order James T. Hall, receiver, 49 West Seventy-fifth Street, north side. 179 feet east of Columbus Avenue, 21 by 102.2, four-story and basement brick and stone dwelling, with two-story extension.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 12 -- The season of golf was opened in a very auspicious and promising manner to-day by the St. Andrew's Golf Club at Gray Oaks, a few miles above Yonkers, but within the city limits.

The twentieth annual Spring games of the College of the City of New-York Athletic Association were held at Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon. The different events were well contested and several college records were broken. Bartow S. Weeks of the New-York Athletic Club was referee. Following are the results:

PARIS, April 27 -- O ciel! Maman! as said the goody-goody children of stories by Mme. de Genlis in 1830. It was thought an appropriate ladylike vent to the overworked feeling; modern strong words were not familiar then. O ciel! Maman, I am called upon to mention the birth of a new Salon!
According to The Statist even six glasses of wins dally (divided between a family of two or three persons) means L18 5s. a year, and six glasses of spirits means u24 6s. 8d. a year.

From The London Daily News. Last night, at the Grocers' Hall, a most brilliant banquet was given by the Spectacle Makers' Company, under the grenial Presidency of the Master, Alderman Faudel Phillips. Among the company were the Duke of Cambridge, Prince Edward of SaxeWeimar, the American Ambassador, and many other guests of unusual distinction.

The belief prevailed some years ago that the germs or characteristic bacilli of typhoid fever and some other infectious diseases were killed by exposure to severe cold. It was afterward discovered that the germs of typhoid would survive continued exposure to very low temperatures and would retain their vitality for a considerable time even in ice.

From The London Daily News. Last night, at the Grocers' Hall, a most brilliant banquet was given by the Spectacle Makers' Company, under the grenial Presidency of the Master, Alderman Faudel Phillips. Among the company were the Duke of Cambridge, Prince Edward of SaxeWeimar, the American Ambassador, and many other guests of unusual distinction.

The belief prevailed some years ago that the germs or characteristic bacilli of typhoid fever and some other infectious diseases were killed by exposure to severe cold. It was afterward discovered that the germs of typhoid would survive continued exposure to very low temperatures and would retain their vitality for a considerable time even in ice.

Last week will go into history as one of the dullest of the halt year. Outside of a few specialties, there was hardly enough trading to indicate the drift of the market, and at times there was so little done that absolute stagnation prevailed. Speculative interest was confined almost exclusively to the industrials.

The Brooklyn police let up yesterday in their efforts to reform Coney Island into a respectable resort. It was facetiously said by a divekeeper that they were too busy thinking about the Tabernacle fire to bother about the dives and concert halls.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Representative Clifton R. Breckinridge of Arkansas was one of the Democratic Congressmen from the South who voted during the late extra cession for the repeal of the Sherman Silver Purchase act. Some of Mr. Breckinridge's political opponents are using his position regarding that law to defeat his renomination to Congress.
ALBANY, May 13. -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Senator Bradley's bill providing for a new Board of Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge. In his memorandum accompanying the veto, the Governor says:
BUENOS AYRES, May 13. -- A dispatch from Rio de Janeiro says that 8,000 insurgent soldiers have been concentrated at Base, Rio Grande do Sul.

The sale of lots belonging to the Vyse estate, which was held on Saturday by Mr. James L. Wells in a tent on the grounds near One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street and the Southern Boulevard, was fairly successful. When the sale began, more than a thousand persons were present, including many ladies. The bidding was slow and particularly trying to the auctioneer, who was ill, but who persevered in his work until evening.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 13. -- How to strengthen the ball nine is the question at Yale just now. Capt. Case is beginning to realize that outside of the phenomenal Carter the team is only second-class and the process of shifting has only begun. Quinby has been retired to the substitute list, permanently probably, as his weak hitting and inability to cover ground make him an inferior candidate for short stop.
The Rev. Robert S. MacArthur celebrated his twenty-fourth anniversary to the pastorate of Calvary Baptist Church yesterday morning.

NEWARK, N.J., March 13. -- One of the most enjoyable runs ever participated in by a party of Newark cyclers was that of the Essex County Wheelmen to Coney Island to-day. It was an ideal day for the run, and arrangements were so perfect that only the very few who suffered the inconvenience of accidents failed to have full share of the sport.

Ex-President Benjamin Harrison will depart for home to-day. He has been nearly a week and a half in this city, on professional business, as he has said, emphatically, on such occasions as he has been interviewed. During that time, however. Mr. Harrison has also been receiving calls from Republican politicians of all degrees of prominence and belonging to about all factions of the party.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Yesterday, in the trial of my case against my sisters and brothers, to make them carry out their agreement to share our father's estate with me, Judge Gaynor, speaking to my counsel, Mr. Wells, decided against me as follows:

At the Madison Square Garden last night a large audience sat with commendable solemnity through a concert by Sousa's Band. In former times such an entertainment would have been called a "sacred concert." It seems that this description is no longer considered necessary, but certainly there was nothing in the deportment of the audience or the playing of the band last evening that suggested undue hilarity.

NEWTOWN, L.I., May 13. -- Special policemen, headed by Police Justice William T. Monteverde, raided the Queens County Park and Lao Park in Maspath this afternoon. The appearance of the officers caused a stampede among baseball players and picnic parties. In their haste to escape arrest some of the pleasure seekers scaled the fences.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 13. -- Pennsylvania-Cornell games are less than a week distant, and there is greater attention paid to the track and field sports than to other features of athletics. The entries for the games are unusually large, but owing to the flabby condition of many of the contestants, owing to lack of training, not many record breakers are looked for.

More than 150,000 men, women, and children were in Central Park at 3:30 P.M. yesterday. This estimate was made at the arsenal by Capt. Collins, who said he believed he underrated rather than exaggerated the attendance.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Mrs. Cleveland accompanied by the babies, Ruth and Esther, and their nurses, and escorted by Private Secretary Thurber, left Washington for Buffalo, over the Northern Central Railroad, at 7:10 o'clock this evening. The party occupied Frank Thompson's private car, the famous "No. 60," and are due to reach their destination at 11:40 o'clock tomorrow morning.

"The Biblical definition of woman," said the Rev. Charles H. Parkhurst last night in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, in preaching on Genesis i., 27, " Male and female created He them," "is an unconscious tribute to her. Nothing is more becoming to man than that he should cherish that estimate of woman.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 13. -- The Louisiana Legislature, which will elect two United States Senators, will convene here to-morrow, and the city is filling up with those interested in these contests and in various measures that will come before the Legislature.
NASSAU, N.P., May 13. -- The yacht Baracouta stopped here for coal and other supplies, with Mr. Fell and party on board, from Puerto Rico last. She cleared for Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- During the week just ended there have been in the Senate some exhibitions of a Republican tendency to sport with the Democrats, to use them contemptuously, to point out the inconsistencies in their propositions, their infidelity to their principles, and what not in a way that has supplied the Republican gallery contingent with opportunities for amusement and applause.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13. -- The revised list of final examinations has been officially issued, and steady "grinding" has begun. The changes have been very slight. In the Dental School they begin on Monday, June 4, and in the Medical School, Wednesday, June 6.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- There has been no case which has excited so much general comment in the army as the forthcoming trial by a court-martial, at Fort Snelling, Minn., of Lieut. J.A. Maney, Fifteenth Infantry. The trial is the result of the killing of Capt. Hedberg, Maney's superior officer, at Fort Sheridan, near Chicago.

The Brooklyn Tabernacle has for the third time been laid in ashes. Fire, its old enemy, destroyed the splendid edifice yesterday, and left only blackened walls of the Hotel Regent, a fine new hostelry which had just been completed.

PANA, Ill., May 13. -- The strike of the coal miners at this place has been declared off, and all the miners who could secure work have returned to their duties. There were over 250 of the strikers who were told that their services would not again be wanted. The cause of the calling off of the strike is, the union men say, the report that McBride has "sold them out."

The Senate of the United States is a body that cannot be killed, however obnoxious it may make itself to the people. Its life is virtually guaranteed by the Constitution, for the one thing that cannot be amended out of that instrument is the equal representation of the States in the Senate, except upon the practically impossible condition that they all consent to give it up.
Thomas C. Latto. Thomas C. Latto, the best-known Scottish poet in this country, died at his residence, 131 Bainbridge Street, Brooklyn, on Saturday evening.

BERLIN, May 13. -- The Brausewetter scandal has assumed national dimensions. Few persons hesitate to say that the Judge disgraced the bench by usurping the functions of the Prosecuting Attorney in the trial of Prussian editors last week, and the newspapers throughout the empire agree as rarely before in admonishing the Government to act quickly in response to public opinion.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Republicans who have been making pilgrimages to New-York and who are stopping in Washington on their way home bring New-York news that ought to set the McKinley men and Reed men thinking. Some very prominent Republicans who have been here during the last week are enthusiastic over the suggestion that Senator Saxton is to be the next Republican candidate for Governor of New-York.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 13. -- It is reported in Tampa that Burke, the defaulting Treasurer of Louisiana, passed through there last night, having arrived at Port Tampa Friday night on the Honduras Lottery Company's steamer Clear Water, from Puerto Cortez. He was accompanied by two prominent New-Orleans men.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 13. -- Not in many years have there been so many yachts in Shaw's Cove in the middle of May as there are to-day, and many of them will remain there throughout the yachting season. The well-known schooner Shamrock, New-York Yacht Club, is now in the cove, but she is to go into commission soon. Her crew is expected aboard about the 15th, when she will be prepared for the season's cruising.

The statistics of public libraries in the United States published by the United States Bureau of Education contain a list of 3,804 libraries, but Mr. Fletcher says that only 566 of these are in a true sense public. He gives a list of the largest free public libraries, and it contains only 100 titles.

ST. JOHN'S, N. F., May 13. -- Nominations for members of the Legislature in place of the unseated members were made in the Bay de Verde district yesterday. Concerted attempts were made to break up meetings of the Government candidates, but the attempts were only partially successful, as the leaders of the opposition were afraid to go to extremes in broad daylight.

Dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange have been light and the prices of speculative issues have shown a downward tendency. The strictly investment houses, however, which sell their bonds over the counter, report a steady inquiry for bonds of the class. These houses secure the bulk of the bond business, being able to offer customers first-class securities, about which all the facts are known.
GREENSBURG, Penn., May 13. -- Col. Galvin's army arrived here from Jeannette this afternoon, and is encamped to-night at Electric Park. The army will stay here until Tuesday.

ALBANY, May 12. -- The few transactions made in the local stocks during the past week were confined to Consolidated Car Heating, Albany Railway, and Hudson River Telephone. Consolidated Car Heating continues to set the pace for strength, and made a gain of 1 per cent., selling at 62, which is the asked price for the stock.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Coxey and Browne did not attempt any incursions into the neighboring villages to-day. They had an experience in Hyattsville last night which taught them a lesson.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- The New-York Times inter-State relay team race between riders of New-York, New-Jersey, and Pennsylvania, to take place on Saturday, June 2, is now assured of success, the committees of the three States having already started to lay out the route and arrange all the plans necessary.

The Brooklyn Whist Club, which has given its rivals many surprises in the game during the past Winter, added another of an agreeable nature last week. This was the admission of a lady player within its ranks. She is Miss Kate Irwin Wheelock, and her position among whist players is well known.

WASHINGTON, May 13. --Even the best of men cannot prevent evil report of themselves, so that it is not surprising that Senator Brice should become the subject of mischievous gossip out of the mouths of men who lack reverence for wealth and are without fear of the dignity that hedges a Senator.

It is quite the proper thing with lovers of racing to go to the race tracks on the Sunday before the running of any great race. Such being the custom it was not strange that what would have been a good racing crowd on an "off day" was at the Gravesend track yesterday to see what they could of the horses that are to take part in the great race of to-morrow, the Brooklyn Handicap.

One of the revising committee's amendments takes lard from the Wilson bill's free list and makes it dutiable at 1 cent a pound. This is one of the curiosities of the revised bill. Why should there be any tariff duty on lard? We shall read with lively interest the revising committee's explanation when the provisions schedule is reached.

We hope every Democrat in the South and West will diligently study the defense and justification addressed to his constituents by Representative Clifton R. Breckinridge of Arkansas in reply to their strictures upon his course in respect to the repeal of the Sherman act. In particular we hope the Democrats of Mr. Breekinridge's district will weigh well his statesmanlike words.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 13. -- Yale Law School students have out their "shingle." In this case it is the annual book giving the statistics of the senior class, and bearing that legal name. Percy Finlay of Memphis, Tenn., is the editor of the present volume, which contains many points of interest relative to Yale Law School, '94.
NEW-HAVEN, May 13. -- Most of the Harvard athletes who competed in yesterday's games left here last night. A few, however, remained with Yale friends over Sunday, leaving for home to-night.

ALBANY, May 13. -- Justice Mayham of the Supreme Court, sitting at a special term at Schoharie Saturday, granted a writ of prohibition restraining the Constitutional Convention from taking any action in the case of Herman Trapper, delegate from Erie County, whose seat in the convention is being contested, other than taking of testimony in the case.

PROVIDENCE, May 12. -- The local stock market has been exceedingly dull during the week. Prices continue about the same, with the exception of Rhode Island National Bank, which was sold at 27. American Screw Company is somewhat lower, having sold during the week at 225 for a small lot. The bank stocks are quiet.

It is strange that opposition to the consolidation of the cities within the metropolitan district should come from Brooklyn, which would inevitably be the chief gainer. That is where one would expect the demand to come from. Thousands of residents of Brooklyn do business and pay a large share of taxes in New-York.

After the Wilson bill is passed Congress should at once pass the laws necessary to punish the fraudulent imitation of foreign trade marks. This imitation is prevalent to an extent but little suspected by the general public. No fault can be found with the Federal courts for the manner in which they administer the existing laws.

BOSTON, May 14 -- It seems impossible to infuse any life into local securities, and they were almost neglected to-day. Sales, when there any were very small, and quotations did not change materially. Mexican Central 4s dropped 1/4, to 53 1/4, and Wisconsin Central 5s declined 1 1/4, to 7. Bell Telephone sold at 189 1/2@190 1/4.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- While the House was considering a District bill to-day, considerable excitement was caused by a colored man in the public gallery. The man arose, and, addressing the Speaker, said that if the Coxey bill was not passed, the White House, Treasury, and Capitol would be destroyed by thunder and lightning.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 14 -- General Superintendent Harrington of the New-York Central Road, while not denying that there was a great shortage of coal in this section, said: "That is no indication that the running of the road is in any way to be interfered with. The Central has a plentiful supply of coal in New-York City depots, and can send us all we want of anthracite.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14 -- The fourth annual Interscholastic tennis tournament was finished this afternoon on the Harvard courts, and resulted in a victory for L.E. Ware of Roxbury. Young Ware is the boy who succeeded in reaching the finals last year, finally succumbing to Budlong, the Providence player, who afterward won the junior championship at Newport in August.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 14 -- When Orin Friday of Stanford was arrested several months ago for stealing chickens, he owned a farm of 155 acres, well stocked and provided with a house, barn, and other buildings.
Preparations are malting in New-York for an active campaign in favor of the Greater New-York, in consequence of the signing by Gov. Flower, last week, of the bill which paves the way therefor.

ALBANY, May 14. -- Gov. Flower to-day ordered the transfer to the Executive Chamber of all the oil paintings of his predecessors in office that have adorned the large open upper hall of the Executive Mansion. In explanation of this step, Gov. Flower said that he was acting as a matter of precaution.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- There was hardly sufficient market to-day to write about. The few orders upon the Stock Exchange seemed to be selling orders. The Traction stocks were inactive, except Philadelphia, which was for sale.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- John Y. McKane has failed in his efforts to secure a release on a writ of habeas corpus.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 14 -- The contest between Joseph F. Johnston and William C. Oates for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination is by no means settled. The few returns coming in to-day have added to the hopes of the Johnston men and taken from those of the Oates men.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 14 -- Andrew Onderdonk of Chicago, the well-known contractor, who built the British Columbia section of the Canadian Pacific Railway, is in the city, accompanied by his son, Shirley Onderdonk, or "Shirley the Lamb," as he is known by some of his familiar friends in Chicago.

In consequence of the suspension of work in the bituminous coal mines caused by the far-reaching strike of miners, the available supply of soft coal is getting very low, and already some of the railroad companies have become embarrassed for fuel for their locomotives.

ROME, May 14 -- The debate in the Chamber this afternoon was exceedingly stormy. The Opposition reiterated all the old objections to the war budget, and insisted that several items should have been cut down. Gen. Mocenni spoke repeatedly to refute the arguments against the budget. On the vote the Government got only nine majority, and the Opposition set up a hideous din of jubilation.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Additional telegrams have been, received by the Acting Commisioner of Indian Affairs from Agent Wisdom, at the Union Agency, Indian Territory, to the effect that the strike of the miners at Alderson is critical and that a riot is imminent.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A much less skillful writer than he who prepared the broadside published in Philadelphia and New-York newspapers, purporting to be a veritable history of the origin and development of the sugar schedule in the Tariff bill, could have compiled an interesting romance on that subject if he had exhibited a like degree of credulity toward all manner of reports, lobby gossip, campaign chatter, and partisan insinuation.

Sanitary Superintendent Roberts made a report to the Board of Health yesterday, giving the result of an analysis of samples of chocolate drops sold by a manufacturer in Canal Street, that had been complained of by President Gerry of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

The theory that the Brooklyn Tabernacle was set on fire, not accidentally, but purposely, is growing among the people of Brooklyn. If the fire was of incendiary origin the incendiary covered his tracks well.

TRENTON, N.J., May 14 -- The legislative session this week opened with a fresh batch of vetoes by Gov. Werts. A half dozen bills were returned to the Legislature to-night with his objections to them, and he is said to be grinding out still more. The Governor's objections to the bill providing for a non-partisan Board of State Prison Inspectors were listened to with special interest.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 14 -- The United Mine Workers' Convention was called to order at 10 A.M. to-day by President McBride, who made an address stating the object of the meeting. There were 183 delegates present.

JERSEY CITY, May 14 -- Katie Rupp of Rome, N.Y., was found by laborers this morning lying in the woods near Snake Hill. She was unconscious. She had a bullet wound in the breast, and another back of the right ear.

It will soon be decided whether Dr. Henry Meyer is to go to the electric chair as the condemned murderer of Ludwig Brandt. The trial of the case is almost over. Today's session will be taken up with the submission of expert testimony by the defense.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Acting Secretary Wilke to-day made a peremptory demand upon the North American Commercial Company for $135,000, the amount of rent due and premium unpaid for the Pribilof Islands last year on the catch of 7,500 seals. Secretary Carlisle had separated last year's debt from former years, which accounts had been adjusted by Secretary Foster.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The return of the condition of the forty-nine national banks in New-York City on May 4 last shows the reserve held to have been 39.52 per cent.; loans and discounts, $336,597,000; lawful money reserve, $191,938,000, of which $79,500,000 is in gold and gold certificates; surplus fund, $43,373,000; undivided profits, $17,008,000, and individual deposits, $315,935,000.

The tournament to decide the tennis championships of the Interscholastic Athletic Association of New-York City was begun yesterday on the turf courts at Berkeley Oval; Representatives from Harvard, Berkeley, Halsey, Condon, Drisler, Cutler, and Barnard Schools have entered. As the boys are now preparing for various examinations the tournaments will be played on every other day, so as not to interfere with their studies.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- By long odds the prettiest game played on the diamond here this season was the contest this after-noon between Ward's Giants and Irwin's Quakers. After a struggle of eleven innings the local club tallied the one run necessary to win, and, in consequence, the enthusiasts here are in a happy frame of mind.

The great audience which listened to the speech of W. Bourke Cockran at the opening of the Catholic School Exhibit last night, at the Grand Central Palace, started in surprise when the Congressman, who was eulogizing the Catholic Church and its parochial schools, turned with a sweeping gesture toward Archbishop Corrigan and said:
