Messrs. Hoffman Brothers have sold for Sachs Brothers, to W.G. Weld of Boston, the new six-story and basement brick and stone business building 13 and 15 Washington Place, 66.6 by 100, for about $300,000. The building is leased for a term of years at $20,500. Mr. Weld has within the past five years invested several million dollars in city real estate.

ALBANY, May 14 -- Gov. Flower has prevented the Niagara General Electric Company from obtaining a monopoly in running boats on the Erie Canal by electricity by vetoing the bill of Mr. Gerst, (Rep., Erie,) which proposed to repeal the law under which the Niagara Company obtained its contract from the Commissioner of Public Works.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Diplomatic relations between Brazil and Portugal have been suspended because of the conduct of the officers of the Portuguese war ships in connection with da Gama's surrender.

Prof. Henry Morley. Prof. Henry Morley, the distinguished author and lecturer, died at Carisbrooke, Isle of Wight, yesterday morning. He was born in London Sept. 15, 1822. He was educated at the Moravian School, Neuwield-on-the-Rhine, and at King's College, London, of which college he was afterward made an honorary Fellow.

Ex-Secretary William C. Whitney was asked yesterday if there was any foundation for the story, published with much detail and circumstance in The Philadelphia Press and The Press of this city, that the Sugar Trust made a contribution of $500,000 to the Democratic national campaign fund in 1892.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., May 14. -- The twelfth day of the season for rifle shooting at Creedmoor was opened this morning by a detachment of the Seventh Regiment composed of Companies B and C, under the command of Lieut. Col. G.M. Smith and under the supervision of Brig. Gen. B.M. Whitlock, Inspector of Rifle Practice, State of New-York, and Capt. W.H. Palmer, Inspector of Rifle Practice, Seventh Regiment.

BOSTON, May 14 -- The Puritan is now at Lawley's and ready for the inspection of any intending purchaser. Commodore Forbes left Fairhaven in her on Saturday afternoon, and made Boston Light early Sunday morning. Then he went for a sail in the bay, and anchored off Lawley's late in the afternoon. To-day she was hauled into the basin, where she will be until the time of the sale.
Out of the arrest of the two young pickpockets in the Central Park monkey house Sunday afternoon came a story yesterday that Dickens would have delighted to write.

The extreme recklessness with which the European publicist treats American affairs is in striking and curious contrast with the extreme caution which he displays in treating of European affairs. This is true even of the British publicist, although the sources of information on American affairs are accessible to him in his own language.
The Brooklyn Handicap and all the other races on the programme of the Brooklyn Jockey Club will be run to-day, and there will be betting and poolselling as if Peter De Lacy did not exist.

BUENOS AYRES, May 14. -- It is now certain that Admiral da Gama is going to Lisbon to explain to the Portuguese Government the conduct of the insurgents on board the Portuguese war ships which conveyed them from Rio de Janeiro to Buenos Ayres.

AUBURN, N. Y., May 14. -- Lucius R. Wilson was executed here to-day by electricity for killing Detective Harvey in Syracuse last July. Wilson's brother, Charles, is in the Syracuse jail, charged with guilt equal to his brother's in the Harvey murder. The State's theory is that the brothers were acting in concert, and that though but one shot was fired both were fairly chargeable with the crime.

ALBANY, May 14 -- Gov. Flower signed the Pound Compulsory Education bill today. This bill was drawn under the direction of the counsel of School Superintendents of the State, with a view of overcoming all the interests that have up to the present opposed compulsory education. It was indorsed by Superintendent of Public Instruction Crooker and nearly all the School Commissioners, Boards of Education, Trustees, and other school officers throughout the State.

The eyes of the bicycling world are at present focused on road racing. Of the large number of road races scheduled it is safe to predict that The New-York Times's 150mile relay race and the Irvington-Millburn race are at present the all-absorbing topics being discussed by those interested in bicycling.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Tennessee law which the officials of that State contend authorize them to tax the property of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad Company for the years 1885 to 1889 inclusive, was declared by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day, in an opinion read by Justice Jackson, to be invalid as far as that company is concerned.

"Gov. Flower is looking for re-election. I had nothing else to expect from him and I cannot say I am very much disappointed," said Senator Daniel Bradley of Brooklyn yesterday to a reporter for The New-York Times who called at his home in Bridge Street and asked him his opinion of the Sovernor's veto of his Bridge bill.

VICTORIA, B.C., May 14 -- The schooner Triumph, the first of the sealing fleet to be warned against violating the new international agreement, arrived at this port yesterday. She was spoken in latitude 57.45 north, longitude 139 west, off Cross Sound, May 7, by the British war ship Hyacinthe.

The Governor has just signed the act "to provide for the compulsory education of children," which goes into effect on the 1st of January next. We have nominally had a compulsory education law for some years, but it has been ineffective for lack of proper means for securing its enforcement.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- It is explained at the Peruvian Legation here that the censoship over telegrams proclaimed at Lima is a result of the political situation. A general election will be held the 1st of June, and in order to prevent malcontents from carrying out any plan they may have to cause trouble, the Government, merely as a precautionary measure, has directed that all telegrams shall be examined before transmission or delivery.

BERLIN, May 14 -- The International Congress of Miners was opened here this morning, with an attendance of ninety delegates, the Socialist element largely preponderating. Among the prominent delegates are Herren Singer, Tuer, Liebknecht, Schonlank, Legien, Mueller, and Waldenburg of Germany, Messrs. Pickard and Burt of England, Lanendieu and Calvaignac, the latter Mayor of Carmaux, of France, Caelverts of Belgium, Scnoeder of Rhennish Prussia, and Zimper of Bohemia.

Many articles of silverware have been stolen from the showcases in the store of the Whiting Manufacturing Company, at Broadway and Eighteenth Street, within the past four or five weeks, and when it became evident that a gang of expert shoplifters was operating in the store Inspector McLaughlin was informed.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 14 -- In the General Term of the Supreme Court to-day John. Y. McKane's appeal from the sentence of Justice Barnard of $250 fine and thirty days' imprisonment for contempt of court was dismissed.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- On the final sea trial trip of the United States steamer Columbia, wnich has been ordered for next Thursday, the vessel is to be run for six hours at 10-knot speed, using the central screw alone, followed by six hours at 14 knots, using the two side engines, and six hours with all three screws at a speed of about 16 knots, thoroughly to test the triple-screw idea.
Miss Sadie Martinet has about $35,000 more in available cash as the result of the sale of her effects than before the four days' vendue at Samuel Kreiser's rooms, 9 West Twenty-eighth Street.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 14 -- The annual race meeting opens here to-morrow. The Derby will be the stake event. The weather is fine and the track is fast. Following are the horses weights and probable riders for the Derby, at one mile and a half: Boyer, 122 pounds. (Ray;) Sigurd, 122. (Overton;) Tom Elmore, 122, (Irving;) Chant. 122, (Goodale;) Pat, 122, (Thorpe;) Song, 122, (R. Williams.)

NEW-LONDON, May 14 -- The schooner yacht Wave Crest, Mr. H.M. Birge, arrived here this forenoon from Whitestone on her way to the Thousand Islands. She is covered with cement paint now, her owner preferring to have her don her dress of white after she gets to her destination. Capt. H.J. Bown is in command of the Wave Crest.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Republicans of the Senate have decided to continue indefinitely the programme which has been followed thus far in connection with the tariff.

Referring to our remarks of May 7 on the reciprocity treaty with Hawaii, of which Article II. gives to the United States the right to use Pearl River Harbor as a naval station, ex-Senator Edmunds, in a letter to The Times, emphasizes the point that certain declarations regarding it made at that time by Secretary Bayard do not alter the character of the treaty, whatever that character may be:

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The death at Governors Island of Capt. C.G. Morrison of the Ordnance Department deprives the army of a valuable officer. One of his principal duties was as recorder of the Board of Ordnance and Fortification, which meets here monthly, the purpose of which is the allotment of public funds for the coast defense.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- When the Senate adjourned to-day, after devoting six hours to the Tariff bill, twenty more items had been disposed of Compared with the progress made In previous days, this is a surprising record, and it is the subject of comment to-night.
Lillian Russell has parted forever from another husband. This is Signer Perugini.

From The Boston Commercial Bulletin. There was a song composed and sung by J.M. Field of the Tremont Theatre company at the grand dinner given Feb. 1, 1842, to Dickens, at Papanti's Hall, in Boston, at which Josiah Quincy presided. It was entitled "The werry last obserwations of Veller, senior, to Boz, on his departure to America," and was received with shouts of laughter and applause. It ran as follows:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 15 -- Eighty-six law students out of a class of eighty-eight passed their examinations before an examining board composed of William N. Dykman, James C. Church, and Wilson Brown, Jr., to-day, and were sworn in by Chief Justice C.F. Brown of the General Term of the Second Judicial Department.

GARDEN CITL, L.I., May 15 -- Fully 2,000 persons attended the services held in the Cathedral of the Incarnation to-day in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the consecration of the Right Rev. Abram Newkirk Littlejohn as Bishop of the Long Island Diocese of the Episcopal Church.

The entire night gang of laborers at worK in the tunnel of the East River Gaslight Company, which is being built under the East River, from the foot of Seventy-first Street, were overcome by the gases in the shaft yesterday morning.
Four milk depots were opened yesterday, each of which bore the sign:

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Navy Department people will be satisfied if Congress agrees to Representative Dunphy's resolution to investigate the complaints about the Carnegie armor plates. Every one in the department believes that the conditions have been greatly exaggerated.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., May 15 -- Another riot occurred yesterday at Bay de Verde. The police patrol in Gull Island, in attempting to arrest the ringleaders of the mob who made an attack upon Ministers Morison and Morine and their companions was set upon by the islanders and driven from the place, after being forced to release the prisoners.

The attention of the great throng of habitual theatrical "first-nighters," which has lately increased remarkably in numbers, was absorbed last evening by the production at the American Theatre of a sentimental play by Clement Scott and Wilsons Barrett, called "Sister Mary." This play is ten years old, and was announced for performance at Wallack's Theatre in the season of 1885-6.

Under Section 86 of the Consolidation act the Common Council has the power "to regulate traffic and sales in the streets, highways, roads, and public places" and "to regulate the use of the streets, highways, roads, and public places by foot passengers, animals, vehicles, cars, and locomotives."
WASHINGTON, D.C., May 15 -- The House to-day passed the Naval Appropriation bill. The bill carries a total appropriation of $25,336,516.27.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 15 -- Eugene Brady, a maniac, killed his mother, aged sixty-five, this afternoon, in a fit of violence, and attempted to kill four other persons. With three knives in his hands, he ran wildly about the streets, cutting right and left, assaulting every one he met.

BOSTON, Mass., May 15 -- Four Harvard students, John Farnum Brown of Philadelphia, W. Campbell Trusdell of Newark, N. J., Edwin Stanton Bach of New-York City, and Franklin Whitall of Philadelphia, have been drowned in Boston Harbor.
Frivolity and earnestness met on Broadway yesterday. The stream of people going down the thoroughfare on the way to the races passed the marching forces of the Salvation Army on its way up town.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- The drop in cereals and the dull, heavy New-York market had a sympathetic effect upon the local exchange. All the important stocks were active but generally at lower figures. West Chicago opened at 146, 1/4 below the closing price of yesterday, and declined gradually to 144 7/8, where it closed.

The trial of Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer on the charge of poisoning Ludwig Brandt, as far as evidence is concerned, is over. At this morning's session of Recorder Smyth's court Charles W. Brooke, chief counsel for Meyer, will begin the summing up. He will speak for more than five hours.

The Lenox Hill Club, famous for a long time in the political and social affairs of the Twentieth Assembly District, has disbanded, and its members have joined the new Delaware Club, which has just been organized, and which is the social wing of the Tammany Hall organization of the Twentieth District.

BALTIMORE, May 15 -- It the first day of the regular campaign for the harness horses can be taken as a criterion, this will be a great season for the sulkies. The Baltimore and Philadelphia Circuit, which began at the Gentlemen's Driving Park this afternoon, set a merry pace, and the sport was much higher in class than is usually seen at this early period.

The shipping interests are beginning to feel the effects of the strike of the coal miners. The Norwegian steamship Christian Johnson, engaged in the fruit trade with the West Indies, sailed from this port early yesterday morning, but in the afternoon she returned to Quarantine because her coal was of bad quality.

The services in connection with the fiftyeighth anniversary of the Union Theological Seminary were concluded last night, when the members of the graduating class were presented with diplomas by Charles Butler.

Henry Alexander, an artist whose studio is at 51 West Tenth Street, committed suicide yesterday morning in the Oriental Hotel, at Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street, by swallowing a dose of poison. Lack of funds, it is thought, caused the artist to take his life. He had been a guest at the hotel for the last two days.

The workers for political equality have not brought their efforts to a close with the opening of the Constitutional Convention. They are continuing them actively and expect to carry on their work with vigor throughout the Summer.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The computation made for Mr. Voorhees by Treasury experts giving the value of imports for the last year under the McKinley act, the estimated duty under the House and Senate bill and the average and ad valorem rates, these figures being based upon the latest revision of the bill, and including, of course, the Jones amendments, shows the following: ...

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 15 -- Fire started shortly before 7 o'clock to-night at the plant of the Worthington Pump Company. Elizabethport. It is a branch of the South Brooklyn works, and covers about five acres. It consists of green sand, loam, and dry sand foundries, and the new pattern shop, the latter being 300 by 80 feet.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., May 15 -- A detachment of the Seventh Regiment, composed of Companies E and F. under command of Col. D. Appleton and a portion of the field, staff, and non-commissioned staff, under the supervision of Capt. William H. Palmer, Inspector of Rifle Practice, Seventh Regiment, shot here to-day. The weather was very fine in the morning, with a moderate 11 o'clock wind, remaining nearly so throughout the day.

Everything is being prepared for the big 150-mile relay road race promoted by The New-York Times, and from present appearances the contest will prove one of unusual interest to cyclers in this and other sections of the country. The road committee of the Atalanta Wheelmen of Newark were out yesterday measuring the first 100 miles of the course.

-- Word reached the Cotton Exchange yesterday that the Supreme Court had dissolved the injunction obtained by Broker Sodeksen, which restrained the Exchange from selling his certificate of membership after his alleged failure. In seeking the injunction, Sodeksen represented that he was solvent, and that the action of the Exchange had damaged his business $50,000, for which amount he threatened suit.

The Trustees of the College of the City of New-York cannot afford to pay for the fire escapes ordered by the Building Department. This was made apparent at yesterday's meeting of the Trustees by Charles L. Holt, Chairman of the Executive Committee, who read a communication from the Building Department to the effect that the college building had been carefully examined, and that the fire escapes previously ordered had been adjudged absolutely necessary.

MONTREAL, May 15 -- Play in the championship chess match between W. Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker for the championship of the world and $2,000 aside was resumed this afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club before a large concourse of spectators. It was Lasker's turn to open the fifteenth game. Both players have exhausted their rights of claiming off-days, and the remaining games will have to be played on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays.

The attempt to secure the removal of the warehouse and purchasing office for Indian supplies from New-York to Chicago crops out again in the peculiarly sneaking and indecent guise of a rider to the Indian Appropriation bill, into which an amendment has been thrust providing "that the office for purchasing goods and supplies and the general depot shall be established at Chicago, and the bids shall be opened there."

The Rapid-Transit bill in the hands of the Governor is far from being a perfect measure, and it contains some defects which may have been intended to interfere with the successful accomplishment of its purpose, but it presents the only hope of a speedy beginning of an undertaking which will necessarily occupy a considerable period of time.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 15 -- Both the torpedo boats Cushing and Stiletto safely ran the gantlet of the torpedo station's big searchlight to-night, and while the entrance to Narragansett Bay was yet being examined by the light, both boats were being moored to their wharves.

What makes some people plump and fleshy and others thin and bony? Is the human body run and shaped in an invisible mould? And what strange effects this difference produces. Beauty always demands curves -- it never allows angles. A woman may be thin and graceful but not thin and beautiful.

The new uniform for the enlisted men of the United States Navy promises to be something quite different from that now worn by the boys in blue. The board which has been investigating this subject of apparel has not yet submitted its conclusions.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met in the Mayor's office yesterday. The request of the Gerry Society for an annual appropriation of $300,000, to be derived from the sale of revenue bonds, was considered.

A motion was made in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday before Justice Barrett to strike out the answer made by the Evansville and Terre Haute Railroad Company in the suit brought against it by William H. Raser. The plaintiff holds quite a number of the bonds of the Evansville and Richmond Railroad Company, upon which the defendant company appears as guarantors, and the action was brought to enforce the guarantee.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The motion for a new trial made in behalf of Jacob S. Coxey, Carl Browne, and Christopher Columbus Jones, the Commonweal leaders, was heard and refused in Judge Miller's police court this afternoon, in the presence of about a score of spectators.
The New-York Catholic Educational Exhibit now being held in the Grand Central Palace of Industry in this city is of exceptional interest.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Capt. Ward's men were beaten here again to-day. They were outbatted and outfielded by Arthur Irwin's aspirants for championship honors, who won in a common canter. The features were Connor's hit over the right-field fence, and a difficult catch of a foul fly by Cross.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 15 -- Gov. Flower has vetoed the three Assembly bills amending the charter of Yonkers, revising the Watertown charter, and incorporating the City of Little Falls. In his veto memorandum the Governor says:
"While the anti-suffragists are gathering in conventions to oppose this advance step, what is becoming of their husbands' suppers?

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Wells, Fargo Co. have discovered a scheme for swindling by means of forged money orders through their offices. Manager Evans of the Atlantic Department has accordingly sent a circular to the company's agents, describing the fraud and warning them to be on guard against it.

Mr. George J. Gould, Mrs. Gould, and their four children will sail for England on the steam- ship Paris this morning. Mr. Gould paid a visit to his yachts Atalanta and Vigilant in the Erie Basin. He was very much interested in the work being done on both yachts, particularly in strengthening the Vigilant for her trip across the Atlantic.

-- City Treasurer Getty, in his report for the month of April, states that his receipts were $426,205.22; disbursements, $397,745.22, leaving a balance on hand May 1 of $28,460. The other city officials reported receipts during April as follows: H.B. Archer, Receiver of Taxes. $189,204.72; John Pogan, Jr., City Clerk, $541,06; F. X. Donoghue, City Judge, $140,80; F.C. Williams, City Court Clerk. $24,58; S.L. Cooper, Commissioner of Public Works, $264,54; James Persice, $28,25.

BLADENSBURG, Md., May 15 -- The barroom adjacent to the Coxey camp is proving too strong an attraction for the maintenance of discipline, and arrests of stragglers and deserters for drunkenness are growing common.

The scene of the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the consecration of Bishop Littlejohn and of the establishment of the Diocese of Long Island was transferred last night to the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Messiah, Greene and Clermont Avenues, Brooklyn, where many clergymen and a large congregation of the laymen of the diocese were gathered to render a tribute of love, honor, and respect to the venerable prelate.

-- The Board of Aldermen yesterday adopted a resolution requesting the Board of Health to amend Section 95 of the Sanitary Code so that property owners or occupants of houses may be permitted to place cans or boxes for the reception of ashes and garbage on the sidewalk, instead of being compelled to been them within the stoop lines.

William Tuohey had been a somnambulist for years, but until yesterday morning the extent of his sleep-walking was going up and down stairs, which he had done a number of times without meeting with any accident. Yesterday morning he walked out of a window into an airshaft, and now he is in the Harlem Hospital suffering from serious injuries.

The multitude that went wild with excitement when, at the ninth furlong pole of the Brooklyn Handicap course, Dr. Rice drew out of the ruck of twelve of the fourteen starters to win the race, was singularly favored. They came by boat, trolley lines, railroads, carriages of every description, and on foot, without mishap.

It is not often that marriages by proxy are performed in this city, although they are frequent in Continental Europe, yet on Friday evening Father Halpln, in the chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, married Miss Julia W. Morris or 96 Lexington Avenue to Frank F. Gearity, who was at the time in El Paso, Texas, Robert J. Hoey, a cousin of the bride, acting as proxy.
From the Portland (Me.) Press. A venerable stranger came into the City Treasurer's office a couple of days ago. "Is your name Libby?" said he, slowly to the genial Treasurer of Portland.

BOSTON, May 15 -- Some small Roxbury boys set themselves up as rivals to Mrs. O'Leary's cow on the Boston baseball grounds this afternoon, and as a result the city was visited by the biggest fire since Thanksgiving Day, 1892, and a confiagration covering a greater area than any since the memorable one of 1872.

This advertisement was published yesterday morning: If the party who was so considerate as to relieve a gentleman of a diamond and sapphire, chain, two gold watches, a pearl pin, and a small sum of money on Sunday morning, between 3d Av. and 5th Av., will return the same he will receive more than their intrinsic value, as they are heirlooms; or the tickets, if pawned.

President C.V. Fornes of the Catholic Club tendered a complimentary dinner to the ex-Presidents of the club in the clubhouse, 120 West Fifty-ninth Street, last night. The building was brilliantly illuminated for the occasion. The table was set in one of the upper rooms and the menu was elaborate.

-- The Jersey City Tennis Club will hold its annual open tournament on its grounds, at Bergen Avenue and Highland Avenue, on June 5 and following days. The events will be gentlemen's singles and doubles, and the entrance fee for singles is $1, and doubles $2 a team. Entries may be sent to H.L. Scott, 545 Bramhall Avenue, Jersey City Heights, N.J. Entries close June 2.

Merchants are disturbed not a little over the situation in respect to the Indian Warehouse. Its removal from this city to Chicago was ordered by the Secretary of the Interior March 12. The Commissioner of Indian Affairs was credited with having secured the order, as he hails from Chicago. Naturally a protest was raised in New-York, and upon representations that appealed to Secretary Hoke Smith as sound and business-like he revoked the order.
The belief that the destruction of the Brooklyn Tabernacle was caused by an incendiary is growing to an almost absolute certainty in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The tariff situation may be summed up in a few words.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 15 -- At this morning's session of the convention of the United Mine Workers of America the wage question was the sole topic of discussion. The meeting was secretly conducted, and a number of operators were denied admission. The Scale Committee was called upon for its report, and the Chairman read a voluminous document.

John J. Morris, a retired merchant of 1 West Eighty-first Street, was stricken with apoplexy about noon yesterday in front of 77 Church Street. An ambulance removed him in an unconscious condition to Chambers Street Hospital.

The stock market yesterday showed a slight revival in activity, but the volume of trading was still small. The opening was so very tame that, until after the first fifteen minutes, there was not a transaction in Rock Island or Burlington, and only one in St. Paul. Sugar was allowed to decline by the pool manipulating it, although the net loss on the day was only 1 1/4 points.

In the easiest possible manner the Brooklyns defeated the Washingtons yesterday. They outbatted and out-fielded the Senators, and were never headed after the opening inning. Petty, formerly of the New-Yorks, pitched for the Washingtons, and his curves were batted all over the field. The score:

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Among the serious charges that Secretary, Herbert is investigating on the coast-defense ship Monterey at San Francisco is one relating to the virtual ruining of the hydraulic turrets, which contain the big twelve-inch rifies of the ship's battery.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The State Department this morning received a telegram from Minister Baker announcing that the Nicaraguan Government had given satisfactory assurances of prompt compliance with the peremptory demands of the United States in relation to the punishment of the murderer of Mr. Wilson, the American who was killed at Pama in March.

UTICA, N.Y., May 15 -- Bernhardt Oldenberger, who shot Katie Rupp in the woods at Snake Hill, N.J., was arrested on the Chicago Limited train here at 10:30 tonight. He confessed that he tried to kill her, but could not tell why.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, May 15 -- The Bering Sea fleet which had been, rendezvousing here since the middle of April sailed to-day. Official orders arrived Sunday night, accompanied by a copy of the British edict, on the arrival of which the departure has been hinging. The fleet includes the war ships Mohican, Adams, and Alert, the cruiser Yorktown, and the cutters Hush and Albatross.

Charles T. Barney, Edward Edes, C.H. Leland, John A. Stewart, and Charles C. Seaman were witnesses before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary in the Northern Pacific hearing, in the Mills Building yesterday. Mr. Barney, who was a Director of the Northern Pacific, said that Thomas F. Oakes knew nothing about the Rocky Fork and Cooke City Railroad transaction.

-- For the past few years W.J.K. Kenny, who is Supervisor of The City Record, has been endeavoring to get the laws relative to that publication amended so that one section will not conflict with the other. He has just succeeded in doing so. Gov. Flower has signed the bill which makes the necessary changes and which Supervisor Kenny caused to be introduced.

Probably the largest crowd of people that has assembled at a race course in this State since the war was at the Gravesend track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday to see Dr. Rice win the Brooklyn Handicap. It was the opening of the racing season in this State, and 40,000 persons were at the track to attest the popularity of the sport.
Man and Wife Paired. From American Industries. "I have Just discovered," said the woman who is struck with an idea every once in a while, "why it is that the men don't want us to vote."

A musical festival in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary at the consecration of Bishop Littlejohn of the Diocese of Long Island was held last night in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Luke, Clinton Avenue, near Fulton Street, Brooklyn. Many persons with tickets were turned away from the stately church, so great was the throng in attendance.
Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

Augustus Barnett, son of Aaron Barnett, a wealthy linen merchant at 44 Leonard Street, and Aaron Silberberg of 256 West Forty-fourth Street, said to be an actor, were held in $3.000 ball each yesterday in the Jefferson Market Police Court on charges of extortion and perjury.

-- A resolution has been adopted by the Halifax Board of Trade strongly favoring the South Shore Railway from Yarmouth to Shelburne, Nova Scotia, as against the Coast Railway. Both companies profess a willingness to build a railway between the same points. The first-named company is prepared to proceed with the construction of a standard-gauge road, the latter proposing to build a narrow-gauge.

School Commissioner Randolph Guggenheimer has bought, through Messrs. M. L. Hess, from Jonas Kolb, the six-story iron-front business building, 175 and 177 Greece Street, 40 by 100, for $150,000. In exchange Mr. Guggenheimer has given thirteen lots on the north side of One Hundred and First Street. 76 feet east at Madison Avenue, at $80,000. These lots were taken in exchange by Mr. Gussenheimer for the Columbia and West End apartment houses in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Yesterday wheat broke with the news nearly all bullish. To-day the market, with like inconsistency, advanced under conditions that are ordinarily considered conducive to a decline. Why the course of prices should be in direct opposition to the trend of the advices was enigmatical to the trade, who finally accepted the situation in the light of a natural recovery from the late depressed state of the market.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 16 -- The result of the charter election on Tuesday leaves the canvass for Mayor in such shape that the courts may have to decide who is elected.

Increased activity was the feature of yesterday's stock market, but, as on the previous day, the selling was considerably better than the buying. The bear leaders were active, and they were successful in dislodging a certain amount of long stock. London was a seller, but principally of the receivership stocks, the impression across the water being that coming reorganizations will involve heavy assessments.

Fire swept the East River bluffs, from Sixty-seventh to Seventy-first Street, at break of day yesterday, and destroyed John F. Schultheis's two picnic grounds, Jones's Wood and Washington Park; wrecked a number of dwellings and stables and a stoneyard, obliterated the Street-Cleaning Department's pier at Seventieth Street, and burned the Sheds over the machinery and shaft of the East River tunnel.

Up to the ninth inning yesterday the Brooklyns looked like losers in their ball game with the Washingtons. The latter had been playing a remarkably strong game and were in the lead by figures of 2 to 1. But the uncertainty of the national sport again manifested itself, and, just when the poor, forlorn Senators were about to congratulate themselves, victory was changed to defeat.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- There is the promise of a sensation in connection with the resolution introduced in the Senate to-day by Mr. Lodge, which calls for an investigation of the charges that attempts have been made to bribe Senators, and that the sugar schedule of the Tariff bill was revised in the interest of the Sugar Trust by reason of the large contribution made by the trust to the Democratic campaign fund in 1892.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Georgetown University and the University of Virginia ball teams played here to-day for the college championship of the South, Georgetown winning easily by a score of 20 to 0. The grounds were in a miserable condition owing to a heavy fall of rain before and during the game. Score:

Brooklyn came very near having another disastrous fire yesterday, and had it not been for a sufficient supply of water a big business block might have been in ashes. Chief Engineer Dale demonstrated that he was thoroughly capable of handling a fire with proper facilities at hand.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- There have been many ridiculous stories published lately regarding the navy, and, to some persons interested in the service, there has seemed to be a systematic attempt to find an error in everything relating to new ships of war.

Ninety-year-old Lena Samsmullur was murdered late Tuesday night or early yesterday morning by her son Charles, fifty years old. After nearly severing his mother's head from her body with a razor, the son killed himself by cutting his throat.

-- The Tankers Coal Company is the title of a new organization formed in that city having as its object the keeping of the price of coal down as low as possible by lessening the expenses of the Individual dealer The company is composed of the coal dealers of Yonkers who have during the past Winter done all in their power to help the poor of the city.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 16 -- Six thousand people witnessed the second day's events of the great international regatta to-day. Gaudaur and Durnan rowed, a double scull race for three miles against Teemer and Hosmer. The second crew rowed so strong and so well that the old-timer Gaudaur and his partner were completely done for when they landed at the safety line.

LONDON. May 16 -- Advices from Rio de Janeiro say that the Brazilian Government forces, under command of Gens. Juca and Tigre, have been defeated in a battle with the insurgents, near Iguazu, on the river of that name, which divides the States of Sao Paulo and Rio Grande do Sul. The Federals had 140 men killed in the engagement.

The indications are that the big tri-State relay road race from The New-York Times office to the baseball grounds in Philadelphia on June 2 will be a grand success. In Pennsylvania. New-Jersey, and New-York the fast road riders are preparing themselves so as to be in the finest condition on the day of the race.

Charles W. Brooke made a great struggle yesterday to save the life of Dr. Henry Meyer, accused of poisoning Ludwig Brandt. From 11:30 in the morning until 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Mr. Brooke addressed the jury in defense of Dr. Meyer. A recess was taken from 1 o'clock until 2, but with this exception the entire day's session was consumed by the speech of Meyer's advocate.

Upon the whole, it is a very good thing that Coxey and the Coxeyites have been impelled to make their "demonstrations." The solid and respectable citizens have as good reason to be grateful that they turned out "with boots on," in order to be looked at and counted, as Scaliger had for "thanking God that He had put it into the hearts of some men to make dictionaries."

Everybody who takes any interest in such matters understands the motives of Peter De Lacy in his efforts to prevent poolselling at race tracks under the protection of what is known as the Ives law. That law gives a practical monopoly of poolselling on horse races to the managers of the tracks, or at least limits the practice to the tracks or grounds of incorporated racing associations, and to the authorized racing days thereon.
PEMBERTON, N.J., May 16 -- This village had a narrow escape from destruction by fire lo-day. Nearly all the houses are of wood, and the flames spread rapidly.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Ten pages of the Agricultural Appropriation bill disposed of in the Committee of the Whole was the net result of nearly five hours' session of the House to-day.
Meetings were held from morning until night yesterday in the annual May Congress of the Salvation Army.
A million dollars to bribe Senators and thus kill the Wilson bill.

The first sale of yearlings and two-year-old thoroughbreds in the North this year brought a large crowd of turfmen to the American Horse Exchange last night. The consignment of, yearlings was from A.J. Alexander's Woodburn Stud. Owing to the uncertain state of racing in this vicinity at present, the prices were rather low. The forty-one head sold for $11,420, an average of $270 per head.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- It is altogether likely that Mr. Harris will to-morrow endeavor to secure the assent of the Senate to his proposition that the daily sessions shall begin at 10 o'cloc-k. The motion to that effect which he introduced a few days ago lies upon the table, and he thinks it should now receive attention.

BOSTON, May 16 -- The Committee on Railroads to-day gave a hearing on the petition, with accompanying bill, of Gordon Abbott and others for incorporation as the New-England and New-York Railroad Company. The incorporators are Gordon Abbott, A.S. Bigelow, Charles F. Adams, second, Francis C. Lowell, A.C. Tower, Stephen M. Weld, T. Jefferson Coolidge, Jr., all of Massachusetts; Henry W. Cannon and John I. Waterbury of New-York.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- There has been much interest in the Navy Department in finding out who made the mistake on the Columbia, in placing the port-hole plates of the four-pound guns. It was found that these guns could not be elevated, the tube being jammed against the top of the port holes.

Keokuk, Iowa, May 16 -- A decree has been entered in the Superior Court foreclosing a two-hundred-and-fifty-thousand-dollar mortgage on the Fort Madison Water and Light Company in favor of the Central Trust Company of New-York. The plant will be sold to satisfy the claim.
Louis Clovis Bonaparte, a grandnephew of the first Napoleon, died Monday in London.

It was learned yesterday in Brooklyn that the plan of the counsel for the people in the election prosecutions for an Extraordinary Grand Jury to continue the investigation in Brooklyn and Gravesend had been abandoned. It was also learned that it had been decided to indict no more Gravesenders for participation in the McKane frauds last November.

Instead of a deserted race course, such a usually follows such a day as the running of a Brooklyn or Suburban Handicap, there were some 5,000 or more people at the Gravesend track yesterday. It was a crowd that was out for business instead of fun, however, and in the intervals between race packed the betting ring and left the grand stand deserted.

It is difficult to understand why a duty on zinc or spelter is retained in the pending Tariff bill. The House imposed a duty of 20 per cent., and the Senate committee has neither reduced nor increased it. The zinc producers in this country not only supply the home demand, but also export large quantities of the metal, as the following official figures show:

-- Justice Barrett, in Supreme Court, Chambers, Saturday last, granted an injunction to John Power of 83 Cedar Street, restraining the Clearing House Building Company from tearing down the premises 83 Cedar Street, as Power claimed to have a ten-year option on the premises, under the conditions of a lease entered into in April, 1884.

BOSTON, May 16 -- Despite the fact that the section burned over by last night's fire covers an area of from ten to twelve acres, on which stood nearly 200 buildings which served as dwellings for about 2,000 people, the actual loss will be comparatively small. This is due to the peculiarly cheap class of buildings which were erected in this neighborhood.

Commissioner Wurster of the Brooklyn Fire Department yesterday finished his informal inquiry into the Brooklyn Tabernacle fire on Sunday, and came to the conclusion that it was due to electric sparks.

TRENTON, N. J., May 16. -- Unless the programme shall go wrong again, the Legislature will to-morrow afternoon quit business and reassemble next Wednesday to pass over his head any partisan bills that the Governor may veto in the recess. The Legislature expects to be able to finish this business in two or three days, and then it will take a recess until September or October.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 16 -- The second day of the circuit meeting at the Gentlemen's Driving Park promised well, as the classes were faster than those of Tuesday. Just before the 2:29 trot, which was carried over from yesterday after four heats, a smart shower fell, but this only made the track smoother for the time.

The Rev. Thomas Powers Field died yesterday, in Amherst, Mass., of heart trouble. He was born in Northfield, Mass., and was graduated from Amherst in the class of '34. He went to Andover Theological Seminary, but, after two years of study there, returned to Amherst, and held a position as tutor for two years, after which he finished his course at Andover.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 16 -- The strike of the brickyard laborers is spreading to many yards down the river, and the men here, who started the movement, boast that in a few days there will not be a yard in operation along the entire river.

Charles Coghlan has become reconciled to his first wife and has broken with Kuehne Beveridge, whom he married about six months ago. The reunited couple are now living in an up-town boarding house in this city.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 16 -- The annual convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island was held in the crypt of the Cathedral of the Incarnation to-day. It was the twenty-eighth session of the body, and particular interest was taken in its deliberations, coming as it did during the period of celebration of the quarter century of service rendered by Bishop Littlejohn.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Certain ancient gods, it is said, when they wished to destroy persons against whom they had acquired an unpleasant feeling, first made them mad. It seems as though somebody with method akin to that of these oldtime deities had attacked the protectionists of this country.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Preparations have been completed for the greatest armor test thus far made by the Government, and it is possible that the first attack upon the maximum ship protection may be made to-morrow with the highest uower rifles yet constructed at Indian Head unless Commodore Sampson, Chief of Ordnance, shall be detained at Pittsburg, in which event the trials will take place on Saturday.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 16 -- The Commissioners-eleot to the one hundred and sixth Presbyterian General Assembly are here in readiness for the opening session, which begins at 11 o'clock to-morrow. The small hotels and boarding houses are crowded. The Moderator, Dr. Craig, and the leaders of the conservative side are quartered at the Adelphi and at the Balch House.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 16 -- Katie Rupp, who was shot by Bernhardt Altenberger at Snake Hill on Sunday, died at 11:15 to-night.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., May 16 -- Miss Emma Reynolds Moody, daughter of Evangelist Dwight L. Moody, was married at 6 o'clock this evening in the Congregational Church to Arthur P. Fitt of Chicago. The students in the young ladies' seminary, the pupils of Mount Hermon School, and many personal friends were present.

Jones's Wood or Coliseum, Avenue A to the East River, from Sixty-eighth to Sixty-ninth Street and Washington Park, from Avenue A to the East River, from Sixty-ninth to Seventieth Street, buildings owned by J.F. Schulthies and ground by the Jones estate. Loss estimated by Schulthies at $300,000, but by insurance experts at $200,000; partly insured.

Senator Gallinger of New-Hampshire represents a civilized community, and he is not a Henry W. Blair. In fact, he was chosen to succeed Blair upon the express ground that he was not Blair -- that is to say that he was not the kind of man who regarded the emptying of his own mind as more urgent and important than all other affairs, including the business of the United States of America.

The Park Commissioners formally agreed yesterday to comply with the law in regard to preserving the continuous sidewalk on the river side along the Harlem River Driveway. They passed a resolution sent to them by the Corporation Counsel instructing the engineer to prepare revised plans. The Corporation Counsel informed the Commissioners that, in his opinion, the act was imperative in the requirement of a sidewalk on each side of the driveway.

PAWTUCKET, R.L, May 16 -- A column of black smoke, rising from a wide area and mounting high into the sky before it spread, attracted attention from all sections within a radius of ten miles of Pawtucket this afternoon. In that column of smoke there went up over $500,000 worth of property, and all of the large coal and lumber yards in Pawtucket were practically swept away.

BERLIN, May 10 -- There was war m the International Miners' Congress this morning in consequence of a misunderstanding of the translations of the official interpreters. Delegates Wilson, Lamendin, and Struntz, representing the English, French, and German, had been selected to act as presiding officers for the day.

MOSCOW, May 10 -- Six peasants living near the town of Ostrogoisk have recently engaged in wholesale thefts of wood from the forests of Peskow, selling the wood and bribing the keepers of the forest with part of the proceeds. One of the keepers, a man named Goworoff, refused their bribes, and threatened them with punishment if they continued their thefts.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 16 -- The second day of the great coal conference opened with two meetings behind closed doors. The miners held a consultation, and so did the operators.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 16 -- The Democratic State Convention has nominated Francis M. Black for Supreme Court Judge, W.T. Carrington for Superintendent of Public Instruction, and Joseph H. Finks for Railroad Commissioner.

Although the majority of society people have left town for their country homes or Europe, the Berkeley Lyceum was well filled with a fashionable audience last evening when the Students' Dramatic Club gave an interesting theatrical entertainment. Two clever plays were unusually well presented.

LONDON, May 10 -- The Government has received intimation from United States Ambassador Bayard that the United States Government desires to recede from the Berlin agreement in regard to Samoa, provided that all the rights of citizens of the United States in Samoa are safeguarded.

The cosey little clubhouse of the Corinthian mosquito fleet on Echo Bay, at New-Rochelle, is open for the season. Commodore Pryer's flagship, the sloop Eurybia, is anchored in the bay. Several other yachts are anchored there, and by the end of the week there will be quite a large fleet in commission.

-- Milton Fuerst, sixteen years old, of 244 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, was arrested at the Barclay Street Ferry yesterday, as he was about to start for Chicago. Fuerst was employed as bookkeeper by H.A. Rosenfeld Co. of 95 Bleecker Street, hat manufacturers. He was discharged last week, and on Tuesday, it is said, forged a check for $300 on the Mechanics and Traders' Bank, signing Mr. Rosenfeld's name to it.

Although Mr. Seidl has gone to the Catskills and washed his hands of German opera for a year, convinced that two projects cannot succeed and that he cannot agree with Mr. Walter Damrosch, and although Mr. Damrosch has gone to Europe to engage artists for his season, the war between the two armies of supporters of the conductors goes merrily on.

Among the well-known persons who sailed for Europe yesterday were the Earl of Warwick, Mrs. T. De Witt Talmage and Miss Talmage, George J. Gould and family, the Rev. H.H. Stebbins, D.D.; Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, W.B. Leonard, Elbridge T. Gerry, A. Bierstadt, Willls S. Paine, the Right Rev. Charles R. Hale, D.D., and Peter Cooper Hewitt.

ALBANY, May 16 -- Gov. Flower made a record for himself to-day by vetoing nineteen bills. The only measure of importance which he signed was that of Mr. Taylor (Rep., Kings,) placing the Brooklyn Bridge policemen upon the same footing as the Brooklyn policemen in regard to salaries.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- Notwithstanding the weakness in New-York, the Philadelphia market was fairly steady. Pennsylvania was inclined to be heavy, and sold around 49 1/2. Lehigh Valley was comparatively quiet, but there was a good demand for it all day at 37. Reading was featureless, and declined only very slightly.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 16 -- Half a million dollars will scarcely cover the damage done by the great storm of yesterday and last night in Minnesota and Western Wisconsin. The downpour of rain was the greatest ever known in this section of the Northwest, and in many places was as destructive as a waterspout.

-- Andrew Zeiloth of 307 East Thirty-eighth Street, twelve years a butler for E.C. Benedict at 1O West Fifty-first Street, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Cowing, in Part III, of the General Sessions, to an indictment charging him with grand larceny in the second degree. Mr. Benedict sat beside Judge Cowing to hear the sentence.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- There was another and much more serious break in the stock market to-day. The unfavorable reports made by the West Chicago and City Railway Companies affected the surface roads stocks, and, as a consequence, all of them showed a falling off. The L road stocks were also weaker, and the softness extended through the entire list.

LONDON, May 16 -- The committee which is arranging the banquet to be given to the officers of the United States cruiser Chicago on May 24 received letters of regret this afternoon from Lord Rosebery, Earl Spencer, and many other conspicuous men, who will be compelled to attend official dinners on the same evening, in celebration of the Queen's birthday.
Peter De Lacy kept his threat to continue his fight against the Broklyn Jockey Club yesterday.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 16 -- Democrats who believe in standing by the National Administration feel very joyful to-night, as the returns from the County Conventions held to-day indicate almost beyond a doubt that Congressman William C. Oates has the Democratic nomination for Governor over Joseph F. Johnston, free silverite and antiAdministration.
FIRST RACE -- For mares three years old and upward; a sweepstakes of $15 each, with $1,000 added, of which $200 to second and $100 to third. One mile and a sixteenth.

BOSTON, May 17. -- State Street Block, a six-story granite structure, bounded by Atlantic Avenue on the east, India Street on the south, and State Street on the north, was badly damaged and part of its contents ruined by fire and water early this morning. It was used as a United States bonded warehouse.

Miss Mary L. Darragh, who is an Inspector in the Custom House, applied to the Court of Common Pleas to have her father. Robert L. Darragh, a well-known and wealthy contractor and builder, adjudged insane, and to have a committee appointed to care for his person and estate.

Dr. T.S. Waring, one of the house physicians of Bellevue Hospital, was suspended on Thursday by the Commissioners of Charities and Correction for alleged infringement of the rules. It is alleged that he diagnosed wrongly the case of Juliette Haushon, a nurse, who was brought to the hospital from Swinburne Island on April 26. Health Officer Jenkins diagnosed the case at the time as typhoid fever.

Camped out on the narrow sidewalk in front of the tall tenement house 19 Allen Street, Mrs. Sarah Goldberger and her four little children spent Wednesday night and all day yesterday. The unfortunate family had been evicted because they owed $4, two weeks' rent. It was a piteous sight and excited the commiseration of the residents of a neighborhood where poverty is widespread and suffering is common.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- It was the old story on the local stock market, raid after raid being made by the bears, and all more or less successful. West Chicago Street Railway received the greatest attention, but the weakness was so pronounced that it was reflected in other stocks. About 5,000 shares of West Chicago were sold.

-- The Century Cycle Club of Newark held its entertainment in Association Hall Wednesday night. F. Madden Frint played several instruments, including the banjo, and Miss Mabel Rutan gave piano selections. Miss Emlly McElroy and Miss Irving S. Albey received a great ceal of applause, the former for her recitals, and the latter for her soprano solos.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Army and navy officers are sticklers for etiquette, and there is no better illustration to what extent they will go to secure a decision than a recent occurrence when certain naval officers used up some of Secretary Herbert's time.

Interests that centre in the Wall Street district have kept close watch upon tariff proceeding's at Washington, and probably nowhere have the reports bearing upon this measure been read more carefully. Although the district is one in which men are accustomed to deal with the unexpected, the news that open bribery had been attempted to defeat the Wilson bill was somewhat staggering.

The Bridgeport Traction Company of Bridgeport, Conn., which comprises the entire street railway system of that city, has sold to Redmond, Kerr Co., bankers of New-York, its issue of $1,300,000 first mortgage bonds, and with the proceeds of the sale will equip the entire system with electricity.

The Protest Committee, having in charge the petitions against striking the word male as a qualification for voters from the State Constitution, announces through Mrs. Arthur M. Dodge that its work has been brought to a successful conclusion.

The Rev. Dr. J.O. Peck. The Rev. Dr. J.O. Peck, Corresponding Secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church of the United States, died yesterday morning at the Hotel St. George, in Brooklyn. He had been for several years a sufferer from Bright's disease, and for the last ten days was confined to his bed, suffering great agony.

A decision of the Supreme Court will be had on the question as to the legality of horse racing, betting, poolselling, and bookmaking. By arrangement of the counsel of the officials of The Jockey Club and the Brooklyn Jockey Club and Peter De Lacy, proceedings will be had to-day in the case against Philip J. Dwyer which will eventually bring it before the Supreme Court.

Considerable interest has been occasioned of late among stamp collectors and dealers throughout the country by a corner which has been formed by certain dealers in the stamps of the Columbian issue. These stamps, so much despised on their first issue, now command a substantial premium, particularly those of the larger denominations.
Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

ST. PAUL, May 17 -- The loss by the flood in Pierce County was at least $100,000. Rush River rose high above its banks, carrying along every bridge from the headwaters to the Mississippi River. At Martelle, El Paso, and other places flouring and saw mills were swept along by the flood, entailing losses of which no accurate estimate can be formed.

With the annexation of the town of Flatbush to Brooklyn, the free postal delivery system was extended into the new territory, but with it a change in postal rates was inaugurated. Postmaster Sullivan has issued this circular regarding it:

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 17 -- The one hundred and sixth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church was convened to-day by W.G. Craig, the retiring Moderator, in the auditorium of the First Presbyterian Church. The Assembly is composed largely of new men, few of whom have taken any part in the struggles that have brought the Presbyterian Church into prominence the past few years.

Dr. Clarence Sharp, the Junior Warden of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Archangel, at St. Nicholas Avenue and One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, accompanied by Frank Keck, a prominent member of the church, and Walter Stabber, the clerk of the Vestry, called on Bishop Potter at the See House in Lafayette Place yesterday, and presented a petition requesting the resignation of the Rev. Ralph Wood Kenyon, rector of the parish.
Additional testimony was taken yesterday before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary in the matter of the alleged irregularities in the past management of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company.

LONDON, May 17 -- The British Royal Commission to the World's Fair at Chicago has just issued its report. Its tone is decidedly favorable to the exhibition. It gives an excellent description of the exhibits and concludes by saying:

Mr. John N. Golding has sold for Mrs. N.E. Baylies to Dr. George H. Butler the lot 25.6 by 100, on Fifth Avenue, 76.8 feet south of Seventy-eighth Street. For Dr. Butler, Mr. Golding has sold the dwelling, with stable, at 42 East Sixty-sixth Street.

The naval court of inquiry which convened yesterday at the British Consulate to consider the circumstances of the grounding of the steamer Persian Monarch on the Long Island shore decided to deprive Capt. Robert James Bristow of his master's certificate for six months and to grant to him during his suspension a first officer's certificate.

Higher prices were the rule during the first hour of Business in the stock market yesterday. They were due to the covering of short contracts, and it was noticeable that when the covering movement ceased the general list declined. The ease with which stocks were obtained was regarded as good evidence that the quiet liquidation which has been in progress for several days was still going on.
BOSTON, May 17 -- There is no doubt in the minds of the young men at Harvard College to-day that there were five victims in the yachting accident off City Point last Sunday afternoon.

If the Democratic Senators at Washington had been politically sagacious and loyal to their party they would long since have passed the Tariff bill. If through a late awakening they should now become sagacious and loyal they would immediately have done with their tangle of amendments and get the bill to a vote.

CAPE MAY, N.J., May 17 -- A short battle took place at Woodbine this afternoon when 150 men began to take away the crossing placed last night on the West Jersey's tracks by employes of the South Jersey Railroad.

The home of Mrs. Fred Oppermann, Jr., 154 East Forty-sixth Street, was the scene of a pretty home wedding last night, when her daughter, Miss Mamie Oppermann, was married to William G. Ringler. Only near relatives of the bride and bridegroom attended the wedding. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. L. Halfmann of the Lutheran Immanuel Church.

LINCOLN, Mass., May 17 -- Early this morning James Farrar discovered two men in his room. He arose, and the men jumped from one of the windows. Farrar summoned assistance, and he and several other citizens followed the burglars, who were joined in the street by three other men.

PARIS, May 17 -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Government was interpellated on the circular of Mgr. Ferrata, the Papal Nuncio to France, to the French Bishops respecting the law regulating Church Wardens' accounts.

Mayor Schieren, Commissioner White, Chief Engineer Van Brunt Bergen, Architect Wundrum, Superintendent of Ponds and Conduits Skilton, Dr. Johnson of the Health Department, and fourteen members of the Board of Aldermen inspected the Brooklyn water system on Wednesday. The party visited the most important points along the line, stopping at Jamaica, Baisley's Pond, Springfield, Milburn, Ridgewood, and Rockville Centre.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Before the Republicans of the Senate have seen the end of the investigation that their allies, the protected manufacturers, in their desperate determination to kill the Tariff bill at any price have brought about, they will have about all the investigation they want. While there seemed to be a chance of investigating only the charges they had accumulated against the manipulators of the sugar tax, they were satisfied.

Dr. Henry Meyer's life is in the hands of the jury chosen to try him. At 5 o'clock yesterday the case was completed on both sides. Recorder Smyth began his charge at 6:30 and finished at 9:10, when the jury went out to deliberate.

-- David B. Sickels, receiver of the Harlem River Bank, wants less expensive accommodations for the bank and some assistants who are willing to work for small pay to help wind up its affairs. A motion to this effect was made on behalf of the receiver to Chief Justice Daly at a Special Term of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.
TRENTON, N.J., May 17 -- Gov. Werts appointed the following as the commission of twenty to suggest amendments to the Constitution for the revision of the judicial system of the State:

The Brooklyn Tabernacle, which was consumed by fire last Sunday, was a huge under box. Instead of being plastered in the usual way, it was sheathed throughout, above, below, and on all sides, with a preparation of paper stock and straw fibre, macerated, soaked in boiling resin, and then covered with oils and paints.

ALBANY, May 17 -- Gov. Flower has not acted upon any of the four important New-York City bills yet awaiting his action -- the Rapid-Transit bill, the Non-Partisan Police Commission bill, the bill increasing pay of patrolmen, and the Elevated Railway Continuous Fare bill.

T.T. Timayenis, a Greek manufacturer, of 25 Vandewater Street makes serious charges against the police, who, he asserts, are persecuting Greek flower peddlers. He says also that the peddlers, when taken to the Tombs Police Court, are unjustly treated and cannot say a word in their own defense, as they cannot speak English, and the interpreter at the court cannot either understand or speak Greek.

Although Miss Rose Coghlan acts every part she undertakes considerably more than very well indeed, yet it is, perhaps, as Peg Woffington that she gives most brilliant and conclusive evidence of her powers and talents, best proves her competency to express with equal skill emotions widely different, and to the highest degree wins the sympathy, as well as the admiration, of her auditors.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Should any of the migratory bands of Coxeyites throughout the country succeed in reaching this city, the police authorities will arrest them under the vagrant laws, and the tramps will be liable to a three months' commitment to the workhouse farm.

Henry King, twenty years old, of 568 West Twenty-fifth Street, was arrested about 11 o'clock last night by Policeman William Gray on a charge of trying to set fire to Eben Peek's lumber yard in Eleventh Avenue, between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Streets. Frederick Fielding, of Corona L.I., saw King place a lighted candle underneath a stack of pitch pine, and called to the policeman, who knocked the candle over and placed King under arrest.

The thirty-sixth anniversary and commencement exercises of the Packard Business College were held last evening in the Music Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. In a short but felicitous speech Mr. Packard welcomed his friends.

BOSTON, May 17 -- Local stocks were not active, and quotations generally did not differ materially from those of yesterday. Lamson Store Service sold at 22, the same as the close last night. The annual meeting of stockholders was held to-day, and the old Board of Directors was elected. Wisconsin Central 5s dropped 5 1/2 points, selling at 64 for a small lot.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A pilot chart of the great lakes is proposed on the order of the publications relating to the North Atlantic and the Pacific. A preliminary chart appeared to-day. Commander Sigsbee, the chief of the Naval Hydrographic Office, says it is not intended to go into the subject of the weather as exhibited on the Atlantic chart, for which there is not an appropriation and perhaps not the necessity.

Charles F. Hoffman, thirty years old, who has no home, Wednesday made such a strange declaration of his intention to become a citizen that a policeman arrested him, and he is now awaiting examination as to his sanity.

Rondout, N.Y., May 17 -- M.J. McNaught of Hobart, a young man belonging to one of the first families in Delaware County, died a few days ago at a gold-cure establishment in Cornwall, where he had gone for treatment for the liquor habit. A few years ago he inherited $20,000, which he quickly Squandered by bad speculations made while he was under the influence of liquor.

A train of five cars, composing the South Norwalk local on the New-Haven Railroad, crashed into the bumper while being switched into the Grand Central Station yesterday morning. One passenger was severely injured. The blame for the accident is laid on Conductor Warren, who was in charge of the train.

Virginia Stuart, a young lady of Philadelphia, came to New-York to act the part of Pauline Deschappelles in "The Lady of Lyons." A performance of Bulwer's wornout drama was given in Palmer's Theatre yesterday afternoon for that purpose. This, it is understood, was the preparatory note of a "starring tour," presumably in the oil region.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 17 -- Sheriff Toffey to-day made a formal demand upon Jailer Davis for the surrender of the HudBon County Jail, having been advised by his counsel that under the new law he is responsible for the safekeeping of the prisoners.

ALBANY, May 17 -- Gov. Flower has received notice from the Secretary of the Navy that several United States men-of-war will be in readiness the latter part of July or early in August for the benefit of the two divisions of the Naval Reserve of this State.

With a banquet which represented a cost of 15 cents for each participant, the May Congress of the Salvation Army was closed yesterday. In the morning there was an officers' council in the Calvary Baptist Church. Nearly 500 staff, field, and local officers were present.
BRYAN, Ohio, May 17 -- The village of Kunkle, in Williams County, was almost entirely destroyed by a cyclone this afternoon.

-- One of the best players in Brooklyn is Harry C. McGowan of the Kings County Tennis Club. He never has done very much in tournaments, although he made W. Gordon Parker play three sets to beat him in the Prospect Heights tournament, but plays much better in practice. This is probably caused by the fact that he has not yet acquired that nerve and pluck which is the result of frequent tournament practice.

Despite the exposure of the methods of the New-York Juvenile Guardian Society made in The New-York Times some months ago, the society persists in soliciting contributions from the community. There was an investigation into the doings of the society by a special committee of the State Board of Charities, consisting of Dr. Stephen Smith, Edward H. Litchfield, and Oscar Craig, President of the board, and the findings of this committee were published last January.

The New-York Times's relay race to Philadelphia is an absorbing topic among the wheelmen of Brooklyn. Several of the clubs there will make entries in the race, and the riders are confident that the handsome prizes to be given to the members of the winning team will go to the riders from New-York State.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Ex-Congressman John B. Clark of Missouri is lying in a critical condition at a private sanitarium in this city. Last Thursday he was compelled to submit to a serious surgical operation for kidney troubles. It is said to be the first operation of the kind ever performed at the national capital.

The Staton Island Cricket Club sent a team of only eight men to play the New-Jersey Athletic Club at Bergen Point yesterday afternoon, and, consequently, it was easily defeated, with an inning to spare. T. Hope-Simpson did the best work for the islanders in both innings, securing double figures both times; while Wright did the best work with the ball.

Proceeding have been instituted by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company as Trustee to foreclose a mortgage of $750,000, given by the Charles S. Higgins Company of Brooklyn to secure an issue of bonds for that amount. The preliminary papers were filed in the office of the County Clerk, Brooklyn, yesterday.
At the last meeting of the Trustees of Barnard College, May 11. Miss James-Smith was chosen Dean. She will enter upon her duties at the beginning of the next collegiate year, in October.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The armament for the coast defenses is being satisfactorily completed. In another month there will have been finished at the army gun factory forty-two eight-inch, forty-one ten-inch, and twenty twelve-inch guns, the calibres which will comprise the main strength of the emplacements.

A case that calls for the attention of the Department of Charities or some charitable organization exists on the top floor of 153 Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, where two aged widows live. They are Mrs. Jeanette Wier and her sister, Mrs. Margaret Archibald, who occupy two squalid apartments.

LONDON, May 17 -- The Queen, accompanied by the Prince of Wales and the Duke of Cambridge, journeyed to Aldershot this afternoon to witness the annual review of the troops on Laffan's Plain. They were received with appropriate ceremony by Gens. Sir Redvers H. Buller, Sir Henry Evelyn Wood, and Sir Francis Wallace Grenfell.

The Rev. George H. Boswell, pastor of one of the rival colored congregations at 451 Seventh Avenue, about which complaint has been made to the Board of Health because they worship in such a noisy manner, called on Sanitary Superintendent Roberts yesterday morning at the Health Department and stated his side of the trouble.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- All of the Democratic Senators are not fully alive to the importance of passing the Tariff bill without further delay and by revolutionary means if necessary. There are five or six Senators who have thus far refused to join the majority in an attempt to change the rules and decide upon a day when the final vote on the bill shall be taken.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 17 -- Advices from Bluefields, Nicaragua, bearing date of May 12, say:

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Senate has decided that there shall be an investigation of the charges of corruption which have been made concerning the Tariff bill. This action was taken this morning with commendable promptness. It is not comfortable to the Democratic majority that this investigation is due to resolutions introduced by a Republican Senator.

Representatives of organizations interested in improved municipal government from several cities met at the City Club, 677 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon and discussed proposed amendments to be submitted to the Constitutional Convention. The amendments proposed had been prepared by committees from the City Club and the Civil Service League.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 16 -- Harvard will send the following men to the intercollegiate games at Berkeley Oval May 26. Merrill is looked upon as a sure winner in the 440-yard dash, Bremer, the world's record man, in the 220-yard hurdles, and Bloss in the broad Jump. The other men are considered possible winners only:

At last the New-Yorks have won a game. Their victims were Capt. Foutz's aggregation of misfits, who have been taxing the patience of the baseball public of Brooklyn since the season started. This is how the game was won: Doyle was on the team, and he made three hits -- two singles and a two-bagger.

The announcement of the intention of the Navy Department to reuniform the seamen of the navy naturally arouses curiosity as to the reasons for the movement. The first thought that occurs is that the uniform of a sailor is pretty much the same the world over, and that it would be difficult to associate with Jack Tar in the popular mind any other form of costume.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 17 -- William C. Oates, the National Administration candidate for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination, undoubtedly will win over Joseph F. Johnston, anti-Administration and free silverite. He has 256 1/2 uncontested votes in the State Convention, or 3 1/2 votes more than necessary to nominate, while Johnston has but 236 1/2 votes.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 17 -- The conference between the representatives of 200,000 striking miners and operators representing every coal-mining district in the United States has ended in failure.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: While agreeing with much that is said in your able review (May 12) of "The Crisis in Exchanges," I venture to comment on your statement that "the theory that unlimited coinage at a fixed ratio will keep the two metals in circulation at that ratio has never been demonstrated in practice."

Senator Gorman of Maryland was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. He has been in this city for several days. During the forenoon messages came to him from Washington with reference to the proposed investigation under the Lodge resolution. He departed for Washington on the Congressional limited train.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Navy Department is having soms difficulty in securing efficient powder for its huge thirteen-inch guns. The explosive makers have not yet succeeded in meeting the required conditions, and, although their powder for guns of twelve-inch calibre is acceptable, it seems impossible to obtain the proper combination to secure the best results with the greatest rifles yet manufactured.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- The local bears displayed more confidence, and hammered away at the entire list. They took each stock in turn, and met with more or less success.

The new Suburban Riding and Driving Club, having failed to secure the McCormick villa, One Hundred and Seventy-second Street and King's Bridge Road, has obtained the Drake (formerly Seamen) Castle, King's Bridge Road and Two Hundred and Seventeenth Street.

There will be an investigation by the State Lunacy Commissioners of the insane asylums on Ward's, Hart's, and Blackwell's Islands, which are under the charge of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction of this city, growing out of the recent publication of charges of gross mismanagement and serious abuses on the part of the officials in charge of the Women's Insane Asylum, on Ward's Island.

-- When Collector Kilbreth released from seizure a fortnight ago the lithographic "Rape of Lucretia," bearing date 1537, which an art collector in this city obtained after it had been viewed without shock by passing generations in the Berin Museum, H.W. Gourley. Acting Naval Officer, took sides with the Inspector who had seized it. The Collector released it on the ground that it was a work of art.

Francis Coyle of the mounted Park police received a severe scalp wound yesterday while trying to stop a runaway horse near the entrance at Fifth Avenue and Fiftyninth Street, and two women received slight injuries.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.T., May 17 -- The only brickyards running to-day in the Fishkill district were Budd's, at Dutchess Junction, and Brockaway's and William H. Aldridge's north of Fishkill Landing. The two former are paying higher wages, but Mr. Budd does not guarantee to furnish work at the expiration of five days, and his men will then have to accept the new seak leave.

Two match races have been arranged between the Vigilant and the Valkyrie. The first race will be sailed over the Clyde course during the Clyde regatta week, and the second race will be over the English course for the Cape May and Brenton's Reef Cups -- that is, from Cowes to Cherbourg Breakwater and return. A gold cup is to be given to the winner of each race.

The result of the Democratic primaries and County Conventions in Alabama is at once a vindication of the method adopted there for determining the nomination for Governor and of the sound tendencies of the party in that State. In Alabama the State election takes place early in August, and the Democratic Convention is to be held next Tuesday.

Under the management of the Mutual Employment Society of New-York, organized recently at the Hotel Waldorf, a free labor exchange and employment bureau was opened Tuesday at 25 Clinton Place to secure employment for deserving artisans and others out of work.

The Rev. Joseph Norwood, agent for the American Bible Society in Venezuela, arrived at this port on the Red D Line steamer Philadelphia late Wednesday night. He was in Venezuela at the time of the recent terrible earthquakes, and when seen at the Bible House early yesterday morning, he gave an account of the disaster.

According to a bicyclist who is a long-distance road rider, "a common error made in connection with the care of a machine is that of excessive oiling. The novice is apt to think that if he only empties his can on his machine 'promiscuous like,' it is good enough, and, indeed, very well. In oiling up a bicycle there is a right way and a wrong way of doing the business.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., May 18 -- An assault case, by which it is sought to determine the ownership of about 100 acres of land at Arverne, valued at about $300,000, was tried before Justice Smith in this village to-day. The principals in the suit were F.C. Norton and Remington Vernam, who both lay claim to the property in dispute.
