CREEDMOOR, L.I., May 18 -- Companies G and H shot at Creedmoor to-day. The weather in the morning was threatening, with a light 5 o'clock wind, followed by clearing skies and a mild wind. There were 201 men present, all of whom qualified as marksmen. In the volley firing the result was Company G, 930 rounds, 446 hits; Company H. 960 rounds, 473 hits.

The fire which, on last Sunday afternoon, destroyed the Brooklyn Tabernacle, was the fourth in the building since its erection. Trustee and ex-Treasurer John Wood gave this information to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday. He said:

FLUSHING, L.I., May 18 -- An inquest was held to-night by Coroner Corey and a jury on the death, from eating poisoned oatmeal, of Mrs. John Sharkey of Springville, on April 27. Her husband was poisoned at the same time, but recovered. Mr. Sharkey testified that he and his wife had been poisoned in the early part of last November at Christmas, and at New Year.

Charles Scheff, twenty-three years old, of 33 Smith Street, Brooklyn, and Joseph Long, twenty-four years old, of 281 Bowery, New-York, were arrested in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, after an exciting chase, in which a servant girl, park laborers, and policemen were participants.

BRIDGETON, N.J., May 18 -- During a thunderstorm this morning the house of Zaccheus Johnson was struck by lightning. The bolt passed between Mrs. William Porch and her baby, who were in bed. The mother was burned on the shoulder and a streak was left on her neck and breast and holes were torn in her night dress.

BERLIN, May 18 -- The International Congress of Miners in Harmony Hall was on the verge of riot throughout to-day's session. The trouble was due to the differences of opinion between the English and Continental delegates and the arbitrary rulings of Chairman Wilson in favor of his own countrymen.

ALBANY, May 18 -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Senator Lexow's bill providing for the payment of the expenses of the Senate committee appointed to investigate the Police Department of the City of New-York, acting by order of a resolution of the Senate known as "Senate Document No. 27," adopted Jan. 3, 1894, and resolutions supplementary thereto.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., May 18 -- The campaign in the St. John's East District has been suspended until the completion of the second trial of Mr. Fox, the late Receiver General. The trial will take place May 28.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 18 -- With only her masts sticking out of the water the three-masted schooner M.J. Cummings is sunk in the bay south of the Straight Cut.
SARATOGA, May 18 -- The second day s session of the Presbyterian General Assembly was opened this morning with devotional exercises, after which the routine business began.

Two or three of our contemporaries still seem to think that they have found something of deep significance and great importance in that memorandum concerning the sugar duties alleged to have been forwarded to the Democrats of the Senate Committee on Finance "in Mr. Carlisle's own handwriting."

At the missionary meeting in the Chapel of Calvary Baptist Church last night, Dr. Stephen Smith, one of the American delegates to the recent International Sanitary Conference at Paris, talked of the work of the conference and the plans made to prevent the spread of cholera.

A petition signed by a number of influential gentlemen was received yesterday by Mayor Gilroy asking to have the new Harlem River Speedway laid out under the supervision of a competent landscape architect. A similar request had been previously presented to the Park Commissioners, but was not heeded by them.

Reports down town yesterday that Gov. Flower had decided to sign the Rapid-Transit bill had the effect not only of increasing the pressure to sell Manhattan Railway stock, which broke from 121 to 116 1/2, closing at 117 1/4, but they also stimulated renewed interest in the matter among members of the Chamber of Commerce.

Somewhere near 7,000 people went to the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday in hopes of seeing the much-talked-about Clifford try conclusions with Dr. Rice, the Brooklyn Handicap winner. They were both in the Parkway Handicap, at a mile and a sixteenth, which should be nearer Clifford's distance, as practically all his victories have been at a mile or less.
ROME, May 18 -- The Very Rev. Thomas M.A. Burke, Vicar General of the Diocese of Albany, has been nominated a Bishop of that diocese, to succeed the late Right Rev. Francis McNierney.
Theodore B. Smalley of 349 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, is suing the Fulton Bank, Brooklyn, in the Kings County Supreme Court, to recover $10,000. The case came up before Justice Bartlett yesterday.
Senator David B. Hill was in this city yesterday, and, with several Democratic politicians, proceeded to prepare the outline of a programme for the State Commutes during the next few months.
Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.
The New-York Yacht Club has amended its constitution so as to allow women who own yachts to become associate members, and has elected Mrs. Carnegie, the owner of the steamer Dungeness, to membership.

Application was made to Judge Lacomb in the United States District Court yesterday for an injunction to restrain the City of Brooklyn from disposing of certain property belonging to the heirs of Edwin C. Litchfield. This property was bought in 1860. Prospect Park now covers some of the tract which belonged to it originally.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A notable disposition to accelerate business was observable in the Senate to-day, and it was attributed to every cause except to the conviction on both sides of the chamber that here is a new storm of indignation brewing against the Senate.

The first lot from the consignment of thoroughbred yearlings from the Fairview stud of Gallatin, Tenn., was sold at the American Horse Exchange, Fiftieth Street and Broadway, last night by Auctioneer William Eastern.

While the Directors of the Harlem River Bank, which was closed by the State Banking Department on April 26, were helping themselves and their friends to loans on security more or less convertible, J.J. Kean, a bookkeeper, is said to have taken a share of the money of depositors by methods quite as depleting to the bank's assets.
CHICAGO, May 18 -- Lake Michigan has not been lashed and churned for months as it was to-day by the fierce wind that has been sweeping down from the north for the past thirty-six hours.
The Duke of veragua has made a gift to the Lenox Library of forty-six original documents of the Columbus family, which were exhibited at the Chicago World's Fair.

A circular to the 4 per cent. general mortgage bondholders of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad was issued yesterday bearing the signatures of Frederic P. Olcott, Adrian Iselin, Jr., J. Kennedy Tod, Henry Budge, and Thomas Denny.
Racing went on at the Brooklyn Jockey Club meeting without interruption yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- Very few stocks that pretend to be at all active could be called at all strong. Reading was one of the few exceptions. It was hammered and pounded, but at no time did it sell below 15 7/8. Around 16 there was good support. The buying through the day was much better than selling.

The Pittsburg Iron Manufacturer to-day says that the past week was not as satisfactory for iron and steel as the previous week. Salesmen report a general hesitancy to enter upon new work that had been practically determined upon. Pig iron is quiet and weak in all markets, Bessemer excepted.

Company C. Eighth Battalion, is in a great turmoil over the summary dismissal of First Sergt. William Eckenfelder by Capt. G.W. Mooney. The men are practically in open mutiny. Three of the ringleaders were placed under arrest yesterday by Capt. Mooney, although not deprived of liberty, and he says that if necessary all the other members will be arrested.

Henry King, the young man who was arrested Thursday night after having endeavored to set fire to a pile of lumber next to the fence which surrounds Eben Peek's lumber yard, at Eleventh Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, was arraigned for examination at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

ALBANY, May 18 -- By some sort of a blunder, among the number of bills that the Governor was reported to have signed on Tuesday was Senate Bill No. 437, introduced by Senator Parsons of Rochester, entitled "An Act to Encourage and to Promote the Professional Training of Teachers."

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The stamp collectors who have not already supplied themselves with complete sets of the Columbian issue of postage stamps will probably find themselves obliged to patronize the dealers, who have cornered the market and are now exacting big prices, or be satisfied with incomplete sets.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- The Order of Tonti to-day made an assignment to the Land Title and Trust Company and Francis Shunk Brown, the attorney of the order. The assets, which are principally in Pennsylvania, amount to $1,250,000.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The House, in Committee of the Whole, to-day considered the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill. Mr. Dockery, (Dem., Mo.,) in charge of the bill, made an explanation of its provisions.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- There is to be a meeting to-morrow of the committee which is to investigate the sugar bribery cases. Mr. Gray returned from New-York last night, and to-day he consulted with members of the committee regarding the plan of procedure.

The inquiry into the alleged irregularities in the past management of the Northern Pacific Railroad was resumed before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary yesterday. William Nelson Cromwell, attorney for the receivers, was the first witness examined. He was at one time a Director of the Rocky Fork and Cooke City Railroad.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 18 -- There was a promise of fair weather for the meeting at the Gentlemen's Driving Park this afternoon, and the horses were called early to make up for the time lost Wednesday and Thursday. Both the unfinished events were decided on a dry track, but a thunder shower came up before the next class was called, and flooded the course so that only one heat could be trotted.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Navy Department to-day received the following dispatch from Capt. Watson, commanding the San Francisco, at Bluefields: Arguela escaped May 9. I send this by steamer to New-Orleans.

-- William Aldis Wright has yielded to "a very generally expressed wish" in making the collection ot Edward Fitzgerald's letters which Macmillan Co. have Just ready. The desire was that these letters should be separated from the "Literary Remains." Mr. Wright has not only reprinted letters from that work, but has added several others hitherto unpublished.

The verdict of murder in the second degree brought in against Dr. Meyer is one of those perfectly illogical and absurd conclusions of a petit jury that nerve the arms of the theorists who write against the jury system. Indeed, there is nothing to be said in favor of this verdict.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 18 -- The strikng soft-coal miners held a final consultation to-day, at which it was decided to continue the fight until the operators agree to restore the old scale.
Carl Schurz, Dorman B. Eaton, and President Seth Low participated in the work of the conference at the City Club in the interest of municipal reform yesterday.

LONDON, May 18 -- The Pall Mall Gazette to-day publishes an interview with Sir George Grey, formerly Prime Minister of New-Zealand, on the Samoan question. Sir George expresses his opinion that the United States would not for a moment tolerate German interference in the government of Samoa.

Dun's Review will say to-day: "The obstacles to improvement do not lessen. The strikes of coal miners and coke workers have not ceased, but have caused the stoppage of numerous works this week and embarrassment to some railroads. The conference at Cleveland exhibited much angry feeling and wider differences than had been expected, and seems to render agreement more distant.

Messrs. Westervelt, German, and Clarke were tried against the Brooklyns yesterday in the game at the Polo Grounds, but their united efforts availed but little. The Brooklyna were in a batting mood, and they hit the ball hard and often, beating the New-Yorks by figures of 16 to 7.

The Harlem Yacht Club is going to give up its property at College Point. A suitable site has been secured on the Pelham Bay side of City Island. One lot of land has been purchased, and the club has an option on the adjoining property, which it will probably buy very soon. The water frontage of this site is 100 feet, and the depth 375 feet.

Mrs. Emma C. Bloss, the divorced wife of Newell W. Bloss, President of the National Mutual Insurance Company, alleged, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, that President E.B. Harper of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association, is withholding from her a policy for $10,000 on Mr. Bloss's life.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- In comparison with its previous work on the Tariff bill, the Senate made rapid progress to-day. When it ceased work at 5 o'clock, Schedule C, which relates to metals and manufactures of iron and steel, had been reached.

Postmaster Dayton was at his office yesterday, having returned from Washington late Thursday night. His visit there was for the purpose of urging the passage of the Postal Clerks' Classification bill, which has been reported by the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads and is now on the House calendar.

BOSTON, May 18 -- Local stocks, with the exception of the coppers, did not show much activity, and prices varied little from those of yesterday and the day before. Wisconsin Central 5s fell 1 1/4 from yesterday's close and 5 3/4 from the close of the day before, to 63 3/4. Interest prospects are said to be doubtful, and the damage by recent storms is believed to be quite large.

Prince, the black cocker spaniel, said to be worth $250, which is the cause of litigation as to ownership between Dr. Sumter Battey of 154 West Fourth Street and Mrs. Ida Streep, wife of the proprietor of the Wilton House, in West Twenty-seventh Street, was present as an exhibit at the adjourned hearing in the case before Justice Martin, in the Sixth District Court, yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 18 -- Fifty Italian weavers in the Hackensack silk mill owned by Givernaud Brothers, who also own the mill at Homestead, in West Hoboken, went on strike this afternoon because of a reduction in their wages. They were very demonstrative, and attempted to prevent the other weavers from entering the mill after dinner.

There seemed to be much mystery yesterday about the case of Lorenze Govin, who was sent from the Yorkville Police Court to Bellevue Hospital to be examined as to his mental condition, and those interested were very reticent about the matter. Govin is thirty years old, and has been living at 205 East Eighty-third Street.

The downward tendency in the stock market was more marked yesterday than at any other time since the present decline began. There was little or no rallying power; occasionally stocks were steady at the decline for brief periods, but on the approach of activity the weakness became pronounced.
"I cannot come to any other conclusion than that there is 'probable cause,' and I will hold the defendants for the action of the Grand Jury."
Congressman Isidore Straus called at the Custom House yesterday, and when the business which had taken him there was ended he talked with Collector Kilbreth about tariff prospects.

Gov. Flower has shown a regard for the principle of municipal "home rule" in dealing with most of the bills of minor importance in his hands which involve that question. He has vetoed the measures which were intended to compel this city to pension school teachers and employes of the Board of Health, but he has still under consideration the bill fixing the salaries of the policemen.
Dr. Henry Meyer was found guilty yesterday of murder in the second degree for poisoning Ludwig Brandt. This means a sentence of imprisonment for life.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- There was an interesting exchange of views to-day at the last session of the Convention of Labor Bureau Chiefs from the various States on the subject of penalties to compel manufacturers and others to answer questions for use in statistical reports.

-- The Rev. C. Venton Patterson, his assistant, the Rev. David E. Post, and their allies in the controversy over the possession of the Central Park Baptist Church in East Eighty-third Street will have to hold in abeyance their claims regarding the control of the church and the right to hold religious services therein until a final adjudication of the matter in the courts.

Mr. Bernard Mayhoff has sold for Louis Ranger to Mitchell A.C. Levy four full lots, with six three-story and basement brick dwellings on them, on the north side of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, east of Third Avenue, at $95,000.

A rebel flag was unfurled in All Souls' Unitarian Church, in South Ninth Street, near Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, and it was greeted, not with a rebel yell, but a vigorous Northern hiss from nearly 2,000 public school children.

In the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, Justice Connolly refused to dismiss the case of Mrs. Josephine Cartwright of 386 Central Avenue, against her mother, Mrs. Hilah A. Woram of 805 Columbus Avenue, New-York, for alleged threats to do her harm. Mrs. Cortwright is sixteen years old.

The present census, just published on this point, confirms previous statistics and presents the problem again to us -- why is there such an excess of women in New-Orleans, and what is there in the climate or conditions of life here that makes it so favorable to the so-called "weaker sex"? The figures are as follows:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 19 -- A illac tea was the attraction of society last Saturday afternoon. It was given by Mrs. Joseph W. Sandford, at her home, on West Seventh Street. Mrs. Sandford was assisted in receiving by her sister, Mrs. A.A. Drake of Westfield; her daughter, Mrs. H. G. Brewster of New-York, and Mrs. Froment of New-York.

M. de Tinseau's hero, Paul de Neuvillars, a young officer on the French iron-clad Prometheus, is a product of the times. He is highly educated, has visited all parts of the world, and is indifferent to everything. He is ignorant of the existence of the true woman. He has heard words of love, and has spoken them, but they were lip labials, and never came from his heart.

Some months ago we showed how formidable had become the competition of the Argentine Republic with the United States and other exporting countries in the European wheat market. At that time the new Argentine crop, much larger than any which had preceded it, had not been harvested.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- It is virtually admitted at the State Department that the information relating to French Anarchists referred to in United Press cablegrams from Paris has been received, and it is plainly intimated that information of a similar character has been secured from other nations besides France.

"I do hope," writes the accomplished wife of a Western missionary to some Eastern relatives," that my heavenly mansion will have a bathroom and a bay window," and the seeming irreverence of the wish is overshadowed in the eloquent tale it tells of privations and hardships bravely borne and gayly ignored.

During the fortnight or three weeks following the departure of Battery G it became clear to every one that the war was as good as over. It had lasted already a whole year, but now the end was obviously at hand.

There was a rush of plumbers to the Health Department yesterday to secure registration. This unwonted activity among the plumbers was due to a recent decision of the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas that a plumber who is not registered according to law cannot enforce payment of a bill for work done. There are nearly 900 "boss" plumbers in this city, and only 309 of them are registered at the Health Department.

An English girl traveling without her mother or old friend may be safe, but she is looked at a little askance by well-bred people, as I have constantly noticed. Why? Because it is assumed that, having had the usual English education, she is either not fit to take entire charge of herself, or -- it is too late to matter.

Dr. William R. De Kraft, who has a hospital at 30 West Thirtieth Street, where he prescribes the magnetic-electro treatment for various diseases, rested uncomfortably last night in a narrow cell of the Charles Street Police Station. A charge of swindling one of his former patients out of $10,000 was the cause of the doctor's incarceration.

ITHACA, N.Y. May 20 -- Elections of editors to fill positions on the various college publications have been held this last week. The system adopted by most of the Cornell publications is a combination of popular vote and competition. The constitution of The Cornell Era has for some years allowed the editors of that street to name in the end of each year a part of the succeeding year's board.

The strong homeopathic dose to which Justice Gaynor treated Health Commissioner Emery of Brooklyn on Friday, when he handed down a decision declaring that the Health Commissioner has no authority to quarantine persons who refuse to be vaccinated, and thus keep them prisoners until they submit to his orders, is not relished by that official.

The muscular young men of the different colleges will take part in the annual intercollegiate games at Berkeley Oval on Saturday next and strive to gain points for their Alma Mater. Last year Yale won with apparent ease, but this season the enforced retirement of Richards, the crack sprinter of the New-Haven institution, will add interest to the games.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 19 -- The annual examination order has been issued. The examinations will begin Friday, June 1, and continue daily, except Sundays, until finished. The Academic Board is divided into two committees. The first, composed of the Professors of Philosophy, Mathematics, Chemistry, and Engineering, and the Instructor in Practical Military Engineering, will sit in the library.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- To a letter congratulating him on his speech at the opening of the Parochial School Exhibit in NewYork City, Congressman Bourke Cockran has sent the following answer:

Brooklyn continues to be a delightful place of refuse for crooked politicians. They seem to think there is no more disposition now to annoy gentlemen with unclean records by suggestions of State prison than there was in the past.

From The St. Louis Globe-Democrat. In sorting over some old papers the other day. Col. Walter French, the file clerk of the National House of Representatives, who is noted for his antiquarian lore, discovered the following interesting letter from the widow of Abraham Lincoln:

A friend tells me that she has four cats, each of which (or whom) dotes on asparagus, and believes herself cheated out of her legal rights if she does not have some whennever the family does. Ordinarily, these cats are well-mannered, but they will steal asparagus whenever they get a chance.

LENOX, Mass., May 19 -- The Lenox cottagers who have arrived are enjoying the fine May weather in riding and driving. The evenings are so cold that wood fires are almost a necessity. Before another week nearly half the cottages will be occupied.

Converting a marine into a deserter is one of the fine arts. He comes on shore for a week, and finds the authorities very pleasant. He imbibes freely, and the authorities wink. For six days he paints the town a brilliant gory hue, and the authorities smile, and on his last night on shore the individual constables who constitute the authorities become bountifully generous.

The early Christians for a long time actually despised patriotism; they not only saw and felt that on this earth they had no abidingrcity, but they claimed to owe their allegiance to a higher power. This was a notion that prevailed until the growth of national sentiment became strong enough to make a Christian a patriot as well.

The origin of "croft " Itself is "wrop in mystery." It Is a very old English term, appearing in the charters of title deeds of estates as long ago as the reign of Edgar, where the phrase "at the croft's head" is quoted by Dr. Murray; but it remained long unrecognized in the literary language.

BOSTON, May 19 -- Twenty-five years ago to-day Charles W. Eliot became President of Harvard University. When he assumeed charge, there were 563 students in the college and 1,097 in the university as a whole; now there are 1,655 and 3,502 respectively. To keep pace with this increase there has been a great development in the corps of instruction.

LONDON, May 19 -- Parliament will resume its sittings on Monday under the shadow of dissolution. Sir William Harcourt, the Government leader in the House, has informed the leaders of the McCarthyite section of the Irish, party that the next general election will probably take place in July, and other Liberal authorities have conveyed similar intimation.
Denver women are organizing themselves into a dress club, which is to put its uniform in ocular evidence as soon as 100 women have signed the pledge of its membership. This is as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J. May 19 -- The Princeton freshmen defeated Lawrenceville, at Lawrenceville, this afternoon, by the score of 12 to 9. Both teams played a loose fielding game. Princeton won by hard hitting. Score:

The death is announced in Paris of Charles Jacque, painter and one of the most famous engravers. He painted in etchings, before Millet, peasants who were impressively of the fields and Incomparable sheep. He produced more than 400 etchings and engravings, and 200 of them are of the first order of merit.

A curious fly, belonging to the family of the Cicadariae and the sub-order of Hemiptera, or half-winged or gauze-winged insect, is now making the residents of a large territory miserable by its monotonous Screeching. Fortunately, it goes to sleep at night, or the plague would be as unbearable as that of the ancient Egyptians.

A large, plain, red brick building, standing in a spacious inclosure in Schermerhorn Street, just off Boerum Place, Brooklyn, has an air of calm solidity, peacefulness, and eminent respectability that would almost proclaim its use, if a small placard on the fence did not bear the words: "Friends' School."

The throngs of people at Eldorado last Sunday afternoon and evening gave unmistakable evidence that they fully enjoyed the many changes which have been made by the new management for their welfare and convenience, while the concert by Gilmore's famous Twenty-second Regiment Band, under the able direction of Victor Herbert, came in for an unusually large share of applause.

An actor in Henry E. Dixey's company fired a shot in the air near the stage entrance of Palmer's Theatre, in West Thirtieth Street, about 7:45 last night. Then he hurried into the theatre. The chorus girls were trooping in, and when they heard the shot they set up a chorus of screams that in a few minutes brought 2,000 persons from Broadway to see how many had been killed.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Twenty-two lives lost, six large schooners destroyed, and more than a score driven ashore, is the record, so far as can be compiled to-night, of the furious gale which for more than two days has blown over Lake Michigan.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The sessions of the naval war college and torpedo school at Newport will commence June 1. The following officers have been ordered there for instruction: Commanders George E. Ide, John S. Newell, C.J. Train, Joshua Bishop, George F.F. Wilde, R.T. Leary, and N.M. Dyer, Lieut.

The receipt of several letters asking The Times to give some designs suitable for making up gowns to be worn without corsets has suggested the article here presented. The leaven is working among women: Many have discarded them, many more, mothers, who feel that it is too late for them to change, are persuading their growing daughters to omit their adoption.

There was shipped to this city a few days ago from Orange County the carcass of a cow badly infected with tuberculosis, or the disease commonly called consumption. Fortunately, there is a good inspection service here, and the beef was promptly condemned by the Board of Health.

The exhibiton of school work by the Catholic schools included in the Diocese of New-York at the Grand Central Palace has been gaining steadily in popularity since the opening night. Large crowds visit the exhibition daily, the principal attendance being in the evening.
PORT HURON, Mich., May 19 -- The tug Thompson, which left here at 9 o'clock this morning with a party of volunteer life savers to attempt to rescue the crew of the schooner Cchupe, has returned.

Representative Haines of the Troy (N.Y.) district returned to the Capitol yesterday from a visit to his home. He reports the political condition as exceedingly mixed, but is, of course, hopeful for Democratic success.

Mayor Schieren has approved the resolution of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen granting permission to the Brooklyn and Brighton Beach Railroad Company, of which Gen. James Jourdan is the receiver, to construct an extension of its tracks from Atlantic and Franklin Avenues to Fulton and Franklin Avenues, to connect with the Kings County Elevated Railway, of which Gen. Jourdan is President.

Spectacle-makers for poodles, tailors for greyhounds, and hatters for pet cats we have known ere this, but an elephant's dentist has only just made his first appearance. He has earned his spurs -- or the dentist's substitute for them -- by operating on one of the Jumbos at the Paris Zoo. For some weeks the poor beast, who had been the jolliest elephant of the troupe, had turned sombre and melancholy.

The past week, so far as real estate dealings go, has been devoid of special features. There is still the same exasperating lack of transactions that has been characteristic of a year's business. A little speculation here and there is visible, usually as to small and inexpensive pieces of property. An occasional dwelling, intended for the purchaser's own use, is sold.

The fatigue that Sibyl had gone through since nightfall had made no impression upon her physical being, or no impression of which her mind was conscious. If her limbs ached with the tramping to and fro and up and down over the rough ground by the cliff she had no consciousness of her pain.

What races the Vigilant will enter for when she is on the other side is a question that yachtsmen just now are paying a great deal of attention to. The Messrs. Gould have said that they will race her whenever and wherever they get a chance, and that they will race her for all she is worth.

The question of cleanliness is another on which the ideas of the French and English are at variance. In France the cleanliness of the thing seen is the primary consideration; in England, things both seen and unseen are required to be clean. Cleanness in the preparation of food, in the outer clothing of the body, in the elimination of dust is always remarkable in France, and dirt is never allowed to offend the eye.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 19 -- The Rev. Iso Abe, pastor of the largest native Congregational Church in Okayama, Japan, will complete a three years' course of study in the Hartford Theological Seminary this month, and will go from here to England and Germany, with the idea of spending one year in the European universities.

It is fitting that a monument to Heine should be set up in this country. German poet as he was, the first edition of his works that was in any wise complete or satisfactory was published in America, and he has always been immensely admired here. The American reader of Heine enjoys him more unreservedly, we doubt not, and likes him for more reasons than any of his admirers of other nationalities.
Call loans were made at per cent, throughout the day.

BOSTON, May 19 -- In local yacht-building yards the week has been a repetition of those immediately preceding it. At Lawleys Well's ballast-fin-centreboard Knockabout, as described last week, has been taken out of the mold loft, where she was built, and la having her fin put on. The Priscilla, the schooner for John M. Richmond of Providence, has been rigged and will be ready to sail early next week.

Little Murphy, the Giants' short stop, had an off day at Eastern Park, and prevented his team from defeating the Brooklyns. The ground around his position was soft and slippery and he made four errors, which were responsible for all the runs scored by Brooklyn. Luckily, however, the New-Yorks did not lose.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 19 -- With every day that the strike in the soft-coal regions continues the situation becomes graver. Should it continue another month the suffering among the non-combatants will be fully as great as among those actively on strike.

When a certain New-York mother opened a book the other evening to read to her children, they saw its title, and cried out, and said: "Oh, don't read stupid old Grecian fables and tales from mythology. Tell us a fairy story." And so the mother shut the book and began the story of Echo and Narcissus.

At the beginning of the war, April 15, 1861, the United States Army was composed exclusively of white troops. The army regulations provided that "any free white male person above the age of eighteen," , "might be enlisted." Negro slavery existed in fifteen States of the Union, and fugitive slaves escaping from one State to another were delivered up on claim of their owners.

A man on an elevated train one day last week got himself into just the kind of trouble that a woman is usually expected to monopolize, and to the woman who looked on it didn't seem as if the men about were nearly so brotherly or kind as the sisterhood would have been to a similar suffering member of their sex.

BOSTON, May 19 -- Local stocks were rather inactive and the tone of the market was mixed. Wisconsin Central securities were very weak, on a rumor that a plan for funding one or two coupons of the 5 per cent, bonds was being discussed. On the probability that the July interest would be defaulted, the 5s sold down 53/4, to 58, and the stock was off 1/4, to 4 3/4.

ROME, May 19 -- The Voce Della Verita. publishes a letter from Mr. Gladstone, in reply to a communication from Mgr. Farabulini, an attache of the Vatican, asking the ex-Premier's opinion as to the present status of Ireland. Mr. Gladstone sympathizes with the reasons actuating the inquiry and the sentiments expressed by Mgr. Farabulini, which, he believes, reflect the opinion of the Pope.

The burning of the Brooklyn Tabernacle and the departure of the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage for Australia while the ruins are yet smoking bring to a close another chapter of the strange story of that noted church, its pastor, and its people.

In the fervor of the Catholic reaction in the latter half of the Sixteenth Century, Europe seemed ablaze with miracles. Saints, It is said, flew in the air, were in two places at once, uttered prophecies, and raised the dead. England, the theatre of a supreme papal efforts hallowed with the blood of many martyrs, seemed alone to lie under the shadow of a supernatural eclipse.

We have little more hope of the extinction of war, or of the burden now so terrible -- of military preparation. It is as certain that nations will quarrel as that individuals will; it is most improbable that when the quarrel is vital they will submit to arbitration, and when the quarrel has once attained that height, there is no substitute for war even conceivable by the mind.

The large kindergarten room on the lower floor of the Teachers' College, 9 University Place, was crowded at 10:30 yesterday morning by the kindergartners and their friends, who were assembled to witness a demonstration of the principles of Froebel's system. On the stage, which was tastefully decorated with flowers, were the junior and senior classes.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Advices were received at the State Department to-day from Consul Plumacher at Maracaibo, dated May 5, showing that the greatest damage of the Venezuelan earthquake was done on the famous San Carlos and Merida Railway, nearly completed, in the Andes. The axis of the disturbance, which lasted at some points three days, was along its line.

Taking the earth's mean distance from the sun at 92,796,950 miles, as given by Harkness, the mean distance of Jupiter from the sun will be 482,803,970 miles. The eccentricity of its elliptical orbit being 0.04825, its distance from the sun at perihelion is 459,507,760 miles, and at aphelion 506,100,180 miles.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., May 19 -- Not since the great flood of 1889 have the people of Johnstown been so much concerned as they are to-night, in view of the heavy rains and the consequent rise in the famous streams, the Conemaugh River and Stony Creek. Both of these streams are out of their banks in several places, and are mounting up.

Walter Hamilton tells us that George Cruikshank" sang the old English ballad" in the manner of a street-ballad singer at a dinner of the Antiquarian Society, at which Dickens and Thackeray were present. The latter is reported to have remarked, "I should like to print that ballad, with illustrations," but Cruikshank warned him off, saying that this was exactly what he himself had resolved to do.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 10 -- In the vicinity of the Pequot and all along the shore on both sides of the harbor the signs are indicative of a prosperous season for New-London Summer resorts. Messrs. Blanchard Hager made the Pequot House very popular last season, and the many applications for rooms at this time show that their efforts were appreciated.

An interesting alliance rather out of the usual order is that reported to be arranged between the daughter of the English novelist George Meredith and Henry Sturges of Boston. Although Mr. Sturges has lived long in England, he is American born and bred, being a member of the well-known New-England family of that name.

The performances of operetta and extravaganza which have let themselves out upon the town within the last moon have suggested the possibility that the breed of composers of light music ran out with Leo Delibes. Yet Johann Strauss still lives. So does Sir Arthur Sullivan. George W. Chadwick can write better than that of "Tabasco."

Whether we believe in the suffrage principle or do not believe in it, says Augusta Larned in The American Woman's Journal, we must acknowledge that the time for woman's political enfranchisement is not far off. A few years more or less make but little difference. The power of womanhood has been acknowledged.
Three Bishops and more than 100 Methodist Episcopal clergymen attended the funeral of the Rev. Dr. J. Orimel Peck, which was held yesterday afternoon in the Hanson place Church, Brooklyn.

A meeting of a company in the Eighth Battalion to take action against its Captain, and the field day of the Twelfth Regiment at Van Cortlandt Park, furnish the only items of unusual importance in the military field during the week. The first occurrence is likely to end with the summary arrest and imprisonment of every man implicated.

PITTSBURGH, May 19 -- A morning paper to-day contained a long account of extensive preparations for war alleged to have been made by Allegheny County officials in anticipation of serious labor troubles, particularly in connection with the miners strike. Sheriff Richards, in conversation with a representative of the United Press, said this afternoon that the allegations are entirely without foundation.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Many signs point to an attempt at an early day to rid the Senate of that tradition, sacredly cherished by some of its members, that it is an undignified thing for the majority of the body to insist that a majority shall decide when a bill or resolution has been discussed a sufficient time, and that it shall be brought to a vote.

The horoscope of this wonderful power as applied to the residences of the future reads like a fairy tale. Says The Tradesman: The elevators will be run and lighted by it. They will be like huge gilt bird cages in appearance. The shafts for them will be of plate glass set In bronze columns and protected by elaborate bronze grilles.

ORANGE, May 19 -- As predicted by The New-York Times this morning, the baseball nine of the University of Pennsylvania ran against a snag in their gama with the Orange Athletic Club this afternoon, and the result was a disastrous one for the heretofore unconquered Quaker giants.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- An arrangement has been entered into between the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate which is expected to bring about a vote on the Tariff bill much earlier than the Democrats thought possible a few days ago.

HANOVER, N.H., May 10 -- During com- mencement week -- June 26 -- the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of Dartmouth College will be fittingly celebrated. The oration of the day will be delivered by Nelson Dingley, '55, of Maine, and Richard Hovey, 85, of Boston will read a poem.

An order was signed by Justice Barrett of the Supreme Court yesterday committing John E. Roosevelt to jail for contempt of court because of his failure to pay the personal tax imposed upon him for 1892, as administrator, with the will annexed, of the estate of Amos Cutting.

Very nearly one-half of yesterday's business in the stock market was confined to Sugar. The stock opened at 98, advanced 1/2 and then declined almost without a halt to 94. In the final sales the price rallied to 94 3/4, making the net loss for the day 3 7/8 points and for the week 11 1/2 points. The selling was of the same character as on recent days.

There is a certain amount of mystery connected with a harem, therefore we were greatly pleased when its occupants sent to ask the ladles of our party to pay them a visit. We were shown into a smaller reception room, and they came to us. Their appearance was disappointing, for they were neither beautiful nor well dressed; their costumes were of flowered muslin, and their, headdresses were quite devoid of ornament.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 19 -- Ever since Wednesday the trotting turfmen have been battling with the elements to try and get through with the programme for the inaugural meeting of the year at the Gentlemen's Driving Park. The prospects this morning were favorable, and as the course dried fast under the blistering sun, aided by a strong wind, the bedraggled sulkies were started again soon after 1 o'clock.

One of the most fashionable and important weddings of the Spring season took place in Trinity Church, Hoboken, at noon yesterday, when Miss Esther Marie Lewis was married to Charles Chapin of Englewood, N.J. The bride is the eldest daughter of the late Edward Parke Custis Lewis, and a granddaughter of Mrs. Edwin A. Stevens of Castle Point, Hoboken.

One of the most gratifying evidences of progress is the fact that Representative Bland of Missouri feels himself constrained to declare that he is "satisfied" with the platform adopted by the Democrats of his State at the Kansas City Convention. It demands "free bimetallic coinage of both gold and silver," whatever that may mean, and the "restoration of the bimetallic standard," but it is against "silver monometallism," as well as "gold monometallism."

The Staten Island Cricket Club opened their league season in a most auspicious fashion yesterday at Hoboken, where they grained an easy victory over the Victorias by 66 runs, after declaring their own innings closed with only five men out.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A substantial service to the maritime world was performed yesterday and to-day by Congress, and Senators White and Frye and Representatives Fithian, Robbins, Dingley, Loud, Coombs, and Tracey have done a philanthropic work, greater, perhaps, than they fully realized at the time.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Washington detectives are looking for a young man representing himself to be the son of H.O. Havemeyer, the millionaire sugar refiner, who attempted to pass a check for $21,000 on the National Bank of the Republic. The young man presented the check at the bank Wednesday morning, introducing himself as H.O. Havemeyer, Jr., a son of the millionaire, and saying he had a letter from Congressman Bourke Cockran as identification.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- Two thousand persons attended the Meadowbrook Farm's steeplechases and pony races, at Meadowbrook, this afternoon. The meeting was a success and not marred by accidents. In several of the events the horses either fell or threw their riders, but no one was hurt.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

NYACK, N.Y., May 19 -- One of the most rare, and, to an entomologist, most interesting phenomena of natural history was discovered the other day on South Mountain. A path ran through a wide area that had recently been burned over, and this space, extending for hundreds of feet in every direction, was almost literally covered with what looked like miniature adobe huts, two to three inches high and one or two in diameter.

The New-Rochelle Yacht Clubhouse was opened for the season yesterday, and the occasion celebrated with a yacht race for catboats. The club burgee was hoisted at 2 o'clock and saluted by all the yachts in Echo Bay. Among these were the steam yacht Ola, Rear Commodore Jabez Harris; sloop Sasqua, Commodore Henry Andrus; sloop Wacondale, Henry Doescher; yawl Proteus, S. C. Cooper; cabin cats Ida K., Aura, Almira, Mary C., and Twilight.

BOSTON, May 19 -- Boston's wool merchants and woolen manufacturers indignantly deny the intimation that they have resorted to other means than arguments in their efforts to induce Congress to maintain the tariff on wool. They admit they have made, and are making, a big fight against free wool, but assert that their weapons are facts, and not dollars.

J.J. Kean, bookkeeper of the Harlem River Bank, has, so far, evaded arrest on the warrant obtained at the Jefferson Market Police Court by Bank Superintendent Preston Thursday. The warrant was intrusted to Central Office Detective Titus, who has established that Kean disappeared Wednesday from a boarding house in West Eleventh Street.

Nearly 500 men and several women assembled at Fraternity Hall, 869 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, last evening, to express their indignation at the supreme officers of the Order of Tonti, for allowing the order to go into the hands of a receiver.

But for the intervention of friends, Horace M. Lower, son of the Rev. Samuel O. Lower of Altoona, Penn., would have been buried in a pauper's grave on Hart's Island as Harris Allen, the name he gave to the police. Lower was found in Park Row Tuesday night suffering from hunger and fatigue.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- Terence V. Powderly, ex-General Master "Workman of the Knights of Labor, or, as he recently termed himself, "the Uncrowned King of the Workingmen"; A. W. Wright of Toronto, Canada, ex-member of the General Executive Board of the Knights, and P.H. Quinn, Master Workman of District Assembly No. 99, an ardent supporter of Powderly, have been unceremoniously expelled from the Knights of Labor.

A lock-out of motormen and conductors employed on the Atlantic Avenue trolley system is expected to take effect this morning, and the Brooklyn police have made preparations to deal with any trouble that may arise.

GARRISONS-ON-HUDSON, N.N., May 19 -- There is hardly a quainter or more picturesque Summer resort in the country than Garrisons. It was known in Revolutionary days as "Mandivel's." Every nook is filled with historical reminiscences of that eventful period. Here was situated the Beverly Robinson House, where Arnold concocted his schemes of treason.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 19 -- The warm Spring sunshine has been working wonders in the hills and valleys of the sleepy old Catskills, and every trace of Winter has disappeared. Where two months ago the hillsides were deep with drifted snow, wild flowers shed their fragrance upon the air and the running brooks mirror on their surface the green foliage and blossoms of the overhanging trees.

A judgment for $7,885, which was obtained some time ago, on the report of a referee, by Charles E. Foster and another, patent solicitors in Washington, against John W. Bookwalter, prominent in Ohio in business and politics, has been reversed on appeal by the General Term of the Supreme Court, in an opinion written by Presiding Justice Van Brunt.
The whist congress, which will open next Tuesday and continue in session through Saturday, at Philadelphia, is to be the largest and most important of its kind ever held in this country.

CHAPTER XII -- "GRUDGED I SO MUCH TO DIE?" "Now," said Sibyl, when she and Urquhart were walking along the windblown path toward the inn where she had left her maid, "now, Mr. Urquhart, what is the first thing to be done?"

The principal yachting organ of London expresses satisfaction that the Vigilant has been induced to visit British waters by the promise of being allowed to sail for "Queen's cups"; though it adds that, "as a general principle, it would be absurd for the State to provide prizes for foreign competitions."

BALTIMORE. May 19 -- C. Ridgely Goodwin, recently appointed by President Cleveland Surveyor of the Port of Baltimore, died this evening of a complication of diseases, the chief of which were pneumonia and Bright's disease.

All arrangements are being perfected for the great tri-State relay race promoted by The New-York Times, and from the present outlook the contest will prove one of the racing features of the season. In New-Jersey and Pennsylvania the committees in charge are making strenuous efforts to get together teams capable of making record-breaking performances, and they believe that the New-York team will not get a place.

BERLIN, May 19 -- Despite the riotous scenes among the miners' delegates yesterday, the international congress has shown that the miners of all nations are nearer a union in thought and action than was generally supposed. At no conference of academic Socialists has such a near approach to international solidarity been made as at this meeting of workingmen.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 19 -- The schooner yacht Arethusa, which was purchased by Mr. Charles Whann of New-York from Col. F. De Funiak, when the latter bought Richard Mansfield's schooner, Her Royal Highness, arrived here from Noank this morning, and soon after left for New-York. Her owner is on board. The schooner yacht Monhegan, Mr. C.L. Johnson, will start for Gloucester to-morrow.

MONTREAL, May 18 -- Many chess players here expected that the seventeenth game of the chess match for the championship of the world and $2,000 a side between W. Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker, this afternoon, at the Cosmopolitan Club, would be the last, as the German expert only needed one game to win.

MANCHESTER, May 19 -- The preparations for the reception of the Queen on the occasion of the formal opening of the Manchester Ship Canal on Monday are complete. Seven miles of streets are lined with, stands, Venetian masts, &c., and profusely decorated with flags, banners, and floral arches.

Cardinal Gibbons of Baltimore will preach the dedication sermon in the new Roman Catholic Church of St. John,the Baptist, Willoughby Avenue, near Lewis Avenue, Brooklyn, this morning. This church, which has been five years in building, is without equal in magnificance in this part of the country.

J.B. Haggin testified in the Northern Pacific inquiry before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary yesterday. He was at one time a Director in the Northern Pacific Company. He said that he did not attend any of the meetings of the board when the question of acquiring either the Chicago terminals or the Northern Pacific and Manitoba was brought up.

Some remarkable particulars respecting this peculiar form of the madness of crowds is given in The British Fortnightly by Mr. W. Roberts. In England the craze has some very distinguished patrons. The President and Vice President of the Philatelic Society respectively are the Duke of SaxeCoburg-Gotha and the Duke of York, while its ordinary list of members includes one Prince and two Earls.

It is a long- time since the students of Columbia College have had an opportunity to celebrate an athletic victory, but they had a chance last night, and to say that they took advantage of it is using a mild expression. Princeton and Columbia met in their annual field competition yesterday afternoon, and the New-York boys came off the victors by a score of 61 to 50.

Andrew J. Graham, author of the Graham system of phonography, died at his residence, in Cleveland Street, Orange, N. J., yesterday, of Brlght's disease. He was born at Green Creek, Sandusky County, Ohio, Aug. 2, 1830. His father was a farmer. When Andrew was nine years old his parents moved to St. Joseph County, Mo.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 19 -- At a special term of the Supreme Court before Judge Alton B. Parker this afternoon, among the matters that came up was that of the people, ex rel. Thomas W. Fitzgerald of Buffalo and others against the convention to revise and to amend the Constitution of the State of New-York and others.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- It was all one way again this morning, but not, as usual, the way of the bears. Fortune favored the patient bulls with an encouraging smile for once in a way. Besides being strong, the market was active. West Chicago, of course, attracted particular attention. The stock opened 3/4 higher, at 138 1/2 and advanced steadily to 139 1/4 declined 5/3, and finally closed firm at 139 1/4.

When Joseph and Andrew Ernest, brothers, eighteen and sixteen years old respectively, and John Doran, twenty-two years old, were arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday on charges of burglary, the Ernest brothers pleaded that they were compelled to commit criminal acts by threats made by Doran.

The investigation of the New-York Police Department by Mr. Platt's Senate committee will be resumed to-morrow in Part II of the Court of Common Pleas. Gov. Flower's veto of the twenty-five-thousand-dollar appropriation bill put through the Legislature to provide for counsel fees and otherexpenses of the committee would, it was supposed, put a stop to the investigation.

Mr. Louis C. Tiffany and the younger Dr. Doremus have been experimenting in dyes for colored glass, not for stained-glass windows, but for objects of use and decoration which are blown. The Tiffany Glass Company, on Fourth Avenue, near Twenty-fourth Street, has another attraction besides the Tiffany Chapel.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 19 -- Justice J.V. Dykman, holding a Special Term of the Supreme Court, this morning granted an order directing the Board of Aldermen of Mount Vernon to meet and as a Board of City Canvassers recanvass the votes polled at the election last Tuesday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 19 -- The Laurel House alone remains of the hotels to finish the season, which ends June 1. A greater number of the guests than in previous years have registered at this house during the Spring season. The Laurel-in-the-Pines closed its doors Tuesday, after a successful season.

LONG BRANCH, May 16 -- George Work of the Carteret Gun Club and Fred Hoey of Hollywood met on the Hollywood Grounds this morning and treated the spectators to a fine exhibition of pigeon shooting. The trophy shot for was the valuable Riverton Challenge Plate, which had been won by Hoey in Philadelphia last week. A purse of $1,000 went with the club trophy.

About 10 o'clock on Friday night, April 13 we were waiting at Pisa Station for the night train to Rome. Speculation was rife as to the meaning of long lines of tables spread with cups and plates, which stretched half the length of the platform. While we were discussing this problem and our coffee at the same time, a long train drew up.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- There will be much reasonable disappointment in the decision of Senator Gray's investigation committee that the inquiry ordered by the Senate into alleged attempts at bribery of Senators Hunton and Kyle is to be secret.

The gun of the famous old schooner Dauntless boomed from the lawn in front of the Larchmont Yacht Clubhouse yesterday afternoon, the blue and white burgee was broken out at the head of the big flagstaff, the Seventh Regiment Band played "The Star-Spangled Banner," the members of the club saluted the flag, and the yachting season of the Larchmont Club for 1894 was opened.

The trial Friday in the United States Federal Court at Chattanooga of the Rev. Clement W. Lewis exposed and brought to justice probably the most accomplished swindler and impostor the negro race has ever fostered.

An old story concerning the alleged destruction of about 5,000 indictments, which had been abstracted from the safe in the District Attorney's office nearly twenty years ago, was revived recently by Lawyer Ambrose H. Purdy, who was at one time an Assistant District Attorney.

Mayor Schieren, who has been confined to his house for several days, was able to attend to his duties in the Mayor's office yesterday. He had been slightly ill, and his Illness was caused by the nauseating odors from Newtown Creek. A few days ago he and a party of city officials went up the creek in a tugboat.

The fog in the lower bay and the mud in the harbor conspired yesterday to treat the big Anchor Liner City of Rome very shabbily. She reached the lightship at an early hour, but the fog became so thick that Capt. Hugh Young did not consider it wise to proceed up the bay, so he anchored outside.

PARIS, April 30 -- Opinion seems to be divided concerning the Salon of the Champ de Mars this year; while many pronounce is to be simply a reunion de chefs d'oeuvre others go about with an injured, dejected air, and charge that it is the worst exhibition ever seen in Paris.
PARIS, May 21 -- Emile Henry, who, on Feb. 12, threw a bomb in the cafe of the Hotel Terminus, -was executed at 4:10 o'clock this morning.

Horatio Nelson Holt. Horatio Nelson Holt, one of the pioneers of business on the Erie Canal, died at his home, 165 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, on Saturday, after a short illness. He was born in Cherry Valley, Otsego County, N.Y., Jan. 11, 1811. His father was a member of the first State Senate.

BERLIN, May 20 -- The Federal Council has not yet acted upon the bill to repeal the anti-Jesuit law, although the Reichstag sent up the measure weeks ago. This delay has caused increasing anxiety recently among the Protestants, and they have been storming the Federal Governments with inquiries as to the significance of the Council's hesitation.

Senator Jones, who has been the "whip" of the tariff-reform Democrats, is reported in our dispatches this morning as saying that the "end is in sight," and Senator Harris is said to have added that the collection of taxes under the new bill will begin with the first day of the new fiscal year, July 1.

On the other side of the broad Atlantic certain enthusiastic Englishmen are cooking a dinner for American naval officers. Capt. Mahan, author of a book which added something to the enormous conception of personal greatness cherished by every Englishman worthy of the name, is the special object of adulation.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., May 21, 2:20 A.M. -- Bulletin. -- The Conemaugh River is overflowing, and people are fleeing for their lives.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- An unknown number of the employes of the Government Printing Office, estimated to be about 700, have received copies of the following notice from Mr. Benedict:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., May 20 -- Four men put out from Henry Muff's boathouse, at Steinway, shortly before midnight of yesterday in a small skiff to board the yacht Progress, lying at anchor off the Williamsburg Yacht Clubhouse. They were William Broughton, thirty years old, or 95 Russell Street; T.C. Hawkins, thirtytwo years old, of Leonard Street; William T. Collins of 108 Oak Street, and Louis Rade of 261 Ainslie Street, Brooklyn.

JAMAICA, L.I., May 20 -- One man mortally wounded, six others in jail, and two others suffering from painful injuries, is the result of a fight that took place about 8 o'clock this morning near the grounds of the Jamaica Athletic Club. The combatants were a gang of Italians and a gang of colored men.

"The Democratic Party in Connecticut stands with the National Administration on the tariff measure now pending in the Senate," said ex-Judge Lynde Harrison of New-Haven to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday.

WEST POINT, May 20 -- The programme for the graduation exercises has been published. The examinations will begin June 1, and continue daily, except Sunday, until finished. The Academic Board will conduct the examinations. The board is composed of Profs. Tillman, Larned, Bass, Michie, Mercur, Wood, Clous, and Postlethwaite, Capt. James L. Lusk, Capt. Lawrence L. Bruff, and Lieut. Col. Samuel M. Mills.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 20 -- John McFarrall of Schuyler County, N.Y., who was on his way home from Illinois, stepped from a Pennsylvania train last night when a stop was made at West End. He thought the train had reached the ferry. After the train started he realized his mistake, and started to walk to the ferry, following the railroad embankment, which runs along the Bergen cut.

"We hope to build another Tabernacle, but, as a mater of fact, I don't believe we will. I don't think we want to go into the real estate business again. Our experience in that line has been very sad. Instead of paying $12,000 a year interest on a mortgage and $5,000 to our pastor, it would be better to pay $5,000 a year rent and $12,000 a year to our pastor."

Architect Gilbert A. Schellenger of 128 Broadway has completed plans for the new Salvation Army National Headquarters. They were submitted to Commander Ballington Booth, and were approved by him Saturday. The work of tearing down the old barracks in West Fourteenth Street, which now occupy the site where the new structure will be erected, will be commenced at once.

Other charges of swindling may be made against Dr. W.R. De Kraft, proprietor of an "electro-therapeutic" institute, at 30 West Thirtieth Street, who was arrested Saturday night on John A. Anger's charge of defrauding him out of $10,000.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The bullet-proof cloth may not amount to so much after all. Reports recently received indicate that the value of the material is somewhat limited by the fact that the cloth cannot be converted into wearing apparel. It is of such thickness and composition that it does not lend itself to cutting and shaping, such as is required of cloth from which coats, for instance, are made.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., May 20 -- Upon the steamship Arawa, which sailed Friday for Vancouver, B.C., are Sir Henry J. Wrixon, Nicholas Fitzgerald, and Simon Fraser, representing the colony of Victoria; Mr. Stutter, representing New South Wales; Andrew J. Thynne, representing Queensland, and Lee Smith, representing NewZealand.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Senator Gray's announcement that the bribery and sugar investigations are to be secret, has met with almost unanimous public disapprobation, but that fact does not yet appear to have convinced the members of the committee that they erred in deciding that they were entitled to monopolize the information that is to be derived from the investigation.
John Carberry, an employe of the Street-Cleaning Department, was shot in the back Saturday night while going to his home, 442 East Seventy-eighth Street. The man died of his wound yesterday forenoon.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 20 -- Striking miners are held responsible for a cowardly assassination at Pratt Mines. A mob of masked men went to-day to the house of Walter Glover, a miner, who had refused to join the strikers, and called him to the door, telling him they were officers. As Glover unfastened the door, the mob fired a volley, the door was perforated, and Glover was riddled with bullets.

The weather hereabout yesterday succeeded in making itself objectionable to nearly everybody who was exposed to it. The wind played boisterous pranks with craft in the bay, where it took on a gait of forty miles an hour.
Woman suffrage was the theme in several pulpits in this city yesterday.

The new Lewis Avenue Congregational Church, Madison Street and Lewis Avenue, Brooklyn, was yesterday formally dedicated as a house of worship. It was announced that the ceremonies would begin at 10:30 A. M., and before that hour every seat in the graceful edifice was occupied. The later arrivals assembled in the aisles.

In the stock market last week a lower level of prices was established. The predominating influence was the break of about a dozen points in Sugar. This came about through liquidation on the part of belated bulls and through the closing out of the accounts of certain people in Washington who are indisposed to continue operations in the face of the coming investigation of affairs connected with the Sugar combination.

One-half of Brooklyn was wrapped yesterday in the peaceful and somnolent embrace of a trolley car tie-up. It was the first trouble of the kind since the introduction of the electric cars in the City of Churches.

PARIS, May 20 -- An international athletic congress is to be held here between June 18 and 20 under the auspices of the French Societies for Athletics. Baron Pierre de Coubertin is Commissioner General. Prof. Sloane of Princeton is the American Commissioner, and Theodore Stanton is the American member of the Paris Executive Committee.

CONEY ISLAND, May 20 -- There were very few visitors at Coney Island to-day. It is usually only in Winter that the streets are as deserted as they were this afternoon. The trains and trolley cars from Brooklyn carne down almost empty.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 -- With the appearance of Stevenson, Lewis, and Forbes in the 'Varsity boat at Harvard has come the expected organization of the "college crew." The men who sit in the new boat are supposed to be the choicest lot of rowers in the college, next to the 'Varsity, and are expected, in a few trial races, to set the 'Varsity a pace such as it has not known this year.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Stealing a railroad train and the defeat of a Congressional aspirant in Indiana are the allegations in Circuit Court proceedings against the Chicago and Erie Railroad Company for $50,000 damages. Marcus M. Towle, ex-Mayor and ex-Postmaster of Hammond, Ind., is the plaintiff and sponsor for the aspirant.

A former volume of Roumanian folk songs, collected by Mile. Vacaresco, was received with such favor that the translators were encouraged to put forth a second volume in the English language. These poems, like those of the first series, were written down by Mile. Vacaresco as they fell from the lips of the peasants, who had preserved them by oral tradition.
BRADFORD, Penn., May 20 -- Three days' incessant rain and the flooding of mountain streams have swollen the east and west branches of the Tunungwant Creek into a raging torrent.

The people's singing classes, under the leadership of Frank Damrosch, and assisted by several soloists, gave their second annual concert at the Music Hall yesterday afternoon. Nearly every box and that part of the auditorium which was left after about 600 members of the elementary classes had taken their seats in the parquet, were filled.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed a decrease in reserve of $1,635,450. The banks now hold $78,999,125 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show a decrease in loans of $475,100, an increase in specie of $156,700, a decrease in legal tenders of $2,027,000, a decrease in deposits of $939,400, and a decrease in circulation of $14,200.

TRENTON, N.J., May 20 -- The Legislature is resting at the end of the nineteenth week so that the Governor can catch up in his work, and he is doing it well, for on Friday he placed on Secretary Kelsey's desk forty laws that he had considered that morning. The Governor has still fifty-two bills, delivered to him by the Committee on Passed Bills in the two houses.

The conference of organizations interested in municipal reform which was held in this city last week indorsed a proposed amendment of the State Constitution, which emanated from the Civil Service Reform Association, intended to embody the principles of the merit system in the organic law of the State.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A great combination among the senior officers of the navy has fallen through. The differences may be readjusted, but, at present, there is no hope of the plan working out to the satisfaction of those who would be benefited by its operation.

Mr. Charles S. Fairchild was asked yesterday whether the New-York State Democracy proposed to confine its labors only to the City of New-York, or contemplated extending its influence to other parts of the State.

-- The Messrs. Appleton have nearly ready Dr. William M. Conway's "Climbing and Exploring in the Karakoram Himalayas." They will also bring out soon "A. Daughter of To-day," a novel by Mrs. Everard Cotes, (Sara Jeannette Duncan;) " Cleopatra," by Dr. Georg Ebers; " Mary Fenwick's Daughter," a novel, by Beatrice Whitby, and "General Washington," by Gen. Bradley T. Johnson, in the Great Commanders Series.
ALBANY, May 20 -- Gov. Flower, through the use of his veto power, is rapidly undoing the work of the Legislature.

Bishop Henry Codman Potter ordained twenty-one deacons and eight priests at Christ Church, Boulevard and Seventy-first Street, yesterday morning. The services and ceremonial were strikingly impressive. There was a processional pageant, sumptuous church music, and lavish floral decorations.

SPRING VALLEY, Ill., May 20. -- Nos. 1, 2, and 4 of the Spring Valley Coal Company mines in this city are on fire at the bottom. The company asked the miners to go to work extinguishing the flames, but by a close vote it was decided not to let a man go down the shaft. When the miners adjourned the French Anarchists set up shouts of "Let them burn!"

Breeders of thoroughbred horses are inanything but an enviable frame of mind. The recent sales of stock in this city have been depressing. Prices have ranged at fuly 50 per cent, less than they were a year ago. Yet thoroughbred horses never did have such an earning capacity as they have at the present time.
PARIS, May 20 -- Harry Wheeler, the American bicyclist, won the scratch race of 10,000 meters to-day for the Prix Ruffec.

A number of delegates from the majority of the building trades unions met yesterday afternoon at 147 West Thirty-second Street to take steps toward a combined movement against the use of prison-made materials and possibly against men who use them. The session was a secret one.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., May 20 -- A United Press representative to-day visited the scene of the wreck of the British steamer Calitro, which went ashore on the rocks at Horse Cove, near Grate's Cove, fifty miles north of this port, Friday night. The steamer is a total wreck. She left Sunderland Thursday, May 10, for Baltimore, laden with cement, and was commanded by Capt. J.M. Storm.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 -- President Eliot began to-day the second quarter century of his service with Harvard. This period since 1869 has seen many changes of great value to the university and to American education.

While William McLachlan was fighting with policemen at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue last evening, his three-year-old child clung to his coat. By the time McLachlan had been subdued by clubbing, the little girl's clothing was covered with blood. A messenger boy carried her to the station house behind the policemen, who were leading her father.
The Rev. J.F. Carson of the Central Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, preached last evening on the lessons taught by the destruction of the Tabernacle.
Some of those who are supposed to have taken a great deal of interest In the BlPartlsan Police bill refused to say last night what they thought of the action of Gov. Flower In vetoing it.

David Swem, who lives with his parents in a handsomely-furnished house at 139 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, in a fashionable neighborhood, has had an experience within the last week which he is likely never to forget.

PROVIDENCE, May 19 -- The extreme dullness in all local stocks continues, and but few sales nave been made. Offerings are very light, and the bid prices hold about the same, with tew exceptions. The common stock of the American Wringer Company has sold at 102 1/2 at private sale. There has been some little demand for the stock of the Providence Telephone Company, and a small lot is offered at 110.

NEWARK, N.J., May 20 -- The New-York Times's inter-State bicycle relay race of June 2, the Irvington-Millburn race of Decoration Day, and the century run to Philadelphia June 9 give the New-Jersey Wheelmen plenty to talk of. To-day the threatening weather largely interfered with the plans of the bicyclists.

The past week has been one of the dullest of the year in the bond market. The reasons are not hard to find. The exports of gold have been heavy in the face of a remarkably favorable trade balance, and these exports have aroused abroad, if not at home, renewed fears of our unstable currency system, and with tills a disposition to question the value of our securities.

HOPKINTON, Mass., May 20 -- A shooting affray which occurred in Cordaville this afternoon will probably result in the loss of the lives of two men. John Kelly conducts a so-called kitchen barroom nearly on the line between Hopkinton and Cordaville, which a resort for disreputable people from surounding towns.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 20 -- Commissioners to the Presbyterian General Assembly observed Sabbath religiously to-day by attending church. The local pulpits were filled by the visiting preachers, and the Saratogdans had an opportunity to listen to some of the greatest of Presbyterian divines.

Thomas Flynn, son of Alderman Flynn, had a narrow escape from being killed by revengeful Italians last Thursday night. He is a deportation officer at Ellis Island, and on that night was returning to his residence, 7 Broadway, from Buffalo Bill's show. At his own door three men were lying in wait for him.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 -- A new edition of the "Carmina Princitonia" will appear next week. The book will contain 157 pages instead of 125, as before, and 143 songs, as compared with 122 in the last edition. Alfred L. Dennis, '79, has special supervision of the new work.

LONDON, May 20 -- Edmund H. Yates, author and journalist, was stricken with apoplexy last evening at the Garrick Theatre, where Lytton's "Money" was being played. He was removed to the Savoy Hotel, where he died this afterpoon.

Admiral Farragut's statue in Madison Square was decorated yesterday afternoon by the naval veterans. The veterans met at the headquarters of the National Association of Naval Veterans, Grand and Ludlow Streets, and marched, under command of Rear Admiral R.S. Osbon, via Grand Street and Broadway, to Madison Square, headed by the drum and fife corps of the naval cadets.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Four more victims were added to the death list from the Lake Michigan storm, which has not ended yet, by the finding of a rowboat on the beach this morning. The dead men were young mechanics, who were out of employment and hired the boat to go fishing Thursday afternoon just before the great gale came from the north.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 20 -- Seventeen new courses are offered in the curriculum announced for next year -- two in Greek, two in French, three in German, including one in scientific German; one in physiographic geology, seven in mathematics, including two in solid analytical geometry, two in modern geometry, and one each in determinants, calculus, and theory of equations; one in English on modern literature, and one in economics, money and banking.

Stories that the Central Labor Union had been entrapped by false representations into aiding George Rice of Marietta, Ohio, in his warfare against the Standard Oil Company, were disposed of at the meeting of the union at Clarendon Hall yesterday.

The assertions made in England and Germany that the Government of the United States is anxious to withdraw from the tripartite agreement relating to Samoa no doubt derives some plausibility from Mr. Gresham's recent statement on the subject. That the arrangement made at Berlin when Mr. Blaine was Secretary of State has proved in several respects a disappointment, if not a failure, is plain.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., May 20 -- The golden jubilee of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, of this place, was celebrated to-day with elaborate ceremonies, which were attended by over 1,000 persons. The celebration marked both the fiftieth anniversary of the laying of the cornerstone and the third anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev. T.J. Earley.

PERTH AMBOY, May 20 -- Perth Amboy and other places on Raritan Bay are stormswept. A northeast gale has prevailed since last night. Five vessels are ashore, and two more are aground near this city. There has been a heavy fall of rain and a heavy sea has been running. The steam barge Frolic of New-York sank last night, stern first, and now lies in twenty feet of water.

HATTHRAS, N.C., May 21 -- The Violet, having on board the Presidential party, arrived at Body's Island last night from the trip across the Sound. Early to-day the party disembarked and are now shooting snipe and marsh birds along the shore.

BLUEFIELDS, M.R., May 15, via New-Orleans, May 21, per steamship Clinton. -- There are now two American war ships here -- the San Francisco, which returned from Greytown Sunday morning, whither she had gone to take Consul Braida and Minister Baker, and the New-York, which arrived here Sunday evening.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- The various tractions seemed to be affected by the weather. Metropolitan declined to 110 and Philadelphia to 98 1/2, although there was a slight rally in both toward the closing. While these are both high-priced stocks, they are dividend payers, and the status of them has now become so established that they are likely to find support from investment buying on declines.

The four-story brick dwelling and lot, 25 by 100 feet, at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, has been sold by John C. Sares for about $140,000. It was bought in 1868 for $55,000.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The next additions to the navy will be torpedo boats. The Naval Appropriation will is sure, whatever it contains in the way of larger ships, to obtain for the navy provision for several of the lighter craft, which are so popular with foreign experts in war. The United States Navy has only two torpedo boats at present, and one of these will not be ready for service for some time.

The Regatta Committee of that powerful and prosperous body of amateur oarsmen, the Middle States Rowing Association, met last night at the Marlborough Hotel to arrange for its annual regatta, the date for which, after a little discussion, was fixed for Saturday, July 14, the racing to begin at 9 o'clock in the morning.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate has decided that the item in the Tariff bill which calls for a duty of 40 cents a ton on iron ore shall stand.
