Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day. Time money was without change. The supply was liberal, but the demand was light. Rates were 1 per cent. for thirty days, 1 1/2 per cent. for sixty to ninety days, 2 1/2 per cent. for four months, and 3 per cent. for five to six months.

A more undesirable day for racing than yesterday could not have been made to even Peter De Lacy's order. The weather at the Gravesend track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club was riotously bad, and did not have a single redeeming feature. There was the most penetrating sort of wind blowing up from the ocean, a drizzling rain at intervals, and occasional gusts of wind that nearly swept one off his feet.
BETHLEHEM, Penn., May 21 -- The Lehigh River has overflowed its banks, the freshet being the highest in thirty years.

The spacious Rescue Home of the Salvation Army, at 130 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, was opened by the Rescue Staff yesterday afternoon, when a pleasant meeting and reception were held. The home was first opened about a year and a half ago in a smaller house, in One Hundred and Twenty-third Street.
The semi-centennial jubilee or the New-York Association for the Protection of Game, or the New-York Sporting Association, which was founded in 1844, was celebrated last night at the Gerlach.

John W. Goff said yesterday, before the Senate Investigating Committee, that he proposed to show, if possible, that Police Commissioner John McClave had been "banking the proceeds of bribery and corruption."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- In the Senate this afternoon Mr. Jones (Dem., Ark.,) reported a revision of seven sections of the cotton schedule, in which, compared with his amendments of May 7, a reduction of about 20 per cent, is made.
The trolley car tie-up on the lines of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad system in Brooklyn came to a peaceful end last night. The victory was about equally divided between the men and the company.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Assistant States Attorney Todd, prompted, it is generally believed, by the legal power behind the Prendergast prosecution -- A.S. Trude -- moved before Judge Chetlain this afternoon to have the insanity inquiry postponed until June 18.

The authorities of the European countries chiefly infested by Anarchism seem to have arrived at the most effectual and exemplary method of disposing of Anarchists. The Anarchist seems to be a new type of criminal, and in some respects he is so. To his production are necessary an acute misanthropy and an egregious love of notoriety.

It has well been said that the nature of the task of reorganizing the navy personnel under restricted conditions was shown when, very soon after presenting one elaborate plan to the joint committee on the subject, Secretary Herbert felt impelled to substitute another.

A fifteen horse-power boiler, owned by Contractor W.N. Meyers, which supplied steam to drills for blasting in Eagle Avenue, between One Hundred and Fifty-sixth and One Hundred and Fifty-seventh Streets, exploded yesterday morning a few minutes after the men employed there had begun work. About twelve men were there.

NEW-HAVEN, May 21 -- Yale defeated Princeton, 5 to 3, this afternoon in one of the greatest games of baseball ever played on the Yale field. Both nines contributed about equally to the brilliant exhibition. At the outset it was a pitchers' battle, and Carter and Altman struggled skillfully with the opposing batsmen till the sixth inning.

A few days ago a successful book agent was passing through Albany and finding several congenial companions, he was induced to relate some of his experiences. He is one of those whose work is a study. He makes his first appearance with a Chesterfieldian air, and rapidly unbends, and proceeds to "soothe with flattery, beguile with anecdote,"

The Amateur Fencers League of America met in regular annual meeting last night in the hall of the Fencers Club. Dr. Graeme M. Hammond was elected President, Bernard F. O'Connor Vice President, W. Scott O'Connor Secretary and Treasurer, and Messrs. Charles Nadal, C.G. Bothner, Charles Tatham, and M.J. Echeverria to the Council.

United States Ambassador to Berlin Theodore Runyon, accompanied by Mrs. Runyon, Miss Runyon, Miss Nellie L. Runyon, and Frederick T. Runyon, returned here on the North German Lloyd steamer Kaiser Wilhelm II, which arrived at her Hoboken pier at 5 P.M. last evening.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21 -- The seventy-first General Assembly of Ohio adjourned sine die to-day, with a record of broken promises that ought to be sufficient to disgust the public with Republican supremacy in State affairs and give the Democrats the next Legislature. The chief characteristics of this body were its overwhelming Republican majority and its complete subserviency to street railway and similar corporate interests.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 21 -- Among the overtures before the Assembly is one relating to the Breckinridge case. It comes from New-Albany, Ind., and calls upon the Assembly to give expression to an opinion on personal purity in members of Congress. Tie Assembly has referred the overture to the Committee on Bills and Overtures for consideration.

The Tribune recently published a long interview with Senator Manderson of Nebraska concerning the production of beet sugar in this country and the protection afforded to the producers of such sugar and to the combined refiners by the pending Tariff bill as amended by the revising committee.
DANSVILLE, N.Y., May 21 -- The water in the Canaseraga Creek has been rising steadily, and is now two feet above the high-water mark of five years ago.

A dispatch from San Francisco yesterday said that Mrs. W.A. Martin, wife of the manager of The New-York Witness, who, with her seven-year-old son, has been missing from home for two years, had been found in California, and that her husband was on the way to Los Angeles to meet her and bring her home. The dispatch said Mrs. Martin had wandered all over the world.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Navy Department this morning received a long report from Captain Watson, commanding the San Francisco, at Bluefields. It is dated May 10, and tells of the escape of Arguellas, the murderer of the American, Wilson. Capt. Watson does not hesitate to attribute the escape to the laxity with which the prisoner was guarded.

ALBANY, May 21 -- The sixth Constitutional Convention of the State of New-York will resume operations in the Assembly chamber to-morrow at noon, after a two weeks' vacation, which was taken to enable its President, Joseph H. Choate, to form his twenty-seven committees.

The Democratic Club last night devoted an hour or more to the discussion of some resolutions urging Congress to take speedy action in disposing of the tariff question. The meeting was at the clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue. President John Fox presided.

The property owners in the vicinity of Amity and Clinton Streets, Brooklyn, have protested to Mayor Schieren against the erection of a public school building in that neighborhood. The Board of Education has recently purchased the St. Matthew's Church property, on the corner. Mayor Schieren is one of the Trustees of the church.

Joaquin J. Francke, a prominent sugar merchant of this city, died in Havana, Cuba, on May 17, of pneumonia, after a short illness. Although only thirty-six years of age at the time of his death, Mr. Francke had attained a commanding position in the business communities of Havana and New-York.

ALBANY, May 21 -- Gov. Flower has cringed to the power of the police force of New-York City. Having vetoed yesterday the bill that enlarges the power and authority of the Superintendent, he signed to-day the bill which was opposed by the city authorities, to increase the salaries of the patrolmen of New-York.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Coxey, Browne, and Jones were sentenced, by Judge Miller, in the Washington Police Court this afternoon, to twenty days in jail, for violating he statute of the United Stages prohibiting he display of partisan banners in the Capitol grounds, and Coxey and Browne were fined $5 each additional for trespassing on the grass, the alternative being another ten days in jail.
ALBANY, May 21 -- Gov. Flower has vetoed Assemblyman Taylor's bill regarding the appointment of Brooklyn Police Justices. In his veto memorandum the Governor says:

BARCELONA, May 21 -- The Anarchists Codina, Crezuela, Sogas, Bernat, Villarubia, and Mir, who were condemned to death for complicity in the attempt of Pallas to assassinate Gen. Martinez de Campos, were put to death at 4 o'clock this morning. The prisoners walked quietly through an underground passage to the place of the fortress, where they were to be shot.

LONDON, May 21 -- The officers of the United States cruiser Chicago have received invitations to visit all the large towns in England. Admiral Erben and Capt. Mahan have accepted invitations to a dinner at the Royal Naval Club of London on June 2. This club is the most conservative one in London.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., May 21 -- There was but little change for the better in the flood situation here to-day. The waters, which receded slightly last night, rose again to-day, after a cloudburst and additional heavy rains on the mountains west.

NASSAU, N.P., May 15 -- Much interest is felt here in an article lately published in The Indian River Advocate of Florida in reference to the improvements being made along the eastern coast of Florida by H.M. Flager, the hotel magnate of the peninsula. The article in question promises that Messrs. Flagler and Plant will next Winter run a steamer from Biscayne Bay to Jamaica, via Nassau.

That a variety performance better than the one provided this week for the entertainment of Koster Bial's patrons might be given is probable enough; that better ones will be given, both there and elsewhere, in the future is also probable enough; but that better ones have been given, either there or anywhere else, is a matter of very grave doubt indeed.

BELGRADE, May 21 -- King Alexander has accomplished another coup d'etat. A royal proclamation issued this morning abolishes the Constitution of 1888, and restores that of 1869, giving the King the right to appoint one-third of the members of the Chamber of Deputies.

The report that the Triton Boat Club has withdrawn from the Passaic River Amateur Rowing Association is incorrect. The Triton Boat Club is one of the strongest and most active clubs in the association, and has not the slightest cause or intention of withdrawing.
ELMIRA, N.Y., May 21 -- All communication with Williamsport, Penn., was cut off a little before 12 o'clock to-night.

With Lasker's victory on Thursday, it looks now almost a certainty that the young expert will become the champion of the world. Even Steinitz's most ardent supporters have no hopes that he will be able to win in the end and all they want now is to see him win another game or so.

The pawnshop established under the auspices of the Charity Organization Society of New-York, known as the (Provident Loan Society, was opened in the United Charities Building, at Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue, yesterday, and the Superintendent, Leopold Hecht, who was a Ninth Avenue pawnbroker, and his three assistants might have done a land-office business if they had not discriminated against classes which the scheme does not aim to aid.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., May 21 -- Every hour adds, new names to the already large list of vessels lost. The barges Frankie W. and Elizabeth A. Snow have sunk at the Pennsylvania freight wharves. Five others sank at the Wyoming Pier, together with one of Chapman's steam wrecking boats. The latter capsized.

It appears from the evidence obtained by the police yesterday that the shot which killed John Carberry of 442 East Seventy-eighth Street, a driver in the Street-Cleaning Department, was fired by Policeman R. C. Harvey of the Twenty-fifth Police Precinct. Harvey was arraigned in the Harlem Police Court yesterday afternoon and was remanded in the custody of Capt. Strauss.

Vice President Searles of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company was recalled yesterday in the Northern Pacific inquiry before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary. He was asked to complete his testimony relative to the Northern Pacific and Manitoba Railway. The book containing the record of the bond transactions was placed in evidence.

MANCHESTER, May 21 -- The Queen, accompanied by Prince and Princess Henry of Battenberg and the Princess of Leiningen, arrived here at 4:30 P.M. It is estimated that 2,000,000 people lined the route which was taken by her Majesty in going to and returning from the canal. The entire distance was guarded by troops, volunteers, and police.

The horses of the Suburban Coaching Club used on the coaches between this city and Philadelphia were sold at auction by William Easton at the American Horse Exchange. A number of Philadelphia people were present, and Mr. Caner, one of the gentlemen interested in the coaching project, purchased several of the offerings. The horses sold well, prices ranging from $150 up to $600, the latter for the best of the lot.
ALBANY, May 21 -- Adjt. Gen. Porter has detailed the following organizations for a tour of service at the State Camp of Instruction in Peekskill this season:

BALTIMORE, Md., May 21 -- It was an open question this morning whether the half-mile track at the Gentlemen's Driving Park would be fit for trotting. By noon the sun appeared, and a stiff breeze dried up the water so that it was safe to go on. The footing was worse than it looked, and neither trotters nor pacers could make anything like fast time.

The tenants of the three-story dwelling 235 Third Avenue were disturbed by a fire shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday morning, and those living on the top floor were penned in and had narrow escapes from being suffocated by the smoke.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 21 -- Ex-General Master Workman Powderly, when seen to-day by a reporter, said that he could not believe that he had been expelled from the Knights of Labor, since the laws of the Knights require that charges shall be served and a trial held, all of which had not been done.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., May 21 -- The waters which early to-day threatened destruction in the Conemaugh Valley began slowly to recede at noon, and no additional damage is now expected.

Henry Spencer, a Colorado miner, is fitting out a small naphtha launch for a novel prospecting tour. He intends to work the bottom of the Sacramento River above Redding, and is confident that his venture will prove successful. The launch is 40 feet long, and is propelled with an eight horse power engine.

Messrs. Jones Co. have sold, for Edward J. Stapleton, to Thomas Foley of Pittsburg, at $16,500, the four-story brownstone flat, with store, at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, 24 by 45, and, for August Moritz, to Eugene W. Drew, at $6,250, the three-story brick flat 408 Prospect Avenue, 20 by 45 by 100.

ANDERSON, Ind., May 21 -- Delos Matthews of Willet's Point, N.Y., and Mrs. Fannie Dennison of New-York City are under arrest in this city on an affidavit made by Mrs. Delos Matthews, who came West in search of them.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The investigating quintet was hidden most of the day in the room of the Committee on Privileges and Elections of the Senate, coddling their secrets and whetting the curiosity of every one who expected to be afforded an opportunity to know whether the inquiry was to be prosecuted as a joke or in earnest.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., May 21 -- The storm continues as fiercely as ever throughout this county, and there are no signs of abatement. Every colliery of the Reading Company, except Bast and Preston No. 3, near Ashland, and Beachwood, near Pottsville, was idle, and it is not expected to be able to work even these three to-morrow.

Until Mr. Goff has made good his promise to prove that Police Commissioner John McClave has "banked the proceeds of bribery and corruption in his bank" it would be improper and unjust to draw either morals or conclusions from the exciting but incomplete testimony elicited by the Senate investigating committee yesterday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 21 -- The storm of rain and northeast wind which set in along the coast last night has caused much damage north of here. At this point no damage was done except the crippling of both the telegraph and telephone wires, which are down in all directions.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- The United Press correspondent at Honolulu, writing under date of May 15, per steamer Gaelic, which arrived this evening, says: "The make-up of the coming Constitutional Convention furnishes striking illustrations of the essentially native character of the whole movement.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 21 -- Daniel Maher of 1,237 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, was found dead this morning in the hallway of the building 85 and 87 Main Street. Death was caused by heart disease. Maher came here yesterday with two companions. He had spent all his money and went into the hallway to sleep.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: At a session of the Mississippi Legislature less than a score of years ago, the session, which begun early in January, had reached late in March and nothing of importance had been done; it was speechmaking and talk from day in to day out. Senator Blarek, from a back county, was one of the very few who had said little and been always ready to vote.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 21 -- The delegates to the Democratic State Convention have been coming in all day. So far there is nothing to indicate any change from the figures heretofore sent out of 272 delegates for the nomination of Oates for Governor and 232 for Johnson.

The sale of the thoroughbred yearlings of the McGrathiana Stud, the property of Milton Young of Lexington, Ky., at Tattersalls last night was by far the best of the season. The forty-five head disposed of were the get of Onondaga, Duke of Montrose, Strathmore, Woodlands, and other well-known sires, and the average was $1,002 per head.
Mayor Gilroy yesterday appointed Charles Henry Murray, Republican, to succeed Charles F. MacLean as a Police Commissioner for the full term of six years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the article in to-day's Times, in regard to the fire at "Jones's Wood," allusion is made to the private family cemetery on the Schermerhorn property at the foot of Sixty-sixth Street, East River, as follows: "Near by, in the Schermerhorn grounds, on a knoll under two old acacia trees, is another family cemetery, whose tombstones tell of old New-York days.

SARATOGA, May 21 -- Dr. Briggs is expected to arrive in the village to-morrow, in order to be present at the sessions of the General Assembly which are to be given up to the Smith trial. Mrs. Briggs arrived to-day. She joined the family of Prof. Smith at the Worden. During the long sessions of her husband's trial in the New-York Presbytery and in the Washington Assembly Mrs. Briggs was a constant and earnest listener.
PAUILLAC, May 22 -- The report that the American yacht Etruria is lying at the mouth of the Gironde, on the west coast of France, with her machinery disabled, is denied.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., May 22 -- Williamsport to-day emerged from its enforced isolation, and began to calculate the damage done by its immersion by the flood. The rain in this section began last Thursday morning, with frequent heavy showers, and continued until this morning.

In order that the inquiry of the Senate committee may not be embarrassed through Gov. Flower's veto of the appropriation bill for investigation expenses, a committee of the Chamber of Commerce has undertaken to raise the necessary funds. An appeal for that purpose was prepared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The following is the text of the report of the House Committee on Rules on Representative Dunphy's resolution for the appointment of a committee to investigate the condition and character of all armor plate, bolts, and other appurtenances delivered to the Government by the Carnegie Steel Company, Limited, during the entire period of the contract between the company and the Government:

ALBANY, N.Y., May 22 -- Superintendent of Public Works Hannan to-day received word from Assistant Superintendent McDonough from Buffalo to the effect that navigation on the Erie Canal is entirely suspended between Black Rock and Rockport, owing to the recent heavy rains, which have greatly swollen Tonawanda Creek from Tonawanda to Pendleton.

BOSTON, May 22.--The market for local securities showed some activity, though the quotations changed but little. Wisconsin Central securities rallied somewhat from the lowest of yesterday, the 5s selling at 60, 2 points above the close, and the incomes gaining 1 1/8, to 9 1/8. Boston local specialties were a little weak, Boston and Albany dropping 1/2, to 206, and Boston and Maine 2, to 145 1/2.

While there was a fair amount of trading in stocks yesterday, by far the most of it was the result of professional operations. The liquidation which had been in progress for several days was apparently completed on Monday afternoon. There were evidences then that the market had been oversold, and they became more pronounced yesterday morning.

NEWTON, Mass., May 22 -- The residence of Edward B. Haskell, one of the proprietors of The Boston Herald, situated on Vista Avenue, Auburndale, was practically destroyed by fire to-night. The house was built in 1869 by E.D. Winslow, at a cost of $30,000, and after it came into his possession Mr. Haskell spent fully $100,000 on it.

Action by the Chamber of Commerce was prompted in February by the general conviction that hope of a solution of the rapidtransit problem through the Rapid-Transit Commission might as well be abandoned. While the commission had at times displayed industry and had collected data of value, it had failed to accomplish anything of visible benefit to the public in three years, and some of its acts had excited distrust.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- There was a better feeling in the local stock market. From just what source it emanated nobody seemed to know, as there was no bullish news afloat. There was considerable short covering in Cable and Lake Street " L." West Chicago and Lake Street were the only issues which showed any decided activity.

The defeat of the Ministry of M. Casimir-Perier is not at all wonderful. Indeed, the life of that Ministry has already been longer than impartial observers were inclined to believe it would be when it began. When the Government of M. Dupuy collapsed last December. The Times ventured the prediction that it would be succeeded by a series of makeshifts.

It would take a very vivid imagination to make anything like sport out of the races that were run over the Gravesend track yesterday. Yet the return of the ticket takers showed that 3,800 people braved the wind and rain to go there and see a crowd of horses flounder about in the mud and rain.
Edward M. Shepard has been reappointed an Assistant District Attorney of Kings County and is again at work on Gravesend election frauds.

Several hundred persons attended a meeting in Cooper Union last night in response to a call from the Manhattan Single Tax Club. The avowed purpose of the meetign was "to express indignation at the action of the Democratic Senators in thwarting the demand of the people for a radical reduction of the tariff."
Police Commissioner Charles H. Murray attended the meeting of the Police Board for the first time yesterday afternoon.
Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

ALBANY, May 22 -- The Constitutional Convention resumed its sittings to-day with a deliberation that was becoming to its dignity and with a businesslike air that augurs well. President Joseph H. Choate announced his committees, which were acceptably received on the whole. The usual grumbling that is heard on similar occasions in Washington and Albany upon the promulgation of Congressional or legislat- ive committees was missed.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 22 -- The General Assembly gathered into its fold to-day the entire thirteen theological seminaries of the Church by a vote of nearly 4 to 1. The plan of seminary control was adopted after an exciting debate late this afternoon, 115 Commissioners only, in a body of 550, going on the record in the negative.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- The serious floods of the Schuylkill and Susquehanna furnished the bear contigent with additional ammunition, and they sold stocks to-day with a good deal of confidence; but, as the general market was very much oversold, prices became strong, and there was a fairly good rally, followed by a slight decline.

The American Protective Association, notorious throughout the United States as the "A.P.A.," has at last reached this State with its propaganda. Within a few days every delegate to the Constitutional Convention at Albany has received from the "A.P.A." a copy of a cartoon attacking the Roman Catholic Church in the most rabid and vicious manner.

There are indications that the real measure of protection given to the combined refiners of sugar by the revised sugar schedule was not perceived by certain Democratic Senators for some time after the revision was made, and that the protective effect of the ad valorem rate is not understood by some of them even now.

The striking feature at yesterday's sessions of the Republican Senate committee's inquiry into the official conduct and personal affairs of John McClave, a Republican Police Commissioner, was the non-appearance of Gideon Granger.

PARIS, May 22 -- Dr. Bernoit, one of the Faculty of the Ecole de Medicin, after a thorough examination of the body of Emile Henry, the Anarchist, who was beheaded yesterday morning, expresses his opinion that Henry was already dead when the knife fell. Dr. Bernoit believes that the Anarchist died from syncope, due to intense excitement before the knife was released.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Mr. Gray's star-chamber investigating committee did not have an opportunity to-day to acquire any information relating to the bribery cases, for the reason that Major Buttz, who attempted to purchase the votes of Senators Hunton and Kyle, failed to put in an appearance.

ALBANY, May 22 -- Gov. Flower signed the Sheffield Rapid-Transit bill late this afternoon, and with it filed what is becoming to be recognized as the inevitable "memorandum," which explains why he should sign his name.

Anthony Comstock, Secretary of the New-York Society for the Suppression of Vice, has sent to Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn a letter criticising the opinion Corporation Counsel Albert G. McDonald of Brooklyn, that the local authorities were not bound by Judge Pryor's decision to prevent pool selling on the grounds of incorporated racing associations in the city.

If, from conviction, political expediency, or any other cause, Gov. Flower had seen fit to veto the bill increasing the salaries of the police force of this city, one can readily imagine the denunciation he would have bestowed upon the Legislature for its violation of the "principle of home rule."
